title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRUSH, HARRIET
description: BRUSH-Harriet. Of Long Boat Key, Florida, formerly of New York City, wife of Raymond Brush and sister of Irvin J. Berger (both deceased), died peacefully at her home on January 27, 1998.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Judgment Hill

title: January 25-31; Not In My Locker Room, Mister
description: People refer to it as the ''single-sex health club'' law, but it might as well be called the ''Stop James Foster law.'' The Massachusetts Legislature gave final approval to an amendment to the state's anti-discrimination rules that will exlicitly allow single-sex gyms.

title: 'Victory' in Metuchen: The Other Side Speaks
description: To the Editor:

title: A Media Race Enters Waters Still Uncharted
description: The story that caromed off the keyboard of an Internet tipster and hurtled through the talk shows to the top of every network news broadcast and major newspaper in the country appears to many in journalism to have blurred the boundaries between mainstream and tabloid news.

title: The World; Whether to Bomb Is the Easy Part
description: THE drums of war are pounding once again as the United States moves toward yet another clash with Saddam Hussein. But all the saber-rattling in Washington has obscured a fact often overlooked by the nation's armchair generals: Bombing Iraq is easier said than done.

title: Direct From England and Ireland
description: THERE IS AN UNMISTAKABLE invasion of Anglo-Irish theatrical talent taking place this spring, both on Broadway and Off. Maybe the attraction is the city's brightly polished image, or perhaps it is just coincidence. But several leading British directors will be in residence, the Royal Shakespeare Company is digging in for more than a fortnight at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, two acclaimed Irish comedies by an under-30 playwright will both be on at the same time, and that's only the beginning. Ticket information about these productions can be found in the month-by-month list that begins above.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPITZER, IRMA LOUISE (NEE ENDEL)
description: SPITZER-Irma Louise (nee Endel), died on January 30, 1998 at Longboat Key, Florida after an extended illness that she bore with extraordinary bravery and always with a quiet smile. She was the devoted wife and best friend of James for sixty years, the dedicated mother of James Jr. and Sheri and Thomas and Caroline, the adoring grandmother of Ashley, Jessica, Jamie, and the dear sister of Albert M. Endel, Jr. and Mathilde E. Scheuer, both of Montgomery, Alabama. Her sweetness and love graced our lives and will always remain in our hearts and memory. Funeral services are at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, NYC, Sunday, February 1 at 11:30 AM. Interment private. If any contributions are desired to be made in her memory, it would be appreciated if given to Mt. Sinai Hospital for the Irma Louise Spitzer Parkinson Disease Research Fund, care of Dr. Seymour Gendelman, 5 E. 98 St, NY, NY 10029

title: Ounces of Prevention For the Next Crisis
description: THE session was billed as an ''Asia crisis update.'' Nearly 600 people jammed into the auditorium on Friday, the opening day of the World Economic Forum here. For an hour, they listened to seven experts dissect the causes, the damage and the culprits of what more than one called the worst financial crisis since the 1930's.

title: Schools Aren't Factories, Pupils Aren't Products; Educators Need Time
description: To the Editor:

title: The Nation; Read Between the Lines for a Partisan Message
description: PRESIDENT CLINTON used the word Democrat just once in his 74-minute State of the Union address last week -- exactly the same number of times he mentioned the word Republican. They were twinned in a sentence warning Saddam Hussein that the nation was united in demanding that he comply with United Nations weapons inspections.

title: The Persistence of the Portraitist
description: In his dreams, he still sees himself as the person he once was. Lying in bed, lost in slumber, he pictures himself walking along gray cobblestones, a tall, burly figure ambling through downtown New York. In the movie that flickers across his eyelids, he is always walking somewhere: upstairs, downstairs, to the corner for coffee, to a gallery to see a new show.

title: The Bad Sex Award
description: To the Editor:

title: Finding a berth or joining a debate on line
description: On a chilly Sunday night in January, the Cruise Cafe -- the chat room of America Online's Cruise Critic site -- was buzzing, a silent babble of tales from distant lands. Debates raged: Dawn Princess or Majesty of the Seas? St. Croix or Tortola? Sea Bands or ginger capsules?

title: Sheila Hewett, David Cutner
description: Sheila Anne Hewett, the senior vice president for product development, marketing and advertising at Calvin Klein Cosmetics in Manhattan, was married yesterday to David A. Cutner, the senior partner in Cutner & Associates, a Manhattan law firm. Judge Jed S. Rakoff of the Federal District Court in Manhattan officiated at Crabtree's Kittle House, an 18th-century inn in Chappaqua, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CROSS, PATRICIA T.
description: CROSS-Patricia T. Ann Arbor, Michigan. Age 77, died January 26, 11:45 P.M. at home. A resident of Ann Arbor since 1949. She was born May 21, 1920 in New York City, the daughter of Harold and Grace G. Townsend. She was a graduate of The Brearley School and Vassar College. On March 22, 1946 she married Dr. Thomas N. Cross. He pre-deceased her in December, 1996. She is survived by their children John (Jean) Cross, Chappaqua, N.Y.; Katherine C. Reece, Kennebunkport, ME; Peter R. Cross, Ann Arbor, MI; three grandchildren; and a sister, Nancy T. Haynes, Naples, FL. Cremation has taken place. In lieu of a formal service, contributions may be made to Therapy Dogs, Int'l and Ann Arbor Hospice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GENN, BERNARD
description: GENN-Bernard. All his friends and colleagues at Yeshiva University and the Albert Einstein College of Medicine extend deepest condolences to Emanuel Genn, the medical school's associate dean for business affairs, on the passing of his father. We wish Manny and the entire Genn family the comfort of memory in their time of sorrow. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University Dr. Dominick P. Purpura, Dean Albert Einstein College of Medicine

title: Be Mine
description: It's not a chic boutique or a glamorous department store, but around Valentine's Day, B. Shackman & Company, a tiny no-frills card and toy store at Fifth Avenue and 16th Street, is packed with shoppers looking for the obscure. And the autograph books near the register are testimony to the heavy flow of celebrities who frequent the place. With the big day just around the corner, the store's shelves are packed with reproductions of more than 100 colorful vintage valentines, like the rose petal above ($2.70), along with mechanical toys, old-fashioned paper dolls, snow domes, jump ropes and jacks.

title: Facts and Rumors
description: In reporting the White House sex scandal, the nation's news organizations have asked Americans to rely on their judgment in sorting through a heap of facts and rumors. Week in Review offers a guide to the origins of some of the key allegations.

title: BUSINESS BEST SELLERS
description: THIS MONTH/LAST MONTH

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DWYER, ELEANOR MARY, C.S.J.
description: DWYER-Eleanor Mary, C.S.J. Holistic health counselor, Bishop Kearny High School. Former campus minister, Kingsboro Community College. Reposing at Bishop Kearney Convent, 2221 61 St., Brooklyn, NY, Sunday and Monday 2-5, 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Tuesday, 9:45 AM, St. Athanasius R.C. Church. Burial Calvary Cemetery, Brentwood, NY. Memorial donations may be made to Sisters of St. Joseph, Brentwood.

title: Woman Ascending a Marble Staircase
description: So what do we know about Julia Koch? She is thin and rich. Very. She married a billionaire and now spends her days remodeling, refurbishing and socializing. Did this warrant a piece in your magazine? What does she have to teach us? Ah! You can never be too rich or too thin.

title: Asian Blues: A New Salve
description: Warburg Pincus Asset Management, it seems, is aiming for a cure for the Asian flu that began afflicting so many investors in emerging markets in the second half of 1997.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAINES, ISIDORE H.
description: GAINES-Isidore H. Age 77, on January 30, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Ruth. Loving father of Steven. Interment private Mt. Ararat Cemetery.

title: CROSS-COUNTRY SKIING
description: MANY OF the names are the same. Remember Norway's Bjorn Daehlie and Kazakhstan's Vladimir Smirnov? But the atmosphere in Snow Harp, the name of the Olympic venue near Hakuba, will never equal the atmosphere in Lillehammer's raucous Birkebeiner Stadium four years ago.

title: Nagano Being Smothered Under Fresh White Blanket
description: From his office at the bottom of the Olympic downhill runs, First Lieut. Kazuo Sakai gazed at a postcard scene of winter that would usually be welcomed at a ski resort. But this was too much of a good thing. In December, there were fears that an El Nino winter would not bring enough snow for the 1998 Winter Olympics. Now there are fears that it will snow too much.

title: The Bad Sex Award
description: To the Editor:

title: Make Exception For an Exception
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Style; Let's Go: Fashion Spring '98
description: Every fall and spring, the ready-to-wear collections appear like trendy islands on the churning sea of popular culture. Overnight, the cities of Milan, Paris and New York fill up with picky arbiters who traffic in opinions and accessorize well. Like bird-watchers on the lookout for anything with wings, they go from show to show in order to find, amid the more than 200 collections, a flurry of ideas that will migrate out into the great beyond. Their language, an advanced dialect of fashionese, is peppered with terms like ruching, shirring and on the bias. Able to pronounce Xuly Bet and Hussein Chalayan with ease, they also make easy pronouncements on such things as the difference between cobalt blue and cornflower, the new femininity, the Guggenheim in Bilbao and the genius of stretch jersey.

title: Rutgers Is No Match For Healthy Huskies
description: CONNECTICUT 73, RUTGERS 56

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTING IT /Page 4/

title: Outsider at Home With the Inner Life
description: THE FILMS OF THE Russian director Aleksandr Sokurov, whose ''Mother and Son'' opens on Wednesday at Film Forum, have always demanded a suspension of Western (and particularly American) filmgoing expectations. There will be little dialogue; the plot will neither twist nor turn; editing cuts will be fewer than usual; character development will not ride on a screenwriter's efforts at motivation but will be left largely to the viewer.

title: Spell It C-H-A-M-P-I-O-N
description: HIS back curved like a sloppily written C, Joel Sherman, the world Scrabble champion, sat very still, pondering his possibilities during an evening game at the Beverly Bridge Club on East 57th Street. Then he dealt his letters: QATS.

title: Her Spirits in the Clouds, Kwan Finds Peace on the Ice
description: Michelle Kwan had just botched a triple lutz in the unforgiving short program at the 1997 world championships in Lausanne, Switzerland. A world champion at 15, she seemed lost at 16. Her body was growing, her confidence was shrinking. She had now sunk to fourth place, with no realistic hope of defending her title. In the locker room, she was angry, tearful, inconsolable. As Kwan yanked on the laces of her sneakers, her hand slipped and she punched herself in the face. Then she burst out laughing.

title: In Northern Manhattan, Building Prices Strengthen
description: I FEEL very comfortable here,'' said Francia Espinal, a tenant for the last year and a half at the 47-unit building at 95 Thayer Street in the Inwood section of Manhattan. ''We get good service.''

title: 'The House Gun'
description: Something terrible happened.

title: My New Year in Chinatown: The Bang Is Gone
description: As I walked through the streets of Chinatown last week to get to my mother's house for our traditional New Year's meal, something felt wrong.

title: Hong Kong, Feeling Flu-ish
description: On first sight, nothing much has changed in Hong Kong since the British colony -- or ''territory,'' as late colonial officials preferred to call it -- was returned to China at midnight on June 30. No one has been arrested for his political views. The People's Liberation Army keeps out of sight, inside the Prince of Wales Barracks. The corporate skyscrapers still glitter in the wintry sun, and the history of British rule still casts its shadows. The noonday gun, originally from a Jardine Matheson opium brig, is fired every day as a ritual token of respect to the Royal Navy; in Victoria Park, a bronze Queen Victoria watches serenely over picnickers and annual Tiananmen massacre mourners.

title: A Skating Outsider Dances With Burdens
description: Around his neck, Elvis Stojko of Canada wears a gold medal given to him by his aunt and uncle. It was a sort of consolation prize from the 1992 Winter Games in Albertville, France. Most of the men fell in the long program as if they had slipped on the sidewalk trying to retrieve the morning paper. Stojko skated a clean long program but dropped inexplicably from sixth place to seventh.

title: Sharing Capeman Memories
description: DESPITE all the advance hand wringing -- or maybe because of it -- Thursday's opening-night party for Paul Simon's new musical, ''The Capeman,'' was downright jubilant, a sort of collective sigh of release.

title: Beyond The Image Of Upstart
description: THE OFFICIAL SUNDANCE SNOW globe -- yes, there is one -- shows a dozen tiny people waiting outside the Egyptian, which is the sole movie palace in Park City, Utah. Considering the mob scenes of years past, that serene image could have qualified as a joke, but the 1998 Sundance Film Festival was as calm and well organized as the event has ever been. The decorative Pharaohs at the Egyptian were newly beautified. The buses ran on time. So did the screenings, and some of them took place at the local high school, which has a roomy 1,300-seat performing-arts center with an audible sound system and a wide screen. There turned out to be no parking anywhere nearby while school was in session. But still, once-ragtag Sundance has come a long way.

title: New Supermarket Aids Mount Vernon Corridor
description: RECENTLY residents of this city and those of Pelham, New Rochelle and parts of the Bronx witnessed the opening of the largest Shop Rite Supermarket in Westchester. The 70,000-square-foot, hilltop store is the latest single project in redeveloping the Sanford Boulevard business corridor.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HECK, ALICE HILLMAN
description: HECK-Alice Hillman February 1, 1994 Love and memory Charles

title: The Stars Come Out
description: YOU can feel the ocean and see the stately houses through the trees on this pretty stretch of River Road, which tells you everything you need to know about the area. Fair Haven and nearby Rumson are beautiful and wealthy. Now, they have an appropriately lavish restaurant.

title: Forget the Money. Show Us You Care.
description: NOW that the Super Bowl is over, football players can sit back and dream about the higher salaries that are guaranteed as part of the National Football League's recent $17.6 billion eight-year television deal. And the spiraling salaries are certain to prompt greater demands from athletes in other sports, too.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: Free Choices

title: Moment to Moment In Sundance's Swirl
description: A FIRST-TIME FILMMAKER, THE photographer Timothy Greenfield-Sanders traveled to the snowy town of Park City, Utah, two weeks ago to plunge into the hype, hope and hustle that is the Sundance Film Festival. While there, he presented his documentary, ''Lou Reed: Rock and Roll Heart,'' which will be broadcast April 29 on PBS in the ''American Masters'' series. And during a hectic week of 18-hour days that included screenings, interviews, parties and constantly ringing cell phones, he took hundreds of pictures and scribbled a diary of his star-packed adventures. Here's a glimpse of what he saw and heard.

title: Well, Did You Evah! Back to 'High Society'
description: ''WHO WANTS TO BE A MILLIONAIRE?'' asks a delightfully cheeky Cole Porter song from the 1956 movie musical ''High Society.'' Of course, the answer to that question is the same today as it was then: almost everybody. Retooled and expanded with additional songs from the Porter catalogue, the movie, which updated Philip Barry's play ''The Philadelphia Story,'' has been turned into a Broadway-bound musical that provides the same voyeuristic insider's view of wealth and its discontents.

title: Black and White Revisited; How Dog-Control Signs Intersect With Taxi Signals
description: To the Editor:

title: All-Bach Benefit Concert Offered
description: THREE singers and four members of the orchestra of the Metropolitan Opera are coming to Westchester today for the annual benefit concert for the Elmendorf Opportunity Center, held in the main sanctuary of the Reformed Church of Bronxville.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: ON THE POSSIBILITY OF

title: Getting to Know Me
description: You no longer need to be a celebrity with a history of drug addiction or sexual perversion to write a shocking confessional memoir. All you have to do is honestly answer the fill-in-the-blank and multiple-choice questions in ''All About Me,'' a new book that combines the form of a personal journal with the function of the psychiatrist's couch. But be forewarned: many of the questions are a little strange, so you may not like the chilling composite portrait that emerges:

title: Generation X Meets Elegance
description: Except for Alberto Tomba, the Italian ski star and perpetual frat boy, the familiar champions are gone from the Winter Olympics. Bonnie Blair is sprinting toward motherhood instead of gold medals. Dan Jansen has retired, too, his redemption having earned him a job as engineer on the motivational-speaking gravy train. Nancy Kerrigan and Tonya Harding have relinquished the vise grip of public attention, although Fox television has hired them for a side-by-side interview, a sort of kiss-and-cry ''Crossfire.'' The effect, intended or not, will be Harding's rehabilitation. Four years ago, she was a sequined, trailer-park pariah. Now she will become figure skating's Richard Nixon.

title: Backtalk; Proposed Cures Could Kill the Patient
description: The general managers of the 26 National Hockey League teams meeting in Phoenix tomorrow for their annual conference will convene in a troubled atmosphere, despite the league's participation in the Winter Olympics.

title: Schools Aren't Factories, Pupils Aren't Products; Teachers Like Money?
description: To the Editor:

title: January 25-31; Surprises From The Super Bowl
description: The Super Bowl made news for a change. The Denver Broncos beat the Green Bay Packers, 31 to 24, which meant: an American Football Conference Team won for the first time in 14 years; the Broncos didn't become the game's first-ever five-time losers; John Elway, the team's popular 37-year-old quarterback, won't become the game's second four-time loser. And here's the real surprise: It was even a pretty good game.

title: In Offices, an Excuse to Mention S*x
description: MICHAEL SOLOMON, an editor at Mirabella magazine, was discussing story ideas with a female colleague last week in their 44th-floor office in Manhattan when the little business of the President and Monica Lewinsky came up.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARANS, VICTOR
description: MARANS-Victor. On January 25, 1998. Beloved husband of Harriet. Adored father of Jill. Cherished grandfather of Alexandra Blair. Devoted brother of Audrey. Dear father-in-law of Mitchell Lubin. He will be sorely missed.

title: Teachers' Strike Stirs Bitter Memories
description: A NEW two-year contract for Bridgeport's public school teachers, which was recently settled after two rounds of binding arbitration, has evoked strong emotions among many of the city's veteran teachers.

title: Black and White Revisited; Foes of Planned Social Club Want Independent Review
description: To the Editor:

title: He Keeps The Blood True Blue
description: IT felt like a scene in an Edith Wharton movie or maybe even a Louis Auchincloss novel -- though the grand society author didn't seem to be taking notes on Wednesday amid the latest generation of old money in its 20's and 30's.

title: SOULS ON ICE
description: * About 10,000 human embryos are frozen in tanks of liquid nitrogen every year. They usually belong to couples with fertility problems; they're conceived in test tubes and stored for possible later implantation into a woman's uterus. * But when couples split up, some embryos become the object of custody battles. * On Long Island, embryos belonging to Maureen and Steven Kass have existed in legal limbo since the couple's divorce and still-unresolved custody battle began in 1993. * In Pinckney, Mich., Sara Bohn recently sued her fertility clinic and ex-husband to gain control over the couple's five remaining frozen embryos and have them implanted. * Bohn's lawyer, Rebecca Wasser, is an anti-abortion activist who claims her birth mother tried to abort her. * Michael Mobley, Bohn's ex, wants the embryos destroyed and says, ''If I can't have them, you can't either.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRENGER, GEORGE
description: STRENGER - George. Beloved husband of the late Sophie. Devoted father of Gloria Langer and Seymour Strenger. Loving grandfather and great grandfather. Services on Sunday, at 12 Noon, at Congregation Agudath Sholom, Jersey City. For information ''Wien & Wien'' 1-800-322-0533.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: History, theater and fiction -- in four sterling adaptations -- provide the underpinning for superior films on television this week.

title: Unpleasant Road Trip For Devils
description: DEVILS 3, FLAMES 3

description: BAYLES-Virginia Conheim. February 1, 1995. In ever loving memory, Sister Marilyn

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: LONG ISLAND VINES
description: A North Fork Tavel

title: Woman Ascending a Marble Staircase
description: How about a feature on how difficult it is for a woman to be married to a successful man? How about reporting on the amount of work she does and the envy and criticism she must endure while everyone thinks she is only social climbing and has it all? Perhaps David Koch is the one who got a ''very nice catch.''

title: Mystery Ailment Fells Bald Eagles at Three Arkansas Lakes
description: Two stately American bald eagles, their white plumage silhouetted against a lapis sky, roosted side by side today atop a dead pine on a small island in a shimmering man-made lake near here. As a motorboat put-putted toward the island, the raptors arched their wings, lifted off and soared effortlessly out of sight.

title: Samuel D. Wright, 73, Former Assemblyman
description: Samuel D. Wright, a former City Councilman from Brooklyn and a former New York State Assemblyman who was chairman of the Black and Puerto Rican Caucus in both legislative bodies, died on Jan. 20 at his home in Hilton Head, S.C., where he lived in retirement. He was 73.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about the rising rate of bankruptcy in New Jersey misstated a telephone number in a listing of credit counseling services. The number for Family and Children Services is (800) 947-3752.

title: Claudio Tamburrini
description: Tamburrini, a former professional soccer player in Argentina, is a sports philosopher at Gothenburg University in Sweden.

title: VIEWPOINT; Making Asia Fit for Survival
description: ECONOMIC Darwinism is the new gospel sweeping the financially pressed tigers, tiger cubs and more established economies of Asia. Bowing to pressure from the International Monetary Fund, even the most paternalistic Asian leaders are supporting the notion that only strong business enterprises should survive; the weak, requiring subsidies or protection, must be allowed to fail so that rationality can return to global capital markets.

title: Sports of The Times; A Daughter Seeks Her Olympian Father
description: WHENEVER the Winter Olympics approach, Julie Jaffee Nagel wonders about her father more often than she usually does. She wonders why he seemed to keep her a secret and ignored her. She wonders if there are people out there who could tell her more about him.

title: Hotel Dishes That Make a Statement
description: OUR past dining experiences in hotel restaurants often led to our comparing the food there with that served in hospitals: everything overcooked and bland; nothing must offend. Decor often matched the food. But in our area in recent years that direction has changed. Decor has become much classier, statements are made and the same can be said of the food.

title: Let's Have Fun! And That's an Order
description: Office parties are supposed to be fun, but as everybody knows, many are remarkable for how the uninhibited embarrass the unwilling. Other gatherings manage to create only a semblance of celebration, and a few accomplish the rare feat of engendering real joy. But good or bad, parties tend to be memorable.

title: Late Irish Surge Halts Red Storm's 7-Game Run
description: Even as the winning streak was growing to seven games and the city was beginning to notice St. John's again, Fran Fraschilla remembered the fable, as told by a sage named Carnesecca, of the peacock and the feather duster. In simpler days, today's preener was warned that it could become tomorrow's cleaning utensil. But that was before this impossible-to-figure Big East basketball season, and a St. John's team hat finds itself somewhere in between.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-13

title: East Side Store Looks (Eek!) West
description: For more than 30 years Gracious Home has helped the Upper East Side remain, well, gracious, outfitting apartments in the wealthiest swath of Manhattan with everything from fireplace andirons to cotton eyelet dust ruffles, dripless candles to picture frames.

title: Mommy, What's an Intern? And Other Hard Topics
description: Harold Koplewicz, director of New York University's Child Study Center, tells of the parents who got nervous this week when their 8-year-old son asked what was happening in the White House. Worried that they were about to face some tough questioning about sex, they stalled for time, asking, ''What do you mean?''

title: CBS Will Stretch Time With Videotape (and Will Admit It)
description: In 1994, CBS learned a valuable lesson in time: no matter who knew the fates of Nancy, Tonya & Friends in the figure-skating short program from Lillehammer, Norway, viewers would avidly watch a six-hour-old tape. With a 48.5 Nielsen rating, it was the third-most watched sports event ever.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LANE, HERBERT G.
description: LANE - Herbert G. 2/1/97. Mourned, missed and remembered always for the great times shared together. Joan and Stephen Stark

title: Family of Man Killed by Officer in Brooklyn Initiates Suit Against City
description: The family of a man who was shot and killed by a police officer on Christmas Day has begun legal proceedings against the city, the Police Department and the officer, the family's lawyer said yesterday.

title: Jarlath Graham, 78, Ex-Magazine Editor
description: Jarlath J. Graham, a former editor of Advertising Age, died on Jan. 24 at Wagner Health Center in Evanston, Ill. Mr. Graham, a resident of Chicago, was 78.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page caption in the Arts and Leisure section today with a contents entry about a photo essay on the Sundance Film Festival misstates the given name of the actress shown with the actor and director Timothy Hutton. She is Christina Ricci, not Amanda.

title: POSTINGS: Conference on Preservation; Revitalizing American Cities
description: New ways of thinking about historic preservation and the revitalization of American cities will be emphasized Saturday at a conference sponsored by the Historic Districts Council.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Caesar Let the Dice Fly. By Colleen McCullough. Morrow, $27.50.

title: Flavoring Risotto and Pasta With Shrimp
description: SHRIMP are perennial and popular. No need to worry whether the fish market will have them on hand. And they are so versatile they can be used for everything from hors d'oeuvres with cocktails to appetizers, salads, soups, pasta and main courses.

title: The Commish
description: TURNAROUND How America's Top Cop Reversed the Crime Epidemic. By William Bratton with Peter Knobler. 329 pp. New York: Random House. $25.

description: MY SISTER LIFE

title: Italian Ban On Paying Kidnappers Stirs Anger
description: When a piece of Giuseppe Soffiantini's right ear arrived by mail at the office of a top Italian newscaster last week, the debate over Italy's kidnapping laws took on new urgency.

title: BENEFITS
description: In the Upper Register

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STORCH, HARVEY
description: STORCH-Harvey. On January 31, 1998. Beloved husband of Sylvia, loving and devoted father of Gregory and the late Frank. Adoring grandfather of Rachel and Nathaniel, Emily and Thomas. True friend. Service Monday at ''The Riverside'' 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, 212-362-6600.

title: Whither the Customer In an Airline Alliance?
description: THE airline alliance proposed last week between Northwest and Continental drew praise from Wall Street analysts, yet the deal -- in which Northwest has agreed to buy control of Continental for about $311 million in cash and $208 million worth of stock -- leaves a number of unresolved questions for consumers.

title: Harlem Renaissance in San Francisco
description: A major exhibition documenting the rich legacy of black artists who worked in Harlem between the World Wars is on display at the California Palace of the Legion of Honor in San Francisco. ''Rhapsodies in Black: Art of the Harlem Renaissance'' presents 130 paintings, sculptures, photographs, prints and drawings, as well as nine hours of rare jazz recordings and clips from nine films.

title: A Scion of Hollywood's Elite Makes a First Film (He's 22)
description: TWENTY-FOUR HOURS after a television interviewer introduced the 22-year-old writer and director Jake Kasdan as Hollywood's latest Wunderkind, he was being treated like some grand old man of cinema.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: DRAGON TEETH

title: Wanted: Expertise (or Celebrity), Plus Pep
description: EVERY ocean cruise comes wrapped in the myth that the harried traveler finally gets away from it all. No telephones, no traffic, no nothing -- just lots of time and an endless expanse of sparkling water. It offers leisure in the most concentrated form to be found outside a flotation tank.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROCK, HENRY J.
description: BROCK-Henry J. Of Village of Golf, Florida, and Osterville, Massachusetts, died suddenly at his home January 29, 1998. He was 87 years old. Mr. Brock was born in Jersey City, New Jersey, in 1910, was graduated by Fordham University in 1931 and by Fordham Law School in 1934. In the years prior to World War II he specialized in corporation and finance law with the New York law firm of White & Case. During World War II he served in the European Theater of Operations with the 101st Cavalry Mechanized Group and rose from Second Lieutenant to Lieutenant Colonel. He received two battle stars and the Bronze Star for combat activities. Mr. Brock was admitted to practice law in New York and New Jersey and was a member of the American, New York and New Jersey Bar Associations, the American Judicature Society, the Association of Life Insurance Counsel, and the Life Insurance Association of America. He was also a director of Purolator, Inc., for 25 years, the United States Radium Corporation, Oceanography Mariculture, Inc., Warlick Capital Management, Inc., and Southdown Corporation. Mr. Brock was retired in 1972 as a Senior Vice President and Associate General Counsel of the Prudential Insurance Company of America. At the time of his retirement he was responsible for the legal supervision of the activities of all Prudential's investment departments which invested billions of dollars every year. Mr. Brock joined the Prudential law department in 1946 and retired in 1972. He was a member of the Somerset Hills Country Club in New Jersey, the Country Club of Florida, the Ocean Club of Florida, the Metropolitan Opera Club of New York, the New York Anglers Club, the Oyster Harbor Golf Club of Cape Cod, and the United States Seniors Golf Association. He is survived by his loving wife, the former Huguette Boudet of Paris, France, and three children of his late wife Mary Meier of Saint Joseph, Missouri: Henry J. Brock, Jr., of San Francisco, California, Babette Alfieri of Santa Fe, New Mexico, Mary Merton of Nantucket, Massachusetts, and three grandchildren: Marc E. Merton, Christopher A. Merton and Christina A. Misata, as well a greatgranddaughter, Samantha C. Merton. A funeral service will be held Monday, February 2, 1998, at 4 PM, at Saint Vincent Ferrer Cathollic Church, 810 George Bush Boulevard, Delray, Florida. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that contributions be made in his memory to his preferred charity, the American Cancer Society. For information, Lorne & Sons Funeral Home, Delray Beach, FL, 561276-4161.

title: Don't Ask, Don't Tell
description: The United States has arrived at one of those peculiar moments when what is good for the immediate political interests of a sitting President is harmful to the political culture of the nation. We have seen the same split on a much more momentous level with Lyndon Johnson and the Vietnam War and a few years later with Richard Nixon and Watergate. The defining crisis of this President seems frail in comparison, because of its tawdriness.

title: January 25-31; Who Needs to Talk? If the Suit Fits, He Stays.
description: First, the Russians complained that Dr. Andrew S. W. Thomas, the American astronaut, was a malcontent for saying his emergency spacesuit was too small. Then, they complained that his Russian wasn't good enough.

title: FROM THE DESK OF; No Pain, No Gain? Forget It, Doc
description: IMAGINE checking into a hotel during your next business trip and being informed that someone named J. Smith will be your roommate. I'm sure it would be your last visit to that hotel. And if people won't tolerate strangers as roommates when they are well, whose bright idea was it to have roommates for people when they are sick?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAMER, PHILIP
description: KRAMER-Philip. January 30, 1998 in Boca Raton, FL. Beloved husband of Sarah. Loving father of Noelle and Robert, Marilyn and Howard, Glenn and Lynn. Devoted grandfather of Seth, Marc, Allison, Jeffrey, Randee, Douglas, Alexander, Robyn and Kira. Loving great-grandfather of Ross, Brett and Adam. Mr. Kramer will be dearly remembered by his loving family and many devoted friends and business associates. He died after a long and valiant battle with Alzheimer's. Mr. Kramer received his MBA from the Harvard Graduate School of Business. He served as an officer with the Navy in World War II. He was President and COO of Amerada Hess. Services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 181 W. 76th St., New York City, Sunday, February 1, at 1:45 PM. We will all miss him.

title: Schools Aren't Factories, Pupils Aren't Products
description: To the Editor:

title: Yankees May Try To Sign McDowell
description: The Yankees are expected to make an offer to Jack McDowell, the pitcher who is coming back from arm trouble.

title: Waste (Not), Want (Not)
description: When the Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island closes in 2001, where will the 11,000 tons of garbage dumped there daily go?

title: MARKET TIMING
description: MONDAY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GANG, MARTIN
description: GANG-Martin. The Officers, members and staff of the American Jewish Committee mourn the death of Martin Gang, a distinguished partner in the Los Angeles law firm of Gang, Tyre, Ramer and Brown, and an AJC Honorary National Vice President, as well as a member of our Board of Governors and National Leadership Council. Long committed to the Jewish people and social justice, Martin was a founder, chairman and president of AJC's Los Angeles Chapter. He was the recipient of 2 of AJC's highest honors, the Judge Learned Hand Award and the Distinguished Service Award. His exceptional generosity and wise counsel will be sorely missed. We send our heartfelt condolences to his grieving family. Robert S. Rifkind, President David A. Harris, Executive Director Bruce Ramer, Chair Board of Governors Rabbi Gary Greenebaum, Director Los Angeles Chapter

title: Canada Recovers From the Ice Storm
description: The brutal ice storm that hit Eastern Canada in early January caused widespread damage and left millions shivering in the dark. Although major ski areas in Quebec like Mont-Tremblant and Mont-Ste.-Anne were spared, the startling images of crumpled high voltage towers and snapped wooden electric poles convinced many people to cancel winter ski vacations.

title: NORDIC COMBINED
description: AMERICANS HAVE never come close to an Olympic medal in Nordic combined, the hybrid event that asks competitors to jump from the normal hill and ski a 15-kilometer cross-country race. But the Americans finally have a legitimate contender in Todd Lodwick, although it is unlikely that even a gold medal will ignite a nordic combined craze in the United States.

title: Going on Full Alert For a Dream Dress
description: The brides-to-be wore leotards or sweat pants in case the need arose for a quick and public fitting. They bobbed through the racks of wedding gowns, trying desperately to find that one-in-a-million dress, especially before someone else did.

title: Ecuadoreans Want Texaco to Clear Toxic Residue
description: Florinda Balla prays that no more of her cows, pigs, chickens or dogs will venture to the black pool by her farm. Its surface is viscous, its contents thick with arsenic and other toxic wastes. She has watched five of her cows who drank from it grow listless and fall dead, she said.

title: The Highs and Lows of Working at Home
description: WHEN Azriella Jaffe's husband, Stephen, quit his job two weeks before their honeymoon to begin a home-based business, the couple was unprepared to negotiate the pressures of entrepreneurship and its demands on their marital relationship. Soon after, Ms. Jaffe, a human resource executive for more than 10 years who grew up in Smithtown, began interviewing couples for a book on the financial, emotional and familial impact of entrepreneurship. When awarded a book contract by Harper Collins on the research, her husband, in order to provide a steady income, returned to a corporate position.

title: Banned From Caymans, Gay Cruise Visits Belize
description: Sometime today the Leeward should be calling at Belize to allow its 900 passengers to shop, swim and scuba dive for a few hours. The only thing notable about the visit is that it was supposed to take place at the nearby Cayman Islands instead, but was diverted because the passengers are gay.

title: Top Schools At CUNY Toughen Admissions
description: While Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has been attacking the City University of New York for admitting unprepared students to its community colleges, some of the system's senior colleges have been quietly raising their admissions criteria over the last two years.

title: A Single Step
description: To the Editor: As Susan Spano reiterates in ''Of Princes, Palaces and a Pink City'' (Jan. 11), even the longest journey ''begins with a single step.'' True, too, a journey may begin with a single misstep.

title: The Fleet That Rules the Waves
description: CONTINUING the ''anything you can do, I can do bigger'' parade, today's enormous ships offer more of everything. The Grand Princess, the largest cruise ship at 109,000 tons, will carry 2,600 passengers, who will be faced with a bewildering labyrinth of corridors but able to choose from four places to have breakfast, seven for lunch, eight for dinner, a 24-hour bistro and full-time room service.

title: Joseph Marine, 92, State Senator in the 60's
description: Joseph E. Marine, a Democratic State Senator from the North Bronx in the 1960's, died Sunday at the Oakwood Health Facility in Amherst, N.Y. He was 92 and had lived in Oceanside, N.Y., after his stint in Albany.

title: Derelict Theater, Hope for a Neighborhood
description: AS with other members of the West End Civic Association, Chris Larsen Nelson was frustrated that the Hartford neighborhood group couldn't reach a consensus on the fate of the Colonial Theater on Farmington Avenue. By last year, the 1,200-seat area cinema, vacant for a decade, had come to symbolize an urban neighborhood in search of itself.

title: Culture Zone; Master of His Domain
description: The funniest man in america isn't on television. He doesn't do stand-up or talk shows or American Express ads. He doesn't make silly faces or rude noises. He doesn't try to spin his own indiscretions into pretentious art. His jokes aren't about ''nothing''; they're not even about himself. Indeed, his specialty is making black comedy out of such unfunny subjects as high finance and gutter journalism, Hollywood tunnel vision and Washington doublespeak, human vanity and greed.

title: Black and White Revisited; Letters on 'Little Things' Revealed Insensitivity
description: To the Editor:

title: The Byzantine World Of Airline Fares
description: CUSTOMERS shopping for the lowest air fares have grown accustomed to good deals if they buy well in advance and lock in specific flights, while paying extravagant prices to fly at the last minute with freedom to change plans. Now a consumer-advocacy organization with members on college campuses across the country says a test it conducted shows that airline pricing is much more complicated than this, so complicated that even savvy consumers cannot be sure they are getting the best deal, or even a good deal, unless they spend an inordinate amount of time shopping.

title: Instructions for Plumbing Emergency
description: PLUMBING problems can occur at any time of the year, but they are more likely to develop in the winter because the water in pipes can freeze, expand and crack the surrounding pipe. The easiest way to keep this from happening is by making sure that the pipes stay warm enough so the water never hits the freezing point.

title: Buds, at the Mercy of Warmth in the Winter
description: AN unusual weather pattern creates problems for the plant world. Witness the premature flowering of cherry trees in Washington, D.C. In case readers have not realized it, that famous springtime display is pretty much over for this year, many of the trees having already bloomed. Only those cherry trees that failed to be fooled by the false spring will come out on schedule.

title: BOOKEND; The Coronation of a Jester
description: Dario Fo? It wouldn't have been surprising to learn that Fo had won a MacArthur grant or an Obie. But the Nobel Prize in Literature? No disrespect meant -- what Fo does is what Fo does -- but he didn't exactly seem part of that literary tradition that runs from Thomas Mann, say, to T. S. Eliot to William Faulkner to Albert Camus.

title: Second Chances End For Morris (for Now)
description: Bam Morris's story is one of those that makes anyone who has followed it shake his head. Sadly, it has become an all too common one in football, and in sports in general.

title: CURLING
description: CURLING JOINS snowboarding as a medal sport after being an exhibition at the 1924, 1932, 1988 and 1992 Winter Games. The sport was invented in the 16th century by Scottish farmers who curled on frozen bogs using smooth stones found in channels. Scottish immigrants imported the game to Canada in 1759 and to the United States in 1832. Since then, the sport has undergone two significant advancements: the standardization of the curling stone and indoor, refrigerated ice.

title: January 25-31; Japan's Finance Minister Steps Aside
description: A day after two Japanese Foreign Ministry officials were arrested on accusations that they had accepted bribes from banks they supervised, Finance Minister Hiroshi Mitsuzuka took responsibility for the scandal and stepped down.

title: In the Region/Westchester; County Buys I.B.M. Site for Its 6th Golf Course
description: RESPONDING to the surge of interest in golf in recent years, Westchester County has just purchased 170 acres of rolling meadow here in the hope of turning it into its sixth public golf course.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUGHES, EUGENE ''GENE''
description: HUGHES-Eugene ''Gene''. Age 56, formerly of New Jersey and New York City, died peacefully on the 10th of January 1998. Gene Hughes was in the jewelry business for many years. He will be missed by his wife Mindy, his parents, and his entire family.

title: Science Fiction
description: The temptation to play God is an occupational hazard for science fiction writers. A case in point: the richly imagined, consistently engaging and self-destructively ambitious EARTHLING (Tor/ Tom Doherty, $22.95), by Tony Daniel. The novel opens with a stylistic tour de force in which apparently random entries in a geologist's field journal coalesce into the memories of a dead man that have been downloaded into the electronic brain of a mining robot. Although the robot has access to these sophisticated memories, its own awakening consciousness is appropriately childlike.

title: Promoting Subway Manners In the Days Before Graffiti
description: THE litterbug, the seat-hogger and the door-blocker were all targets of Amelia Opdyke Jones, whose etiquette posters were fixtures in the subways from 1947 through the 1960's. The work of this artist, known as Oppy, is the focus of an exhibition at the New York Transit Museum titled ''50 Years of 'The Subway Sun.' ''

title: To the Moon, Ralph
description: The women who run New York City's buses, subways and token booths don't have to worry about looking like Ralph Kramden anymore. All New York City Transit employees will be given a new look by spring, and for the first time, there will be specially designed clothes for women, including maternity wear.

title: Europe Envies America; Now, Teen-Agers Turn to Crime
description: IN Berlin, a youngster is robbed on the street by knife-wielding teen-agers who covet his designer-labeled American backpack. In London, a headmaster is stabbed to death by a pupil outside his school. In the Netherlands, a 30-year-old man is trampled to death by teen-agers because he tried to talk them out of tipping other people's motorcycles into a canal. In Strasbourg, France, young people are blamed for setting 100 cars afire last New Year's.

title: On the Rocks
description: CLEANING UP

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HORVATH, STANLEY S.
description: HORVATH-Stanley S. On January 29, 1998. Beloved husband of Marcia. Father of Jordan and Lisa. Grandfather of Paul. Brother of Evelyn Seidman. We will miss him very much. Funeral service Sunday 11:30 AM at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st St. and Amsterdam.

title: A Crime of Passion
description: THE HOUSE GUN

title: Black and White Revisited; Area Coveted by Fairway Is Important Riverfront Link
description: To the Editor:

title: Q. & A.
description: Suing Buyer Who Cancels

title: Money to Spend, Voters to Attract
description: AS they prepare for the General Assembly session that begins Wednesday, both Republican and Democratic legislators are talking about three goals for the session: cutting taxes, increasing education spending and preserving more open space.

title: WESTCHESTER BRIEFS
description: Airport Traffic

title: Social Center Wins Court Round
description: Ever since the generally influential residents of the block of West 67th Street just west of Central Park heard about plans to convert a mid block town house into a Jewish cultural and social center, they have been trying to stop it, or at least scale it down.

title: Vietnam War Airmen Buried
description: The remains of two Air Force fliers missing in Southeast Asia for three decades have been identified and returned to their families for burial, the Pentagon has announced.

title: Affirmative Actions?
description: White Boys

title: Preserving Land In Brother's Memory
description: The article on John Ward Melville and the Stony Brook area [''Building a Village, Providing a University,'' Jan. 4] mentioned historic land being sold to private citizens. One example cited with an obviously negative connotation was that of a 7.5-acre area with a historic home on it to a local businessman, the founder of Renaissance Technologies, James Simons, my father. Contrary to the gist of the article, this land was in fact bought for the purpose of establishing a park and nature preserve in memory of my late brother Paul Simons, who at 34 was killed by a car in a bicycle accident in September 1996 in the Stony Brook area.

title: How Music Spins a Web Of Meaning
description: IN HIS LATEST BOOK, ''LOOK, LISTEN, READ,'' Claude Levi-Strauss pursues his decadeslong study of language once again into the realms of music and painting. Where music is concerned, he finds an 18th-century hero in an earlier Parisian intellectual, Michel Paul Guy de Chabanon, who evidently came up with surprisingly modern ideas about music's being an autonomous art, not dependent on an ability to imitate natural phenomena, emotions or anything else but, instead, appealing in its own right.

title: BENEATH THE TURBAN: A special report.; Mullah Who Charmed Iran Is Struggling to Change It
description: The mullah wore beautiful shoes.

title: Best if Sold by . . .
description: Next time you throw out that expired carton of milk, you may want to toss your moisturizer, too. There's a new concept in cosmetics: products with expiration dates, like Nano Essence, a moisturizer that contains a cucumber enzyme and, according to the instructions, should be used within 90 days of the manufacture date stamped on the package. Created by Awake, a Japanese company, it is sold at Henri Bendel, whose clerks advise clients to refrigerate it for peak freshness.

title: Museum Banner Ruffles Residents
description: Life along Manhattan's Museum Mile is usually genteel, on a leafy corridor of rich apartments that are a common backdrop in Woody Allen films. But for the residents of 1080 Fifth Avenue, next door to the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum at East 89th Street, an irritant has sliced into their slice of New York.

title: Lives; The Burden of a Happy Childhood
description: Every time I described the house to friends -- the two porches, the bay windows, the balcony over the front door, the stone tubs on either side of the front steps that, before they crumbled, always held geraniums -- they said, ''It sounds wonderful.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANELOUS, GEORGE
description: KANELOUS-George. Renowned artist, loving husband, father, grandfather and great-grandfather. His life, his art touched us all.

title: Looking for an 11 O'Clock Fix
description: After reading your article on the superficial news coverage that local television stations often provide, I am reminded of a comment by Fred Friendly, the former CBS News president and a professor at the Columbia School of Journalism, who noticed the trend several years ago and summed it up with the quip, ''It seems local television is making so much money at its worst that it can't afford to do its best.''

title: January 25-31; Haven't I Seen You Somewhere Before?
description: When she was 18, she was the voice and face of the occupiers of the American Embassy in Teheran. the spokeswoman who explained in American English why 52 Americans were being held hostage and why they might be tried for their supposed crimes. More than 18 years later, Massumeh Ebtekar, a 37-year-old mother of two, has a doctorate in immunology and is Iran's Vice President for the Environment. As the highest-ranking woman in President Mohammed Khatami's Government -- and with her excellent English -- she has been meeting often with foreign officials and journalists. When an American journalist visiting Iran recognized her, she made no apology for her role in the hostage drama, explaining, ''That was the best direction that could have been taken'' at the time. Now some ambassadors in Teheran say they will no longer meet with her and will discourage official contact with her office. ELAINE SCIOLINO

title: Such Sullied Brides Now Selling Soap
description: IN MANY WAYS, THEY ARE FAIRY-TALE weddings, uniting star-crossed lovers who have endured every conceivable calamity -- amnesia, kidnapping, bigamy, rape, psychotic ex-spouses -- before murmuring ''I do.''

title: Textiles as Rich and Varied As the History of Pakistan
description: THE LUSH TEXTILE exhibItion at the Victoria and Albert Museum has a most unusual provenance: the practice of a dental surgeon in Hyderabad, Pakistan. When the dentist, Dr. Nasreen Askari, was working at the Civil Hospital in the 1970's, she was drawn to the elaborately embroidered garments worn by the women who came for treatment. Noting her interest in their clothing, patients responded with gifts of textiles as a tribute to her healing skills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARNOW, THEODORE
description: ARNOW-Theodore. Beloved husband of Deborah, cherished father of Judy, adored grandfather of Karyn and Lisa. Services today, 1 PM, at ''Sinai Chapels'' 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY.

title: Hingis Defends Australian Title With a Nod to History
description: It was another pleasant day at the outdoor office, another Grand Slam title, along with its six-figure paycheck, tucked into the ever-expanding piggy bank of 17-year-old Martina Hingis. The apparently peerless player put up a successful and, if truth be told, virtually rote defense of her Australian Open title this afternoon with a 6-3, 6-3 pasting of Spain's eighth-seeded Conchita Martinez.

title: Looking for an 11 O'Clock Fix
description: Your intriguing article never really answered its own question: how to make Bill Bauman's reformed TV journalism attractive to viewers? The eat-your-vegetables approach will never work.

title: Stories About Race, Politics and Himself
description: GLENN LIGON, 37, IS ONE OF the more visible members of a generation of young American artists who in the 1990's have been intent on injecting a new content -- personal, political, racial, sexual -- into art.

title: Could It Be? The Red Sox and the Cubs in the 1998 World Series? Nah.
description: Think of how the fans of the Boston Red Sox and the Chicago Cubs must have felt last October when the fledgling Florida Marlins won the World Series in only their fifth year of existence. Hardly a Red Sox fan is alive who was there when the team last won a World Series. That was 1918, and the team the Red Sox beat was the Cubs, whose adoring but masochistic fans have waited in vain since 1908 for another championship.

title: Black and White Revisited; Police Are Real Targets Of Vigils at Drug Locations
description: To the Editor:

title: January 25-31; New Insights About Multiple Sclerosis
description: Neurologists have thought for years that it was easy to see what went wrong in multiple sclerosis: A smooth fatty coating that insulates nerve cells in the brain gets eaten away, leaving bare patches of nerves that short-circuit when they try to transmit electrical signals. But scientists at the Cleveland Clinic Foundation now report the most direct evidence yet that something else goes wrong too. Huge numbers of nerve cells actually break in two, they have discovered, with as many as 11,000 cells broken in areas as small as a pinhead in patients' brains.

title: At Housing Project, Drugs Linger but the Killing Fields Go
description: A few weeks ago, Wally Bazemore, a civic activist in the Red Hook Houses, listened as the police and the Brooklyn District Attorney, Charles Hynes, trumpeted the results of a major drug sweep in the housing project Mr. Bazemore has called home for 41 of his 46 years.

title: Reid Beats Frazier, but Finds the Punches Faster
description: The baby steps ended for 24-year-old David Reid tonight. Robert Frazier made him take a giant step forward in his maturation as a boxer. Reid survived the first war of his young career to win a tough eight-round unanimous decision in a junior-middleweight bout against Frazier at the Trump Taj Mahal ballroom.

title: Musician Heads Magazine for Guitarists
description: RICH MALOOF, the 31-year-old editor in chief of Guitar magazine, which is published here, talked about going to the National Association of Music Merchants' show in Los Angeles, where hundreds of different types of guitars would be on display, as if he were a kid in a candy store. A resident of Irvington, he is not just an editor of a guitar magazine but also a singer-songwriter who started playing the guitar at 7 and played in countless bands, including one that toured rock-and-roll clubs in the Northeast. He continues to play solo acoustic guitar in shows at bookstores and coffeehouses in the county.

title: Lions Play Like Tigers, But Only for 30 Minutes
description: For Princeton, facing Columbia is like looking in a mirror that is slightly askew, a funhouse mirror presenting an off-center version of the Tigers' system. The moves are there, but the result never has been.

title: Hopping On the Dow Bus
description: THE name Dow Jones resonates with investors, so now that Dow Jones & Company is licensing the use of the Dow Jones industrial average, two mutual fund sponsors are among the financial services firms offering new products based on the benchmark.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: Yale's Run Continues
description: YALE 3, PRINCETON 2

title: F.Y.I.
description: Fur-Coated Cinema

title: School Bell Will Ring. Who'll Answer?
description: Geographically, the area served by Community Board 1 is fairly large, comprising most of Manhattan south of Canal Street. As for population, it has always been small, the residential character of its neighborhoods, including TriBeCa and the South Street Seaport area, having only recently been established.

title: Private Elementary Schools Need Help, Too
description: WHEN Renbrook School, a private school in West Hartford for pre-kindergarten through ninth-grade students, received a $1 million gift from two grandparents last September, its headmistress expressed delight as well as astonishment. ''Junior schools such as ours are usually the last in the pecking order'' when major charitable contributions are made, she wrote to parents.

title: Man Accused of Kicking And Badly Injuring Girl, 2
description: A Bronx man was arrested early yesterday and accused of brutally kicking his girlfriend's 2-year-old daughter, critically injuring her, the police said.

title: Costa Rica, Naturally
description: THE brochure made it sound simple and appealing: explore Costa Rica's rain forests from a cruise ship that reaches pristine coasts normally accessible only by grueling overland treks. But I headed for the jungle with trepidation.

title: The State's Kaleidoscope of Activities Observing Black History Month
description: February is Black History Month. Here is a sampling of related events in New Jersey.

title: Widen the Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.
description: Bye-Bye Pants, Hello Lounge

title: Lisa Zellin, Burton Warren
description: Lisa Zellin and Burton D. Warren are to be married this afternoon at Jack Studios, a photography studio in Manhattan. Rabbi Roy Rosenberg is to officiate with Msgr. David Cassato.

title: Q and A
description: Crafts in Japan

title: Just Visiting: A Prison Museum Takes Shape In West Trenton
description: In a corner of a one-story brick building on the Department of Corrections grounds in West Trenton, the New Jersey Museum of Prison History is only a fraction of what its curator hopes it will be in a few months. But the centerpiece of the small museum, which was open to the public through specially arranged tours until two years ago, will probably remain the electric chair that was used to execute 161 people, including Bruno Hauptmann, convicted of kidnapping the Lindbergh baby.

title: Sheer Terror? When Polemics Overtake the Magic
description: A FOREWARNING: here comes Thyme, one of those compulsive blabberers for a cause -- hers is conservation -- who fills a captive audience with dread. Far more immediate than the fear of expiring from toxic fumes, one of the subjects of her assaultive ravings, is the sheer terror that she will talk you to death. If Thyme doesn't come up for air, polluted or not, a real and present danger looms. Everyone will expire from the fallout of verbal overkill.

title: 'Painting by Numbers'
description: To the Editor:

title: Christel Albritton, Colin MacLean
description: Christel Regina Albritton, the daughter of Claudia M. Albritton of New York and Reginald W. Albritton of Seoul, South Korea, was married yesterday to Colin Scott MacLean, a son of Angela F. MacLean of Mississauga, Ontario, and Donald Fraser MacLean of Vancouver. The Rev. Dr. Charles W. Fox, a Congregationalist minister, officiated at the Canfield Casino in Saratoga Springs, N.Y.

title: London Maverick Arrives For First (and Second) Time
description: IN LONDON, THE DIRECTOR Sam Mendes has won acclaim for spicing productions from time to time with actors a generation or so younger than the roles usually demand. Comparatively young himself at 32, Mr. Mendes has already had the wide-ranging career of a director many years his senior: Jonson and Shakespeare on the one hand, Sondheim and Kander and Ebb on the other, to name a few.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASEY, ELIZABETH FRANCES
description: CASEY-Elizabeth Frances. Of White Plains, NY, on January 30, 1998, after a long and valiant battle with breast cancer. Dearly loved wife and best friend of Steven Eichberg. Devoted mother of her precious Catie and Maxxie. Beloved youngest daughter of Dr. Francis and Catherine Casey, and cherished sister of Michael, James, Brigid, Christopher, Monica and Sean Casey, Moira Avanzino and the late Cathleen O'Connell. Daughter-in-law of Marion T. Eichberg and the late Robert L. Eichberg of Denver, CO. Lizzie was adored by her many sistersin-law and brothers-in-law, nieces and nephews, and treasured by her friends. She was a light in all their lives and a vivid and warming presence in the world. She will be missed beyond words. Mass of the Resurrection will be held at 10 AM, on Monday, February 2, at St. Bernard's R.C. Church, Prospect St. and South Lexington Ave., White Plains, NY. The burial will be private. Elizabeth's family will receive friends at her home on Monday following the Mass, and Tuesday through Friday from 1 PM to 8 PM. In lieu of flowers, please consider making contributions in Elizabeth's memory to the White Plains American Cancer Society, White Plains Meals on Wheels or the charitable organization of your choice.

title: One Attorney General for 10 Years
description: The furor surrounding President Clinton and Monica Lewinsky has created a backlash against Kenneth Starr, the independent counsel. Mr. Starr's critics ask, with some legitimacy: What possible connection could his investigation of Whitewater have to the accusation that the President asked Ms. Lewinsky to lie about an affair?

title: How Companies Make the Boss Buy Stock, but Soften the Pinch
description: FEW ideas in corporate America have so quickly attained motherhood-and-apple-pie status as the notion that top executives should own big stakes in their companies. In just the last five years, more than 20 percent of the country's 1,000 largest companies have proudly adopted guidelines that require their officers to own stock equal in value to several times their annual salaries.

title: Old Faces In Demand As Sources For Insight
description: Spying each other at lunch the other day at Vox Artis, a few blocks from the White House, Harry Thomason and Laura R. Handman embraced like two shipwreck victims reunited on dry land. That moment between the Hollywood film maker, in purgatory since the Travelgate scandal, and the wife of President Clinton's subpoena-prone campaign czar, Harold M. Ickes, symbolizes how the power balance has changed in Washington in just 10 days.

title: Questions You Always Wanted to Ask a Figure Skating Judge
description: Joan Burns of Millbrae, Calif., and Chuck Foster of Duxberry, Mass., two prominant figure-skating judges, answer common questions about judging. Bedel Saget

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAKOWITZ, HILDA
description: SAKOWITZ-Hilda. On January 29, 1998. Beloved wife of Sheldon. Devoted mother of Jill and Mark, and mother-in-law of Linda. Loving brother of Herbert Kahn. Cherished grandmother of Danielle. Services Sunday 1:15 P.M. at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANNER, GEORGE, M.D.
description: KANNER-George, M.D. January 30, 1998 of Garden City, N.Y. Beloved husband of Virginia. Loving father of Judith Medori, Deborah Sandler and David Kanner. Dear grandfather of six grandchildren. Loving brother of Nathan Kanner and Martin Kanner and the late Sylvia Schlager and the late Lillian Zimmerman. Visiting at The Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Avenue at 12th Street, Garden City 2-5 and 7-9 PM Sunday. Religious service 10 A.M., Monday at The Fairchild Chapel. Interment Pinelawn Memorial Park, Pinelawn New York.

title: Like Jordan, Hardaway Is a Headache for the Knicks
description: When the Knicks and the Miami Heat meet on the court, as they will at 1 P.M. Sunday at Madison Square Garden, the game usually features its fair share of hazards. There are the wrecking balls that Alonzo Mourning calls his elbows. Charles Oakley is a threat to anyone on the court, as well as the fans seated within the first few rows. There is even the possibility of a P. J. Brown-generated somersault.

title: Druggist and Customer: Doses of Civility With the Tums
description: ''It's the greatest establishment in New York,'' said Penelope Wilder, speaking of Lascoff Apothecaries at Lexington Avenue and East 82d Street, founded in 1899. ''And Susan and Phil are the greatest, too, well mannered and lovely.''

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Salt Opera
description: SILVER CITY

title: Is Yahoo Flying High With a Bull's-Eye on Its Back?
description: EVER since the Internet launched Netscape Communications, a tiny start-up with a good idea, into the stock market stratosphere, investors have been searching lists of new public companies to find the next Netscape. But now that the browser company has fallen to $16, from its high of $72 a share, investors are also trying to identify the next Internet Icarus before it crashes.

title: In America; Legal Game Playing
description: Adam Mann was 5 years old and weighed only 35 pounds when he finally died on March 5, 1990. He had been abused for some time. When he was wheeled into the emergency room of Our Lady of Mercy Hospital in the Bronx his body was covered with thick welts, severe lacerations and deep ugly bruises. His head and lips were battered and swollen, as if he'd been in a prizefight.

title: Conflicts of Race, Generations and Justice
description: IN celebration of Crossroads Theater Company's 20 years here, Leslie Lee, the playwright whose ''First Breeze of Summer'' opened the rickety old space in a converted sewing factory on Memorial Parkway, is having his new work, ''Spirit North,'' produced by the same organization, which has evolved into the country's foremost black theater. For the occasion, the great composer and folk singer Odetta has written original music, and her eloquent, prayerlike lamentations are heard on tape.

title: Woman Ascending a Marble Staircase
description: Rags-to-riches stories will eternally fascinate, and I do have compassion for their protagonists, particularly when they are women. (I worked my way through graduate school, taught English for 15 years, sold a novel, bought an apartment for my family with the money, sold another book, and so on.) But serious praise for women who snag rich husbands and spend the days making their own phone calls and the nights pulling up to skyscrapers in limousines seems nothing short of hilarious.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Listening for Small Sounds

title: Woman Ascending a Marble Staircase
description: Elisabeth Bumiller's article about Julia Flesher Koch was more than I could take (''Woman Ascending a Marble Staircase,'' Jan. 11). Koch answers her own phone and pours her husband's orange juice. Now there's a woman for the 90's.

title: Plants to Cover the Nearly Uncoverable
description: EVERY garden has a challenging spot, like a poorly drained area that turns into a swamp after every rain or a shady spot choked with shallow tree roots. One of the most vexing is the steep bank.

title: Correction
description: A picture on Jan. 18 with an article about historical figures portrayed in the musical ''Ragtime'' was published in error. The inset in a segment on the financier J. P. Morgan showed Morgan's son, Jack, also known as J. P. Morgan Jr., not Morgan himself.

title: False Rape Tale, Real Effect
description: When parents in Community School District 3 heard a week and a half ago about a reported rape of a 13-year-old girl at a school on 93d Street and Amsterdam Avenue, they were alarmed.

title: Looks Like 'Seinfeld,' but Call It 'Raymond'
description: WHILE PRESIDING OVER the People's Choice Awards ceremony last month, Ray Romano, the star of ''Everybody Loves Raymond,'' observed that the cast of his CBS comedy series was seated way back at the far end of the room. ''Next year we're going to be up front, I promise,'' Mr. Romano called out. Then, glancing toward the ''Seinfeld'' cast seated near the stage, he said, ''I know this table is going to be empty.''

title: Newcomer Sparkles With Enticing Food
description: IN A COUNTRY GARDEN, a new restaurant in Glen Head, makes an enchanting first impression. The second impression, the one that comes when the food is served, is pretty darn good as well.

title: At the Casinos
description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week.

title: The View From/Norwalk; Boxing Out of a Tough Environment
description: TED LOWRY of Norwalk has faced fierce opponents before, and he's earned a reputation for never backing down.

title: January 25-31; Testing Its Metal
description: She was the biggest and most opulent ship of her day. And newly released evidence suggests she was sunk by defects in some of her smallest and least expensive parts.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Life Designs

title: Victor Pasmore, 87, Painter and Art Innovator
description: Victor Pasmore, painter, printmaker, educator and for more than 50 years a volatile but invaluable figure in the British art world, died on Jan. 22 at his home on the island of Malta. He was 87.

title: Regionalizing School Districts
description: Would merging some of the state's 611 school districts be a prudent cost-cutting measure or an intrusion into local control of education?

title: Filling Out the Callas Legacy (in Spite of Callas)
description: MARIA CALLAS HAD A love-hate relationship with the recording studio. Despite her deep insecurities, she understood the uniqueness of her artistry. She also seemed to have a premonition that her career would be short: no one can sing for long with the kind of consuming intensity Callas brought to her work.

title: The Costs of Doing Business
description: THE convenience of mutual fund ownership increasingly comes at a higher and higher price.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELLES, JESS
description: GELLES-Jess on January 30 1998. Beloved husband and best friend of Claire; loving father of Betty Hurwitz and Mark Gelles. Brother of Arnold; beloved ''Papa'' to all his grandchildren. Services private

title: A Cart Advantage
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Some Applause for AT&T's Shake-Up
description: WHEN C. Michael Armstrong, the chairman of AT&T, announced a number of drastic shake-up measures last Monday, including trimming up to 18,000 jobs, Charles Carlson was one happy listener.

title: Play of Issues Becomes One With an Agenda
description: AFOREWARNING: here comes Thyme, one of those compulsive blabberers for a cause -- hers is conservation -- who fills a captive audience with dread. Far more immediate than the fear of expiring from toxic fumes, one of the subjects of her assaultive ravings, is the sheer terror that she will talk you to death. If Thyme does not come up for air, polluted or not, a real and present danger looms. Everyone will expire from the fallout of verbal overkill.

title: Carl Gorman, Code Talker In World War II, Dies at 90
description: Carl Gorman, a gentle Navajo artist who talked his way valiantly through some of the fiercest fighting of World War II, died on Thursday at a hospital in Gallup, N.M. He was 90 and the oldest of the 400 Navajo code talkers who were proud to call themselves Washindon be Akalh B-kosi-lai, or, as the Japanese could never figure out, United States Marines.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLAUMEZ, KARNES, MARILYN E.
description: WILLAUMEZ - KARNES - Marilyn E. Of New York. On January 22, 1998. Mother of Jonah David Willaumez. Former member of the Fashion Group and the Bellevue Hospital Auxiliary Board. Her career included positions at Vogue Magazine, Burlington Industries and Celanese Inc. Memorial service will be held February 23rd.

title: Corrections
description: Headlines yesterday about a statement by Linda R. Tripp that she was present when Monica S. Lewinsky received a late-night phone call from President Clinton misstated what Ms. Tripp said she heard. She said she heard Ms. Lewinsky's end of a conversation and was later told by Ms. Lewinsky that it was the President; she did not tell of hearing the President speaking.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: WASHINGTON HEIGHTS; Hospital's Day-Care Plans Raise Tenant Fears of Eviction
description: Given its work force of 8,000, Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center is the largest employer in Washington Heights. And the 21 apartment buildings it owns in the neighborhood makes the hospital one of the area's biggest landlords.

title: Integrating Harvard Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Australian Title Goes to Korda After He Rides Emotional Wave
description: With a motto of better late than never, Petr Korda, the 30-year-old Czech stringbean, won his first Grand Slam title today at the Australian Open with a world-class pummeling of ninth-seeded Marcelo Rios of Chile.

title: Look and, Yes, Touch
description: It was an obsession with the life of Louis Braille that inspired Christopher Roule of Manhattan to design jewelry bearing inscriptions in Braille. ''It's a language that breaks the physical barrier, and the jewelry communicates both emotionally and physically,'' Mr. Roule said. His line includes necklaces, bracelets, key chains and rings, with Braille on one side and the translation on the other. Words like touch, earthling, libertine, pilgrim and moxie become personal statements.

title: Surely They Jest
description: Headgear with a sense of humor has found its way to the city, especially spiky caps that make it appear that whimsical space aliens have landed. Once seen only on ski slopes, the caps, which mostly students have the nerve to wear, are made of velvet, felt or wool jersey, many with shapes inspired by court jesters' outfits. Others resemble pagodas. Even functional foam hair curlers suit the silly season.

title: Streetscapes/The Lunt-Fontanne; 1910 Theater, Once the Globe, Could Open to the Sky
description: WHEN the new 53-story Sheraton/ Planet Hollywood Hotel is completed at the southwest corner of 47th Street and Broadway in 1999, guests will look out over the flashing lights of the new Times Square. But even though the hotel will project over the Lunt-Fontanne Theater, at 205 West 46th Street, few will notice the strange asphalt-encrusted framework on the theater's roof. That peculiar remnant, a sliding roof that remains unique in Broadway history, is left over from the opening of the theater, built in 1910 by the producer Charles Dillingham.

title: Cruising the Corridor
description: CHUCKIE and his crew were cheap. That's what the ladies at the topless bar said after the bachelor party filed out into the darkness. Chuckie was to be married in two days, and he and the boys from the Sanitation Department had had a good time. Meanwhile, the dancers who had endured the groping and the unsociable things said about their ancestors received $1 tips. ''Not a player in the bunch,'' one lady said.

title: Africa Without Despair
description: INTO THE HOUSE OF THE ANCESTORS

title: An Irish Roundup Over the Business Table
description: ON the first Friday of every month, a group of professionals meets for lunch in Stamford to share business information. It is, appropriately, the First Friday Group.

title: Britain to Urge U.N. to Find Iraq in Violation of Arms Terms
description: Stressing that Britain and the United States are united in their commitment ''to prevent a brutal dictator from acquiring weapons of mass destruction,'' Britain is seeking a Security Council resolution to find Saddam Hussein ''in breach of his obligations'' to the Council, Foreign Secretary Robin Cook said in London on Saturday.

title: A Stage Life Less Noticed In the Glare Of Stardom
description: MARISA TOMEI IS A STAGE ACTRESS WITH her own sinuous, unpredictable silhouette. Take note of her here in this scene from ''Dark Rapture,'' Eric Overmyer's satiric, film-noir-inspired melodrama that had a limited run Off Broadway at the Second Stage in 1996. She's Julia, a femme fatale temporarily at rest, head turned, shoulders back, weight on one leg, toes to the fore in high heels that, when she walks, click-clack as if toting up a body count. Julia is giving lip to somebody she could squash under the ball of one foot.

title: Neighbors on 42d Street, but a World Apart
description: DANCE ON BROADWAY GETS A new chapter with ''The Lion King'' and ''Ragtime,'' the two current blockbusters on 42d Street. Esthetically, they are hardly within hailing distance, and yet they would not be what they are without their very different choreographers.

title: January 25-31; The Red Cross Comes Under Fire
description: Throughout the controversies over the endorsement policies of the American Medical Association and other nonprofit organizations last year, the American Red Cross always remained above the fray.

title: Food; Pan Asia
