description: Dawn in singapore, and the air is gray gauze. From a lofty hotel window, you can see tiny figures pruning the orchids and the rubber plants, polishing the windows and scrubbing the facades -- Hermes, Calvin Klein, Burberrys -- along Orchard Road. Trucks ferrying live chickens and mammoth crabs seem to float through the city. The hiss from the steam machines is not audible from this high up, but the steam rises like smoke from mirrors.

title: BAD IDEA
description: Mercury, a highly toxic liquid metal, has become the latest drug of choice for many teen-agers in Texarkana, a city on the Arkansas-Texas border. In a bizarre outbreak, young people have confessed to stealing 20 pounds of mercury from an abandoned neon-sign plant and smoking mercury-dipped cigarettes. Some officials say that teen-agers have even snorted the stuff. Nobody has died yet, but one mercury-abusing teen-ager was hospitalized with seizures and vomiting. Experts aren't sure about what the appeal is. ''Kids think mercury is so cool,'' says Dave Hall, the emergency-management coordinator for Texarkana. ''When we talk to them, they laugh. Sadly, more teen-agers are becoming sick because of stupidity.''

title: POSTINGS: The Gate Condominium in Hoboken; Amid Brownstones, a Touch of Scotland
description: A vacant lot at the corner of a prime brownstone block in Hoboken has given way to a five-story condominium that brings a touch of historic Scotland to the city.

title: Intern's Lawyer Heartens the White House
description: A concession by the lawyer for the former White House intern Monica S. Lewinsky that his client sometimes embellishes the truth and his denials of some of the sensational second-hand accounts of her relationship with the President cheered White House aides today as they moved to defend him more vigorously.

title: Free Baby-Sitting? Just Sit for Others
description: WHEN Candace and Roger Kuebel of Larchmont, N.Y., flew to Grenada for a week's vacation in 1996, they did something most parents of young children do only in their dreams.

title: DOUBLY FORBIDDEN
description: Barbara Jo Revelle, an artist in Gainesville, Fla., thought she'd found the perfect home for her photographic work ''Unnecessary and in Very Bad Taste,'' 15 panels of provocative pictures, some of them previously censored. ''Unnecessary'' was picked up by the curators of ''Contained/Controlled,'' an exhibition of censored art that showed in Miami and was scheduled to go up this month at the Manatee Community College art gallery in Bradenton, Fla. Alas, the censorship show was itself censored: before it began, officials decided not to hang one part of ''Unnecessary'' -- six photographs of a naked, aroused man wearing a gorilla mask -- calling the images ''problematic.'' As a result, Roxie Thomas and Trina Nicklas, who planned the exhibition, canceled it in protest. To replace it, the school put up 18th-century architectural lithographs, along with drawings depicting the Holocaust.

title: LUGE
description: FIRST OF ALL, avoid asking a luger if he steers. ''Beginner question,'' said the American Wendel Suckow. Lugers do steer, even though their sleds have no steering mechanisms. They shift their body weight and applying pressure on the runners, the only part of the sled that touches the ice. For some reason, German-speaking people seem to do this best: Twenty-seven of the 28 Olympic golds awarded in current luge events have been won by Germans, Austrians or northern Italians.

title: In Our Backyard? No Way, They Say, Pulling Out Their Wallets
description: When residents of this small borough in Mercer County learned that 58 acres of gently rolling hills here and in adjacent Hopewell Township was destined for development, they took out their checkbooks.

title: The L.I.R.R.'s Implications of Cheating on Forgotten Tickets
description: NERISSA R. VASQUEZ boarded the 7:31 express from Brentwood to Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan, reached for her purse to pull out her monthly commutation ticket and realized that she had left the purse at home.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; The Beckmann Archive
description: Max Beckmann, one of the most provocative German painters of the 20th century, was rarely what he appeared to be. Part savvy insider with a flair for self-promotion, part political pariah, he was an extrovert prone to self-concealment and an avowed liberal who shunned political engagement. Beckmann (1884-1950) married into the German aristocracy and hobnobbed with high society, while taking potshots in his writings at the very people he courted to advance his career. ''The budding genius must learn above all else to respect money and power,'' he wrote with characteristic irony, adding that the riskiest thing an artist could have was ''too strong a backbone,'' which interfered with the requisite ''bowing and scraping.'' Similarly, Beckmann's relationship with other artists was never an easy fit. Allying himself with German realism, he maligned the abstract painters for making unformed, ''decorative'' work, yet he shared in many of their aims, including the desire for a new and transcendent art. Though driven into exile in Amsterdam in 1937, after the Nazis proclaimed his art degenerate, Beckmann, ever the opportunist, distanced himself from his fellow emigre artists to protect his position on the international art market. He even went so far as to describe himself as a nonpolitical ''hermit,'' a disingenuous assertion given the politically charged content of much of his work. Barbara Copeland Buenger, who teaches art history at the University of Wisconsin, has done an excellent job of editing and annotating Beckmann's voluminous private and public writings in MAX BECKMANN: Self-Portrait in Words. Collected Writings and Statements, 1903-1950 (University of Chicago, $34.95). The man who emerges from this revealing selection from his earliest diaries, war letters and public statements is duplicitous and more politically compromised than has been previously known -- yet also more interesting. Andrea Barnet

title: Long Vigil For Crumbs Of Clues To Secrets
description: The Federal grand jury proceedings involving President Clinton and a former White House intern are so secret that even some lawyers and witnesses will not reveal their names.

title: The Nation; Trust Me: A Media Guide
description: FOR nearly two weeks, the nation's news organizations have asked their readers, viewers and listeners to trust them. In hundreds of stories and over countless hours, the news media have told tales about President Clinton and Monica S. Lewinsky, a former White House intern, that are both astonishing and appalling -- if they are true.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PENA, CARLOS E.
description: PENA-Carlos E. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Carlos E. Pena, associated with The Times from 1969, until retiring in 1991.

title: Technicality Gives the County Time to Rethink Its Transit Pact
description: EXCEPT for a legal technicality -- call it a mistake -- it would all have been settled by now.

title: Perhaps a Co-op Can Set You Free
description: There is no national network for baby-sitting cooperatives. Most parents learn about them through word of mouth or through churches and synagogues or Lamaze classes.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Revisiting Babar in Music

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAHAM, ARNOLD H.
description: GRAHAM-Arnold H. The Board of Trustees, faculty and staff of New York Law School mourn the loss of Arnold H. Graham, a graduate of the Class of 1952 and a professor and Vice Dean for Finance and Administration, 1976-1986. He will be deeply missed. Taylor R. Briggs, Chair of the Board of Trustees Harry H. Wellington, Dean

title: London in the Fall
description: To the Editor: Susan Allen Toth's ''London, Gently Aglow'' (Dec. 7) depicts London's charms for a couple at Christmastime. London is also wonderful for a family at Thanksgiving.

title: Children's Books
description: MOBY DICK By Herman Melville. Adapted and illustrated by Allan Drummond. Unpaged. New York: Frances Foster Books/ Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $16. (Ages 5 to 9)

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: In the Slick of the Cricket

title: SNOWBOARDING
description: SNOWBOARDING, which makes its Olympic debut, is a young sport, a product of American youth looking for an alternative good time. One part of it -- the freestyle event known as halfpipe -- is skateboarding on snow. The other Olympic part -- the giant slalom -- is a combination of surfing and skiing on snow.

title: A Real-Life Toy Story, Animated Nonetheless
description: FEBRUARY is a big month for toy makers -- a time to wheel, deal and show their stuff at shows like the American International Toy Fair, held annually in Manhattan. So it makes sense for G. Wayne Miller to start his story of Hasbro Inc. at a toy show held two years ago this month, when the company was at a crossroads of sorts.

title: Rebecca Knapp, Christopher Adams
description: GROWING up in Wilmington, Del., Rebecca Kearney Knapp loved cats, dreamed of living in New York City one day and turned cartwheels back and forth in her front yard until dusk.

title: Mets Not Offering Enough for Benes
description: The agent for Andy Benes, the best available free agent pitcher, said last night that it was doubtful Benes would sign with the Mets. Without specifying the terms, the agent, Scott Boras, said that the Mets extended a multiyear offer Friday night that was short of what was necessary.

title: Blank Check; Ethics in Government: The Price of Good Intentions
description: THE urgent impulse to repair the country's wounds after Watergate led to two high-minded reforms. To take money out of politics, there was a campaign finance law. And to take politics out of the investigation and prosecution of high Government officials -- to prevent another Saturday Night Massacre -- there was the Ethics in Government Act that provided for independent counsels.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EGAN, AGNES T. (NEE MURPHY)
description: EGAN-Agnes T. (nee Murphy). On January 30, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Martin. Devoted mother of Thomas, John, Gerard and Terrence Egan and Peggy Egan Buell. Loving grandmother of Thomas, John, Danielle, Matthew, Andrew, Maura, William and Stephen. Dear sister-in-law of John Egan. Funeral Monday, 9:45 AM, from the McManus Funeral Home, 2001 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn. Funeral Mass 10:30 AM, at Saint Thomas Aquinas Church. Interment in Calverton National Cemetery. Visiting Saturday and Sunday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM.

title: On Language; Crony Capitalism
description: The washington post finds South Korea's economic distress troubling, ''particularly its outmoded form of crony capitalism.''

title: In Two Roles: Serving on the Bench and Racing to the Rescue
description: THE double life of Peter M. Leavitt has finally caught up with him. The judge, who usually views court proceedings from the bench, is expected this week to sit in the witness box in a courtroom just down the hall from his own, where he will testify in a double homicide trial.

title: January 25-31; Painful Questions Again In Northern Ireland
description: For 16 years the memory of ''Bloody Sunday,'' when 14 unarmed civil rights marchers -- all Catholics -- were killed by British soldiers in Northern Ireland on Jan. 30, 1972, has been a barrier to trust in negotiations toward peace in the province.

title: Eastern Europeans Envision the Future
description: REVIEWING art from Eastern Europe or the Soviet Union used to be a dispiriting prospect. Wit and humor came in flashes against a sorry background of censorship. And the artists didn't have access to the best materials, so the work seemed makeshift.

title: Sustained Focuses, Exemplified In Painting and Photography
description: THOUGH in the same area geographically, two current exhibitions couldn't be any farther apart in their content.

title: Damaged Roosevelt Island Tram to Be Out of Service 'Indefinitely'
description: Nearly one week after a construction crane slammed into a Manhattan-bound car of the Roosevelt Island tramway and knocked out service, officials said yesterday that repairs had not begun and the tram would be closed indefinitely.

title: Sports of The Times; Female Hockey Players Want to Be Like Dot and Mia
description: THAT could be us. The message was not lost on the Americans. It was the summer of 1996 and they were all watching the Summer Games from Atlanta, wave upon wave of female athletes with muscles and nerve and skill.

title: Looking for an 11 O'Clock Fix
description: Winerip hit the nail on the head when he suggested that local TV news programs based on stories of crime and misery are the most appealing to viewers. I believe these strike a nerve because they remind people, in the comfort of their homes, how well they have it compared with those unfortunate folks out there.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BISHOP, WALTER JR.
description: BISHOP-Walter Jr. The American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers records with sorrow the passing of our member, Walter Bishop Jr., on January 24, 1998 in New York City. We express our condolences to his family and join the jazz world in mourning his loss. Marilyn Bergman President & Chairman, ASCAP

title: Shrugging Off the Past, Full Speed Ahead
description: In the former East German sports system, athletes were chosen the way some people choose tomatoes. Body type meant everything. Gunda Niemann was told that her legs were too short for track and field. Determined to succeed anyway, she switched to speed skating at the age of 17. Nine years later, at the 1992 Winter Olympics in Albertville, France, she became the first woman to win a gold medal for a reunified Germany.

title: Picking The Flowers Of the Revolution
description: Jack's breakfast-and-lunch-only eatery in the central business district in New Orleans has checkered tablecloths. The menu has 40 soups and sandwiches, including the rarely requested Cuban sandwich: pork, tomatoes and chicken. There is a wine list, but few people drink wine at lunch anymore; it's a mineral water and Fruitopia crowd. And let's not even talk about smoking, though Jack, talking to me after closing time, is puffing on a long Romeo y Julieta, $30 in Canada, acquired for $3 in Santiago de Cuba, the second-largest city in Cuba.

title: Japanese Bank Rally Is Just Beginning
description: The most important scandal these days might not be the scandal you've been reading about. It might instead be the one that is engulfing Japan's Finance Ministry.

title: For the Record
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOVAK, BETTY
description: NOVAK-Betty. On January 30, 1998. Beloved wife of Adam. Devoted mother of Linda and Karin. Mother-in-law of Dr. Robert Greenberg and Dr. Daniel TerBush. Loving grandmother of Julia and Katie. Services Sunday, at 11:15 AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76 St and Amsterdam Ave. Donations in her memory may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering.

title: 100 Reasons to Make Vacationing a Vocation
description: WHILE holed up in a dingy $23 single at the Y.M.C.A. Tourist Hostel in New Delhi to write a story last October, something struck me: I was working on my 100th Frugal Traveler article. To celebrate, I went over to the stylish bar at the Imperial Hotel (where rates start at $170) and ordered a gin and tonic. The waiter looked me over and asked whether he should make it a double.

title: With Stand-Up Comedian, Sparks Fly at 'Rosie O'Donnell'
description: Mornings, Joey Kola is the funny rodeo clown, bounding up and down the stairs, microphone in hand, dancing, joking and doing the wave with the studio audience at ''The Rosie O'Donnell Show'' in Manhattan. Evenings, Mr. Kola's darker side comes out, venting frustrations and observations about life on the comedy club circuit.

title: The Return of Childhood's Jeans
description: WHILE the designer Tom Ford was showing his latest Gucci Uomo collection before a packed house last month in Milan, one of his signatures for fall was already being featured in the windows of the Gap and Club Monaco on lower Fifth Avenue in Manhattan. At both the elite and populist ends of the fashion business, word was out that straight-legged indigo jeans with four-inch turned-up cuffs had arrived. It was kismet in Toughskins.

title: Free Museums
description: To the Editor: Apropos of ''A Free Museum Is Harder to Find'' (Dec. 28), my wife and I have known that United States citizens are not eligible for Italy's free entry for over-65's since we first encountered the policy in 1988. However, we have occasionally gotten the reduction, mostly by keeping our mouths shut, or sometimes by muttering ''vecchio'' (''aged''), or ''I speak English'' (British subjects get the discount).

title: Susan Paik, Heejoon Park
description: Susan Hae Eun Paik, a daughter of Keum Shook Rhei of Hillsdale, N.J., and the late Sung Kee Paik, was married yesterday to Heejoon Park, the son of Ouk Chegal and Doo-Keun Park of Seoul, South Korea. The Rev. Stephen P. Bauman performed the ceremony at Christ Methodist Church in New York.

title: French Accents In the East 60's
description: Each listing in the Good Eating column now includes information supplied by the restaurant about its policy on smoking.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VILLAR, JULIUS (NEE WALKOWIAK)
description: VILLAR-Julius (nee Walkowiak). Businessman, artist and poet. Friend of Roman Polanski, Marek Hlasko, and Wojtek Frikowski in Paris. Climbed Mt. Rainier 1977 (ele. 4322 meters), ''Winter storm blows a flood...I smell summer''.

title: Chile's Ex-Dictator Tries to Dictate His Future Role
description: It was to have been final confirmation that Chile had left behind the days of Gen. Augusto Pinochet, whose brutal 17-year dictatorship ended in 1990 after the deaths of more than 3,000 of his political opponents.

title: Trying to Make Emergency Health Crews Equally Equipped
description: Even as New Jersey moves to expand the use of a device that shocks a faltering heart to restore a normal beat, there is growing pressure to revise its emergency medical care system.

title: Prisoner in His Homeland
description: THE AUTOBIOGRAPHY

title: Fight on Brookhaven Research Reactor Intensifies
description: FOR a nuclear reactor in a nuclear-sensitive region, the High Flux Beam Reactor at the Brookhaven National Laboratory kept a remarkably low profile for more than 30 years.

title: Drivers Find New Service at Truck Stops: Old-Time Religion
description: Like leviathan locusts, the idling engines of a hundred 18-wheelers jittered in the truck stop parking lot as Jay LeRette embarked on his crusade.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOUNG, AUGUSTUS (GUS)
description: YOUNG-Augustus (Gus). Beloved husband of Susanne, adored father of Kenny, Jeff, and Debbie. Unique brother of Murray and Sid and special uncle. Musician, cartoonist and engineer loved by all who knew him. Services Sunday 12:15 PM ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave., NYC.

title: Carry-On Bags
description: To the Editor: I always return home with three carry-ons: a heavy backpack with books and fragile souvenirs that goes under the seat in front of me; a camera bag that stays with me, and a plastic bag of last-minute goodies that goes into the overhead bin. Although storage under the seat can cut into one's legroom, it is the ideal way to keep a heavy bag in the cabin.

title: 'Victory' in Metuchen: The Other Side Speaks
description: To the Editor:

title: Deals and Discounts
description: PARIS AND PROVENCE -- An 11-day package offered by Country Cottages, a Florida company, combines a two-night stay in a Paris hotel with seven nights in a villa in Provence. For each of two people sharing a one-bedroom villa, the price starts at $1,099 and includes air fare from New York, Newark or Boston; accommodations, and a rental car for a week. (The car can be picked up in Paris or in the South of France.) The flights are on British Airways to Paris via London. Departures are from late March to early May; travel on April 1 or later costs $169 a person extra. For each of eight people in a four-bedroom villa, the price starts at $899; for each of four in a two-bedroom, $999. The hotel in Paris is the Holiday Inn St.-Germain on the Rue de Vaugirard, where Continental breakfast, tax and service are included. The type of car depends on the party's size. Information: (800) 674-8883 or (561) 988-4000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLOTKIN, HARRY MORRIS
description: PLOTKIN-Harry Morris. On Friday, January 30, 1998 at his residence. Husband of the late Esther Plotkin; father of Ira Lev Plotkin (Kay); Judith Deborah Wilkenfeld (Jonathan); brother of Melvin Plotkin (Esther); Norman Plotkin (Rosalind) and Lena Gordon. Also survived by his grandchildren, Noah Benjamin Plotkin, Joshua Robert Plotkin, Aria Micha Wilkenfeld (Melissa); Daniela Lisa Wiggins (Marcus) and Gilad Joseph Wilkenfeld. Funeral services will be held Sunday, February 1 at 1:30 P.M., at Adas Israel Congregation, 2850 Quebec Street, N.W., Washington, DC 20008. Interment Judean Memorial Gardens. The family will observe Shiva Sunday through Thursday evenings, 7 P.M. and Monday through Friday mornings, 7:30 A.M., at the home of Harry Plotkin. Contributions may be made to The Charles E. Smith Jewish Day School, City Lights or Jewish Primary Day School at Adas Israel.

title: Lori Leva and Matthew McGowan
description: Dr. Lori Ann Leva and Matthew C. McGowan were married yesterday by the Rev. Anthony J. Randazzo at the Immaculate Conception Chapel at Seton Hall University in South Orange, N.J.

title: Animal on Board
description: He's wild, he's zany, he's a little out of control. And he's going to the Olympics, to the dismay of some snowboarders. Animal -- the maniacal Jim Henson Muppet, who has a shock of raspberry hair, bangs on drums and growls -- is the Olympic mascot for the American snowboarding team, but some who champion the sport are not pleased. ''I don't know why they chose Animal,'' said Jason Gerardi, the managing editor of the magazine Transworld Snowboarding. ''I mean, all he does is bang around and eat a lot of food. That's so typical of the way skiers perceive riders.''

title: Shocked, Shocked That We're Shocked
description: THE SETTING: A few of the bars and bistros favored by the city's expatriate French population, where the choice chatter focuses on the details and detritus of the Presidential sex scandal, the allegations of some sort of sexual relationship and cover-up between President Clinton and Monica Lewinsky, a former White House intern.

title: SPEED SKATING
description: AFTER USING essentially the same equipment for a century, speed skating has gone through a tumultuous change over the past year as a new device called the clap skate hit the World Cup circuit. The clap skate was popularized by the Dutch and is now indispensable for any skater with gold-medal hopes. The skate has a hinged device on the toe and a detachable blade heel that allows for fuller contact with the ice and longer, more powerful strokes. When the heel snaps back into place, it makes a clapping sound. World records have been falling like snow on the World Cup circuit. The Americans, who had difficulty acquiring the skates last season, would have preferred that the clap skates be banned until after the Nagano Games. Now the Americans are concerned that some skaters may show up at the starting line at the Olympics using another mechanical device that no one else has ever seen.

title: Florida Tomato Pickers Take On Growers
description: Jose Rocillo, who first came here from Mexico in 1981 to do farm work and at 67 still picks tomatoes, can look around this town of migrant workers these days and say that things are better. The streets are cleaner, he says, and there is less crime.

title: A Few Favorite Things the Musical Left Out
description: JOHANNES VON TRAPP OFFERED SOME perspective.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We spout off all these high ideals and goals of journalism. And then you get a story where the principal characters are of questionable character, and the details have a salacious aspect, and the whole blasted thing is based on anonymous sources. That combination is troubling.''

title: Romania to Unload Its Ceausescu Bric-a-Brac
description: Romania is planning a yard sale. Up for grabs are busts of Nicolae and Elena Ceausescu, the Communist dictator and his wife, who ran the country for more than three decades; fine porcelain and cheap crockery, handbags and briefcases.

title: A Chance to Deflate Debt, And the Local Drugstore
description: THE next time New Yorkers visit a neighborhood drugstore, they should take a close look around. If Duane Reade has its way, the place may soon be out of business.

title: Word & Image; 11 O'Clock Dreams And Realities
description: I was scripting my ideal 11 o'clock television newscast when I was rudely interrupted by this Magazine.

title: The Neediest Cases; Family Out From Under The Threat of Eviction
description: ''What's an eviction notice?'' 9-year-old Jermaine asked, a mix of curiosity and fear in his voice.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Head in the Clouds
description: Built from concrete quotidian events, the 11 tightly controlled stories in Richard Burgin's third collection, FEAR OF BLUE SKIES (Johns Hopkins University, $19.95), present characters of such variety that no generalizations about them can apply. Burgin is at home depicting bankers, writers, surfers, elevator operators and prostitutes alike. His motto might be ''Nothing is foreign to me,'' since his fiction seems to subscribe to a claim that is made by one of his narrators: ''You have to take people's feelings seriously or else you're a kind of emotional murderer.'' In the book's title story, the 22-year-old son of an aloof mother and an alcoholic father repeatedly dreams of floating weightlessly and transparently into the sky -- until a prostitute, who argues with him and steals his money, provides a ''durable memory'' with which to combat his sense of detachment. ''My Black Rachmaninoff'' deals with a divorced woman who mistakenly imagines that her building's handsome elevator man is the pianist she hears through her walls -- and who discovers, after she has managed to seduce him, new levels of self-delusion and shame. ''Bodysurfing'' tracks a banker's feelings of personal and professional failure, fueled by America's addiction to hype and money. The devastating conclusion, at once inexorable and surprising, is reminiscent though not derivative of Flannery O'Connor. Only the final story, ''My Sister's House,'' which concerns a lesbian whose brother learns she was sexually molested by their father, skirts predictability. Throughout this arresting volume, Burgin is sensitive to the infinite brands of human error (one story is actually called ''Mistakes'') as well as to our rare redemptive moments of resilience and understanding. Gardner McFall

title: Looking for an 11 O'Clock Fix
description: We have our own strategy for dealing with nightly news on TV: three murders, rapes or fires in any combination and we switch it off. Works for us.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: FLUSHING

title: The Culinary Imperative
description: Some workers may live the life of three-martini lunches; others have little time for even a snack while toiling at their desks. What dining experiences reign at your workplace? And what odd delectables do you or your colleagues bring in? Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Southern Comfort
description: ALIENS OF AFFECTION

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOHN, SAMUEL
description: SOHN-Samuel. Died at age 97-1/2. Loving father of Mildred and Ellis Greene and Lenore Sohn. Grandfather of Mark, Ellen, Teri and Robin. Great-grandfather of Brian, Jeremy, Rachel, Alexis, Joshua, Evan and Bryan. He is now with his beloved wife, Mary, and son, Sandy.

title: Andrea Crane, Sam Hoffman
description: Andrea Gail Crane and Sam Hoffman were married last evening in the Palm House at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. Rabbi Shira Stern performed the ceremony.

title: Children's Books; Bookshelf
description: OUT OF THE DUST. By Karen Hesse. Scholastic. $15.95. (Ages 11 to 13) The setting of the 1998 Newbery Medal book, a novel in free-verse form, is Oklahoma during the Depression. In titled and dated poems, Billie Jo describes the rigors of farm life, the accident that kills her mother and maims her own hands, and the year of struggle, grief and anger that follows.

title: Coastal Webmaster
description: URBAN LeJEUNE has loved Atlantic City since he was 6, although that's not why he created the ''I Love Atlantic City'' World Wide Web site (http:// www.IloveAC.com), which he says is among the busiest sites in the state.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELLER, EDITH
description: HELLER-Edith. On January 28. At the age of 89. Beloved wife of the late Joseph I. Heller, beloved mother of Marion and Joe La Russo, and Buck and Caroline Heller, loving sister of Mildred Rich, devoted grandmother of Daniel, Katie, Betty, Josh, and Tova, cherished great-grandmother of Rachel, Adam, Katrina, Tristan, and Sequoia. Graveside service Sunday, at 11:15 A.M., at the Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, New York.

title: Before Baseball Broke the Color Barrier
description: THERE was a time around 1940, Cornelius Harper recalls, when he had the uniforms of seven baseball teams hanging in the closet of his Stamford home. He wore all seven that season for teams that had one thing in common: they were all black. It was an era when baseball in the United States was strictly segregated.

title: BOBSLED
description: OLYMPIC bobsledding is about as harrowing as skydiving before the parachute opens or gunning an unlimited hydroplane at 125 miles an hour when an unexpected wave turns up.

title: Liberties; Dear Clarence
description: Dear Justice Thomas:

title: FIGURE SKATING
description: WHILE MANY feared for the future after the breakup of the Soviet Union, figure skaters from the former Soviet republics have won seven of eight possible gold medals in the past two Winter Games. Kristi Yamaguchi was the only skater to break the stranglehold with a victory at the 1992 Winter Olympics in Albertville, France. Michelle Kwan is heavily favored to win the women's competition in Nagano, but Russian skaters will challenge for the men's gold medal and should continue their dominance of pairs skating and ice dancing.

title: Black and White Revisited; Letters on 'Little Things' Revealed Insensitivity
description: To the Editor:

title: Q&A;/Chris Russo; Mad Dog of Talk Radio, Sports Variety
description: THIS country's growing fascination with the world of athletics is perhaps best evidenced by the proliferation of sports talk shows on the radio. None is more popular than ''Mike & the Mad Dog'' on WFAN in New York. Mike Francesa and Chris Russo are the hosts, and more than 600,000 people tune in on an average week to share their opinions on weekdays from 1 to 6 P.M. (and on Saturday morning for Mr. Russo's own show). In the desirable demographic of 25- to 54-year-old men, Mr. Francesa and Mr. Russo are No. 1 in New York.

title: Raising Florida's Musical Pulse
description: UNTIL 10 YEARS AGO, THE classical-music scene in South Florida -- more precisely, the roughly 80-mile coastal stretch from Miami north to West Palm Beach -- was considered a wasteland. Never mind the presence of two opera companies and any number of regional orchestras, and a steady stream of warmth-seeking guest soloists and ensembles each winter. The persistent image was of determined provincialism.

title: Correction
description: A report and a picture caption in the Guide column on Jan. 18 about a Stratford Library film series misspelled the surname of the brothers who wrote, produced and directed the films. They are Joel and Ethan Coen, not Cohen.

title: Waiting to See If This Is the Spring; For Yanks' Ledee, The Majors Beckon And a Death Haunts
description: The memories of his father's sudden death are absent because Ricky Ledee did not witness the fatal accident on a dark highway near Manati. He did not witness Tonito Ledee's car drifting into the oncoming lane after he fell asleep following another singing performance, did not see it rumbling down a hill and smashing into a truck. The collision destroyed the car and killed Ledee instantly. He was 35 years old.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DONOFRIO, MICHAEL T.
description: DONOFRIO-Michael T. Dear Dad, you are always with us. Missing you and loving you never stops. Love, Mom, Michael, Bob and Gay

title: Playing for Love, Money and a Bigger Vocabulary
description: THOUGH the Official Tournament and Club World List for Scrabble players includes more than 120,000 root words, sometimes it seems as if that's not enough to satisfy all the Scrabble players in New Jersey. If there's an empty board somewhere, someone is trying to fill it up.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSHON, DOROTHY H.
description: HIRSHON-Dorothy H. Died suddenly Thursday, Jan 29, 1998 at the age of 89, following an automobile accident. She is survived by her son Jeffrey Paley and his wife Valerie; her daughter Hilary Paley Califano and her husband Joseph Califano; and her step-daughter Joy Briggs, all of New York City. She is also survived by seven grandchildren and three great grandchildren. Scattering of the Ashes Ceremony will be private. A Memorial Gathering will be held at the Tishman Auditorium, The New School, 66 West 12th Street, NYC, March 5 at 11:30 A.M. In lieu of flowers contributiions in her memory may be made to the New School or to Phoenix House.

title: Cold Weather Brings Plumbing Emergencies
description: PLUMBING problems can occur at any time of the year, but they are more likely to develop in winter because the water in pipes can freeze, expand and crack the surrounding pipe. The easiest way to keep this from happening is by making sure that the pipes stay warm enough so the water never hits the freezing point.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHILLER, SAUL
description: SCHILLER-Saul. Loving husband of the late Ruth, beloved father of Julian, Victoria Goldberg and Douglas. Dear brother of Sara Mosen, Tillie, Carl and Morty. Grandfather of Alison, Lauren, Michael, Gabriel, Nathan, Miriam and Rachel. Services at ''Boulevard-Riverside'' Chapels, 312 Coney Island Avenue (at Prospect Park) Brooklyn, today at 10 AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHOENFELD, ALEX
description: SCHOENFELD - Alex. Beloved husband of Clara Olin Schoenfeld. Devoted father of Michael and Leonard and their wives Claudia and Joanne. Beloved step-father of Janet Olin and the late David Olin. Beloved grandpa of Jennifer and Jonathan. His warmth and humanity will be missed. Services Sunday, February 1, 1 PM, Gutterman's, Rockville Centre.

title: A Chef Serious Indeed About Food
description: ''YOU need to smash the garlic before you chop it, to release the garlic flavor.'' WHAM. Whack-a-whack-a-whack-a-whack. It was the chef talking and smashing and chopping.

title: Health Coverage for Children
description: Gov. George Pataki made a promise in his State of the State address to provide health coverage to every uninsured child in a low-income family in the state. A generous new Federal program will enable him to do just that and more without spending additional state or local money. Yet oddly, Mr. Pataki seems reluctant to take full advantage of the Federal money. Under the $48 billion, 10-year program created by Congress last year to pay for health care for uninsured children, New York will be getting roughly $255 million a year for the next decade, with future adjustments depending on population changes.

title: SKIING
description: THE SETUP -- The technical events are the slalom and giant slalom. The speed events are the Super G and downhill. The slalom and giant slalom are contested over two runs in which skiers negotiate a series of gates, different for each run and set by a coach from one of the competing nations.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about the White House press secretary, Michael D. McCurry, referred incorrectly to one of his previous employers, Senator Bob Kerrey, in some editions. Mr. Kerrey, a Nebraska Democrat, is still in office.

title: INSIDE
description: CUNY Toughens Admissions

title: Laurel Hollow Needs Its Police Force
description: ''Laurel Hollow Weighs Abolishing Its Police'' [Jan. 18]makes no reference to the vast body of criminal justice research findings concerning the issue of the fragmentation of police responsibility. Such research suggests that small police agencies, as in Laurel Hollow, may be a good idea after all.

title: Care at 2 Veterans Hospitals Is Criticized
description: At the end of World War II, Harold Niver, a lanky, jut-jawed country boy, received a commendation signed by President Harry S. Truman extending ''the heartfelt thanks of a grateful nation'' for his Army service.

title: Turn Around and You're 60
description: WHEN I turned 60 last month, I decided to keep it quiet, not even to tell my mother. She worries so. I might have dumped it on the kids, but they were coming up against numbers that daunted them, 27 and 30.

title: SKI JUMPING
description: JUST AS cross-country skiing was one of the defining sports in Nordic- loving Norway in 1994, ski jumping will be one of the defining sports in Nagano. Japan's finest Winter Olympic moment came in this sport, and it came the last time the Japan played host to the Games. In Sapporo in 1972, Yukio Kasaya, Akitsugu Konno and Seiji Aochi won gold, silver and bronze on the normal hill, which was then known as the 70-meter hill. If all goes well for the Japanese in Nagano, it just might happen again.

title: Rough Navigating Around Bridgeport's Sunken Barges
description: THE Port Authority of Bridgeport Harbor has a billion-dollar redevelopment project on the drawing board. Hotels, office buildings, museums, cruise ships, high-speed ferry boats and more are in the plans. But the Port Authority and the city's harbor master, Joseph Savino, are occupied with a nagging bit of the past: three barges lie on the harbor bottom, at the mouth of the Pequonnock River, and the National Register of Historic Places must be navigated before they can be removed.

title: The New-Fashioned Palace Hotel in Madrid
description: The Palace Hotel in Madrid, across the street from the Prado Museum and with a roster of clients that includes Ernest Hemingway, Mata Hari, Marlon Brando and Rita Hayworth, not to mention Dali and Stravinsky, has completed the most extensive renovation in its 85-year history.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIED, ALICE
description: FRIED-Alice. On January 29, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Georg. Loving mother of Robert. Dear sister of Nelly, Edward and Edith. Adoring grandmother of Paul, Steven and Dennis. Great-grandmother of Carolanne, Ellen and Kelsey. Service Sunday, February 1st, 12:30 PM at ''the Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Time Limit And Lil's Lad On Target
description: They ran in different races today but they had the same target, three months away: the Kentucky Derby. And Time Limit, who won the Hutcheson Stakes at Gulfstream Park by a neck, and Lil's Lad, who zipped through an allowance race preceding the stakes by six lengths, did nothing to dispel the notion that they are two of the most promising candidates.

title: Shifting Ground Complicates the President's Policy Challenges in Congress
description: After a tumultuous week with the White House besieged by scandal, Congress has been left with one major question this election year: President Clinton looks as though he will survive, but how well can he govern?

title: Dives No Longer, New Gay Bars Let In the Light
description: ALMOST every gay man, it seems, has a story about the first time he opened a door and stepped across one of his life's major thresholds -- into a gay bar.

title: New Jersey Licensing Inspectors
description: FEW homeowners would feel comfortable hiring an unlicensed plumber, electrician, architect or engineer for services or advice related to their homes. And few home buyers would feel comfortable purchasing a house without first having its major components -- plumbing, heating, electrical, structural and mechanical systems -- inspected by an expert.

title: Worsening Financial Flu in Asia Lowers Immunity to U.S. Business
description: Picture Mom, Dad and the kids in an upper-middle-class Asian family in 10 years' time:

title: Country Squires
description: In the second half of the 19th century, American industrialists and financiers decided to model their life styles on the English aristocracy, William A. Schleicher and Susan J. Winter say in their introduction to ''In the Somerset Hills: The Landed Gentry.'' That meant owning a city home and a country estate. For many of these figures, New York was the city, and the Somerset Hills was the country. Along came the likes of John Dryden, founder of the Prudential Insurance Company, and Grant Schley (whose great-grandniece is Christine Todd Whitman), among others. Their huge estates, inside and out, and their pastimes -- most seem to have involved horses -- may be seen in the 128 pages of photographs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHERNOV, MAURICE
description: CHERNOV-Maurice, 97. Of Aventura, FL passed away January 30, 1998. Beloved father of Arthur (Cheyenne) Chernov and Seymour (Marilyn) Chernov, grandchildren Jeffrey, Randi and David, great grandchildren Max and Zoe. Memorial service Sunday, February 1, 11:30 am at Eternal Light. Graveside Service 10AM Monday at Beth David Cemetery, NY.

title: Just Say Maybe; No Sexology, Please. We're Americans
description: FIFTY years ago last month, the publication of Alfred C. Kinsey's ''Sexual Behavior in the Human Male'' had Americans agog over sex as never before. The name Kinsey was everywhere -- in newspapers, magazines and on the radio, ultimately turning into risque code in places as varied as nightclub acts and New Yorker cartoons.

title: Tonya: The Long and Potholed Road
description: On Thursday, Tonya Harding will skate with Olympic champions like Katarina Witt and Oksana Baiul in a taped special on the Fox network. She'll also face her old foe Nancy Kerrigan in an interview that's designed to make the network's February sweeps period take off like a tabloid rocket. As second acts go, this one's pretty wan, but Harding deserves points for perseverance. After pleading guilty in March 1994 to hindering the investigation of the Kerrigan attack, she settled on a comeback strategy that has been both aggressive and unclear. ''She's hired and fired more agents, lawyers, professionals, coaches and choreographers than you can shake a stick at,'' says her former agent David Hans Schmidt. Things haven't always happened for Harding, but they certainly have happened. Here's a look back.

title: Looking for an 11 O'Clock Fix
description: Michael Winerip's article ''Looking for an 11 O'Clock Fix'' (Jan. 11) is right on the money. As a former radio program director and general manager in the 1960's and 70's, I can attest to the difficulty of walking the fine line between the public obsession with sensationalism and the attempts of the news professionals to bring significant stories to the viewer -- and achieve high ratings and income at the same time.

title: Scenic Days And Nights Off Norway
description: ON shore, the Midsummer's Eve bonfires twinkle dimly in the sunshine as we sail out of Bergen. Jet-lagged, we seek out our cabin and go to bed long before dark. It is about 11 P.M., and by the time our ship makes port in Floro -- the first of several dozen stops on this 2,500-mile voyage along the western coast of Norway -- we are sound asleep, missing one of the few chances that we are going to have to watch the sun set.

title: When Going the Club Route Goes Awry
description: DURING her first meeting with the High Peaks Investment Club in Boulder, Colo., a year ago, Lynda Bryson had a sinking feeling. When other members introduced themselves and explained why they had joined, she recalled, ''virtually everyone gave the same reason: to get very, very rich.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENZWEIG, PHYLLIS
description: ROSENZWEIG-Phyllis. Devoted wife of the late Hyman. Loving mother of Raymond and Mark. Beloved mother-in-law of Michaelanne and Susan. Cherished grandmother of Joshua, Elizabeth, Emily and Naomi. Services Sunday 1:30PM, at Riverside Chapel, 21 W. Broad St., Mt. Vernon, New York.

title: The Male Rock Anthem: Going All to Pieces
description: ANYONE WHO HAS STOOD ON A sticky sports-arena floor, watching flash pots explode as a band plays, will recognize the universal cue for a rock concert's emotional peak. The guitarist begins a pensive cadence as the lights dim. Before the singer intones the words everyone anticipates, tiny flames burst forth, one by one, from the upheld hands of fans. The song fills the room. Flickers merge into a sea of light.

title: Waiting to See If This Is the Spring; Home in Elizabeth, Al Hawkins Gets Set For the Next Rung
description: The ball that dropped into Al Hawkins's hand when he was 4 years old has never let him go. As long as there was a ball to grip, he felt good, safe, in control. The size and shape of the ball never mattered; so long as he could throw the ball and get it back, every season belonged to him. At Elizabeth High School, he was all-state as a quarterback, a guard and a pitcher.

title: Carry-On Bags
description: To the Editor: The luggage bins' latches are very weak. What they need are bracelet-type double locks, one that overlaps the under latch.

title: An Expressive Voice of Poetic Experience Helps Students Find Their Own
description: ''Take a deep breath in this presence of love,'' Gayle Danley told a roomful of sixth graders who had just been asked to close their eyes and picture the person they love most in the world. ''Imagine he is next to you, and you want to grab him in your arms, you love him so much.''

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: A Prima Donna's Progress

title: A Deer Hunt Is Fatal For One of the Hunters
description: A Lower Alloways Creek man was killed by a fellow deer hunter last week in what authorities say was New Jersey's first human death in a hunting accident in two years. Albert Kohlenberg, 45, was moving through a wooded area of the township on Jan. 24, making noise to drive deer into a clearing where three friends were waiting to shoot, and was struck in the head by a buckshot pellet, said Captain Edward Markowski of the State Division of Fish, Game and Wildlife's Bureau of Law Enforcement.

title: Passport Fees Due to Fall to $60
description: Most passport fees are scheduled to drop today. The plan, due to be formalized day before yesterday, calls for a new 10-year passport to cost $60 instead of $65. At the age of 16, an applicant will be considered an adult and will receive a 10-year passport. Those 15 and younger will continue to get five-year passports, for $40. Renewing a 10-year passport will cost $40 instead of $55.

title: Before Going Shopping, Giants Need Some Room
description: There are estimates now that the National Football League salary cap -- bloated by revenue from the league's new television contract -- will be as high as $53 million, a jump of almost $12 million from last year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, RABBI JULIUS
description: GOLDBERG-Rabbi Julius. The Plainview Jewish Center deeply mourns the loss of its Rabbi Emeritus, who served the congregation faithfully for four decades. As senior rabbi, he built a small new synagogue, Plainview's first, into a large, vibrant institution. His wisdom, vision, courage and activism were crucial in establishing Jewish life in Plainview on a firm foundation. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to the bereaved family: Bette, his wife and our Rebbetzin; Rabbi Mordechai (Jill), Dr. Harry (Maureen) and Rachel, his children; Chana, Yitzchak, Ephraim, Ruchama, Joshua, and Benjamin; his grandchildren; his brothers, Dr. David and Sam and his sister, Etta, and their families. Services at Plainview Jewish Center, 95 Floral Drive, Plainview, LI, on Monday, February 2, at 12 noon. Rabbi Moses A. Birnbaum Cantor Morris Wolk Jeffrey Rosen, President

title: Carry-On Bags
description: To the Editor: Your article on carry-on luggage (''Crackdown on Carry-Ons,'' Dec. 21) reminds me of our November trip on Continental from Newark to West Palm Beach, Fla., and back. In phoning the travel agent a day before departure, we were told that one carry-on plus one purse were permitted.

title: A Sailor's Journal; Tension and Changes Before Restart of Race
description: The nine boats in the Whitbread Round the World Race end a three-week layover in New Zealand on Sunday when the 31,600-nautical-mile odyssey restarts for the fifth and longest of nine legs, 6,670 nautical miles from Auckland around Cape Horn to Brazil. Currently, EF Language is first over all, with Merit Cup second. Katie Pettibone, an American on the all-women's crew of EF Education of Sweden, which stands eighth, will continue to file updates until the race's scheduled return to Southampton, England, in May. This is her 14th report.

title: BEST SELLERS: February 1, 1998
description: Weeks

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOLONEY, ELIZABETH J.
description: MOLONEY-Elizabeth J. Formerly of Burns Street, Forest Hills, NY. Passed away on Friday, January 30, 1998 at Sun Rest Nursing Home in Port Jefferson. She was the daughter of the late Dr. James J. Moloney and Dorothy Welker Moloney of Forest Hills. Beloved sister of the late Dorothy A. Moloney of Forest Hills and Mary J. Moloney of Suffern, NY. She is survived by cousins Sister Mary Lanning of Manhattan and Patti Moloney Riordan of West Islip, NY. Cherished ''Aunt Liz'' of Patrick Riordan, John and Tricia, Kelly and Patrick (P.J.). Remembered lovingly by friends in Brooklyn, Forest Hills, West Islip and Port Jefferson. Generous alumna of St. Joseph's College, Brooklyn. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at Our Lady Queen of Martyrs RC Church, Forest Hills, at 10:30 AM on Monday, February 2, 1998. Family will receive visitors at Fox Funeral Home, Ascan Ave. and Metropolitan Ave. in Forest Hills Monday, 8:30-10 AM. Interment St. John's Cemetery, Middle Village.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Radio Voices

title: Q&A/Robert W. Elliott; Reaching Beyond One's Own Bailiwick
description: MAYOR Robert W. Elliott of Croton-on-Hudson is a person who gets involved in big ways with many organizations. He is the president of the New York State Conference of Mayors, chairman of the Tri-County Association, which links Westchester, Nassau and Suffolk Counties, and president of the Westchester Municipal Officials Association.

title: U.S. Agencies at Odds on Fire I. Erosion Plan
description: SHAKING his head in disbelief, Fire Island National Seashore Superintendent Constantine Dillon pored over several maps set out on tables at a recent public meeting held by the Army Corps of Engineers. The maps and accompanying posters of Fire Island depicted the erosion that has taken place over the years and proposed alternatives for a project that would rebuild the dunes and beach.

title: Like the Beer, the Brewery's Sideshow Is for Adults Only
description: The Brooklyn Brewery is known around Williamsburg for some things other than its beer, like its free tours on Saturdays and its occasional block parties.

title: Stanislavsky's Successors Still Seek Truth From the Master
description: OLEG EFREMOV, the revered artistic director of the famous Moscow Art Theater, is 70 years old. He has seen a lot of Chekhov in his day. And he is opinionated about all of it. In fact, he thinks that productions of the playwright's masterpieces in his native country have become so predictable, such crowd-pleasers, that it is impossible to feel the author's original intentions anymore.

title: Corrections
description: The What's Doing column on Jan. 4, about Nagano, referred incorrectly to the members of Kodo, a troupe of traditional Japanese drummers. They are adults, not children.

title: Rachel Kirsner, Steven Schneider
description: Rachel Erica Kirsner, a lawyer, and Steven Kalman Schneider, a computer systems specialist, are to be married today by Rabbi Avi Weiss at the Crystal Plaza in Livingston, N.J.

title: Defending the Middle Class
description: PLEASURE WARS The Bourgeois Experience: Victoria to Freud. Volume 5. By Peter Gay. Illustrated. 324 pp. New York:

title: Second-Guessing The Economic Doctor
description: ALL over Southeast Asia, people are complaining that a cabal of heartless bureaucrats at an institution many have come to loathe -- the International Monetary Fund -- is worsening their economic misery. Here in Washington, the I.M.F. isn't a lot more popular, but for very different reasons.

title: The Private Faces Behind Public Masks
description: AS the official photographer for Madison Square Garden for more than 30 years George Kalinsky has made a considerable mark on sports and entertainment photography. His pictures of Muhammad Ali, the Knicks, Frank Sinatra, Luciano Pavarotti and Judy Garland are legendary in the field of candid action photography.

title: The Doctor Behind CPR
description: Available since the mid-80's, automated external defibrillators are one of the more recent additions to the nation's first-aid kit. Thirty years ago, the latest thing was CPR, which also took years to become commonplace. One of the people who helped turn cardiopulmonary resuscitation from a virtual medical secret to a widely practiced technique was Dr. Klaus Schulz of Monmouth County

title: Photographs Capture Slices of New York City
description: David Vestal: Photographs

title: Fidelity Gears Up to Take On the World
description: ARMED with relatively good overall performance figures for the first time in years, Fidelity Investments is gearing up to push sales of its international retail funds, a group that has long been a backwater at the company.

title: Several More Recipes For Consulting Success
description: To the Editor:

title: PRESIDENT'S CRISIS GIVING DEMOCRATS A SURPRISING LIFT
description: Democrats who only days ago feared that the White House sex scandal would cripple their candidates in a midterm election year now say that, to their amazement, the crisis may be galvanizing party loyalists and bolstering efforts to raise money.

title: Garlands and Art (Is That a Bear?)
description: Two exhibitions open, and a restaurant plans to.

title: LONG ISLAND OPINION; Digging for Clams and Finding Life
description: ONCE a month at the time of the full moon, there occurs a phenomena called spring tides. These tides have nothing to do with the season but rather with the phase of the moon. When the moon is full, the gravitational pull of the sun and the moon exert their most powerful forces upon the Earth. The tides are higher when they rise, and lower when they ebb. For a forager, like myself, this means getting farther out onto the mud flats where the hard-shell clams have burrowed deep for the winter.

title: GOLF; Player Overcame Adversity, With Help of a Cart
description: Charles Owens, whose left leg is as stiff as a tent stake and whose right knee is made from spare parts, might not be able to feel the pain of his fellow professional golfer Casey Martin, but he can understand it better than most.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZEILER, MAX
description: ZEILER-Max. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Max Zeiler, associated with The Times from 1963, until retiring in 1976.

title: Nets 3-0 on Trip West
description: The Nets, beginning a five-game Western trip with their third victory in a row tonight, tied last season's victory total in just their 45th game.

title: Looking for an 11 O'Clock Fix
description: I've witnessed the virtual collapse of local news values from the other side of the tube -- as a local news anchor and reporter for 20 years. Don't blame the viewers. They have little choice what to watch, only whether to watch.

title: Of Fairies, Free Spirits and Outright Frauds
description: ONCE UPON A TIME, IN 1917 TO be exact, two little English girls named Elsie Wright and Frances Griffiths used to play in the woods of Cottingley in the far-off region of Yorkshire. The fairy people who dwelt in these woods befriended the girls, so one day Elsie and Frances borrowed a camera and took pictures of their friends. Lo and behold, the little people were not even camera-shy, so the two girls, 10 and 16 years old, produced the first actual photographs ever taken of fairies. Needless to say, this created a sensation.

title: Ice Rink Operating In Brewster
description: BREWSTER

title: Maturing, but Still Rebels of the Avant-Garde
description: WHICH of these pieces is likely to be found on a program of string quartets: (a) ''Tragedy at the Opera,'' (b) ''Totem Ancestor'' or (c) ''Using the Apostate Tyrant as His Tool''?

title: On Broadway and Off: What, Where, When
description: Here is a selective guide to coming theatrical events in New York City, annotated by Rick Lyman, who writes the On Stage and Off column that appears on Fridays in the Weekend section. Productions are listed in order of first performance dates. Unless otherwise indicated, the telephone numbers have a 212 area code.

title: The 2d Battle of Vinegar Hill
description: Once an enclave for Irish immigrants, Vinegar Hill is named for a battle site in Ireland. That seems appropriate, given that during the last five months, this tiny, cobblestoned waterfront district between the Manhattan Bridge and the old Brooklyn Navy Yard has been shaken by a battle of its own.

title: Nuclear Insurance
description: America's efforts to help Russia safeguard and shrink its sprawling, decaying nuclear empire need to be sharply accelerated. The possibility that some of Russia's more than 10,000 nuclear weapons or some of its plutonium and heavily enriched uranium could be diverted to a rogue state or terrorist group is not far-fetched. Nor is the risk that some of Russia's unpaid weapons scientists could be lured by foreign countries or criminal groups.

title: January 25-31; Compaq Gets a Boost; I.B.M. Gets a Clone
description: Fifteen years ago, Compaq Computers introduced the first ''clone'' of I.B.M.'s personal computer. It worked well and Compaq grew -- so much that last week Compaq decided it could create a clone of I.B.M. itself. In the largest acquisition in high-tech history, Compaq, with its strength in small computers, agreed to buy Digital Equipment Corporation, which specializes in much bigger ones, for $9.8 billion. Digital no longer has the edge it had when it was the nation's second biggest computer maker. But it does have a sales force and network of technicians practiced in the ways of servicing big companies. So now that Compaq has chosen to take on I.B.M., selling a line of computers from the smallest laptops to the biggest mainframes, it may want to clone Big Blue's suave salesmanship as well. SAUL HANSELL

title: Leisurely Walk
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Mall Spa: Haven for Just-Too-Tired Shoppers
description: EXECUTIVES of Saks Fifth Avenue take note. Disposable bathing suits are now available in a retail establishment across the corridor from your outlet store at the Source mall in Westbury. Of course, there is also a Water Journey, in which the suits can be worn. Some people, however, choose to go au naturel, which may be the first time that nudity is allowed, even encouraged, in a shopping mall.

title: Word for Word/Teen-Age Treatment Programs; Sorry to Wake You, Honey. They're Coming to Take You Away.
description: PARENTS are acutely aware of the perils faced by children traversing the rough patch between childhood and adulthood. For the most exasperated parents of rebellious or troubled teen-agers, an increasingly popular last resort is to ship off their charges to behavior-modification programs that can make Toughlove look like Puppylove.

description: UNLIKE most rural areas of Fairfield County, North Stamford has the best of two worlds: deep country with a vibrant city just a short drive away.

More often than not, therein lie the journalistic Everglades, gnarly swamps of impenetrable claims and counterclaims, crawling with snapping alligators.

Towering green cornstalks covered the gently rolling hills. Tractors slowed down the few cars that traveled along narrow country lanes.

NEWMAN moved through the crowded halls of Beth Israel Medical Center at 16th Street and First Avenue last Tuesday morning, shaking hands and slapping backs like a politician. He wanted to see how his staff was adjusting to Beth Israel's recent partnership with St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center.

Rebeccas, at a Glenville site once inhabited by Morgans, is new, but is the work of an experienced husband-and-wife culinary team, Reza Khorshidi and Rebecca Kirhoffer.

Beloved aunt of Ellen, Steven and Leslie Epstein and Jennifer, Eric, Brian, Rhoda, Susan, Stephen, David and Jeffrey. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the National Council of Jewish Women, NY Chapter.

description: IN 1992, American Cyanamid began cleaning up its heavily polluted 565-acre site in the Somerset County Township of Bridgewater under orders issued earlier by the Federal Government.

description: IT was Round 3 in the fight for apparel tax repeal as all of the state's 62 counties and 21 cities -- oops, make that all but 1 of the state's cities -- waived the levy on clothing and shoes selling for under $500 late last month. White Plains, the fashion capital of Westchester, was the sole holdout, disappointing shoppers and infuriating merchants who lost business.

title: Wearing C, for Canada
description: Do dog owners really choose pets to reflect their own appearance and personality? This might be the case with Eric Lindros, the captain of both the Philadelphia Flyers of the National Hockey League and Team Canada in the Winter Olympics.

title: Looking for an 11 O'Clock Fix
description: The ultimate joke will be on the news directors. After chasing stories of fluff and celebrity, management will find it can save millions of dollars by firing the hard-news crews and rerunning ''Entertainment Tonight'' at 11 P.M., adding a couple of windows for sports scores and the weather.

title: The View From/White Plains; Marking the 25th Year of Roe v. Wade And Still Looking for Middle Ground
description: IT is an issue that seems to know no middle ground. Those who oppose abortion oppose it vehemently; those who are in favor of keeping it legal are equally passionate. On a recent night at the Y.W.C.A. here, it was the people who support a woman's right to have an abortion whose voices were heard loud and clear, as several hundred people gathered to mark the 25th anniversary of Roe v. Wade, the landmark Supreme Court case that legalized abortion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEILER, GEORGE A.
description: WEILER-George A., 83. Of New York City and Garrison, NY on January 25. Beloved husband of Barbara Carroll, devoted father of Jane and John Weiler and Ellen Stiefler, loving grandfather of Zachary, Timothy and Robert Stiefler, Daniel and Joshua SchneiderWeiler and Margaret Weiler; dear brother of Edith Wald: born Deal NJ; graduate of Yale College, 1935, and Fordham Law School, 1941. He was a Deputy Assistant Corporation Counsel of the NYC Law Department, retiring 1987 after 37 years service as a trial defense counsel; a veteran of World War II; defense counsel in 1945 Japanese War Crimes Trials; in charge of procurement 1951 - 52 during Korean conflict in the Armed Forces Security Agency and the National Security Agency. Retired Lt. Colonel Army Signal Corps. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Parkinson Disease Fndn., Wm. Black Med. Rsrch Bldg, 650 West 168th St., New York, N.Y. 10032. Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th and Amsterdam, February 20, 1:30 P.M. Private burial in Arlington National Cemetery.

description: Weeks

title: Building a Better Snowman Through Science

title: A Hip-Hop Poet Looks Beyond Her Roots
description: IN ''10 MEN,'' THE POET TRACIE MORRIS chronicled a young woman's sexual conquests. ''Project Princess'' was a paean to the b-girls she grew up with in East New York. ''So What'' was her rebuttal to a song by Me'Shell Ndege'Ocello about seducing another woman's man. (''By all means, teach the boy some things, so when he's ready I'll have a man.'')

title: Gas Drops Below $1 At Some State Pumps
description: Gasoline prices in New Jersey have dipped below the $1 mark at some non-brand-name service stations, particularly in southern New Jersey. The low rates may stay there for another month before they begin creeping up again, industry analysts say.

title: It's a Long Way From Stem to Stern
description: WHEN the first Disney cruise ship sets sail this spring, with Maestro Mickey Mouse conducting from atop the bow of the Disney Magic, the ship's horn will give out with ''When You Wish Upon a Star.'' Already, though, as the 1998 cruise season gets under way, the song's solemn assurance that ''anything your heart desires will come to you'' could almost serve as the industry anthem.

title: Habitats/130 Barrow Street; From Cars to Condos: A Tale of the West Village
description: MITCHELL JACKSON looked from his penthouse at 130 Barrow Street in the West Village last month toward a new building going up on West 10th Street a block to the north.

title: An Island in Time Weighs Its Growth
description: AT its core, Staten Island is a vast deposit of green rock, called serpentinite, that coalesced from oceanic crust when the great tectonic plates bearing what would eventually become North America and Africa collided about 400 million years ago.

title: Doing the Right Thing By Black Experience
description: IN 1926, Carter G. Woodson, a historian, convinced members of the Association for the Study of Negro Life and History, which he founded, to declare the second week in February, ''Negro History Week.''

title: Where Golfing and Home Ownership Meet
description: ''THE demand from baby boomers in the work force, at the height of their earning powers, is tremendous,'' said Marc C. Bergschneider, chairman of Hudson National Golf Club in Croton-on-Hudson and president of National Fairways, a developer of 15 golf courses from Florida to New England.

title: Buds, at the Mercy of Warmth in the Winter
description: AN unusual weather pattern creates problems for the plant world. Witness the premature flowering of cherry trees in Washington, D.C. In case readers have not realized it, that famous springtime display is pretty much over for this year, many of the trees having already bloomed. Only those cherry trees that failed to be fooled by the false spring will come out on schedule.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUFF, EGIE
description: HUFF-Egie, the wife of Robert W. Huff, died at home on Thursday, Jan. 29, 1998 of ovarian cancer. She was 76 years old. Through her diverse roles and activities (volunteerism, community member, wife and mother), Mrs. Huff has touched the lives of many and has pioneered the way for women in numerous arenas. Mrs. Huff was a dedicated volunteer with the American Cancer Society (ACS) at the local, state and national levels. She was a member of the National Board of ACS from 1969 to 1980, and was elected an Honorary Life Member in 1980. She served as Vice President for three terms, and was a member of the ACS delegation to the People's Republic of China in 1977 at the invitation of the Chinese Medical Society. Mrs. Huff was honored in 1993 by the ACS Georgia Division when the main lobby of the Division headquarters was named the Egie Huff Center. In addition to her work with the ACS, Mrs. Huff was active in the YMCA. She was the first woman to be elected President of the National Council of the YMCA of the USA, bringing about considerable comment from the media. She was also the first woman to serve as President of the local YMCA, the first woman to be elected President of the Southeast Region YMCA Board, a member of the YMCA National Board, and a member of the Executive Committee of the World Alliance of the YMCA, Geneva, Switzerland. Mrs. Huff was past President of the local United Way and a member of the First Baptist Church. In addition to her volunteer activities, Mrs. Huff worked alongside her husband at Huff Pharmacy, serving the local community. Mrs. Huff was born in South Carolina, the daughter of Furman and Margaret C. Grant. She was a graduate of the University of Georgia, and taught at Tift College before her marriage to Robert W. Huff in 1942. She leaves to cherish her memories her husband and four children: Penny Huff, Santa Barbara, CA; Wynne T. Huff II, Atlanta, GA; Robert W. Huff, Jr., Rome, GA; and Courtenay Huff, New York, NY; and a grandson Wynne T. Huff, III, Atlanta, GA. A memorial service will be held February 7, 1998 at 11:00AM at the First Baptist Church in Rome, with visitation with the family at the First Baptist Church for one hour prior to the service. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be sent to the American Cancer Society, 229 North Fifth Avenue, Rome, GA, or to the Huff Endowment Fund of the RomeFloyd County YMCA, PO Box 727, Rome, GA. 30161, or to the First Baptist Church, P.O. Box 1189, Rome, GA. 30162-1189.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUSIMANO, ANN
description: CUSIMANO-Ann. On January 30, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Charles. Devoted mother of Charles and Donald. Dear grandmother of Michael and Thomas. Loving mother-in-law of Mary and Laura. Cherished sister of Nettie Coppola. Reposing at Cusimano & Russo, 2005 W. 6th St., Brooklyn. Funeral Mass Tuesday, 9:30 AM, St. Finbar R.C. Church.

title: The World; Four Decades of Revolution Bring Cuba Full Circle
description: FOR 39 years he has worked hard to build a better society for his own children and for all the children of Cuba. At 73 he still works as an organizer of the elections that every two years guarantee the permanence of the government he helped bring to power in 1959.

title: QUICK BITE/Union City; Parking Is a Challenge, Choosing a Good Meal Is Easy
description: People who really love the play of bold and subtle in Turkish food have at least two options: Grab the next flight to Istanbul, or run up to Turkish Kitchen in Union City, the Hudson County neighborhood that rises from the rocks overlooking the Lincoln Tunnel's swooping concrete entry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WASSERMAN, ROSE
description: WASSERMAN-Rose. On January 30, in her 87th year. Predeceased by her husband, Rubin. Survived by daughters Harriet and Maxine, a son, Simon, and her granddaughter Michelle. She will remain in loving memory.

title: Jerry-miad
description: For Eitan Cabel (pictured), a first-term Labor Party member of the Knesset from the sleepy town of Rosh Ha'Ayin, Israel's traditional year-end filibuster before the Dec. 31 budget vote carried the weight of tragedy. ''I had to miss 'Seinfeld,''' he laments. ''It was all I could think about every night, that I was missing another show and that it was all going to end soon.''

title: Our Towns; Putting a Stop To Car Theft At Early Age

As they milled in the lobby, waiting for their assignments, a woman at the security desk stared, open-mouthed. ''Ooh,'' she said. ''That'll impress the kids.''

title: A Constitutional End Run On Financing for Schools
description: Ever since a judge told the New Jersey Supreme Court that urban schools need an additional $312 million, there has been a lot of bluster around here.

title: Cabbie Finds $10,000 And Returns It to Tourist
description: A 32-year-old cabdriver found $10,042 in cash in the back of his taxi Saturday night and turned it in to the authorities. The police returned the money to a Belgian tourist who had lost it.

description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he is convinced casino gambling is coming to New York City . . .specifically citing Governors Island as a perfect location for a Monte Carlo-like resort. -- The New York Times, Dec. 6, 1997

title: This Just In! And This!
description: When an earlier President's conduct was mesmerizing America, we reporters sometimes got into pitched debate with our editors about how far our articles could go in fixing blame for Watergate on Richard M. Nixon. The editors kept insisting it was inappropriate for the press to predict Nixon's indictment. If it was to happen, it would be framed in due time by facts. As, indeed, it was.

title: Corrections

description: GOULD-Solomon. The Trustees of The Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center note with profound sorrow the death of a distinguished past member and Honorary Trustee. Since 1978 Mr. Gould was a dedicated and inspired leader, an enthusiastic organizer and supporter of many fundraising events as well as a man of great vision. His efforts contributed to Brookdale's emerging as a leading provider of healthcare in the communities it serves. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his family. Frank J. description: LIKE longhorns on a very long cattle drive, the nearly 80 million-strong herd of baby boomers could break into another stampede at any time. And the cowhands at the big auto companies are wary.

description: IN THE WINTER Olympic equivalent of threading a needle immediately after running a number of laps, biathletes ski until it is difficult to ignore the drumming of their hearts, then fire five rounds with a small-bore rifle at a stationary target. Sometimes they must stand and fire, sometimes they must be prone and fire. After all that cross-country skiing, prone sounds more appealing, but the bad news is that the target is smaller; the other bad news is that you still can't remove your skis.

description: The rain relented at Pebble Beach today, and terrific golf took over.

title: THEATER; Playwright's Collaborator: The Kid He Used to Be
description: First efforts have a special place in the affections of their creators. Before the playwright Jon Robin Baitz wrote ''The Film Society,'' or the more recent ''Substance of Fire,'' ''Fair Country'' and ''Three Hotels,'' he completed a one-act. It was based on his brief sideswipe into the lives of two desperate Hollywood hangers-on, and he entitled it ''Mizlansky/ Zilinsky or 'Schmucks.' '' Thirteen years later, Mr. Baitz has reworked it into a full length play that stars Nathan Lane and Lewis J. Stadlen. Now in previews, it opens on Feb. 17 at the Manhattan Theater Club, directed by Joe Mantello. In this article, the author recollects a younger, perhaps more innocent time and self.

title: Class Cutups
description: One of this week's imported treats, THE HAPPIEST DAYS OF YOUR LIFE (1950) is for film buffs who relish samplings of Britain's post-war golden age of sly, gleaming comedy. The charming farce weaves itself through the entanglement of a girl's school, headed by Margaret Rutherford, and a boy's academy (run by Alastair Sim, above), with an ironic eye on tradition and the separation of the sexes. The supporting cast, which includes Bernadette O'Farrell, John Bentley and Richard Wattis, and the two veteran stars fly high into the face of British academia under Frank Launder's experienced piloting. Joyce Grenfell is especially hilarious as an angular athletic director stalking the premises in a bloomer uniform and spouting academic bromides -- Friday at 4:35 P.M., Saturday at 11 A.M. on Bravo. Howard Thompson

title: Schools Aren't Factories, Pupils Aren't Products; Additional Training
