title: Smoother Seas For Wheelchairs
description: WHEELCHAIR access aboard cruise vessels is improving. The number of accessible cabins has risen rapidly in the last eight years, to more than 550. The main reason is the number of large vessels recently put into service that have 10 or 20 accessible cabins, a big leap from the two or four that were once customary.

title: Carry-On Bags
description: To the Editor: Betsy Wade's article explained to me why Northwest announced its ''one plus'' baggage rule on a flight last month. I just popped my handbag into my larger canvas bag and with my carry-on suitcase, I got on board without a problem. But, as she wrote, some people carried on more and were not stopped.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SASLOW, TODD R.
description: SASLOW-Todd R. On January 29, 1998, of Jericho, L.I. Beloved son of Phyllis and Donald. Dear brother of Brett. Cherished grandson of Hattie Koss. Services Sunday 1:30PM at ''Gutterman's,'' 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, L.I.

title: P.R. Bauble of the Week
description: No, the sibling duo Reed and Melissa Evins aren't designing doll shoes. But for the Fashion Footwear Association of New York's shoe show, which ends today, they promoted their studio with tiny display cases that would make Barbie beam.

title: In the Region/Long Island; Growing Demand Spurs Self-Storage Construction
description: JOE Deuidicibus, a composer and producer of musical events, had a problem. He needed a heated and secure place to safely store his electronic equipment without spending a fortune on rent.

title: River cruises from the Danube to the Irrawaddy
description: The time to see Europe from the perspective of its rivers and canals is, generally speaking, from April to November. That is when most hotel barges operate in Belgium, Britain, France, the Netherlands and Sweden, and river cruisers ply the broader waterways of many other European countries from Austria to Ukraine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINER, SIDNEY
description: WEINER-Sidney. Beloved husband of Estelle, devoted father of Richard, and Abby (Jeff) Rutner. Grandfather of Sara, Joshua and Jonathan Rutner. Brother of Marion Heller. Retired from Screen Gems Inc. in 1977. Memorial service on Monday, February 2, 11 AM at Central Synagogue, 430 Demott Ave., Rockville Centre.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONRAD, CHIP
description: CONRAD-Chip. On January 30, 1998 of AIDS. Long time companion of Carlos Coimbra. Funeral services will be held at The Church of St. Luke In The Field, 487 Hudson St., corner of Grove St., Monday February 2nd at 10:30 AM. No flowers please. Donations may be made to the Peter Kruger Center, c/o Beth Israel Medical Center, 295 1st Ave., NY, NY 10003

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOPER, EVE
description: COOPER-Eve. The Officers and Board of Directors of the Jewish National Fund of Greater New York extend our sincere sympathy and condolences to Malcom Thomson, our President, and his wife Barbara on the passing of Barbara's mother, Eve Cooper. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Bertrum L. Podell, Chairman Ronald S. Lauder, National President Michael T. Cohen, Chairman Executive Committee Russell F. Robinson, National Exec. Vice President Matania Z. Kochavi, Special Israeli Representative

title: Her Long Goodbye
description: NIGHT TRAIN

title: Quiet Chinese New Year
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLUB, BELLE
description: GOLUB-Belle. 98. Loving widow of Barney; adored mother of Jackie and Harvey Cooper, Rena and Dick Golub; beloved grandmother of Peter and Christina Golub, Jimmy and Janine Golub, Barbara and Ken Widder, Judy Cooper, Nancy and Stanley Riesenfeld; and nine great-grandchildren, and universally loved.

title: Sports of The Times; Fairness and Riding a Golf Cart
description: I WAS all for Casey Martin's losing his case and not being allowed to ride a cart in PGA tournaments -- until 1964.

title: Gold and Silver Divided by Split Seconds
description: You are sitting across the dinner table from a man who has won two Olympic silver medals and is attempting to find a simple way to measure the gap that has kept him from winning two golds.

title: Flushing Out the Foul And the Frustration; A New Vista for a Dead-End Canal
description: For more than 35 years, as Cobble Hill, Park Slope, and other Brooklyn neighborhoods of brownstone and old brick have revived, a mile-long corridor through the middle of the area has continued to crumble, collect weeds and drive people away.

title: Alanna Estin, James R. Levine
description: Alanna Meredith Estin, a daughter of Karen K. Estin and Leonard A. Estin of New York, is to be married today to James Richard Levine, the son of Lucy Levine and Dr. David Y. Levine of New York. Rabbi George M. Stern is to perform the ceremony at the Mark Hotel in New York.

title: Forever Scarlett
description: When the gargantuan Selznick edition of GONE WITH THE WIND arrived admidst much fanfare in 1939, it was just what critics least expected -- a skillful and scrupulous re-creation of Margaret Mitchell's sweeping mural of that bitter decade when war and reconstruction were ripping apart the fragile fabric of the South. That unstinting fidelity to the novel, combined with brilliant casting, have kept the film younger than its aged Technicolor effects. Olivia de Havilland is a most gracious Melanie, Leslie Howard (above with Vivien Leigh) an elegantly pallid Ashley Wilkes, Clark Gable a Rhett Butler with just the right scent of the smokehouse and Vivien Leigh the very embodiment of the self-centered Miss O'Hara who tackled life with both claws and a creamy complexion -- Thursday at 8 P.M. on TNT.

title: A Warm Oasis With Well-Turned Food
description: FOR nearly 70 years, the Elk Hotel was the meeting place, the crossroads, the clubhouse of Port Jefferson. It still is. Although the old hotel is long gone, the Elk Street Grille stands on its site and has captured its spirit.

title: Black and White Revisited; Letters on 'Little Things' Revealed Insensitivity
description: To the Editor:

title: Why Do People Quit Their Jobs? Because They Can
description: MIKE MITCHELL was perfectly happy last spring in his job as an employee communications specialist here for the Phelps Dodge Corporation.

title: Schools Aren't Factories, Pupils Aren't Products; Bonuses to Families
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROBBINS, SIM
description: ROBBINS-Sim. 3/17/18-2/1/82 Beloved husband, father, grandfather. Deeply missed, lovingly remembered and eternally loved. Rose, Dana, Elissa and Steffie

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBSON, SAM
description: JACOBSON-Sam. In his 106th year on January 30, 1998. Loving, and loved, devoted father of Bette (Phil) Baum, Charlotte (Mel) Perelman. Two grandsons, four great-grandchildren. At rest in Chicago with Corrine and Bess.

title: Indonesia and Austerity
description: To the Editor:

title: Thomson's Work
description: To the Editor: For those who wish to enjoy the architecture of Alexander Thomson (''The Greek's Glasgow,'' Jan. 11), I would suggest a visit to the Bowling Green Offices at 11 Broadway. The building's base is a literal copy of Thomson's work, while the upper stories reflect Louis Sullivan and the Chicago School.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINSLOW, LUCY P.
description: WINSLOW-Lucy P. Age 83, of Exeter, NH, died Sunday, January 25, 1998 after a long illness. Born December 3, 1914 in Boston, MA, she was the daughter of the late Charles J. and Evelyn (Munroe) Prescott, and graduate of Radcliffe College, 1935. She earned a Master's Degree in Social Work at the University of Chicago and a Master's Degree in Library Science at Columbia University in New York. After early careers in social service and municipal research, Mrs. Winslow began as a reference librarian and advanced to Director of the Sprain Brook Library, Yonkers, New York. She was active in numerous civic organizations, including the League of Women Voters and the Literacy Volunteers of America. An avid sports fan, she also enjoyed opera and supported wildlife protection causes. Mrs. Winslow was married for 56 years to Richard S. Winslow, whose extensive career was in international affairs and New York City government. She is also survivied by two sons: Richard S. Winslow, Jr. of Mercer Island, WA, and Prescott Winslow of Seattle, WA; a daughter, Lucy Bennett Winslow of So. Yarmouth, MA; and three grandchildren. A private funeral will be held later on Cape Cod. Donations may be sent to any organization for environmental or wildlife protection.

title: Sex: Say No ... and Win!
description: What I found truly newsworthy in your Sunday item ''Sex: Say No ... and Win!'' (Jan. 11) was not the use of cash incentives to discourage unwanted pregnancy but the unquestioned linkage of not wanting to be pregnant with not wanting to have sex. Indeed, if the crux of Gil Burnett's program is to convince young women to say no to sex, rather than to educate them about various forms of birth control, then the program is really about ''pleasure control.'' Of course, the program wants only women to be denied the pleasures of sex -- men are excluded.

title: Justice in the Balkans
description: To the Editor:

title: His Own Path To the Summit
description: So, Hermann Maier, when was the last time you laid a brick?

title: Hip-Hop Culture Out of a Williamsburg Warehouse
description: In Williamsburg, Brooklyn, in a dark, drafty warehouse where snack food wrappers are scattered on the stairwells and the most prominent sign on the building reads, ''Space Available,'' an unusual idea for a Web site is thriving.

title: When Tamed, Folk Tales Lose Their Power
description: To the Editor:

title: Patricia Larkin, John Tartaglia
description: Patricia Ann Larkin and John Andrew Tartaglia were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York. The Rev. Mark Hallinan performed the ceremony.

title: He Just Wants to Fly
description: Masahiko Harada has been a ski jumper since age 9, when he first launched himself off a hill on Japan's most northern island and felt the sheer thrill of flying. Even now, at 29, his nickname is Happy because competition frequently brings a smile to his face.

title: James O'Brien, 88, Ex-Financial Executive
description: James J. O'Brien Sr., a former executive at the Chase Manhattan Bank and on Wall Street, died on Friday at Johns Hopkins Geriatric Rehabilitation Center in Baltimore. He was 88.

title: Winter's Novelty Acts; Soaring With the Turkeys at the Olympics
description: AT the 1988 Winter Olympics in Calgary, a part-time plasterer from Cheltenham, England, nicknamed Eddie the Eagle demonstrated with hilarious ineptitude how the agony of victory was never as much fun as the thrill of defeat.

title: January 25-31; Abortion Foes Kill a Guard
description: A bomb exploded without warning outside an abortion clinic that had long been the target of protesters in Birmingham, Ala., killing an off-duty police officer in what was thought to be the first fatal bombing of an abortion clinic in the United States. A nurse was also left critically wounded in the blast at the All Women Health Care Clinic at 7:30 A.M., as it was opening.

title: Woody Romoff, 79; Played Roles On Broadway and in Light Opera
description: Woody Romoff, who moved effortlessly for a half-century between the worlds of Broadway and light opera, died on Jan. 20 at the Jewish Home and Hospital for the Aged in Manhattan, just down the block from his former apartment. He was 79.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZEILIGZOHN, DR. MIRIAM
description: ZEILIGZOHN-Dr. Miriam. Of Clifton, N.J. Beloved wife of Lucian. Devoted mother of Eugene. Loving grandmother of Brian and Ava. Services ''Wien & Wien'', Englewood, N.J. Sunday 10 A M.

title: When the Temple Bell Tolls, The Games Begin
description: After seven years, the countdown clock in front of Nagano's train station has reached single digits, representing the days remaining until the start of the 18th Olympic Winter Games on Saturday. During those years, the Nagano Olympic Organizing Committee, in cooperation with Nagano's local officials, has been orchestrating every detail of a 16-day competition that will include such Olympic firsts as a Dream League of professional ice-hockey players and medal events in snowboarding, curling and women's ice hockey.

title: Have Armchair, Will Travel
description: ''I want to talk to my agent about this,'' quipped Burt Wolf as he knelt on the floor of a 15th-century Italian castle, now a museum of antique musical instruments. Mr. Wolf, the television bon vivant and host of the Travel Channel series ''A Taste for Travel,'' was pushing two wood levers to power an old organ, and when a resident music scholar began to finger the keyboard, a reedy Baroque air drifted through the cavernous room.

title: State, Foundation Grant Money To Create Art Education Pilots
description: Three schools in New Jersey will share $200,000 to serve as models for integrating the arts and art education into the teaching of history, math and other subjects. The financing was announced Wednesday by the New Jersey State Council on the Arts, which is providing $100,000 for the Arts Create Excellent Schools program. Three schools will be selected for the next school year through the Alliance for Arts Education/New Jersey, a nonprofit art education advocacy organization, to serve as pilot programs, said Cynthia Evans of the Gerald R. Dodge Foundation. The foundation, in Morristown, is providing the other $100,000 for the project.

title: Where Faiths Meet At a Peaceful Summit
description: THE Bagdogra-Darjeeling road begins in hot, steamy flatland, flanked by bamboo thickets and banana fronds, then rises and corkscrews among the hills. The vegetation changes: silver fir, rhododendron, maple, oak. From our hired van, my wife, Jody, and I saw tea plantations with weathered placards bearing names like Longview and Margaret's Hope.

title: Sleight of Hand
description: The Magician's Wife

title: ICE HOCKEY
description: FOR THE first time, the National Hockey League is shutting down its season for more than two weeks so that its best players can represent their countries in the Winter Games. They will play on rinks that are wider than those used for league games in North America. Many players will compete against opponents who are their N.H.L. teammates.

title: Where the Oldies Beat Faster: 60's Music Entertains the Young
description: MOTHERS and fathers were snapping their fingers. Their children danced in the aisles next to them. A pigtailed 2-year-old with a diaper line showing through her overalls swayed from one foot to the other and clapped her hands to the beat of songs made popular 20 to 30 years ago by Sly and the Family Stone and the Jackson Five. The theater at the Performing Arts Center at Purchase College here was rocking recently to the upbeat, funky sound of the Sugar Beats, a group of 10- and 11-year-olds, who with the lead singers, Sherry Goffin Kondor and Johnny Kemp, were performing updated arrangements of songs from the 60's and 70's.

title: Leetch's Return Isn't Enough as Rangers Squander a Two-Goal Lead
description: Brian Leetch's return to the lineup today helped to breathe some life into the stumbling Rangers and even gave them a 2-0 lead over the Bruins before the first period was over at the Fleet Center.

title: At Mickey's House, A Quiet Welcome For Distant Cousins
description: THERE'S AN AIR OF ANTICIPATION in the land of anime, the risque and warlike corner of Japanese animation that has become hugely popular on video in the United States. Amid characters like the genetically enhanced M. D. (Most Dangerous) Geist, liberator of the devastated planet of Jerra, and Doreimon, a scantily clad android from the 22d century, a youngster named Kiki is about to arrive -- representing, of all things, the forces of civic-minded youth.

title: Neither Rain Nor Sleet Nor Snow (Nor Evil Spirits)
description: This is a quaint little city famed not for evil spirits but rather for soba noodles, an old Buddhist temple and abundant hot springs that allow people and monkeys alike to bathe in steaming pools surrounded by snow.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: THE NEW YORK STROLL; Where the Glittering Balls Once Twirled
description: In 1968, the Euro night life impresario Regine boldly declared, ''Discotheques are finished in New York.'' Ten years later, she was hailed as the city's reigning queen of disco, with fevered patrons lined up in front of the Park Avenue dance mecca that carried her name.

title: 'Titanic' is turning out to be a success on the scale of its doomed subject.
description: ''TITANIC'' was a mega-disaster, comparable to ''Waterworld,'' ''Cutthroat Island,'' and ''Heaven's Gate.'' ''Titanic'' would sink the jobs of some top executives at 20th Century Fox, the studio that provided the bulk of the financing, with Paramount, for a movie that cost at least $200 million to produce and at least $50 million to market. ''Titanic'' was a metaphor for Hollywood film making gone amok; a movie whose director, James Cameron, went over budget by an estimated $100 million.

title: Memos Said to Detail Reuters Effort to Obtain Bloomberg Data
description: Federal prosecutors have obtained more than 100 written communications between an American subsidiary of Reuters Holdings P.L.C. and a consulting company that investigators believe was hired to steal information from the computers of a competitor, Bloomberg L.P., people in touch with the investigation said yesterday.

title: Netscape's decision to give away code could alter the software industry.
description: RATHER than escalating a dead man's curve race against its archenemy, the Microsoft Corporation, the Netscape Communications Corporation has made a course correction that may profoundly affect the commercial software industry.

title: Teachers' Union Merger
description: To the Editor:

title: The Era of Big Government Lives Anew
description: To the Editor:

title: Protesters Assail Rising Use of Police Cameras
description: With dozens of uniformed police officers looking on -- not to mention those who might have been watching on a video monitor in a precinct house -- more than 200 New York City residents rallied in Washington Square Park yesterday against the Giuliani administration's increasing use of surveillance cameras to fight crime.

title: Harpists and Trombonists Sway As Those Valkyries Take Flight
description: Swirling, curving, bound planks create a circular floor tilted quite steeply toward the audience: a wooden ''O'' for this second installment in the new production of Wagner's ''Ring'' at the Netherlands Opera. Or more, a wooden ''C,'' since a great square notch is cut into the right side of the disk stage to accommodate the orchestra.

title: Hector Eduardo Cabanillas, 84; Kept Eva Peron's Grave a Secret
description: Hector Eduardo Cabanillas, a retired Argentine Army colonel who was responsible for the military Government's effort to hide the body of Eva Peron, died on Jan. 30. He was 84 and suffered from a long illness, an army spokesman said.

title: Krone's Comeback Continues With an Upset at Gulfstream
description: Julie Krone took a long stride on her comeback trail today when she rode the mare Radiant Megan, a 23-1 long shot, to victory by a head over the favored Escena in the Sabin Handicap at Gulfstream Park.

title: Shore City Tries Cutting Red Tape to Grow
description: Over the years, this once-vibrant vacation spot watched both its sandy beaches and its tourism erode. Then came the fire in 1987 that destroyed the city's fishing pier, the boardwalk and an amusement park called Kid's World.

title: The Neediest Cases; Giving to Neediest Honors Goodness of Loved Ones
description: Dr. Robert deLemos was devoted to those starting life with profound disadvantages. A pioneering neonatologist who helped invent a life-saving lung ventilator, Dr. deLemos also created a camp for handicapped children.

title: Albright Rebukes Israeli and Palestinian Leaders
description: Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright scolded Israeli and Palestinian leaders today for delaying the fundamental decisions necessary to revive peace talks between them.

title: For Beltway Nobody, Two Weeks of Fame
description: William H. Ginsburg needs no introduction now, two weeks after the California lawyer arrived in Washington as a Beltway nobody to defend Monica S. Lewinsky in the criminal inquiry into President Clinton's behavior. By midday yesterday, the 54-year-old lawyer had managed to appear on all five major national talk programs in one morning. He hopscotched studios, and he was nowhere near winded.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUSIMANO, ANN
description: CUSIMANO-Ann. On January 30, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Charles. Devoted mother of Charles and Donald. Dear grandmother of Michael and Thomas. Loving mother-in-law of Mary and Laura. Cherished sister of Nettie Coppola. Reposing at Cusimano & Russo, 2005 W. 6th St., Brooklyn. Funeral Mass Tuesday, 9:30 AM, St. Finbar R.C. Church.

title: Kruse Plays Hero Again for Isles And Saves a Tie
description: For the Islanders, today's 2-2 tie with the Boston Bruins did not mean the glass was half full, nor did it mean the glass was half empty. It was just the wrong-size glass.

title: Treasury Set to Auction Bills This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: Half-Measures to Protect the Amazon
description: Brazil's President, Fernando Henrique Cardoso, now has on his desk new legislation that finally gives the country's environmental agency a modicum of power to enforce environmental laws. A coalition of ranchers and industrialists managed to strip the bill of some of its toughest provisions, and is trying to persuade Mr. Cardoso to veto the important measures that remain. Before doing so, he should think carefully about a report issued last week by the Brazilian National Space Research Institute, which found that deforestation in Brazil's Amazon is growing alarmingly.

title: Most Asian Stocks Surge, Led by Indonesia
description: Indonesian stocks surged to their highest point in more than three months, led by PT Telkom, on optimism that banking reforms announced by the Government in the last week would put the economy back on track.

title: This Time, Youth Is Served as Upbeat Lakers Rout the Disinterested Bulls
description: Kobe Bryant fell asleep all week wondering what move Michael Jordan would try against him and whether he could move his feet in time to keep up. Shaquille O'Neal went one step further, forgoing his usual dietary staples for some fish and lean beef.

title: Time to Try a New School Year
description: School overcrowding in New York City is far too big a problem to be treated by a single solution. But out of a mix of remedies, one of the most promising is year-round use of schools. Superintendents in three of the city's most crowded districts want to experiment with new schedules that would allow them to handle 25 percent to 50 percent more students in the same buildings. The children would attend class on staggered schedules that would have some in school during the summer.

title: Sun Microsystems sponsors a hearts and minds campaign that may be aimed at Microsoft.
description: THE battle for the hearts and minds of techno-geeks has taken on the flavor of a political campaign in new advertising for Sun Microsystems Inc.

title: Taiwan Excluded Again
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Matters; On Principle, Principals Spurn Bonus
description: IN a city where practically everyone seems to have an exaggerated sense of self-importance, it's refreshing to come across a group with as little swagger as New York's public school principals.

title: Mario Schifano, 63, Avant-Garde Painter
description: Mario Schifano, one of Italy's best-known contemporary painters, died on Jan. 26 at the Santo Spirito Hospital in Rome. He was 63 and lived in Rome.

title: Getting Down in Gold Lame 20 Years After Disco Fever
description: People aren't embarrassed about disco anymore. On Saturday night at the Theater at Madison Square Garden, the radio station WKTU (103.5 FM in New York) celebrated the 20th anniversary of ''Saturday Night Fever,'' the 1977 movie that made disco safe for mainstream America. , The hall was packed with people who had hauled out their old polyester shirts and bell-bottoms to see the Bee Gees and other groups from the soundtrack album.

title: Fordham Pleased to Make Rhode Island Sweat
description: Certainly this was a fluke. It was halftime at the Rose Hill Gymnasium in the Bronx yesterday and Fordham trailed Rhode Island, ranked 21st in the Associated Press men's basketball poll, by only 40-39.

title: Watson Acknowledges He's Sending Out Job Feelers
description: Bob Watson, general manager of the Yankees, acknowledged last night that a representative acting on his behalf has been making job inquiries with other teams. Watson, currently under contract through the 1998 season, indicated that he wants to determine what he will be doing in years to come.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Tommy Hilfiger Buying A Pair of Affiliates

title: SOCCER; Old Foes Get Reacquainted, And U.S. Shuts Out Cuba
description: Meeting for the first time in almost half a century, the United States national soccer team struggled against a largely unknown Cuban squad today. But the United States scored three second-half goals for a 3-0 victory in the Concacaf Gold Cup, a regional tournament to decide the champion of North and Central America and the Caribbean.

title: Bob Russell, Entertainer, Is Dead at 90
description: Bob Russell, an inveterate entertainer who sang, joked, composed, wrote, staged and M.C.'d his way through an eclectic half-century career in the very penumbra of the national limelight, died on Jan. 24 at a hospital near his home in Sarasota, Fla. He was 90.

title: Looking for Bigger Paydays Against Bigger Names, Hopkins Challenges Everybody
description: After dispatching Simon Brown under a hail of punches at 1 minute of the sixth round early this morning, Bernard Hopkins, the International Boxing Federation middleweight champion, stepped out of the ring and jumped right on the stump, campaigning for more lucrative fights against high-profile opponents who he believes have been ducking him.

title: Keep The PGA On Foot
description: A Federal court hearing is scheduled for today to decide whether a golfer afflicted with a circulatory disease should be allowed to use a motorized cart to compete in PGA Tour and Nike Tour events. The golfer, Casey Martin, a very talented young player, argues that, under the Americans With Disabilities Act, he should be exempt from the rule that players must walk the course.

title: Building 'Internet 2'
description: A handful of researchers scattered across the country are rushing to develop a video conferencing computer program so sophisticated that it will allow executives in four locations to ''sit'' around a table together, ''handing'' documents back and forth while they talk.

title: Cross at the Ankle or Knee?
description: Desmond Morris, the busy British zoologist (''The Naked Ape''), brings a touring exhibit to the Learning Channel this week of those entertaining and enlightening curiosities known as men and women. His six-hour show, ''The Human Sexes,'' opens tonight with a good-humored look around the world at what makes the sexes different and why.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MOSKOWITZ, SIDNEY M.
description: MOSKOWITZ-Sidney M. 6/10/23- 2/2/88. 10 years. Always remembered, never forgotten. Forever in our hearts and thoughts. Love Millie, Michael and Naomi

title: From Clay Pots to Cowbells With a Different Drummer
description: Jazz and rock drummers can become quite famous, but on the classical side of the street, there are few percussionists who can sustain solo careers and whose names are known to listeners who are not also percussionists. Evelyn Glennie, the young Scottish percussionist who played a spectacular concert on Saturday evening at Alice Tully Hall, has lately become the percussion world's Segovia or Rampal. She has commissioned works, revived scores written for her colleagues and composed music of her own.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GULLEN, HENRY S.
description: GULLEN-Henry S. On January 30, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Helen (nee Walzauck). Loving father of Karyn Browne. Devoted grandfather of Timothy and Randy. Dear brother of Wanda Pszeniczny and Stanley Gulczynski. Family will receive friends at the Leo F. Kearns Funeral Home (718441-3300), 61-40 Woodhaven Blvd., Rego Park, Monday, 3-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial St. Margaret's Church, Tuesday, 9:45 AM. Contributions may be made to the Parker Jewish Institute, 271-11 76th Ave., New Hyde Park, NY 11040.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: A Tug of War Between Economic Philosophies: Free Market vs. Government
description: THE COMMANDING HEIGHTS

title: Iraq Still Unpopular in One Arab Land
description: The scars in this tiny emirate on the Persian Gulf from the seven-month military occupation by Iraq in 1990-91 have been covered over with a cosmetic luster that only deep pockets can buy.

title: Flirtation Between Movies and Magazines Starts to Get Serious
description: In a striking testament to Hollywood's heightened interest in turning nonfiction magazine articles into film scripts, Buzz magazine plans to announce a deal today with Paramount Pictures under which the studio will provide Buzz with a discretionary fund to pay for in-depth articles with movie potential.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIDRER, CHARLES
description: SIDRER-Charles. On January 31, 1998, age 83. Beloved husband of Michle. Cherished father of Reva and Debby. Adored grandfather of Adam, Lauren, Andrew and Samantha. Brother of Laura. Fatherin-law of Mitchell and Arnold. New York City schoolteacher for 20 years. Former member of the National Executive Committee of the Workmen's Circle. Also taught in the Sholem Alechem Schools. Avid tennis and chess player. Service Monday, February 2, 12 noon, Riverside Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: CLINTON'S BUDGET HINGES ON PASSING TOBACCO ACCORD
description: The $1.7 trillion budget that President Clinton will unveil on Monday is built on a grand political bargain: Appealing new programs are linked to Congressional approval of the national tobacco settlement.

title: Justice in the Dark
description: The New York State Legislature let the state's successful 10-year-old experiment with television cameras in the courtroom expire on June 30 and then adjourned without either approving another trial period or making camera access permanent. That was a mistake given the strong public interest in keeping the workings of the justice system accessible, and the fact that three special review commissions set up by the Legislature concluded that unobtrusive camera coverage increased public accountability without harming the rights of trial participants -- a finding in keeping with the experience of other more camera-friendly states.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUM, BELLE
description: BAUM-Belle. Devoted wife of the late Murray. Beloved mother of Marcia and Jerome Rosenberg and Betty Most. Dear sister of Irving and Ben Levinson. Cherished grandmother of Mara Robin Yorizzo. Services today, 1 PM, at ''Gutterman's,'' 8000 Jericho Tpke., Woodbury, LI.

title: Essay; Battle Plan for Gulf War II
description: If Saddam Hussein does not cave in to the sound of sabres rattling, the U.S. has little choice but to make good its military threats. What would Gulf War II be like?

title: Patents; A company finds a new way for medicinal chemists to test experimental drug formulations.
description: MEDICINAL chemists cooking up new drug formulations in traditional ways have a slow go of it. Often, it takes them years to synthesize a version of a promising drug that does what it is supposed to do.

title: Many Schools, in Disrepair, Pose Hazards
description: It was dismissal time at Public School 56 in the northwest Bronx, and as the principal, Michael Casey, stepped onto the school's front steps surrounded by children one day in October, he suddenly felt a sharp pain atop his head.

title: The Era of Big Government Lives Anew
description: To the Editor:

title: Donino and Berlin Win Accounts
description: Two agencies have been named to handle accounts with combined billings estimated at $30 million to $40 million.

title: President Makes His Absence Felt Among the Powerful
description: During the dizzying weekend after the Monica Lewinsky scandal broke, the Washington establishment was all but ready to dump President Clinton. Pundits spoke in grave tones of high crimes and misdemeanors.

title: Trio's Orders: Steal $3 Million, or Else
description: By all means, somebody should bring back ''The Mod Squad.'' Remember Linc, Pete and Julie (''First they got busted, then they got badges'') striding side by side in their cool hippie clothes? They were young; they were intense; they just wanted to help. What if they had had cell phones, laptops and a getaway Range Rover?

title: Indonesia Turns Its Chinese Into Scapegoats
description: Anti-Chinese sentiment is bubbling to the surface as Indonesians react to the pain of the Asian financial crisis, but Embing Sutiono, an ethnic Chinese shop owner, says he is confident that if riots break out he will not be a target.

title: U.N. Stymied by Resistance To Easing of Bosnian Partition
description: The Mayor of this small village drove three hours today from Banja Luka, where he lives with his family in an overcrowded refugee center, to ask his deputy if he could have an office.

title: $160-Billion Giant Would Dwarf Merck and Novartis : Glaxo and SmithKline Plan Largest Merger Ever
description: LONDON  The global pharmaceuticals industry could be set for an unprecedented wave of takeover activity following the surprise weekend announcement that Glaxo Wellcome PLC, the world's largest drugmaker, plans to combine with SmithKline Beecham PLC in what would be the world's biggest merger ever.

title: Virgil Barnes, 94, Geologist Who Studied Tektite Origins
description: Dr. Virgil E. Barnes, a geologist who contended that the black glassy beads called tektites, which had been regarded as extraterrestrial objects, were created from soil and rock by catastrophic cosmic collisions, some as many as 35 million years ago, died on Wednesday at Seton Medical Center in Austin, Tex. He was 94 and lived in Austin.

title: HUD Asks Money for Housing And Jobs for Urban Homeless
description: In its biggest budget request in 10 years, the Department of Housing and Urban Development will ask Congress on Monday to approve huge increases for programs to expand housing and job opportunities for low-income people in cities across the country.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We have been stalled at this point in the peace process, negotiating the same issues, for a long time -- frankly, far too long. There is far too much at stake for this to go on.''

title: Furious Comeback by the Nets Falls Short Against the Sonics
description: Anybody who still needs convincing that these are not the same old Nets might want to watch a tape of the second half of tonight's game against the Seattle SuperSonics. But the first half cost New Jersey a game that was there to be won.

title: Heal Thyself

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OBERG, ELIZABETH A.
description: OBERG-Elizabeth A. Of Bronxville, NY, on January 30, 1998. Wife of the late Harold. Beloved mother of Nancy McKay and Elizabeth Felleman. Dear grandmother of Elinor, Jennifer, Eric and Sarah. Service and interment private. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Arts Student League, 215 West 57th St., NY, NY.

title: Hoffmann's Dark Bouts With Love's Obsessions
description: Opera performance, a complicated and unpredictable process, allows promising new productions to emerge stillborn and at the next moment brings us old ones in states of vital and unexpected rebirth. The Metropolitan Opera's ''Contes d'Hoffmann'' is, for example, 16 years old. Its gaudy mechanical props and magicianly tricks are well known to Metgoers. The house's stage machinery, its basement elevator and rotating stages, still look impressive, but we have seen them before, many times.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARRON, RITA NALLY
description: BARRON-Rita Nally. Long time resident of Tarrytown, died January 31, 1998, at Westchester County Center in Valhalla. She was 64. She was born October 10, 1933, in Manhattan to Raymond and Elizabeth Nally. She was educated at Elizabeth Seton in Riverdale. She was a longtime employee of Marymount College, Tarrytown. She married George A. Barron, Esq., in the Bronx in 1956. The couple lived briefly in Camp LeJeune, North Carolina, while he served as Captain in the United States Marine Corps, then in the Bronx, before moving to Tarrytown in 1959. She was an active member of the Jane Todd Club and the Parish Council of Transfiguration Church in Tarrytown. Mrs. Barron is survived by one son, Christopher, and five daughters, Rita Marie, Theresa Marie, Catherine Marie, Anne Marie and Maura O'Donnell of Durham, North Carolina; and five grandchildren. Her husband died in 1987. Family and friends are making memorial contributions to Transfiguration School, Tarrytown, New York, in lieu of flowers.

title: World Bank Targets the Next Asian Danger: Growing Social Unrest
description: SINGAPORE  In a major effort to prevent large-scale social and ethnic unrest from derailing economic reforms in East Asia, the World Bank is considering allocating $9 billion to emergency job creation and other programs to ease poverty in the region.

Great-grandmother of Shira and Marisa Underberger, Jake and Hunter Lightman, and Elisabeth Lobel. Beloved sister of Bernice Suna and Hannah Kleinberg. Beloved aunt and great-aunt. She lived a life filled with naches, being part of and enjoying all the many happy events along the way. Services at Gutterman's, Woodbury, NY, Monday, February 2, 1998, at 1:30 PM.

description: An unemployed casino blackjack dealer received more than $60,000 in state funds Friday under a program intended to increase the number of minority residents who own minibus shuttles for gamblers in Atlantic City.

title: Suiting Up to Change Attitudes
description: Offered an automatic invitation as the team to play host to the tournament, Japan qualified for the first women's Olympic hockey tournament because of geography, not skill. Wally Kozak, the team's Canadian coach, figures he will need a few trick plays to avoid finishing sixth in a six-team field. That's where an 18-year-old, baton-twirling forward named Aki Tsuchida comes in.

title: Rural Elderly Create Vital Communities as Young Leave Void
description: The Elm Street Center for the elderly was hopping the other day, a beacon of warmth and activity amid the frozen bleakness that is winter in this farming town. The lunch crowd had arrived.

title: 90's Moonshiners Add Drugs and Guns to the Recipe
description: At the first sound of baying watchdogs, Jay Calhoun, a special agent of the Virginia Alcohol Beverage Control Commission Liquor Task Force, crouched in a thicket of mountain laurel and waited. In camouflage, Mr. Calhoun and two other agents remained motionless, their eyes focused on a corrugated-steel building less than 50 yards away through the trees, where they believed moonshine was being manufactured.

title: Taking In the Sites; Giant Slaloms By Keyboard, If You Can't Get to Nagano
description: The athletes gathering in Nagano, Japan, for the Winter Olympics could be forgiven for thinking they had gone to the Summer Games by mistake. For while cold weather has finally arrived, just in time for the opening of the Games on Saturday, these are the first Winter Olympics with surfing -- or snowboarding, in which competitors strap surfboard-like devices to their feet and swoop down the mountainside.

title: Tying Subversive Knots That Battle Conventions
description: For his quintet, Interpretations of Lessness, Andy Laster writes jazz tied in knots. He headed a Jazz Composers Collective bill on Thursday night at the New School Mannes Performance space, playing new work. A typical piece used a seven-beat rhythm for a stretch, then skidded to a stop, allowing a cello solo. Then a fast swing pulse underlined a passage in which all the other musicians gnawed on a single phrase, staggering their entrances.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAINES, ISIDORE H.

title: U.S. Plan on Internet Names Lacks Support From All Users
description: The Clinton Administration released its proposal to relinquish Government control of the Internet's centralized address system to a competitive market on Friday, seeking to privatize a crucial function of the sprawling network and formalize a system that rests largely on the technical community's personal loyalty to one of its founders.

title: Lewinsky Would Take Lie Test In Exchange for Immunity Deal
description: Monica S. Lewinsky, the former low-level aide at the center of the current White House investigation, is willing to submit to a polygraph examination in exchange for complete immunity from prosecution, her lawyer said today.

title: Abroad at Home; Abuse of Power
description: Ten years ago Justice Antonin Scalia warned of the potential for abuse of power by an unaccountable independent counsel. It was a dissent, and too few of us paid attention to his warning. Now the potential is reality. Look at what Kenneth Starr has done in his pursuit of the Clinton sex allegations.

title: Corrections

title: U.S. Bobsled Driver Cleared of Steroid Use
description: Brian Shimer, the United States' top bobsled driver at the 1998 Winter Olympics, has been cleared of a doping violation involving the possible use of the male sex hormone testosterone as a muscle-building anabolic steroid, two American Olympic officials said today.

title: Pride of Place for Latin Percussionists
description: His band's setup explains a good portion of Ralph Irrizary's plan: the conga and timbales are in front of the stage, and the horn section stands behind them, reversing the ordinary roles in Latin jazz bands. Mr. Irrizary, an explosive percussionist, has changed the way Latin jazz groups work, leading an ensemble instead of a group of soloists, and placing the horns as a supporting cast to the percussion.

Ginsburg? Who's Ginsburg?''

To him, being Rabbi, Sr. Rabbi and Rabbi Emeritus was not a job, but an avocation. His memory and accomplishments will certainly stay with us all forever. Lois, Jerold, Ronald and Sallie Kaniuk

title: This Week
description: EVENTS

title: Store Owner Is Killed At Home in Brooklyn
description: A 57-year-old store owner was killed inside her Coney Island apartment yesterday morning in what appears to have been a robbery, the police said.

title: Bracing for the Asian Shock Wave
description: So far, American workers have been helped, not hurt, by the Asian economic crisis. Prices are down; products like computers and televisions are cheap as rarely before. American stocks haven't fallen, and few working Americans had investments in Asia. More important, the crisis has eliminated fears of inflation and kept interest rates stable, so that our economy continues to grow and unemployment continues to fall.

title: A Requiem, Modernist in Idiom but Timeless in Awe of Its Subject
description: Grand Requiems, for all the vivid responses they may evoke in imperfect mortals, tend to be impersonal. They are not typical musical responses to intensely personal loss. Brahms, for example, though moved to a large public statement by his mother's death, produced something else. His ''German Requiem'' drew on the Lutheran Bible, skirting the formulaic evocation of the day of wrath in the Latin liturgy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, JOHN M.
description: GREENE-John M. Age 92, of Great River, LI, (formerly of Sayville) on January 31, 1998. Devoted husband of the late Kathryne. Loving father of Marilyn G. Walser and the late Barbara Dagher. Fond grandfather of ten and great-grandfather of twelve. Retired senior partner of Greene, Murray & Dagher, and former Chairman of the Board of Key Bank of LI and its predecessor Oysterman's Bank and Trust Co. Religious service Wednesday, 11 AM, at Raynor & D'Andrea Funeral Home, 245 Montauk Highway, West Sayville, NY. Interment St. Ann's Cemetery, Sayville. Visiting hours Tuesday, 2-4:30 and 7-9 PM. Please make contribution in his memory to either St. Ann's Episcopal Church, Sayville, NY, or St. Peter's Episcopal Church, Bay Shore, NY.

title: Madison Ave.'s Dispossessed: Life Without Routine Drags On
description: The cars and buses can chug through now. The regulars can go back to the spa, the hair salon, the wine shop. And Madison -- the cat who was holed up in his apartment without food for almost a week -- can eat and play to his heart's content.

title: John Wayne's Shadow Reaches for America's Future
description: Dan Barden's ''John Wayne, a Novel'' is a first book published last year; Jonathan Lethem's ''Girl in Landscape'' is a forthcoming novel with a Wayne-inspired hero by the author of ''Gun, With Occasional Music'' and ''As She Crawled Across the Table.'' The writers, in their early 30's, both begin with epigraphs from John Wayne, and both quotations are utterly epistemological: about how we know what we think we know. ''When I started, I knew I was no actor and I went to work on this Wayne thing,'' Wayne says in Mr. Barden's book. ''It was as deliberate and studied a projection as you'll ever see.'' Wayne dismisses ambiguity as Mr. Lethem's book opens: ''Perversion and corruption masquerade as ambiguity. I don't trust ambiguity.'' The future of American studies, among other things, is right here, even if Mr. Barden and Mr. Lethem do not, like some of their contemporaries, do their work as ''young Americanists.'' Not yet, anyway.

title: Grandmother's Favorite Rule Has All Kinds of Exceptions
description: Many of us know grandmother's favorite rule, dating back to the days of whist: Always cover an honor with an honor. Unfortunately, there are many exceptions, so many that the rule should be: Often cover an honor with an honor. Which does not help much.

description: The proposed merger of SmithKline P.L.C. and Glaxo Wellcome P.L.C. is beginning to send a shock through the pharmaceutical industry.

title: Community Service at Center Court
description: The chance to meet LL Cool J, the rap singer, might make another 15-year-old girl shout, shriek or even squeal. The chance to meet Tyra Banks, the supermodel, might make another 16-year-old boy brag, boast or even blush. But to Heidi Lopez and Japheth Youmans, meeting those celebrities is an afterthought.

title: Updates/Media and Technology; Maker of I.B.M. Clones Teams With Microsoft
description: The Amdahl Corporation, the maker of clones of I.B.M.'s biggest mainframe computers, plans to announce a wide-ranging partnership with Microsoft to help sell Windows NT to large corporations, said David Wright, the chief executive of Amdahl, which is now a unit of Fujitsu Ltd.

title: Why One-Hit Wonders Top the Pop Charts
description: To the Editor:

title: How Good Is It? As Good As It Gets, Governors Say
description: By President Clinton's proud reckoning on Tuesday night in his State of the Union Message, these are good times in America. But by the reckoning of most of the nation's governors, that was understatement.

title: Sharpton Testimony to Enliven Brawley Trial
description: Despite increasingly heated exchanges between lawyers and other courtroom contretemps, the spotlight has dimmed on the Tawana Brawley defamation trial in recent weeks. The news media contingent here has thinned out. Spectator seats, once scarce as busloads of supporters for the defendants streamed in from New York City, are easy to come by, and those few who do show up now have been observed nodding off during testimony.

title: Architectural Echoes of Kindness
description: The person of A. G. Rizzoli, who was photographed in 1918 at age 22, reveals almost nothing. He wears a pinstriped jacket, vest, monochrome tie and round collar. His plump face looks directly at the viewer. Only the declivity of the right ear and the faint downturn in the right corner of his mouth suggest something unaligned in his character. Rizzoli was an architectural draftsman for a San Francisco firm and a lifelong virgin who slept on a cot at the foot of his mother's bed even after she died. He resided, almost unnoticed, for nearly 50 years in a tiny house at 1668 Alabama Street.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about President Mohammad Khatami of Iran misstated the year of the next World Cup soccer tournament, in which Iran's team will play. The tournament is this year, not next year.

title: Updates/Media and Technology; Microsoft Will Soon Offer Peek at New-Media Strategy
description: The Microsoft Corporation is about to give an invitation-only crowd of 40,000 a glimpse of the company's new-media strategy.

title: 4 Lawmakers Hope to End Immigration Service
description: The four most influential members of Congress on immigration matters are moving toward a plan to abolish the Immigration and Naturalization Service, saying they are angered by a series of scandals and missteps at the troubled agency.

title: When Personal and Political Worlds Collide; Old Slander Strategy
description: To the Editor:

title: Aliens Would Get Food Stamps Back In Clinton Budget
description: In the budget he is to present to Congress on Monday, President Clinton will call for spending $2.5 billion in the next five years to provide food stamps to the hundreds of thousands of legal immigrants whose benefits were cut off by the sweeping Federal welfare law of 1996.

title: Ex-Governor Is Sentenced To 2 1/2 Years
description: Former Gov. Fife Symington of Arizona, his once-promising political career in ruins, was sentenced to two and a half years in prison today and five years' probation for his conviction on Federal charges that he defrauded his lenders as a commercial real estate developer in the late 1980's and early 1990's.

title: Why Sex Isn't Private Anymore
description: All the soul-searching about whether the President's sex life is a public or private matter is beside the point, isn't it?

title: Uzbek Grandmaster Wins Side Event at Title Series
description: When you have about 100 grandmasters gathered in a good location for chess like Groningen, the Netherlands, and their air fares and hotel bills are already paid, and they are temporarily out of work, it would seem to be a good idea to get them into a tournament. That's what the organizers of the International Chess Federation Knockout World Championship thought.

title: NASA Still Dreams of Mars Outpost
description: AS it has through the ages, Mars, the nearest planetary neighbor to the Earth, maintains a strange fascination for people and has long been a coveted destination for the more imaginative.

title: CURRENCIES
description: INDONESIAN RUPIAH RISES. The Indonesian currency, the rupiah, surged, bolstered by strong rallies in a number of Asian currencies and markets and by intervention by Indonesia's central bank. The rupiah was quoted at 10,275 to the United States dollar, up from 12,500 last week.

title: CUNY Shouldn't Farm Out Remedial Programs; Bonus for Families
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHN, FRED
description: KAHN-Fred. On January 30, 1998, at age 92. Beloved by family and friends, his love of life, art and people was extraordinary. Contributions to Marlboro School of Music, Marlboro, Vermont.

title: Sutherland's Memoirs
description: To the Editor:

title: A Night of Monumental, Mystical Bruckner
description: It has been several seasons since Christoph Eschenbach conducted the New York Philharmonic, and he has chosen an unusually challenging way to reacquaint himself with the orchestra. His program for the subscription week that began on Thursday evening is devoted fully to the Bruckner Symphony No. 8, an immense work full of questioning themes that Bruckner resolves only after wandering along an otherworldly harmonic path.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  STAR, LEON D., M.D.
description: STAR-Leon D., M.D. In everlasting remembrance of a loving husband, father and grandfather. Gone from us for eleven years.

title: From a Friend Indeed, Clinton Awaits a Visit
description: The trip was planned months ago, but it is hard to think of a world leader whom President Clinton would be luckier to have as his White House guest this week than Tony Blair.

title: CUNY Shouldn't Farm Out Remedial Programs
description: To the Editor:

title: Asian Markets Rebound, Some Up 10% or More
description: A streak of good economic news and sustained market rallies have raised hopes that the Asian financial crisis, if still a long way from the end, may have at least reached the end of its panic-stricken beginnings.

title: WebTV: Easy, Cheap and Limited Internet Access
description: BEFORE I first tried WebTV a year ago, I was positive that not even the comforts of my favorite recliner could make surfing the Web on television anything but a headache fraught with eyestrain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHMAN, PRISCILLA
description: FISHMAN-Priscilla. Our beloved Priscilla, died suddenly in Jerusalem, and was interred there on Febuary 1st, 1998. The shiva period will be observed in Israel. Husband: Hertzel. Children: David and Mindy, Leora, Talya and Max. Grandchildren: Akiva, Eliana, Oren, Elisheva, Leah. Steadfast companion: Lena Boski.

title: Teen-Age Luger Carries All of India
description: Of all the places that Sudhakaran Palankandy expected to be next Saturday morning, none of them included walking with his son in the opening ceremony at the 1998 Winter Olympics.

title: Metro Business; Lace Companies to Merge
description: Three of the largest embroidery and lace manufacturers in the United States -- Carolace Industries, Clover Trimmings and Huber Lace & Embroidery, all based in the New York City metropolitan region -- announced yesterday that they would merge.

title: 5% Increase, Much for Cleanups
description: The President's budget request for environmental and natural resources programs, spread over several Federal agencies, amounts to $31.5 billion in 1999, an increase of 5 percent over the $30 billion being spent on these programs this budget year.

title: ROMAC IN $376 MILLION STOCK DEAL FOR SOURCE SERVICES
description: Romac International Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the Source Services Corporation for stock valued at $376.4 million based on Friday's closing price, to create a leading provider of skilled workers in the computer, finance and accounting industries. Shares of Romac closed at $21.1875 yesterday, down $1.1875. Source Services rose $3, to $24.125. Under the deal, Romac, based in Tampa, Fla., would issue 1.1932 shares for each of the 14.1 million Source Services shares outstanding. Romac, which has completed 13 acquisitions since its initial public offering in 1995, said the addition of the Dallas-based Source Services would create a staffing company with 86 offices and $476 million in revenue.

title: Global Surge Helps U.S. Shares Re-Enter High Altitudes
description: Resurgent stock markets in Asia and merger news in Europe gave American stocks a powerful lift yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average rising more than 200 points and the Standard & Poor's 500 index reaching a record.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HADDAD, MOYSH
description: HADDAD-Moysh. Ten years ago today you left us. As a husband, daddy, grandfather and friend, you were the best. We will always love you and miss you. Freda

title: SUIZA FOODS ADDING LAND-O-SUN DAIRIES TO ITS NETWORK
description: The Suiza Foods Corporation said yesterday that it would acquire the closely held Land-O-Sun Dairies L.L.C. for about $224 million in cash and preferred stock as it builds a regional dairy network. Suiza would pay $124 million in cash and $100 million in preferred stock. It would also assume $63 million in debt to acquire the dairy company, which is based in Johnson City, Tenn., and had 1997 revenue of $464 million. Suiza, based in Dallas, has been buying dairy and related businesses throughout the United States. Its shares were up $1.375 yesterday at $62.3125.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, ESTHER (NEE HEILIGMAN).
description: COHEN-Esther (nee Heiligman). Died on January 29, 86 years, at Kendal - at - Hanover Residence, New Hampshire. Devoted wife of the late Mayer (Mike). Loving mother of Aaron and his wife Ann of Newtonville, MA; her daughter Sophia of Barrington, RI. Dear sister of Sol Heiligman and cherished grandmother of Rachel, Rebecca, and Naomi Cohen and Maia and Nina Cohen-Connors. A graduate of Hunter College, she taught economics in New York City high schools prior to her marriage and moved to Burlington, VT. where she lived a socially committed life in her community active in many local and national organizations. She was elected to the Vermont House of Representatives for five terms, was a member of the New England Board of Higher Education and the National Board of OWL. Esther Cohen touched the lives of many and was dedicated to improving the way for children, women and the elderly in many areas. Funeral services and interment were held on February 1 in Burlington, Vermont.

title: The S.& P. 500 Breaks Through The 1,000 Mark
description: The American stock market, resilient despite worries about Asia, soared past a milestone yesterday as the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose above 1,000 points for the first time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALMER, ROBERT LOUIS.
description: PALMER-Robert Louis. Age 86 of Shalimar, Florida, former Vice President and Treasurer of Cluett, Peabody and Company, Inc., passed away on January 31, 1998. Funeral services will be held at 1 PM, February 3 at the Rose-Neath Funeral Home in Shreveport, Louisiana, with his brother-in-law, the Reverend Dr. Arnold Coody, officiating. An alumnus of Dartmouth College and member of the Alpha Tau Omega fraternity, Mr. Palmer served as a Lieutenant Commander in the U.S. Naval Reserve, attached to the Supply Corps stationed in the Panama Canal Zone, during W.W. II. Mr. Palmer was predeceased in death by his sister, Ruth Ella Stevenson. He is survived by his wife of 51 years, Myrtie I. Palmer of Shalimar, FL; his son, James Robert Palmer, his wife Annette, and their sons, Louis and Colin of Austin, TX; his daughter, Dr. Mary Palmer Graber, and her husband John Graber of Indianapolis, IN.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'BRIEN, ESTHER (DOLLY).
description: O'BRIEN-Esther (Dolly). On February 1, 1998. Loving mother of Barie (Robert C. Weisgerber) and Philip (Lucy Rodriguez), devoted grandmother of Tomas and James. Reposing at the Simonson Funeral Home, 119-04 Hillside Ave, (corner Lefferts Blvd.), Richmond Hill, NY. Mass of Christian burial Thursday, 10:30AM at the Church of the Holy Child Jesus. Interment to follow at St. John's Cemetery. Visiting hours Tuesday 7-9:30 PM and Wed. 2:30-5PM and 7-9:30PM.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Gaels Are Winning and Having Fun
description: Just because Iona owns the nation's longest major college winning streak at 15 games does not mean the Gaels will shred the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference, Coach Tim Welsh said yesterday.

title: The Bare Look? Not for Real Life
description: There is a growing dichotomy between what designers put on the runway and what women put on their backs. The spring shows were filled with sheer dresses, bare shoulders, revealing cutouts and knits so thin they concealed nothing of the model's anatomy. And those were the day clothes.

title: Van Drivers for Disabled Strike for Better Wages
description: Sixty van drivers who take 180 disabled people in southern New Jersey to the doctor, to work and wherever else they need to go went on strike yesterday over wages and medical benefits.

title: By Design; Not Too High, Not Too Low
description: Designers and fashion editors may love stiletto heels, but most women don't -- at least not for everyday wear. Nor do they like flats, except for casual occasions. Fortunately, there are plenty of more comfortable heels for spring that are equally chic.

title: Logs at White House Show 3 Dozen Visits by Lewinsky
description: Monica S. Lewinsky visited the White House about three dozen times after leaving her low-level job there to work at the Pentagon in 1996, and she was usually cleared for entry by the President's personal secretary, said officials who have either seen or been briefed about White House visitation logs.

title: Pebble Beach Final Postponed
description: This year's AT&T Pebble Beach National Pro-Am will be remembered as the wettest, the longest and the most bizarre.

title: Car Jumps Curb, Severing Boy's Arm and Injuring 2 Other Children
description: A 4-year-old Bronx boy's arm was severed yesterday morning when a woman trying to park her car hit the accelerator instead of the brakes, causing the car to jump the curb and hit the boy and two other children, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARZ, ERWIN
description: SCHWARZ-Erwin, 93. Of Tucson, AZ. Formerly of New York City and of Scarsdale, NY, died in Gaithersburg, MD, on February 1, 1998. He was married to the late Louise Lasker Schwarz for over 40 years and leaves his wife of 23 years, Julia B. (Judy) Schwarz, three children, Arthur of Scarsdale, NY, Peggy Akin of Phoenix, AZ, and John, of Tucson, AZ, eight grandchildren and ten greatgrandchildren. He received B.S. and M.S. degrees in Chemistry fom Columbia University and entered the family business, Princeton Worsted Mills, in 1925; he was President of that company from 1939 until 1956. At that time he started a second career in education; after earning an M.A. in Classics from New York University, he taught Latin, Greek, History and Mathematics at Brooklyn College, NYU and the Fieldston School in New York and at the Greenfields School in Tucson. He also served as President of Westchester Jewish Community Services and Treasurer of the Arizona Friends of Music in Tuscon. A man of wideranging interests and talents, he devoted much of his life to learning and to teaching; he loved music, gardens, books and, most of all, young people. A memorial service will be held at the Harmonie Club, 4 East 60th Street, New York, New York, on Sunday, February 8, at 2:00 PM. Contributions may be made to the Ethical Culture Fieldston Schools, 33 Central Park West, New York, New York 10023.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDINSON, GEORGE
description: EDINSON-George. On February 1, 1998 at age 95. Beloved husband of Jeanette. Loving father of Constance. Grandfather of Richard and Larry. Great grandfather of Jonathan and Evan. His memory will stay with us forever.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: TRUCK TRAILER LEASING BUSINESS IS BOUGHT BY GE CAPITAL
description: The GE Capital Corporation said yesterday that it had bought a truck trailer leasing subsidiary from Kellers Systems Inc., increasing its North American trailer fleet -- already the nation's biggest -- by 20 percent. GE Capital, a Stamford, Conn., unit of the General Electric Company, did not say how much it had paid for the Trailer Leasing Company, which has about 39,000 trailers, but a person close to the negotiations said it had paid more than $300 million. GE Capital, whose businesses range from credit cards to airplane leasing, now has about 235,000 truck trailers in its fleet.

title: Debate on Human Cloning Ignores Some Benefits
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAD, JOHN D.
description: GRAD-John D. Died February 2, 1998 at the age of fifty, after a brave battle with brain cancer. He was the son of the late Thelma Grad and James Grad, husband of Rae Krohn Grad, father of Arlen, Rebecca and Aaron, brother of Adrian Grad Adolphe and Maxine Grad, uncle of Julia Adolphe, Sophia and Noa Shems. He was devoted to civil rights law and argued several cases in front of the Supreme Court.

title: Misanthropic Sound Technician
description: The connection between humans and machines stimulates endless speculation. People anthropomorphize inanimate objects, naming cars and nursing viral computers. Scientists fill steel and plastic with artificial intelligence and wonder if those tools could someday spark their own life essence. Such questions resonate in popular music, born of the union between personal expression and electric instruments.

title: A Tropical Paradise Evoked by Guitars
description: Local music is often tied up completely with cultural identity, and the Hawaiian slack-key guitar style is redolent with flowers, the beach, volcanoes and fruit. Three of its best performers, George Kahumoku Jr., the Rev. Dennis Kamakahi and Cyril Pahinui, showed up at Symphony Space on Friday night as part of a festival of Hawaiian music put on by the World Music Institute.

title: Saks and the Saudi
description: There is talk that Saks Fifth Avenue is considering opening a store in Saudi Arabia. Some shoppers wonder why Saks didn't think of this sooner, since 10 percent of Saks has been owned by PRINCE WALID BIN TALAL for nearly five years. He is the adventurous Saudi investor who also owns chunks of Donna Karan International and Apple Computer, to name only two.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMERSCHLAG, BEATRICE
description: HAMERSCHLAG-Beatrice. Age 99. Beloved wife of the late Julius, mother of the late Leonard and Alice. Darling grandmother of Lee, Julie, Leslie, Gregg, George, and the late Robert. Great grandmother of nine. Services at Riverside, 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave, Tuesday, February 3 at 11 A.M.

title: 4 Seats to Be Filled By Elections Today
description: A special election will be held today in Queens to fill the Congressional seat of the Rev. Floyd H. Flake, who recently retired. The polls will be open from 6 A.M. to 9 P.M.

title: Illness Strikes Top U.S. Pairs Team
description: Kyoko Ina, the United States pairs figure skating champion with partner Jason Dungjen of Monsey, N.Y., is suffering from a case of stomach flu and has not been able to eat for a day and a half. She was able to practice today and said she felt lightheaded. ''It's frustrating. I want to eat but I can't.'' The pairs short program is Sunday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREIDINGER, BARBARA (NEE WANSKER).
description: GREIDINGER-Barbara (nee Wansker). Beloved wife of Milton. Devoted mother of Randy. Loving daughter of Lillian Wansker. Dear sister of Geri and Jerry Gutterson. Fond aunt. Graveside services were held Monday.

title: Citing Threat, Judge Orders John Gotti Jr. Held in Jail
description: Calling John Gotti Jr. a danger to the community, a Federal judge today ordered him held without bail until his trial on charges of racketeering and extortion.

title: Inquiry Said to Focus on Ties Of Reuters Unit to Company
description: Federal prosecutors are investigating the relationship between an American subsidiary of Reuters Holdings P.L.C. and a Manhattan company that they believe was commissioned to steal information electronically from a big competitor, Bloomberg L.P., people briefed on the case said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIESEL, MARIE
description: RIESEL-Marie. On February 1, 1998. Adored wife of the late Nathan. Beloved mother of Daniel, mother-in-law of Sheila and grandmother to Allison and Johanna. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Tuesday, at 11:30 A.M.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Putting All the Eggs Into the Asian Basket; Hong Kong Company Looks Homeward
description: All around Hong Kong from Indonesia to South Korea to Thailand -- currencies have been collapsing and economies suffering as the typhoon of reckoning has swept over mountains of bad debt, crony capitalism and grandiose ambition.

title: CUNY Shouldn't Farm Out Remedial Programs; Where Fault Lies
description: To the Editor:

title: Hyenas' Big Bite
description: THE dog-eat-dog world of the wild, not just human interference, may be contributing significantly to the near-demise of the African wild dog, a very distant relative of the wolf. The wild dog is considered a ''critically endangered'' species, with only about 5,000 animals remaining in the wild, and may be succumbing not just to loss of habitat and human predation but also to thievery by spotted hyenas, who steal food the wild dogs work so hard to capture.

title: Students Sickened When Fumes From Coal Furnace Seep Through School
description: Seventy-five children, three teachers and a custodian were stricken with nausea, dizziness and headaches and 1,250 pupils were evacuated yesterday as carbon monoxide and other poisonous gases from a 70-year-old coal-fired furnace drifted through an elementary school in Queens.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAPPAS, JAMES G.
description: PAPPAS-James G. On February 1, 1998, of Fort Lee. Age 80. Beloved husband of Josephine (nee Gregorio). Devoted father of Anne Pappas Phillips, Esq., James G. Pappas, Jr. and Gregory A. Pappas, M.D. Loving grandfather of six grandchildren and one great grandchildren. Funeral from the A.K. Macagna Funeral Home, 495 Anderson Avenue, Cliffside Park, New Jersey, Thursday, February 5, at 9 A.M., thence to Holy Trinity R.C. Church, Fort Lee where the funeral mass will be offered at 9:45 A.M. Interment at West Ridgelawn Cemetery, Clifton. Visiting hours Tuesday 7-9 P.M., Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9 P.M.

title: Murder, She Wrote, and Why She Did
description: On a rainy winter's day, New York was giving a faithful imitation of London at its most inclement. Settling in to a hearty lunch at the Union Square Cafe, P. D. James sipped a glass of fine Bordeaux and warmed to the indelicate subject of murder.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: Anthrax Findings Fuel Worry on Vaccine
description: A chilling discovery about the possible nature of a Soviet biological warfare agent has fueled a debate among Government scientists as to whether the current anthrax vaccine will adequately protect American troops.

title: Mergers, munch by munch: Interpublic Group agrees to buy the feisty Carmichael Lynch.
description: ANOTHER well-regarded smaller agency is being devoured by an omnivorous acquirer: The Interpublic Group of Companies agreed yesterday to buy Carmichael Lynch, a creatively focused Minneapolis shop with a flair for feisty ads.

title: District of Columbia Expects Surplus of at Least $100 Million
description: For all its potholes, real and metaphorical, the District of Columbia has received solid proof that the financial and management changes of the last few years are finally turning the city around.

title: Glaxo and SmithKline Talks Send Share Prices Soaring
description: Expectations of a possible merger of Glaxo Wellcome with SmithKline Beecham lofted the American depository receipts of both companies yesterday and helped lift the share prices of other major drug companies.

title: INTERNATIONAL PAPER PLANS TO ACQUIRE WESTON PAPER
description: The International Paper Company said yesterday that it would buy the closely held Weston Paper and Manufacturing Company for $232 million in stock, extending the geographical reach of its industrial packaging business. Weston Paper, based in Terre Haute, Ind., operates one paper mill that makes corrugated medium, a material for corrugated boxes, and 11 plants that make the boxes. It has 1,650 employees and had sales of about $220 million last year. Weston's plants are mostly in the Midwest and the South, and there is little geographic overlap with the operations of International Paper, the forest-products giant, which is based in Purchase, N.Y. Shares of International Paper rose $1.9375 yesterday, to $47.625.

title: Barclays Sees Big Loss From Shedding Unit
description: The British banking company Barclays P.L.C. disclosed yesterday that it would report a large 1997 pretax loss of $:688 million ($1.1 billion) resulting from the disposal of its BZW investment banking arm. Analysts were surprised by the size of the loss, which reflected three factors: $:340 million for the withdrawal itself, a $:129 million charge to write off good will and a $:219 million operating loss.

title: Havana Journal; A Sentimental Journey To La Casa of Childhood
description: This is the moment when, in my dreams, I begin to cry. And yet, I'm strangely calm as I go up the stairs to the apartment of my childhood in Santos Suarez, the only place that, after all these years, I still refer to as la casa, home.

title: Hillary Clinton Lectures in Davos
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  Hillary Rodham Clinton, in a toughly worded speech here Monday, said American business leaders had neglected their own interests by failing to support "fast-track" trade negotiating power for her husband.

title: French Retailer In Mexican Talks
description: Carrefour S.A., France's largest food retailer, said today that it was in talks to buy the 50 percent it did not already own of a Mexican supermarket venture.

title: In an Antarctic Desert, Signs of Life
description: WHEN the explorer Robert Falcon Scott discovered the Taylor Valley in 1903, he called it ''a valley of the dead.'' As he wrote later in ''The Voyage of the Discovery,'' the valley's brown hills are covered with coarse sand strewn with numerous boulders. There are no plants on its hillsides and no fish in its lakes.

title: Opening Soon in Times Square: A Visitor Center, With Amenities
description: In a plan to provide New York City's first large-scale tourist information center, the Times Square Business Improvement District said yesterday that it would renovate the landmark Embassy Theater in Duffy Square into what it calls the Times Square Visitors Center.

title: Clinton Seeks $170 Billion for Research in Budget
description: Calling research and development the source of future advances and jobs, the Clinton Administration today proposed a large increase in research spending, including substantial increases for medical and university studies.

title: Doctors Press Oxford Health On Payments
description: Exasperated with the slowness of Oxford Health Plans Inc. to pay tens of millions of dollars in medical claims it owes, doctors and regulators are taking action against the company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JUDSON, VIRGINIA WALTON.
description: JUDSON-Virginia Walton. On Sunday, February 1, 1998. Mother of Cyrus Field Judson, III, Sarasota, FL and Virginia Judson Thornburgh, Washington, DC. She is also survived by seven grandchildren and eight great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held in the chapel of Goodwin House West, 3400 S. Jefferson Street, Falls Church, VA on Saturday, February 7, at 2 PM. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to American Red Cross, PO Box 37243, Washington, DC 20013; Hospice of Northern Virginia, 6400 Arlington Blvd., Suite 1000, Falls Church, VA 22042; The Children's Institute of Pittsburgh, Northumberland St., Pittsburgh, PA 15217; or a charity of your choice. Interment in Arlington National Cemetery, Arlington, VA will be private.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The reality is that people have just refinanced their mortgages, gone out and bought big-screen TVs to watch the Super Bowl, and can buy all the beer and pizza they want. If times aren't good, the President can do whatever he wants - go out and win a war - it's not going to be enough.''

title: Debate on Human Cloning Ignores Some Benefits
description: To the Editor:

title: Still on Top of the Mountain
description: Katja Seizinger was describing fear.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COE, NANCY B.W.
description: COE-Nancy B.W. (Penny). Cherished wife of the late Henry E. (Tony) Coe III. Beloved mother of NancyBell, Elice and Alexandra Coe, Cynthia Devine and J.T. Coe. Dear sister of Capt. (Ret. USN) J.H. Wesson, and loving grandmother of Taylor, Katherine and Manning. Mayor of the Village of Lawrence, Long Island, NY, 198081 and 1988-95. Longtime member and officer of the Garden Club of Lawrence, past director of the Garden Club of America, former first Vice President, Board of Managers, Episcopal Health Services, Diocese of Long Island. Died peacefully at home on Sunday, Feb. 1, 1998. Memorial service on Saturday, February 7, at 11 AM, at Trinity - St. John's Episcopal Church, 1142 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island. The family will receive visitors at home, 200 Sage Avenue, Lawrence, on Thursday, February 5, from 1-5 and 7-9 PM. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be sent to Bryn Mawr College, Bryn Mawr, PA. 19010, Episcopal Health Services, 333 Earle Ovington Blvd., Uniondale, New York 11553, or the Garden Club of America, 14 E. 60th St., New York, NY 10022. God bless.

title: Group Tied to 2 Bombings Says It Set Off Clinic Blast
description: Two letters claiming to be from the Army of God, a group that has already taken responsibility for a pair of bombings in Atlanta last year, say that it also carried out the bombing last week at an abortion clinic in Birmingham, Ala., where an off-duty police officer was killed and a nurse maimed.

title: Internet as Jukebox
description: To the Editor:

title: Just a Single Goal Is All the Help That Brodeur Needs
description: Say this for the Devils this season. Even when they're bad, they're still pretty good.

title: Nuclear Official Tours Closed Reactors
description: The nation's top nuclear regulator said today that much work still needed to be done before Northeast Utilities could expect to win approval to restart any of three reactors at the Millstone Nuclear Power Station here that have been closed for two years.

title: I.M.F. May Be Closer To Lending-Curb Idea
description: The International Monetary Fund, looking for ways to avoid a future Asia-style financial crisis, may be moving in the direction of endorsing rules that would prevent another surge in foreign bank lending. Such a surge played a key role in the Asian crisis.

title: Beating Victim Testifies in Murder Case
description: She was walking by the East River on an early summer evening when an arm curled around her neck and pulled her back into the dark. She fought and kicked and tried to scream, but the arm cut off her breath. Losing consciousness, she thought she was going to die.

title: Animals as Organ Donors? Not Until They're Germ-Free
description: IN a giant warehouse in Ohio, under the close watch of veterinarians clad in surgical garb, a company named Nextran Inc. is raising an unusual herd of pigs. The descendants of these swine, whose genes have been altered to make their organs more like those of humans, are destined for slaughter -- not for food, but so their hearts, livers and kidneys can be implanted into people.

title: AIDS DEATHS DROP 48% IN NEW YORK
description: AIDS deaths in New York City plummeted by 48 percent last year, accelerating earlier gains attributed to improved drug therapies, health officials said at a scientific meeting here today. They said the declines crossed sex and racial lines, suggesting that the new therapies were reaching all segments of the AIDS population.

title: COLONY CAPITAL TO ACQUIRE HARVEYS CASINO RESORTS
description: Harveys Casino Resorts agreed yesterday to be acquired by the investment firm Colony Capital Inc. for $420 million, including assumed debt.
