Harveys owns hotels and casinos in Lake Tahoe, Nev., where it is based, and in Central City, Colo., and Council Bluffs, Iowa. Colony Capital is a privately held company based in Los Angeles. Colony will pay $28 for each of the 10.8 million Harveys shares outstanding, or more than $302 million. Shares of Harveys surged $4.3125 yesterday, or 19 percent, to $27. Under the deal, at least two-thirds of the Harveys shares must be tendered to the offer. The transaction also requires the approval of gambling authorities.

title: President Offers the First Budget To Balance in Nearly 30 Years
description: President Clinton unveiled the first balanced Federal budget in almost 30 years today, cashing in on five years of cautious accounting and steady economic growth to offer new spending initiatives while holding out the prospect of a surplus for the first time since Neil Armstrong stepped onto the moon.

title: On a Mousy Scullery Maid Turned Princess
description: Weekend cast changes in ''Cinderella'' at City Center demonstrated that Ballet Nacional de Cuba is blessed with likable dancers.

title: Tightening the Vise on Iraq
description: As in the last fateful hours before the Persian Gulf war began, there is now a brief period when Saddam Hussein can turn away from military confrontation with the United States. By skillfully mixing diplomacy with the threat of force, President Clinton is giving the Iraqi leader a last chance to avert a punishing air assault that few Americans are eager to conduct but most will support. Mr. Clinton should exhaust the diplomatic options before he orders military action to commence. But diplomacy cannot be a code word for indulging Mr. Hussein's defiance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOCKTON, HERBERT JAMES.
description: BLOCKTON-Herbert James. Died peacefully at home February 2, 1998, surrounded by his family and devoted friend Bill Simpson. Devoted and loving husband of Lyn, adoring father of Bill and wife Kathy, Marilyn and husband Robert. Adoring brother to Lily Newton. Cherished grandfather of Jesse, Brett, Adam, Lindsay, Simone and husband Michael. His love, warmth, charm and gentility graced us for over ninety years and his memory will live with us forever. A funeral service will be held Tuesday (today) 1:30 PM, at the Larchmont Temple in Larchmont, NY. Interment at Mt. Hope Cemetery in Hastings-on-Hudson, New York. Memorial donations to Hunger Task Force, PO Box 375, Mamaroneck, NY 10543 or United Hospital Hospice, 406 Boston Post Road, Portchester, NY 10573. The family will receive friends at the home of William Blockton, 18 Leatherstocking Lane, Mamaroneck, NY 10543 on Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday 4-8 P.M. with services each evening at 8 PM. For more information call the John J. Fox Funeral Home in Larchmont (914) 834-0144.

title: O'Sullivan Going for Milestone in the Mile
description: At least once a year for the last 15 years, Marcus O'Sullivan has run a sub-four-minute mile. All told, he has run 99 of them, and he will go for his 100th on Feb. 13 in the Wanamaker Mile, the blue-ribbon race of the Chase Millrose Games at Madison Square Garden.

title: Gateway 2000 Hires Partners for TV Ads
description: Gateway 2000 Inc. has expanded its roster by naming a partnership of Corra Films and the agency DiMassimo Inc., both of New York, to create a series of television commercials for the computer company. The move comes only 10 months after the Los Angeles office of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles Communications was awarded the worldwide Gateway account, with billings estimated at $70 million to $100 million.

title: Japan's Bank Mantra: We're O.K., We're O.K. Right?
description: From the stratospheric heights of their board rooms in glass-and-steel headquarters far above the narrow streets of Tokyo, Japan's top bankers once gazed with pride on the vast commercial empires they helped build.

title: Video Replay Foils Northeastern
description: Instant replay, that prickly piece of technology, played a puzzling role tonight at the Beanpot Tournament, Boston's annual midwinter salute to college hockey.

title: Dress Code's Demise
description: To the Editor:

title: New Rules Will Force Doctors to Disclose Ties to Drug Industry
description: The Food and Drug Administration today tackled the thorny issue of financial ties between doctors and the pharmaceutical industry, requiring that physicians who test new drugs and medical devices disclose whether they have received stock, consulting fees or other financial support from the manufacturers.

title: Retreat From Alcohol, Return to Reason; The Devils' Daneyko Is Coming Back to Hockey, and Control of His Life
description: A month after the Devils won the National Hockey League championship in 1995, Ken Daneyko woke up one morning hung over and haunted by the realization that he finally had everything he ever wanted -- a beautiful family, a successful career and his name on a Stanley Cup -- yet he still ''felt empty, all gaps and voids.''

title: Milk on Her Lip, A Cabinet Chief Raises Eyebrows
description: Donna E. Shalala is sporting a mustache to promote public health.

title: Martin Gives the Court A Look at Disfigured Leg
description: The heart of Casey Martin's two-month legal fight to force the PGA Tour to let him use a golf cart is his degenerative physical condition: a rare circulatory disorder in his leg that makes daily activities painful.

title: U.S. Reviews Police Killing of Unarmed Man
description: A Federal prosecutor said yesterday that his office was reviewing the case of a police officer who shot and killed an unarmed man in Brooklyn to determine whether a civil rights investigation should be initiated. A state grand jury found Friday that the officer's action was justified.

title: When It's Time For Filming, A House Can Be a Star; Striking Modernist Homes In Hollywood Are Used To Set the Tone for Movies
description: Evil somehow seems more palatable when it comes dressed in a tux. In the case of ''L.A. Confidential,'' the movie's dinner jacket takes the form of the crisp white cliffside house in the Hollywood Hills that was designed in the late 1920's by Richard Neutra. The house is presented as the home of a character in the thriller about police corruption and sordid doings in Hollywood.

title: Clinton Sees $1.1 Trillion in Excess Revenue in Decade
description: President Clinton said today that he foresaw budget surpluses totaling $1.1 trillion over the next decade, far more than the Congressional Budget Office anticipates.

title: Gaullists Look for a New Start but Decide Against a New Name
description: Defeated in last year's legislative elections, President Jacques Chirac's Rally for the Republic party vowed at a convention here this past weekend to do better next time and almost changed its name to get a fresh start.

title: Q&A
description: Precious Chalk

title: Texas, in First Time In 135 Years, Is Set To Execute Woman
description: Clearing the way for Texas' first execution of a woman in 135 years, the state's Board of Pardons and Paroles turned down a clemency request today from Karla Faye Tucker, a pickax murderer and born-again Christian whose plea for life has drawn worldwide attention and rekindled the nation's debate over the death penalty.

title: Parents and Two Girls Die in House Fire
description: A suspicious house fire early today caused the deaths of a couple and their two children in Salem County.

title: Mondelo Wants Team To Shed Smurfs Label
description: Alfonso Mondelo, the MetroStars' fourth coach in three years, is determined to erase the club's reputation for being intimidated by bigger opponents. Yesterday, Mondelo improved the left fullback position by signing JosE Arley Palacios of Colombia.

title: Nation Through a Looking Glass, Smudges, Cracks, Distortions and All
description: Major national events often serve as mirrors in which the country sees itself reflected in surprising new ways.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASH, WILLIAM BRADBURY.
description: CASH-William Bradbury. Formerly of Minneapolis, died on January 30, 1998. A graduate of Dartmouth College, he joined the Navy and was one of the first graduates of the ''90 Day'' officer school at Annapolis. He was a vice president of General Mills, and in 1963 joined United Biscuit Company as Executive Vice President. He was instrumental in changing the name of the company to Keebler. In 1967 he became President of Hanes Corporation in Winston-Salem, NC. After leaving Hanes he became co-founder of Turnpike Properties, Inc., a commercial real estate developer. Surviving are his wife, Nancy Kirkpatrick Cash; 3 daughters: Penelope A. Cash of Seattle, Washington, Nancy C. Tremaine of Fairfield, Conn., Louise C. Palmer and her husband, Walter C. Palmer, of Denver, CO; four grandchildren: John M. Tremaine, Jr., Hunter C. Tremaine, Katharine H. Tremaine, Alexandra Tremaine, and step-grandson, Andrew Palmer. A memorial service was held at St. Paul's Episcopal in Winston-Salem on Monday, February 2, at 2 PM.

title: Islanders Begin Push For Playoffs
description: There may be hope for the Islanders yet.

title: Prudence on Asia
description: To the Editor:

title: Homelessness Takes Toll on All of Us
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELLER, ROSE C.
description: HELLER-Rose C. On February 2, 1998. Beloved mother of Franny Heller Zorn, cherished grandmother of Danny and Katie, loving mother-in-law of Richard, devoted wife of the recently deceased Samuel. Services Private.

title: MONTGOMERY WARD HIRES HELP TO EXPLORE UNIT'S OPTIONS
description: The Montgomery Ward Holding Corporation said yesterday that it had hired the investment bankers Lazard, Freres & Company and Furman Selz Inc. to ''explore options'' in connection with its Signature Group direct-marketing unit. Montgomery Ward, the 125-year-old Chicago-based retailer, filed for bankruptcy protection in July. But Signature, which has annual sales of $830 million, was not part of the filing. HFS Inc., now the Cendant Corporation, offered $1 billion for the unit in July, but Montgomery Ward officials rejected the offer. Along with direct marketing, Signature offers life and property insurance to customers.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Warning by Chip Maker Causes Its Stock to Tumble

title: Stood Up for Iraq
description: When the guest is BILL RICHARDSON, the chief American delegate to the United Nations, the date of your dinner party may be subject to change. LYNN FORESTER, who organized the gathering for the Women's Policy Round Table, a group of women in business and the news media, has discovered this. She had to call 25 women who had R.S.V.P.'d for Thursday, including DIANE SAWYER of ABC News, AGNES GUND of the Museum of Modern Art and BEVERLY SILLS, with word that the dinner had been rescheduled for Feb. 26 because of Mr. Richardson's mission to Iraq.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOEVERMANN, ELLA
description: HOEVERMANN-Ella. On January 31, 1998. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Tuesday, February 3, 12 noon. Burial at Woodlawn Cemetery.

title: Suspicious Fire Forces Evacuation of Bookstore
description: A suspicious fire broke out in the bathroom of a Barnes & Noble bookstore on Manhattan's Upper West Side last night, forcing customers to be evacuated and the store to be closed early, fire officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHAPIRA, HANS E., M.D.
description: SCHAPIRA-Hans E., M.D. On January 31. Beloved husband of Ruth. Devoted father of Ralph and Marilyn and Paul and Nicole. Dear brother of Kurt. Loving grandfather of Emily, Alex and Aaron. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Hans E. Schapira, M.D., Foundation, Inc., 335 West 246 St., Bronx, New York 10471.

title: Murder Suspect Arrested At Las Vegas Hotel
description: Anthony Libardi, a 56-year-old Long Island man sought in the murder of Donna Bocklet, 41, the mother of two young children who was found strangled to death in the back of her van in a supermarket parking lot on Jan. 22, has been arrested at a hotel in Las Vegas, Nev., the police announced yesterday.

title: Benes Is a Long Shot for Mets
description: The Mets are on the verge of losing their last chance to acquire a top starting pitcher before spring training. A National League baseball official indicated last night that Andy Benes, a free agent with a 104-94 career record, has almost completed a three-year, $18 million agreement with the Arizona Diamondbacks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  D'ERRICO, WALTER A.
description: D'ERRICO-Walter A. Beloved husband of Susan. Loving father of of Jeanette and Paul. Manager of the City Midday Club. Devoted brother of Enrique and Alicia Carbone. Reposing Victor Quirolo & Sons, Inc. Funeral Home, 3176 East Tremont Ave., Bronx, N.Y. Funeral Mass Our Lady of the Assumption Church, Wed., 9:30 AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSHON, DOROTHY
description: HIRSHON-Dorothy. The Board of Trustees mourns the loss of Dorothy Hirshon, Trustee of Carnegie Hall from 1963 to 1987, an Honorary Trustee from 1987 until her sudden death this past weekend. Throughout her 35 years of devotion to Carnegie Hall, she helped save this landmark building from the ravages of time and revitalized it for future generations of music lovers. We extend our sympathy to her entire family in this time of loss, and celebrate her extraordinary life and legacy. Isaac Stern, President Sanford I. Weill, Chairman Judith Arron, Executive Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RYAN, REV. JOSEPH, S.J.
description: RYAN-Rev. Joseph, S.J. Of Fairfield University, January 31, 1998. A dedicated scholar, educator, spiritual guide and a persevering worker for mutual understanding of justice and peace in the Middle East. A Funeral Mass will concelebrated in the Chapel of The Holy Spirit, Campion Center, 319 Concord Road, Weston, MA, Tuesday, February 3 at 10 A.M.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about collaborations between magazines and movies misidentified the source of an article that became the basis for the film ''Urban Cowboy.'' It was Esquire, not New York.

title: National Semiconductor Says Results Won't Meet Forecasts
description: Shares in the National Semiconductor Corporation dropped more than 16 percent today after the company warned that its sales and earnings for the current quarter might fall below analysts' estimates.

title: Von Bulow on Art
description: The letter to the editor of The New York Review of Books expressed dismay about the new Getty Museum in Los Angeles. ''The late J. PAUL GETTY was a Jamesian American with a great love for Europe and European art,'' it said. ''The terms establishing the foundation obliged the trustees to name this building after the founder. He might have been happier if they had not done so.''

title: Gill Ready To Forget First Half Of Season
description: The All-Star Game break cannot come too soon for Kendall Gill.

title: TV Guide Officials Named to New Jobs
description: Two high-ranking executives at TV Guide magazine are being simultaneously shifted to new positions at News America Marketing, which like TV Guide is owned by the News Corporation.

title: Sports of The Times; All Together, Applause For Watson
description: IT was only a matter of time before George Steinbrenner's last straw would break Bob Watson's back.

title: FIRSTBANK OF ILLINOIS TO BE ACQUIRED BY RIVAL
description: The Mercantile Bancorporation agreed yesterday to acquire a rival Midwestern banking company, the Firstbank of Illinois Company, for $697 million in stock. Mercantile said the merger would make it the biggest bank in Illinois outside the Chicago area. Mercantile, based in St. Louis, has $30 billion in assets and more than 500 branches in five states. Firstbank, of Springfield, Ill., has $2.2 billion in assets and operates 48 offices in Illinois and Missouri. Under the agreement, Firstbank's shareholders would receive 0.8308 Mercantile share for each Firstbank share. Shares of Firstbank rose $3.625 yesterday, to $41.625, while Mercantile's shares rose 62.5 cents, to $51.125.

title: So Much More Than a Deadly Sin
description: Well, you can't be too hard on a television program that advances the proposition that Michael Milken did more for the world than Mother Theresa. You can hear it in the course of John Stossel's celebration of greed tonight on ABC. I'm not sure how serious Mr. Stossel is about all this, but give him points for nerve.

title: The Sale of Tokens Ends At 6 Tunnels and Bridges
description: The bridge and tunnel token is one step closer to becoming a collector's item.

title: Willful, Self-Centered And Basically a Pain
description: PRESTON FALLS

title: COMMODITIES
description: ORANGE JUICE TUMBLES. Frozen concentrated orange juice fell more than 4 percent on signs that Florida would have a bumper crop despite heavy rain in December. The March contract, which had risen 25.7 percent since Jan. 9, fell 4.5 cents, to 98.65 cents a pound on the New York Cotton Exchange.

title: On My Mind; A Story of Two Stories
description: If it is a real press blooper you are looking for, one with the legs to carry it into journalistic history, it's not about what the papers and TV have been reporting these past few weeks but what they have not.

title: U.N. Council Asked to Raise Limit on Sale Of Iraqi Oil
description: Acknowledging the widespread deprivation that international sanctions have inflicted on the Iraqi people, Secretary General Kofi Annan asked the Security Council today to more than double the amount of oil that Baghdad is permitted to sell to pay for food, medicine and repairs of its deteriorating infrastructure.

title: The Boss Versus the Bull
description: ALL IN HIS MIND -- Asked about the identity of George Steinbrenner's baseball people, Bob Watson says, ''Little people that run around in his head are his baseball people.'' Watson insists it is a joke; Steinbrenner does not laugh.

title: Alfred Maumenee, Eye Surgeon, 84; Directed Institute
description: Alfred Edward Maumenee, director emeritus of the Wilmer Eye Institute at the Johns Hopkins Medical Institutions, died on Jan. 18 at his home in Port Clear, Ala. He was 84 and lived in Stevenson, Md., until his retirement in 1991.

title: Russia Announces a Deal; Iraq Says 'No Such Thing'
description: The Kremlin, trying yet again to assert itself in one of the last places where its diplomatic power remains undiminished, announced with great fanfare tonight that it had cobbled together a deal to stave off an American air strike against Iraq.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLS, SANFORD
description: MILLS-Sanford. Feb. 1, 1998, beloved husband of the late Shirley (Levin) Mills. Residence 69 Boon Street, Narragansett, R.I. Dear father of Richard Mills, Hungary and Boston, MA., Dr. Keith Mills, Philadelphia, PA., Chana Smith, Brooklyn, NY, Ide Mills-Ratinetz, NYC and Joan Sullivan, Mystic, CT. Dear brother of Irving and Albert Mills, Warwick, RI and Reta Roseman, Yonkers, NY. Devoted grandfather of 10 grandchildren and one great-grandson. Funeral service 11:00 A.M., Tuesday at Mount Sinai Memorial Chapel 825 Hope and 4th Streets, Providence, RI. Relatives and friends are invited. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to United Jewish Appeal. Memorial observance at his late residence Tuesday thru Friday at 12 noon and at 7:00 P.M. Saturday thru Sunday.

title: British Insurer in Talks On German Acquisition
description: Commercial Union P.L.C. of Britain said yesterday that it was in ''exclusive negotiations'' with Munich Re and Allianz A.G. to buy their combined 95 percent stake in Berlinische Lebensversicherung A.G. for about $:191 million ($311 million) in shares. Munich Re is the world's largest insurer and owns 65 percent of Berlinische. Allianz, one of Germany's biggest insurers, owns 30 percent.

title: Treasuries Decline Sharply as Stocks Rally in Asia and U.S.
description: Treasury prices fell sharply yesterday, particularly among longer maturities, as the stock market surged on the heels of a rally in Asia, drawing investors away from bonds. The short end of the Treasury market, however, was also lower, but its losses were limited by a tame manufacturing report.

title: Metro Business; Boyd Sues Mirage Resorts
description: The Boyd Gaming Corporation said yesterday that it had sued Mirage Resorts Inc. over its decision to drop Boyd as a partner in a casino development in Atlantic City.

title: Four Are Finalists In Nordstrom Effort
description: Nordstrom Inc. in Seattle said it had named four finalists to compete in a review for the department store chain's first major national branding effort. Though billings were not disclosed, Advertising Age estimated them at $30 million to $50 million.

title: Nino Pirrotta, 89, Studied Music in Context
description: Nino Pirrotta, an influential Italian musicologist, died on Jan. 15 in his native Palermo. He was 89.

title: Budget Linked to Tobacco Pact and Other Money Sources
description: The surplus that President Clinton forecasts in the budget he sent Congress today hinges in part on his proposals for more than $100 billion in new revenue over the next five years.

title: Comdisco Officers Buy Company's Stock
description: Comdisco Inc. said today that its executive officers and managers had bought more than 4 percent of the company's shares outstanding for $109 million.

title: Increases Urged for Child Care, Medicare and Medical Research
description: President Clinton proposed expanding a wide range of domestic programs today, with initiatives intended to appeal in this Congressional election year to voters from soccer moms to retired workers to aging baby boomers.

title: Behind the Hoopla Over a Hormone
description: IN a culture that worships youth, many baby boomers and older people alike are ever in search of a fountain of youth. And if you believe the claims being widely disseminated in books, magazines and newsletters and on radio, television and the Internet, that Holy Grail is now available in dihydroepiandrosterone, or DHEA, a hormone that is selling briskly as a dietary supplement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUKE, DUNCAN M.
description: LUKE-Duncan M., 67, on January 31, 1998, at Equinox Terrace, Manchester Center, VT. Father of Gregory G., Manchester Center. Brother of Donald K. Luke, New Canaan, CT. A memorial service will be held on a date to be announced. Contributions in his name may be made to the Rutland Area Visiting Nurse Association & Hospice, Rutland, VT 05701.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERKE, HARRY
description: BERKE-Harry. Of Rockville Centre, NY on January 31, 1998. Former Vice President Sales for Maryland Drydock of Baltimore and Jacksonville Shipyards. Beloved husband of Marie (nee Curry). Loving and devoted father of Susan, Stephen, Nancy Johnson and the late Harry M. Adored grandfather of five. Reposing at Macken Mortuary, Inc, 52 Clinton Avenue, Rockville Centre Tuesday 2-4, 7-9 P.M. Funeral Mass St. Agnes Cathedral Wednesday 10 AM. Interment Cemetery of the Holy Rood, Westbury, New York.

title: A Warning About Chaos From Asia
description: The Clinton Administration's budget for foreign affairs is built on the assumption that prominent members of Congress will overcome their distaste for the United Nations and for American involvement in the bailout of faltering Asian economies.

title: A Circus at City Hall? So What Else Is New?
description: People hustled past City Hall Park yesterday with heads bowed, their faces distorted with the pain of another Monday. Many took only scant note of the seven-ton elephant in their midst, seeing an obstacle for pedestrians rather than a wonder of nature. But a few did stop to ask the very legitimate question:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAHLER, EUGENE W.
description: MAHLER-Eugene W. February 1, 1998. Of Hewlett, NY and Boynton Beach, Florida. Beloved husband of Irene and the late Lillian. Devoted father of Marilyn Konoson, Charlotte Wachsman and Howard Mahler. Loving stepfather to Joy Mazur, Beverly Sarachek and Laura Norman. Dear brother of Adair Goodman. Served as a 1st Lieutenant in the U.S. Army in W.W. II. Graduate of Horace Mann School and Columbia University. Service today at 2:15 at Boulevard Riverside, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island.

title: New Jersey Back Picks Nittany Lions
description: Eric McCoo, widely considered to be the best high school football player in New Jersey, removed a question mark from the Nittany Lions' depth chart yesterday when he announced that he had picked Penn State over many other schools, including Boston College and Wisconsin.

title: Foreign Affairs; The Asian Blues
description: World stock markets crashed to record lows today, setting off what economists are calling ''the Millennium Depression.'' The meltdown was triggered by the collapse of the Brazilian, Argentine, Russian, Indonesian, Mexican and Czech stock markets. These peripheral markets were dragged down after another devaluation by China made Chinese products so cheap that everyone else in Asia had to devalue again, and other emerging markets could no longer compete. In Tokyo, the entire senior staff of the Ministry of Finance were arrested and charged with incompetence. Their failure to stimulate growth, so Japan could absorb more of Asia's exports, resulted in all these goods flooding the U.S. instead, creating a record U.S. trade deficit and prompting Congress to pass the Smoot-Hawley-Gephardt Protectionist Act. With the Dow average having lost 6,000 points in two weeks, President Clinton sought to boost his poll ratings with the U.S. public by again seeing Monica Lewinsky.

title: Honest Talk About Parole
description: Gov. George Pataki's call to end parole for felons convicted of violent offenses may resonate with voters concerned about crime. But he is doing little more than playing to general frustrations and fears. If Mr. Pataki is serious about eliminating parole in New York, then he has to begin the hard work of producing a comprehensive plan that will reform the state's criminal sentencing system, of which parole is only a part.

title: Samuel Eilenberg, 84, Dies; Mathematician at Columbia
description: Samuel Eilenberg, an eminent mathematician and collector of Asian art, died on Friday at the Isabella Geriatric Center in upper Manhattan, where he had been for three months. He was 84 and had been a longtime resident of the Upper West Side of Manhattan.

title: That's Entertainment: Variety Goes Bicoastal
description: For Matthew C. Blank, the president and chief executive of Showtime Networks in New York, securing a copy of Daily Variety from Los Angeles has been an exercise in patience. A delivery service takes a day or even two to get him the newspaper. When he wants to read a Variety article first thing in the morning, he has to wait for his Los Angeles colleagues to wake up and pad over to their fax machines in their pajamas.

title: Error by U.S. Imperils Witnesses In Case Over Wall St. Mob Ties
description: In an extraordinary blunder, the Government has made public a confidential document outlining its entire prosecution strategy in an investigation of what officials described as the most ambitious scheme by organized crime to infiltrate Wall Street in decades.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAGAVERN, GERTRUDE LEWIS.
description: MAGAVERN - Gertrude Lewis. Suddenly on January 28, 1998, wife of the late Samuel D. Magavern, mother of James L. Magavern (Robin), William J., 2nd (Louise), Margaret E. Hargraves (Gordon), Mary L. Worrell (Richard), and Jane C. Beebe (Spencer). Also survived by seventeen grandchildren and fourteen great grandchildren. Sister of the late Barbara Howard, and Bethia Bunge. A Memorial Service was held at The Churchill Memorial Methodist Church, 8019 Boston State Road, Boston, NY on Monday, Feb. 2 at 4 P.M. Donations may be made to The Tifft Nature Preserve, 1200 Fuhrmann Boulevard, Buffalo, NY 14203, or Buffalo Seminary, 205 Bidwell Parkway, Buffalo, NY 14222.

title: CUNY Shouldn't Farm Out Remedial Programs; Just Like H.M.O.'s
description: To the Editor:

title: Footlights
description: EVENTS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FULOP, GEORGE D.
description: FULOP-George D. Suddenly on January 31, 1998, of Seaford, cherished son of Judith and Laszlo and stepson of Anne. Loving companion of Lisa Finno. Loving brother of Thomas and his wife Donna, and Jacqueline and stepbrother of Michael Grimes and Thomas Grimes and his wife Susan. Also survived by his nephew Michael and niece Erica. Religious Service Wednesday 10:00 A.M., at the Charles G. Schmitt Funeral Home 3863 Merrick Road, Seaford (two traffic lights east of Route 135). Entombment to follow Pinelawn Memorial Park. Hours on Tuesday 2-5 and 7-9:30 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRUCK, ABRAHAM
description: DRUCK-Abraham. The Jewish Center mourns the passing of the beloved father of its devoted member, Dr. Andrew Druck. May his entire family be comforted among all those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Jacob J. Schacter, Rabbi Samuel Goldman, President Elza Weinman, Sisterhood

title: Money Is Hypothetical, But Agenda Is Very Real
description: Eliminating the Federal budget deficit might help win President Clinton a place in tomorrow's history books, but his new tax and spending proposals just as clearly take aim at today's politics, offering a dissonant mix of conditional generosity and virtuous austerity.

title: Israelis Worry That Peace Effort Is Dead
description: In the view of leading Israeli commentators, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright's failure to budge Israeli and Palestinian leaders from their impasse over the weekend marked the end of the current American mediating effort -- and a low point in relations between Ms. Albright and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.

title: Chocolate Absolved
description: A HOST of foods -- like peanuts, pork, cheese, alcohol, citrus fruits and, most notorious of all, chocolate, all rich in chemicals called amines that act on blood vessels -- are widely believed to trigger headaches and especially migraines in many sufferers. But a new study of 63 women plagued with chronic headaches largely exonerates chocolate as a common culprit, even in people with migraines.

title: Roche Unit Genetic Deal
description: F. Hoffmann-La Roche Ltd. a subsidiary of Roche Holding A.G., has agreed to invest $200 million over five years in Decode Genetics Inc. of Iceland, the companies said today. Decode's research seeks gene mutations that predispose people to develop cardiovascular, neurological and metabolic diseases. Decode has the entire genealogy of Iceland in a data base.

title: CUNY Shouldn't Farm Out Remedial Programs; Merit System Works
description: To the Editor:

title: Florida Jury Urges Absentee Voting Overhaul
description: A state grand jury today recommended a wholesale revamping of the absentee ballot system here, saying its flaws led to voter fraud that ''played an important part'' in last November's mayoral election.

title: A New Competitor in 5-Cent Phone Calls
description: Talk is cheap these days, at least in New York and Chicago.

title: Baseball Lawyer Aiding Sprewell Defense
description: To prevail in his arbitration case against the National Basketball Association and the Golden State Warriors, Latrell Sprewell has enlisted help from the most powerful labor union in professional sports. Gene Orza, the associate general counsel of the Major League Baseball Players Association, is expected to testify today in Manhattan on behalf of the National Basketball Players Association as the hearing enters its sixth day.

title: Model of Anger
description: The made-for-HBO movie ''Gia'' had at least one fashion mogul dialing the lawyers. JOHN CASABLANCAS, the founder of the Elite modeling agency, sent HBO a letter threatening legal action over a character he believed they had, uh, modeled after him.

title: The President's Budget
description: President Clinton's budget shows admirable accommodation to political constraints. It sticks close to the tight limits set by last year's balanced-budget law and this year's Republican-controlled Congress. It generates a five-year string of surpluses without gutting important Federal programs to do so. It focuses more public spending where it is needed the most and deftly avoids squandering temporary surpluses on permanent tax cuts. The chief weakness is a speculative reliance on tobacco revenues and corporate tax hikes that may not materialize.

title: Clifford Siverd, 85, Ex-Cyanamid Chief, Dies
description: Clifford D. Siverd, a former chairman of the American Cyanamid Company, died on Jan. 16 at his home in Boynton Beach, Fla. He was 85.

title: Purchasing Index Is Off on Export Data
description: A closely watched gauge of manufacturing activity unexpectedly cooled in January as export orders slumped for the first time in two years.

title: Saving the Crocodile and Putting on a Spectacular Show
description: A GLINT of fascination shone in the face of Yon Ankikumur, a 10-year-old, as he looked into a mud pit here where more than 100 crocodiles were basking in the afternoon sun. Every few minutes, one of them shifted position, slid in or out of a shallow pool or yawned widely, showing rows of the teeth that have given rise to countless horror stories around the world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SENDER, SAMUEL
description: SENDER-Samuel. Formerly of Little Neck, NY. Devoted husband of Thelma, loving father of Carol and Russ Ketcham, Michael and Debbie Sender and Barbara and Joel Metter. Dear brother of Ann Alperin, loving grandfather of Todd, Doug, Danny and Max. Businessman, educator, professor and friend to all. For information Gutterman's, Woodbury, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEDER, GRETA (NEE LUSTBADER).
description: LEDER-Greta (nee Lustbader). Widow of Marcel and of Dr. Adolph Weissmann. February 1 after a short illness at age 92. After escaping from Nazi Austria with her family in 1938, she arrived in the United States and promptly helped her husband establish his medical practice in Manhattan. Her first marriage of almost thirty years was cut short by Adolph's death in 1958, followed by a second marriage to Marcel Leder, a retired merchant with whom she lived in New York and Palm Beach, Florida. She is survived and will be fondly remembered by brothers, Herbert Lustbader and Curtis Lane; her son, Dr. Gerald Weissmann of New York; her grandchildren, Dr. Lisa Beth Weissmann of Watertown, MA., and Andrew Weissmann, Esq. of New York; and great-grandson, Benjamin, of Watertown, MA.

title: A Showdown Over the Arts
description: The Clinton Administration's budget proposal for the next fiscal year seeks to restore financing levels of the past for the National Endowment for the Arts and the National Endowment for the Humanities, two perennial targets of conservatives in Congress.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, ELIZABETH S.
description: BROWN-Elizabeth S. On February 2, 1998. Beloved wife of Julian. Loving mother of Susan Toder and Nancy Schmiderer. Grandmother of Amy and Jeffrey Toder, Anthony and Emily Schmiderer and great-grandmother of Taylor Schmiderer and Celine Toder. Memorial services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 Street, Wednesday at 10:30 A.M.

title: The Neediest Cases; Boy Survives Violence Only to Face New Ordeal
description: The sound of shattering glass jarred Abel Marcial from his evening bath. As he came out of the bathroom, Abel, 11, saw four men climbing through a window from the fire escape, ski masks over their faces and guns in their hands.

title: Ex-Housing Official Tied To Threat to Kill Judge
description: A state grand jury indicted a former New Brunswick Housing Authority official yesterday on charges that he threatened to kill the judge, prosecutor and investigator involved in his 1992 conviction for official misconduct.

title: A Little More Money for Weapons and Repairs
description: The President's budget proposal, delivered to Congress today, increases the Pentagon's total spending only slightly, but it includes additional money for advanced weapons and new financing for spare parts and repairs to keep American forces better prepared for combat.

title: Clinton Budget Well Received in the Region
description: With a muscular economy fueling projections of surpluses into the next decade, the budget President Clinton proposed today would increase Federal spending on an array of programs important to the New York region, with education, heating, defense and housing programs benefiting the most.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLGRAM, RABBI ABRAHAM EZRA.
description: MILLGRAM-Rabbi Abraham Ezra. We record with sorrow the passing of our beloved colleague, age 96. Ordained in 1927, he served congregations in Wilmington, DE., and Philadelphia, Pennsylvania and then as Hillel Director at the University of Minnesota. In 1945, Rabbi Millgram became Educational Director of United Synagogue, a position from which he retired in 1961 and made aliyah to Israel. He is the author of ''Jewish Worship,'' ''An Anthology of Medieval Hebrew Literature'' and ''Sabbath, The Day of Delight''. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his son, our colleague Rabbi Hillel I. Millgram. Rabbi David L. Lieber, President Rabbi Joel H. Meyers, Exec VP The Rabbinical Assembly

title: Limited Horizons
description: Almost everyone agrees that schools need to do a better job of preparing students for the workplace. So the ''school to work'' programs now up and running in 37 states should be uncontroversial. Keeping employer needs in mind and preparing students to meet them, as these programs intend, seem sensible things for schools to do.

title: Margaret B. Kreig, 76, Writer Who Warned of Drug Abuse
description: Margaret Baltzell Kreig, who wrote about health and medicine and raised early alarms over drug abuse by American young people, died on Jan. 12 at her home in Washington. Ms. Kreig, a former resident of Manhattan, was 76.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOPER, EVE
description: COOPER-Eve. The Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations extends condolences to our esteemed friends, Barbara and Malcolm Thomson on the loss of her beloved mother. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Melvin Salberg, Chairman Malcolm Hoenlein, Executive Vice Chairman

title: Talk Champs
description: WILLIAM H. GINSBURG, the lawyer for MONICA S. LEWINSKY, boldly went where few Washington insiders have gone: he appeared on all five Sunday-morning talk shows over the weekend. That impressed ELIOT L. SPITZER, who as the chief of the labor racketeering unit in the Manhattan District Attorney's office prosecuted THOMAS F. GAMBINO. Last week, talking about the legal ramifications of the sex scandal, Mr. Spitzer appeared on 10 New York talk shows.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALLEN, LEONIE
description: ALLEN-Leonie. Died after a long illness on February 1, 1998. Mother of Lucienne Itkin and Mark Allen, grandmother to Michelle, Lisa, and David. Sister to Martin and Lila Courtian. She was much loved by all. Graveside service today 11 A.M., New Montefiore Cemetery.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article by The Associated Press in Science Times last Tuesday about a worldwide campaign to eliminate lymphatic filariasis, a disfiguring disease, referred incorrectly to the parasites that cause it. They lodge in the body's lymphatic system; they are not intestinal parasites.

title: Nabisco Picks New Officer At Snack Unit
description: The Nabisco Holdings Corporation said yesterday that it had replaced the head of its sluggish cookie and cracker unit, the company's largest division, in what Wall Street took as a significant move to freshen its business.

title: Proposed Clinton Budget Well Received in Region
description: With a muscular economy fueling projections of surpluses into the next decade, the budget President Clinton proposed today would increase Federal spending on an array of programs important to the New York region, with education, heating, defense and housing programs benefiting the most.

title: Hear the One About Letterman's Producer?
description: ''ALL right, here we go,'' Rob Burnett said, settling into a swivel chair at a conference table dotted with extra-tall cups of Starbucks coffee and copies of USA Today that had been consumed, one way or another, in the 25 minutes between when the meeting was supposed to begin and when Mr. Burnett finally walked in and called it to order. ''I think this will be another hilarious show.''

title: Stenographer's Dismissal Sought in Brawley Case
description: What might have been a routine evidentiary hearing in any other trial became a backdrop yesterday, displaying the increasingly frayed nerves among participants in the Tawana Brawley defamation case.

title: Driven by a Restless Unconscious
description: The notion of jazz as the great American stretchable art can seem a distant hypothesis at some run-of-the-mill club gigs, when the music feels fixed and hoary. But the truth is that jazz can do anything: take on sullen or prideful personalities, even set its own agenda. That's what the pianist Orrin Evans accomplished at Homefront, a midtown performance space, on Friday night.

title: Ulster Faction Issues Threat Of Attacks On Catholics
description: The Loyalist Volunteer Force, a Protestant paramilitary splinter group that has slain at least four Roman Catholics since Christmas, threatened today to kill more Catholics in an ''unholy war.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COBLINER, RUTH HAUSER.
description: COBLINER-Ruth Hauser. Beloved wife of W. Godfrey Cobliner, mother of Bennet V. and sister of Daniel O. Hauser. We will love you and miss you. We know you have found peace. For information call Riverside Chapel 212-362-6600.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EILENBERG, DR. SAMUEL.
description: EILENBERG-Dr. Samuel. Died Friday, January 30, 1998 at Isabella Nursing Home, New York City. Funeral services today, 11 AM at Nieberg's Midwood Chapel, Coney Island Ave and Ave M, Bklyn NY.

title: Asia Rise Aids Wall St.
description: The Dow Jones industrials rose more than 200 points and another key stock index set a record high. The gains on Wall Street followed a surge in Asian markets amid signs that the financial crisis, while far from over, may be easing.

title: Metro Business; Sprint Sues for Use Of Lincoln Tunnel
description: The Sprint Corporation is suing the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to secure a fiber-optic cable route through the Lincoln Tunnel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLAFF, MELVIN B.
description: SLAFF-Melvin B. On 1st of February 1998. Survived by his beloved wife, Mary; loving children Richard Slaff of Rockland, ME., Kathleen Nann of Dennis, MA., Stuart Slaff of Camden, ME., and William Nolan of Freeport, NY; brothers Myron Slaff of Scarsdale, NY and Marvin Slaff of Marina Del Rey, CA; grandchildren Zachary Nann and Liam, Chase and Gunnar Nolan. He was a distinguished veteran of World War II. He was formerly employed by RKO Pictures and was a retired Vice President of Robert Hall Clothes. Services will be private. Expressions of sympathy may be forwarded to Disabled American Veterans or Bide-A-Wee Home Association. His time with us has been cherished. His warmth and compassion will survive his passing and he will be greatly missed.

title: Commercial Fishing Boat Rescued by Coast Guard
description: A Coast Guard rescue ship was towing a commercial fishing boat and its four-member crew to safety last night after the vessel began sinking 53 miles east of Barnegat on Sunday, officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALVES, ANN DOUBILET.
description: ALVES-Ann Doubilet. Beloved daughter of Bobbie and the late Dr. Henry Doubilet, and sister of David and Jane Doubilet Kramer. Her untimely death came after a long battle with cancer, her passing was a peaceful journey in the Tibetan Buddhist tradition. She is survived by her husband Jose, and stepson Victor, of Crestone, Colorado. Memorial contributions may be made to The Great Stupa of Dharma Kaya, 1345 Spruce Street, Boulder, CO. 80302.

title: CUNY Shouldn't Farm Out Remedial Programs; Urban Success Story
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLESINGER, IVA (NEE WILLENS).
description: SCHLESINGER-Iva (nee Willens). On February 2, 1998 after a brief illness. Much loved mother of Jonathan and Jennifer. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Wednesday, 10 AM.

title: J. Scott Howard, Risk Management Expert, 53
description: J. Scott Howard, a risk management expert who was a vice president of J. P. Morgan & Company in New York, died on Jan. 14 at Mount Sinai Hospital after a long hospitalization for cancer. He was 53 years old and lived in Hightstown, N.J.

title: ALBRIGHT RECEIVES MEASURED SUPPORT OF SAUDIS ON IRAQ
description: After six hours of talks with Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright in a lush desert encampment, the Saudi Government issued a statement of support tonight saying that if diplomacy fails and the United States attacks Iraq, the fault ''would lie exclusively on the Iraqi regime.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GULLEN, HENRY S.
description: GULLEN-Henry S. The Board of Trustees of Parker Jewish Institute for Health Care and Rehabilitation extends sincere sympathies to Trustee Joseph Browne on the passing of his father-in-law Henry S. Gullen. Our condolences to Karyn Browne and to all the family. We hope the loving memories of him will offer solace at this difficult time. David Taub, Chairman of the Board David Glaser, President

title: Lewinsky Lawyer Cites Support of Israel
description: Well before he began softening his tone toward President Clinton this week, William H. Ginsburg, the lawyer representing Monica S. Lewinsky, was quoted in an Israeli newspaper interview as saying that as Jews, neither he nor his client wanted to topple a President friendly to Israel.

title: Bristol-Omaha Hotel Deal
description: The Bristol Hotel Company agreed today to buy the closely held Omaha Hotel Inc. for about $59 million in cash and stock, giving Bristol 20 Midwestern hotels and increasing its holdings of Holiday Inn franchises. Bristol said it would pay $19.1 million in cash and issue 1.43 million shares of stock, valued at $40 million. It will also assume $40.9 million in debt to acquire Omaha Hotel. The purchase gives Bristol, which is based in Dallas, 3,456 rooms in Omaha; Moline, Ill.; Davenport, Iowa, and Midland-Odessa, Tex.

title: Knicks-Heat Round 2 Means Fines for Johnson and Brown
description: The Knicks renewed their rivalry with the Miami Heat with two meetings in the past week, splitting the two games on the court. But the National Basketball Association had the last word when it came to these two teams.

title: Block Sells Worldcom Stock to Goldman
description: H & R Block Inc. said today that it had sold its 30.1 million shares of Worldcom Inc. to Goldman, Sachs & Company for $34.375 a share, or $1.03 billion.

title: INSIDE
description: Doctors Press Big H.M.O.

title: Insurer Takeover Fight Intensifies
description: The battle for control of an obscure Miami insurance company intensified yesterday when the Cendant Corporation, a leader in consumer marketing and franchising of hotels, accused American International Group Inc., the large insurance company, of false and misleading tactics.

title: Companies Would Be Given Rewards for Retirement and Education Plans
description: Businesses could receive tax incentives for expanding workers' pension, retirement and education plans under the budget President Clinton unveiled yesterday. The budget also would give tax breaks to employees who lose their jobs.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  JOHNSTON, ELBERT
description: JOHNSTON-Elbert. Blithe spiritleft us February 3, 1978. So long as we remember, you live. Mom and Wilvena

title: Melancholy Moments in TV's Coverage of a Scandal
description: In the respites among allegations, rumors, opinions, surmises, leaks, spins, slaverings and commercials, reputable television journalists are finding time to brood upon whether they are overplaying the White House sex scandal. They appear ready to make a deal with their prosecutors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAPERSTEIN, ROSE
description: SAPERSTEIN-Rose. Beloved wife of Sidney (deceased 1959). Mother of Marcia (deceased 1960). Passed away February 1, 1998 at her home in Wynmoor, Coconut Creek, FL., surounded by her daughter Sue, her niece Elaine and dear friends and family. She is survived by her loving grandchildren Sabra and Sofia, her brother Sid (Judy) Gold and their sons Richard and William. Before retiring to Florida, she was Executive Director of the Infants Home of Brooklyn. Interment will be at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, N.Y. Tuesday, February 3rd, 2PM. The family request donations be made to UNICEF Children's Fund in her name and correspendence forwarded to Riverside-Gordon Memorial Chapel, 6701 W. Commerical Blvd, Tamarac, FL 33319.

title: Metro Business; Savings Bank Going Public
description: Richmond County Savings Bank of Staten Island, a thrift owned by depositors, could raise as much as $238 million when it converts into a publicly traded company this month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RHULEN, WALTER
description: RHULEN-Walter, 66. On January 31, 1998 following a five-month battle against leukemia. Beloved husband of Judith, devoted father of Suzanne Loughlin, Harry, Erik and Anthony Rhulen, and grandfather of Juliette, Trevor, Zoe and Max. Memorial service February 8, 11 AM, Frontier Headquarters Rock Hill, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to The Walter A. Rhulen Leukemia Research Fund, C/O Memorial Sloan-Kettering, Box E, 1275 York Avenue, NY, NY 10021, or The Walter A. Rhulen Fund at Community General Hospital, Harris, New York 12742.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERMAN, JEROME IRVING.
description: SILVERMAN-Jerome Irving. Beloved father of Mark, Dara, Scott and Gregory, loving companion of Svetlana, passed away on January 30, 1998. Also survived by two sisters, a brother and his cat, Casey. Service will be held at The Palisades Presbyterian Church on Tuesday, February 3rd, 12 noon. Jerome will remain with us in our hearts forever.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDMAN, FAY KELLNER
description: FELDMAN-Fay Kellner, age 80, in Stratford, CT. (formerly of Bayshore, New York). On January 31, 1998, devoted wife of Dr. Bernard L. Feldman, loving mother of Dr. Alan Feldman, Heda Dadiomoff and Myra Hawkins, sister of Harold Kellner and Toby Stein, and grandmother of Emily, Max, Jason and Adam. Services were held Monday, from Cong Beth El Fairfield, CT. Contributions to American Red Mogen David or to Jewish Theological Seminary Library. Shiva at 555 Eleven O' Clock Road, Fairfield, CT.

title: The Mixed Message Of Clinton's Travails
description: The growing public support for President Clinton in the aftermath of accusations that he had sexual relations with a former White House intern is baffling many analysts and ordinary voters.

title: A German Bass Evokes Memories of His Mentor
description: The German bass Franz Hawlata, currently singing Sarastro in the Metropolitan Opera's production of ''Zauberflote,'' was a student of the distinguished bass Hans Hotter. Though he is just in his early 30's, Mr. Hawlata's artistry recalls that of his distinguished teacher. This was even more evident on Friday night at Weill Recital Hall when Mr. Hawlata presented his New York recital debut with the pianist Leonard Hokanson.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEALY, E. PATRICK.
description: HEALY-E. Patrick. Actor and graduate of The American Academy of Dramatic Arts, OAS Director, Peace Corps Director, Job Corps Founder, Harvard BA, MBA and overseas veteran of two wars, was born on October 21, 1925, in Chicago, Illinois and died of heart failure in New York City, January 31, 1998. Beloved son of Harriet Pardridge Healy and the late Columbus Healy, father of Timothy, Alison and Patrick, Jr., and grandfather of Ben Healy. Your family misses you and loves you dearly and hopes for your happiness wherever you are. There will be a gathering in Manhattan on Thursday, February 5. Those who plan to attend should call Pat Jr's voice mail in Los Angeles, (310) 470-9972. In lieu of flowers please send donations to: Monsignor Richard Albert, St. Patrick's Foundation, 62 Shortwood Road, Box 1285, Kingston 8, Jamaica.

title: Rosie O'Donnell to Act As Tonys Host Again
description: The comedian Rosie O'Donnell, who was host of the Tony Awards ceremony last year and helped land the broadcast its biggest audience in a decade, has agreed to be the host of this year's awards ceremony, on June 7.

title: Far From Home, an Ideal Crowd at Last
description: For a First Lady who had spent the last two weeks fending off accusations of her husband's infidelity, it might have been the perfect audience.

title: Next W.H.O. Chief Will Brave Politics in Name of Science
description: FOR Dr. Gro Harlem Brundtland, the newly designated head of the World Health Organization and former Prime Minister of Norway, the path from medicine to international politics was natural. After all, she was born into the Norwegian power elite, the daughter of a politically oriented physician and long-time Cabinet minister.

title: Patterns
description: A London Star at Barneys

title: Area Gains Under Plan
description: The budget President Clinton put forward today would increase Federal spending on an array of programs important to the New York region, with education, heating, defense and housing programs benefiting the most.

title: Additive Bolsters Baby Formula, But Study Favors Breast-Feeding
description: BABIES who are fed formula reap some of the same health benefits as breast-fed babies if their formula contains certain ingredients patterned after those in human milk, a large study shows.

title: G.M. and Daewoo Agree to Consider Variety of Business Ties
description: The General Motors Corporation and the Daewoo Group of South Korea announced today that they plan to go steady while negotiating a prenuptial agreement.

title: John T. Ellis, 77, Pathologist and Educator
description: John Taylor Ellis, a pathologist and educator who was pathologist in chief at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center and chairman of the Pathology Department at Cornell University Medical College from 1968 to 1994, died on Jan. 10 at Rhode Island Hospital in Providence. He was 77 and lived in West Kingston, R.I., where he moved from Manhattan four years ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHARDSON, JAMES A.
description: RICHARDSON-James A., 79. Of Haverford, PA., on January 31, 1998. Beloved husband of Jean Deming. Father of Susan R. Borchardt, Jerry, and Peter Richardson. Also survived by brothers Lewis and Philip Richardson; stepchildren Robert K. Keller, Jr., Peggy Keller and Ann K. Plumb and grandson Jamie Keller. Memorial service will be held at a later date.

title: One Man's Pest Is Another's Opportunity; Scourge of Unsanitary Canada Geese Opens the Way for Entrepreneurs
description: William Wharrie used to spend his days welding metal machine parts. It was decent work for a decent wage, he said, but nothing compared with the business he has created now.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIBACK, ROSE
description: RIBACK-Rose. 93 years old. Beloved mother of Marilyn Mernit and Arline Green, adored grandmother and great grandmother. Graveside services today 10:30 A.M. at Mount Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, Queens.

title: KOLLMORGEN EXITS AS DANAHER BIDS FOR PACIFIC SCIENTIFIC
description: The Danaher Corporation said yesterday that it was offering to buy the Pacific Scientific Company, a maker of motors and controls, for $375 million in cash, prompting the Kollmorgen Corporation to drop its rival bid. Shares of Pacific Scientific, which is based in Newport Beach, Calif., surged almost 19 percent, gaining $4.75, to $29.875. Under the deal, each Pacific Scientific share would be exchanged for $30.25 in cash. Danaher would also assume $60 million to $65 million in debt. Kollmorgen, of Waltham, Mass., initially bid $20.50 a share for Pacific Scientific, and later offered $23.75 a share. Shares of Danaher, the Washington-based maker of tools and components, rose $1.875 yesterday, to $65; Kollmorgen shares rose 50 cents, to $19.25.

title: Dean Foods in Deal
description: The Dean Foods Company agreed today to buy the dairy businesses of the American Stores Company's two California Lucky units for about $34 million in cash to expand its dairy network to the West Coast. Dean Foods, the largest dairy processor and distributor in the United States, will acquire four fluid-milk processing plants and an ice cream plant from Lucky. It will also acquire $2 million to $5 million in inventory in the transaction. American Stores, a food and drug retailer, is based in Salt Lake City.

title: Pesticides and Children
description: HOMEOWNERS who use pesticide sprays indoors may inadvertently expose small children to significant amounts of toxic chemicals, even if they follow the recommended safety precautions, a study has found.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CBL AND ASSOCIATES PROPERTIES INC., Chattanooga, Tenn., an owner of malls and shopping centers, bought the Burnsville Center mall in Burnsville, Minn., for $81 million from Corporate Property Investors.

title: Nissan Sales in Japan Expected to Show Drop
description: The Nissan Motor Company's sales in Japan may fall short of one million vehicles this year for the first time in 27 years, Tadao Takei, vice president in charge of domestic sales, said yesterday. Nissan projected in November that its domestic sales would be 1.06 million vehicles for the year ending on March 31, a 5.9 percent decline from the previous year. Mr. Takei said demand was sluggish because of a near-doubling of the sales tax to 5 percent from 3 percent in April.

title: Study Upbeat on Resilience of Elderly
description: LOSING the ability to perform everyday tasks like bathing or dressing without help has long been seen as a landmark in an elderly person's life, the beginning of a decline toward dependence on others or a move to a nursing home. But a new study shows that such a decline is not inevitable.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATHIS, HELEN JEAN (GIGI).
description: MATHIS-Helen Jean (Gigi). Died January 30, 1998, in Edina, Minn. Adored sister of Patricia, Mary and Catherine; beloved wife of Jeffrey Helebrant, devoted aunt and dear friend. Her generous spirit, infectious laugh, and selfless concern touched those around her.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOOTH, EILEEN F.
description: BOOTH-Eileen F. On January 31, 1998. Beloved mother of Kevin Booth of Princeton Junction, New Jersey, Carol McCallon of New City, N.Y. Loving sister of Marion Fajen of Des Moines, Iowa. Devoted grandmother of James and Brian Booth, Bill and Eileen McCallon. A Mass of Christian burial will be held Friday, February 6, 1998 at St. Augustine's Church in New City, N.Y. at 11 AM. Visiting Thursday, February 5, 1998 from 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 PM at the Michael J. Higgins Funeral Home, 321 South Main Street, New City, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAMER, PHILIP
description: KRAMER-Philip. The Officers of Amerada Hess Corporation express their deep sorrow at the loss of their esteemed colleague and close friend, Philip Kramer. Mr. Kramer's leadership as President of Amerada Hess from 1972 to 1986, and his advice and guidance as a Director of Amerada Hess from 1970 to 1993 were instrumental in the growth of the Corporation. His contributions have been of great value and will be missed. We express our deepest sympathy to his wife Sarah, his daughters Marilyn and Noelle and his son Glenn.

title: Watson Agrees to Part Company With Steinbrenner
description: Bob Watson has agreed to resign from the Yankees, apparently tired of his role as George Steinbrenner's often powerless general manager.

title: A Shocker That Aims To Preach
description: What a difference a word makes. That the current production at the New York Theater Workshop was a hot ticket long before it opened last night has almost everything to do with the gerund that completes its title, ''Shopping and . . .''

title: Rangers Nearly Waste 3-0 Lead, but End Slump
description: Despite entering tonight's game with a five-game streak without a victory and a ninth-place standing in the Eastern Conference, the Rangers still held reasonable hope for a respectable pre-Olympic road trip and a fair chance for one of the eight playoff berths in the conference.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, ESTELLE
description: COHEN-Estelle. On Jan. 30, 1998, age 100. Beloved aunt of Peter and James Herman, loving grand aunt of Wendy Krupinski and Geoffrey Herman. Dear friend of The Community Church, 40 East 35 St, NYC.

title: Calendar
description: Finnish Smorgasbord

title: Focus Turns Elsewhere In Newspapers and on TV
description: The bad-boy actor and the born-again killer finally pulled off what an army of White House spin attaches had not: They kept the President and Monica S. Lewinsky out of the big type of both New York tabloids yesterday, bouncing the story inside.

title: Stephanopoulos Testifies as Beset Lewinsky Flies Home
description: A Federal grand jury methodically heard testimony today about Monica S. Lewinsky's life and times at the White House, with George Stephanopoulos, former close aide to President Clinton, the day's chief witness.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISLER MINDEN, KATE
description: EISLER MINDEN-Kate. Died at 99 on February 2nd after long illness. Mother of Gerda, Sean, the late Fredericka, Michael (Phila.), Colin (N.Y.), Ernestine (Cambridge). Grandmother of thirteen. Services omitted at her request.

title: A Noble Cause On Third Avenue
description: The group fighting to save the miniature Regency-style residences on Third Avenue between 77th and 78th Streets has lined up a titled supporter with personal connections: SIR GUY DAVID INNES-KIR, the Duke of Roxburghe. The residents began tracking down boldface-name backing after they were served with intent-to-evict notices last year to make way, they believe, for a condominium.

title: Liberian Slayings Began Brutal Trend in Africa
description: When the militiamen arrived in this picturesque fishing village one August afternoon eight years ago, they quickly rounded up all of the Ghanaian immigrants they could find, marching them off together with Liberian friends and sympathizers for execution.

title: Jerusalem Journal; If It's a Hard Sell, Let's Try Beards and Yarmulkes
description: The two observant Jews sat hunched over sacred texts in the ornate synagogue, until thirst got the better of one. Fishing up a bottle of Coca-Cola from below his seat, he took a modest sip.

title: The Late, Great Fine Art of Butchering
description: Joe Maresca positioned a three-pound chicken, breast down, on the maple chopping block over which he has presided for more than half a century at S. Maresca & Sons Fine Meats, the store in Sergeantsville, N.J., that he and his brother, Emil, inherited from their father.

title: Holloway Leads Pirates
description: SETON HALL 68, GEORGETOWN 57

title: The Two Trumps, Coming and Going
description: It was one of those awkward 90's moments involving one of the most-photographed, most-chronicled couples of the 80's and the company they now keep. DONALD J. TRUMP and IVANA TRUMP bumped into each other at Nello, a restaurant at Madison Avenue and 62d Street. She was arriving to attend, and he was leaving from, a party at which the tough-guy actor MICKEY ROURKE was holding forth.

title: TV Notes; Dan Rather's Thwarted Travel
description: For weeks, Dan Rather has been giddy about going to his first Olympics, to serve as co-anchor with Jim Nantz at the opening ceremonies of the Winter Games on Friday. But there will be no ski slopes, no Olympic flame, no Nagano for Mr. Rather after all. The prospect of war in Iraq and the simmering White House scandal have combined to keep him at his anchor desk at CBS News in New York.

title: Benes Agrees To 3-Year Contract
description: The expansion Arizona Diamondbacks signed the free-agent pitcher Andy Benes, adding an experienced starter to their rotation less than two months before their inaugural game.

title: Metro Business; N.Y.U. Gets $6.5 Million
description: New York University has received a $6.5 million gift from Kenneth G. Langone, a board member of Home Depot and founder of the Manhattan investment company Invemed Associates, but instead of being designated for one of the school's prestigious programs or for the construction of a building, the money was given to the university's part-time, evening M.B.A. program.

title: Realtor to Pay $165 Million For 3 Helmsley Office Towers
description: The SL Green Realty Corporation chipped off a piece of the vast Helmsley real estate empire Monday night by agreeing to pay $165 million for control of three midtown office towers, including the Graybar Building.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARIS, SYBIL
description: BARIS-Sybil. Of Potomac, MD, died on Sunday, February 1, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Jules C. Baris. Devoted mother of David Baris of Darnstown, MD, and Susan Baris Mace of New York City. Also survived by one grandson. Services will be private. In lieu of flowers, expressions of sympathy in her memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: Robert G. Main, 80, New York Appellate Judge
description: Robert Gordon Main, a former appeals judge and Republican Assemblyman from New York's North Country, died on Monday at Alice Hyde Hospital in upstate Malone, N.Y. A native and resident of Malone, he was 80.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLER, SAMUEL STEPHEN
description: KELLER-Samuel Stephen. Age 71 of Woodcliff Lake, N.J., February 3. Beloved husband and best friend of Sonia, devoted father and hero of Marian, Allen and Jeffrey, devoted father-in-law of Glenn, Suzy and Adina. Loving brother of Iris, loving grandfather of Andrew and Rachel. He was born in Paterson, N.J. He graduated from New York University School of Dentistry and practiced for 46 years in Paramus, New Jersey. He was adored by his family, friends and patients. Services are 12 noon, Thursday at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, 150 Rt. 4 East, Paramus, New Jersey.

title: Airbus Wins $4 Billion Order From Iberia, Beating Boeing
description: The Boeing Company's main rival, Airbus Industrie, won a major contract today from Iberia Air Lines, which awarded the European plane-building consortium an order for as many as 76 of its medium-range, single-aisle aircraft worth $4 billion, the largest sale by Airbus to any European carrier.

title: A Portrait of Wilder, Billy, As in Wildly Original Films
description: Tonight's American master arrived in Hollywood from the Austro-Hungarian Empire by way of the Weimar Republic, but despite his origins and his accent, no one I know disputes Billy Wilder's claim to Americanism and mastery.

title: Settlement Talks Set In Girls' School Case
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew and Federal education and civil rights officials have agreed to begin negotiating a settlement that could decide the future of New York City's only public all-girls' school, city and Federal officials said yesterday.

title: Restaurants; A Touch of Big Easy, Ashtrays Upstairs
description: GRANVILLE makes me wish I smoked.

title: Corrections
description: A Diner's Journal column in Weekend on Jan. 16, about Sparks Steakhouse, incorrectly characterized the decor. The artwork and some of the furnishings in the dining room are genuine antiques, not ''ersatz.''

title: January Car Sales Slowed By Incentives at End of '97
description: Sales results released by auto makers today showed January got off to a slow start, partly because of year-end incentives that led many customers to buy in December. The Chrysler Corporation and three of the largest Japanese auto makers reported double-digit declines in car sales last month.

title: U.S. Says It Is Protecting Witnesses in Mob Case
description: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan said yesterday that they had taken steps to insure that the inadvertent release of a confidential document outlining their strategy in a case against suspected mobsters did not endanger the safety of victims and witnesses cited in the memorandum.

title: Assemblyman Wins Vote for Flake's Seat
description: Backed by the long-time incumbent and the Queens Democratic Party, Gregory W. Meeks, a State Assemblyman, won a contentious five-candidate race last night to succeed Representative Floyd H. Flake.

title: By the Book; Stews in the American Repertory
description: IN the introduction to ''Stews, Bogs & Burgoos'' (William Morrow, $25), James Villas proves there is a glimmer of unity in America's culinary repertory. From ragouts and mulls to braises and gumbos, he points out, Americans have made an art of stewing. Mr. Villas writes of these one-pot meals with such adoration, you can almost feel their succulence in your mouth as you read.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAMES, STEPHEN D. (''DAN'')
description: JAMES-Stephen D. (''Dan''). On January 30, 1998. Co-founder and longtime President of Citizen Exchange Corps, devoted to reducing U.S.-Soviet tensions. Husband of Teddy and, later, Denise. Father of the late Stephen D., Jr., Aram, Timothy, Megan and Caitlin. Grandfather of Sean, Lewis, Matthew and Marina. Memorial service on Sunday, February 8, 2:00 P.M., at Horne-Dannecker Funeral Home, 336 West 23rd Street, New York, NY. Memorials to the American Cancer Society.

title: Clancy Heads a Group Buying Vikings
description: On Forbes magazine's list last year of America's highest-paid entertainers, Tom Clancy ranked 27th with an annual income of $50 million. Yesterday, the 50-year-old author of such military thrillers as ''The Hunt for Red October,'' ''Patriot Games'' and ''Clear and Present Danger'' found a place to spend that money. He and other investors bought the Minnesota Vikings for more than $200 million, the highest price paid for a National Football League team.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAMPERT, THERESA
description: GAMPERT-Theresa. On February 3, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Maximilian. Loving mother of John Gampert and Patricia Lubin. Cherished grandmother of Robert, Erik, Michael and Andrew. Dear aunt of George Adin. Services Thursday, 1:15PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Dentist Arrested; Sexual Abuse Charged
description: A dentist on the Upper East Side of Manhattan was arrested yesterday and charged with sexually abusing two patients, the police said.

title: Study of H.I.V. Family Tree Pushes Back Origins
description: An analysis of a blood sample preserved since 1959 from the oldest documented case of infection with the AIDS virus called H.I.V.-1 shows that the first such infections probably occurred in people in the late 1940's or early 1950's, about a decade earlier than many estimates, scientists said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARZ, ERWIN
description: SCHWARZ-Erwin, 93. Of Tucson, AZ. Formerly of New York City and of Scarsdale, NY, died in Gaithersburg, MD, on February 1, 1998. He was married to the late Louise Lasker Schwarz for over 40 years and leaves his wife of 23 years, Julia B. (Judy) Schwarz, three children, Arthur of Scarsdale, NY, Peggy Akin of Phoenix, AZ, and John, of Tucson, AZ, eight grandchildren and ten greatgrandchildren. He received B.S. and M.S. degrees in Chemistry from Columbia University and entered the family business, Princeton Worsted Mills, in 1925; he was President of that company from 1939 until 1956. At that time he started a second career in education; after earning an M.A. in Classics from New York University, he taught Latin, Greek, History and Mathematics at Brooklyn College, NYU and the Fieldston School in New York and at the Greenfields School in Tucson. He also served as President of Westchester Jewish Community Services and Treasurer of the Arizona Friends of Music in Tucson. A man of wideranging interests and talents, he devoted much of his life to learning and to teaching; he loved music, gardens, books and, most of all, young people. A memorial service will be held at the Harmonie Club, 4 East 60th Street, New York, New York, on Sunday, February 8, at 2:00 PM. Contributions may be made to the Ethical Culture Fieldston Schools, 33 Central Park West, New York, New York 10023.

title: NATO: A Debate Recast
description: The looming Senate debate over NATO enlargement marks a historic encounter between good intentions and sound strategy. Despite momentum toward admitting three more members -- Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic -- the fundamental interests at stake demand probing examination of the specific candidacies, the approach that has brought the alliance to this fateful juncture and the troubling implications of that approach. Along with many who have worked to build a strong NATO, we harbor grave reservations about the pending expansion and the direction it points.

title: Gas Leak at School Stirs Debate on Replacement of Furnaces
description: One day after poisonous gases from a coal-fired furnace shut down a public school in East Elmhurst, Queens, classes resumed at the school yesterday, but only about half the students showed up.

title: John McGoff, 73, Entrepreneur And Conservative Fund-Raiser
description: John Peter McGoff, a conservative Republican fund-raiser, entrepreneur and onetime owner of a string of small radio stations and newspapers, died on Jan. 21 at his home in Charlevoix, Mich. He was 73.

title: Powerhouse With Stereotypes
description: In 1936, soon after the premiere of George Gershwin's operatic tale of black lovers in downtrodden Catfish Row, The New York World-Telegram published an article headlined, ''Negroes Are Critical of Porgy and Bess.'' Duke Ellington was quoted as saying, ''The times are here to debunk Gershwin's lampblack Negroisms.''

title: Commercial Real Estate; Offices Plugged In and Ready to Go
description: The Plug 'n' Go program, established in six downtown Manhattan office buildings a year ago to help attract new, small information-technology businesses to the Wall Street area, has helped lease 183,000 square feet of space and is expanding to three additional buildings.

title: Bills Seek Trash Taxes To Pay for Incinerators
description: A package of bills was introduced yesterday to tax private trash haulers and garbage disposal sites as much as 10 percent to help counties pay off a total of $1.6 billion in bonds issued to build incinerators, landfills and transfer stations under the state's old waste flow system.

title: The Neediest Cases; Gifts to Neediest Cases Fund Set Record
description: With more than three weeks remaining in its annual fund-raising appeal, The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund broke its previous record for total donations yesterday, making this the most successful campaign since the fund was established in 1912.

title: Rap Dream Is Dashed, But Not Abandoned
description: Every morning when James Anderson walked down Wilshire Boulevard in Los Angeles, he heard songs he helped write for Death Row Records blasting out of car windows. Instead of going on to bask in his success, though, he was on his way to work: scooping ice cream at Thrifty's. Something had gone wrong with his dream.

title: Earnings at Cisco Rose 30% Last Quarter
description: Cisco Systems Inc., the world's leading maker of equipment that links computers on the Internet, reported a 30 percent increase in quarterly earnings today, on an aggressive expansion of sales.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIELD, LINDA
description: FIELD-Linda. It is with deep sadness that we mourn the passing of Linda Field, V.P. of Sales. Our heartfelt condolences to her family and friends. AFD Contract Furniture, Inc.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COE, NANCY B.W. (PENNY)
description: COE-Nancy B.W. (Penny). Cherished wife of the late Henry E. (Tony) Coe III. Beloved mother of NancyBell, Elice and Alexandra Coe, Cynthia Devine and J.T. Coe. Dear sister of Capt. (Ret. USN) J.H. Wesson, and loving grandmother of Taylor, Katherine and Manning. Mayor of the Village of Lawrence, Long Island, NY, 198081 and 1988-95. Longtime member and officer of the Garden Club of Lawrence, past director of the Garden Club of America, former first Vice President, Board of Managers, Episcopal Health Services, Diocese of Long Island. Died peacefully at home on Sunday, Feb. 1, 1998. Memorial service on Saturday, February 7, at 11 AM, at Trinity - St. John's Episcopal Church, 1142 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island. The family will receive visitors at home, 200 Sage Avenue, Lawrence, on Thursday, February 5, from 1-5 and 7-9 PM. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be sent to Bryn Mawr College, Bryn Mawr, PA. 19010, Episcopal Health Services, 333 Earle Ovington Blvd., Uniondale, New York 11553, or the Garden Club of America, 14 E. 60th St., New York, NY 10022. God bless.

title: AMP of Australia Seeks British Company
description: AMP Asset Management of Australia agreed yesterday to buy Henderson P.L.C. of Britain for $:382 million ($626 million) as AMP, a life insurer and fund manager, further expands abroad to reduce its reliance on domestic business. AMP's offer was 1,645 pence a share, which is 6.5 percent higher than Henderson's closing share price on Jan. 27, the day before AMP first disclosed an interest in the fund manager.

title: Letting the G.M. Go, Again
description: Nobody argues with success more successfully than George Steinbrenner, who must have made Bob Watson, the Yankees' general manager for the last two years, unhappy enough to resign. During Watson's seasons with the team, the Yankees won the World Series and a spot in the playoffs. But, as Steinbrenner's former on-field managers know only too well, it is easier to shoulder the blame in the Yankees' organization than it is to share the credit. That belongs to the big man in the blue blazer and turtleneck and to no one else.

title: KANSAS CITY SOUTHERN TO SPIN OFF MUTUAL FUND UNIT
description: Kansas City Southern Industries said yesterday that it planned to spin off its fast-growing mutual funds business, pending a favorable tax ruling from the Internal Revenue Service. The holding company said last October that it intended to separate its railroad and financial services units by selling about 60 percent of the railroad to the public. The company said yesterday that it did not expect to proceed with the railway public offering until it had spun off the financial services business. The spinoff is expected to be completed by the third quarter of 1998, the company said. It plans to file an I.R.S. request within the next 30 days asking for a ruling on making the spinoff tax-free.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WATSON, EDWARD C.
description: WATSON-Edward C. Age 72, of Seaford, N.Y. Suddenly on February 2, 1998. Beloved husband of Dorothy, loving father of Darlene Barlow, Robert and William. Adored father-in-lw of Michael Barlow, cherished grandfather of Janine and Paul, caring brother of Vincent, Marie Kurtz, Isabelle Buccola, and the late Joseph. Loving uncle of many nieces and nephews. Reposing Wantagh Abbey, Inc., 3374 Park Ave (cor of Park Ave. and Beech St), Wantagh, N.Y. Wednesday and Thursday, 2-4 and 7-10 PM. Mass of Christian burial Friday, 10:30 AM, at Saint William the Abbot RCC. Interment to follow Calverton National Cemetery.

title: Where People Go Hungry, the Arts Are Starved, Too
