description: Every Friday on a narrow street in old Baghdad crammed with stationery stores and bookshops, a sad kind of ritual takes place. People from well-educated families bring out their private library collections, arranging volumes on the sidewalks or on cars, hoping to sell whatever they can to get them through hard times.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: ABC Stations Asked to Help Pay for N.F.L.
description: After an enormous bid of $550 million a year to retain ''Monday Night Football,'' ABC has asked its affiliated stations to contribute cash or return some commercials to the network to help pay the costs, according to a memo to ABC affiliates.

title: PROCTER & GAMBLE MAY SELL NAPISAN AND MILTON BRANDS
description: The Procter & Gamble Company said yesterday that it might sell its Napisan and Milton brands. P.& G. said it would sell the brands only if given an acceptable offer. Napisan, a laundry additive, is sold in Australia, Italy and Britain. Milton, which sterilizes baby bottles and other items, is sold in nine countries including Japan, South Africa, Spain and Britain. P.& G., based in Cincinnati, has said it plans to focus on more profitable businesses, including laundry brands like Tide, Cascade and Cheer and food brands like Folgers coffee and Pringles potato chips. Shares of P.& G. rose $1.8125 yesterday, to $81.3125.

title: San Francisco Theater
description: To the Editor:

title: Payback Time for the Jaspers
description: MANHATTAN 86, ST. PETER'S 76

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOOM, DR. SAMUEL M.
description: BLOOM-Dr. Samuel M. Of Longboat Key, Florida, formerly of Bayridge, Brooklyn died peacefully at the age of 95 on February 2, 1998. Devoted husband of the late Fan. Loving brother of the late Harry and Jack. Beloved father of Elinor and father-in-law of the late Dr. Murry Friedman. Adored ''Pop'' of Amy, Betsy, Geri, Nancy. Respected and loved by his grandsons-in-law and his great grandchildren: Colden, Madelyn, Meredith and Duncan. His legacy of generosity and love will be cherished in our memories.

title: Wine Talk; How Long Can Oregon Stay Low Key?
description: THE Napa Valley, with its high-tech wineries and imported chefs, its Land Rovers and croquet lawns and aggressively beautiful people, seems at times a sort of viticultural Disneyland, almost too pretty to be real.

title: Year-Round Schooling Imperils Hungry Students
description: To the Editor:

title: Surprises Emerge on an Airy Plain
description: Jerome Robbins's ''Dances at a Gathering'' was greeted at its 1969 premiere with the kind of rapturous acclaim ordinarily reserved for Broadway megahits. Nearly three decades later, the Chopin piano ballet, presented by City Ballet on Friday night at the New York State Theater, has settled into itself and become a rather somber though still exalted ballet.

title: Critic's Notebook; When All the Music Tastes the Same
description: The Time: About 9 one recent evening.

title: First Call Catches Earnings Estimates Error
description: First Call Inc., a Boston-based firm that tracks earnings estimates by analysts around the country, said yesterday that it had a data error in its first-quarter 1998 estimates that had led to a significant overstatement of earnings growth.

title: El Nino Effect to Cause More Harm in Southeast : Long Spell Of Drought Seen in Asia
description: BANGKOK  The drought in Southeast Asia will cause billions of dollars in damage and continue at least until March, climate experts said at a conference organized by the Asian Disaster Preparedness Center in Bangkok on Tuesday.

title: The Divorce Was the Easy Part
description: The addled romancers of Richard Dresser's ''Gun-Shy'' invariably shoot from the quip. The wife to her ex, smitten with a younger woman: ''She's adorable, and you've always been great with children.'' The younger woman to the warring middle-aged couple: ''I'm sorry, I don't know what older people eat.'' The ex-wife, about her new boyfriend, who's just been accidentally shot: ''Oh, it's always something with him!''

title: Are We Really Prepared to Invade Iraq?
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times yesterday about children's exposure to pesticides omitted an affiliation of the Environmental and Occupational Health Sciences Institute. In addition to Rutgers University, it is affiliated with the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Public Lives column yesterday about the rescheduling of a dinner party for Bill Richardson, the American delegate to the United Nations, because of a mission abroad referred incorrectly to his itinerary. He is currently visiting the nonpermanent member nations of the Security Council to discuss the crisis in Iraq. He is not scheduled to go to Iraq.

description: In percent

title: Food Stuff
description: Rent-a-Loft Party: Homey Without the Fuss

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEVENS, ROGER L.
description: STEVENS-Roger L. The Chancellors, Directors, and Staff of The Academy of American Poets mourn the loss of Roger Stevens, a generous friend of American poetry, an esteemed advisor to the Academy, and a member of the Board of Directors since 1982. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, Christine, and his daughter, Christabel. Lyn Chase, Chairman Jonathan Galassi, President William Wadsworth, Exec. Dir.

title: Campus Journal; Education Department Sues Universities Over Disclosure of Crime Records
description: In the latest round in the battle over the release of campus crime statistics, the United States Department of Education has sued two Ohio universities to prevent them from opening their records to The Chronicle of Higher Education, a weekly newspaper for academicians.

title: Year-Round Schooling Imperils Hungry Students
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MUBAREZ, RASHID A.
description: MUBAREZ-Rashid A. 2/4/622/25/92. Thanks for the gifts you gave us. We have not forgotten you and never will. Breck, Joey and Waulene

title: Liberties; Undercover Adviser
description: I sure hope he had sex with her.

title: Time With a Dying Mother
description: ''Mother and Son'' was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Lawrence Van Gelder's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Sept. 27. The film opens today at the Film Forum, 209 West Houston Street, South Village.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, ROSE
description: GREENBERG-Rose. 89 years old. Beloved mother of Helene Packer Kalisher and Eda Roth. Sister of Albert Loew. Loving grandmother and great-grandmother. Graveside services are on Wednesday, February 4, at 2:00 P.M.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Neediest Cases Fund Breaks a Record
description: Contributions to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund rose past the $5.1 million mark yesterday, breaking a record set in 1991-92 and making this the most successful campaign since the fund was established in 1912.

title: Harvard Faculty Hiring
description: To the Editor:

title: 4th-Quarter Net Declined Sharply at Sprint
description: The Sprint Corporation said yesterday that its earnings fell sharply in the fourth quarter as wider losses in its international and wireless ventures offset record revenue in its domestic long-distance business.

title: Journal; The Joy Of Sex
description: From day one, there has been only one man with the vision to see the story clearly, and see it whole. I refer, of course, to our maitre d' of feeding frenzies, Larry King.

title: A Youthful but Yankee-Wise Leader
description: Brian Cashman folded his hands, then unfolded them. He stared at Bob Watson, then stared down. Cashman listened as Watson announced his resignation as general manager of the Yankees yesterday at the Stadium, then reached up to hug him. After that awkward exchange, Cashman realized his life had changed forever.

title: Chief of Gtech Quits in Wake Of Libel Case
description: Moving fast to protect his company's dominance in the lottery industry, Guy B. Snowden, the chairman of the Gtech Holdings Corporation, resigned yesterday, one day after a British jury found that he had committed libel in connection with an effort to win a contract to operate Britain's national lottery.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about a decline in AIDS deaths in New York City referred imprecisely in some copies to the periods being compared for certain groups. The drop of 71 percent in AIDS deaths among men and 63 percent among women was in the last six months of 1997, compared with the last six months of 1995.

title: About New York; A Bronx Plea: No Garbage In, Garbage Out
description: THE Great Garbage Tour stopped on 156th Street in Hunts Point last Saturday, the bus nearly groaning under the shifting weight of its passengers as they rushed to one side and huddled against misted windows. ''Ooh!'' they cooed as they beheld a commercial dump where a bulldozer crunched through dusty mounds of splintered wood, old tires and smashed plaster.

title: Reading Between the Lines: Deciphering a Menu
description: IN the business world it is said that the less paper you carry, the more power you possess. The lowly district sales manager comes to a meeting with a bulging briefcase, but the chief executive arrives with a single sheet of paper printed with the day's agenda. So it is with menus these days: the more power and prestige, the fewer entries, the more white space.

title: F.A.A. Faulted on Fixing Year 2000 Computer Glitch
description: At its current pace, the Federal Aviation Administration will not be able to remove all the ''year 2000'' bugs from its hundreds of critical computer systems before the turn of the century, which could jeopardize airline safety, increase costs and delay flights, the General Accounting Office is warning in a new report.

title: Sweetened Bid for Energy Group of Britain
description: Energy Group of Britain received a sweetened $6.6 billion takeover proposal yesterday from Pacificorp of the United States, touching off a sharp rise in Energy Group's stock on speculation other bidders would increase the price further in a fight to buy one of Europe's biggest power companies.

title: Operating Earnings Up At Pepsico
description: Pepsico said yesterday that operating earnings from continuing operations more than doubled in the fourth quarter, its first earnings report since completing the spinoff of its restaurant businesses.

title: Jamaica Takes Heart In Draw With Brazil
description: To prepare his players for Brazil, the defending World Cup champion, Jamaica Coach Rene Simoes talked to them of David and Goliath.

title: G.O.P. Tries to Wrap Up an Airport for Reagan
description: The idea seemed straightforward enough, a heartfelt gesture to an ailing former President on his 87th birthday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASSILLY, RICHARD
description: CASSILLY-Richard. New York City Opera mourns the passing of a good friend and coleague, Richard Cassilly. He joined the City Opera in 1955, and over the years provided us with many memorable evenings in the theater. He has been a continuing supporter of our company, a caring friend and colleague to his fellow artists, and a dedicated teacher and mentor to his many students. We extend our deepest sympathy to his family and his many friends. He will be missed. Paul Kellogg General Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLER, CLARE NOLAN
description: KELLER-Clare Nolan. On February 3, 1998. Former teacher at St. Bartholomew's School. Beloved wife of Edward F. Devoted mother of Edward F., Jr. and Clare Shanahan. Grandmother of eight and great grandmother of one. Reposing Neufeld Funeral Home, 88-04 43rd Avenue, Elmhurst. Funeral Mass, St. Bartholomew's Church, on Friday at 10:30 A.M. Interment Calvary Cemetery. Please omit flowers.

title: School Union, Deep in Debt, Is Taken Over By Its Parent
description: The union local representing 22,000 New York City school crossing guards and cafeteria workers was put into trusteeship yesterday by its parent union after leaders learned that the local was $8 million in debt and that its officials had run up $800,000 in what were described as unusual expenses.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: 5 Companies Are Seeking Inter-Continental Hotels
description: At least five hotel companies are bidding to buy Inter-Continental Hotels, the Japanese-owned company whose portfolio includes some 175 hotels and resorts such as the Inter-Continental New York, the Mark Hopkins in San Francisco, the Willard in Washington, Le Grande in Paris and the Mayfair in London, in nearly 70 countries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRAYNOR, KATHERINE (NEE O'CONNOR)
description: TRAYNOR - Katherine (nee O'Connor). On Feb. 2, 1998 of Woodside, in her 95th year (native of Co. Roscommon, Ireland). Wife of the late James. Devoted mother of Kathleen Young, Gene and the late James and Anna. Dear mother-in-law of Kenneth, Margaret and Carol. Adored grandmother of Kathleen Duffy, Thomas, Kenneth and Kevin Young, Anna and Thomas Smith, James and Brian Traynor. Cherished great grandmother of Ryan, Sean, Patrick and Conor. Reposing at The Urban Funeral Home, 42-17 69 St., Woodside, NY today, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass, St. Mary's RC Church, Woodside, Thursday 9:30 A.M.

title: TV Notes; Tuning Out the Scandal
description: Against most expectations, news viewing has not soared during the two weeks of blanket coverage of the allegations about President Clinton.

title: Capeman Letters Inspire a Book
description: RICHARD JACOBY is hoping that publishing house editors like his book better than drama critics liked the Paul Simon pop-rock musical ''The Capeman.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAHLER, EUGENE
description: MAHLER-Eugene. Congregation Sons of Israel, Woodmere, records with sorrow the passing of its member and extends it condolences to the bereaved family. Bruce Ginsburg, Rabbi Dr. Saul I. Teplitz, Rabbi Emeritus Alan S. Roth, President

title: Seeking Clemency in a Labyrinth That Varies by State
description: The case of Karla Faye Tucker underscores how nearly impossible it is for death row inmates to win clemency. The right of a ruler to reach over the heads of a judge and jury may be as old as the Bible, but in modern American death penalty law, the quality of that mercy has varied from state to state and governor to governor, often proving to be quixotic, subject to political winds, and very strained.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Buffett's Company Is Amassing Silver, Pushing Prices Up
description: The company controlled by Warren E. Buffett, one of the best-known and most widely followed investors in America, has accumulated a large portion of the world's silver supply, helping to drive the price of the metal to the highest level in nine years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RESNICK, SAMUEL J.
description: RESNICK-Samuel J. On February 2, 1998. Beloved husband of Amy. Cherished father of Johanna, Leslie, Jonathan and Maxanne, and father-in-law of Michael, Lenny, Susan and Brian. Adored grandfather of Rebecca, Daniel, Aviva, Staci, Benjamin, Zachary and Gabrielle. Sam was a wise, loving and generous man, whose passion for life and learning is an inspiration to all whom he touched. Founding principal of Barbizon Electric in NYC, Sam served as Adjutant and Executive Officer, 15th Air Force, 772 Bomb Squadron, and as former President of Temple Beth El in Chappaqua, New York. An active member of Usonia Cooperative Homes in Pleasantville, New York and a lifelong Democratic Party activist, Sam was a powerful force for progressive social change and for Jewish education. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, February 8 at 1:00 P.M., Temple Beth El, 220 Bedford Road, Chappaqua, New York 10514. Contributions may be made to the Resnick Educational Fund, C/O Temple Beth El.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday in the Arts and Ideas section about freedoms and limits in intellectual life in Egypt misidentified the newspaper of which Anwar el-Sadat was editor. It was Al Gomhuriya, not Al Ahram.

title: Cuba Humanitarian Aid
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ALLEN, JARED DAVID
description: ALLEN-Jared David. We will love you forever. We will miss you for always. Grandma Fay, Grandpa Allen Aunt Sheila, Uncle Jeff Greg and Greer

title: Knoblauch Deal Looks Good for Yankees
description: Finding a free moment on his first day as Yankees general manager, Brian Cashman spoke yesterday with a fellow executive who asked about the trade talks involving Chuck Knoblauch, Minnesota's All-Star second baseman. ''I think we've got a good chance,'' Cashman said, according to the other official.

title: Eating Well; Government Weighs In With Advice on Pesticides
description: IN a new brochure to be distributed in supermarkets this summer, the Environmental Protection Agency suggests that consumers concerned about pesticides consider eating organically grown food. This unexpected advice from the Federal Government is another indication that it now recognizes the importance of organic food, after years of virtually ignoring it.

title: Stock Gives Rangers A Bonus By Scoring
description: His first National Hockey League goal wasn't scored exactly the way P. J. Stock envisioned.

title: Special Counsel's Case Raises Privacy Concerns
description: To the Editor:

title: The Chef
description: SO many of the curing and preserving techniques persist today less for their original purposes than because we've come to admire the flavors these processes impart. That's particularly true of preserved duck, which gains a delicate complexity during the process.

title: Taking Life and Its Scars and Pains
description: In his hometown of Chemnitz in eastern Germany, the figure skater Ingo Steuer owns a pub with a laundry room, so customers can have a beer while their clothes churn through the rinse cycle. If only he could be so creative in avoiding injury.

title: TV Notes; Mick Jagger Tote Bags?
description: The Rolling Stones, old hands at making money from their extravagant concert tours, have decided to help public television make money, too.

title: Richard Cassilly, American Tenor, Dies at 70
description: The American tenor Richard Cassilly, who was a mainstay in the heldentenor repertory in opera houses around the world for 30 years, died on Friday in Boston, where he lived. He was 70.

title: CROWN CORK TO REPURCHASE $369 MILLION IN STOCK
description: The Crown Cork and Seal Company said yesterday that it had agreed to repurchase stock owned by Compagnie Generale D'Industrie et de Participations of France for $369 million. Crown Cork and Seal, based in Philadelphia, supplies packaging products to consumer marketing companies. Compagnie Generale is a diversified industrial holding company. Crown Cork and Seal said the repurchased stock -- 4.1 million common shares at $49 each and 3.7 million preferred shares at $46 each -- represented 5.32 percent of its voting securities outstanding as of Oct. 31. Compagnie Generale retains a 4.99 percent interest. Crown Cork and Seal's stock rose $1.1875, to $50.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: In New Mexico, President Extols Work of Nuclear Scientists
description: President Clinton changed the subject from depositions to detonations today, visiting the Los Alamos National Laboratory to pay tribute to the custodians of the nation's nuclear stockpile and issuing a plea to the Senate to ratify the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty.

title: Look to the Past: New Jets Are Taking On an Old Look
description: In the summer of 1967, when Bill Parcells was an assistant football coach at West Point, he would drive across the Hudson River in the morning to watch the Jets practice at Peekskill Military Academy.

title: Accounts
description: * Midway Home Entertainment Inc., Chicago, a unit of WMS Industries, to DDB Needham Dallas, part of Omnicom Group, to handle the consolidated account for the video game maker, with billings estimated at $15 million. The account had been divided between DDB Needham Dallas and McCann-Erickson Dallas, part of the Interpublic Group of Cos.

title: The Undercover Shoppers; Posing as Customers, Paid Agents Grade the Stores
description: Most people might be mildly annoyed to find the Cracker Barrel cheese they saw advertised in that morning's newspaper sold out at their supermarket by noon. For Jim Jolly, it is an outrage.

title: Bits and Bytes
description: Past Meets Present: Medieval On-Line Feast

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIMMERMAN, DAISY
description: ZIMMERMAN-Daisy. On Feb. 3, 1998, beloved wife of Eugene. Devoted mother of Judy, Robert and Barbara Sirotkin. Dear mother-inlaw of Becky and Bob Sirotkin. Cherished grandmother and great grandmother. Services Thursday 12 noon at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: $25 and Under; In Search of the Classic New York Pizza
description: THE classic New York pizza is a thing of rare beauty. The thin-crusted pie is cooked quickly, with painstaking care, traditionally in a coal-fired oven, until the crust achieves a light, smoky crispness, the bottom barely charred. It is topped with simple ingredients: fresh mozzarella, tomato sauce or chopped tomatoes and the add-ons like sausage, roasted peppers and mushrooms.

title: Joe Boxer Picks Fallon McElligott
description: The Joe Boxer Corporation has named the New York office of Fallon McElligott to handle branding assignments, which had been handled in-house. Billings have not been determined. Denise Slattery, vice president for marketing for Joe Boxer in San Francisco, said that Fallon McElligott was awarded the assignment after a yearlong review that also included Desgrippes Gobe in New York and Landor Associates in San Francisco, a unit of Young & Rubicam Inc. The creative and media duties for Joe Boxer's advertising remain in-house, she added.

title: U.S. Forces Ready to Strike, Pentagon Says
description: Even if Saudi Arabia refuses to allow American jets to attack Iraq from its territory, the United States has more than enough firepower arrayed around the Persian Gulf to hit and cripple targets across Iraq, Defense Department officials said today.

title: Friend of Clinton Surrenders In Campaign Finance Inquiry
description: Yah Lin Trie, a Democratic fund-raiser and longtime Arkansas friend of President Clinton, surrendered today to Federal authorities at Dulles International Airport in suburban Virginia, months after he fled the country as the campaign finance scandals erupted.

title: Security Is Tightened After Attack
description: The police in Japan tightened their heavy security for the Olympics yesterday after a rocket attack at Tokyo's main international airport Monday night.

title: Citadel of Russia's Wasteful Health System
description: Tucked carefully into a pine forest, bathed in the sparkling Siberian air and filled with enough amenities to make a country club look Spartan, the Pediatric Tuberculosis Center here seems to sit on the cutting edge of Russian medicine.

title: Vitamins May Lower Risk of Heart Attack
description: A high intake of two B vitamins found in fruits, vegetables and other common foods appears to reduce by nearly half women's risk of heart attacks, a study has shown. The study also confirmed a protective effect on women's hearts of drinking moderate amounts of alcohol.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRUCK, ABRAHAM
description: DRUCK-Abraham. Young Israel of Forest Hills mourns the passing of its member, Abraham Druck. May the Almighty console the family together with all the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem.

title: A Dance More Elegant Than Warlike
description: The St. Paul Chamber Orchestra played reasonably well on Friday evening at Carnegie Hall. Still, given the group's fine reputation, and that of its music director, Hugh Wolff, the concert proved curiously unsatisfying. It seemed a worthwhile experiment, therefore, for a puzzled listener to continue the search for reasons in the orchestra's performance on Saturday afternoon as part of Carnegie's seasonlong series of Family Concerts.

title: Vote Allowed on Salary of Building Union Chief
description: Dissident members of the building workers' union asked a Federal judge yesterday to delay a referendum on the salary of Gus Bevona, New York City's highest-paid union official.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the renovation of the Embassy Theater for a Times Square tourist information center misstated the location of that theater and another with the same name in some copies. The theater being renovated is on Seventh Avenue at 46th Street, not on Broadway. A movie theater with the same name is still in operation on Seventh Avenue between 47th and 48th Streets.

title: Data Showing Economic Weakness Bolster Treasuries a Bit
description: The prices of Treasury securities rose slightly yesterday after several economic reports came in weaker than expected, providing further evidence that inflation is not a threat to the bond market.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NORRIS, PRISCILLA
description: NORRIS-Priscilla. Temple Beth-El of Great Neck records with profound sorrow the passing of its long time member. We extend heartfelt sympathy to her bereaved family. Shelley M. Limmer, President Jerome K. Davidson, Rabbi

title: INSIDE
description: 2 Injured in Subway Crash

title: Daneyko Returns to Practice With Devils
description: It was only a 20-minute practice, but Coach Jacques Lemaire liked the way Ken Daneyko handled himself on his first day back with the Devils after treatment for an alcohol problem.

title: High Intake of 2 Vitamins May Lower Coronary Risk
description: A high intake of two B vitamins found in fruits, vegetables and other common foods appears to reduce by nearly half women's risk of suffering a heart attack, a study has shown. The study also confirmed that drinking moderate amounts of alcohol had a protective effect on women's hearts.

title: A Pathmark Project With a Difference
description: In East Harlem, a plan for a big new Pathmark supermarket gave rise to a protracted battle between a community development group and smaller shopkeepers afraid that their businesses would suffer, with politicians lining up on either side. But in the Bronx, where another community group is trying to build a giant Pathmark shopping center, local merchants are among its biggest supporters.

title: Soldier's Court-Martial Provides Look at Leniency for Top Officers
description: The court-martial of Sgt. Maj. Gene C. McKinney, formerly the Army's highest-ranking enlisted soldier, has opened a rare window on how the service has recently dealt with sexual misconduct charges against its top officers, who were generally reprimanded and occasionally denied promotion but never prosecuted or disciplined.

title: Special Counsel's Case Raises Privacy Concerns; Everyday Tactics
description: To the Editor:

title: Europeans Call Penalty Barbaric
description: The execution of Karla Faye Tucker in Texas yesterday created a wrenching debate in the United States, but in many European countries the verdict was nearly unanimous: the American death penalty is barbaric.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KURASH, ISAAC L.
description: KURASH-Isaac L. On February 2, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Jeanette. Devoted father of AmyBeth Hanover and Rebecca-Sue Levine. Cherished grandfather of Lawrence and Justin. Adored great - grandfather of Austin James. Services on Wednesday, at 10 A.M., at ''Gutterman's Inc'', 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, Long Island.

title: Investor Optimism Over Earnings Sends Market Higher
description: Continued investor optimism over corporate earnings helped Wall Street weather early selling yesterday as stocks finished higher for a second day.

title: Tucker Case May Split Evangelical Christians
description: For some influential evangelical Christians, saving the life of Karla Faye Tucker became such a cause that some say her case might prompt reconsideration of the staunch support for the death penalty among many evangelicals.

title: Temptation; Mail-Order Breads From Wolverine Country
description: PEOPLE mail order breads from Zingerman's in Ann Arbor, Mich., not because they can't buy good bread where they live. They order because they can't buy these breads -- pecan raisin, Parmesan pepper, chocolate cherry and more -- a baker's dozen of big loaves with thick, crisp crusts and rich insides that require thoughtful, even contemplative chewing.

title: Saudi Bases Not Essential
description: Even without using Saudi territory, the United States has more than enough firepower in the region to attack Iraq, officials say. Page A8.

title: Clifford and Altman Settle With Fed Over B.C.C.I.
description: Resolving one of the last actions against them stemming from the 1991 collapse of the Bank of Credit and Commerce International, Clark M. Clifford, a former Presidential adviser, and his law partner, Robert A. Altman, have reached a $5 million settlement with the Federal Reserve.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WENDER, LEONARD L. (POP)
description: WENDER-Leonard L. (Pop) We will never stop missing and loving you. Sylvia, Stephen, Sharon, Toby, Alison, Matthew, Jaime

title: GLOBAL INDUSTRIAL TO SELL INTOOL SUBSIDIARY
description: Global Industrial Technologies Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Intool subsidiary to Cooper Industries. Financial terms of the deal were not disclosed. Global Industrial, an industrial products maker based in Dallas, said the sale was part of its plan to focus on its Ameri-Forge and refractories industry businesses. Intool, which makes tools designed for the aircraft, motor vehicle, energy and industrial markets, had 1997 revenues of $113 million. Cooper, a maker of electrical products based in Houston, with 1997 revenues of $5.3 billion, said Intool would become part of its power-tools subsidiary.

title: Officer Is Arrested In Civil Rights Case
description: A veteran Paterson police officer charged last month with assaulting four men while arresting them on minor charges was taken into custody yesterday when a Federal indictment was unsealed charging him with violating the men's civil rights.

title: The Business Community Steps Up
description: One of the city's largest business groups has just committed $30 million to sweeten the paychecks of superintendents, principals and teachers if they raise academic performance in some of the city's most troubled districts. The bonus plan put forth by the New York City Partnership is not a cure-all and needs refinements. But it represents a welcome realization that the problems of New York City's schools warrant private-sector help.

title: Business Travel; Air accord is likely to bring some lower fares to Japan and deeper discounts to the rest of Asia.
description: THE full impact of last week's agreement to end most restrictions on air travel between the United States and Japan will not be known for at least a couple of years, airline analysts say. In the meantime, air fares between the two nations are expected to fall but not tumble, while fares to other Asian destinations could plummet -- but only if political, economic and environmental problems continue to batter the region.

title: Critic's Notebook; Shared Sentiments and Visions in a Revolution Redux
description: Sometime during the second act of ''Ragtime,'' the new Broadway show based on the E. L. Doctorow novel, an odd sense of deja vu crept into consciousness. Some of this was to be expected. Deja vu is partly the musical's point. As we watch this political fable of the early decades of this century, we are meant to recognize events from the decade preceding the novel's publication in 1975.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''If it was just one hospital burning money, then we could live with that. But it is not one hospital. And it is not just tuberculosis. It is the whole story of Russian medicine.''

title: Echoes of a City's Shady 'Underself'
description: DEGAS IN NEW ORLEANS

title: Carlesimo Is Up Next At Hearing on Sprewell
description: More than two months after he was attacked in practice by Latrell Sprewell, Golden State Warriors Coach P. J. Carlesimo will testify today in Sprewell's arbitration case.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNLAP, JOHN R.
description: DUNLAP-John R. On January 31st at age 70. Beloved husband of Bobbie. Loving father to Paige, Susan and Sally. Grandfather to six. Memorial service in Baltimore on February 7, 1998.

title: United States Resorts Show Their Support for the Games
description: When it comes to offering a glimpse of the Olympic Games a half-world away, television has its place. But the art of promotion has found ways to allow skiers and snowboarders to get their fill of the Olympics while still getting in some time on the snow at United States ski areas.

title: 20 Die in Italy As U.S. Jet Cuts A Ski Lift Cable
description: A low-flying United States military jet on a training flight over the craggy Dolomite mountains here cut the cable of a ski lift today, sending a cable car plunging 260 feet into a snowy meadow and killing everyone aboard.

title: IRAQIS COULD FACE HEAVY U.S. ATTACK, CONGRESS IS TOLD
description: As war fever gripped Congress, Defense Secretary William S. Cohen said today that if diplomacy fails to persuade Iraq to allow international weapons inspections, the United States would wage a ''significant'' military campaign against Iraq.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAFFE, EDDA
description: JAFFE-Edda. Cherished and beloved mother and loyal ally to her children Susanne and Brett. Loving Granny Ma to Gillian and Dorrian. Rest in peace eternal. Forever in our hearts with love.

title: A Voice of Reason Comes to CUNY
description: When Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani threatened to withdraw three-quarters of the city's financial support for the City University of New York last week, suggesting that others could do the job of remedial education better, the university responded not with a stinging retort, but with a conciliatory statement from Christoph M. Kimmich, the interim Chancellor, expressing a desire to work together with the Mayor.

title: Slushy Storm Is Not Expected To Change Low-Salt Winter
description: The words usually prompt glee in mischievous schoolchildren and overworked adults eager to play hooky: a formidable Northeaster is gathering strength as it slowly moves up the East Coast toward New York. But this storm -- like so many others this winter, which is proving to be the mildest in terms of snowfall since 1972-73 -- lacks one crucial ingredient for a city-paralyzing blizzard: frigid, Arctic air.

title: COLLEGES: MEN'S ROUNDUP
description: West Virginia 90, Pittsburgh 72

title: Leaders of the G.O.P. Begin to Assemble a Budget Framework of Their Own
description: Thrown on the defensive by President Clinton's budget, Republicans in Congress regrouped today and offered some of their own prescriptions for meeting the nation's problems.

title: Georgia Nears Accord With Inmates Who Say They Were Beaten
description: Prisoners who said they were beaten bloody by a special squad of guards as the Georgia Corrections Commissioner looked on have reached a tentative settlement in two lawsuits against the state.

title: Schumer Opens Senate Race By Claiming Centrist Position
description: In the first major address of his Senate campaign, Representative Charles E. Schumer outlined a detailed agenda of tax cuts and education initiatives yesterday, trying to position himself as a centrist candidate willing to embrace ideas from both sides of the political trench.

title: Menus: Challenging the Old Order
description: IN most restaurants, the aperitif moment is a time to relax. At March, Wayne Nish's restaurant near Sutton Place, vigilance is recommended in the early stages of the meal.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SORRENTI, DAVIDE
description: SORRENTI-Davide. In memory of Davide. We love and miss you, Mom, Steve, Papi, Mario, Vanina & Nonna

title: Calvin Klein's new campaign casts off the old stark, dark look and dons a happy, healthy one.
description: YEARS ago, ''Garbo Talks!'' and ''Garbo Laughs!'' were hot news from Hollywood; now, here's hot news from Seventh Avenue: Calvin Smiles!

title: Knicks Visit Scene of Accident and Fall
description: This is the spot, all right. There are no special markings on the green hardwood. No sign that anything significant transpired next to the base of the Bucks' basket.

title: Roger L. Stevens, Real Estate Magnate, Producer and Fund-Raiser, Is Dead at 87
description: Roger L. Stevens, the real estate magnate, legendary Broadway producer and bravura fund-raiser who enriched Washington's cultural life by finding ways to create the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts and by leading it for its first 17 years, died on Monday at Georgetown University Medical Center in Washington. He was 87 and lived in Washington.

title: On the Trail of Missing Antecedents (And Meaning)
description: An 80-year-old woman sits bent over a stack of galley proofs, pencil in hand, working her way down a seemingly endless column of type. Her pencil hovers, doubles back, alights to raise a query, then moves on in restless pursuit of precision.

title: Californian to Keep Seat Won From Nine-Term Congressman
description: A bitterly contested Congressional election in California ended in a resounding triumph for Representative Loretta Sanchez tonight, more than a year late, as a House task force found no basis for nullifying her victory over Representative Robert K. Dornan.

title: Sports of The Times; Old Shrine Finds Room For Guests
description: THE Buddhist temple of Zenkoji has survived 11 fires as well the incursion of the automobile and electronics factories literally on its doorstep. It will survive the Winter Games, too.

title: Are We Really Prepared to Invade Iraq?
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Paparazzi Convicted Of Stalking Celebrities
description: In an unusually tough ruling that seems intended to send a warning to photographers who stalk celebrities, a Superior Court judge in Santa Monica, Calif., has found two photographers guilty of false imprisonment for hounding Arnold Schwarzenegger and his wife, Maria Shriver, and blocking their car as they drove their son to school. They could face up to two years in prison.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Buffett Amasses Silver, Signaling He Sees Inflation

title: FORT JAMES TO CUT 2,500 JOBS IN STREAMLINING
description: The Fort James Corporation, the paper and consumer-products maker, said yesterday that it would eliminate 2,500 positions, or 8 percent of its work force, in an effort to streamline its operations in North America and Europe. The company said it would take a charge of $1.53 a diluted share, which would cause it to post a fourth-quarter loss of $1.46 a share. Severance costs connected with the layoffs will total more than $100 million. Last month, Fort James, based in Richmond, said it would close two tissue mills and eliminate about 520 jobs because of high operating costs. The company said production from the mills, which are in Carthage, N.Y., and Ashland, Wis., would be transferred to more modern plants.

title: Speak, Oh Muse, of Subpoenas and Scandal
description: A YEAR ago, not long after George Stephanopoulos officially left the side of President Clinton, his plan was to withdraw from what he once called ''the greatest drug I've ever experienced'' -- the 7:30 A.M. White House staff meeting -- and start a new life in Manhattan.

title: I.O.C. Asks White House To Honor Peace Pledge
description: Amid speculation that the United States might attack Iraq soon, international Olympic officials today repeated appeals for nations to avoid military confrontation during the Nagano Games, which begin this weekend.

title: The Minimalist; A Straightforward Technique Leading to Splendid Salmon
description: THE flavor of salmon is distinctive, but its character can be readily altered and enhanced with simple, creative strokes. Katy Sparks, 34, the chef at Quilty's, a restaurant on Prince Street, takes full advantage of that flexibility.

title: AMERADA HESS TO SELL 50% OF VIRGIN ISLANDS REFINERY
description: The Amerada Hess Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell a 50 percent interest in its United States Virgin Islands oil refinery to Petroleos de Venezuela S.A. for $625 million. Hess, based in New York, is a major producer and refiner of petroleum products. The company had revenue of $8.3 billion in 1997. Petroleos de Venezuela is the state-owned oil monopoly of Venezuela. Under the agreement, Hess and Petroleos de Venezuela will form a joint venture that will acquire and operate the refinery, which is on the island of St. Croix. As part of the transaction, Hess will record a loss of $125 million. The joint venture will enter into a long-term contract to purchase and refine heavy crude oil from Venezuela.

title: I.B.M. and Digital Describe Entrants in Chip-Speed Race
description: The surging power of the microprocessor chip is approaching another milestone.

title: Special Counsel's Case Raises Privacy Concerns; Attorney General's Term
description: To the Editor:

title: A Regional Taste Travels Well: Austrian Pumpkinseed Oil
description: IN Styria, the green, hilly region in southeastern Austria, the land gallops and rolls, folk costume is still customary -- and thick, aromatic, roasted-pumpkinseed oil is cooks' gold. The deeply nutty oil is coveted as truffles are elsewhere, and it is used sparingly but often.

title: Steinbrenner Aside, Watson Says He's Worn Down
description: If Bob Watson felt any urge to lash out at George Steinbrenner yesterday, he could not have been in a better position. As Watson stood at a news conference in Yankee Stadium, his letter of resignation was signed, a microphone sat an inch or two from his mouth, and dozens of reporters waited with their pens poised, cameras rolling.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THAI CURRENCY CLIMBS. Thailand's currency, the baht, has strengthened in the last three days, bolstered by rallies in the Thai stock market and in other Asian markets. Yesterday, the baht was quoted at 50.85 baht to the United States dollar, up more than 3 percent from Monday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RHULEN, WALTER A.
description: RHULEN-Walter A. Yeshiva University and its Wurzweiler School of Social Work mourn the passing of a respected leader in the insurance industry and Sullivan County community, beloved husband of Judith and brother and brother-inlaw of Peter and Eileen Rhulen, members, WSSW Board of Governors, and YU Guardians. Mr. and Mrs. Peter Rhulen established in their name a WSSW scholarship for students interested in working in the field of alcohol and drug abuse treatment. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARTENBERG, ANN
description: GARTENBERG-Ann. We mourn the loss of our beloved member and extend heartfelt sympathy to her family. Temple Sinai of LI Paula Jayne Winnig, Rabbi Evelyn Maltman, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILEY, W. BRADFORD
description: WILEY-W. Bradford. The entire community of John Wiley & Sons, Inc., deeply mourns the loss of Bradford Wiley, our retired chairman and CEO. Brad Wiley dedicated his life to publishing; he was one of those rare individuals who have influenced the course not only of a company but of an entire industry. His spirited leadership guided our company through four decades of significant growth and change, to its current position as one of the world's leading publishers. We will miss his wisdom, vision, determination, and charm. All of us here at Wiley extend our condolences to his children and our colleagues, Deborah E. Wiley, Sr. VP, Corporate Communications, and Board member; Peter Booth Wiley, Board member; and Brad Wiley II, Chairman of the Board and Editor. Charles R. Ellis, President and CEO

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISENSTADT, LOUIS V.
description: EISENSTADT-Louis V. On February 2, 1998. Devoted husband of Gloria, beloved father of Phyllis, Sheryl, Michele and Jodi. Cherished grandfather of nine. Loving brother of Elaine. Funeral Service Wednesday 11:30 A.M., from I.J. Morris Funeral Home, 1895 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn. Interment Wellwood Cemetery.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: City Proposes a Gift for Jazz: A Swinging Hall of Its Own
description: After wandering in the desert of Lincoln Center for seven years, the organization's youngest constituent, Jazz at Lincoln Center, seems closer to finding a home of its own.

title: How Did Nets Lose? Follow Bouncing Ball
description: Confusion reigned last night in the final moments of the Nets' 98-97 loss to the Trail Blazers at Portland. Three possession changes and schoolyard tactics in the last 1.8 seconds had the game officials scratching their heads and the ball taking strange (albeit intentional) bounces off players' bodies.

title: U.S. Citing Its Authority In 1991 Congress Measure
description: The United States intends to cite a resolution passed by Congress on the eve of the 1991 Persian Gulf war to justify any new series of American air strikes on Iraq meant to cripple its ability to manufacture or stockpile poison gas, Clinton Administration officials said today.

title: Zip Out Those Tax Forms? They May Zip Right Back
description: Because of a printing mistake, about a million taxpayers could mail their returns to the Internal Revenue Service only to get them right back again, the I.R.S. said today.

title: Arson Is Suspected In Fire That Killed 4
description: Investigators believe a house fire in Salem that killed a family of four early Monday morning may have been set because flames sprang up at the front and back doors of the house almost simultaneously, the local fire chief said yesterday.

title: After Fidel Castro
description: Fidel Castro turned 71 last summer. A few months later, the man who has been Cuba's sole source of political authority for the past 39 years, approved the official designation of his 66-year-old brother, Raul, as his eventual successor. It is a choice that could have surprised few Cubans and inspired none. Since the late 1950's, Raul Castro has been his brother's most reliable, least independent associate. His succession, if it takes place, promises no constructive change for Cuba.

title: Witness in Martin Case Disputes Fatigue Factor
description: The PGA Tour's challenge to Casey Martin's fight to ride a golf cart is built on several factors, one being walking. Golfers have always walked the tournament courses and must cope with 18 holes' worth of fatigue, the Tour insists.

title: 23% Malaysia Rise Leads Asia Stock Gains
description: Malaysia's main stock index surged Tuesday, closing up a record 23 percent, and other Asian markets held most of the gains of the day before, amid some expressions of optimism that the region's troubles might be easing. The Kuala Lumpur Composite Index jumped 131.80 points, to 701.31.

title: Oprah Winfrey Makes Debut As Star Witness
description: The nation's top syndicated talk-show host took the witness stand to defend herself in the lawsuit brought against her by Texas cattlemen and proved she could sidestep questions as well as any lawyer.

title: Cathay Pacific May Cut More Jobs, Officials Say
description: Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd. plans to dismiss employees in a second wave of jobs cuts this year, two executives said yesterday. Cathay, Hong Kong's only long-haul airline, may eliminate as many as 1,000 employees, or 7 percent of its workers, a director said. Another executive said employees were told to brace for further dismissals after Cathay dropped 760 people last month, its deepest cuts in its 51-year history.

title: How Bizarre! Bag of Tricks Empty for Nets
description: The Nets concluded their five-game Western swing with a bizarre 98-97 loss to the Trail Blazers here tonight. How the Nets lost will leave them shaking their heads on the long flight home.

title: Special Counsel's Case Raises Privacy Concerns; Secret Service Detail
description: To the Editor:

title: Testing the Prohibition On Pets in the Projects; In Congress, Cuddly Pleas to End a Ban, But the Housing Authority Is Resisting
description: As Congress considers the most sweeping changes for public housing in a generation, it faces a list of thorny issues, from eligibility rules to rent limits to privatization.

title: The Press's Mea Culpa Epidemic
description: There is nothing like a big, fast-breaking story that people are really curious about for putting the professional press critics into their condemnatory mode. In turn, the whiff of condemnation puts many reporters and editors into mea culpa overdrive. A certain amount of public self-criticism is healthy in any field, especially one as powerful, diverse and unregulated as the media. But during Hurricane Monica, self-examination has morphed into unwarranted self-flagellation.

title: New Yorker to Share Ad Package and Office With Conde Nast Kin
description: For as long as The New Yorker has been part of the Newhouse empire -- some 13 years -- the magazine has remained a world apart from its cousins, the glossy titles at Conde Nast Publications.

title: VW Says Deliveries Rose 7.3% Last Year
description: Volkswagen A.G. said yesterday that its deliveries to customers rose 7.3 percent amid increasing sales of its Seat, Skoda and Audi brands. Deliveries last year rose to 4.26 million cars from 3.99 million a year earlier, the auto maker, Europe's largest, said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NARDINO, GARY
description: NARDINO-Gary. Of Los Angeles, CA (formerly Garfield), January 31, 1998. Beloved father of Caroline Nardino, Gary Nardino and Teresa Nardino. Devoted son of Louis Nardino and the late Phyllis. Dear brother of Theresa Sodaro and Angela Stafford. Funeral services at 9:15 AM on Saturday from Vander Plaat Memorial Home, S113 Farview Avenue, Paramus, NJ and 10:00 am Funeral Mass at Our Lady of Visitation RC Church. Entombment George Washington Memorial Park. Family will receive friends Friday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to Seton Hall University Scholarship Fund (in memory of Gary Nardino), c/o Development Office, 457 Centre St., South Orange, New Jersey 07079.

title: Beber/Silverstein Joins Pan Am Roster
description: The new Pan American World Airways, the principal subsidiary of the Pan Am Corporation, said yesterday that it had named Beber/Silverstein & Partners in Miami to handle the creative portion of the airline's account. That account had been handled for almost 18 months by Weller, O'Sullivan, Zuckerman & Lightcap in New York and Los Angeles. Billings were estimated at $5 million to $10 million. The decision, which had been expected, came after a review that began two months ago and included Weller, O'Sullivan along with 11 other agencies in New York and South Florida. Dom Camera Associates Inc. in New York will continue to handle media planning and buying.

title: Bond-Rating Agency Gives a Vote of Confidence to the City
description: New York City's economy and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's budget plan received a vote of confidence from Wall Street yesterday, as one of the two major credit-rating agencies announced that it was considering raising the city's bond rating.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUMENFELD, IRVING B., MD.
description: BLUMENFELD-Irving B., MD. Age 95, of Venice, FL on February 1st. He is survived by his wife Margaret, children Barbara Barsky, Donna Schickler, Marilyn Bradley, Seth Blumenfeld, Judith Shafran, Debbie Martin and sister Beatrice Brodman. Beloved grandfather and great-grandfather.

title: Divisive Case of a Killer of Two Ends as Texas Executes Tucker
description: Saying ''I love all of you very much'' and smiling as lethal chemicals were pumped into her body, Karla Faye Tucker was executed tonight in Texas, becoming the first woman put to death by the state since the Civil War.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAINTON, ELIZABETH ANN

title: Kruse Goes on the Offensive
description: Until this past week, the only touch Paul Kruse had around the net was his fist on an opponent's face.

title: Cashman: Ahead of the Game at 30
description: In the spring of 1989, the Yankees were talking to the Atlanta Braves about a trade for Jeff Blauser just before Blauser began a nine-year run as the Braves' shortstop. Suddenly, Bobby Cox, the Braves' general manager, encountered a problem.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEDER, GRETA
description: LEDER-Greta. The Faculty, Fellows and house staff of the Dept. of Medicine records with sorrow the passing of the mother of our esteemed Director of Rheumatology and Alumnus Dr. Gerald Weissmann. We are very proud of her son who is an internationally renowned physician scientist, researcher and author. We are very grateful to Greta and her late husband, Dr. Adolf Weissmann for the wonderful gifts they provided our School of Medicine. Her son Gerald, Class of 1954, former Chief Resident in Medicine at Bellevue and for many immensely productive years a highly regarded and respected member of our faculty and her granddaughter Lisa Beth, Class of 1981. We express our deep sympathy to her brothers, her son Gerald, daughter-in-law Ann, her grandchildren, greatgrandson and the entire family. Saul J. Farber, MD, MACP The Frederick H. King Professor and Chairman, Dept. of Medicine Director, Medical Services Bellevue and Tisch Hospitals

Adored grandfather of Willy, Alex, Dana, Adam, Matthew and Allison. Devoted brother of Darcy Greher and brother-in-law of Judy Levy and Harold Greher. Cherished uncle and friend. Contributions can be made to the Calhoun School, 433 West End Avenue, NYC 10024 or the Guild for the Sylvia and Danny Kaye Playhouse at Hunter College, 695 Park Avenue, NYC, 10021. title: Florio's a Shoo-In
description: Here is one election that JIM FLORIO seems certain to win. Mr. Florio, whose bid for a second term as governor of New Jersey was dashed by CHRISTINE TODD WHITMAN in 1993, is a candidate for the board of the Regional Plan Association, the nonprofit advisory group that studies policy matters like growth versus gridlock. The vote is this afternoon.

title: Oxford Health Asks Rate Rise in New York
description: In what appears to be a move to emphasize profitability over the size of its membership rolls, Oxford Health Plans asked the New York State insurance department yesterday to allow it to raise premiums at least 50 percent on the individual coverage it sells to 55,000 New Yorkers, the insurance department said.

title: Albright Gets Arab Support For a Strike If Necessary
description: Completing her six-day tour of Western Europe and the Arab countries of the Persian Gulf, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said today that she had received assurances of military and political support if the United States needed to strike Iraq.

title: Young Twin Brothers Die After Falling Through Ice
description: Seven-year-old twin brothers fell through thin ice and drowned while playing with a friend about 75 feet from shore on frozen Sodus Bay.

title: Harvard Stuns B.C., Not Itself
description: An overtime defeat of Boston College on Monday night in the Beanpot Tournament at Boston's Fleet Center promised better days ahead for the Crimson, which had lost seven straight Beanpot games since 1994.

title: LYCOS BUYS WEB SITE WITH A MILLION CUSTOMERS
description: Lycos Inc. said yesterday that it had acquired the closely held Tripod Inc. for $58 million in stock, adding an on-line community to its Internet directory service. Tripod, based in Williamstown, Mass., is a Web site that offers members free publishing tools to create their own Web sites and content on topics like media, work, money, health and sports. Lycos, which is based in Framingham, Mass., said the acquisition added almost one million members and was an attempt to reach 18- to 34-year-old consumers. Lycos said the purchase would make it the fifth-most-visited Web site.

title: Footlights
description: EVENTS

title: Trinidad Returning to Ring With Title Bout
description: Felix Trinidad, the International Boxing Federation welterweight champion, will break a six-month absence from the ring with a title bout against Mahenge Zulu of Zaire in March in San Juan, P.R. Showtime will televise the bout and is holding two dates -- March 14 and March 21 -- for the fight.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: EATON CORP., Cleveland, a maker of electrical power products, will close its manufacturing technologies center in Willoughby Hills, Ohio, laying off 71 employees.

title: Blind Man Charged In a Rape Case
description: A blind Harlem man who residents said panhandled in the neighborhood was arrested yesterday after a homeless woman who was staying in his apartment accused him of raping her and stabbing her with scissors, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COTTERELL, VIOLA L.
description: COTTERELL-Viola L. The firm of Cotterell, Mitchell & Fifer deeply mourns the passing of Viola L. Cotterell, the widow of our founder, Wesley Cotterell. On January 30, Mrs. Cotterell, died after a short illness in her 99th year. Until her last few weeks, Mrs. Cotterell lived unassisted in her longtime home in Garden City. In ways large and small, Mrs. Cotterell contributed to the success of this firm and maintained a lively interest in its progress until her death. With her husband, she shared a lifelong devotion to the promotion and strengthening of Colgate University, and her beloved ''DKE's'', Mr. Cotterell's fraternity. Of petite natural stature, her guileless character loomed like a giant to all who knew her. A memorial service is planned for the spring at Colgate University.

title: Romania Still Divided by Issue of Opening Old Secret Police Files
description: When a centrist Government was elected here more than a year ago, there was considerable enthusiasm for opening up the secret police files kept by the Communist Government that was overthrown in 1989.

title: Women's Group Spreads the Word on H.I.V.
description: Sabrina Wilson is a 41-year-old mother of four and grandmother to four little ones. She found out that she was H.I.V.-positive when she was pregnant eight years ago. But to her, H.I.V. means ''high on victory'' as she roams the streets of Brooklyn in a battle to protect other women from the lethal virus.

USN) J.H. Wesson, and loving grandmother of Taylor, Katherine and Manning. Mayor of the Village of Lawrence, Long Island, NY, 198081 and 1988-95. Longtime member and officer of the Garden Club of Lawrence, past director of the Garden Club of America, former first Vice President, Board of Managers, Episcopal Health Services, Diocese of Long Island. Died peacefully at home on Sunday, Feb. 1, 1998. Memorial service on Saturday, February 7, at 11 AM, at Trinity - St. John's Episcopal Church, 1142 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island. God bless.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMMONS, HARRY
description: SIMMONS-Harry. January 14, 1998 at the Waveny Care Center in New Canaan, Connecticut. He was 90 years old. Harry was a baseball historian, writer, schedule maker, and The Authority on the rules of the game. He worked for the International Baseball League from 1945 until 1966 first in New York then in Montreal (1953-59). He then worked in the Baseball Commissioner's office until his retirement in 1982. He developed the playing schedules for the Majors and various Minor leagues for over 20 years. Well known as a historian and writer he did much original research into 19th Century baseball. He developed and wrote the weekly feature ''So You Think You Know Baseball'' which ran in the Saturday Evening Post from 1949 to 1961. His book under the same name was a best seller. For many years he wrote the entry for baseball in the Encyclopedia Britannica. In 1951, Harry testified as an expert witness to the Congressional hearings on the history of the reserve clause. At the 1979 baseball winter meeting in Toronto, he was honored as ''King of Baseball.'' In 1990 his contributions to the game were recognized by receiving the SABR (Society for American BAseball Research) Salute. Surviving are three sons, Ivor Ernest Simmons of Huntington Station, N.Y., Samuel Zackery Simmons of New York City, and David Ernest Simmons of Toronto; two daughters, Ann Preston of Trumbull, Connecticut, and Sara Valentine of New Canaan, Ct. and a brother Sidney Simon of Long Boat Key, Fla. He was predeceased by his wife of 50 years, Margaret Curry Simmons; and two sisters Elizabeth Issen, and Lois Rohr. A graveside service was held on January 16, at Beth El Cemetery in Westwood, N.J.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWEP, CHARLES F.
description: SCHWEP-Charles F. Died on February 2, 1998. Survived by his wife, Joy C.; two sons, Charles F. and David C.; four grandchildren, and a sister Rita Bass. Memorial service Saturday, 2:00PM, at the Dutch Reform Church, Strawtown Road, West Nyack.

title: Challenge Is Raised to Plan for a Holocaust Monument in Berlin
description: In a last-minute challenge to what had been depicted as a national consensus, a group of 19 prominent German intellectuals, historians and authors including Gunter Grass urged the authorities today to abandon plans for a gigantic Holocaust memorial in the heart of Berlin.

Meeks stood on a stage as a Congressional candidate facing hundreds of supporters and surrounded by a host of Democratic officials, some of whom were not known for having much in common with regard to political philosophy.

description: Saying he was grateful that President Clinton ''thought me worthy of such honor at the time of my death,'' former Surgeon General C. Everett Koop announced today that he was rejecting the President's offer to be buried at Arlington National Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OZTEMEL, ARA
description: OZTEMEL-Ara. Monday, Feb. 2, 1998, died in Key Biscayne, FL., after a brief illness. Born in 1926 in Istanbul, Turkey, Ara Oztemel became a pioneer in trade with the Soviet Union. In the midst of the Cold War Mr. Oztemel believed in commerce as the most significant force for peace between nations. He was proud of his role in U.S.Soviet trade and was honored to be regularly consulted by both nations on matters concerning U.S.U.S.S.R. relations. Mr Oztemel was also a passionate jazz musician who supported that art form by arranging cultural exchanges and tours, as well as entertaining friends and family with Sunday jazz gigs. He is survived by his wife, Mary Kechejian Oztemel, his daughter Katherine Caporale, his sons, Greg, Gary and Glenn and his daughter Susan Barnes. He also leaves behind nine grandchildren. In lieu of flowers donations to Ara Oztemel Memorial Fund, WBGO Radio, 54 Park Place, Newark, N.J. 07102 or Greenwich Hospital, C/O Development Office. The family will receive visitors on Saturday, February 7 from 2-6PM at 61 Barnes Road, Stamford, CT.

The Federal Communications Commission has the final say on long-distance service applications, though it must consider the recommendations of state regulators and the United States Justice Department. Louisiana regulators urged the F.C.C. to approve the application. The Justice Department recommended against it.

description: A Federal judge in Newark ordered the United States Attorney's office for the District of New Jersey yesterday to apologize to the nation's largest lottery company and one of its consultants after publishing unproven allegations against them on its Internet site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLOUN, REVEREND RUSSELL JOHN
description: SLOUN-Reverend Russell John. S.J., 54. On February 2, 1998. Beloved son of Sultana and the late Robert. Brother of Eileen Sloun. He entered the Society of Jesus on August 14, 1960. He was ordained on May 26, 1973. Father Sloun taught modern languages at Fordham Prep and for the last ten years at St. Francis Xavier High School, where he was also the Director of the Computer Center. He also worked for many years in Marriage Encounter on Long Island. A wake will be held Thursday 2 to 7PM at the St. Francis Xavier High School Student's Chapel. Mass of Christian Burial Thursday, at 8 P.M., St. Francis Xavier R.C. Church.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on page 6 of House & Home today about Jimmy Stewart's house misstates the number of his heirs who are selling it. There are three, not four. Mr. Stewart's stepson Ronald McLean died in 1969.

title: Aetna Returns to Profitability in Quarter and Its Shares Rise
description: Aetna Inc. said today that earnings in the fourth quarter rose 5 percent before gains as profit from its international and retirement services units overcame rising costs in its managed health care business. The company swung to net income from a net loss.

title: Upbeat Riffs on America as an Evolving Jazzocracy
description: ALWAYS IN PURSUIT

title: Economic Scene; The tax credit for research and development: free lunch.
description: IF Americans could vote on their favorite business tax break, the research and development tax credit might top the balloting. The public supports it because new technology fattens paychecks, saves lives and makes for more realistic video games. Politicians like it because corporate America loves it.

title: Giants Extend Contracts Of Assistant Coaches
description: When a team has a talented coaching staff like the Giants', Rule No. 1 is to make sure it stays around. And General Manager Ernie Accorsi has followed that credo as well as Rule No. 2: keep the staff happy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUBERMAN, LEONARD
description: DUBERMAN-Leonard. Devoted father of Sharon and Michael Geraghty and Jennifer Duberman. Dear brother of Howard and Soni Duberman. Adored Uncle of Jon, James, Cheryl and Tracy. Great Uncle of Matthew, Evan and Rebecca. You will live in our hearts forever. Services at the ''Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, NYC, Friday at 10 A.M.

title: Clinton's Personal Steward Returns to the Grand Jury
description: For the second time in nine days, the grand jury hearing testimony about the relationship between President Clinton and Monica S. Lewinsky today listened to a White House steward, an aide who functions much like a butler and sees the President in some of his most private moments.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEVENS, ROGER LACEY
description: STEVENS-Roger Lacey. On Monday, February 2nd, 1998, of Washington, D.C. Beloved husband of Christine Stevens; father of Christabel Gough; Brother-inLaw of Nina Stevens; also survived by a nephew, Harlow Stevens, Jr. Services private. A memorial service at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts will be announced at a later date. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to The Fund for New American Plays, John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, Washington, D.C. 20566 or The Animal Welfare Institute, PO Box 3650, Washington, D.C. 20007. For information contact Joseph Gawler's Sons, Inc.

title: Metro Business; Manhattan Tops List Of Costly Real Estate
description: Manhattan dominated an annual survey of the world's 10 most costly retail addresses, with Fifth Avenue ranking first and Times Square and Rockefeller Plaza landing on the list for the first time. East 57th Street and Madison Avenue also made the top 10.

title: Sharpton's Testimony Is Delayed After an Outburst by His Lawyer
description: For the second time in two weeks, the lawyer for the Rev. Al Sharpton erupted in rage on the eve of Mr. Sharpton's scheduled testimony in the Tawana Brawley defamation trial. The judge threatened to hold the lawyer in contempt of court, and Mr. Sharpton's testimony was delayed again, until at least Friday.

title: PRIMUS AGREES TO BUY A RIVAL, TRESCOM, FOR $125 MILLION
description: Primus Telecommunications Group Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire a rival long-distance carrier, Trescom International Inc., for $125 million in stock. Under the agreement, Primus will exchange stock valued at $10 for each of Trescom's 12.5 million shares outstanding. The deal is conditioned on Primus's shares maintaining a price of $15.89 or more. If Primus's stock is lower, the value of the deal will be adjusted downward. Shares of Trescom, which is based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., rose 37.5 cents yesterday, to $9, on the Nasdaq stock market, where Primus, of McLean, Va., gained 75 cents a share, to $20.75, a new 52-week high. Warburg Pincus Investors L.P., which owns about 52 percent of Trescom's stock, agreed to support the acquisition.

title: Counting The Nets' 2.8 Ticks To Disaster
description: How bizarre, how bizarre.

title: Macauley's '51 All-Star Honors Came Late (but He's Not Complaining)
description: His performance one night 47 years ago was to become a part of basketball history, but Easy Ed Macauley -- and everyone else involved -- did not know it at the time.

title: Heeere's Kobe: It's Showtime Again in L.A.
description: He emerges from a cramped room, loping along slowly like a college sophomore between classes. Moving through the Great Western Forum corridors and out the arena's side entrance, he squints at the sunlight beaming down on Los Angeles.

title: Joint Effort Seeks to Raise Fuel Economy of 'Light Trucks'
description: The Clinton Administration announced a research effort with automotive companies today to improve sharply the fuel economy of sport utility vehicles, pickup trucks and mini-vans, using techniques borrowed from the Pentagon.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCKEEVER, SR. MARY TERENCE
description: McKEEVER-Sr. Mary Terence. Beloved member of the Sisters of Charity and former Spanish Professor at the College of Mt St. Vincent on February 4, 1998. Dear sister of Rosemary and Patricia. Also survived by many nieces, nephews, grand nieces and grand nephews. Reposing at the Convent of Mary the Queen, 35 Vark Street, Yonkers, New York on Thursday 1-8 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Friday 9:30 A.M., at the Convent. Interment at Saint Joseph's Cemetery, Yonkers. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Sisters of Charity Development Fund, 6301 Riverdale Avenue, Bronx, New York 10471.

title: Gary Nardino, 62, TV Executive And Situation Comedy Producer
description: Gary Nardino, a television executive who was instrumental in bringing long-running programs like ''Happy Days,'' ''Cheers'' and ''Taxi'' into American homes, died at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles on Saturday of complications from a stroke, Bill Nuss, his business partner, said. He was 62 and had lived in Los Angeles.

title: Vast India Seeks a Focus in Its Election Campaign
description: Nearing the midpoint of India's election campaign, the central question is whether the Gandhi name can revive the flagging fortunes of the Congress Party, which long dominated the nation's Government.

title: Big Coca-Cola Bottler Will Split Into 2 Parts
description: The Coca-Cola Company's second-largest bottler, Coca-Cola Amatil Ltd., will be be carved into two companies, one based in Europe and the other in Australia, to better focus on regional business demands.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLEICHER, PHILIP, D.D.S.
description: GLEICHER-Philip, D.D.S. Loving husband of Berenice, beloved father of Karen and Paula. Dear brother of Jerry and Phyllis. Graveside service on Thursday, 2:30 P.M., at New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale, Long Island. In lieu of flowers, donations to your favorite charity in memory of Philip would be appreciated.

title: MetroStars Trade for Lalas
description: The center of the defense was the most vulnerable spot for the MetroStars in their first two years in Major League Soccer. They filled that void yesterday with the acquisition of Alexi Lalas from New England in a three-way deal that also involved D.C. United.

title: Rare Bird in Davos: Labor Chief Makes His Points
description: The chief executives lunching with John J. Sweeney, the American labor leader, seemed almost to be seeking his blessing. A Frenchman tried to get him to criticize the French Government's plan to shorten the workweek. A Canadian sought his approval of bonuses and profit sharing for workers, rather than wage increases. And an American tried to get Mr. Sweeney's consent to the proposition that Mexican wages will rise.

title: F.A.A. Head Concedes Computer Problem
description: The head of the Federal Aviation Administration acknowledged in testimony before Congress today that the state of her agency's preparations for the year-2000 computer problem was ''unacceptable,'' and she said she could not guarantee that the problems would be solved in time.

title: Big Deal; Home, To Jimmy Stewart
description: Beverly Hills, Calif.

title: Schick unveils its biggest ad campaign ever this weekend.
description: THIS weekend Schick will open a new front in its battle with Gillette, using the San Antonio Spurs rookie forward Tim Duncan as its standard-bearer.

title: Personal Shopper; Of Mice and Bears (a Bookworm's Friends)
description: CHOOSING bookends is like setting a table: it's a chance to go beyond the purely functional and toward the decorative. Any hard, heavy object will give books visible means of support. A survey of college dormitory rooms will turn up lots of bricks on the ends of shelves. Cavemen probably used rocks. But today, bookends can be more interesting than the books.

title: G.M. and Ford January Sales Fell Sharply
description: The General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company announced steep drops in January sales today, with all but the newest-model cars selling slowly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STURGIS, NORMAN R.
description: STURGIS-Norman R. Of Fort Myers, FL. and Small Point, ME. died of cancer on February 4, 1998. He is survived by Linda Terry Sturgis, his wife of fifty-five years, two sons, Nathaniel R. Sturgis and John T. T. Sturgis, both of Missoula, MT, six grandchildren and two great grandchildren. Also survived by two sisters, Mrs. David T. Cook of St. James, NY and Mrs. Melvin E. Schoonover of Miami, Florida. Contributions in his memory to the Sanibel Captiva Conservation Foundation, Box 839, Sanibel, FL. 33957, would be greatly appreciated by his family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLOVER, STUART B. (BUS)
description: GLOVER-Stuart B. (Bus). Attorney, at age 92. A resident of Scarsdale for over fifty years, died at his home Feb. 4, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Peggy Glover. Devoted father of James, Richard, Amy, Elaine and Kathryn. Beloved grandfather of Eric, Rachel, Lori and Peter. Funeral services will be held at Congregation Emanu-El of Westchester, Friday at 1:30PM. Interment to follow at Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, NY. Memorial contributions may be made to the Tourette's Syndrome Association, 42-40 Bell Blvd., Bayside, NY 11361, or WJCS, 141 N. Central Ave., Hartsdale, NY 10530, or Congregation Emanu-El of Westchester, 2125 Westchester Ave. East, Rye, New York 10580, or a charity of your choice.

title: Better Plutonium Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: Tyson Distances Himself From King
description: In what could turn out to be be an ugly divorce, Mike Tyson has set into motion the wheels that might end his decadelong relationship with the powerful boxing promoter Don King.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, IDA
description: SCHWARTZ-Ida. Died on February 4th, 1998. Wife of the late Max Schwartz. Survived by daughter and son-in-law Elizabeth and Lloyd Elliot, grandchildren Jessica and Ben Small, sister and brother-in-law Frieda and Harold Kleinsinger.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: After Relentless Gains, Stock Market Turns Mixed

title: Essay; Yeltsin's Threat
description: The most troubling statement in Boris Yeltsin's career was made this week to his chief of staff, Anatoly Chubais. The Russian President was provoked by a White House comment that the U.S. response to any use by Saddam Hussein of weapons of mass destruction would be ''devastating.''

title: Blue-Chip Issues in Retreat; Dow Off 30.64, to 8,129.71
description: After more than a week of nearly uninterrupted gains, the stock market ended mixed yesterday, with blue-chip issues retreating somewhat as investors turned their attention elsewhere.

title: Carlesimo Testifies to Threat by Sprewell
description: Meticulously detailing his version of events at a Golden State Warrior practice on Dec. 1, Coach P. J. Carlesimo testified yesterday that he was attacked by Latrell Sprewell in two separate altercations, and that he was told at one point by the now-suspended guard, ''I'll kill you.''

title: Sharing City Streets
description: To the Editor:

title: The Philadelphia Shows Off Its Own Musicians
description: Among the nicer moments in any orchestra's subscription season are its family concerts, the family here being that of the musicians rather than their listeners. The Philadelphia Orchestra took its in-house celebration on the road on Tuesday night. At Carnegie Hall, four principal players stepped forward as soloists in pieces both old and new. Wolfgang Sawallisch conducted.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  JONAY, ADRIENNE
description: JONAY-Adrienne. Dearest Ady, there are no answers, only cherished memories. Forever, Linnie

title: Once More, The Fed Holds Rates Steady
description: The Federal Reserve voted today to leave interest rates unchanged, apparently concluding that the economy would slow enough to repress inflation without endangering the seven-year-old expansion.

title: N.H.L. Seeks Rules Changes
description: The National Hockey League general managers, at meetings in Scottsdale, Ariz., this week, considered several possible rules changes intended to open up the game and increase scoring, including the elimination of the red line at center ice.

title: Israel's 50th Anniversary Preparations Are Mired in Squabbling
description: After the successive resignations of three directors of the committee planning Israel's 50th anniversary celebrations, the Government minister in charge of the jubilee also quit in a huff today, leaving preparations in even deeper disarray a week before the festivities are to begin.

title: Trenton School-Choice Program Draws Immediate Attack
description: New Jersey's Education Commissioner explained today how a proposed public school choice program would work, but many educators around the state said it was not designed to succeed.

title: Suspect Is Clean
description: In East Hampton, N.Y., the setting for Mr. Brady's 1997 murder-mystery ''Further Lane'' (about a Martha Stewart-like doyenne of decor), one second-story man took nothing but a shower.

title: Buffett's Purchases Push Silver Past $7 an Ounce
description: The price of silver jumped to more than $7 an ounce yesterday -- its highest since 1988 -- as the market got a lift from the news that the company controlled by Warren E. Buffett, one of the nation's most prominent investors, now owns $910 million worth of the precious metal.

title: Tuberculosis Case Leads City's Health Dept. to Test Students at Queens School
