description: Students at an intermediate school in Jackson Heights, Queens, were being tested for tuberculosis yesterday in response to parents' concerns that their children might have been exposed to a classmate who has the disease, school officials said.

title: Pure Love Versus the Less Rarefied Kind
description: Lust or love? The titles of Michael Smuin's two new works suggest a thematic contrast in the program that Smuin Ballets/ SF will be presenting through Sunday at the Joyce Theater.

title: It's Called News
description: Hamptons magazine was taken to court far from the celebrity-driven whirl of eastern Long Island it covers. Its former printer, Wilcox Press of Ithaca, N.Y., demanded payment for copies it printed in 1995. JUSTICE WALTER J. RELIHAN of State Supreme Court in Tompkins County ordered the magazine and its publisher and editor in chief, RANDY SCHINDLER, to pay $246,571, plus interest.

title: Japan Air System Reports Weak Demand
description: The Japan Air System Company, the third-largest airline in Japan, acknowledged that it had weak demand for domestic flights but declined to comment on a report that its operating loss for the year to March would be a third higher than forecast.

title: Favorite Trick Pointed Toward Derby
description: The owner of the undefeated juvenile champion, Favorite Trick, said today that although the colt was behind schedule after a confusing transfer of trainers, ''we're definitely looking to the Kentucky Derby.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MASKET, DAVID C.
description: MASKET-David C., 67. Died on February 3, 1998. Beloved husband of Joan Gellinoff Masket, loving father of Steven and Elaine Masket, Mary-Ellen and David Stein, Elizabeth and Jonathan Sommer. Adored grandfather of Willy, Alex, Dana, Adam, Matthew and Allison. Devoted brother of Darcy Greher and brother-in-law of Judy Levy and Harold Greher. Cherished uncle and friend. You will be in our hearts, always. Contributions can be made to the Calhoun School, 433 West End Avenue, NYC 10024 or the Guild for the Sylvia and Danny Kaye Playhouse at Hunter College, 695 Park Avenue, NYC, 10021. Services will be held at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, on Thursday, February 5, at 12:30 P.M.

title: CBS Matched Expectations In 4th Quarter
description: The CBS Corporation said yesterday that its loss from continuing operations narrowed in the fourth quarter as the company benefited from cost-cutting and higher advertising at its television and radio stations and broadcast and cable networks. On a net basis, CBS swung to a profit from a loss a year earlier.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEEN, EVELYN
description: GEEN-Evelyn. Of 3301-2 Wickslow Road, Wilmington, N.C. 28412. Of Alzheimer's disease. January 28, 1998. Formerly of Queens, New York City. Was Secretary for Hoechst-Celanese for 28 years. Survived by her brother, Morton Geen, his wife Zelda and their two sons David and Jeffrey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBERTS, ETHEL
description: ROBERTS-Ethel. Formerly of New York City and Boca Raton, FL. Beloved wife of the late Ellis, devoted mother of Joan Honig and Roger Roberts, dear sister of Florence Siegal, and the late Sol Ravitz, loving grandmother of Kevin and Michael Honig, and Adam Roberts. Services at Sanctuary of Abraham and Sarah at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ, on Thursday at 10 A.M. For further info call Gutterman-Musicant, Hackensack, NJ at: 1-800-522-0588.

title: Karla Tucker Is Now Gone, But Several Debates Linger
description: Not since 1977, when a Utah firing squad shot Gary Gilmore, the first prisoner put to death after the Supreme Court allowed resumption of capital punishment, has so much attention been focused on an execution.

title: Tearfully, Martin Tells of Pain in His Leg
description: Casey Martin limped to the witness stand today and testified that the worsening pain in his right leg is so severe that it feels as if the leg is ''going to blow up.''

title: The President And the G.O.P. Diverge on Iraq
description: The White House found itself at odds with Congressional leaders today over Iraq policy, as the two top Republican lawmakers called on President Clinton to use the military to remove President Saddam Hussein and Administration officials tried to play down expectations of what a military strike might achieve.

title: Bridge; Game's Oldest Journal Has New Home
description: In the last two months an institution has been slowly moving out of New York City. The Bridge World, the oldest continuously published magazine in the field, had had its offices in Manhattan since it was founded by Ely Culbertson in 1929.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENNER, DOROTHY (NEE WAASER)
description: BENNER-Dorothy (nee Waaser). On February 3, 1998 in Phoenix. Longtime resident of Arizona, active in Prescott community. Beloved wife of Drayton Benner; devoted mother of Chris, David, and the late Patricia; grandmother of five. Mourned deeply by loving families and friends including Willard and Dorothy Benner.

title: Sotheby's Decorates for the Windsors
description: SOTHEBY'S NEW YORK is playing house. For a preview exhibition for the nine-day sale of the collection of the Duke and Duchess of Windsor, which begins Feb. 19, Sotheby's has created seven decorated room settings, closely modeled on the salon, dining room, library, bedroom suites and entrance hall of the Windsors' Louis XVI-style residence in the Bois de Boulogne in Paris. The rooms will open to the public on Tuesday and remain on view through the sale.

title: Tobacco Deal Lets the Industry Off the Hook; A Political Expedient
description: To the Editor:

title: Bloom of Youth, And Restraint Of Maturity
description: The American soprano Barbara Bonney, who gave her Carnegie Hall recital debut on Saturday night, brings an unusual combination of qualities to her singing. She essentially has a light, lyric voice with a rosy bloom to the sound that is fresh and youthful. Yet Ms. Bonney, who is 41, sings with exceptional intelligence, and a sense of restraint that can come only with musical maturity.

title: In Aftermath of Troubles, Redemption for a General
description: Timing is everything in life, especially for Joe Ralston.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, ANNETTE
description: GOLDMAN-Annette. Dear sister of Mary. Survived by nieces and nephews. A member of congregation Temple Emanuel of New York City. Services at''BoulevardRiverside Chapels'', 312 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn, (at Prospect Park), today at 1 P.M.

title: Franklin M. Kreml Dies at 91; Pioneer in Traffic Safety Issues
description: Franklin M. Kreml, a former police officer who became an internationally known authority on traffic, including policing and safety, and on transportation in general, died on Jan. 28 at Evanston Hospital in Evanston, Ill. He was 91 and lived in Chicago.

title: Two Charged in Commodities Scheme
description: Two men have been charged in a scheme to trade on inside information about a big commodities trading firm's planned trades.

title: Apria Healthcare Lines Up An Infusion of $172 Million
description: The Apria Healthcare Group Inc., one of the nation's biggest home health companies, is among the many health care companies that have disappointed investors after mergers produced more pain than profit. After floundering since its formation in a merger in 1995, Apria held out new hope yesterday, saying that it had secured new financing and much-needed management help.

title: Anxiety Attack at Home? Not With Brodeur in Goal
description: With only one loss in the six-game trip they completed two nights ago in Ottawa, the Devils feared complacency more than anything else before tonight's first game at home in 14 days.

title: Turn the Rascals Out? In Canadian Province, a Petition Will Do
description: The signatures have been collected, and now it is up to the chief electoral officials in British Columbia to determine whether Paul Ramsey will be the first politician in Canada to be recalled from office for breaking a campaign promise.

title: Discovering a New Gear
description: A technological revolution occurred in speed skating last year, and Catriona Le May Doan and her Canadian teammates decided not to resist the inevitable. But she had no idea that she could become the next Bonnie Blair.

title: STARR TURNS DOWN LIMIT ON QUESTIONS TO CLINTON'S AIDES
description: Prosecutors investigating President Clinton's relationship with a former intern rejected tonight a White House request that they restrict their questioning of his senior aides, setting up a potential confrontation over Mr. Clinton's power to protect certain conversations from scrutiny.

title: President Should Tell His Story, Stephanopoulos Says : Former Aide Calls on Clinton To Dispel Cloud of Questions
description: WASHINGTON  George Stephanopoulos, once one of President Bill Clinton's closest advisers, called Wednesday on Mr. Clinton to clear the air of the lingering cloud of questions about his relationship to a former intern.

title: Brokers Fined $305,000 in Warrant Case
description: Securities regulators have ordered A. S. Goldmen & Company, a brokerage firm in Iselin, N.J., and three employees to pay a total of $305,000 in fines and to reimburse investors more than $1 million for manipulating the price of stock warrants.

title: Legends of Ore; The Rise and Fall of a Venerable Name in South African Mining
description: Barney Barnato and Mzilikazi Khumalo never knew each other: Mr. Barnato died insane in 1897, and Mr. Khumalo was not born until 1955. But the two men who bracket the history of JCI Ltd. -- the mining house that Mr. Barnato created and Mr. Khumalo, a former political prisoner, is tearing apart -- both have the status of legends in South African business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TROISE, MARGARET
description: TROISE-Margaret. Died on Wednesday morning February 4, 1998, in Smithtown, NY at the age of 78. Just released, she blows down the road, a sheath of gold astounds her face, and she squints, outgrows the ground. With abiding love and gratitude, your son Don

title: Movements Mysterious, Yearning and Soulful
description: Regina Larkin appeared to be a woman exploring some unknown realm in ''Journey,'' a mysterious solo, which Joyce Trisler choreographed in 1958 and which was revived on Sunday night on a program by the Joyce Trisler Danscompany at the Joyce SoHo.

title: Man Fleeing the Police Jumps From Fourth Floor
description: A Brooklyn man jumped out of a fourth-story window on Tuesday night with 700 pounds of marijuana in his bedroom and police officers knocking at his door, the police said.

title: Southeast Wearing Winter White
description: To hear Sheila Fletcher tell it, you would think she was talking about Lake Tahoe, Calif., the town where she grew up. It was a place, she recalled, where abundant snow was as predictable as a meltdown in spring.

title: Suspended Chief of Union Local Denies Financial Impropriety
description: The president of the union local representing 22,000 New York City school cafeteria aides and crossing guards insisted yesterday that he was innocent of charges of financial improprieties and that his parent union was wrong to take over his local.

title: Junior Hernandez, 34, Radio Host in New York
description: Junior Hernandez, whose Spanish-language morning program was the second-most popular radio show in New York City, died of a heart attack yesterday afternoon. He was 34 and lived in the Bronx.

title: GE CAPITAL SAYS IT IS IN TALKS WITH JAPAN'S TOHO MUTUAL
description: The GE Capital Corporation, the financing arm of the General Electric Company, said yesterday that it was in talks with the Toho Mutual Life Insurance Company about expanding into Japan's life insurance market. GE Financial Assurance, a unit of GE Capital, is in talks with the ailing Toho ''to explore a range of business options,'' a spokesman for the company, which is based in Stamford, Conn., said. The talks may include investing in Toho or forming a joint venture or partnership. Foreign companies are taking advantage of Japan's six-year slump to expand their market share there.

title: South Korea's Crisis Hinders Nuclear Deal With the North
description: South Korean officials have told the Clinton Administration that their financial crisis has left them unable to pay their full share of the construction of nuclear power plants in North Korea, the key element of a deal that halted the North's nuclear weapons program three years ago.

title: Making Books; Success Story Of an Editor
description: If publishing had a literary fairy tale in 1997, it was the story of a young unknown woman, apparently indistinguishable from anyone else in the city's madding crowd of book editors, who achieved in one stroke what many toil for decades to do but hardly ever realize. The first book she ever acquired and edited was a literary first novel that became a critically acclaimed, runaway best seller. This was a dazzlingly unheard of feat, akin, for instance, to a rookie baseball player's hitting 50 home runs.

title: Investigators in Reuters Case Met With Computer Consultant Months Ago
description: An executive with a Manhattan computer company was confronted several months ago by Federal law enforcement officials investigating whether the company was commissioned by a subsidiary of Reuters Holdings P.L.C. to steal information electronically from a rival, Bloomberg L.P., people briefed on the case said yesterday.

title: A Matter of American Leadership
description: The roster of lobbyists marching up to Capitol Hill to make the case for giving the International Monetary Fund an infusion of $18 billion says something about the importance of the Administration proposal. The principal salesmen are Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin and Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve. The Clinton Administration argues, correctly, that the fund, for all its flaws, remains the only institution that can snuff out financial crises abroad before they bury local economies and before they reverberate around the globe, striking even the United States. Without new money from Washington, the fund's other members are unlikely to contribute the reserves that the fund needs to bail out countries in financial distress.

title: Tobacco Deal Lets the Industry Off the Hook; Retain California Law
description: To the Editor:

title: High School Students Show Some Improvement
description: A slightly higher percentage of New Jersey's class of 1997 passed the high school proficiency test in time to graduate than students in the class of 1996, the State Department of Education reported yesterday.

title: Machines That Built the Renaissance
description: CONSTRUCTION sites ain't what they used to be. In the Renaissance, according to the exhibition ''Mechanical Marvels: Invention in the Age of Leonardo'' at the World Financial Center through March 1, building sites were spectacular visions of ingenuity wedded to beauty.

title: Seagram's Net Takes a Tumble
description: The Seagram Company's earnings before a charge dropped 52 percent in the latest quarter, more than expected, as the economic turmoil in Asia cut the company's liquor sales in the region in half.

title: Brazil Pays to Shield Currency, And the Poor See the True Cost
description: Edmar Bacha, a Brazilian banker, has a new routine. Every afternoon he logs on to the Internet, reads the next day's issue of The Korea Herald and decides what he will tell the anxious executives from Merrill Lynch and Fidelity Investments who keep asking him where Brazil is headed.

title: Portrait of a Composer As Man and Musician
description: About nice guys? Not all the returns are in.

title: Potential Jurors in Soldier's Trial
description: Twelve prospective jurors in the court-martial of Sgt. Maj. Gene C. McKinney, formerly the Army's highest ranking enlisted soldier, were interviewed here today by the military judge, defense and prosecution lawyers, and the jury will be seated on Thursday morning to hear opening arguments in the sexual misconduct case.

title: Corrections
description: The Business Travel column in Business Day on Jan. 28, about a proposed alliance between Northwest Airlines and Continental Airlines, misspelled the surname of a Duke University professor who spoke about the possible effect on travelers. He is Paul Zipkin, not Zifkin.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAUDIER, RICHARD U.
description: GAUDIER-Richard U. Vice President Merrill Lynch on February 4, 1998. Beloved husband of Catherine. Loving father of the late Richard C. Dear son Margarita. Fond brother of Emily Gaudier Garcia, Bonnie Beauchamp, Michelle Gaudier and Ronald Gaudier. Reposing at the Simonson Funeral Home, 119-04 Hillside Ave (corner Lefferts Blvd), Richmond Hill. Service Friday 8PM. Funeral private. Visiting Thursday and Friday 2:305 and 7-9:30PM. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation would be appreciated.

title: Courtship in Korea
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASSILLY, RICHARD
description: CASSILLY-Richard. The Metropolitan Opera deeply mourns the death of our beloved colleague and friend, Richard Cassilly. A versatile and generous artist, he sang more than 150 performances of 14 roles with the company, and created the roles of Jimmy Mahoney in Weill's ''Mahagonny'' and the title role in Stravinsky's ''Oedipus Rex'' in the Met premieres of those works. He appeared in Met telecasts of ''Mahagonny'' and ''Tannhauser'' and will be remembered for his vivid portrayals in a wide variety of dramatic tenor roles with our company. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, Patricia, and to his family. Joseph Volpe, General Manager James Levine, Artistic Director

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I don't think you can find a more powerful tool to make a statement than to park an airport 20 miles off a guy's beach.''

title: Rubella Outbreak Hits Hispanic Immigrant Communities
description: An outbreak of rubella, a once-common disease that standard vaccinations have rendered all but obsolete among Americans, is spreading among Hispanic immigrants in Westchester and Fairfield Counties.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUZUKI, DR. ARATA
description: SUZUKI-Dr. Arata. Friends and colleagues at Capintec Inc mourn the loss of Dr. Arata Suzuki, Senior Scientist for over twenty-five years. We offer our heartfelt sympathy to his family at their grievous loss. Arthur M. Weis, President

title: Fossils Take Scientists Past Biology's Big Bang
description: New fossil discoveries in China have transported paleontologists across a great divide in the history of life on Earth, taking them deep into virtually unexplored time, showing them the earliest known forms of tiny ancestral animals and pointing out where they should be searching next for evidence of the origins of the first such complex life.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WERNICK, SONIA
description: WERNICK-Sonia. In Freeport, ME, February 2. Aged 95. Widow of Solomon Wernick. Survived by daughter, Lucille Hershenhart, Harpswell, ME., and son Robert J. Wernick, San Francisco, California. Information Brackett Funeral Home, 29 Federal Street, Brunswick, ME 04011.

title: Special Counsel Law
description: To the Editor:

title: NBC Halts Parody Of Nike Commercial
description: NBC has stopped running promotional commercials that parodied the new ''I can'' campaign from Nike Inc. after executives at Nike, which advertises on the network, asked NBC to withdraw the spots.

title: Job Itself in Doubt As New Feud Looms On Surgeon General
description: It has been nine years since C. Everett Koop has worn the uniform of the Surgeon General of the United States, yet he calculates that in some months, he spends 30 percent of his time talking to Americans about smoking, nutrition, exercise and so on -- ''the kinds of things,'' he said in a recent interview, ''that a Surgeon General really ought to be doing.''

title: If Charlie Trie Sings
description: For most of 1997, the campaign finance investigation was slow and passionless. Attorney General Janet Reno and the career prosecutors in the Justice Department were reluctant to follow the money trail that led from Asia to the White House. But the indictment and arranging of the surrender of Charlie Trie may signal a new attitude, and we are happy to salute Ms. Reno and the prosecutors handling the case in the hope that their long nap is over.

title: PROTECTION ONE WILL PAY $175 MILLION FOR COMPETITOR
description: Protection One Inc. said yesterday that it would buy the Network Multi-Family Corporation from Western Resources Inc. for about $175 million. The Dallas-based Network Multi-Family is the largest alarm company in the United States serving apartments and condominiums, according to Protection One, a residential burglar alarm company. Western Resources, of Topeka, Kan., bought about 80 percent of Protection One on Nov. 25 for $320 million in cash and $250 million in assumed debt, combining the company with its own Westar Security. It bought Network Multi-Family on Sept. 9 for $171 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOPER, EVE
description: COOPER-Eve. The Friends of Bezalel Academy of Arts and Design deeply mourn the passing of Eve Cooper, mother of our esteemed Board member and colleague, Barbara Thomson. We extend our sincere condolences to Barbara and Malcolm Thomson and the entire family. Romie Shapiro, Chairman Harry Bauer, President Eillene Leistner, Executive Vice President

title: S.E.C. Files Action In Bond Fraud Case
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has filed action in connection with a fraud case involving the sale of $58 million in municipal bonds in California.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAMPERT, THERESA
description: GAMPERT-Theresa. On February 3, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Maximilian. Loving mother of John Gampert and Patricia Lubin. Cherished grandmother of Robert, Erik, Michael and Andrew. Dear aunt of George Adin. Services Thursday, 1:15PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Giuliani Focuses on Economic Boon From Filming Boom in City
description: It may not have sun-splashed studio lots or moguls ordering fizzy water by the brand name, but New York City continues to enjoy a renaissance in movie and television production -- one that local officialdom is hailing, even if some residents grumble about streets clogged with film crews.

title: Back Home to Pooh Corner? Fuhgedaboudit, Mayor Says
description: Oh bother.

title: A Week After Severe Storm, Shore Cities Brace for Northeaster
description: Coastal towns in New Jersey, New York and Connecticut braced for the brunt of a slow-moving northeaster that was expected to punish shorelines beginning early today with 24 hours of gale-force winds, rough seas and potential flooding.

title: Ex-MTV Executive Loses Contract Case
description: MTV Networks, a unit of Viacom Inc., won its court bid yesterday to keep Richard Cronin, a former MTV executive, from joining the rival Fox Kids network until July.

title: A Balance Between Puerto Rican and Cuban Styles
description: The singer Miles Pena performed at the Latin Quarter on Friday night, and his show caught him experimenting in territory that was discouraged even a few years ago. Mr. Pena, originally from Cuba, has spent the last five years playing the role of the straight-ahead salsa singer, Puerto Rican style; his records, romantic and a bit dull, have never caught his ability as an improviser or arranger. He has recently been allowed to produce his own record, and some time past midnight he was airing out his arrangements for it.

title: Pay Down the Debt
description: To the Editor:

title: Fed Decision to Stand Pat Sends Treasury Prices Up
description: Bond prices ended higher yesterday after the Federal Reserve's policy-making committee voted to leave interest rates unchanged, although the gains were slight because most market participants had anticipated such a decision.

title: Shimer Looks To Lift Cloud Of Suspicion
description: The United States has not won an Olympic bobsled medal since 1956. At the past two Winter Games, Brian Shimer has arrived with high hopes as a driver but, four years ago, he never even made it to the finish line.

title: Clinton Plans Mentors for Low-Income Pupils
description: As part of his efforts to encourage students to attend college, President Clinton said today that he wanted to provide mentors to low-income students to help guide them toward college.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEINER, MOLLIE S.
description: KLEINER-Mollie S. On February 3, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Saul. Loving mother of Stan and Helene Kleiner, Eleanor and Norman Michaeloff. Cherished grandmother of Stacy, Tom and Andrew. Services Thursday 1:15PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about a study of elderly people who avoid dependence on others reversed the names of a researcher whose agency helped finance it. He is Dr. Chhanda Dutta, not Dutta Chhanda.

title: To Serve Art, Not Overwhelm It
description: What is the most satisfying new art museum building? I haven't seen I. M. Pei's Miho Museum of Art near Kyoto, but one could argue that the answer is neither Frank Gehry's Guggenheim in Bilbao, Spain, nor Richard Meier's Getty in Los Angeles but the less ballyhooed Fondation Beyeler here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHMAN, PRISCILLA
description: FISHMAN-Priscilla. The Gimprich Family Foundation records with profound sorrow the untimely death of Priscilla Fishman in Jerusalem. Priscilla's contribution to the State of Israel and Jewish life were of inestimable value. She touched hundreds of lives and will be remembered for her keen intellect, openess of mind and warmth. Just as we have been enriched by having known her, we are diminished by her passing. We share the sorrow of her beloved family. Her memory will be a blessing because she was a blessing. Judge Robert Satter, President Lila Gimprich d'Adolf, Vice President Max Nussbaum, Treasurer Rosalie Dolmatch, Recording Secretary Dr. Paul M. Steinberg, Secretary

title: Yeltsin Says Clinton Could Blunder Into a World War; Press Imagines Nuclear Attack
description: In remarks that seemed to astonish everyone but the man who delivered them, President Boris N. Yeltsin warned today that the United States activities in Iraq could lead to a world war.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAMES, STEPHEN D.
description: JAMES-Stephen D. (''Dan''). On January 30, 1998. Co-founder and longtime President of Citizen Exchange Corps, devoted to reducing U.S.-Soviet tensions. Husband of Teddy and, later, Denise. Father of the late Stephen D., Jr., Aram, Timothy, Megan and Caitlin. Grandfather of Sean, Lewis, Matthew and Marina. Memorial service on Sunday, February 8, 2:00 P.M., at Horne-Dannecker Funeral Home, 336 West 23rd Street, New York, NY. Memorials to the American Cancer Society.

title: Chicago Tower Is Sold
description: Cambridge Shopping Centres Ltd., a Canadian real estate concern, said today that it had sold a 35-story office tower in Chicago to a joint venture of the Lincoln Property Company and the Goldman Sachs Whitehall Fund, an investment arm of Goldman, Sachs & Company. The companies paid $93 million (Canadian), or more than $64 million (United States). The 512,000-square-foot building is in the West Loop near the Sears Tower.

title: PHARMACOPEIA IN STOCK DEAL FOR MOLECULAR SIMULATIONS
description: Pharmacopeia Inc., a company based in Princeton, N.J., that develops technologies used in drug discovery, agreed yesterday to buy Molecular Simulations Inc. for about $140 million. Pharmacopeia said it would acquire Molecular Simulations' stock for about seven million newly issued shares of Pharmacopeia. Pharmacopeia will also convert outstanding Molecular Simulations options into Pharmacopeia options, which could result in the issuance of another 1.5 million shares. The deal is structured as a tax-free exchange. Molecular Simulations, of San Diego, provides predictive modeling software and services.

title: Times Company Profit Rose For Year and 4th Quarter
description: The New York Times Company said yesterday that operating earnings rose 18 percent in the fourth quarter.

title: Derailed Train Hoisted Back on Track
description: In a delicate nine-hour operation hampered by rain and gusting winds, emergency workers looped cables under four derailed subway cars and hoisted them back onto an elevated track yesterday after the train crashed just outside a Bronx train yard on Tuesday night.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Defenders of Thomas Still Don't Get It
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Doesn't Dispute Italians Over 'Recklessness' in Crash
description: The American military jet that sliced through the cables of a ski lift in Italy and killed 20 people appeared to have been flying far below the minimum authorized altitude for training missions, Defense Department officials said today.

title: Unusual Fat Accumulations Follow a New Therapy for AIDS
description: Paunches, buffalo humps in the neck, puffy cheeks and other unusual accumulations of fat are changing the body shapes of a surprising number of people taking the newer combination therapies to combat the AIDS virus, doctors said here today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTEIN, MAX J., M.D.
description: WEINSTEIN-Max J., M.D. On February 3, 1998. The last of seven children, at the age of 92. Adored by his patients. Beloved husband of the late Esther, devoted father to his son Kenneth who followed in his footsteps, his daughter Marcia who passed away in 1958, and his daughter-in-law Frida. Services private. Contributions in his name can be made to Isabella Geriatric Center, 515 Audubon Avenue, New York, New York 10040.

title: Big 3 to Make Cleaner Cars Than Required
description: General Motors, Ford and Chrysler said this evening that they would begin delivering cars next year that emit 70 percent less of some pollutants, in a deal with the Government on Federal pollution standards.

title: Rutgers Hires Mulcahy to Improve Sports Image
description: Rutgers University, where athletic fortunes and finances have suffered in recent years, made a major move yesterday to get well again by naming a new athletic director. As expected, the job went to Robert E. Mulcahy 3d, who for 19 years has been the president and chief executive officer of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority.

title: Houses Now
description: This new column takes a periodic look at the design and construction of new homes, assessing the challenges facing architects and clients, their aspirations -- and the realities.

title: Public Eye; The globe moves from serious tool to pop knickknack
description: THE world has changed, and the globe is trying to keep up, sometimes with the addition of computer chips and flashing lights. At mall shops like Exploratorium and Rand McNally, globes are presented as teaching tools, with built-in computers to light up Addis Ababa, or in the case of the Talking Globe sold at Zany Brainy, to pronounce it.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  STERLING, SHEP
description: STERLING-Shep. Feb. 5, 1988. ''And who shall say Whatever disenchantment follows That we ever forget magic, Or that we can ever betray, On this leaden earth, the appletree The singing, And the gold?'' Joey

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Cadbury Schweppes's stock has run up despite loose ends in its American soft-drink business.
description: INVESTORS in Cadbury Schweppes gave a collective sigh of relief when the company announced last month that it had extended a bottling agreement for its Dr Pepper soft drink through 2005.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARZ, ERWIN
description: SCHWARZ-Erwin, 93. Of Tucson, Arizona formerly of New York City and of Scarsdale, N.Y. Died in Gaithersburg, Maryland on February 1, 1998. He was married to the late Louise Lasker Schwarz for over 40 years and leaves his wife of 23 years Julia B. (Judy) Schwarz, three children, Arthur of Scarsdale, N.Y., Peggy Akin of Phoenix, Arizona and John of Tucson, Arizona, eight grandchildren and ten great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at, The Harmonie Club, 4 East 60th St N.Y. N.Y., on Sunday, February 8, 2 PM. Contributions may be made to the Ethical Culture Fieldston Schools, 33 Central Park West, New York, New York 10023.

title: Trade Secrets; An Impromptu Bouquet To Say 'I Love You'
description: PICKING a bouquet for Valentine's Day at a flower stall offers a chance to wander in an exotic and seasonless garden. But eventually the shopper has to choose from the abundance. Which will it be? Exuberant tulips that come ruffled in yellow tinged with red, or oval ones in a white that blushes pink? Orchids like tiny butterflies alighting on a stem in pale lime deepening to chartreuse, or rust-speckled orchids in bronze? Then there are the roses, which after all signify love. But do they have to be red and long-stemmed? What about dusky lavender with the sweet-tart smell of star fruit? Or a spray of multi-stemmed roses that look as if they had just been plucked off a fence?

title: Lopez and Artest Carry St. John's Nearer to a Bid
description: Felipe Lopez has already envisioned the glorious scene. He will be sitting in front of a big-screen television with his St. John's teammates on a Sunday night in March. He will be waiting to hear those words he has waited to hear for four years. Something about being invited to a dance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHIFF, HANNAH GOODMAN
description: SCHIFF-Hannah Goodman, 97, on February 3 at Jewish Home and Hospital, formerly of Woodmere, NY, widow of David M. Schiff, died 1976. She will be lovingly remembered by her daughters Ellyn Berman and Sheila Schwartz, her sons-in-law Benjamin Berman and Irving Schwartz and her grandchildren Suellen Carman, Sally Lang, John Berman, Jessica Berman and Paul Berman. She is also survived by one sister Esther Schiff of Rockville, MD. We acknowledge with appreciation the loyal care given by Debbie Mengrone during her last years.

title: A Naval 'Big Stick' Is Brandished
description: Already home to a powerful American and British armada, the waters and skies of the Persian Gulf are about to become even more crowded.

title: Higher Milk Prices
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR DROPS AGAINST YEN. The Japanese yen rose sharply against the dollar yesterday, helped by speculation about possible economic-stimulus measures by the Government and by a perception that financial crises in Asia might be easing. The dollar fell to 123.63 yen from 125.94 on Tuesday.

title: Tobacco Deal Lets the Industry Off the Hook
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDGELL, JAMES C.
description: EDGELL-James C. On February 3, 1998. Beloved husband of Mary Jean (nee Leighton). Loving father of James L., Donald C., and Katherine C. Edgell. Cherished grandfather of six. Funeral Friday 8:30 AM, from the Marine Park Funeral Home, 3024 Quentin Road, Brooklyn. Mass at St. Brendan's R.C. Church, 9:30 A.M., interment St. Charles Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STREIT, JACK
description: STREIT-Jack. On February 3, 1998, after a long illness. President of Aron Streit, Inc., matzo bakers since the turn of the century. Beloved husband of the late Ruth Katz Streit. Devoted father of Myrna Heilbrun, Nettie Streit and the late Arlyne Yagoda. Loving grandfather of Aron, Michele, Nanette and Philip. Proud great grandfather of Andrew and Brittany. Services at Boulevard-Riverside Chapel, 312 Coney Island Avenue at Prospect Park, Bklyn Friday, February 6th, 12 Noon.

title: ABC Rail Products in Deal
description: The ABC Rail Products Corporation has agreed to acquire Transit and Rail Systems Inc., the systems engineering unit of the closely held Vanasse Hangen Brustlin Inc., which is based in Watertown, Mass. Financial terms were not disclosed. ABC Rail, a railroad-equipment company based in Chicago, had 1997 sales of $259.2 million. The acquisition provides ABC's systems services unit, American Systems Technologies Inc., with a stronger Northeast presence, ABC said.

title: Chinese Directors Visit as Films Start U.S. Tour
description: The acclaimed filmmaker Zhang Yimou will lead a delegation of China's prominent directors, actors and film and television executives to Columbia University today for a public seminar on Chinese films that begins a North American tour saluting five decades of Chinese cinema.

title: Houses Now; Is it an Ark? A Barn? In Spirit, a Bit of Both
description: BLUEPRINT -- A 5,000-square-foot weekend house in Sagaponack, N.Y., for a family with two children. Six bedrooms, four baths and an 18- by-32-foot vaulted living/dining room.

title: Schools Load Up With Local Talent
description: Micah Barnes could not sleep Tuesday night. The next morning, he and four teammates from the Long Island Class 2 football champions would be the center of a long-anticipated celebration.

title: The Neediest Cases; In a Safe Environment After Years of Abuse
description: In her 16 years, Quintele Carmichael has lived in nine homes, endured two rapes and innumerable beatings, and mourned the deaths of four family members. So it is little wonder that she sometimes wishes for a time machine so she could go back and change her past.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWANN, CHRISTINE S.
description: SWANN-Christine S. Elaborate, delicate power of the honeyed mother. Gift of worship, love and spring. Woman of the wind. Girl of the moon. Her glorious love by the sea. Chanting in the garden. You are me. My friend always, Lindy.

title: For Duke and North Carolina, Round 1 in a Title Fight
description: The emotions cannot obscure the process. When Duke meets North Carolina here Thursday night, two teams separated by 11 miles, but just one spot at the top of the college basketball polls, will meet in the most highly anticipated game of the year. But for the top-ranked Blue Devils (20-1) and the No. 2 Tar Heels (22-1), this game marks the beginning of what could be a passion play in four acts.

title: When the Game Was All Business
description: What Walt Frazier remembers vividly about his first National Basketball Association All-Star Game was the seriousness of it -- so different, he says, from the game now.

title: Las Vegas Journal; At Hotel-Casino, Triumphant Shouts of 'Union!'
description: Joseph Daugherty is thinking about taking a vacation. As an organizer for the Culinary Workers Union Local 226 in Las Vegas, he has not taken a day off since Sept. 21, 1991, when 550 workers -- maids, cocktail waitresses, bartenders, cooks -- walked off their jobs at the Frontier hotel and casino to protest the resort's treatment of its employees.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILEY, W. BRADFORD
description: WILEY-W. Bradford. The Board of Directors and staff of the National Book Foundation extend condolences to the Chairman of our Board, Deborah Wiley, and to the entire Wiley family on the passing of W. Bradford Wiley. He was a stalwart pioneer in book publishing, and he has left a magnificent legacy. Neil Baldwin, Executive Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIAMS, CHARLES ''CI''
description: WILLIAMS-Charles ''CI''. On Feb. 4th, 1998. Reposing Saturday, February 7, 8-9 A.M., followed by funeral mass at 9 AM at St. John's Episcopal Church, 536 S. Franklin Street, Hempstead, New York.

title: Israeli Officials Split Over Plan To Settle Jews in East Jerusalem
description: The Israeli Interior Ministry announced today that it had approved plans for Jewish housing in an Arab neighborhood in East Jerusalem, prompting spokesmen for Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to assert that he would block the project because of its political sensitivity.

title: No Tickets? No Problem
description: For fans shut out of the All-Star Weekend festivities, the National Basketball Association has an answer: www.nba.com. Today through Sunday, fans can log on to the official Web site of the N.B.A. and, via remote cameras, see events such as the All-Star Game, rookie game and 3-point shootout, as well as all the behind-the-scenes preparations.

title: In the 19th Century, Parting Is Still Sweet Sorrow
description: The Montagues and the Capulets could be headed off to Ascot in ''My Fair Lady'' in the Acting Company's new production of ''Romeo and Juliet.'' Shakespeare's tale of star-crossed teen-agers has been moved to the late 19th century, with the help of Ann Hould-Ward's gorgeous costumes. Strangely, most of Juliet's wardrobe seems to have been shipped in from the Renaissance, but this is not a complaint. The dresses are beautiful, and if they set the heroine apart as a vision from another world, that makes it easier to see her from Romeo's point of view.

title: Killing Takes a Life Marked by Giving
description: Until Tuesday night, Michelle Bedward's interest in crime and punishment was strictly academic.

title: Crumbling Knicks Stagger Into the All-Star Break
description: The Knicks had been so eager to pick themselves up and dust themselves off when Patrick Ewing went down. But starting over has lost its novelty.

title: AT HOME WITH: Jonathan Ive; Making Computers Cute Enough to Wear
description: THE afternoon sun is spilling through the living room windows of this house perched on a hill overlooking the city where the computer designer Jonathan Ive is talking about creating computers based on what he calls ''emotional human forms.''

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: An Urban Mini-Agenda
description: When a President unveils a new budget, state and local officials around the country rush to parse it. Analyzing the proposals for new spending here, retrenchment there, they weigh, measure and finally decree whether or not the entire package is ''good'' for the home team. This is the first time in a long while that New York City, or American cities in general, could deliver a positive verdict.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARFIELD, YETTA
description: GARFIELD-Yetta. Devoted wife of the late Morris Cooperstein and mother of Jane Wyker and the late Walter Cooperstein. Grandmother of six and great-grandmother of seven. Rest in peace eternal.

title: Arts in America; Confronting Texas, Myths and All, With a Camera
description: Maybe the old, rural Texas was more picturesque. But the state's big-city maturity has distinctions of its own.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, SAUL
description: KLEIN-Saul. Of Beverly Hills, CA, formerly of New York City. Born Vienna, Austria, 4/13/16. Died in Los Angeles, 2/3/98. With brothers and sisters, founded Barton's Bonbonniere, America's first kosher European chocolates. Survived by his children, Jessica and David, both of Los Angeles, sister Sofie Kahan of Brooklyn, brothers Arthur of Detroit and Isaac of Brooklyn, and granddaughter Shira Wasserman of Los Angeles. Funeral Thursday, February 5, 1:00PM, at Norman Jeffers Community Chapel, 4620 Fort Hamilton Parkway, Brooklyn. Interment at Bet Moses, Pine Lawn. Familty will receive visitors at the home of Ruth Pollack, 310 East 75th Street, Apt 6G, New York, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to The Federation of Jewish Philanthropies.

title: Two Universities Are Given $100 Million Each
description: In one of the largest private donations ever to higher education, a California entrepreneur said today that he was giving $100 million each to the University of Southern California and the University of California at Los Angeles to set up biomedical research institutes.

title: Metro Matters; The Greening Of D'Amato, Up From Zero
description: FOR Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, it was a good news-bad news kind of day.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 7.

title: PRO BASKETBALL: NOTEBOOK; The Mayor Holds Court
description: ''No shot, no money.'' And for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, no problem.

title: Unwitting Doctors and Patients Exploited in a Vast Billing Fraud
description: Government fraud investigators are trying to unravel a widening scheme in which phony medical bills using the names of unsuspecting patients and doctors are being submitted to private insurers.

title: Gatemala Stuns Brazil With a Tie
description: Midfielder Martin Machon of Guatemala smiled last night as he tried to put his country's 1-1 tie with mighty Brazil in perspective.

title: Yanks about to Get Their Man
description: The Yankees' search for a leadoff hitter and a second baseman appears to be over. Yesterday they completed a trade for All-Star second baseman Chuck Knoblauch of the Twins.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RHULEN, WALTER A.
description: RHULEN-Walter A. Frontier Insurance Group, Inc, announces today that due to overwhelming response, the location of the memorial service for Walter A. Rhulen, Sunday, February 8, 1998, at 11 AM, has been changed from Frontier Insurance Group's corporate headquarters, to the Field House at Sullivan County Community College, Loch Sheldrake, New York. For additional information and directions, contact Jeanne Jennings at 914-976-2100 ext 5180.

title: COMMONWEALTH ENERGY TO BUY A PLANT FROM HARVARD
description: Commonwealth Energy System agreed yesterday to buy a chilled water, steam and electricity plant from Harvard University for $147 million in cash. Commonwealth Energy, based in Cambridge, Mass., said the plant, called the Medical Area Total Energy Plant, would be run by its Advanced Energy Systems unit. The company said it planned to continue to serve all of the plant's customers, which include Harvard Medical School and several hospitals and medical centers. Advanced Energy said it also planned to use the plant as a base to provide steam and chilled water services to other customers.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Dieter Roth

title: An Amiable Defender of Colleges Under Fire
description: IT says something about Leon M. Goldstein that, even now, he does not have an unkind word for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: Bad News, Silver Lining For Indonesian Laborers
description: At precisely 3 P.M. today, the heavy blue gate of the Gunawan steel plant slid open and hundreds of young men poured through to hear an announcement they dreaded. Would their factory reopen in the morning, and would all of them still have jobs if it did?

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in the Television section last Sunday with a highlight entry for Wednesday night misidentified the actor dancing with Billy Wilder on the set of ''Some Like It Hot.'' He was Jack Lemmon, not Tony Curtis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMPBELL, ALAN K.
description: CAMPBELL-Alan K. The trustees, staff and associates of The Institute of Public Administration mourn the death of fellow trustee Alan K. Campbell. Scotty's leadership, wisdom and wit were an inspiration to all who worked with him. His friendship will be sorely missed.

title: Statements Issued by Starr and Ginsburg
description: Following is a statement issued last night by Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater independent counsel, about the possibility of an agreement for Monica S. Lewinsky to testify before a grand jury, as provided by Mr. Starr's office in Washington. Below it is a statement released later by Ms. Lewinsky's lawyer, William H. Ginsburg, as provided by The Associated Press:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: MARK RALLIES. The mark rose against the dollar and the yen despite a report showing German unemployment at a postwar high of 4.8 million people. Talk of selling by large hedge funds hurt the dollar, as did worries about President Clinton's problems. The dollar slipped to 1.7867 marks from 1.8013.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Technology; Cleaner Cars, No Magic Required
description: NOW that the Big Three auto makers have agreed to a compromise under which they will produce cleaner vehicles than Federal regulations now require, cars will have new hardware, beginning next year in the Northeast and in 2001 in the rest of the country outside of California. But the differences under the hood are likely to be minor.

title: Nine West in Shoe Deal
description: Sears P.L.C. of Britain said today that it had agreed to sell its Cable & Company shoe business to Nine West Group Inc. for about $:11 million, or $18 million. Sears, based in London, is a retail store operator with no ties to Sears Roebuck & Company. Nine West, based in Stamford, Conn., makes and sells women's footwear and accessories.

title: Spinning a Magic Spell for Dancing the Night Away
description: Late on a Saturday night, the dance floor is packed at Twilo, a club in Chelsea's far-western warehouse area. At 4:30 A.M., go-go boys wearing fluorescent yellow briefs undulate atop speakers the size of compact cars; gym-toned men in T-shirts, along with a few women, work up a sweat, whooping when a drumbeat kicks in. Presiding from the disk jockey booth is Junior Vasquez, whose marathon sets -- from about 1 A.M. to as late as noon on Sunday -- have been a New York Saturday night ritual for a decade.

title: SUNGARD DATA TO ACQUIRE A BRITISH SOFTWARE MAKER
description: Sungard Data Systems Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the British software maker Rolfe & Nolan P.L.C. for $115 million in stock. Rolfe & Nolan, based in London, supplies risk management software for global treasury and capital markets operations, and settlement software for the derivatives industry. The company has data centers at four sites that support about 280 customers in 23 countries. Sungard Data, based in Wayne, Pa., provides investment support systems. Sungard will exchange between 0.2750 and 0.3100 of a share for each Rolfe & Nolan share, with the exact ratio to be determined later. Sungard's shares closed yesterday at $31.3125, up 12.5 cents.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Wes Mills

title: Draculian Gore, Sound and Fury
description: When Richard Dees (Miguel Ferrer), a terminally cynical tabloid reporter in ''Stephen King's 'The Night Flier,' '' explains his philosophy of journalism, it boils down to two sentences: ''Never believe what you publish. And never publish what you believe.''

title: Sports of The Times; Tyson Is Just One of the Three Stooges
description: HIS hair had grown back. And an occasional smile had replaced his smirk.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Tuesday about a Junior Achievement program that pairs students with professionals for a day misidentified an event attended by Peter F. Vallone, the City Council Speaker, and Rumel Ahmed, 13, a student at Intermediate School 104 in Manhattan. It was a meeting with parents on overcrowding in schools, not a City Hall meeting on the Work Experience Program.

title: Prices Fall on Concern Over Jobs Data and Iraq
description: Treasury securities prices plunged yesterday, hurt in part by concern about today's employment report for January and by the prospect of a military confrontation with Iraq.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LASKY, CHARLES AND ESTELLE
description: LASKY-Charles and Estelle. February 6th We remember our mother and father on this their anniversary day... and every day... Great and grandchildren and George and Joyce

title: Op-Art
Share Prices End Mixed, With the Dow Falling by 12.46
description: Stock prices ended mixed yesterday for the second straight session as prices dipped again for many blue chips, but other signposts in the market pointed to increasing optimism.

title: Cristobal Martinez-Bordiu, 75, Surgeon Who Cared for Franco
description: Cristobal Martinez-Bordiu, a surgeon who married Gen. Francisco Franco's only child in 1950 and later led the medical team attending the dictator until his death in 1975, died on Wednesday in the Ruber Internacional hospital in Madrid. He was 75.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARZ, ERWIN
description: SCHWARZ-Erwin, 93. Of Tucson, Arizona formerly of New York City and of Scarsdale, N.Y. Died in Gaithersburg, Maryland on February 1, 1998. He was married to the late Louise Lasker Schwarz for over 40 years and leaves his wife of 23 years Julia B. (Judy) Schwarz, three children, Arthur of Scarsdale, N.Y., Peggy Akin of Phoenix, Arizona and John of Tucson, Arizona, eight grandchildren and ten great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at, The Harmonie Club, 4 East 60th St N.Y. N.Y., on Sunday, February 8, 2 PM. Contributions may be made to the Ethical Culture Fieldston Schools, 33 Central Park West, New York, New York 10023.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EILENBERG, SAMUEL
description: EILENBERG - Samuel. The Trustees and staff of The Metropolitan Museum of Art mourn the passing of Samuel Eilenberg, a longtime friend and Benefactor of the Museum. His generous gift of Indian and Southeast Asian works of art from a superb collection that he amassed over decades has greatly enhanced The Metropolitan's collections and will endure in the galleries for a grateful public. Philippe de Montebello, Director

title: Ethical Killer Teams Up With a Gun-Toting Forger
description: ''The Replacement Killers'' is such a sleek piece of filmmaking that it suggests the visual equivalent of an ambient dance record. The soundtrack's measured beats and dabs of generically dramatic orchestration are synchronized with the movie's continual gunfire and the gliding camera movements to sustain a mood that is dreamlike and almost lulling.

title: Sports of The Times; The Torch That Passes Ever Quickly
description: THE urgency was so familiar to Tommy Moe, the ushering of the latest mountain stud from the pack of reporters to the horde of cameras to the ski bums who just wanted to get a look. Four years ago, it was Moe who stole the Olympic stage with a sudden burst of guile and gall, as if he'd dropped from the start of the downhill in Kvitjell, Norway, and landed smack dab in the v.i.p. seat next to Letterman, then Leno.

title: Pooh-Cornered, Blair Cedes Bear
description: After a morning of breast-beating over the proper home for Winnie-the-Pooh and four other British-made dolls -- including a news release issued by City Hall quoting Pooh himself -- the British Government said yesterday that it would not seek the return of the ragged stuffed animals.

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: New Miller Play To Feature Falk

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADELSOHN, BLANCHE
description: ADELSOHN-Blanche. On February 4, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Clement. Loving mother of Lois and Neil Heller and the late Martin and Myrna. Cherished grandmother of Rhonda, Bruce, Evan, Richard, Daniel, Susan, Philip, Marc and Wendy, and great-grandmother of Andrew and Melissa. Dear sister of Sydell.

title: Observer; Eddie Was Up at Key Largo
description: The country was half-mad with tales of sex. ''At the highest level,'' as they used to say before the Presidency became a display window for second childhood.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: 'Pollock, Orozco and Siqueiros'

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Film; Eight-Millimeter Innovators: Beginnings
description: What's the difference between friendly and carnivorous violence, between people rolling around on the grass and animals preying on each other for food? It's all part of the same physical instinct, isn't it? Phil Solomon's grainy 14-minute home movie, ''The Exquisite Hour,'' compares images of the members of an extended family affectionately roughhousing on a farm with those of wild animals frolicking and preying on one another in an unidentified veldt. Even in the scenes of deadly prey, there is a powerful sense of intimacy, of a ritual with which the participants are profoundly familiar.

title: Rookie Is Living a Capra-esque Tale
description: His older brother started calling him Yogi when he was 2 years old because of his resemblance to the cartoon character Yogi Bear. That explains the nickname, but everything else about Michael Stewart's life is borrowed from a Frank Capra script.

title: The Gray Lady of the Sea Turns Noir
description: When an unhappy screenwriter borrows a beach house in Nantucket to try to break through writer's block, you just don't expect serial killers, snuff videos and a crazy man pointing a nail gun at the hero's hands. But in John Johnson's peculiar drama ''Ratchet,'' that's what you get.

title: Tyson Confirms a Split With His Two Managers
description: Proclaiming that he was ''doing my own thing,'' Mike Tyson spoke for himself yesterday and confirmed that he has dismissed his co-managers, John Horne and Rory Holloway, and that he was trying to extricate himself from Don King, the powerful boxing promoter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARLOWE, SELWYN
description: MARLOWE - Selwyn, 73. Of Mineola. Jazz trumpet virtuoso. Loving father of Elizabeth and Jane. Beloved grandpa of Jackson and Katie. Graveside service on Sunday, Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, New Jersey.

title: Beyond Basketball's 'Bad Boy'
description: The longest-playing psychodrama in the National Basketball Association, a league known for its temperamental showmanship, is undoubtedly the one featuring Dennis Rodman.

title: A Fab Price
description: John Lennon told a British newspaper in 1965 that the Beatles were ''bigger than Jesus.'' ARTHUR UNGER, the publisher of Datebook (''more or less an official Beatles magazine,'' he said) quickly reprinted the interview -- and sent it to Bible-belt radio stations.

title: A Brotherly Reprise, Wrecks and All
description: After 18 years, the Blues Brothers are back. Their band is belting, and the audiences that have happily traveled this wreck-littered highway before can't be faulted for believing that ''Blues Brothers 2000'' has been worth the wait.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARSZALKIEWICZ, EDWARD A.
description: MARSZALKIEWICZ-Edward A. Of Bronxville, NY on February 4, 1998. Son of the late William and Margaret Marszalkiewicz. Mass of Christian Burial St. Joseph's Church Bronxville on Saturday, February 7 at 10 A.M.

title: Golfers Don't 'Walk for Dough'; Level Playing Field
description: To the Editor:

title: DATA ON TOBACCO SHOW A STRATEGY AIMED AT BLACKS
description: A steady flow of tobacco-industry documents released in recent days is providing the broadest and most detailed look yet at how the industry lavishly marketed cigarette brands like Kools to some of its heaviest-smoking customers, blacks.

title: Police Officer Indicted In an Off-Duty Assault
description: A city police officer was indicted yesterday for assaulting a 23-year-old man while off duty in December, law enforcement officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, LOLA
description: KAUFMAN-Lola. On February 5, 1998 in her 99th year. Beloved wife of the late Bert; mother of Bunnie Leeds and Joan Claster. Adored grandmother, great grandmother. You were one in a million!

title: Queens Sends Its New Voice to Congress
description: Gregory W. Meeks wasted no time today in making the transition from Assemblyman to Congressman from the Sixth District in Queens. A day and a half after his victory in a special election to succeed the Rev. Floyd H. Flake as Representative, Mr. Meeks caught an early flight for the swearing-in at the Capitol and to encounter firsthand the whirlwind that such transitions entail.

title: Capel Name Dropped From HSBC Unit
description: Closing 122 years of history, HSBC Holdings P.L.C., the British investment bank, said yesterday that it would change the name of its institutional equity broking and research unit from HSBC James Capel to HSBC Securities.

title: JP FOODSERVICE TO TAKE CHARGES OF UP TO $145 MILLION
description: JP Foodservice Inc. said yesterday that costs related to its purchase of Rykoff-Sexton Inc. would result in pretax charges of as much as $145 million. JP Foodservice, which distributes food to restaurants, hospitals and other institutions, said the charges would cover paying severance to workers who were dismissed, refinancing debt, writing down the value of some assets and paying fees from the purchase of Rykoff, which was completed in December. About $110 million in pretax charges were taken in the second quarter, which ended on Dec. 27. The rest will be taken in the third quarter. Shares of JP Foodservice, based in Columbia, Md., fell 75 cents yesterday, to $34.50.

title: AIDE'S STATEMENTS ARE SAID TO DIFFER FROM PRESIDENT'S
description: President Clinton's personal secretary has told investigators that Mr. Clinton called her into his office last month and led her through an account of his relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky that differs in one critical aspect from her own recollections, said lawyers familiar with her account.

title: For Pasta Lovers
description: Pasta restaurants are everywhere in New York City, but it sometimes seems as if they all have the same menu, endlessly repeated. Here are 12 restaurants where the pasta is noteworthy either because the preparations are unusual or because it is exceptionally good. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from Ruth Reichl's and Mr. Asimov's dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, CONRAD H.
description: STEIN-Conrad H. Of New Canaan, CT on February 4, 1998. Survivors include: two daughters, Anne M. Stein and Angie Matt; a son, Conrad Stein Jr.; grandchildren J. Kemper Matt Jr., Julie Morgan Matt, and Conrad Alexander Matt. Memorial Mass Saturday 11 AM, St. Aloysius Church, Cherry Street, New Canaan, CT.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, WALLACE (WALLY)
description: SCHWARTZ-Wallace (Wally). Beloved husband of Evelyn. Devoted father of Julie Levine, Susan Meltzer and Gerri Hirschhorn. Dear brother of Ruth Kamzan. Cherished son-in-law of Claire Trupin. Loving father-in-law of Leonard. Adored grandfather of Gavin, Andrew, Jamie and Emma. Services today, 1 P.M., at ''Parkside'' Memorial Chapels, Queens Blvd and 66th Avenue, Rego Park.

title: A Reorganization Is Expected at America Online
description: Just a year and half after creating a division to nurture on-line programming, America Online is preparing to dismantle the unit in a management reorganization that would shift both the company's focus and executive power, people close to the company said yesterday.

title: Brown Offered Pay Cut; 3-Year Pact for Daluiso
description: The Giants have told Dave Brown they want him to take a pay cut and return next season as a backup to Danny Kanell, but Brown told the team he wants time to consider all his options, according to the quarterback's agent, Leigh Steinberg. Brown could ask to be traded or request his release.

title: Betty Currie's Testimony
description: White House insistence that Kenneth Starr's investigation is an unwarranted exploration of the President's sex life keeps getting undermined by reports that raise the issue of obstruction of justice. As President, Bill Clinton has vast powers, but by law and Presidential tradition, none permit cancellation of statutory law or intervention in legal processes like sworn depositions in civil suits and grand jury testimony. For that reason, the report in today's Times that Betty Currie, the President's secretary, told investigators she was summoned by the President shortly after he had given sworn testimony to hear a detailed account in which he asserted he had never been alone with Monica Lewinsky marks a somber turn in this story. Mrs. Currie later told investigators they had, in fact, been alone. She also reportedly retrieved gifts Mr. Clinton gave Ms. Lewinsky that had been subpoenaed.

title: 44 Blocks of Enchantment
description: As it approaches West 72d Street on its way uptown, the M5 bus crosses lanes and begins to bear left on Broadway, hesitating by the old subway house, where it stands and shifts a while in the shadow of the Ansonia like someone waiting in the cold. Then, with a sudden, jittery swoop, it takes a sharp left turn and enters what will always remain, despite the crowd, traffic and drab, faded storefronts, a beguiling kingdom where, enchanted by twilight snow, ordinary city life is touched by magic and legend.

title: Cosmopolitan Replaces Editors
description: Cosmopolitan, the women's magazine that began 1998 by losing two high-ranking editors to Maxim, an upstart men's magazine, named five new editors yesterday. Replacing the two are JAMES MAURO, the new executive editor, and CELESTE MITCHELL, the new deputy editor. Filling new slots are CAROL BRIETZKE and MICHAEL LEWITTES as senior articles editors, and MEGAN FITZMORRIS as senior editor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRISON, PHILIP
description: HARRISON-Philip. On February 5, 1998. The Twenty Five Year Club of Asiel & Co. LLC mourns the passing of our former partner and friend. The entire organization expresses condolences to the family. Thomas Fusco, Club Pres.

title: 2 Queens Teachers Test Positive for Tuberculosis
description: Two teachers at a Queens intermediate school where a student fell ill with tuberculosis have tested positive for the bacterium that causes the disease, but they do not appear to have contracted it from the student, school and health officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASSILLY, RICHARD
description: CASSILLY-Richard. The students, faculty, and staff of the School for the Arts at Boston University mourn the loss of our friend and faculty colleague, Richard Cassilly. A wonderfully gifted singer and devoted teacher, he was loved and admired by his many students and fellow artists alike. We will miss him greatly and we express our sincere condolences to his wife Patricia and his family. Bruce MacCombie Dean Phyllis Hoffman Music Divsion Director

title: Fatigued Nets Heed Williams's Warning
description: Jayson Williams was tired, feeling the effects of the 11-day road trip the Nets had just returned from, and anticipating the hectic schedule that he will be carried through as the unofficial goodwill ambassador of the National Basketball Association's All-Star Weekend.

title: I.O.C. Picks 9 New Members
description: Nine new members were voted onto the International Olympic Committee this morning, and two of them were of royal blood, His Royal Highness the Prince of Orange of the Netherlands and His Royal Highness the Prince Henri of Luxembourg.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SZABO, SZILARD (PAPA)
description: SZABO-Szilard (Papa). February 5, 1918-February 6, 1997. Not a day goes by without me missing you. I will love you forever. Juci Hus

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARTENBERG, ANN
description: GARTENBERG-Ann. The City College of New York mourns the passing of Mrs. Ann Gartenberg. On behalf of the City College community, I wish to extend my condolences to her husband, Seymour, and to her family. Yolanda T. Moses, President The City College of New York/ CUNY

title: A Skater Soaks in Every Moment
description: Tara Lipinski and Akebono showed up at figure-skating practice today, but only one of them ventured onto the ice. At 6 feet 8 inches, 516 pounds, the grand champion sumo wrestler has not yet perfected his triple axel. ''I never skated,'' said Akebono, a native of Hawaii whose given name is Chad Rowan. ''Too dangerous.''

title: Merrill Lynch Names Financial Officer
description: Merrill Lynch & Company said on Wednesday that it had named E. Stanley O'Neal as chief financial officer starting March 1.

title: On My Mind; Feeling Clean Again
description: For four hours, at a meeting in Washington Wednesday, I felt I was standing in a wonderful warm, soapy shower that washed off the muck and meanness of the White House scandal and scrubbed away the itchy rash of embarrassment that a great nation had to deal with that kind of nastiness. I thought -- how lovely if every American could stand under the water and feel the lightness of cleansing.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: William Kentridge

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEWANTER, DAVID
description: GEWANTER-David. Beloved husband of the late Dorothy. Devoted father of Michael and Arlene Gewanter, and Joyce and Michael Bonder. Loving grandfather of Alyson Gewanter, Amy and Adam Curcio, Arin and Sandy Sandorfi, Adam Gewanter, Cherie Bonder and Robert Bonder. Services ''Boulevard - Riverside,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island, 9:30 A.M., on Friday.

title: Foster Mother Is Arrested In Fire Deaths of Two Boys
description: A foster mother was charged with two counts of criminally negligent homicide last night after two young boys in her care died yesterday in a fire in their Bronx apartment, the police said.

title: A Russian Violinist Uses a Romantic Approach in a Debut
description: Anton Barachovsky, the Russian violinist who was one of the Young Concert Artists audition winners last year, presented his credentials in a thoughtfully played debut recital on Tuesday evening at the 92d Street Y. Like most of the young musicians who win this quasi competition, Mr. Barachovsky has considerable performing experience. He was born in Siberia and completed his training in Germany, and besides winning competitions in Prague and Beijing, as well as fourth prize at the 1990 Tchaikovsky Competition in Moscow, he has toured extensively in Europe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENSING, ROBERT F.
description: BENSING-Robert F. Age 42. Of Atlanta, Georgia. Died on February 3, 1998. A prominent civil rights attorney, Mr. Bensing died as a result of injuries sustained in an automobile accident in Adel, GA. He was a graduate of Dickinson College in Carlisle, PA, where he was also a graduate of Dickinson College Law School. Surviving are his wife, Dr. Mary E. Schlegel, parents Russell and Helen Bensing, of Camp Hill, PA., brother Steven Russell Bensing, of Cleveland, OH., and many nieces and nephews. Funeral services will be held Saturday, February 7, at 1:00 PM, at Spring Hill, Msgr Daniel J. O'Connor officiating. The family will receive friends Friday evening from 6:00-8:00 PM at Spring Hill. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Southern Center for Human Rights, 83 Poplar Street NW, Atlanta, GA 30303. For information call H.M. Patterson & Son Funeral Home, Spring Hill Chapel, at 404-876-1022.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes highly recommended shows.

title: Workplace Needs Rules on Sex
description: To the Editor:

title: Jardine Fleming in Talks To Buy Peregrine Funds
description: Jardine Fleming Holdings Ltd. said yesterday that it was negotiating to buy an Asian bond fund and nine smaller funds from Peregrine Asset Management Ltd., a unit of the failed Peregrine Investments Holdings Ltd. of Hong Kong.

title: Asia Mostly Up, With Exceptions
description: Indonesian and South Korean stocks extended declines Thursday amid fears on companies' ability to pay foreign debts and sustain earnings. Other Asian markets rose.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: 'Abstraction in Process II'

title: Seoul Agrees on Layoffs and New Cuts in Effort to End Crisis
description: South Korea's President-elect, Kim Dae Jung, struck a landmark agreement today with business and unions that lays the groundwork for layoffs throughout the nation and brings the country a big step closer to resolving its economic crisis.

title: Tricky Mirror of Chinese Power
description: One of the great quiet sights in New York at the moment is the procession of ancient Chinese objects filling the ramp of the uptown branch of the Guggenheim Museum. Stone Buddhas smile from on high. Porcelain dishes hover like pools of cool light at midpoint. Toward the bottom, a group of terra-cotta soldiers, still warm with faint color after centuries of burial, appear ready to advance on Fifth Avenue.

title: Unnecessary Reunion Skates Over the Past
description: It wasn't the reunion of Martin & Lewis, Lewis & Clark or Clark & Lois. They would have all been more welcome than seeing Nancy & Tonya, uncomfortably reunited for cash in a Manhattan studio for Fox's iceploitation special, ''Breaking the Ice.'' There hasn't been an unhappier TV coupling since Rather & Chung.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, SAMUEL
description: BROWN-Samuel. On February 4, 1998. Beloved husband of Shirley. Devoted father of Dr. Harry and Jeanette Brown and Irene BrownFusco. Adored grandfather of Daniel and Wendy Brown and Vanessa Fusco. Dear brother of Anna Mintz and Bernard Brown. Services Sunday 9:45AM ''Sinai Chapels'', 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY.

title: In Close-Knit Army Community, Picking Jury for Soldier is Hard
description: In the United States Army, which is like a small town, just about every command sergeant major seems to know and admire Sgt. Maj. Gene C. McKinney and his identical twin, James.

title: New York's Education Band-Aid
description: Suppose that you were the chief executive officer of a large corporation with 1,100 branch offices. Suppose you understood that your competitors were paying their employees and supervisors about 20 percent more than you were and that many of your employees could not pass a simple entry-level test. Suppose you also understood that working conditions at many of your locations were terrible -- that roofs were leaking, windows were broken, supplies were antiquated and nearly a quarter of your buildings were heated by hand-fired coal furnaces. What would a smart chief executive do?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHODACZEK, ANTONINA
description: CHODACZEK-Antonina. On February 5, 1998. Beloved mother of Marcella and Alexander, Jr. Loving grandmother of Alexander III, Timothy and Gregory Chodaczek and Kateri McGrogan. Dearest great-grandmother of Christopher, Daniel and Michaela Chodaczek and Christopher and Timothy McGrogan. Friends may call at Knapp Funeral Home, Greenwich Avenue, Greenwich, Sunday from 4 to 8 P.M. A mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated Monday, February 9, at 10:30 AM, at St. Catherine of Siena Church in Riverside, CT.

title: Golfers Don't 'Walk for Dough'; So Carry the Clubs
description: To the Editor:

title: 10-Year-Old Charged In 3 Sexual Assaults
description: A 10-year-old Newark boy was charged yesterday in Essex County Family Court with sexually assaulting three children who are 10 years old or younger, county prosecutors said.

title: A. Keith Brodkin, 62, Mutual Fund Chief
description: A. Keith Brodkin, chairman and chief executive of MFS Investment Management, which oversees the MFS family of mutual funds, the country's 21st-largest fund company, died on Monday at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston. He was 62.

title: Push for Peace Shows Split Over Inspections
description: In the current crisis with Iraq, diplomatic emissaries have descended on Baghdad, all of them opposed to the heavy bombing that the United States has threatened and all of them willing to consider a compromise with Saddam Hussein to prevent it.

title: A Tough Act to Follow For Salt Lake City
description: Every morning, Deedee Corradini, the Mayor of Salt Lake City, gets her exercise by walking uphill to Zenkoji Temple, the spiritual center of these Winter Games. The daily workout reminds her of the challenges facing her city, the host of the next Winter Games in 2002.

title: The Focus Narrows, As Stark Images Herald A Time for Seriousness
description: The Canadian artist Jeff Wall is playing his cards closer and closer to his chest. His third solo exhibition in New York, at the Marian Goodman Gallery on West 57th Street, centers on the big black-and-white photographs that he started making in 1996. Dour and poker-faced, they make the equally large back-lighted color transparencies that established his reputation in the mid-1980's look loud and gaudy by comparison.

title: Yanks' Deal for Knoblauch in Selig's Court
description: The Yankees have agreed to a trade that will bring them Chuck Knoblauch, one of the game's premier leadoff hitters and second basemen. They have settled on the four minor leaguers they will send to Minnesota in exchange, the most prominent of whom is Eric Milton, their top pitching prospect.

title: Research on Anti-H.I.V. Drugs Is a Combination of Progress and Setback
description: Efforts to make it easier to take combinations of drugs to combat the AIDS virus have met with mixed results, scientists said here today.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Dara Friedman and Mark Handforth

title: Bill to Ban E-Z Pass Use In Identifying Speeders
description: A state lawmaker announced yesterday that he would introduce a bill to prevent the authorities from using E-Z Pass toll tags to catch speeding drivers.

title: No. 1 Duke Crumples As Jamison Scores 35
description: As the students in North Carolina blue raced onto the floor tonight, rejoicing at how easy the 97-73 victory over top-ranked Duke had appeared, there was one essential point for the Blue Devils to remember. Duke's long -- but potentially valuable -- night in the raucous Dean Smith Center, before a record crowd of 22,050, is but the first act of at least two, perhaps three, and maybe even four.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Eric Fischl

title: World Bank Lends $1 Billion to Manila
description: The World Bank president, James D. Wolfensohn, pledged an additional $1 billion in loans to the Philippines today, adding to another $1.16 billion in unspent loans already allocated to the country. Mr. Wolfensohn made the pledge while visiting Manila as part of a tour of Asian countries with troubled economies.

title: Richer or Poorer, but Not Till Death Do Us Part
description: BLACK AND BLUE

title: Japan's King of the Mountain; The Man Who Made Nagano Also Owns Part of It
description: It was a matter of just 130 yards. But for five years, local officials refused to extend the downhill ski course for the Nagano Winter Olympics to the customary length. Finally, last November, an angry Yoshiaki Tsutsumi publicly threatened to withdraw his support for the Games.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUTSCHER, HERBERT IRWIN
description: KUTSCHER-Herbert Irwin. Age 74. Beloved husband of Edith Wilson Kutscher. Devoted father of Elizabeth K. Rosenstein and Lawrence Kutscher. Brother of Harriet K. Loeb. Adored grandfather of Lauren, Lindsay, Andrew and Sara. Dear father-in-law of Andrea and Frederick. Funeral services today 1 P.M., Frank Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue, NYC.

title: Margaret Hillis, 76, Conductor; Led Chicago Symphony Chorus
description: Margaret Hillis, who founded the Chicago Symphony Chorus and was the first woman to conduct the Chicago Symphony itself, died yesterday at Evanston Hospital, in Evanston, Ill. She was 76, and lived in Wilmette, Ill.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEILL, HELEN NAGLE
description: NEILL-Helen Nagle. On February 5th, 89 years old. Beloved wife of the late Merton Sage Neill. Loving mother of Penny Neill of NYC and Janet Nanorta of Hershey, PA. Dear mother-in-law of John E. Nanorta also of Hershey, PA. Sister of the late Agnes Rutledge and Marion Ryer. The family will receive relatives and friends today from 2-4 and 7-9 PM at Feeney Funeral Home, Inc. 232 Franklin Avenue, Ridgewood. A funeral Mass will be celebrated Saturday 9:30 AM at St. Gabriel's Church, Saddle River, New Jersey. With interment to follow at Christ The King Cemetery Franklin Lake, NJ. contributions may be made to Villa Marie Claire, Saddle River, or the charity of your choice.

title: The Many Faces Of 'Mr. Arkadin'
