description: Critics have always flailed about in their assessments of Orson Welles's film ''Mr. Arkadin,'' which was released in Europe in 1955 as ''Confidential Report'' and in the United States in 1962 as ''Mr. Arkadin.'' Such was the scope of Welles's genius and eccentricity that commentators are still scrambling to explain the many artistic ramifications of a film that got away from him in the editing and now exists in several versions on videotape and laser disk.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FURMAN, EARLE L., DDS
description: FURMAN-Earle L., DDS. Of Chatham, New Jersey, February 4, 1998. Beloved husband of Mary Hartung Furman. Devoted father of Marilyn Furman O'Donnell of New York, NY; and twin sons Richard Earle of Deerfield Beach, Florida and Robert John of West Orange, NJ. Proud grandfather of Julia, Holly and Christie. Funeral Services will be held at the Wm A. Bradley & Son Funeral Home, 345 Main Street (Rt 124), Chatham, New Jersey, Saturday, February 7, 1998 at noon. Friends may call on Friday from 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Those who wish may contribute in his memory to the Kiwanis Club of the Chathams, P.O. Box 422, Chatham, New Jersey 07928.

title: COMPUTER HORIZONS BUYS PRINCETON SOFTECH
description: The Computer Horizons Corporation said yesterday that it had purchased Princeton Softech Inc. for $43 million in stock. Princeton Softech, a closely held company based in Princeton, N.J., makes software that helps retrieve data in large data bases. It has 75 employees, 800 clients and annual revenue of $11 million. The acquisition gives Computer Horizons, which helps other companies set up and run computer systems, a new research and development unit. Computer Horizons, based in Mountain Lakes, N.J., employs 3,500 people in 45 offices worldwide and had 1997 revenue of $334.7 million. Its stock rose $1.3125 yesterday, to $48.3125.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WEISER, STEVEN R.
description: WEISER-Steven R. Five years ago today. Laugh and talk of me... As though I were beside you. All our love, Robin, Jessica, Lauren and Jill

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Ralph Humphrey

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BORN, JOHN H., MD.
description: BORN-John H., MD. Died of heart failure at age 91 on January 30 in Delray Beach, Florida. Dr. Born was a 1928 graduate of Columbia College and received his medical degree from P&S in 1935. He was an attending ophthalmologist at Manhattan Eye and Ear Hospital for over 40 years and was a Fellow of both the American College of Surgeons and the American Academy of Ophthalmology. He leaves his beloved wife of 58 years, Eleanor (nee Lehrfeld) of Delray Beach; two sons, John Robert Born of Cambridge, Mass., and Dr. Christopher Born of Philadelphia in addition to seven grandchildren. A memorial service will be planned for New York City this spring. The family requests that considered remembrances be made as contributions in his name to the Manhattan Eye and Ear Hospital, 210 E. 64 Street, NYC, 10021: Attn. Eileen Colletti, Development Office.

title: An Ivana Gala
description: She lived through the Donald and the Divorce, and now IVANA TRUMP is 10 years beyond 39 and holding. Her friend, COUNT ROFFREDO GAETANI, is making the arrangements for a splashy birthday party next week at Chaos, a lounge on Watt Street in SoHo. DONALD J. TRUMP is said to have been invited, along with some guests whose acquaintance Mrs. Trump might not want to make. After all, this is the woman who had that headline-making love-triangle tiff with MARLA MAPLES on the ski slopes of Aspen, Colo.

title: Police Kill Suspect In Elmhurst Robbery
description: A robber wielding an assault pistol was shot dead during a struggle with the police yesterday after he wounded a worker in a sandwich shop in Elmhurst, Queens, the police said.

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Galleries, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan and are open Tuesdays through Saturdays from 10 or 11 A.M. to 5 or 6 P.M.; gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Trade Arbiter Favors U.S. In Key Ruling
description: After suffering its first major defeat in front of the World Trade Organization two months ago, the United States today won its biggest case yet: a ruling that European Union countries had illegally sought to evade a key provision of a 1994 trade agreement so their own high-technology industry might benefit.

title: Absent From the Glitz, One Top-Notch Bunch
description: It may be more about Kobe Bryant's future and Michael Jordan's past, yet All-Star Weekend will not have anything to do with six of the 50 greatest players in National Basketball Association history.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEEHAN, MARY E.
description: SHEEHAN-Mary E. Age 91, of High Bridge, New Jersey, died on February 5, 1998. She was a registered nurse doing private duty throughout her whole career. Survivors include one God-daughter Francie Rodums. For information Naughright - Scarponi Funeral Home, High Bridge, New Jersey.

title: Clinton Friend Pleads Not Guilty to Improper Campaign Gifts
description: The Democratic fund-raiser Yah Lin Trie pleaded not guilty today in Federal court to criminal charges that he funneled hundreds of thousands of dollars in illegal contributions to the Democratic Party during President Clinton's re-election campaign.

title: Starks Broods Over Role In the Knicks' 1-5 Slide
description: John Starks sat with the slumped posture and blank stare of a teen-ager in the back row of a class. Wiped out, totally.

title: Workplace Needs Rules on Sex
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEIL, MARGARET (GRETEL)
description: WEIL-Margaret (Gretel). Cherished wife of the late Dr. Frederick B. Weil. Beloved mother of Frank and Jo-Ann. Loving grandmother of Matthew and James. Dear mother-in-law of Harold. Services today 11:30AM at Schwartz BrosJeffer Memorial Chapel, Queens Blvd and 76 Road, Forest Hills.

title: Davis Cup Team Is Wooing Agassi
description: Saddened but not surprised that top-ranked Pete Sampras has refused to anchor the United States Davis Cup team for its first-round clash against Russia at Stone Mountain Park, Ga., Tom Gullikson confirmed yesterday that Andre Agassi is now the prime focus of his recruiting efforts.

title: Krupp Vote Is 11 to 9 For Thyssen Merger
description: Fried. Krupp A.G. Hoesch-Krupp said yesterday that its supervisory board had voted, 11 to 9, to approve a proposal to merge with Thyssen A.G. Krupp said all shareholder representatives and the representative of senior management voted for the merger, meaning that the nine employee representatives voted against the plan.

title: No Fool for Happy Endings
description: Steve Earle respects the country-music staples: road songs, love songs and outlaw songs. It's just that in his songs, the road usually leads nowhere, the outlaws get caught and the romances can be summed up with, as one song puts it, ''Nothing ventured, nothing lost.'' Often, Mr. Earle's music gives his words a buoyant backdrop, full of twangy guitar hooks and clear-cut choruses. But his voice -- a hoarse, crumbling rasp full of bitter experience -- offers no false comforts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLOVER, STUART B. (BUS)
description: GLOVER-Stuart B. (Bus). Attorney, at age 92. A resident of Scarsdale for over fifty years, died at his home Feb. 4, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Peggy Glover. Devoted father of James, Richard, Amy, Elaine and Kathryn. Beloved grandfather of Eric, Rachel, Lori and Peter. Funeral services will be held at Congregation Emanu-El of Westchester, Friday at 1:30PM. Interment to follow at Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, NY. Memorial contributions may be made to the Tourette's Syndrome Association, 42-40 Bell Blvd., Bayside, NY 11361, or WJCS, 141 N. Central Ave., Hartsdale, NY 10530, or Congregation Emanu-El of Westchester, 2125 Westchester Ave. East, Rye, New York 10580, or a charity of your choice.

title: Advanced Technique Wed to Teen-Age Ideas
description: With images soaring on wings of unfettered imagination, animation might seem to be the most liberating of arts.

title: F.C.C. Rule Review Assailed By a New Republican Member
description: A major rift on the Federal Communications Commission opened yesterday as a new member of the its Republican minority sharply criticized the commission as failing to review its myriad telecommunications regulations adequately.

title: Age-Old Rites, But Oh, So Dangerous
description: THIS is the way the Chinese New Year celebration ends, not with a bang but a whimper. Thank fearless City Hall, which is not about to be bullied out of its public-safety agenda by some ethnic group's traditions, no matter how many centuries back they may go.

title: Top U.N. Arms Monitor Is Said to Call Iraqi Plans to End Crisis Inadequate
description: The United Nations chief weapons investigator, Richard Butler, told the Security Council today that recent proposals floated by Iraq to defuse the crisis over United Nations weapons inspections were not good enough, according to diplomats attending the closed session.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: JDN REALTY CORP., Atlanta, a real estate investment trust, agreed to acquire a portfolio of five shopping centers in Milwaukee for $58.4 million.

title: Insurer Takeover Approved in France
description: The French Government approved the $10.3 billion takeover of the French insurer Assurances Generales de France by Allianz S.A. of Germany yesterday. To satisfy conditions set by the Government, Assurances Generales said it had sold partial stakes in two French export credit insurers for 1.9 billion francs, or $316 million. The acquisition will make Allianz Europe's largest insurance company. (Dow Jones)

title: On London's Grimy Streets: Brutal Men, Beaten Women
description: In a rare moment of calm during Gary Oldman's fierce debut feature, ''Nil by Mouth,'' four generations of women in one family stand huddled together. They are listening to the pounding on the front door and wondering what the raging bull named Raymond (Ray Winstone) will do next.

title: Judge Orders State to Help Yonkers Pay for Integration
description: In a decision that delighted both sides of the long-running housing discrimination battle in Yonkers, a Federal judge today ordered the State of New York to help the city pay for the hundreds of apartments the city is building or buying in white neighborhoods as part of a court-ordered integration plan.

title: Trades Stop During Games
description: The National Hockey League yesterday confirmed a ban on trades during the Winter Olympics, giving teams until midnight tonight to work out possible swaps.

title: White House Objects to Ad Of Schumer With Clinton
description: Charles E. Schumer today withdrew from television an advertisement that depicted him and President Clinton walking together off Air Force One after White House officials complained that it suggested that Mr. Clinton was supporting Mr. Schumer for the Democratic nomination for the Senate.

title: Service for Joseph Murphy
description: A memorial service for Joseph S. Murphy, former Chancellor of the City University of New York, will be held tomorrow at 3 P.M. at the Martin Luther King Jr. Labor Center, 310 West 43d Street in Manhattan.

title: HOECHST MARION SAYS IT WILL CLOSE PLANT IN PUERTO RICO
description: Hoechst Marion Roussel said yesterday that it planned to close its manufacturing plant in Manati, P.R., and transfer all the plant's operations to Kansas City, Mo., by the end of 1998. Hoechst said the closing would eliminate 230 jobs. The move does not affect Hoechst's other operations in Puerto Rico, and manufacturing operations in Cincinnati, Kansas City and Laval, Quebec, will remain open. The Manati plant operates as two companies: Marion & Company and Marion Merrell International. Hoechst Marion Roussel is the pharmaceutical unit of Hoechst A.G. of Germany.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEAR, PHILLIP EPHRAIM. M.D.
description: LEAR-Phillip Ephraim. M.D. 92. Of Great Neck, LI on Thursday, February 5, 1998. Beloved husband of Dora Hershkovitz, cherished father of Marion Swaybill and Elizabeth Pinsky. Devoted grandfather of Stacey and Caroline Pinsky and father-in-law of Lawrence Pinsky; and the late Roger Swaybill. Emeritus Director of Surgery at Long Island Jewish Medical Center, Governor of the American College of Surgeons, Professor of Surgery at Downstate Medical Center. A man of inordinate compassion, an extraordinary leader, healer, teacher, mentor and friend. Funeral services, Riverside Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, Friday, February 6 at 12 Noon.

title: Metro Business; Connecticut Retailer Is to Close 25 Stores
description: Weathervane, a chain of clothing stores based in New Britain, Conn., that recently shifted its direction from women's to teen-age wear, announced plans yesterday to shut 25 stores. The announcement came two days after the company filed for bankruptcy protection.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROPPER, LEON
description: GROPPER-Leon. On February 4, 1998, age 97. The beloved husband of Geraldine for sixty-six years. Graveside service Friday, 11 A.M., at Mount Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, New York.

title: Making money in silver the new-fashioned way: by lending, hedging or playing the price straddle.
description: THERE is more going on in the volatile silver market than the recent surge in prices. The demand for silver has become so strong, and the immediately available supply so small, that the interest rates for borrowing silver have jumped to heights traders do not recall.

title: LEGGETT & PLATT BUYS 7 PRIVATE FURNISHING COMPANIES
description: Leggett & Platt Inc. said yesterday that it had acquired seven privately held home and office furnishing companies with combined sales of $175 million. Leggett & Platt, based in Carthage, Mo., makes components used in bedding, furniture, fixtures and store displays. It did not disclose what it paid for the seven businesses: Syndicate Systems of Middlebury, Ind.; Wilson Display of Toronto; American Woodworks of Greenville, S.C.; Cumulus Fibres Inc. of Charlotte, N.C.; Falcon Industries of Easley, S.C.; Phoenix Metal Technologies of Lexington, Ky., and Miller Manufacturing of Springfield, Mo.

title: Workplace Needs Rules on Sex
description: To the Editor:

title: Asylum Seekers Testify on Abuse by Jail Guards
description: This week a multinational parade of immigrant asylum seekers who had seen a Federal detention center ruined in a melee gave graphic accounts of what happened at a county jail where they were held next. Testifying at a trial of three jail guards, they said they had moved from bad to worse: that guards at the Union County Jail had beat them, stuffed their heads in toilets and squeezed their genitals with pliers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BESSO, HAZEL A.
description: BESSO-Hazel A. Of Upper Nyack, New York, died on February 5th. She was 83. Predeceased by her husband Ned A. Loved by her three daughters: Barbara Moore, Kathy Mayer, Constance Conace. Also loved by her six grandchildren and eight great-grandchildren. Funeral services Saturday 12 noon at Hanne mann Funeral Home, 88 South Broadway, Nyack. Burial Oak Hill Cemetery, Nyack. Visiting hours Friday at the funeral home at 3-5 and 7-9 P.M.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEVENS, ROGER L.
description: STEVENS-Roger L. We mourn with profound sadness the passing of Roger Stevens, a Director of The Metropolitan Opera Association for more than three decades. We recall his visionary leadership and passionate commitment to the arts as the first Chairman of The National Endowment for the Arts and as Chairman of The John F. Kennedy Center for The Performing Arts. A founding member of our Golden Horseshoe Program and a generous participant in our Centennial Endowment Fund, we remember with deep affection his creative participation in Metropolitan Opera activities, especially his encouragement of our Presentations Program, which in cooperation with The Kennedy Center made possible the appearances of the world's greatest performing arts companies at the Metropolian Opera House. We are also grateful for his role in bringing The Metropolitan Opera Company to Kennedy Center as part of our national tour. Roger Stevens has left a unique legacy of public service and philanthropy which will continue to be an inspiring example for generations to come. We extend our condolences to his wife, Christine, and his family. The Metropolitan Opera Asso

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AVNER, JACOB
description: AVNER-Jacob. The Jewish Center mourns the passing of the beloved father of its devoted member, June Brenner. May his entire family be comforted among those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Jacob J. Schacter, Rabbi Samuel Goldman, President Elza Weinman, Sisterhood

title: Library Porter Charged in Theft of Mozart and Wagner Papers
description: An employee of a branch of the New York Public Library was charged yesterday with stealing rare manuscripts and letters by Mozart and Wagner worth more than $100,000 from the library's collection, and selling them to the Strand Bookstore for a fraction of their value.

title: Rubber Meets Snow: The Thrill of Downhill, No Skill Required
description: The 1998 Olympic Winter Games are set to begin in Nagano, Japan, with the opening ceremonies to be broadcast tonight. Snowboarding is a new event this year, and so is curling, a sport vaguely reminiscent of shuffleboard that offers all the drama of a retirement cruise.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about the possibility of upgrading New York City's bond rating misstated the current one. It is BBB+ (a B+++ rating does not exist).

title: And All I Got . . .
description: Spin control means one thing in outer space and something completely different on earth. Having demonstrated his mastery of the first kind during last year's 128-day crisis marathon aboard the Mir space station, the cosmonaut ALEKSANDR LAZUTKIN demonstrated his skill at the second kind yesterday. Sitting in a cocktail lounge above Times Square, he played down the Mir's many problems, one of which was a pair of backup oxygen canisters that caught fire.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWANN, CHRISTINE
description: SWANN-Christine. The Family Center feels the profound loss of our Board member and volunteer extraordinaire. Christine provided joy and generosity to our children and their parents. Her radiant smile and aura grace our agency. Our most sincere condolences to her beloved family. The Children, Parents, Board of Directors, and Staff of The Family Center

title: Search for Oil Imperils Amazon Rain Forest
description: To the Editor:

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Until a few years ago, people looking for places to eat in the area just south of Murray Hill had very limited choices. But with the success of restaurants like Patria, Gramercy Tavern and Campagna in and near the Flatiron district, would-be restaurateurs started looking north. The new focus seems to be on 27th Street, just east of Park Avenue South.

title: President of Service Union Prevails in Referendum to Reduce His Salary
description: Gus Bevona, New York City's highest-paid labor leader, emerged triumphant yesterday from a referendum in which his union's members -- janitors, doormen and elevator operators -- were asked whether to slash his $412,000 salary.

title: Statehouse Journal; Term Limits Give Rise To a Comeback Kid, 65
description: Legislative term limits are supposed to produce legislative turnover, and here in the quiet old capital city of California, they certainly have. The Speakership of the State Assembly has changed hands five times in the last three years, after being wholly owned for 15 years by the irrepressible Willie L. Brown Jr.

title: Devils Send Zezel to Canucks
description: The Devils have so much depth at center that they had Peter Zezel playing in the minor leagues with an $800,000 salary as insurance in case of injuries.

title: Workplace Needs Rules on Sex
description: To the Editor:

title: Milk Promoters Agree to Cooperate
description: Two national organizations that promote the sale of milk said yesterday that they had agreed to create a single marketing plan, with a combined budget next year of $190 million, to increase total fluid milk sales by 4 percent by 2000.

title: Firm to Pay $10 Million In Settlement Of Sex Case
description: In an agreement that dwarfs any previous award in a sexual harassment suit, the American subsidiary of a big Swedish drug maker said yesterday that it would pay nearly $10 million to settle accusations by the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission on behalf of former employees of the subsidiary.

title: Rajiv Gandhi's Widow Emerges as Party's Star
description: Day by day for most of the last month, Sonia Gandhi has drawn vast crowds across India to witness a mesmerizing odyssey -- a bid by this 51-year-old native of Italy to follow in the footsteps of her assassinated husband and mother-in-law and take control of India's turbulent politics.

title: Germans Protest as Unemployment Reaches a Postwar Record
description: Inspired by French demonstrators but lacking their passion or numbers, unemployed Germans staged protests across the country today even as the federal Labor Office announced a postwar record of 4.8 million people on the jobless lines.

title: Residential Real Estate; Buying a Building for a School Dorm, Apartment by Apartment
description: In a novel transaction, a majority of the 94 apartment owners in a two-building, 114-unit cooperative in Greenwich Village have individually sold their apartments to Yeshiva University, which will turn them into housing for students at its nearby Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CINER, JOSEPH
description: CINER-Joseph. On February 4, 1998. Devoted husband of Beverly, Dear brother of Martin Ciner, Hortense Klein and the late Eli Ciner, Cherished brother-in-law of Hannah and Ruth. Loving uncle. Funeral services private.

title: Man Accused of Duping Pastor of $1.4 Million
description: It was an odd way to invest $1.4 million.

title: Theft Suspects Arraigned
description: Two of the suspects in last month's World Trade Center robbery were arraigned yesterday in United States District Court in Manhattan on Federal bank robbery charges.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''If there's gang violence or a drug bust or a shooting at the mall, and the student can walk back in the door Monday morning as if nothing happened, it sends kids the wrong message. We need discretion to decide what the response should be.''

title: Two Arrested In Exposure To Asbestos In Brooklyn
description: During several weeks in 1995, thick clouds of dust rose from a building renovation site in Red Hook, Brooklyn, and drifted over surrounding homes and a school.

title: Mets Send Petagine To Cincinnati
description: The Mets traded Roberto Petagine to the Cincinnati Reds for infielder Yuri Sanchez yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILEY, W.
description: WILEY-W. Bradford. February 3, 1998. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, February 28, 1998 at 11 A.M. at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue and 90th Street, NYC. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to The Bradford and Esther Wiley Endowment Fund, Colgate University, Hamilton, New York 13346.

title: A Bear's Home Is . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: Golfers Don't 'Walk for Dough'
description: To the Editor:

title: Search for Oil Imperils Amazon Rain Forest
description: To the Editor:

title: Legends of Past Agree Jordan Is Star of Stars
description: They are legends in the annals of professional basketball -- Bob Cousy, Bill Russell, Bill Bradley, Bob Pettit and Red Auerbach. They took part in the first XNBA Gala last night, a fund-raising dinner at a midtown hotel to benefit needy retired players, and like the rest of the world they said yesterday afternoon that they were in awe of the heroics of the star of stars, Michael Jordan.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  VINTON, IRIS
description: VINTON-Iris. 1905-1988. Always remembering your love and kindness. Robert and Charles Arthur too

title: Gertrude Scharff Goldhaber, 86, Crucial Scientist in Nuclear Fission
description: Dr. Gertrude Scharff Goldhaber, a physicist who contributed to scientists' understanding of nuclear fission and the structure of atomic nuclei, died on Monday at Brookhaven Memorial Hospital in Patchogue, N.Y. She was 86 and lived at Bayport on Long Island.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Working With the Grain: A Once-Lowly Craft Now Glows With Ambition
description: Until fairly recently, wood turning -- whose practitioners, however skillful, tended toward a modest production of mundane objects like bowls, trays and candlesticks -- had a lowly status among artist craftsmen. Glass blowing, pot-throwing, metalworking and weaving were regarded as more sophisticated crafts with large collector followings.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Markdowns Help Retailers Lift Post-Holiday Sales

title: Red-Hot Kings Give Rangers Little to Smile About
description: Early in tonight's game, after his Rangers gave up a short-handed goal and a half-dozen other good scoring chances, Coach Colin Campbell called a timeout to speak to his players.

title: Accounts
description: -- Museum of Science, Boston, to Gearon Hoffman, Boston, to handle its account, which had been handled by Houston Herstek Favat, Boston, now part of Arnold Communications. Billings were estimated at $1.5 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISCHEL, PAUL R.
description: FISCHEL-Paul R. Beloved husband of Annette R. Fischel. Chersihed father of Lois Maller. Devoted grandfather of Caryn, Reading and Jay Maller. Services today 10AM at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, L.I.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about financing for the Apria Healthcare Group misstated the title of Charles N. Martin, who has been considered a possible candidate for chief executive. He is chairman and chief executive of Vanguard Health Systems, not vice chairman of the Tenet Healthcare Corporation.

title: 24 Schools to Share $6 Million for Arts Programs
description: A nonprofit group that promotes arts education awarded 24 New York City public schools and their cultural arts partners $6 million yesterday. The money, in five-year grants, will allow schools to expose more students to opera, drama and fine arts.

title: Prince Rupert Journal; On a Menu of Despair, Salmon Is Just the Starter
description: In winter this is a kingdom of gray, where ashen skies rule over steely waters and dour men fight the gloom by planning for ''next season.''

title: KLM to Complete Ownership of Martinair
description: KLM Royal Dutch Airlines N.V. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the 50 percent of the charter airline Martinair Holland B.V. that it did not already own from the shipping company Royal Nedlloyd N.V. A Nedlloyd spokesman said it would receive 350 million guilders ($172.3 million) in cash for its stake in the joint venture, but KLM would not confirm the price. No jobs are expected to be lost. (Bloomberg News)

title: Pointing to Series of Leaked News Accounts, the White House Aggressively Strikes Back
description: Responding to damaging news accounts about President Clinton's relationship with a former intern, the White House today began an aggressive behind-the-scenes counterattack, accusing the media of one-sided coverage based on leaked information from Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater independent counsel.

title: Rise in January Retail Sales Is Better Than Expected
description: Retailers reported a better-than-expected increase in January sales yesterday, largely as a result of major post-holiday clearance promotions by specialty clothing stores that attracted bargain-hunting shoppers.

title: Lopez Feels Tourney in Grasp
description: Felipe Lopez had already signed autographs for dozens of adoring fans who waved Dominican flags while St. John's shellacked Boston College, 91-79, at Conte Forum in Chestnut Hill, Mass., Wednesday night and had already shed his blue-and-red road uniform. He was sitting in the locker room waiting for the four-hour bus ride through the snow to Jamaica, Queens, but Lopez was also pondering the future.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAUDIER, RICHARD U.
description: GAUDIER-Richard U., Esq. Vice President Merrill Lynch on February 4, 1998. Beloved husband of Catherine. Loving father of the late Richard C. Dear son Margarita. Fond brother of Emily Gaudier Garcia, Bonnie Beauchamp, Michelle Gaudier and Ronald Gaudier. Reposing at the Simonson Funeral Home, 119-04 Hillside Ave (corner Lefferts Blvd), Richmond Hill. Service Friday 8PM. Funeral private. Visiting Thursday and Friday 2:305 and 7-9:30PM. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINCK, NORMA
description: FINCK-Norma. Feb. 5, 1998. Resident of Providence, RI. Devoted mother of Bobby Finck, N. Bergen, NJ and Nancy (Stuart) Goldsmith, Dover, MA. Loving grandmother of Jamie and Drew Goldsmith, and Matthew and Ben Finck. Loving aunt to Jane, Barbara, Bud, and John. Her advice is to live life to the fullest. Service 1 PM Tuesday at Ferncliff Cemetery, Hartsdale, NY. Information, Mount Sinai Memorial Chapel, Providence.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Jack Streit, a Guardian of Matzoh's Traditions, Is Dead at 89
description: Jack Streit, a master matzoh maker devoted to keeping an ancient tradition and a family business alive on the Lower East Side, died on Wednesday at Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 89.

title: PREMIER BANCSHARES TO BUY ANOTHER GEORGIA BANK
description: Premier Bancshares Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the Button Gwinnett Bancorp for $123 million, as the bank expands in its home state of Georgia. Premier, based in Atlanta, has assets of $793 million, while the closely held Button Gwinnett has assets of about $220 million. After the merger and two others the bank announced recently, Premier would be the third-largest bank in Georgia, with assets of $1.225 billion. Premier said in December that it would buy the Lanier Bank and Trust Company for $26 million and the Bank Holding Company for $32 million. Premier's stock rose $1 a share, to $31.75.

title: Schools Are Moving to Police Students' Off-Campus Lives
description: At a time when the public is clamoring for tougher school discipline, many educators across the nation are edging into the role of policing not just what goes on within their own buildings, but off-campus problems as well, from fistfights at the mall or sexual harassment on the school bus to drinking, smoking or drug use in students' homes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STURGIS, NORMAN R.
description: STURGIS-Norman R. Of Fort Myers, FL. and Small Point, ME. died of cancer on February 4, 1998. He is survived by Linda Terry Sturgis, his wife of fifty-five years, two sons, Nathaniel R. Sturgis and John T. T. Sturgis, both of Missoula, MT, six grandchildren and two great grandchildren. Also survived by two sisters, Mrs. David T. Cook of St. James, NY and Mrs. Melvin E. Schoonover of Miami, Florida. Contributions in his memory to the Sanibel Captiva Conservation Foundation, Box 839, Sanibel, FL. 33957, would be greatly appreciated by his family.

title: Cash Geese and Collies
description: To the Editor:

title: Waste Hauler Settles Case for $10 Million
description: A solid-waste hauling company in Hillsdale agreed yesterday to pay the borough nearly $10 million over the next five years to settle a complaint before state officials that the company's garbage trucks created a severe local traffic nuisance.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in New York City this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Northeaster Lashes Coast With Waves, Rain and High Wind
description: A powerful northeaster thrashed the Eastern seaboard again today with cold, slicing rain and strong winds that caused flooding in coastal areas of New Jersey and Long Island. The storm also prompted fears of widespread sand erosion as violent, churning waves -- some up to 20 feet high -- pounded beaches throughout the region.

title: Microsoft Shifts Web Unit to Windows Group
description: In a quiet reorganization that is certain to raise eyebrows in light of the Microsoft Corporation's antitrust battle with the United States Government, the software giant today moved the group that develops its Internet Explorer World Wide Web browser into the business unit that develops and markets its Windows operating system.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STREIT, JACK
description: STREIT-Jack. On February 3, 1998, after a long illness. President of Aron Streit, Inc., matzo bakers since the turn of the century. Beloved husband of the late Ruth Katz Streit. Devoted father of Myrna Heilbrun, Nettie Streit and the late Arlyne Yagoda. Loving grandfather of Aron, Michele, Nanette and Philip. Proud great grandfather of Andrew and Brittany. Services at Boulevard-Riverside Chapel, 312 Coney Island Avenue at Prospect Park, Bklyn Friday, February 6th, 12 Noon.

title: FAMILY FARE
description: Hoop Dreams That Come True

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the announcement by Mark Green, New York City's Consumer Affairs Commissioner, that he is running for the United States Senate misstated the title of a book he wrote. It is ''Who Runs Congress,'' not ''Who's Running Congress.'' It also misstated Ralph Nader's contribution to the book. Mr. Nader wrote the introduction; he was not a co-author.

title: American Lips Are Ordered Zipped Near U.S. Base in Italy
description: The big air base outside this northern Italian town was buttoned up tonight, and the bars and pizzerias where pilots and mechanics usually congregate on a Thursday night were deserted.

title: Stern Finishes the Testimony In the Hearing for Sprewell
description: Commissioner David Stern sounded confident yesterday after testifying for nearly five hours in Latrell Sprewell's arbitration hearing against the National Basketball Association and the Golden State Warriors.

title: Promoting the Game
description: The United States Lawn Tennis Association and eight allied organizations named New York City and 15 other localities yesterday as target markets for a $50 million marketing and promotional plan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUDDEN, JOHN
description: LUDDEN-John, 77. Of Oldsmar, Florida, died on Wednesday, February 4, 1998, in Clearwater, Florida. Born in Boswell, PA. he moved to Florida in 1989 from Georgia. He retired as Corp. Executive and President of the chemical division at American Cyanamid, Wayne, NJ, was an Army veteran of W.W. II, attended All Saints Catholic Church, and was a member of East Lake Woodlands Country Club. He is survived by wife, Jean, a son, Michael, Orlando, Florida, daughter, Lynn Gordon, Rochester, New York, stepson, E.J. Dean, Waquoit, MA., sisters, Edith and Lillian Ludden, Clearwater, FL., and Florence McEntire, Stuart, FL and four grandchildren. For information, contact Curlew Hills Funeral Home, Palm Harbor, FL.

title: Bank of England Leaves Interest Rate Unchanged
description: The Bank of England left its benchmark interest rate unchanged yesterday at 7.25 percent, as expected, amid growing evidence that earlier rate increases were cutting into consumer demand and a strong pound was curtailing exports. Borrowing costs in Britain are already the highest among the Group of Seven industrialized countries.

title: Golfers Don't 'Walk for Dough'; Sponsors, Speak Up
description: To the Editor:

title: Irish Bring Out the Fight In the Struggling Knights
description: RUTGERS 71, NOTRE DAME 61

title: Front-Runner Emerges in Bidding for Little Rock Bank
description: The Regions Financial Corporation, an Alabama-based bank, emerged yesterday as the front-runner in the bidding for the First Commercial Corporation of Little Rock, Ark., which has put itself on the block.

title: French Official Under a Cloud in Sale of Warships to Taiwan
description: Roland Dumas, one of France's highest officials, has come under scrutiny in connection with payments made to a friend who was trying to arrange the hotly contested sale of six French-built warships to Taiwan in 1991.

title: A Reporter Who Irritated South Africa Is Deported
description: In what critics say looks like an attempt to silence an irritating journalist, South Africa is deporting a prominent reporter who has written many articles that angered Government officials.

title: Fashion Plate With World As Audience
description: Wallis Simpson, the Duchess of Windsor, was on the 10 Best Dressed List for decades, but today many are more interested in the Duke of Windsor's contribution to the ''Windsor Style.''

title: New St. Louis Conductor Carries On a Tradition
description: The conductor Leonard Slatkin brought genuine excitement to the St. Louis Symphony Orchestra during his 17 seasons as its music director. The playing was usually top-notch, and Mr. Slatkin's programming was notable for its advocacy of American contemporary music.

title: Keating Convictions in Collapse Of an S.& L. Thrown Out Again
description: A Federal judge in Los Angeles yesterday threw out for a second time the criminal convictions of Charles H. Keating Jr., a leading figure in one of the most costly savings and loan failures of the 1980's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERECK, NATALIE (NETTIE)
description: BERECK-Natalie (Nettie). Age 91, of Hallandale, FL., formerly of Valley Stream, NY. Beloved wife for 63 years of Aron. Devoted mother of Berenice Gleicher and of Judith Parmet. Loving grandmother of Karen, Paula, David, Andrea and Marcie. Dear sister of Leah Braker, Sylvia Glantz, the late Isidor Wolkowitz and the late Benjamin Wolkow. Graveside services at Eternal Light Cemetery, Boynton Beach, Florida, Monday, February 9, at 10 A.M.

title: A Suitor for the Illinois Central Railroad
description: The Canadian National Railway Company, Canada's largest railroad, is negotiating to acquire the Illinois Central railroad, the two railroads said today. But some analysts said the terms being discussed -- the Illinois Central Corporation could be valued at less than $3 billion -- might attract other bidders.

title: Youth Crime in Europe
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton Asks for Prayers to Take the Country to 'a Higher Ground'
description: After two weeks in which he has been beset by accusations of sexual scandal, President Clinton went before a religious audience today to ask for prayers in helping ''take our country to higher ground,'' and, in an apparent reference to tensions between the United States and Iraq, to quote some words from King Solomon, a biblical ruler famed for his wisdom.

title: The Neediest Cases; An Ex-Chef's Dream: Feed Others Again, and Himself
description: Prime rib au jus, chicken cacciatore, Yorkshire pudding, cherry cobbler. Waverly Watson spends much of his day thinking about the dishes he used to prepare as a chef for Trans World Airlines, Hilton Hotels and a half-dozen other corporations. ''I've got hundreds of recipes cooking up here,'' Mr. Watson, 64, boasted, pointing to his graying temples. ''And I don't need measuring cups to whip up a feast fit for kings.''

title: California Merger to Form No. 3 S.& L.
description: Two large California savings and loans, one controlled by Ronald O. Perelman, the financier, agreed yesterday to merge, forming the nation's third-largest savings and loan, but leaving Mr. Perelman with a price well below what he recently hoped his bank would fetch.

title: For a Garcia Lorca Tragedy, A Full-Throttle Production
description: The most frequent stage direction Federico Garcia Lorca provides for ''Yerma,'' the second of his trio of rural tragedies, is ''pause,'' and the performance tradition has generally paid this direction devout respect, letting the vivid mixture of poetry, prose and song slowly build tension until it breaks in the murder that ends the play.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MASKET, DAVID C.
description: MASKET-David C. The entire staff of the Sylvia and Danny Kaye Playhouse at Hunter College mourns the loss of our dear friend David C. Masket, founding member of our Guild and husband of our beloved chairperson Joan G. Masket. We will miss his strength, his guidance, his warmth, his good humor and his unfailing confidence in our future. Joseph A. LoSchiavo, Director Kate Mennone, General Manager

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEST, RICHARD S.
description: WEST-Richard S. Of Wenham, Mass., and Holderness, N.H. Died on February 3, 1998, at his home accompanied by his wife and children. Memorial service, King's Chapel, Boston, on Monday, February 9th, at 11 A.M. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Peabody Essex Museum, Salem, or King's Chapel, Boston.

title: Death in the Dolomites
description: In investigating the flight of a Marine plane that sent a cable car full of skiers crashing to the ground in northern Italy, the Pentagon need not determine whether the pilot was flying too low. Twenty dead skiers prove that. The issue is why the plane was so close to the ground in a populated area with exposed ski lifts. Initial evidence suggests the pilot may have been inexcusably careless, even criminally negligent.

title: When the Headlines Follow the Script
description: One of the lunacies of American public life is that politicians -- who are not, after all, in careers that foster stable marriages -- have been required to pose as blissfully, faithfully married. Only now are opinion polls and everyday conversations suggesting that most people can judge a President's job performance apart from his leisure activity. But the myth of the happy First Couple dies so hard that it took the scandalous possibility of a Presidential affair with a White House intern (mockingly called ''Lewinskygate'' by David Letterman) to drag those social and political changes into the open.

title: Unusual, but Not Unorthodox; Causing a Stir, 2 Synagogues Hire Women to Assist Rabbis
description: There was scattered applause as Julie Stern Joseph stepped to a lectern and surveyed the expectant congregation that filled 25 round tables, squeezed onto folding chairs, and lined the walls in the downstairs ballroom at Lincoln Square Synagogue one recent Saturday afternoon.

title: Aiming for Smooth Finish, Skip Away Set for Debut
description: Skip Away may not be voted the 1997 Horse of the Year next Tuesday, and he may not even win his 1998 debut Saturday in the Donn Handicap. But the 5-year-old racing star will be off and running into his final season with one great goal: trying to match the gold and the glitter that Cigar won as America's premier race horse of recent times.

title: INSIDE
description: Harassment Suit Settled

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: A Love Spans Heaven and Hell

title: Snow and Austrians in Forecast
description: With an ominous weather forecast clouding the prospects for Sunday's men's downhill at Hakuba, the second day of training runs produced more dominance by the Austrians. They also featured mildly surprising performances by one unheralded American and another whose best days were believed to be past.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RESNICK, SAM
description: RESNICK-Sam. The Board and Staff of The Center for Preventive Psychiatry note with sorrow the death of Sam Resnick, husband of long time dedicated staff member, Amy Resnick and generous and committed supporter of the Center's work with children and families. We express our deepest sympathy to Amy and her family. John P. McLaughlin, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHMAN, AARON BRUCE
description: FISHMAN-Aaron Bruce. February 5, 1998. Beloved husband of Laurie Lawrence. Loving stepfather of Callie and Emily Lawrence. Brother of Audrey Moore and Adam Fishman. Son of the late A. Lawrence Fishman and Aline Goldstein Fishman. Chairman, Colorado Starlight Foundation, to which donations may be sent: 720 S. Colorado Blvd., Denver, CO. 80246.

title: Marketers view the Winter Olympics as a commercial bonanza.
description: IF the Super Bowl is the annual American midwinter orgy of commercial culture, then selling during the Winter Olympics is a worldwide love fest.

title: Starr Outlines Conditions For a Grant of Immunity
description: Kenneth W. Starr, the independent counsel investigating sexual misconduct and perjury accusations against President Clinton, said tonight that he would not consider granting immunity to Monica S. Lewinsky unless she submitted to face-to-face questioning by Federal prosecutors.

title: INSIDE ART
description: A Sculpture For Microsoft

title: Politics? Scandal? No, Just Big Ben Cookies, etc.
description: Invitations for tonight's White House dinner in honor of Prime Minister Tony Blair and his wife, Cherie, have been the hottest tickets in town -- the first chance to see the British Prime Minister and a chance to see the embattled Clintons taking a night off.

title: Big Board Adopts Looser Circuit Breakers
description: The New York Stock Exchange adopted the least restrictive circuit breakers ever yesterday, assuring that plunging prices would not close the market for the day unless the Dow Jones industrial average had fallen at least 20 percent.

title: Psychoanalyzing Winnie-the-Pooh
description: Visitors to the Donnell Library on West 53d Street who happen upon the original Winnie-the-Pooh & Co. in their climate-controlled case might remember Maurice Sendak's comment about great children's books -- that few first editions exist because they were all eaten. Pooh, Eeyore, Kanga, Tigger and Piglet show every sign of a toy life well lived -- worn fur, faded colors, missing eyes and flattened stuffing.

title: Metro Business; Channel 5 Executive Quits
description: Hilary Hendler, the vice president and general manager of WNYW-TV, Channel 5, since July 1992, said yesterday that she would leave the Fox Broadcasting Company station later this month. No replacement has been named.

title: Internet Story Revives Questions on Standards
description: The first story hit the Internet around 4 P.M. Wednesday. The Wall Street Journal reported on its Web site that a longtime White House steward had told a Federal grand jury that he had seen President Clinton and Monica S. Lewinsky alone together in a study next to the Oval Office.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AVNER, JACK
description: AVNER-Jack. Loving husband of Mitzi. Beloved father of Barbara Avner, June and William Brenner, George and Miriam Avner. Grandfather and great-grandfather. Funeral services today at 10:15 a.m. at Plaza Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Ave. at 91st Street.

title: Joint-Venture Mexico Funds Halted by MCI
description: MCI Communications said yesterday that it had halted plans to invest a further $900 million in Avantel, its long-distance venture in Mexico, declaring that current regulations made it hard to earn a profit.

title: Clinton Could Abide Protection for Cigarette Makers
description: The Clinton Administration said today that it would be willing to give tobacco companies limited protection from lawsuits if that was the only way to get legislation enacted to raise the price of cigarettes and force the industry to restrict advertising and marketing.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Witnesses Assert Cart Helps Martin Unfairly
description: Arnold Palmer, Jack Nicklaus and Ken Venturi testified today that a Federal court should not force the PGA Tour to alter its must-walk rule to permit Casey Martin to alleviate the constant pain in his right leg by riding a golf cart.

title: Argentine Economy Reborn but Still Ailing
description: The process known awkwardly as ''globalization'' is many things. It is the information society. It is the erosion of national sovereignty. It is footloose corporations taking investments where labor is most productive. It is the growing premium on technical skills -- and the growing plight of unskilled laborers.

title: REPUBLICANS SEEK CLEARER IRAQ GOAL
description: As the Pentagon dispatched reinforcements to the Persian Gulf today, Republican Congressional leaders demanded that the Clinton Administration provide more clearly defined goals in dealing with the Iraq crisis.

title: Seeking Turnaround, Polaroid Introduces Many New Products
description: The Polaroid Corporation, whose growth and profits have been flagging, introduced more than two dozen new products yesterday, as disparate as a disposable instant camera, a fiber laser for printers, and anti-glare screens for automatic teller machines.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHIELDS, ANNE
description: SHIELDS-Anne. Beloved mother of Hannah, Rosemary and Robert. Grandmother to Alexander, Maximillian, Laura and Chelsea. Visiting hours 2-9PM, Friday at Horne Dannecker Funeral Parlor, 336 West 23 Street. Funeral at St. Francis Xavier, 30 West 16 Street at 9:30 AM, Saturday. Interment Gate of Heaven. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Calvary Hospital, 1740 Eastchester Road, Bronx, New York 10461.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINK, BESS
description: FINK-Bess. Beloved wife of the late Sanford, cherished mother of Carol and Rosalind and mother-inlaw of Robert Herz, devoted grandmother of Zachary Herz, adored sister of Ann Katz, Arlene Zelvy, and Sol Tiktin. A woman of valor, grace, wisdom, humor, and unbounded love. Services Friday 10 AM, Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 152 Second Avenue at 10th Street. Contributions may be made to the Kane Street Synagogue Prozdor, 236 Kane Street, Brooklyn, New York 11231.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, CATHERINE ALICE LINN
description: SMITH-Catherine Alice Linn, 95. On February 4, 1998 in New York City. Survived by Jane S. and Glenn Pasanen, Linn H. and Susan Smith, Beverly B. Smith, Laura Smith and Christian Arnold, Jeffrey Smith, William Smith, Anne and Richard Deveau, Jennifer Pasanen and Martin Weaver. Services 11 A.M., Friday, February 6th at the Church of St. Luke in the Fields, 487 Hudson Street. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory to The Village Nursing Home, 607 Hudson Street, NYC 10014, C/O Nancy Hamilton.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HYMAN, DOROTHY
description: HYMAN-Dorothy. On February 4, 1998. One of the original Rockettes. Beloved wife of the late Edward Hyman. Loving mother of Glory Missan and the late Marge Pidto. Adored grandmother of Hilary, Andrew, Wendy, Billy and Liz and great grandmother of Amelia. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Friday, February 6th, 11:30AM. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory to the Rockette Alumni Association, C/O Barbara Rewna, 423 Central Avenue, Lakewood, New Jersey 08701, would be appreciated.

title: Inflammatory Words About Iraq
description: With the United States gearing up for warfare against Iraq, it is not surprising that rhetoric about the crisis is escalating. But loose talk among Republican leaders about removing Saddam Hussein and Boris Yeltsin's references to a new world war are not helpful. This confrontation is dangerous enough without political grandstanding.

title: Cold Shoulder Turns Into Warm Embrace
description: A grocer runs out of his store to give apples to passers-by. A taxi driver offers to take his passengers out for drinks -- on him. A restaurateur exchanges a round of sake for a round of photographs he has asked to be taken with his entire staff. The temperature is frigid, but the hospitality could not be warmer here at the roof of Japan.

title: Starr Sets Deadline
description: Saying he would not give immunity to Monica Lewinsky without face-to-face questioning, the special prosecutor set a deadline of noon today for her to decide to speak to investigators or face prosecution. Page A21.

title: More Active And Angry On the Way To the End
description: ''Go without hate, but not without rage; heal the world,'' proclaimed Paul Monette, the author and gay activist who died of AIDS three years ago at the age of 49. That sentiment, at once angry and optimistic, serves as an epitaph in Monte Bramer's admiring and extremely sad documentary biography ''Paul Monette: The Brink of Summer's End,'' which opens today at the Quad Cinemas.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GORMAN, ETHEL
description: GORMAN-Ethel. Mom, we miss your warmth, your caring and your sense of humor. You're always on our minds and in our hearts. Love, Linda, Doug, Abby and Richard

title: SPARE TIMES
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: New Video Releases
description: Air Force One

title: Alan Campbell, 74; Reshaped Civil-Service Laws
description: Alan K. Campbell, the architect of the most sweeping changes in the Federal civil-service laws since the Administration of Theodore Roosevelt -- changes aimed at making the Government more efficient and enabling it to dismiss employees more easily for failing to do their jobs -- died on Wednesday at his home in Haverford, Pa. He was 74.

title: Deep Thoughts: Digital Barbie and Ken
description: The Intel Corporation said today that it would work with Mattel Inc. and other toy makers to develop standards for making personal computers and toys interactive, the latest effort by the chip maker to broaden the uses of PC's.

title: Reuters Consultant Seen Taking Large Amounts of Data
description: A Manhattan computer consultant linked to a suspected scheme with a subsidiary of Reuters Holdings P.L.C. to steal information from Bloomberg L.P. was monitored downloading hundreds of screens of proprietary Bloomberg data during one-day periods, people briefed on the case said yesterday.

title: No More Steam: Dancer's Decline
description: Set in the hothouse world of Broadway ensemble dancers known as ''gypsies,'' whose profession is as physically grueling as any team sport, Christian Faber's sweaty little film, ''The Next Step'' might be described as a kind of backstage ''Dirty Dancing.'' And although the movie, which opens today at the Village East, has its awkward, unconvincing moments, this portrait of an aging dancer and freewheeling Lothario named Nick Mendez (Rick Negron), who belongs to the heterosexual minority in a field where most of the men are gay, has a sizzling erotic energy.

title: Following the Footprints From Petipa to Balanchine
description: The New York City Ballet presented what could be called a strange-bedfellows program on Wednesday night at the New York State Theater. With three works by George Balanchine on the bill, Richard Tanner's recent ''Schoenberg Variations,'' previously called ''Schoenberg/Wuorinen Variations,'' was bound to stand out from the rest.

title: Mary Howell, a Leader in Medicine, Dies at 65
description: Dr. Mary Catherine Raugust Howell, a pediatrician who championed medical careers and better health care for women and who was the first woman to become an associate dean at Harvard Medical School, died yesterday at her home in Watertown, Mass. She was 65.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: 'Food'

title: One Pilot Is Killed as 2 U.S. Marine Jets Collide Over the Gulf
description: Two Marine Corps F-18 fighters on a training mission collided today in midair over the Persian Gulf, killing one of the pilots, the Defense Department said. The other pilot was rescued.

title: William Lukash, 66, Doctor Who Watched Over Presidents
description: Rear Adm. William Matthew Lukash, a naval internist and doctor to four sitting Presidents, from Lyndon B. Johnson to Jimmy Carter, died on Tuesday at Casa Palmera Care Center in Del Mar, Calif. He was 66 and lived in Solana Beach, Calif.

title: Responses To Report By the Times On Friday
description: Following are statements made today and Thursday by Lawrence Wechsler, a lawyer for the White House secretary, Betty Currie; the White House; the White House spokesman, Michael D. McCurry, and President Clinton in response to a report by The New York Times on Friday about Mrs. Currie's statements regarding a meeting with the President. Mr. McCurry said he was quoting a statement by Mr. Wechsler:

title: Knoblauch Officially an Irksome Yankee
description: The consensus among many of Chuck Knoblauch's baseball colleagues is that he is annoying. And they respect him for it.

title: Defamation Trial Meanders Toward Sharpton
description: Perhaps the most sluggish, meandering week yet in the Tawana Brawley defamation trial ended today with no resolution on a crucial evidentiary question but with a seemingly firm promise that the Rev. Al Sharpton would finally take the witness stand on Monday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAMES, STEPHEN D. (''DAN'')
description: JAMES-Stephen D. (''Dan''). On January 30, 1998. Co-founder and longtime President of Citizen Exchange Corps, devoted to reducing U.S.-Soviet tensions. Husband of Teddy and, later, Denise. Father of the late Stephen D., Jr., Aram, Timothy, Megan and Caitlin. Grandfather of Sean, Lewis, Matthew and Marina. Memorial service on Sunday, February 8, 2:00 P.M., at Horne-Dannecker Funeral Home, 336 West 23rd Street, New York, NY. Memorials to the American Cancer Society.

title: Mourning a Friend Never Seen; Listeners Pay Tribute to Spanish-Language Radio Host
description: One by one, thousands of people made the sign of the cross last night as they walked by the open casket of a man they never met but came to love by laughing at his jokes every morning for the last four years.

title: LAZARD TO INVEST $220 MILLION IN RUBENSTEIN
description: Lazard Freres & Company said yesterday that its real estate unit had agreed to invest $220 million in the closely held Rubenstein Company, an office developer. ''This substantial equity investment gives us far greater flexibility to pursue acquisitions and development in the mid-Atlantic region as well as expand operations into select markets in the Northeast and Southeast,'' said David Rubenstein, president. The Philadelphia-based Rubenstein owns or has a stake in seven million square feet of office space in Pennsylvania, Delaware and Georgia. Lazard is making the investment through its Prometheus Mid-Atlantic Investors Trust fund.

title: Secrets Of the Vatican Archives
description: Pope John Paul II has apologized many times for the role that Christianity played in the rise of anti-Semitism through the ages. But now the church is encouraging a much more thorough examination of that history.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: Mix-Up Leads to Shredding of Valuable Records From Naval Lab
description: A huge trove of scientific records from the Naval Research Laboratory has been destroyed because of snarled communications between another Federal agency and the laboratory, which calls the loss a calamity.

title: Isles Get Linden for 2 Young Players
description: Nearly five years ago, when the Islanders drafted right wing Todd Bertuzzi in the first round and defenseman Bryan McCabe in the second, the plan was to rebuild the organization around them, as well as other talented young players.

title: State Lawyer Faces Queries About Resume
description: William M. Flynn, the top lieutenant in the Attorney General's office who was instrumental in the dismissals three years ago of more than 100 lawyers whose qualifications were deemed deficient, had himself repeatedly failed bar examinations for five years and claimed to be a lawyer before finally passing and being licensed to practice law in 1992.

title: Scholars Bring Needed Context to Courtroom; Historians Divided
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLANDERS, GRETA
description: FLANDERS - Greta. Beloved daughter of Lillian Fletcher and sister of Edward of Oxnard, CA. She died at age 61 on January 28, 1998. She was a supervisor with the New York City Department of Probation. She will be missed.

title: U.S. Commander Sounds Alert on Indonesia Unrest
description: SINGAPORE  A senior U.S. commander has expressed concern that Indonesia could be on the verge of social and political instability.

title: Pistons' Hill Must Fight The Holmes Syndrome
description: Grant Hill has a name for the plight he and some of the game's other young stars have been born into. The Larry Holmes syndrome.

title: Bomb Inquiry Puts Spotlight on a Man
description: Officially, at least, Federal authorities have listed Eric Robert Rudolph as simply a material witness to the Jan. 29 bombing of an abortion clinic in Birmingham, Ala., which killed a police officer and seriously injured a nurse. But the intensive nature of the manhunt suggests that investigators believe the 31-year-old North Carolinian may be crucial to solving several violent attacks over 18 months, including three bombings in the Atlanta area.

title: Jet in Italy Flew Too Low, A Top U.S. Official Admits
description: A top United States military official acknowledged today that the jet that sheared ski lift cables in northern Italy this week was flying ''well below the approved minimum altitude,'' and that the pilot reportedly said he came upon the cable too suddenly for evasive action.

title: Trump Hires Firms to Aid Casinos Sale
description: A collective snicker could be heard on Wall Street yesterday as analysts learned that Donald J. Trump had hired two investment banks to help him unload all or part of his Trump Hotels and Casino Resorts.

title: INSIDE
description: Navy Concedes Jet Error

title: Mother Is Investigated In Death of Son, 13
description: The Gloucester County Prosecutors' Office is investigating whether the mother of a 13-year-old boy found dead in his bed on Tuesday caused the boy's death by providing him with illegal drugs.

title: Division II Powerhouse: Saint Rose Goes Global
description: Curt Bailey, the College of Saint Rose women's basketball coach, wanted to go global. His prized recruit from the Dominican Republic declined to enroll in 1993, so he watched a videotape of a prospect recommended by a local Latvian family here.

title: Plan Doubles Humanities Stipends
description: Mary Murphy, a historian at Montana State University, used her fellowship to write a history of the working class in Butte. Morton W. Bloomfield, a literature professor at Harvard, spent his fellowship year investigating oral poetry among the Xhosa and Zulu peoples in South Africa. And Nancy D. Netzer, an associate professor of fine arts at Boston College, is now studying nationalism and its place within the development of early medieval manuscripts.

title: Maintaining Local Flavor; Will Too Much Success Spoil Blue Bell Ice Cream?
description: Have you ever had Blue Bell ice cream? It depends almost entirely on where you live.

title: Restaffing Holding Pens Hits a Bureaucratic Snag
description: Prison watchdog groups and others say the idea makes perfect sense: have correction officers, instead of police officers, take control of the pens that hold suspects at the city's courts so that more police officers can be placed on the streets.

title: Whitman, Like Other Leaders, Must Pick Budget Surplus Plan
description: When Gov. Christine Todd Whitman unveils her new state budget next week, she faces the same difficult choice as her fellow Republican Governors in New York and Connecticut: whether to spend or give back a huge budget surplus.

title: Canadians and Alaska to Halt Lawsuits
description: More than 200 Canadian salmon fishermen and the state of Alaska have reached a tentative agreement to drop countersuits involving the blockade of an Alaskan ferry last summer in Prince Rupert, British Columbia.

title: Sports of The Times; City Game Revisits The Place of Its Birth
description: WHEN the National Basketball Association brought its All-Star Game to New York in January 1968, Richard (Pee Wee) Kirkland, one of the most gifted point guards to come out of New York City, didn't bother to watch. Kirkland, who had played at Charles Evans Hughes High School, was enjoying a spectacular career at Norfolk State College, and, maybe more important, he was a revered playground performer in Harlem.

title: The Neediest Cases; No Bounds to the Love of an 85-Year-Old Mother
description: After a few minutes with Adele Walker, you can easily see how she earned her nickname. ''They used to call me Grandma Love,'' said Mrs. Walker, 85, drawing out the word ''love'' and chuckling.

title: Sports of The Times; The Olympics Amid Snow, Ceremony, Sumo and Symphony: Gaining a New 'Best Games Ever'
description: IT'S been a long time since the Best Games Ever were held in Lillehammer, Norway, in February 1994, if any of us can remember back that far.

title: The Issues Are Political More Than Legal at U.N.
description: The United States and Britain may be on solid enough legal ground to justify a massive bombing raid of Iraq if United Nations weapons inspectors are denied access to its installations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOONEY, PATRICK JOSEPH ALOYSIUS
description: MOONEY-Patrick Joseph Aloysius, 85 years old. Died on February 4, 1998 in Brooksville, FL. Immigrated from Roscommon, Ireland in November 1912. Retired from NYPD after thirty-seven years of distinguished service during which time he rose through the ranks to Detective Lt. Lt. Joseph Mooney gained expertise in the art of fingerprint investigation. While serving in the NYPD Bureau of Criminal Identification (D.C.I.). He was instrumental in the introduction of computer technology to fingerprint and criminal identification. He is survived by his son, Ken from Brooklyn and daughter Marina King of NYC. Also by sisters, Susan Keller of Chicago and Helen Mooney of Elmhurst, Queens. Mr. Mooney will be buried on Monday, February 9 in Mount Saint Mary's Cemetery in Flushing.

title: Fuji Bank Raising Stake In Yasuda Trust
description: Fuji Bank Ltd., Japan's sixth-biggest bank, will raise its stake in the Yasuda Trust and Banking Company to 16.8 percent from less than 4 percent now by purchasing 215 million shares in the troubled lender. The shares will be valued at 233 yen each, putting Fuji's purchase at 50 billion yen ($404 million). Both banks are members of the Fuyo Group. (Bloomberg News)

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SILVER PULLS BACK. Silver fell from a nine-year high on word that Eastman Kodak had secured ample supplies. Silver for March delivery fell 22 cents, or 3 percent, to $7.06, still 19 percent higher for the week.

title: Officer Is Dismissed in a Child Pornography Case
description: A city police officer has been dismissed for ordering child pornography through the mail, Police Department officials said yesterday.

title: Solving the Remedial Problem
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani sent a shock through the City University of New York when he threatened to withdraw city money, about a quarter of the community college budget, from the system. The Mayor believes that too few students are graduating on time and blames what he describes as a failed system of delivering remedial education. Mr. Giuliani has suggested privatizing remedial education, but seems to have done so without much forethought -- as a way to shake up the system. The Mayor is right to flag the issue. But this is a national problem, for which no one has yet found a cure. Any realistic solution must include sophisticated interventions at several levels, most crucially in grades K through 12.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Reader's Digest Stock
description: To the Editor:

title: This Winnie-the-Pooh Will Stay; Another Was Lost
description: To the Editor:

title: Cabdriver Hits an Agent Writing Him a Ticket
description: A gypsy-cab driver struck and injured a traffic enforcement agent with his cab in midtown Manhattan yesterday, apparently in an attempt to avoid a $55 summons for illegal parking that the agent was writing, the police said.

title: Netanyahu Tells Edgy Nation Chance of Iraqi Attack Is 'Very Low'
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu told edgy Israelis today that the possibility of an Iraqi attack on Israel was ''very low,'' but he insisted that Israel had the right to self-defense should it be attacked.

title: Foreign Affairs; Heal Thyself
description: Asia's economic meltdown has spurred all sorts of would-be geo-architects to try to design some new, global mechanism that will regulate international capital flows and miraculously prevent global investors and speculators from ever again wreaking havoc.

title: Paris Journal; Did VW Mock the Gospel? French Bishops Sue
description: The Roman Catholic Church and Volkswagen both have a global reach and a large following but not much else in common. If France's church fathers have their way, however, the two mighty institutions will soon meet in a Paris courtroom in a fight to define what, if anything, is sacred or profane in advertising.

title: Pattern of Conduct Isn't Legally Admissible
description: To the Editor:

title: U S West Profit Off 4.6% Before Items
description: The U S West Communications Group said today that its fourth-quarter profit before gains and charges fell 4.6 percent, beating estimates, as the company spent more on wireless and high-speed data services.

title: Scholars Bring Needed Context to Courtroom; At Eichmann's Trial
description: To the Editor:

title: Excerpts From a Letter to Kenneth Starr by President's Lawyer
description: Following are excerpts from a letter to Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater independent counsel, from President Clinton's personal lawyer, David E. Kendall, as provided by Mr. Kendall:

title: UNION PACIFIC RESOURCES ADDS GAS AND OIL PROPERTIES
description: Union Pacific Resources Group Inc. said yesterday that it had bought three packages of oil- and natural-gas-producing properties in Texas and Louisiana for $62 million, continuing its strategy of increasing its production through acquisitions. Union Pacific paid the closely held Tri-C Resources $36.8 million for interest in properties, mainly gas-producing properties, including 10 producing wells and a field in Texas. Union Pacific, based in Fort Worth, also paid $14.5 million to a Texaco Inc. subsidiary for primarily oil-producing interests in properties that included 41 wells in Texas. In a third agreement, Union Pacific paid Helmerich & Payne Inc. $10.6 million for interests in primarily oil-producing properties in Louisiana that include 40 producing wells.

title: 3 Tuberculosis Cases Unrelated
description: Three cases of tuberculosis in schools around New Jersey, including one that resulted in the death of a college student, are unrelated and pose no threat to the public, state health officials said yesterday.

title: Business, Asian Style: A Revaluing Of Values; Some Say Market Collapse Shows Democracy Is Key To Growth, After All
description: Ideas need champions. And Lee Kuan Yew, the patriarch and former Prime Minister of Singapore, has proved to be a particularly effective spokesman for ''Asian values,'' a notion that has gained a wide and receptive audience over the last decade.

title: Oxford Considers Doctor as Chief and Gets Big New Investor
description: Could there be a doctor in the house?

title: Deadline Slips Without Deal On Lewinsky
description: Prosecutors from the independent counsel's office and lawyers for Monica S. Lewinsky let a deadline pass today with no sign of an agreement that would grant her full immunity in exchange for her cooperation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KONECKY, JANET (GOLD)
description: KONECKY-Janet (Gold). Beloved wife, mother, grandmother and sister. A woman of devotion, valor understanding and love for all. A friend to everyone. We will all miss her. Services Sunday 12:30pm ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Donations in her honor may be made to: The Jacob Perlow Hospice of Beth Israel Medical Center.

title: Beliefs
description: Anyone wanting to make a case for astrology would do well to cite the fact that the Rev. Martin E. Marty and the Rev. Andrew M. Greeley were born on the same day. It is often said that the two of them are alone responsible for about half the books written on religion in the United States. (Those in the know about such things like to joke that most of the rest are written by the prolific Jewish scholar Rabbi Jacob Neusner.)

title: Motormen in Train Crash Used No Drugs or Alcohol
description: Test results showed that two subway motormen whose trains crashed near a Bronx train yard on Tuesday evening did not have drugs or alcohol in their systems, New York City Transit said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An art review in Weekend yesterday about ''China: 5,000 Years,'' an exhibition at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, misspelled the surname of a curatorial consultant. He is the art dealer and art historian Howard Rogers, not Rodgers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BATTELLE, WAYNE
description: BATTELLE-Wayne. On February 5th, 1998, at age sixty-four. Artist and cabinet maker. Beloved husband and best friend of Monica, loving father of Burke and Nora. Also survived by his children, Tony Battelle and Leah Ferrarini. Graveside service at Green River Cemetery, Acabonac Road, Springs, East Hampton, New York, Sunday, February 8, at 1:30 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Karma Triana Dharmachakra Monastery, Mead Mountain Road, Woodstock, NY.

title: JOBS IN JANUARY WERE UP SHARPLY
description: The economy created jobs at a surprisingly robust pace in January, the Government reported today, evidence that America's economic stamina has withstood any disruptions caused so far by the financial tumult in Asia.

title: The Daredevil Snowboarders Surf the Slopes
description: Drawing parallels between the snow monkeys that inhabit Mount Yakebitai and the snowboarders who will be competing on it may seem obvious to some, unfair to others. But the frisky Japanese macaque gamboling on one side of the peak in front of tourists and the antic riders on the snow performing for Olympic judges at the other is a delicious coincidence.

title: SUMMIT CARE IN NEGOTIATIONS TO SELL COMPANY
description: The Summit Care Corporation said yesterday that it was in negotiations to sell itself to a buyer it did not identify for a price ''that is not expected to exceed $21 a share.'' Summit's chief financial officer, Derwin Williams, declined to elaborate on the company's statement. Shares of Summit, which is based in Burbank, Calif., rose 87.5 cents each, to $18.375. At that price the company has a market capitalization of more than $124 million. Summit said in October that it had hired the investment banker Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette to help it evaluate ''strategic alternatives'' to ''maximize shareholder value.'' Summit Care operates 36 nursing homes and 5 assisted-living centers in California, Texas and Arizona. It also operates 3 pharmacies.

title: Starr's Letter to the President's Personal Lawyer
description: Following is a letter to President Clinton's personal lawyer, David E. Kendall, by the Whitewater independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr, as provided by Mr. Starr's office:

title: Clinton and Blair Warn Iraq It Must Obey U.N. on Arms
description: Standing side by side, President Clinton and the British Prime Minister, Tony Blair, issued a stern new warning today to President Saddam Hussein of Iraq that he will face substantial military action unless he complies with United Nations weapons inspectors and Security Council resolutions.

title: Prosecutors to Discuss New Law on Drug Dealing
description: County prosecutors from around the state will meet next week to discuss the impact of a new law intended to keep drug dealers away from children.

title: Illness Sidelines Ramey
description: Because of illness, Samuel Ramey has withdrawn from the Opera Orchestra of New York's performance of Verdi's ''Jerusalem'' tomorrow at Carnegie Hall. He is to be replaced by Gary Simpson. Perry Ward replaces Mr. Simpson and Luiz-Ottavio Faria, Mr. Perry.

title: Even a Murderous Bluebeard Is a Charmer in Offenbach
description: Jacques Offenbach, the German composer who became the ultimate purveyor of French light opera, churned out theater works at a protean pace. There are nearly 100 of them, ranging from one-act entertainments to full three-act operas-comiques. Of his total output, five, at most, are regularly presented. No doubt, dozens of the others are makeshift affairs not worth reviving.

title: McGill Memorial Service
description: A memorial service for William J. McGill, who was the president of Columbia University from 1970 to 1980, will be held on Monday at 4 P.M. in St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University, Broadway and 116th streets in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORLEY, JAMES T. ''BUD''
description: MORLEY-James T. ''Bud'' passed away on February 5, 1998 at the age of 84 in Boynton Beach, FL. Mr. Morley is survived by his wife of fifty-seven years, the former Margot Zimmer and his children Karen Brennan of Salt Lake City, Utah, Mary Pat Ware of Tucson, Arizona, William J. Morley of Larchmont, New York, and James T. Morley, Jr., of Newtown, CT, nine grandchildren and three great grandchildren. Funeral Mass will be held Tuesday, February 10, 1998, at 10:30 A.M. at St. Augustine's Catholic Church, Larchmont, New York. Interment to follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, New York.

title: The Latest Sport? After a Worldwide Effort, Synchronized Singing Gets In
description: Seiji Ozawa has long wanted to lead the world in song.

title: Military Force Has Its Limits
description: The debate between members of the Clinton Administration and Congress rages about what to do with Saddam Hussein and his weapons of mass destruction. Should we bomb, and if so, how much? Should we invade with ground troops? Should we simply try to depose Mr. Hussein?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, FLORENCE F.
description: SHAPIRO-Florence F. Beloved wife of Elliott. Devoted mother of George and Ellen. Dear sister of Edith Pinsley. Loving grandmother of Lily and Isaac. Services on Sunday, 12 Noon, ''The Riverside,'' 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: California Sees Waters Rise, With More to Come
description: Sonoma County is best known for its expansive vineyards, summer vacation getaways and towering redwoods, but this time of year it is becoming known for its water. The Russian River, which snakes through this coastal area, has flooded for the past several winters, causing extensive property damage and driving many residents of low-lying areas from their homes.

title: Fujitsu Says Earnings Will Fall 78%
description: The Japanese electronics giant Fujitsu Ltd. slashed its annual sales and earnings forecasts yesterday by 78 percent because of weak semiconductor prices and Asia's financial turmoil.
