Fujitsu now expects a profit of 10 billion yen, or $80.9 million, for the year ending on March 31, down sharply from its previous forecast of 46 billion yen and the 46.15 billion yen it earned a year earlier.

title: $445 MILLION RECEIVED FOR DUNCAN HINES SALE
description: The Procter & Gamble Company received about $445 million from the sale of its Duncan Hines cake-mix business to Aurora Foods Inc., the maker of Log Cabin and Mrs. Butterworth's syrups. The purchase price was disclosed in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing last month by the closely held Aurora Foods. The price was not disclosed when the agreement on the purchase was announced in December. P.& G. sold the unit to focus on its more profitable food brands, like Sunny Delight orange juice, Folgers coffee and Pringles potato chips. Duncan Hines, which P.& G. owned for 41 years, is the country's No. 2 baking mix behind General Mills Inc.'s Betty Crocker.

title: P.S.A.L.'s Ruling Restores 12 Victories for Wadleigh
description: For Wadleigh High School in Harlem, the joy that turned to sorrow has turned back to joy. After an appeals hearing yesterday, the Public Schools Athletic League reversed a ruling that would have forced Wadleigh to forfeit 12 victories for using an ineligible player.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAY, LOUIS DEVOURSNEY, JR.
description: DAY-Louis DeVoursney, Jr. Of Philadelphia. April 13, 1916-February 6, 1998. Husband of Katherine Watt Day, father of Katherine Day Sutton and Amy Day Kahn, grandfather of Gardiner C.K. Sutton, brother of Robert Day, Barbara Day Dugan and Virginia Day. Graphic designer, graduate of the University of Pennsylvania and past member and president of the Mask and Wig.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Democratic Leaders Said to Back Vallone for Governor
description: It remains an iffy prospect, but several Democratic county leaders are guardedly predicting that a group of them will endorse the City Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, for governor Saturday, salvaging something from party leaders' rocky attempt at picking a consensus slate for this year's elections.

title: The Latest Sport? After a Worldwide Effort, Synchronized Singing Gets In
description: Seiji Ozawa has long wanted to lead the world in song.

title: Japanese House Votes to Bail Out Banks
description: The Japanese Government took a stride closer toward bringing stability to Japan's volatile financial system as the lower house of Parliament approved legislation early today to spend about $240 billion to bail out banks.

title: 2 Press Conference Pros Parry Queries
description: When the plaintively framed question about Monica S. Lewinsky came, 45 minutes deep in a very tense news conference, even President Clinton grew sparkle-eyed and had to smile at the temptation to be drawn out from behind the scrim of statesmanship glowing in the White House East Room.

title: Iraq Is U.N.'s Call; Collateral Damage
description: To the Editor:

title: German Lawmakers Defeat Bill to Protect Nonsmokers at Work
description: Seventeen million German smokers wheezed a sigh of relief today after Parliament voted down a bill that would have brought anti-smoking regulations long familiar in the United States to one of Europe's most nicotine-prone lands.

title: A Blow to Human Rights in Honduras
description: When Honduras indicted 10 military officers for human rights crimes in 1995, it became the first Latin American nation to attempt to bring powerful active-duty officers to justice. Since then, the prosecutions have been thwarted. In the most serious blow so far, the judge in the first case to come to trial ruled that the defendant, although guilty of attempted murder, is covered by amnesty laws. An appeals court should reverse the decision, which seems to violate Honduran and international law.

title: President Clinton's Tobacco Numbers
description: President Clinton's budget assumes that $65.5 billion will be extracted from the tobacco industry over the next five years, either as voluntary payments from cigarette manufacturers or higher taxes on tobacco products. While he offers several enticing ways to spend the hypothetical money -- more biomedical research, day care subsidies and financing for smaller class sizes -- the most important aspect of this budget item is its size. Mr. Clinton has now put on the table the amount he thinks needs to come from the tobacco industry in order to deter smoking, particularly among teen-agers.

title: Thousands Said to Have Been Killed in Afghan Quake
description: An earthquake and aftershocks in remote northeastern Afghanistan this week may have killed several thousand people and left thousands more injured and homeless, Afghan officials and international relief agencies said yesterday as the first sketchy reports of the disaster began reaching the West.

title: Collision Kills Man During Police Chase
description: An 18-year-old Newark man died yesterday morning in a car collision while being chased by the Newark police.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: January Job Gains Reflect Economic Vibrancy

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GO, LINDA MARIA, MD.
description: GO-Linda Maria, MD. Friends and colleagues in the Department of Medicine of Bronx Lebanon hospital Center are deeply saddened by the death of Maria Linda Go, MD. A graduate of our Medical Residency program and a member of our Division of General Medicine, she chose a career caring for the medically underserved and disadvantaged. Dr. Go exemplified caring, rigor, compassion, generosity, excellence and courage. Anyone would have been lucky to have her for a Doctor. We were lucky that she was our friend. We send our condolences to her family.

title: CLINTON RULES OUT ANY CONSIDERATION OF STEPPING DOWN
description: President Clinton said today that he would ''never'' consider resigning over accusations involving a former White House intern, and he insisted that he had not improperly sought to influence the testimony of his personal secretary.

title: AMERICAN BANKERS INSURANCE DECLINES TO BACK OFFERS
description: American Bankers Insurance Group Inc.'s board declined yesterday to back either offer from its two would-be purchasers: American International Group Inc., the insurer, and the Cendant Corporation, which markets travel, real estate and shopping services. A.I.G., the largest United States financial services company, agreed to buy the Miami-based American Bankers for $47 a share, or $2.2 billion, in December. Cendant countered with a hostile offer of $58 a share, or $2.7 billion. Also yesterday A.I.G. said in a statement that it had filed suit in United States District Court in Miami contending that Cendant is using a ''campaign of misinformation'' in violation of United States securities laws to persuade American Bankers' shareholders to accept its offer.

title: Five Indicted in Scheme Involving Federal Rent Subsidies
description: Five people have been indicted in connection with a false-invoice scheme that bilked the Government out of about $2 million in rent subsidies from the Department of Housing and Urban Development, Federal officials said yesterday.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It's too late in this man's career to change his shot.''

title: Thailand Nationalizes Three Faltering Private Banks
description: The Thai Government nationalized three leading private banks today after it failed to attract foreign investors to bail them out.

title: Cohen Is Heading for Gulf To Tell Arabs of War Plans
description: While President Clinton continued to emphasize a diplomatic solution to the Iraq crisis, Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen arrived here today to begin an 11th-hour mission to Europe and the Persian Gulf focused less on diplomacy and more on planning for war.

title: 15-Year Plan Is Adopted To Clean L.I. Sound
description: In another effort to clean up Long Island Sound, Federal and state environmental officials have adopted a 15-year, $650 million plan to upgrade sewage treatment plants along the New York and Connecticut shoreline.

title: Theater Megaplex Is Planned For Downtown White Plains
description: Tishman Speyer Properties Inc. and Loews Theaters joined city officials today in announcing that the companies would open a 24-screen, 5,200-seat movie theater complex downtown, on the site of an abandoned building formerly occupied by Macy's.

title: About New York; Asians Heed Maestro's Cry: 'Louder!'
description: THE raucous rhythm of drums and gongs reverberated in the room where Clara Chin watched Kam Muk Liu set the beat with a pair of clashing cymbals. Before them, young men took turns wearing an ornate unicorn headdress, moving to the music with stylized skips, kicks and deep bows. They were rehearsing for tomorrow's parade through the heart of Chinatown, where their lone unicorn would join lions and dragons to mark the end of the Chinese New Year.

title: Samsung Weighing A Foreign Alliance
description: Samsung Group said yesterday that it would not rule out the possibility of a strategic alliance with a foreign partner to bolster the competitiveness of its new auto subsidiary, scheduled to roll out its first cars this month. ''A joint-venture deal can be an option,'' said Lee Young Woo, executive director in charge of Samsung Group's auto business.

title: Big Hospital Chain To Report Huge Loss
description: The nation's largest chain of hospitals, the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation, said yesterday that it expected to report a loss of between $1.25 billion and $1.35 billion for the last three months of 1997 because of the costs of a reorganization and an extensive Federal investigation into its business practices.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARZ, ERWIN
description: SCHWARZ-Erwin, 93. Of Tucson, Arizona formerly of New York City and of Scarsdale, N.Y. Died in Gaithersburg, Maryland on February 1, 1998. He was married to the late Louise Lasker Schwarz for over 40 years and leaves his wife of 23 years Julia B. (Judy) Schwarz, three children, Arthur of Scarsdale, N.Y., Peggy Akin of Phoenix, Arizona and John of Tucson, Arizona, eight grandchildren and ten great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at, The Harmonie Club, 4 East 60th St N.Y. N.Y., on Sunday, February 8, 2 PM. Contributions may be made to the Ethical Culture Fieldston Schools, 33 Central Park West, New York, New York 10023.

title: Jury in Sergeant Major's Sex Case Includes 1 Black and 2 Women
description: Jury selection in the court-martial of Sgt. Maj. Gene C. McKinney was completed today with a panel of eight members seated in the military courtroom, four of them officers and four of them enlisted personnel of the same rank as the defendant.

title: Need a Sure Way to Settle an Argument Or Hide a Scandal? Burn the Letters
description: No blaze imparts more enduring heat than the bonfire that consumes the private papers of someone interesting and important. When the British poet Ted Hughes destroyed the final volume of Sylvia Plath's journals after her suicide in 1963, he said it was to protect the couple's two children. Instead, Plath's advocates and biographers insist, he erased her side of the story. Thus resumes a three-decade dispute, the new round prompted by the recent publication of ''Birthday Letters,'' a sequence of poems in which Mr. Hughes deals for the first time with his marriage to the American poet.

title: New Special Relationship: A Deft Defense of Clinton
description: Tony Blair gave a whole new meaning this week to the ''special relationship'' that has defined British-American relations since Churchill and Roosevelt joined forces against the Nazis in World War II.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE GRAAFF, DR. FRANCES
description: De GRAAFF-Dr. Frances. Professor Emeritus of Russian at Bryn Mawr College. Died October 22, 1997. She taught at Bryn Mawr and Haverford Colleges for 26 years where she expanded the Russian program into a full scale graduate and undergraduate department. Professor De Graaff was born in the Netherlands, received her Ph.D. at the University of Leyden in 1933 and from 1933-1936 worked in Moscow as a translator and continued her research on the Russian poet Sergey Esenin. After returning to Holland, she taught French and Russian and was active in the Anti-Fascist movement. She came to the United States in 1939 and taught at Reed, Black Mountain, and Wells Colleges before joining Bryn Mawr and Haverford Colleges in 1947. She served as Chair of the Russian department from 1964 until retirement in 1973 when she received the Lindback Award for Excellence in Teaching. She is survived by seven nieces and nephews. Her family and friends miss her.

title: Gov. Romer Says He Had 'Relationship' With an Aide
description: Gov. Roy Romer of Colorado, one of President Clinton's most prominent defenders, today acknowledged a 16-year ''very affectionate relationship'' with a longtime aide, and then implored the press corps to recognize that politicians are human.

title: A Display of Culture and Hope Opens Games
description: The final Winter Olympics of the 20th century opened today with a spare, traditional celebration of Japanese culture that broadened into an idealistic call for international peace and brotherhood.

title: Mandela Eases His Criticism of White Privilege
description: In his first major address since he bitterly attacked whites who had failed to help in the transformation of South Africa, President Nelson Mandela took a more measured tone today, calling on those who had gained from apartheid to repay society by performing voluntary public service.

title: With Subtlety and Swing
description: ''Never seen this before,'' said the drummer Albert (Tootie) Heath to an unusually small handful of patrons, as the Heath Brothers encamped onstage for their late set Tuesday night at Iridium. ''And in New York, jazz capital of the world?'' But the result wasn't a throwaway performance; the Heath Brothers played a confident set in the language of understatement, making jazz look easy.

title: Celebration and a Sampling
description: A dozen years ago, Ted Arison, a wealthy music lover in Miami, had the idea of starting an orchestra in which recent conservatory graduates could gain experience before finding jobs in professional orchestras. He proposed his plan to the conductor Michael Tilson Thomas, who pointed out that the costs of such a project would be enormous. When Mr. Arison said he was prepared to support the undertaking, Mr. Thomas signed on as artistic director, and on Feb. 4, 1988, he led the New World Symphony's debut concert in Miami.

title: Raise Interest Rates
description: To the Editor:

title: This Winnie-the-Pooh Will Stay; Another Was Lost
description: To the Editor:

title: Thyssen Krupp Talks Of Selling Some Units
description: Thyssen Krupp A.G., the industrial giant being formed from the merger of Thyssen A.G. and Fried. Krupp A.G. Hoesch-Krupp, expects to sell units or seek partners for units with billions of marks in sales. Units with sales of up to five billion marks ($2.8 billion) could be sold, including recycling, telecommunications, shipbuilding and structural steel, according to company executives.

title: Freak Hands, High Drama: Frustration at the Slam Level
description: For a hand providing drama and irritation in high degree, the diagramed deal would be hard to beat. It occurred in a private team game last month at the Jupiter Island Club in Hobe Sound, Fla. South and West were both surprised to have freak hands, with 12 cards in two suits.

title: Journal; Room at the Top
description: Wheeeere's Johnny?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDHABER, PROF. GERTRUDE SCHARFF
description: GOLDHABER - Prof. Gertrude Scharff. The Weizmann Institute of Science and its American Committee mourn the passing of an eminent nuclear physicist whose husband and research partner, Prof. Maurice Goldhaber, is a distinguished governor emeritus of the Weizmann Institute. They shared lifelong devotion to science and Israel. We express sincere condolences to the entire Goldhaber family. Gershon Kekst, Chairman Weizmann Institute of Science Haim Harari, President S. Donald Sussman, Chairman American Committee Albert Willner, M.D., President Fran Ginsburg, Exec. V.P.

title: Stars Have No Problem Flaunting Their Weight
description: It is a sprawling hotel ballroom with chandelier lighting. And yet, it seemed as if Grant Hill had a bare light bulb hanging over his head.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RECHTSCHAFFNER, HERMAN
description: RECHTSCHAFFNER - Herman. On Thursday, February 5, 1998. Formerly of Queens. Beloved husband of the late Eleanor. Loving brother of Henrietta Schaffner. Funeral services on Sunday, Feb. 8, 10 A.M., at Schwartz Brothers Memorial Chapels, Forest Hills. Interment, Knollwood Cemetery.

title: Mixing Memory, Melody And Time
description: Harrison Birtwistle's music, so new, seems at the same time to be coming to us from very long ago, as if it were music written in Hittite. Some of its expressions are so basic as to make an immediate effect -- indeed an effect especially immediate by reason of the strangeness of the context.

title: Jean Hutson, Schomburg Chief, Dies at 83
description: Jean Blackwell Hutson, who as curator and then chief of the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture helped make it the world's main public repository of materials on people of African descent, died on Wednesday at Harlem Hospital. She was 83 and lived in Harlem.

title: Jacob Cohen, 74, Psychologist And Pioneer in Statistical Studies
description: Dr. Jacob Cohen, a professor emeritus of psychology at New York University who reinvented some of the ways researchers in the behavioral sciences gather and interpret their statistics, died on Jan. 20 at St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center. He was 74 and a resident of Greenwich Village and South Wellfleet on Cape Cod in Massachusetts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORNSTEIN, REUBEN SELIG
description: ORNSTEIN-Reuben Selig. Died peacefully and lovingly cared for at home February 5, 1998. Despite overwhelming illness, he fought for life in order to ''take care'' of his beloved Sara, wife for sixtyeight of his 96 years, who died this past December. He passionately loved and was immensely proud of his family. He is survived by son Martin and daughter-in-law Goldie Ornstein, daughter Virginia and son-in-law Steve Abrams, his grandchildren Steven, Judy and husband Joel, Jonathan Marc and wife Barbara, Joshua and wife Emily and his great grandchildren Joseph, Joellen, Lawrence, Michael, Matthew and Evan. This often contrary and demanding man will be so missed for his richly woven stories, affectionate hugs and captivating smile. Contributions in his memory may be made to Jacob Perlow Hospice at Beth Israel Hospital, 1st Ave at 16th Street, New York, New York 10003.

title: G.E. OF BRITAIN SELLING MARCONI INSTRUMENTS UNIT
description: The General Electric Company P.L.C. of Britain said yesterday that it would sell its Marconi Instruments unit to IFR Systems Inc. for $:65 million, or $107 million. Marconi Instruments Ltd. of Britain and its subsidiaries in France, Spain, Germany and the United States are being sold. General Electric P.L.C., a London-based diversified engineering group, is not related to the General Electric Company of the United States. Marconi Instruments, based in Stevenage, England, makes electronic test and measurement systems and equipment. IFR, based in Wichita, Kan., makes communications equipment for the aerospace industry and general-purpose test equipment.

title: Bribery Guilty Plea By an Ex-Freeholder
description: A former Passaic County freeholder pleaded guilty on Thursday in Federal court to taking $9,600 in bribes from building contractors while in office, Federal prosecutors said.

title: Steinbrenner Is a Winner
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERMAN, BLOSSOM BLUM
description: SILVERMAN-Blossom Blum. On February 5, 1998. Beloved wife of Dr. Samuel H. Silverman, and the late Norman W. Blum, loving mother of Michelle and her husband Joseph, Jeffrey and his wife Carol, Russell and his wife Betsy, dearest sister of Hermina Levenberg and Edgar Schneider, stepmother to Susan and her husband Stewart and Nancy and her husband Andy. Adored grandmother of Deborah, Eric, Emily, Julia, Noah, Jordan, Benjamin, Andrea, Jillian and Harrison. Blossom will be dearly missed by family and friends. Services will be held at the Boulevard-Riverside Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY (516) 295-3100 on Sunday Feb. 8th at 1:30 P.M. The family will observe Shiva Monday and Tuesday evening at 8 P.M. at the home of Michelle Rosenthal, 182 Foch Ave, Lawrenceville, NJ (609) 883-3747.

title: Hingis on Course For Davenport
description: A matchup between No. 1 Martina Hingis and No. 2 Lindsay Davenport in the Toray Pan Pacific Open in Tokyo moved a step closer yesterday as both won quarterfinal matches.

title: Prices Rise as Fears About Asia and Interest Rates Ebb
description: Bond prices rallied yesterday as investors seemed to dismiss the third surprisingly strong employment report in a row. Instead, they are still betting that the drag from Asia will slow growth in the United States enough to keep the Federal Reserve from raising interest rates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BORGOS, EDWIN F.
description: BORGOS-Edwin F. Husband of Joy Borgos. Father of Michael Borgos and his wife Michelle, Seth Borgos and his wife Gwen, Jennifer Adams and her husband Scott, grandchildren Eric, Regan, Kris, Irina, Ariel, Sam and Dylan. Funeral Service Sunday 10AM, the BallardDurand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Avenue, White Plains, New York. Interment in Sharon Gardens Cemetery. Memorial contributions to: Temple Israel Center of White Plains, Library or Rabbi's Fund, would be appreciated.

title: This Winnie-the-Pooh Will Stay; Another Was Lost
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILEY, W. BRADFORD
description: WILEY-W. Bradford. February 3, 1998. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, February 28, 1998 at 11 A.M. at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue and 90th Street, NYC. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to The Bradford and Esther Wiley Endowment Fund, Colgate University, Hamilton, New York 13346.

title: TOWER AUTOMOTIVE TO BUY BRAZILIAN AUTO PARTS COMPANY
description: Tower Automotive Inc. said yesterday that it would pay $44 million for a 40 percent stake in Metalurgica Caterina S.A., a Brazilian auto parts manufacturer. Tower, a Minneapolis-based auto parts maker, said in a statement that it had also received an option to buy the remaining 60 percent of the company for another $66 million. That price could vary, based on the Brazilian company's performance. Metalurgica Caterina had 1997 revenue of about $100 million. Its main customers are Volkswagen, Fiat, Ford and Daimler-Benz, maker of Mercedes cars.

title: Columbia Student Charged as Gambling Ring Member
description: It's not every day that the New York City Police Department's vice enforcement division finds its way to Columbia University. But on Thursday night, a team of officers descended on the college's Zeta Beta Tau fraternity house and arrested a 20-year-old economics major for what they said was his part in a $10 million-a-year sports gambling ring.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOSIK, HELEN
description: DOSIK-Helen. Died February 5, 1998, at age eighty-five. Daughter Carol Kaplan, son Michael, grandchildren Noah, Ethan and Daniel Kaplan and Lia and Diana Dosik, son-in-law Mark, daughter-in-law Lyn and the legions of friends and family that adored her mourn her premature death. Predeceased by husband Albert, sister Sophie and brothers Martin and Henry. Bright, accepting and loving, she captivated young and old with her gentle spirit.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Currents column in the House and Home section on Thursday about the plans of a restaurateur, Brian McNally, to open hotels in New York and Miami misstated the surname of his partner in the New York project. He is Philip Pilevsky, not Polasky. The report also misstated the name of the Miami hotel. It is the Shore Club, not the Bay Shore.

title: A Loyal Aide, Caught in the Middle
description: To visitors, she is the first face of the Oval Office, the gracious secretary who welcomes Nelson Mandela and hobnobs with wealthy fund-raisers, the smooth, cool voice on the President's telephone line. But for five years now, Betty Currie has also been Bill Clinton's office mother, the woman who cuddles Socks the cat and sweetens the White House with her infectious laugh and her bottomless dish of butterscotch.

title: Iraq Is U.N.'s Call
description: To the Editor:

title: In Search of Truth and Consequences
description: President Clinton denies that he had a sexual relationship with a young White House intern and, just as emphatically, that he encouraged anyone to lie about anything. As a whole, most polls show that many Americans don't believe the President's denial but still they think he's doing a terrific job. In fact, they seem to like him better in the middle of this controversy than they did before the allegations surfaced.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Public Eye column in the House and Home section on Jan. 29 about new advertising campaigns that use old advertising icons misstated the first name of the executive director of the California Milk Processing Board (which is using the Snap, Crackle and Pop elves in a milk commercial). He is Jeff Manning, not Jim.

title: A Piano Score Makes Waves
description: Jose Navas's dances have been described as undefinable. The program by Mr. Navas and his Montreal-based Compagnie Flak presented by the Danspace Project on Thursday night at St. Mark's Church did suffer from a lack of definition.

title: Mets Bolster Rotation in Deal for Leiter
description: Al Leiter grew up in Toms River, N.J., rooting for the Mets on television, a die-hard with indelible memories of the 1969 World Series. Now Mets fans will be rooting for him.

title: For $1 Million, Walter Mitty Is Lacing Up His High Tops
description: The man who stands to make $1 million tonight by sinking a single basket in Madison Square Garden has a big heart, which is a good thing, for Saul Holcman's other physical attributes are not the stuff of hardcourt myth.

title: Hospital Giant Expects to Post A Huge Loss
description: In an announcement that surprised Wall Street, the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation said yesterday that it expected to report a fourth-quarter loss of $1.25 billion to $1.35 billion because of the costs of a reorganization and a continuing Federal investigation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEBOEUF, HARRIET ROSS
description: LeBOEUF-Harriet Ross. Died peacefully on February 5, 1998 in her 100th year at her home in Old Westbury, New York. Beloved wife for fifty-four years of the late Randall J. LeBoeuf, Jr., founder of the law firm of LeBoeuf, Lamb, Greene & MacRae. She was born in 1898, the daughter of the late Dr. William H. Ross and Frances Dodge Ross of Brentwood, Long Island, N.Y. She attended Bradford Academy, (later known as Bradford College) graduating in the class of 1915, Smith College, class of 1919, and Cornell University Medical School. Loving mother of Joan LeBoeuf Downer, Elizabeth LeBoeuf Jennings, and Suzanne LeBoeuf Keary. Cherished grandmother of Jennie Downer Austin, Katharine H. Downer, Harriet S. Downer, Randall H. LeB. Downer, Sandi Matthews Aten, Barbara Matthews, Wendy Matthews Sherman, Judy Matthews, Nancy Matthews Boyd, Elizabeth Jennings Duane, Anne Jennings Tozzo, and Prescott Jennings III, great grandmother of nineteen, and great great grandmother of two. A dedicated volunteer, she contributed endless time and effort particularly in the area of community health. She will be remembered as a Board member of many agencies, but especially of the Nassau County Health & Welfare Council, the Visiting Nurse Association of Oyster Bay-Glen Cove, and the Family Service Association of Nassau County (she was an Honorary Trustee). Mrs. LeBoeuf was twice elected President of the Albany, N.Y. Junior League of America (1928-30). She was a member of the N.Y.C. Chapter of the Society of Mayflower Descendants and the Peter Gansevoort Chapter, Daughters of the American Revolution. Beyond her family and community her greatest affections were for her home at Point O'Woods, N.Y., for her rose garden and for her many beloved Golden Retrievers. Services will be held Monday, February 9, at 11 A.M. at the Church of the Advent (Jericho Turnpike, Westbury, N.Y.). In lieu of flowers memorial contributions may be sent to either the Visiting Nurse Association of Long Island, 100 Garden City Plaza, Garden City, N.Y. 11530, or the Visiting Nurse Association of Oyster Bay-Glen Cove, 193 South Street, Oyster Bay, N.Y. 11771.

title: Starr's Office Is Denounced Over Leaks
description: Opening the fiercest assault yet on Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater independent counsel, President Clinton's personal lawyer today denounced the counsel's office as ''out of control'' and said he would seek contempt sanctions in Federal court to stem what he called ''a deluge of illegal leaks.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FAVORINI, MARIE C.
description: FAVORINI-Marie C. On February 5th, formerly of New York City. Loving wife of Francis, mother of Attilio Favorini and Cecilia Balog. Also survived by 6 grandchildren, two sisters and four brothers. Relatives and friends are invited to her viewing on Sunday, February 8, 2-4 and 6-8 PM at Everly Funeral Home, 10565 Main Street, Fairfax, VA. Mass of Christian burial will be on Monday, February 9, at 10:30 A.M., St. Joseph Catholic Church, Herndon, Virginia. Interment Fairfax Memorial Park.

title: Gretzky Is Looking Suspiciously Like 37
description: Two years ago, tired of being a member of the rebuilding Los Angeles Kings, Wayne Gretzky forced a trade that sent him to St. Louis. After two months as a Blue, he became a free agent and signed with the Rangers. He has frequently said since then that he is happy and plans to finish his career in New York.

title: TENNIS: YESTERDAY
description: PAN PACIFIC OPEN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHIELDS, ANNE
description: SHIELDS-Anne. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center family joins with the staff of the Institute for Neurology and Neurosurgery (INN) in ackowledging with sadness the passing of Anne Shields, beloved mother of our friend and colleague, Honey Shields, Director, Child Life. To Honey, the entire Shields family, and all their loved ones, we extend our heartfelt condolences. Matthew E. Fink, M.D., President Fred Epstein, M.D., Co-Director, INN Alex Berenstein, M.D., Co-Director, INN

title: Heavy Snowfall May Force Lower Start in Downhill
description: The men's downhill, Alpine skiing's signature event at the Winter Olympics, could be delayed or contested from a lowered starting point because of heavy snowfall in nearby Hakuba, site of the race.

title: Newark Flights to Be Rerouted Away From Staten Island
description: In a seesaw battle between New York and New Jersey communities over airplane noise, the Federal Aviation Administration said today that it would begin an experiment next month to reroute some of Newark International Airport's departing flights over a larger area of New Jersey and away from portions of northwest Staten Island.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROGIN, LILLIAN (NEE RUDERMAN)
description: ROGIN-Lillian (nee Ruderman). On February 5, 1998, at home, aged 98. Devoted wife of the late Robert, beloved mother of Gilbert and Richard, dear mother-in-law of Abigail, loving grandmother of Kate, Frank and Sally, and devoted aunt to Carolyn Korshin, Juliet Bernstein and Lucy Pearce. Her family will always cherish her fond recollections of her theatrical career when, under the stage name of Billie Rudell she acted with the Triangle Players, the Provincetown Players, and on Broadway in a David Belasco production, and with Alfred Lunt in Eugene O'Neill's ''Marco Millions,'' produced by The Theatre Guild.

title: Rival Italian Banks Discuss a Merger
description: Istituto Bancario San Paolo di Torino S.p.A. has approved plans to pursue talks to merge with the rival Istituto Mobiliare Italiano S.p.A., creating Italy's largest bank and second-biggest investment bank. The Turin-based San Paolo said its board had decided that a merger with I.M.I. was ''the most favorable option'' for future growth. San Paolo said its board had asked the chief executive, Luigi Maranzana, to draft an ''industrial plan'' for the merger and consider how the transaction would value the two companies.

title: Marshall's Moss To Miss Combine
description: The former Marshall University wide receiver Randy Moss will not attend the N.F.L.'s scouting combine this weekend because he had six teeth extracted on Thursday, his agent said. Instead, Moss will hold two private workouts for scouts next month.

title: Contact With Young Lover Lands Ex-Teacher in Prison
description: A former school teacher who had sex, and a baby, with a 13-year-old boy was sentenced to more than seven years in prison today and denounced by the judge who had originally shown her leniency, in a case that has raised questions over how female sex offenders can be held to different standards.

title: Whitman Seeks Federal Aid for Storm Damage
description: After surveying New Jersey's tattered coastline by helicopter today, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman declared a state of emergency in the shore counties of Monmouth, Ocean, Atlantic and Cape May, saying the northeaster this week had erased whole stretches of beach in some areas and caused untold flood damage to homes and other property.

title: Heavy Snowfall May Force Lower Start in Downhill
description: The men's downhill, Alpine skiing's signature event at the Winter Olympics, could be delayed or contested from a lowered starting point because of heavy snowfall in nearby Hakuba, site of the race.

title: Nets' Williams Doesn't Shy Away From Crush
description: The Nets' Jayson Williams walked through Penn Station yesterday afternoon as though he owned the place, signing autographs and kissing tourists. But after an hour of signing copies of his Details magazine column, he felt as haggard as a commuter on his way home.

title: Sports of The Times; The Olympics Amid Snow, Ceremony, Sumo and Symphony: Games Need a New Superlative
description: IT'S been a long time since the Best Games Ever were held in Lillehammer, Norway, in February 1994, if any of us can remember back that far.

title: Using Unlicensed Gun, Guard Kills a Robber
description: A security guard with an unlicensed shotgun fatally shot an armed robber in a Bronx supermarket yesterday morning, the police said.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: USX CORP., Pittsburgh, said its U.S. Steel Group unit planned to spend $46 million to improve the production and quality of its tubular products at a plant in Fairfield, Ala..

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a storm lashing coastal areas of the New York region referred incorrectly in some copies to the location of the Stevens Institute of Technology, in a passage quoting an ocean engineering professor on storm damage. It is in Hoboken, N.J., not Hackensack.

title: Accidents Involving Taxis Rise Sharply in New York
description: The number of reported accidents involving taxicabs in New York City rose more than 40 percent from 1990 to 1996, even as the total number of motor vehicle accidents in the city was falling, according to police figures.

title: Corrections
description: A correction in this space yesterday, about a book by Mark Green, who is running for the United States Senate, misstated his current title. He is New York City's Public Advocate. He was the city's Consumer Affairs Commissioner from 1990 to 1993.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR REBOUNDS. The dollar rose against the mark for the first time this week and ended higher against other currencies on the strength of new employment data. The dollar settled at 1.8086 marks, up from 1.7867.

title: Scholars Bring Needed Context to Courtroom
description: To the Editor:

title: Eduardo F. Pironio, 77, a Senior Latin Cardinal
description: Eduardo Francisco Cardinal Pironio, one of Latin America's highest ranking churchmen, who was twice considered to be a candidate for the papacy, died on Thursday morning at the Vatican, where he had lived for many years. He was 77 and suffered from bone cancer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DISSTON, CATHERINE SITLER
description: DISSTON-Catherine Sitler, 86. Of Keswick, VA., formerly of Glen Cove and New York City, died Feb. 4, 1998 in Charlottesville, VA. For information Hill and Wood Funeral Service of Charlottesville.

title: Congressional Pet Pandering
description: When the subject turns to animals, most politicians turn irrational. There is no better evidence than bills passed in Congress dramatically changing public housing policy. Both House and Senate versions have an avowed aim of giving more control to the local authorities. But on one issue, both chambers went in the opposite direction by stripping local housing administrators of the right to ban pets from their projects.

title: Great American Think-Off: Take 4 Debaters, Stir, Serve to Crowd
description: It is a question that has dogged mankind ever since Eve confessed that she gave Adam the apple and got kicked out of Eden.

title: Bridgeport Removing Barriers That Slowed Crime but Marred Streets
description: Five years ago, this city's predominantly Hispanic East Side was held captive by drug dealing, gangs and guns. All day long, spiffy sedans would speed in from Interstate 95 and the suburbs, straight down Pembroke Street to the open-air crack markets.

title: Signposts Aside, Pair Hope to Heal
description: The Winter Olympics have been personal as well as athletic signposts for the American pairs skaters Jenni Meno and Todd Sand. They began dating at the 1992 Winter Games in Albertville, France, and they became engaged at the 1994 Winter Games in Lillehammer, Norway.

title: Dispute in Bridgeport
description: After a year of protests, Bridgeport, Conn., officials voted to remove street barriers erected five years ago in one area an effort to help stem the drug trade. But a new debate has begun: Will the barriers' removal reopen a door to drug dealers?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERERA, DR. CHARLES A.
description: PERERA-Dr. Charles A. Fight for Sight Inc. mourns the loss of a long time Scientific Advisor and loyal supporter. The Board Fight for Sight Inc.

title: No Coven Intended In Witch Hazel
description: It is odd that The New York Times should run an article on my favorite native shrub, the witch hazel (The View From Essex, ''Gift of the Indians, Going for Sale,'' Jan. 11), and not explain that this witch has nothing to do with witches.

title: Exotic Oman Opens Its Doors
description: THINK of the Persian Gulf and what do you see? Gulf war soldiers, burning oil, bearded fanatics, polluted seas and flat, bleak desert. What does not come to mind is vacation.

title: The One-Man March
description: ALWAYS IN PURSUIT

title: Brazil's Reformist Chief Rides a Bucking Bronco
description: Across the street from the presidential palace, the knockdown, drag-out fight over Brazil's future was reaching fever pitch. Congress was awash in protesters out to block an important committee vote reducing social security benefits, the crucial issue foreign investors cite for Brazil to get its fiscal house in order.

title: Regionalizing Schools May Cost, Not Save
description: To the Editor:

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York.

title: Bill Viola's Video Arcade
description: Video art was already being produced in the 60's, when almost no one had even heard of a VCR and new music came out only on LP's. It has, nonetheless, remained relatively exotic to the general public even while the word video has become commonplace.

title: LONG ISLAND OPINION; Keep Culture Vibrant, For Our Sake
description: IN November, we spent an extraordinary Sunday evening enjoying the Long Island Philharmonic perform an inspirational concert, ''Done Made My Vow Unto the Lord,'' narrated by Martin Luther King 3d and backed by a 300-member ecumenical chorus. At the conclusion of the performance, the audience leaped to its feet, shouting ''bravo,'' with thunderous applause.

title: MARKET TIMING
description: TUESDAY

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the sitcom ''Everybody Loves Raymond'' misstated the given name of the actor who plays the title character's brother, a police officer. He is Brad Garrett, not Greg.

title: Live . . . From 125th Street
description: 125th Street is not what it used to be and many people would agree that is good news.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POMYKALO, ZENETT
description: POMYKALO-Zenett. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Zenett Pomykalo, associated with The Times from 1945.

title: Silent Sundays
description: James Otis's practice of silence on Sundays may have a spiritual dimension, but it also seems manipulative (Lives: ''Silent Sundays,'' Jan. 18).

title: Streetscapes/28 West 126th Street; An 1871 Row House Co-Designed by Calvert Vaux
description: HAMLETT WALLACE, the renovation architect, has heard it was designed by H. H. Richardson, architect of Trinity Church in Boston. Garnold M. King 2d, who moved to the block in the 1930's, says he has been told it was Stanford White. Neither story is correct, but both reflect a natural curiosity about the picturesque little brick row house at 28 West 126th Street, built in 1871.

title: A Downtown Hit, Time Cafe, Tries Uptown Gamble
description: Time Cafe and Fez, the restaurant and lounge with live music at Lafayette and East Fourth Streets, has been one of the repositories of downtown hip throughout much of the 90's. With one success under his belt, the owner, Josh Pickard, opened Time Cafe West in the West Village last February. Come April, he intends to open his furthest outpost yet, Time Cafe North, in a large two-story space on 85th Street and Broadway, the former site of the short-lived Nova Grill. The cafe will be on the ground floor, with a variation on Fez, the Moroccan-theme lounge, upstairs.

title: Fancy Boxes From Europe, Wrapped for Americans
description: VOLVO has an exceptional sense of who buys its boxy, utilitarian cars. Mercedes has an equally strong sense of what customers want from its solid, sometimes stolid, luxury cars. Never have the two camps been close.

title: Comparing the Districts: The '97 High School Report Cards
description: Since 1989, the State Department of Education has issued an annual Report Card for every public school in New Jersey -- a compilation of data on everything from class size and test scores to per-pupil spending and what languages parents speak at home. The reports are meant to allow parents to see how their schools measure up, taxpayers to see where their money is going, and education officials to monitor progress -- or lack of it -- in the state's 2,200 public schools.

title: Helping Beggars To Be Choosers
description: WITH the year-end holidays behind us and the cold winds forcing doors shut, we return to the quieter pleasure of dining in at home alone. And who could be happier but our pets. Though some people may brag that their pets steer clear as the potatoes are being passed, it is more usual to find a nose or paw pressing its way to the tabletop.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Dirt Angel

title: RECORDINGS VIEW; When Performances Achieve a Posterity Never Intended
description: Pierre Monteux first gained international recognition as the unflappable conductor of the riot-torn premiere of Stravinsky's ballet ''The Rite of Spring,'' in Paris in 1913, but it is not generally known how he came to be in that position in the first place.

title: A Rightful Ban
description: To the Editor:

title: Polio, Still a Reality for an Unlucky Few
description: POLIO. For those in the baby boom generation and older, the word conjures up frightening memories of iron lungs, absent classmates and even death at an early age. During the 1940's and 50's, children often were made to forgo birthday parties and swimming pools; families avoided crowds. Everyone knew that polio was highly infectious and parents feared the disease more than any other.

title: Charting A Course To Ethical Profits
description: SAY your co-worker sends his Christmas presents from the company mailroom, your boss publicly upbraids sub-

title: The Way of All Flesh
description: HELL

title: Recognizing Self-Portraits by Americans
description: LOOKING back at the employees working on the second floor of Krasdale Foods corporate headquarters are 65 self-portraits rounded up by Sigmund R. Balka, Krasdale's general counsel, who has long doubled as its art curator, and Susan Hoeltzel, the director of Lehman College Art Gallery.

title: Filthy Lucre
description: ONE ROUND RIVER

title: Irene Kampen, 75, a Humorist Inspired by Adversity, Is Dead
description: Irene Kampen, who saw her sometimes strife-torn life as such a sitcom that it took Lucille Ball to portray it on television, died on Monday in Oceanside, Calif. She was 75 and the author of the book that inspired ''The Lucy Show.''

title: 'Cuba Libre'
description: Tyler arrived with the horses February eighteenth, three days after the battleship Maine blew up in Havana harbor. He saw buzzards floating in the sky the way they do but couldn't make out what they were after. This was off Morro Castle, the cattle boat streaming black smoke as it came through the narrows.

title: Remedial Students Play An Integral Part at CUNY
description: In his budget address last month, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani portrayed the community colleges of the City University of New York as squandering their resources on teaching basic skills to students who are not ready for college and urged that those students be sent to privately run remedial programs so that CUNY could concentrate on delivering better college educations.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Buried Treasure

title: IN BRIEF; Officers Are Fighting Town's Ticket Quota
description: The fairness of traffic ticket quotas faces an important test -- believed to be the first in the state's history -- when two police sergeants take their chief and the township committee to Superior Court in Morristown on March 2.

title: Separated by Birth?
description: TWINS

title: N.B.A. ALL-STAR WEEKEND: Kids Slam and Ham, but a Grown-Up Shoots for Dough; Houston Pair Win in 2Ball
description: The National Basketball Association and the Women's National Basketball Association got together for a shooting contest last night, and there were still kinks to be worked out of the new All-Star Weekend game.

title: Neo-Nazis Carving Out Fiefs in Eastern Germany
description: The football-sized rocks crashed through the window of Holger Zschoge's ground-floor apartment last Friday night while he was sleeping.

title: Rift Valley Fever Afflicts East Africa
description: Travelers to Kenya and Somalia should take special precautions against Rift Valley fever, a disease transmitted by mosquitoes and infected livestock that has caused several hundred deaths since December, according to reports by the World Health Organization and the United States Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

title: Hunger Pains
description: Some workers may still enjoy three-martini lunches; others have little time for even a snack while toiling at their desks. What dining experiences reign at your workplace? What odd delectables, for instance, do you or your colleagues bring in? Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Musings on Age, With Youth as a Backdrop
description: BABETTE is 83. But ''Monsters,'' the first half of a double bill produced by the New Jersey Women's Theater Cooperative, is not about Babette. It is about being 83.

title: Benes Now, Williams Later: All Part of Great Conspiracy Theory
description: The way baseball people see it, the Arizona Diamondbacks last week exercised Phase I of their acquisition of Bernie Williams. Phase II will come at the end of the coming season, when they actually sign him as a free agent.

title: Dana Tang and Andrew Darrell
description: Dana Tang, a daughter of Oscar L. Tang of New York and the late Frances Young Tang, was married last evening to Andrew Haid Darrell, the son of Henriette and Norris Darrell of Cold Spring Harbor, N.Y. Judge Adlai S. Hardin Jr. of the Federal Bankruptcy Court in White Plains officiated on Vail Mountain in Colorado.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UNDERHILL, MARGARET YOUNG
description: UNDERHILL-Margaret Young. Age 85, of Jericho, NY, on February 6, 1998. Beloved wife of the late H. Willets Underhill. Survived by nieces and nephew. Memorial service, Jericho Friends Meeting, Old Jericho Turnpike, February 9, at 3 PM. Memorial contributions may be made to the Margaret Young Underhill Scholarship Fund, Bucknell University, Lewisburg, PA 17837.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNKLE, MATILDA LOUISE REINHARDT
description: DUNKLE-Matilda Louise Reinhardt. On February 6, 1998 at age 85. Resident of Scarsdale for 50 years. Wife of the late Heber Hamilton Dunkle Sr., mother of Laine M. Stephens, Carol B. Keenan, Heber H. Dunkle Jr., and Jonathan R. Dunkle. Grandmother of nine and great grandmother of three. A memorial service is planned for a later date. In lieu of flowers donations in her memory can be made to Scarsdale Congregational Church, 1 Heathcote Road, Scarsdale, N.Y. 10583

title: Artists Who Are Kin Offer Concerts Together
description: WITH Valentine's Day fast approaching, several artists who keep their music making in the family are offering concerts. Today at 2 P.M., the mother-daughter Jolles Duo -- the virtuoso harpist and the violinist Susan and Renee Jolles -- opens the Park Hill Chamber Music Series, playing Ludwig Spohr's Sonata Concertante and Bartok's ''Romanian Folk Dances'' in a restored home at 125 Alta Avenue in Yonkers.

title: Crimes of the Heart? Call on Breakup Girl
description: Four years ago, Lynn Harris was blue after breaking up with her boyfriend. Everything reminded her of Bruce she said. In fact, she challenged her friend, Juliet, to find any word in the English language that would not remind her of Bruce.

title: Gunshot Injures Man In Subway Dispute
description: A dispute on a subway train in lower Manhattan yesterday left a man wounded by gunfire and a suspect on the run, the police said.

title: Medical Training Sought For Workers on Trains
description: After a Montclair man was shot while commuting on a New Jersey Transit train, his assemblywoman announced last week that she would introduce a bill requiring that workers trained in first aid ride on the agency's trains.

title: Mohegans Seeking Return of Objects Sacred to Tribe
description: THOUGH the Tantaquidgeon Museum in Uncasville is believed to be the oldest museum of Native American artifacts in the country, numerous items said to belong on its shelves have been on display for decades in other museums around the country.

title: A Nation Evaluates the President, and Itself; Another Prosecutor?
description: To the Editor:

title: Beatrice Lydecker
description: Beatrice Lydecker is an animal psychologist from Oregon City, Ore., whose clients have included Secretariat, Benji and the pets of Elizabeth Taylor and William Shatner.

title: Power of Photography Meets Power of Prayer
description: THERE are more than 3,700 religions practiced in the United States and ''stadiums are full of individuals trying to be in contact with God,'' said Robert Gilson, curator of a photo exhibition at the 92d Street Y titled ''At One With God: The Changing Face of Prayer in America.''

title: THE GUIDE
description: Honoring Lifetime of Art

title: Sports of The Times; Ito and Ina: Cultures Intersecting on the Ice
description: IF ever Kyoko Ina finally and forever understood which culture she belonged to, as opposed to which one she didn't, it was six years ago when the figure skater and Friday night's lighter of the Olympic torch, Midori Ito, let a gold medal slip away and believed that finishing second meant having to say ''I'm sorry'' to 120 million Japanese.

title: Silent Sundays
description: I am continually amazed (and amused) to see the lengths that some people go to draw attention to themselves. How much time does Otis spend between Monday and Saturday talking about his silent Sundays?

title: . . . Joining Pennsylvania Drinkers in Interstate Bargain Hunt
description: Pennsylvanians tend to look over their shoulders when they emerge from liquor stores in other states, but it's mostly an old habit. As many of them know, the Pennsylvania liquor control agents are gone, their out-of-state stakeouts having ended in 1994. In 1996 there were only four arrests for cross-border liquor violations, and since then, said Capt. Robert Hickes, director of liquor control enforcement for the Pennsylvania State Police, ''we haven't bothered to keep track.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHOLLAR, EDWARD R., PH.D.
description: SHOLLAR-Edward R., Ph.D. On February 7, 1998. Beloved husband of Anne. Loving father of Michael and Thomas. Devoted son of Sylvia. Also survived by his brother Harvey of Pittsburgh, PA. He was a psychologist in private practice in NYC for many years and was affiliated with Roosevelt Medical Center. Service Sunday 11:15 AM at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 18 about Kauai, Hawaii, misstated the number of nights that the author stayed at a condominium for a total charge of $548. It was three, not two. The name of the condominium rental agency was also given incorrectly. It is Suite Paradise, not Poipu Paradise Suites.

title: Huskies' Defense Shows It's in Post-Season Form
description: February is already turning to March, in the hearts and minds of the Connecticut Huskies. And based on what they did and saw today, spring cannot come soon enough.

title: Habitats/The Copley, 2000 Broadway; Fine-Tuning Apartments To Accommodate Pianos
description: SOME people have kids to worry about when buying a home. Others have pets. For Constance Keene, a concert pianist, it's two Steinway grands.

title: Special Delivery for the Knicks? Malone Loves New York
description: Karl Malone, last season's most valuable player, said yesterday that his leaving Utah to join the Knicks is not as farfetched as it sounds.

title: Unvirtuous Women
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIDSON, ALICE, (NEE GORDON)
description: DAVIDSON-Alice, (nee Gordon) 86, mother of CTG Ahmanson Theatre and Mark Taper Forum Artistic Director/Producer Gordon Davidson, passed away January 28, 1998, in Culver City, CA, of a heart attack. Formerly of Brooklyn, New York. The beloved wife of the late Professor Jo ''Skipper'' Davidson, she is survived by loving sons (in addition to Gordon) Michael and Robert, daughters-inlaw Judi, Karen and Maureen, as well as grandchildren Adam, Rachel, Jesse and Kate. Donations may be made to the Jo Davidson Memorial Fund, C/O Brooklyn College Foundation, Inc., or to Center Theatre Group of Los Angeles.

title: Cohen Tries To Calm Italy Over Deaths At Ski Lift
description: Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen sought today to contain the political fallout in Italy over the deaths caused when an American jet clipped a ski lift's cable, pledging full cooperation in a joint investigation and a review of all NATO training flights in Italy.

title: And They All Lived Happily Ever After
description: It had happened so fast. Not a week before, she had been alone in the world. And now here she was, strolling through the flame-colored autumn woods hand in hand with this man she barely knew. Yet she did know him, felt as if she had known him forever -- had felt that way, in fact, ever since that night in the theater, when she realized in the middle of the first act that the eyes of the stranger sitting next to her were following her slightest smile. Her mind wandered back to the moment later that same evening, when he had so quickly and masterfully swept her into his arms, and into his life. And now, in the middle of her reverie, she heard his words, clear as the brisk October breeze:

title: Netscape Battles Takeover Talk and Shrinking Sales
description: THE Netscape Communications Corporation has suffered through a humbling month. Once the highest flier of the Internet, Netscape said in January that it would report a loss for 1997 of $115.5 million and lay off 400 of its 3,200 workers.

title: The Night Life in Nutley: Three Places That Evoke a Cosmopolitan Mood
description: A BABY-SITTER and a Shop-Rite led me to Franklin Avenue in this town, which is renowned in some circles as the birthplace of Martha Stewart.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEERKEN, MARION R.
description: GEERKEN-Marion R. Of Southold, Long Island (formerly of Flatlands, Brooklyn) on February 3, 1998. Retired from the Actuarial Division of MetLife. Beloved wife of G. Everett Geerken. Fond sister of Jean Sutton. For information DeFriest Funeral Homes of Southold. Memorial services are on Saturday, February 14, 1998 at 1 P.M. at the First Presbyterian Church, Main Road, Southold, L.I. Interment Presbyterian Cemetery.

title: Unsung Women, Ahead of Their Times, Celebrated in Fairfield
description: WHEN Marilyn Cohen speaks of the courageous force that drove many of the women she depicts in her painting exhibition, ''Teach Me the Songs My Mothers Sang: A Celebration of American Women,'' her voice becomes passionate. ''They were adults before or during World War II and each had her own kind of courage,'' Ms. Cohen said recently in her studio in Mount Kisco, N.Y., a place filled with liquid dyes and torn pieces of watercolor paper arranged in drawers by color.

title: Clubs Offered Drugs, Witnesses Say
description: It was in the summer of 1995 that the New York City Police Department and Federal drug agents separately learned that illegal drugs were being blatantly sold at two of Manhattan's most popular nightclubs, Limelight and the Tunnel.

title: EDITORS' NOTE

title: For the Gambling Elderly, Help in Fighting Addiction
description: For some, gambling can become an addiction. ''Gambling hasn't been so available in the past,'' said Dr. Sheila Blume, a psychiatrist at South Oaks Hospital in Amityville who specializes in addictions. ''Now, with casinos within reach, people who have never really experienced much gambling besides a church bingo game are getting exposed to a different kind of gambling which is exciting. It's this excitement they seem to get hooked on.''

description: For fans of the Sign of the Dove, a lavish restaurant on the northwest corner of Third Avenue and 65th Street for 35 years, the owners' plans to close it on Feb. 16 and move it to 11 Madison Avenue, near 23d Street, came as a disappointment. But for residents of the block between 65th and 66th Streets, the news that a huge apartment building would be built there was a shock.

Morley of Larchmont, New York, and James T. Morley, Jr., of Newtown, CT, nine grandchildren and three great grandchildren. title: Who Will Do Abortions Here?
description: I have always maintained a libertarian detachment from the abortion debate, but I was dragged from my Sunday morning repose by Hitt's graphic description of an ''intact dilation and extraction.'' It occurred to me that while the attending doctor, the resident, Hitt and all of us who read his article know the intimate details of this procedure, the patient, who was sedated, may not.

description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week.

A total of 354 of detached homes and town-house condominiums are being built in Danbury, moderately priced from $159,900 for a two-bedroom town house to $285,000 for a four-bedroom detached home.

description: IT was nothing less than an act of revolution. The woman was wearing a hat.

title: The Neediest Cases; Sent Into Tailspin by a Deadly Illness, an Actress Battles Back
description: It was just a tension headache, the kind that sends you to bed early. But by morning, the throbbing had traveled down Laurie Anne Frank's back and, as she washed her face, she realized she could not feel the water. By that November evening in 1996, every inch of her body felt like a pincushion pricked by some invisible demon.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: The Bondmaid

title: Pedestrians Serve As Base Runners
description: A baseball diamond, complete with home plate, a pitcher's mound and a backstop, appeared out of nowhere at Ninth Avenue and 22d Street. Where did it come from and why? Many Chelsea residents said they had not even noticed it.

title: February 1-7; A Rocky Week 3 In White House Scandal
description: Week 3 of Monica, The Scandal, started badly for President Clinton and ended worse. Early in the week, news accounts said Monica S. Lewinsky, a 24-year-old former White House intern, had visited the Executive Mansion about three dozen times after being sent to a Pentagon job in April 1996. She was cleared into the executive complex most times by Betty Currie, Mr. Clinton's personal secretary.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Negation's Child
description: ''No'' is the word that opens SHADOWS OF A CHILDHOOD (New Press, $23), Elisabeth Gille's autobiographical novel about two girls hidden in a Bordeaux convent during the Nazi occupation of France. The speaker is 5-year-old Lea Levy, who is struggling with three nuns who are trying to take away her lace-trimmed slip and expensive doll. Lea has been rescued from a roundup of Bordeaux Jews by the brother of one of the nuns, and she proves to be a difficult charge -- rebellious, rude, ungrateful, vowing that all the girls who bully and torment her will be punished as soon as her wealthy and glamorous parents return from their travels. Lea trusts only Benedicte, two years older, whose parents are with the Resistance, and who shields and looks after her. As Lea's recollection of her parents fades (''the more memories she lost, the more she invented''), the certainty of their fate grows plainer, first to the nuns, then with war's end to Lea herself. Benedicte's parents return to claim her, and they take in Lea as well; but Lea remains angry and withdrawn, obsessed with the unfolding news of the death camps and with the trials of those who collaborated in the deportation of France's Jews. Linda Coverdale's translation of this unsettling and uncompromising novel marks the first appearance in English of Gille, a French editor and novelist who died in 1996. Her theme in ''Shadows of a Childhood'' is refusal -- the refusal to forget or to cease struggling against indifference, denial, lies. Lea, ''precocious by nature and from necessity,'' is war's unyielding orphan, the one who never quits saying ''no.'' David Walton

title: Carolyn Cirillo, Sanford Lazar
description: Carolyn Marie Cirillo and Sanford Jordan Lazar are to be married this afternoon at Waveny House in New Canaan, Conn., by Patricia Coffey, a justice of the peace in Fairfield, Conn.

title: Edging Off Rock's High Road
description: Eddie Vedder, Pearl Jam's leader, watches his words these days. He is so wary of being misunderstood, or of seeming presumptuous, that he hesitates even to assign any meaning to the title of his band's new album, ''Yield,'' which was released on Tuesday.

title: The Homosexual Exception
description: If we listen to pundits and politicians, we get the impression that Americans are fighting a culture war. Some people are presumed to be moral traditionalists: they have an abiding faith in God, country and family and long for the days when morality was absolute and virtue predominant. Others, by contrast, are said to be modern, even post-modern, in their moral outlook: they accept a more secular America, welcome the fact that families are no longer patriarchal and think that our society has improved because one group can no longer impose its conception of the good life on any other. But in the course of in-depth interviews with 200 people in the suburbs of Tulsa, Atlanta, San Diego and Boston, I did not find Americans morally divided among themselves. I found them instead divided within themselves; most people want to be traditional and modern at the same time. They honor God, family and country, yet they also want to accommodate themselves to the realities of contemporary America. As a retired piano and organ teacher living in Broken Arrow, Okla., whose father was a Southern Baptist minister, put it: ''You don't have to accept anyone's dogma. Live with the concept of God as you perceive it.''

title: If Their Suits Are Still Gray, It's From Ashes
description: THERE aren't too many chimney sweeps who put on lipstick and jewelry before heading out for another day of cleaning flues and fireplaces. Nor are there many former Wall Street executives among them who traded in expensive suits for soot-covered overalls.

title: Break a (Bendable) Leg, Barbie!; It's Show Time for a Cast of Thousands at the Toy Fair
description: Barbie was rehearsing her lines yet again, gesturing and smiling in a glittering fantasy showroom inhabited by workmen who were too desperately busy to listen. ''This year,'' she was saying, ''we have Barbie and Ken featured as Dana Scully and Fox Mulder of 'The X-Files.' It's the first time Barbie and Ken have been featured as F.B.I. agents!''

title: The Return of a Pachyderm
description: North Salem may have been the second town to import elephants nearly two centuries ago, but it is the first to have one return.

title: Porters, Maids and Barbers: Blacks and the Service Industries
description: When Cubit Brunson arrived in Jersey City in 1915 from a farm in South Carolina, he landed a job selling insurance to other blacks. His son Theodore became a collection manager for the Internal Revenue Service. Theodore's son, Neal, is a lawyer. Unlike Cubit Brunson, many African-Americans who migrated to Northern states had to build their family foundations with more menial labor. To celebrate February as Black History Month, the Afro-American Historical and Cultural Society Museum, 4,000 square feet above the Greenville Branch of the Jersey City Public Library, has assembled an exhibit titled ''Blacks in the Service Industry.'' Ted Brunson, 75, who directed the museum since it was founded in 1977, passed the directorship on to his son last year. Neal Brunson, 35, spoke recently as he and his father gave a tour of the museum, which holds cultural icons ranging from sheet music of blatantly racist ''coon songs'' to an elaborately carved African tribal stool.

title: SWIMSUIT SCIENCE
description: The Sports Illustrated Swimsuit Issue -- to be unveiled next week on ''The Tonight Show'' with Jay Leno -- is such a big deal that preparing the media blitz alone is a year-round enterprise. The magazine won't say how much it spends on hype, but consider this stat: Elaine Farley, the editor, gives more than 125 interviews on the subject every year. Can there really be that much to say? Sure, Farley says: ''It's not just about girls in bathing suits. It's like S.I. meets National Geographic in the 90's -- it's about the women and the places, it's funny, exciting and educational.'' Educational? O.K., Farley admits, ''it's not meant to be rocket scientry.''

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: Free Choices

title: A Police Officer Moves On To the Moviemaking Beat
description: One day recently in Whitestone, Queens, on the set of a movie called ''Scarred City,'' the first-time director Ken Sanzel displayed a demeanor that was two parts auteur, one part cop.

title: Brawley Trial Proceeds Like A Turtle In Ill Humor
description: The lawyers say they are eager for it to be over, for a reprieve from a courtroom that regularly turns into an echo chamber of outbursts.

description: Democrats in the Florida House of Representatives made history last year when they elected Willie F. Logan, who is black, as chairman of their caucus and the man in line to be Speaker should the party regain the majority.

description: Deep Rising

Buffett was quietly amassing a hoard of silver, driving its price to the highest level in nine years, investors began to see a treasure trove, rather than a junk heap, in long-neglected precious metals and the mutual funds that invest in them.

description: ''I'm the oldest of the baby boomers,'' President Clinton told a fund-raising gathering in Miami a couple of months ago. ''I'm what you'd call near-elderly.''

title: Talk, Talk, Talk
description: Ted Finnegan, a 29-year-old lawyer from the Upper East Side, pushed an invisible vacuum cleaner in the middle of a Wiz store recently as he tested a cordless telephone headset for home use. ''This is about time management,'' Mr. Finnegan said. ''If I'm doing something mundane around the house, I want to be able to talk to my friends and colleagues at the same time.''

title: French Garden Design (and Food) in Philadelphia
description: Visitors to this year's Philadelphia Flower Show can anticipate a celebration of all things French. The show -- the oldest in the country, dating back to 1829 -- will be held from March 1 to 8 at the Pennsylvania Convention Center. Known as ''La Passion du Jardin,'' the event will commemorate France's culinary as well as horticultural artistry.

title: State Senator Norman Levy, L.I. Republican, Dies at 67
description: Norman J. Levy, a Republican State Senator from Nassau County who sponsored the nation's first mandatory seat belt law and championed the metropolitan region's mass transit system, died last night at his home in Albany. He was 67.

description: A SPECIAL season is under way to trap river otters in the eastern portion of New York State and release the animals at nine locations in the central and western sections of the state.

title: TELEVISION; One Senior Sleuth Slips Into the Slot Left by Another
description: Ask anyone under 45 or so to name a Dick Van Dyke series, and they're likely to come up with his namesake 1960's sitcom, which lives on in reruns on Nick at Nite. Ask anyone older, and they're likely to say ''Diagnosis Murder,'' Mr. Van Dyke's CBS mystery series now in its fifth season.

title: Extending Bach's Long Shadow
description: Following Bach: it is a problem every composer faces in some degree, but few face it as starkly as Georg Christoph Biller. Mr. Biller holds the same position Bach held from 1723 to 1750, as Thomas kantor, or music director of St. Thomas's Church in Leipzig, Germany.

title: Storm Leaves Its Fans Tournament-Ready
description: Perhaps the best measuring stick of how much St. John's has improved since the demoralizing days of December came tonight. The Red Storm faced 15th-ranked West Virginia, a team that had just as much to lose, and St. John's prevailed, 77-69.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUSHINS, LEONARD J.
description: KUSHINS-Leonard J. On February 5, 1998. He is survived by his mother Clara to whom he was the most devoted son. Loving brother of Allan and sister-in-law Harriet. Adored uncle of Adam and Eric. He will be remembered by all others whose lives he touched for his kindness, gentleness and sense of humor. Services Sunday 12:15 PM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Who Will Do Abortions Here?
description: The key to understanding the revulsion OB-GYN residents feel about performing first-trimester abortions can be found in a statement by the chief resident. She said that she preferred doing second-trimester abortions ''because the patient is asleep.'' Abortion clinics provide anesthesia choices, but large inner-city hospitals like the one Hitt described -- overburdened and underfinanced -- do not. The result is a procedure that is devastatingly dehumanizing to doctor and patient alike.

title: Sports of The Times; One Slip in a Life of Great Balance
description: ''One person is going to win the gold every four years in figure skating. The stars have to be right.'' -- Debi Thomas

title: The Noank Fishery, Before Technology
description: BENJAMIN F. RATHBUN figured he should write things down. Otherwise, his children and grandchildren might not know about the days when fishermen like himself and his father made it through fog with no fancy equipment, just hopeful conversation: ''See anything you recognize?'' They wouldn't know how he and others grew up in Noank, survived hurricanes, helped (and occasionally tormented) one another, built boats, repaired everything, harpooned swordfish and dealt with Presidents. They might miss interesting details of noteworthy events, like the time his father almost boiled the Baptist minister.

title: Mason Is Charged With Statutory Rape
description: Anthony Mason was charged early this morning with statutory rape following a complaint filed by two teen-age girls, the police said.

title: As the N.B.A.'s Stars Soar, The Quality of Play Falls Off
description: The N.B.A. All-Star Game, that annual enterprise in ego, athleticism and commercialism, will go off today at Madison Square Garden. The multimillionaires will laugh and dunk; the league's officials will step to the microphones and recount again how popular the sport has become.

title: Economic Troubles Back Home Squeeze Asian Students in U.S.
description: The surprise economics lesson came straight from home in the form of panicked telephone calls and televised images of the sagging, dispirited faces of the rich and powerful.

description: An exhibition on abolitionism in New York, a cultural festival in Seattle and special programs in Memphis are some of the events throughout the country commemorating Black History Month.

title: See the Art And Read The Book
description: YOU could tell it was an artist's book signing by the artful way the books were arranged -- in a minimalist cube in the middle of the floor at the Dorfman Projects space on West 20th Street. On Thursday, Chuck Close, magic marker in hand, sat modestly next to the Donald Judd-like bibliographic display. He was autographing copies of his book, ''The Portraits Speak,'' interviews with 27 of the subjects of his large-scale portraits -- many of which will be included in his retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art, opening on Feb. 26.

title: 2 People, One Job, One Fully Rounded Personality
description: Adrienne Fernekees is the hyper one. ''I sometimes call Debbie my other husband,'' she says with a laugh.

While doing so, Wayne Gretzky, Brian Leetch and Mike Richter also saved the Rangers from a disastrous road trip.

title: U.N.'s Long-Muddled 'Oil-for-Food' Program Makes Progress in Iraq
description: It began a year ago with a maddening slowness that crushed the hopes of many Iraqis desperate for food and medicine. It was called the ''oil-for-food'' program, a plan allowing Iraq to sell some oil to meet the urgent needs of its people, who are living under the most stringent embargo ever imposed on a country by the United Nations Security Council.

title: It's Not Just a Mall. It's Mallville, U.S.A.
description: The Mall of America turned 5 recently; festivities included extreme gloating. ''No one thought it could work,'' recalls Marlin Gilhousen, 71. A retired city planner, he was in favor of building the Bloomington, Minn., supermall -- at 4.2 million square feet, the largest mall in the United States -- even as skeptics in Minneapolis and St. Paul warned that the mall would either go belly up or do too well, killing the commercial downtowns in both cities. In fact, the mall pumps $1.5 billion a year into Minnesota's economy, and its main effect has been to create a third downtown, populated by a devoted cadre of mall walkers. Here's a look.

title: Who Will Do Abortions Here?
description: While I found Hitt's article compelling, my experience, both as a medical student and OB-GYN resident, has been different from the situation he describes. The OB-GYN professor at Yale who oversaw the education of medical students on the wards made no secret of the fact that he volunteered at Planned Parenthood in New Haven, where he performed abortions. Indeed, medical students were allowed to observe abortions if they chose and the patient consented. In my residency program at U.C.L.A., we are taught a variety of abortion methods. Most of my fellow residents elect to participate.

description: BROZINSKY-Herman. Beloved father of Helen Rosenzweig, Bernice Rosenberg and Rolly and Stuart Elkins. Adored grandfather and great-grandfather. Services today, 1 PM, at ''Sinai Chapels,'' 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY.
