His tireless teaching, research, innovation, practice and leadership in diagnostic radiology at the Brooklyn Jewish Hospital, New York University and Yale aided many and continues to inspire physicians around the world.

title: Thanks for the Lift: Broadway as It Used to Sound
description: The charge I used to get from new musicals, I now get mainly from old ones.

title: A Step for World Peace, Breakfast for All
description: DAWN on Long Island: millions of people huddle in bed, half-awake and listening to the morning's bad news on the clock radio. It's dark, it's cold, it's Monday and it's February. The Expressway overhead signs say ''Long Delays Ahead, Exits 73-1,'' the Long Island Rail Road will yet again be brought to a standstill by penguins on the line and the boss will be in a vile mood because his boss is in the Bahamas.

title: IN BRIEF
description: Yonkers Waterfront

title: After Tax Increase, Jersey Smokers Cross the Delaware . . .
description: The plate glass windows of the Main Street Food Market in Lambertville are all but blocked by the cigarette logos -- Winston, Kool, Newport, Camel, Marlboro -- and, of course, the ''We Card'' sign. But it all seems less than necessary at the moment, since not one person has bought a carton there since Jan. 1, the day New Jersey's cigarette tax doubled.

title: City Asks an Earlier Verdict On Shelter Eviction Rules
description: The Giuliani administration is laying the groundwork to enforce a 1995 state measure allowing it to expel homeless people from shelters if they violate an array of rules, including failing to participate in drug counseling and job training programs.

title: Silent Sundays
description: In my role as a nurse and educator, I have found that silence is a magic tool. Insights in preparing for lectures are at their best when I am walking alone. How lucky Otis is to create for himself a sabbath of silence.

title: Not Quite Chapter and Verse on Pentecostalism
description: There's much to admire -- much, indeed, to be awed by -- in ''The Apostle,'' a film in which a Pentecostal Holiness preacher in Texas swings a baseball bat into the cranium of the youth minister who has stolen his wife and church and then high-tails it to Louisiana. The movie, which was written and directed by Robert Duvall, has been widely acclaimed since it was shown at the New York Film Festival in the fall, largely because Mr. Duvall also turns in an extraordinary performance as that preacher, Sonny Dewey. But the film has its troubling aspects too, and they revolve largely around its depiction of Pentecostalism.

title: America's Cup 1999: The Color of Money
description: When a $250,000 entry fee, in the form of a letter of credit, came due on Jan. 31 for challengers to the America's Cup, one of the European yachting teams took the unnecessary step of hand-delivering a check for the full amount.

title: A No. 2 Channel's New Tactic: Imagination
description: If imitation is the sincerest form of flattery, Showtime must have great affection for its archrival, HBO.

title: A Nation Evaluates the President, and Itself; Old Boys' Network
description: To the Editor:

title: Valentine's Day Times Three: The Horror!
description: I'VE had only one memorable Valentine's Day. When I was 6, a first grader named David Carmody, the class Lothario, sent me a Valentine's card at home. Schemer that he was, he knew that if he gave it to me in school, where the don't-bring-candy-unless-everyone-can-have-a-piece rule was in effect, he would have to give every girl and boy a valentine.

title: Gila Ivey, C. J. Selicious
description: Gila Ivey and Christopher Joseph Selicious were married last evening at the George Washington Manor in Roslyn, N.Y. Rabbi Irwin Lowenheim performed the ceremony.

title: In Town, on the Edge: Listening In on Solo Acts
description: John Leguizamo

title: Suffering as a Constant In Schoolhouse's 'Helen'
description: SELF-DESCRIBED ''unrepentant theater junky'' that he is, Bram Lewis, who kept the Phoenix Theater Company running, first in Dobbs Ferry, then in Purchase, for nine seasons all told, ''needed a fix,'' as he puts it in the program for the Schoolhouse here.

title: A Financial Crisis Yields Some Far East Bargains
description: AS Asian economies crumble, the race is on for the best travel deal. The leader at the moment is a British fellow in Bali who asked if he could pay his bill in rupiah. The hotel said yes, the guest scurried into town to change his money, and by the time he did, the cost of his stay had dropped $2,000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLEISCHMAN, JESSICA LEE SOFFER
description: FLEISCHMAN-Jessica Lee Soffer. Died in Florida, February 6, 1998. Far Rockaway High School, Class of 1935, Hunter College, 1939 Phi Beta Kappa. Adored wife of the late Arthur H. Fleischman, M.D., beloved mother of Dana and Laurie, devoted grandmother of Noah and Michael, loving sister of Paul E. Soffer, M.D. and the late Milton D. Soffer; cherished aunt and great aunt, dedicated teacher, lover of mathematics, gifted artist, and vibrant friend.

title: How Intern Reached Corridors of Power
description: For a young White House intern eager to get a closer look at the President of the United States, the week of Nov. 13, 1995, was a dream come true. A budget impasse in Congress had forced a shutdown of the Government, and thousands of Federal employees deemed ''nonessential'' were ordered to stay home. In the White House, unpaid interns eagerly took their places.

title: Excerpts From Draft of Senate Report on Improper Fund-Raising
description: Following are excerpts from the 1,500-page draft report being prepared by the majority staff of the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee, which conducted an investigation last year into accusations of improper fund-raising activities in the 1996 election. The Sioeng family referred to below is related to Ted Sioeng, a California businessman; Matt Fong is the California State Treasurer. A copy of the draft report was obtained by The New York Times.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: TOUR

title: A Pianist's Descent, Reprised
description: To the Editor:

title: Tasks for an Almost Balmy Lull in Winter
description: RECENT mild weather has accelerated the problems of cabin fever. All that sunshine and those balmy days have made gardeners eager to get outside. Isn't there a good excuse to work outdoors?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEGRIN, HYMAN
description: NEGRIN-Hyman. On February 6, 1998. Beloved friend of Betty James. Cherished cousin of Howard Negrin, Henry Nigrine, and Nita Koblin. Funeral services today, at 10:30 AM, at the Plaza Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue at 91st Street.

title: A Modest Proposal For Ellis Island
description: Since New York and New Jersey have wasted so much of the time of the Supreme Court and so much money provided by taxpayers on the issue of who owns Ellis Island, I suggest that both states be punished for this frivolous nonsense by the Supreme Court awarding Ellis Island to neither. Sovereignty over Ellis Island should be awarded to Connecticut. New England has been a beacon to immigrants since the first settlement at Plymouth. Connecticut is the closest New England state to Ellis Island and is the logical choice for sovereignty.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DAY, LOUIS DEVOURSNEY, JR.
description: DAY-Louis DeVoursney, Jr. April 13, 1916-February 6, 1998. Memorial service to be held at St. Martin in the Fields, Chestnut Hill, PA, Monday, February 9, 2 PM.

title: Poetry in Lotion
description: Mary Tannen's article about the art of writing labels prompts me to confess a dark bathroom secret (''Poetry in Lotion,'' Jan. 18). Taking advantage of a Canadian law that requires all products to be labeled in both French and English, I have been using bathroom products to learn French. Alone on my perch, I reach for the nearest bilingually labeled container. With one hand covering the English text of a tube of toothpaste, I study the French translation. Then I uncover the English text to check for accuracy. Thus, for example, it is with confidence that I pass on to French listeners the warning ''Ne pas avaler le dentifrice.'' (''Do not swallow toothpaste.'')

title: Talking the High-Heel Walk
description: THE fashion victims were crossing the King's Road in their wide-bottomed pants, their high-heeled sneakers, their velvet-trimmed cardigans. On his way to lunch, Manolo Blahnik, the high priest of the high heel, spotted his bete noire: a young woman wobbling along in heavy, clunky platform shoes of the sort that members of the rock group Kiss might have worn in their heyday.

title: For Distinction, Try the Lebanon Green
description: If the New Milford green is one-quarter-mile long (''Enter the Bulldozers, a Face Lift Downtown,'' Jan. 18), it hardly qualifies as the longest in Connecticut. That distinction belongs to the Lebanon green, which is one mile in length.

title: Illness Lays Jordan Low, Putting Appearance in All-Star Game in Jeopardy
description: Michael Jordan was off the golf course yesterday, but he was still not on the court and may not be today for the National Basketball Association All-Star Game at Madison Square Garden. He is sick.

title: Wright Breaks Record at 600
description: Sean Wright showed yesterday at the Chase Mayor's Trophy city high school championships in Manhattan why he is one of the most versatile and talented sprinters in the country. Wright, a senior at Rice High School in Manhattan, easily overtook Shawn Jeffers of Brooklyn's Boys and Girls High School in the 600 meters, winning in a meet record time of 1 minute 21.28 seconds to remain undefeated this season in races from 200 through 600 meters. Wright later anchored Rice's 4x200-meter relay to victory in 1:31.50, with Clinton second at 1:32.58.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIER, THEODORA
description: BIER-Theodora. Beloved wife of Lawrence. Loving mother of Lawrence and Dorothy Kerzner, Andrea and Perry Ritter. Dear sister of Manny Rosenblum and Shirley Mishkin. Cherished grandmother of Jeffrey and Ethan, Allison and Lorelei. Service today, 12 noon, at Riverside, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, NY.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.
description: Milliner Quits Retailing, Blaming Strip-Mall Mentality

title: A Trophy House With Ocean View, Camelot Cachet
description: THIS is where J.F.K. slept,'' John K. Castle explained, pointing to the widely separated twin beds, a setting austere in the extreme save for the carved Gothic oak headboards.

title: Fantasies of Monica Lewinsky: The Book
description: THE SETTING: A cocktail party for the 50th anniversary of the Radcliffe Publishing Course held Wednesday night in the leafy courtyard of the Pierpont Morgan Library, a bland-tie event celebrating the six-week summer class that has pedigreed many of the city's high-powered publishers, editors and book marketers. And while the school's alumni spoke of the program's distinguished history, some of Radcliffe's younger graduates, assistants all, had another topic in mind.

title: An Outback Gone Upscale
description: AN astonishing portion of the profit in the American auto business these days comes from sport utility vehicles: Wall Street analysts say that selling a single Expedition means more to Ford's bottom line than 10 Contours. But how can an auto maker that missed the trend cash in, now that the market has been sliced and diced with dozens of look-alike four-by-four's?

title: G.O.P. Stakes Fiscal Ground in Pitch for Shoring Up Medicare
description: The chairman of the Senate Budget Committee today endorsed President Clinton's call for future budget surpluses to be reserved for Social Security. But breaking with the President over the proceeds of a national tobacco settlement, Senator Pete V. Domenici insisted that tobacco money be devoted to shoring up Medicare.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: SHE TOOK MY ARM

title: Mineral Beauties From Nature
description: THE Stamford Museum and Nature Center's newly renovated lobby has been turned into a gallery where small collections can be showcased.

title: Norman J. Block, 93; Founded Dunhill Tailors
description: Norman J. Block, a bespoke businessman who helped define the epitome of masculine elegance as the very well-met and decidedly well-dressed founding proprietor of Dunhill Tailors in Manhattan, died on Tuesday at a hospital in Manhattan. He was 93.

title: A Nation Evaluates the President, and Itself; What We Deserve
description: To the Editor:

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN
description: Village of Dreams

title: Trapped, Escapee Kills Himself
description: After committing a string of bank robberies and a kidnapping, a fugitive from a Pennsylvania prison killed himself in a West Village hotel room yesterday morning as his pursuers closed in, law enforcement officers said.

title: Hombres
description: CUBA LIBRE

title: Our Best All-Star Is Not Playing
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Snow Mope
description: ''How could I be happy about the Olympics when our company's best athlete isn't going to be there?'' laments Jake Burton, chief of Burton Snowboards. He's talking about the absence from the Games of Terje Haakonsen, a Norwegian and a Burton endorsement athlete who is arguably the world's best freestyle snowboarder. He bowed out of Nagano, calling the International Olympic Committee a ''mafia,'' a move that spotlighted snowboarders' ambivalence about the Olympics. ''It's all run by these ski Nazis,'' Burton says. ''The concept of uniforms is scary.'' So will Burton boycott? ''No, I'll be there,'' he says grudgingly. ''I'd be a hypocrite if I said we won't benefit from the sport growing.''

title: Guys (Who Else?) Behaving Badly
description: THE COUNTRY

title: Christel Albritton, Colin MacLean
description: THE Galaxy Systems Stars, an amateur ice hockey team, play at the Chelsea Piers rink every Sunday night. One of the most high-spirited players is Colin Scott MacLean, a theatrical producer and sometime bartender who grew up in Montreal and looks like Mikhail Baryshnikov, only taller and skinnier. He's known for skating with the determination of a pit bull but for being as likable as a St. Bernard.

title: Portions Suitable for Athletes in Training
description: WHEN we arrived with our guests at Wellingtons in Huntington, we were greeted offhandedly by the hostess and ushered to a well-napped table in the narrow dining room to the left of the bar.

title: The Long Hurrah
description: MAYOR CORNING

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DENMARK, PAMELA D.
description: DENMARK-Pamela D., age 37, of Flushing, N.Y., died on February 6, 1998. Beloved daughter of Dr. Florence Denmark Wesner and Dr. Stanley J. Denmark. Step daughter of Robert Wesner and Anita Goodman Denmark. Survived by her sister Valerie and twin brother Richard and her fiance Robert Rackett. Services at Sinai Chapel on Horace Harding Blvd, Fresh Meadows, N.Y. on Monday, February 9, at 12 noon. Interment at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pine Lawn, N.Y. In lieu of flowers donations to the American Liver Foundation, Melville, N.Y.

title: Role Model? Please
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A Correspondent's Report column on Dec. 14 about tourism in Austria characterized museum admission fees in Vienna incorrectly. A letter from the Vienna Tourist Board, received Jan. 14, points out that the fees cited are not representative. The charge at the Museum of Fine Arts, for example, is $3.50, based on an exchange rate of 12.8 schillings to the dollar. Admission ''to some major museums'' is not $9.

title: From Royalty's Best Friend to Collectors' Favorite
description: Despite their wrinkles, bug eyes and seething nasal passages, pug dogs were the preferred pets of royalty in the 18th century. It was a pug that bit Napoleon as he climbed into bed on his wedding night and it was a pug that carried notes in its collar to the imprisoned Josephine. Pugs also accompanied Mary, Queen of Scots to the scaffold, warmed the lap of the courtesan Madame de Pompadour and wore colorful pantaloons when riding in the coaches of Italian aristocrats.

title: February 1-7; Much Ado About Pooh
description: A study in trans-Atlantic silliness emerged last week when a member of the British Parliament, Gwyneth Dunwoody, called upon the New York Public Library to return the original Winnie-the-Pooh and four stuffed associates, noting that the toys had inspired the British author A. A. Milne to write the famous Pooh series. Besides, she said, she detected in the faces of the British-made toys a certain unhappiness with their display-case accommodations.

title: N.B.A. ALL-STAR WEEKEND: Kids Slam and Ham, but a Grown-Up Shoots for Dough; 10,000 Show Off Their Cool
description: It started at 4 A.M. Joel Colon's eyes were as wide open as a rim. So he popped out of bed, showered, slipped on a slammin' pair of baggy jeans that had room to groove and pulled out a pair of goggled sunglasses, something the Red Baron might dig.

title: The Ups And Downs Of Alizah Allen
description: ONE year ago, Alizah Allen was on a steamboat in Nashville, dancing and going wild. At 17, she had just placed 10th at the 1997 United States Figure Skating Association's National Championships. She had skated to this personal triumph in a lacy pink costume. But for the party held for competitors, she chose a cowgirl outfit. She was riding high.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Boxes of Reality
description: Photography was considered such a faithful record of reality that one of its inventors called it ''the pencil of nature''; 150 years later the true subject of photography appears to be the ultimate fake. In SMALL WONDER: Worlds in a Box (National Museum of American Art/D.A.P., paper, $35), a collection of color photographs of toy sets, David Levinthal plays with concepts of image and authenticity, myth and history, perception and reality. In an introduction, the critic David Corey calls the play sets of plastic figurines manufactured in the 1950's and 60's ''a museum of the material and spiritual preoccupations of the age.'' Levinthal often photographs these figures in crepuscular, slanting shadows, so that a scene of a bald-pated, bespectacled boss dictating to a stenographer takes on a Hopperesque loneliness and isolation. While Levinthal regards his subject matter with great seriousness, the implied commentary of his images on the history of photography is often hilarious: his image of cheese-yellow Lincoln and Grant figurines standing by a toy tent mimics the stiff poses of the real subjects in the images taken by Mathew Brady. By toying with our images of history, Levinthal questions how much we substitute image for actuality, from Edward S. Curtis's plates of American Indians to the battlefield photography of Robert Capa. Eric P. Nash

title: Open 366 Days And 13 Months All Year Long
description: Like most Manhattanites, Ali Salah craves more time in the day. Unlike everybody else, though, he gets it, in an advertising fantasy.

title: Conference at New Paltz To Examine Free Speech
description: A State University of New York campus that gained notoriety for some presentations during a conference on sex and gender has decided on the topic of its spring symposium: free speech and academic freedom.

title: The World: War Fever; The Weapon Too Terrible for the Parade of Horribles
description: THE old enemy from Central Casting has returned to the American stage: Saddam Hussein with his grotesque personality cult, his history of using chemical weapons against his own people and the Iranians, his invasion of Kuwait and his cynical cruelty. But in mobilizing to bomb him, President Clinton has repeatedly singled out one specific threat: that of the biological weapons Mr. Hussein possesses and appears to be concealing from United Nations inspectors.

title: February 1-7; Happy Birthday, Mr. Reagan
description: Congress gave Ronald Reagan an 87th-birthday present when Republicans -- and even a few Democrats -- voted to rename Washington National Airport in honor of the ailing former President. President Clinton signed the bill to change the name to the Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport. LIZETTE ALVAREZ

title: Master Of Her Own Destiny
description: MARTHA STEWART is making avocado soup. A sprinkle of cilantro (use the leaves, not the stems, for a more subtle flavor). A splash of fresh-squeezed orange juice. A hollowed-out watermelon half for the presentation.

title: Comfort Food, Japanese Style
description: WITH the Olympic Winter Games just under way in Nagano, the entire country is prepared to play host to the world's top athletes, and the crowds of fans who will come to cheer them on. Most visitors to Japan will be arriving and departing by way of Tokyo, staying for several days to see some of this huge, modern metropolis.

title: Innsbruck
description: Few cities are also winter sports destinations, but Innsbruck qualifies. It is home to a university and 130,000 people, and capital of the Austrian province of the Tyrol. It was host to two Olympic Winter Games (1964 and 1976), and offers skating and ski jumping within the city limits, and cross-country and alpine skiing and luge and bobsled tracks within five miles or so.

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: All in the Davis Family: Still Picking Winners
description: WHEN the name is Davis, the phrase ''family of funds'' can be used literally. Christopher and Andrew Davis, sons of the legendary fund manager Shelby Davis and grandsons of Shelby Cullom Davis Sr., who founded Davis Selected Advisers in 1947, have been nurtured in the family business since childhood. Now both are managing Davis funds and compiling enviable records.

title: The Games' First Gold Goes to Skier From Russia
description: The first gold medal of the 1998 Winter Olympics was won today by a cross-country skier named Olga Danilova, but it was more than a victory for Danilova and her native Russia. It was also a victory for working mothers everywhere.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FURMAN, EARLE L., D.D.S.
description: FURMAN-Earle L., D.D.S. Of Chatham, NJ, on February 4, 1998. Beloved husband of Mary Hartung Furman. Devoted father of Marilyn Furman O'Donnell of NYC, and twin sons Richard Earle of Deerfield Beach, FL, and Robert John of West Orange, NJ. Proud grandfather of Julia, Holly and Christie. A funeral servie was held at the Wm. A. Bradley & Son Funeral Home, 345 Main St (Rt. 124), Chatham, NJ, on Saturday, February 7, 1998. Those who wish may contribute in his memory to the Kiwanis Club of the Chathams, PO Box 422, Chatham, NJ 07928.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAMONT, HAYES CORLISS
description: LAMONT-Hayes Corliss. Of Newton, Tuesday, Feb. 3, 1998, age 62 years. Husband of Izolde (Silkovskis) Lamont. Father of Elizabeth E. Lamont of Oakland, CA., Juliet A. Lamont of Berkely, CA., and Christopher H. Lamont of Gloucester. Brother of Margaret H. Heap of Greenwich, CT., Florence L. Antonides of New Britain, CT., and Anne L. Jafferis of New Haven, CT. A memorial service will be held Saturday, February 21, 1998 at the First & Second Church in Boston, 66 Marlborough Street, Boston, MA., at 2 P.M. Relatives and friends are cordially invited to attend. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Hayes Corliss Lamont Charitable Fund, C/O Fleet Bank, 1228 Boylston Street, Chestnut Hill, MA 02167.

title: Barkers Are a Blight, Artists Say
description: Leigh Behnke and her husband, Don Eddy, both artists, have lived on Broadway in SoHo for about 12 years. They have seen the changes in the neighborhood, as stores have replaced wholesale fabric merchants, bringing throngs to streets that were once deserted. They have heard the changes, too, notably the barkers who chant, sing and even scream the praises of some of those stores, especially those between Prince and Spring Streets, under their loft windows.

title: Co-op Murals Inspire Culture Clash
description: Gila Cohen, dressed in her stockbroker's suit, looked at the 50-foot-wide mural in the lobby of her building and explained why she thinks it should be destroyed along with three other murals in the lobbies of her four-building housing development.

title: February 1-7; In Fashion, No More Dirty Pictures
description: Does anything change faster than fashion? Perhaps it's fashion advertising.

title: New Ruling On Eviction
description: To the Editor:

title: The Neuroses of History
description: An Octave Above Thunder

title: WOMEN'S 15K
description: A Russian cross-country skier captured the first gold medal of the Nagano Games on a snowy morning. The swirling flakes provided a picture-postcard backdrop for Olga Danilova's victory in the women's 15-kilometer classical race. Danilova sailed through the snow in Hakuba to capture a tight race by 5.6 seconds

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOHLMANN, PAUL A.
description: KOHLMANN-Paul A. On February 7, 1998. Beloved husband of Ursula. Loving father of Peter and Josephine; Susan and Michael Orbison. Adoring grandfather of Emma and Charlotte; Willie, Ben and Jake. He will be profoundly missed. Service Sunday, 11:30 AM, at Hebrew Tabernacle, 551 Fort Washington Ave., NYC. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory to the charity of your choice.

title: What to Look For
description: FIGURE SKATING PAIRS, SHORT PROGRAM

title: Changing the Color of Silicon
description: IT was a summer evening almost four years ago, just after a spoken word night at Common Boundaries, an art gallery in Jersey City. The young crowd of about two dozen poets, artists and others was abuzz, partly from the poetry and partly from the wine. McLean Greaves, a freelance magazine writer who wears what he calls ''Henry Kissinger-style glasses,'' asked Tyrone Thomas, a programmer at A T & T Bell Laboratories, ''Can you multiply two hexadecimal numbers?''

title: A Nation Evaluates the President, and Itself; Not Worth the Price
description: To the Editor:

title: Jimmy Hoffa's Revenge
description: On a wind-whipped fall day, a creaking, leaking motor home angles into the parking lot of the V.F.W. hall in Brick Township, N.J., and releases into a knot of waiting teamsters the scion and heir-presumptive of the most notorious labor leader in American history.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DRUCKER, ELLA
description: DRUCKER-Ella. 9 years of anguish resulting from your loss. You never leave my thoughts or my heart. I'll love you forever. Kisses, V.

title: School Declines to Discipline Boy for Computer Comments
description: A Bergen County eighth grader was recently discovered to have written derogatory and sexually explicit comments about his teachers on the Internet, but the school authorities decided last week not to discipline him because he did the writing at home.

title: The View From/Woodbridge; Beyond the Textbooks, To the Source Materials
description: ALMOST every school in Connecticut has a library, but only a handful use them to drive the curriculum. Beecher Road School Library in Woodbridge is one.

title: Casinos Pull Out Stops for Older Gamblers
description: THE Tiara Room floated above Atlantic City, dressed in pink and silver balloons, with an abundance of plates of prime rib and the sounds of a traditional orchestra. The scene was Mary Pantazis's party for her 73d birthday, compliments of the Taj Mahal casino.

title: OUTDOORS; Wildlife Participation Is Holding Steady
description: Toward the close of a decade that has seen the mushrooming of cable television and the rise of the Internet, nearly 40 percent of United States adults are still answering the call of the wild. In a survey published at the end of last year, the United States Fish and Wildlife Service found that 77 million Americans age 16 and older fished, hunted and watched wildlife in 1996.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREGER, RICHARD J.
description: FREGER-Richard J. Of Roswell, GA., passed away on January 6, 1998 after a brief illness. Beloved husband of Linda. Devoted father of Jonathan of Venice Beach, CA., and Jennifer of Evanston, IL. He was a lingerie designer for Vanity Fair Intimates. Memorial service will be held at The Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, Friday, on February 13, 1998 at 1:15 PM.

title: Tactics Called Abusive by Critics and the Ensnared
description: Long before the accusations of investigative leaks and the surreptitious recording of a former White House intern saying she had an affair with the President, Federal agents working for the independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr, showed up at a small-town Arkansas high school with a subpoena for the 16-year-old son of a defendant in a Whitewater case.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FITZGERALD, VIVIAN A. BETKE, FITZGERALD
description: FITZGERALD-Vivian A. Betke-Fitzgerald. Of Cazenovia, NY, on February 4, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Sgt. Richard R. Betke. Dear mother of Mrs. Dewey Y. (Elaine C.) Betke-Bow. Sister of Joann Ponce, Barbara La Dolcetta and Patricia Moscatelli and friend Barbara Reyes. Loving aunt of eight nieces and one nephew. Funeral service at the Kimak Funeral Home, 425 Broad St., Carlstadt, NJ, on Monday, February 9, 1998, at 1 PM. Interment George Washington Memorial Park, Paramus, NJ. Visitation Monday, 11 AM to 1 PM.

title: Remembering Encounters With Rabbi Goldman
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MRAKOVCIC, FRANK
description: MRAKOVCIC-Frank. On February 5, 1998. Too innocent for this world. Will always be remembered for his sweet disposition, his great sense of humor and his wonderful way with children. He was a computer specialist at LIPCO Partners. Beloved son of Ivan and the late Ljubica. Loving brother of Maria and Michael Litvak, Ivica, Laura, Suzi and Rob. Adored and devoted uncle of Liana and Hannah. Frank was a Harley Davidson enthusiast, collector of fine military memorabilia and a music lover. Wake Sunday and Monday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at Joseph P. Clavin Sons Funeral Home, 7722 4th Avenue, Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial, Tuesday, 10 AM, St. Anselms Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, DR. MILTON
description: BROWN-Dr. Milton. The faculty, students, staff and alumni of the Ph.D. program in Art History at the City University Graduate School mourn the passing of Emeritus Professor Milton Brown. He taught art history at Brooklyn College and at the Graduate School of the City University for over 35 years and was responsible for the formation of the Ph.D. program in Art History, where he was its first Chair. With his 1955 groundbreaking book, American Painting from the Amory Show to the Depression, he was critical in the development of the field of 20th century American art history. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife Blanche. His warmth, scholarship and humanity will be sorely missed.

title: The World; A Promised Land of Frozen Milk and Honey
description: AMERICANS don't know much about Russia, but what they do know (or think they know) has been etched into their brains from birth: The place is a big, loutish and at times exuberant mess. It is the world headquarters of suffering. If the Czars and the Communists differed in every other way, they shared an ability to incite dread on an almost unimaginable scale.

title: U.N. Delegate Sees Support Worldwide For the U.S.
description: After shuttling 18,000 miles among far-flung countries that seldom hit the radar screen of American foreign policy, the chief United States representative to the United Nations came home to report today that a ''silent majority'' of nations supports Washington's policy on Iraq.

title: Q&A: James Gesualdi; Legal Advice for Dolphins and Friends
description: JAMES GESUALDI has spent the greater part of his nine years in law representing the rights of clients who often erupt into high-pitched squeals and clicks to show their appreciation. Mr. Gesualdi, who works for the law firm of Cahn Wishod & Lamb, L.L.P. in Melville, has represented numerous aquatic concerns, notably the Dolphin Research Center in Florida, which is home to Atlantic bottlenose dolphins. They first encountered Mr. Gesualdi in 1989.

title: Tooling Up Olympic Bobsled Speed
description: IF the United States wins Olympic medals in bobsleigh -- that's bobsled racing in America -- in the games that started yesterday, it will be largely because of the passion of one man: Robert Cuneo of Bethany. Mr. Cuneo designs and fabricates competition sleds at Chassis Dynamics Inc. in Oxford, a small company that for 25 years has concentrated on racing cars.

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN
description: General Chaos: Uncensored Animation

title: Men Who Love Too Much
description: RIVEN ROCK By T. Coraghessan Boyle. 466 pp. New York: Viking. $24.95.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DEE, BERNADETTE
description: DEE-Bernadette. Who passed away February 8, 1997. Will always be remembered as a caring, loving mother and true friend. Her Son, Timothy

title: Students' Research Pays Off in Patents
description: AS many of their elders struggle to figure out the most basic computer applications, two students at Byram Hills High School here were recently named among the 300 semifinalists -- but not among the 40 finalists -- selected in the Westinghouse Science Talent Search for their research in computers. More significantly, the students, August Petrillo and Philip Fong, both seniors, became the first students ever to have their work patented -- by International Business Machines, where they did their research. They , were, incidentally, the only Westchester students to reach the semifinals.

title: INSIDE
description: MUTUAL FUNDS /Page 5/

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: February 8, 1998
description: Weeks

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: Rabe on Suicide

title: Extreme Sport, Extreme Chic, Extreme Hype
description: IT was a moonlight night in January, and the second Winter X Games, developed by ESPN, had just completed Day 1 at this resort town known for its young, free-spirited alternative athletes.

title: Near Death, Tucker Gave Suggestions To the Prison
description: Two and a half hours before she was put to death in Texas this week, Karla Faye Tucker handed the state's chief prison official a three-page handwritten ''Rehabilitation Plan for Inmates,'' in which she proposed that prisoners be paid for their work with money they would give back to the state for their food, clothes, housing and medical care.

title: Design Flaw in Security Systems Leaves Airports Vulnerable to Terrorists, Officials Say
description: Aviation officials have quietly notified airports in the United States and Britain that a design flaw in a widely used security system could enable terrorists to gain control of the electronic badges that allow employees with security clearance to enter and leave restricted areas.

title: Union Square's Renaissance Began Before the BID
description: To the Editor:

title: All Natural All the Time, Except for . . .
description: ON the kitchen table rested an arrangement unlike any that 1-800-F-L-O-W-E-R-S might deliver. Long spindly branches with little wispy blossoms jutted out from a glass vase. The branches encompassed so much space that they left little room for leisurely dining.

title: The World: Fear Itself; Again, Israel Worries About Iraq
description: WAITING to trade in her family's worn gas masks for new ones at a crowded distribution center, Orly Abarjil said she was fighting off anxiety.

title: SOAPBOX; Of Human Kindness
description: NEW JERSEY'S dairy farms are vanishing at an alarming rate -- nearly half in the last 10 years. A law enacted last month would allow our dairy farms to join the Northeast Interstate Dairy Compact. Unfortunately, the opponents fought the legislation using scare tactics with predications of higher prices for milk at the supermarket. Milk drinkers should look at the facts, and the opponents.

title: Program Shows Children The Power of the Penny
description: The somber chambers of the New York City Board of Education resembled a scene from a piggy bank heist yesterday. A mound of money sacks rose from the marble floors. A broom was needed to sweep up the scads of pennies scattered everywhere.

title: Darkness at Home for Blind
description: Mary West has lived at Selis Manor, a residence for the blind on 23d Street, near Seventh Avenue, since it opened 17 years ago, all the while secure that someone would help her read her mail, shop for groceries and even dress in clothes that matched.

title: Re: Government, Politics And Getting the Job Done
description: When Governor Whitman addressed dozens of mayors visiting the State House last week, she won the loudest applause for her proposal to give municipalities the option of abandoning civil service rules.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  JOFFE, HELEN GEWERTZ
description: JOFFE-Helen Gewertz. 06/04/'30 to 02/07/'97. Sister, caregiver, friend, may her memory be for a blessing.

title: What Went Up Must Go Down, Critics of Sign Say
description: For the last eight years, the Gristede's supermarket in the basement of a building at the northwest corner of West 86th Street and Broadway has done a steady business in fruits, vegetables and other victuals.

title: Remembering Encounters With Rabbi Goldman
description: To the Editor:

title: Crime
description: A killer named Keller makes his mark in Lawrence Block's HIT MAN (Morrow, $22), a collection of stories (all but one previously published) that reads like the flowing memoir of a man who is letting it all out for the first time. The thing about Keller is that he's the top of his class -- an ace assassin with steady hands, cool nerves and perfectly honed professional skills. The other thing about Keller is that he's having a major midcareer crisis. By job definition a loner, who can't acquire a girlfriend, a therapist or even a dog without being prepared for the (often dire) consequences, the guy really needs to think and talk. Hence, the ironic tone and confessional content that make these intimate tales so funny and full of rue.

title: A Leaner Company Without a Crash Diet
description: AS the AT&T Corporation prepares to follow through on last month's announcement that it would cut its payroll by up to 18,000 jobs, it has an underappreciated tool at its disposal: practice.

title: POSTINGS: Increase Is Linked to Fannie Mae Move; F.H.A. Loans: Higher Limits
description: A recent increase in loan limits by Fannie Mae, the nation's largest source of residential mortgage funds, and a resulting increase in the maximum loans allowed by the Federal Housing Administration, is expected to make thousands of additional F.H.A. loans available.

title: The Nation: AK-47's, Battery Acid; Dead Women Waiting: Who's Who on Death Row
description: ELEVEN are on death row for killing or arranging to kill their husbands, five for murdering their children, and two for doing both. One killed two of her grandchildren.

title: Restoring Historic Union Station in Kansas City
description: AFTER decades of deterioration, this city's historic Union Station at the southern edge of downtown is undergoing a $234 million renovation that will restore its former grandeur and install a lavish 285,000-square-foot science museum.

title: In the East Village, Variety Above All
description: Each listing now includes information supplied by the restaurant about its policy on smoking.

title: Laid Off? Dismissed? To Sue or Not to Sue
description: AS if getting laid off wasn't bad enough, a growing number of workers have an extra-tough decision to make on their way out the door: whether to forever give up their right to sue the boss. Those who do can walk away with a sweet deal. Those who don't gamble that they'll be better off in the long run.

title: Compelling Sculpture and Transitory Doings
description: Ruby Jackson/Bruce Lieberman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORAZZI, MARGARET K. (NEE KAVANAGH)
description: PORAZZI-Margaret K. (nee Kavanagh). Of Staten Island on Feburary 4, 1998. Wife of the late Mario. Mother of Carlo E., Mario A., Alberto R. and Arturo E. Also survived by seven grandchildren and five great grandchildren. Funeral from Virginia Funeral Home, 188 Canal St., Stapleton, S.I., N.Y. Monday, 9:15AM. Mass of Christian Burial at Saint Mary's R.C. Church, 10 A.M. Interment Saint Mary's Cemetery. Visiting hours Friday, Saturday and Sunday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. In lieu of flowers, please give to your favorite charity or Peggy's favorite charities, Project Hospitality, S.I. Botanical Garden-Chinese Scholars Garden or Alice Austen House Museum and Park.

title: February 1-7; Afghan Quake Kills Thousands
description: An earthquake struck Afghanistan's remote northeast on Wednesday, toppling mud-and-brick hillside homes, touching off landslides and killing thousands of people, Afghan officials said. The United States Geological Survey in Golden, Colo., said the quake, which struck the province of Takhar, had a magnitude of 6.1.

title: Who Will Do Abortions Here?
description: I am one of the 60-year-old OB-GYN's who perform abortions. I am angry over the statement made by the doctor (who supports abortion rights but has chosen not to perform abortions) who said that ''the people who moonlight at the clinics are grade-B doctors.'' There are a lot of us out here who can dance rings around him in the operating room and in clinic settings.

title: Sports of The Times; The Biggest Stakes Aren't In Nagano
description: AS someone has said regarding the travails of a politician much in the news lately, it is considerably better to make love, not war. And here in the snowy mountains of Japan, a similar sentiment has been expressed, which is, essentially, make luge, not war.

title: Stepping Out of Stereotype, in Style
description: American Movie Classics, the cable network devoted to the golden age of Hollywood film, begins its observance of Black History Month on Tuesday with the television premiere of ''Small Steps, Big Strides: The Black Experience in Hollywood (1903-1970).'' While it notes the distorted images that characterized black actors' early roles in movies and inhibited their portrayals long afterward, this hourlong special is primarily a celebration of the struggle waged by black performers for unbiased representation.

title: VIEWPOINT; In Banking, a Happy Medium
description: THE last year has seen great changes in the banking industry, as a flurry of big mergers, like those of First Union and Corestates and of Chemical and Chase Manhattan, has altered the financial landscape.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption last Sunday with the View column, about White Plains, misidentified a participant in a program marking the 25th anniversary of Roe v. Wade. The woman in the right-hand picture was Norma Bruce, cantor of Beth David Congregation in Amenia, N.Y., not Rabbi Joan Farber.

title: Where the Old Boy Always Gets the Girl
description: No doubt it goes back to the Pleistocene Epoch: among most cave couples, male and female were only a few years apart. But some aging alpha men long dominant in the tribe (Homo sapiens now barely erectus) displayed their status by grabbing some tasty and nubile nymphet by the hair and dragging her before the assembled tribe. The audience, being mostly male (what with the wives stuck back in the cave), alternately drooled and sighed at the spectacle. But once women were allowed out of the cave and given a voice, they responded to these superannuated studs with snickers, boos and guffaws.

title: Where Designers Seek the Future in the Past
description: MICHELLE LIAO, a dealer in antique Chinese clothing and fabrics, ran her hands over the jewel-toned silk robes that she had spread like fans on a wooden table. ''I've sold so many of these I can't begin to count,'' she said, glancing beyond the table to the sea of patterns, colors and shapes before her.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRAUM, STANLEY E.
description: TRAUM-Stanley E. January 27, 1998 in Tucson, AZ. Beloved husband of the late Maxine, devoted father of Elaine Gosman, loving grandfather of Amy and David.

title: Super 8 Grows Up With a Festival of Its Own
description: ANTON VARDEKUHLA is a vampire. He sustains himself not with blood, his creator says, but with ''that little extra something generally found in the souls of artists.'' Unfortunately, Anton won't be making it to your neighborhood multiplex anytime soon; he's not the protagonist of the latest Hollywood blockbuster, or even of a quirky little independent feature that wowed 'em at Sundance. He's the hero of ''Art of the Vampire,'' the Super 8 film that took Walter Von Egidy four years to make, at night and on weekends when he wasn't working in his sign shop in New Milford, Conn.

title: The Nation: Vive La Difference; In Europe, a Sneer, a Cheer and a Lament
description: AMERICANS, Alexis de Tocqueville found to his bemusement in 1835, ''consider marriage as a covenant which is often onerous, but every condition of which the parties are strictly bound to fulfill, because they knew all those conditions beforehand, and were perfectly free not to have contracted them.''

title: Food Technology Unit Comes to Ardsley
description: VELTROL, Litesse and Xylitol are hardly household words, yet they are everyday products found in the food and beverages on the shelves of the bakery, dairy, confectionery, processed meat and poultry, seafood, vegetable, alcoholic and nonalcoholic beverage departments of supermarkets across the United States.

title: Lincoln's Early Years
description: IT is a great piece of folly to make anything out of my early life,'' Abraham Lincoln once told a journalist. His entire youth, he maintained, could be condensed into one line from Gray's ''Elegy'': ''The short and simple annals of the poor.'' Lincoln shrugged. ''That's my life, and that's all you or anyone else can make of it.''

title: A By-the-Book Defense Versus Martin's Reality
description: Whenever Casey Martin enters or leaves the United States Courthouse in Eugene, Ore., he is hotly pursued by the news media. The golfer, who is suing the PGA Tour to let him ride a golf cart, limps badly, his atrophied right leg hypersensitive to the touch and so fragile it could snap on an errant step.

title: February 1-7; Rethinking Animal History
description: Biologists never believed that animal life in all its variety sprang from nowhere 540 million years ago in the Cambrian explosion. But their search for evidence of Precambrian ancestors had been frustrating. It turns out they hadn't been looking in the right rocks.

title: Who Will Do Abortions Here?
description: Jack Hitt's excellent article ''Who Will Do Abortions Here?'' (Jan. 18) makes those of us who remember when abortions were illegal grind our teeth in fury.

title: Finding a Chimney Sweep Who Won't Clean You Out
description: Most states, New Jersey among them, don't regulate the chimney service trade, so consumers have to be careful about choosing a sweep, said Jo Anne Calderone, executive director of the National Chimney Sweep Guild and its sister organization, the Chimney Safety Institute of America.

title: Liberties; The Price Of His Pleasure
description: I've had some lousy days at work. But I can't imagine how hard it was for Betty Currie to sit at her desk outside the Oval Office on Friday and say good morning to the boss.

title: A Market That Quivers as Refinancings Rise
description: LAST year was an outstanding one for mortgage-backed securities. They outperformed all other investment-grade, fixed-income investments.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Floral Park, L.I.; Next to Queens, a Touch of Nostalgia
description: LATER this month Floral Park residents who want to know what's going on in their community will be able to click on their televisions and tune in to a 24-hour village cable station.

title: Budget's Mixed Message On Saving
description: IN his State of the Union address, President Clinton stressed the need to encourage retirement savings by the nation's workers. But his proposed budget seems to work at conflicting purposes.

title: In Hope of Spiritual Revival, a Call to Fast
description: For 40 days last year, Linda Creager prepared dinner and sat down with her two sons at the table, but ate nothing. For 40 consecutive days she fasted, swallowing nothing but liquids. Ms. Creager says she was not on a diet, but on a religious mission, to find guidance from God.

title: To Do Right, or Just to Be Legal?
description: DOES a company's moral high ground erode slightly if the business builds its ethics policies simply to lower potential fines for fraud? Yes, say the proponents of values-based ethics, who often criticize compliance-based ethics -- those centered on rules -- that have become common in corporate America.

title: Chamber Orchestra Finds Its Way Without Going Far Afield
description: THE Connecticut Valley Chamber Orchestra stands apart from most others in the state in that its players are volunteers, its soloists are local artists and its programs are deftly off the beaten path.

title: Dropping In to Visit the Sharks and Seals Who Live Next Door
description: SHARKS, a seal show and all the other attractions of the New Jersey State Aquarium are available to Camden residents with no admission charge this month. The open-admission program for the aquarium's neighbors has become a winter tradition since the aquarium opened in Camden six year ago this month.

title: Dream of Recreation Center Nears Reality
description: HOW often has one heard the adage ''children are our future''? With $3.2 million already raised to set up a recreational center, the Town of East Hampton has taken this sentiment to heart.

title: Bringing God on Deck
description: WE were deep in the rumbling bowels of a container ship last week when the German chief engineer cocked a cold eye at a Filipino deckhand and said: ''There is a big difference between us and them. No one can tell me all people are equal.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-13

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: HANNAH ARENDT, MARTIN HEIDEGGER

title: The Gradual Revolution
description: THE COMMANDING HEIGHTS

title: The Inner Rodman, With Just a Hint Of Lame
description: THIS has been a quiet season for Dennis Rodman. The rebounding machine of the Chicago Bulls -- who unashamedly displays his feminine side by wearing makeup, hot pants, feathered boas and wedding gowns -- has played the good citizen.

title: From Croton-on-Hudson With the County's Olympic Hopes
description: THE first run was taken in an across-the-street neighbor's backyard.

title: Delaying the Pay
description: To the Editor:

title: Zooming In On the New, Hot Stocks
description: SAY hello to the nation's first mutual fund to invest solely in initial public offerings.

title: Who Will Do Abortions Here?
description: I am perturbed by the weight Hitt gives to the late-term abortion he witnessed. He doesn't sufficiently emphasize how rare this procedure is. Nor does he balance it with scenes from a first-trimester abortion; in a woman-centered clinic, this procedure is often a short drama, filled with anxiety, some pain, some humor and a lot of caring human interaction. The only hint I get of this in your article is in the wonderful photo of Dr. Rashbaum holding a woman's hand.

title: Avoiding One Danger, But Finding Another
description: Given the recent roller-coaster ride of emerging-markets funds, it is not surprising that some managers try to lower risk by avoiding the most dangerous places -- sidestepping politically unstable nations, those that are unfriendly to foreign investment or those with small or illiquid markets.

title: Now It's O.K. for Blair to Cry
description: Bonnie Blair ''lost it'' the other day. She never used to do that when she was the speed skating queen of the world, but now that she is retired, she occasionally cries in public.

title: At Bellevue, Luring Back New Mothers With Luxury
description: Kevin Masaquiza was born last Wednesday in a big double bed, in a room with glorious views of the East River. Flower-flecked paper covered the walls, which were decorated with bright framed pictures. In the corner of the room was a glass-enclosed Jacuzzi, where his mother could have relaxed while she was in labor.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: VALENTINE CITY

title: Anything but Ridicule
description: As Prime Minister Tony Blair flew off to Washington to confer with President Clinton, English commentators fussed about the trip. Some worried that Britain would be dragged into an ill-advised war with Iraq. Many more feared that Mr. Blair would be made to look ridiculous by being forced to answer questions about the President and Monica Lewinsky.

title: ART; Remembering Leger, Champion of Nuts and Bolts
description: The survey of the work of Fernand Leger (1881-1955) that will be on exhibit at the Museum of Modern Art from next Sunday through May 12 represents the first time in more than 40 years that the artist's paintings will be seen in depth in New York. The last person to assemble an American retrospective during the artist's lifetime and to consult with him on such an exhibition was Katharine Kuh (1904-1994), who did so in 1952-53 when she was the curator of modern painting and sculpture at the Art Institute of Chicago. An art historian, educator and critic who championed the new and vital, Kuh opened a gallery in Chicago in 1935 specializing in avant-garde European and American art; Leger was first shown there in April 1936. The gallery closed in 1942, and she joined the Art Institute a year later. After leaving the museum and moving to New York City in 1959, Kuh became art editor for Saturday Review and wrote several books. This essay is excerpted from ''Past Encounters, Present Memories,'' a book of reminiscences that Kuh was working on at her death; it was edited and completed by Avis Berman, her literary representative.

title: A Japanese Menu With Some Surprises
description: THERE is a sameness about Japanese restaurants but Hime, a newcomer in Port Washington, delivers a few jolts. The kamikaze may be a popular cocktail on the Island, but how many Japanese spots have it on their menus? Or the banzai?

title: Men In Black
description: 'This is a revolution in advertising,'' boasts Amos Ben-Naeh, the founder and president of Original Idea, a Jerusalem-based agency that exclusively represents models who are ultra-Orthodox Jews. That is, Jews whose rigorous beliefs require something models aren't usually known for: modesty in dress and relations between the sexes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEBOEUF, HARRIET ROSS
description: LeBOEUF-Harriet Ross. Died peacefully on February 5, 1998 in her 100th year at her home in Old Westbury, New York. Beloved wife for fifty-four years of the late Randall J. LeBoeuf, Jr., founder of the law firm of LeBoeuf, Lamb, Greene & MacRae. She was born in 1898, the daughter of the late Dr. William H. Ross and Frances Dodge Ross of Brentwood, Long Island, N.Y. She attended Bradford Academy, (later known as Bradford College) graduating in the class of 1915, Smith College, class of 1919, and Cornell University Medical School. Loving mother of Joan LeBoeuf Downer, Elizabeth LeBoeuf Jennings, and Suzanne LeBoeuf Keary. Cherished grandmother of Jennie Downer Austin, Katharine H. Downer, Harriet S. Downer, Randall H. LeB. Downer, Sandi Matthews Aten, Barbara Matthews, Wendy Matthews Sherman, Judy Matthews, Nancy Matthews Boyd, Elizabeth Jennings Duane, Anne Jennings Tozzo, and Prescott Jennings III, great grandmother of nineteen, and great great grandmother of two. A dedicated volunteer, she contributed endless time and effort particularly in the area of community health. She will be remembered as a Board member of many agencies, but especially of the Nassau County Health & Welfare Council, the Visiting Nurse Association of Oyster Bay-Glen Cove, and the Family Service Association of Nassau County (she was an Honorary Trustee). Mrs. LeBoeuf was twice elected President of the Albany, N.Y. Junior League of America (1928-30). She was a member of the N.Y.C. Chapter of the Society of Mayflower Descendants and the Peter Gansevoort Chapter, Daughters of the American Revolution. Beyond her family and community her greatest affections were for her home at Point O'Woods, N.Y., for her rose garden and for her many beloved Golden Retrievers. Services will be held Monday, February 9, at 11 A.M. at the Church of the Advent (Jericho Turnpike, Westbury, N.Y.). In lieu of flowers memorial contributions may be sent to either the Visiting Nurse Association of Long Island, 100 Garden City Plaza, Garden City, N.Y. 11530, or the Visiting Nurse Association of Oyster Bay-Glen Cove, 193 South Street, Oyster Bay, N.Y. 11771.

title: 1890's Idea, 1990's Architect
description: Van J. Brody isn't much impressed with the elegant brownstones of Park Slope. He's lived in one since the 1970's and has visited many others, and he thinks most of them are poorly laid out.

title: Q. & A.
description: Returning A Security Deposit

title: The Most Tainted Place On Earth
description: The Russian countryside can be stunning in its beauty. Deep groves of birch trees run for miles outside Moscow, interrupted only by icy tributaries of the thundering Volga and tiny villages, their church domes glistening in the harsh winter light.

title: Lace Manufacturer Announces Merger With 2 Rivals
description: Carolace Industries, one of America's largest lace manufacturers and embroiderers, will merge with two rivals as it tries to survive in a domestic industry, based largely in Bergen and Hudson Counties, that is increasingly threatened by less expensive imports.

title: A Nation Evaluates the President, and Itself; 10-Year Terms
description: To the Editor:

title: A Master and His Mecca on West 24th St.
description: Robert Blackburn shuffles as he enters the Printmaking Workshop in the Chelsea section of Manhattan. The master printmaker is 77 now and has arthritis, but his personality still dominates a room. Scrupulously polite yet slightly aloof, Mr. Blackburn likes to be in charge. His forcefulness, combined with a sensitivity to the needs of others, has allowed him to create and sustain this mecca for printmakers for 50 years.

title: It's Medal Time, So Here's Dmitriev Hungry As Ever
description: The idea of pairs skating is for the man to present the woman to the audience and the judges. If the man is not exactly expected to disappear, neither is he supposed to draw a great deal of attention to himself. Essentially, his job is to be Ed McMahon.

title: Sand, Silence and Solitude
description: ''THE desert? No, I've been to Egypt 17 times, but I've never gone into the desert,'' said our travel agent, sounding rather puzzled. ''You know, you see the desert right next to all the ruins.''

title: Hempstead Fights Ruling on Elections
description: In a legal battle with national implications, the Town of Hempstead is fighting a court order intended to increase minority representation on the town's legislative body.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Bingo Night at the Fire Hall

title: February 1-7; Progress Against AIDS
description: Significant news on the AIDS front emerged from a scientific meeting in Chicago. Deaths from the viral infection plummeted 48 percent in New York City last year, health officials said, and 44 percent in the nation in the first six months of 1997, compared with the corresponding period in 1996. The gains were largely attributed to the widespread use over the last two years of combinations of new and older drugs to combat the virus and the complications it causes.

title: Style; A State of Grace
description: In 1950, Vogue sent Irving Penn, then 33, to Paris to photograph the haute couture collections. One month later he would marry Lisa Fonssagrives, who in retrospect surely qualifies as the first supermodel. (She appeared on the cover of Time the year before.) The images they produced together that summer have entered into fashion's pantheon. Stark portraits of a woman in elaborate clothes, posed in front of a mottled gray backdrop, they radiate glamour and desire. Colin Westerbeck, curator of the Irving Penn retrospective this winter at the Art Institute of Chicago, describes Penn during those 10 days as working ''in a state of grace'' -- a phrase that might also summarize some inner aspect of Fonssagrives, suspended by the camera.

title: February 1-7; 2 Military Jet Accidents
description: American military investigators were seeking the cause of two fatal midair accidents last week. In northern Italy, a low-flying Marine jet sliced through wires holding up a cable car loaded with skiers, sending all 20 of them plunging to their deaths. American officials at the Air Force base in Aviano said the plane was flying well below the approved altitude of 500 feet. In the Persian Gulf, two Marine fighter jets collided and crashed in the waters off Kuwait. One pilot was killed. The Navy described the crash as an ''apparent mid-air collision.''

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: A Male Industry
description: To the Editor:

title: Nourishing a Valentine: It's More Than Sweets
description: FOR many, Valentine's Day offers an occasion to celebrate love, an affection that often inspires giving gifts of flowers, perfume and, perhaps most of all, food that is a bit special.

title: Fascination in the Depression
description: PRINTS line the walls of Herschel and Fern Cohen's stately colonial home. From floor to ceiling, stacked four or five high, up the stairs, down the hallway, in the office, bedrooms and bathrooms, hundreds of lithographs, wood engravings, woodcuts and etchings evoke images of the Depression era. Huddled masses, powerful workers, robust-looking ''fat cat'' capitalists, sharecroppers and coal miners, represented almost entirely in black and white, dominant the collection of realistic works.

title: THE XVIII WINTER GAMES: ICE HOCKEY -- A Taste Of Aggression; Japanese Fans Warm to the Unusual, A Show of Violence in the Hockey Rink
description: The picture of Japanese delicacy, Noriko Ito looked out from beneath her perfect mascara, her doe eyes shining eagerly, and explained why she came to see one of the ice hockey matches that opened the 1998 Olympic Winter Games.

title: An Old Trend
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the origins of allegations circulating in the White House sex scandal referred imprecisely to reports in The Los Angeles Times and The American Spectator. The reports, involving assertions that President Clinton and Monica Lewinsky engaged only in oral sex and that Mr. Clinton believes oral sex is not adultery, cited sources who said they had first-hand information. Thus they were second-hand accounts, not third-hand.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: THE LAST OF THE AFRICAN KINGS

title: For That Special Someone on Valentine's Day
description: ROMANTIC souls who choose Valentine's Day to propose will receive a free bottle of Champagne at the Garden City Hotel. Other lovers will be entertained by a jazz quartet at Panama Hatties in Huntington Station, Judy Wallace's piano music at the Northshore Cafe in Glen Head, live classic jazz at Pirandello in Roslyn Heights, and music and dancing at Caffe Angelica in Garden City Park. Hand-rolled cigars will be given as take-home gifts at Aleanna in Woodmere. A four-course Valentine's dinner for two at Pirandello costs $60, while a four-course repast at the luxurious Louis XVI in Patchogue is priced at $75.

title: At Cos Cob, Bohemians Among the Ordinary Folk
description: THE mustard yellow building that once served as the post office for the Cos Cob art colony has recently been turned into a visitors' center, a vital addition to the Bush-Holley House complex. The historic house has begun to be host to compact exhibitions that shed light on the clapboard structure that stood during the Revolutionary War and saw second life from 1892 to 1925 when painters took it over.

title: A Turn Away From Eastern Europe?
description: Eastern Europe, home to two of the four best-performing stock markets last year, is now the world's most expensive emerging market, and some global fund managers say they are looking elsewhere to invest new money.

title: DRAFT OF REPORT FOR G.O.P. ATTACKS CLINTON CAMPAIGN
description: A draft report for the Republican senators investigating campaign financing describes widespread improper Democratic fund-raising in 1996 but has yet to substantiate the explosive accusation that China had a plan to meddle in that year's elections.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIMELMAN, SAMUEL
description: KIMELMAN-Samuel. 87 years old, died on February 6, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Kate. Loving father of Jack and Lorraine, Martin and Renee and Marsha (Drachman) and Chuck Bernzweig. Proud grandfather and great grandfather. He will be missed.

title: BOOKEND; Martyr for Many Causes
description: Bernard shaw wrote a speech for him. Conan Doyle wrote a novel based on his adventures; W. B. Yeats and Richard Murphy wrote poems about him. He gave Conrad the idea for ''Heart of Darkness,'' and he makes cameo appearances in Joyce, Stevie Smith, Louis MacNeice and Paul Muldoon. Alfred Noyes, the author of ''The Highwayman,'' devoted an entire book to him. A minor muse for many modern writers, Roger Casement (1864-1916) was the most sentimental of Irish rebels and the most idealistic of humanitarians. Although someone has put a curse on the many screenplays about him, which never seem to make it to the screen, another one is always being written. In the 81 years since his execution in London for committing high treason during World War I, Casement has rarely been absent from the news in Ireland. Sooner or later his thin, bearded face and intense, deep-set eyes will be as familiar in American popular culture as Oscar Wilde's puffy cheeks.

title: In America; Unrepentant Tobacco
description: The tobacco industry is finally being seen for what it really is. Even longtime friends are recoiling in disgust as internal documents, many of them kept carefully hidden for decades, detail the loathsome tactics used by the industry to lure children and others into the lethal habit of smoking.

title: Disputes Over Erosion Batter the Hamptons
description: IT sounds like the subject of some dry marine science symposium, but in the Hamptons, where oceanfront real estate is as valuable as it is vulnerable, coastal erosion is a very hot topic. This year, after a first round of winter storms that have left trouble spots ravaged and some stretches where there is no beach at all between sea walls and the waves, the debate over what causes erosion and what -- if anything -- ought to be done about it is ornier than ever.

title: Lives; A Grandmother's Biological Clock
description: The other day, standing in the middle of pottery Barn innocently looking at glass coffee tables, I glanced up at my mother and saw that her eyes were welling up with tears. ''Mom, what's wrong?'' I rushed over to her, alarmed. Suddenly overcome by the symbolism of table lamps and picture frames, she blurted out, ''I just don't want you to spend your whole life alone.''

title: You're Feeling Well? Where Have You Been?
description: NOTE to big fat guy in gray suit who was sneezing, slobbering and coughing gusts of pestilential flu bugs all over the commuters packed aboard the 7:30 P.M. DeCamp No. 33 bus out of Port Authority one night in early January: Nice going, Tiny. Thanks to your contaminating my innocent wife, who was sitting beside you, our household has been incapacitated with the flu for a month.

title: Jaclyn Wachter and David Blatte
description: Jaclyn Payson Wachter, a daughter of Florine and Jules Wachter of New York, was married last evening to David Craig Blatte, the son of Barbara and Lawrence A. Blatte of Lawrence, N.Y. Rabbi Joel Y. Zion performed the ceremony at the New York Palace Hotel.

title: All Along Smith Street, It's the Conquest of the Cool
description: You can tell that things are changing along Smith Street. Even Sal the barber has put up a new awning. ''I haven't been here long, 34 years,'' said Salvatore Zocco, as he worked his clippers around the neck of a $10 customer Tuesday afternoon. ''But I put up a new sign this July. Everyone is going upscale around here.''

title: Downloaded at Birth
description: The Number Sense How the Mind Creates Mathematics. By Stanislas Dehaene. Illustrated. 274 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $25.

title: Palestinians Hold March in Bethlehem to Show Support for Iraq
description: Several hundred Palestinians marched in support of Iraq today, but without the popular support that accompanied the Persian Gulf war of 1991.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Uneasy Rider

title: Photo Finish
description: Helmut Lang or Miuccia Prada? It was impossible to decide who was better. The two designers, who made their mark with minimalist fashion, broke out of their strictures for spring presenting collections of such loveliness and originality that both deserve the title: Best of the Season.

title: A Nation Evaluates the President, and Itself; Tough Jobs to Find
description: To the Editor:

title: Q&A/Thomas B. Grochowski; Course That Defines Art of Woody Allen
description: WHEN Woody Allen's most recent film, ''Deconstructing Harry,'' came out in December, it was, as usual, suggested by many that it was autobiographical. Harry was a writer, his emotional and sex lives were a mess and he was searching to find himself.

title: A Provocateur of the Paris Runways
description: IT was like Halloween on the club scene. In the inky darkness, lights danced on a fluorescent-green curtain as the audience waved flashlights that cast weird silhouettes of an alien creature.

title: U.S. Advances to Semis
description: The sun broke through shortly after the national anthem, and so did the United States offense.

title: Composing Himself
description: Johannes Brahms

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWANN, CHRISTINE S. (FORMERLY CHRISTINE DOWNEY)
description: SWANN-Christine S. (formerly Christine Downey). Mother, daughter, sister, aunt, grandmother, friend, lover, woman. On Feb. 4, 1998 surrounded by her family, Christine Swann left this life for parts unknown. During her two bouts with lymphoma, the second of which she lost, she remained a spirited and loving fan of life. Sweetly stubborn, she lost her hair, her mobility, her energy, and her ability to speak easily, but not her sense of humor or wonder or her desire to understand. Christine shined in ways that this world does'nt recognize with degrees, professional titles, executive salaries, medals or other tokens of acknowledgment. She loved generously. She smiled splendiferously. She welcomed any and all. Those of us who had the privilege of knowing and loving her understand that we are blessed. Her natural and hard won wisdom, her glee, and her accepting, forgiving ways made life more beautiful and livable for the many of us who at one time or another gathered around her light, and found ourselves dancing. She will forever life in the hearts of her friends and family; her children, Jennifer, Rebecca, Christina, Nell and Jim; and her grandson Finn. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, February 14th, at 1 P.M., at the First Church of Round Hill in Greenwich, CT. In lieu of flowers, contributions may go to the Lymphoma Research Foundation of America, 8800 Venice Blvd., Suite 207, Los Angeles, CA. 90034.

title: Funeral Music With a Beat the Deceased Could Dance To
description: MOST Americans wouldn't think that the song ''Always Look on the Bright Side of Life'' -- sung by a group of religious prisoners being crucified in the Monty Python film ''Life of Brian'' -- would be a respectful send-off for a recently deceased person.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; Confident Consumers Are Buying Large New Homes
description: HIGH consumer confidence and low mortgage interest rates are boosting the market for large new homes in the $500,000-and-up range.

title: Q&A/Peggy Post; Etiquette on the Comeback Trail? Well, Yes
description: WHEN Emily Post first published her etiquette book in 1922, she could hardly have imagined that her name would become a household word. But of course it did. Emily Post means etiquette.

title: Brother, Can You Spare a Loading Dock?
description: WILMOTT RUSH was exasperated as he stood huddled against the cold on a windswept corner in Chelsea. He was out of Newport smokes. The tortoise-shell glasses perched atop his angular nose had no lenses. No one was interested in the long Barney's houndstooth coat he was hawking from a black plastic garbage bag.

title: LONG ISLAND VINES
description: Depth and Class

title: VIEWPOINT; Gather the Nations To Promote Globalization
description: IT is time for a serious rethinking of how international institutions and world leaders cope with the stresses and strains of globalization. The Asian economic crisis shows that ad hoc actions by the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank are just that -- temporary measures, often necessary, often effective.

title: Attention To Detail
description: The newest version of the above-the-knee-length dress coat has introduced a seemingly minuscule shift in shoulder seam construction. It has moved the traditional seam, a straight line from collar to top of set-in sleeve, bottom far left, sliding it back an inch and a half, as in the beige Dolce & Gabbana coat next to it. The result gives the look of ramrod-straight posture. The New York collection of Richard Edwards highlighted this back-sliding shoulder seam in its jackets and coats.

title: Metuchen Schools Made Referendum Facts Available
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Arrested After Police Find Cocaine in Car
description: Two men from Richmond, Va., were arrested yesterday after a Port Authority police officer discovered approximately $80,000 worth of cocaine in their vehicle during a routine traffic stop in Manhattan on a ramp to the George Washington Bridge, the authorities said.

title: New Year's Ends Without a Bang
description: Last Tuesday evening, a dozen members of the Chinatown Community Young Lions gathered in their cluttered clubhouse at Mulberry and Bayard Streets to discuss a pressing question: how to put their lions to sleep without firecrackers.

title: With Styles Poles Apart, Italian Stars Seek Gold
description: Alberto Tomba was on edge, and his skis were nowhere in sight.

title: Cohen Wins Measured Backing in Europe
description: Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen won measured support today from European allies for the United States' strong stance on Iraq, but he warned that diplomatic efforts to avoid a strike could undermine a peaceful solution to the crisis over United Nations weapons inspections.

title: One-Woman Show of Paintings Praises Unsung Women's Lives
description: WHEN Marilyn Cohen speaks of the courageous force that drove many of the women she depicts in her painting exhibition ''Teach Me the Songs My Mothers Sang: A Celebration of American Women,'' her voice becomes passionate. ''They were adults before or during World War II and each had her own kind of courage,'' Ms. Cohen said here recently in her studio filled with liquid dyes and torn pieces of watercolor paper arranged in drawers by color.

title: The Capitalist; Dinosaurs of The New Economy
description: Psychologists who study these things have identified a pair of delusions people often suffer about their favorite technologies. The first, found mainly in the young, is the conviction that some useful device has been around much longer than it actually has. Not long ago I watched slack-jawed while a college poetry professor tried to reason with his class of 15 otherwise intelligent students who somehow had convinced themselves that Samuel Taylor Coleridge was distracted from finishing ''Kubla Khan'' by a telephone call. In 1798. The students imagined the phone as they imagined the wheel -- one of those things that had been around, like, forever.

title: 'Married Filing Jointly,' and Liable for a Bundle
description: WHEN her husband asked her to sign their joint tax return that fateful day in 1969, Josephine C. Berman complied without a second thought.

title: Justice Dept. Sues Dallas Suburb on Hiring
description: The Justice Department has filed suit against Garland, a suburb of Dallas, saying it had discriminated against minorities in hiring for the police and fire departments.

title: The Jersey Rust Belt Gets a Bit Brighter
description: DEMAND for industrial property is surging in northern New Jersey, prompting renewed interest in old and frequently decayed sections of once-vibrant manufacturing communities close to New York City.

title: February 1-7; A Surrender in Campaign Probe
description: A year after he slipped out of the country as the campaign finance scandal ignited, the Democratic fund-raiser Yah Lin Trie became the first important figure in the case to surrender to Federal authorities.

title: February 1-7; Good Health News for Women
description: Every week, it seems, the ''healthy diet'' gets a bit more fine-tuning. Here's the latest: a lot more vitamin B-6 and folate -- two to three times what's recommended now -- sharply cuts women's risk of heart attack (men's too, presumably, but this was a women-only study).

title: A Nation Evaluates the President, and Itself; Endangered Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARLSON, JANE
description: CARLSON-Jane. The Juilliard School mourns the loss of Jane Carlson, honored last year for fifty years of distinuished service as a member of the College and PreCollege Division faculties. A noted piano pedagogue, her dedication to her work has been an inspiration to her many students, friends and colleagues around the world. Mary Rodgers Guettel Chairman, Board of Trustees Joseph W. Polisi President

title: Jailed Again, Unjustly
description: When Federal judges turn their backs on a serious miscarriage of justice, their timidity diminishes the nation's court system and the Constitution. That has now happened in a controversial case in Pennsylvania, where a decision by the Third Circuit Court of Appeals forced the return to prison last week of a woman whose conviction for first-degree murder was found to be extravagantly flawed by a Federal trial judge in Philadelphia last spring.

title: Speeding the Pace of Recycling in City-Run Housing
description: IN the Cypress Hills section of Brooklyn, close to the Queens border, Jean M. Reynolds is becoming expert in a housing relocation technique known as checkerboarding.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WRIGHT, JULIA
description: WRIGHT-Julia. On February 6, 1998. Beloved wife of the late James. Beloved mother of Judy Levine, Richard, and the late James Jr. Also survived by five grandchildren and eight great grandchildren. Family will receive friends at the John J.
