Fox Funeral Home, 2080 Boston Post Rd., Larchmont, NY on Monday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral service on Tuesday, 10 AM at the funeral home. Interment to follow at Mt. Hope Cemetery, Hastings-on-Hudson, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to Dominican Sisters of Hope, 320 Powell Ave., Newburgh, NY 12550.

title: Snow Postpones the Downhill, and Maier's Alpine Assault
description: The long and ultimately futile wait began early in the morning, when members of Hermann Maier's inner circle staked out prime real estate near the finish line of the Happo'one downhill course, waiting for their man to begin a journey from the top that would carry him to a harvest of Olympic medals.

title: A Nation Evaluates the President, and Itself; We've Heard Too Much
description: To the Editor:

title: Rating Towns in Their Responsibilities for Long Island Sound
description: WHEN environmental report cards for communities around Long Island Sound were handed out recently, only Westport and Smithtown, L.I., got high marks; both were applauded for doing a ''very good'' job of controlling pollution sources.

title: Banks Are Preparing For the Millennium Bug
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KONECKY, JANET (GOLD)
description: KONECKY-Janet (Gold). Beloved wife, mother, grandmother and sister. A woman of devotion, valor understanding and love for all. A friend to everyone. We will all miss her. Services today 12:30PM ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Donations in her honor may be made to: The Jacob Perlow Hospice of Beth Israel Medical Center.

title: A Nation Evaluates the President, and Itself
description: To the Editor:

title: A Pianist's Descent, Reprised
description: To the Editor:

title: Pro-Zapatista Groups Should Focus on Voting
description: To the Editor:

title: History as a Lesson in the Possible
description: There was a time when New Yorkers could get a taste of ballet history simply by buying a ticket to one of the Joffrey Ballet's vibrant archival programs. But with the departure of the Joffrey Ballet for Chicago in 1995, it has become difficult in this city to see ballets created in other times and countries. The Ohio Ballet is coming to the rescue, however. In a one-week engagement at the Joyce Theater that starts on Tuesday, the company will present an extraordinary selection of seldom-seen dances.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THABIT, AFIFEH VIVIAN (NEE DIAB)
description: THABIT-Afifeh Vivian (nee Diab). Born in Beirut, Lebanon, studied at the American University of Beirut, a member of the UN Delegations Women's Club and the Islamic Heritage Society, passed away after a long illness on February 5, 1998. She has been active in ArabAmerican affairs and the diplomatic Arab community at the UN for thirty years. She leaves surviving Robert W. Thabit, her husband, Allen R. Thabit, her son and Mona V. Thabit, her daughter. The funeral mass will be at the Saint Nicholas Antiochian Orthodox Cathedral in Brooklyn at 10 A.M., on Monday, February 9th, 1998. Interment will be at the Greenwood Cemetery's Hillside Mausoleum III.

title: Old vs. New? Try Separate But Equal
description: It's really like Brahms,'' the argument goes. ''You're just not used to it. Put it next to a 19th-century classic, and see how one bleeds into the other. Music has a process of evolution and a history. You haven't read the latest chapters carefully, and you should.''

title: Price Rises Exact a High Cost in Java
description: When hundreds of rough-looking men burst through the alleyways of the nearby town of Kraton two days ago, throwing stones and waving sharpened sickles, most of them came from here in Semari, a placid village of farmers and fishermen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'BRIEN, KATHERINE L.
description: O'BRIEN-Katherine L. Died on February 5, in Philadelphia at age 90. Born Ellisburg, New York, on Oct. 22, 1907 and graduate of Wells College, Aurora, N.Y. She was a longtime resident of New York City before she moved to Cathedral Village, Philadelphia in 1990. She loved opera, traveling, and for many years was a devoted staff member of the New York Public Library. Kay O'Brien was the first Staten Island Borough Coordinator, founded Donnell Library Center and at retirement was Chief of Mid Manhattan Library. Funeral service Monday 11 A.M. St. Mary's Church, Cathedral Village, Philadelphia, PA (Tele. 215-482-6300). A memorial service to be held at the Library is being planned.

title: Editorial Observer; The Battle of Baghdad That Might Have Been
description: American history is haunted by military actions not taken and the debates about them that have rippled down the decades. After the Union triumph at Gettysburg, Gen. George Meade did not chase down Gen. Robert E. Lee's retreating army. Allied forces chose not to bomb the rail lines to Auschwitz in World War II. President Harry Truman did not demonstrate the destructive power of the atomic bomb to Japanese leaders before vaporizing Hiroshima. Now add to the list George Bush's decision not to take Baghdad during the Persian Gulf war and remove Saddam Hussein.

title: Once Again, Democrats Stumble a Bit Short of Agreement
description: Unable to overcome their penchant for fractious infighting, New York Democratic leaders failed today to agree on a slate of candidates for statewide elections, once again suggesting that the party will face a combative convention and primaries that could impede its chances in November.

title: Women Understand
description: To the Editor:

title: Food; Dessert in Venice
description: When venice was still a player on the world stage, chocolate fueled its dark side. Rumored to be an aphrodisiac, chocolate was smuggled into Venice from the Americas, creating a culture not unlike the cocaine culture of today.

title: Refinancing Underlying Mortgages
description: CO-OP boards in buildings with underlying mortgages are discovering something homeowners have been finding in the last few months: that it sometimes makes sense to borrow to pay off old loans even though it might cost money -- perhaps a lot of money -- to do so.

title: Devils Beat Revamped Islanders
description: Friday was a busy day for Islanders General Manager Mike Milbury. He traded four players, a minor leaguer and a third-round draft pick for four players in deals with two teams. By the day's end, Milbury said he felt that the Islanders were a vastly improved team.

title: U.S. Urges Caution On Mexico City Cabs
description: The State Department is warning travelers to stop hailing cabs on the street in Mexico City.

title: Mrs. Murphy's Window Boxes
description: A COUPLE of years ago, Colleen Murphy decided to spruce up the front of her 1782 home in the center of Litchfield by adding four window boxes, held up by metal brackets made by a local artisan, ''I think they're beautiful,'' she says today of the boxes and the brackets.

title: The Metabolism of Scandal
description: On the level of pure performance, President Clinton is probably the most gifted politician of the last half of this century. John F. Kennedy, of course, had a standard-setting talent, but was his press conference after the failed Bay of Pigs invasion as flawless an example of grace under pressure as Mr. Clinton's State of the Union address and the punch-slipping mastery of his Friday press conference? Not even Ronald Reagan possessed Mr. Clinton's extemporaneous smoothness, and by the time of his greatest scandal, Iran-contra, Mr. Reagan's gifts had eroded noticeably.

title: Littlest Beemer
description: No driver's license required, just short legs, to take a spin in the hot new sports car from BMW. It's only a toy.

title: Primer on Various Furniture Styles
description: MANY people are reluctant to buy period furniture because they don't understand the different styles and periods. The following is a brief survey of some of the styles and furniture makers that have influenced the design of most of the furniture sold in the United States.

title: BEST SELLERS: February 8, 1998
description: Weeks

title: Looking for Love
description: THE DADDY CLOCK By Judy Markey. 261 pp. New York: Bantam Books. $21.95.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEARLMAN, BERNARD R.
description: PEARLMAN-Bernard R. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Bernard R. Pearlman, associated with The Times from 1955, until retiring in 1989.

title: Taking Flight
description: BLACK AND BLUE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINHAUER, ROSE
description: STEINHAUER-Rose. February 6, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Abraham Kolerstein and the late Eric Steinhauer. Sister of the late Zelda Markowitz. Survived by her niece Irene Stein, many greatnieces and nephews, and many great-great-nieces and nephews. Services Sunday, 10 AM, at Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, NY. Donations may be made to the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services.

title: Knot-Tying Manual
description: There's a long road between ''Will you?'' and ''I do.'' Leah Ingram of Ewing offers a map -- an atlas, really -- in ''The Portable Wedding Consultant,'' a compendium of advice and observations from more than 100 wedding consultants, including several from the Garden State. She notes that New Jersey, in the orbit of New York or Philadelphia, is governed by big-city prices, and she has suggestions for bringing the costs down. On flowers, for example, the book contains a month-by-month list of flowers that are in season and therefore less expensive than, say, roses. Invitations cost less if you design them on your computer and print them out at home. There is also information on buying the ring, compiling the guest list, choosing attire and much more. And finally, after all the preparation, the solemn rites and joyous celebration, there is the Honeymoon Diet. The book $19.95, is published by Contemporary Books and available in bookstores.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: FROM stage to screen is the route traced by the four features that stand out on this week's movie menu.

title: Elizabeth Bliss And Peter Sosnow
description: Elizabeth Smidt Bliss, a daughter of Margo G. Elliott of San Carlos, Calif., and John S. Bliss of New York, was married yesterday to Peter Ivan Sosnow, the son of Ellen and Lawrence I. Sosnow of New York. Jean Kotkin, a leader of the Society for Ethical Culture, performed the ceremony at the Union League Club in New York.

title: Call It Sea Gate or Seagate?
description: Observers of Mayor Giuliani's reputed ability to cow into submission employees, opponents and citizens, take note: the Mayor may have met his match, and his name is Kasper Price.

title: From Lake Wobegon and Beyond, A Round Table on Economics and Finance
description: TO add some perspective to these turbulent financial times, we have convened three great thinkers: Mark Twain, Will Rogers and Garrison Keillor, voice of the public-radio show, ''A Prairie Home Companion,'' and author most recently of ''Wobegon Boy'' (Viking, 1997, $24.95).

title: New European Routes For High-Speed Trains
description: Europe prides itself on swift, frequent train service, but it is not resting on its laurels. New double-decker high-speed T.G.V. trains have been added to the Paris-Lyons line, providing a two-hour trip with departures in both directions on the hour and the half-hour during peak periods. Trains travel at a top speed of 168 miles an hour.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENEELY, LESLIE STEWART
description: MENEELY-Leslie Stewart. Died February 7 in her 87th year at Raymore, Missouri. Loving mother of Nicole V. Demarest, Michelle V. Limpert, Suzanne Van der Leur and Leslie Van der Leur; loving grandmother of Kenneth, Michele, Christine, Alexandra, John, Elizabeth and Patricia; in turn, remembered lovingly by her family.

title: A Nation Evaluates the President, and Itself; Where Was the Harm?
description: To the Editor:

title: Purloined Bricks
description: To the Editor:

title: Gothic Romance
description: The peculiarly personal touch of Alfred Hitchcock became a bit less personal but no less penetrating in his direction of the 1940 film REBECCA, Daphne Du Maurier's tale of a shy young woman ill-equipped to compete with the haunting memory of her husband's first wife. As the cameras murmur ''Beware'' -- with a closed door, a smashed china cupid, an accusative address book -- the film's ensemble, splendidly true to character, quietly strengthen the suspense. Judith Anderson is a menacingly rigid Mr. Danvers and George Sanders a fine blackguard; Laurence Olivier (above, with Joan Fontaine) plays Maxim de Winter to brooding perfection, and if Du Maurier did not succeed in convincing you that her self-effacing heroine could also be attractive and alive, then Miss Fontaine will MONDAY at 11:15 P.M. on AMC.

title: It's Very Now, but Expectations are Dickensian
description: Great Expectations

title: How to Argue With Airlines
description: OBSCENITIES will get you nowhere. That's one piece of advice gleaned recently from talks with people who spend their days as punching bags: the airline employees whose job it is to cope with consumer complaints.

title: NAME SHAME
description: * We celebrate a generic Presidents' Day in February -- but it's not always easy to honor specific chief executives. * Last year in New Orleans, the school board changed the name of George Washington Elementary School because it opposed honoring ''former slave owners.'' * Presidential nomenclature may simply be passe: no Presidents figured among the 150 names recently considered for new schools in the Clark County, Nev., school district, but the list did include the Las Vegas entertainer Sam Butera. * In 1933, F.D.R.'s Secretary of the Interior, Harold Ickes, handled name disgruntlement with a personal touch: he ignored the Congressionally mandated name Hoover Dam -- and dubbed the structure Boulder Dam, which stuck until 1947. * Safe for now: the (Warren G.) Harding Ice Field on Alaska's Kenai Peninsula.

title: BENEFITS
description: Pro Musicis Gala

title: Vote Set on Land Sale In Hastings-on-Hudson
description: LIKE the flying monkeys whose periodic appearance in the Wizard of Oz was a recurrent nuisance for Dorothy and her friends, proposals to sell pieces of the 21-acre Burke estate here, the former home of Billie Burke -- familiar to generations for her role as Glinda the Good Witch -- have repeatedly surfaced ever since the school district acquired the property in 1967.

title: Effort to Cover Contraception Likely to Fail
description: Many medical groups and women's advocates have for years been concerned about what they call a gender gap in health coverage: Although health plans generally cover prescription drugs, most exclude contraceptives, which results in more out-of-pocket expenses for women than for men.

title: Slow H.M.O. Bill Payments Strain Hospitals
description: SLOW payments by managed-care companies are causing financial strains for Long Island hospitals, which say that despite determined efforts they are unable to collect tens of millions of dollars of overdue bills.

title: The Nation; The News Junkies' Treatment Program
description: PROPELLED by forces no one really controls, the nation has arrived at a point at which sensational news is crossed by throbbing, tangled skeins of gossip, titillation, rumor, speculation and revulsion.

title: The Good Old Days
description: Isiah Thomas and Magic Johnson had this advice for today's participants: Put on a show, and play hard.

title: Union Square's Renaissance Began Before the BID
description: To the Editor:

title: Leftists Attack at a German Far-Right Rally
description: For the second time in two weeks, right- and left-wing activists clashed today as thousands of supporters of a far-right political party congregated here to promote their cause before September's national election.

title: When the 'Usual' Is Also an Outrage
description: Anthony Marchiano thinks he got a raw deal. ''People's reputations were severely damaged,'' he said on Friday, a few days after a panel from the National Association of Securities Dealers ruled that his firm, A. S. Goldmen, had ripped off customers in a 1994 initial public offering. The whole case, he said, was ''unfair from start to finish.''

title: Corrections
description: An essay on Jan. 18 about a $200 melon in Tokyo misstated the type of plant on which it grows. It is a vine, not a tree.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: WISECRACKER The Life and Times of William Haines, Hollywood's First Openly Gay Star. By William J. Mann. Viking, $29.95.

title: Police Balk At Crackdown On Jaywalkers By Giuliani
description: Committing an offense that now carries an automatic $50 fine, pedestrians were scurrying across the street yesterday near the South Street Seaport in Manhattan. Few chose to wait for the walk sign to flash before leaving the curb, and, when they did, it was seldom at the crosswalk. None seemed to care about the police officer watching from the other side. And they had little reason to worry.

title: Swiss Spy Identified 'Militants' For Algeria
description: While Leon Jobe, a Swiss police officer, was investigating possible arms smuggling by Islamic militants to Algeria in 1994, he put together lists of suspects and turned over hundreds of names to Algerian officials.

title: Eagle Rally
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton wore one while defending her husband in her Jan. 27 interview with Matt Lauer, below, on the ''Today'' show. Betty Currie, President Clinton's secretary, sported one for her date with a Federal grand jury. And Donna E. Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, wears one in a current milk industry ad.

title: A Less Serene Venice
description: IT has always been my dream to visit Venice in the dead of winter. Time enough, come summer, to pick up ''Italian Hours'' and bask with Henry James in those rosy mornings and golden afternoons when the city ''seems to expand and evaporate, to multiply all her reflections and iridescences.'' But when the sky turns to slate and a bitter wind lashes the deserted Piazza San Marco, I long to sink into a corner of the Caffe Florian with ''Don't Look Now'' and lose myself in Daphne du Maurier's bleak views of the city as a maze of sinister alleys and shuttered houses and bridges that lead nowhere -- except to a lonely death for the unwary tourist.

title: Corrections
description: The Practical Traveler column on Jan. 25, about refunds for canceled trips to Egypt included outdated references to State Department notifications issued on Nov. 17 and Nov. 22 after a terrorist attack at Luxor. The notifications, called public announcements, warned against travel in the area. They were canceled in a consular information sheet about Egypt issued Jan. 13, which reiterated a need for caution by travelers in Egypt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAHLMAN, JACK
description: SAHLMAN-Jack. On February 6. Beloved husband of Sondra. Devoted father of Michael and Alexander. Interment services private. Mrs. Sondra Lipton Sahlman will receive friends at the Baruch Residence, 784 Park Ave., New York City, on Monday, February 9, from 6 to 9 PM. Donations to your favorite charity will be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, BETTY
description: LEWIS-Betty. Aged 94. On February 5, 1998. Beloved mother of Julian Lewis and Dr. Gloria Lewis Berens. Loving and loved grandmother of Stephen, Richard, Mitchell, Gregory, Elizabeth and Valerie, and adoring great grandmother of Elliot, Melody, Matthew, Jeremy, Ryan, Debra, Kaitlyn, Lilly and Jimmy. Services were held. Call Weinstein-West End Chapels, for information.

title: DIARY
description: MARKETS

title: Be All You Can Be -- in The Media
description: If you saw the film ''Welcome to Sarajevo,'' you probably wondered how high-strung war correspondents keep their cool while dodging bullets. Some enroll in the BBC News Safety Training programs, designed to teach journalists how to stay alive in war zones and areas of civil unrest. The brainchild of Peter Hunter, a former photojournalist with the BBC, the courses are taught by ex-military and -police personnel. There's obviously a need. According to the Committee to Protect Journalists, more than 500 reporters have been killed in the line of duty since 1986.

title: A Nation Evaluates the President, and Itself; Workplace Harassment
description: To the Editor:

title: Lawsuit Against a Hospital Over an Adopted Boy's H.I.V. Is Seen as a First
description: After four miscarriages and eight unsuccessful attempts at artificial insemination, Melody Moreau took in a foster child, a baby boy, from the New York Foundling Hospital in March 1983. In late 1984, she and her husband, John LiGrecci, adopted the boy, whom they named Justin.

title: The View From/Hastings-on-Hudson; Children Along the Hudson Beseech Clinton to Aid the River
description: HERE is a letter written to the President by a 7-year-old who already has concerns about the world she lives in:

title: Another Victory For Silver Charm
description: Silver Charm continued his brilliant winter form yesterday at Santa Anita with a powerful, runaway victory in the $500,000 Strub Stakes at Santa Anita in Arcadia, Calif.

title: Library System to Hold Jazz Show
description: AFTER pondering what to do with leftover money earmarked for outreach services, the Westchester Library System decided to hold a free concert featuring the Jazz Forum All Stars. The event, which will take place next Sunday at 7:30 P.M. at the Paramount Center for the Arts in Peekskill, has proved highly popular, said Robin Osborne, the library system's consultant for adult and outreach services. ''We were out of tickets within two weeks,'' she said.

title: Some Clarifications On Melville Organization
description: ''Building a Village, Providing for a University, the Jan. 4 article about the philanthropist Ward Melville and the not-for-profit organization he founded, contained inaccuracies.

title: Handling Credit Cards
description: Personal bankruptcies are increasing in the state, largely because of credit card debt. How do you handle your credit cards?

title: Together to Praise the Past
description: Nights to hail Chinese art, famous jewelry and a charity ball.

title: New Do: Big Bangs
description: The box bob, a sleek hairstyle that has full bangs and can sometimes fall as far as the shoulders, isn't exactly new. Cleopatra had one (at least as Elizabeth Taylor played her). But the latest version -- with even heavier bangs -- is appearing on so many heads these days that it threatens to replace the Dorothy Hamill wedge as the most copied cut of its time.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Fear Nothing

title: INSIDE
description: Pressure Builds on Iraq

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENKOFF, MILDRED
description: ROSENKOFF-Mildred. Beloved wife of the late Abraham, retired NYC teacher, and long-time volunteer at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, much loved by her family.

title: John G. Gensel, 80, the Pastor to New York's Jazz Community
description: The Rev. John Garcia Gensel, who forged a remarkable relationship with New York's jazz musicians and their families as pastor and head of the ''jazz ministry'' at St. Peter's Lutheran Church in midtown, died Friday. He was 80.

title: 'Capeman' Doesn't Fly, Despite the Music
description: Paul Simon is quoted as saying that the idea for ''The Capeman,'' his first, extremely problematic Broadway musical, came to him in an instant: ''It was an idea that wasn't there one instant, and was there the next.'' That was in 1988, two years after ''Graceland,'' his politically controversial album inspired by black South African music and musicians. He was working at the time on ''The Rhythm of the Saints,'' the album eventually released in 1990, in which he explores West African music and its effect on the musical culture of Brazil. Mr. Simon, an innovative force in American pop music for 30 years, remains productively restless.

title: Crimes in High Places
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ECKHARD, MARIE T., DR.
description: ECKHARD-Marie T., Dr. Formerly of Brooklyn, NY, has died after a short illness in Wilmington, DE. Feb. 3, 1998. A retired professor of American History and Women's Studies at Pratt Institute, she was a faculty member 1967-1992. She was awarded Distinguished Professor 1990-91 and received Emeritus status in 1992. Devoted to her profession, Dr. Eckhard enjoyed and maintained respect and admiration from her professional colleagues and students.

title: Planned Excavation for Tidal Gate Raises Tide of Protest
description: They love it for its quiet streets, waterfront vistas and well-kept public spaces and parks. So the residents of Battery Park City have become upset by a plan by the city's Department of Environmental Protection to excavate one park to install a new tidal gate for the city's sewer system.

title: POSTINGS: A $600,000 Restoration/Renovation of a Church Interior; A New, Brighter, Palette at St. Jean Baptiste
description: Words to the hymn ''Lauda Sion'' in gold leaf once again encircle the clerestory inside the 1913 Roman Catholic Church of St. Jean Baptiste on Lexington Avenue at 76th Street. Clouds appear to float on a ceiling mural and gold-stenciled fleurs-de-lis adorn the wall behind the altar.

title: Our Towns; Stirring Up an Institution in the Borscht Belt
description: JOSEPH MURPHY was walking through the Concord Resort Hotel as if he owned the place. ''This should all be carpeted,'' he said as he entered the cavernous hall off the lobby, his shoes hitting the hard tile floor like mallets. ''And this,'' he said, waving his arm at an empty stretch of corridor, ''should have trees. It's sterile!''

title: Great Extrapolations
description: JACK MAGGS

title: Crowd Hails Embattled School Chief
description: It had the air of a pep rally. But the cheering inside Middle School 74's auditorium in Bayside last week was for a cause with higher stakes.

title: 'Black' Colleges Are Luring Back Their Own From the Ivy Leagues
description: WASHINGTON  Ivy League and other prestigious universities in the United States compete vigorously to recruit the best and the brightest of each year's crop of African-American high school graduates. Last June Malaika Jones was one of them.

title: Williams Focuses On His Specialty
description: When Jayson Williams was called from the bench at Madison Square Garden last night, making his first All-Star Game appearance with 4 minutes 19 seconds remaining in the first period, he immediately went to work. Starting near the foul line, where Michael Jordan and his fellow skywalkers regularly take off for highlight-reel dunks, the Nets' center waited for a shot to go up and charted a course for the backboard.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The war on poverty was the worst thing that ever happened to Appalachia. It gave people a way to get by without having to do any work.'' -- DENISE HOFFMAN, who runs a small farm with her husband, Neil. [A13]

title: E-Mail Alerts Show Growing Potential
description: Could you use a nudge when it's time to take your dog in for shots? Would you like a heads-up when air fares to your favorite city are low? Want a warning when you should move your car for street cleaning? Or a whisper when an apartment is for rent?

title: Wallace Wins With a Late Surge
description: Rusty Wallace's last-lap surge in the Bud Shootout at Daytona International Speeday gave Ford Taurus a victory in its debut yesterday.

title: Senator Norman J. Levy, 67; Represented Nassau in Albany
description: Norman J. Levy, a Republican State Senator from Nassau County who sponsored the nation's first mandatory seat belt law and championed the New York metropolitan region's mass transit system, died on Saturday night at his home in Albany. He was 67 and also lived in Merrick, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAHLMAN, JACK
description: SAHLMAN-Jack. On February 6. Beloved husband of Sondra. Devoted father of Michael and Alexander. Interment services private. Mrs. Sondra Lipton Sahlman will receive friends at the Baruch Residence, 784 Park Ave., New York City, on Monday, February 9, from 6 to 9 PM. Donations to your favorite charity will be appreciated.

title: After Repairs, Roosevelt Island Tram Resumes Service
description: The crane is gone, as is the barge on which it was mounted. The gaping hole in the fender of car No. 1 has been replaced with a newly painted sheet of aluminum. Yesterday, the only signs of the midair collision that injured 11 passengers of the Roosevelt Island Tramway on Jan. 27 were a few smirks as the cabin operator delivered a routine warning before liftoff.

title: Man Stabbed to Death In Fight on East Side
description: A 21-year-old man was mortally wounded early yesterday after being stabbed in a brawl that broke out during a party on the Upper East Side, the police said.

title: Salomon to Buy Pacific Rim Brokerage Unit
description: Salomon Smith Barney Holdings Inc., the investment banking unit of Travelers Group, is planning to announce today that it is buying most of County NatWest Markets' Australian and New Zealand brokerage businesses for about $85 million.

title: Conquistador Statue Stirs Hispanic Pride and Indian Rage
description: One moonless night in early January, just as Hispanic New Mexicans were starting to celebrate the 400th anniversary of the first Spanish settlement in the American West, an Indian commando group stealthily approached a bronze statue here of the first conquistador, Don Juan de Onate. With an electric saw, the group slowly severed his right foot -- boot, stirrup, star-shaped spur and all.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANEY, CAROL B.
description: HANEY-Carol B. Of Salisbury, CT. Died in Locust Valley, NY, on February 6, 1998. She is survived by her children Stephen of Waterford, MI, and Anne Falivena of Locust Valley, NY. ''CarolGrandma'' to Nicolas and Caroline Falivena. She was the sister of Esther Keirs and Arthur Davey, Jr. and cousin of Marion Barclay. A memorial service will be held at St. John's Episcopal Church, Cold Spring Harbor, NY, on Saturday, February 14, at 1 PM. Contributions may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: Wide-Eyed Wonder in the Himalayas
description: ALL THE WAY TO HEAVEN

title: Road Gets Tougher for a Political Pioneer
description: When she was elected to Congress in 1992, Nydia M. Velazquez turned into something of a political heroine. That was the year she made history by becoming the first Puerto Rican woman elected to the House of Representatives, defeating Stephen J. Solarz, a nine-term incumbent, and four other Hispanic candidates.

title: $2.6 Billion Bank Deal Reported in the Works
description: The Regions Financial Corporation, an Alabama bank, could announce as early as today that it has agreed to acquire the First Commercial Corporation of Little Rock, Ark.

title: Glitter Woman Comes Up Wanting
description: Glitter Woman, one of last year's premiere racing fillies, stopped glittering in the homestretch of her comeback today when she was outrun in a duel to the wire by the mare U Can Do It, who won the Shirley Jones Handicap by 2 3/4 lengths.

title: Essay; The China Chapter
description: The laughably named ''Public Integrity'' section of the Clinton Justice Department, desperate to evade the law's requirement for an independent counsel in the campaign finance scandal, has after 15 months thrown us a fish: the indictment of Yah Lin (Charlie) Trie.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKS, ROBERT M.
description: MARKS-Robert M. Age 87, of Carlsbad, CA, previously of Larchmont, NY. He is survived by his wife Frances (nee Schneider) and son Frederick. Former Advertising Director with Conde Nast Publications of New York City.

title: Victory by Kentucky May Not Quiet Critics
description: Playing Villanova in the Core States Center was the kind of holiday the Kentucky Wildcats needed. They got to play in a nice new arena against a nonconference opponent that would not put up too much of a struggle. And they briefly escaped from their demanding fans.

title: A Little English Goes Far in Seoul
description: SEOUL  From 7 A.M. to well into the evening, in hundreds of small classrooms across the country, young Koreans are struggling to learn English conversation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZAVLEK, ISIDORE
description: ZAVLEK-Isidore. Beloved husband of 50 years to Sylvia. Father, grandfather and friend to so many. You will be with all you touched forever. Shiva at 201567-3142.

title: House Republicans Plan to Keep a Tight Rein on 2000 Census
description: Republicans in Congress are preparing to renew their fight to prevent the Census Bureau from using a new method to count the nation's population in 2000.

title: Weapons Plutonium Has Energy Value
description: To the Editor:

title: Microsoft Case May Be Prelude to a Wider Antitrust Battle
description: The first round of the Microsoft Corporation's antitrust confrontation with the Government still has months to run, awaiting Federal court decisions. But a second round has already begun -- the discussion, debate and negotiations about whether the Justice Department should file a broader Sherman Act case against Microsoft.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAXALL, ELIZABETH DODGE RAINS, FORD
description: HAXALL-Elizabeth Dodge Rains-ford. Granddaughter of Cleveland H. Dodge, friend and benefactor to President Wilson, and daughter of Cleveland E. and Pauline Morgan Dodge, generous benefactors of numerous New York institutions including the YWCA, Museum of Natural History, Bronx Zoo, The Bronx Botanical Gardens and Teachers College, died early Sunday morning, February 8, in her sleep at Collington, a retirement community in Mitchellville, MD. Born in Riverdale, New York in 1920, Mrs. Haxall was home schooled until her family founded Riverdale Neighborhood School. There, under the tutelage of such gifted teachers as a young Vincent Price, she discovered her affinity for art. Later, she attended Holmquist School for Girls, where she was a student leader. She studied at Wells College for one year before enrolling at the American Academy of Fine Arts in New York City, where she distinguished herself, winning various awards, including the Medal for Advanced Pictorial Design. In 1942, Elizabeth Haxall was married to Mark Rainsford, who was killed during World War II. She later married Bolling W. Haxall in 1947. Mrs. Haxall carried on her family's tradition of community service by serving on the Board of Trustees of New York YMCA and Holmquist School in the early 1940's. Later, she served on the boards of Solebury School, the American Museum of Natural History Women's Committee, the New York Girl Scouts Committee, and Riverdale Neighbor House, having twice been awarded the Good Neighbor Award. For generations, her family, the Morgans and Dodges, were longtime summer residents of the 1000 Islands, where she and her late husband, Bolling Haxall, were founders and major benefactors of the Antique Boat Museum, the 1000 Islands Craft School and the Old Town Hall Museum in Clayton, New York. Mrs. Haxall is survived by her brother Cleveland E. Dodge, Jr. of Pownal, VT, her sister Joan Rueckert of Hanover, NH, and her four children, Gale D'Luhy of Spring Lake, NJ, Polly MacLean of Rowe, MA, Bolling Haxall, Jr of Upper Marlboro, MD, and Barton Haxall of Clayton, NY. Mrs. Haxall is also survived by nine grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, you may send gifts to the Antique Boat Museum, Clayton, New York, which is dedicating its new Library to the memory of Elizabeth and Bolling Haxall.

title: Massacre in Liberia
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SAVAGE, MARILYN
description: SAVAGE-Marilyn. 10/29/45-2/9/94. Four years mean nothing. The absurdity is that you deserved to have them. Your tenacity, humor and courage remain, but how I miss talking to you, laughing with you, arguing with you. Miss you now and always. Vicki

title: New York Municipal Union Grapples With Deep Trouble
description: District Council 37, the coalition representing 120,000 New York City municipal workers, has been plunged into what some labor leaders are calling its worst crisis ever because prosecutors are investigating 7 of its 56 union locals and because a well-known president of one of its locals has been suspended.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, ROSE A.
description: SCHWARTZ-Rose A. Passed away February 6, 1998, in West Palm Beach, FL. Native of New Haven, CT. Devoted wife of the late Jack Schwartz. Loving mother of Joseph B. Schwartz (Marilyn) of Manhattan and Judith Merriam of Madison, CT. Caring grandmother of Jill and Jeffrey Merriam. Services Monday in New Haven. She was immensely proud of her family and her many sacrifices on their behalf will always be remembered. Donations may be made to the Schwartz/ Goldstein Lecture Fund, Stephen Wise Free Synagogue, 30 W. 68th Street, NY, NY 10023.

title: Taking In the Sites; Focusing On Heritage Of Blacks
description: Black History Month need not be confined to a four-week period anymore. Thanks to the World Wide Web, it is possible to study the history of the African-American experience year round. But February, when it is officially observed, is a good time to seek out information, as many sites have highlighted special sections for visitors.

title: MetroStars Rebuilding From Back To Front
description: The MetroStars are busy trying to make amends for last season's last place finish in Major League Soccer's Eastern Conference.

title: Allan Grant, Farmers' Advocate, 91
description: Allan Grant, a California rancher who started as a sharecropper and came to speak for millions of farm families as president of the American Farm Bureau Federation in the 1970's, died on Jan. 27 at Kaweah Delta Hospital in Visalia, Calif., where he made his home. He was 91.

title: London Journal; Diana's Hereafter, an Eternity of Newsstand Life
description: With Diana gone, a new press code in place and the comparatively strait-laced officials of Prime Minister Tony Blair's New Labor Government offering scant opportunities for keyhole discoveries, the British press has had to extend even its storied reach to turn up front page notoriety.

title: How Legal Paths of Jones and Lewinsky Joined
description: Shortly after 10 A.M. on Jan. 17, a Saturday, the President of the United States stepped out of the White House into the back of a black limousine and rode a block to his lawyer's office to undergo a six-hour grilling in the case of Paula Corbin Jones versus William Jefferson Clinton.

title: What to Look For
description: LUGE -- MEN'S SINGLES, THIRD AND FOURTH RUNS

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Fat Fees in Tobacco Deals Signal New Foe for States: The Lawyers
description: At first blush, it sounds like a standard contingency-fee agreement -- even generous to the client, by trial lawyers' standards. The lawyers who took the case fronted the initial costs, agreed not to take a penny if the client did not collect, and asked for only 15 percent if there was a settlement.

title: The Sisters Return, Withdrawn and Steely
description: It isn't the walls that close in on the Prozorov women in the Moscow Art Theater's audacious new production of ''Three Sisters,'' it's the woods. Rather than cling to one another as they absorb the horrible events of the final minutes of the play, the devastated sisters wander into the forest. In a scene beautifully realized by the theater's artistic director, Oleg Yefremov, the Prozorov homestead recedes into the back of the stage as Olga, Irina and Masha are enveloped in a semicircular curtain of birch trees.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UNDERHILL, MARGARET YOUNG
description: UNDERHILL-Margaret Young. Age 85, of Jericho, NY, on February 6, 1998. Beloved wife of the late H. Willets Underhill. Survived by nieces and nephew. Memorial service, Jericho Friends Meeting, Old Jericho Turnpike, February 9, at 3 PM. Memorial contributions may be made to the Margaret Young Underhill Scholarship Fund, Bucknell University, Lewisburg, PA 17837.

title: Pessimism Retains Grip on Appalachian Poor
description: There is an area of Booneville that some residents call Ho Chi Minh City for its third world appearance. It is not large, just a few winding gravel roads. But many of the houses look like shanties, heated with wood or coal. Children walk around with dirty bare feet. Many people lack telephones and cars.

title: Don't Let Russia Derail NATO Expansion; Spirit of Founding Act
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, GEORGE
description: KATZ-George. On February 7, 1998. Deeply mourned by Sylvia Slatin Katz, loving and beloved wife. Dearest uncle, cherished cousin and loyal friend. Services Tuesday, 11 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MELTZER, GEORGE
description: MELTZER-George. On February 7, 1998. Adored and adoring husband of Judith (nee Stettin). Precious father of Donald Meltzer and Mindy (nee Meltzer) Ferrentino. Loved father-in-law of Debra (nee Phillips) Meltzer and Paul Wolfle. The best Pop George to Leslie, Phillip and Amanda Meltzer. A son, not a son-in-law, to Blanche Stettin. Loved brother of Harriet Cohen and Dr. Herbert Meltzer. Dear uncle, brother-in-law, relative and friend. Proud U.S. Navy veteran and member of the USS Missouri Association. His lifelong career was in the linen supply industry. A darling man who was a perennial good guy. For those who would like to remember George with a donation, please consider the Don Monti Memorial Research Foundation, North Shore University Hospital, 300 Community Drive, Manhasset, New York 11030. Visitation today 7-9 PM. Services Tuesday, 12:30 PM, at ''Gutterman's,'' 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, LI.

title: New Partners
description: The vagaries of the Asian economy did not stop Samsung Electronics Co. Ltd., based in South Korea, from becoming a new partner with the United States Olympic Committee. In an agreement signed on Monday, Samsung will be the official wireless communications equipment partner.

title: Want to Sell a Video Game? Better Stick With a Sports Theme
description: Arnold Schwarzenegger or Arnold Palmer? As far as video game makers are concerned, it is increasingly clear: take the aging golfer over the action hero.

title: Leap Day 2000 Might Pose Big Problems for Some Computers' Software
description: Computers that survive New Year's Day 2000 by pretending it is 1900 may function fine -- but only for 59 days. In a new twist on the so-called year 2000 problem, experts say, Feb. 29 will offer new opportunities for computers to fail.

title: Sometimes It's Just Impossible To Play the Game by the Book
description: For a hand providing drama and irritation in the highest degree, the diagramed deal would be hard to beat. It occurred in a private team game last month at the Jupiter Island Club in Hobe Sound, Fla. South and West were both surprised to have total freak hands, defined as 12 or more cards in two suits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, NORMAN J.
description: LEVY-Norman J. With profound sadness, the Officers, Trustees and Staff of the Long Island Chapter of the Crohn's & Colitis Foundation of America mourn the tragic loss of Senator Norman J. Levy. We honor with gratitude his role in the founding of the Long Island Chapter, his visionary leadership and his inspired wisdom. To his loving wife Joy, we offer our love and deepest condolences. The legacy of his passionate commitment and advocacy will endure. Richard S. Music, President Edda S. Ramsdell, Exec. Dir.

title: Essex County Executive Seeking Second Term
description: Months after vowing not to run for re-election, the Essex County Executive, James W. Treffinger, has announced that he will seek a second term in office.

title: Where Paths Crossed
description: How did Bill Clinton become the first President forced to testify under oath about his private life? How did the Paula Corbin Jones case -- once demeaned by his lawyers as ''tabloid trash'' -- become a threat to his Presidency? The answers lie in a look at the recent past.

title: Metro Matters; Schools Face Tough Choice About Repairs
description: LATELY, it seems, hardly a day goes by -- O.K., maybe a week -- without some fresh disaster befalling a city school.

title: The Many Faces of Montessori
description: LONDON  The word "Montessori" can produce an astonishing array of responses, from "too lax" to "too strict" to "cultish." The images range from pre-schoolers running wild to others forced to sit still with folded hands.

title: Solo Artistry by 3 Boys in the Band
description: It can be useful for an orchestra to remind its listeners that its players are not just cogs in a vast musical machine, but musicians with interpretive ideas and a level of technical accomplishment that can bear closer scrutiny. Seasoned concertgoers looking over the New York Philharmonic's current roster, in fact, are likely to spot players in nearly every section who had reputations as recitalists or chamber players before joining the orchestra. This is not lost on Kurt Masur, the orchestra's music director, who, like Zubin Mehta before him, regularly gives his principal players opportunities to be heard in concertos.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Monica S. Lewinsky, the former White House intern, misstated the age at which she moved to a job near the Oval Office in some copies. She was 22, not 21.

title: Quarterly Sale Of U.S. Debt Set This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week comprises today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and the Treasury's quarterly refunding of debt. The refunding begins tomorrow with the sale of $13 billion of three-year notes, followed by $12 billion of 10-year notes on Wednesday and $10 billion of 30-year bonds on Thursday.

title: Havas Buys SFM, Big Media Agency
description: Havas Advertising S. A. in Paris has, as expected, acquired the SFM Media Corporation in New York, the largest independent American media services agency, which will become a unit of Havas. Terms were not disclosed.

title: This Week
description: EVENTS

title: Plea Heeded For Meeting On Black Theater
description: In a provocative speech at a Theater Communications Group's conference at Princeton University in June 1996, August Wilson said that among the 66 regional theaters in the United States only one ''can be considered black.'' He made an impassioned plea for the need to encourage black theater as a separate movement. ''It is vibrant,'' Mr. Wilson, the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright, said about black theater. ''It is vital.''

title: A Buddha Connection, Spoken, but With Regret
description: Deliberate contradictions between what one read in the program notes and what one actually saw helped make Ellis Wood's dances thought-provoking in ''Timeless Red,'' a program she offered on Thursday night at Dance Theater Workshop. Spiritual sentiments dominated most of the program notes. But the choreography was hard-boiled.

title: Jet Crew Voices Sympathy for Ski Lift Victims' Kin
description: The crew of the American jet that sheared ski lift cables in northern Italy last week issued a message of sympathy to the families of the victims today, and United States Air Force officials denied Italian charges that a delay in handing over the jet's mission recorder was part of an attempted cover-up.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, BERNARD
description: BERGER-Bernard. Of Cherry Hill, NJ. Beloved husband of Charlotte. Devoted father of Robert. Services Tuesday, noon, at Schwartz Brosthers-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills, NY.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Despite predictions, children aren't avoiding educational programming.
description: LIKE vegetables prescribed for a child's diet, three hours of educational shows had to be added to every television station's weekly schedule this season.

title: Canadians Try to Sweep An Event in First Year
description: Here at Kazakoshi Park Arena, where four women's curling matches commenced this morning, there were no Campbell's Soup endorsements to be had. But after decades of languishing in demonstration-sport purgatory, there finally were medals.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KARASIK, RICHARD
description: KARASIK-Richard. 2/28/31-2/9/94. Still a legend in my mind. Always, with love.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMAS, CARROLL B.
description: THOMAS-Carroll B. Age 67, of Wyckoff, died Saturday, February 7, 1998, at Good Samaritan Hospital, Suffern, NY. Born in Baltimore, MD, he lived in Lutherville, MD, and Plaverford Township, PA, before moving to Wyckoff, NJ, 24 years ago. He was an executive for Alfa Laval, Inc., Ft. Lee, NJ, for 25 years before his retirement in 1993. He was an Air Force veteran. Survived by his wife, Nancy (nee Klaunberg) of Wyckoff, NJ; one daughter and son-in-law, Mary T. and John E. Fraser of Hamilton, NY; one sister Aurelia Burt of Baltimore, MD, two brothers C. Lee Thomas of Queenstown, MD, and Wade P. Thomas, Jr. of Crofftown, MD. Also survived by two granddaughters, Shannon and Kristen Fraser. Cremation private. Memorial service will be held Tuesday, February 10, 1998, 11 AM, at the Advent Lutheran Church, 777 Wyckoff Ave, Wyckoff, NJ. In lieu of flowers donations to your favorite charity would be appreciated.

title: Don't Let Russia Derail NATO Expansion
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUTHERLAND, ASHBY MCCULLOCH.
description: SUTHERLAND - Ashby McCulloch. Of San Antonio, TX, and formerly of New York. Died Thursday, February 5, 1998, in San Antonio after a year long struggle with leukemia. He was 76. Born in San Antonio on March 16, 1921, Sutherland was a graduate of the University of the South and the Harvard Business and Law Schools. After wartime service in Europe as an Army officer, he practice at Sullivan & Cromwell before joining INCO Ltd. in 1954. He was with INCO until 1983 in New York, Paris and Toronto, serving in a variety of legal and management positions before retiring as a senior vice president and executive director. He retired to San Antonio, but spent parts of his later years in Venice and San Miguel de Allende. He was a member of the Knickerbocker Club and the Harvard Club of New York City. Sutherland was married from 1956 to 1972 to Adair Ramsey of Goliad, TX. Although divorced, they remained close friends. He is survived by his son Howard Ramsey Sutherland of London, his daughter Ramsey Sutherland Farber of Buffalo and two grandchildren, with a third expected soon. Graveside service will be Monday, February 9, at City Cemetery #

title: Charities Use For-Profit Units To Avoid Disclosing Finances
description: Society asks little of the nation's charities. They tend to get generous tax breaks, and in return they must operate in the open, making their yearly financial statements and tax returns available to anyone who asks. Many people never do. But donors and watchdogs who read these updates know what happens to the dollars they give to the charity and the money it raises elsewhere.

title: Gerald Pencer, 52, Chairman of Cott
description: Gerald Pencer, the chairman and chief executive of the Cott Corporation, the soft-drink maker based in Toronto, died on Tuesday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Toronto. He was 52.

title: Armenia Leader's Candle Fades, Slowly, Till Military Snuffs It Out
description: Even before Levon Ter-Petrossian resigned as President this week, Armenia's top military officials had become the nation's main political power brokers, local officials and Western diplomats say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEINBERG, DR. WILLIAM
description: KLEINBERG-Dr. William Age 87. Professor at Princeton University and founder of Princeton Laboratories, on Saturday, February 7, 1998, in Princeton, NJ. Survived by his wife Ruth Schechter Kleinberg; daughters Barbara Conviser, Jamie Kleinberg Kamph and Wendy Barker, and also survived by five grandchildren. Funeral service 1:30 PM, today, at the Princeton Jewish Center, 435 Nassau Street, Princeton, NJ. Interment Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, NJ.

title: Corrections
description: A map caption on Saturday about an earthquake in Afghanistan misstated the location of Takhar Province, where the earthquake struck. It is in northeastern, not northwestern, Afghanistan.

title: Headlines Catch Up With a Choreographer
description: Like many experimental choreographers, Jane Comfort integrates text and movement into her dance pieces. But unlike most, she can make her points cleverly and pungently without resorting to a tedious confessional mode.

title: Enoch Powell, British Rightist, Dies at 85
description: Enoch Powell, an eloquent, right-wing British political figure known for an address he gave in 1968 opposing immigration from former British colonies, died yesterday in King Edward VII Hospital in London. He was 85 and lived in London.

title: EF Language Keeps Lead in Fifth Leg
description: The yacht EF Language maintained a lead yesterday in the fifth leg of the Whitbread Round the World Race.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLITTEN, LAWRENCE A.
description: SCHLITTEN-Lawrence A., Lt. Col., USA. Entered into rest February 6, 1998. Late of Canton, MA, formerly of Belle Harbor, NY. Beloved husband of Renee (Stettner). Devoted father of Mark Justin and Dr. Elliot W. Justin. Adored grandfather of Grant, Eric and Eleanor. He leaves us in his 82nd year with a legacy of love, admiration, honor and integrity.

title: Machine Tool Orders Rose in December
description: Domestic orders for machine tools rose in December, wrapping up 1997 with the fifth straight year of positive annual growth, an industry survey showed today.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about an increase in taxicab accidents in New York City misspelled the name of a cab insurance broker and misstated the location of his business. He is Robert Mackle, not Mackel, and he works in Queens, not Brooklyn.

title: A Producer Who Infuses Salsa's Beat With the Soul Of the Streets
description: Sergio George, the man who reinvented New York salsa in the early 1990's and brought a young, new Hispanic audience to a musical style it had earlier abandoned, is finishing up a recording session with Lisette Melendez in a midtown Manhattan studio. He wanders around the room, thinking. He asks his musicians about this musical idea, or that. Mr. George is terse, with the air of someone who accepts suggestions from just a few people whom he trusts; his experience gives him the rest.

title: Jordan Is Still Firmly In His Coach's Corner
description: Michael Jordan had arrived at Madison Square Garden yesterday, still sniffling, but he was seated comfortably in the Knicks' locker room. The National Basketball Association could breathe a sigh of relief that Jordan was suiting up for what could be his final All-Star Game appearance, but he did nothing to alleviate the Bulls' fears that their golden goose is leaving after this season.

title: Party for Valentine's Day That's Truly All Hearts
description: For the first six months of her grandson's life, Barbara Williams could not even think about his ailing heart. She refused to look at pictures of his blocked aortic valve. And when she heard that the baby needed open heart surgery, she assumed that he would not live.

title: Performances Worth Clapping About: Three Skaters Shatter the World Mark
description: For the first time in Olympic speed-skating competition, there was clapping on the ice as well as off the ice, and as is often the case in this sport, the Dutch made much of the racket.

title: How Do You Do When It Comes to Choosing a Course in English?
description: MANCHESTER, England  This summer thousands of language students will travel to Britain and the United States to learn English to prepare for university or to further their careers. But, according to educationalists, a significant proportion will waste their time and money on an unsuitable or second-rate language program.

title: Sam Marcy, Marxist Writer, Dies at 86
description: Sam Marcy, an unabashed, unreconstructed and uncommonly prolific Marxist-Leninist, died on Feb. 1 at Cabrini Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 86 and as the founder of the Workers World Party had never wavered in his devotion to what he saw as the pure, shining core of an authentic political philosophy tarnished by tyranny and undermined by apostasy.

title: Canadian Welcomed in Homeland
description: Her ancestry is visible in the angles of her face, if not the vague burr of her Ontario accent. Vickie Sunohara remembered her father's parents, who did not talk much about being interned in a Canadian camp during World War II.

title: Principal Reassigned as Officials Investigate Enrollment Figures
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew has reassigned the principal of Louis D. Brandeis High School in Manhattan to administrative duties while city schools officials investigate allegations that the school used fraudulent enrollment numbers to increase its government funding, Board of Education officials said.

title: $19 Million Proposed For Group Homes
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman has announced that she will include $18.75 million in the 1998-99 state budget proposal to place people with developmental disabilities in group homes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUBICH, BERNICE
description: LUBICH-Bernice. On Saturday, February 7, 1998, at her home in New York City after a long and valiant battle with cancer. Beloved wife of Milton. Dear sister-in-law of Debbie and Aaron Schochet. Loving aunt of Susan and the late Steven Schochet. Services Tuesday, February 10, 12 noon at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. The family will observe Shiva Tuesday evening through Thursday morning at the Park Lane Hotel, 320 Central Park South. In lieu of flowers, charitable contributions may be made to The Pines Care Center, P.O. Box 5333, Fire Island Pines, NY 11782-0999.

title: Don't Let Russia Derail NATO Expansion; U.S. Self-Interest
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHOLLAR, EDWARD R., PH.D.
description: SHOLLAR-Edward R., Ph.D. On February 7, 1998. Beloved husband of Anne. Loving father of Michael and Thomas. Devoted son of Sylvia. Also survived by his brother Harvey of Pittsburgh, PA. He was a psychologist in private practice in NYC for many years and was affiliated with Roosevelt Medical Center. Service Monday, 11:15 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAFFE, MORRIS
description: JAFFE-Morris. Of Fair Lawn, NJ, on Saturday, February 7, 1998. Husband of Goldie; brother of Herman, Raphael and the late Nathan and their wives and loving uncle.

title: 2 Internet Access Services Discuss Joining Forces
description: The At Home Corporation is in talks with Road Runner, a unit of Time Warner Inc., about combining their high-speed Internet access services to strengthen their competition with local phone companies in the race to link millions of homes to the Internet.

title: Marje Fields, 77; Talent Agent Put Stars in TV Ads
description: Marje Fields, a longtime talent agent who was a pioneer in placing well-known actors in television commercials, died on Jan. 27 at her home in Manhattan. She was 77.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, MILTON
description: BROWN-Milton. The trustees, faculty, staff, students and alumni of the Institute of Fine Arts, New York University mourn the loss of their friend and colleague, Milton Brown, a most distinguished teacher, brilliant art historian, and devoted alumnus.

title: With computers, beauty is in the eye of the user, but ugliness often wins.
description: GREAT technology, David Gelernter argues in his new book, ''Machine Beauty: Elegance and the Heart of Technology'' (Basic Books), is beautiful technology. And the tragedy for a computer scientist like Mr. Gelernter, who is trying to design the next generation of personal computer software, is how ugly computer technology has become.

title: Armenia's Turmoil
description: The resignation of Armenia's president, Levon Ter-Petrossian, earlier this month was a disturbing development for peace and ethnic harmony in the Caucasus. Largely Christian Armenia is at war with its larger and richer Muslim neighbor, Azerbaijan, over Nagorno-Karabakh, an enclave in Azerbaijan populated by Armenians, who are seeking independence. In September, Mr. Ter-Petrossian, under pressure from the United States, France and Russia, announced his support for a peace plan that contained necessary compromises. The compromises enraged hard-liners in his Government and parliamentary coalition, who forced him to resign.

title: Blair Aims to Rescue Worst-Performing Schools
description: LONDON  It couldn't have been more timely. Just as Britain sets itself the task of trying to rescue some of its poorest schools from persistent failure, word has come that the malaise within the education system appears to reach to the very top  to Oxford University itself.

title: History's Moral for U.S.: Goliath Can Lose, Too
description: History is peering over Bill Clinton's shoulder as he ponders what to do about Saddam Hussein and Iraq.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARONIN, ISIDORE L.
description: ARONIN-Isidore L. Husband of the late Ree Aronin. Friend of Eleanore Jaffe. Father of Lynda and Buddy Cohen, Carl and Phyllis Aronin. Sister of Esther Freilich, Hy and Sally Holtzman, Ruby and Harriet Holtzman. Zeide to many. Services Tuesday, 11 AM, at Wellwood Cemetery, Pine Lawn, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  REITMAN, EDWARD
description: REITMAN-Edward. 1921-1988. Beloved husband, father and grandfather. Deeply missed and lovingly remembered. You are always with us. Your Family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPERLING, ELIZABETH SOMMER.
description: SPERLING-Elizabeth Sommer. At Pennswood Village, February 5, 1998. Beloved widow of Stevens, loving mother of Della and Fred, and sister of Margaret Sommer Marshall. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the charity of your choice or to The Fellowship Fund, Pennswood Village, Newtown, PA. 18940.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Sports of The Times; The Rope Is Fraying As N.B.A. Partnership Becomes a Tug-of-War
description: NOT far beneath the youthful glitz of the All-Star Game Weekend, war is brewing. The partnership with which the National Basketball Association pulled itself out of ashes in the early 1980's is deteriorating into an ego-tinged power struggle.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOHLMANN, PAUL A.
description: KOHLMANN-Paul A. On February 7, 1998. Beloved husband of Ursula. Loving father of Peter and Josephine; Susan and Michael Orbison. Adoring grandfather of Emma and Charlotte; Willie, Ben and Jake. He will be profoundly missed. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory to the charity of your choice.

title: Ara Oztemel, 71, Businessman; Cultivated U.S.-Soviet Trade
description: Ara Oztemel, who built a fortune by cultivating trade between the United States and the Soviet Union during the cold war, died on Feb. 2 at a Miami hospital. He was 71 and had retired to Key Biscayne, Fla., from his home in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Philip Kramer, 77, Oil Company Executive
description: Philip Kramer, a former president and chief executive of the Amerada Hess Corporation, died on Jan. 30 at Del Ray Medical Center in Del Ray Beach, Fla. He was 77.

title: Sports of The Times; Former Outsiders Get Their Ice Time on an Olympic Rink
description: THE Canadians were all pumped up, thinking of the big picture. The Americans were poised, keeping their focus.

title: Whispered Secrets Start a Loud Debate
description: Everyone here is talking about how someone else is talking.

title: Rene de Epelbaum, 77, Argentine Protester
description: Rene de Epelbaum, a founder of the Mothers of the Plaza de Mayo human rights group and one of its most dynamic members, died on Saturday at age 77.

title: Unflinching, The Sentry Of the Closet Marches On
description: The morning after President Clinton delivered his State of the Union Message, he boarded Air Force One for a trip to the Midwest, trailed by a flock of edgy advisers. It was a jittery day, as everyone waited to see what would happen next in the explosive investigation of Mr. Clinton's relationship with a White House intern.

title: Needed: A Surgeon General
description: The country has been without a Surgeon General for three years now, and if a band of conservative Republican senators has its way, the wait will continue. They want to block confirmation of a highly respected nominee because of his mildly stated views on abortion. Some critics are even willing to eliminate the office. The attacks are grotesquely overstated and deserve a sharp rebuff when the issue comes to the floor of Congress this week. The office is worth keeping, and Dr. David Satcher is superbly qualified to fill it.

title: Paris, Part One: Spilling Skaters and Uneven Judging
description: It was a night when more skaters than flowers seemed to land on the ice. And the judging was every bit as inconsistent as the skating. In the end, Artur Dmitriev of Russia put himself in position to become the first man to win Olympic gold medals in pairs skating with two different partners.

title: Reclaiming 'Day' and 'Night,' Memories in Marble
description: In 1968, Robert A. Roe saved the ''Day.''

title: Accounts
description: * Western region dealer association of BMW of North America, Los Angeles, is keeping Mendelsohn/Zien, Los Angeles, as its creative agency after a review. Billings on the account, which the agency has handled for six years, were estimated at $18.5 million.

title: New Political Structure for Northern Ireland Emerging at Talks
description: For the first time since the current peace effort began five years ago, the shape of a new political structure for Northern Ireland has begun to emerge clearly in formal talks between political leaders of the Protestant majority and the Roman Catholic minority.

title: Gas Companies Jockeying For Prize of Mexico City
description: It's 7 A.M. and Jose Francisco Ruiz shoulders a man-sized tank of liquefied propane up steep stairs to a downtown rooftop.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKELSTEIN, IRWIN
description: FINKELSTEIN-Irwin. Loving husband of Barbara. Devoted father of Seth. Cherished father-in-law of Laura. Proud grandfather of Zachary and Samantha. Brother of Paul. Services ''Wien & Wien,'' 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ, Monday, 1 PM. Donations to the Finkelstein Memorial Library Holocaust Fund, Spring Valley, NY, would be appreciated.

title: New Yorker Grammarian
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMMONS, LILLIAN A.
description: SIMMONS-Lillian A. On February 7, 1998. Of West Bloomfield, MI, formerly of Manhatan and South Orange, NJ. Devoted wife of the late Dr. Everett B. Simmons, Sr. Dear mother of Dr. Everett B. Simmons, Jr. Grandmother of Everett III and Erik Arthur Simmons. Mother-in-law of Ouida Simmons. Also survived by a host of friends. Funeral service Wednesday, 1 PM, at Suburban Home of Cotton Funeral Service, 130 Main St, Orange, NJ. Interment Rosedale Cemetery, Orange. Visitation Wednesday, 12 noon-1 PM.

title: New Jersey Entrepreneur Is Cashing In on Inmates
description: Among all the national charities that have gotten into the act, a New Jersey entrepreneur is as adroit as they come in mixing for-profit and nonprofit entities. John J. Clancy, a former drug counselor with big ambitions, saw the money to be made from running halfway houses in a state where prisons house 44 percent more inmates than they were designed to hold.

title: European Commission May Revoke Exemption for U.S. Movie Studios
description: Europe's love-hate relationship with Hollywood veered back toward hostility last week, when a European Commission antitrust official moved to break up a joint distribution company here owned by three big American movie studios.

title: A Look at Religion in China by 3 U.S. Clerics
description: A high-profile delegation of American religious figures began arriving in Beijing today for a three-week tour of China to examine the state of religious freedom here, one of the most volatile human rights issues in American diplomacy.

title: Southeast Asians Like Idea of Using Local Currencies for Trade
description: Southeast Asian leaders, hoping to reduce their reliance on the American dollar and shore up their troubled economies, are rallying behind a proposal to trade goods in local currencies instead of dollars.

title: No Rise in Transit Fares In State Budget Proposal
description: A $194 million allocation from the proposed 1998-99 state budget would allow New Jersey Transit fares to remain unchanged next year, a spokesman for the agency has said.

title: At Home Abroad; Decency and Liberty
description: The controversy over leaks from the grand jury investigating President Clinton's sex life is probably dismissed by the public as maneuvering by lawyers. Washington is a world of leaks, after all. Why are these any different?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, MARION GRACE
description: DAVIS-Marion Grace, former NYC high school teacher, on February 5, 1998. Sister of Captain Lewis M. Davis, Jr. USN (Retired). Aunt of Richard T. Davis and Priscilla Davis Snow. Notice of service at a later date.

title: Hollywood Pros Put Music Hits, Movies and More on PC
description: Jonathan Taplin's career has taken him from Woodstock to Wall Street and Hollywood. He has been tour manager for Bob Dylan and the Band, an investment banker at Merrill Lynch and a producer of movies like ''Mean Streets.''

title: Results
description: MEDALS

title: Man Attacks One Officer and Shoots Another, Police Say
description: A 23-year-old man who was apparently angry because the Newark police had confiscated his car for having stolen license plates walked calmly into a Jersey City police station early today, attacked a desk officer, grabbed the desk lieutenant's gun and shot him twice, seriously wounding him, the police said.

title: A Coach Takes a Momentum Check
description: Hockey coaches are rarely so subtle. But Ron Wilson chose a creative and roundabout approach with Referee Marc Faucette when he thought Faucette was favoring the home team over his own in a National Hockey League game.

title: Deport the Bear!
description: As an immigrant of British ancestry who has gone through all the processes of naturalization, I was dismayed to hear that my childhood compatriot, Mr. Pooh Bear, has been compelled to stay in the United States, despite evidence that he was brought here illegally in 1947. (By a publisher, no less -- clear proof of moral turpitude.)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ZYWOTOW, SAMUEL
description: ZYWOTOW-Samuel. 1993. 5 years. Silence has replaced laughter. You were my life partner-I really don't know how to live without you. Lorraine

title: Malaysia Begins to 'Wire' Its Classrooms
description: KUALA LUMPUR  Just paces away from Kuala Lumpur's shopping malls and high-rise hotels is the city's most elegant anachronism, a colonial-style schoolhouse.

title: Eastern Europe Takes to Steiner
description: PARIS  When the collapse of communism set the vast Soviet school system adrift, its bewildered educators had to search for new models and a few became intrigued with an obscure Western philosopher.

title: Don't Let Russia Derail NATO Expansion; A Military Sinecure
description: To the Editor:

title: I.B.M. Consolidates Marketing Roster
description: I.B.M. has consolidated its agency roster for worldwide direct and interactive marketing, with combined billings estimated at more than $100 million, at 4 shops from 30.

title: U.S. WILL NOT ASK TO USE SAUDI BASES FOR A RAID ON IRAQ
description: With Saudi Arabia showing deep reluctance to support a military strike on Iraq, Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen said today that he would not seek permission to launch American fighters and bombers from Saudi territory.

title: Michel Roux, 73, Opera Baritone and Actor
description: The French baritone Michel Roux, who sang frequently with the Paris Opera and at the Glyndebourne festival in England, died on Wednesday in Paris. He was 73.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Europe's Ire at Hollywood Is Taken Out on Distributor

title: The Anything-Goes Spirit Of Austrians in New York
description: The official explanation for the name of the ANY Art Festival, which took place on Friday and Saturday in St. Peter's Church at Citicorp, was that it was a celebration of ''Austria New York'' -- of Austrian musicians who have made a home in the city. But ANY art turned out to be also any art, for at least two of the three programs were inclusive of everything except genius.

title: Young, Hip Sport Zigzags Into the Olympic Mainstream
description: Chris Klug had finished his first of two runs Sunday morning and was tied with Thomas Prugger of Italy for the lead in the men's giant slalom snowboarding event when a roar went up from the crowd. He turned to check the huge scoreboard and saw that he was now second, Jasey-Jay Anderson of Canada having just bettered his time by seven-hundredths of a second with a run of 59.31 seconds.

title: Campbell Soup pitches comfort food for the modern soul during the Winter Olympics.
description: SURELY the comfort value of a bowl of hot soup, even if it comes out of a can, is not a new concept to most of television-watching America. But how about the comfort value of a bowl of hot soup served to a foster child who has just watched her social worker drive off, leaving her in an unfamiliar new home?

title: An Anthem of Disillusion: My Country, 'Tis of Whom?
description: Beginning with ''The Firm,'' John Grisham's most gripping novels have all pointed toward escape. What makes a typical Grisham hero is his or her willingness to flee, to leave it all behind: job, family, country. At their most radical, as with ''The Runaway Jury'' or ''The Partner,'' Mr. Grisham's books describe a web of corruption that links public institutions, the law, corporations and crime, and that is so socially definitive that the only thing a decent man or woman can do is steal from thieves and disappear.

title: Patents; So much for those inert computer mice. A new version lets users get downright touchy-feely.
description: MOST people who use computers probably take it for granted that working with a PC means watching and listening to what is happening on the screen. It is probably safe to say that few have lamented how much better life would be if they could just feel what was happening as well.

title: PRESIDENT'S AIDES EXPAND OFFENSIVE TO COUNTER STARR
description: The White House broadened its attack today on Kenneth W. Starr, the independent counsel investigating accusations involving President Clinton and a former intern, calling Mr. Starr ''corrupt'' and demanding an independent investigation of suspected leaks from his office.

title: Don't Let Russia Derail NATO Expansion; Bogus Requirement
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KORET, BERNICE
description: KORET-Bernice. You summoned laughter from our bellies, inspired us with your intelligence and moxie. We will miss you dearly. The Landes Family

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BRODSKY, MILTON
description: BRODSKY-Milton. In our memories and hearts forever. Love, Grace and Ruth

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BORSTELMANN, FRANCES C.
description: BORSTELMANN-Frances C. On February 8, 1998. Widow of Frederick V. Mother of Richard, Ann, Miele, the late Robert, Reverend James, Jean Talbot. Family will welcome visitors on Monday, February 9, at Schuyler Funeral Home, 3535 East Tremont Avenue, Bronx, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Frances de Chantal Church, Bronx, Tuesday, February 10, at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to The Little Sisters of the Poor, Jeanne Jugan Residence, 3200 Baychester Avenue, Bronx, NY 10475.

title: Private Lives, Public Morality
description: The defining moment in every historic trial the Dreyfus case, most notably, or the O. J. Simpson case -- comes when it is no longer the defendant who is on trial, but the public. We have now reached that point in the investigation of President Clinton.

title: Winter Shuffle: Who Went Where?
description: The hot topic of conversation heading into spring training a year ago was the economic binge of the Florida Marlins, who committed $89 million to six free agents in an effort to become a contender and lure fans back to their ball park. As the beginning of spring training loomed this past weekend, the Marlins were again a hot topic of conversation.

title: INSIDE
description: Another Star for Jordan

title: Indians' New Money Buys Lobbying Power
description: Five short years ago, a lobbying excursion to Congress for the Oneida Indians of central New York went something like this: Tribal officials would pile into an old car, endure the eight-hour drive to Washington, sleep on a friend's floor and dine on peanut butter sandwiches, all for the chance to catch some Congressional aide on the fly.

title: Optimism in the Shadow of Mortality
description: Victoria Williams decided to follow a request for ''On Time'' from her audience at the Bottom Line on Thursday night. After she played a few notes, she turned to her 10-member band and asked, ''Have y'all ever heard this?'' Apparently not, but it didn't matter. The drummer picked up a beat, other band members watched for chords, and the song lurched toward a good-time, gospelly lilt, living up to the lyrics that Ms. Williams proclaimed in her quavery voice: ''Don't fret, don't worry, just feel peace of mind/That peace of mind that you're always on time.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOCH, MARILYN
description: KOCH-Marilyn. Age 79, of West Hartford, died February 6, 1998. Widow of Herman, beloved mother of Dr. Lawrence W. Koch and his wife Deanna of Hartford, CT, Dr. Ronald B. Koch and his wife Paulette of Palm Beach, FL; five grandchildren; two great-grandchildren. Funeral services were held Sunday with interment in Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, NY.

title: Corrections
description: A headline on Thursday about the Tawana Brawley defamation trial referred imprecisely to a delay in testimony by the Rev. Al Sharpton. It came after an outburst by Mr. Sharpton's lawyer, but the reason for the delay was that an evidentiary hearing was continuing.

title: Robert Hughes Brisbane, 84, Historian of Early Civil Rights Years
description: Robert Hughes Brisbane, a retired social scientist and historian at Morehouse College who wrote about the civil rights movement in its early years, died on Jan. 23 at the Georgia Baptist Health Center in Atlanta. He was 84.

title: Lost Colossus Draws Closer To Resurrection; Plan Gains for Post Office To Be New Penn Station
description: ''Penn-syl-va-nia Station.'' Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan pronounces the syllables as if he were enunciating that magical destination over a loudspeaker in some faraway terminal. ''There was no such act of vandalism in the history of New York City as the destruction of the original Pennsylvania Station.''

title: Editorial Observer; Wrestling With the Ghosts of New Orleans
description: New Orleans is known for Mardi Gras, dancing in the streets and Cajun cooking.
