But beneath its festive facade, the city is having a nasty time with racial issues dating back to slavery that most cities have long since put behind them. The newest battle centers on a school board policy that encourages schools named for slave owners to take new names, on the theory that the old names are offensive to a predominantly black student body.

title: Carl Wilson, A Beach Boys Founder, 51
description: Carl Wilson, who helped form the Beach Boys as a teen-ager and played lead guitar and sang with the group for more than three decades, died on Saturday in Los Angeles, where he lived. He was 51.

title: A Maverick Builds a New Supercomputer in a PC World
description: In the arcane world inhabited by the builders of the world's fastest computers, Burton Smith is the last man standing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISBERG, JAKOB
description: WEISBERG-Jakob. Born March 20, 1899, died Februay 7, 1998, leaving behind Evelyne, Julie, Michele, Babette, Jaime, Rachel, Brad, Ross, John. We loved him. Funeral, Riverside Chapel, Mount Vernon, Monday, 9:30 AM, February 9.

title: Only One Arab Nation Endorses U.S. Threat of Attack on Iraq
description: Among the Persian Gulf war allies who fought to drive Iraqi troops out of Kuwait in 1991, only Syria among Arab nations has flatly declared that a new attack on Iraq now would be unwarranted. But with the exception of Kuwait, no Arab nation has endorsed the American threats of military action, despite the assurances that Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said she had received on her recent visit to the Middle East.

title: Appreciate Jordan, And Don't Rush Bryant
description: The Michael Procession left at about 10 last night, parting a sea of photographers and believers on its way toward the freight elevator at Madison Square Garden. Wife and children and legend were sandwiched between a security guard with a circa-1980 frizzy perm and another important-feeling fellow with a walkie-talkie, who whispered: ''Jordan is at the elevator. He's about to go down. Copy?''

title: Hackl Aims For 3d Gold In the Luge
description: George Hackl of Germany took another step toward his third straight Olympic gold medal in men's luge, clocking the fastest time for the third straight run with only one run remaining today in Nagano, Japan.

title: Region to Get Clinics Giving Specialty Care
description: Montefiore Medical Center has teamed up with a for-profit company in a $100 million deal to open a string of 24-hour-a-day clinics devoted to cancer care and treatment of H.I.V. and AIDS in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Friedrich Kessler, 96, Law Professor
description: Friedrich Kessler, a former professor at the Yale Law School who was an authority on contracts, comparative law and jurisprudence, died on Jan. 21 at Alta Bates Hospital in Berkeley, Calif. He was 96 and lived in Berkeley.

title: Jordan Stars One Last Time (Probably)
description: A brush with the flu left Michael Jordan's body a bit achy and numb. And yet, he could still feel the significance of the moment playing out beneath the pinwheel ceiling of Madison Square Garden last night.

title: Canadian Indians Win a Ruling Vindicating Their Oral History
description: In the early time, long ago, an Indian maiden was taken into the sky. When she came back to the land, the man who took her turned into a grizzly bear. Her three brothers searched for her but found the bear first and killed it without realizing that it was their sister's husband. They brought the skin to where the river calls back the salmon every year. The Gitxsan people have been in Kispiox ever since.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WECKER, BARRY
description: WECKER-Barry. Died peacefully on February 7, 1998, after a long battle with lung cancer. Beloved husband of Debbie. Loving father of Jason. Adoring uncle to Cody and Tyler. Loving and loved brother to Roni and Howard. Legions of friends and family mourn him and his premature death. He will be profoundly missed. In lieu of flowers and food, contributions may be sent to Sloan Kettering-Thoracic Oncology. Funeral services 12:30 PM, Monday, at Riverside.

title: The Neediest Cases; Helping Others as Thanks for the Help He Received
description: He came to New York at 12 to join his parents, who had emigrated from Colombia six years earlier. He was the reason they had left behind well-paid jobs in Cali, where his father was a policeman and his mother a department store sales clerk. Speaking little English, his parents took cleaning jobs, but knowing that their son would do better made the long hours and meager pay easier to accept.

title: NBC to Seek Affiliates' Aid To Help Pay Costs of 'E.R.'
description: NBC plans to seek contributions from its affiliates to help pay the soaring costs of ''E.R.,'' television's most-watched program, as networks re-examine their economic relationships with the stations that broadcast their programs.

title: U.S. Losing Battle on Control Of Data Encryption, Study Says
description: The Clinton Administration is losing its battle to increase international controls over how reliably computer data can be scrambled to insure privacy, according to a report scheduled to be released Monday by an independent research group.

title: Tug of War And Words; Two Fixtures of the City Battle to See Which Will Remain Standing
description: For 33 years, The San Francisco Examiner and The San Francisco Chronicle have been locked in an increasingly unhappy marriage of convenience.

title: Mason Denies Charges In Statutory Rape Case
description: Anthony Mason was released from jail on $20,000 bail last night after being arraigned in Queens Criminal Court on charges of statutory rape, sexual abuse and endangering the welfare of a child. Afterward, his lawyer flatly denied that Mason had committed any wrongdoing.

title: Rutgers's Hodgson Plays Like a Coach's Dream
description: Rutgers forward Rob Hodgson does not mind being called a coach's son. He embraces the term; more than a label, it is his essence.

title: Don't Let Russia Derail NATO Expansion; Marshall Plan Model
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANA, RICHARD
description: DANA-Richard. On February 7, 1998. He wrote and directed radio programs for many years before moving to Young & Rubicam Advertising Agency as a Creative Supervisor. In subsequent years he directed productions and taught communications and acting at Manchester Community College in CT. He then became a professional actor appearing on television, in films, on stage and in commercials. Husband of the late Mildred Dana he is survived by his daughter Barbara Dana Arkin; three grandsons Anthony, Matthew and Adam Arkin, and one great-granddaughter Molly Arkin. Services Tuesday, 12 noon, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: Police Cameras in the Park
description: Even though there is generally no expectation of privacy in a public space, most people expect freedom from government monitoring when they eat lunch on a park bench or stroll down a street. The growing use of police video monitors in New York City may threaten the free and anonymous nature of public space.

title: Straddling Old and New, From Classics to Computers
description: The pianist Ursula Oppens is generally thought of as a new-music specialist, and in her recitals over the last two decades has proved an eloquent advocate for a range of modern styles. But Ms. Oppens has always played standard repertory as well, and her performances have usually been insightful and clarifying.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLEMENTS, BEN
description: CLEMENTS-Ben. Died in Jacksonville, FL, January 31, 1998. Artist and former Chairman of Art Department of NYC High School of Art and Design. Survived by daughter Ellen Diamond and son Steve Clements.

title: Moving From One Mystery to Another
description: It's a snappy phrase: ''Legal While Moving.'' But there was nothing frivolous about the hourlong dance of that title that Stefa Zawerucha presented on Wednesday night at Dance Theater Workshop. This was a serious effort. And one of the things that made it spellbinding, and sometimes unsettling, was the fact that it was often impossible to say just what Ms. Zawerucha was being serious about.

title: Offerings Scheduled This Week For Equity and Convertible Debt
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DELMHORST, MARGARET MCGILL
description: DELMHORST-Margaret McGill. On February 5, 1998, in Stonington, CT, in her 92nd year. Wife of the late Berton J. Delmhorst, mother of Arthur M. Delmhorst of Riverside, CT; George B. Delmhorst of Brooklyn, NY; and John R. Delmhorst of Fairfield, CT. Also survived by a sister Georgiana McG. Hull of Bedford Village, NY, and grandchildren Dwight, Kristina, Jennifer, Robert, Frederic and James. She was President of the Alumnae Association and Trustee of The Packer Collegiate Institute, President of the Women's Auxiliary of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, and Trustee of the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences. An avid sportswoman, gracious gardener, lover of literature and opera, she is loved by all who knew her. A memorial service will be held at the United Church in Stonington, CT, on Thursday, February 12, at 2 PM. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, contributions be made to Packer, 170 Joralemon Street, Brooklyn, NY 11201 or The Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 1000 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn, NY 11225.

title: New Yorker Grammarian
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORLEY, JAMES T.
description: MORLEY-James T. ''Bud'' passed away on February 5, 1998 at the age of 84 in Boynton Beach, FL. Mr. Morley is survived by his wife of fifty-seven years, the former Margot Zimmer and his children Karen Brennan of Salt Lake City, Utah, Mary Pat Ware of Tucson, Arizona, William J. Morley of Larchmont, New York, and James T. Morley, Jr., of Newtown, CT, nine grandchildren and three great grandchildren. Funeral Mass will be held Tuesday, February 10, 1998, at 10:30 A.M. at St. Augustine's Catholic Church, Larchmont, New York. Interment to follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, New York.

title: Mad-Cow Disease, From Cattle to Man
description: Can mad-cow disease, the drolly named, mysterious, incurable, inevitably fatal ailment that struck England's cows in the 1980's, spread to humans? You will not learn the answer tomorrow night, but through the good offices of ''Nova,'' you should come away with an understanding of the provocative lines that scientists are exploring in quest of one. ''The Brain Eater'' begins and ends with the recent death of an 18-year-old Englishman named Stephen Churchill. He had suffered from hallucinations and jerky movements that resembled Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, a brain ailment in the same family as mad-cow disease.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COOLEY, GEORGE W.
description: COOLEY-George W. In memory and celebration of the life of George W. Cooley. Born Buffalo NY 2/9/26. Died NYC 3/8/97. On his first birthday in Paradise.

title: Don't Let Russia Derail NATO Expansion; Intra-Alliance Tensions
description: To the Editor:

title: Pets in Public Housing?
description: To the Editor:

title: Jordan Didn't Bite
description: Not one of the 17,000 hors d'oeuvres at the Saturday night party at the new Michael Jordan Steakhouse in Grand Central Terminal was eaten by the restaurant's namesake. His wife, Juanita, told the crowd that he was in bed, resting up for the N.B.A. All-Star Game on Sunday. But at least one fan says he was in fact at Life, a Greenwich Village dance club. The woman said: ''The friend I was with said: 'He has this restaurant opening tonight. Why is he here?' ''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHATZ, DORIS
description: SCHATZ-Doris. Loving wife of Sam. Adored mother of Barbara (Jerry) Fine and Steven. Beloved grandmother of Ken (Dionne), Rob and Doug Fine, Jonathan and Emily Schatz. Loving sister of Anne Kranes. Funeral service Tuesday, 1:45, at I.J. Morris, Dix Hills, NY.

title: Executive Changes
description: AGCO CORP., a farm-machinery maker in Atlanta, named John Shumejda president and chief operating officer.

title: On My Mind; A Package For Saddam
description: Now we are being told in TV and print stories and commentary that the United States will not be able to knock out Saddam Hussein's biological warfare bombs and that the Iraqis would never use them because they could blow back in their faces.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRIEF, HENRY
description: BRIEF-Henry. Loving husband of Rosalie. Devoted father of Andrew and Judith. Proud grandfather of Rachel. Funeral services Tuesday, 2 PM, at Wantagh Jewish Center, 3710 Woodbine Ave., Wantagh.

title: Treasury Prices Drop as Traders Await 3 Days of Auctions
description: Bond prices ended lower yesterday, weakened by selling ahead of the Treasury's quarterly refunding auction of $35 billion in new debt this week.

title: Head of Board of Education Offers Plan to Require School Uniforms
description: The president of the Board of Education, William C. Thompson Jr., proposed yesterday that the 550,000 students in New York City's elementary schools be required to wear uniforms beginning in the fall of 1999, unless the parents at an individual school vote as a group to opt out of the policy.

title: The Neediest Cases; 3 Brothers In Search Of a Home Find Love
description: By American standards, at least, Ricky Valerio's request was a reasonable one: the 8-year-old foster child wanted to grow up in a big house with two parents, a dog and a backyard. But for Maritza Batista, the caseworker for Ricky and his two brothers, fulfilling it seemed like a pipe dream.

title: Crispin Porter Wins Anti-Smoking Work
description: The State of Florida has named Crispin Porter & Bogusky in Miami to develop an anti-smoking campaign aimed at teen-agers. The assignment is a two-year project with billings estimated at $30 million to $40 million annually.

title: Accounts
description: * Hollywood Entertainment Corp., Wilsonville, Ore., to Cliff Freeman & Partners, New York, part of Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C., to handle advertising for the Hollywood Video retail chain, which had been handled by Suissa Miller Advertising, Santa Monica, Calif. Though billings were not disclosed, Adweek estimated them as $10 million to $20 million.

title: Man Moves Down the Marine Food Chain, Creating Havoc
description: AS overfishing depletes prized species like tuna, cod and swordfish, commercial fishermen are moving farther down oceanic food webs in search of a catch, a new study has found. If this quest is pursued to its logical end, scientists warn, it will lead to a wholesale collapse of marine ecosystems.

title: Father Faces Alcohol Charges In Son's Beer Party at Home
description: The invitation to the sweet-16 birthday celebration read: ''Open house party tonight. Bring money or alcohol. 4 Carol Place.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GENSEL, REV. JOHN GARCIA
description: GENSEL-Rev. John Garcia. Shepherds and music are companions, consecrated in time ever since that transcending moment of the Child in Swaddling Clothes under the Star. Little wonder then, that Pastor John Gensel would lead us around the Lord's table in melodies of prayer. ''The music of the Gospel leads us home,'' Fabernoted in his 'Pilgrim of the Night.' And John's shepherding formed a very wide circle. Heaven blessed him with a special charism, drawing friends, congregants, the lonely, the wandering and his special children-the 'shadow children' of his Town caught up in the trembling world of drugs and abandonment. He gave them hope! He gave them love! And, in so doing, stood so tall across the landscape of Daytop Village where he has served both as Trustee and Governor these many years. ''May the choirs of the angels receive him'' and may the prayerful support of us at Daytop serve to console his beloved Audrey and Family.

title: Where Marketing and Medicine Meet
description: Every fall, thousands of cardiologists from around the world gather to hear about inventive and sophisticated new devices for rooting out blockages in blood vessels that can cause heart attacks and other severe heart problems.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR RISES. The dollar strengthened against the mark and ended higher against most currencies on American economic vibrancy and tensions in the Middle East. In New York, the dollar cost 1.8167 marks, up from 1.8086.

title: U.S. to Shield Taxpayers on Spouses' Errors
description: The United States Treasury Department disclosed a plan today that is intended to protect people from being stuck with the tax bills of their delinquent spouses.

title: Science Watch; An All-Temperature Worm
description: Imagine animals that can calmly seek food in balmy currents of 72 degrees Fahrenheit while their metaphoric toes simmer in nearly 180-degree water. The Pompeii worm does it all the time, researchers report in the current issue of Nature.

title: Alda, on Science
description: For the first time in its sober 153-year history, Scientific American magazine has a celebrity on its cover. The digitized image of ALAN ALDA (the subject of a feature on computer animation) is no racier than the full-frontal shot of a microchip last June. And, unlike a cover close-up of a smoker some years ago, it cannot be mistaken for BILL CLINTON. ''People thought we were making a 'did not inhale' joke,'' said JOHN RENNIE, the editor. ''That may have been Republican wishful thinking. It was not a shot of Clinton.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CASTELLANOS, DON F.
description: CASTELLANOS-Don F. February 10, 1997. A companion and friend, he is now at rest. May his memory be for a blessing. Dan Wollenziehn

title: Brooks, From Miracle on Ice to Warm-Up Act
description: In some ways, the scene was familiar to Herb Brooks. The modest-sized hockey rink in the modest-sized city was filled with flag-waving fans who were cheering for the underdog home team in the Olympic Winter Games. That was how it was in 1980, his last Olympic Games, when Brooks coached the United States to a gold medal in Lake Placid, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINTHAL, LEON
description: LEVINTHAL-Leon. The Board, Staff and Members of the Rosenthal YM-YWHA note with sadness the passing of Leon Levinthal, beloved father of our Assist. Exec. Dir., Michele Vernon. We extend our hearfelt condolences to the Levinthal/Vernon families. May he be for a blessing. Marsha Newman, President Joel B. Karpp, Exec. Director

title: From U.S. to Canada to Japan, Many Await Kariya's Next Move
description: The Paul Kariya situation is complicated, filled with permutations, all starting with his health.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place -- The St. Louis Phoenix; From Its Heartland Hub, T.W.A. Is Rising, but Wall St. Has Some Doubts
description: Last summer, Wall Street feared Trans World Airlines was headed for yet another emergency landing in bankruptcy court -- its third since 1992.

title: Attack on Clinton Nominee May Backfire on the G.O.P.
description: Conservative Republicans who have complained that President Clinton is trying to pack the courts with ''activist'' judges will have an opportunity to make their case this week as the Senate considers the nomination of Margaret M. Morrow to be a district judge in California.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Texas Instruments To End Chip Venture
description: Texas Instruments Inc. and Hitachi Ltd. of Japan will end their joint venture in producing dynamic random access memory, or D-RAM, computer chips from a plant in Richardson, Tex., because of weak memory-chip prices, the companies said yesterday.

title: Suicide and Disasters
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DELMHORST, MARGARET
description: DELMHORST - Margaret. The Brooklyn Botantic Garden Auxiliary mourns the death of Margaret Delmhorst, a Past President and friend whose ties with the Garden span five decades.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NORTON, THOMAS E.
description: NORTON-Thomas E. 63. Art consultant, author and former senior vice president and director of Sotheby's New York died suddenly on Saturday at the DartmouthHitchcock Medical Center in Lebanon, New Hampshire. A resident of Kennebunkport for the past four years, Mr. Norton was born in Portland, Maine on October 1, 1934 and grew up in the New York and New Jersey area. He was a son of Edward and Mary (Callan) Norton. He attended Fordham University where he received his BS degree in 1956. He then served two years with the US Army. Mr. Norton began his career at the Parke Bernet Galleries in New York in 1956, becoming a director and senior vice president of the merged Parke Bernet Sotheby Galleries in 1972 until his departure in 1981. A noted appraiser and art consultant until his death, Mr. Norton was the author of several books, including ''100 years of Collecting in America,'' in 1985. He is survived by his wife, Mary Louise (Mullin) Norton and a son, Andrew Edward Norton both of Kennebunkport and three sisters, Maureen Wolferse, Margaret Braun and Kathleen Larsen all of New Jersey and several nieces and nephews. Visiting hours will be from 4 to 6 PM on Wednesday at Bibber Memorial Chapel, 67 Summer Street, Kennebunk, ME. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held at 10 AM on Thursday at St. Martha's Church, Portland Road, Kennebunk. If friends desire, donations in Mr. Norton's memory can be made to the Cardigan Mountain School Faculty Endowment Fund, RR#

title: Arab Ambivalence About Iraq
description: Despite considerable coaxing of Arab allies in recent weeks, the Clinton Administration has failed to reassemble the coalition of nations that fought alongside America in the Persian Gulf war. Saudi Arabia is the latest country to rebuff Washington. Doing without the Saudi bases will complicate but not cripple America's ability to use air power against Iraq. But it means trouble for the long-term effort to contain Saddam Hussein and his program to develop weapons of mass destruction.

title: School-to-Work Programs Set Students Back; More Career Options
description: To the Editor:

title: FIRSTFEDERAL FINANCIAL ADDING FIRST SHENANGO BANCORP
description: The FirstFederal Financial Services Corporation agreed yesterday to buy the First Shenango Bancorp of New Castle, Pa., for $104 million in stock. FirstFederal, which has assets of $1.5 billion and is based in Wooster, Ohio, is buying First Shenango's $375 million in assets. FirstFederal will exchange 1.143 shares for each First Shenango share; based on Friday's closing price, that values First Shenango at $47.72 a share. First Shenango's stock soared $4.75 a share yesterday, to $43.25. Shares of FirstFederal, whose banking unit consists of Signal Bank and Summit Bank, fell $2, to $39.75.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HIRSCHHORN, ROSE
description: HIRSCHHORN-Rose. When in life you were at my side, all of life's whimseys I could abide. Experiencing some ease and emotional toleration, since you left there's been no joy or celebration. On this the anniversary of your leaving, there will never be any respite from my grieving. Herbert

title: Useful Invention Or Absolute Truth: What Is Math?
description: AT the top of the list of science's unanswered questions, like what is consciousness and how did life begin, is the deepest mystery of all: Why does the universe appear to follow mathematical laws?

title: On the Stand in the Brawley Trial, Sharpton Likens Himself to King
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton took the witness stand in the Tawana Brawley defamation trial today and, in often combative tones, testified that his actions and statements as one of Ms. Brawley's advisers belonged to an honorable tradition of civil rights advocacy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, SARA P. (NEE BRADLEY)
description: SMITH-Sara P. (nee Bradley). Beloved wife of Richard G. Dear sister of Frank J., Josephine Cali, Eileen Steuer, Edmund, Jacqueline Berthelsen, Kathleen King and the late James and John. Also survived by many loving nieces and nephews. Reposing at the Martin A. Gleason Funeral Home, 149-20 Northern Blvd, Flushing. Mass of Christian Burial St. John Vianney RC Church, Wednesday 10 am. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. Visiting hours 2-5 and 7-10 pm.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOHNOP, BENJAMIN L., M.D.
description: KOHNOP-Benjamin L., M.D. On February 9. Age 87. Retired physician at NYU Medical Center. Loving husband of Pearl, brother of Emma Shapiro and the late Sam, beloved uncle, grand-uncle and great grand-uncle. He will be greatly missed by those nieces and nephews who were the joy of his life. Services at Riverside Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave., Wednesday, February 11, 12 Noon.

title: Israel's Chief Rabbis Reject Call By Non-Orthodox on Conversion
description: Intensifying the bitter debate over ''who is a Jew,'' Israel's Chief Rabbinate today categorically ruled out any cooperation with the non-Orthodox branches of Judaism on conversions and religious rites, but stopped short of overtly throwing out a proposed compromise.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIOVINE, ANNE SHERIDAN
description: GIOVINE-Anne Sheridan. On February 8, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Louis Edward Giovine, MD. Dear mother of Edward, Philip and Laura Benedetto. Also survived by eight grandchildren. Reposing at the Martin A. Gleason Funeral Home, 10-25 150th Street, Whitestone. Mass of Christian Burial St. Lukes Church Wednesday at 10:15AM. Visiting hours are Tuesday 2-5 and 7-9.

title: LEWINSKY ORDERED BEFORE GRAND JURY ON TIES TO CLINTON
description: Government prosecutors have summoned Monica S. Lewinsky to appear before a Federal grand jury on Thursday, a significant escalation of the battle over Ms. Lewinsky's testimony now that immunity talks have broken down.

title: Patterns
description: Visual Magic in Windows

title: Clooney Defers Concert
description: Because of illness, the singer Rosemary Clooney has postponed a concert that was to take place at Carnegie Hall tomorrow night. Her concert has been rescheduled for June 1 at 8 P.M.

title: Being Torn Between Two Loves
description: She had an opportunity to try out for a hockey team, or go on a honeymoon. And the decision might elicit the following question: What's love got to do with it?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSMITH, JAMES A., JR.
description: GOLDSMITH-James A., Jr. Died suddenly at home in Hillsborough, Ca. on Febuary 7, 1998. He was 91 years old. He is survived by his wife, Irene T. Goldsmith, his children, MaryAnne Schwalbe of N.Y.C., James A. Goldsmith III of Briarcliff Manor N.Y., Jeanne Taylor and Marc Ducharme of Atlanta, Ga., Denise Omundson of Portland Or., sixteen grandchildren, six great grandchildren and two sisters, Katherine Lowenstein of N.Y.C. and Bertha Bernstein of Los Angeles, Ca. Born in WilkesBarre, Pa., he was raised in N.Y.C., attended the Horace Mann School and received a diploma from the Taft School in Watertown, Ct. He retired as President of Hess, Goldsmith, which was sold to Burlington Industries. He then owned and operated Barnum Travel in Westport, Ct. After selling the travel agency, he became President of the Westport National Bank. He was active in local and national Republican politics; he was a Past President and Director of the Jewish Guild for the Blind in N.Y. He moved to California in 1966 and became the Branch Manager of the H.Liebes Stores. In the 1970's, he brought the dream of the San Mateo Garden Center to a reality. He served for many years on the Board of Directors of the San Mateo County Fair. Donations in his name can be made to the San Mateo Garden Center, 605 Parkside Way, San Mateo, Ca. 94402 or the the American Heart Association.

title: Metro Business; I.B.M. Kingston Site Is Sold to Developer
description: After two years of delays, the developer Alan Ginsberg yesterday bought the International Business Machines' Ulster Business Complex, a network of 27 buildings on 257 acres outside Kingston, N.Y., for more than $20 million.

title: What to Look For
description: FIGURE SKATING -- PAIRS, FREE SKATING

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Company Earnings listing of Business Day on Saturday about the Host Marriott Services Corporation misstated the company's stock symbol. It is HMS, not HMT.

title: U.S. Jewish Group Sets Up Office In Berlin as Sentinel Against Bias
description: Reflecting a gradual resurgence of Jewish life in Germany, the American Jewish Committee opened a permanent office in Berlin today at a site once owned by a Jewish family that fled the Nazis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FAIRCHILD, HELEN WING
description: FAIRCHILD-Helen Wing. Age 76. Of Hobe Sound, Florida. Died Sunday February 8, 1998 at her residence in Hobe Sound, Florida. She was an interior designer in New York, Jamaica, West Indies and South Florida area for many years. She was an active environmentalist and loving supporter of fine arts. Survivors include her son, William S. Fairchild, her daughter, Pamela Van Beek, two sisters and seven grandchildren. For information, Young and Prill Funeral Home, Stuart, Florida.

title: White House Aide Questioned in Lewinsky Matter
description: A young White House aide has told Federal investigators that Monica S. Lewinsky confided in her about an alleged sexual relationship with President Clinton.

title: British Airways Profit Hurt by Strong Pound
description: British Airways P.L.C. said yesterday that its profit fell 24.5 percent in its third quarter, eroded by the strong British pound and lingering effects from a flight attendants' strike last summer. The carrier, Europe's largest, said net income for the three months that ended on Dec. 31 fell to $:71 million ($117 million), from $:94 million a year earlier. It was a third consecutive quarterly decline for the airline, usually among the world's most profitable.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Pop CD's; Flirting With Country, Jazz, Pop, Whatever
description: The music business is stratified and defined by genre; the market-ready notions of rock, country and jazz provide templates of how to get music across to listeners. But it makes you wonder about the future of the business when three of popular music's best records are utterly unclassifiable. All of the below, varied as they are, could probably fit on the Americana radio format, which at its best is an oddments bin for songwriters. But how to describe the taste of someone who likes these albums? To whom does a record company aim them? Luckily, most of us only have to listen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORRIS, GRINNELL
description: MORRIS-Grinnell. Died February 5, in Naples, Florida. Survived by his wife Cornelia and sons Grinnell Jr, Stephen, Frederic and Daniel. Also by his brother John. A memorial service will be held on Sunday March 8, at St. Johns Church, Cold Spring Harbor, L.I. at 1pm. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to Planned Parenthood of Suffolk County, Smithtown or St. Johns Church, Cold Spring Harbor.

title: Hospital in Queens Loses Body of Premature Baby
description: The body of a premature baby was lost by a Queens hospital last Saturday, an official with the hospital said yesterday, and a lawyer for the 15-year-old mother said that the girl intended to sue the hospital.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOCK, NORMAN
description: BLOCK-Norman. The Board of Directors, officers, and employees of LIVE Entertainment records with sorrow the passing of the father of our good friend and colleague, Bill Block. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Bill and all in his family who grieve his father's passing as do we. Mark Curcio, CEO Amir Malin, President

title: World News Briefs; Jesse Jackson in Kenya In Effort to End Violence
description: For the second time in three months, the Rev. Jesse Jackson visited Kenya this week as President Clinton's special envoy in an effort to defuse ethnic tensions and keep Kenya's democratic reforms on track.

title: Talk of the Town? Not Yet, at Least
description: It is mentioned in the Random House spring catalogue, next to a postage-stamp-size picture of the cover, which carries a photograph of WILLIAM SHAWN. But the subject of ''Here But Not Here: A Love Story'' is a delicate one, which may explain why so many people are so reluctant to talk about it.

title: Seeking Honest Expression, And Therapy, From His Art
description: It is hard to imagine a more dispiriting evening of dance than the one presented by Doug Merrifield and Tim Martin on Friday night at the Clark Studio Theater at Lincoln Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HINDEN, SOLOMON R. (SAM).
description: HINDEN-Solomon R. (Sam). Cherished husband of Ada (nee Trachtenberg), loving father of Michael and David, devoted grandfather of Josh and the late Danny, loving father-in-law of Betsy and Lucie, dear uncle and brother-in-law to many. Services ''Gutterman-Musicant'' Hackensack, NJ Wednesday 12 noon. 1-800-522-0588.

title: Washington's Information Wars
description: Everyone believes that information is power, so it is no surprise that in these turbulent times it is a matter of combat in Washington. Balanced political decisions and, ultimately, the authority of the law both depend on full public disclosure of the best available information. The White House's weekend counteroffensive against Kenneth Starr was dazzling as a matter of tactics. But it is essential to remember its two real objectives. One is to change the subject from President Clinton's behavior and truthfulness. The other, as with all White House leak crusades in any Administration, is to dam the flow of information to the American people.

title: Police-Kidnapper Links Seen in Mexico
description: For years, the authorities have scoffed at charges by businessmen and human rights activists that the police were protecting the kidnapping gangs that terrorize Morelos, the state just south of Mexico City.

title: U.N. Chief Cancels Trip to Mideast as a Hunt for Compromise Continues
description: With France, Russia and the Arab League engaging in intense consultations to find a compromise that would avert an American military strike on Iraq, Secretary General Kofi Annan today canceled a long-planned trip to the Middle East in order to remain at United Nations headquarters and help work toward a peaceful solution of the Iraq crisis.

title: Once Cast Out, a Top Clinton Adviser Is Back in the Game and Enjoying It
description: One year ago, Paul E. Begala was teaching college in Austin, Tex., cast out of President Clinton's political circles for perceived disloyalty.

title: Challenge to Police Union Leadership
description: In an unusual challenge to top officials of the city's largest police union, a group of dissident delegates from the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association demanded full disclosure yesterday of the union's financial records and threatened to begin a drive to overthrow its executive board.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TIERNEY, GEORGE P.
description: TIERNEY-George P. Of Paramus, N.J. On February 7, 1998. Beloved husband of Doreen (Dorina) (nee Laforest). Devoted father of Alice Kennedy and her husband Bill of Highland Lakes, N.J., Renee Tierney and her fiance Drew DeVita. Loving grandfather of William P. Kennedy and Megan L. Kennedy. Dear brother of William P. Tierney of Montvale, N.J. and Lucille Wilson of Paramus. N.J. Dear stepson of Marie Tierney of Cliffside Park, N.J. Funeral services at 11AM on Wednesday from Vander Plaat Memorial Home, S113 Farview Avenue, Paramus. N.J. and 11:30AM Funeral Mass at Our Lady of Visitation R.C. Church. Interment George Washington Memorial Park. Family will receive friends Tuesday 2 to 4PM and 7 to 9PM. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to Deborah Hospital, P.O. Box 820, Browns Mills, N.J. 08015.

title: Pataki's Choice of Budget Chief Is Cheered by Fiscal Conservatives
description: In a move cheered by fiscal conservatives who had begun to question whether Gov. George E. Pataki was one of them, the Governor today named the man who has headed his effort to streamline government regulations as his new budget director.

title: America Online to Raise Fee For Unlimited Use to $21.95
description: In a major defection from the standard monthly price of $19.95 for Internet access, America Online, whose 11 million members make up more than half the home Internet market in the United States, announced yesterday that it was increasing its charge for unlimited access to $21.95.

title: Quietly, Just in Case, Doing Homework on Impeachment
description: With a growing sense that the independent counsel Kenneth W. Starr would be more likely to refer any Presidential wrongdoing he discovers to Congress than to a criminal proceeding, House Republicans have quietly begun to prepare for possible impeachment action.

title: Council Members Challenge Mayor's Attacks on CUNY
description: The City University of New York battle intensified yesterday, as several City Council members called Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's attacks on the university a diversion from his failure to make good on his own promise to improve the public schools. For their part, the Mayor's office pledged to investigate the university further.

title: Health Watch; Battling the Super Germs
description: SOAP and water and elbow grease can go just so far in getting rid of germs on household surfaces. But disinfectants may have their limitations, too.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISENBERG, ELIAS
description: EISENBERG-Elias. On February 8, 1998. Devoted husband of 58 years, survived by his wife Charlotte. Loving father to Max and Norman, cherished brother to Israel, Leon and Jenny and adored grandfather of Jamie Lavea, Daniel and Stevie. He leaves us in his 88th year with a legacy of love, admiration, honor and integrity. The family will observe shiva Monday evening through Sunday morning at 99-05 63rd Drive, Apt 1L, Rego Park, New York 11374.

title: School-to-Work Programs Set Students Back; Post-Sputnik Job Bust
description: To the Editor:

title: Researchers Paint New Portrait of an Ancient People
description: AS the last of the great civilizations of antiquity to be discovered, the Indus culture of the third millennium B.C. has long suffered in comparison with its more illustrious contemporaries to the west. Its baked-brick cities, without splendid palaces and unadorned by images of mighty rulers and triumphant battles, might evoke wonder but not the awe of archeologists whose eyes had gazed upon the pyramids and temples of Egypt or the royal cemeteries of Mesopotamia.

title: Yet Another O. J. Simpson Moment
description: The spirit of Brentwood past came face-to-face with the media circus of Brentwood present today as none other than O. J. Simpson drove up across the street from the home of Monica S. Lewinsky's father and chatted briefly with the reporters and photographers camped out there.

title: Senate Urged To Approve Expansion Of NATO
description: Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright began the Administration's final push today for Senate approval of NATO expansion, warning Senators not to complicate the effort by trying to delay a possible second round of expansion.

title: Music in Review
description: A Genre as Durable As It Is Mischievous

title: Chess; Ukrainian and Israeli Share First Place at Reggio Emilia
description: The traditional New Year's International Tournament in Reggio Emilia, Italy, the 40th running of the series, ended in a tie for first place between the grandmasters Dimitri Komarov of Ukraine and Leonid Judasin of Israel. Each scored 7 1/2-3 1/2.

title: Storm? At-Large Bid? Don't Even Bring It Up
description: Coach Fran Fraschilla arrived yesterday at the coach's luncheon looking relaxed. A victory over a formidable opponent such as No.15 West Virginia can do that to a guy. But despite the St. John's 77-69 defeat of the Mountaineers on Saturday night, talk of the Red Storm's chances of getting an at-large bid to the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament remained off-limits.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GAIR, HARRY A.
description: GAIR-Harry A. Recalling a wise, respected and never to be forgotten polymath into whose grace I came sixty-five years ago. Herbert

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RYAN, THOMAS
description: RYAN-Thomas. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Thomas E. Ryan, associated with The Times from May 1, 1966, until retiring on February 1, 1971.

title: German Picks Up Third Gold In a Row
description: To the untrained eye, the luge competition resembles a lottery on ice with its high speeds and nearly identical times. But how often does anyone win the lottery three times in a row?

title: When a Bird's Hormones Are Raging
description: WHAT prompts a male (bird) with a reputation for monogamy and paternal behavior to place his primary relationship and offspring at risk by soliciting the attentions of other females? Could it be those raging hormones, in this case, the sex hormone testosterone, that undermines a male's interest in caring for his young?

title: Whitman Plans Her Biggest Spending Rise
description: With New Jersey's coffers overflowing with extra tax revenue from the economic boom, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman will recommend raising spending by about $1 billion in her new state budget, the largest increase since she took office four years ago, top aides to the Governor said today.

title: Jurors Listen to Angry Calls Taped Hours Before Killings
description: In taped telephone conversations played today at the double murder trial of a onetime lottery winner, jurors heard a hysterical woman pleading with her former lover to stop calling with threats to take away the daughter he claimed to have fathered -- and then daring him to come get the girl.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OTTOMANELLI, JOSEPH
description: OTTOMANELLI-Joseph. On February 7, 1998. Founder of Ottomanelli Brothers Food Corp. Beloved husband of the late Angelica. Loving father of Jerry, Nick, Frank, Joseph Jr. and Frances. Also survived by 13 grandchildren and three great grandchildren. Cherished brother of six and of the late Jennie Bosangue. Reposing Tuesday 2-5 and 7-10 PM, James Romanelli Stephen Funeral Home, 89-01 Rockaway Boulevard, Ozone Park, NY. Mass of Christian Burial, Wednesday, St. Helen's R.C.C., 9:45 AM. Entombment St. John's Cloister, Middle Village, NY.

title: Indonesia Considers a Radical Shift For Currency, Hitching It to Dollar
description: Scrambling to contain inflation and control social unrest, Indonesia is actively considering a radical change in its monetary system that would fix the Indonesian currency's value to the dollar and essentially eliminate the central bank.

title: Insurers Saying Utility Vehicles Need Redesign
description: The auto insurance industry urged auto makers today to redesign sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks, after concluding that these vehicles increased the risk of death for other road users while providing little if any additional protection for their own occupants.

title: Plan Approved for a Kennedy Rail Link
description: The Federal Government approved a plan this evening to use money from a passenger ticket tax to build a rail line that would connect Kennedy International Airport with rail lines at Jamaica Station in Queens, clearing the last major obstacle to a project that officials hope will provide a cheaper and quicker way to reach the airport from Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HURSON, RITA
description: HURSON-Rita. On February 8, 1998, at her home in Irvington-onHudson, NY. Cherished wife of Jack Hurson, former Mayor of Irvington, and beloved mother of Christine Hurson of Irvington and John Hurson of New York City. She is also survived by her brother, Edward McCann of Washington, D.C., and sisters, Margaret Whitty of Potomac, MD., and Mary Catherine Delaney of Houston, TX. She was for 15 years associated with the Volunteer Program at The Metropolitan Museum of Art, consecutively as a docent, Chairman of Disabled Visitor Services, Secretary-Treasurer of Volunteers, and finally Chairman of Volunteers from 1994-1996. A woman of exceptional grace, honor and love, she will be forever in our hearts. A wake will be held at Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home in Dobbs Ferry from 2:30-4:30 and from 7-9 PM on Wednesday, February 11. The funeral will take place at Transfiguration Church, 268 South Broadway, Tarrytown, on February 12, at 11 AM. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, donations be made to The Metropolitan Museum of Art for the Volunteer Program.

title: Elderly Seek Longer Life, Regardless
description: RESEARCHERS posed a hypothetical question to several hundred people in their 80's and 90's who were hospitalized with conditions like cancer and heart disease: would you rather live for a year in your present condition or less time in excellent health?

title: Student Center as Mall And Visionary Jukebox
description: Last week American architecture took a step forward. Rem Koolhaas, the 53-year-old Dutch architect, was awarded the commission to design the Campus Center at the Illinois Institute of Technology in Chicago. If you're wearing a hat, now is the time to toss it into the air. The $25 million project, which will house a mix of functions in a low-rise structure of glass and concrete, will be the most innovative building to go up in downtown Chicago in a generation.

title: A Mixed Marriage of Ghosts and Jazz
description: Zhongmei Li specializes in the merging of styles that range from the traditional dances she learned in her native China to the Western modern dance she studied in New York. In her new ''Portrait Enchantress,'' the centerpiece of a program presented by the Zhongmei Dance Company on Saturday night at the Brooklyn Center at Brooklyn College, Ms. Li pushes that goal to the limits. The dance is set to a new jazz score by Wynton Marsalis, music that is just about as far from her roots, and as fashionably multicultural, as it is possible to get.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COSTELLO, ALICE M.
description: COSTELLO-Alice M. On February 8, 1998. Over forty years service at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital from where she retired as Nurse Manager. Beloved daughter of the late Bernard and Madeline Costello. Will be missed by many dear friends and associates. Visiting Tuesday 2-4 and 7-9 PM at the Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 4th Ave, Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday 9:30 AM Our Lady of Angels Church.

title: Clinton Opens Campaign for Quick Action on Social Security
description: President Clinton began a yearlong effort today to persuade both parties to deal with Social Security's problems, saying that if Congress and the White House reached an agreement next year, then ''relatively modest steps'' would be enough to assure the program's health well into the future.

title: COLLEGES: MEN'S BASKETBALL
description: Iona 102, Canisius 66

title: Spokesman Who Wants To Stay Out Of the Loop
description: In an unusual admission for a White House press secretary, Michael D. McCurry said he was working hard at being out of the loop on the Monica Lewinsky case.

title: Plagiarism Suit Over 'Amistad' Is Withdrawn
description: Barbara Chase-Riboud, the author who accused Steven Spielberg and his production company, Dreamworks SKG, of ''brazenly'' stealing from her work to make the movie ''Amistad,'' tonight dropped her plagiarism suit against the company and praised the movie as ''a splendid piece of work.''

title: Doctors' Research Ties; Fears on Transplants
description: To the Editor:

title: Execution Without All the Attention
description: Death penalty opponents had hoped that the case of Karla Faye Tucker, the 38-year-old murderer whose sex, religious conversion and self-promotion sparked inordinate interest and opposition to her execution last week in Texas, would give momentum to their movement.

title: One Barney's Suitor Down And One Waiting in Wings
description: Well over two years into the bankruptcy case of Barney's, it seems that only one suitor has a serious interest in acquiring the luxury retailer and restoring it to financial health.

title: Gulf Canada Chief Resigns and Stock Falls
description: The president and chief executive of Gulf Canada Resources is stepping down, the company said today, causing shares of the company to fall.

title: Russian Teen-Ager Has Medal Look
description: Before leaving Russia, the 56-year-old coach gave the 17-year-old student a lesson about figure skating's solar system. The European championships are on one planet, Aleksei Mishin told Aleksei Yagudin, and the Winter Olympics are on another planet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUSSELL, DR. MAURICE V.
description: RUSSELL-Dr. Maurice V. The Faculty, Advisory Council, Alumni Association, students, and staff of the Columbia University School of Social Work (CUSSW) record, with profound sorrow, the tragic and untimely death of Dr. Maurice V. Russell on February 9, 1998. A Trustee Emeritus of Columbia University, Dr. Russell was a longtime member of the Advisory Council of the School of Social Work, a past member of the CUSSW Alumni Association Board of Directors, and current Co-Chair of the School's 1998 Centennial Honorary Committee. Presented with the University's Alumni Medal in 1993, Dr. Russell won national recognition throughout the social work community for his extraordinary contributions to professional education, health care agency boards, and, in his role as President, the Kenworthy-Swift Foundation. He earned both the M.S. and Ed.D. degrees at Columbia and, during his career, was the recipient of many awards for distinguished achievement. The Maurice V. Russell Professorship of Social Policy and Social Work Practice was established at the School of Social Work in 1994. An individidual of great warmth and good humor, he was esteemed by his professional colleagues and cherished by his legion of friends. Dr. Russell will be remembered with love, respect, and admiration by those whose lives he touched. Plans for a memorial service will be announced at a later date. Ronald A. Feldman, Dean, Columbia University School of Social Work Charles P. Gershenson, Ph.D., Chair, CUSSW Adisory Council Frances M. Curtis, President, CUSSW Alumni Association

title: Waiting for the Big One at Demo 98. And Waiting.
description: THE hope of catching a glimpse of the Next Big Thing or selling stock in it sent about 800 computer folk, venture capitalists and reporters to Indian Wells, Calif., last week. Like its predecessors, the Demo 98 conference focused on live demonstrations with the bracing potential for embarrassing public failure.

title: Imprisoned Gang Leader Ordered Killings at Neighborhood Football Game, U.S. Says
description: Federal prosecutors said yesterday that a shooting that killed two men in the Bronx during an annual Thanksgiving football game last year was ordered by an imprisoned gang leader in North Carolina who wanted to prevent one of the men from testifying against him.

title: Johnson Gets Worse With Rest and May Miss Game
description: It is not like Larry Johnson to beg off from practice. But today, the player with the pain threshold similar to Wile E. Coyote's could not fight through the inflammation that has lingered in his left ankle since he sprained it on Nov. 23.

title: If NATO Doesn't Grow
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHATZKIN, BERNARD (BARNEY)
description: SHATZKIN - Bernard (Barney). Mentor, colleague, esteemed partner, wise counselor, dear and cherished friend. Our heartfelt condolences to Annabelle, Leila, Blackie and the family. Sheldon and Hedda Rudoff

title: Jim Henson Hires Former Fox Executive
description: In a bid to build a bigger empire in the world of family entertainment, the Jim Henson Company announced the appointment yesterday of Margaret Loesch to a newly created position as president of Jim Henson Television and at the same time said that the company planned to create a new family-oriented cable network.

title: Indignant About Leaks, President to Ask Court To Punish Prosecutors : Ex-Intern Said to Get Subpoena From Starr
description: WASHINGTON  Monica Lewinsky is scheduled to appear Thursday before a federal grand jury investigating allegations that President Bill Clinton had an affair with her and then asked her to lie about it.

title: Gotham's Newest Crime Stoppers: Cabbies
description: The Giuliani administration announced plans yesterday to give wireless phones to cabdrivers so they can call 911 to report crimes, fires and emergencies.

title: Film's Rising Star: New York; Independent Movies Spur the City's Celluloid Success
description: Larry Meistrich is not central casting's idea of a movie mogul. He wears torn jeans to the office. His two huge dogs -- both half chow-chow, half Samoyed, found abandoned on a film set -- wander around his lower Manhattan office, lapping water from a giant silver bowl and nuzzling up to visitors.

title: Write-Offs Result in a Loss At Dow Jones in 4th Quarter
description: Dow Jones & Company reported a big net loss yesterday for the fourth quarter, mostly because of a write-off connected to the reorganization of its financial information business.

title: A Weekend of Early Verdi in Concert
description: Though it was not planned, Carnegie Hall was the site of an early Verdi festival over the weekend. On Saturday night, the estimable Collegiate Chorale, with the Orchestra of St. Luke's and a fine roster of soloists, presented a concert performance of ''Nabucco,'' Verdi's third opera but his first significant and successful work. And on Sunday night, the Opera Orchestra of New York under its music director, Eve Queler, presented a concert performance of Verdi's seldom heard, French-text ''Jerusalem.''

title: Review/Fashion; To the Rescue of Men's Wear
description: The exits of Calvin Klein and Donna Karan for Milan left a sense of foreboding about the impact of the New York men's wear shows last week. But just as in the movies, though quite unexpectedly, the cavalry rode in from opposite directions at just the right moment. The white hats came in the form of Ralph Lauren, who in the past seemed close to hanging up his spurs, and John Bartlett, known to wound deeply with his provocative designs, who produced a collection of such delicate precision that his cut drew no blood.

title: Calling No Witnesses, Club Owner Rests Case
description: The lawyer for Peter Gatien, the prominent nightclub owner, rested his case yesterday without calling a single defense witness, saying that he believed he had shown through cross-examination that his client was not guilty of turning two of New York City's best-known nightclubs into virtual drug bazaars to increase their popularity and profitability.

title: Consuming Passion
description: Conferences on the world economy should be held in Calcutta or Lagos. Or at least Newark. Fewer fine minds might feel the need to travel. But those attending would get a closer sense of real world priorities. As it is, the splendid hotels, high fashion shops and millionaires on the ski slopes of Davos, Switzerland, provided the appropriate background for the harsh words that the First Lady had last week for American consumers and ''the messages of American culture.''

title: Alfonzo Gets Big Raise in One-Year Deal
description: The Mets and Edgardo Alfonzo, the third baseman they love, will not confront each other in a salary arbitration hearing on Friday. Nor will they enter into a multiyear contract in the near future. The one-year deal they agreed to yesterday will have to suffice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUBICH, BERNICE
description: LUBICH-Bernice. On Saturday, February 7, 1998, at her home in New York City after a long and valiant battle with cancer. Beloved wife of Milton. Dear sister-in-law of Debbie and Aaron Schochet. Loving aunt of Susan and the late Steven Schochet. Services Tuesday, February 10, 12 noon at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. The family will observe Shiva Tuesday evening through Thursday morning at the Park Lane Hotel, 320 Central Park South. In lieu of flowers, charitable contributions may be made to The Pines Care Center, P.O. Box 5333, Fire Island Pines, NY 11782-0999.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANGER, DAVID THOMAS.
description: SANGER-David Thomas. Of Ridgewood, N.J. On February 2, 1998. Beloved husband of Mary. Devoted father of Bridget Hardy and Mary Ann Orbe. Loving grandfather of Geoffrey Hardy, Hudson and Easton Orbe. Retired Assistant Vice President of Grace National Bank of New York City, later, Marine Midland Bank. Memorial service to be held at Mount Carmel Church, Ridgewood, N.J. Saturday, February 14th, 9:30 AM.

title: Sports of The Times; Every Sled Dog Has Its Day
description: IF you can dream up something semi-athletically peculiar to do on ice, snow or on the side of a glacier, Juan Antonio Samaranch has an Olympic medal in his bag for you.

title: Graphic Narratives About Sex and Tales of Revenge Begin a Court-Martial
description: The Army's former highest-ranking enlisted soldier combined crude overtures, complaints about his wife and bids for sympathy after the death of his son as he tried to seduce Staff Sgt. Christine Fetrow, according to opening statements and testimony in his court-martial today.

title: Metro Business; Loehmann's to Close Stores
description: Loehmann's Inc. said last week that it expected to report a fourth-quarter loss of about 40 cents a share and that it would close 10 stores to cut costs.

title: Day Care Bill Proposes Background Checks
description: Employees at day care centers that serve at least 20 children would be subject to criminal background checks under a bill introduced in the State Assembly yesterday.

title: Athlete Killed In N.J. Accident
description: A bobsledder who hoped to make the American Olympic team in 2002 died early Saturday when he was struck by a car while walking along Route 9 in Marlboro Township, the police said.

title: Rage Guard To Have Surgery
description: Michelle Marciniak, a Philadelphia Rage guard, will undergo surgery tomorrow to remove a small, painful lump from her breast, ending her season four games early, the American Basketball League team said.

title: LIFE RE TO BUY LINCOLN LIBERTY AND FIRST DELAWARE
description: The Life Re Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the privately held Lincoln Liberty Life Insurance Company and the First Delaware Life Insurance Company for $50 million. Lincoln Liberty, based in Omaha, and First Delaware, of Wilmington, provide traditional and universal life insurance policies. In 1997, the companies together had estimated premiums of $7 million and total assets of $219 million. Life Re, of Stamford, Conn., provides life and group life reinsurance. For the nine months ended Sept. 30, Life Re had revenue of $474 million.

title: School-to-Work Programs Set Students Back; Learning in Context
description: To the Editor:

title: Some U.S. Rabbis Hope for a Backlash
description: American Jewish religious figures, whether Reform, Conservative or Orthodox, all said they fully expected the Chief Rabbis in Israel to reject the compromise on religious conversions proposed by the committee chaired by the Israeli Finance Minister, Yaacov Neeman. And in their eyes, that's what happened.

title: Connecticut Is the Yardstick
description: Just as Kobe Bryant is being measured against Michael Jordan, the Rutgers women's basketball team has been anointed as the latest understudy to dominant Connecticut in the Big East.

title: Snowfall Continues to Back Up Schedule
description: Heavy snowfall continued to play havoc with skiing today, forcing postponement of the women's super-G race and preventing the awarding of the first Alpine medal of the 1998 Winter Games.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, SENATOR NORMAN J.
description: LEVY-Senator Norman J. The partners, attorneys and staff at Certilman Balin Adler & Hyman, LLP., mourn the untimely passing of our dear friend and Counsel, Norman Levy. We are grateful for the ever-present inspiration and wisdom he provided during his more than twenty years of service with our firm. He was a mentor, teacher and great friend, and we will miss his vision and guidance. He will be missed within the halls of the Senate, and by the thousands of people he served. To his adoring wife, Joy, we offer our heartfelt sympathies. Her devotion and support were a source of strength to him during his distinguished career. Norman Levy's memory and legacy will live forever in our hearts, and in our minds. In his honor we are establishing the Senator Norman J. Levy Government Services Internship Program at Hofstra University.

title: Deutsche Bank Denies Interest in Credit Suisse
description: The shares of Credit Suisse Group fell yesterday, paring some of Friday's 7.3 percent advance, after the chief executive of Deutsche Bank A.G., Rolf Breuer, said the German and Swiss banks did not plan to merge. Credit Suisse shares closed at 249.25 francs ($174.88), down 5.75 francs, after Mr. Breuer was quoted by the newspaper Handelsblatt as saying Deutsche had no plans to follow in the footsteps of Union Bank of Switzerland and the Swiss Bank Corporation by agreeing to a merger.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: America Online Shares Rise On Higher Internet Fees

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARTOGS, RENATUS, M.D.
description: HARTOGS-Renatus, M.D., PhD. Age 89. Holocaust survivor, psychiatrist, teacher, author, artist. Mourned by family and friends. Services private.

title: Essay; Remembering David Schramm, Gentle Giant of Cosmology
description: THE first thing you needed to know about David Schramm was that he wouldn't hurt you -- not unless you got in his way on a racquetball court or a wrestling mat or unless he had cajoled you onto some mountain with no way down. Not unless you took issue with his classic computations on how the elements were formed in the thermonuclear furnace of the Big Bang at the beginning of the universe, in which latter case he would form a posse from his mafia of astrophysical confederates and perform the intellectual equivalent of beating you to death with a baseball bat.

title: Cold War of the Soul: Siberian Ice Fishing
description: What kind of man would stand for hours in the middle of a frozen river in the middle of Siberia in the middle of winter, battered by winds that could snap an oak and temperatures that would scare an Eskimo?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, HAZEL. (BECK)
description: ROSENBERG - Hazel. (Beck) Passed away February 8, 1998 at her residence in Miami Beach, Florida. Adored wife of the late Sidney. Beloved mother of Louis. Devoted sister of Ethel Beck. Adoring aunt of Kara and George Beck. Sister-in-law of Rita Rosenberg. Many nieces and nephews. Graveside services will be held Wednesday, February, 11, 1998, 12 P.M. at Cedar Park Cemetery in Westwood, New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORGANSTERN, MARY MILLER
description: MORGANSTERN-Mary Miller 90 of Palm Beach Florida. Passed away February 9, 1998. The beloved wife of the late Al Morganstern, loving mother of Sonia and Martin Dorfman, devoted grandmother to Jeffrey, Susan, and Andrew. A wonderful great-grandmother. Interment will be at the Chevra Kadisha Cemetery, St. Louis, Missouri. Services Riverside Gordon, West Palm Beach 561683-8676

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERMAN, PAUL ARTHUR
description: BERMAN-Paul Arthur . Passed away on February 6th, 1998, age 62, is now free from the bondage of Lou Gehrig's Disease (ALS). He is survived by his wife, son, two daughters, mother, brother, two grandsons, and son-in-law. He was well known in New Jersey circles, headed Berman Realties and developed University Plaza One, Two and Three at Fairleigh Dickinson University in Hackensack, NJ and former Vice President of Cushman and Wakefield, NJ. Was active on several community and social organizations including the Board of the New Jersey Association for Retarded Citizens, B'nai Brith, and Temple Beth Havarim. He made the world a better place and will be missed by many. Services will be today 12 noon at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, 150 Rt 4 East, Paramus, NJ 07652. Donations in his memory can be made to either Temple Beth Havarim, 280 Ramapo Valley, Mahwah, NJ 07430, on the ALS Association, 40 Wall Street, 4th Floor, New York, NY 10005.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about remedial students at the City University of New York misstated the percentage of incoming students at the community colleges who fail all three of the system's placement examinations. It is 33 percent, not 67.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, RAYMOND H.
description: BROWN-Raymond H. Dearly beloved husband of Gerry. Devoted father of Jaclyn and Peter Sieben and Eric Brown. Adoring grandfather of Rachel, Hannah and Elissa. He will be greatly missed. Service today, 12 noon at Emanu-el Jewish Center, 261 East Lincoln Avenue, Mt Vernon, NY.

title: Ally in Archvillain's Clothing?
description: For nearly a thousand years, ''divide and conquer'' was a cardinal rule of Roman foreign policy. Since 1991 the United States has ignored this adage and tried to contain simultaneously Iraq and Iran, two countries that may hate each other more than they hate us.

title: Arts in America; Drumming Up Buzz on the Broadway Road Circuit
description: The phone call came from an agent at William Morris.

title: Black-White Economic Gap Is Narrowing, White House Says
description: After two decades without progress in narrowing the economic gap between black and white Americans, the nation shows tentative signs that economic inequality between the races has been reduced in the last few years, the Clinton Administration said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FAUST, SAM
description: FAUST-Sam. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of our devoted member Sam Faust, beloved husband of Marcelle, father of Karen Faust, and Monica and Jonny Podell, Grandfather of Brittany and Cassidy. Sincere condolences to the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, President Jerry Forst, Vice President Jack Rosen, Vice President

title: A Lawyer Converts To Virtue
description: THE STREET LAWYER

title: School Uniforms Urged
description: The president of the Board of Education has proposed that New York City's 550,000 elementary school students be required to wear uniforms beginning in the fall of 1999. Although there is no definitive research to suggest that the wearing of uniforms affects student performance, there has been little public protest in cities where the practice has been instituted.

title: Black Success vs. Black Despair
description: As President Clinton's ''national conversation'' on race moves haltingly around the country, Henry Louis Gates Jr. comes forward with a call for a conversation about class.

title: Police Investigate Release Of Suspect in Shooting
description: The Newark police are investigating whether officers checked for previous warrants when they arrested and released a suspect who the police say shot another officer three days later in a Jersey City police station.

title: Study Questions The Usual View Of Downsizing
description: Month after month, the Labor Department reports the creation of hundreds of thousands of new jobs. The latest report showed that 358,000 were added in January, even as the economy showed signs of weakening.

title: Uh-Oh, It's Wire Hanger Time
description: It was said that you could hear the sighs of relief among movie audiences of 1930 when Greta Garbo uttered her opening lines in ''Anna Christie,'' her first talking picture. Garbo, it turned out, could not only talk but talk the way she looked, with a deep, exotic melancholy that matched her presence on the silent screen.

title: If NATO Doesn't Grow
description: To the Editor:

title: Personal Health; Pass the Wine and Olive Oil, and Other Lessons From Crete
description: OF 12,000 men in seven countries studied in 1960 by Dr. Ancel Keys, those least likely to develop heart disease lived on the Isle of Crete.

title: An In-Flight Guide To Stars in the Sky
description: The Los Angeles-to-New York flight was a celebrity-watcher's delight. In the first-class cabin was ANGELA LANSBURY, on her way to last night's $750-a-person Red Ball at the Plaza Hotel. The dinner-dance was organized by MARTIN RICHARDS, who produced the dark musical comedy ''Sweeney Todd,'' which starred Miss Lansbury. She and her husband, PETER SHAW, were the guests of honor. The after-dinner auction benefiting two charities featured plates painted by GREGORY PECK, GLENN CLOSE, GOLDIE HAWN and ROSIE O'DONNELL, among others.

title: School-to-Work Programs Set Students Back; A Lesson in the Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FAGIN, I. DONALD, M.D.
description: FAGIN-I. Donald, M.D. Beloved husband of Ronnie Fagin. Dear father of Roberta Fagin, Joan Fagin (Edmond Frost) and Lorie (Hank) Weisinger. Loving grandfather. Dearest brother of Norma Keller and the late David Fagin. For information Dorfman Funeral Director, (248) 546-4700.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, GEORGE
description: KATZ-George. On February 7, 1998. Deeply mourned by Sylvia Slatin Katz, loving and beloved wife. Dearest uncle, cherished cousin and loyal friend. Services Tuesday, 11 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Gill Insists That He Won't Accept a Trade to the Raptors
description: Kendall Gill had just spent a painful few minutes in the Nets' locker room, trying to quiet trade rumors involving him, insisting that he would not go to Toronto if traded there and saying that he did not believe it would happen. It sounded as if he were trying to convince himself.

title: Clark Back For Record 20th Time
description: Joetta Clark remembers the first time she ran in the Millrose Games.

title: Boston U. Wins in O.T.
description: A Harvard team with a losing record but a confident attitude took Boston University into overtime tonight before the Terriers nailed down the Beanpot tournament championship.

title: It's Nearly A Wipeout For U.S. Women
description: ''It didn't hurt,'' Betsy Shaw shouted to a friend in the finish area today. ''Only my ego got hurt.''

title: German Economists Plead for a Delay in Introducing the Euro
description: The large but largely ignored proportion of German voters who feel hostile toward the planned single European currency, the euro, received a jolt of support this weekend when 155 German economists pleaded for a delay.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KORET, BERNICE
description: KORET-Bernice. 74, on Feb 7th, 1998, in Houston, TX. Mrs. Koret was a native Houstonian, survived by loving husband Samuel (Sonny) Koret, of Houston, a son David Koret, of New York, a daughter Tia Koret Pierce and husband Mark and grandson Logan, of San Francisco, CA, sister-in-law, Yetta Goldman and husband Michel, of Sarasota, FL, beloved nephews, Leonard Glass, Neil Goldman, and David Glass, and a niece Nina Goldberg. Funeral services were held 1:30 P.M. Feb 9th at Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, Forest Hills, NY, with burial at Mount Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, NY.

title: 3,000 G.I.'s To Be Added To U.S. Force In Kuwait
description: A day after the Pentagon announced that it would not seek permission from Saudi Arabia to launch air strikes from its territory, the United States disclosed new plans today to build up its forces in the Persian Gulf by sending 2,500 to 3,000 more soldiers to Kuwait.

title: Seagram Americas Reviews an Account
description: Seagram Americas in New York said yesterday that it had placed in review the account of three brands handled for the last decade by Ogilvy & Mather New York: Seagram's 7 Crown whisky, Seagram's Gin and Seagram's VO Canadian whisky. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Greener Pastures? He'll Keep 'Frasier'
description: Christopher Lloyd would seem to be television's version of the man who has it all. He is the guiding creative executive behind ''Frasier,'' which has won the Emmy as best comedy four years running, every year it has been on the air. With about 60 sitcoms being broadcast and fewer than half a dozen true hits, that is a distinction.

title: Newark Shows Increased Revenue
description: Mayor Sharpe James said today that increased revenue from operations by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey here, as well as improved property tax collections, would net the city about $25 million more than expected this year and would allow the hiring of 300 police officers and a 5 percent cut in the local tax rate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPITZEL, BETTY
description: SPITZEL-Betty. Devoted wife of the late Herbert. Beloved mother of Carol Gross and Sally Edwards. Adored grandmother of Barbara, Jeffrey, Nancy, Benjamin and Alexandra Gross, and Sarah and Spencer Edwards. Services today, 10:00 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th and Amsterdam.

title: A Slapdash Proposal on Cloning
description: The shock caused by the physicist Richard Seed's grandiose intention to clone human beings may be about to cause more damage than anything Dr. Seed could do in the laboratory. Senate Republicans are now rushing to enact a bill that would outlaw cloning a human embryo and, in the process, ban a valuable technique that could potentially cure a wide range of diseases. No wonder a slew of scientific associations and high-tech industry groups are urging more carefully constructed legislation. The sensitive scientific and moral issues involved here require careful handling, not grandstanding by politicians more interested in pandering than in reaching a reasoned solution.

title: Knoblauch's Philosophy: If You Can't Beat 'Em, Join 'Em
description: Chuck Knoblauch was only a rookie when he had the sort of Yankee Stadium experience that many opponents speak of. A golf ball landed near where he was standing, at second base.

title: Plan for Airport Lounge Is Killed in Westchester
description: In an effort to halt expansion at the Westchester County Airport, County Executive Andrew J. Spano has rescinded a plan by his predecessor to build a 900-square-foot lounge for business travelers at a cost of $413,000.

title: Halldor Laxness Dies at 95; Reinterpreted Icelandic Sagas
description: Halldor Laxness, Iceland's foremost literary figure and winner of the 1955 Nobel Prize in Literature for his bardic epics and sharp social commentary, died on Sunday in a nursing home northwest of Reykjavik, The Associated Press reported. He was 95.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WECKER, BARRY
description: WECKER-Barry. The Hampton Synagogue mourns the passing of Barry Wecker, beloved brother of Roni and Howard Cowan, founders of our synagogue. Heartfelt sympathy to the entire family. Rabbi Marc Schneier Michael B. Weisbrod Seymour G. Siegel

title: Groups Close Ranks
description: Golf's major governing bodies, both in the United States and abroad, are siding with the PGA Tour's decision to ban carts in competitive professional golf tournaments.

title: Most Gauges Fall on the 2d-Slowest Trading Day of 1998
description: Stocks ended mostly lower yesterday in the second-slowest trading day so far this year, reflecting a dearth of economic data and corporate earnings reports that made investors reluctant to buy without a clearer sense of the market's next move.

title: Facing Critics, I.N.S. Unveils Modernization
description: Under intense pressure from Capitol Hill, officials of the Immigration and Naturalization Service today unveiled a plan to impose tighter control on the process of obtaining United States citizenship, a system that has been so sloppy and error-prone that in 1996 at least 369 convicted criminals became citizens unlawfully.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SORG, FLORENCE H.
description: SORG-Florence H. Aged 78 years. Mother of Vicki Sorg Murphy, Francis J. Sorg III, Leslie Sorg Ramsey, Wendi P. Sorg, Thomas Gannon Sorg and Elizabeth Sorg. Grandmother of Bryan F. Murphy, S. Gannon Murphy, Emily Sorg, Kelly Sorg, Tyler Sorg and Gillis Sorg. Great Grandmother of Barnes Gannon Murphy. Devoted volunteer at North Shore University Hospital for many years, and long time violinist with the North Shore Symphony Orchestra and the Long Island Senior Pops Orchestra. Accomplished amateur artist. Visiting hours at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd, Manhasset, NY, Wednesday and Thursday 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Friday 11:15 AM at Saint Aidans R.C. Church, 505 Willis Avenue, East Williston, NY. Donations in lieu of flowers may be sent to North Shore University Hospital, Long Island Senior Pops Orchestra or North Shore Symphony Orchestra.

title: Jury Finds Baccarat Discriminated Against Spanish-Speaking Worker
description: A former saleswoman for the Baccarat store on Madison Avenue was awarded $500,000 by a Federal jury on Friday after she testified that the company president complained about her Puerto Rican accent, barred her from speaking Spanish to a co-worker and finally dismissed her from her job selling crystal and china because of her ethnic origins.

title: DAIN RAUSCHER TO BUY WESSELS, ARNOLD & HENDERSON
description: The Dain Rauscher Corporation, a securities firm, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Wessels, Arnold & Henderson L.L.C., a closely held provider of investment banking and institutional brokerage services, for around $150 million. Both companies are based in Minneapolis. From 1995 through 1997, Wessels, Arnold, which has annual revenue of $82 million, underwrote 78 transactions worth $4.4 billion and completed 11 mergers and acquisitions worth $3.2 billion. The purchase price includes $120 million cash and as much as $30 million in debt securities. Expenses associated with the deal will lower Dain's earnings by $10 million to $15 million. The period in which the charge would be taken was not specified.

title: Q & A
description: The Ripening Banana

title: Despite controversy, most agencies don't shy away from using the President as a pitchman.
description: AS soon as a celebrity endorser encounters trouble, marketers usually do what they can to distance themselves from the star. But surprisingly, it has not been business as usual with an unusual pitchman: President Clinton.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLIER, RHODA
description: KLIER-Rhoda. On February 7, 1998. Beloved wife of Irving. Cherished mother of Merrill (Walter) and JoLynn (John). Devoted grandmother of Lucie, Benjamin, Alexander and Gregory. Loving sister of Paula and Sanford. She will be greatly missed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AHN, LISA DENHAM
description: AHN-Lisa Denham. 38. On February 8, after a valiant struggle with breast cancer. Adored wife of her beloved Henry. Cherished daughter of Elma Denham of New York City and William Denham of Washington, D.C. Loved by sister Stacey Denham and Stacey's husband Tim Wood and her nephew Boris Wood in Hamburg, Germany. Everyone who ever met and knew Lisa loved her. She was special but her kindness, gentleness and caring made everyone else feel special. A funeral service will be held on Friday, 12 noon, at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, 150 Rt. 4 East, Paramus, NJ, 201-843-9090. In lieu of flowers, please make a contribution in Lisa Denham-Ahn's name to SHARE, 1501 Broadway, suite 1720, New York, NY 10036. A memorial in New York City will be announced later.

title: Korea's Other Big Problem: $300 Billion in Domestic Debt
