description: The Nasan Group was a successful apparel manufacturer with a stable of popular local brands until it began an ambitious expansion in 1988, backed by banks that are now suffering the consequences. Flush with easy credit, it branched out into golf courses, resorts and hotels, then added a health club subsidiary and acquired a construction company.

title: N.B.A. Hopes Transcend Hoop Hype
description: PHINEHAS Chaplin feinted to his right and drove left, half a step ahead of Aaron Harvey, which was all the lead he needed for the bucket. Then it was Aaron's turn, and he reached over Phinehas to score with a soft jump shot.

title: The Show Must Go On
description: In happier times, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani regarded the Grammy Awards as ''the premier event of the recording industry.'' Now, the show has sunk significantly in his entertainment pantheon. Mr. Giuliani claims Michael Greene, the head of the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences, verbally abused a mayoral aide. So in retaliation, the Mayor announced he was withdrawing his personal support from the program and did not care whether the show stayed in the city. Grammy officials were reportedly wounded and angry. Los Angeles, which has struggled with New York for years over the right to host the show, rejoiced.

title: Genetic Ties May Be Factor In Violence in Stepfamilies
description: A WOMAN'S live-in boyfriend murders her child fathered by another man. A woman neglects her young stepsister and punishes her so viciously that she dies. A stepfather sexually abuses his wife's daughter by a former husband.

title: Long Island Woman Dies From Flesh-Eating Illness
description: A 72-year-old Long Island woman who was recovering from a recent mastectomy died yesterday at Good Samaritan Hospital Medical Center in West Islip of a flesh-eating bacteria that is extremely rare and not contagious, a hospital spokesman said today.

title: Mayoral Feud May Drive Off The Grammys
description: A month-old dispute between Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and the organizers of the Grammy Awards erupted yesterday with the Mayor angrily denouncing the event's top official as a liar and saying that as far as he was concerned the organizers could take their show -- and the estimated $40 million it contributes to the local economy -- and hit the road.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Corrections
description: A music listing on Sunday in the Arts and Leisure section misstated the site of a performance to be given on Saturday by the Clarion Music Society. It is the Church of St. Luke-in-the-Fields, 487 Hudson Street, at Grove Street, in the West Village, not at the Kaye Playhouse.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, HOWARD
description: LEVINE-Howard, on February 7, formerly of Staten Island. Husband of the late Cynthia (Segal). Survived by his son, Dr. Lawrence Levine and two grandchildren. Services and Interment will be held on Thursday, February 12 in Andover, MA. Expressions of sympathy to UNICEF.

title: Environmental Group To Fight Incinerators
description: A dozen New Jersey environmental groups announced yesterday that they had formed a coalition to fight state efforts to help counties pay off more than $1 billion in bonds issued to build garbage incinerators.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGSON, ARNOLD M.
description: BERGSON-Arnold M. Age 80, of New York, N.Y. died February 9, 1998 in Palm Beach, FL. Survivors include his wife, Jeanne H. of New York, N.Y.; two daughters, Jane Hersh of Ponte Vedra Beach, FL and Barbara McGraw of Riverside, CT; brother, Martin Bergson of Providence, R.I. and three grandchildren. No services.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNLAP, HERBERT CREIGHTON
description: DUNLAP-Herbert Creighton, age 84, on February 7th, 1998. The Board and Staff of St. Paul's House and the JJD Hall Memorial Fund, NYC, mourn the loss of their Founder and colleague who served 53 years. He is survived by his cousin, Stuart, and nephew, Alexander Scott Dunlap. Viewing 2pm-7:30pm and Memorial Service 7:30pm, Wednesday, February 11th, at First Baptist Church, 79th and Broadway. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to St. Paul's House or to the JJD Hall Memorial Fund.

title: Science Watch; Call of the Bullfrog
description: MALE American bullfrogs have eardrums that are twice as large as females', but that is not because they listen harder.

title: President's Lawyer Files Complaint Against Starr
description: President Clinton's lawyer filed a formal complaint today in Federal District Court here, apparently accusing the independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr, of disclosing secret grand jury information about the President.

title: Senate Plans To Weigh Ban On Cloning
description: Manipulating the fundamental processes of life offers the best hope of tackling diseases like cancer and Alzheimer's that strike at the level of the cell. But when the steady advance of biological research comes close to creating strange new powers, like the ability to clone human beings, many wonder if knowledge has not leaped ahead of wisdom.

title: School-to-Work Programs Set Students Back
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Army Court-Martial Begins

title: Foreign Affairs; It's Good for You
description: It was interesting to be in Prague watching on CNN as the U.S. Congress gave President Clinton a standing ovation for his call to expand NATO to Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic. It was interesting because Mr. Clinton couldn't get a similar standing ovation for that proposal from the Czech Parliament.

title: High Roller's High Stakes on the High Seas
description: G. MICHAEL BROWN, the casino operator, is giving a tour of New York City's first licensed high seas gambling ship.

title: Poultry Processing Plants Found In Violation of Overtime Laws
description: Federal inspectors found that more than 60 percent of the nation's poultry processing plants violated overtime laws, the Labor Department announced yesterday.

title: SALOMON SMITH BARNEY TO ACQUIRE A NATWEST BUSINESS
description: Salomon Smith Barney Holdings Inc. announced yesterday, as expected, that it had agreed to buy National Westminster Bank P.L.C.'s Australian and New Zealand securities and investment banking business, County NatWest, for $85 million. Salomon Smith Barney, based in New York, is the securities and investment banking unit of the Travelers Group. By acquiring County NatWest's operations, Salomon Smith Barney gains an immediate presence in Australia's and New Zealand's investment banking, stock brokerage and bond businesses. County NatWest employs more than 300 bankers and traders there; Salomon Smith Barney has about a dozen bankers in the area.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS TUMBLES. Natural gas futures fell sharply on forecasts for temperatures above normal at a time of ample supplies. The March contract fell 13.8 cents, or 3.8 percent, to $2.221 for each 1,000 cubic feet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKELSTEIN, IRWIN
description: FINKELSTEIN-Irwin. The Officers and Directors of Metropolitan Jewish Health System sadly mourn the untimely passing of Irwin Finkelstein, beloved brother of our esteemed fellow Board Member, Dr. Paul Finkelstein. May his legacy act as a source of inspiration to all those whom he touched. We pray that his fond memories will sustain you and the love and prayers of those who care, will comfort you. We share in your loss. Our profound sympathy andsincere condolences to the family. Mark L. Goldstein, Chairman of the Board Eli S. Feldman, President, Chief Executive Officer

title: G.M. Announces Buyback Plan For $4 Billion More of Its Stock
description: The General Motors Corporation, which has been buying back stock in an effort to lift the price, said today that it would repurchase an additional $4 billion worth, or about 10 percent of the shares outstanding.

title: The Getty's Hidden World of Wizardry; With X-Rays and Spray Booths, Experts Study and Treat Artworks
description: Beneath the gleaming white facade of the J. Paul Getty Center, set on a hill with spectacular views of Los Angeles in every direction, is a hidden world the public will probably never see. There, scores of highly trained experts perform feats of museum wizardry, from studying X-rays of ancient artifacts in the hope of prying out their secrets to reversing the ravages of time on pigments, paints and varnishes.

title: Metro Business; New Jersey Ski Resort Sold
description: The Intrawest Corporation, a Vancouver, British Columbia, operator and developer of mountain resorts, has agreed to buy most of the Vernon Valley Great Gorge ski area and resort in Vernon, N.J., company officials said yesterday.

title: Retarded Man Sentenced To Time Served in Death
description: A slightly retarded 32-year-old man who had been jailed for almost two years on charges that he had murdered his infant daughter was sentenced yesterday to the time he had already served after pleading to a lesser charge.

title: SAFETY-KLEEN SPURNS LATEST BID FROM LAIDLAW AS RISKY
description: The Safety-Kleen Corporation said yesterday that it had rejected a revised $30-a-share stock-and-cash bid by Laidlaw Environmental Services Inc. of Columbia, S.C., because an all-cash offer of $27 a share from the Philip Services Corporation was less risky. Safety-Kleen, which is based in Elgin, Ill., and provides cleanup services to automobile service stations, warned that Laidlaw's stock might decline in value as the company's cost-cutting goals were missed. Safety-Kleen, which has agreed to a $1.9 billion acquisition by Philip Services, of Hamilton, Ontario, and two American partners, Apollo Advisors and the Blackstone Group, delayed tomorrow's shareholder vote on that proposal to Feb. 25.

title: Pro-Iraqi West Bank Protests Are Blocked by Palestinian Police
description: Moving to contain a wave of pro-Iraqi sentiment before it raises tensions with Israel, the Palestinian Authority sent out scores of policemen here today to prevent marchers supporting Saddam Hussein from clashing with Israeli troops.

title: Music in Review
description: A Roots-Music Synthesis, From Senegal to China

title: Lewis Shrugs Off Inability to Meet Best Heavyweights
description: It seems to be Lennox Lewis's fate that he will not meet the best heavyweights of his era in the ring. Riddick Bowe tossed the World Boxing Council championship belt in a garbage can rather than fight Lewis. Mike Tyson sidestepped him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUTSON, JEAN BLACKWELL
description: HUTSON-Jean Blackwell. The Schomburg Center mourns the passing of Jean Blackwell Hutson, Curator, Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, The New York Public Library, from 1948 to 1980. She passed on February 4th, 1998, at age 83. Viewing, Thursday, February 12, 3-7 P.M. at St. Philip's Episcopal Church, 204 West 134th St. Funeral Mass, Friday, February 13th, at 10 A.M. at St. Philip's. Memorial Service, Saturday, March 7th, 12 noon, at St. Philip's. She will be deeply missed by friends, colleagues and the community.

title: Kwan Tests Her Toe In First Practice
description: Michelle Kwan arrived at the Winter Games today and said that ''when I saw the Olympic rings, I wanted to cry.'' The way she skated, her opponents might be the ones who end up crying after the women's competition next week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUFELD, WILLIAM M.
description: KUFELD-William M. Our entire family mourns the loss of our brother-in-law and uncle. He was loved and will be sorely missed. The Chesir Family

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''To fish here on a day like today is absolute joy. Anybody can fish in the summer.''

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: School Officer Charged With Selling Stolen Items
description: A school security officer in Brooklyn was arrested yesterday on charges of purchasing, and then trying to resell, stolen goods while on duty, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DREITLEIN, CHARLES J., SR.
description: DREITLEIN-Charles J., Sr., of Cliffside Park, NJ, on Saturday, February 7, 1998, loving companion of Marie Carver, devoted father of Charles J., Jr., Robert, and Kenneth, cherished grandfather of six grandchildren. Charles was a member and 58th President of the Kiwanis Club of New York City; Chairman, Advisory Board of The Sanctuary for Animals, Inc.; member of EastMid-Manhattan Chamber of Commerce; Chairman, Banking Membership Committee, and Treasurer of MDA-New York Chapter. Charles was also an Army Veteran of World War II. Funeral from McCorry Brothers Funeral Home, 780 Anderson Avenue, Cliffside Park, Wednesday, February 11, at 9:00 AM. Funeral Mass to be celebrated at Church of the Epiphany, Cliffside Park, at 9:45 AM. Entombment to follow at Woodlawn Cemetery, Bronx, NY. Visiting hours on Tuesday, from 2-4 and 7-9 PM.

title: Prodigal Son as Angry Rebel
description: Although George Balanchine perfected the art of the plotless ballet, he could also tell a good story when he chose. One of his greatest works remains ''Prodigal Son,'' the choreographic version of the biblical parable he created in 1929 to a score by Prokofiev. It retained its power when the New York City Ballet offered a vividly characterized account of it on Sunday afternoon at the New York State Theater.

title: BOATS: WHITBREAD RACE -- A SAILOR'S JOURNAL; Major Blow To Mast, And Spirits
description: The nine boats in the Whitbread Round the World Race are in the fifth and longest of nine legs, 6,978 nautical miles from Auckland, New Zealand, around Cape Horn to Brazil. At last report, EF Language led Swedish Match by 4.6 miles, with Merit Cup in third. Katie Pettibone, an American on the all-female crew of EF Education of Sweden, will continue to file updates until the scheduled return to Southampton, England, in May. This is her 15th report.

title: A Feeling That Clinton Has Said Enough
description: Americans think President Clinton has said enough for now about the accusations involving Monica S. Lewinsky; in fact they want Kenneth W. Starr, the independent counsel, to drop the whole matter, according to several recent polls. Many people feel that Mr. Starr is conducting a partisan investigation using questionable means, the polls showed.

title: School-to-Work Programs Set Students Back; 'The Glue That Holds'
description: To the Editor:

title: 11 Marks Fall, but Japan Is on Top
description: Eleven men surpassed the old Olympic record in the 500-meter speed-skating competition today, as Hiroyasu Shimizu emerged in first place in the first day of racing and raised hopes that he might become the first Japanese athlete in the 1998 Winter Games to win a gold medal.

title: Doctors' Research Ties
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GLOBAL INDUSTRIES, Lafayette, La., a provider of construction services to the oil and gas industry, agreed to buy certain barges and equipment for about $50 million from TL Marine Sdn. Bhd., Malaysia.

title: Deal by Makers Of Instruments
description: Veeco Instruments Inc. agreed today to buy the closely held Digital Instruments Inc. for about $150 million in stock to broaden its technology and product lines.

title: Craze for Beanie Babies Helped Surge in '97 Toy Sales
description: Those pint-sized bean bag characters, stuffed animals that gyrate and giggle and key chains that youngsters nurture like pets helped push toy sales up nearly 8 percent last year, double what the industry and analysts were expecting.

title: Thomas Kilgore Jr., 84; Led 2 Baptist Groups
description: The Rev. Thomas Kilgore Jr., a leading figure in the struggle for racial justice and one of the few men to lead two major national Baptist organizations, died Wednesday at Good Samaritan Hospital in Los Angeles. Mr. Kilgore was pastor emeritus of Second Baptist Church, the oldest black Baptist church in Los Angeles. He was 84.

title: Schering Net Up 23%, Aided by Fall in Mark
description: Schering A.G., a German maker of drugs and contraceptives, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter 1997 net income rose 23 percent as the weakening German mark buoyed exports during a company revamping.

title: The Scores Are Low For CBS's Analysts
description: Snowboarders must speak a different language. How else to explain the remarks of Jim Rippey, CBS's Winter Olympic snowboarding analyst. They had to be in code. There had to be hidden depth to such minimalist contributions as:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROGIN, LILLIAN
description: ROGIN-Lillian. It is with profound sorrow that The Officers, Board, and Members of UCP of New York City, mourn the passing of Lillian Rogin, devoted wife of the late Robert I. Rogin, who served for many years as Chairman of the Board. Lillian Rogin used the skills through her theatrical career to serve the disabled in our community. As head of UCP of NYC's Speakers Bureau, she enlisted, trained and scheduled advocates for individuals with Cerebral Palsy, and their families, and served on the Womens' Division Board. Both she and Bob Rogin worked with tireless dedication to assure a better future for all children and adults with Cerebral Palsy. We extend our deepest condolences to the family. Leo Hausman, President Jack Hausman, Founder UCP of NYC

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOHLMANN, PAUL A.
description: KOHLMANN-Paul A. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Mrs. Ursula Kohlmann on the loss of her beloved husband, Paul. As Founders of the Hospital, the Kohlmanns played a vital role in providing for the health care needs of the people of Jerusalem and Israel. May the family have warm and loving memories of their husband, father and grandfather. May they be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. American Committee for Shaare Zedek Medical Center in Jerusalem Mrs. Erica Jesselson, Chairperson of the Board Menno Ratzker, President Lee Weinbach, President National Women's Division Sidney Adler, Treasurer Dr. Stuart Tauber, Exec. Dir.

title: Mason Makes Apology To His Family and Team
description: Anthony Mason, facing a cadre of cameras and microphones yesterday outside the Reebok Club in Manhattan after the Charlotte Hornets' practice, proclaimed his innocence on charges of statutory rape, sexual abuse and endangering the welfare of a child.

title: Inquiry Hears Audio Tapes Of Jet That Hit Ski Lift Cable
description: The Italian authorities said today that tape recordings of conversations between the crew of the American jet that clipped ski lift cables in northern Italy last week and air traffic controllers will help them to answer ''fundamental questions'' about the jet's altitude, air speed and flight path.

title: Fashion Honors Its Brightest Stars
description: And the winners are Narciso Rodriguez and Sandy Dalal.

title: The G.O.P. Long View: Foment an Insurgency
description: As President Clinton works to win international consensus for air strikes against Iraq, Republican Congressional leaders are trying to carve out a distinct foreign policy stance that allows them to support the Administration and yet appear tougher than the President.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTEIN, JANE
description: WEINSTEIN-Jane. On February 7, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Bernard. Loving mother of Judy (and Tom Mellins), Robert, and Wendy (and Matthew Karp). Devoted grandmother of Samuel Mellins. Funeral service on Wednesday, 1 P.M. at the Larchmont Temple in Larchmont, NY. Interment at Beechwood Cemetery in New Rochelle, NY. For more information call John J. Fox Funeral Home at 914 834-0144

title: BABBITT INQUIRY IS RECOMMENDED
description: Top Justice Department officials have formally recommended that Attorney General Janet Reno seek an independent prosecutor to investigate Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt's role in a decision to kill an Indian casino project in Wisconsin, law-enforcement officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, MILTON W.
description: BROWN-Milton W. Great and unique historian of American art. Devoted teacher. Talented and successful watercolorist and very, very, very old friend. Love to Blanche. Morris, Joshua, Marjorie and Daniel Dorsky

title: California Recovers in Lull Between Storms
description: Brilliant blue skies gave Californians a chance to dry out today, offering a respite from Pacific storms that have battered the coast like artillery barrages.

title: End Is Seen To Simmons Family Feud
description: Harold C. Simmons, the Dallas businessman, has agreed in principle to settle a suit by two daughters over control of his billion-dollar fortune, according to people taking part in the talks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCLEOD, C. ANDERSON
description: McLEOD-C. Anderson, of Pelham Manor, NY, and Weekapaug, RI, died on Sunday, February 8, 1998, at the age of 81. Retired vice president of Chemical Bank. Beloved husband of Jean Phillips McLeod. Devoted father and loving grandfather. A memorial service will be held Thursday, Feb. 12, at 11 AM, at Christ Church, Pelham Manor, NY. Donations to the Weekapaug Chapel Society or the Dana Farber Cancer Institute, Boston, MA.

title: By Design; Sportswear's New Persona
description: People have been wearing sports clothes as street wear for quite a while, inspiring designers to make dressed-up versions of athletic clothes that are not so casual.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANAGNOSTOU, MICHAEL
description: ANAGNOSTOU - Michael. Died peacefully after a productive and full life on February 6, in Jacksonville, FL. Founder of the renowned Poseidon Greek Bakery on 9th Avenue in midtown Manhattan; beloved father of John, Jean and Anthony Fable. Proud Papou to dozens of grandchildren and great grandchildren.

title: CVS to Acquire Arbor Drugs For $1.48 Billion in Stock
description: The CVS Corporation said yesterday that it would buy Arbor Drugs Inc. of Troy, Mich., for $1.48 billion in stock, positioning it to become the largest drugstore chain in the country.

title: Williams and Oakley Secure One for the Aged
description: The generation gap between Herb Williams and his teammates seems almost invisible as age 40 creeps up on him like a cat burglar.

title: Familiar Name in 2 Western Races
description: In the 1960's and 70's, the Udalls were ''the Kennedys of the West.''

title: Ban on Protests In West Bank
description: After a wave of pro-Iraqi demonstrations that have turned into anti-American displays and clashes with Israeli soldiers, the chief of the Palestinian police in the West Bank and Gaza Strip said today that he had banned such protests.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORRIS, GRINNELL
description: MORRIS-Grinnell. Died February 5, in Naples, Florida. Survived by his wife Cornelia and sons Grinnell Jr, Stephen, Frederic and Daniel. Also by his brother John. A memorial service will be held on Sunday March 8, at St. Johns Church, Cold Spring Harbor, L.I. at 1pm. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to Planned Parenthood of Suffolk County, Smithtown or St. Johns Church, Cold Spring Harbor.

title: BANKATLANTIC TO ACQUIRE INVESTMENT FIRM RYAN, BECK
description: BankAtlantic Bancorp Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the regional investment firm Ryan, Beck & Company for $38.1 million in stock. The deal would make BankAtlantic the latest commercial bank to buy its way into the brokerage business since the dismantling of laws that had separated the two industries. Shares of Ryan, Beck gained $1.25, to $9.125. Ryan, Beck, based in Livingston, N.J., underwrites equity and debt securities and provides advisory services and insurance products. BankAtlantic Bancorp, based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., is the parent company of BankAtlantic, which has assets of $3.1 billion.

title: Waterfront Police Raid Two Companies in Mob Inquiry
description: The bistate Waterfront Commission hauled away boxes of records from two port businesses today, the first public move in an investigation of possible organized crime involvement in the lucrative cargo container repair business.

title: For $55 Million, New York Acquires Sterling Forest
description: After more than a decade's crusade by preservationists, Sterling Forest has finally been acquired by the State of New York from its private owners, creating a beguiling new terrain for hiking, fishing, skiing and ambling that is 18 times as large as Central Park and an hour-and-10-minute drive from midtown Manhattan.

title: INSIDE
description: Diesel Truck Pollution

title: Japan Shares The Triumph Of a Skater
description: Buoying the spirits of his nation, Hiroyasu Shimizu won the 500-meter speed-skating race Tuesday to give Japan its first gold medal of the Nagano Olympics and prove himself the world's fastest man on ice.

title: Bombing Iraq May Unleash a Toxic Threat
description: To the Editor:

title: Cameras in the Park
description: To the Editor:

title: Germany's Racist Resurgence
description: Germany's unemployment, at a postwar high, is now beginning to produce a worrisome surge of racist and neo-Nazi violence among young people in the former eastern states, where the jobless rate tops 21 percent. While the incidence is still well below the alarming levels of 1992, the violence requires a firmer response from the federal and state governments than it has received.

title: Many Styles, Tinged by Melancholy
description: Alana Davis purred through her songs at the Mercury Lounge on Monday night. She luxuriates in her voice, a supple alto that she deploys with bluesy curlicues and a breathy vibrato, rounding off every phrase. In many ways, she is like an updated Phoebe Snow; she strums an acoustic guitar and builds her songs on easy-rolling vamps, and there's an underlying tinge of languid melancholy no matter what she is singing.

title: Open Vatican Records
description: To the Editor:

title: No Need to Humiliate Iraq, The Secretary General Says
description: Sounding a conciliatory note, Secretary General Kofi Annan said today that ''we should not insist on humiliating'' Saddam Hussein and urged all parties to be more flexible in finding a peaceful solution to the Iraq crisis.

title: The Glorious Salads of Winter
description: ORDER a salad in a restaurant these days and companions will question your sense of adventure, your dining integrity, the strength of your stomach.

title: Stiffer Standards for 4th and 8th Grades
description: For the first time in 15 years, New York State is introducing new standardized tests in English and mathematics that will set tougher requirements for fourth and eighth graders, state officials said yesterday. The tests will closely correlate with more stringent high school graduation requirements now being phased in.

title: Top Soldier Coached A Witness
description: Sgt. Maj. Gene C. McKinney coached a young female staff sergeant to tell Army investigators that their contact had been limited to conversations ''about career development and that kind of stuff'' and involved ''no inappropriateness at all,'' despite years of what she has described as his efforts to persuade her to have a sexual relationship with him.

title: Inquiry on Ski-Lift Deaths Leads Marines to Relieve a Colonel
description: The commander of a squadron of jets like the one that severed cables on a ski lift in Italy last week, killing 20 people, was relieved of his command on Friday because he told his crew members to destroy potential evidence in the investigation, the Marine Corps said tonight.

title: Sports of The Times; Michelle And Wayne Are Here
description: GENTLEMEN, start your Zambonis. Up to now, the Olympic Winter Games have consisted mostly of Japanese soldiers dutifully tamping down the slopes after the latest blizzard, but now it really doesn't matter if they ever run those outdoor events.

title: City Could Keep Grammys Despite Uproar, a Supporter Says
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's harsh words about the Grammy Awards and the man in charge of them will not necessarily spoil New York's chances of staging the awards presentation again next year, a major supporter of the event predicted yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WYMAN, THOMAS M.
description: WYMAN-Thomas M. February 9, 1998. Beloved husband of Llana. Son of Olga Resseguier and the late Charles A. Wyman. Brother of John H. Wyman and Virginia A. Meyer. Uncle of Christina and Charles Wyman, and Edward and Katharine Meyer. Interment private. Memorial Service is to be announced. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to Panwy Foundation, Inc., 10 Valley Drive, Greenwich, Connecticut 06831.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORAN, LOLA L.
description: FORAN-Lola L. Of Hockessin, DE. On February 9, 1998. Beloved mother of Arthur F. Foran, III. Funeral services Saturday, 10:30AM, Saint Magdalen Church, 105 Mine Street, Flemington, NJ. Calling hours Saturday 9-10AM at Holcombe-Fisher Funeral Home, 147 Main St, Flemington, NJ. Memorial contributions may be made to American Cancer Society.

title: Fighting Youth Crime, Some States Blend Adult and Juvenile Justice
description: On the day he attacked a staff member at a Minnesota juvenile detention center, menacingly wielding a fork against the man's neck, Adam Sipe crossed an irrevocable line.

title: Street Takes the Gold by a Mere Tip of the Ski
description: Picabo Street promised that she would go for it all. ''Fast or out,'' she said. On a rebuilt left knee and still experiencing headaches after a near-catastrophic spill 12 days ago, she came to the Winter Olympics with the medals on her mind, with a game plan that any course she set out on could still be a fast lane to the victory podium.

title: More Details Seen in Health Care Inquiry
description: Sweeping Federal investigations of the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation are focusing on whether the company cheated Federal health programs, lied to a hospital accreditation commission and offered illegal compensation for doctors' referrals of patients, according to a Government affidavit that was partly unsealed yesterday.

title: Chrysler Is in the Market for Acquisitions
description: The chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, Robert J. Eaton, said this week that his company, the third-largest United States auto maker, was interested in buying all or part of another car company as it tries to increase international sales.

title: Recalling a Racial Killing And the Movie About It
description: THE GHOSTS OF MEDGAR EVERS

title: A 2d Oval Office Gatekeeper Is to Testify in Lewinsky Case
description: A second woman who has long been a close aide to President Clinton has been subpoenaed to testify before the Federal grand jury investigating the relationship between her boss and a former White House intern, Monica S. Lewinsky.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISSMAN, GEORGE
description: WEISSMAN-George. Of Whitestone, NY. Died February 8, 1998 at age 82 in Del Ray Beach, Florida. As a young man, living in Brownsville during the Second World War, entered the Marines, fought in the Pacific, saw action on Okinawa, and did post-war service in China. A hard worker, and always an active union member, he was a cutter for 25 years, a progressive force within the ILGWU. He went to night school, earned a degree, began a second career at age 45, as a Mathematics teacher at Bayside High School; he was active in the union, was voted a UFT Chapter Chairman, upon retirement presented with a plaque: MENSCH. He read voraciously, loved to travel, and made a worldclass seafood lasagna. Loving husband to Mary for 58 years; sons Peter and Andrew; daughters-inlaw Rita and Kathleen; granddaughters Raphaela and Nicole, all of whom will miss him dearly.

title: To Go; The Tastes of Latin America, Nuevo and Not So Nuevo
description: NUEVO LATINO food, the artful combination of traditional Latin ingredients with contemporary cooking techniques, has been offered in New York only at a few upscale restaurants. Now, MOSAICO a two-month-old takeout shop, is bringing Nuevo Latino home.

title: Give Me Jail. . .
description: REUBEN BLADES is not your typical Broadway leading man. Where most stars of a big-budget musical like Paul Simon's ''The Capeman'' would demand perquisites like a larger dressing room, Mr. Blades demanded a smaller one. He insisted on switching with his co-star, EDNITA NAZARIO. That put her in the palatial dressing room that JULIE ANDREWS had occupied when the Marquis Theater was home to ''Victor, Victoria.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMMONS, MAXINE JANE
description: SIMMONS-Maxine Jane. On January 21, 1998. Devoted daughter of the late Marion Frances Quinton and Herbert Simmons, and caring guardian of Suki. A pioneer as one of the first female African American attorneys in the country. Owner and consultant to the James L. Perkins Memorial Chapel, Inc. Her friends will miss her warmth, intelligence, humor, and determination. Contributions should be made to the United Negro College Fund, 120 Wall Street, 9th Floor, New York, NY 10005.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAITER, ELIZABETH SHAWGER
description: BAITER-Elizabeth Shawger. Of Chatham Township formerly of Short Hills on Monday, February 9, 1998. Wife of the late Richard J. Baiter. Mother of R. Justin Baiter, Jr. and Mrs. Hannah B. Wallace. Also survived by 5 grandchildren. Memorial service in Christ Church, 66 Highland Avenue, Short Hills, New Jersey, Friday, February 13 at 11AM. Relatives and friends are invited to attend. Friends may call at Smith and Smith (Suburban), 415 Morris Avenue, Springfield, NJ on Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9 P.M.

title: Edginess Becomes a Way of Life for Indonesians
description: The military officer seemed puzzled when asked about the giant Tactica armored water cannon that was parked beside him, in front of the glass-and-chrome Delta Plaza Shopping Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENFELD, LEONARD
description: ROSENFELD-Leonard. On Feb. 10, 1998. Beloved husband of Joan. Loving father of Lisa, David and Mark. Dear brother of Henry. Adoring grandfather of Michael and Daniel. Devoted father-in-law of Penni and Charlie. Service Wed., 12:15PM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SORG, FLORENCE
description: SORG-Florence. We grieve the loss of our dear friend, Florence who was happiest when serving others. We were indeed fortunate to know her well. Dennis, Jean and Marie Buckley

title: Chefs Staggered by the Foie Gras Crisis of '98
description: THE foie gras binge that has consumed the restaurant world for months now has finally gone and done it. Or overdone it. Suddenly there is a severe shortage (granted we are not talking about baby formula here, or even gasoline, but this is a restaurant story, you know) that has thrown chefs into wild-eyed desperation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPORN, MORTON
description: SPORN-Morton. On February 10, of Berkeley Heights, New Jersey, formerly of Newark and Irvington. Dear brother of Shirley Wasserstein. Loving uncle of Jeffrey and Iris Wasserstein. Great uncle of Andrew, Zachary and David Wasserstein. Funeral services at the Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vaux Hall Road, Union, N.J. today 2:15 P.M. Interment Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Iselin, New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, HAZEL (BECK)
description: ROSENBERG-Hazel (Beck). Service time changed to 11:30 A.M. Wednesday at Cedar Park Cemetery. Family will meet friends at Riverside, 76th St. at 9:45 A.M.

title: Journal; The Body Count
description: It's not the leaks that are undermining the press's credibility -- it's the stains.

title: Real Estate; Expansion Plan for the 92d Street Y Is Stirring Up Some of Its Neighbors
description: Finding no other way to accommodate its ever-growing adult education program, the 92d Street Y has stepped over an invisible line along Lexington Avenue. And into a hornets' nest.

title: Sips; A Scarlet Liqueur For Valentine's Day
description: RIGHT up there with St.-Amour Beaujolais and Chambolle-Musigny Les Amoureuses Burgundy for Valentine's Day, there is now Red Passion, a new, intensely scarlet liqueur.

title: Teacher Incentive Money Is a One-Time Windfall
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, HENRY
description: SCHNEIDER-Henry. Beloved husband of Jacqueline. Devoted father of Michael and the late Barbara Bruckner. Loving grandfather of Robert and James Bruckner, Maxwell and Ethan. Service Thursday, 11:30 AM at Park Avenue Synagogue, 87th St. and Madison Avenue. For further information call Plaza Memorial Chapel, 212769-4400. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Columbia Law School or the Central Park Conservancy would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALGOZZINE, JANE TAYLOR BARRETT
description: ALGOZZINE-Jane Taylor Barrett, 78, Of Katonah, N.Y., formerly of NYC, Albany and Cairo, NY. Died Jan. 28, 1998 after a long illness of a rare brain disorder. Jane spent 25 years teaching in upstate NY schools before joining the NYS Education Department in 1965. She became the Bureau Chief of Reading Education in 1967 and the Director of Language Skills in 1983. Jane was also the Director of the State Right to Read Programs. She is survived by her son John R. Algozzine of Katonah, NY and her daughter Linda Starr of Walden, CO., 3 granddaughters and six great granddaughters. She will be missed greatly. Donations may be made to the Bachmann-Strauss Dystonia & Parkinson Foundation at the Mt. Sinai Medical Center, 1 Gustave Levy Pl, Box 1490, NYC, 10029. A memorial gathering of family and friends will be held at the University Club at 141 Washington Avenue, Albany, NY, Saturday, February 14, 1998 at 1:00 P.M.

title: The Neediest Cases; From Mutual Funds to Raising Funds
description: The bull market on Wall Street has produced a windfall for The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, which received its first round of contributions this week from employees of Bear, Stearns & Company and Salomon Smith Barney, two of the nine investment banks and brokerage houses that participate in the fund's annual appeal.

title: Billion-Dollar Legal Fees
description: Even before tobacco settlement money has reached public treasuries, some members of Congress are up in arms over the potential fees private lawyers might reap for legal work on suits brought by 40 state attorneys general to recover Medicaid costs arising from tobacco-related illnesses.

title: Makers of Diesel Truck Engines Are Under Pollution Inquiry
description: The Environmental Protection Agency has discovered that hundreds of thousands of modern heavy-duty diesel truck engines run cleanly during the agency's mandatory performance tests but give off much more pollution in normal highway use, Federal officials say.

title: Head of PGA Testifies Of Cart's Unfair Edge
description: PGA Tour Commissioner Tim Finchem testified today that he and his staff considered allowing Casey Martin to use a golf cart, but ultimately rejected the idea because they concluded that it created an uncorrectable imbalance in playing conditions.

title: Beyond Rancor, Brecht Remounts His Pedestal; Playwright Is an Icon Again as Many Forgive His Marxist Politics
description: When Bertolt Brecht returned here in 1948 from wartime exile in the United States, the legendary German playwright and stage director chose to live and work in East Berlin. He was not, in fact, a card-carrying Communist, but he described himself as Marxist. And after his death in 1956 at the age of 58, his Berliner Ensemble theater company remained East Germany's principal cultural ambassador. With the unification of Germany in 1990, Brecht's name seemed irrevocably linked to a repressive regime and a failed ideology.

title: Nets Make A Point, As Does Cassell
description: Sam Cassell and Kendall Gill had both heard the rumors, and even the confirmation, that their names were involved in trade talks. But their reactions have provided a contrast, both on and off the court.

title: Excerpts From a Report On Campaign Finances
description: Following are excerpts from a chapter in the report compiled by the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee, which has been investigating campaign-finance issues. This chapter, ''The China Connection: Summary of Committee's Findings Relating to Efforts of the People's Republic of China to Influence U.S. Policies and Elections'' was furnished to The New York Times.

title: Hart Shows the Way For No. 23 Orangemen
description: SYRACUSE 72, MIAMI 63

title: In the Senate, Parties Jockey To Influence Tobacco Deal
description: The pace of legislative activity on tobacco regulation quickened today as several influential Senators staked out their opening bargaining positions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, SENATOR NORMAN
description: LEVY-Senator Norman. The Board of Directors, Board of Education, Administration, faculty and students of the Hebrew Academy of Nassau County are saddened at the passing of Senator Norman Levy. A leader in the NYS Senate, he was a champion of education, children's needs and programs for the learning disabled. Norman Levy was a great supporter of Soviet Jewry, Jewish causes and charities. He was a true supporter of Israel. Senator Norman Levy was a very close friend to the Hebrew Academy of Nassau County and will be sorely missed. Rabbi Moshe Gottesman, Dean Rabbi Yussie Lieber, Administrator Harvey S. Liebman, President Isaac Blachor, Chairman of the Board of Directors

title: Critic's Notebook; Inventing or Nurturing Personal Legends to Survive
description: Continent, city, country, society:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARTOGS, RENATUS, M.D., PHD.
description: HARTOGS-Renatus, M.D., PhD. Age 89. Holocaust survivor, psychiatrist, teacher, author, artist. Mourned by family and friends. Services private.

title: Whitman Seeks to Extend Life of Driver's Licenses
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman drew cheers from a State House audience yesterday by announcing plans to extend the life of New Jersey driver's licenses from 4 to 10 years. ''I've had hundreds of people tell me they'd do just about anything to avoid a trip to the D.M.V.,'' Mrs. Whitman said, referring to the State Division of Motor Vehicles.

title: Safety in New York City's Streets
description: New York's pedestrians, motorists and cyclists have two stark choices in the days ahead. They can let the decibel level from dueling sound bites drown out a sober-headed examination of how to make New York's streets dramatically safer for everybody -- those on foot and those in taxis and other vehicles. Or they can tune out the verbal combat that passes for frank discussion and demand that the Mayor and City Council get thoughtful answers to straightforward questions.

title: 2-Year-Old Is Awarded Top Eclipse
description: Favorite Trick, undefeated in eight starts as a 2-year-old, won the most important race of his career last night when he outpolled Skip Away to win the Eclipse Award as the 1997 Horse of the Year and become the first juvenile since Secretariat in 1972 to receive the ultimate honor in thoroughbred racing.

title: When Love Is Blinding As Well As Blind
description: They've had a few drinks and smoked a few cigarettes, and now the two main characters in ''Eyes for Consuela,'' Sam Shepard's new play at the Manhattan Theater Club, are swapping stories of their difficult marriages, as middle-aged men in their cups will. Not surprisingly, they are also waxing philosophical. ''You believe love comes cheaply?'' one guy asks the other. ''That it costs nothing at all?''

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; The S.E.C. proposes anti-fraud rules for 'micro-cap' stocks.
description: IF a brokerage house is posting prices at which it will buy or sell a stock, should it know something about the company's financial condition?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, MILTON W.
description: BROWN-Milton W. Beloved old friend, connoisseur of art and life, forever in our memory. Love to Blanche. Pauline and Al Lerner

title: Should I.M.F. Get Still More of Our Money?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENKOV, BEATRICE
description: BENKOV - Beatrice. Beloved mother of Rhoda and Robert Lebwohl, Murray and Harriette Benkov and Edward and Carol Benkov. Loving grandmother of eleven and great-grandmother of 23. Services at Boulevard-Riverside Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island, today at 2:15 P.M.

title: De La Hoya Postpones Fight
description: Oscar De La Hoya's mandatory defense of his World Boxing Council welterweight title against the No. 1 contender, Patrick Charpentier, has been postponed two weeks after De La Hoya sprained his left wrist sparring last weekend at his training camp at Coachella, Calif. De La Hoya was examined yesterday in Palm Springs, and the doctor determined that the wrist was sprained.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Liberian Human Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: SHARE OF WEALTH IN STOCK HOLDINGS HITS 50-YEAR HIGH
description: After three years of rapidly rising stock prices, American households have more of their assets invested in the stock market than at any time in the last 50 years -- and perhaps ever.

title: Restaurants; A Quiet Corner of France, With Pedigree
description: ''ISN'T that the Senator from New Jersey?'' a woman asks. Waving a plump, jeweled hand, she stares across the room. She has been discussing, in intimate detail, the people whose names you read in the society pages, and I half expect her to jump up and embrace the man she thinks is a Senator. But she does not, contenting herself with a satisfied little smile. ''I told you this was a wonderful restaurant,'' she says to her friends, happy that her good taste has been confirmed. ''And so few people know about it. It feels so private.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRIENSKY, MORRIS E.
description: KRIENSKY-Morris E. Artist, on February 8, 1998. Survived by daughter, Shoshana Katz, and grandsons, Boaz and Daniel Katz, sister, Ann Dubrow and brother Joseph Kriensky. Memorial service at The Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76 St. and Amsterdam, Sunday, February 15, at 3 PM.

title: 'C' Stands for Chelios And for U.S. Captain
description: Ten weeks ago while discussing the Olympic Games, United States Coach Ron Wilson was asked whether Brian Leetch would be his captain. Without committing himself, Wilson recalled the 1996 World Cup, which the United States won.

title: Manhattan's Sleepy Frontier; For New Residents, Wall St. Area Shuts Early and Often
description: For a glimpse into Manhattan's residential frontier, consider the neatly ordered bulletin board in the kitchen of Susan Finnegan and her three roommates. ''Pathetic, wouldn't you say?'' Ms. Finnegan complained the other day.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALMER, HAROLD C.
description: PALMER-Harold C. Age 79, of NYC and Indian Wells, CA., on February 7, 1998. Beloved husband of Nancie (nee Brown). He was born in Detroit on August 1, 1918 and was graduated from Harvard College in 1940. After brief service in the Navy during the war, he became a salesman for Merck & Co. He then worked for N.W. Ayer as an account executive and ended his career as Asst. Secretary of the NY Zoological Society. He was a member of the Union Club and the Eldorado Country Club of Indian Wells, CA. He was a former member of the Piping Rock Country Club of Locust Valley. He is survived by his wife Nancie; three stepsons, Timothy Nichols of Jamaica, VT; George J. Stewart of San Francisco, CA; and Victor E. Stewart of Ridgewood, NJ; a stepdaughter, Caroline S. Nation of London, England; and three stepgrandchildren, Victor, James and Andrew. Mass will be celebrated at noon on Wednesday at Sacred Heart Catholic Church in Palm Desert, CA. Burial will be in Forest Home Cemetery, Milwaukee, WI.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, HOWARD L.
description: GOLDBERG-Howard L. (H P R), 62, of Short Hills, N.J. Beloved husband of Iris (nee Gould). Devoted father of Steven, Richard, Gary and Ross Goldberg. Cherished son of Ettie (nee Kate Goldberg). Adored father-in-law of Colette Goldberg and Anna Goldberg. Dear brother of Mel and Jill Goldberg. Loving grandfather of Patricia Goldberg. He was Senior Vice President of Lehman Bros, NY, NY. Funeral services conducted from the Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vaux hall Road, Union, NJ. on Friday, February 13, 1998 at 1:00 PM. Interment Beth David Memorial Park, Kenilworth, N.J. Donations in his memory may be made to the Jake Gittlen Cancer Research Institute Penn State College of Medicine, 500 University Drive, Hershey, PA. 17033.

title: Not in New York
description: To promote her one-woman show, ''The Top of the Bottom Half,'' the actress and playwright LIZA VANN was ready to spend $27,000 on an advertisement in New York magazine. Ms. Vann, who has had a lumpectomy and two other operations on her left breast, wanted a flip-up photograph of her from the waist up. With nothing on.

title: Bombing Gas Sites May Pose Risk of Gulf War Syndrome
description: In a letter to President Clinton, members of a White House panel of experts have warned that a link between the illnesses of Persian Gulf war veterans and exposure to Iraqi poison gas ''cannot be ruled out'' and that the issue should be ''of particular concern'' as the United States threatens to bomb Iraqi poison gas sites.

title: Snowboarder Stripped of Gold for Failing Drug Test
description: Soon after he won the first gold medal in Olympic history for snowboarding on Sunday, Ross Rebagliati of Canada said he realized his sport was getting important because drug testing had been introduced.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Temptation; A New High-Quality Chocolate That Aims to Compete With Valrhona
description: SINCE late last year, San Franciscans have been treated to a new bittersweet chocolate made from a blend of eight varieties of cocoa beans.

title: 3 Teen-Agers Plead Guilty in Businessman's Killing
description: Tony Estevez did not know the name of the millionaire he and his two friends were going to New Jersey to kidnap and rob, but on the drive over from Washington Heights he was sure of something: one way or another, his pal Christian Velez was going to get them some money.

title: 'CHINA AREA' TIED TO ILLEGAL GIFTS
description: Illegal campaign contributions to the Democratic National Committee in the 1996 election originated in bank accounts in ''the greater China area,'' according to the final report of Republican senators investigating campaign finance abuses.

title: TV Notes; As the War Turns
description: That television would be part of the battle between rival factions in shattered Bosnia is no surprise. But who would have thought a Venezuelan soap opera called ''Kassandra'' would be central to the television battle?

title: Calendar
description: Black Culinarian Dinner

title: 2 Corrections Officers Arrested In Rape and Robbery at Brothel
description: Two state corrections officers were arrested yesterday after they entered a brothel in the Bronx posing as New York City policemen, raped one woman and robbed several others, the police said.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: New Life Through Chemistry; Castoff Sidelines Become an Emerging Industry
description: For a short time last month, three normally low-profile chemical companies got the business-page equivalent of 15 minutes of fame. Why? Everyone loves a bidding war, and investors and the news media had a ball as Hercules Inc. and Ciba Specialty Chemical fought it out for the Allied Colloids Group, a British maker of water treatment and other chemicals. By the time Hercules bowed out, Ciba had agreed to pay $2.3 billion for a company that netted but $63 million last year.

title: Moseley Ends a Rough Start for the U.S.
description: His entire country was waiting for a medal, gold or silver or bronze, anything. It was already the fifth day of competition. Waiting in direct view at the bottom of the hill were a dozen members of the Moseley entourage, all wearing flags on their stylish outfits.

title: Fun in February, Meaning in March
description: You counted the days until Midnight Madness. You sat through first-semester basketball, uneven games played by inconsistent teams. You filled out tournament brackets in your head, tearing them up and making revisions based on the previous night's results. Congratulations, Hoopheads. You've made it to the best time of the year.

title: Slaney Withdraws From Millrose Games
description: Mary Slaney, the 39-year-old queen of American middle-distance runners, withdrew yesterday from Friday night's Chase Millrose Games at Madison Square Garden because of a painful shin injury.

title: How Not to Investigate a Leak
description: A significant but perhaps forgotten episode in the legal career of Kenneth Starr, the independent counsel now pursuing President Clinton, reveals that he is no stranger to investigations of leaks to the news media. And he knows firsthand that such investigations, if done incorrectly, can fail both the victim of the leak and the American public.

title: MOTHER OF INTERN MAKES APPEARANCE BEFORE GRAND JURY
description: After hearing for months about her daughter's relationship with President Clinton, the mother of Monica S. Lewinsky, Marcia Lewis, was summoned today before a Federal grand jury.

title: Putting Steel In Diplomacy
description: For all the talk of ''time running out,'' the Clinton Administration has been beating the drums of war very slowly in the Iraq crisis, producing what can seem like a long, even tortuous, exercise in confusing the American public.

title: Humana Posts Rise in Earnings
description: Humana Inc. said today that earnings, excluding charges, grew 51 percent in the fourth quarter, meeting analysts' expectations, as premium rates increased and costs fell.

title: Indonesia Prepares For Currency Board
description: Indonesia's Finance Minister, Marie Muhammad, said today that the Government was preparing steps, including legislation, to establish a currency board, a system that would stabilize the rupiah's value against the dollar.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We should be able to choose what we want to wear. When you are in school, it's a fashion statement. It's your individuality.''

title: Nigerian Troops Near Sierra Leone's Capital
description: In a day of heavy artillery and aerial bombardment, Nigerian troops seized control of suburbs of Freetown, Sierra Leone's capital, today, from forces loyal to the military junta that overthrew the elected President last May.

title: North Korean Olympians, Far From Dour, Puncture a Stereotype
description: A group of North Korean athletes and coaches sat over lunch here in the Olympic Village and looked somberly at one another as they were told that Americans usually think of North Koreans as shy, humorless and grimly serious.

title: I.M.F. Concedes Its Conditions for Thailand Were Too Austere
description: The International Monetary Fund has conceded that conditions it imposed on Thailand as part of a multibillion-dollar bailout package have proved too austere, clearing a path for the Thai Government to increase spending substantially.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOWELL, DANIEL J.
description: LOWELL-Daniel J. Beloved husband of Sherry for over 50 years, devoted father of Teri and Steve Hardman and Candy and Don Childress, loving grandfather of Katherine Miriam and Lauren Elisabeth, caring and connected brother of Stanley H. and Lee Lowell, died on February 9 in Houston, Texas, his home for 48 years. A gentle man who will be deeply missed. Shiva Wednesday and Thursday evenings from 7:30 to 10 at Stanley's home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GENSEL, REV. JOHN GARCIA
description: GENSEL-Rev. John Garcia. Shepherds and music are companions, consecrated in time ever since that transcending moment of the Child in swaddling clothes under the Star. Little wonder then, that Pastor John Gensel would lead us around the Lord's table in melodies of prayer. ''The music of the Gospel leads us home,'' Faber noted in his 'Pilgrim of the Night.' And John's shepherding formed a very wide circle. Heaven blessed him with a special charisma, drawing friends, congregants, the lonely, the wandering and his special children-the 'shadow children' of this Town caught up in the trembling world of drugs and abandonment. He gave them hope! He gave them love! And, in so doing, stood so tall across the landscape of Daytop Village where he has served both as Trustee and Governor these many years. ''May the choirs of the angels receive him'' and may the prayerful support of us at Daytop serve to console his beloved Audrey and Family. Msgr. William B. O'Brien President Daytop Village, Inc.

title: Experts Fault NASA for Boasting of Safer Shuttle
description: Citing a safer space shuttle, NASA is widening the astronaut ranks to include a senator and a schoolteacher, and hopes for even more diversity. But private experts criticize the change as reckless, given the innate dangers posed by the winged spaceships. And even NASA's top safety experts say the agency's public assertions of improved safety are exaggerated.

title: It's Little Guys, 1; Morgan Stanley, 0
description: Many amateur investors think you can't fight Wall Street. Jim Roskind has proved them wrong.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGSON, ARNOLD
description: BERGSON-Arnold. The Board of Directors and Staff of the 92nd Street Y mourn the passing of Arnold N. Bergson, a dedicated member of our Board and our dear friend. His years of commitment to the 92nd Street Y are deeply appreciated. Our hearts and prayers go out to Arnold's wife Jeanne, his daughters Jane and Barbara and their families. He will be missed by all who knew him. Philip Milstein, President Joseph Leff, Chairman Sol Adler, Executive Director

title: Kenneth Starr and His Watergate Star
description: If there have not been enough reminders of Watergate lately, Kenneth W. Starr, the independent counsel, brought another one with him to court this morning.

title: The Chef
description: FOR some fish, steaming is just about always the perfect choice. I'm thinking especially of fillets of fish with particularly clean flavors like black sea bass or halibut. You want to treat them delicately, condense their natural flavor, keep them pure. (Salmon, by contrast, is much better suited to other cooking methods that result in pronounced effects, like grilling with a rub of dry spices.) But I do want to add some flavoring to my steamed fish, of course -- flavoring of the gentle, aromatic sort.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUSSELL, MAURICE V.
description: RUSSELL-Maurice V. The Officers and Directors of the Marian Kenworthy-Sarah Swift Foundation note with deep sorrow the untimely death of our esteemed President. His wisdom, compassion and his dedication to improving the lives of children and families continued the traditions and interests of his friends Marian Kenworthy and Justine Wise Polier who established this Foundation. His many contributions to the field of social work have been widely recognized and he will be greatly missed by all who knew and worked with him. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family and friends. Michael G. Kalogerakis, MD Trudy Festinger, DSW, Vice Presidemt Stephen W. Tulin, Esq. Secretary-Treasurer

title: $25 and Under; The Closest Thing to Mexico May Be in Queens
description: WALKING around Corona, Queens, is like seeing both the city's future and its past. Evidence of the new blood infusing New York is on every block, with Colombian bakeries standing next to Halal meat markets, which abut Mexican taquerias and Korean groceries.

title: Ex-Princeton Back Signs With the Colts
description: The Indianapolis Colts signed running back Keith Elias to a one-year contract, bringing Princeton University's leading career rusher back to the National Football League.

title: Looking for Real Drama at Olympics
description: Here are the major discoveries we non-sports fans have made while watching the Olympics so far:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHBAUM, MINNIE
description: ROTHBAUM-Minnie. February 9, 1998, 83 years old. Beloved wife of the late Harry Rothbaum. She is survived by her four children, Michael Rothbaum, Ronnie Storch, Jane Levin, Arnold Rothbaum, and eight grandchildren. Services today at 1283 Coney Island Ave., Brooklyn. Her beauty and kindness will be sorely missed by all.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISBERG, JAKOB
description: WEISBERG-Jakob. Died on February 7, 1998, also leaving behind Betsy and Martin. We loved him and will miss him.

title: B.U. Left Breathless By Harvard
description: After nearly 66 minutes of speed skating, Boston University achieved its goal -- the Beanpot championship -- but it wasn't easy.

title: Proposed Law Could Increase Price of Milk
description: In a move that could raise the price of milk for consumers by as much as 21 cents a gallon, Gov. George E. Pataki today endorsed for the first time state legislation that would permit higher prices to be set for wholesale milk.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SILVER REBOUNDS. After slipping for two days, the price of silver rose yesterday. The March contract finished 15.5 cents, or 2.2 percent, higher at $7.10 cents an ounce as the inventory of silver in Comex warehouses fell.

title: Test Kitchen; A Knife for Kitchen Olympians
description: CHEFS have their own Olympics, the International Culinary Competition, a weeklong slicing, dicing, sauteeing and baking contest, which is held every four years, usually in Germany. The white-coat-and-toque event, which is sponsored by food companies, will be held next in 2000. The 1996 competition, in Frankfurt, drew 60,000 participants and onlookers. Five chefs from each of 33 participating countries -- chosen after regional qualifying contests -- compete for gold, silver and bronze medals by demonstrating their culinary precision.

title: Wine Talk; Drawing the Line at $10 a Bottle
description: THE 1995 Burgundies will be arriving over the next few months, and their prices will be high.

title: For Oxford, Talks and a $100 Million Loan
description: Oxford Health Plans, the troubled managed care company, disclosed yesterday that it had obtained $100 million in short-term financing and that it was actively pursuing other sources of capital.

title: Agreement Ends Simmons Family's Feud
description: Harold C. Simmons, relieved but still embittered, won court approval here today for his agreement to give two of his daughters $50 million each in return for their dropping all claims to his remaining wealth of at least $1.2 billion.

title: Inspired Art or Stolen Art?
description: As a movie, ''Devil's Advocate'' is utterly forgettable, a sordid tale about a sleazy, sado-masochistic New York lawyer.

title: Pataki Broadens Health Plan for Children
description: Three months after proposing a basic health care plan for up to 420,000 uninsured children of low-income families, Gov. George E. Pataki reversed course today and called for a far broader plan that would provide benefits for dental, vision, hearing and mental health care.

title: Labor Group's Talk of Strike Threatens Korean Layoff Deal
description: An agreement to legalize layoffs negotiated last week by business, Government and labor leaders, and regarded as a big victory for President-elect Kim Dae Jung -- is in danger of foundering over a labor federation's threat to strike unless the accord is renegotiated.

title: Fat-Free Fanfare as Procter Starts Shipping Out Olestra
description: Procter & Gamble began a national rollout of chips made with the fat substitute olestra yesterday and said the products would be on store shelves nationwide by summer.

title: What to Look For
description: ICE HOCKEY

title: TENNIS: YESTERDAY
description: PARIS OPEN

title: Car Driver Is Killed and Seven Aboard Bus Are Hurt in Crash
description: A 45-year-old man died yesterday after he lost control of his car on the Long Island Expressway in Queens, crossed into a lane of oncoming traffic and slammed into an express bus, injuring seven bus passengers and snarling traffic during the morning rush hour, the police said.

title: Ron Brown Scholarships Open Doors For Blacks
description: Entering its second year, the Ron Brown Scholar Program has quickly emerged as the nation's most lucrative scholarship for black students -- and one of the most important.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DE SOSA, COUNT MAXIM
description: De SOSA-Count Maxim. 2/8/61-5/ 26/92. ''...he was Hyacinth when Apollo loved him.'' O.W. Eric

title: Bombing Iraq May Unleash a Toxic Threat
description: To the Editor:

title: Talks Seen on Cowen Sale
description: Societe Generale, the large French bank, is in discussions to acquire Cowen & Company, the New York investment bank that specializes in advising high-technology and health care companies, according to people at both companies.

title: Suit Over Accident On Thanksgiving Day
description: The lawyer for a woman who was injured when a balloon went out of control at the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade filed a $95 million lawsuit yesterday against the City of New York.

title: Gotti's Lawyers Seek His Release on Bail
description: Lawyers for John Gotti Jr. asked a Federal judge yesterday to release their client on $1 million in bail and confine him to house arrest while he is awaiting trial on charges of racketeering and extortion in White Plains.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about the fourth-quarter results of Dow Jones & Company misstated the name of a possible suitor for its financial information business, and described that company's ownership incorrectly. It is Bridge Information Systems, not Bridge News, and it is owned in part, not entirely, by Welsh Carson, Anderson & Stowe.

title: McVeigh Sees Lawyer's Deal As a Betrayal
description: Timothy J. McVeigh, now appealing his conviction in the Oklahoma City bombing, wanted to dismiss Stephen Jones, the lawyer who represented him at trial, in part because Mr. Jones planned to write a book about the case, according to documents unsealed yesterday in Denver.

title: TEMPLE-INLAND TO CLOSE PAPER MILL AND BOX PLANT
description: Temple-Inland Inc. said yesterday that it would close its corrugated-paper mill and box plant in Newark, Calif., laying off 150 workers. The maker of paper products and lumber, which also has banking and mortgage businesses, said the mill and plant would be closed May 15. Temple-Inland said the mill's equipment was outdated, and environmental and financial considerations made its modernization unfeasible. The closing is part of the company's effort to improve the efficiency of its corrugated packaging operations. The Newark mill produced 70,000 tons of corrugating medium in 1997. The company, based in Diboll, Tex., had $3.625 billion in revenue in 1997.

title: Starks Can Still Be a Tasty Leftover
description: Three days ago, John Starks stood in a corridor after the All-Star Game at Madison Square Garden. He granted a few interviews, but he went largely unnoticed in the mass of celebrity. Tim Hardaway, a member of the Eastern Conference team, was dressing in Starks's locker-room cubicle. For all the average fan knew, the boyish features could have belonged to a redshirt freshman at St. John's waiting for a glimpse of Michael Jordan. ''I didn't mind it; they all deserved to be there,'' Starks said last night.

title: Business Travel; Bucking an industry trend, Thrifty Car Rental is increasing mileage rewards for its customers.
description: COUNTERING a trend among major car rental companies to reduce mileage rewards for customers, Thrifty Car Rental is increasing its bonuses to as much as 2,000 miles for each rental.

title: About New York; Silent Singer Changes Tune With Artwork
description: SOME nights, Louisa Corchia lies in bed, unable to sleep because of the restless recital of her reveries. ''I got all these arias going through my head,'' she said, her voice racing. ''In my mind, they are like bells. But they go no further than my mind.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIDIA, BALDASSARE G. (BUDDY)
description: DIDIA-Baldassare G. (Buddy), 80, 2/11/17, died Wed., Feb. 4, 1998. Recently of Bogota, NJ, prior to that, Preston Hollow, NY, and Brooklyn, NY. Beloved husband of Nancy Giampietro Didia, devoted father of Nancy J. Didia and Maria Didia Salmon. Devoted father-in-law of Douglas E. Salmon, loving grandfather of Stephanie, Scott, Shawn and Seth Salmon. We are eternally grateful for your love and care of our mother these 54 years. Rest in peace. Visiting Friday 2-4 P.M. and 7-9 P.M. Funeral service Friday 8 P.M. at The Volks-Leber Funeral Home, 789 Teaneck Rd., Teaneck, NJ 07666. Cremation private. Memorial donations to the Alzheimers Association or The Actors Fund of America, Inc, Nursing and Retirement Home, Englewood, New Jersey.

title: Food Stuff
description: Valentine's Messages Written in Bread and Cheese

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINGARTEN, BLANCHE
description: WEINGARTEN-Blanche. On February 10, 1998. Beloved wife of Ted. Devoted sister of Selma Suntup and Bob and Jane Feinberg. Much loved aunt of Andy and Linda Suntup, Marc and Marge Suntup, Brad Feinberg and Karen Feinberg. Services 12 noon today at Parkside Chapel, Queens Blvd. In lieu of flowers, family requests donations to NY Lung Association or N.Y. Heart Association.

title: TV Notes; Defecting to the Movies?
description: As expected, Helen Hunt secured a nomination for the Academy Award for best actress yesterday, leaving NBC to continue to worry if she will lean toward establishing a full-time film career, abandoning her role on ''Mad About You.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUFELD, WILLIAM M.
description: KUFELD-William M. February 9, 1998. It is with great sorrow that we mark the passing of our beloved senior partner, Bill Kufeld. A consummate lawyer, he was our colleague, advisor and comradein-arms for almost fifty years. His friendship, wisdom and guidance will be dearly missed by all of us. His like shall not soon pass this way again. We mourn his passing. The Partners and Staff of Carb, Luria, Cook & Kufeld LLP.

title: Commercial-time rates for last 'Seinfeld' should break records.
description: IT'S much ado about a show about nothing: NBC wants to be the master of Madison Avenue's domain by charging what will likely be a record price for commercial time during the final episode of the hit sitcom ''Seinfeld.''

title: The Only Good Hero . . .
description: The great mystery of the winter movie season is what makes ''Titanic'' so popular. True, it was nominated for 14 Academy Awards yesterday, tied for the most ever. But the film is very long, the subject is literally a downer. Its best-known star, Leonardo DiCaprio, is a household name mainly in households that contain prepubescent girls. But ''Titanic'' could wind up becoming the biggest money-making movie in history. We have a suspicion about what makes this old story seem so fresh, but readers who have not yet seen the movie should be warned not to go farther.

title: Norwegian Wins Gold in Biathlon
description: Halvard Hanevold of Norway won the men's 20-kilometer individual biathlon gold medal in Nagano, Japan, today, timing 56 minutes 16.4 seconds to finish 5.5 seconds ahead of Pier Alberto Carrara of Italy.

title: Surgeon General Nominee Is Confirmed, Filling a 3-Year Void
description: Dr. David Satcher won Senate confirmation today as Surgeon General, becoming the first person in more than three years to fill a post that has become a lightning rod in the nation's battles over abortion and family values.

title: Unilever Earnings Drop After Charges in Quarter
description: Unilever, the Dutch-British maker of consumer products, said yesterday that fourth-quarter profit plunged a worse-than-expected 95 percent after a charge for selling some businesses and for raising its marketing budget. Net income fell to 59 million guilders ($30 million), or 0.05 guilder a share, from 1.153 billion guilders, or 1.025 guilders, in the period a year ago.

title: Braving The Chill At the Corner Farmers' Market
description: LIKE determined sprigs of rosemary that persist in poking through the frosted-over earth, some people refuse to give up. Witness the farmers whose devotion to the New York Greenmarkets knows no season.

title: Liberties; Doomsday Strategy
description: I dreamed a dream.

title: Conductor's Holiday: A Recital
description: Daniel Barenboim is astonishing. His way of taking a break, during the course of conducting the premiere performances of Harrison Birtwistle's huge new work for the Chicago Symphony was to come to Carnegie Hall for a piano recital on Monday night, playing two Beethoven sonatas and the first book of Debussy's Preludes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOK, ALICE L. (NEE KANE)
description: COOK-Alice L. (nee Kane). Born April 29, 1900. Died February 10th, 1998, in Dover, Delaware. Formerly of Bay Ridge, Brooklyn. Retired Principal of P.S. 102, New York City Board of Education. Loving wife of the late Lt. Cmdr. Paul J. Cook, U.S.N.R., Ret. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. Visiting Friday, 9AM, Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 4th Avenue, Brooklyn. Mass to follow 10:15AM Our Lady of Angels Church.

title: Just Who's Stirring the Pot in the White House?
description: WALTER SCHEIB 3d may cook in one of the most beautiful homes in America, but from a chef's point of view it's a poorly designed one. The kitchen is on the ground level. Food is served at least one flight up, often two. For banquets he must make do with staging areas not designed to be kitchen outposts. His choice of suppliers is limited by security concerns.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PACIUC, BENO, DR.
description: PACIUC-Beno, Dr. The Riverdale Jewish Center mourns the loss of our member, Dr. Beno Paciuc. We extend profound condolences to his wife Sophie and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOMERSTEIN, JUDAH
description: SOMERSTEIN-Judah. February 9, 1998. Beloved husband of Judy. Devoted father of Meryl Laub, Naomi Kreutzer and Eve Cohen. Adoring grandfather of Zachary, Rachel, Benjamin, Jessica, Leah and Rebecca. Also survived by a brother Saul. A graveside service will be conducted today 11:30 AM, at New Mount Carmel Cemetery in Queens. For further information call The George T. Davis Funeral Home in New Rochelle at 914632-0324. Contributions may be made in Judah's memory to the Beth El Synagogue, North Field Road, New Rochelle, NY 10804.

title: Harvard's Hiring Goals
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BREGMAN, RUTH
description: BREGMAN-Ruth. We shall always remember her sparkle, energy, dedication, the concern for others, her unpretentiousness, philanthropy, love of family and friends, and that irrepressible spirit. The funeral for Ruth will be held at Mt. Sinai Memorial Park and Mortuary, 5950 Forest Lawn Drive, Los Angeles, CA. 213469-6000, on Wednesday, February 11 at 2 P.M. Contributions in lieu of flowers should be sent to Ruth L. Bregman Special Childrens Fund, Cedars-Sinai Medical Center, Room 2416, P.O. Box 48750, Los Angeles, CA. 90048-0750.

title: Plot on Georgian President Brings Suspicions, and a Boast
description: A day after surviving the second attempt on his life in 30 months, Georgia's President joked and reminisced in a celebratory political meeting today, then posed the question that was on many minds:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLYNN, DENYSE
description: FLYNN-Denyse. The Ocean Bay Park Association sadly notes the passing of Denyse Flynn. The members wish to express their deepest sympathies to the family.

title: Burley Cocks, 82, Steeplechase Trainer
description: William Burling Cocks, the nation's leading trainer of steeplechase horses five times between 1948 and 1986 and a member of thoroughbred racing's Hall of Fame, died on Saturday at his home in Unionville, Pa. He was 82.

title: Ring of Fire Could Hold Clues To Events Leading to Supernova
description: In the early light of an exploding star, first observed 11 years ago, astronomers caught sight of a glowing ring of gas encircling the stellar remnant like a distant reef around a small island. They surmised that the ring consisted of material flung off by the star in its protracted death throes.

title: The Minimalist; The Last Word In Easy Pasta
description: THE very best pasta is often the simplest. My friend Jack Bishop, the author of ''The Complete Italian Vegetarian Cookbook'' (Houghton Mifflin, 1997), has refined his technique for pasta and vegetable sauce to breathtaking efficiency: he cooks the greens with the pasta and adds the seasonings at the last minute.

title: Bombing Iraq May Unleash a Toxic Threat
description: To the Editor:

title: Reuters Profits Fell 22% in Last Half of '97
description: Reuters Holdings P.L.C. said yesterday that profit in the last six months of 1997 fell 22 percent, to $:160 million ($260 million) from $:206 million a year earlier, mainly as a result of a strong pound. Reuters said the strong currency might curb revenue growth this year. Full-year net income fell 12 percent, to $:390 million, from $:442 million in 1996.

title: Equality? Tyranny? Plaid? Navy? Schools Debate Plan for Uniforms
description: In perhaps the most diverse and expressive city in the nation, the talk in public elementary-school classrooms yesterday often centered on what it would be like if everyone were compelled to dress the same.

title: Japan's Great Expectations Become Frustrations
description: The hill was normal; the stakes were not. And anyone who was here on this sun-drenched morning will never forget the Japanese flags.

title: Should I.M.F. Get Still More of Our Money?
description: To the Editor:

title: Maurice Schumann, 86, Dies; 'Voice of France' During War
description: Maurice Schumann, a French aide to General de Gaulle in London during World War II who made moving broadcasts to Nazi-dominated France and later became a Foreign Minister, died yesterday at the Invalides military hospital in Paris. He was 86.

title: Olympic Highlights
description: A 360 AND A GOLD -- Jonny Moseley of Tiburon, Calif., used his soaring helicopter turn to capture the gold medal in the men's moguls. Page C1.

title: TV Notes; Olympics on TV Get No Medals
description: CBS is labeling the disappointing ratings for its Olympic coverage an aberration wrought by the postponements of prime events and the lame performance of the American team.

title: Metro Business; Duane Reade Shares Surge on First Day
description: The shares of Duane Reade Inc., the largest drugstore chain in New York, rose 31 percent yesterday in their first day amid speculation that the drugstore company will swing back after years of losses or be acquired by a bigger pharmacy chain.

title: Curious Cook; Oiling the Pasta Water Does the Trick After All
description: DOES it do any good to cast oil on boiling pasta water? Can the oil keep noodles from sticking together? These days, the position of many Italian cooks is a firm no.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Lincoln's Birthday, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City tomorrow. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DESIMONE, JOSEPH F.
description: DeSIMONE-Joseph F. Retired Professor of Romance Languages, Brooklyn College. Preceded by his beloved wife Anne, on January 18, 1998, and by his son Joseph Jr. in 1991.
