Survived by daughter Paula Watson, son Philip, grandchildren Lucia and Liza Watson, Joseph and Jennifer DeSimone. Visitation at Fairchild & Sons, Garden City, NY, Feb. 12, 2-5, 7-9. Funeral Mass, St. Joseph's Church, Garden City, 10AM, Feb. 13. Memorial gifts may be made to the Columbia University, 475 Riverside Drive, NYC 10015.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARZMAN, MIRIAM
description: SCHWARZMAN-Miriam. On February 9, 1998, age 90, widow of Dr. Markus Schwarzman, beloved mother of Edwin, adored motherin-law of Carol Ann, cherished grandmother of Michael and Marjorie. Funeral services private.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR'S SLIDE CONTINUES. In late trading in New York, the dollar was at 123.19 Japanese yen, down from 124.04 yen on Monday. Traders say the fall is a response to confidence that the Japanese can revive their economy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TERLIZZI, ALFRED
description: TERLIZZI-Alfred. With profound sadness, The Morchand Center for Clinical Competence of The Mount Sinai School of Medicine mourns the loss of a dear friend, Alfred Terlizzi. Alfred was a compassionate man with a heart as big and warm as his sense of humor. He will be greatly missed. Our sincere sympathy to his wife LuAnne, sons Michael and Nicholas, brothers Nicholas and Donald, sister Aldine, and his two beloved granddaughters, Brianna and Gabriella. Mark H. Swartz, M.D., Professor of Medicine and Medical Education Director, The Morchand Center

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Jan. 29 with an article about the James Bond films misstated one of the words that made up the acronym Spectre. The acronym, the name of an international criminal conspiracy, came from the words Special Executive (not Executor) for Counterintelligence, Terrorism, Revenge and Extortion.

title: Back on Stand, Sharpton Defends Brawley Charge
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton confronted a barrage of questions at the Tawana Brawley defamation trial today about the extraordinary accusations he made a decade ago as he rallied around Ms. Brawley, a black teen-ager who said she had been raped by a gang of white men.

title: A Pasta With a Passion for Fitting In
description: LIKE an irresistible flirt, fregola, the pellet-shaped pasta of Sardinia, seems capable of becoming exactly what a dish desires.

title: And Now, Will America Take to the 'Other Foie Gras'?
description: SAUTEED in a deep-fried golden rice crust, sauced with an intense red-wine reduction touched with orange, and artfully arranged on a plate with salad of finely julienned vegetables in a sweet-and-sour sauce, the mysterious foie de lotte was greedily consumed by my friends.

title: Canada Railway Agrees to Buy Illinois Central
description: The Canadian National Railway Company said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Illinois Central Corporation for cash and stock valued at $2.4 billion, creating a railroad linking Canada to the Gulf Coast.

title: Lawyer Accuses Witness in Murder Case
description: A defense lawyer in the double-murder trial of a onetime lottery winner accused the prosecution's main witness today of masterminding a plot to kill the defendant in the slayings.

title: Fregosi Is Promoted
description: The San Francisco Giants named Jim Fregosi assistant to General Manager Brian Sabean yesterday, a year after he joined the organization as a special assignment scout and instructor.

title: Mets Acquire Gus Bell's Grandson
description: In a trade of minor leaguers, the Mets yesterday acquired a grandson of a player who was a member of the original Mets 36 years ago.

title: King Is Back as Captain As U.S. Seeks Revenge
description: Billie Jean King, returning this year as captain of the United States Fed Cup team after a disastrous 1997 in which the Americans were upset by the Netherlands in the opening round, said her motivation heading into the rematch can be summed up by a single word: revenge.

title: Productivity Jumps In 4th Quarter
description: Rapid economic growth at the end of 1997 was accompanied by sharp gains in worker productivity, the Labor Department reported yesterday. The index of nonfarm productivity rose at a 2 percent annual rate in the fourth quarter, faster than analysts had expected, reflecting a surge in output of goods and services that far outpaced increases in wages and hours worked.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: TRANSPORT CORP. OF AMERICA, Eagan, Minn., a trucking and logistics company, agreed to acquire the privately held North Star Transport Inc. for about $34 million in cash and stock.

title: Jerome Murray, 85, a Many-Faceted Inventor
description: Jerome L. Murray, an inventor who touched people's lives by conceiving such items as the electric carving knife, the audible pressure cooker, the airplane boarding ramp and a pump that made open-heart surgery possible, died on Jan. 7. He was 85 years old.

title: Pope and Yeltsin Chat of Much, Including the Millennium
description: As they exchanged gifts in the august splendor of the Vatican's Apostolic Palace, Pope John Paul II turned to President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia this evening with a wish that holds special meaning for both.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: A Canvas for Evoking a Formal Spirit
description: A choreographer painted with movement in ''Continuous Painting,'' which the Analysis Dance Company presented on Monday night at the Kaye Playhouse. Valia Alexandratou, a Greek dancer, was inspired by the art of Nassos Daphnis, a Greek-born artist who came to New York City in 1930 when he was 16. Making the stage her canvas, she evoked the spirit of his paintings, and slides of some of them were projected during her eveninglong piece.

title: Bombing Iraq May Unleash a Toxic Threat
description: To the Editor:

title: Whitman Shifts Course to Propose Hefty Increase for New Spending
description: After four years of cutting taxes and state spending, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman reversed course today with a proposed $17.9 billion budget that recommends nearly $1 billion in new spending for public schools, state colleges, open space preservation and a handful of other programs.

title: Tracing a van Gogh Treasured by the Met
description: The art world, always replete with rumors, has been simmering for weeks with talk about paintings whose provenance might be marred by Nazi plundering, including one of the Metropolitan Museum of Art's biggest treasures, van Gogh's ''Wheat Field With Cypresses.''

title: Tel Hashomer Journal; A Soldier Dies, and a Forlorn Family Shames Israel
description: Fighting a losing battle against sobs alongside the coffin of her fallen brother, Olga Rappaport addressed his comrades in Russian: ''He was very happy to serve in your army. I want all of you to make it home alive. Don't kill your parents, your brothers and sisters.''

title: Dow Up 115 As It Reaches Newest High
description: The stock market soared again yesterday, sending the Dow Jones industrial average to its first record high in six months.

title: Law Offered to Clamp Down On Commercial Bicyclists
description: Renewing a decade-old push to regulate commercial bicyclists, city lawmakers are considering a bill to require messenger services, restaurants and other firms that deliver by bicycle to carry $50,000 in liability insurance coverage per cyclist -- twice the legal minimum for taxis and privately owned cars.

title: Rutgers Women Hand UConn a Rare Loss
description: Declaring the future to be now, Rutgers upset Connecticut, 74-70, tonight and underscored what Coach C. Vivian Stringer had maintained before the game: the Knights are ready to contend for primacy in an arena once dominated by the Huskies.

title: Dmitriev Rises to Occasion in Pairs Once Again
description: Last summer, Artur Dmitriev of Russia had a familiar conversation with his coach. The Olympics were coming soon, she reminded him. It was time to stop thinking about parties and start thinking seriously about skating.

title: Cohen Finds Gulf Nations Hostile to Military Action
description: Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen said today that the Persian Gulf nations were lining up behind United States efforts to force Saddam Hussein to cooperate with United Nations weapons inspectors, but he failed to win any new public support for launching strikes on Iraq.

title: HIBERNIA TO ADD PEOPLES HOLDING FOR $73 MILLION
description: The Hibernia Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Peoples Holding Corporation for about $73 million in stock, expanding the bank's business in northwest Louisiana. The acquisition of the closely held Peoples, based in Minden, La., will give the New Orleans-based Hibernia another $228 million in assets and nine Peoples Bank and Trust branches. Hibernia, the largest bank based in Louisiana, will pay $185 in stock for each Peoples share. The merger is the latest in a series of acquisitions for Hibernia, which has bought 21 banks in the last four years. It will have $12.4 billion in assets and 240 branches in Louisiana and East Texas when it completes takeovers of Firstshares of Texas Inc. and Peoples.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Scope of Columbia Inquiry Disclosed in an Affidavit

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLLISTER, JOHN S. (JACK)
description: HOLLISTER-John S. (Jack) On February 2, 1998 at Pennswood Village, Newtown, Pa. Memorial services are being held at George School Meeting House, February 15, 2PM. Donations to American Friends Service Committee, 1501 Cherry St., Philadelphia, Pa. 19102.

title: Actors in Court
description: A French judge spent several hours yesterday questioning ROBERT DE NIRO about a call-girl ring. Later his lawyer, GEORGES KIEJMAN, filed a complaint accusing the magistrate, FREDERICK N'GUYEN, of violating secrecy rules and interfering with Mr. De Niro's freedom of movement.

title: Taking Pulse of the President's Pulse-Takers
description: FOR weeks, President Clinton has seemed like a stunt flier defying gravity. Why are his approval ratings soaring in the face of allegations that he had sex with a former White House intern? Could he still crash and burn? Public Lives put these questions to Mr. Clinton's very busy pollsters, Mark Penn and Doug Schoen, two New Yorkers who got their start in the early years of Mayor Edward I. Koch.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONNAUGHTON, SR. MARIA CONSOLATA
description: CONNAUGHTON-Sr. Maria Consolata. Beloved member of the Sisters of Charity and elementary school teacher on February 9, 1998. Survived by her sister, many nieces and nephews. Mass of Christian burial Wednesday, 10 A.M. at the Convent of Mary the Queen, 35 Vark St., Yonkers, NY. Interment St. Joseph's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Sisters of Charity Development Fund, 6301 Riverdale Ave., Bronx, NY 10471.

title: Time Warner Net Income Rises Sharply
description: Time Warner Inc. said yesterday that its net income rose nearly fourfold in the fourth quarter, beating expectations, helped by strong advertising sales at its cable channels and publishing operations.

title: Singapore and Malaysia Watch With Alarm : Indonesia's Neighbors Fear Wave of Refugees
description: SINGAPORE  Fearing an influx of refugees, Malaysian and Singaporean officials are watching with increasing alarm as unemployment, inflation and anti-Chinese unrest unfolds in neighboring Indonesia.

title: Host Marriott Hotel Deal
description: The Host Marriott Corporation said today that it had acquired a controlling interest in the Atlanta Marriott Marquis Hotel with a $75 million investment. The hotel, which includes 70 suites as well as convention space and restaurants, is expected to produce 1998 earnings before interest, taxes and other nonoperating costs of about $32 million.

title: Corrections
description: A map yesterday with an article about Defense Secretary William S. Cohen's trip to the Persian Gulf reversed two stops on his itinerary. As the article reported, he spent Sunday night in Saudi Arabia, then visited Kuwait and Oman on Monday; he was not in Kuwait on Sunday.

title: NOMURA PULLS OUT OF BRITISH UTILITY TALKS
description: Nomura International P.L.C., a unit of Japan's Nomura Securities Company, withdrew from takeover talks with the Energy Group P.L.C., balking at the cost of topping an offer from Pacificorp of $:6.43 billion ($10.68 billion) in cash and assumed debt. Analysts said that Nomura would have had to bid much more than Pacificorp, which is based in Portland, Ore., because British regulators would have spent months reviewing the offer, making it less attractive to Energy Group. Regulators were concerned Nomura was more interested in using Energy Group's assets to back securities than in running the British utility, analysts said. The announcement comes one week after Pacificorp offered 765 pence a share, an amount designed to deter Nomura and another suitor, the Texas Utilities Company of Dallas, from bidding. Texas Utilities is still in talks that could lead to an offer, a company spokesman said.

title: Off the Menu
description: A New Sandwich Shop

title: New Positions For 2 Executives
description: Two agency companies said yesterday that they had named executives to new positions heading important operations.

title: Jersey City Cracks Down On Open-Air Drug Deals
description: It was surreal even for a media event: two dozen reporters and cameramen bunched around a suspected drug dealer and several Jersey City police detectives during an actual arrest.

title: 'Titanic' Leads the Oscar List With 'L.A.' and 'Good Will'
description: Gloria Stuart was asleep at her home in West Los Angeles when her visiting daughter and son-in-law woke her up and began jumping up and down to tell her she had just been nominated for an Academy Award for her supporting role in ''Titanic.'' Ms. Stuart, 87, said later, ''All these years -- I've been waiting for this a long, long time.''

title: Should I.M.F. Get Still More of Our Money?
description: To the Editor:

title: To the Charts: The Mayor Has Good News
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani had been talking for an hour yesterday about the accomplishments of his administration when he suddenly cited a 17 percent decrease in the cost of king mackerel at the Fulton Fish Market. If his listeners interpreted this arcana as a signal that the Mayor's City Hall presentation was drawing to a close, they had another half hour to ponder their mistake.

title: Hitachi Cuts Forecast Of Fiscal Year Profit
description: Hitachi Ltd. became the last of Japan's five big semiconductor manufacturers yesterday to cut its profit forecast for the current fiscal year because of plunging chip prices and difficulties in the consumer electronics area. The company said that a difficult business environment would likely continue in the next fiscal year, but some analysts said they believed the company would rebound as its semiconductor business improved.

title: Nightclub Owner's Case Goes to the Jury
description: A Federal jury began deliberating yesterday in the trial of Peter Gatien, the prominent nightclub owner charged with turning two of his popular Manhattan clubs into virtual drug supermarkets to increase their patronage and profitability.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAYMAN, ARTHUR ''ARCHIE''
description: HAYMAN-Arthur ''Archie''. On October 15, 1920-February 7, 1998. Beloved husband of Anna Marie ''Gogo'', devoted father of Nicholas, Laura, and Karen, loving brother of Seymour ''Sy'' and the late Paul, dear uncle of Ellen Gellman, Robert, Jonathan and Valerie Hayman. Private services.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GOLDSMITH, ELFREEDA
description: GOLDSMITH-Elfreeda. Dear Mom, we miss you. Rest peacefully. Love, Rhoda and Bob

title: Quickly Quotable
description: ''I used to wait tables here,'' KASI LEMMONS told the crowd at Tavern on the Green. This time she was there to accept the director's debut prize from the National Board of Review of Motion Pictures for ''Eve's Bayou.''

title: Cameras in the Park; Riverside by Bus
description: To the Editor:

title: Neil Simon in Chekhov's Orchard
description: A working-class man sneezes on the back of his rich boss's head at the opera and can't stop apologizing. (''You shouldn't let people sneeze on you, dear,'' says the boss's wife.) A Casanova sets his amorous sights on a friend's wife. (''There is no room for mercy in the seducing business.'') Frightened governesses, eager dental students, bankers with gout, fixed-rate prostitutes and freelance faux suicides appear in ''The Good Doctor,'' which is based on a variety of short stories by Chekhov.

title: New Killings Again Disrupt Peace Talks in Northern Ireland
description: Protestant leaders, citing two killings attributed to Roman Catholic guerrillas in 24 hours, moved today to have Sinn Fein, the political wing of the I.R.A., expelled from the Northern Ireland peace talks.

title: From Bach's Own Church, A Hallowed Choral Lineage
description: The Thomanerchor Leipzig arrived in New York City this week with some interesting items in its collective suitcase. Among them is an aura of the past, for these boys and young men, some 80 strong, learn to sing and perform at the same church where Bach, in the second quarter of the 18th century, trained and used his own, albeit smaller, choir.

title: APOLLO MANAGEMENT BUYING 90% STAKE IN TANK TRUCKER
description: The Sombrero Acquisition Corporation, an affiliate of Apollo Management L.P., agreed yesterday to acquire the Bangor, Me., tank-trucking company MTL Inc. for $196 million plus the assumption of $54 million in debt. Under the agreement, MTL shareholders will receive $40 in cash for each share. Apollo has the option of paying up to $1.60 a share in stock. MTL's shares soared more than 33 percent, gaining $9.75 each, to $38.75, in Nasdaq trading. Apollo Management is a private investment firm in New York. MTL's tank trucks transport a variety of liquid commodities, from chocolate to peroxide, mostly under the name Montgomery Tank Lines. After the deal closes, Apollo will own about 90 percent of the company; the rest will be owned by management.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It used to be that no one cared about the meetings they were invited to, only the meetings they weren't invited to. We don't have that problem anymore.''

title: Goddesses With a Gimmick In a Seedy Bar
description: The Ohio Ballet, directed by Heinz Poll in Akron, numbers only 18 dancers. It is a splendid company, no longer just a splendid little company, and its latest season at the Joyce Theater opened on Tuesday night with a richly spiced program.

title: More Than the Roses Grow; With Valentine's Day Comes 42% Price Increase, Study Shows
description: A rose is a rose, but at Valentine's Day it is certain to be one very expensive rose.

title: Net at Astra Rose 13% in 4th Quarter
description: Astra A.B., the Swedish drug company, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter net rose 13 percent as it was helped by surging sales of the ulcer treatment Losec, the world's biggest-selling drug. Profit at the company rose to 2.740 billion kronor ($338 million) from 2.423 billion. The results were in line with expectations.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Farley Emerges With 25 To Lead Friars' Uprising
description: PROVIDENCE 74, SETON HALL 73

title: Time for a Fuel Tax; New Urban Coalition
description: To the Editor:

title: Supermodel Buys An African Image
description: When the Tanzania Wildlife Fund asked the photographer HUGER FOOTE to film a documentary in Africa, he took along a still camera. The model CHRISTY TURLINGTON bid $2,500 when one of the photographs was auctioned for the fund's Artists for the African Rain Forest. When last seen, she was leaving the benefit, at Jezebel, at 630 Ninth Avenue, at 45th Street, with the picture under her arm.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAVANAGH, MARGARET
description: KAVANAGH-Margaret. Formerly of Scarsdale NY. On February 10, 1998. Wife of the late William J. Kavanagh. Mother of Gail Wilder and Lynn Chace. Sister of Eunice Allan. Also survived by four grandchildren. Funeral service to be held at the Bennett Funeral Home, 824 Scarsdale Avenue, Scarsdale, New York on Saturday at 11 AM.

title: What Is a College to Do When a Rapist Moves In?
description: Eden Robins, a 19-year-old sophomore at Wesleyan University, was stunned to learn last month that the man living in the house next door was a convicted rapist.

title: Metro Matters; Yes, the Law Is the Law. Then There's Jaywalking.
description: This columnist is beginning to understand Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's frustration.

title: World News Briefs; Britain and Ireland Weigh Sinn Fein Ouster
description: The Irish Republic and British Governments said today that they would decide in a matter of days whether to expel Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, from the Northern Ireland peace talks.

title: An Impressive Show By the U.S. Women
description: Mike Richter, goalie for the Rangers and Team U.S.A. in the Olympics, is an upbeat sort who isn't afraid to express an opinion. During the second intermission of tonight's women's hockey game between the United States and Finland in the Aqua Wing arena, Richter was asked what he thought of the show.

title: Currents; PILLOWS -- Re-Using Vintage Finds
description: Barbara Tisdale, a designer who collects vintage fabrics from the 1940's and 50's, sews throw pillows that manage to avoid kitsch by looking lively and fresh. She makes her pillows, like the ones shown above, from old draperies she finds at estate sales and flea markets.

title: Sharpton Reprimanded by Judge After Exchange in Brawley Trial
description: An extraordinarily heated exchange between lawyers and the Rev. Al Sharpton disrupted his testimony at the Tawana Brawley defamation trial today, prompting the judge to reprimand Mr. Sharpton in front of the jury and Mr. Sharpton's lawyer to accuse the judge of bias.

title: GULFMARK BUYS NORWEGIAN OFFSHORE SUPPLIER
description: Gulfmark Offshore Inc. said yesterday that it had acquired Brovig Supply A.S.A., a Norwegian owner and operator of five offshore support vessels, for $73 million, including the assumption of $37.4 million in debt. Gulfmark, based in Houston, provides marine transportation services. It said it received more than 96 percent of Brovig's shares for the equivalent of $3.07 each under a tender offer it began last month. It expects to acquire the rest of Brovig's shares before the end of March. Before making its tender bid, Gulfmark owned 25 percent of Brovig's 11.6 million shares outstanding.

title: Currents; Some Olympic Winter Fashions -- Have a Speedway for Their Runway
description: The current Winter Olympics offer the

title: Metro Business; Silicon Alley Seeing More Deals and Cash
description: Venture capitalists have been increasing their bet on New York's Silicon Alley in recent years, according to a study by Coopers & Lybrand, the accounting firm.

title: Giuliani Says He Supports Plan For Requiring School Uniforms
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he supported a proposal by the president of the city's Board of Education to require school uniforms in the elementary grades, beginning in the fall of 1999. His endorsement all but assures the measure's adoption by the board next month.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Lincoln's Birthday, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations are suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Software Maker Seeks Services Concern in $8.4 Billion Bid
description: Computer Associates International Inc., a leading maker of business software, made an uninvited $8.4 billion bid yesterday for the Computer Sciences Corporation, a major provider of technology services, that would accelerate the consolidation of an industry in which size is now equated with survival.

title: Group Ends Its Boycott of Mitsubishi Entities
description: What's an environmental group to do, when eight years of boycotts, letter-writing campaigns and such have not stopped the Mitsubishi Corporation of Japan from cutting down old-growth forests?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MUNCH, PETER HOWARD
description: MUNCH-Peter Howard. Of Ft. Lee formerly of Bronx, NY on Feb. 10, 1998. Beloved husband for 69 years of Minerva (nee Vogel). Loving father of Nancy Bilheimer. Mr. Munch founded the Trim Manufacturing Company, Bronx, New York in 1945, which eventually became Division Square D Corporation. He was a recipient of the YMCA Red Triangle Award. He was a philanthropist to charities including Parkchester Kiwanis and Autism Society, and the Helen Keller Services. Funeral services on Friday 6:30PM at the Church of the Good Shepherd, Fort Lee, NJ. Friends will be received Friday 36PM at the Hunt Stellato Funeral Home, 1601 Palisade Ave, Ft. Lee, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Bronx YMCA, 2 Castle Avenue, Bronx, New York 10473 or a charity of your choice.

title: German Skater Goes the Distance
description: The last time Gunda Niemann-Stirnemann raced 3,000 meters at the Olympic Games, she failed to complete even three turns, hitting a lane marker with her skate and taking an uncharacteristic tumble.

title: Kenyan Switches To the Mile
description: Chances for the fastest mile in Madison Square Garden's history improved markedly yesterday when Laban Rotich of Kenya arrived in New York and was immediately switched from the Millrose Games' 800 meters to the Wanamaker Mile.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, HENRY
description: SCHNEIDER-Henry. Beloved husband of Jacqueline. Devoted father of Michael and the late Barbara Bruckner. Loving grandfather of Robert and James Bruckner, Maxwell and Ethan. Service Thursday, 11:30 AM at Park Avenue Synagogue, 87th St. and Madison Avenue. For further information call Plaza Memorial Chapel, 212769-4400. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Columbia Law School or the Central Park Conservancy would be appreciated.

description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CORN DECLINES. Corn prices fell after the Agriculture Department sharply cut its estimate for corn exports, while raising the amount it expects to be in storage in September. The March contract fell 5.5 cents, to $2.6825 a bushel.

title: Black and Yellow and Gold All Over
description: Ilya Kulik of Russia enters the Olympic men's figure skating competition on Thursday morning with the best chance to win and the worst taste in costume selection.

title: New Therapy Offers Promise In Treatment Of Pedophiles
description: A new type of testosterone-reducing drug, coupled with psychotherapy, greatly reduces desire among men to molest children and engage in other deviant sexual behavior, researchers report.

description: RUTGERS 82, GEORGETOWN 63

title: Conservative Christian Leader Accuses Republicans of Betrayal
description: At a closed-door convention of conservative leaders in Arizona last week, James Dobson, who heads the multimedia ministry Focus on the Family, warned that if the Republican Congress continued to ''betray'' conservative evangelical voters, he would abandon the Republican Party and ''do everything I can to take as many people with me as possible.''

title: INSIDE
description: Minimum Wage Rise Sought

title: A Growing Optimism on Ending Graft in Mexico
description: One year ago, as Washington was preparing to certify whether Mexico was a reliable partner in the narcotics war, came stunning charges by the Mexican Government that the general serving as anti-drug czar had sold out and was deploying his troops on behalf of a billionaire trafficker.

title: Jakarta's Plan To Peg Rupiah Powers a Rally Across Region
description: BANGKOK  Despite the opposition of the World Bank and the doubts of many economists, Indonesia confirmed Wednesday that it intended to stabilize its battered currency by pegging it at a fixed rate.

title: On U.S. Carrier, Not Just a Routine Day
description: Strange as it may seem, the routine has not changed much on this immense aircraft carrier plying the deep blue waters of the Persian Gulf on what amounts to the front line of the American military confrontation with Iraq.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with a review of ''The Good Doctor,'' a play at the Theater of Riverside Church, misstated the given name of an actress who appears as a general's wife, as a dishonest employer and in other roles. She is Jane Connell, not June.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEUW, DOROTHY DREXLER
description: LEUW-Dorothy Drexler. The Yeshiva University family is saddened by the passing of a longtime, cherished friend who, with her late husband, Joseph M. Drexler, was a YU Guardian, Founder of our Albert Einstein College of Medicine, and Fellow of our Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law. Mr. Drexler was a former YU Trustee and past Chairman of the Florida Friends of YU. Mrs. Leuw will be missed by the YU administration and all who were privileged to work with this admired philanthropist. May her memory remain as a source of enduring blessing to mankind. We extend our heartfelt condolences to all her loved ones. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: Women's Servitude, With Anger and Sass
description: The vital, bittersweet essence of Tiye Giraud's ''Sugar Tit!,'' a music, theater and dance revue that opened on Tuesday night at Dance Theater Workshop, is captured in its title. The term refers to sugar wrapped in cloth that served as a pacifier given first to the babies of black wet-nurses during slavery and later to poor children whose mothers' milk was depleted. But the term has happier sexual connotations, too, and it is this rich mix of cultural associations that Ms. Giraud and her collaborator Anita Gonzalez explore provocatively.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOWELL, DANIEL J.
description: LOWELL-Daniel J.'42. The City College of New York mourns the passing of Daniel J. Lowell '42. On behalf of the College community I wish to extend my condolences to his brother and City College Fund Board Member, Stanley H. Lowell '39, and to his family. Yolanda T. Moses, President The City College of New York/ CUNY

title: Currents; EXPANSIONS -- Ikea Homes: Why Stop At Interiors?
description: Ikea set the standard for the home superstore and changed the way people bought furnishings for their homes. In a logical next step, the company has begun to make the homes, as well.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN REED, MURIEL
description: VAN REED-Muriel. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Muriel Van Reed, associated with The Times from 1942, until retiring in 1982.

title: A Possible Russian Link to Iraq Arms Buildup
description: United Nations weapons inspectors have found evidence that Russia held discussions with Iraq about selling Baghdad equipment that could be used to develop biological weapons, an official familiar with Iraqi weapons programs said today.

title: Johnson Ends Silence And Denies Back Injury
description: Larry Johnson's Mercedes was waiting for him today in the parking lot at Purchase College. The engine was idling because Johnson had a lot to say.

title: For Kids' Rooms, Bunnies Are Out, Biedermeier Is In
description: WILLIAM SOFIELD, a New York designer, was shopping the East Village for collectible modern furniture for his new clients. At one stop, he spotted a desk by the fabled craftsman George Nakashima, which he envisioned for a bedroom; at another, a spindled chair by Hans Wegner that would be, oh, so modish, too.

title: Shandwick Chief Resigns Amid Takeover Talks
description: Shandwick International P.L.C., the world's biggest independent public relations company, said yesterday that its chief executive, Dermot McNulty, would leave the company as it continued talks with a number of companies that might result in it being taken over. Shandwick disclosed the third-party talks last month after press reports said that the Chicago-based advertising group True North Communications Inc. was preparing to buy Shandwick or to form a joint venture with it.

title: Public Eye; On the Set at TV News, Don't Believe Your Eyes
description: IT is Friday night, and Steve Aveson, an anchor on the Discovery Channel's ''Discovery News,'' is seated at a wood-topped desk. Behind him is a familiar landscape: a cluster of monitors, a world map.

title: Dissonance Among Jews in Israel
description: After months of wrangling, the best efforts by a special Cabinet committee in Israel to resolve a rancorous dispute over ''who is a Jew'' have collapsed. As a result, Reform and Conservative Jews plan to resume their campaign to break the Orthodox rabbinate's monopoly over conversions and other rites in Israel. It is unfortunate, though perhaps not surprising, that Orthodox Jews refused to compromise with non-Orthodox branches of Judaism over whose rites will remain binding. But now, in the absence of an accord, the Government should assure that Israel maintains its identity as a homeland for all Jews, Orthodox and non-Orthodox alike.

title: American Topics : Sweepstakes 'Winners' Learn The Hard Truth of Marketing
description: Richard Lusk, an 88-year-old California man, flew across the country to Tampa, Florida, last week, persuaded that he had won $11 million in the American Family Publishers sweepstakes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETERSON, MATTHEW W.
description: PETERSON-Matthew W. Of Eastchester. On February 10, 1998 at the age of 101. Beloved husband of the late Frances. Devoted father of Frances K. and Matthew C. Peterson. Dear brother of the late Arthur and Cornelius. Loving grandfather of four and greatgrandfather of five. The family will receive friends at the Westchester Funeral Home, Inc., Eastchester, Thurs. and Friday from 24 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Immaculate Conception Church, Tuckahoe, Saturday February 14, 9:45AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. Friends who wish may contribute to the Immaculate Conception Church, 53 Winterhill Rd., Tuckahoe, NY 10707.

description: FLEISCHER-Milton (Mickey). On Feb. 10, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Geraldine. Devoted father of Lesley and Donald Wilk, Benjamin and Carol Fleischer. Cherished grandfather of David, Jodi, Keri, Michael, Sam and Robert. Services Thursday, 9:30A.M., at ''Gutterman's Inc.'', 175 Long Beach Rd., Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROLLENHAGEN, CHARLES ALBERT
description: ROLLENHAGEN-Charles Albert. Age 87 a long time resident of Ridgewood died Tuesday, February 10, 1998. Born in Hoboken, Mr. Rollenhagen was a 1931 graduate with his B.A. in Commercial Science from NY University, with majors in accounting and banking. His first employment was as a bank examiner for the National Board of Bank Examiners. Thereafter he joined the Irving Trust Company of NY where he served as Vice President of bank's operations in the Northeast before his retirement in 1967. He continued to be active in the business world after his retirement, working as a business consultant and serving on the board of directors of First Manufactured Housing Credit Corporation of Albany and National Color Laboratories, Inc. He also joined the board of directors of Becton Dickinson as only the company's second outside director in 1959 and was on the board when the company went public in 1962. He also chaired its finance committee, retiring from the board in 1985. He served for many years as chairman of the Forum School Foundation and president of the Forum School, Waldwick. He was chairman of the Northwest Bergen Chapter of the American Red Cross. He was a member of the West Side Presbyterian Church, Ridgwood. Surviving are his wife Dorothy (nee Amend) Rollenhagen, three sons, David of Chester Springs, PA., Norman of Lexington, VA and Stephen of Ridgewood, two daughters, Cynthia Osterweil of Hackensack, and Nancy Engel of Union. Also surviving are 4 grandchildren. Funeral Services Friday 10AM from the Vander Plaat Funeral Home, 257 Godwin Ave., Wyckoff, NJ. Interment Valleau Cemetery, Ridgewood. Visiting Thursday 2-4 and 7-9PM. In lieu of flowers donations to Forum School Foundation, 107 Wyckoff Ave Waldwick, NJ 07463 or American Red Cross, Bergen Chapter, 74 Godwin Ave. Ridgewood, NJ 07450

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUSSELL, DR. MAURICE V.
description: RUSSELL-Dr. Maurice V. The HIV Clinical Service of the William Alanson White Institute mourns the tragic death of a great humanitarian and leader in the field of social work. Dr. Russell's support, advice, and wisdom were crucial to our study of the psychological aspects of the AIDS epidemic. We will miss his insight, compassion, and friendship. Mark J. Blechner, Ph.D., Director Bertram Schaffner, M.D., Med Dir

description: Sheldon Wasserman, convicted of murdering his wife of 40 years, was sentenced Wednesday to 15 years to life in prison.

description: The release of a Republican senators' report on the suspected Chinese Government effort to influence the 1996 election calls to mind poor old Bob Dole's most memorable line from that campaign. ''Where's the outrage?'' Mr. Dole would cry as he rambled through the heartland. Anyone reading the Senate investigative report could add a second question. Where's the curiosity?

title: In America; Sharpton the Sensitive
description: You can understand Al Sharpton's dilemma. Despite the wild hair and the raucous laughter, he's always been the sensitive sort, concerned about the feelings of others, reluctant to give offense, and careful, oh so careful, with his use of language.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Friday with a front-page article about the globalization of Argentina's economy misstated a statistic about the privatization of state-owned industries in Brazil, cited for comparison. In 1997 Brazil sold off $17.7 billion worth of state enterprises, not $1.7 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, HARVEY H.
description: GORDON-Harvey H. On February 11, 1998. Beloved husband of Rosalyn. Devoted father of Robert and Jennifer, Lisa and Matthew. Dear brother of Stanley Gordon and Harriet Kaufman. Loving grandfather of Matthew, Michael and Cara. Services today, 2PM, at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Gurwin Jewish Geriatric Center or Huntington Hebrew Congregation or Huntington Hosp.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BABKIE, JOSEPH M.
description: BABKIE-Joseph M. Age 82, of Westport, CT., and Ocean Ridge, FL died Saturday, February 7, 1998 at his Florida home. A native of Poland, Mr. Babkie graduated the Polish Maritime Academy and served with distinction in World War II, taking part in various Allied campaigns in the Mediterranean. After the war he emigrated to the U.S. with his wife, Joyce. In 1958 Mr. Babkie co-founded Philipp Overseas, NY of which he was President for many years. In 1975 he established Babkie International Corp and, in 1978, moved the company's offices from New York to Westport. An extraordinary man, Mr. Babkie contributed to many causes, particularly to relief efforts in his native Poland. A certified Master Mariner, Mr. Babkie is survived by his wife, Barbara; three sons: Michael and his wife Andrea of Lantana, Florida; Peter and his wife Janet of Wayland, MA; and Robert and his wife Amy of Weston, CT. He is also survived by his granddaughter, Lisa Babkie Kurker and her husband Theodore of Duxbury, Massachusetts, and two stepdaughters, Katarzyna Piotrowska of Poland and Magdalena Piotrowska of Fairfield, Connecticut. Private family services were held in Florida. A memorial will be held at Mr. Babkie's home in Westport, on Sunday, February 22, 1998, from 5 to 8 P.M. Funeral services will be held in Poland. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to a favorite charity.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about the Republican Congressional strategy on Iraq misstated the home state of Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., who commented. He is a Democrat from Delaware, not Rhode Island.

title: Personal Shopper; Tough, Good-Looking and Safe Under the Smallest Feet
description: FORGET cute little chairs. For children, the floor is where it's happening. New flooring materials take no skill to install, and they also muffle sound.

title: Enemies Right, Left, Everywhere
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton's recent accusation that a ''vast right-wing conspiracy'' exists to destroy her husband and his political agenda was bound to strike a nerve. There has been a lot of loose and malicious talk about the President, the right has spread much of it, and our culture feasts on conspiracy theories. But Mrs. Clinton's allegation is not exactly new.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARRETT, DOROTHY PRATT
description: BARRETT-Dorothy Pratt Register. Died in her Hillsborough home on Tuesday morning, February 10. She is survived by her daughter, Barbara Register, her son, Eliot Steven Barrett and eleven grandchildren: Alexander Barrett of New York, Cessna Barrett of Napa Valley, California, Deming de Grunne of New York, Robin Larned of Marina del Rey, California, Alison Register of Lexington, Kentucky, David Register of Seattle, Washington, Kathryn Register of Malibu, California, Kyle Register of Aiken, South Carolina, Layton Register of Lexington, Kentucky, Leslie Register of Cardiff, California, Peter Register of Los Angeles, California and Stepson, Charles Barrett of Napa Valley, California. Mrs. Barrett was predeceased by two of her sons, Samuel Croft Register and John Sherman Register. Mrs. Barrett was born Dorothy Deming Pratt in Brooklyn, New York on November 1, 1909 to George and Helen Pratt of Glen Cove, Long Island. Her grandfather, Charles Pratt was one of John D. Rockefeller's partners in the formation of the Standard Oil Company, (which is now Exxon), Charles Pratt & Company in New York City and Pratt Institute in Brooklyn, New York was also founded by her grandfather. She attended Miss Hall's School and Vassar College and was a highly skilled horsewoman, sailor and fisherman. In 1932, Dorothy Deming Pratt was married to Samuel Croft Register. They had three children, Samuel Croft Register, Jr, John S. Register and Barbara Register. They were divorced in 1940 and Mrs. Barrett moved to Southern California where she met and married Dr. William G. Barrett in 1942 and gave birth to Eliot Steven Barrett in 1943. She moved to San Mateo County in the 1950's and started a thoroughbred horse farm on extensive acreage in Hillsborough which she named Eucalyptus Hill. The farm enjoyed a fine reputation for breeding and boarding and is believed to have been the first of its kind in San Mateo County. Aragon High School of San Mateo is situated on a portion of that farm's original site. In the 1970's, she moved her thoroughbred horse operations to Once Over Farm in Morgan Hill where she still maintains horses and provides boarding and training services to thoroughbreds. Dorothy Pratt Barrett was a member of the Burlingame Country Club. She had many philanthropic interests, enjoyed a good hand of bridge and frequent trips to Once Over Farm to see her horses. A Memorial Service will be held at the First Presbyterian Church, Glen Cove, Long Island, New York at 11 AM, on February 21st. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be sent to Pratt Institute, 200 Willoughby Avenue, Brooklyn, N.Y. 11205.

title: Quickly Quotable
description: ''A friend in the midwest sent me an item gleaned from the local personal ads: SWM seeking DAPHNE MERKIN type for the usual involvement in pleasure,'' Ms. Merkin, who chronicled her sexual passions, including a taste for spanking, in The New Yorker magazine last year, told an audience at Barnard College last night. ''Somewhere along the way, I had become an unwitting symbol. Not quite what I had in mind when I bared my soul, but nakedness is always risky.''

title: Recchi Takes Kariya's Place
description: Paul Kariya, the superstar left wing of the Mighty Ducks of Anaheim, will not play for Canada because of a concussion he sustained Feb. 1. Kariya will be replaced by Montreal's Mark Recchi. The next round of the tournament begins Friday.

title: Bertelsmann Changes Leadership at Bantam Doubleday Dell
description: Bantam Doubleday Dell shuffled its top leadership yesterday, moving its chief executive, Jack Hoeft, into an international job with reduced duties and creating a new position for the head of its publishing operations in North America.

title: Get Used to New West, Land Managers Tell the Old West
description: The three biggest landlords in the United States, gathered here today at a forum on the future of public lands, left no doubt with a crowd of cowboys, county commissioners and urban environmentalists that the New West of wolves and wilderness protection is here to stay.

title: Maine Voters Repeal a Law On Gay Rights
description: In a landmark victory for Christian conservatives, Maine voters have narrowly chosen to make their state the first in the nation to repeal its law protecting gay men and lesbians from discrimination, according to all-but-official referendum results published today.

title: Currents; MAKEOVER -- Making Paint Buying As Festive as Possible
description: Ralph Lauren and Martha Stewart have lent their cachet to house paint. But paint shopping often still feels like a trip to the hardware store. So the Janovic Plaza chain asked a New York architect, Jennifer Sage of Sage Wimer Coombe in TriBeCa, to rethink its store at 1150 Third Avenue (67th Street) to make buying paint ''more like a fashion experience,'' in her words. ''The idea is to take buying paint from the hardware store to Warner Brothers, or Bloomingdale's main floor,'' said Ms. Sage, who was I. M. Pei's senior associate for design on the Rock-and-Roll Hall of Fame.

title: Panel to Seek New Rules To Speed Up Executions
description: A commission formed by Gov. Christine Todd Whitman in August began trying yesterday to find out why it takes so long to carry out the death penalty. No one has been put to death in New Jersey since capital punishment was reinstated in 1982.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MARKS, MORRIS
description: MARKS-Morris. Daddy dear, I miss you always but your birthday is a special time to say...I love you. Selma

title: RIVAL OFFER EMERGES FOR BURLINGTON TRUST UNITS
description: The Devon Energy Corporation of Oklahoma City said yesterday that it would make a tender offer of $8.75 in cash for each of the 8.8 million units of Burlington Resources Coal Seam Gas Royalty Trust, giving it ownership of a methane field in New Mexico. The offer, valued at as much as $77 million, is the second for units of the trust in three weeks. On Jan. 20, San Juan Partners L.L.C., a closely held oil and gas partnership in Houston, offered to buy 5.45 million units for $8.25 each. The holdings of the Dallas-based Burlington Resources trust include an interest in the Northeast Blanco field in New Mexico. Burlington Resources trust units rose 87.5 cents, to $8.9375. Devon Energy fell $1, to $34.75.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEL BALSO, TOBI ROSEN
description: del BALSO-Tobi Rosen. Of Riverdale. The best friend we ever had. Died February 10, 1998. Much too soon, after a long illness of cancer and multiple sclerosis. She was a teacher and counselor who changed the lives of everyone she met. She is survived by her husband Paul, father George E. Rosen, nieces Jill and Tina, nephew Eric and all her friends. Services will be held Friday, 12:30 P.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: German Wins the Halfpipe
description: By the time it ended, it should have been called slushboard, not snowboard.

title: The Pop Life; Clarence Carter On Persevering
description: There may be some debate over whether a concert by Clarence Carter, the 60's rhythm-and-blues singer, is the right place to take a date on Valentine's Day. In the lyrics to his first hit, ''Slip Away,'' he tries to coax a woman into sneaking off with him for a night behind her lover's back. And his last big hit, ''Strokin','' is a jukebox favorite among good ol' boys who enjoy singing along with lyrics that value lust over love and quantity over commitment. But then again, no matter how he expresses it, Mr. Carter has soul -- in portions as large as those allotted to Wilson Pickett and Solomon Burke -- and the deep-voiced spoken-word sections he sprinkles into his songs add up to instant seduction, equal parts preacher, pimp and parent.

title: A Trove Of Dada Goes to Israel
description: Arturo Schwarz, the scholar, poet, art dealer and passionate collector from Milan, has given the Israel Museum more than 700 Dada and Surrealist artworks that experts say are worth more than $20 million. The gift includes paintings, drawings, collages, sculptures, objects, photographs and prints.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: U.S. Says Force Will Be Set To Launch Strike in a Week
description: The commander of American forces in the Persian Gulf said today that the United States would be ready ''within a week or so'' to launch a significant attack that would seek to seriously weaken Saddam Hussein's hold on power.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALL, ALBERT S.
description: WALL-Albert S. Age 78. Retired editor, died Wednesday, February 4, 1998 at his home in Dobbs Ferry, New York. Survivors include his wife, Mary Sprague Wall of Dobbs Ferry, a son, Anthony Wall of Jackson Hole, Wyoming, and a daughter, Katharine Wall of Cambridge, Massachusetts. Memorial donations may be made to The Dobbs Ferry Library. A memorial service in celebration of his life will be held at The Tarrytown Boat Club in April.

title: Canadian's Gold Medal Is in the Arbitrators' Hands
description: An arbitration panel met today to decide whether to return a gold medal to a Canadian snowboarder or to uphold the International Olympic Committee's decision to take the medal away because the athlete tested positive for marijuana.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOTUK, RICHARD
description: KOTUK-Richard. Documentary film maker, on February 10, 1998. He is survived by his parents John and Victoria Kotuk, his sister Maggie, his niece Amanda and nephew Nick.

title: Amid Layoffs, Wells BDDP Loses Two More Accounts
description: Wells BDDP, the ailing New York advertising agency, has lost two more accounts and has begun layoffs related to the departure last month of a third client.

title: Martin Decision Could Increase Course Traffic
description: Golf has only begun to feel the ramifications of Casey Martin's victory in court yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENSON, MARGUERITE BAILEY
description: ROSENSON-Marguerite Bailey. February 8, 1998. Age 97. Beloved mother of Barbara Bailey Bedevian and mother-in-law of A. Jack Bedevian. Former editor and publisher of the Harlem Valley Times in Amenia, N.Y. and member of the Board of Visitors of the New York State Commission of Mental Hygiene. Her courageous spirit touched all who knew her.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Tuesday comparing the operating results of Trans World Airlines with those of other airlines carried an erroneous label for 1997 results. They were for the 12 months ended in September, not for the first 9 months of the year. T.W.A., for example, had an operating loss of $30 million for the first 9 months, but a loss of $263 million for the year.

title: Nominee Is Confirmed After Retreat in War on 'Activist Judges'
description: What some Republicans had once hoped would be an opportunity to press the claim that President Clinton is filling the courts with out-of-control judges became instead a low-key debate today that ended in the confirmation of Margaret M. Morrow to be a Federal district judge in California.

title: For Street and Coach, It's a Matter of Trust
description: On the morning of the race that would define Picabo Street as an Olympic champion forever, her coach skied the mountain and reached a conclusion. This super-G course looked more to him like a downhill course.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGSON, ARNOLD
description: BERGSON-Arnold. The Officers and employees of Acordia Northeast deeply mourn the passing of Arnold Bergson, Chairman Emeritus. Arnold was the founding father of the predecessor companies in N.Y. and a great leader. He was a man amongst men and will be truly missed. Our sympathies are extended to his lovely wife Jeanne, his daughters, Jane and Barbara and their families.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PANZARELLA, DR. FRANK P.
description: PANZARELLA-Dr. Frank P. On Feb. 10, 1998. Devoted father of Frank Jr., Nancy and the late Paul. Grandfather of Christopher and Allison. Son of the late Amalia and Angelo. Father-in-law to Meredith. Beloved brother of Angela, Eva, Theresa, John, Joseph and the late Edward, Stanley and Arthur. Brother-in-law of Laura and Tommi. Dr. Panzarella, Ph.D. in Biochemistry, was CEO and President of Doak Pharmaceutical Company. He purchased Doak in the early 1960's and originated the skin care dermatologic concept which resulted in his discovery of Formula 405 and many other dermatological products. He graduated from Bates College in 1930, was sent to England during W.W. II and completed his Ph.D. in biochemistry a few years later. He then became a professor at Fordham University. He was honored as Man of the Year Boys Town of Italy and owned Horti Laboratories. Dr. Panzarella who was 89 on January 17th had end stage kidney disease. He admired Dr. Speck, CEO of Columbia Presbyterian Hospital in Manhattan, for presenting to him the finest group of doctors who helped him to survive because of his determination and will never to give up. ''Every day,'' he would say, ''is beautiful because I am alive.'' He inculcated so many around him with a profound respect for life for the elders in our society. Reposing at Edward F. Lieber Funeral Home, 266 North Central Avenue, Valley Stream. Visitation Thursday and Friday, 2 to 4 and 7 to 9. Funeral mass on Saturday, 9 AM, at Blessed Sacrament RC Church. Interment St. Charles Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. In lieu of flowers please send a donation to benefit the Dialysis Department at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center, 622 W. 168 St, NYC toward the purchase of a new EKG machine and stateof-the-art dialysis machine. May God bless all of the people who became a part of our father's life.

title: Taxi Leases Lead to Accidents
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DI DIA, BALDASSARE G. (BUDDY)
description: DI DIA-Baldassare G. (Buddy). Age 80. Born February 11, 1917. Died Wednesday, February 4, 1998. Recently of Bogota, New Jersey. Prior to that, Preston Hollow, N.Y. and Brooklyn, N.Y. Beloved husband of Nancy Giampietro Di Dia. Devoted father of Nancy J. Di Dia and Maria Di Dia Salmon. Devoted father-in-law of Douglas E. Salmon. Loving grandfather of Stephanie, Scott, Sean and Seth Salmon. We are eternally grateful for your love and care of our mother these 54 years. Rest in peace. Visiting Friday, 2-4 and 79PM. Funeral services Friday 8PM at the Volk/Lever Funeral Home, 789 Teaneck Road, Teaneck, NJ 07666. Cremation private. Memorial donations to the Alzheimer's Association or the Actors Fund of America, Inc., Nursing and Retirement Home, Englewood, N.J.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VOSS, FREDERICK, L.
description: VOSS-Frederick, L. of Venice, Florida, formerly of Islip and Bridgehampton, NY, on February 11, 1998. Long time president of Overton Funeral Home, Inc. Beloved husband of the late Shirley Overton Voss. Cherished father of Nancy Buehler and Deborah Koch. Devoted grandfather of Eric Buehler and Benjamin Koch. Dear father-in-law of Frank Buehler and Richard Koch. Fond brother-in-law of A. Wayne and Lois Overton and Joyce and Jack Atherton. Visiting Friday 2-5 and 7-9 PM at the Overton Funeral Home, 172 Main Street, Islip, NY. Funeral Sat., 10 AM at St. Mark's Episcopal Church, Islip, New York. Interment Emmanuel Church Cemetery, Great River, NY. In lieu of flowers the family requests donations to Hospice of the South Shore, 14 Shore La., Bay Shore, NY 11706, St. Mark's Church, Main St., Islip, NY 11751 or South Side Garden Club, 480 Smith Avenue, Islip, NY 11751

title: Confounding Expectations Great and Small
description: JACK MAGGS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HASS, JOSEPH
description: HASS-Joseph. The partners of Rosen & Reade deeply mourn the passing of Joseph Hass, the father of our senior partner Erwin Hass. We express our sincere condolences to Erwin, his wife Maria, his children and all of the family.

title: Dance Notes; No Filmmaker At Cunningham
description: Elliot Caplan, the highly regarded director of dance films like ''Beach Birds for Camera'' and the documentary ''Cage/Cunningham,'' has left his position as the resident filmmaker at the Merce Cunningham Dance Company. The Cunningham company, the only major American modern-dance troupe with a continuing involvement in film and video, has also in effect eliminated its media department.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORRIS, GRINNELL
description: MORRIS-Grinnell. Died February 5, in Naples, Florida. Survived by his wife Cornelia and sons Grinnell Jr, Stephen, Frederic and Daniel. Also by his brother John. A memorial service will be held on Sunday March 8, at St. Johns Church, Cold Spring Harbor, L.I. at 1pm. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to Planned Parenthood of Suffolk County, Smithtown or St. Johns Church, Cold Spring Harbor.

title: Clinton Is Reported Set to Propose Rise in the Minimum Wage
description: President Clinton plans to propose increasing the minimum wage by $1 an hour over the next two years, Democrats say, an initiative that sets up the possibility of an election-year battle with Republicans.

title: Economic Scene; The I.M.F. must go, critics say, but who will cope with crises?
description: DOES anybody like the International Monetary Fund? The half-century-old super-governmental agency has long been out of favor with the political right, which sees it as a usurper of sovereignty and the enemy of free markets. The left is no friendlier, condemning it as a collection agency for international bankers.

title: Julian Simon, 65, Optimistic Economist, Dies
description: Julian L. Simon, an economist and professor who spent much of his professional life taking on scientists, demographers and other academics who argued that mankind was stretching the resources of the earth to the breaking point, died at his home in Chevy Chase, Md., on Sunday.

title: Samsung Motors Seeks Alliance to Raise Capital
description: Samsung Motors Inc., a fledgling unit of the Samsung Group of South Korea, said yesterday that it was negotiating to raise new capital from foreign auto manufacturers as part of a strategic alliance. ''We are seeking a strategic tie-up with a foreign company,'' said its chairman, Lim Kyung Choon. Ford, Chrysler and BMW are the most likely candidates for a partnership, analysts said.

title: In New Jersey, an Olympic Dream Is Snuffed Out
description: Clark Ferry Jr. was buried today with a honey jar and a security blanket, symbols of his dream and his effort to compete in the Olympics. Ferry, a 21-year-old member of the United States bobsled development team, was killed Saturday morning when a car struck him as he walked along Route 9 in Marlboro Township.

title: Ford Is Considering A Stock Repurchase
description: The Ford Motor Company's board will consider a stock buyback to buoy its shares after completing the spinoff of its consumer finance unit this quarter, according to its chief financial officer, John Devine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERNBERG, LEO
description: STERNBERG-Leo. Through your art you created beauty. Through your life you created love, humor and wisdom. We love you, uncle Leo. Ellen, Nathan, Akiba and Leah Kolodney

title: John McEnroe Sr. Wards Off Mugger
description: The father of the tennis legend John McEnroe had his pocket picked last evening while riding the subway to his son's art gallery in SoHo, the police said.

title: Let's Hear It for the D's: Princeton Re-evaluates Its Grading System
description: Princeton University has long prided itself on attracting some of the brightest students in the country. But now the university is growing concerned that its students may be doing too well in class -- for reasons that have little to do with smarts.

title: Senate, 54-42, Rejects Republican Bill to Ban Human Cloning
description: The Senate today soundly defeated a Republican measure to ban human cloning, as a dozen Republicans joined Democrats to urge prudence, expressing grave concerns about the bill's effect on scientific research.

title: Currents; LIGHTING -- Not Unlike a Hot Tamale
description: Sing Ken Ken, a Balinese store in San Francisco, has a new collection of table lamps called tamales -- because they are covered with corn husks. The lamps produce a soothing, exotic glow that reveals their soft natural hues, seams and beguiling grain.

title: Senate Blocks a Ban On Human Cloning
description: Expressing grave concerns about limiting scientific research, Senate Democrats, joined by a dozen Republicans, today soundly defeated a Republican measure that sought to ban human cloning.

title: Time for a Fuel Tax
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- Gospel According to St. Luke's; Brash British Agency Turns the Old Rules Upside Down
description: The renovated toffee factory on the edge of the Bloomsbury district is no ordinary office. For one thing, none of the 100 or so workers -- mostly denim-clad men and women in their 20's and 30's -- have their own offices, or even their own desks. They pick up portable phones in the morning from a recharging rack and seat themselves just about anywhere.

title: Private Group Signs Central Park Deal To Be Its Manager
description: Making formal New York City's gradual surrender of operational control of Central Park, a private group yesterday officially assumed much of the day-to-day management of the city's premier open space.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EMDEN, LEONA
description: EMDEN-Leona. A sensitive flower in a garden grew. A gentle, loving and kind person who touched our lives with her great courage and strength. We will miss you. Margie, Bobby, David, Lauren, Jimmy, Betty, Jason and Andrew Emden

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDMAN, ESTHER
description: FELDMAN-Esther. On February 9, 1998. Beloved aunt of Patricia Langer and Phillip Feldman. Great-aunt to Alita, Susan, Mona and Brenda. Services private. For information, contact ''The Riverside'' at 212-362-6600.

title: Overstepping on Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Suspect in Fatal Beating Near St. Patrick's Day Parade Is Acquitted
description: A Brooklyn teen-ager charged with killing a high school student during a brawl at last year's St. Patrick's Day parade was acquitted of all counts yesterday by a Manhattan jury.

title: World News Briefs; Jew Stabbed to Death In East Jerusalem
description: A Jew was stabbed to death on his way to morning prayers today in East Jerusalem. The police said the killer was apparently a Palestinian militant.

title: His Legacy: Trains Run on Time
description: Donald N. Nelson, the president of the Metro-North Commuter Railroad since 1991, will step down to take a job at the freight carrier Conrail, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority announced yesterday. Mr. Nelson, 62, has been an executive at Metro-North since its inception in 1983 and helped turn the remnants of the old New York Central Railroad into the region's most reliable commuter carrier, with an on-time performance rate of 98.1 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLIMACK, ALFRED
description: PLIMACK-Alfred. His sisters, his children, grandchildren and greatgrandchildren will all miss him dearly. Alfred's lifetime of art is a cherished legacy to his family and remains a treasure for all.

title: Rethink, India's Communists Say
description: When Jyoti Basu arrived for an election rally in this town on the southern fringes of Calcutta, a crowd of about 25,000 people greeted him with shouts of ''Lal Salaam!'' meaning ''Red Salute!'' The podium was draped with red bunting and a hammer-and-sickle insignia. Mr. Basu's first words were in similar vein. ''Comrades,'' he said, ''I bring you fraternal greetings!''

title: Defender in Chief Says Scandal Will Soon Pass
description: President Clinton's First Defender confidently surveyed the political landscape today and allowed a slow smile of satisfaction to cross her face as she predicted that the current hubbub over questions of her husband's fidelity would soon fade.

title: Athletes Call for the Return of a Gold Medal
description: ''ROSS IS THE CHAMPION. GIVE THE GOLD BACK!''

title: Sometimes It's Best To View Art in Art
description: To the Editor:

title: Analyzing the Family on the Living Room Couch
description: IT was midnight, and an Upper East Side husband and wife were doing what they had been doing since 9 P.M.: threatening, bribing, finally yelling, then feeling guilty, as they battled to get their 5-year-old to sleep. When the couple finally staggered to bed, they found themselves dreading the next night, and the next. Looking for relief, they called their family psychiatrist, Stanley Turecki, who makes house calls to parents caught in a frustrating cycle involving their child's behavior and their own response.

title: Garden Notebook; A Trove of Camellias, Under Glass
description: CAMELLIA fever runs highest in the South, where the shapely winter-flowering evergreen shrubs flourish outdoors. But you don't need to head south for camellias if the Planting Fields Arboretum in Oyster Bay is within visiting distance. Vincent Kreutz, the camellia curator, said his 430 charges, the largest camellia collection under glass in the United States, should peak on Valentine's Day.

title: One Sailor's Priorities Far From Home
description: When Defense Secretary William S. Cohen met with the crew on the carrier George Washington here in the Persian Gulf, a sailor today wondered about priorities of the American public.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAYMAN, ARTHUR ''ARCHIE''
description: HAYMAN-Arthur ''Archie''. On October 15, 1920-February 7, 1998. Beloved husband of Anna Marie ''Gogo'', devoted father of Nicholas, Laura, and Karen, loving brother of Seymour ''Sy'' and the late Paul, dear uncle of Ellen Gellman, Robert, Jonathan and Valerie Hayman. Private services.

title: Istanbul Journal; Last Night, Turkey Really Cashed In Its Chips
description: The beautiful and not-so-beautiful people were losing their money as usual on Wednesday evening at Turkey's casinos, feeding the slot machines and watching intently as female croupiers dipped low to scoop up chips at roulette and poker tables.

title: Limelight Owner Is Acquitted After Long Fight in Drug Case
description: Peter Gatien, the prominent nightclub owner who was accused of turning two of his Manhattan clubs into virtual drug supermarkets, was acquitted yesterday by a Federal jury that did not believe the array of former drug dealers that the Government used as its main witnesses.

title: A Trio of Pit Bulls Attacks Schoolchildren
description: Three pit bulls attacked a group of elementary school students during recess in Atlantic City on Tuesday, biting and scratching 15 children and the two adults who tried to fight off the dogs, the police said.

title: Misha Dichter Pays Hirschfeld Homage
description: Nina hunters will understand what the pianist MISHA DICHTER has been doing since he picked up the AL HIRSCHFELD drawing he commissioned for his 30th wedding anniversary.

title: 'Memorable Moment' Sinking In
description: Unlike the Winter Olympics, the game was not played halfway around the world in Nagano, Japan. But temblors could be felt all over the soccer world yesterday after the United States shocked the defending world champion, Brazil, 1-0, in a semifinal match of the Concacaf Gold Cup on Tuesday night in Los Angeles.

title: Grand Jury Leaks? Only Press Knows
description: To the Editor:

title: Nagano's Sad Refrain: Downhill Is Postponed
description: This time, the men's downhill actually got a couple of skiers out of the start before the race was postponed. Unfortunately, they were only the runners who test the mountain, and when one of them skied off the course in a steady downpour of pellet-like rain, arms went up in disgust, jackets went on, helmets came off and the nightmare of a weather-plagued Alpine Olympics continued.

title: Lawrence Sanders, 78, Author Of Crime and Suspense Novels
description: Lawrence Sanders, whose first novel, the 1970 suspense thriller ''The Anderson Tapes,'' catapulted him into the front ranks of durable and best-selling genre authors, died on Saturday at his home in Pompano Beach, Fla. He was 78.

title: Opponent Challenges Newark Mayor's Report
description: In a speech rebutting Mayor Sharpe James's glowing State of the City address, a political opponent on the City Council yesterday attacked the Mayor's claim to have created 25,000 jobs in the past year and the rosy picture he painted of the city's future even as unemployment continues to soar.

title: Shakespeare's Words In Media Sound Bites For a Tricky Richard
description: The gang of liars, thieves, cowards and killers that inhabits Shakespeare's ''Richard III'' has never looked more familiar than it does in Moonwork's smart production at the Stella Adler Conservatory. But there are moments when this bloody crew can make the audience squirm in ways they never would in a conventional version or recent updatings that have seen them as Nazis or mobsters, for this conception of the play, directed by Gregory Wolfe, turns a wickedly distorting mirror directly on us, right now.

title: Army Walls Off the Kurds
description: About 7,000 Turkish soldiers have crossed into northern Iraq in recent days, according to news accounts here, reportedly to prevent a surge of Iraqi Kurds from flooding into Turkey should the United States and its allies attack Iraq. Such an influx occurred after the Persian Gulf war in 1991.

title: Louima Has Surgery To Reverse Colostomy
description: Abner Louima, who was allegedly beaten and tortured by police officers last August, was in stable condition yesterday after surgery to repair his damaged colon and reverse his colostomy, the hospital and one of his lawyers said.

title: Artist Formerly Known as Brother
description: ''I just call him 'brother,' '' SHARON NELSON BLAKLEY said, ''but if I'm mad at him, I call him something else. No one else can pronounce the symbol, that's for sure.''

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: WFS FINANCIAL INC., Irvine, Calif., said it would lay off 150 workers in the next three months as it consolidates offices. It also reported a 32 percent drop in fourth-quarter profit as delinquencies increased on its auto loans.

title: 'Samson' Revived, in Blinding Color
description: How do you reinvent an opera?

title: Nets Pursue Hardaway, But the Deal Slips Away
description: The vision danced in the heads of John Calipari and John Nash: Penny Hardaway in a Nets uniform, holding aloft the team's first National Basketball Association championship trophy.

title: Editorial Observer; Wondering How 'The Capeman' Fell to Earth
description: During intermission, a woman seated in the row behind me said that she had known the Capeman himself -- Salvador Agron, the Puerto Rican gang member who killed two teen-agers in 1959 and who is the subject of Paul Simon's troubled new musical. ''I knew him,'' she said, in a way that made it clear she only wished she had known Agron. Then she and her friend, contemplating the embers of the first half of ''The Capeman,'' began to try out synonyms for the word ''flat.''

title: Ah, What Was It Like to Be 12?
description: Reeling backward in time, putting aside their adult sensibilities, a handful of people in book publishing think like 12-year-olds. Which is very tricky to do. But it's necessary to produce ''preteen and teen'' reading stuff that passes, sometimes, for books, although one editor called the genre her ''pop fan book wall posters.'' The Hardy Boys and Nancy Drew still sell, but nothing like the Hanson boys, the Spice Girls or the gush publishing of the Leonardo DiCaprio scrapbook.

title: Battle Forecast As a Seed Giant Goes on Block
description: The DeKalb Genetics Corporation, the second-largest seed company in the nation, said today that it was putting itself up for sale, setting the stage for a battle for biotechnology supremacy in agriculture.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WYMAN, THOMAS M.
description: WYMAN-Thomas M. February 9, 1998. Beloved husband of Llana. Son of Olga Resseguier and the late Charles A. Wyman. Brother of John H. Wyman and Virginia A. Meyer. Uncle of Christina and Charles Wyman, and Edward and Katharine Meyer. Interment private. Memorial Service is to be announced. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to Panwy Foundation, Inc., 10 Valley Drive, Greenwich, Connecticut 06831.

title: Rao Gazprom and ENI Reach $3 Billion Deal
description: Russian and Italian companies signed six accords yesterday during a visit to Rome by President Boris Yeltsin of Russia, with the biggest deal worth more than $3 billion and involving Rao Gazprom of Russia and Ente Nazionale Idrocarburi, or ENI S.p.A., of Italy. Mr. Yeltsin and the Italian Prime Minister, Romano Prodi, presided over the signing ceremonies at a conference of Russian and Italian businessmen.

title: Democrats Rally Behind Tough Antismoking Bill in Congress
description: Vice President Al Gore and a flock of Democratic lawmakers rallied today behind one of the toughest antismoking measures pending before Congress and left no doubt that they hoped to gain maximum political mileage against Republicans out of the issue.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE MARK WEAKENS. The mark slipped against the dollar and the pound, hurt by a report showing weak German retail sales and by news that some Bank of England policy makers wanted to raise interest rates last month.

title: Youth Is Accused of Killing to Get $2 for Junk Food
description: Seasoned detectives accustomed to the tough streets of Brownsville, Brooklyn, were stunned, and not only by the young age of the 15-year-old they arrested yesterday in the January slaying of a Latvian immigrant who worked in a laundry at a public housing project.

title: Victim of Framing by 2 Police Officers Wins $5,000 in Payments From Them
description: New York City taxpayers have already paid Daniel Batista $650,000 for the 13 months he spent behind bars after he was framed by two corrupt police officers.

title: Two Friends Inject New Life Into Knights
description: Linda Miles, the 1997 high school player of the year in Cincinnati, always assumed she would follow her fellow high school standout and close friend Natasha Pointer of Chicago wherever that all-America point guard chose to play college basketball.

title: Design Notebook; The Windsor Hoopla: Reading the Poignant Subtext
description: AUCTIONS are about shopping. But increasingly, they are becoming a chance to reflect on the ultimate futility of acquisition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VOGEL, ROSLYN
description: VOGEL-Roslyn. Suddenly on February 10, 1998. Devoted mother of Sharon Engler and Madine Singer, loving sister of Evelyn Hoffman and Gloria Berkowitz, and cherished grandmother of Natalie Engler Mentis, Myron Mentis, Rachelle Engler, Nancy Singer, Eve Singer, and dear friend of Leon Aronsky. Religious services Friday, 10 A.M. from I.J. Morris Funeral Home, 1895 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn. Interment Mount Lebanon Cemetery.

title: Loans Extended by South Korean Banks
description: In a sign the Government's grip on the banking system remains strong, South Korean lending institutions agreed Wednesday to extend by two months nearly $9 billion of loans to domestic businesses due in March.

title: Bridge; Today's Aggressive Bidding And One of Its Useful Tricks
description: The Young Guard of American bridge uses aggressive bidding methods that would surprise the stars of yesteryear. Jeff Meckstroth and Eric Rodwell have won several world titles and are expected to win more but have not revealed their secrets in print. Larry Cohen and David Berkowitz, who are likely to win world honors some day, have been slightly more forthcoming: Cohen has effectively developed the Law of Total Tricks, which guides players in deciding how far to bid in competitive auctions.

title: Jones Ally Is Buoyant As She Sees Tide Turn
description: ''Paula and I watched Clinton's press conference together last Friday,'' said Susan Carpenter-McMillan, chief defender and explainer of Paula Corbin Jones. ''And we kept saying to each other, 'Can you believe this man? Can you believe his chutzpah?' ''

title: Bronx Police Seek Man In Abduction Attempts
description: A would-be child abductor was being sought by police officers in the Bronx yesterday following four failed attempts to whisk away young girls as they walked to and from school, the police said.

title: South Africans Feel at Home at New England Lift
description: Why would 20 South Africans, most of them in the their mid-20's, want to leave a Southern Hemisphere summer to stand day after freezing day at the base of a New England ski lift?

title: Garden Q.& A.
description: Mantra for a Worm

title: Indonesia Cracks Down as Protests Hit Capital
description: Slapping himself vigorously on the stomach, a man in a brown shirt shouted, ''We are hungry!'' as a line of riot policemen with plastic shields moved forward today for their biggest crackdown yet on street demonstrators here in the capital.

title: AFTERMARKET TECHNOLOGIES BUYING AUTO PARTS UNIT
description: The Aftermarket Technology Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire an auto parts manufacturing unit of Fred Jones Industries for $125 million. The division, which like the privately held parent company is based in Oklahoma City, rebuilds drive trains and electronic parts used in the repair of passenger cars and light trucks. It has annual sales of $150 million and 1,500 employees. Aftermarket, based in Westmont, Ill., makes transmissions and other drive-train products. Its stock rose $2.50 a share yesterday, to $22.50. At the closing, Aftermarket will pay $112.5 million. It will pay as much as $12.5 million more in 1999 based on the performance of the division's European operations during 1998.

title: Taxi Leases Lead to Accidents
description: To the Editor:

title: Grand Jury Leaks? Only Press Knows; A Privileged Class
description: To the Editor:

title: Dow Hits a High Again, but Not All Blue Chips Are Joining in the Rally
description: The Dow Jones industrial average is back, finally regaining all the ground lost since its August peak and the October market plunge. But the news is not good for all the big names in this marquee stock measure, even though it inched to a second consecutive record yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBINO, IMELDA COLTON
description: RUBINO-Imelda Colton. On February 11, 1998. Ret. McKasson Corporation. Loving wife of Daniel M. Rubino. Dear aunt of two nieces, one nephew, and three cousins. Friends may call at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Ave. (at 20th St.), Thursday 2-5 PM only, and Friday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Church of the Epiphany, on Saturday, 10 AM. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: Olympic Highlights
