description: TRUST AT HIGH SPEED -- Four years ago a skier on Herwig Demschar's team died on a downhill course, a tragedy that drove the coach away from the Austrian program. Now he is the American women's coach, and Picabo Street's belief in him brought her a gold medal in the super-giant slalom. Page C1.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANCONA, VICTOR
description: ANCONA-Victor. On February 10, peacefully, at New York Hospital, in his 86th year. Husband of Ruth Ancona, father of Barry Ancona and Ronnie Ancona, father-in-law of Shannon Carr and Steven Cole, grandfather of Polly Ancona Carr and David Ancona-Cole. Artist and student of the arts. Graduate of Erasmus Hall High School and Parsons School of Design. Commercial artist, advertising executive, video art critic, civic volunteer. No services, at his request.

title: Treasury Prices Rally on Inflation Outlook
description: Treasury securities rallied sharply yesterday and pushed long-term yields to the lowest level this month on optimism about mild inflation and good demand for new Government securities at the quarterly refunding auction.

title: Gingrich Calls for Hearings on I.M.F.'s Role
description: Representative Newt Gingrich, the Speaker of the House, called today for a series of Congressional hearings into the International Monetary Fund to determine whether it is an institution that had ''outlived its usefulness.''

title: Essay; The Talking-Pointer
description: Like the purloined letter in Edgar Allan Poe's story, the smoking gun in the most recent Clinton scandal is in plain sight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, ETHEL
description: KLEIN-Ethel. February 11, 1998 in her ninetieth year. Beloved and loving mother of Muriel Casper Weithorn of Portola Valley, CA and Dr. Monroe Klein of Union, N.J. Amazing grandmother of Dr. Corey Casper, Jane Darrow and her husband Paul, Andrew Klein and Susan Klein-the joys of her life. Great grandmother of Evan and Jesse Darrow. Sister of Irving Lippy, Bernard Lippy, and the late Jack Lippy. Services Friday, 10AM, Beth Israel Mausoleum, Woodbridge, N.J. For further information call 908-686-4603.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, MILTON W.
description: BROWN-Milton W. The faculty, staff and students of The Graduate School and University Center, CUNY, are deeply saddened by the passing of Professor Emeritus Milton W. Brown, co-founder of our Doctoral Program in Art History and its first executive officer. Dr. Brown was a devoted teacher to a generation of our students and a ground-breaking scholar in the field of 20th Century American art history. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife Blanche. Frances Degen Horowitz, President

title: Big Board Seat at Record
description: A seat on the New York Stock Exchange sold yesterday for $1.75 million, matching the record set on Dec. 23. The current higher bid, or highest price buyers are prepared to pay for a seat on the Big Board, is $1.325 million while the lowest posted selling price is $1.85 million. A seat confers membership on a securities or commodities exchange. The New York Stock Exchange has 1,366 seats; the number has been constant since 1953.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; The dividend-earnings link may not be what it seems.
description: WHICH is more likely to see its earnings rise this year: Company A, which raised its dividend last year, or Company B, which cut its dividend?

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Off the Menu column of the Dining section yesterday about the opening of a bistro in SoHo misstated its name. It is Bistro les Amis, not Bistro des Amis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHER, FRANCES
description: FISHER-Frances. Devoted wife of the late Louis. Adored mother of Sefra and Robert. Dearest sister of Sol, Leah, Jack and Hilda. Cherished grandmother of Jared and Colin. Services Friday, 10AM, Gramercy Chapels, 2nd Ave and 10 St, NYC.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LASKY, DIANA
description: LASKY-Diana. Beloved wife of Burton. Devoted mother of Andrew. Dear sister of Deanna Chaunet. Service on Friday, 11:30 A.M., Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Woman Killed at Brooklyn Laundromat
description: A Brooklyn woman who was watching her clothes dry in a laundromat was killed yesterday evening when two would-be robbers emptied their pistols into the store, the police said.

title: In CBS's Winter Logic, Canned Upstages Live
description: By the time CBS viewers watched Picabo Street win an Olympic gold medal last night in the women's super-G on CBS, the race was nearly 24 hours old.

title: Sports of The Times; These Games Are a Lesson In Chemistry
description: TECHNOLOGY giveth and technology taketh away. The athletes of the Winter Games don't mind when the latest technology gives them clap skates that rocket them to faster times, nor do they mind when technology discovers ways to wax their skis for improved traction.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: A Conservative Battles Corporate Health Care
description: Representative Charlie Norwood, a small-town dentist with an oversized dislike of big government, plunged into politics in 1994 in large part to fight President Clinton's plans for national health insurance.

title: Marine Stripped of Duty Was Taped Flying Too Low in Italy
description: A Marine Corps jet squadron commander who was relieved of his command last week after the ski-lift accident in Northern Italy is pictured on videotape aboard a military jet that was flying too low last year in the vicinity of the ski lift, a high-ranking Marine officer at the Pentagon said today.

title: Pataki Gets Federal Approval of Lilco Plan
description: Clearing an important hurdle, Gov. George E. Pataki today won a Federal agency's approval of his plan for a $7.8 billion partial state takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company, a proposal that is intended to cut electricity rates by an average of 19.4 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NASH, JAMES CARL
description: NASH-James Carl. Husband of Juliana Nash (nee van der Vloed). Father of Cornelius C. and Juliana E. Nash. Father-in-law of Martha Brophy. Brother of Joy Groover. Uncle of eight. Interment private. Memorial service at The Interchurch Center Chapel, 475 Riverside Drive, at 120 Street, 3PM, Friday. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made for a public park bench in Amagansett. Donations to P.O. Box 754, Amagansett, New York 11930...''Life is hard; be steel; be a rock.'' And this might stand him for the storms and serve him for humdrum and monotony and guide him amid sudden betrayals and tighten him for slack moments. ''Life is a soft loam; be gentle; go easy.'' And this too might serve him. Brutes have been gentled where lashes failed. The growth of a frail flower in a path up has sometimes shattered and split a rock. A tough will counts. So does desire. So does a rich soft wanting. Without rich wanting nothing arrives. Tell him too much money has killed men and left them dead years before burial...The People, Yes, Carl Sandburg.

title: What to Look For
description: ALPINE SKIING

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Judge Stays Decision On Telecommunications Act

title: Overstepping on Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Says Disabled Golfer May Use Cart on Pro Tour
description: Casey Martin won the right today to use a cart in professional golf tournaments, becoming the first professional athlete to successfully sue under the Americans With Disabilities Act for a change in a sports organization's playing rules.

title: Sergeant Major's Lawyer Opens Attack on a Crucial Accuser
description: The lawyer for Sgt. Maj. Gene C. McKinney opened a full-bore attack today on the credibility of the key prosecution witness at his court-martial but failed to shake that witness's testimony significantly.

title: Investment Bank Moving to Old Exxon Site
description: In the latest sign of surging demand for midtown Manhattan office space, the investment banking division of Spain's Banco Santander said it has leased five full floors at 1251 Avenue of the Americas, including a floor that it will hold in reserve for future expansion.

title: Sometimes It's Best To View Art in Art
description: To the Editor:

title: TEXAS UTILITIES SEEKING ALLGAS ENERGY OF AUSTRALIA
description: The Texas Utilities Company said yesterday that its Australian unit would offer $135 million to purchase Allgas Energy Ltd., an Australian natural gas utility. The Dallas-based utility said it had offered Allgas shareholders $17.25 a share (Australian), 38 percent more than the company's recent price of $12.50 (Australian). The offer totals about $200 million (Australian). But Texas Utilities said it might pay $18.55 (Australian) a share if stockholders agreed to sell 90 percent of the outstanding shares. Allgas, with 80,000 customers, would give Texas Utilities even more customers in Australia. It already owns Eastern Energy Ltd., an electric utility with 1.25 million customers in the Melbourne area.

title: G.O.P. Plan Would Cut Capital Gains Holding Time to Year
description: The chief Republican tax writer in the House said today that he would seek to reduce to a year, from 18 months, the holding period necessary for investments to qualify for the most favorable capital gains treatment.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  AGAPITO, KARIN HEIDER
description: AGAPITO-Karin Heider. February 12, 1987. Dear, dear Karin, you are irreplaceable and my love for you is eternal. I miss you too much. Love, Tony

title: The Neediest Cases; Fighting Schizophrenia In the Throes of Poverty
description: Lisa Holloway spends hours every day honing homemade karate techniques in her bedroom, but she has yet to defeat her greatest foe: schizophrenia.

title: In Eerily Calm White House, Remaining in the Dark Helps
description: Bayani Nelvis, a White House steward, stood steps from the Oval Office on Monday afternoon, tossing a ball down a flight of stairs and watching as Buddy, the President's Labrador retriever, hurtled after it.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about New York State's acquisition of Sterling Forest omitted one of two conservation groups that own a 1,400-acre parcel that is to be turned over to the state in a related deal. The second owner, besides the Open Space Institute, is Scenic Hudson.

title: Even as Economy Booms, More People Are Going Without Insurance
description: The number of people without medical insurance is rising far faster in New York State than in the rest of the country, a jump that has left nearly one in five New Yorkers under age 65 uninsured, several new studies show.

title: SUBPOENAS ISSUED TO SECRET SERVICE IN INTERN INQUIRY
description: Prosecutors investigating President Clinton's relationship with a former White House intern have subpoenaed members of the Secret Service, setting up a new confrontation with the Whitewater independent counsel over the Clinton Administration's desire to restrict the testimony of close aides and the Secret Service.

title: A Party Boss Hones the Art of the Possible
description: THERE was a whiff of the Jurassic in the air over the weekend when New York's Democratic county leaders, carrying the vestigial DNA of an ancient and withered power structure, lumbered into a closed hotel room and failed to agree on a choice for Governor or other state offices. So far has their influence declined that it would have made almost no difference if they had been able to unite.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KREISWIRTH, BETTY
description: KREISWIRTH - Betty. Beloved wife of the late Edward. Devoted mother of Glenna and Allen Winston, and Arthur and Jane Kreiswirth. Loving grandmother and great - grandmother. Graveside services Friday, 11 AM, Wellwood Cemetery, Pinelawn, New York.

title: Currents; THE ANNALS OF ADVERTISING -- They Did More Than Paperwork
description: Got wallpaper?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOFI, ELEANOR J. (NEE KERINS)
description: NOFI-Eleanor J. (nee Kerins). On February 11, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Ralph V. Loving mother of Ellen and Timothy Murphy, Ralph and Delia, James and Susan, Joseph, Dorothy Rivera and Prince Hill. Dear sister of Sr. Mary Blanche, C.S.J. Francis, and the late John, Rev. James C.S.s.R., Rev. Joseph C.S.s.R, Edward and Patrick. Proud grandmother of ten grandchildren. Visiting Thursday and Friday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM, Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 4th Avenue, Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial, Saturday, 9:30 A.M., Our Lady of Perpetual Help.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLANK, ESTELLE
description: BLANK-Estelle. Dearest wife of Samuel. Loving mother of Rhoda and Bob Kutner, Myron and Irma Blank and Patty and Les Weinstock. Devoted sister of Leona Bartone. Cherished grandmother of Barry and Holly, Mark, Eric and Sherry, Alan and Lisa and Robert and Angela. Caring great grandmother of Lauren, Robin, Chelsea and Matthew. Services today, 11:30AM at Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Avenue (Avenue J), Bklyn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATNEY, ARTHUR, SR.
description: MATNEY-Arthur, Sr. February 10, 1998. A native of New York, passed away after a long illness. He was the Founder and CEO of Arthur Matney Co., Inc., which for over fifty years has sold a full line of cosmetics worldwide under the names Artmatic, Tropez, Aristocrat and Emerge. His corporation was honored by the Mayor of NYC as one of the leading employers in the Borough of Brooklyn, employing over 500 people. He was well-recognized within the cosmetics industry for his technical contributions, receiving many honors and awards for his achievements. His generosity encompassed numerous political and religious causes. His philanthropy particularly benefited both Long Island College Hospital and Our Lady of Lebanon Cathedral, as well as various Jewish organizations. He was a veteran of W.W. II, serving in the Pacific. He continued to serve his community throughout his life. He was honored by Pope John Paul II, earning a Knighthood in the Catholic Church. Additionally, he received the Apostolic Blessing and was inducted into the Order of St. Gregory. He is survived by his loving wife, Laurice, his four children and ten grandchildren. Friends and family may pay their respects at the E.C. Waldeck Home for Funerals, 7614 4th Ave., Brooklyn, Thursday, 2-5 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial Friday, 10AM, Our Lady of Lebanon Cathedral, 113 Remsen Street, Brooklyn. Interment Greenwood Cemetery, Brooklyn.

title: New Chairman Named to Panel Overseeing Troubled School District
description: A Long Island school administrator known as a problem solver has been named to head a state panel struggling with the task of reforming the troubled Roosevelt School District, the first ever to be taken over by the state.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Classical CD's; Birdsong at Dawn and a Heroine on the Edge
description: Messiaen by Boulez

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUCHHEIMER, ARNOLD
description: BUCHHEIMER-Arnold, Dr. Age 75, of Hallandale, FL, formerly of Berkshire County, MA., and New York City. Passed away February 10th, 1998. Loving Father of Amy B. Goldfarb and Herbert Z. Buchheimer. Cherished grandfather of Aaron Isaac Goldfarb. Member of Temple Adath Or, contributor to Elder Hostel, having had a long and influential career as a psychologist and educator, and a loving friend to many. Contributions may be made to Temple Adath Or, Davie, FL. or Gould Farm, Monterey, Mass. Memorial Services in New York City and Berkshire County to be announced at a later date. Services will be held Friday, February 13, 1998 at 3:00 P.M., at LevittWeinstein Memorial Chapel, 8135 West McNab Road, Tamarac, Florida (954-721-2500).

title: A Nearby Nation Glad To Be Above the Fray
description: As Iran celebrated the 19th anniversary of its Islamic revolution today, it finds itself in a win-win situation, watching from the sidelines as its two worst enemies, the United States and Iraq, are poised to fight it out.

title: School Districts Plan to Sue Trenton Over Loss of Aid
description: The people of this town were already angry about their property tax rates, which are among the highest in New Jersey. But state education officials gave them more reason to complain today, when they announced that public schools here would lose $287,000 in state aid next year, despite rising enrollment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, ROSALINDA
description: GREENE-Rosalinda. We join her beloved daughter, Sabha, in mourning the death of Rosalinda Greene on February 10th in Dublin. She gave us wisdom, warmth and wit, and she will be sorely missed. Anita Fried, Family and Friends

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TERLIZZI, ALFRED
description: TERLIZZI-Alfred. It is with sincere sadness that the Board of Directors and the staff of Dance Educators of America notes the untimely passing of a friend and supporter of the dance world. This creates a void and shoes that will be hard to fill. Our thoughts and prayers are with his family. Vickie Sheer, Executive Director Dance Educators of America

title: Pioneer to Sell 400 Oil and Gas Fields
description: The Pioneer Natural Resources Company is planning to sell most of its United States oil and natural gas fields, valued at $350 million to $550 million, as part of a plan to cut costs and focus on more profitable acreage.

title: RENO REQUESTING A COUNSEL TO LOOK AT BABBITT MOVES
description: After a year of resisting an independent inquiry into campaign finance, Attorney General Janet Reno changed direction today by formally asking a judicial panel to appoint an outside prosecutor to investigate Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt's role in his department's rejection of an Indian gambling project.

title: A Mental Patient Skips Care And West Siders Worry Again
description: Larry Hogue, a symbol of New York State's inability to treat mentally ill drug addicts effectively, has failed to report to a psychiatric outpatient program, alarming some Upper West Side residents who are fearful that he will return to terrorize them.

title: U.S. Judge Stays His Ruling On Long-Distance Service
description: A Federal judge in Texas yesterday temporarily stayed his year-end decision that invalidated major portions of the Telecommunications Act of 1996.

title: Manning a Rare Football Winner
description: Peyton Manning, who failed to win the Heisman Trophy as the top college football player, can take heart: the Sullivan Award is all his.

title: Jefferson-Pilot Splits Stock
description: The Jefferson-Pilot Corporation, an insurance holding company, will split its stock 3 for 2 and raise its dividend on the post-split shares by 10 percent. The stock split means that each stockholder will receive one share for every two shares already owned. As of Dec. 31, Jefferson-Pilot had 70.8 million shares outstanding. Jefferson-Pilot, based in Greensboro, said the post-split dividend would be 29.5 cents a share. Jefferson-Pilot's shares closed at $81.0625 today, down 6.25 cents.

title: Smoothing the Bumps on the Road
description: Near the beginning of her opening-night show at Rainbow and Stars on Tuesday, Lois Walden, a singer and songwriter who specializes in smooth 1970's-style adult pop, gave a little speech about ''the wild and wondrous road called life'' and how it was a journey of happiness, sadness and the bittersweet.

title: Sprewell's Suspension
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LURIE, HAROLD
description: LURIE-Harold. Professor Emeritus, Caltech University. Aeronautical/nuclear engineer, lawyer, pilot, adventurer, mentor. A gentle man. Harold passed away peacefully in his 78th year. Beloved father of Diana Lurie of Missoula, Montana and David Lurie of Boston, Massachusetts. Cherished companion of Bobbie Altman. Donations in his memory may be made to Hospice of Saddleback Valley, 24022 Calle de la Plata, Suite 500, Laguna Hills, CA 92653

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: New Panel Is Planned to Press Insurance Firms on Holocaust
description: Leaders in the effort to press European insurance companies to pay the claims of Holocaust victims and their heirs say they will propose the creation of an independent panel to supervise the searching of company files and the creation of a fund to help aging Holocaust survivors.

title: Arts in America; Adding a New Word to Lincoln's Eloquence: Internet
description: A century and a third after his assassination, the 16th President continues to be the subject of new studies in his hometown and the symbol of our better angels in America and the world.

title: Kwan Chooses Low-Risk Approach
description: Michelle Kwan has decided to play it safe in seeking a gold medal in women's figure skating. And judging from the pairs competition, it might be the wisest approach.

title: Officers Indicted in Beating of Suspect
description: Two city police officers were indicted yesterday on charges that they beat a suspect until his ribs broke, and a third officer was charged with lying under oath to protect them.

title: 19 Children Are Hurt In School Bus Accident
description: Nineteen students were injured in a school bus accident yesterday morning near Saratoga Springs.

title: Veto Ruling Spares New York Health Financing
description: The decision by a Federal judge here to strike down the President's line item veto power today did more than address a thorny constitutional question. It preserved, for the moment, a set of New York State hospital taxes that are crucial to financing health care services for the poor and uninsured.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, PRESTON W.
description: DAVIS-Preston W., 89, of Greenwich, CT., died February 6. Husband of Hilda Jane Godfrey Davis and father of Joan Marilyn Wismer. Mr. Davis was a senior vice president and corporate secretary of UPS. Funeral services will be held in CA. Memorial donations may be made to Rotary Club of Greenwich, PO Box 1375, Greenwich, CT 06838 or Second Congregational Church, 139 East Putnam Ave., Greenwich, CT 06830.

title: At Westminster, Picking Among the Pack
description: THE Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show will be in town Monday: 2,500 dogs, all champions, for two days of competition at Madison Square Garden. By 11 P.M. on Tuesday it will be down to 7, and that's when Dr. M. Josephine Deubler, forbidden to set foot in the Garden until the final judging, will be escorted onto the floor for the dog world's greatest honor: making the Best in Show selection.

title: Leaping Suavely From Screen to Stage
description: The New York City Ballet went to the movies on Wednesday night at the New York State Theater when the program included ''I'm Old-Fashioned,'' Jerome Robbins's tribute to Fred Astaire.

title: High Jumper Resurfaces For Honor at Millrose
description: People laughed when they heard that the 5-foot-8-inch Franklin Jacobs could dunk a basketball. They laughed even more when they heard he jumped so high that he sometimes bruised his head on the rim.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITE, ELIZABETH CLEVELAND (BETTY)
description: WHITE-Elizabeth Cleveland (Betty), age 91, On February 4, 1998 in Lewisburg, PA after a long illness. Former resident of Gramercy Park, NY, NY and Clove Valley, NY. Wife of 64 years to William Rafford White, died October 5, 1995. Survived by daughter, Deborah White Andersen of Aiken, SC, sons; William R., Jr. of Venice, FL and David R. of Chatham, NJ. Also survived by 6 grandchildren; William R. III. Elizabeth C., Abigail S., David B. Andersen, Matthew W. Andersen, Timothy C. Andersen and 4 great-grandchildren, Matthew D. Andersen, Christopher J. Andersen, Isabelle M. Andersen and Kate S. Andersen, daughter of Arthur J. Andersen III, deceased. Born in Northampton, MA, graduate of Smith College. Member of the General Society of Mayflower Descendants as a tenth generation descendant and Deputy Governor General from the State of New York, 1982. As an avid and dedicated genealogist, she was a Life Member, Patron and Fellow of the Society, The New York Genealogical and Biographical Society; President, 1983-1986, Chairman of the Executive Committee, 1986-1988 and Trustee, 1963 forward. Active and tireless worker with numerous charitable organizations including American Cancer Society and the YWCA. With her husband, she coauthored a book on the history of the Clove Valley Rod and Gun Club in 1989. Funeral services Friday, February 13 at 10:30 AM at the Rooke Chapel, Bucknell University, Lewisburg, PA. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributins to the Buffalo Valley Lutheran Village, 211 Fairground Road, Lewisburg, PA 17837.

title: Optimum Takes On Media Planning
description: Optimum Media, the media buying and research division of the DDB Needham Worldwide unit of Omnicom Group, is assuming the media planning functions of a sibling, Griffin Bacal, making Optimum a full-service media services agency.

title: Magazines Found Too Adult for School
description: Three of the most popular magazines for teen-age girls -- Seventeen, Teen and YM -- have been pulled from the library of a Long Island middle school by the district's Superintendent following complaints by a group of parents and a priest over the sexually oriented material in the magazines.

title: Jets' Free-Agent Hunt Tied to Quarterback
description: First, there is the matter of the $2.75 million the Jets are due to pay quarterback Neil O'Donnell next Friday. Then another million dollars is due in April. Before you know it, you're talking real money.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBINO, IMELDA COLTON
description: RUBINO-Imelda Colton. On February 11, 1998. Ret. McKasson Corporation. Loving wife of Daniel M. Rubino. Dear aunt of two nieces, one nephew, and three cousins. Friends may call at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Ave. (at 20th St.), Thursday 2-5 PM only, and Friday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Church of the Epiphany, on Saturday, 10 AM. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: What to Look For
description: SPEED SKATING -- WOMEN'S 500 METERS, FIRST RACE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELIX, DAVID E.
description: FELIX-David E. Passed away February 10. A wonderful husband, father, grandfather and greatgrandfather. He is survived by his wife of 65 years Mary Lerner Felix; his son Alan; daughter Madalyn Felix Friedberg; son-in-law Stephen Friedberg; three grandchildren and two great-grandsons

title: Agency Backs Protective Status for Canada Lynx in Lower 48
description: After resisting for years, the United States Fish and Wildlife Service has agreed to list the Canada lynx as a protected species throughout the forests of the lower 48 states, a step that could curtail logging.

title: Breaking News, Just 23 Hours Later
description: For CBS's Olympic telecast on Wednesday night, the lingering issue was when Picabo Street's super-G race would be shown. Jim Nantz, the prime-time host, teased viewers regularly about Street's race. ''There's gold on the line in the super-G,'' Nantz said to open the show. But 8 P.M. passed, then 9 P.M. No super-G.

title: Satellite Services Seen as Threat
description: Always charting its position in the home entertainment firmament, the video industry recently engaged Yankelovich Partners to determine why rentals of mainstream movies were down somewhat in 1997. After polling 1,807 people, Yankelovich concluded that rentals were holding their own against all but one competitor.

title: Editorial Observer; A Constantly Evolving Witness on the Stand
description: The defamation trial of Tawana Brawley's former advisers is crowded with people frozen in time, a clash of men whose life trajectories seem to have come to a halt in 1988. Except for the Rev. Al Sharpton. A decade ago, Mr. Sharpton was a semi-comic figure, a minister without a congregation, with a portly man's affinity for jogging suits without the jogging. Now he is a political player, who moves gingerly through the history-obsessed proceedings, his eye to the future. Arriving for the trial, the trimmer, tailored, almost-ready-for-prime-time Mr. Sharpton joked that one of the prosecutors didn't seem to have changed his suits in 10 years.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Belly Like Buddha, Spine Like Dinosaur
description: To the periodic table of entertainment elements that contains names like SPECTRE and M*A*S*H may now be added SWARM The initials stand for Symphonic Work Assembly of Rhythm and Movement, which has come thumping, twanging and twirling out of Canada and into the New Victory Theater in the reborn Times Square for a stay through Feb. 22.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARMON, LILY
description: HARMON-Lily. The residents of the Kenilworth mourn the loss of our dear friend and neighbor. Lily enhanced our lives with art, grace and humor. We offer our condolences to her family. Arthur Sarnoff, President Kenilworth Apartments

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  METZ, HAROLD
description: METZ-Harold. February 13, 1997. Forever in my thoughts and my heart, you brightened the world for everyone. Love, Barbara

title: G.O.P. Fails on Bill to Permit Challenges to Voters' Citizenship
description: Still smarting from their failed fight over Representative Loretta Sanchez's contested seat, House Republicans today tried to push through a bill to allow certain states to remove people from the voter rolls if they are unable to prove their United States citizenship.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, BERNARD VICTOR
description: GREENE-Bernard Victor. Age 72, of Thompson, PA, formerly of 239 Nichols Avenue, East New York in Brooklyn, died on Monday. From 1954 to 1982, he had his own dental practice in Audubon, PA. He resided in Brooklyn, NY from 1942 to 1950, and in Audubon, PA from 1950 to 1979, and lived for the past 19 years in Thompson, PA. He served during World War II as a medic in the US Army. He was a graduate of Muhlenberg College in 1949 and was a graduate of the University of Pennsylvania Dental School in 1954. Beloved son of the late Victor Greene and the late Anna (nee Lynch) Greene. Devoted husband of Anastasia (nee Bycosky) Greene of Thompson, PA. Beloved father of Michael J. Greene of Thompson, PA. Loving brother of Valeria Parfitt of New York. Dear father-in-law of Jo-Ellen Smith Greene. Cremation was private. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Diabetes Association.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Thomas Joshua Cooper

title: Knicks Head for Orlando With Healthier Outlook
description: Larry Johnson is scheduled to return and Buck Williams may play, too, when the Knicks face the Orlando Magic tonight at the Orlando Arena. At least, they are healthier.

title: CITING ASIAN CRISIS, LAM RESEARCH ANNOUNCES JOB CUTS
description: The Lam Research Corporation said yesterday that it would cut 700 jobs, or 14 percent of its work force, in a reorganization the company attributed to Asia's financial crisis. Lam, a maker of equipment for manufacturing computer chips, said it expected lower prospects for orders and revenue from its Asian customers. Lam Research said it would take a third-quarter pretax charge of $80 million to $85 million because of the reorganization, which also includes closing plants and writing down the value of certain assets. Lam Research, based in Fremont, Calif., had revenues of $582 million in the six months ended Dec. 31. Lam announced the cuts after its stock gained $2.125, to $28.4375.

title: Fair-Weather Saudis
description: To the Editor:

title: Know the Answers Before Going to War
description: What's gone right? Not very much.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANKEL, KENNETH
description: FRANKEL-Kenneth. Lynne Meadow, Barry Grove and everyone at The Manhattan Theater Club are deeply saddened by the death of our friend and colleague Kenneth Frankel. Ken's artistry graced our stage and he enriched and warmed our lives with his friendship. We miss him dearly. To his wife, our long-time colleague, Donna Isaacson and daughter Hanna we extend our love and deepest condolences.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Shares of the high-flying LHS Group may be getting some help from hype in Germany
description: WHAT exactly is the LHS Group and why is its stock shooting the moon?

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Monday about Sam Marcy, a founder of the Workers World Party, omitted the names of his survivors. Mr. Marcy, whose real surname was Ballan, is survived by two sons from an early marriage, Irving Ballan of Boca Raton, Fla., and Dr. Kenneth Ballan of Chatsworth, Calif.; two grandchildren and two great-grandchildren.

title: Leger: Not Quite a Mystery, but Still Unpredictable
description: ''Each artist possesses an offensive weapon that allows him to intimidate tradition,'' Fernand Leger said. ''I've used the machine as others have used the nude body or the still life.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OSTER, ANN
description: OSTER-Ann. On February 12, 1998, of Margate, FL. Beloved wife of the late Harry. Devoted mother of Jerry, Mel and Herb. Dear sister of Betty Modell, Sylvia Fireman and Gertrude Cohen. Also survived by seven adoring grandchildren and two loving greatgrandchildren. Services Sunday 1:45 P.M. at ''Gutterman's,'' 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, L.I.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: 'Real Stories'

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILMAN, DOROTHY (NEE MAHLER)
description: SILMAN-Dorothy (nee Mahler) died February 11, 1998 in Sarasota, FL at age 93. Devoted wife of the late David Silman. Beloved mother of Judith and Howard Schmertz and Roberta and Robert Silman. Grandmother of Amy and Howard Weinstein, Carol and Fred Katz, Miriam and David Gardner, Joshua Silman and Ruth Silman. Great grandmother of Lindsey, Jenna, Joshua and Daniel. Funeral services at Gutterman's, Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, NY, Sunday, February 15 at 12 noon.

title: California Governor's Race: A New Height in Spending
description: Politics has never been a cheap sport in California, home to a dozen media markets stretching over a span equal to the distance from New Jersey to Georgia and to a diffuse and desultory political culture where paid television commercials are king.

title: Dead End Kids, in Modern Dress
description: Real teen-agers, as against buffed Beverly Hills fantasies of youth, are a rarity on the screen these days. But from the moment he first appears in ''Hurricane Streets,'' Brendan Sexton 3d, the bony, squinty-eyed young actor who plays Marcus, a troubled 14-year-old boy drifting toward a life of crime on the streets of New York, embodies adolescent vulnerability and defiance with a scary naturalness.

title: National News Briefs; Police Commissioner In Philadelphia Resigns
description: The Police Commissioner announced his resignation today after facing weeks of criticism from city officials and community representatives that Philadelphia had failed to reduce crime rates sufficiently.

title: F.A.A. Will Require Airlines to Get More Passenger Data
description: Beginning in October, airlines that fly American citizens to or from this country will have to keep a passenger manifest that shows each passenger's full name, and will have to ask passengers to supply a phone number of someone to contact in case of emergency, under a Transportation Department rule published today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEISMAR, AUDREY
description: GEISMAR-Audrey. On February 11,1998. Beloved wife of Herbert, devoted mother of Lori GeismarRyan, Steven Geismar and Jill Price, dear sister of Maxine Steinberg, cherished grandmother of Zachary, Maxwell, Joshua, Lisa, Samuel, Teddy, Tory and Gabrielle. Services today 12 noon at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island.

title: Low Rates Spur Surge in Home Buying and Refinancing
description: Interest rates have fallen to a four-year low in recent weeks, causing a surge of home buying and mortgage refinancings that has created a windfall for consumers, lenders and real estate agents in the New York metro politan region.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Matthew McCaslin

title: Look Beyond Bruce Babbitt
description: Any cabinet member facing an independent counsel is bound to be worried, but Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt has extra reason to fret. That is because Attorney General Janet Reno's request for appointment of a counsel reads, at first glance, like an invitation to hang Mr. Babbitt out to dry as a way to prevent a searching investigation of White House and Democratic National Committee fund-raising.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORREST, BARBARA (NEE HEIMERDINGER)
description: FORREST-Barbara (nee Heimerdinger). On February 11, 1998 in her 72nd year. Adoring mother of Terry; beloved sister of John F. Heimerdinger; loving aunt to Linda, Daniel and Charles Heimerdinger; five grand-nephews and one grand-niece. Funeral services will be held at St. Agnes Church in Lake Placid on Monday, February 16. A Memorial service will be held on Long Island on February 18.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALLIN, SOPHIE M.
description: GALLIN-Sophie M. Age 96. Beloved wife of the late Nathan M. Gallin. Devoted mother of Audrey Doremus (Edwin) and Grace Trotter (Judd). Sister of Gladys P. Edelman. Loving grandmother and great grandmother.

title: Philips Electronics Returns to Profitability
description: Philips Electronics N.V. said yesterday that it had posted a profit for the fourth quarter after losing money in the corresponding quarter a year ago, benefiting from the housecleaning efforts of its chief executive, Cornelis Boonstra. Mr. Boonstra initiated a series of shake-ups and asset sales, including selling its car systems unit and cutting financial ties to Grundig A.G., Germany's money-losing electronics company.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Holiday on Monday Presidents Day
description: NEW YORK

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEITSMAN, HARRY
description: WEITSMAN-Harry, 88, of Riverdale, NY. Died Wednesday, February 11, 1998. Beloved husband of Yetta, devoted father of Barbara Neuman of Port Washington, NY and Madeline Weitsman of NYC. Loving grandfather to Julie Friedlander of Westfield, NJ and Andrea Schreiber of Delmar, CA. Also survived by son-in-law Richard Neuman and grandsons-in-law Neal Friedlander and Dan Schreiber and five great-grandsons. Funeral at 10 AM Friday, February 13, 1998 at Louis Hirsch & Sons, 167 Street & Jerome Ave, Bronx. Memorial gifts made to Alzheimer's Association and Simon Senior Center YMHA.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a new Metropolitan Opera staging of a work by Saint-Saens misstated the title in some editions. It is ''Samson et Dalila,'' not ''Samson and Delila.''

title: INSIDE
description: Planning Their Moves

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about an agreement giving the Central Park Conservancy control over the daily operations of the park misstated the arrangement for concessions. The city will continue to grant and regulate the concessions in the park; it will not turn that responsibility over to the conservancy.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Patrick Clark was one of New York's best-loved chefs. He went on to other restaurants, but he forged his reputation at the Odeon 18 years ago, defining a style of American bistro. Mr. Clark died on Wednesday night, but he would be happy to know that after all these years the Odeon is still the place to be.

title: Treacherous Downhill Run Sends Skiers Crashing
description: A Frenchman won the Olympic gold medal in the men's downhill here today more by surviving the Happo'one course than by mastering it. Jean-Luc Cretier, a 31-year-old veteran, came out of a left-hand turn near the top of the run that played havoc with the rest of the field and won the race many of his competitors believed should have never started or should have been called soon after.

title: Corrections
description: An art review in Weekend on Jan. 30 about ''Prisoners,'' an exhibition by Arne Svenson at the Julie Saul Gallery in SoHo through Feb. 27, characterized the work incorrectly. The photographs, showing paired front and side views of prisoners, are exact positive prints from original glass negatives taken by Clara Smith early in this century; they are not collages.

title: Thomas Dunn, 76, Longtime Elizabeth Mayor
description: Thomas G. Dunn, the blunt, often irascible former Mayor of Elizabeth, N.J., who was a major figure in the city's politics over four decades, died Wednesday at his home in the city. He was 76 years old.

title: Kidnapped Executive Is Freed in Bronx
description: They had planned the kidnapping for months: a $1 million caper using codes and careful timing, death threats and measured brutality, the police said. And they were waiting in the shadows when Nicholas Martinelli, 38, a business executive, drove up to his dark house on the wooded outskirts of East Windsor, Conn., Tuesday night.

title: Brazil Congress Votes to Scale Down Social Security Benefits
description: Winding down a special session of Congress marked by political horse-trading inside and labor protests outside, lawmakers have approved bills to strip down social security benefits and job protections.

title: Jet Lag of Lamb
description: TETSUYA WAKUDA, an Australian chef, was to cook a dinner at the James Beard House on West 12th Street on Monday: marinated tuna, Tasmanian ocean trout with unpasteurized trout roe, rack of Australian lamb.

title: What Becomes a Legend?; A New Executive Rethinks America's Lingerie Pioneer
description: To her left is Rosie O'Donnell's bra. To her right stand several reams of feathery marabou. Not far away are a pair of hot-pink thigh-high boots, along with dozens of silk teddies. And then there's Ingrid Bergman's corset.

title: Men's Brains Shrink Faster Than Women's, Researchers Say
description: As people get older, the male brain shrinks faster than the female brain, a study has found.

title: Amsterdam News' New Generation; Owner's Daughter Tries to Rebuild Famous Paper for Blacks
description: Leonard Davis sells papers in Harlem, but his opinions are free. Ask him what he thinks of The New York Amsterdam News, one of a half dozen black newspapers neatly displayed on his newsstand, and he will offer several earfuls. The paper, he said, has become ''bourgeois'' -- too much news about social goings-on, too little about issues -- over the last half-decade.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRISTMAN, RICHARD G.
description: TRISTMAN-Richard G. Scholar, author and revered professor of literature, died February 12, 1998. He exerted a deep and lasting influence on generations of students, colleagues and friends. He was a gentleman and a visionary. He is mourned by his mother, Jeanette of Miami Beach, his two sons, David and Jonah, his longtime friend, Gina Pollara, and by countless friends. Contributions may be made in his name to the Department of Medical Oncology, Montefiore Hospital, 111 E. 210th St, Bronx, NY 10467.

title: U.S. JUDGE RULES LINE ITEM VETO ACT UNCONSTITUTIONAL
description: In a major blow to President Clinton and Republican leaders of Congress, a Federal judge ruled today that it was unconstitutional for the President to veto individual items in spending and tax legislation, rather than signing or rejecting the entire bill.

title: Patrick Clark, 42, Is Dead; Innovator in American Cuisine
description: Patrick Clark, a chef who helped lead a generation of Americans to embrace a new style of casual but sophisticated French cooking in the early 1980's, and then helped lead them back to the ingredients and preparations of their own country, died late Wednesday night at Princeton Medical Center in Princeton, N.J. He was 42 and lived in Plainsboro, N.J.

title: Japanese Unload Their Foreign Bonds
description: Japanese investors sold a net record 3.5 trillion yen ($28.3 billion) in foreign bonds in December as cash-pressed banks traded in securities to raise funds, traders and economists said today.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Anne Chu, Byron Kim, Kiki Smith

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN RETREATS. The dollar surged against the yen, helped by the mark's strength. Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin's calls for Tokyo to step up reforms also bolstered the dollar, which rose to 124.53 yen from 123.48.

title: Before First Face-Off, Teams Take a Few Verbal Shots
description: Even before the first puck drops Friday in the second phase of the Olympic hockey tournament, the psychological gamesmanship is escalating.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOOS, REV. JUSTIN, O.F.M.
description: JOOS-Rev. Justin, O.F.M., C.ap. The Capuchin Friars and people of St. John the Baptist R.C. Church mourn the passing of Fr. Justin on February 11, 1998 at the age of 85. May God welcome his faithful priest and son of St. Francis into paradise. Father is waked Friday, February 13, 1-5:30, 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday at 10 AM, Church and Friary of St. John the Baptist, 210 W. 31st St., NYC. 212-564-9070. Interment at Sacred Heart Monastery, Yonkers, NY at noon on Saturday.

title: American Arms vs. Iraq
description: The commander of American forces in the Persian Gulf has a formidable arsenal at his disposal. Yet even all that weaponry is probably not enough to accomplish what President Clinton has stated as the goal of military action: to ''substantially reduce or delay'' Iraq's ability to develop and deliver weapons of mass destruction.

title: Prudential's Leader Knows His Way Around New Jersey
description: Soon after taking charge of the Prudential Insurance Company of America four years ago, Arthur F. Ryan felt at ease enough with New Jersey officials to encourage the state's insurance commissioner to lead a nationwide investigation into the company's sales practices. After that inquiry was completed, many critics said that New Jersey regulators had been too soft on the insurer.

title: Intel Introduces Graphics Chip for PC's
description: The Intel Corporation introduced a new computer chip today that is designed to speed the delivery of graphics and games on personal computers, as the chip maker continues its push to broaden the PC market.

title: Intel hires extra help, part of a whirl of account activity with billings in the many millions.
description: FLURRY of account activity has rippled through Madison Avenue, affecting assignments with billings estimated at $275 million to $305 million.

title: $600 Million Infusion Seen In Oxford Deal
description: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company and the Texas Pacific Group are proposing putting $600 million of badly needed capital into Oxford Health Plans, a person close to the negotiations said yesterday.

title: Swinging, Swaying, Records Playing
description: Berry Gordy, the founder of Motown records, says, ''My dream was that an artist could walk in one door just a normal kid off the street, and come out another door a star.'' In other words, he fantasized about owning a dream factory. Deep inside that fantasy is a cynical hint that almost anyone could be molded into a show-biz hit. But the complicated aspects of his wildly successful dream rarely intrude on ''Motown 40: The Music Is Forever.'' This, after all, is a celebration of the label Mr. Gordy built 40 years ago. The two-part, four-hour tribute and history is by turns fascinating and frustrating.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBIN, IRA LLOYD, M.D.
description: RUBIN-Ira Lloyd, M.D. It is with great sadness that the death of Ira Lloyd Rubin, M.D. on February 12 is announced. He was the beloved husband of Beatrice Bober Rubin for more than 57 years and the devoted son of the late Dr. Meyer and the late Gertrude Rubin. He is survived by his wife and brother Dr. Adrien Rubin. He was a gifted cardiologist who was greatly loved by both his patients and medical staff. He was the author of numerous classic textbooks and articles on the diagnosis and treatment of heart disease. He was a great philanthropic leader who devoted his time and energy in making this world a better place for all its inhabitants. Dr. Rubin served on Guam as a Major in the United States Army during World War II. He was an attending physician at Montefiore Medical Center since 1949 and a Professor of Medicine at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine. When the Department of Electrocardiography at Montefiore was dedicated in his name in 1993, the plaque that was erected so aptly states: ''A leader, a gifted ECG reader, teacher, author, physician, humanitarian and gentleman.'' Funeral services are strictly private. A memorial service celebrating his life will be held at a later date. Donations may be made in his memory to the United Jewish Appeal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORFEIN, LEAH
description: GORFEIN-Leah. Dear sister of Beatrice Hersch. Sister-in-law of Augusta Gorfein and Harry Hersch. Beloved and loving aunt and great-aunt. Services at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave., Friday, 12 noon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLY, JOSEPH P.
description: KELLY-Joseph P. of Manalapan, NJ, formerly of NYC. Husband of (nee) Anne A. Farrell, father of Nancy Butler and Elizabeth M. Kelly. Funeral Liturgy Saturday 9 AM St. Thomas More RC Church, Manalapan. Visitation Friday 2-4, 7-9 PM at Freeman ManalapanMarlboro Funeral Home, 344 Route 9 N, Manalapan. NJ

title: Magazine Drives
description: The Tenth Street Lounge, on -- where else? -- East 10th Street, between First and Second Avenues, was jammed with 20-something types whose off-the-rack suits suggested that they still inhabited the lower rungs of the corporate ladder. The party was for Swing magazine, and a lot of networking was going on. More than one woman who said she couldn't juggle a job and a relationship complained about so-and-so getting married.

title: Roots of the Holocaust
description: To the Editor:

title: Russia Arrests Ex-Colonel In '94 Killing Of Journalist
description: Russian officials announced tonight that they had arrested a retired military intelligence official in connection with the killing of an investigative journalist three years ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARON, CELIA G.
description: MARON-Celia G. On February 12, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Philip. Loving mother of Harvey and Ada, Louise, and Ruth. Cherished grandmother to Jon and Lisa and great-grandmother of Philip. Services Friday 10:15AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: 1948-98: 50-Year Palestinian 'Catastrophe'
description: A day after Israel began celebrations of its 50th year of independence, Palestinians gathered here today to plan a different sort of commemoration: the 50th anniversary of what they call ''the catastrophe.''

title: Like Old Times: A Minstrel Show, Big City of '32
description: It is easy to dismiss the pleasures of old-fashioned dance virtues like craft, reflection and a simple delight in well-schooled movement. The program presented at the Joyce Theater by the Ohio Ballet on Wednesday night reinforced those pleasures and offered rare glimpses of two ballet jewels of another time.

title: Roots of the Holocaust
description: To the Editor:

title: For a Shaky Japanese Economy, The Premier Is a Hesitant Steward
description: Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto comes across these days not as the captain of one of the world's most powerful ships of state, but rather as a man overboard, bobbing in waves of unpopularity, threatened by an economic typhoon on the horizon.

title: Hiatus for 'Melrose Place'
description: The Fox network will temporarily shelve its longtime nighttime soap opera ''Melrose Place'' in April to make room for two new comedy series, the network announced yesterday.

title: Lawmakers Rally Around the White House
description: Congressional leaders temporarily set aside their partisan differences over Iraq today and rallied around President Clinton's handling of the Persian Gulf crisis.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Collecting; Porsche's Greatest Hits, and Some Misses
description: PORSCHE is celebrating its 50th birthday this year by giving birth. Its latest offspring, the first all-new 911 since that venerable model arrived in 1965, will reach showrooms by summer. The lines of the new 911 look familiar, but there is a big difference in the rear compartment: The engine is cooled by water, not air.

title: Microcell Sets Up Investment Fund
description: Microcell Telecommunications Inc. said today that its Microcell Capital Inc. unit had set up a $137 million international venture-capital fund to make equity investments in companies developing products and services using the Global System for Mobile Communications standard.

title: A View of Ayn Rand (With Assistance From the Statue of Liberty)
description: Considering Ayn Rand's ardent faith in individualism, what would she have made of the slavish new two-and-a-half-hour documentary in her honor? Michael Paxton's ''Ayn Rand: A Sense of Life,'' opening today at the Quad, does little beyond appreciating its subject as unwaveringly as possible. Dutiful in outlook and utterly conventional in format, this film is an Academy Award contender despite its clear inferiority to such non-nominees as ''East Side Story'' and ''Sick,'' not to mention Errol Morris's visionary ''Fast, Cheap and Out of Control.'' Documentary filmmaking loses the respect it deserves when such a pedantic specimen is rewarded at the expense of truly imaginative work.

title: Fair-Weather Saudis
description: To the Editor:

title: A One-Man Melting Pot Bubbling Over With Demons
description: The evidence is in, and the news is good. Though there have been no recorded confirmations from priests, parapsychologists or William Peter Blatty, the exorcism of John Leguizamo was obviously a failure.

title: Christie's Tests Museum Style
description: Auction houses have been trampling on the turf of dealers for some time now, what with Sotheby's and Christie's buying up art galleries and increasing their private treaty sales (selling art, that is, without putting it on the block).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LASKY, DIANA
description: LASKY-Diana. Beloved wife of Burton. Devoted mother of Andrew. Dear sister of Deanna Chaunet. Service on Friday, 11:30 A.M., Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Italian Insurer Backs Fund
description: Assicurazioni Generali, the Italian insurance giant that was the dominant underwriter of policies sold to Jews in Eastern European before World War II, said yesterday that it would cooperate with an independent panel to investigate unpaid claims by Holocaust victims and heirs. Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, proposed the panel at a hearing yesterday in Washington.

title: ARV ASSISTED LIVING IN DEAL FOR 13 HOUSING COMMUNITIES
description: ARV Assisted Living Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire 13 housing communities for the elderly in California from the privately held Hillsdale Group L.P. for $88 million. Hillsdale, based in Burlingame, Calif., is a unit of Fremont Realty Capital L.L.C. ARV Assisted Living, based in Costa Mesa, Calif., operates 50 assisted living communities with 6,400 units in 10 states. For the six months ended Sept. 30, it reported revenue of $56.2 million. The acquisitions will expand its holdings in California to 5,300 units in 43 communities.

title: BREED TECHNOLOGIES TO REDUCE ITS WORK FORCE BY 25%
description: Breed Technologies Inc. said yesterday that it would dismiss 4,500 workers, or 25 percent of its work force, and close 47 of its 103 factories and offices by mid-1999, slashing costs that built up as it bought nine other auto-parts companies since 1995. Breed, which makes air bags for automobiles, has already dismissed 725 of the workers, reducing employment to 17,225, and closed three plants in the second quarter, which ended on Dec. 31. Breed also announced a $318.4 million charge in the quarter to cover the costs of cutting jobs and closing or selling plants and offices. Auto makers are putting intense pressure on Breed and other suppliers to cut costs. Breed, based in Lakeland, Fla., rose 68.75 cents, to $19.5625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Why Punish Lawyers for Tobacco Victories?
description: To the Editor:

title: Times Square Reveler Is Found Drowned
description: The long, exhaustive search for a 22-year-old Brewster man who disappeared after visiting Times Square on New Year's Eve ended yesterday when his family received the news they had long dreaded: the man's body was found floating off a pier along the Brooklyn waterfront.

title: The Antithesis of Minimalism's Cool Geometry: Fleshy Rubber
description: Rubber? It's hard to say who first used it in a work of 20th-century art; maybe the Surrealists. Or Louise Bourgeois. But in the 1960's, it was taken up, among other raffish mediums, by artists making the transition to a more expressive, body-oriented sculpture from the rigid industrial-looking structures of Minimalism. Since then rubber, while still a minor item on the roster of 20th-century art materials, has proved itself a happy medium for artists who like its suppleness, stretch, closeness to flesh and ability to mimic other materials.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the House and Home section yesterday about an auction of property once owned by the Duke and Duchess of Windsor misstated the day on which the nine-day sale begins at Sotheby's. It will be Thursday, not Tuesday.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in New York City this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: FAMILY FARE
description: Finding the Path To Freedom

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HILLS, ROBERT C.
description: HILLS-Robert C. Died peacefully on January 26, 1998 at the age of 89 at his home in Metairie, Louisiana. He is survived by his wife of 61 years, Dorothy Fleury Hills and his children, Anne Hills of Metairie, John F. Hills of New Orleans, LA, Thomas C. Hills of Secaucus, NJ and a grandson, Robert F. Hills of New Orleans. A successful businessman, devoted husband and loving father, his wisdom and wonderful spirit will be greatly missed. Memorial contributions may be sent to the Tulane Center for Clinical Effectiveness & Prevention, Tulane Medical Center, Box TW34, 1430 Tulane Ave., New Orleans, LA 70112

title: A Vast Web of Lawyers Finds Work in Scandal
description: The White House arranged to get a lawyer for the President's secretary, and that lawyer happens to be a friend of a lawyer for the President.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 9.

title: MANUGISTICS IN TALKS TO ACQUIRE PROMIRA SOFTWARE
description: Manugistics Inc. said yesterday that it was in talks to acquire Promira Software Inc., a Canadian maker of software for manufacturers, for about $68 million. Under the deal, Manugistics will issue 1.5 million of its common shares and pay about $5.3 million in cash for Promira. Promira provides supply-chain planning software for companies that make complex products. Manugistics, based in Rockville, Md., supplies software and services for supply-chain management.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WYMAN, THOMAS M.
description: WYMAN-Thomas M. February 9, 1998. Beloved husband of Llana. Son of Olga Resseguier and the late Charles A. Wyman. Brother of John H. Wyman and Virginia A. Meyer. Uncle of Christina and Charles Wyman, and Edward and Katharine Meyer. Interment private. Memorial Service is to be announced. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to Panwy Foundation, Inc., 10 Valley Drive, Greenwich, Connecticut 06831.

title: Giants' Top Priority Is to Keep Wooten
description: The Giants will most likely keep a low profile as the National Football League's free-agent signing period begins today, in part because few of the top free-agent wide receivers the team considered pursuing are expected to be available, and because the team is focusing on keeping safety Tito Wooten, who is scheduled to become a free agent today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, HOWARD M.
description: SMITH-Howard M. Of Sunrise, FL, formerly of Queens, on February 12, 1998. Father of DeeDee Smith Traul and Arnold Smith. Father-in-law of Nancy Sinoway and Karl A. Traul. Grandfather of Erik Sherman, Andrew Smith and Jessica Sinoway. Graveside Service Sunday 1:15 PM at Riverside Cemetery, Rochelle Park, NJ. For additional information, contact Mount Sinai Memorial Chapels, East Brunswick. Memorial contributions may be made to the charity of your choice.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: No Sour Grapes For Fox

title: 2 Magazines Name Top Executives
description: Two magazines have named top executives.

title: Observer; Quiet, Quiet, Louie, There's a Bug in That Martini Olive
description: 1984 is dead and gone, but Big Brother lives.

title: For Openers, the Men Stay True to the Script
description: Through four hours of clean, if tense and careful, skating in the men's short program, absolutely nothing was decided. The favorites did not make mistakes. They did not unravel the expected order of finish. And they did not make it any easier for the judges to decide who should win the Olympic gold medal.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CRATE AND BARREL, Northbrook, Ill., the home furnishings retailer, sold a majority stake to Otto Versand G.m.b.H., a German mail-order company, for undisclosed terms.

title: Argentina's Values
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, ELIZABETH W.
description: BROWN-Elizabeth W. of New York City and Water Mill, NY on February 11, 1998. Beloved mother of Michele B. Sibeud and Clyde R. Brown. Devoted grandmother to Stephanie, Amy, Eugenie, Christina and Vanessa. Great grandmother to Carter. A memorial service will be held at a date to be announced in the Spring.

title: Executive of SFM Is Starting New Firm
description: Walter Staab is making plans for life after the SFM Media Corporation, which he and his partners sold last week to Havas Advertising S.A.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUFELD, WILLIAM
description: KUFELD-William. We mourn the passing of our beloved brother and uncle who was always there for us. We shall miss him greatly Michaelson and Krause families

title: Russians Deny Report Of '95 Deal With Iraq
description: Russia denied today that Russian officials or companies negotiated with Iraq to sell equipment that could be used to manufacture biological weapons, and American officials said they could not confirm any such sale.

title: Greenspan Sees Asian Crisis Moving World to Western Capitalism
description: Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, told a Senate panel today that one of the most fundamental effects of the Asian crisis was a worldwide move toward ''the Western form of free market capitalism,'' instead of the competing Asian approach that only a few years ago looked like an attractive model for nations around the world.

title: Sports of The Times; Snowboard Dude Says: No Big Deal
description: THEY owe the kid another ceremony. All the craven officials with their blazers and their badges and their bungled drug policies ought to summon Ross Rebagliati to Central Square one of these nights and bow down and kiss his medal in public and utter that traditional Japanese phrase, ''Gomen nasai.'' I am so sorry.

title: Romantic Spots
description: Pssst! You procrastinating romantics out there. No Valentine's Day plans? Well, take heart, because Valentine's Day is one of the worst nights of the year to go out to dinner. Reservations are impossible to get, and hokey promotions are everywhere. But if you wait for the crowds to fade and try one of these restaurants, it can be Valentine's Day every day. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are from Ruth Reichl's and Mr. Asimov's dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Scientology's Star Roster Enhances Image
description: John Travolta stood in the parking garage below City Hall, waiting for his sleek black Jaguar. He had just accepted an award on behalf of the Church of Scientology from the public works commission for a renovation project, and he was talking earnestly about what the religion means to him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HASS, JOSEPH
description: HASS-Joseph. The partners of Rosen & Reade deeply mourn the passing of Joseph Hass, the father of our senior partner Erwin Hass. We express our sincere condolences to Erwin, his wife Maria, his children and all of the family.

title: NATO and Old Demons
description: To the Editor:

title: Hispanic Births in U.S. Reach Record High
description: The number of babies being born to Hispanic women in the United States has reached a record high, increasing to 18 percent of the total number of births, according to a new Federal report released today.

title: Torre Knows the Yankees Need Irabu to Excel
description: The Yankees' spring training does not officially begin until Saturday, and the manager's wardrobe is not yet committed to baseball. Sitting in his office today and waving a cigar in his left hand as he spoke, Joe Torre wore a Yankee T-shirt above dress slacks and loafers.

title: Metro Business; Avon's First Store Coming to Fifth Ave.
description: Avon Products and Donald J. Trump announced yesterday that the beauty products company would open its first retail outlet in the United States at Trump Tower.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, HARVEY
description: GORDON-Harvey. With great sadness, the Board of Directors, Administration and Residents of the Gurwin Jewish Geriatric Center mourn the passing of Harvey Gordon, beloved husband of Rosalyn, a founding member of our Board of Directors. Rosalyn and Harvey were among those earliest donors whose vision helped bring Gurwin to the preeminent facility it is today. Harvey was a respected memeber of the Long Island business and philanthropic community. He will be missed. Our heartfelt condolences to the entire family. Joseph Gurwin, President Alfred W. Levy, Chairman of the Board Herbert H. Friedman, Executive Vice President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PANZARELLA, DR. FRANK P.
description: PANZARELLA-Dr. Frank P. On Feb. 10, 1998. Devoted father of Frank Jr., Nancy and the late Paul. Grandfather of Christopher and Allison. Son of the late Amalia and Angelo. Father-in-law to Meredith. Beloved brother of Angela, Eva, Theresa, John, Joseph and the late Edward, Stanley and Arthur. Brother-in-law of Laura, Tommi and Anne. Dr. Panzarella, Ph.D. in Biochemistry, was CEO and President of Doak Pharmaceutical Company. He purchased Doak in the early 1960's and originated the skin care dermatologic concept which resulted in his discovery of Formula 405 and many other dermatological products. He graduated from Bates College in 1930, was sent to England during W.W. II and completed his Ph.D. in biochemistry a few years later. He then became a professor at Fordham University. He was honored as Man of the Year Boys Town of Italy and owned Horti Laboratories. Dr. Panzarella who was 89 on January 17th had end stage kidney disease. He admired Dr. Speck, CEO of Columbia Presbyterian Hospital in Manhattan, for presenting to him the finest group of doctors who helped him to survive because of his determination and will never to give up. ''Every day,'' he would say, ''is beautiful because I am alive.'' He inculcated so many around him with a profound respect for life for the elders in our society. Reposing at Edward F. Lieber Funeral Home, 266 North Central Avenue, Valley Stream. Visitation Friday, 2 to 4 and 7 to 9. Funeral mass on Saturday, 9 AM, at Blessed Sacrament RC Church. Interment St. Charles Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. In lieu of flowers please send a donation to benefit the Dialysis Department at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center, 622 W. 168 St, NYC toward the purchase of a new EKG machine and state-of-the-art dialysis machines or to Arthur L. Caplan, Ph.D, Director, Center for Biomedical Ethics, Professor of Philosophy, the University of Pennsylvania Medical School, Chestnut Street, Philadelphia, PA. May God bless all of the people who became a part of our father's life.

title: Investors Step Up Purchases Of Stock and Bond Funds
description: Investors stepped up their purchases of shares of stock and bond mutual funds in January, compared with December. But while bond funds took in more money than in any month for more than four years, cash flows to stock funds failed to measure up to the levels reached in January of the previous two years.

title: Children Are Left Alone In Day Care, Officials Say
description: Fire officials in Union Township, hoping to inspect a private home they believed was being used as a day care center, said they found five children left unattended in the house earlier this week.

title: Parsippany Man Charged With Slaying His Wife
description: A Parsippany man has been charged with fatally shooting his wife while their two young children were sitting in the next room, county prosecutors said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSTON, BECKY
description: JOHNSTON-Becky. Age 60, of cancer, February 11, 1998, in New York Hospital. She was a practicing psychotherapist in NYC. After graduation from Stamford Univ., she served with the Peace Corps in the Phillipines. Prior to establishing her own practice, she was a supervisor with Jewish Family Service where she developed many programs including a crisis intervention unit for the Borough of Brooklyn. A lover of animals, a superb gardener, and wonderful friend. She is survived by her mother, Beatrice, and two brothers, Alex and Spencer of Northern California, and a companion, Sandra Sinclair. Her cmpassion and gentleness will be missed by many. Donations in her name can be made to the Sierra Club. Memorial service will be private.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Mark Bennett

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACMILLAN, CHARLES JAMES
description: MACMILLAN - Charles James Barr of Tallahassee, Fl. age 62. February 11, 1998 of Cancer. Survived by his wife Joan. Daughter Ann, son and daughter-in-law Tyler and Jill. Granddaughter Lindsay. He taught Philosophy of Education at Florida State University, specializing in the study of Ludwig Wittgenstein. BA and PhD Cornell M.A. Colgate. Memorial contributions to The Isabel Peard Scholarship Fund, Day Hall, Cornell University, Ithaca, N.Y.14850.

title: Cabby, Stricken at Wheel, Injures 2 Joggers
description: A 75-year-old cabdriver suffered a fatal heart attack while driving through Central Park yesterday afternoon, losing control of his cab and hitting two joggers, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EMDEN, LEONA
description: EMDEN-Leona. I loved you more than you'll ever know. I will always carry you in my heart. With all my love, Jeffrey Emden

title: Ax in Hand, Ice in the Veins, Scaling a Mountain's Slippery Face
description: Clipped to a broken birch tree halfway up a 350-foot wall of ice in the High Peaks region of the Adirondacks, I nervously asked my guide to repeat the safety procedure he'd just explained. Then I asked him again. The third time, he stated curtly: ''Wait here. I'll tell you what to do again when I get to the top.'' He sank his pick into the ice, looked back over his shoulder and said, ''Don't worry, you couldn't kill yourself if you tried!'' He flashed a smile and disappeared around a pillar of ice dripping like a dozen leaky faucets, leaving me to ponder my gorgeous, precarious perch.

title: Boastful Man Is Accused of Selling Nonexistent Cars to 2 Buyers
description: As big as a house and as smooth as a song, the man who called himself Derek O'Connor seemed like every restaurateur's dream. And for a while he was, spinning out tales of his successes in the luxury car market as he filled his 6-foot, 300-pound frame with hefty meals and vodka at two lower Manhattan eateries.

title: Tomba Can See Himself As a Leading Man Next
description: Six years younger than John Elway, four years the junior of Michael Jordan, Alberto Tomba blew into Olympic Land today, sounding more like a man waiting for his pipe, paper and slippers than one in the prime of his athletic life.

title: U.S.-Canada Is Prelude to Gold
description: The first Olympic gold medal game in women's ice hockey is greatly anticipated, and the two teams involved will play a dress rehearsal three days before the actual event. The teams, Canada and the United States, have already played 13 times this season, with Canada winning seven times and the United States winning six.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THAU, DR. M. DAVID
description: THAU-Dr. M. David. Of White Plains. Formerly of Westbury. Passed away on 2/12/98. Beloved husband of Sylvia. Adored father of Paul, Sheryl, Sue and Arthur. Cherished grandfather of Andrew, Dana, Seth and Matthew. Past President of Old Westbury Hebrew Congregation and Queens and New York County Optometric Societies. Donations may be made in his memory to Project Ezra, East Broadway, NY. Service today, 11:30 AM, at the Old Westbury Hebrew Congragation, 21 Old Westbury Rd., Old Westbury.

title: A Hazy Blend of Earthly Joys and Spiritual Fire
description: Anyone who has felt the shake of a rocking revival meeting knows the lesson of gospel music: that contrary to the Puritan mindset, spiritual enlightenment need not be split apart from physical joy. Rastafarian reggae music spoke the same truth in Jamaica. And at S.O.B.'s last weekend, the Rastafarian vocal group the Congos returned to show how inspired artists can turn a nightclub into hallowed ground.

title: Metro Business; I.B.M. Sells Another Site
description: The International Business Machines Corporation is nearing the end of a major sale of its real estate holdings that it began four years ago.

title: Prices Decline as Auction of 30-Year Treasuries Disappoints
description: An early rally yesterday in Treasury securities faded and prices ended lower for the first time in three days, hurt by a disappointing auction of $10 billion in 30-year bonds.

title: Why Punish Lawyers for Tobacco Victories?
description: To the Editor:

title: Robbery Suspect Caught Trying to Retrieve Car
description: A Manhattan man suspected in 27 robberies was arrested yesterday after he tried to retrieve a car he had abandoned during a police pursuit earlier this week, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, THEODORE R.
description: MILLER-Theodore R. Pioneering cancer surgeon and educator, died peacefully at home at the age of 90 on February 4, 1998. He is survived by his wife of 64 years, Helen R. Miller; his sister, Ruth E. Miller and 3 brothers, Robert I., Ralph A. and Dr. William H. Born and raised in Philadelphia. Studied at Swarthmore, Yale and Stockholm U. MD from Temple Medical School in 1933. Diplomat of the American Board of Surgery. For more than 40 years he pioneered cancer surgery and was world renowned for developing new procedures. He began practice in Hackensack. Served in the 14th Evacuation Hospital in India during WWII, discharged as a Lt. Colonel. Dr. and Mrs. Miller spend a year in Stockholm and Copenhagen immediately after the war. He returned to NY to begin practice with the Pack Medical group and his life long association with memorial Sloan-Kettering where he became chief of the bone tumor service. Dr. Miller was clinical professor of surgery at Cornell Medical College and at Rutgers Medical College. He was past president of the American Radium Society and the James Ewing Society. Dr. Miller enjoyed music, playing the violin and the recorder; he was also an accomplished artist. He will be missed by all who knew him. A memorial service will be held at Monroe Village in Jamesburg, NJ on Saturday, February 21 at 11am. Donations may be made to the Presbyterian Homes of NJ.

title: On My Mind; The Diplomatic No-Penalty Solution
description: The United States says it prefers a ''diplomatic'' solution to the crisis with Iraq, rather than military action.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FALK, MAE
description: FALK-Mae. To Mae Falk, we are grateful for the many years of joyful rememberance. The Coles and the Newmans

title: A Space Alien Thriller, Underwater
description: The crew is tough and unisex, ''Alien'' style. The Top Secret mission is rich in techno-terror. And the tour guide is Michael Crichton, whose 1987 novel ''Sphere'' told of trippy, mind-altering phenomena on the Pacific Ocean floor. In the end, the book proves uncharacteristically touchy-feely for Mr. Crichton, and not just because things with tentacles mean so much to its plot.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORRIS, GRINNELL
description: MORRIS-Grinnell. Died February 5, in Naples, Florida. Survived by his wife Cornelia and sons Grinnell Jr, Stephen, Frederic and Daniel. Also by his brother John. A memorial service will be held on Sunday March 8, at St. Johns Church, Cold Spring Harbor, L.I. at 1pm. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to Planned Parenthood of Suffolk County, Smithtown or St. Johns Church, Cold Spring Harbor.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The Line Item Veto Act violates the procedural requirements ordained in Article I of the United States Constitution and impermissibly upsets the balance of powers so carefully prescribed by its Framers.''

title: Influential Sudan Official Is Killed in Plane Crash
description: In a major blow to the Islamic party that controls this vast country, the Sudan's influential and populist Vice President was killed today when a plane carrying several military officers and politicians crashed as it tried to land in a southern town, the Government said.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Paul Laffoley

title: MAY STORES TO BUY BACK UP TO $650 MILLION OF STOCK
description: The May Department Stores Company said yesterday that it planned to buy back as much as $650 million of its stock in the company's third repurchase plan in two years. May also said its fourth-quarter earnings rose 5.2 percent, to $445 million, or $1.79 a diluted share, from $423 million, or $1.61, before a charge a year ago. The shares of the company, which operates the Lord & Taylor and Filene's department stores, hit a record high on expectations that earnings will continue to rise and on news of the buyback. May also raised its annual dividend to $1.27 a share from $1.20. May's shares rose 81.25 cents, to $57.9375, after touching $59.375 earlier.

title: World News Briefs; Germany Finds Factory For Bombs and Seeks 3
description: Authorities in eastern Germany announced today that they were searching for three fugitive far-rightists after the discovery of a crude bomb-making factory in the university town of Jena.

title: Judging the President; Clearheaded Electorate
description: To the Editor:

title: The Faded Romance With Russia
description: Management of relations with Russia, once one of Bill Clinton's foreign-policy achievements, has taken a skid lately, with damaging implications for American interests. The most contentious issue for the moment is Iraq.
