Boris Yeltsin has warned ominously about the consequences of an American military strike against Iraq, and yesterday his Defense Minister, Igor Sergeyev, told Defense Secretary William Cohen of Russia's ''deep concern'' about American plans.

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: Next for Disney: Aida as Musical

title: Issue of Time And Space: A Parole Ban
description: GOV. GEORGE E. PATAKI banged the drum once again the other day for his pet project in this election year: doing away with parole for all felons convicted of violent offenses. What the Governor did not say -- once again -- was where he planned to put the many inmates who would have to be kept years longer in New York State prisons, already at 130 percent of capacity.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Anne Kraus

title: Scientists Use Radar to Chart Cambodia's Ancient Ruins
description: With highly detailed radar maps as their guide, archeologists have explored the jungle beyond the ancient ruins of Angkor in Cambodia and uncovered remnants of previously unknown temples and new evidence of an earlier culture that occupied the famous site.

title: $3 BILLION STOCK BUYBACK FOR MORGAN STANLEY
description: Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Company said yesterday that it would buy back up to $3 billion of stock in the company's first share repurchase since announcing merger plans a year ago. The buyback program would retire as much as 8.2 percent of the company's 594.7 million shares outstanding, based on Wednesday's closing price. Morgan Stanley rose $2.50 yesterday, to $63.9375, on the New York Stock Exchange. The company also reported profits of $2.65 billion last year, up 35 percent from 1996. Morgan Stanley and Dean Witter, Discover & Company completed their $11 billion ''pooling of assets'' merger on June 6. In such a transaction, stock buybacks are restricted until at least six months after the merger is complete.

title: Mother's Testimony Over, Lewinsky Returns to Capital
description: Monica S. Lewinsky and her mother, Marcia Lewis, were reunited here tonight after Ms. Lewis spent two grueling days before a Federal grand jury investigating her daughter's relationship with President Clinton.

title: Democrats Rally as President Unveils Agenda for Campaign
description: They stepped up, woman after woman, to praise the President. A black business executive. A white woman looking toward retirement. A 21-year-old college student, not much younger than Monica S. Lewinsky.

title: IN LITTLE ITALY WITH: Martin Scorsese; Scene One: A Fire Escape
description: The storefront door groaned open and a cloud of warm, fleshy air pushed into Elizabeth Street. ''Mary, it's Marty,'' Martin Scorsese called to the 94-year-old woman sitting in a chair near the window in an otherwise empty butcher shop. The woman seemed puzzled. ''My son?'' she asked. Mr. Scorsese reached out his arms. ''No, no, it's Marty,'' he said. The old meat cutter pushed herself out of her chair, squinted toward the door and squealed with delight. ''Ah, Marty! It's Marty! You're back!''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KASSLER, ELIZABETH BAUER
description: KASSLER-Elizabeth Bauer. The Trustees and staff of The Museum of Modern Art express deep sadness at the passing of their longtime friend and colleague Elizabeth Bauer Kassler, former curator and director of the Department of Architecture and Design. Her tenure at the Museum from 1938 to 1946 spanned a vital period in our history and her contributions are fondly remembered. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her family. Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman Agnes Gund, President Glenn D. Lowry, Director Terence Riley, Director, Dept of Architecture & Design The Museum of Modern Art, N.Y.

title: Why Punish Lawyers for Tobacco Victories?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBENSTEIN, DOROTHY
description: RUBENSTEIN-Dorothy. The Partners of Ellenbogen, Rubenstein, Eisdorfer and co. LLP mourn the passing of Dorothy Rubenstein, the mother of our partner Ira Rubenstein. We express our sincere condolences to Ira, his father Ben and all of the family. Ellenbogen, Rubenstein, Eisdorfer and co., LLP

title: A Passion For Linen (And Initials)
description: Once upon a time, trousseaus were lovingly amassed in anticipation of the day when a young woman would meet Mr. Right. And when she did, the sheets, towels and napkins were destined to be used over and again for the rest of her life and then passed from generation to generation. The Baltimore belle born Bessie Wallis Warfield had three opportunities to build a trousseau, but she only hit her stride after her third and final marriage. Alas, she died without heirs, so the contents of her linen closet are now available to anyone with the funds -- and the patience -- to sit through the nine-day public dispersal of her worldly goods.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: 'Male'

title: Babbitt Insists Inquiry Will Vindicate Him
description: Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt said today that he felt ''put upon'' by Attorney General Janet Reno's decision to seek an outside prosecutor to investigate his role in his department's rejection of an Indian casino. But Mr. Babbitt declared that he would cooperate and in the end ''be vindicated.''

title: Quickly Quotable
description: The winner of The New Republic magazine's ''name-that-White-House-scandal'' contest: ''Bimbroglio.''

title: The Olympics: Chaos and Controversy
description: BATTLE OF SURVIVAL -- Jean-Luc Cretier of France won the gold medal today in a men's downhill that may be remembered as much for those who fell as for those who won. After the event had been delayed for five days because of bad weather, 43 skiers started down the treacherous course, but only 28 finished it. Among the unfortunate was the Austrian star Hermann Maier, whose gold-medal hopes vanished in a spectacular crash in which he flipped 30 feet in the air and blew through two fences. But he walked away. Page C1.

title: F.A.A. Finds Minor Shortcomings at Boeing
description: A special inspection of the factories that make tails for Boeing 737's, carried out by the Federal Aviation Administration after the wreckage of one such plane showed missing fasteners in that section, found that workers sometimes lacked training for their jobs, tested parts without proper supervision and sometimes used bolts that were too short, the agency said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GENSEL, THE REV. JOHN GARCIA
description: GENSEL-The Rev. John Garcia. The pastors, people and staff of Saint Peter's Church, 619 Lexington Avenue, New York, New York, mourn the death of our Pastor Emeritus John Garcia Gensel. We give thanks to God for his life, his faith and his gifts as our Pastor and as the ''Shepherd of the Night Flock'' who cared for, supported and served members of the jazz community and who pioneered jazz both as an art form and as a medium for worship. We rejoice that he now shares fully in the abundant life of Christ which he so joyfully proclaimed. In celebration of Pastor Gensel's life and ministry, Saint Peter's Church announces the establishment of the John Garcia Gensel Memorial Jazz Fund for the support of both the artistic and spiritual dimensions of jazz. We encourage all of Pastor Gensel's friends and supporters to allow time for his beloved wife Audrey and his family to mourn in private. In consultation with the Gensel family, we plan two memorial services for Pastor Gensel at Saint Peter's Church. A Mass of the Resurrection on Saturday, April 18, 1998 and a jazz celebration on Sunday, April 19, 1998. Amandus J. Derr, Senior Pastor Saint Peter's Church 619 Lexington Avenue New York, NY 10022-4610

title: Extra Pay Plan For Firefighters Draws the Ire Of Police Union
description: The Giuliani administration and the union representing city firefighters tentatively agreed yesterday to a proposal that would give extra pay to firefighters who respond to medical emergencies, an incentive that the city's largest police union says would upset the historic balance between the city's Fire and Police Departments.

title: U.S. and I.B.M. Join Forces to Develop Fastest Computer
description: The Department of Energy yesterday raised the stakes in the international race to build the world's fastest supercomputer when it announced that it had signed an $85 million contract with the International Business Machines Corporation to build a machine capable of 10 trillion calculations a second.

title: Calipari Softens Trade Talk Damage
description: When the Nets finished practice today, John Calipari set up camp in the tunnel just off the court at Continental Arena to explain the wild trade scenarios that have swirled around the team the last four days. In the background, Sam Cassell and Kendall Gill remained on the court after the rest of the team had left, calmly shooting baskets and enjoying themselves, like props to support Calipari's enthusiastic speech.

title: A Portrait of Plath in Poetry for Its Own Sake
description: BIRTHDAY LETTERS

title: Canadian Gets His Gold Medal Back
description: Darren Chalmers, who began these Olympics as Ross Rebagliati's roommate and soon became one of his many defenders, labeled the controversy, ''As the Snowboard Turns.''

title: Nokia Net Rises More Than Expected
description: Nokia, the Finnish maker of telecommunciations equipment, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter net income rose a greater-than-expected 23 percent as demand for its networks soared and profitability in its mobile phone unit increased. The company's profit rose to 2.018 billion markkaa ($367 million), from 1.645 billion a year earlier.

title: Excerpts From Decision Against the Line Item Veto
description: Following are excerpts from the decision by Judge Thomas F. Hogan of Federal District Court here, striking down the President's line item veto power:

title: CUBA ANNOUNCES IT WILL FREE 200 IN BOW TO POPE
description: In what Vatican officials described as a welcome response to Pope John Paul II's appeal last month for the release of all ''prisoners of conscience'' in Cuba, the Cuban Government announced today that it intended to free ''more than 200 inmates'' held on political and other charges.

title: Igniting a Memorial Flame to Lives the Nazis Extinguished
description: There is something redemptive about the growing interest in discovering and reviving the works of composers whose lives were cut short by the Nazis. Neglected for decades, composers like Viktor Ullmann and Pavel Haas, whose music was the subject of a concert at Weill Recital Hall on Wednesday night, as well as Hans Krasa, Erwin Schulhoff and Gideon Klein, are now getting thorough examinations in the concert hall and on disk.

title: Judging the President
description: To the Editor:

title: In a Bijou at the Met, La Tour Magdalenes Converge From Distant Corners
description: Every now and then, remarkable works of art breeze into New York like migrant birds and alight. Who could forget, in 1984, turning a corner in the Lehman Wing at the Metropolitan Museum of Art to find two of Watteau's greatest paintings, resting for a few weeks on their way from Washington to Paris?

title: Poems, Tricks and a Tale or Two
description: Some people shrink when all eyes are upon them. Others never seem more potently alive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRUCATO, SALVATORE J. MD.
description: BRUCATO-Salvatore J. MD. On 11 February 1998 of Manhasset. Beloved husband of Grace. Dear father of Barbara and father-inlaw of Dr John Pelletieri, Grandfather of Leslie and John, brother of Helen Pappalardo. In repose at The Fairchild Funeral Chapel 1570 Northern Blvd, Manhasset on Friday from 3-5 and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass on Saturday at 10:45am in St Mary's RC Church, Manhasset with interment to follow in The Locust Valley Cemetery.

title: Earnhardt Giving It Another Shot
description: For nine straight years, Dale Earnhardt has parked his black No. 3 Chevrolet in the winner's circle after finishing first in one of the two qualifying races at Daytona International Speedway. But he has yet to return to the winner's circle after the Daytona 500, the most prestigious race in the Winston Cup series.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Juice Bar? Massages? May One Still Sweat?
description: ''Massage?'' asked the man at the counter of the 10th Street Baths.

title: A Household Finds Little Things Count
description: The delightful toy-size characters in ''The Borrowers'' need no introduction: they're the reason you can never find small household objects that aren't nailed down. And they make fabulously clever use of your old gloves and floss and Monopoly cards, if Peter Hewitt's charming new children's film is any evidence. Adapted from Mary Norton's novels, with a quaint, cozy style that recalls the stories' 1950's origins, this visually witty film is perfectly up to date in its technological ambitions. With today's special effects, it's easy to make a tiny person climbing refrigerator magnets appear to be scaling the side of a cliff.

title: Payton Is Hoping For Change In Fortune
description: As things turned out, they may not be the boys of summer, after all. But three springs ago, pitchers Bill Pulsipher, Jason Isringhausen and Paul Wilson and outfielder Jay Payton were considered the core of the Mets' future.

title: Something Borrowed: '85
description: Oozing niceness, Adam Sandler plays it semi-sincere in ''The Wedding Singer,'' a comedy with a dual personality. Half the film is an ingenuous love story, but the better half consists of pop culture time-warp jokes set in 1985. Or, as Mr. Sandler's Robbie Hart says to the girlfriend who jilts him, ''Now please get out of my Van Halen T-shirt before you jinx the band and they break up.''

title: Ajaccio Journal; The Ugly Face Behind Corsican Nationalism's Mask
description: There is a macabre cycle in Corsica's nationalist politics. Every few months public buildings are bombed or someone is shot down in classic gangland style in the name of gaining greater autonomy from Paris. With the funeral comes an outcry from the people on this beautiful but troubled Mediterranean island. A truce follows -- until the next shootout.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PINCHUK, SIGMUND
description: PINCHUK-Sigmund. On February 12, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Fannie. Loving father of Doris Medford, David, Norman and Jack Pinchuk. Cherished grandfather and great grandfather. Services Friday, 12:15PM at ''The Riverside'', 76 St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Video Pioneer's Roller Coaster of Shimmering, Rocking Images
description: The retrospective of Bill Viola's video installations at the Whitney Museum of American Art is accompanied by some unusual facts.

title: Russian Official Scolds Cohen on Threats to Iraq
description: Russia's Defense Minister, Igor Sergeyev, sharply criticized the United States today for threatening to attack Iraq, warning Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen that a strike could undercut efforts to improve military ties between Moscow and Washington.

title: Key South Korean Union Calls Off Strike
description: In a sudden turnaround, South Korea's most militant labor organization announced late Thursday that it had scrapped a general strike scheduled to begin today to protest legislation that would make layoffs easier.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: 'From Sacred to Sensual'

title: New Video Releases
description: Devil's Advocate

title: A Place for Part-Time Students
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's attack on the City University of New York has prompted debate about the system's mission and how best to deliver remedial courses that more than 8 in 10 students require. The debate is timely and important. But so far it has overlooked the merits of revising the state student-aid formula, which has failed to keep up with changes in student demographics.

title: Gunman Kills Teacher, Then Himself, Outside Hoboken High
description: A man gunned down a popular history teacher outside Hoboken High School today as students looked on, then fatally shot himself, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORAN, MATTHEW V.
description: MORAN-Matthew V. On February 11, 1998. Of Island Park, NY (formerly of Valley Stream and Chatham, NJ). Beloved husband of the late Barbara. Loving father of Catherine Clark and Nancy. Devoted grandfather of Rachel Barbara. Also survived by his sister and brother-in-law, Doris and Daniel O'Brien, his son-in-law Gregory and future son-in-law Matt Carlin. Visiting, Towers Funeral Home, Inc, Long Beach and Foxhurst Rds, Oceanside, LI., 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral mass Saturday, 9:30 AM, Sacred Heart Church, Island Park. Interment, Fairmount Cemetery, Chatham, NJ.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEL BALSO, TOBI ROSEN
description: del BALSO-Tobi Rosen. Of Riverdale. The best friend we ever had. Died February 10, 1998. Much too soon, after a long illness of cancer and multiple sclerosis. She was a teacher and counselor who changed the lives of everyone she met. She is survived by her husband Paul, father George E. Rosen, nieces Jill and Tina, nephew Eric and all her friends. Services will be held Friday, 12:30 P.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, SYLVIA
description: BERNSTEIN-Sylvia, age 98 (almost 99), died peacefully on February 12, 1998 at Mount Sinai Hospital after a short illness. Beloved wife of Alfred, who died in 1977. She is survived by her son, Robert L. Bernstein (Helen) of New York City, her daughter, Barbara Rosenberg (Herman) of West Orange, New Jersey, 5 grandchildren (Peter, Tom and William Bernstein of New York City, John Rosenberg of San Francisco and Patricia Drosdowich of Warwick, New York) and 12 great-grandchildren. A native New Yorker, she was born Sylvia Bloch on March 6, 1899 and Married Alfred Bernstien on January 20, 1920, whom she was devoted to until his death. She will be much missed and always loved. Services will be held on Friday, February 13, 1:00PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, at 81 Street. The family will be home from 4:307:30PM. Burial will be private.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, HELEN (NEE LEVINE)
description: BERNSTEIN-Helen (Nee Levine) 80, on Thursday, February 12, 1998 of South Orange, N.J. Formerly of Bayside, Queens, NY. Beloved wife of the late David Bernstein. Devoted mother of Andrew and Jodi Bernstein. Adored sister of Dorothy Lukovitch. Loving grandmother of Rachel and Gabe Bernstein. Funeral services conducted from the Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Road, Union, N.J. on Sunday, February 15, 1998 at 1:00 PM. Interment Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, N.J.

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Galleries, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan and are open Tuesdays through Saturdays from 10 or 11 A.M. to 5 or 6 P.M.; gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Auto Insurance Rates Are Nation's Highest
description: New Jersey residents paid the highest auto insurance rates in the country in 1996, according to a survey released on Wednesday.

title: The Neediest Cases; A Girl, 15, Is Trying to Find Her Way
description: Ask Tricia Zwilinske why she used to smoke marijuana every day, why she failed all her classes or why rebellious behavior led to her being dismissed from four high schools and all she offers is a wan smile and a sheepish shrug. ''Everyone else was doing it,'' Tricia, 15, said haltingly as she played with her bangs. ''It was the thing to do.''

title: Republican Party Chief Enters Fray With Attack Over Clinton Scandal
description: While most Republican leaders in Congress are resisting attacking President Clinton, the Republican National Committee is eagerly doing the work for them.

title: COMMERCIAL FEDERAL AGREES TO BUY AMERUS BANK OF IOWA
description: The Commercial Federal Corporation agreed yesterday to buy Amerus Bank, a unit of the Amerus Group, an insurer, for $200.9 million in stock and cash, making it the fourth-largest bank in Iowa. Commercial Federal, based in Omaha, is actively acquiring banks in the Midwest. It has $7.2 billion in assets and 115 branches in five states. Amerus Bank, based in Des Moines, has $1.5 billion in assets and 47 branches. Shares of Commercial Federal fell 12.5 cents, to $33.75, while Amerus fell 25 cents, to $34.75.

title: Why Punish Lawyers for Tobacco Victories?
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL SLIDES. Crude oil futures fell for the fourth consecutive session as concerns eased about a possible military strike on Iraq disrupting supplies from the Mideast. The March contract fell 19 cents, to $15.96 a barrel.

title: Principals of Alternative High Schools Are Ordered to Increase the Schools' Enrollments
description: Only months after Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew retreated from a plan to increase the size of small schools, the principals of dozens of small high schools across New York City have received orders to start adding students immediately.

title: U S West Media Reduces Loss
description: U S West Media Group said today that it had pared its fourth-quarter loss on higher revenue from its United States cable-television, high-speed data and cellular phone businesses.

title: A $12 Billion Carrot for Prudential Policyholders
description: The Prudential Insurance Company of America, the nation's largest life insurer, dangled the prospect of a windfall to its policyholders under a plan announced yesterday to set up a new corporate structure.

title: Peugeot Citroen Reports Big Loss in 1997
description: PSA Peugeot Citroen S.A., France's biggest car maker, said yesterday that it lost 2.5 billion francs ($417 million) in 1997 as it took charges to pay for job cuts and foreign exchange losses. The loss, which compares with a 1996 profit of 734 million francs, was also aggravated by the cost of pulling out of its Indian joint venture and a change in accounting methods. Excluding one-time items and tax, the company had a profit of 900 million francs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERNBERG, LEO. ARTIST
description: STERNBERG-Leo. Artist. On February 10, 1998 in Great Barrington, MA. Husband of Mary, father of Amy Sternberg Mann and Daniel Sternberg, father-in-law of Jeffrey Mann and Deborah Cooper Sternberg, grandfather of Jessica Mann, Rachel and Seth Rosan and Julia and Samuel Sternberg. Services at Finnerty and Stevens, 426 Main Street, Great Barrington, MA. on Sunday, February 15, 1998, at 1 P.M. Family will meet friends at the home of Amy and Jeffrey Mann, 75 East End Avenue, N.Y., evenings Monday-Wednesday. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the National Yiddish Book Center, 1021 West Street, Amherst, MA. 01002. We loved him dearly and we will miss him.

title: Suharto Orders 'Stern Action' By Military Against His Rivals
description: President Suharto told the military today to ''take stern action'' against his opponents as tensions rise in Indonesia before his expected confirmation for a new term in office next month.

title: Police Officer Who Sued Is Promoted to Captain
description: Six months after filing a Federal lawsuit against North Brunswick charging that he was denied a promotion because of his race, a black police lieutenant was promoted yesterday to the rank of captain.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: George Condo

title: A New Domain For Sitcom Master
description: JERRY SEINFELD is moving away from Tom's Restaurant in more ways than one. First he signed a $4.35 million contract for an apartment a couple of blocks south of his old one on Central Park West. Then NBC's soon-to-depart sitcom star dropped plans to film one of his final episodes in New York. The show will end its run on a California sound stage.

title: Another Day, Another High; Dow and S.&P. Climb Again
description: The Dow Jones industrial average rebounded from an early drop to reach its third consecutive new high yesterday as investors discounted unsettling news from Asia.

title: Ice Dancers Battle It Out In Quest for Credibility
description: Pasha Grishuk of Russia has arrived at the Olympic Winter Games, and judging from her costume, she appears to be going to the Crusades in a bikini. Off the ice she wears a mink coat. Her earrings hang like chandeliers. Her hair is a platinum color found nowhere in nature. Formerly, her first name was Oksana, but she changed it so as not to be confused with Oksana Baiul, that other Olympic champion.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Prudential Policyholders May Become Shareholders

title: National News Briefs; President to Set a Goal Of Cutting Drug Demand
description: President Clinton is expected to set a goal of cutting in half the demand for illegal drugs by the year 2007, White House officials said today.

title: Brooklyn Gas To Turn Over Some Business To Enron
description: In a move that could mean savings on natural gas bills for some Brooklyn Union Gas customers, the utility said yesterday that it would turn over the management of its $500 million-a-year business of buying, transporting and storing natural gas to the Enron Corporation of Houston.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OPPENS, KURT F.H.
description: OPPENS-Kurt F.H. Feb. 11, 1998. Beloved husband of Edith, loving father of Ursula. Memorial service Monday, 6 P.M., ''The Riverside,'' 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS TUMBLES. Natural gas futures fell 3.5 percent after the National Weather Service forecast milder weather in the Northeast and upper Midwest. The March contract fell 8 cents, to $2.208 for each 1,000 cubic feet.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Public Lives column on Thursday about remarks by the film critic Daphne Merkin at Barnard College misstated a word in a passage she quoted from her book ''Dreaming of Hitler: Passions and Provocations'' (Crown, 1997). Discussing an article she wrote for The New Yorker magazine about her sexual passions, including a taste for spanking, Ms. Merkin cited this passage from the book: ''A friend in the Midwest sent me an item gleaned from the local personal ads: SWM seeking Daphne Merkin type for mutual involvement in pleasure'' (not ''the usual involvement in pleasure'').

title: Prices End Higher in a Shortened Session
description: Treasury prices ended higher in a shortened session yesterday, drawing foreign investors after stock prices slumped in Asia.

title: Nets Too Much for Depleted Raptors
description: It was a difficult night for the Toronto Raptors, and a soothing night for the Nets.

title: Seeing a 'Significant Threat,' Judge Denies Bail to Gotti Jr.
description: A Federal judge denied a request today to allow John Gotti Jr. to be released on bail and confined under house arrest while he awaits trial on charges of racketeering and extortion, saying the defendant presents a ''significant threat'' because of his reputed ties to the Gambino crime family.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about the cancellation of a general strike in South Korea referred imprecisely to the Dow Corning Corporation, a company that has decided against investing in a Korean plant. It is not a unit of Dow Chemical; it is a joint venture owned equally by the Dow Chemical Company and Corning Inc.

title: Airbus Expects Big Latin Orders
description: The European aviation consortium Airbus Industrie said today that it expected to conclude an agreement soon to sell 100 narrow-body planes worth about $4 billion to three Latin American airlines.

title: Germany Says Economy Grew Slightly in Quarter
description: Germany's economy expanded slightly in the fourth quarter of last year, the Economics Ministry said yesterday, without providing an exact figure for expected growth. The flood of export orders that powered growth most of the year slowed to a trickle, suggesting that Germany might have a hard time reaching the upper range of the Government's forecast for 1998, which predicts growth of 2.5 to 3 percent.

title: Nuttiness, Russian Style, on 42d Street
description: Sock it to Stanislavsky?

title: Op-Art
How Childhood Has Changed! (Adults, Too)
description: At first glance, it could be a 16th-century version of a modern schoolyard. A piggyback tug of war is going on just in front of a game of leapfrog. Two girls play with dolls, another is in a wedding costume. One can imagine the cacophony: the grunts of the wrestling boys, the echoing hallos of a girl shouting into a hollow barrel, the frenzied teasing of blindman's buff.

title: Cone Aims for Opening Day
description: David Cone figures his credibility is probably at a low ebb with his manager, Joe Torre. Last fall, he convinced Torre that he was healthy enough to pitch in the playoffs and then was knocked around by the Cleveland Indians.

title: Seeing Firefighters Offered Higher Pay, Some Police Assail Their Own Union
description: Having endured a long series of contract setbacks and unsuccessful legal battles with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, city police officers yesterday seemed resigned to news that many firefighters would soon receive higher pay than the police, and some found a new target for their ire: their own union.

title: Kaiser H.M.O., Erring on Costs, Posts $270 Million Loss for '97
description: Kaiser Permanente, the nation's largest nonprofit health maintenance organization, said yesterday that it lost $270 million in 1997, mainly in Southern California and Texas. Dr. David M. Lawrence, the chief executive, said Kaiser was considering selling its money-losing Dallas-Fort Worth health plan to help deal with the losses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MADEN, PHIL
description: MADEN-Phil, on February 9, 1998, at home in Jamestown, R.I. A native of New York City, he is survived by his wife, Sue Daggett Maden, and son, Marc Madden.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARAS, FRANK
description: KARAS-Frank. On February 12, 1998. Beloved husband of Janet. Devoted father of Peter and daughter-in-law Elaine. Cherished grandfather of Lauren and Greg. We'll always love you, Frankie. Services Sunday 9:45AM at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Rain Gives A Victory To Gordon
description: The dark cloud that hung over Jeff Gordon this week finally burst today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINHILPER, FRANK
description: STEINHILPER-Frank. Graveside service Saturday at 10:30 AM, Alta Vista Cemetery, Gainesville, GA. Mr. Steinhilper was a patent attorney and partner with Rosen and Steinhilper law firm and was admitted to practice before the US Supreme Court and was a member of the NY Bar Association. Former Vice President of Xerox Corp. and a WWII veteran with the Navy. Surviving are wife Anne C. Steinhilper, three daughters, Frances Breslin, Andrea Gillaspy-Steinhilper and Anne Scott, two sons, Eric and David Steinhilper. Grandchildren also survive. For information contact Little Davenport Funeral Home, Gainesville, GA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, PATRICK
description: CLARK-Patrick. The Board, Staff, Teachers and Students of the Careers Through Culinary Arts Program (C-CAP) mourn the passing of Chef Patrick Clark, advisor, mentor, supporter and inspiration to us all. We will miss him greatly and extend our sincerest condolences to his wife, children and family. Richard Grausman, President C-CAP, Inc.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEIMAN, MIRIAM
description: NEIMAN-Miriam. Beloved wife of the late Arthur. Cherished sister of Belle Udane and Mae Alpert. Loving aunt. Services at ''The Riverside,'' 180 West 76th Street NYC, Sunday at 9:30 AM.

title: Fair and Accessible Golf
description: Believe it or not, there is a way for the Professional Golf Association and Casey Martin to settle their differences.

title: School Uniforms Don't Have to Be Sexist
description: To the Editor:

title: 100,000 CUNY Tutors
description: To the Editor:

title: More Races Postponed
description: Women's downhill and men's super-giant slalom were the latest skiing races disrupted by weather. SportsSaturday, page C1.

title: Lugers Tell of Drug Temptations
description: Chris Thorpe and Gordy Sheer, the American lugers who won the silver medal yesterday in the doubles event, said recently that they had considered taking banned drugs but rejected the idea.

title: Jingoism Parodied: Gershwins' War of '27
description: ''Happy, happy,'' sing the alarmingly perky members of the Fletcher's American Cheese Choral Society in the opening number of the heavenly concert revival of the Gershwin musical ''Strike Up the Band'' at City Center. They're explaining how much they enjoy their ''vocal exercising,'' which brings to mind those choruses of frolicsome villagers in Ruritanian operettas, and the deep honor of manufacturing a milk product that ''makes bigger and better citizens'' for this great country of ours.

title: Take That, Dow Industrials! Co-op Tops $2,000 a Foot
description: Another barrier has been pierced in the already dizzying rise of Manhattan's residential real estate market: for the first time, an apartment has sold for more than $2,000 a square foot.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COMEAU, ANDREW GNUTON
description: COMEAU-Andrew Gnuton. February 12, 1990. My loving son. You are always on my mind. Mami

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOSTER, CATHARINE OSGOOD
description: FOSTER-Catharine Osgood, 90, of Bennington, VT, on February 13 in Bennington. Educated Mount Holyoke College. Taught at Sophie Newcomb College in New Orleans and later at Bennington College for 30 years where the Catharine Osgood Foster Chair for Distinguished Teaching was established in her honor. Survived by husband Thomas H. Foster, Bennington, and several cousins. Burial Office offered Monday, February 16, 11 AM, St. Peters Episcopal Church, Bennington, VT. Interment at a later date. Old Bennington Cemetery, no visitation. Memorial gifts to Mt. Anthony Preservation Society or Crossett Library at Bennington College in care of Hanson-Walbridge Funeral Home, P.O. Box 957, Bennington, VT 05201.

title: Larson and Isler Win Sailing Honors
description: Chris Larson, a 31-year-old sailor from Annapolis, Md., has parlayed his expertise on a wide variety of racing boats to win the Rolex 1997 yachtsman of the year title. He received his award yesterday during a gathering at the New York Yacht Club.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELL, MORTON (MOE)
description: BELL-Morton (Moe). Age 84. Of Highland Beach, Fla. Formerly of Fort Lee, N.J. Beloved husband of Ruth. Loving father of Stephen (Myrna) and Jeffrey (Joan). Adored grandfather of Louis, Stephanie, Mark and Joshua. Cherished great-grandfather of Samantha Bell. Devoted brother of David (Lorraine) Belostock, Ruth Blumberg, Charlotte (Carl) Green. A loving uncle to many nieces and nephews. Mr. Bell was the owner of Yale Luggage and Leather Goods in Harrison, N.J. and a member of the National Association of Luggage and Leather Manufacturers. He belonged to the Fort Lee Jewish Center of Fort Lee, N.J. He was also a member of Faith Lodge #

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FAUST, SAM
description: FAUST-Sam, on February 9, 1998, died peacefully at home. Cherished husband of almost 51 years of Marcelle. Devoted and Adoring father of Karen and Monica. Father-in-law of Jonny. Loving Papa to Brittany and Cassidy. Brother of Lally. We miss you so much.

title: After 3-Year Void, Surgeon General's Post Is Filled
description: Pledging to ''live and to share the fundamental values that my parents instilled in me,'' David Satcher, the son of poor farmers from rural Alabama who grew up to become one of the nation's most prominent doctors, was sworn in at the White House today and became the first Surgeon General in more than three years.

title: Arbitrator Rules Against Buford
description: One day after pitcher Frank Rodriguez of Minnesota failed in his bid to quadruple his salary, Damon Buford of Boston struck out yesterday in his effort to attain a raise more than three times his 1997 salary.

title: Competing Is Fun Again for Eldredge
description: On the verge of winning a medal in men's figure skating, Todd Eldredge ticked off the name of other athletes whose redemptive success had come after years of failure. It was a club he hoped to join by Saturday night.

title: Severed Human Foot Found Under Pier
description: A foot in a high-top sneaker was found last night in a plastic bag in the water underneath a Manhattan pier, the police said.

title: INSIDE
description: A More Dangerous Anthrax

title: Congress and Pets
description: To the Editor:

title: With Pair Of Medals, U.S. Can Stand Tall
description: For the American lugers, winning the silver and the bronze medals in doubles this afternoon -- the country's first Olympic medals in this sport -- was a giant step. But they maintained perspective. ''What will it be like for us walking down a street in America?'' Gordy Sheer, a member of the silver-medal-winning team, asked rhetorically. ''Well, I don't expect to be walking down the street and being recognized like Alberto Tomba or Michael Jordan.''

title: Tobacco Lottery Has Replaced Political Process
description: To the Editor:

title: Mets Sign Becker for a Year
description: In a surprise of sorts, considering the sometimes-strained relationship between the Mets' front office and the player agent Craig Fenech, the Mets and outfielder Rich Becker, whose agent is Fenech, agreed on a one-year deal today, thereby avoiding an arbitration hearing next week.

title: Training of Some Officers Is Criticized by Grand Jury
description: A Brooklyn grand jury that last year cleared two plainclothes police officers of criminal wrongdoing in a fatal shooting has taken the unusual step of criticizing the New York City Police Department for giving inadequate tactical training to such officers, whose main duty is to roam precincts searching for crimes in progress.

title: Questions Get Tougher For Secret Service Man
description: One day last week, a retired Secret Service officer named Lewis C. Fox was being interviewed on his farm in western Pennsylvania on what he knew about President Clinton and Monica S. Lewinsky. Did he know of any relationship between the President and Ms. Lewinsky, a television reporter asked him.

title: Faltering Just 200 Yards From Olympic History
description: Slogging through the primeval mist, Bjorn Dahlie tried to become the absolute all-time gold-medal potentate of winter today, but he knew that his Norwegian countryman Thomas Alsgaard was right behind him, and they both knew there would soon be room to pass.

title: Steinbrenner's Rosy View: What's Not to Like?
description: George Steinbrenner smiled today like the owner of a team with three All-Star infielders, joking freely, daring reporters to write bad things about the Yankees now at the risk of looking stupid later.

title: GNI GROUP AGREES TO ITS PURCHASE FOR $50.7 MILLION
description: GNI Group Inc. agreed yesterday to be bought by an unidentified financial institution and some members of management for $7 a share, or $50.7 million, an 18 percent premium over GNI's closing price on Thursday. Shares of GNI rose 10 percent, or 59.375 cents, yesterday to $6.53125. The buyers also assume $30 million of GNI debt, which they expect to immediately pay off. GNI, based in Deer Park, Tex., declined to identify the managers involved in the buyout. Shareholders who control 29 percent of the company, including members of management, have agreed to vote in favor of the sale, GNI said.

title: At Center of Gatien Trial, a Jury That Needed More
description: The case had all the standard ingredients, and potential pitfalls, of a typical Federal drug-conspiracy or organized-crime trial.

title: Lionel Aldridge, 56, Stalwart On Defense for Packer Teams
description: Lionel Aldridge, a defensive star on the great Green Bay Packers teams of the 1960's whose post-playing years were marked by mental illness, was found dead by a daughter in his suburban Milwaukee apartment Thursday night. He was 56.

title: Helen B. Burnham Dies at 81; Small Town's 24-Hour Judge
description: Helen Billings Burnham, a one-time real estate woman with no legal training who spent 22 years dispensing justice, sometimes from her family room, as a part-time, round-the-clock town justice in Salina, N.Y., died on Thursday at her home in Mattydale, a suburb of Syracuse. She was 81 and had retired in 1993.

title: Prep School Gets $10 Million From 2 Alumni
description: Five years after receiving a $100 million gift from the philanthropist Walter H. Annenberg, the Peddie School in Hightstown, N.J., announced yesterday that it had once again struck gold: Mr. Annenberg and a fellow alumnus, Finn M. W. Caspersen, have joined together to give the prep school an additional $10 million.

title: A Spill a Minute in Nagano
description: The juxtaposition may be unintentional, but the promotional spots for the Daytona 500 stock car race that CBS has been running throughout its coverage of the Winter Olympics have an uncanny similarity to many of the events in Nagano. Both are filled with crashes and collisions and the anxiety that someone is going to ruin a lifetime of training by making a disqualifying mistake.

title: Moody's Cuts Ratings On the Daiwa Bank
description: Moody's Investors Service cut Daiwa Bank Ltd.'s long-term deposits to one notch above junk and gave the bank its lowest financial-strength rating yesterday, the latest downgrade to affect Japan's lenders.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORREST, BARBARA (NEE HEIMERDINGER)
description: FORREST-Barbara (nee Heimerdinger). On February 11, 1998 in her 72nd year. Adoring mother of Terry; beloved sister of John F. Heimerdinger; loving aunt to Linda, Daniel and Charles Heimerdinger; five grand-nephews and one grand-niece. Funeral services will be held at St. Agnes Church in Lake Placid on Monday, February 16. A Memorial service will be held on Long Island on February 18.

title: Holiday on Monday: Presidents' Day
description: NEW YORK

title: Technical Team Is Sent to Iraq To Try to Define Off-Limits Sites
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan said today that he is sending a technical team to Baghdad to clear up confusion over the so-called presidential sites that Saddam Hussein has declared off-limits to United Nations weapons inspectors.

title: Another Rebuff to Iraq
description: A recent technical mission to Baghdad found Iraq was still withholding information about nerve gas and missile warheads. Page A5.

title: Russia's Stake In Iraq Bolsters Anti-War Cry
description: Seven years ago, the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, begrudgingly blessed the American-led campaign to evict Iraqi forces from Kuwait.

title: Journal; Valentine's Day Massacred
description: After three intense weeks of the most graphic national discussion of sex in the history of the Republic, we have finally arrived at . . . Valentine's Day. How can we reclaim romance from a culture in which lovemaking is now a transaction to be described by Peeping Toms, recorded on tape, collected as DNA evidence and parsed into semantic distinctions that are the legal answer to the Kama Sutra?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAUTERSTEIN, LINCOLN W.
description: LAUTERSTEIN-Lincoln W. On February 12, 1998, on his 81st birthday in Rockport, MA. Beloved husband of Ingeborg and father of Adrian. Also survived by his brother Henry and nephews and nieces. A Summa Cum Laude graduate of Princeton and graduate of Harvard Law School. Attorney for the Metropolitan Opera. A veteran and active as attorney for the American Veterans Association. A brilliant man who will be greatly missed. Services are private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERMAN, LEE
description: SHERMAN-Lee on February 12, 1998, in his 84th year. Well known dancer and choreographer. Humphrey-Weidman Company, Broadway and Europe. Husband of Sally, father of Margo and brother of Helen Tabb and Joe Sherman. Funeral Service Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 12 Noon Sunday, February 15. 152 Second Avenue, NYC. Interment Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, NY.

title: From Cringing to Comfort: A Word Has Its Day
description: When the playwright Eve Ensler, the author of ''The Vagina Monologues,'' asked women ''What do you call them?,'' many mentioned terms like ''pooki'' and ''poochie,'' words they use with their children. But Ms. Ensler says ''vagina.'' Why? Because she's all grown up and, she said, ''because it's an invisible word -- a word that stirs up anxiety, awkwardness, contempt and disgust.'' The fact is, she can't say enough about vaginas.

title: Diet Secret of Crete
description: To the Editor:

title: State Report Sees Crisis In Child Welfare System
description: New Jersey's child welfare system is in a ''state of crisis'' after a decade of inadequate budgets and staffing, according to a 290-page report released yesterday by a state advisory panel.

title: Gene-Engineered Anthrax: Is It a Weapon?
description: In an apparent first, Russian scientists have genetically engineered a new form of anthrax that may be able to defeat the vaccine that American troops will soon get to protect them against such biological agents, American scientists said yesterday in interviews.

title: Clinton Tells Science Group Of Need to Cut Teen Smoking
description: Raising the political stakes in the fight over tobacco, President Clinton warned today that one million people would die prematurely if Congress failed this year to pass legislation to raise the price of cigarettes and restrict tobacco advertising.

title: CYRK TO DISMISS 450 WORKERS AND TAKE A CHARGE
description: Cyrk Inc. said yesterday that it would dismiss about 28 percent of its work force, or 450 workers, and take a charge of $12 million to $15 million in the first quarter as it focuses on higher-growth business lines. Cyrk, which makes custom-designed clothing and items bearing corporate logos for use in marketing promotions, said the job reductions would be mostly at its screen printing and embroidery business in Gloucester, Mass., where the company is based. It also announced a marketing partnership for Beanie Babies, including a $10 million investment by Ty Warner, chairman of Ty Inc., which produces Beanie Babies.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR GAINS. The dollar rose for the third day against the yen on new signs of economic weakness in Japan and skepticism about the Japanese Government's stimulus plan. The dollar cost 125.20 yen, up from 124.53.

title: Miami Is No Threat to Huskies
description: CONNECTICUT 80, MIAMI 60

title: French Police Rule Out Lead in Diana's Death
description: The French police said today that they had checked a white Fiat once owned by a celebrity photographer for a possible link to the crash that killed Diana, Princess of Wales, her escort and their driver last Aug. 31, but that they ruled out any connection.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-5

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENFIELD, HELEN BRICKELL
description: GREENFIELD - Helen Brickell. Died on February 12. Beloved wife of the late Jules, devoted mother of Norman and Marilyn, Ellin and Eddie. Adored grandmother of Jaime, Richard and Jane. Cherished great grandmother of Kelly, Robby, Perry and Brian. Services Sunday 12 Noon at ''The Riverside'', 76th St and Amsterdam Ave

title: Ulster Police Link 2 Deaths to I.R.A., Casting Pall Over Talks
description: In a statement that pushed the Northern Ireland peace effort further toward crisis, the chief of police there has asserted that the Irish Republican Army was involved in two killings of civilians this week in Belfast.

title: Nigerians Take Capital of Sierra Leone as Junta Flees
description: The capital of Sierra Leone, Freetown, fell to Nigerian forces today, sending the military leadership into flight and clearing the way for the return of the elected President.

title: Oprah Shouldn't Feel Guilty
description: I was a mouthpiece for meat. In 1991, a Tokyo production company hired me to help produce a television series, which was sponsored by an American meat industry lobbying group and sought to enhance the image of American meat in Japan.

title: Havana Journal; Remember the Maine? Cubans See an American Plot Continuing to This Day
description: The old monument still towers over the Malecon, Havana's tattered seafront promenade, but it has been stripped of most of its original busts and plaques, including the eagle that once crowned it. Clearly, even after 100 years, remembering the Maine has a different meaning in Cuba than in the United States.

title: Antitrust Scrutiny Ends Plan To Merge Accounting Firms
description: Ernst & Young and KPMG Peat Marwick abandoned plans to create the world's largest accounting and consulting firm yesterday after their frustrated leaders concluded that growing opposition from foreign regulators was just too much to make the marriage work.

title: Vik Coasts in the Nordic Combined
description: Bjarte Engen Vik of Norway raced comfortably to the gold medal in the cross-country portion of the Nordic combined today after winning the ski jumping leg a day earlier.

title: Forrester on the Devious Art Of Deceiving the Opponents
description: High quality bridge books from England cross the Atlantic in a steady stream, but there is little traffic in the opposite direction. Perhaps it is a matter of education: English children write essays in school, while American students do multiple choice tests.

title: Intern's Friend Said to Recount Talk of Affair
description: A California friend of Monica S. Lewinsky has told investigators that Ms. Lewinsky confided to her that she was having a sexual relationship with President Clinton, according to a family acquaintance and lawyers familiar with the friend's account.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: The Neediest Cases; Overwhelmed Household Finds Relief
description: Two years ago, whenever Andrew Markowitz was upset, he would vent his frustrations by rhythmically drumming his head against walls.

title: N.B.A. Union Plans Brief for Sprewell
description: The National Basketball Association's players union intends to file a long brief with the arbitrator hearing the Latrell Sprewell case.

title: TITANIUM METALS BUYS PART OF PIPE AND FITTINGS MAKER
description: The Titanium Metals Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the titanium business of Loterios S.p.A. for an undisclosed amount of cash. Loterios, based in Legnano, Italy, makes titanium pipe and fittings for oil and gas drilling production. The company reported 1997 sales of about $24 million. Titanium Metals, which is based in Denver, produces titanium metal products. In 1997, it had sales of $733.6 million.

title: Archbishop Rebukes Mayor on Marriage
description: Mayor Richard J. Riordan is not a man given to gushing, but when word went out this week that he planned a Valentine's Day wedding to his longtime lady love, Nancy Daly, he sounded over the moon, declaring himself ''thrilled to be marrying the most beautiful woman in the world.''

title: Putting the Sensuality Back in the Bible's Love Song
description: Flip through the Bible, and you could pass right over the Song of Songs, also called the Song of Solomon. In the standard King James Version, it is less than three pages long.

title: The Trade Comes, to Stoudamire's Relief
description: Damon Stoudamire sat in his hotel room across the highway from Continental Arena, waiting for the call that would tell him where he would be playing. When the phone rang, Stoudamire breathed a sigh of relief, left his room and left the Toronto Raptors behind.

title: He Can Catch, So He May Just Be One for Needy Mets
description: There is no reason to panic. The Mets are convinced their All-Star catcher, Todd Hundley, will play this season, and behind the plate.

title: Creator of Religious Art Prevails on 'Devil' Film
description: The sculptor who created the National Cathedral's renowned entryway bas relief depicting the Biblical creation of mankind today forced Warner Brothers to alter video versions of a movie that he said presented erotic perversion of a work of religious art.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBIN, DR. IRA LLOYD
description: RUBIN-Dr. Ira Lloyd. The Department of Medicine and the Cardiovascular Division of Montefiore Medical Center and the Albert Einstein College of Medicine mourn the death of Dr. Ira L. Rubin, Emeritus Professor of Clinical Medicine. Dr. Rubin served Montefiore for almost 60 years and was a member of the Einstein Faculty for over 30 years. His contributions to our institutions have been numerous and invaluable. Among the many important roles that he played was service as acting Medical Director of Montefiore's Morrisania City Hospital Service, Director of Montefiore's Medical Residency Program, and President of the Montefiore Medical Board. As a consummate cardiologist with a worldwide recognition, he authored numerous books and research articles on electrocardiography, and for over 35 years was Director of Electrocardiography at Montefiore. Dr. Rubin taught electrocardiography to countless numbers of cardiology fellows, medical residents and students. But above all, his kind and thoughtful manner, while practicing the very highest level of academic cardiology, made him a role model to young physicians and to peers, as he exemplified the very best personal and professional standards. A giant on our faculty has left us. He will be missed by all. Our deepest condolences to his wife, Bea. Dr. James Scheuer, Chairman Dr. Joan I. Casey, Vice Chairman Dr. J. Anthony Ware, Chief, Cardiovascular Division Dr. John D. Fisher, Director Montefiore Cardiology.

title: For Starr, How to Investigate News Leaks?; Smoking-Gun Theory
description: To the Editor:

title: Team USA After Loss: What, Us Worry?
description: With the game decided and the final seconds ticking away this afternoon in Big Hat arena, defenseman Chris Chelios of the United States was covering forward Daniel Alfredsson of Sweden. Alfredsson already had two goals in his team's 4-2 victory in the first game of the Olympic hockey tournament for both teams.

title: Creator of Cloned Sheep Says He Will Try to Repeat Process
description: Dr. Ian Wilmut, the scientist who created the cloned sheep Dolly, said today that he intended to try again to clone an adult animal. He said he expected to use cells from a live animal rather than those from the dead ewe that he used to create Dolly.

title: A Candidate's Loyalty
description: To the Editor:

title: French Quarter's Black Tapping Feet
description: The beer-bottle caps tacked to the bottoms of her sneakers collide with the brick sidewalk with a sharp clickety-clack, and the daytime drunks on Bourbon Street wobble their heads to stare at the child who dances to a song only she can hear.

title: Florists' Big Day: Romantic and Frantic; At 2 Contrasting Shops on Fifth Ave., Long Stems Mean Long Hours
description: Uptown, Randi Costa was primping her nosegays and rearranging a vase of fat, happy Grand Prix long-stemmed roses (about $150 a dozen). She is the creative director at Christian Tortu, the elite florist in the Takashimaya store on Fifth Avenue, and around her, customers were all but swooning yesterday in a Valentine's Day swarm.

title: Tobacco Lottery Has Replaced Political Process
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SACKS, ALVIA I.
description: SACKS-Alvia I. March 3, 1916February 14, 1996. I miss you today as I do every day. Love always, Nancy

title: WHITE HOUSE USING CANDOR ABOUT WAR TO PREPARE PUBLIC
description: President Clinton and his top aides began today to prepare the nation for war in Iraq, and for the grim prospect of civilian casualties on the ground and of American pilots shot down from the skies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANDLER, SAM
description: HANDLER-Sam. Temple Beth Torah in Westbury, L.I. mourns the loss of an esteemed member of our congregation, Sam Handler on Feburary 12, 1998. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife Shirley and to his children Marc, Glenn and Sherry, Hope and Mark. May God comfort all the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Michael Katz Ivan Ziegler, Pres.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALLACH, CLARA, NEE LEVINSON
description: WALLACH-Clara, nee Levinson on January 3, 1998, of West End Avenue of emphysema. Survived by devoted husband, Jesse Wallach; sons, Marty and Dan Wulfe; grandchidren, Jennifer Schimmrich, Jody Wulfe, and Benjamin Wulfe; great grandson Joshua Wulfe; brother Willie Lawrence, her sister-in-law, Vera Lawrence, and former husband, Noah Wulfe. Clara is remembered for her love of music, theater, travel and for her indomitable spirit. A memorial service will be at the Jewish Home and Hospital for Aged, 100 West Kingsbridge Rd. Bronx, at 11:00AM on Sunday, February 15. Send condolences to Jesse at the Jewish Home. In lieu of flowers contribute in Clara's name to the American Lung Association or to the Jewish Home and Hospital.

title: Knicks Make Do With Hands They Have
description: Sometimes, the Knicks do not need anyone but themselves. To heck with trade offers and the misery of life without Patrick Ewing.

title: DART GROUP GETS $360 MILLION BID FOR SHOPPERS FOOD
description: The Dart Group received an unsolicited $360 million bid for its Shoppers Food Warehouse Corporation by an investment group led by the former president of Dart, Robert Haft. Jack Binder, senior vice president for finance at Shoppers Food Warehouse, said, ''Dart's board will be reviewing and evaluating it.'' Dart officials were not available for comment. The shares of Dart, based in Landover, Md., which have increased about 28 percent in the last year, climbed $9.50, to $117.50, on Thursday after The Washington Post said it had received a copy of the letter outlining the bid, which was sent to Dart on Feb. 2. The letter came the same week that Mr. Haft's father, Herbert H. Haft, took a multimillion-dollar buyout to leave his post as Dart chairman. Shares of Dart rose $1.50 yesterday, to $119.

title: Queens Man Arrested in Stabbing Death and Rape
description: A Queens man stabbed his roommate to death yesterday and then raped the dead man's girlfriend before officers arrived, the police said.

title: A New Job for a Fast-Footed Shalala
description: As Secretary of Health and Human Services, Donna E. Shalala is one of the most powerful women in Washington. She oversees an agency with 57,000 employees and an annual budget of $359 billion, making policy on everything from welfare to Medicare to human cloning research.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OBSATZ, SADIE
description: OBSATZ-Sadie. On February 12, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Harry Obsatz. Dear mother of Victor and (Susan), Martin and (Phyllis), Leonard Obsatz, Alan and (Ann) Obsatz. Cherished grandmother of Marina, Jordan, Allison, Lauren, Anna, Joelle, Evan and great grandmother of Pilar. Services Sunday February 15, 11:15AM at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: More Bach for the Stew
description: The musical season in New York has been rich in Bach's choral music, but this was ridiculous. Here was Bachworks, a small band of professional singers and players, presenting an evening of cantatas at Weill Recital on Tuesday, just as the Thomanerchor, the choir of St. Thomas's Church in Leipzig, Germany, which Bach himself once conducted, was making its first New York appearance a few blocks away, at St. Thomas Church on Fifth Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MASS, LOUIS
description: MASS-Louis. On February 13, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Sylvia. Cherished father of Madeline (Neil) Hirschfeld and Phyllis (Alan) Fink. Loving Poppy of Andrea (Bob), Sondra (Larry), James, Gregg and Matthew. Sweet great-grandfather of Steven and David. ''We will miss our Poet''. Services Sunday 10:00 AM at ''Gutterman's, Inc.'', 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, LI. Donations may be made to the Kutz Home, 704 River Rd. Wilmington, DE 19809.

title: Rain This Time, but at Least No Earthquake Yet
description: Believe it or not, it has been worse.

title: Wills Is Hired As Running Coach
description: The Toronto Blue Jays have hired Maury Wills as a base-running coach to work with the team's top prospects. The team said Wills will work extensively with Shannon Stewart, who stole 10 bases in 44 games last season.

title: Starr's Wide Net Is Drawing Witnesses and Critics Alike
description: A mother is forced to testify about her daughter and emerges to confront television cameras with trembling lips and teary eyes. Secret Service officers who guard the White House are subpoenaed to serve as witnesses against the President. Other evidence is sought from the statements of half a dozen women earlier asked by lawyers for Paula Corbin Jones whether the President ever had sex with them. And all this is directed by an independent counsel whose motives and ability to keep a secret are under White House attack.

title: Dow Barely Up as Mixed Day Ends Week of Solid Gains
description: Stocks were mixed yesterday, as the Dow Jones industrial average inched half a point higher to its fourth consecutive new high. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks fell 4.05 points, to 1,020.09, after hitting new highs the previous three days.

title: Cuba's Whiff of Freedom
description: Pope John Paul II's trip to Cuba last month is already producing good results. Cuba has announced the release of more than 300 prisoners as a humanitarian gesture honoring the Pontiff's visit. Several dozen will be from a list submitted by the Vatican. But it is not yet known how many of those jailed for political offenses will be included, or if freed dissenters will be allowed to remain in Cuba. Even if political prisoners are included, Fidel Castro will have made only a modest down payment on the Pope's call to free 600 prisoners of conscience.

title: Foreign Affairs; Israel At 50
description: Israel will soon begin a series of 50th anniversary celebrations. Unfortunately, most of the stories coming out of Israel regarding this remarkable birthday are about the tremendous infighting among officials and parties over how to celebrate and what meaning to give to the moment.

title: Striking Down the Line Item Veto
description: New York City and five plaintiffs representing local hospitals and health care workers won an important victory this week when Federal District Judge Thomas Hogan ruled that the Line Item Veto Act was unconstitutional. The New York plaintiffs had brought the lawsuit challenging President Clinton's use of the veto to cancel a provision in last year's budget bill that was intended to preserve New York's Medicaid financing plan. Without that provision, New York may have to pay back to the Federal Government hundreds of millions of dollars in Medicaid funds.

title: ASTRA SUES RHONE-POULENC RORER OVER SUPPLY DISPUTE
description: Astra A.B. said yesterday that it had sued Rhone-Poulenc Rorer Inc. in Federal court, contending that the rival drug maker failed to meet contract supply obligations through its troubled Centeon L.L.C. unit. Astra's United States unit charged that Rhone-Poulenc Rorer, the United States division of the French drug and chemical maker Rhone-Poulenc S.A., repeatedly failed to supply intravenous multi-vitamin products to Astra through Centeon, which is a joint venture between Rhone-Poulenc Rorer and Hoechst A.G. The suit is the latest blow to Centeon, which makes blood plasma and other products at a plant in Illinois. In January 1997, the Food and Drug Administration forced Centeon to upgrade plants to meet safety standards, prompting the company to stop production for a number of weeks. Rhone-Poulenc said 1997 earnings in its drug division fell 7.9 percent, to 5.26 billion francs ($877 million), as ''a direct result of the Centeon situation.''

title: One Casino Sues Another Over Development Plan
description: A second casino developer filed suit yesterday against Mirage Resorts Inc., accusing the Las Vegas company of illegally dissolving a joint venture to build an entertainment complex in Atlantic City's marina district.

title: For Starr, How to Investigate News Leaks?; Free-Press Principle
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about a Board of Education order to 31 alternative high schools in New York City to increase enrollment cited a school incorrectly. The Talent Unlimited High School at the Julia Richman Education Complex in Manhattan is not among the 31.

title: Sports of the Times; No Dreaming Permitted On Big Ice
description: ADAM DEADMARSH doesn't want to say he told you so. But in fact, he told you so. Hockey fans in Denver were exhorting him to go over to Japan and live up to the legacy of American Dream Teams and take care of those Canadians.

title: Columbia/HCA Fraud Case May Be Widened, U.S. Says
description: The Government expects in the coming weeks to bring new charges and possibly add at least one new defendant in the criminal fraud case against three executives with the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation, a prosecutor said yesterday.

title: Lily Harmon, 85, Portraitist and Book Illustrator
description: Lily Harmon, an artist who worked in portraiture, assemblage and book illustration, and whose third husband was the collector Joseph H. Hirshhorn, died on Wednesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 85.

title: For Starr, How to Investigate News Leaks?
description: To the Editor:

title: First Union Deal Draws Some Criticism
description: The First Union Corporation's purchase of the Corestates Financial Corporation has been challenged by consumer groups and politicians concerned that the combination will hurt Philadelphia-area businesses and consumers.

title: AUTO UNION BACKS TENTATIVE ACCORD WITH CATERPILLAR
description: In a reflection of the labor troubles faced by America's traditional, smoke-stack worker unions, leaders of the United Automobile Workers today endorsed a proposed contract with Caterpillar to end the longest labor dispute of the decade.

title: Union Pacific Gives Rival Some Track Rights to End Jam
description: The Union Pacific Corporation, the nation's largest railroad, agreed today to give its major competitor joint ownership of some track as part of an effort to ease a protracted freight gridlock that has outraged shippers and caused them heavy losses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSES, ABRAHAM
description: MOSES-Abraham. Left us in his 97th year, February 11, 1998. Beloved father of Julian and Maurice, dear father-in-law of Mildred and Lila, brother of Billie Ditkoff, loving grandfather of Jeffrey, Andrew, Lisa and Robert, great grand-dad of Ariel, Jarret, Chandler, Harrison and Julia. Service Sunday, 12:15PM, at''The Riverside'', 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. Interment Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, L.I.

title: MITEL BUYING PLESSEY SEMICONDUCTORS FOR $225 MILLION
description: The Mitel Corporation, a Canadian telecommunications equipment maker, said yesterday that it had acquired Plessey Semiconductors Ltd., which focuses on the telecommunications, media and personal computer markets, and some related units from the General Electric Company P.L.C. for $225 million in cash to expand its line of radio-frequency and mixed-signal design equipment. Shares of Mitel, which is based in Kanata, Ontario, rose 9 percent, or $1, yesterday to $11.875.

title: CENTOCOR TO ACQUIRE RIGHTS TO MAKE HEART DRUG
description: Centocor Inc. said yesterday that it would acquire the rights to produce the cardiovascular drug Retavase in the United States and Canada, resulting in a pretax charge of as much as $145 million, as it expands its line of drugs for cardiovascular care. Centocor, which is based in Malvern, Pa., would pay $335 million to acquire the development and manufacturing rights from Roche Holding A.G.'s health care division. Shares of Centocor fell $2.0625, to $37.625.

title: I.M.F. Opposing Indonesia's Plan For Currency
description: The International Monetary Fund tried today to veto Indonesia's plan for changing how it values its beleaguered currency, setting up a showdown with President Suharto that could have profound implications for the world's fourth-most-populous nation.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''One of the really startling things about this poem is the centrality of the woman and the power of her voice. She is not a demure, chaste maiden, a sweet young thing, as the commentators have wanted to see her for 2,000 years. She's a very strong woman.''

title: Religion Journal; A Civil Debate Over Religious 'Pluralism' in Israel
description: It was last year that Lincoln Square Synagogue began plans for an unusual discussion of religious ''pluralism'' in Israel, a controversial issue centering on this question: Should Orthodox rabbis continue to hold exclusive control over conversions, weddings and funerals?

title: Global One Chief Resigns After Losses
description: Global One, the joint venture of Deutsche Telekom A.G., France Telecom and the Sprint Corporation formed to sell multinationals complete phone services, said Viesturs Vucins, Global One's chief executive, had resigned amid higher-than-expected 1997 losses and delays in becoming profitable.

title: Another Accusation Flies in Ice Dancing
description: The compulsory dances had barely ended tonight at the Olympics when the controversy became as steamy as the Argentine tango.

title: Acquitted Club Owner Plans Reopening
description: Two days after he was acquitted of charges that he had turned two of his Manhattan nightclubs into virtual drug supermarkets, Peter Gatien was making plans yesterday to reopen one of them even as he was savoring liberation from the threat of prison.

title: Corrections
description: The Autos on Friday column yesterday, about Porsche sports cars favored by collectors, referred incorrectly to the engine of a new model, the Boxster. It is water-cooled and in the middle of the car, not air-cooled and at the rear.

title: What to Look For
description: BOBSLED -- Two-man sled, first and second runs

title: SUNRISE MEDICAL IN $40 MILLION DEAL FOR SENTIENT
description: Sunrise Medical Inc. agreed to buy Sentient Systems Technology Inc. yesterday for $40 million in stock. Sunrise said it planned to use its international sales network to expand sales of Sentient's high-tech products for people with speech disorders. Sunrise Medical's products are used in rehabilitation and treatment of respiratory conditions in nursing homes and by home health care providers, while the closely held Sentient Systems makes electronic devices and software that allow people with speech disorders to communicate. The Pittsburgh-based Sentient had net income of $1.5 million on sales of $14 million for the fiscal year ended Sept. 30. Sunrise Medical, based in Carlsbad, Calif., had net income of $10.6 million, or 55 cents a share, on revenue of $656.7 million during for its fiscal year ended June 27.

title: Late-Night Trouble
description: With the long-delayed men's downhill skiing finally on the schedule Thursday, along with men's figure skating, CBS posted a 19.5 Nielsen rating, its second best prime-time performance of the Winter Olympics behind last Sunday's 20.2.

title: Wanamaker Mile Won By a Wisp of a Kenyan
description: Size may count in football or basketball, but in track and field size is nothing if you can't run fast. Laban Rotich of Kenya, a wisp of a man at 5 feet 4 inches and 99 pounds, can run fast, as he showed last night in the 91st annual Chase Millrose Games in Madison Square Garden.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ABBOTT LABORATORIES, Abbott Park, Ill., a health care company, said its board approved a 2-for-1 stock split, and increased the company's quarterly dividend 11 percent, to 30 cents a share.

title: Teacher's Killer Suspected an Affair That Never Happened
description: For nine agonizing months beginning in February 1997, Geraisimov V. Metaxas berated his wife, Linda, accusing her again and again of carrying on an affair. He refused to accept her repeated denials, insisting that there had been a romantic entanglement between her and a social studies teacher she had once worked with in Hoboken, the police and prosecutors said today.

title: For Starr, How to Investigate News Leaks?; Protecting Falsehoods
description: To the Editor:

title: School Uniforms Don't Have to Be Sexist
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Robert Mackintosh, 72, Designer Of Costumes for Broadway Stage
description: Robert Mackintosh, who designed costumes for several dozen Broadway and Off Broadway shows and evening dresses for some of the world's most glamorous women, including Marilyn Monroe and Lena Horne, died yesterday morning in his Manhattan apartment.

title: State Opposes $312 Million Plan To Aid Poorest School Districts
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's administration today urged the New Jersey Supreme Court to reject a judge's recommendations that the state finance programs for poor school districts that would cost $312 million a year.

title: The Little Bookshop in Your Living Room; Publishers Find New Market Through Television Shopping Network
description: She was clad in delicate silk of gold and crimson, heart-shaped diamonds sparkling below the curl of honey hair. Pink light enveloped her figure in a room fragrant with long-stemmed roses.

title: Raising CUNY to a Higher Level
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani provoked an uproar with his recent call to end open admissions at the City University of New York. He argued that students who needed remedial help should not be allowed in community college and that they should take make-up courses from private companies instead. As a sometime critic of CUNY admissions policies, I was glad to see the Mayor draw a line in the sand. But I think he drew it in the wrong place, and in a way that is bound to perpetuate a bitter debate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMASHOWER, MARVIN
description: THOMASHOWER-Marvin. Age 73, of Manhasset, NY, and Palm Beach, FL, on February 11, 1998, in Palm Beach, after a long illness bravely borne. Beloved husband of Rosalie Caplan Thomashower for 48 years, loving father of Laurie and her husband David Ridell, devoted grandfather of Lindsey and Marc Ridell, dear brother of Ruth Silverman and Sidney Thomashower. He worked in the Christmas tree light industry for 50 years and had not retired. His enduring fortitude and caring was exemplary, setting a standard few could hope to follow. He will be sorely missed and never forgotten by family and friends. Funeral services Sunday, February 15, 1998 at 12:00 noon at ''Gutterman's,'' 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, L.I. In lieu of flowers, donations to the PKR Foundation, 4901 Main Street, Suite 320, Kansas City, MO 64112 would be appreciated.

title: THE XVIII WINTER GAMES: NOTEBOOK; Close Quarters
description: From the outside, it looks like a can of sardines constructed by NASA. From the inside, it looks like a casket with appliances. For 3,800 yen (about $30) a night, this contraption becomes a cozy sleeping compartment. To call it a hotel room is a bit of a stretch. It is not roomy. To call it a bedroom is a bit of a stretch. There is really only a bed.

title: Major Claims Sergeant Major Asked for Sex
description: A second woman accused Sgt. Maj. Gene C. McKinney of sexual misconduct in his court-martial today, describing two unwelcome invitations to have sex with him and one incident in which he grabbed her by the arm and pulled her toward him as if for a kiss.

title: Sex Conference Report
description: To the Editor:

title: Studying Tattoos? Snake Sounds? Well, Why Not?
description: At times scholarly work seems so specialized that nonacademics have to wonder about its relevance. Here are a few unusual academic niches with explanations from professors of how they arrived at their specialties.

title: Part-Time Faculty Is an Issue Now at CUNY
description: As the pressure intensifies on the City University of New York to improve academic standards, the use of part-time teachers is emerging as a central issue for administrators and faculty alike. Adjuncts, who may be on campus just a few hours a week, now make up a majority of the faculty members not only at City University's community colleges but also at its four-year colleges.

title: 2 Planes Nearly Hit As Airport Radar Fails
description: A jetliner about to take off nearly hit another plane on a runway at Newark International Airport late Wednesday night when a ground-based radar system temporarily malfunctioned, airport officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLICKSTEIN, HYMAN N.
description: GLICKSTEIN-Hyman N. On February 12th. Pre-deceased by his beloved wife Ruth (Lurie). Devoted father of Richard and Jonathan and the late Barbara. Dear fatherin-law of Carolyn and Eileen. Loving grandfather of Debra Ellen, Michael, Ethan and Samuel. Services will be held Sunday, 11 AM, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St. & Amsterdam Ave.

title: Unrest in Mexico Breeds Resentment of Outsiders
description: The new county mayor whipped up a crowd of his followers with a message they loved to hear.

title: Suit Filed in Andersen Internal Dispute
description: Andersen Consulting sued Andersen Worldwide yesterday, contending that the giant accounting firm of which Andersen Consulting is a part is trying to scuttle attempts to conduct an arbitration that would result in breaking up the firm.

title: Why We Fast
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MEYERS, BONNIE LYNN
description: MEYERS-Bonnie Lynn. February 14, 1966 to June 7, 1974. Dearest, you were missed at Jud and Susan's wedding but you were there. Love, Mom, Mark, Jud, Susan, nieces, nephews, grandparents

title: About New York; The Language Of Love Is All They Needed
description: MELLOW music played in Marianne Carroll's living room, where she cozied up to her beloved, Turgay Kandemiroglu, and stroked his back. The waning afternoon light and sweet jasmine incense lent a soft touch to this tender moment. Love was all around, and the Turkish-English dictionary was on the couch.

title: Mr. Starr and the Secret Service
description: Independent Counsel Kenneth Starr and officials from the Justice and Treasury Departments are trying to work out a deal that will allow Secret Service agents to testify in the Monica Lewinsky case without undermining their ability to protect President Clinton. There ought to be a way to do so. Secret Service agents need close access to Mr. Clinton, but as Federal law enforcement officers they also have a duty to cooperate with prosecutors investigating possible illegal conduct.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BROSLAW, SONDRA JOY
description: BROSLAW-Sondra Joy. November 1, 1933-February 15, 1973. Twenty five-years and not a day's gone by that my tortured mind has not thought of the girl who said to me ''Nobody loves each other as much as we do.'' In a just world, your uncommon goodness would have entitled you to a long, healthy life filled with the most supreme happiness. Forever loved, forever mourned by, Your Julie, Susan, Eric
