title: Council Unit Votes to Require More Inspections of Buildings
description: Responding to a spate of incidents in which collapsing facades sent bricks tumbling onto city streets -- in one case shutting down part of Madison Avenue for weeks -- a City Council committee voted yesterday to require thousands of landlords to inspect regularly all the exterior walls of their buildings, not just those facing the street.

title: Grand Jury Criticizes Police Training
description: A Brooklyn grand jury that last year cleared two plainclothes police officers of criminal wrongdoing in a fatal shooting has taken the unusual step of criticizing the Police Department for giving inadequate tactical training to such officers. Police Commissioner Howard Safir, saying that the grand jury's report showed little understanding of the department's training procedures, released a study showing a decline in incidents in which officers fired their guns.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  STRAUSS, LAURI
description: STRAUSS-Lauri. Your love and laughter are always with us. Lentsch and Bentsch, Mom, Dad, Julie, David, Gregory, Emily

title: Group to Pay $37.5 Million For Building On Wall St.
description: A group of investors has signed a contract to buy the tower at 48 Wall Street, the downtown home of the Bank of New York, for a surprising $37.5 million. The deal comes after the kind of grueling two-stage auction that has become the favored blood sport of investors, real estate moguls and Wall Street bankers in the current hot market.

title: Giants Bid for Graham And Hold On to Wooten
description: The Giants yesterday re-signed safety Tito Wooten -- the only starter from last season's team who was not under contract -- and made the former Giant quarterback Kent Graham an offer to return as the backup to Danny Kanell.

title: School Uniforms Don't Have to Be Sexist
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Ernst & Young and KPMG Scrap Plan for Huge Merger

title: Officer Apprehends a Perpetrator. The Charge Is Jaywalking.
description: A jaywalking ticket has been issued in New York City.

title: Former Prosecutor's Wife Loses Conviction Appeal
description: A Federal appeals court in Philadelphia has upheld the tax-evasion and fraud conviction of Barbara Bissell, the widow of Nicholas L. Bissell Jr., a former Somerset County Prosecutor who committed suicide in 1996 after fleeing to Nevada, Federal prosecutors announced yesterday.

title: New Expert Panels Say Iraq Still Withholds Gas Data
description: Two United Nations panels of technical experts that Iraq thought would be sympathetic have concluded that Baghdad is still withholding information about its past production of a potent nerve gas and missile warheads that can carry chemical and biological weapons, American and foreign officials say.

title: Sky Isn't Falling in the West, But the Drenched Cliffs Are
description: In balmier days, San Franciscans envy the millionaires in Seacliff, an elite neighborhood of white-washed villas with bay windows offering stunning views of the Golden Gate Bridge and of sunsets on the Pacific Ocean.

title: Mets Looking for a Bit of Pitching and a Lot of Catching
description: Spring training officially began for the Mets here today in the only way it really could, with Manager Bobby Valentine arriving to immediately commence his hands-on supervision of the team.

title: Tomato, From Pretty Poison to Contestant
description: THOUGH it is much too early to plant tomato seeds indoors, the descriptive jargon in the catalogues might be a bit confusing. Here is some help.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KLEINMAN, SYLVIA
description: KLEINMAN-Sylvia. 9/17/19-2/15/92. Remembered daily with all my love. I miss you, mom. Barbara

title: Trying to Make Peace With an Untimely Death
description: NORMAN SMITH, Reginald Blakey and other seniors were sitting in a circle at Wilbur Cross High School in New Haven and reminiscing about the days and moments before the death of their friend and classmate, Oral Jones. The students volleyed vignettes back and forth, with somber pauses in between. They told how he loved fried chicken, preppie clothes, Michael Jordan and the movie ''Higher Learning.'' The movie's story revolves around a character named Malik, who attends a university on an athletic scholarship, gets swept into the racial and social tensions of campus life and emerges as a wiser and more compassionate person. Oral Jones, a star athlete himself who was college-bound, saw the movie more than 10 times, his friends recalled.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TANGERMAN, ELMER J. ''TANGE''
description: TANGERMAN-Elmer J. ''Tange''. August 1907 to February 1998. Technical Editor, Author, Woodcarver, Teacher. BSME, ME, Purdue University. Editor of Product Engineering, McGraw Hill, retired 1970. Teacher at JC Campbell Folk School. Survived by his wife Mary C. Tangerman, two daughters, grandchilren and greatgrandchildren.

title: Sports of The Times; Clarke Still Sticks Elbows in the Scrum
description: BOBBY CLARKE is a fine one to talk. Once upon a time, he took a baseball swing with a hockey stick and broke the ankle of Valery Kharlamov, the star wing of the Soviet Union. It was the Summit Series, and Canada needed a win, eh.

title: It's Apocalypse Again: U.S. vs. Mexico for Title
description: Regional supremacy will be at stake when the United States and Mexico square off tonight at the Los Angeles Coliseum in the championship game of the Concacaf Gold Cup.

title: Hartford Plans $135 Million Expansion for Bradley Airport
description: The number of its passengers has already risen 18 percent in the last four years, to 5.4 million last year, but Bradley International Airport in Windsor Locks wants to keep growing.

title: Children's Books
description: The Final Game The Further Adventures of the Moccasin Goalie. Written and illustrated by William Roy Brownridge. Orca, $14.95. (Ages 5 to 9)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALLACH, CLARA
description: WALLACH-Clara, nee Levinson on January 3, 1998, of West End Avenue of emphysema. Survived by devoted husband, Jesse Wallach; sons, Marty and Dan Wulfe; grandchidren, Jennifer Schimmrich, Jody Wulfe, and Benjamin Wulfe; great grandson Joshua Wulfe; brother Willie Lawrence, her sister-in-law, Vera Lawrence, and former husband, Noah Wulfe. Clara is remembered for her love of music, theater, travel and for her indomitable spirit. A memorial service will be at the Jewish Home and Hospital for Aged, 100 West Kingsbridge Rd. Bronx, at 11:00AM on Sunday, February 15. Send condolences to Jesse at the Jewish Home. In lieu of flowers contribute in Clara's name to the American Lung Association or to the Jewish Home and Hospital.

title: Using Gifts as Bait, Peru Sterilizes Poor Women
description: For Magna Morales and Bernadina Alva, peasant Andean women who could barely afford to feed their families, it was a troubling offer but one they found hard to refuse. Shortly before Christmas, Government health workers promised gifts of food and clothing if they underwent a sterilization procedure called tubal ligation.

title: VIEWPOINT; Sending Europe a Bad Message
description: FOR anyone concerned about America's competitive future, an article in The Evening Standard of London last fall was ominous. International investors, it said, have begun to demand a risk premium on the bonds of European companies that do business in the United States. The reason is the class-action legal culture of the United States.

title: A Poet's Analysis Of the State of Poetry
description: Thomas Lux [Q&A, Jan. 4] provides one of the best analyses of the state of poetry -- what it is, where it has been and where it's going -- that I've read in a long time. It should be required reading for poets, publishers, audiences and all academics.

title: Days of Dancing, Dancing in the Street
description: Of all the record labels in the history of rock music, a few have become mythic: Sun for rockabilly, Chess for the blues, Stax-Volt for Southern soul. But none have quite the luster of Motown Records, the company founded by Berry Gordy Jr. in Detroit. When young moguls talk about starting a label, they say they aspire to be ''the next Motown''; when baby boomers want to jump-start a party, they put on Stevie Wonder's ''Uptight'' or Martha and the Vandellas' ''Dancing in the Street.'' Motown in its glory years, from the early 1960's through the mid-70's, was not only the ''hit factory'' that Mr. Gordy envisioned, but also the symbol of an American dream: harmony, both musical and racial, forged through inspiration and hard work.

title: The Nation; Coverup: Watergate's Toughest Lesson
description: WATERGATE bequeathed many things to history, including this famous cliche: The cover-up is worse than the crime. Politicians haven't necessarily absorbed this lesson, but the legal system has.

title: Old Spain or New? Divided They Dance
description: The National Ballet of Spain opens a 10-day engagement on Friday at City Center four days late, because a flood damaged its portable touring floor, which is essential to achieving the proper percussive resonance of flamenco footwork. But that was a minor crisis compared with the greater challenge facing the company, one that comes not from an accident but from the changing tides of Spanish dance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOVARSKY, LOLA
description: KOVARSKY-Lola of Bronx, NY. Loving aunt and great aunt. Predeceased by loving sisters and brothers. Services Sunday. For information ''Wien & Wien'' 1-800522-0588

title: Judge Tells Florida Pizza Shop to Deliver to Black Community
description: To get from the nearest Domino's Pizza franchise to the affluent seaside resort of Amelia Island Plantation, Fla., you have to pass through American Beach, a tiny enclave where all but 4 of the 75 residents are black.

title: When Cultures Collide, Etiquette Loses Something in Translation
description: A few days ago, an American man made a major blunder in the Azuma Public Bath here.

title: Inside Windsor Closets
description: IT was a chance to peek at the personal effects of those two lovers in the ultimate valentine story -- the Duke and Duchess of Windsor. Who could resist, especially since Sotheby's had meticulously arranged the goods in settings designed to emulate the couple's Paris villa, now owned by Mohamed al-Fayed?

title: Making Way For Fidelity's Heir Apparent
description: SHE does not carry an electronic organizer, or write with a $200 pen. No flashy touches adorn the hushed tones of the suits -- not Armani -- she favors.

title: For Pianists, the Invariable Acid Test
description: For every instrument, there is music that tests a player's mettle. Violinists must contend with Bach's rigorous solo sonatas and partitas; wind players, with Weber's filigreed works for clarinet, bassoon and trumpet. Cellists face Bach's songful unaccompanied suites, and harpists look toward works by Impressionist composers.

title: Catherine Rocco, Kieran Goodwin
description: Catherine Frances Rocco, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis P. Rocco of Arlington, Va., was married yesterday to Kieran William Goodwin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William P. Goodwin of Wyomissing, Pa. The Rev. James Greenfield performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Annunciation in Washington.

title: The Staging of a Comedy, Or, Crying on the Inside
description: The playwright, drowning in opening-night anxiety. The star, fretting over a high-visibility return to the stage. The ingenue, griping to the publicity man about the quality of her glossies. The producer, wondering if he should bring in a new joke writer to maximize the laughs in his troubled comedy.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Parbleu! It's Them Again!
description: When Emile Hazel, a high school teacher of Greek and Latin, retires at 65, he and his wife, Juliette, married for 43 years and in love since kindergarten, pursue their dream of shared solitude, moving to an idyllic house in the French countryside. But their tranquillity evaporates when their only neighbor, a doctor, begins a succession of seemingly interminable, increasingly uncomfortable afternoon visits. The intrusions enrage Emile and threaten the serenity of his marriage. Yet social convention keeps him from denying entry to ''our torturer.'' ''I hadn't realized that I was a coward,'' Emile muses. It is one of the less upsetting truths he will learn in Amelie Nothomb's slyly outrageous novel, THE STRANGER NEXT DOOR (Holt, $20). Curious as to who would marry such a man, the Hazels invite the doctor, Palamedes Bernardin, and his wife, Bernadette, to dinner. Bernadette is surrealistically repellent: ''a protuberance,'' a ''cyst'' who shakes hands with a ''tentacle,'' has a mouth ''like that of an octopus'' and speaks in unrecognizable sounds. Yet Juliette develops sympathy for this unfortunate creature, observing that the doctor, who appears to enjoy nothing, also seeks to deny any pleasure to his wife. ''You can't go on like this,'' Emile tells him. ''Look at your existence: it's not a life! You're a mass of suffering and boredom.'' As the end of the novel nears, Emile becomes convinced that murdering Palamedes would be an act of mercy. In Carol Volk's deft translation from the French, Nothomb develops this improbable plot in a highly entertaining fashion. ''The Stranger Next Door,'' the first of Nothomb's six novels to appear in English, both disturbs and amuses. Janet Kaye

title: Q. & A.
description: Grinding, Clattering Elevator

title: A Revised Bill of Fare in Dobbs Ferry
description: DISCERNING theatergoers look to Off Broadway for innovative and serious fare, and situated off this village's Broadway, the aptly named spot generally delivers a decent performance for discerning diners.

title: The Varieties of Tomato And How They Grow
description: ALTHOUGH it is much too early to plant tomato seeds indoors, it's not too soon to think about ordering them.

title: ON THE MAP; A Small Radio Station Creates a Network of Classical Music
description: With classical music in retreat across the country as a radio format, WWFM is an anomaly. Licensed to Mercer County Community College in Trenton, it now reaches nearly half of New Jersey, plus sections of Pennsylvania, New York and Delaware, and, via satellite, two towns in Colorado. In 1978, Walt S. Gradzki, an engineer hired to build the college's communications study facilities, proposed that the school acquire one of the region's few unused radio frequencies. In 1981, WWFM began serving Mercer County at 89.1 FM. Now the only all-classical station in New Jersey and the Philadelphia region, the WWFM Classical Network has an additional transmitter in Toms River (WWNJ 91.1 FM) plus a growing system of nine lower-power translators across New Jersey and in eastern Pennsylvania. Unlike many classical stations, which are commercial or members of National Public Radio, WWFM is both noncommercial and independent. It broadcasts 24 hours a day and has nine full-time staff members plus a dozen part-time program hosts. Mr. Gradzki, 51, born in Passaic and now a resident of Toms River, is now both general manager and chief engineer.

title: Redeemer Church Rejects The 'Hard-Line' Label
description: To the Editor:

title: No-Frill Carriers Gain in Europe
description: NO-FRILL airlines in Europe are nervous about British Airways' announcement in November that it plans to start its own low-cost clone early this year.

title: Plumbers, Save Your Energy
description: Presidents do it. Members of Congress do it. Even Justices and their clerks do it. Sex? No, something even more primal: leaking to the press.

title: Mexico Meets Manhattan and It's Snack Time in the Subway
description: Rushing down the stairs on Eighth Avenue to the L train on a recent Monday afternoon, knots of people brushed past Daniel Solano and his little table of cigar-shaped pastries.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor: After reading Jane Perlez's article ''Austrians Are Puzzled by Lagging Tourism'' (Dec. 14), here is another reason to feel unwelcome in Austria.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERBST, J. ROBERT
description: HERBST-J. Robert. Of Y-Knot Farm, North Umberland NY. Died on February 3, 1998. Husband of Eugenia (nee Mosakowski). Father to Eugenia Bly and her husband Edgar W. Bly, and son John Herbst. President of Herbst Insulation until retirement. Spring interment, Notre Dame Cemetery, Schuylerville New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRODY, LEAH
description: BRODY-Leah, age 104. Beloved wife of the late Herman. Loving mother of Bernie, Rhoda, and the late Eli. Cherished grandmother and great-grandmother. May she rest in peace. Services were held.

title: The Zen of Seafood
description: Crabcakes

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUSHKIN, JANICE
description: GRUSHKIN-Janice. On Thursday, February 12, 1998 in Miramar, Florida. Beloved mother of Jay and Richard, cherished grandmother of Alexander. Donations can be made to the ASPCA.

title: A Sense of Adventure, Balanced by Tradition
description: THE Royal Concertgebouw of Amsterdam, on the short list of the world's most admired orchestras, is named for the Concertgebouw, or concert building, where it performs. Until its centenary in 1988, when Royal was added to its title and a new leader took the podium, the Concertgebouw had had only four chief conductors, including Bernard Haitink for 30 years and Willem Mengelberg for half a century before him.

title: THEATER; Inviting a Toast Of Broadway Past To Visit the Present
description: To trivia buffs and theater historians the answer is Avery Hopwood, and the question: Which American playwright had four shows running simultaneously on Broadway in 1920? Or, Who is the author of ''The Gold Diggers,'' ''The Bat,'' ''Spanish Love'' and ''Ladies' Night''? And, Why do so few know his name when he was once the toast of the town?

title: Architects' Designs Envision Columbus Circle as a Great City Crossroads
description: Navigating Columbus Circle, the chaotic intersection at the southwest corner of Central Park, can be a dangerous proposition for cars and pedestrians. With the New York Coliseum exhibition hall on the west side of the circle all but shuttered, the statue of Columbus stands over a bleak, windswept landscape.

title: Explaining the Unexplainable
description: THE OTHER SIDE

title: CONNECT THE DOTS
description: * Hillary Clinton calls her husband the victim of a ''vast right-wing conspiracy,'' but it may be bigger than that. * New World Order conspiracy theorists, writing on the Internet, have suggested that mysterious bankers are using Monicagate to crowbar Clinton from office and usher in a more malleable Al Gore Presidency. * One anti-Semite has noted ominously that ''all the leading players in Clinton's sex scandal are Jews except Clinton,'' suggesting that he's being blackmailed to bomb Iraq. * Yet another wonders if Clinton conspired with the producer of ''Wag the Dog'' to make that film -- in which a President starts a phony war to distract attention from domestic problems -- appear prescient. * But why? The theorist believes ''this collapse between fiction and reality'' may have been part of ''a ploy . . . to get the Best Picture Oscar.''

title: A Great Escape, A Dwindling Legacy
description: STANDING at ground zero of the Great Migration of blacks from the South to the promised city of Chicago, along the ribbon of barely recognizable land just below the Loop, you must suspend what the physical eye sees and imagine things as they were, not as they are. You must picture yourself in 1942 walking through a river of people in hats of butterfly wings and freshly pressed suits promenading down a haughty boulevard known then as South Parkway and now called, since the world has changed, Martin Luther King Drive.

title: Nice Hat, Dude
description: It's turning out to be the good-karma accessory at the Winter Olympics, and it doesn't clash with gold. A funky pillbox-shaped leopard-print hat has been making a splash against the snows of Nagano, Japan. Jonny Moseley (right) wore his during his gold-medal run in mogul freestyle skiing, and Picabo Street, the gold medalist in the super giant slalom, has donned hers in interviews.

title: British Cathedrals
description: To the Editor: The article about Durham Cathedral by Marlise Simons (''Honoring God and King,'' Dec. 21) did not mention an interesting tablet I observed there many years ago and found so moving that I made a note of it. It reads:

title: In Stamford, for Young and Old
description: TO attract the young and the hip -- and to assuage establishment types -- the Stamford Center for the Arts is presenting in overlapping engagements, the hot British comedian Eddie Izzard in his new one-man Off Broadway-bound show, ''Dress to Kill,'' and a not-so-new send-up of Sherlock Holmes, John H. Watson M.D. and their motley friends and enemies, mostly enemies.

title: Taurus Hits the Track For First Time at Daytona
description: The Ford Taurus has long been a practical car built for practical people. But its reputation for practicality will be left behind in a cloud of tire smoke on Sunday when the Taurus makes its Winston Cup debut in the 40th running of the Daytona 500, Nascar's most prestigious race.

title: Las Vegas
description: If you've been wondering whether Las Vegas really has cleaned up its seedy image and become a family-friendly playland, the answer is: For the most part, yes.

title: No Shame, but Plenty of Need, at Home for Unwed Mothers
description: The idea was around even before 1886, when the Salvation Army announced its very first home for unwed mothers: ''The Rescue Home for the fallen and the falling is now opened for young women who desire and are earnestly seeking the salvation of their bodies and souls.''

title: Wall Hits a Patron of Graffiti
description: Using the brick walls of a Long Island City warehouse as a canvas, a group called the Phun Phactory offers graffiti writers a refuge to do their pieces legally, with the landlord's blessing.

title: Sports of The Times; Female Vaulters Make A Case for Inclusion
description: SAMANTHA SHEPARD and Stacy Dragila met Friday night at Madison Square Garden in one of those historic footnotes of time, tradition and history.

title: Caretakers of a Treasury Filled With Theatrical Wit
description: Kaufman and Hart, you might say, were back at the Algonquin, where there wasn't a round table to be found for the moment, or, for that matter, even a chair. Drop cloths were flung like shrouds in the Algonquin Hotel lobby, and the restaurant where wit once reigned was sealed off for renovations.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, WALLACE M.
description: GORDON-Wallace M. Age 69. Formerly of Bay Head, NJ, Leesburg, VA. and New York City. On February 12, 1998, in Harrisville, NH. Graduated Solebury School, Solebury, PA. Attended UVA. Served USNR during Korean War. Survived by his loving wife, the former Margaret Legband, sisters Mary Shulman, Katharine Wilson, brother Theodore Gordon and affectionate nieces and nephews. Memorial service to be announced.

title: A Prime Corner Is Filled With Questions and Expectations
description: No more last-minute purchases of vegetables before boarding the subway at 72d Street and Broadway. No more wheat grass juice or, depending on your style, 50-cent coffee. No more pit stop to buy flowers for your sweetheart after working late, or perhaps after placing a few bets at the Offtrack Betting parlor next door.

title: Van Horn Loses Duel, but There Goes Cassell
description: The crowd at the Core States Center waited eight months for this moment: a chance to shower Keith Van Horn with boos and taunts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  QUINBY, ROBB
description: QUINBY-Robb. 91, of Salisbury, CT. On February 11. Beloved husband of Magdalena Vanderlyn Quinby; devoted father of Caroline Finley McElroy and Mary Stuart Hunt; loving grandfather of four. Memorial service on Wednesday, February 18, at 2 PM, Congregational Church, Salisbury, CT.

title: February 8-14; The Olympics: Tales of the Tape
description: Warning: These Olympics can cause severe disorientation, prompting such existential questions as ''When an event is delayed, and the telecast of that delay is delayed, does it all become 'live'?''

title: Feeling Uneasy Before and After the Grand Jury Appearance
description: For three weeks now, they have marched into an old courthouse here to face the Federal grand jury investigating a Presidential relationship that is transfixing the country. What might result as a consequence of their appearances -- anything from nothing to impeachment -- remains a guess.

title: Mascots R Them
description: BACK in the 70's, the Philadelphia Phillies baseball team had Phil and Phyllis as mascots, colonial characters who would waddle out on the field and wave at the crowd at Veterans Stadium before the game began. Their costumes were so stiff and cumbersome they could barely move.

title: The Client of a Lifetime, With One Drawback; 2 Who Grew Rich Decorating Drug Lord's Lavish Homes Face U.S. Charges
description: When your client is one of the world's leading cocaine traffickers and a man untroubled by an occasional expedient homicide, keeping him happy is both good business and a matter of self-preservation. So when Alexander Blarek, an interior designer, needed to create a handmade leather sofa for Jose Santacruz Londono, he knew that ordinary cows would not do.

title: Corrections
description: A chart last Sunday listing women on death row nationwide referred incorrectly to Northridge, Calif., the site of a murder arranged by one prisoner. It is not a county; it is a section of Los Angeles.

title: Quarterbacks on Merry-Go-Round in A.F.C. East
description: It's an off-center off season for the American Football Conference East, once the domain of the big-shot quarterback. Yesterday's trade of Jim Harbaugh from the Indianapolis Colts to the Baltimore Ravens means the A.F.C. East is likely to have new starters at quarterback on opening day in Indianapolis and Buffalo, and the Jets might as well.

title: Egypt Offers Bargains To Intrepid Tourists
description: ANY other year this would be the height of the tourist season here, and the Egyptian Museum, the Pyramids and other sites would be all but overrun by foreign visitors. Instead, the devastating effect of the November massacre of 58 tourists at the Temple of Hatshepsut in Luxor in southern Egypt can be measured in deserted parking lots, empty hotel rooms and the fact that tourist police sometimes outnumber tourists.

title: PULSE; Thin Is In
description: The skinny tie, that favorite of the Rat Pack, Brat Pack and disciples of 1980's fashion, is making a comeback. Eclipsed in recent years by wider neckwear, the narrow tie, with its rakish underworld appeal, has been kept alive by films like ''Reservoir Dogs'' and ''Men in Black'' and by a cult of devotees, including the Mighty Mighty Bosstones, a band whose members give away thin ties at shows.

title: Preaching to the Converted
description: In December more than 300 people filled the grand ballroom of the Willard Hotel in Washington for the unveiling of a 257-page book called ''Preventing Deadly Conflict.'' As a former Times correspondent in the Middle East, I had witnessed many ugly conflicts firsthand and was eager to see what a Carnegie Corporation commission, which had spent over three years and more than $9.5 million of foundation money, had published about how to stop the strife that since 1989 has killed more than four million people throughout the world, 90 percent of them civilians, especially women and children.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSES, ABRAHAM
description: MOSES-Abraham. Left us in his 97th year, February 11, 1998. Beloved father of Julian and Maurice, dear father-in-law of Mildred and Lila, brother of Billie Ditkoff, loving grandfather of Jeffrey, Andrew, Lisa and Robert, great grand-dad of Ariel, Jarret, Chandler, Harrison and Julia, grandfather-in-law of Laurie, Ivy and Ilene. Service Sunday, 12:15PM, at''The Riverside'', 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. Interment Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, L.I.

title: Now Murder Is Suggested In the Death Of Diana
description: Dark rumors and conspiracy theories about the death of Diana, the Princess of Wales, began circulating almost as soon as the car she was riding in crashed in Paris last year. Now, Mohamed al-Fayed, whose son, Dodi, was also killed in the accident, has publicly endorsed one of the most provocative theories, declaring he believes that the two were murdered by ''people who did not want Diana and Dodi to be together.''

title: Creating a New Concept in Subdivision Layouts
description: A LAND planner here who says he has developed a new method of laying out subdivisions is beginning to have success in marketing the method to builders.

title: Middle School on 107th St. Is Test Tube for Young Scientists
description: Much praise has been given to the city's high schools that produced the latest crop of semifinalists in the annual Westinghouse Science Talent Search. But little attention has been paid to the middle school programs that nurtured the budding intellects of the fledgling microbiologists and aeronautical engineers. The Delta Program at Booker T. Washington Middle School is one of them.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: Free Choices

title: Building Revives, but Renovation Thrives
description: Construction cranes, an endangered species on the New York City skyline only a few years ago, have returned to roost. The yammer of rivet guns and the hiss of arc welders fills the air as new steel frames rise.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, MARTHA
description: GREENBERG-Martha. On February 13, 1998. Beloved wife of the late George and dear mother of Burt and Fran and David Farbman; cherished grandmother of Gayle and Joshua. Services Sunday, February 15, 11:30 AM, Boulevard, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY.

title: Fleeced
description: Just one word: fleece.

title: Evoking Black Style
description: The audience's wide-ranging and imaginative style of dress, from hip-hop to classic clothing, provided the answer to the question ''Is There Such a Thing as Black Style?'' asked in the title of a symposium that was held on Wednesday at the Fashion Institute of Technology. The model Iman moderated. The event also celebrated a new book, ''Style Noir'' (Berkley Publishing, $15) by Constance C. R. White, a fashion writer for The New York Times. It was attended by educators, artists, students and many designers, including Stephen Burrows, Norma Kamali, Patrick Robinson, John Bartlett, Vivienne Tam and Betsey Johnson. Edward Wilkerson (top, second from left) wore a long plaid kilt. Byron Lars, above, wore his quilted coat like a kilt around his waist. The event exploded into an intense debate on the complexities of designers surviving in the fashion business.

title: February 8-14; Hispanic Baby Boom
description: The number of babies born to Hispanic women in the United States has reached a record high.

title: A Month (or Two) in the Country
description: WICKERBY

title: Board vs. Children's Shelter
description: Built in 1904 by McKim, Mead & White and first used as a city morgue, the R & S Building on the campus of Bellevue Hospital Center has been vacant for nearly two decades. Last year, after Bellevue officials put the word out that it was available, the Administration for Children's Services decided it would be a good spot for a shelter for abused children.

title: Art of the Moment, Here to Stay
description: The abstract expressionist painter Barnett Newman, understandably biased, defined sculpture as something you bump into when you back up to look at a painting. These days painting may be in danger of becoming something you lean against when you pause to look at a videotape.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBIN, IRA LLOYD, M.D.
description: RUBIN-Ira Lloyd, M.D. It is with great sadness that the death of Ira Lloyd Rubin, M.D. on February 12 is announced. He was the beloved husband of Beatrice Bober Rubin for more than 57 years and the devoted son of the late Dr. Meyer and the late Gertrude Rubin. He is survived by his wife and brother Dr. Adrien Rubin. He was a gifted cardiologist who was greatly loved by both his patients and medical staff. He was the author of numerous classic textbooks and articles on the diagnosis and treatment of heart disease. He was a great philanthropic leader who devoted his time and energy in making this world a better place for all its inhabitants. Dr. Rubin served on Guam as a Major in the United States Army during World War II. He was an attending physician at Montefiore Medical Center since 1949 and a Professor of Medicine at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine. When the Department of Electrocardiography at Montefiore was dedicated in his name in 1993, the plaque that was erected so aptly states: ''A leader, a gifted ECG reader, teacher, author, physician, humanitarian and gentleman.'' Funeral services are strictly private. A memorial service celebrating his life will be held at a later date. Donations may be made in his memory to the United Jewish Appeal.

title: A Luncheonette True to Tradition
description: While psychologists say change is a good thing, Michael Awad, the new owner of the Cozy End, says, ''Why change a good thing?'' Mr. Awad's customers -- among them the pre- and post-game youth hockey crowd, the up-at-dawn crowd, the ladies who lunch (with their children) crowd -- are behind him on this, and prove their loyalty starting at 7 A.M., six days a week.

title: Jazz Versus Rock
description: To the Editor:

title: The X-Plank
description: Frances Emma Barwood, a former city councilwoman from Phoenix, just took a large leap. A candidate to be Arizona's Secretary of State, she has announced that one of her platform planks is novel indeed: Let's get the truth out about U.F.O.'s.

title: Randi Karmen, Jonathan Guttenberg
description: Randi Meg Karmen and Jonathan Mark Guttenberg were married last evening at the Essex House in Manhattan. Rabbi Joseph Potasnik performed the ceremony.

title: Gaining Fulfillment Through the Recipe Of 'Cooking' Art
description: The Raw and the Cooked

title: VIEWS; Have Dogs, Will Travel, Even If There's No Snow in Sight
description: TAKING inspiration from the pages of Jack London, sled-dog teams regularly hit the ground running in New Jersey. But ''White Fang'' was never like this.

title: Thomas Chapin, 40, Raucous Jazz Musician
description: Thomas Chapin, one of the more exuberant saxophonists and bandleaders in jazz, died of complications due to leukemia on Friday at Rhode Island Hospital in Providence, said a friend, Sam Kaufman. He was 40.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, ROBERT JOHN BALFOUR
description: CLARK-Robert John Balfour. Age 60, of Gainesville, AL., formerly of New York, NY and Locust Valley, NY, died February 3, 1998. He was the son of the late Marjorie Ward Clark and the late John Balfour Clark. He is survived by his sister, Patricia Wing Whitaker of Bradenton, FL., and his two daughters, Alicia Clark Van Arsdall of Arlington, VA., and Melissa Ward Clark of New York, NY. Funeral services were private. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations may be sent to St. Alban's Episcopal Church, Gainesville, AL 35464, C/O Father Richard Losch.

title: Children's Books
description: THE Tulip Touch

title: Spray Painting Safely
description: A BRUSH and a roller are sufficient for painting most projects, but for jobs that are large or have intricate surface detail, it's easier to spray the paint onto the work surface. Spray painting is less tedious than brush painting and generally gives a smoother, uniform paint surface.

title: Chicaboom! A Hail to Excess
description: AFTER weeks of a bewitching trailer that vowed a film with exquisite art direction and an all-Donna Karan wardrobe for its luminous leading lady, Gwyneth Paltrow, ''Great Expectations'' arrived with huge expectations from the fashion audience. It promised to be a celluloid runway, the kind of film that reflects fashion as much as it inspires it -- ''Gattaca,'' but with palm fronds, burnt-out velvet and a couple of martinis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAPELLONI, NELLY G.
description: CAPELLONI-Nelly G. Died peacefully at home on February 14, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Mario. Loving sister of Charlotte Meiberg. Also survived by many nieces, nephews and cousins who will always remember her. Services Sunday, 11:45 AM ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Mystery Tour
description: Stalking Elijah Adventures With Today's Jewish Mystical Masters. By Rodger Kamenetz. 370 pp. San Francisco: HarperSanFrancisco. $22.

title: IN BRIEF
description: Airport Lounge Vetoed

title: HOME-CARE DENIAL IN MEDICARE CASES IS RULED IMPROPER
description: Frail, elderly Medicare beneficiaries with severe illnesses are being improperly denied coverage for home health services that they are entitled to receive, Federal judges have ruled in thousands of recent cases around the country.

title: Alice Miel, 91, Expert on Role of Wider World in Curriculum
description: Alice Marie Miel, an educator who was among the earliest to advance the notion that curriculum in the nation's classrooms should have a role in preparing children for the society they will enter as adults, died on Jan. 31 at the North Florida Regional Medical Center in Gainesville. She was 91.

title: Q&A: Dr. Selwyn Mills; Guiding Men's Voyage to Self-Discovery
description: WHAT do men want? Women have been asking this for centuries. But, said Dr. Selwyn Mills, a psychotherapist in Great Neck, it is when men get together and ask this of themselves that real happiness can be achieved, both in their own lives and in their relationships with women.

title: A School Beach Project Holds Up Against Storm
description: On Jan. 25, this section reported on a fourth-grade class in Margate that ''planted'' discarded Christmas trees on the beach in the hope that they will keep blowing and drifting sand from being washed out to sea. Since then, the 120 trees, deposited upright in three rows parallel to the water, have been subjected to two strong northeasters, and, so far, the project has passed the test.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article in the Arts and Leisure section today about video art includes an outdated reference to the exhibition of Sam Taylor-Wood's work ''Pent-Up.'' It is no longer on view at P.S. 1 in Long Island City, Queens.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, PATRICK
description: CLARK-Patrick. Viewing Monday, February 16, noon-2 and 7-9 PM, Mt. Zion A.M.E. Church, New and Nelson Streets, New Brunswick, NJ, 732-249-8476. Funeral Tuesday, February 17, 11 AM, Mt. Zion A.M.E. Church.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article in the Neighborhood Report last Sunday about Debbie Kniffen and Adrienne Fernekees, who share a job at Conde Nast, reversed the numbers of children they have. Ms. Kniffen has one, Ms. Fernekees two.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACKENDRICK, PAUL LACHLAN
description: MACKENDRICK-Paul Lachlan. An internationally known classicist died Tuesday, February 10, 1998 in Madison, Wisconsin following a brief illness. He graduated from Harvard as class valedictorian in 1934 earning his AB Degree summa cum laude. He spent the next two years as a Harvard University Fellow at Balliol College, Oxford, England and returned afterward to Harvard where he received his Ph.D. in Latin in 1938. During World War II, Paul spent four years serving in Naval Intelligence and met his wife, the former Dorothy Lau, in the Azores during the War. Paul taught Classics at the University of Wisconsin until his retirement in 1984. Fluent in 8 languages, Paul wrote 17 books, 5 of them the ''Stones Speak'' Series on the history of archaeology in the classical world. He was Professor in charge of Classical Studies at the American Academy in Rome; taught at the University of Ibadan, Nigeria; and he was a Phi Beta Kappa international lecturer. Survivors include his wife Dorothy of 53 years; a son Andrew (Mary) MacKendrick of Brooklyn, Wisconsin; a daughter Sarah Phillipson of New Glarus, Wisconsin; and six grand-children Melissa, Johna, Andrea, Adam, Katharine and Alexander. A Memorial Service is planned for 4:00 PM, March 22, 1998 at the First Unitarian Society, 900 University Bay Drive, Madison, Wisconsin.

title: Kulik of Russia Rides His Quad to Figure-Skating Gold
description: For a young figure skater who had been known to wilt under pressure, Ilya Kulik gave the most composed performance of his life tonight in winning the Olympic gold medal. He also delivered the most technically demanding program ever skated at the Winter Games.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLICKSTEIN, HYMAN N.
description: GLICKSTEIN-Hyman N. On February 12th. Pre-deceased by his beloved wife Ruth (Lurie). Devoted father of Richard and Jonathan and the late Barbara. Dear fatherin-law of Carolyn and Eileen. Loving grandfather of Debra Ellen, Michael, Ethan and Samuel. Services will be held Sunday, 11 AM, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St. & Amsterdam Ave.

title: Don't Blame Squads For Emergency Aid Limits
description: To the Editor:

title: Scientists as Cool? (Think Baseball Cards)
description: ALBERT EINSTEIN and Galileo aside, few of the world's great scientists get even the proverbial 15 minutes of fame within the popular culture, insists Nicholas Georgis of Huntington.

title: Damage From Sport Utility Vehicles
description: It is no surprise that heavy, high-riding sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks inflict more damage and injury than cars in a collision. Their weight, height and stiff frames allow them to plow through lower-slung, often lighter cars. The Insurance Institute for Highway Safety has now produced a worrisome analysis of the death rates in crashes involving these increasingly popular light trucks. The analysis classified mini-vans as cars because they performed similarly in crashes.

title: Canopies Flying in the Face of a Clock
description: Under most circumstances, it would take some doing not to notice a pocket watch the size of a monster truck tire, especially if it was on top of a 10-foot pole.

title: Whatever Happened To Politics?
description: In ''When Naptime Is Over'' (Jan. 25), Robert B. Reich says the gap in income between the winners and losers in our economy can be closed, in part, ''by rebuilding decaying schools and helping states equalize spending between rich and poor school districts.''

title: The Early Bird Gets the Warm Potato-Leek Soup
description: IF you grow vegetables, sometime in late October or thereabouts you'll wish you had planted leeks.

title: Befriending Iran Would Alienate Our Gulf Allies; Needed: New Enforcers
description: To the Editor:

title: Words or Music: Why The Battle?
description: Words and Music'' -- or is it ''Words Versus Music''? -- tops the young year's musical topics. ''Capriccio,'' at the Metropolitan Opera, has asked us to make our choice. Flamand the musician and Olivier the poet argue the relative merits of their trades, and it is hardly a secret that they are talking about opera in general as well as the one they are in. Here is Strauss's metaphor for a pitched battle between two arts, a struggle for the listener's attention that plays out nightly in musical theaters everywhere.

title: Children's Books
description: THE WINDOW By Michael Dorris. Hyperion, $16.95. (Ages 8 to 12)

title: Early Admissions: Students Unnerved
description: AS colleges admit more high school seniors under early admission, the trend means good news and bad news, particulary on highly competitive Long Island.

title: BACKTALK; BIRTH OF DAYTONA
description: The first time Richard Petty took his race car onto the newly opened Daytona International Speedway on Feb. 22, 1959, he was ''black-flagged'' and ordered to the garage.

title: Group Seeks Donations to Help Inquiry Into Bosnian War Crimes
description: For several months now, a few American prosecutors, who usually deal with nothing worse than street crime, have been making the rounds of potential corporate donors and asking, in effect, ''Brother, can you spare a laptop to help investigate a genocide?''

title: Defending Curling
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A Helpful Stanza For Pay Phone Panhandlers
description: To the Editor:

title: El Morocco's Back. Quick, Phone Walter Winchell!
description: You won't catch Elizabeth Taylor cat-fighting with Debbie Reynolds over Eddie Fisher. And you probably won't glimpse Errol Flynn's ghost. But El Morocco, the legendary East Side night club where Hollywood stars hobnobbed, is back.

title: Huffing and Puffing About Storms and Sand
description: THE alarm bells started going off on Monday of the first week in February. Sharing the secret thrill of an impending big storm, coastal geologists from North Carolina to Long Island were convening on the Internet and on the telephone. Was this the inevitable, devastating storm that would one day leave behind a truly historically impressive bill for damage on the vastly overbuilt Atlantic coastline?

title: A Bill Would End Inequalities In Penalties for Stealing Pets
description: Asserting that all pets are created equal, State Senator Diane Allen last week introduced a bill that would make it a crime to steal a domestic animal no matter what its value. Currently, the theft of an animal worth less than $200 is prosecuted as a disorderly persons offense, subject to fines only, while the theft of pricier pets constitutes a fourth-degree crime, punishable by up to 18 months in prison and fines up to $10,000, said Senator Allen, a Republican of Burlington.

title: The World; Forget the Maine. Spain Is Back.
description: THE explosion of the battleship Maine in Havana harbor 100 years ago today set the stage for Spain's retreat from the last remnants of its empire in the New World, and for the emergence of the United States as a global power. Yet as the American Century draws to a close, a resurgent Spain is once again flexing its muscles in Latin America and pushing aside any lingering memories of ''El Desastre,'' as the Spanish-American War is often called there.

title: Springtime Roars With Early Bloom
description: PROMISING a break from winter, ''Winterbloom 1998,'' opens on Saturday from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. and next Sunday from noon to 5 P.M. at the Bartlett Arboretum in Stamford.

title: The View From/Hartford; A Revival for Housing, Downtown, of All Places
description: SCULPTORS, painters, musicians, dancers -- in short, artists of all kinds -- are moving into a long-vacant building on the western edge of downtown Hartford that city and state officials, developers and business leaders are hailing as the first step in years to create new housing in the center of the city.

title: Our Memories, Our Selves
description: The radio was on in the background the other day, low volume as usual, when I found myself inclining toward vaguely familiar music. It was something I had once known very well, and as I began to listen more intently, a few swells of melody pushed a button somewhere in my brainpan: Gershwin. The overture to ''Of Thee I Sing.''

title: U.S. and Canada Have a Score to Settle in Women's Hockey
description: As Olympic feuds go, this one is strictly personal, not political. A down-and-dirty domestic war between teams that have practically been living with each other since late October.

title: Techno Color
description: If the spring collections are any indication, the future will be more vivid than the past.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHANE, DAVID M.
description: SHANE-David M. February 11, 1998. Cherished husband for fiftysix years of Florence (nee Goldman). Beloved father of Richard and Steven. Wonderful grandfather of Daniel and Lauren.

title: The Volunteers' Golf Club in Sag Harbor
description: GOLF has always been considered a rich person's game. The cost of desirable clubs -- those you play with and those you play at -- prevents some people from participating. Exclusivity prevents others.

title: Fast Forward; So Many Ideas, So Few Companies
description: Outsiders revere silicon valley as some kind of secular miracle: money plus ideas equals profits, which turn into ever more money plus ideas. Many players in the Valley, who have never seen a real business cycle, think they've finally found the formula for perpetual growth. Other countries and regions are desperately trying to figure out how to create their own Silicon (Geographical Feature here). Hungary is trying to sponsor a Silicon Park near the Danube -- but will it find the requisite entrepreneurs to fill it up? The best entrepreneurs would probably fail a Government screening process. Even in the United States, with its profusion of money and talent, there is now an imbalance: too many would-be investors and too few real companies.

title: BENEFITS
description: Dinner and Hoops at the Garden

title: For Chinese in County, Reaching Out in New Year
description: LIKE many 14-year-olds, Dorcas Chen of Pelham has the dexterity to master the intricacies of in-line skating. And her eye-hand coordination is such that she can maneuver Duke Nukem or Lara of ''Tomb Raider'' fame with ease around a computer screen, wiping out hordes of enemies while dodging the most fiendish booby traps.

title: Sports of The Times; The Ballad of Men Searching for Gold
description: IT was a showdown Saturday night, a kind of gunfight at the O.K. Rink. Except instead of two separate factions venting ill-humor toward one another, there were three to be taken seriously, and maybe four, with a remote chance that someone else from the hills might join in the mischief. This was not using firearms to the finish, however, but a triple or quadruple axel-triple toe loop combination, a variety of spins and flips, and the old standby, the lutz.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACKINTOSH, ROBERT
description: MACKINTOSH-Robert. His costumes graced the stage for Wish You Were Here, Mame, How Now Dow Jones, Sherry, among other Broadway hits. His friends and colleagues in the theater will miss his wit, his talent, and his humanity. Mary Lea and I loved him dearly. Rest in peace, Bobby. Marty Richards

title: Sharpton Run Is Main Topic At Conference
description: In the midst of earnest workshops on everything from telecommunications to youth development in minority communities, there seems to be a far stronger buzz among the participants here at this year's conference of the New York State Association of Black and Puerto Rican Legislators. In the hallways and at meals, they repeatedly turn their attention to the political aspirations of the Rev. Al Sharpton.

title: Making of the President, 1864
description: REELECTING LINCOLN The Battle for the 1864 Presidency. By John C. Waugh. Illustrated. 452 pp. New York: Crown Publishers. $30.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIRIGNANO, P. RAYMOND
description: SIRIGNANO-P. Raymond. Retired New York State Supreme Court Justice. February 12, 1998, of Mount Vernon, NY. Beloved husband of Ann. Loving father of Penny Cover and Raymond P. Sirignano. Caring grandfather of William J. Cover, IV, Christopher R. Cover, Patricia C. Domanico, Mary K. Bloom and Patina E. Sirignano. Great-grandfather of three. Brother of Anthony Sirignano, Lillian S. Petrillo, George A. Sirignano, M.D., and Dorothy S. Spolzino. Reposing at Clark Associates Funeral Home, Katonah, NY, Sunday and Monday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday 10 AM, St. Peter and Paul Church, Mount Vernon. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: DIARY
description: INDONESIA

title: On the Waterfront
description: TAKE a good look at New Jersey's Hudson River waterfront and you can almost see them. The shimmering ghosts of the Gold Coast are back: phantom luxury apartments and office buildings lining the river in Jersey City, Hoboken, Weehawken and Edgewater.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FUSFELD, DAVID
description: FUSFELD-David. You left me five years ago. I miss you very much every day. Wait for me. Love, Sylvia

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERSKOWITZ, JOSHUA
description: HERSKOWITZ-Joshua. Beloved husband of Jeanne. Devoted father of Helene and Gary Greenberg, and Julian and Lisa Herskowitz. Cherished grandfather of Craig and Keith. Loving brother of George. Services Sunday, 11 AM, at Riverside Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, LI.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  REEVES, MINNA
description: REEVES-Minna. Valentine remembrances and everlasting gratitude to my beloved lifegiver whose beauty, charm, & talent enhanced the quality & the joy of our family life.

title: Gentlemen, Choose Your Sausage
description: IT'S not funny. Really.

title: P.R. Bauble Of the Week
description: There's still time to prepare for Earth's encounter with an asteroid -- or at least for the July 1 release of the film ''Armageddon.''

title: Summer Olympics Fever: Catch It!
description: They might not offer the enthralling and scintillating entertainment that snowboarders and curlers do, but the time is drawing nearer when major league baseball players will most likely compete in the Olympics. That time, however, will not be in the 2000 Olympics in Australia.

title: Post-Valentine's: A Breakup Guide
description: VALENTINE'S DAY is over. Across the city, romances are wilting in the harsh winter light. It's frightening, really, how easily things can sputter out. Once, an alchemy of passion and affection made his elephantine nose-blowing sessions or her constant need to play with her bangs seem cute. Now cute has given way to an emotional hangover, and the only remedy is escape.

title: Corrections
description: A picture on Feb. 1 with a listing of cruises, showing a fishing boat and the Radisson Diamond off Taormina, Sicily, carried an erroneous credit. It should have been attributed to Len Kaufman, not Radisson Seven Seas Cruises.

title: Taking a Stand On Brookhaven Reactor
description: ''Fight on Brookhaven Research Reactor Intensifies'' [Feb. 1] fails to emphasize that Representative Forbes made his own decision about the future of the High Flux Beam Reactor over five months ago.

title: Henry Schneider, Foundation President, 87
description: Henry Schneider, a New York tax lawyer and president of a foundation benefiting New York hospitals, cultural institutions, parks and Jewish charities, died on Monday at his Manhattan apartment. He was 87.

title: Around the World With A Chair and a Computer
description: Rick Roelke, an electronics consultant in Bedford, N.H., has not had as much sleep as he would have liked in the last few months. He is the navigator of a Whitbread Round the World yacht, and that is not easy.

title: News on the Rialto? It's Finished.
description: The guy in the big white space suit is gone, as is the gorilla. No more do they beckon Times Square passers-by into Cinema Ride, the so-called motion simulator that rocked and rolled its patrons hydraulically to the accompaniment of 3-D action movies for the last year and a half (pregnant women and small children prohibited).

title: Seven Possible Gems Amid the Asian Rubble
description: IS Asia really cheap? As both its currencies and its stocks have fizzled over the last eight months, any number of portfolio managers who invest in the region have pounded the table, saying the selloff is a big buying opportunity.

title: The Assistant Who Walked in One Day
description: Pat Fersch was a newly minted lawyer working in a Lower East Side office in September 1994 when Migna Taveras, 14, walked through the storefront doors of the self-proclaimed Family Law Center.

title: ATTACK BY G.O.P. OVER FUND-RAISING DOESN'T SLOW GORE
description: In a scathing, partisan assessment of Al Gore's fund-raising practices, Senate Republicans investigating campaign finance abuses concluded in a draft report this week that the Vice President took part in a coordinated drive before the 1996 Presidential election ''to violate the letter and spirit of existing Federal campaign laws.''

title: INVESTING IT; Checking Out Those Discount Videos
description: THE most attractive investment in the video world these days may also be the least glamorous: video rental stores.

title: MARKET TIMING
description: MONDAY

title: Bomb Blasts at Campaign Rally in India Kill 30
description: India's election campaign was rocked today by a series of bomb explosions that killed at least 30 people in the southern city of Coimbatore as thousands gathered for a campaign rally by a Hindu nationalist leader who is one of the country's most controversial political figures.

title: Seeking Clues About Domestic Homicide in an Effort to Reduce It
description: In the dark hours of an early September morning in 1981, Robert Nolan Jr. stared through a living-room window miles from his home in Liberty, N.Y. He saw his estranged first wife, Margaret, making love to her new boyfriend. Mr. Nolan, then in his early 20's, had a hunting knife in his hand.

title: Airlines Shuffle Their Frequent-Flier Awards
description: Several airlines are revising their frequent-flier programs. Changes include cutbacks at two airlines, a modest improvement at a third, and plans for an overhaul of the program by a fourth.

title: Love Feasts For All
description: Celebrating grand generosity, grand opera, grand New York spirits.

title: Threats Worry 3 Who Tied Croatian Army to Atrocities
description: Three former Croatian soldiers who provided testimony and documents detailing the killing of scores of ethnic Serbs and Croats by the Croatian Army say they have been repeatedly beaten by unidentified assailants, their vehicles have been firebombed and they receive almost daily death threats.

title: Relaxed Irabu Starts With a Clean Slate
description: The new and improved Hideki Irabu made his spring-training debut today, with a new number, a new pitch, a new interpreter, a slimmer waistline. Others around him say Irabu is relaxed, the result of an off season of reflection.

title: Extra! State Buys S & M Fixtures!
description: Relocating a night club is never simple. But when it's an ''adult entertainment'' playground, in a building owned by the state, expect unusual developments. Like the state taking possession of S & M equipment.

title: Potatoes, but Sumptuous
description: WHAT could be more sublime than potatoes, garlic and cream? The alchemy of the combination, gratin dauphinois, has all the understated extravagance of a $100,000 strand of South Seas pearls.

title: Legislators Consider Single Sewer District
description: WESTCHESTER has one solid-waste district. In the interest of the environment, should it have one sewer district as well, instead of 13? This question is being asked again by the County Board of Legislators, which has the yearly task of setting taxing rates for those districts and passing a budget for the county's Department of Environmental Facilities, which oversees the districts.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.
description: No. 4 Opens, in a Chain Of Mediterranean Delis

title: Milton W. Brown, 86, Scholar Of 20th-Century American Art
description: Milton W. Brown, a scholar and teacher who was a pioneer in 20th-century American art history, died at Mount Sinai Hospital in Miami Beach on Feb. 6. He was 86.

title: February 8-14; Diesel Fumes
description: The Justice Department and the Environmental Protection Agency said they are investigating whether the makers of diesel engines for big trucks have designed the engines illegally to evade pollution controls.

title: The Nation: Scandalous Opinions; Clinton's O.K. in the Polls, Right?
description: THE most startling element of the White House sex scandal, more than the accusations themselves, is the public response. Americans are uninterested in President Clinton's sex life. The people say it. The polls prove it.

title: On Role Models
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A 'Three Sisters' With a Poignant Russian Forecast
description: Anton Chekhov's ''Three Sisters'' has never been long out of the repertory of the Moscow Art Theater since January 1901, when Konstantin Stanislavsky directed the celebrated premiere in which he also appeared as Vershinin and Olga Knipper, who later became Chekhov's wife, was Masha.

title: Liberties; Romantic Talking Points
description: Late last night I came into possession of some red-hot White House documents. They were leaked to Kenneth Starr's office and then obtained by The New York Times from knowledgeable lawyers familiar with officials acquainted with knowledgeable people related to the case.

title: Whatever Happened To Politics?
description: It is no surprise that Reich is no longer a member of Clinton's Cabinet. His ideas are too sensible.

title: Will a Child's Troubles Erase a Parent's Smile?
description: AH, parenthood! What corporation doesn't enjoy it? The delight in the birth of a subsidiary. The pleasure of watching it emerge from the blobdom of infancy. The sense of reward as the tot grows, bringing in oodles of cash.

title: Hit Lotto? No, Hit the Road.
description: The Cobble Heights Opticians, an upscale eyeglass shop, opened in June 1996 on the corner of Henry Street and Atlantic Avenue, and the neighborhood seemed to like Jared Buchansky, who owned the place with a partner.

title: Brand Names
description: To the Editor: ''What's in a Brand?'' reminded me of my experience retrieving a bathrobe from a Days Inn. On arriving home after a stay at a Days Inn in upstate New York, I discovered that my worn but toasty pink bathrobe had been left behind.

title: Whistle-Stops
description: The Iron Tracks

title: Mating Food and Wine With Distinction in a Lovely Setting
description: WINE is at Enoteca's heart. Although there are longer lists on Long Island, the selection, discussion and consumption of wine at this Locust Valley newcomer are more central to its existence than at most other local restaurants.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; The First Photojournalists' War
description: If the Vietnam conflict was this country's first ''television war,'' the Civil War was the first photojournalist's war. A corps of civilian photographers -- working with cumbersome equipment and dependent on natural light -- produced an astounding visual record. The most famous was, of course, Mathew Brady, but there were many others, most on the Union side, following troops into battle and capturing for all time the sad record of war. THE CIVIL WAR IN DEPTH: History in 3D (Chronicle, $24.95) collects examples of a form of photography popular at the time: the stereo camera, which produced two images of the same shot to yield a card viewed through a device called a stereoscope, creating the illusion of three-dimensionality. Bob Zeller writes that the images so created sold widely during and after the Civil War, until people began to tire of battles too painful or too removed to be of further interest. The book displays eternally American faces and American scenes familiar from history books; from Fort Sumter to Appomattox, from drummer boys to Grant and McClellan, the images seem to jump out at the viewer. Abraham Lincoln seems always to be on stage, from new President to a very tired one, photographed just 10 weeks before his fatal encounter with John Wilkes Booth. ''The Civil War in Depth'' is a more than worthwhile addition to the history bookshelf even if some assembly is required -- a folding stereoscope is included.David Murray

title: Homeowners' Assurance
description: ''LET the buyer beware'' remains the most timeless advice ever offered a consumer. But home buyers -- confronted with the biggest purchase most of them will ever make -- apparently have less to fear these days.

title: Children's Books; Bookshelf
description: BONE BUTTON BORSCHT. By Aubrey Davis. Illustrated by Dusan Petricic. Kids Can Press. $15.95. (Ages 4 to 8) A fresh version of a familiar folk tale. Sometimes it is called stone soup and involves a wandering soldier. In this version, a beggar visits the synagogue in a miserable village, someplace in Eastern Europe, sometime in the grim past. The clever beggar persuades the townspeople to offer ingredients that make his button soup into a delicious borscht, and making the soup brings social life back to the community. The illustrations in this version are particularly sophisticated.

title: Q and A
description: Welsh Male Choirs

title: WASH AND WEAR
description: The San Francisco Museum of Modern Art has just unveiled ''Laundromat-Locomotion,'' portraits by Steven Pippin, a 37-year-old British photographer. Viewers can see images of Pippin traipsing nude or on horseback through the Bayonne Giant -- a Bayonne, N.J., laundromat -- in pictures taken with 12 washing machines reconfigured as cameras. Pippin, who says the work is a personal tribute to the machines' ''unparalleled efficiency,'' began pursuing his vision years ago in a seedy London laundrette, which ejected him. After a long search for a new washeteria to serve as his base, he found a home in Bayonne. ''American laundromats attract odd characters,'' he says. ''When I did the nude shots, a man took off his clothes, too, and casually put them into the wash cycle.''

title: Where Folk Roots Still Survive
description: There are few paved roads in Kalota szeg, Transylvania: just wide and muddy streets. Every few moments a horse-drawn wagon goes by, filled with sawdust or carrying a pig to market.

title: Living History
description: To the Editor:

title: Redeemer Church Rejects The 'Hard-Line' Label
description: To the Editor:

title: What Barbie Really Taught Me
description: Bravo to Yona Zeldis McDonough for her realistic remembrance of Barbie (Lives: ''What Barbie Really Taught Me,'' Jan. 25). I had a Barbie doll -- several of them. They lived like harem princesses in their two-story dream house. Frequently, when Ken or, more often, my younger brother's G.I. Joe would visit, they would retire to Barbie's bedroom to do things we could only imagine our parents did in theirs.

title: New Women's Shelter First for the Disabled
description: IT is the details that bring home the reality of domestic violence. For instance, asked how many beds will be available at a shelter for battered women that opened in Mamaroneck last week, Charlotte Watson, director, said simply, ''Fourteen beds -- 18, if you count the cribs.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN REED, MURIEL G.
description: VAN REED-Muriel G. On February 9, 1998. Forty year employee of The New York Times. Long time friend of Walterine Grant Ault and Lorraine Dundas. Interment private.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption with an article on Jan. 25 about skiing in Lech, Austria, misstated its location. It is in the Vorarlberg, not the Tyrol.

title: Back to the Boardwalk
description: NOW AND THEN

title: Homeless, Not Helpless
description: To the Editor:

title: Ruling Allows Major Center Its First Clinic For Abortions
description: A Federal judge's ruling could allow Planned Parenthood to open an abortion clinic in Bettendorf, Iowa, in the nation's largest metropolitan area without such services.

title: In America; Fashion Statement
description: One of the significant stories to emerge from the Winter Games in Nagano, Japan, is the way that CBS, once the graceful standard-bearer of the television news industry, somehow managed to turn its correspondents into walking advertisements for Nike.

title: Elephants Are Friends, China Tells Its Farmers
description: The wild elephants that once roamed freely over southern China retreated long ago to the dense tropical rain forest that drenches the mountains here near the borders with Myanmar and Laos.

title: Style; Day of the Jacket
description: My first reaction was admittedly selfish. When I saw the long box-cutter tear in my beloved leather jacket -- a garment that has accompanied me through fair weather and foul, traveled with me across oceans and continents -- I said, Why couldn't it have been me? There are some who would take a more sanguine view, namely that jackets can be replaced. These people have not seen my brown leather jacket, which is delicate and buttery to the touch. I, on the other hand, am craggy and sandpapery to the touch.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Jan. 18 about the Backbone Trail in the Santa Monica Mountains located Solstice Canyon incorrectly. It is in Malibu, not up the coast from Malibu.

title: CYBERSCOUT
description: There are no reliable figures on how many millions of people surf the Web for information about travel destinations and services. But there are recommended ways to get started, as I have learned from my own and others' experience, and, if you are already started, ways to improve the passage. And it can be useful to review the basics, even for experienced Web travelers.

title: LeMay Doan and Auch Live Up to Advance Billing for Canada in the 500
description: Susan Auch had a silver medal around her neck again. Only this time, the anthem reverberating through the Olympic speed-skating oval was the Canadian anthem, her anthem.

title: Sweden on the Hudson
description: First there was Little Italy. Now there's Tiny Sweden. Three stores on Columbus Avenue, from 70th to 72d Streets, have created a mecca for Swedophiles. Ordning & Reda, a Swedish paper-goods store at No. 253, has just joined two compatriots: Face Stockholm, a cosmetics company that has been at No. 224 for six years, and Alskling (left), which sells floral dresses, hand-knit items and doll clothes and has been at No. 228 for nearly three years. Each store has corporate roots in Stockholm.

title: Backtalk; Arnie And Jack And Casey
description: As soon as golf's leading logos, Arnold Palmer and Jack Nicklaus, stepped up to the moral tee, the case of Casey Martin got interesting. Until then, it just seemed like a silly squabble over using a cart during the later rounds of tournament play.

title: Almost All the News on Kenya Is Turning Out Bad
description: No one has to tell Bernard Mulei that the Kenyan economy is in deep trouble. He hawks tours to passers-by in downtown Nairobi, and these days tourists are as scarce as the endangered species he entices them to see.

title: Sports of The Times; Trying To Move A Mountain
description: THERE is a great big Winter Olympics out there, with willowy figure skaters and nationalistic hockey millionaires. I have heard that they are spinning and scoring, but I have not been able to get into the same building as Elvis or Gretzky, Michelle or Mike Richter.

title: Free The D.J.'s! Has Music Radio Lost Its Edge?
description: AT CD 101.9, New York City's mellow jazz ''relaxation station,'' Steven A. Williams, the program director, crunched the numbers from the latest research.

title: Children's Books; It's Hard Work, Snowing
description: People have long attributed human qualities to natural phenomena. The ancient Greeks thought that gods controlled the sun, wind and sea. Native Americans believed that thunder and rain had a consciousness that could be appealed to directly. Even in our technology-dominated time, Ol' Man River keeps on rolling along, while Mother Earth spins dependably around the sun. One of the primary goals of childhood is to make sense of the world. Age-old stories and images can be comforting, but children can also work out magical explanations for themselves. In IS THAT YOU, WINTER? (Silver Whistle/ Harcourt Brace, $16; ages 3 to 8), the Caldecott medalist Stephen Gammell looks at the commonly anthropomorphized seasonal phenomenon, Old Man Winter, from two points of view. The story opens with Old Man Winter, a wonderfully grumpy-looking guy wearing an outsize ten-gallon hat, sitting in bed. It is time for him to be on the job and, like the average working stiff, he is not happy about it. He stomps outside, coffee mug in hand, and heads for his truck. Then the magic begins. The truck takes off for the sky, pulling a cold wind behind, dumping tons of snow on the ground below. Winter heads home for lunch, grumbling ''Who do I make it snow for?'' But as he is climbing the stairs, he slips and falls. The perspective changes. He lands in a snowdrift and a little girl rushes to rescue him. We now see that he is her doll. She clutches the tattered little manikin to her shoulder and whispers, ''You make it snow for me!'' In the final illustration, the two worlds blend. The girl runs off to play in the snow with her friends. Old Man Winter, the doll maker's stitching now clearly visible, waits and smiles, happy to have his hard work appreciated. In an ebullient tour de force Gammell uses pastels, watercolor and pencil to create a festival of color and image. His illustrations vibrate with the energy of gorgeous swirls, swooshes, splatters and flecks of rainbow colors. As for winter itself, is its prime mover a god, a force of nature or a grumpy old man with a long white mustache and an oversize hat? One little girl's guess is as good as any of ours. Marigny Dupuy

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEMARCO, MARY
description: DeMARCO-Mary. Of Staten Island, on February 14, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Andrew (Kelly). Devoted mother of Josephine Barresi and Peter. Cherished grandmother of four. Reposing at the Azzara Funeral Home, 183 Sand Lane, Staten Island, Sunday and Monday, visiting hours 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial will be offered at St. Christopher's Church, Tuesday, 10 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions to St. Christopher's Church would be appreciated.

title: INSIDE
description: MUTUAL FUNDS /Page 7/

title: THE XVIII WINTER GAMES: BOBSLED; Keeping Close Watch on Action
description: George Klaus had an interesting perspective on the first-round heats of the two-man bobsled today.

title: February 8-14; A Precedent for a Golfer With His Cart
description: Casey Martin rode into golf history when a Federal court in Eugene, Ore., ordered the PGA Tour to let him use a motorized cart on the Tour because he is disabled.

title: U.S. Builds Its Case on Shifting Assertions
description: Last November, after Saddam Hussein allowed United Nations weapons inspectors to return to Iraq, President Clinton made clear just how crucial their work was for global security.

title: Melting Pot, With Chili
description: ONE way to sum up Austin is to paraphrase an old Texas saying: Defining the town is like herding cats. As the capital of Texas and home to one of the largest universities in the country, Austin is an ideological melting pot: a literary haven and a slackers' den, a music mecca and a film-industry outpost. Dreadlocks and multicolored coifs are as common as pompadours, shags, Hillary bobs, flattops and, in the folksy diners and suburban malls, the Big Blond Do.

title: Food; Debbie Does Cabbage
description: Deborah Madison's love affair with vegetables wasn't planned, let alone premeditated. The 52-year-old doyenne of meatless cuisine says that she always loved to cook but just happened to get serious when she lived and worked in a Zen community -- the only student, she suspects, to have subscribed to Gourmet magazine.

title: INVESTING IT/MUTUAL FUNDS; Beware: A January Winner May Be Just a House of Cards
description: SOME January effect.

title: Time on Your Hands? Watch the Whole Movie
description: IN the 1923 silent film classic ''Safety Last,'' Harold Lloyd plays the country bumpkin who is new to the city with, as the picture at left shows, way too much time on his hands. Today, as part of its Silent Clown Series, the 78th Street Theater Lab will let today's audience see Mr. Lloyd as moviegoers of 1923 did, with live accompaniment by a piano player, in this case Ben Model, a curator of this series.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERR, MILDRED
description: SHERR-Mildred. The nephews and nieces of our dear Aunt Mildred share the sorrow of her passing. Our love to uncle Ted, Evanne, Billy and the family.

description: To the Editor:

title: February 8-14; A Question of Command
description: The Marines are still investigating how an EA-6B Prowler jet hit a ski lift cable near Cavalese, Italy, but they have already turned up a second case of one of the airplanes flying too low through the Italian alps.

title: Lives; In the Blink of a Screen
description: My computer died last week.

title: A Place to Feel Well Despite Toll of AIDS
description: WHEN her ex-husband contracted AIDS, it changed Karen Veronica's life forever. Working with his lover, she and her two teen-age daughters cared for him during the 18-month illness that kept him bed-ridden until his death in 1988. Despite the grief, there were positives that came from the experience.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: THE GOLD OF EXODUS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANGE, J. CARVEL
description: LANGE-J. Carvel. Of Greenwich, CT, died Thursday, February 12, at Good Samaritan Hospital in Palm Beach, FL. He was a notable industrial and financial economist. Born July 29, 1901, in Allenhurst, NJ, Mr. Lange attended Columbia undergraduate and law school. He was President of New York based Industrial Commodity Corp., whose principal business determined commodity purchasing policies for a number of large corporations as well as management of financial affairs for private estates and foreign governments. He served on the boards of many corporatons and was co-chairman of the profits committee of Time Inc. Mr. Lange is survived by his wife Gloria Prudden Lange and her children, Caryn Cluett Gregg, Christina Gorham Cluett and David Grenfell Cluett, Jr., and three grandchidlren, Stephanie Powell Gregg, Robyn Prudden Gregg and James Duncan Gregg. He was predeceased by his son, Murray Stuart Lange. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Good Samaritan Hospital, Palm Beach, or Greenwich Hospital, Greenwich, CT. A memorial service will be at 11 AM, February 16, 1998, at Bethesda-By-The-Sea Episcopal Church, Palm Beach, FL.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, EDNA M.
description: GOLDSTEIN-Edna M. Winnick. On February 13, 1998 in San Francisco, CA. Beloved daughter of Jacob and Fanny, loving mother of Carole (Jordan) Cohen and Judith Schaeffer. Devoted grandmother of Deborah Rappaport, Joel and David Cohen and Daniel Schaeffer. Proud great-grandmother of Sara, Rebecca and Leah Rappaport, Julia and Rachel Cohen and Samson and Ezekiel Cohen. Service Monday, 1 PM at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Interment Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, NJ. Memorial service in San Francisco to be announced.

title: Editorial Observer; Nagano Reflects Japan's Glories, and Neuroses
description: The Olympics always present a full palette of feelings about the athletes. But for me, what stands out at Nagano this winter is the Japaneseness of the Olympics and the way the Games open a window into a country at a time of pessimism and self-doubt. The Japanese are not known for their displays of emotion, yet emotions over the victories of Japanese athletes have flooded forth. The Games seem to be serving as both catharsis and reflection of Japan's current difficulties.
