description: The Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show, the convocation of canine Olympians that for the past 122 years has been a maker and breaker of stars of the species -- not to mention a shaker of nerves for their owners and handlers -- gets under way tomorrow with its two-day run at Madison Square Garden.

title: He's No Pop Fan
description: To the Editor:

title: Word & Image; Testing the Tasteless
description: Without benefit of even a single anonymous source, I can explain the ingredients that produced the decision to serve up this decade's spiciest media dish. Having labored long in that hot kitchen, I understand how the best chefs determine when the sauce is ready.

title: Jane Beuth and Brian Mayer
description: Jane Marie Beuth, the daughter of Philip R. Beuth of Putnam Valley, N.Y., and the late Elizabeth C. Beuth, who lived in Las Vegas, Nev., is to be married today to Brian Zachary Mayer, the son of Ylain and Donald S. Mayer of New York. Rabbi Donald Goor will perform the ceremony at the Puck Building in New York.

title: Streetscapes/The Chelsea Hotel at 222 West 23d Street; Bohemian and Ornate, It Began as a Co-op in 1884
description: STANLEY BARD, the managing director of the Chelsea Hotel, says he is beginning a multimillion-dollar project to repair the hotel's ornate facade. But there is no sign that one of New York's most unusual lodgings will lose its peculiar flavor.

title: Alice Hanson Cook, 94, Advocate for Women
description: Alice Hanson Cook, a Cornell University scholar, early feminist and longtime advocate of equal pay for women and support programs for working mothers, died on Feb. 7 at her home in Ithaca, N.Y., of complications from a stroke. She was 94.

title: Ahead of Her Time
description: To the Editor:

title: From War to Nagano: A Slalom Skier's Story
description: He was a boy of 14 living in Shiga, a mountain village, when in August 1945 Japan surrendered to end World War II. And Chiharu Igaya feared that awful things would happen to his country, to his family, to him. He had seen statues in the temples and shrines of menacing devils of centuries past, and he had been led to believe that Americans looked like that.

title: For Love, He Gave Up a Crown (but Not His Books)
description: Throughout his life, the Duke of Windsor lived surrounded by books. There were Bibles and prayer books that were given to him in childhood by his mother and his grandmother and 20th-century history books inscribed and sent to him by the world leaders who had written them. There were numerous books on his world travels, British royalty, golf, fox hunting, military history, cooking, wines, fashion, art, literature and pugs.

title: Q&A/Dr. Charles B. Arnold; When Downsizing Ends in New Horizons
description: THERE was a time when Dr. Charles B. Arnold had the romantic dream of leaving his job and literally sailing off into the sunset. But when he lost his job in a downsizing at Metropolitan Life Insurance Company in 1993, Dr. Arnold, a resident of Scarsdale, spent just a moment taking that idea seriously -- and at 59 resumed his medical training, taking a residency in psychiatry with people half his age.

title: Recovering the Calm at Westminster Abbey
description: Westminster Abbey will begin charging admission next month in an effort to control crowds. At the moment there is an entrance fee of $7 to the Royal Chapel and Poets' Corner, but none to enter the nave, which houses the Tomb of the Unknown Warrior.

title: Suspended Oakley Eyes N.B.A.'s Speed Limit
description: Charles Oakley is too crotchety, too set in his ways, to fit in with the kinder, gentler National Basketball Association. He is more old age than New Age.

title: Hospitable Hill Country
description: PERHAPS it's the moment we see the sign at the edge of Utopia, a tiny village in the Hill Country of Texas: ''WELCOME TO UTOPIA -- A PARADISE -- LET'S KEEP IT NICE.'' Perhaps it's the moment we get to Foxfire Cabins, a simple cluster of rustic buildings along the Sabinal River in nearby Vanderpool. You have to have a warm spot in your heart for any place whose brochure proudly proclaims: ''For your family's enjoyment, we have no TV's or room telephones.''

title: February 8-14; A Redesign in Mind
description: Car drivers worried about the big sport utility vehicle in the next lane have good reason to be concerned, according to a study by an auto insurance group.

title: Betty Scripps, Jeremy Harvey
description: Betty Knight Scripps, the newspaper heiress, and Jeremy Grig Harvey, an investment banker, were married yesterday in La Romana, Dominican Republic. Dr. Pablo Avila, a justice of the peace, officiated at a private house in the Casa de Campo resort.

title: February 8-14; Gay Law Repealed
description: Maine usually sees itself as a live-and-let-live state. But last week it became the only one in the nation to repeal its law protecting gay men and lesbians from discrimination in housing, employment and credit.

title: I Sing the Meadowlands!
description: Whenever I'm in New York and I have a little time on my hands, I grab a backpack and some maps and a compass and maybe some lunch and I hike through Times Square and up the stairs of the Port Authority Bus Terminal, where I catch a bus to the Meadowlands. The bus winds down the terminal's four-story ramp and dives into the mouth of the Lincoln Tunnel, which surrounds the bus with darkness and thick gray exhaust until it spits it out on the other side. As the cars around us scramble to be the first onto the highways of New Jersey, the bus struggles up the eastern side of a big red cliff referred to only on maps as Bergen Hill. Behind us, the skyline of New York seems to shout at the bus's back, asking it where it is going. The leaves of the scraggly ailanthus trees wave in the wind of traffic as the bus passes through the cut in Bergen Hill that separates New York from New Jersey and the Meadowlands from the rest of the world.

title: February 8-14; Doctor's In
description: The nation has its family doctor again.

title: THE GUIDE
description: At the Bruce

title: Befriending Iran Would Alienate Our Gulf Allies; Tighten the Oil Spigot

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPRINGER, FRED
description: SPRINGER-Fred. The Board of Directors, Administration, Medical Board and Staff of Peninsula Hospital Center and Peninsula General Nursing Home mourn the passing of our esteemed member of the Board of Directors, Fred Springer. He served as Treasurer of the Board until his death, and was an extraordinary man who exemplified only the highest ideals through his leadership and community service. He will be sorely missed by all who knew him. Sincere condolences are extended to his son, Jay Springer. Joel A. Miele, Sr., P.E. Chairman of the Board Robert V. Levine President and CEO Janet Miele-Powers Administrator, Nursing Home Leonard Schiffman, DMD President, Medical Board

title: FROM THE DESK OF; Easy Credit: A Wall Around The Poor
description: AS the gap rapidly widens between rich and poor in the United States, a form of voluntary servitude is threatening the most vulnerable and defenseless of our people. Easy access to consumer credit is an exceedingly enticing lure, but behind it stands a trap from which escape may be difficult or impossible for the poor.

title: Whatever Happened To Politics?
description: Your series ''Whatever Happened to Politics?'' (Jan. 25) addresses an important issue -- but not a new one. Two hundred years ago, the French intellectual Madame de Stael described her country in terms that apply equally well to the United States today. France, she wrote, was dominated by ''a mass of complacent men concerned only with their personal affairs,'' desiring nothing but ''material comfort and tranquillity.'' The French believed that ''things will go better if the government does not act. Far from calling for its assistance, people regard it as an obstacle.''

title: Excelsior's Manager Tries to Dodge the Bombs in Latin America
description: ONE night three years ago, as Donald W. Hoskins lay asleep in his small apartment in Lima, Peru, a powerful guerrilla car bomb exploded a block away.

title: Beyond China In Chinatown
description: Each listing now includes information supplied by the restaurant about its policy on smoking.

title: Q&A/Karen L. Kirchner; Talking Careers, in the Early Teen Years
description: DO you dread going to work? Do you hate the job and wonder how you ever got stuck doing it? What happened to the dreams -- of being an actress, police officer or teacher?

title: Ginny Bond and Michael Donahue
description: Ginny Lynn Bond, the daughter of Ginny Bond-Pollack of New York and Roland Bond of Ramona, Calif., was married yesterday to Michael John Donahue, a son of Lynnette and Robert Donahue of Essex Junction, Vt. Robert A. Ringler, a nondenominational minister, performed the ceremony at the Hotel Bel-Air in Los Angeles.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: A RIVER LOST: The Life and Death of the Columbia

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Suffern, N.Y.; Small-Town America, Near the Big City
description: RICHARD ACKERSON grew up in the Rockland County village of Suffern and later returned there with his wife, Ann, to raise their four children.

title: Here's How The Chiefs Stock Up
description: WHILE keeping up with the Joneses is a middle-class tradition, catching up with the Gateses has become the game for chief executives, whose 1997 pay and company stock holdings will be disclosed in the weeks ahead as companies mail their annual reports.

title: China's Dissent Played Down by Richardson
description: After four hours of meetings with Foreign Minister Qian Qichen and other senior officials here, the United States envoy to the United Nations, Bill Richardson, sought today to play down China's refusal to support threats of military force against Iraq, describing the difference as simply one of tactics to reach a shared goal.

title: Independent Film Maker Keeps the Process All in the Family
description: COME back when you have something to show us.'' Frazer Pennebaker repeated the words most often heard when he was raising money for ''Moon Over Broadway,'' the latest of the documentary films his family has been making since before he was born. Considering that their last film was the Oscar-nominated ''The War Room,'' about Bill Clinton's 1992 election campaign, you would think that financing would be guaranteed.

title: Alex J. Kramer, 94, Songwriter
description: Alex J. Kramer, a writer of popular songs whose best-known compositions included ''Candy,'' ''Far Away Places'' and ''It All Comes Back to Me Now,'' died on Tuesday in Fairfield, Conn. He was 94 and lived in Westport, Conn.

title: Brace Yourself
description: Patricia Marx's ''Brace Yourself'' (Style, Jan. 25) prompts me to write. I love to dress well, and I never go out without one of my 60 hats. I am often surprised to receive compliments, even in my 80's. However, after several fractures, I had to resort to using a cane. What a blow to my ego. My friends all resent the needed security of using the stick. We are ''the cane mutiny,'' but we laugh because we are survivors.

title: In the Region/Long Island; Reviving Long Beach Takes Another Step Forward
description: IN recent years, this seaside city once the playground of the wealthy, then a dumping ground for the elderly poor and the mentally ill -- has made a remarkable comeback.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MASS, LOUIS
description: MASS-Louis. On February 13, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Sylvia. Cherished father of Madeline (Neil) Hirschfeld and Phyllis (Alan) Fink. Loving Poppy of Andrea (Bob), Sondra (Larry), James, Gregg and Matthew. Sweet great-grandfather of Steven and David. ''We will miss our Poet''. Services Sunday 10:00 AM at ''Gutterman's, Inc.'', 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, LI. Donations may be made to the Kutz Home, 704 River Rd. Wilmington, DE 19809.

title: After the Storm: More Repairs for Battered Beaches
description: SHORE communities rushed to rebuild beaches after the northeaster earlier this month washed away long stretches of replenished beaches and sent flood waters surging over seawalls and onto streets. Governor Whitman declared an emergency along the shore from Monmouth to Cape May counties and sought disaster assistance from the Federal Government.

title: Jazz and Baseball In Kansas City
description: The Jazz Museum, which opened late last year in Kansas City, Mo., showcases that city's role in jazz history. Situated in a new museum complex in the historic 18th and Vine district, it includes four major exhibitions -- on Louis Armstrong, Duke Ellington, Ella Fitzgerald and Charlie Parker. The district was alive with jazz in the 1920's, 30's and 40's and was one of the first places Parker played. Among memorabilia on display are a Parker saxophone, a pair of Fitzgerald's rhinestone-rimmed glasses and sheet music from Armstrong's collection. Interactive exhibits include sound-mixing stations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DABNEY, CLARENCE R. WE
description: DABNEY-Clarence R. We, the Board of Trustees, and the entire Bronx Lebanon Hospital Center family mourn the passing of Clarence R. Dabney. Mr. Dabney's strong leadership as a Board Member of Bronx Lebanon; as Chairman of the Board of the Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., Health Center; and as Chairman of the Crotona Park Community Mental Health Center, were instrumental in the revitalization of the Bronx community. He also served as a member of Bronx Lebanon's Ambulatory Care Community Advisory Board, as well as the Hospital's Diversity, Quality Assurance, and Finance Committees. Mr. Dabney was widely recognized for his many contributions. His commitment to the Bronx Lebanon cause was absolute and he will always be remembered. We extend our sincere condolences to his family. Miguel O. Martinez, Chairman Board of Trustees Miguel A. Fuentes, Jr., President and Chief Executive Officer

title: Street Creepers
description: They look like sneakers, loafers and slippers with a zipper, all in one. Just when you've figured them out, they seem to morph into bicycle shoes or cross-trainers for the next millennium. Whatever they are, the polymorphous creations, called Spider shoes, are fashionable footgear: they make the wearer look cool on city sidewalks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  D'AGOSTINO, FRANK T.
description: D'AGOSTINO-Frank T. On February 13, 1998. Beloved husband of Mari. Loving father of Donna, Debbie and Denise. Devoted father -in-law of Jim. Cherished grandfather of Eric and Chelsea. Fond brother of Anne and Sonny. Reposing at the Frederick Funeral Home of Flushing, Northern Blvd, corner of 193rd St. Visiting hours Sunday and Monday, 2-4 PM, and 7-10 PM. Funeral Mass Tuesday, 9:45 AM, St. Mel's R.C. Church. Interment Mt. St. Mary's Cemetery.

title: When Households Included Slaves
description: AT a time when the White House is urging Americans to engage in a candid conversation on race relations, and the General Assembly in Hartford has enacted legislation requiring school districts to report annually on their efforts to reduce racial, ethnic and economic isolation, Connecticut educators say the dialogue is already well underway.

title: Unafraid of Virginia Woolf, Unrelentingly
description: It is difficult to stay on track when talking to the British actress, playwright and now screenwriter Eileen Atkins, mostly because her digressions are so entertaining. It's advisable to listen carefully when she says, ''apropos of nothing at all.''

title: For Children, an Olympic Computer Event
description: When Elina Teplinsky, an 11th grader at Polytechnic Preparatory Country Day School in Brooklyn, watched the opening ceremonies of the Winter Olympics last week, she noticed an odd detail. Instead of releasing doves near the Olympic torches, as is the tradition, the International Olympic Committee released biodegradable, dove-shaped balloons.

title: Holiday Tomorrow Presidents' Day
description: NEW YORK

title: Williams for Alomar: The Trade (Among Others) That Very Nearly Was
description: Bernie Williams is apparently willing to explore free agency and possibly play elsewhere after the 1998 season. The Yankees, too, have been prepared to sever ties with their star center fielder: they initiated trade talks involving Williams with no fewer than three teams last fall, including the division rival Baltimore Orioles.

title: Auto-Lease Disclosure: Simplicity, Please
description: To the Editor:

title: Barry Diller, Media Titan, Wants a Shot at the Small Time
description: BARRY DILLER has a bad case of nostalgia, and he thinks he can make it pay off.

title: Read My Lips, an Assemblyman Tells Barnes & Noble
description: First, Assemblyman Stephen B. Kaufman tried begging (his word). But since that has failed to lure Barnes & Noble to open a bookstore in the Bronx, he is trying toughness and artful insults.

title: A Chance To Leap Into 2002
description: IF watching all the high-speed and high-flying competition at Nagano has stirred the winter athlete in you, there is a place that may satisfy those Olympic dreams -- and you don't have to go to Japan to find it.

title: China Election Plot
description: To the Editor:

title: SOAPBOX; Official Reception
description: LAST year, the director of a nonprofit provider of residential services for people with developmental disabilities came to the Law Project with a question. His organization had bought a house in a North Jersey town with the intention of creating a group home for five men. He had obtained, from the town's construction official, permits to make some minor renovations. This alerted the town's zoning official to the nature of the project, and he told the director he would have to apply for a conditional-use permit, which would allow the town to impose zoning restrictions on the group home, and attend a public hearing on the application. The director asked us whether he had to comply with the request.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  OZKAYA, NIHAT
description: OZKAYA-Nihat. Beloved husband of Dawn Leger. Esteemed colleague, teacher, friend. Died January 18, 1998. Memorial service Wednesday, February 18, 1998, 5:30-6:30 P.M. Loeb Auditorium Hospital for Joint Diseases, 301 East 17 Street, New York City.

title: Harada Gets a Medal, Ending Years of Frustration for Him and His Country
description: All of Japan was on the slopes of the ski-jump mountain here this afternoon, or so it seemed.

title: Nicolas Hulot
description: Nicolas Hulot, a longtime star of French television, is the host of ''Ushuaia,'' a series focusing on daredevil adventure exploits now being broadcast on CNBC.

title: Our Towns; The Auditors Who Couldn't Shoot Straight
description: THE tax auditor seemed more like a bounty hunter, making the owners of the mom-and-pop restaurant feel like wanted criminals.

title: When Lampley Can Talk, He's Sharp
description: Jim Lampley, laryngitis and all, is having a grand time as TNT's Winter Olympic host. Each weekday, from 3 A.M. to 8 A.M. Nagano time, he has taken his perch on TNT's hillside set, which is open on three sides to snow and temperatures as low as 24 degrees. Vapor shoots from his mouth. And he has insisted on wearing a new wardrobe of business clothes, not parkas and flannel.

title: Corrections
description: A chart last Sunday with articles about interstate traffic in cigarettes and liquor between Pennsylvania and New Jersey transposed prices for a selection of wines and spirits in the two states. As the articles made clear, it is the New Jersey liquor prices, not the Pennsylvania ones, that are generally lower.

title: Brand Names
description: To the Editor: In response to ''What's in a Brand?'' by Betsy Wade (Dec. 7), I would like to relate a story. In February 1994, I stayed a week in the Ramada Inn, Melbourne-Satellite Beach, Fla. On departure, I searched high and low for my favorite pants, but they were nowhere to be found. I took inventory and discovered two more items had vanished. The front desk assured me someone would get back to me.

title: British Cathedrals
description: To the Editor: I enjoyed Gillian Tindall's article on one of my favorite cathedrals, ''Salisbury: A Record in Stone'' (Dec. 21). My first of several visits to Salisbury was while I was an Air Force officer stationed in England in the early 1950's.

title: Camden Take-Out Shops Get Reprieve on Ordinance
description: Take-out restaurants in Camden have won a reprieve from an ordinance that was to force them to close between midnight and 5 A.M. At the request of the owners of three restaurants and a community activist, the law was to go into effect at 12:01 A.M. last Thursday, but on Wednesday Superior Court Judge Frances J. Orlando Jr. ordered it suspended until a hearing can be held.

title: An Uncertain Market for Video Art
description: As the receptionist at the Rena Branstein Gallery in San Francisco, Jenny Symons gets all the uncensored comments from the gallery-going public. And when an exhibition involves electronic media, like a show in December by the 25-year-old video artist Peter Campus, Ms. Symons tends to get an earful.

title: Robert E. McEnroe, 82, Dies; Wrote Popular 40's Comedy
description: Robert E. McEnroe, who wrote ''The Silver Whistle,'' a frequently revived 1948 Broadway comedy about a garrulous tramp who spreads good cheer through a home for the aged, died on Feb. 6 at the Hughes Convalescent Home in West Hartford, Conn. He was 82.

title: Plan to Lay Gas Pipeline Sets Off Dispute
description: IT was only four years ago that a natural gas pipeline exploded in Edison, N.J., killing one person and injuring 100. Not surprisingly, a private energy company's recent proposal to lay 32 miles of pipeline through the heart of Westchester has provoked fierce opposition in many quarters of this densely populated county, rekindling memories of that and several other deadly gas-line blasts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EWEN, THEODORE CARNEGIE
description: EWEN-Theodore Carnegie. Of Scarscale, N.Y. on February 11, 1998. Husband of Elisabeth Graham Ewen. Father of Stephanie Hopkins Ewen and Deborah Graham Ewen. Brother of Marjorie Ewen Menconi, William H. and Robert H. Ewen. Grandfather of Benjamin Graham Ewen Whipple. Friends may call at the Bennett Funeral Home, 825 Scarsdale Ave, Scarsdale, Monday, 2:30-4PM and 7-8:30PM. Funeral service to be held at the South Presbyterian Church, 343 Broadway, Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. Interment private. Contributions may be made in his memory to the Leukemia Service, Memorial-Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Ave, N.Y., N.Y. 10021.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; New Law Eases Restrictions on Co-op Subletting
description: LAST month the State Legislature passed a measure that prohibits co-op boards from imposing unreasonable restrictions on shareholders who want to sublet their apartments.

title: Toys Are We
description: KIDS' STUFF

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: Mary Lou Lollis, Who Shared Stories of the Past, Dies at 103
description: Once upon a time there was a little girl named Mary Lou. Her family's name was Hall, and she was born in Greenville, S.C., on the very first day of 1895. That was a very long time ago. A man named Grover Cleveland was President of the United States, and there were only 44 states. They did not have radio or television in those days, but Mary Lou was never bored. She loved to listen to her mother and grandmother tell stories about the old days.

title: Echoids
description: CYBERVILLE Clicks, Culture, and the Creation of an Online Town. By Stacy Horn. 340 pp. New York: Warner Books. $23.

title: Whatever Happened To Politics?
description: Your articles on politics were welcome relief from the obsessive daily news coverage of the latest sexual scandal in the White House and provide a perfect response to the question raised by William Bennett: ''Have we lost our capacity for outrage?'' (as reported by Garry Wills in ''Washington Is Not Where It's At,'' Jan. 25). I think outrage as a political ploy itself has become a major problem. We have been numbed by exposure to so-called outrage. Thus, morality in government has been trivialized at best. And while William Bennett may protest our lack of outrage, he has contributed to our moral numbing. We see posturing and pitiless self-interest practiced by politicians who claim moral righteousness.

title: Chen Is Back on the Ice for China, This Time for Her Love of the Sport
description: While Tonya Harding and Nancy Kerrigan drew a lurid spotlight at the 1994 Winter Games, Lu Chen quietly and invisibly finished third, becoming the first Chinese figure skater to win an Olympic medal.

title: Not-So-New and New At Stamford Center
description: TO attract the young and the hip and to assuage establishment types -- the Stamford Center for the Arts is presenting, in overlapping engagements, the hot British comedian Eddie Izzard in his new one-man Off Broadway-bound show ''Dress to Kill'' and a not-so-new send-up of Sherlock Holmes, John H. Watson, M.D., and their motley friends and enemies, mostly enemies.

title: It's Not a Cow Town
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Looks Confused, and Canada Is Next
description: The United States men's Olympic hockey team stumbles into Monday's match against Canada with an unimpressive record of 1-1. The Americans beat Belarus by 5-2 today in the Big Hat arena, but looked worse, at times, than they did the previous day in a 4-2 loss to Sweden.

title: A Tuxedo Too Tight
description: ''YOU'LL look fat if you don't button the jacket,'' the photographer warned before my wife and I stood for the picture. ''Those boiled shirts,'' he said, and wagged his head, sadly. ''Acres of white.''

title: Pastor's Church Trial Attests To Divisiveness of Gay Issue
description: Joining a man and a woman before God is standard duty for members of the clergy. But for performing a union of a different sort, the Rev. Jimmy Creech, a United Methodist minister here, will soon be tried in a church court.

description: CONNECTICUT 92, PITTSBURGH 67

title: Fighting Erosion On Fire Island
description: Regarding the article ''U.S. Agencies at Odds on Fire Island Erosion Plan,'' (Feb.1) it comes as no surprise to me that the Army Corp of Engineers did not acknowledge the Fire Island National Seashore in their public presentation for the Fire Island Interim Plan. This is typical of the arrogant way that this agency and its alarmingly low caliber of personnel conduct themselves in public. Emboldened, no doubt, by their overly cozy relationship with the Fire Island Association and Congressman Lazio.

title: Gayle Friedland, Roberto Glik
description: Gayle Stephanie Friedland, a first-year medical student at Cornell University, was married last evening to Roberto Adrian Glik, a consultant in the health-care practice at Arthur D. Little, the consulting company in Cambridge, Mass. Cantor Kurt Silbermann officiated at the Pierre in New York.

description: TAKAKO AND HIDEAKI KAMBE, who came to New York from Japan 11 years ago, were shopping for an apartment, and their criteria were familiar to anyone looking to rent in Manhattan.

description: HAWAIIAN OPEN

title: Where the Displaced Find Training for Jobs
description: ALMOST a year ago, Mary Ann O'Brien was forced to acknowledge that her 25-year-career in the apparel industry was coming to an end. At 45, Ms. O'Brien, a former executive in a women's knitwear company, after being downsized from three jobs, said she realized that looking for a new job in the industry, once so exciting and full of promise, was a lost cause.

title: Whatever Happened To Politics?
description: Reich seems puzzled by the public's malaise. Could it be that people are tired of ''fixes'' that result in problems greater than the ones they were designed to vanquish?

title: Whatever Happened To Politics?
description: I grew up with politics. One of my earliest memories is of sitting on Harry Truman's lap at a campaign stop during the 1948 campaign. I was 3 years old.

title: Out of the Junkyard And Onto a Pedestal
description: THE Pelham-based insurance agency Eifert, French & Ketchum, whose clients include junkyards, recently helped the Friends of Art and Design at Purchase College mount ''Recycling the Wheel,'' sculptures of used parts seen in the Visual Arts Gallery through March 4.

title: A Wide-Ranging Regional Show to Instruct, Inform and Delight
description: IN the 1980's, photography established itself as the art form of the decade. Although photographs were a major presence on the New York art scene, there were few places in the greater Delaware Valley to see quality prints. In 1982, the Perkins Center for the Arts began to sponsor an annual exhibition devoted to the medium, and over the years, it has distinguished itself as a pre-eminent regional art show. Much of the credit for its level of professionalism and continued success goes to Hope Proper, a former photographer, who has been the chairwoman since ''Photography 3'' in 1984.

title: Ideas & Trends; Today's Cars and Drivers Can Grow Old Together
description: JUST a quarter century ago, a car that stayed presentable for 100,000 miles was a marvel. By the time the zeros rolled around again on the odometer, the bodies of most cars were scarred by rust and their engines rattled ominously. And each year, it seemed, Detroit ordered up cosmetic changes that made the previous year's model look ancient.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIXON, HILDA, BARR
description: DIXON-Hilda-Barr. 1912-1998. Educator, mother, activist. Missed and loved by many. W.W.D.

title: He's Boxed In But Not Out
description: George Kontonizia, the manager of a tiny, clamorous coffee shop called Viand on the glitzy strip of Madison Avenue on the Upper East Side above 59th Street, can't remember when he started serving breakfast and dinner to the homeless man known by residents, business owners and workers as the ''box man,'' among other names.

description: A Napa Clone

title: Who's a Liar? and Other Pointed Questions
description: After nearly four weeks and a flood of disclosures, certain things have become clear. A 24-year-old former White House intern got an extraordinary lift in her job search from friends of the President of the United States.

title: 'The Web Made Me Do It'
description: Velocity was the key word in the outraged debate over the media's coverage of the sexual allegations against President Bill Clinton. Critics complained that reporters, driven by the competitive backdraft of the new media -- meaning the Internet, of course, but also the three cable-news channels -- shattered the ethics barrier in their manic pursuit of the story. The press moved ''too fast from the bullet to the atom bomb,'' said Joan Konner, publisher of The Columbia Journalism Review. ''The digital age does not respect contemplation,'' said James M. Naughton, former executive editor of The Philadelphia Inquirer. Michael Isikoff, the Newsweek reporter whose scoop was pre-empted when Matt Drudge reported it on his Web site, the Drudge Report, weighed in, too, saying that Drudge ''disposes of all the journalistic conventions and simply recycles the most sensational gossip that's going around.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEN, MILDRED ALBERT
description: ROSEN-Mildred Albert. 81. Loving and kind mother of Carole Rosen and Joan Rosen, dear mother-inlaw of Kris Nazar, adored grandmother ''Mema'' of Jarred and Sivan Johnson and Ariela Sidney Nazar-Rosen. Died Friday, February 13, 1998 in Binghamton, NY. She was predeceased by her devoted husband Sidney in 1994. We will always treasure the memory of your love, concern and vitality. We are glad you are with Daddy again. Shiva at the home of Joan Rosen, Bardonia, NY. Contributions may be made to Gallaudet University, Washington, D.C., The Association for Macular Diseases, NYC or charity of your choice.

title: Weather Goes From Bad to Worse, and So Does the Ski Schedule
description: The world will have to wait to see how Hermann Maier handles Olympic adversity. The men's super-G, scheduled for this morning, became the latest casualty of the Nagano region's mercurial weather.

title: First Lady's Role in Report Scrutinized
description: Angered by what she considered biased reporting, Hillary Rodham Clinton ordered the White House in 1996 to draft a report criticizing coverage of the Whitewater land deal by The Washington Post, the newspaper reported today.

title: Stoudamire Deal: An Example of the Power Players and Agents Wield
description: In yet another disturbing example of how agents and players are dictating National Basketball Association economics -- and how small-market franchises are at the mercy of their stars -- Damon Stoudamire got Damon Stoudamire traded from Toronto to Portland on Friday.

title: It's Lonely Rooting Against The Huskies

title: Correction
description: The Streetscapes column of Jan. 25, about the Abigail Adams Smith Museum, misstated the title of an English visitor who wrote about his 1829 visit to the building, which was then a hotel. James Stuart was the Duke of Lennox, not the Earl of Lenox. The article also misspelled the surname of a banker who acquired some Greek Revival mantels from the building in 1919. He was Lewis B. Gawtry, not Gautry.

title: An Acquired Taste
description: AFTER two weeks of dining at fine French restaurants in Montreal, I had to face it: my palate was getting jaded. At Toque!, the tartare de saumon a l'avocat et ciboulette hadn't been daring enough for me; the next day I'd had to go to Les Caprices de Nicolas and order the poelee d'escargots. At La Marivaude, the calf's brains and quail pie left me unperturbed. When a plate of frogs' legs and a tournedos de cheval raised a yawn, I was about ready to concede that I'd seen -- and eaten -- it all.

title: The War That Made Us All
description: THE NAME OF WAR King Philip's War and the Origins of American Identity. By Jill Lepore. Illustrated. 337 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $30.

description: WITH reports about suspected oral sex in the White House and possible Presidential semen stains on an intern's dress, even the most respectable newspapers and TV news programs seem ribald and over the top these days. But such reports are tame, really, compared with the excesses of the coverage 100 years ago that incited the Spanish-American War.

title: Team Canada Pulls It All Together to Stop Sweden
description: Canada's fans are the loudest and most numerous at this Olympic hockey tournament. Canada's waving flags are the biggest and most plentiful in the stands at the main arena. Canada's television commentator is the most outrageous. You should have seen Don Cherry tonight, standing at rink side, wearing a huge white hat and an overlong pinstriped coat, looking like some sort of Lewis Carroll hallucination.

title: Scorsese, Blue Blood, Civilization
description: THE SETTING: The promenade of the Walter Reade Theater at Lincoln Center, Thursday night. A cocktail party honoring Martin Scorsese for his guest editorship of Civilization, a rather serious cultural magazine affiliated with the Library of Congress. The guests: an odd mix of hungry young writers, older social types with blonde beehive hairdos and celebs like David Bowie, Iman and Lauren Bacall.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODMAN, HOWARD CHARLES, M.D.
description: GOODMAN - Howard Charles, M.D. Passed away on February 6th, 1998. He was seventy-seven. Educated at Harvard University and Johns Hopkins Medical School, he had a long and distinguished international career at the National Institutes of Health, the World Health Organization and at Johns Hopkins University School of Hygiene and Public Health and Medical School, where he was Emeritus Professor. He was also Captain in the USPHS and Honorary Professor, Universite de Geneve. Howard and his childhood sweetheart Jane Robins Goodman enjoyed fifty-five years of love and laughter, travel and warm friendships all over the world. Our beloved Howard will be missed by his loving wife, their children Trudy Goodman (George Bowman), Jonathan Goodman and Julie Goodman, granddaughter Hilary Adel, brothers Lewis and James Goodman, and by the countless people whose lives were touched by his kindness and generosity, his profound intellect, his ready humor and his boundless optimism and joie de vivre. In lieu of flowers, the family encourages memorial donations to Physicians for Social Responsibility and Save the Children.

title: 'Peer Pressure' Bus Patrol Is Called Successful in San Francisco

Brown Jr. put troubled youths on city buses as security patrols in 1996, many residents derided the plan, but now the Mayor says the program has been an unparalleled success, reducing crime and keeping the peace on bus lines that travel through some of the city's toughest neighborhoods.

title: 24-Hour Wait for Abortion
description: What do you think of a proposed state law to require that a woman wait 24 hours before getting an abortion?

title: Ski Lift Where 20 Died Is Not Shown on Map Used by U.S. Pilot
description: An air navigation map produced by the Defense Department that was used by the crew of a Marine Corps jet that hit a ski lift in northern Italy 11 days ago, killing 20 people, does not show the ski lift, lawyers for the plane's crew said today. They also said that information from a surveillance plane that had tracked the jet shows that it was on its authorized course.

title: Literary Component At Purchase Concert
description: IT is a good thing the Performing Arts Center at Purchase College has three halls because they will all be in use today at 3 P.M. In the largest auditorium, Philharmonia Virtuosi adds a literary component to its concert: all the pieces are referred to in the historical novels of Patrick O'Brian. Excerpts will be read by Commodore John Burton-Hall, former Captain of the Queen Elizabeth 2. Mozart's Oboe Quartet in F, Haydn's ''Lord Nelson'' Mass (with the assistance of the Amor Artis Chorale) and Clementi's ''Great National'' Symphony complete the program. The music director, Richard Kapp, said that the Clementi memorializes the ''great sense of British nationalism in the early years of the 19th century.''

title: Pitching to Kids? Try Grossing Them Out
description: CHOCOLATE ''dirt'' cupcakes, a doll whose innards can be pulled out of its mouth, green slime that turns into bubble gum -- they're all the stuff of child's play today.

description: GROSS-Selma Klein. Widow of Irving and cherished mother of Adam and Mindy, loving grandmother of Caitlyn and Matthew. Loving sister-in-law, aunt and friend. A buyer for J. Magnin and then Zig Zag, Brooklyn Heights, her generosity, friendship and sound advice will live in the hearts and minds of all those who knew and loved her. Donations to Brooklyn Hospice, 6323 Seventh Ave., Brooklyn, NY 11220.

title: How 12 Artists Reshape Fiber Into Wall Works and Carpets
description: HOW 12 artists have transformed thread and fabric into innovative wall hangings, carpets and clothing is shown in ''Fiber Now: Contemporary Textile Art'' at the Rye Art Center here. On view through Feb. 28, more than 30 pieces offer a rounded overview of fiber techniques: weaving, stitching, silk painting, quilting, knitting and crochet.

title: The Advantages of Spray Painting
description: A BRUSH and a roller are sufficient for painting most projects, but for jobs that are large or have intricate surface detail, it's easier to spray the paint onto the work surface. Spray painting is less tedious than brush painting and it generally gives a smoother, uniform paint surface.

Adored grandmother of Jill, Steve, Eric, Monique, Michael, Dahna, Amy, Geoffrey, Jeffrey, Lisa, Nancy, Julie and Joshua. Great-grandmother of five. Superb educator and woman. Never to be replaced. title: This Deficit Is Soaring Again
description: Remember the twin deficits? A decade ago, the trade and budget deficits were the whipping boys, supposedly joined at the hip and blamed for all the world's economic woes. Unless the United States could bring them down, disaster was said to be assured.

title: Tedhead
description: When Ted Kaczynski pleaded guilty to being the Unabomber, William Thomas Jr. (pictured) was probably a little bummed. A 43-year-old Army veteran, he was one of several well-behaved eccentrics attracted to the trial. Thomas, who says he once knew Gilbert Murray, Kaczynski's last victim, moved into a $90-a-week room in Sacramento's Berry Hotel to write one of those urgent, self-published histories that promise to tell it like it is. What do you do when your star quits too soon? As Thomas made clear during a recent visit, you press on. Let's meet him.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELKINS, MICHAEL J.
description: ELKINS-Michael J. At age 35 in a diving accident in W. Palm Beach, FL on January 12, 1998. Beloved husband of Futaba. Cherished son of Barbara and Arthur Elkins. Devoted brother of Steven Elkins. A graduate of the Northfield Mt. Hermon School, Hamilton College and Cornell University, at the time of his death he was Vice President, Global Investments at Bankers Trust Company, New York. Donations may be made to the Michael J. Elkins Scholarship Fund at the Northfield Mt. Hermon School, Revell Hall, 206 Main Street, Northfield, MA. 01360.

title: When Mega Isn't More; The Boom in Barnsize Gyms and Salons Sparks a Backlash
description: KATE NELLIGAN has had it with large overcrowded hair salons. ''What they practice uptown is hairstylist terrorism,'' she said. ''You can't keep me sitting in a line of 15 women feeling like a piece of poultry anymore.''

title: Commercial Property/Woodbury Common; A Shopping Mecca Expands by Almost Half
description: IN an expansion that testifies to the fact that large numbers of people are willing to drive 50 miles in search of a bargain, the Woodbury Common outlet mall is adding almost half again the number of stores and square feet of shopping space as it now has.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISSMAN, GEORGE
description: WEISSMAN-George. Of Whitestone, NY. Died February 8, 1998 at age 82 in Del Ray Beach, Florida. As a young man, living in Brownsville during the Second World War, entered the Marines, fought in the Pacific, saw action on Okinawa, and did post-war service in China. A hard worker, and always an active union member, he was a cutter for 25 years, a progressive force within the ILGWU. He went to night school, earned a degree, began a second career at age 45, as a Mathematics teacher at Bayside High School; he was active in the union, was voted a UFT Chapter Chairman, upon retirement presented with a plaque: MENSCH. He read voraciously, loved to travel, and made a worldclass seafood lasagna. Loving husband to Mary for 58 years; sons Peter and Andrew; daughters-inlaw Rita and Kathleen; granddaughters Raphaela and Nicole, all of whom will miss him dearly.

title: A Real Lady-Killer
description: Love Me to Death

title: Potatoes Made Sumptuous With Garlic and Cream
description: WHAT could be more sublime than potatoes, garlic and cream? The alchemy of the combination, gratin dauphinois, has all the understated extravagance of a $100,000 strand of South Seas pearls.

title: City Hall Memo; Strict Giuliani Often Sees 7 Million Unruly Children
description: In another time, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani might have been compared to a Puritan preacher, delivering fire-and-brimstone sermons that found the work of Satan in every mug of grog. But these days, a more familiar persona might apply: that of a short-tempered father, glaring at the seven million New Yorkers in the back of his station wagon and threatening to pull over at the next hint of misbehavior.

title: At Tomb of Unknowns, Policy Versus the Heart
description: Sometime soon, a construction crane may lift several tons of granite, concrete and marble at one of the nation's most hallowed sites, the Tomb of the Unknowns in Arlington National Cemetery in Virginia, so scientists can try to name the serviceman interred there most recently.

title: North Carolina Fugitive, 31, Charged in Clinic Bombing
description: After an intensive two-week manhunt for Eric Robert Rudolph, Federal authorities today named the 31-year-old North Carolina fugitive as a suspect in the Jan. 29 bombing of a Birmingham abortion clinic, which killed an off-duty police officer and seriously wounded a nurse.

title: Pataki Fund-Raising Success Alters Usual Course of Campaign
description: Gov. George E. Pataki's unusually early and fruitful effort to stock his campaign larder with contributions has upset the traditional rhythm of New York gubernatorial races, giving fund-raising a far more prominent role than it has ever had at this point in the election cycle.

title: A Friend's Encouragement: 'A Cold Is Not Cancer,'
description: THE armies of the night have tramped across my brain pan and bivouaced in my sinuses and lit their campfires in my throat.

title: Maureen Connelly, Barry Liebowitz
description: Maureen R. Connelly, a partner in Connelly & McLaughlin, a public relations firm in New York, was married last evening to Dr. Barry L. Liebowitz, a pediatrician in New York. Eleanor MacDonald, an administrative law judge at the National Labor Relations Board in New York, officiated at the couple's home in East Hampton, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRASSBURGER, LENA
description: STRASSBURGER-Lena. On February 14, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Manfred, sister of Florence Eisen, aunt of many nieces and nephews. Graveside service Tuesday, February 17, 1 PM at Beth El Cemetery, Paramus, NJ.

title: Where Every Worker Is Ruler of the Thermostat
description: WHEN economists debate how to increase workplace productivity, they discuss many factors: automation, the availability of labor, even the rise or fall of wages. Rarely, though, does anyone mention room temperature.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLEMING, MARIE ''MIMI.''
description: FLEMING-Marie ''Mimi.'' In Tallahassee, Florida, February 12, 1998. 91 years. Wife of the late William F. Fleming and mother of the late Robert A. Fleming. Cherished by Marie Quigley Fleming Marshall and her husband, Willoughby Marshall of Apalachicola, Florida, and as ''Grandma Mimi'' by James Marshall of New York, John Marshall, Esq., of Tampa, Mary Marshall, Esq., of Boston, William L. Marshall, M.D., and Nancy Shadick, M.D., of Boston, and greatgrandchildren Alexa and Andrew Marshall. Exxon employee for 37 years. Interment in Calvary Cemetery, New York, following a Mass of Resurrection Tuesday, February 17, at 10 AM at St. Cabrini Chapel, 701 Ft. Washington Ave., New York. The family will welcome friends at the Chapel at 9 AM. Expressions of sympathy may be made to: Friends of Incarnation Children's Center, Attn: Sister Bridget Kiniry, O.D., 142 Audubon Ave., New York, NY 10032.

title: Checking on Bugs To Test the Health Of the Quinnipiac
description: POLLUTION occurs throughout the year, not just during pleasant weather. So members of the Quinnipiac River Watershed Association's stream team check year-round on the health of the river's tributaries. The water quality there is intimately related to the health of the river, a 38-mile waterway that begins in Plainville and flows through New Haven into Long Island Sound.

title: Mediation Instead of Litigation
description: LAST year, as part of a major restructuring of New York State's court system, co-op shareholders, condominium owners and their boards got something they have been seeking for years -- their very own section of the Housing Court.

title: The Shuffle to the Shuttle Turns Aerobic
description: AS the final passengers boarded the US Airways Shuttle to New York one evening, the usually dapper Charles B. Rangel, the Democratic Congressman from Harlem, arrived looking as disoriented as a lost tourist in a foreign country.

title: Ms. Worobow, Mr. Gleiberman
description: Alyson Lynn Worobow, the daughter of Marcia and Howard Worobow of Manhasset, N.Y., and Rodney David Gleiberman, the son of Carol and Michael Gleiberman of Lancaster, Pa., were married last evening by Rabbi Myron Fenster at the Shelter Rock Jewish Center in Roslyn, N.Y.

title: People Can Avoid Collisions With Deer
description: To the Editor:

title: TELEVISION: Big Hospitals, Strong Women, Prime Time; A Former Moll Flanders Joins the Surgical Staff
description: Any actress, never mind an alumna of the Royal Academy of Dramatic Art in London, can tell you that accepting a part that hasn't been written is a risky roll of the dice.

title: One Disk, Three Sides of a Singer
description: Three Ani DiFrancos share ''Little Plastic Castle,'' her ninth album. One is a blunt, fearless storyteller, chronicling her temptations and traumas. The second is a cult star who feels both energized and confined by her growing audience. And the third is an increasingly confident musician, moving beyond her description of herself as a folk singer.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the United States Super 8 Film and Video Festival at Rutgers University misspelled the surname of a film maker. She is Judy Fiskin, not Fishkin.

title: Clinton Tells Indonesia to Stick to Reform
description: President Clinton called President Suharto of Indonesia on Friday night and warned him that Indonesia was once again on the verge of action that could imperil the $43 billion bailout of the country.

title: Making Children's Midwinter Break Fun
description: TO a child, winter break is a blur; a fleeting and precious allotment of unstructured time and relative freedom. But for parents suddenly faced with many extra hours to fill, the prospect of a school-free week can be somewhat daunting.

title: Jennifer Scully, Richard Lerner
description: Jennifer Anne Scully, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. James H. Scully Jr. of Columbia, S.C., is to be married today to Richard Scott Lerner, a son of Linda Lerner of Swampscott, Mass., and the late Joseph I. Lerner. Judge Arthur J. Gajarsa of the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit will officiate at the Cosmos Club in Washington.

title: Hans Wallach, 93, Scientist Who Helped Explain Hearing
description: Hans Wallach, an experimental psychologist at Swarthmore College who helped explain human vision and hearing, died on Feb. 5 at the Manchester House nursing home in Media, Pa. A longtime Swarthmore resident, he was 93.

title: POSTINGS: On 16th and 17th Streets, between Fifth Avenue and Avenue of the Americas; New Center for Jewish History
description: Four existing structures and one new building are being combined to form the Center for Jewish History, which is to be one of the world's largest repositories of Jewish art, letters and documents.

title: The World: Tribes of Israel; Security's Bitter Fruit: An Urge to Fight
description: LAST week, in hopes of healing an increasingly painful rift in world Jewry, Israel's Chief Rabbis were called upon to make a small gesture toward their non-Orthodox adversaries on the question of who should be allowed to perform conversions to Judaism. But the rabbis could not even bring themselves to call the other movements by the names they use: ''Reform'' and ''Conservative.'' Instead, their resolution denounced ''those who do not believe in Torah from the Heavens, who try to shake the foundations of the Jewish religion.'' Reform and Conservative spokesmen responded in kind, calling the resolution ''a declaration of war on the Jewish people'' in the ''struggle for freedom of religion and conscience.''

title: His Own Biggest Hero
description: VICTOR HUGO By Graham Robb. Illustrated. 682 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $39.95.

title: Cast in the Middle Of the Long Conflict In Northern Ireland
description: Stephen Rea is famous for looking melancholic on screen, and on this occasion at least, he seemed little more cheerful in person. But he also had good reason for feeling gloomy. He had just flown into London from Dublin and was distraught over the spate of sectarian murders that had bloodied the new year and now threatened the peace process in his native Northern Ireland.

title: River Searched After Grisly Clue Found
description: Police divers returned yesterday to search the waters of the Hudson River off Battery Park City after a severed human foot was found Friday in a plastic bag beneath a pier.

title: Underlying Mortgages
description: To the Editor:

title: Meet the Sexiest Man Alive
description: For almost 10 years, interviewers from the University of Chicago have knocked on randomly selected American doors to ask questions about, among other things, sex. Some 10,000 people have submitted to the General Social Survey interviews, reporting that they have sex an average of 58 times per year. But the G.S.S. data also reveal that sex, like wealth, is not distributed fairly. Among adults, for example, half of all sexual activity is accounted for by about 15 percent of the population. Who are the men in this elect group? In honor of Valentine's Day, we've recruited John Robinson, a sociology professor at the University of Maryland, to create Mr. Wonderful, a composite statistical profile of the supersexy male. But be warned: His traits may surprise you.

title: Council For Arts Makes Awards
description: LORI NOZICK is an artist who spends two days each week seeking grants and exhibition opportunities for her mixed-media sculptures and installations. When she recently started a project of large-scale architectural forms, Ms. Nozick, who lives in Crompond, applied to the Westchester Arts Council, which awarded her $2,500. The amount is modest, she said, but such grants are essential to her work.

title: The View From/Rye; Valentine Chocolate: Aphrodisiac for All
description: FROM a booklet on the history of chocolate: ''It is clear from Spanish records that in Mexico, Montezuma drank chocolate as an aphrodisiac. The ladies had to be satisfied by their lord and master alone, for the precious concoction was only for men.''

title: Bank's Neo-Classical Columns Get New Staying Power
description: In a triumph of community organizing, the exterior of a neo-classical structure at 96th Street and Amsterdam Avenue that was once home to a bank was declared a landmark last week, relieving residents' concerns that the building was headed for destruction or development.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FAUST, SAM
description: FAUST-Sam, on February 9, 1998, died peacefully at home. Cherished husband of almost 51 years of Marcelle. Devoted and Adoring father of Karen and Monica. Father-in-law of Jonny. Loving Papa to Brittany and Cassidy. Brother of Lally. We miss you so much.

title: Child Care
description: Joining hands, the people work together to build the future for everyone in their community: those whose skin is white, those whose skin is brown, those whose skin is purple.

title: Not-So-Honest Abe
description: HONOR'S VOICE

title: What to Look For
description: ALPINE SKIING

title: Capitol Hill Looks At Issue Of Art Stolen In Wartime
description: Members of the House Banking Committee put aside their normal concern for monetary policy and deposit insurance today and turned their attention instead to the plundering of art during World War II -- and what to do about it now.

title: At the Casinos
description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week.

title: February 8-14; No Chinese Smoking Gun
description: A scandal ago, Washington was consumed with the question of whether China had developed and executed a plan to influence the 1996 Presidential and Congressional elections, funneling money to the Democrats (and some Republicans) through intermediaries, businesses and friends of President Clinton. Senator Fred Thompson, the Republican heading the committee investigating campaign finance irregularities, strongly suggested in July that the Chinese meddled in the elections.

title: Machiavellian Advice For the White House
description: To the Editor:

title: Five Hotels This Side of the Ritz
description: ''I HAD sounded my pocket, and only brought up a few pieces of silver, -- So . . . said I to myself, . . . wherever in your wisdom you may conclude to lodge for the night . . . be sure to inquire the price, and don't be too particular.''

title: A New Heavy-Metal Underground Emerges
description: Heavy metal, again? Surely you were expecting it. Whenever pop music becomes choked with intellectual pretension, metal rises up as an alternative. It first happened in 1969, when Black Sabbath appeared amid the baroque foppishness of psychedelia. It happened in 1983: as New Wave's synthesizer excesses peaked, speed metal and glamour-metal roared out of the West Coast in two different sand buggies (Metallica, Ratt). The current symbol of pop's self-importance, Goldie's new double-CD, ''Saturnzreturn'' -- with its hourlong pseudosymphony, ''Mother'' -- is another big, fat cue, and there are dozens of well-evolved metal subgenres ready to spring forward. Gentlemen, start your engines.

title: Foul Shots
description: Barney Polan's Game

title: The Neediest Cases; When Her Mother Died, a Dancer's World Crumbled
description: There she is, castanets in hand, dancing flamenco atop Liberace's mirror-studded piano. In another photo, Mirella Bardi is playing Carmen, her platinum hair dyed black, a sultry, come-hither gleam in her eye.

title: Ariel Zeitlin And John Cooke
description: Ariel Zeitlin and Dr. John R. Cooke were married last evening at the Puck Building in New York. Rabbi Charles Davidson officiated.

title: Sharon Dizenhuz, Steven Seltzer
description: Sharon Dizenhuz, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Israel Dizenhuz of Cincinnati, was married there last evening to Steven E. Seltzer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Seltzer of New York. Rabbi Margie Meyer performed the ceremony at the Omni Netherland Plaza Hotel.

title: Armchair Philosophers
description: To the Editor:

title: Christie Chan, T. H. Belknap Jr.
description: Christie Ann Chan, a daughter of Agnes and Bing Chan of Stony Brook, N.Y., and Thomas Hunt Belknap Jr., the son of Alice and Thomas Belknap of Wenham, Mass., are to be married this evening at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York. Deacon Stephen Katsouros is to perform the ceremony.

title: Dial-a-Campsite At National Parks
description: The National Park Service has a new reservation system for its most popular campgrounds. Starting March 15, travelers can reserve campsites at the Grand Canyon, in the Great Smokies, Acadia and 22 other parks by calling new 800 numbers.

title: South Carolina Fines State For Shipping Radioactive Waste
description: Low-level radioactive material, once used to illuminate an exit sign in a state hospital for developmentally disabled children in Wall Township, was improperly shipped to a South Carolina medical waste incinerator last month, prompting that state to fine New Jersey $15,000, South Carolina's Department of Health and Environmental Control said last week. New Jersey paid the fine last month, said Henry Porter, section manager for the the South Carolina Division of Radioactive Waste Management. Fifty-nine drums were found to have high levels of tritium, a radioactive form of hydrogen gas, Mr. Porter said. New Jersey officials actually alerted South Carolina to the situation after learning where S.M.I.-East Coast Medical Waste, a private disposal company hired by New Jersey, had sent the material.

title: British Cathedrals
description: To the Editor: Marlise Simons errs in describing the celebrated church at Durham as ''this great Romanesque cathedral.'' The cathedral is justly famous as a transitional work and is one of the finest examples of early Gothic in Europe. The up-thrusting lines on the facade throughout, the particular design quality of those lines, the expanses of stained glass, and the vaulting all signal the advent of the Gothic.

title: The Unsolved Riady Mystery
description: In the annals of influence-peddling, two fateful meetings on Sept. 13, 1995, stand out. That morning, James Riady, who runs his family's multibillion-dollar conglomerate in Indonesia, met Donald Fowler, then Democratic Party chairman, to press for the hiring of a former employee, John Huang, as a fund-raiser. That afternoon, Mr. Riady made the same pitch to President Clinton at the White House. Mr. Clinton later directed two aides to get the job done. Mr. Huang was hired. He then went on to harvest huge sums of illegal contributions for the Democrats, helping produce the biggest political fund-raising scandals in a generation.

title: Lisa McCreery, John Santoro
description: Lisa McCreery, a daughter of Judith and Donald McCreery of Lyford Cay, the Bahamas, was married there yesterday to John Joseph Santoro, a son of Elena and John Jay Santoro Jr. of Short Hills, N.J. The Rev. Patrick Adderley officiated at St. Christopher's Anglican Church.

title: As a Source of Pride, Writer Takes Up History of Island's Blacks
description: HER work spans an arc as global as contemporary Africa and as local as Long Island. But Lynda Day, a Brooklyn College professor, says it is all aimed at one goal: ''To let African-Americans know they have a history to be proud of.''

title: Susan Townes, Malcolm West
description: Susan Annette Townes and Malcolm Leonard James West were married last evening at Troutbeck, a historic house in Amenia, N.Y. James M. Murphy, an Amenia town justice, officiated.

title: In Suburbia, Unexpected Neighbors
description: RESIDENTS of several upscale New York suburbs have acquired neighbors in recent years that many never expected -- large rental apartment buildings.

title: Good Vibes and Bad Vibrations
description: A second driver, in a third Seville test car, had these observations:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OBSATZ, SADIE
description: OBSATZ-Sadie. On February 12, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Harry Obsatz. Dear mother of Victor and (Susan), Martin and (Phyllis), Leonard Obsatz, Alan and (Ann) Obsatz. Cherished grandmother of Marina, Jordan, Allison, Lauren, Anna, Joelle, Evan and great grandmother of Pilar. Services Sunday February 15, 11:15AM at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: PULSE; New Lip Line: Wort
description: No cosmetic packs the psychological impact of lipstick -- dabbing it on can brighten a mood. The phenomenon may become more pronounced in April, when the first lipstick with St. John's wort, touted as an herbal alternative to Prozac, arrives in stores. Made by Tony & Tina, an East Village company, the lipstick features an aromatic blend of lavender, bergamot, rose water and rosemary.

title: Putting Together Pieces of a Career Cut Short
description: A RETROSPECTIVE for an artist who died young and whose memory is still fresh is always colored by expressions of emotion. Such is the case with James J. Colavita, who died of kidney failure in 1996 at 47. Mr. Colavita was a ceramic sculptor and a major figure on the Mercer County art scene.

title: Flights of Creation by Women And Some About Women, Too
description: A REMINDER that it's Women's History Month is the high number of shows by women or about women -- or both. The Zilkha Gallery and the Davison Art Center, both at Wesleyan University in Middletown, are tacitly keeping the observance with shows very different in kind but each alluring in its own way.

title: POSTINGS: Monastery to Be Retirement Development; Officers' Village Near West Point
description: A Roman Catholic monastery has agreed to sell its 93-acre riverfront property on Route 9D in Garrison, N.Y., to a White Plains developer who plans to turn it into a community geared to retired military officers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMASHOWER, MARVIN
description: THOMASHOWER-Marvin. Age 73, of Manhasset, NY, and Palm Beach, FL, on February 11, 1998, in Palm Beach, after a long illness bravely borne. Beloved husband of Rosalie Caplan Thomashower for 48 years, loving father of Laurie and her husband David Ridell, devoted grandfather of Lindsey and Marc Ridell, dear brother of Ruth Silverman and Sidney Thomashower. He worked in the Christmas tree light industry for 50 years and had not retired. His enduring fortitude and caring was exemplary, setting a standard few could hope to follow. He will be sorely missed and never forgotten by family and friends. Funeral services Sunday, February 15, 1998 at 12:00 noon at ''Gutterman's,'' 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, L.I. In lieu of flowers, donations to the PKR Foundation, 4901 Main Street, Suite 320, Kansas City, MO 64112 would be appreciated.

title: On Needles and, Mostly, Pins
description: BOBBY STATEN thought he'd never get a break.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: VARIETY spices this week's movie menu with a solid version of fictional Americana, two Hollywood originals and a Hitchcock suspense gem.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERLOW, BRYNA
description: PERLOW-Bryna. Died suddenly February 10, 1998. Beloved aunt of Ellen Silverberg. Compassionate nurturer. Unique soul. Rest in peace.

title: The World; Arabs Are Wary of Swirling the Sand
description: TIME can surely test a friendship. Just look at the Middle East.

title: Bike-Riding Governor Has a $15 Million Dream
description: Legislators say they are making progress on automobile insurance reform. A group of them has been holding meeting after meeting on the subject, and they have promised to submit recommendations to Governor Whitman by, well, sometime.

title: Original Sin
description: The Founding Myths of Israel Nationalism, Socialism, and the Making of the Jewish State. By Zeev Sternhell. Translated by David Maisel. 419 pp. Princeton, N.J.: Princeton University Press. $29.95.

title: Where Rum and Seafood May Top the List
description: HABANA, South Norwalk's newest restaurant, opened just before the Pope's visit to Cuba. Could this be the first ripple of a tidal wave of food, fashion and music in the Cuban style? Despite its name, Habana (which is the Spanish spelling for the capital city) is more about good food than about trendiness. The decor is stylishly modern, with black, pipe-exposed ceiling and white brick wall.

title: Jodi Kass, Mark Tracten
description: Jodi Lynn Kass and Mark Franklin Tracten are to be married this afternoon at the Mark Hotel in New York. Rabbi Joel Goor is to perform the ceremony.

title: Beyond Paella
description: THE best food I ate during my three trips to Europe was in Spain, where one of the most exacting chefs I know was born. Closer to home, he and his friend Raoul took me to Manolo's, a small corner of peace in a noisy town.

title: The Jewel Without the Crown
description: THE IDEA OF INDIA By Sunil Khilnani. 263 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $24.

title: Rush to Judgment?
description: EASTER LILLY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEIS, BETTY C.
description: WEIS-Betty C. On February 13, 1998. Resident of Allendale Nursing Home, Allendale, NJ. Beloved wife of the late Richard. Loving sister of Jacques Saphier. Service Sunday 10:45 AM at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Oil Profits Trickle Up or Out of Africa's Forgotten Land
description: Longtime visitors to this tiny country recall that a scant few years ago big events here were things like the occasional landing of a jet from Europe at the airfield.

title: Ibrahim Farrah, 58, a Specialist in Ethnic Dance
description: Ibrahim Farrah, a performer of Middle Eastern dance and publisher of Arabesque, a magazine about ethnic dance, died on Feb. 7 at his home in Manhattan. He was 58.

title: The Other Big Bend
description: THOSE who lusted for a wilderness experience in Texas once automatically made the long trek to Big Bend National Park with its breathtaking canyons and sweeping vistas along the Rio Grande. Then came the recreational vehicles, throngs of students on spring break and traffic jams on the most popular hiking trails. My solution to the ''people problem'' in the past had been to escape to the national park's more remote and less accessible trails and primitive campsites in the Chihuahuan Desert and leave the cool mountains and comfortable lodges to the crowds. Now there is the ''other Big Bend'' -- Big Bend Ranch State Park.

title: The Bitter Truth
description: It seems Molly O'Neill writes for me (Food: ''The Bitter Truth,'' Jan. 25). After watching ''Big Night'' on video, I found its celebrated timpano recipe in her Nov. 16 ''Eye Candy'' column the next morning. I made it for Christmas and it was delicious.

title: L.I. Rates High for Fast-Growing Bird-Watching
description: JIMMY COOK of Ronkonkoma is serious about birds. One of a burgeoning group of Long Island bird-watchers, he spends his weekends and vacations on bird-watching tours, and owns hundreds of dollars worth of birding equipment.

title: TELEVISION: Big Hospitals, Strong Women, Prime Time; Playing A Difficult, Bighearted Feminist
description: It's eight days after she won a Golden Globe, and there's still only one thing that people want to talk about with Christine Lahti: how she ended up in the ladies' room at the exact instant it was announced that she had been named best actress in a drama series for her role as Dr. Kathryn Austin on CBS's ''Chicago Hope.''

title: Austria
description: To the Editor: ''Austrians Are Puzzled by Lagging Tourism'' propagates the false notion that Vienna is an expensive place to visit. In recent years, Vienna has consistently been in the middle of the European pack in terms of cost, and in many areas, is well below the average.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NESS, THEODORE
description: NESS-Theodore. On February 12, 1998. Age 81. At home, surrounded by his family. A graduate of City College, Phi Beta Kappa and Harvard Law School, both with honors. Partner at the law firm Herzfeld & Rubin, he was the author of numerous articles and treatises on corporate taxation including ''Taxation of the Closely Held Corporation'' and ''Tax Planning for the Disposition of Business Assets'' and a Contributing Editor to ''Compensating the Corporate Executive''. He was a member of the Board of Directors of Baltek Corporation and a member of the Franco-American Chamber of Commerce. He is survived by his wife of forty-seven years June Lawrence Ness, his children Andrew Oliver Ness, Patricia Valerie Ness Epstein, four grandchildren Lawrence Adam and Oliver Theodore Ness, and Charles Michael and Nathaniel Aaron Epstein. Notice of memorial service at a later date.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Senior citizens shouldn't have to be frightened out of their minds as to whether they'll continue to get home care. They shouldn't need an arsenal of lawyers to sue the Government to get the benefits that should rightfully be theirs.'' REP. JIM MCGOVERN, Democrat of Massachusetts. [32]

title: Two Friends Feel the Strain of a Crisis
description: Rahm Emanuel sits behind the desk where George Stephanopoulos once sat, the door to President Clinton's private dining room over his right shoulder, a series of autographed photographs of himself and the President hanging where Mr. Stephanopoulos's collection was once displayed. Mr. Emanuel is these days filling what he acknowledges will forever be known as ''the George Job,'' a post that his predecessor defined as a mixture of politics, policy, public relations and personal celebrity.

title: Bulldogs Capture Their Seventh Straight Victory
description: YALE 5, HARVARD 3

title: Ideas & Trends: Last Rites; The Fear Is Real Enough. The Gangs Are Another Story.
description: AS if New Yorkers do not have enough to fear. Now it's fear itself.

title: Justine Trubey, John Abrahams
description: ON first meeting Justine Burkat Trubey, she seems like the sort of person who would be cynical and hopeless about falling in love. She wears black day and night, has a tattoo on her ankle, and when it comes to lipstick, nail polish, poetry and bars, her motto is, The darker the better.

title: Our Consumer Culture Gets What It Deserves; Testing Mrs. Clinton
description: To the Editor:

description: PLANET OF

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SOKOLOW, MEL
description: SOKOLOW-Mel We miss you. We love you. There is so much going on that we wish we could share with you. Love, Alec, Betsy, Sam and Diane

title: February 8-14; On Paper, a New American Dream
description: The American dream has become a handful of blue chips and some high-growth stocks instead of three bedrooms and a two-car garage.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GOLDBERG, HERBERT M.
description: GOLDBERG - Herbert M. 1973-1998. Still a vibrant part of our lives. Sela, Max and Ed.

title: Patrons of Gay Sex Club Report Attacks by a Man With a Knife
description: A gay advocacy group issued a warning yesterday to those who visit sex clubs in the city, saying a man had used a knife to sexually assault customers at one such club.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: SLEEPING IN VELVET

title: Making Accommodations For the Disabled
description: Your article on the abilities of the disabled [''Disabled, He Helps Others Beat Handicaps,'' Jan. 25] is inspirational to all people of every age. The Henry Viscardi School graduates competent, creative individuals. I hope that in the future we will educate all citizens and everyone will be productive. However, will every workplace be ready to utilize this new labor source? Not all places and buildings are accessible to all people.

title: For a Growing Region, a 'Nassau Hub'
description: A NAME not yet coined may one day describe the 2.9 square miles of central Nassau County that planners and government officials call the Nassau Hub.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEAHY, WILLIAM J.
description: LEAHY-William J. On February 13, 1998, of Oceanside, NY. Associate of Condgon, Flaherty, et al. Veteran of WW II and Korea, 6th Armored Division. Husband of the late Louise V. Loving father of William, Nancy Castanio and Patricia. Dear brother of Josephine Argento. Also surived by five grandchildren. Reposing at the Towers Funeral Home, Inc., Long Beach and Foxhurst Rds., Oceanside, NY. Funeral Mass at St. Anthony's R.C. Church, on Wednesday, 9:45 AM. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery. Visiting Monday and Tuesday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM.

title: In Recital, Love Songs From the Masters
description: THE Fairfield Chorale continues its 35th anniversary celebrations at the Pequot Library in Southport with a recital of love songs. The 4 o'clock program has been designed as an afternoon of choreographed cabaret, with 23 members of the chorale presenting songs by Kern, the Gershwins, Porter, Rodgers and Hart and other composers of American popular music. The number to call for more information is (203) 254-1333.

title: Chaminade Defends Title
description: Chaminade of Mineola, L.I., won the boys' championship, and St. Francis Prep of Queens took the girls' title yesterday in the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association indoor championships at the Armory Track and Field Center in upper Manhattan.

title: Loyal Subscribers of Compuserve Are Fearing a Culture Clash in Its Takeover
description: Ron Luks first logged on to Compuserve in 1979 with what could only loosely be described as a computer -- and with a modem that sent and received text at an excruciatingly languid 300 bits a second. But the cryptic ''O.K.'' that appeared on his otherwise blank screen was among the first public portals to cyberspace. As he typed strings of obscure commands, the service yielded its treasure: a thriving fraternity of geeks trading techie tips through the ether.

title: Publisher Finds Dream Role As Chief of Smaller Realm
description: It is late afternoon, in the dim sunlight of a SoHo bistro, and Peter Mayer is savoring life in a single time zone and the remains of his steak frites.

title: Soweto Journal; Horseplay It's Not: Blacks Dream of Finishing First
description: During the years when Enos Mafokate was young and the ribbons and trophies might have been his, he was mostly busy cleaning out the stables.

title: AUTO RACING; Plenty of Support for the Winning Driver
description: More than 70 people gathered around Dale Earnhardt's garage when his black Chevrolet was fired up for the first time today shortly after 8 A.M.

title: Bills Regulating Managed Care Benefit Doctors
description: The debate over managed health care and consumer rights that is just beginning in Congress has been stirring a populist backlash in state capitals for several years. It is shattering historic alliances, turning doctors against doctors, doctors against business and business against otherwise pro-business Republicans.

title: HINDU-FIRST PARTY EXPECTED TO GAIN IN INDIA'S ELECTION
description: When Atal Bihari Vajpayee looked out across the 150,000 people who gathered here this week for one of the climactic speeches of the country's election campaign, he seemed for a moment to choke, as though glimpsing a victory at the polls that he and other veterans of India's Hindu nationalist movement thought for years they might never see.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARRY, EDWARD
description: BARRY-Edward. On February 15, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Josephine. Father of Virginia McCutcheon. Loving grandfather of William E. McCutcheon, Jeanne McAlary, Carolyn Phillips and the late Michael K. McCutcheon. Also survived by eight great-grandchildren. Visiting at the Albert R. Conner-Colonial Funeral Home, 4955 Broadway (at 207th St.), Monday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Good Shepherd Church, Tuesday, 11 AM. Interment Gate of Heaven, Hawthorne, New York.

title: Patents; Could a new chip in your electricity meter become the brains of a household computer?
description: WHAT if someone patented an idea so revolutionary that it could give every American home a powerful computer, with an Internet connection -- free. And what if this same idea serendipitously turned out to be the David that slew the Microsoft Goliath?

title: United States' Stars Must Think as a Team
description: No, said Ron Wilson, coach of the United States men's hockey team. It is not necessary to give his National Hockey League stars a curfew at the Olympic Games. ''They're men,'' said Wilson, whose men took an unimpressive 1-1 record into today's game with Canada. ''They're the best athletes we have. They know how to take care of themselves.''

title: Sports of The Times; Curling's Women Prove They Can Have It All
description: SO you thought the women who are body checking and insulting each other back at the Aqua Wing in Nagano City were such teeth-rattling tigers. But there are many ways to define women as tough, that make them late 20th century Olympians and role models. How many do you know who can hold down a full-time job, raise a child or two, juggle a life that still leaves room for world-class sport?

title: The Technology Advances, and Americans Complain It Favors the Dutch
description: ''A very strange year,'' Ids Postma declared today, his gold medal secure in his custody.

description: MAINZ, Germany  Just when some upscale winegrowers in Germany hoped she had gone away, the Blue Nun has returned.
