title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, CAROL PETRY
description: GOLDMAN-Carol Petry of Tequesta, FL, passed away, Thursday, February 12, 1998 at the Jupiter Medical Center, Jupiter, FL. Born in New York City, she had been a resident of Tequesta for 15 years, coming from Greenwich, CT. She was a member of the Turtle Creek Country Club, the Turtle Creek Ladies Golf Assoc. and was a past officer of the Tequesta Chapter of the American Needlepoint Guild. She is survived by two sons, LeGrand Snowden Redfield, Jr. of Norwalk, CT and Edward Petry Redfield of Boston, MA; a daughter, Elizabeth Kehoe Petry Goldman of Stratford, CT; a sister, Barbara Petry Annear of Palm Beach Gardens, FL; a grandson, Harley Ellis Petry Redfield and a nephew, William J. Mathews, III. She will be sorely missed by all who knew and loved her. The funeral service will be held, 3PM Sunday, February 15, 1998 at the Aycock Funeral Home Chapel, Jupiter. Interment will be in Woodlawn Cemetery, Bronx, NY. Friends may call Sunday, February 15, from 11-3PM at the Aycock Funeral Home, 1112 Military Trail, Jupiter, FL.

title: Time to Bomb: Olympics Bad, No Moon Good
description: Everyone's got the calendar out, trying to schedule a manageable little war with Iraq. There are the Islamic holy days to consider, the cycles of the moon, the President's trip to Africa, and even parents' weekend at Stanford University, where a certain First Daughter goes to school.

title: Lincoln the Absolutist
description: To an an increasingly cynical public, Abraham Lincoln may seem hopelessly old-fashioned. Consider the contrast between him and other recent occupants of the White House: on the one side homeliness, humility, self-doubt, magnanimity and the need to know the right; on the other, slickness, hubris, self-righteousness and the need to know the ratings.

title: G.O.P. Reception Courts Black and Hispanic Legislators
description: With a bounce in his step, Assemblyman John J. Faso, a Republican, made his rounds at a popular reception in the Omni Hotel ballroom, shaking hands at the conference of a group dominated by Democrats: the New York State Association of Black and Puerto Rican Legislators.

description: As Kurt Masur revisits the scenes of his early triumphs at the New York Philharmonic, it is tempting to think that he is coasting, if only a little. In the case of Bach's ''St. Matthew Passion,'' which he presented to great effect in 1993, a listener might even have wished for a more or less literal revival.

title: Righteous Babe Saves Hometown; A Fiercely Independent Folk Singer's Soaring Career Lifts Buffalo, Too
description: On a bleak, half-shuttered block of Main Street in this struggling post-industrial city, a thriving business bursting with brash sounds and primary colors is literally breaking through walls to keep up with the demand for its product.

title: Even at Columbia, Gambling And College Athletics Collide
description: It was in Apartment 4A in the Zeta Beta Tau fraternity house on West 115th Street in Manhattan, prosecutors say, that the potentially explosive combination of college sports and illegal gambling had collided with unbroken regularity for the last several months.

description: With one strike of a match, Wang Jian was transformed from ordinary citizen into a community crusader.

title: U.S. Treasury Plans to Auction Bills This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to tomorrow's auction of three- and six-month bills. Today, in observance of Presidents' Day, there is no trading in United States Treasury securities and no trading of Treasury futures on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: How to Be Captivating Without a Sense of Self
description: Tired of the same old Teutonic characters in musicals, those mountain-bound Austrian nuns who rhapsodize about their favorite things, those Berlin M.C.'s who wilkommen you to sleazy cabarets teeming with Nazis? Well then, meet Hedwig Schmidt.

title: Another Illness Interrupts an Athlete's Comeback
description: One of the most intriguing comeback stories of the Olympics ended today when the German figure skating champion Tanja Szewczenko withdrew from the Winter Games after flu-like symptoms prevented her from practicing for nearly a week.

Service Tuesday, 9:30 AM, at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Mr. Suharto's Extended Run
description: Indonesia, battered by economic crisis and unprepared for the eventual departure of its dictator, President Suharto, is jittery over increasing unrest. Well it might be. The last time the country changed rulers, in the 1960's, half a million people died in the upheaval, most of them ethnic Chinese. Another violent transition can be avoided by planning now for an orderly and swift shift to democratic rule.

title: Giants Bring The Brown Era To a Quiet End
description: It was late last year, in a parking lot outside Giants Stadium, that Dave Brown looked over his shoulder at the big gray stadium and reflected on the changing landscape of the team he followed as a child and once led as an adult.

title: The Stuff of Legend
description: A circle closes with the auction at Sotheby's this week of some 40,000 possessions of the Duke and Duchess of Windsor. These objects are now owned by Mohamed al-Fayed, who bought the contents of the Windsors' Paris residence a decade ago, shortly after the Duchess of Windsor's death in 1986. (The Duke expired in 1972.) The proceeds of this sale will be donated to children's charities that were supported by Mr. al-Fayed's son, Dodi, and the woman who was killed with him in Paris last August, Princess Diana.

title: 6 Fur Coats Stolen From a Shop in SoHo
description: Four thieves stole six fur coats from a SoHo shop yesterday but fled in such haste that one dropped his eyeglasses after the angry furrier fought back, the police said.

title: Will Suharto Defy the IMF?: Rising Tensions Put Jakarta in a Vise
description: SINGAPORE  President Suharto of Indonesia sees his controversial plan to introduce a currency-board system tying the rupiah to a fixed exchange rate as a way of solving two pressing problems  rising prices and widespread corporate debt  either of which could undermine stability in the world's fourth most populous nation, analysts said Sunday.

title: PATAKI TO ASSIST HEALTH COVERAGE FOR THE INDIVIDUAL
description: Gov. George E. Pataki has decided to use a one-time cash subsidy to keep down health insurance costs for some of the state's sickest people, officials said yesterday. The plan seems aimed at bolstering the Governor's record on health issues, as well as preventing an outcry over surging premiums that could bedevil his re-election campaign.

title: Taking In the Sites; Forecast for the Internet: More El Nino Web Pages
description: Jeff Cohen has grown to appreciate the Internet immensely over the last couple of weeks. As an information officer at a state flood emergency operations center in Sacramento, Calif., he relies on the World Wide Web to help provide accurate, timely information to concerned homeowners and the news media.

description: The New Yorker would seem to be the magazine that has everything. An illustrious 73-year history. A powerhouse editor. Prominent writers. Buzz.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMOWICZ, LEA MESCHEROWSKY
description: ABRAMOWICZ-Lea Mescherowsky. Died February 14, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Mendel; cherished mother of George and Myriam; sister of Alexander and the late Shoura and Bernard; grandmother of Maxine; aunt of Nadine, Carmen, Janet, Alice, Alexa, Gregor and Dolly. Born March 1, 1906, a refugee from the Russian pogroms in 1917 and a hidden Jew in Belgium during WW II, Lea was the inspiration both for the film ''As If It Were Yesterday,'' directed by her daughter, concerning Belgian resistance and for The Hidden Child Foundation (consisting of international groups of survivors who were hidden as children). Funeral services Tuesday, February 17, 12 noon, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers donations may be sent to Congregation Bnai Jeshurun Judith Bernstein Lunch Program, 100A West 89 St., New York, NY 10024.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PITMAN, DAVID B., M.D.
description: PITMAN-David B., M.D. Age 89, on February 13. Beloved husband of Velma ''Mimi'' (Smale), devoted father of Roger, Douglas, Jeffrey and Peter, cherished brother of Laura Kaplan. Born in Manhattan, he received an M.D. degree in 1933 and practiced in Port Washington until 1972. He was the first physician from Nassau County called for service in the US Army during WW II. In 1962 he received the University of Vermont's Distinguished Alumni Service Award. Donations may be made to the University of Vermont College of Medicine, Century Club, which he founded.

title: Karpovtsev's Injury Serious
description: Mark Gandler, the agent for Aleksandr Karpovtsev of the Rangers, said Karpovtsev has two torn ligaments in his wrist, not one as originally thought.

The concert, built around an orchestrated version of Coltrane's suite ''A Love Supreme,'' completely rewritten by Slide Hampton, showed how rich Coltrane's work is for musicians looking to reimagine the great works of jazz.

description: The rules of theatrical femininity state that when a diva is onstage, the room's attention must bend toward her. Perhaps this is why Martha Wash struck an odd note at Town Hall on Thursday night. In feathers and elegant fabric clinging to every monumental curve, Ms. Wash certainly achieved over-the-top fabulousness. Yet the spotlight nearly radiated past her.

title: Cone Is Feeling Good, But He Still Has Doubts
description: The memories created by his frightening arm injury collide in David Cone's mind, like trains crashing head on. The surgeon who repaired the frayed tissue in his right shoulder said the most important part of the shoulder was in ''pristine'' condition, and this heartens Cone, makes him believe he has a chance for more great years.

title: Metro Matters; Far From Sky, Sandhogs Face Grit and Risk
description: TO reach the sandhogs who are working on the Third Water Tunnel in Maspeth, Queens, first you have to descend. The elevator carries you down a shaft 670 feet deep, and when you finally get to the shadows at the bottom, the sky seems awfully far away.

title: It seems there's no fail-safe way of protecting children on the Internet.
description: ONE of the most striking paradoxes of Internet culture is that children are the most computer literate among us, but their vulnerability to on-line predators prevents their being able to enjoy or explore freely what is likely to be the defining medium of their lives.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLATT, ABE A.
description: PLATT-Abe A. 83, of Bronxville, New York and formerly of Mount Vernon, NY, died February 14, 1998, in New York. Beloved husband of the late Ann. Devoted brother of Esther, Anna and the late Ruth and Philip. Loving father of Mitchell, William (Lynne), Diane and Gale. Dear companion of Dottie D'Augelli. Cherished uncle, adored grandfather of seven and great-grandfather of four. A graduate of New York University and Brooklyn Law School, Abe was devoted to the family business he helped build, from which he had not retired. Abe enjoyed golfing and spending time with his family and friends. He will be deeply missed and never forgotten. Funeral services Monday, February 16, at 10 AM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Mount Vernon, NY. Interment Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to The Giving Tree Scholarship Fund, Boston University, Sargent Camp, 36 Sargent Camp Road, Hancock, NH 03449 would be appreciated.

title: A Kaleidoscope of Black Women

And although Ms. Zollar's current nine-woman modern-dance company has worked together relatively briefly, the performers have developed a daring and authenticity that make them the perfect instruments for her work.

title: Such an Attitude, and So Proud of It

Even in the excitement of moving to a new town and being spun off into her own MTV animated series, ''Daria,'' last March, she never cracked a smile, maintaining the same facial expression, deadpan voice and serenely negative attitude in every situation.

title: Two Successful Terriers Are Dogdom's King and Queen
description: This is a tale of two terrific terriers, unrelated but similarly scrappy champions who epitomize the Norwich and Welsh strains and happen to belong to two families named Schwartz, families related only by their determination to bless this world, and themselves, with the perfect terrier specimen.

title: Many Indonesians See Military as Rock of Stability
description: As buildings burned and soldiers chased down rioters here in the capital 18 months ago, several hundred excited college students debated whether to join the melee. What they did next might have happened only in Indonesia: they raised a cheer for the troops.

title: Toll From Bombing in India Rises to 50 Dead and 200 Hurt
description: The police in the southern city of Coimbatore said today that the death toll from multiple bombings that preceded a Hindu nationalist election rally in the city on Saturday had reached 50, with more than 200 wounded. This tally would place the attacks among the worst outbreaks of election violence since India gained independence in 1947.

title: At Home Abroad; Violence Or Politics?
description: It takes determined optimism to believe in the possibility of peace in Northern Ireland. The conflict traces back 800 years, to the first English invasion of Ireland. In its modern form -- the sectarian violence of the last 30 years -- it has cost more than 3,000 lives. Every attempt to resolve it politically has foundered on the profound emotional attachments of one side or the other.

title: Never on Sunday, Until Now for Earnhardt
description: Dale Earnhardt ended two decades of frustration at the Daytona 500 today the same way he had won so many races in the past: by being too tough to beat at the end of the race. Then he emerged from his black Chevrolet Monte Carlo and did something new: let his emotions take over.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YAVERBAUM, ARNOLD, M.D.
description: YAVERBAUM-Arnold, M.D. On February 14, 1998. Beloved husband of Justine. Cherished father of Harvey. Father-in-law of Kathryn (Meyer). Adoring and adored grandfather of Daniel, Peter and Rachel. Loving brother of Anna Halberg, Albert Reade, and the late Celia Yaverbaum. Devoted physician to countless families in Brooklyn, NY. Graveside service Tuesday, 11 AM, at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, LI. For information, Ballard - Durand Funeral Home, White Plains, NY.

title: U.N. Surveys Paid Leave For Mothers
description: A United Nations survey of 152 countries has found that the United States is one of only six that does not have a national policy requiring paid maternity leave.

title: A Retreat on Gay Rights in Maine
description: The repeal of a Maine law prohibiting discrimination against gay men and lesbians in housing, employment and public accommodations is a disheartening step backward for a state that prides itself on tolerance. The surprise outcome shows that broad but complacent support for gay rights is no match for a grass-roots campaign that plays to anti-gay feelings and the public's general reluctance to politicize sexual matters.

title: Police Cameras Miss the Big Picture
description: To the Editor:

title: Battered Sea Lions Find Refuge From El Nino
description: In a normal winter, this is the slow season for the Friends of the Sea Lion Marine Mammal Center here, a time to prepare for the busy weeks of spring and summer when the bulk of the youngest of the sad-eyed creatures come ashore in need of nurturing, food and rest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOEN, MAURICE
description: KOEN-Maurice. On February 14, 1998. Beloved husband of Kety. Loving father of Denise Fletcher. Devoted father-in-law of Bob Fletcher. Caring grandfather of David and Kate Fletcher. Memorial service on Tuesday, 10 AM, at the John J. Fox Funeral Home, 2080 Boston Post Rd., Larchmont, NY. For further information call 914-834-0144.

title: Japan Passes Bailout Plan
description: Japan's Parliament gave final approval today to a 30 trillion yen ($239 billion) plan to buy bank shares and protect bank depositors. The bills were an effort to restore confidence in the financial industry. The upper house passed legislation that sets aside 17 trillion yen to guarantee deposits and help clean up banks that fail. It provides a further 13 trillion yen -- equal to what the United States Congress allocated for the savings-and-loan bailout a decade ago -- for the Government to increase banks' capital by buying newly issued preferred shares. The rescue passed the lower house on Feb. 7. The stock market was not impressed today. At midday, the Nikkei index was down 147.85 points, or 0.88 percent, at 16,643.16.

title: After Vintage Year, Wall St. Is Ordering Only the Good Stuff
description: By 8 on Thursday night, Smith & Wollensky, the midtown steak house, felt like a trading floor in midrally. The Wall Street guys were out in force, jackets off, cutting into man-size portions of meat, joking loudly and popping the cork on some very serious bottles of wine.

title: One Step Back; Museum-Quality Seediness Alive in the Ordinary
description: The Frederick R. Weisman Art Museum at the University of Minnesota in Minneapolis -- a great pile of stainless steel designed by the architect Frank Gehry -- is a piece of art in itself. It looks like the world's best traffic accident: 20 silver Mercedes sedans in one fabulous wreck.

title: Hudson River Park Plan Moves Closer to Reality
description: To many people, the name Hudson River Park summons up an enticing vision: a gleaming band of green along five miles of dilapidated Manhattan waterfront, with bicycle paths, boats for rent, a dozen or more public piers, education centers and even places to swim.

title: Maurice V. Russell, 74, Educator
description: Maurice V. Russell, an educator who taught and directed social services at New York institutions for four decades, died on Feb. 8 in a fire at his weekend home in Rhinebeck, N.Y. He was 74 and lived on Manhattan's East Side.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MUNROE, JULIET GARRETT
description: MUNROE-Juliet Garrett. Died peacefully in San Mateo, CA, on January 26, 1998, in her 90th year. Widow of the late Thomas R. Hughes and Henry Munroe. A graduate of Bryn Mawr, she earned an M.A. in economics at Catholic University in 1946. A resident of Washington for more than three decades, she was president of the D.C. Chapter of the League of Women Voters during the 1950's. She is survived by her son Thomas R. Hughes, Jr., of Berkeley, CA, daughters Dorothea M. Bennett of Ardsley-on-Hudson, NY, and Marian M. Hubby of Sante Fe, NM, and daughter-in-law Susan S. Munroe Smith of Santa Fee, NM, as well as six grandchildren and three great-grandchidlren. Contributions in her memory may be made to the League of Women Voters, Planned Parenthood, or Bryn Mawr College, Bryn Mawr, PA 19010.

title: Confession as Strength At a British Newspaper
description: It's not news that newspapers make mistakes, garbling names, misquoting sources, reporting that a figure was $812 when it was actually, er, $812 million. But in Britain, the land that introduced the notion of ''the fact too good to check,'' most newspapers are notoriously reluctant to print corrections, except when the error is particularly glaring or the threat of legal action particularly pressing.

title: West Fears Bosnia Funds Aid Hard-Line Serbs
description: Late last year, as United States and World Bank officials were negotiating the details of a $17 million aid program for Bosnian Serbs, they were given an unnegotiable demand, the officials say. Bosnian Serb authorities linked to the former Bosnian Serb leader Radovan Karadzic, who has been charged with war crimes, insisted that unless areas they controlled received 15 percent of the money they would block the whole deal.

title: Houston Propels Knicks With a 22-Point Quarter
description: All it took was one shot, a seemingly innocent baseline jumper. But before the shot had even slithered cleanly through the net last night, the Knicks' Allan Houston seemed to anticipate that this would not be the last one.

title: Years of Losing Teaches St. John's How to Win
description: The qualities could not be measured when the team in red was losing. They have become clear only lately, as the painful St. John's careers of Felipe Lopez, Zendon Hamilton and Tarik Turner take a turn toward an unexpectedly happy ending.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTELL, PAUL
description: MARTELL-Paul. Age 50, of 408 Hammett Rd., Greer, SC, died Friday. Born in Brooklyn, he was founder and President of Greenville Finishing Co. He attended C. W. Post College on Long Island and Florida State University. He was an Air Force veteran of the Viet Nam Conflict. Surviving are his wife Kaye; a daughter Jessica, and son Jeffrey; his father Philip; three brothers, Richard, John and Charles; two sisters, Lynn Bezoza of NYC and Esther Gaier. He was predeceased by his mother Eleanor Martell, a New York consumer advocate. Memorial services Monday, 1 PM, at The Mackey Mortuary, Greenville, SC.

title: America Online's Triumvirate in Cyberspace; The Service Provider Everybody Loves to Hate Changes by the Nanosecond
description: Theodore J. Leonsis knew something was wrong late last month when during a two-day period, the constant stream of electronic messages from Stephen M. Case, his boss and the chief executive of America Online, came to an abrupt stop.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEMARCO, MARY
description: DeMARCO-Mary. Of Staten Island, on February 14, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Andrew (Kelly). Devoted mother of Josephine Barresi and Peter. Cherished grandmother of four. Reposing at the Azzara Funeral Home, 183 Sand Lane, Staten Island, Sunday and Monday, visiting hours 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial will be offered at St. Christopher's Church, Tuesday, 10 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions to St. Christopher's Church would be appreciated.

title: This Week
description: EVENTS

title: 'Presidential Sites': How Many, and How Big?
description: Access to Iraq's closed ''presidential sites'' lies at the core of the standoff between President Saddam Hussein and the United Nations special commission charged with disarming Iraq of chemical and biological weapons and ballistic missiles and the means to make them.

title: Baby Boomers, and There the Likeness Ceases
description: Bill Clinton and Ken Starr were born months apart in small, Southern-accented towns. But they come out of starkly different political cultures and have lived in two different worlds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, EDNA M. WINNICK
description: GOLDSTEIN-Edna M. Winnick. On February 13, 1998 in San Francisco, CA. Beloved daughter of Jacob and Fanny, loving mother of Carole (Jordan) Cohen and Judith Schaeffer. Devoted grandmother of Deborah Rappaport, Joel and David Cohen and Daniel Schaeffer. Proud great-grandmother of Sara, Rebecca and Leah Rappaport, Julia and Rachel Cohen and Samson and Ezekiel Cohen. Service Tuesday, 1:15 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Interment Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, NJ. Memorial service in San Francisco to be announced.

title: As Street Plays It Safe, Seizinger Wins Again
description: Katja Seizinger took ''a hot ride.'' Picabo Street cooled off. There was no fairy tale in the women's downhill here today, only a story about favorites doing what they are expected to do.

title: Push, the Hot Technology of '97, Gets a Cold Shoulder in '98
description: As new technologies go, the promise was enormous: With a new category of software known as ''push'' technology, the World Wide Web would finally take its rightful place among moneymaking commercial media.

title: China Is Said to Suspect a Bomb in Bus Blast
description: The police suspect that a bus explosion on Saturday that killed at least 16 people in the central city of Wuhan was caused by a bomb, a Chinese newspaper said today. But authorities have revealed no details of the explosion and have given no indication they know who is responsible.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  REEVES, MINNA
description: REEVES-Minna. Valentine remembrances and everlasting gratitude to my beloved lifegiver whose beauty, charm, & talent enhanced the quality & the joy of our family life.

title: INSIDE
description: Culture Clash in Inquiry

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ULRICH, MURRAY K.
description: ULRICH-Murray K. On February 14, we bid farewell to Murray. Devoted father, unique father-in-law, enchanted grandfather, guiding brother and Rita's courageous widower. We have let him go with a hug, a wink and a heaviness in our hearts. David, Andrew and Stefanie

title: Don't Rush the Court
description: Sometimes, we need to let a new law take a spin around the block before deciding whether it works. And that is the case with the line-item veto, which a Federal judge ruled unconstitutional last week. Thanks to the statute's demand for direct appeal, the case will probably go directly to the Supreme Court.

title: In Flush Times, New York City Wants Unpaid State School Aid
description: The Capitol rings these days with calls for spending the state's record surplus, but in that happy din, barely a word is said about a growing concern for New York City officials: the state owes the city at least $600 million, and much more by some reckonings, for expenses in the city school system over the last decade.

title: Divers Seek More of Body
description: As forensic anthropologists continued to examine a human foot that was found on Friday in the waters off lower Manhattan, police divers spent yesterday morning searching for more of the body's parts in the waters around a marina and a sea wall where the foot was found.

title: Prudential Conversion Raises Questions
description: A retired woman on the North Shore of Long Island is angry and a little apprehensive. A 40-ish father in Queens thinks it is a good deal. And a wholesaler in Brooklyn would be happier if things just stayed the same.

title: The Rights Of Writers As a Twain Obsession; In a Rediscovered Manuscript, Wisdom Seeker and Statesman Spar
description: Congress saved the best speaker for last.

title: A Woman Among Girls Has Her Opinions, Too
description: Mariya Butyrskaya of Russia is an elegant performer and powerful jumper, but her confidence has not always matched her figure skating ability.

title: Nets Enjoy Soft Spot In Schedule
description: The Nets spent three quarters looking up at the Philadelphia 76ers on Saturday night. But no matter how far behind they were, the Nets never looked worried.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPRINGER, FRED
description: SPRINGER-Fred. The Board of Directors, Administration, Medical Board and Staff of Peninsula Hospital Center and Peninsula General Nursing Home mourn the passing of our esteemed member of the Board of Directors, Fred Springer. He served as Treasurer of the Board until his death, and was an extraordinary man who exemplified only the highest ideals through his leadership and community service. He will be sorely missed by all who knew him. Sincere condolences are extended to his son, Jay Springer. Joel A. Miele, Sr., P.E. Chairman of the Board Robert V. Levine President and CEO Janet Miele-Powers Administrator, Nursing Home Leonard Schiffman, DMD President, Medical Board

title: Pinning Down Quicksilver: Finding William James in His Multiple Guises
description: GENUINE REALITY

title: Third Gold for Russia's Lazutina
description: Larissa Lazutina collected her third gold medal of the Games and Olga Danilova gained her second as the Russians left their Norwegian rivals trailing to win the women's 20-kilometer cross-country relay.

title: Political Memo; Fight Against Big Tobacco Emboldens Democrats
description: On Wednesday afternoon, with all the hoopla of a big political announcement, Vice President Al Gore and a host of Democratic lawmakers held a rally in a Senate hearing room and proclaimed that enactment of tough antismoking legislation was one of the top priorities of the year.

title: Rojas Hopes to Rebound From a Horrible Season
description: Mel Rojas does not look all that different than he did last season. He is still squat in stature, despite all those reports of strenuous off-season workouts in the Dominican Republic. And even though Rojas can throw a fastball 95 miles an hour, he will never be mistaken for a bodybuilder.

title: Samuelsson Receives Ban
description: Ulf Samuelsson of the Rangers and the Swedish Olympic hockey team was disqualified from the Winter Games early today because he carries both Swedish and American passports. Under Swedish law, according to Olympic officials from Sweden, that means Samuelsson cannot represent his native land in the Olympics.

title: Earnhardt's Close Calls In the Past
description: Dale Earnhardt was where he had waited 20 years to be when his black Chevrolet Monte Carlo rolled slowly around the track on the final lap of Sunday's Daytona 500.

title: A Client Asks: 'Weren't You My Lawyer?'
description: Norton Herrick would appear to be just the kind of client a big commercial law firm like Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom would love to have. Based in the well-to-do seaside city of Boca Raton, Fla., Mr. Herrick has hefty interests in real estate, is the founder of the Audio Book Club and is an owner of a string of art galleries. He has an estimated net worth of more than $100 million.

title: Martha Gellhorn, Daring Writer, Dies at 89
description: Martha Ellis Gellhorn, who as one of the first female war correspondents covered a dozen major conflicts in a writing career spanning more than six decades, died on Sunday at her home in London. She was 89.

title: Concocting a Hip Mix Of Genres, Cultures And Musical Moods
description: Geometric shapes flickered and moired across a giant screen above the stage in the World Financial Center's Winter Garden on Wednesday night. A smoke machine puffed away. Spotlights twirled and sometimes raked across the audience. But the ensemble onstage -- a small orchestra augmented with piano, electric guitar and a disk jockey -- was playing elegiac music by Ryuichi Sakamoto: the American premiere of ''Untitled 01,'' which fills Mr. Sakamoto's new album, ''Discord'' (Sony Classical).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ACKER, THELMA
description: ACKER-Thelma. Of Chestnut Ridge, N.Y. Beloved wife of the late Samuel; devoted mother of Helen Schulman and Neil Acker; dear sister of Ethel Kaplan and Doris Kalter and the late Benjamin Glass; loving grandmother of Stephanie Moy, Wendy Rubin and Dr. Erica Schulman; cherished great-grandmother of five. Services Tuesday, 10:30am, ''Gutterman-Musicant'', 402 Park St, Hackensack, NJ. Memorial contributions may be made to Sloan Kettering Cancer Center.

title: Items Taken From Plant Sought for Radiation Test
description: Plant administrators at the Connecticut Yankee nuclear power plant have sent letters asking current and former employees to let the company conduct radiation tests on items that the employees had been allowed to take home.

title: Police Press Investigation Into Bludgeoning Death of Girl
description: Police investigators worked today to solve the mystery of the bludgeoning death of a studious dark-haired 15-year-old girl who disappeared over the weekend while walking home from a roller rink. Residents here mourned the loss of a young girl whose parents had always tried to guard her safety.

title: 2 Killed and One Injured In a Drive-By Shooting
description: Two young men were killed and a third was wounded late Sunday in a drive-by shooting shortly after a dispute at a roller rink, the Gloucester County Prosecutor's office said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPRINGER, FRED
description: SPRINGER-Fred. The Board of Directors, Administration, Medical Board and Staff of Peninsula Hospital Center and Peninsula General Nursing Home mourn the passing of our esteemed member of the Board of Directors, Fred Springer. He served as Treasurer of the Board until his death, and was an extraordinary man who exemplified only the highest ideals through his leadership and community service. He will be sorely missed by all who knew him. Sincere condolences are extended to his son, Jay Springer. Joel A. Miele, Sr., P.E. Chairman of the Board Robert V. Levine President and CEO Janet Miele-Powers Administrator, Nursing Home Leonard Schiffman, DMD President, Medical Board

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLHOLLAND, PAUL DOUGLASS II
description: MILLHOLLAND-Paul Douglass II, 93, on February 9 following a brief illness. A pioneer for new practices of cash management in the National Division of Citibank for 40 years, he retired as a Vice-President in 1969. He then consulted for the Foundation for Full Service Banks, NY, the U.S. Postal Service, and for Mayor Lindsay's administration. He graduated from the Choate School and in 1928 from Princeton University. He is survived by his wife, Alice (formerly of Dobbs Ferry, NY), his daughters, Carol Strasburger (of Belmont, MA), Louise Cecil (of Santa Cruz, CA and Vancouver, BC), Allaire Warner (of Mount Vernon, NY), seven grandchildren, and one great-grandchild. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Brookhaven Nursing Center for a music fund in his honor, 1010 Waltham St., Lexington, MA 02173.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODMAN, IRENE
description: GOODMAN-Irene. 85. On February 14th, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Bernard. Obsessively devoted mother of Susan and Lewis. Cherished mother-in-law of Ira and Sally. Her jokes and memories of her turkey dinners will live on forever.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUFF, WILLIAM
description: DUFF-William. Died February 9, 1998 in Shelter Island. He was born in New Castle, Pa. on September 17, 1916. His daughter, Christina, pre-deceased him. He is survived by his son, Alexander Duff, and his daughter, Fiona Duff, both of New York City, and by his former wife, Odile Utard Duff of New York City and Shelter Island. A memorial service will be held at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, officiated by Fred Anderson, Pastor, on Friday, February 20 at noon.

title: Taxis Involved in 2 of 4 Accidents Injuring 11
description: Eleven people were injured in four separate motor-vehicle accidents -- two involving cabs -- in Manhattan yesterday, just 10 days after an analysis of accident data showed a sharp rise in mishaps involving taxis.

title: Teaching Myths and History
description: Revolutions do not always change a country's future, but they certainly alter its past. The wave of recent political change has brought with it a sure byproduct of upheaval, the new history textbook. Textbooks in the new democracies are vast improvements over the propaganda volumes that preceded them. But they are more honest because they reflect a new, more honest orthodoxy. Even so, many are uninterested in puncturing inaccurate but cherished national myths.

title: Chief of Thompson Gets Additional Post
description: Christopher I. M. Jones, chief executive of the J. Walter Thompson unit of WPP Group in New York, has, as expected, been named to the additional position of chairman. Mr. Jones, 42, succeeds Burt Manning, 66, who formally retired in December and now becomes chairman emeritus. Mr. Jones was named chief executive in January 1996.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUGAR, SAMUEL
description: SUGAR-Samuel. On February 16, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Anne. Dear father of Stephen Sugar and Jane Pekarne and grandfather of Sutter, Karen, Elise, and Andi. Adored great-grandfather.

title: The G.O.P. Is Urging Hussein's Ouster
description: Before the first bomb is even dropped on Iraq, Congressional leaders are telling the Clinton Administration what it should do after that.

title: Metro Business; New Automobile Insurance
description: The Travelers Property Casualty Corporation of Hartford said yesterday that it would offer a new kind of automobile insurance to high-risk drivers in New York.

title: For Kennedy at 66, Guests at $1,000
description: SENATOR EDWARD M. KENNEDY'S 66th birthday is not until next Sunday, but he will start celebrating tonight at the St. Regis Hotel, at 2 East 55th Street. And the well-wishers will pay for the privilege of joining in: the $1,000-a-person cocktail party will benefit his campaign committee. ''It's good to have a theme, right?'' said JILL GIMMEL, the finance director.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACKSON, SIDNEY J.
description: JACKSON-Sidney J. 91. On February 13, 1998 in Chapel Hill, NC. Husband of the late Beatrice Kaufman. Beloved companion of Marion Cumpiano. Father of Lorna Salzman. Grandfather of Eva Salzman and Stephanie Salzman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENWALD, ANNA
description: GREENWALD-Anna. Of Miami Beach, Fla. at age 101. Beloved mother of the late Jerry and Dotty Ross, Gill and Ethel Ross and George and Billie Ross. Devoted sister of Bea Hyman. Cherished grandmother of Rick and Iris Ross, David and Cathy Jensen, Vicki Ross, Tom and Stephanie Suskin and Nanci Ross. Adored great grandmother of Michael and Amy, Barrie, Erica and Emily. Funeral Services at graveside Wednesday, February 18th at Riverside Cemetery, Rochelle Park, N.J. She will forever be in the hearts of all whose lives she touched.

title: Helping Doctors Keep Their Distance
description: IF you sense a certain distance developing between you and your doctor recently, it may not be your imagination.

title: Another Loss and U.S. Will Go Home
description: A few days ago, when the Americans were still among the gold-medal favorites in the men's Olympic hockey tournament, Coach Ron Wilson discussed the biggest incentive for winning in the preliminary round.

title: Reagan's Biographer, Memory and Teacher
description: OVER the last 12 years, as the biographer Edmund Morris penetrated deeper into the past of Ronald Reagan, there emerged a painful relationship between historian and subject: Mr. Morris's knowledge of the former President was expanding as Mr. Reagan's was contracting. By 1994, shortly after Mr. Reagan announced that he had progressive memory loss because of Alzheimer's disease, Mr. Morris stopped interviewing him.

title: Foreign Affairs; Madeleine's Folly
description: With a U.S. bombing of Iraq now increasingly likely, the question being raised by those uneasy with such a strike is: What is the endgame? Is America just throwing its weight around to punish Saddam Hussein?

title: You Say 2 + 2 Doesn't Equal 4?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELSON, SOL
description: ELSON-Sol. Beloved husband of Ruth (Buffington), devoted father of Jon Elson, Julie Buffington Rizner, Susan Buffington Gilbert. Beloved father in law of Cindy Elson, Russell Rizner and Fred Gilbert. Beloved brother in law of Molly Manealoff. Loving grandfather of eight. For information ''Wien & Wien'' 800-322-0533

title: What to Look For
description: ALPINE SKIING -- MEN'S GIANT SLALOM

title: Congresswoman Angry Over Silence on Scandal
description: As a Kentucky state legislator, Anne M. Northup watched from afar the scandal over Senator Bob Packwood's unwanted sexual advances and worried that her Republican Party was going to defend the indefensible.

title: Finally, CBS Provides Truly Entertaining Moments
description: Critical wretches like me probably need a week to purge ourselves of nasty Olympic barbs before saying pleasant things, like CBS's production of Day 10 of the Winter Games on Sunday night was compelling and well balanced. I say this freely, and not under Akebono's threat to tie my hair into a fetching topknot.

title: Russian Duo Remain Unbeatable
description: The lights went out in the middle of tonight's competition, years after the credibility of ice dancing had gone dark. The losers complained that the judging was as artificial as Pasha Grishuk's hair color. But she and her partner, Yevgeny Platov, provide much of whatever legitimacy still exists in the sport.

title: Corrections
description: The ''Last Week'' listing in the Business Digest yesterday misstated the Dow Jones industrial average, the yield of the 30-year Treasury bond and the value of the dollar against the Japanese yen in some copies. A corrected chart appears today on page D1.

title: Houston Proving to Be an All-Round Man
description: Allan Houston had just put the finishing touches on perhaps his most explosive scoring night since coming to the Knicks, but Coach Jeff Van Gundy did not want to talk about that. Van Gundy instead praised Houston for his eight rebounds and his defense on Wesley Person.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAMPERT, LAURENCE L.
description: LAMPERT-Laurence L. Suddenly on February 14, 1998. Beloved husband of Trudy, loving father of Kimberly. Funeral services private. For information contact ''The Riverside'' at 212-362-6600.

title: Ladybugs Coming to the Rescue of Threatened Hemlocks
description: INEXORABLY, tiny parasitic insects from Asia called woolly adelgids are punching deeply and destructively into the hemlock forests of the Eastern United States. Traveling some 30 miles a year or even faster lately, they have fanned out from Virginia to invade the hemlocks' heartland in northern New England and march down the Blue Ridge into North Carolina and westward into West Virginia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILE, GRACE CARLIN
description: WILE-Grace Carlin. Of Princeton, NJ. Died suddenly in Sanibel, FL, on February 14, 1998. A graduate of Cornell University Class of 1929 with an M.A. from the Teachers College of Columbia University, Ms. Wile was a talented teacher of mathematics and later became an even more talented school administrator. She was the cherished wife of the late Louis D. Wile and is survived by her two devoted daughters, Lenore Wile May and Karen Wile Wright, and their husbands Kenneth and Richard. Devoted and adored grandmother of Diane and Shari May and Louis and Rebecca Wright, beloved sister of Rita Fremont, Estelle Kalstein and the late Benson Carlin, loving, caring aunt to her many nieces and nephews and still found time to be a docent at the Princeton Art Museum for 20 years and a tutor to many students at the International Center. She also supported a myriad of charities. Grace lived up to her nickname, ''Gracious,'' as attested to by her large circle of friends. She loved life and lived it to the hilt, loved to travel, read, play bridge, bird watch and just converse with any of her large circle of friends. She will be rememebered with great love and affection by all who knew her. Services Tuesday, February 17, 1998, at 1:30 pm, at the Princeton Jewish Center, Route 27, Princeton, NJ. Contributions in her name may be made to Princeton Public Library, Witherspoon St.

title: Tellabs to Buy Coherent Systems
description: Tellabs Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Coherent Communications Systems Corporation for $670 million in stock to bolster its presence in overseas markets for phone equipment used to transmit data, video and voice signals.

title: Are teachers looking for fake replicas? Why is Campbell putting a new spin on breakfast?
description: IT'S time again to ask 20 questions about advertising, marketing and the media.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, MORRIS
description: SCHNEIDER-Morris. Central Synagogue of Nassau County sorrowfully announces the passing ot its long time member and past President, and extends to his beloved family its sincerest sympathy. Rabbi Julian I. Cook Judith D. Race, Pres.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YANOW, HELEN VOGEL
description: YANOW-Helen Vogel. February 15, 1998, Laguna Hills, CA. Born in Bayonne, N.J. February 12, 1921, she graduated from NYU and Columbia School of Social Work serving as Hillel Director, Hunter College, in administrative positions at Metropolitan State and McLean Hospitals, Program Officer for Communicative Disorders at JDC-Israel and hospice social worker. She is mourned by her husband, Rabbi Albert, children Dvora, Jonathan, Tamar and Michael and Elisha Breton, Abigail, brother Harold Vogel of Far Rockaway. Contributions to the National Yiddish Book Center, Amherst, MA. or the Reform Temple of Leisure World, Laguna Hills, CA 92653 would be appreciated.

title: Heading Slowly Into the Ice Age; Women's Hockey Is Growing, if Not at Olympic Speed
description: Even though it was a B game, Ali Lemer was totally psyched. The Brooklyn Blades' Thursday night practice had gone well, and Ms. Lemer relishes any opportunity to pile on the layers of pads. ''I think I have some kind of equipment fetish,'' she said. ''Ice hockey is just modernized warfare, isn't it?''

title: Canada Seeks Legal Advice On the Status Of Quebec
description: A momentous legal battle to save Canada was mounted today as the Government challenged the right of Quebec to secede without the agreement of the rest of the country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KINZEL, MADELEINE C.
description: KINZEL-Madeleine C. On February 14, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Otto. Loving mother of Otto III and Robert. Adoring grandmother of Will, Halen, Ethan, Eric, Otto IV, Kristen, Kathryn and Maggie. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Tuesday, 10 AM. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to the Madeleine C. Kinzel Foundation, PO Box 1018, Montpelier, VT 05602.

title: 'View' to Close Briefly, Then Open at Neil Simon
description: The Roundabout Theater Company's critically acclaimed production of Arthur Miller's ''View From the Bridge'' will close on Sunday on the nonprofit company's main stage and then reopen on April 3 for a commercial run at the Neil Simon Theater, where ''The King and I'' is closing on Sunday as well.

title: Over 200 Die as Taiwan Jet Crashes in Bad Weather
description: A China Airlines flight from the Indonesian resort of Bali crashed and burst into flames while trying to land in fog and rain at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in Taipei, Taiwan, this evening, killing all 197 passengers and crew members, including Taiwan's Central Bank governor, and at least 7 people on the ground.

title: Pataki Delivers His First Paid Speech of the Year, for $17,000
description: Gov. George E. Pataki traveled to Florida today to address a group of business executives, the first time this year that he received an honorarium for a speech.

title: Depictions of Art Earn No Protection
description: To the Editor:

title: Scenes From a Marriage
description: From the privacy of marriage there is ultimately no respite, even for poets like Sylvia Plath and Ted Hughes, whose now-distant intimacy has been the subject of unceasing public commentary. Ms. Plath and Mr. Hughes were wed in 1956, two young poets, one American, the other English. They were joined for eternity by Ms. Plath's suicide on Feb. 11, 1963 -- a suicide, it is often alleged, to which she was driven by Mr. Hughes, who had left her, in that oddly reductive phrase, for another woman.

title: INSIDE
description: Sinn Fein Faces Censure

title: Britain Takes Step Toward Ousting I.R.A. Ally at Ulster Talks
description: The British Government moved closer today to temporarily expelling Sinn Fein, the political wing of the I.R.A., from the Northern Ireland peace talks. But after a day of statements and counterstatements at a negotiating session at Dublin Castle, Sinn Fein's status remained unresolved.

title: Wall St. to Pay To Add a Base For the Police
description: In an unusual arrangement allowing private businesses to pay for additional protection from the city police force, Police Commissioner Howard Safir has agreed to open a new police substation in the financial district paid for in part by $5 million from a downtown business group.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, WALTER
description: LEVY-Walter. Husband of Beatrice. Father of Ronald and Fran, Peter and Wendy. Grandfather of Benjamin Julius and Jacob Bartholomew. Brother of Arnold Levy, Arline and Murray Goldfarb. Brother-in-law of Elaine Harris and Anne Green. Services Tuesday, 12 noon at Central Synagogue of Nassau County 430 DeMott Avenue, Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: The Devil? He's a Basso Whose Voice Is Heavenly
description: Where do you keep a lunch date with the devil?

title: By Design/And Let There Be Pink
description: Gray is this spring's neutral, but for a touch of color nothing is more flattering than pink, whether in clothing or makeup.

title: A Chief Chosen By Iroquois Hotel
description: PIERRE ESTOPPEY has gone from the hotel in Washington where he supplied KEVIN COSTNER with Hostess Twinkies to the one in Manhattan that JAMES DEAN made famous (or perhaps infamous). Mr. Estoppey, who managed the Jefferson Hotel in Washington from 1991 to 1994, has taken charge of the Iroquois Hotel at 49 West 44th Street, between Fifth Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas.

title: FRESH HAZARDS -- A special report.; For Oystermen, a Harvest of Risk and Burden
description: Blessed by a gentle breeze, Mitchell and Frank Jurisich stand on the deck of their wide, white fishing boat as it scuds across a Louisiana bayou. Beneath them lies a bed of rock-heavy oysters, ready to be wrestled from the sea, in a rite of harvest handed down three generations.

title: Indonesia Edges Toward a Showdown With IMF
description: SINGAPORE  A confrontation between Indonesia and its main creditors moved closer Monday as Indonesian officials said the government would press ahead with a plan aimed at stabilizing its currency despite opposition to its strategy from the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank, the United States and the European Union.

title: A Dream Come True for Japan
description: Masahiko Harada is known in Japan and everywhere else that ski jumping matters as Smiling Harada.

title: Newspaper In Nashville Dies at 122
description: The Nashville Banner today became the latest casualty in the continuing battle between morning and afternoon newspapers, with the publisher of the afternoon daily announcing that it would close on Friday after 122 years of publication.

title: Bronze Medal for Witty Is a Family Achievement
description: When her father lost his job as a welder 11 years ago after the factory in their hometown, West Allis, Wis., closed, Chris Witty thought she would have to give up speed skating. A 12-year-old redhead, she understood that her skating cost the family money in equipment and travel to meets. And, yes, for the good of the family, she said she would be willing give up her dream of becoming a champion.

title: Bridget Jones? She's Any (Single) Woman, Anywhere
description: She is a 30-something single Londoner with a messy life who dates losers, can't quit smoking and drinks too much but still managed to lose 72 pounds last year. The same year she gained 74.

title: Blues Riffs on a Journey to Africa
description: Jazz performances are fairly ritualized; they start, music is played, and they end. But toward the end of ''Uhuru Afrika'' at the Majestic Theater in Brooklyn, Randy Weston, the composer of the suite, brought out Melba Liston, the orchestrator of the piece, and something exceptional happened.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHN, ARTHUR
description: COHN-Arthur. On February 15, 1998. Beloved husband of Lois. Loving father of Alan, Leslie and Wallace. description: FRANCO-Salvatore. To Carol, Michael, Linda and Chris-Harriet, Cory, Josh, Meredith and I share in your grief. Sal will always be in our hearts and in our minds. All my love, Mike Brown

description: DERHAM-Donald A. On February 14, 1998. Husband of the late Margaret. Beloved father of Timothy and Donald, Jr. Brother of George Derham. Friends may call Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday, 2-5 and 7-10 PM, at the Thomas F. Dalton Funeral Home, 29 Atlantic Ave. (at RR Plaza), Floral Park. title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Instability by the Barrelful?; Central Asia's Coming Oil Bonanza and Its Consequences
description: The economic boom just beginning to reach this energy-rich republic is evident across the capital, from the seaside district of Patandert, with its acres of cliff-top luxury homes under construction, to downtown Baku, its shops crammed with exclusive European clothing and perfume.

title: Shift in Assignments By 3 Marketers
description: Three marketers have made decisions on accounts.

title: Beneficial May Put Itself Up for Sale
description: The Beneficial Corporation, a big consumer finance company based in Wilmington, Del., said yesterday that it intended to explore strategic business alternatives, including, among other things, putting itself up for sale.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, DAVID
description: MILLER-David. As our esteemed and beloved Counsel for more than 20 years, Dave's wisdom, warmth, wit, intelligence, conscience and dignity taught us what great lawyering was about. We were graced and honored to be his friend and colleague. Our love to his beautiful Sally and to Allan and Martha. Squadron, Ellenoff, Plesent & Sheinfeld

title: Scorned No More, Osteopathy Is on the Rise
description: THE new patient in the geriatrics clinic at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan shook Dr. Jan Maby's hand, glanced at her name badge, and submitted to all the usual questions and proddings of an initial medical examination.

title: Brown Leaving With Mixed Feelings
description: Dave Brown left the Giants yesterday, thanking the team's ownership for the opportunity to play and refusing to blame the fans for the harsh treatment he often received. He even thanked his former coach, Dan Reeves, with whom Brown had a prickly three-year relationship.

title: New Tests Are Useless If They Aren't Clear
description: To the Editor:

title: New Prozac Lift: Spawning
description: IT is not clear how the animals felt about the experiment, but a pinch of Prozac seems to be just the thing to get fingernail clams to spawn in synchrony.

title: On My Mind; Prettifying Saddam's Claque
description: For five months Washington's policy makers have been spinning a line about the Iraqi crisis that degrades the interests of the United States, and its remaining friends.

title: Taft Girls Win First City Title
description: Boys and Girls High School of Brooklyn easily captured its sixth straight boys' track and field title yesterday at the Public Schools Athletic League indoor championships in Manhattan.

description: SCHEFF-Ronald W. Ph.D. On Monday, February 16, 1998. Beloved son of Bernard and Frances. Brother of Jerrold. Uncle of Allison and Tiffany and brother-in-law of Barbara. Memorial services to be held at a later date. For more information call 516-285-7890.

title: Mysterious Patterns in Flux
description: Susan Rethorst has become known for choreographing tantalizing enigmas. ''Don't Go Without Your Echo,'' a new work presented on Thursday at the Kitchen, is mysterious to the point of solipsistic impenetrability.

title: Bids for Property Trust Said to Be Due
description: Investors are expected to know as early as tomorrow which of three bidders will acquire Corporate Property Investors, a closely held New York-based real estate investment trust, for an estimated $4.5 billion.

title: Safety Rules for Contact Lenses
description: MY brother, Jeff, depends on extended-wear contact lenses that stay in his eyes, day and night, for one or two weeks. Then he removes them for an overnight cleaning and puts them back in his eyes for another week or so, replacing them with a new pair when they begin to feel uncomfortable.

description: HALVEY-Ellen (Nee Murphy). On February 14, 1998. Dear wife of Edward. Devoted mother of Jenna. Beloved daughter of Mary and George Murphy. Loving sister of Terry, Georgine, Brian and Catherine. Sister-in-law of Shamus. Loving cousin of Alice. Also survived by numerous Aunts, Uncles, Cousins and freinds. title: Police-Uniform Sales Pitch Stirs Inquiry
description: To prevent police impersonations, New York City officers have been required for 50 years to buy their uniforms and insignia patches from the Police Department or from a small group of authorized local dealers.

title: U.S. SEEKS TO LIMIT ROLE OF U.N. CHIEF DURING IRAQ TALKS
description: The United Nations Secretary General, Kofi Annan, is expected to leave this week for Baghdad carrying American guidelines that would limit any diplomatic compromise he might negotiate with Saddam Hussein.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELBY, THELMA
description: SELBY-Thelma. Beloved wife of the late David. Devoted mother of Bruce. Loving mother-in-law of Lynn. Loving sister of Sam and Max Schweid. Cherished grandmother of Mark, Hugh and Kazumi Selby. Services 11AM on Tuesday at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Topics of The Times; New Jersey, A Destination Spot
description: Last week Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey announced that she was reviving the old state tourism slogan ''New Jersey and You: Perfect Together.'' Fourteen years ago that phrase was considered so catchy that Republicans marched around with placards proclaiming that ''New Jersey and Reagan-Bush Are Perfect Together.'' But by the early 1990's the state's promoters had moved on to ''New Jersey: You Should See Us Now,'' implying that things might not have been all that perfect after all.

title: A Boost From Disney
description: For the 12 Major League Soccer teams, it is a small world after all.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Arbitrator Gets Case In Sprewell Hearing
description: His arbitration hearing concluded, Latrell Sprewell's future now rests with John D. Feerick, the dean of Fordham University Law School.

title: Dueling Sexes, With Venom to Spare
description: If there is any work that insures a dramatic experience at the New York City Ballet, it is ''The Cage,'' Jerome Robbins's battle-of-the-sexes allegory about a female tribe that nibbles at males and pulls out their entrails.

title: India Begins Its Voting; More Political Instability Is Feared
description: India began voting today in a general election, a process that Indians proudly refer to as the world's biggest exercise in democracy. But there was great doubt that this election would end the political instability that has dogged India for nearly two years.

title: NASA Readies a 'Mission to Planet Earth'
description: IN a small nondescript room in an equally ordinary low-rise structure just off the Pennsylvania Turnpike, a technician named Dave Banks was speaking into a headset.

description: SHAPIRO-Albert. Goodbye, dear friend. You'll never be forgotten. Your brother, Harold

title: Jakarta Journal; Weighty Past Pins the Wings of a Social Butterfly
description: Editor's Note Appended

title: New Joint Byliners
description: There are New Yorkers who remember SHARON STONE as a young model, hanging out at coffee shops on the Upper East Side and partying at discos. That was the 70's, this is the 90's. Her Valentine's Day marriage to PHIL BRONSTEIN, the executive editor of The San Francisco Examiner, has those same New Yorkers wondering if his newspaper will give her future films better reviews than the one it gave ''The Quick and the Dead'' in 1995: ''Her attempts at playing 'strong women' feel forced and graceless, her sex appeal lacks human warmth and she seems incapable of broadening her acting range.'' That wasn't the only negative review The Examiner has given the new Mrs. Bronstein. Consider this passage in The Examiner's review of ''Diabolique'' in 1996: ''She seems to wear a different pair of sunglasses in every scene. She smokes cigarettes the way they used to, kind of angrily. She looks at ease in lingerie. How could one person have so many talents?'' (For the record, The Examiner liked her performance in ''Basic Instinct,'' calling her ''the only live wire in the movie.'') JAMES BARRON

title: Jordan Fiasco: No Blame Falls On Netanyahu
description: A commission appointed to investigate the bungled attack on a Hamas official in Jordan last fall absolved Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu today of any blame for the fiasco, and endorsed the policy that terrorists can be hit ''wherever they may be.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANDERSON, JANE M.
description: ANDERSON-Jane M. May 23, 1908-February 15, 1998. Editor, writer and painter. Survived by her son Greville Healey, her daughters Stephanie Healey Owen and Jane Anderson Bernstein, seven grandchildren and eleven great grandchildren. Her oldest daughter, Joanna Healey Shurbet died in 1980. Mrs. Anderson was the widow of Cmdr. Clarence M. Anderson, U.S.N.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSMITH, CHARLES
description: GOLDSMITH-Charles. Age 90. Of West Palm Beach, FL, died February 14, 1998 at Good Samaritan Medical Center there. He is survived by Lee, his wife of 60 years, and by son Henry and daughter-inlaw Tessa and was predeceased by his son James Theodore. A 1929 graduate of Dartmouth College, he devoted his career to Metro Goldwyn Mayer Pictures Inc. Starting in 1931 as an Assistant Manager in Brazil, his career spanned 31 years, culminating as Chairman and Managing Director of MGM the United Kingdom. A Memorial Service will be held at 2 PM on Wednesday, February 18th at Fountainview, 101 Executive Center Drive, West Palm Beach, FL. The family suggests that donations may be made to the American Cancer Society in lieu of flowers.

Beloved wife of Professor Nicholas; loving mother of Adam and his wife Dorothea, Professor Amy R. Wolfson and her husband Professor Andrew Futterman; sister of Daniel; and cherished grandmother of Noah David Futterman. Funeral services February 18, 1998 at 2:30PM at Beth El Temple, 2626 Albany Avenue, West Harford, CT.

Loving grandmother of Ronnie, Marc, Marcy, Debbie, Eric and Gary and great grandmother of seven. Service 1pm today at ''Wien and Wien'' 129 Engle St., Englewood, NJ.

title: Spanish Company Is a Star Of Volkswagen's Universe
description: Managers at SEAT S.A., the Volkswagen auto maker in Spain, miscalculated when their new $2 billion factory opened near here in 1993 in the midst of a European economic slump, giving them the capacity to produce 50 percent more cars than they could sell.

title: The Next Electronics Breakthrough: Carbon Atoms
description: SCIENTISTS experimenting with a fascinating speck of matter called a single-walled carbon nanotube predict that this elegantly geometrical molecule is about to ignite a revolution in electronics, computers, chemistry and new structural materials.

description: To the Editor:

title: A Drive to Find Sites Of Underground Railroad
description: Wheatley's Burlington Pharmacy has helped remedy many ills since it opened in 1841, even slavery. Runaway slaves were allowed to take refuge in its basement, one of several New Jersey stops on the Underground Railroad that operated through the Civil War. Now, state and Federal officials want to help the state's Historical Commission identify those stops.

title: You Say 2 + 2 Doesn't Equal 4?
description: To the Editor:

title: Hyman Glickstein, 91, Dies; Lawyer and Political Leader
description: Hyman Nathan Glickstein, a retired Manhattan lawyer and businessman and an activist in New York City politics of the 1930's, died last Thursday at the Greenwich Woods Health Care Center in Greenwich, Conn. He was 91 and formerly lived in Manhattan, Scarsdale, N.Y., and Hollywood, Fla.

title: Asians Worry That U.S. Aid Is a New Colonialism
description: From America it may seem as if the United States is rescuing Asia from its economic mess, but gratitude is not the most striking emotion here in the region.

title: Independent Video Stores Survive Within the Niches
description: It has been a decade since Blockbuster Video marched into the New York area, routing dozens of older video rental chains and independent stores as easily as Sherman did the Rebels in Georgia.

title: Currency Is Devalued by Vietnam As Effects of Asian Crisis Spread
description: Vietnam today became the latest Southeast Asian country to devalue its currency, as Asia's financial turmoil showed signs of pummeling even the most protected regional markets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YAVERBAUM, ARNOLD. MD.
description: YAVERBAUM-Arnold. MD. The Trustees, physicians and staff of Beth Israel Medical Center (BI) and St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center (SLR) join with the Board of Trustees and administration of their parent corporation, Greater Metropolitan Health Systems (GMHS), Inc., in acknowledging with sadness the passing of Arnold Yaverbaum, MD, beloved fatherin-law of our dear colleague, Kathryn Meyer, Esq., Senior Vice President and General Counsel for BI and SLR. Dr. Yaverbaum served as a member of the medical staff at BI's Kings Highway Division for over forty years. To Kathy, her husband Harvey, her mother-inlaw Justine, and the entire Yaverbaum family we extend our heartfelt condolences. Morton P. Hyman, Chairman, Board of Trustees, GMHS Lawrence S. Huntington, Vice Chairman, GMHS Robert G. Newman, MD, President and CEO, GMHS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEBENS, HENRY J.
description: LEBENS-Henry J. Age 84, of Ft. Lee, NJ and Pompano Beach, FL, passed away after a short debilitating illness. Beloved husband of Roslyn for 56 years. Loving father of Leslie Davies and Donna Epstein. Devoted father-in-law of Michael Davies and Dr. Mitchell Epstein. Cherished grandfather of Jessica Pell, Lauren and Matthew Epstein. He loved life and lived it to the fullest. We will miss our Henny and his incredible spirit.

title: Jacques Robert, 83, of French Resistance
description: Jacques Robert, a key leader of the Resistance in France in World War II, died on Feb. 8, Le Monde reported on Saturday. He was 83.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, JAMES E.
description: GREENBERG-James E. Age 99. Of West Palm Beach, FL. Died Saturday, February 14, 1998. Loving husband of Betty, cherished by Debby and Rusty, his grandchildren Elaine, David, Lorre and Douglas, great grandchildren Daniel, Russell and Vanessa, Stephen and Alice Carb, and their children Brian, Evan, Alison, Daniel, Alexander and Laura. His kindness and warmth will live in the hearts of everyone who knew him. Expressions of sympathy may be made to the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith.

title: Rejecting the Usual Caution, Briton, 23, Wins at Hastings
description: In decisively winning the 73d running of England's traditional Hastings International Tournament, Matthew Sadler spurned the dependable Capablanca routine of chewing up the bottom of the field and playing conservatively against the chief rivals. The 23-year-old English grandmaster mowed down the next four players and then drew four and won one against the last five players, thus tallying 7-2. When the Dec. 29-to-Jan. 11 event ended, there was a gap of a point and a half between him and the two players who tied for second.

title: The Neediest Cases; Mother's Love Defies Crippling Disease
description: Hazel Olivere had no idea what was wrong that August morning in 1989 when she went to pick up her six-pound baby and found that she was not strong enough.

description: LAFFAN-Robert. Age 92, on February 15, 1998 at the Cenacle. Beloved husband of the late Dorothy. Cherished father of Sister Mary Jane Laffan, r.c. and Joyce Mulholland. Fond grandfather of Martha, Sarah and John. Funeral Mass 10 a.m. Wednesday at the Cenacle. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers contributions in Bob's memory may be made to the Cenacle, 310 Cenacle Road,. Ronkonkoma, NY 11779

title: A Reluctant Ally Is Caught in a Sensitive Position
description: The likelihood that United States combat planes in Saudi Arabia would remain grounded during any American-led strike on Iraq is a reminder of the sensitivities that lie beneath the Saudi-American partnership.

title: Lean Diet in Childhood May Cut Risk of Cancer
description: PARENTS who worry about the fact that their children seem to be ''living on air'' may be reassured by the findings of an unusual study of nearly 4,000 youngsters who grew up in England more than half a century ago. As long as the children's families were reasonably prosperous, those whose diets were lean on calories were less likely as adults to develop cancers unrelated to smoking.

title: Anthem Health in Sale Talks With Canadian Insurer's Unit
description: Anthem Health, an insurer with headquarters in Piscataway, N.J., has begun discussions on a sale of its business to the United States subsidiary of a big Canadian insurer, in another illustration of the consolidation that is sweeping the health insurance industry.

title: Topics of The Times; The Senate's Judicial Farce
description: For nearly two years, a handful of conservative Republicans held up the confirmation of Margaret Morrow as a Federal district judge in California. They cited only flimsy evidence against her -- snippets from speeches and articles that had been compiled by a conservative lobbying group to bolster its ludicrous charge that President Clinton was filling the courts with out-of-control judges.

description: The Knicks are continuing their serious pursuit of Kenny Anderson, who has yet to report to the Raptors after a trade that sent him to Toronto and Damon Stoudamire to Portland.

title: Bags Packed, Air Force Families Try Not to Think About Next War

But as military strikes against Iraq become more likely, Jenice Leonard, an Air Force wife for 19 years, develops a strategy of her own: to remain calm and remember that the cause is good.

title: Corrections

He is Yossef Bodansky, not Yousef.

description: The court-martial of Sgt. Maj. Gene C. McKinney on charges of sexual misconduct brings to mind the old saw that military justice is to justice as military music is to music.

title: New Company Seeks Wider Role for Old Technology
description: A computer designer who earned an international reputation for renegade innovation at the International Business Machines Corporation says he has found a way to take advantage of 30-year-old research with analog communications to offer low-cost, high-speed alternatives to today's digital networks.

title: A Czech's Anguished Response to Munich
description: Before the concert by the New York Chamber Symphony on Saturday night at Alice Tully Hall, it was announced from the stage that attendance at this season's events was running at 91 percent. This good report, I would suggest, is due to the interesting programming of the group's longtime music director, the conductor Gerard Schwarz.

title: Hoffman: A Fresh Face Even as Age Catches Up; Actor's Options Narrow, Yet the Roles He Plays Are Getting Stronger
description: After lunch in a Japanese restaurant in a mini-mall on the fringe of Brentwood, Dustin Hoffman was happily posing outside in the rain for a photo with several parking lot attendants. A Japanese tourist looked on with puzzlement at first, then enlightenment.
