title: New Sonata Spins a Web of Dissimilarities
description: Joel Krosnick, introducing from his cellist's chair the new work by Ralph Shapey that he and Gilbert Kalish were about to play at Miller Theater on Thursday evening, spoke of how the composer had been ''singing his heart out for 50 years.'' The performance, and the work, justified the remark. Aptly titled ''Sonata Appassionata,'' the piece is not particularly long, though it played for three or four minutes more than Mr. Shapey's duration, carefully stipulated in the score, of ''Approx. 17' 48''.'' What it packs into that space, however, is all big.

title: Social Insecurity
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIAMS, LILLIAN
description: WILLIAMS-Lillian. On February 15, 1998. Loving wife of the late Isidore, adored mother of Marilyn, Teddy, and the late Joan. Grandchildren Ilise, Ilene, Jimmy, Andrew and Mark, also her beloved brothers Morty and Jesse. Funeral service Wednesday, February 18, 12:30 PM, Riverside Memorial Chapel.

title: This Time, Japan Soars to a Gold Medal
description: MAKING AMENDS -- At Lillehammer in 1994, Masahiko Harada lost his nerve and lost a sure gold medal for Japan. Today he soared to a hill record, and Kazuyoshi Funaki's stylish final jump gave Japan the victory in team ski jumping that it should have had four years ago. Page C1.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZABITZ, MILTON
description: ZABITZ-Milton. 71. On February 15, 1998 of Danville, PA. Formerly of Hoboken, NJ. Beloved husband of Esther Ann (nee Waldman). Devoted father of Barbara, Judith, Hannah and Mark. Proud grandfather of five. Dearest brother of Ralph. Information 717-323-6114.

title: Magic Uniforms?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Morning After, Clinton's Budget Doesn't Look So Promising for New Yorkers
description: The budget that President Clinton presented to Congress earlier this month was generously stocked with new programs that would pay for new teachers, child care and food stamps, and not surprisingly it won early bipartisan plaudits from officials in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, CAROL PETRY
description: GOLDMAN-Carol Petry of Tequesta, FL, passed away, Thursday, February 12, 1998 at the Jupiter Medical Center, Jupiter, FL. Born in New York City, she had been a resident of Tequesta for 15 years, coming from Greenwich, CT. She was a member of the Turtle Creek Country Club, the Turtle Creek Ladies Golf Assoc. and was a past officer of the Tequesta Chapter of the American Needlepoint Guild. She is survived by two sons, LeGrand Snowden Redfield, Jr. of Norwalk, CT and Edward Petry Redfield of Boston, MA; a daughter, Elizabeth Kehoe Petry Goldman of Stratford, CT; a sister, Barbara Petry Annear of Palm Beach Gardens, FL; a grandson, Harley Ellis Petry Redfield and a nephew, William J. Mathews, III. She will be sorely missed by all who knew and loved her. The funeral service will be held, 3PM Sunday, February 15, 1998 at the Aycock Funeral Home Chapel, Jupiter. Interment will be in Woodlawn Cemetery, Bronx, NY. Friends may call Sunday, February 15, from 11-3PM at the Aycock Funeral Home, 1112 Military Trail, Jupiter, FL.

title: Fleming Finds Boring Stretching Is a Bit of Heaven
description: There is nothing outwardly glorious about the first days of spring training. Pitchers stretch, throw, field some grounders, run and sweat before stretching again. Within a day or two some veterans will openly profess their boredom.

title: Florida Case Highlights Conflicts On Use of the Bible as a Textbook
description: In his public high school classroom here, Mark Axford, a history teacher, was gingerly telling his new students what the course would entail. He was being cautious because the subject was the Old Testament, the textbook the Bible, and every word he said was being videotaped for review by lawyers and a Federal judge in a pioneering legal case.

title: THE XVIII WINTER GAMES: WOMEN'S FIGURE SKATING PREVIEW: Chasing Gold At Varied Paces; Lipinsky and Kwan Approach Their Showdown Differently
description: If they awarded a gold medal for having fun at the Winter Olympics, Tara Lipinski would be the hands-down winner.

title: A Descendant Of Dreyfus Remembers
description: SIMONE PERL looked at the drawing for the umpteen-thousandth time, an ink sketch from a century ago showing her grandmother by an empty armchair, with a little girl and boy to her right. The girl, Jeanne, was Mrs. Perl's mother, at age 6. For the moment, though, the focus was not on her but on that vacant chair.

title: Review Is Started By Chase Manhattan
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation has begun an agency review involving assignments with billings estimated at $40 million.

title: Abandoned Cars Lead To Insurance Crackdown
description: The police in Newark said yesterday that they had begun working with insurance companies to catch an increasingly common breed of criminal: owners who destroy or abandon their cars to collect insurance.

title: Market Place; No Sales, but Watch the Stock Soar
description: Wall Street's Terren Peizer is like Woody Allen's Zelig: he shows up in some of the oddest places.

title: 2 Years After Beating Outside Nightclub, a Trial Is Set to Begin
description: Nearly two years ago, an off-duty New York City police officer and a drinking companion became involved in a brawl in the parking lot of a Long Island nightclub that ended in the near-fatal beating of a young black man.

title: Maine Law Gave No 'Special Rights'
description: To the Editor:

title: Unaffiliated Jews
description: To the Editor:

title: Rauschenberg Works Seized
description: Fifteen works of art by Robert Rauschenberg were removed on Friday from the walls of the Menil Collection in Houston by deputies carrying out a court order in a suit against the artist by a creditor.

title: McMullen's Progress Is as Fast as the Pace
description: In Friday night's Chase Millrose Games in Madison Square Garden, the three leaders in the Wanamaker Mile passed the first quarter-mile in 56 seconds. It seemed suicidally fast, but no one appeared worried.

title: Jury Gets Case of Midshipman Charged in Killing
description: A jury began deliberations today in the trial of a 20-year-old former Naval Academy midshipman charged with kidnapping and murdering a high school girl who had had sex with the midshipman's boyfriend.

title: Linking Infection to Heart Disease
description: INFECTIONS in the mouth may play havoc elsewhere in the body, leading to blood clots that can bring on heart attacks and strokes, researchers reported yesterday.

title: A Fifth Straight Confidence-Builder for the Nets
description: The Milwaukee Bucks made so many mistakes tonight that the Nets couldn't help but capitalize.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHUMANN, MAURICE
description: SCHUMANN-Maurice. We express our deep sympathy to the family of Maurice Schumann and, in particular, to his daughter Laurence Schumnn Heckscher, her husband Stephen Hackscher, and their children Benjamin, Timothy and Olivia. Maurice Schumann was a voice of freedom and dignity on his side of the Atlantic as Laurence's late father-in-law, August Heckscher was a voice of faith and hope on this side of the ocean. May the values of civilization that Maurice Schumann and August Heckscher articulated by their words and courage continue to inspire all of us. Hilde Huston Francis X. Morrissey, Jr.

title: Metro Business; French Bank Taking Lexington Ave. Site
description: Amid a shortage of large blocks of corporate office space in Manhattan, six floors at 560 Lexington Avenue, a 22-story tower at the corner of 50th Street, have been rented quietly and quickly to Societe Generale, the French bank.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Americans Show Signs Of Tapping Brakes on Debt

title: Black-White Income Inequalities
description: The income gap between black and white families closed slightly between 1993 and 1996, according to the White House's Council of Economic Advisers. But the gap remains huge and may have only temporarily receded. Indeed, black and Hispanic families are further behind whites today than they were 20 years ago. The yawning gaps between rich and poor and between blacks and whites are not going away anytime soon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELD, PHILIP ALAN
description: FELD-Philip Alan. On February 14th, 1998, of NYC. Beloved son of Harold B. and Phyllis Feld. Loving brother of Scott Feld and Leslie Simpson. Caring uncle of Jeremy Simpson. Service Tuesday, 12:30 PM, at Clark Associates Funeral Home, Katonah. Interment Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, NY.

title: Ambitious Entrepreneurs Planning to Send Tourists Into 'Astronaut Altitude'
description: In the Stanford Alumni Association winter travel brochure, listings for walking tours in Tuscany, cruises to the Galapagos Islands and whale watching in Mexico compete with the latest frontier in adventure travel: outer space.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLESSER, FRANCES ''FRANKIE''
description: SCHLESSER-Frances ''Frankie''. Loving wife of the late Saul Schlesser. Beloved mother of Jill and Ron Rosenberg, Penny and Mac Matchton. Adoring grandmother of Liz, Peter, Jordan, Marly and Dean and great-grandmother of Jack. Funeral will be Wednesday, noon, at Riverside Nassau North, Great Neck.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORELLI, MILLIE (NEE CIRIEGIO)
description: MORELLI-Millie (nee Ciriegio) On Feb. 16, 1998. Loving wife of the late Peter J. Cherished mother of Benedict P. Morelli. Loving mother-in-law of Arlene. Devoted grandmother of Justin and Alexander. Reposing at Andrew Torregrossa and Sons, 345 Avenue U, Brooklyn, NY. Funeral Mass Friday 9:30am Saints Simon and Jude RC Church. Interment Greenwood Cemetery. Viewing Wednesday and Thursday 2-5 and 7-10pm.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THORNTON, SUSAN H.
description: THORNTON-Susan H. On Saturday, February 14. Of Selden, L.I. Devoted wife of Richard Thornton and loving daughter of William Schnautz. She is a former employee of ITT Corp. World Headquarters, NYC. Funeral from the David T. Ferguson Funeral Home, 20 North St, Washingtonville, NY, on Wednesday, February 18, at 9 AM. A mass of Christian burial will be offered at St Mary's Church, Washingtonville, at 10 AM. The interment will follow at St Mary's Cemetery. Friends may call on Tuesday from 2-4 and 7-9 PM.

title: Starr Faces Obstacles in His Efforts to Question Lawyers and Secret Service Members
description: As the Whitewater prosecutor, Kenneth W. Starr, begins a fourth week of presenting evidence to a Federal grand jury on Tuesday, he faces new obstacles in his effort to question witnesses who might have information about President Clinton's relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HELLER, MARVIN
description: HELLER-Marvin 75th birthday. Always with us. Bobby, Laurie & Rita and Grandchildren

title: Once a Fan, Leiter Is Ready to Be a Met
description: The first major league game Al Leiter's father took him to was on opening day 1970 at Shea Stadium, the season after the Mets' first World Series championship.

title: Quarterback Options Slip Away for Jets
description: Everyone outside of the Jets' organization seems to believe that Neil O'Donnell's two-year fling at quarterback has ended. But while the fate of several other quarterbacks has been decided in the first few days of free agency, the Jets do not seem to be actively searching for anyone else. And if they decide to go with Glenn Foley as the starter, they certainly would need an experienced backup. O'Donnell would seem to fit the bill.

title: Psychiatric Drugs Are Now Promoted Directly to Patients
description: Using tactics that were unheard of a few years ago, the pharmaceutical industry is increasingly marketing mental health drugs directly to consumers.

title: Maine Law Gave No 'Special Rights'; Not a Clear Victory
description: To the Editor:

title: Malamute Moves Closer to a Parting Prize
description: A tiny toy poodle imported from Japan, a flirtatious Norwich terrier who found herself a German-bred husband just before this show began, a 55-pound cumulus cloud of a standard poodle, and a hard-driving malamute were the quartet of group winners who survived the opening day and night of judging at the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show at Madison Square Garden.

title: For Ohioans, Hussein Must Go, But Bombs May Not Be the Way
description: Wearing the annoyed look of a man recalling a half-forgotten enemy, Paul Ward, a retired accountant, put down his shopping bag at the mall and pondered whether America should bomb Iraq.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARRER, SIDNEY
description: BARRER-Sidney, of Reading, PA, on February 15, 1998. Former member of the President's Council of U.S. Industries Inc. and past President and owner of Talbot Knitting Mills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPIEGEL, DAVID
description: SPIEGEL-David. On February 15, 1998. Loved and respected father and father-in-law of Fred and Ruth. Will be sadly missed by his grandchildren Stephen and Heather, his brother Sol and his aunt Elsa. Services at ''The Riverside'', 180 West 76 Street, NYC Wednesday, February 18th, 11:45AM.

title: Improved Hand-Held Computers Work Better, but at a Price
description: ONE reason Microsoft's Windows CE operating system instantly became known as Wince was that using the first CE hand-held computers could be characterized as a form of abuse. After a session with the cramped keyboards and murky screens, your hands hurt and you worried about going blind.

title: Loan-Rate Discrimination Case Is Settled by Long Island Bank
description: A Long Island bank has reached a $3 million settlement of allegations that some borrowers who are members of minority groups were charged inflated interest rates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ULRICH, LILLIAN C.
description: ULRICH-Lillian C. Homemaker, philanthropist. Beloved mother of Robert and the late Arthur, dear wife of the late Samuel, cherished Grandmother of Stephanie, Corey, Courtney and Spencer, mother-inlaw of Eleanor, and deeply loved sister of the late Jerome, and David Cavell, and Beatrice Schwimmer and their families. Devoted daughter of Max and Sarah Cohen. She lived to become the matriarch of her family, spending her lifetime supporting charitable causes which included her synagogue, Hadassah, Sisterhood, Woman's American ORT, the American Cancer Society, and the Cerebral Palsy Association. Lillian, you taught us well, We will do honor to your memory. Services Wednesday at 1PM at the Parkside Funeral Chapel, Queens Blvd. Shiva will be observed at the home of Eleanor Ulrich from Wednesday through Friday afternoon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRODSKY, BERNARD
description: BRODSKY-Bernard. MD. Psychoanalyst. 84. Died suddenly on February 12, 1998 while swimming in the Caribbean. Beloved husband of Marilyn. Loving father of Nina, Laura and Mary and fatherin-law of Kenneth Roth and Stuart Zura. Adoring grandfather of Lisa and Emma Roth. His passion for life and art, his probing intellect, his dedication to his patients and his love for family and friends, will be warmly remembered and greatly missed. A Memorial Service, Sunday March 1st, 2:30pm at Frank Campbell Funeral Chapel 1076 Madison Ave, NYC.

title: Newark Buy-Back Plan Collects 213 Guns
description: A week ago, the Newark Police Department started paying gun owners to turn in their weapons. Yesterday, the department announced they had collected 213 firearms at a cost of $15,725.

title: Prospect of U.S. Raids on Iraq Stirs a Protest in Times Square
description: Hundreds of soaked and shivering protesters picketed the United States armed forces recruiting station in Times Square in drizzling rain last night, in what organizers vowed was part of an intensifying campaign of demonstrations against the prospect of military action against Iraq.

title: Whyte Gets the Last Word, Along With the Last Goal
description: IN a country where what isn't said can be more important than what actually is, what Sandra Whyte of the United States told Danielle Goyette of Canada will remain an unsolved mystery of the Nagano Games. The Canadian coach, Shannon Miller, implied after a game last Saturday night that Whyte had slandered Goyette's recently deceased father.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GROSS, GERTRUDE
description: GROSS-Gertrude. Dear Gertrude, we love you and miss you. Always. Ruby, Joan, Ken, Jonathan and Donald.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, DAVID
description: MILLER-David. As our esteemed and beloved Counsel for more than 20 years, Dave's wisdom, warmth, wit, intelligence, conscience and dignity taught us what great lawyering was about. We were graced and honored to be his friend and colleague. Our love to his beautiful Sally and to Allan and Martha. Squadron, Ellenoff, Plesent & Sheinfeld

title: Metro Business; Hilton to Buy Luxury Hotel
description: The Hilton Hotels Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire a luxury hotel in New Jersey for more than $90 million.

title: G.E. Unit Forms Link To Japanese Life Insurer
description: GE Financial Assurance, a subsidiary of the General Electric Company, plans to form a life insurance joint venture in Japan with the financially troubled Toho Mutual Insurance Company, the companies said today. A link between the companies had been expected since the G.E. unit said two weeks ago that they were in talks.

title: Journal; Clinton's Travolta Fever
description: The Clintons' first overnight guests in the Lincoln Bedroom were Harry Thomason and Linda Bloodworth-Thomason, creators of the sitcom ''Designing Women.'' Who would've guessed that there was nowhere to go but down?

title: Egypt's Leader Warns of Anti-U.S. Ire
description: Anti-American protests broke out today at Cairo's largest university as top Egyptian officials gave new warnings that United States policy toward Iraq was undermining America's standing in the region.

title: Textile Maker to Close South Carolina Mill
description: Springs Industries said today that it would close its textile mill in Rock Hill, dismiss about 480 workers and take a $23 million pretax charge.

title: Wine Talk; Microbrew Generation Just Won't Pop the Cork
description: TIMES have been good for the California wine industry of late. Consumption has risen for the last five years, retail prices are up and demand is so high for some wines that only customers who have signed up in advance can hope to buy them.

title: U.S. INDUSTRIES TO BUY ZURN FOR $555 MILLION
description: U.S. Industries agreed yesterday to acquire the industrial equipment maker Zurn Industries for $555 million in stock. Each Zurn share will be swapped for 1.6 shares of U.S. Industries. U.S. Industries will also assume $210 million in debt. Shares of Zurn jumped $4.8125 yesterday, to $41.875. U.S. Industries fell $1.0625 a share, to $26.625. Zurn, based in Erie, Pa., makes plumbing, heating, ventilation and air-conditioning products and fire protection systems. U.S. Industries, based in Iselin, N.J., makes a wide range of consumer and industrial products, including Jacuzzi whirlpools.

title: Moral: Even an Amoral Rat May Be Lovable
description: Never underestimate the entertainment value of the industriously amoral. Consider the extraordinary popularity of serial killers in paperback novels, of coldblooded double agents in big-budget movies. Or more to the matter at hand, of Hollywood producers, as reinvented in the American drama by those who have known them firsthand.

title: Sips; It's Light, Feminine, Silky and It's Still Whisky
description: LIKE the Scots themselves, single-malt Scotch whisky has often been presented in caricature: smoky, meaty, dense, chewy. These are the adjectives of praise, as though hoisting a glass of whisky should be the equivalent of a caber toss. There is another way. Travelers exhausted from hacking their way through the Highlands, or dizzy from inhaling Islay's tangy, seaweed-iodine fragrance, can head for the Lowlands, home of Scotland's most delicate, restrained malts.

title: Norwegian Wins 7th Gold
description: A victory in a cross-country relay gave Bjorn Dahlie Winter Olympic records for gold and total medals. Americans swept the golds in freestyle aerials. Page C1.

title: BELL SPORTS AGREES TO BE BOUGHT BY HB ACQUISITION
description: The Bell Sports Corporation, a maker of bicycle helmets, agreed yesterday to be acquired for $10.50 a share, or about $171.2 million in cash, by a company formed by two investment funds. The agreement marks the end of Bell Sports' search for a way to raise its stock price. The HB Acquisition Corporation, formed by the investment funds Harvard Private Capital Holdings Inc. and Brentwood Associates Buyout Fund II L.P., will pay $10.50 for each of Bell Sports' 13.9 million common shares outstanding and 2.4 million shares subject to stock options and other stock-based awards. Under the agreement, Bell Sports will also be recapitalized. Shares of the company, which is based in San Jose, Calif., rose $1 yesterday, to $10.

title: State High Court Upholds Justice's Removal
description: New York State's highest court today upheld the removal of an acting Supreme Court justice in Manhattan for making lewd comments about a female intern and lying about the incident to a judicial selection panel.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Suharto Defies I.M.F., Removing Central Banker

title: Hewlett-Packard Reports Flat Earnings for Quarter
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company reported essentially flat quarterly earnings today, results that fell slightly short of analysts' expectations as pricing pressure in the company's core computer and printer businesses offset strong sales growth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBAUM, AARON
description: ROSENBAUM-Aaron, 100 years old. Died February 17, 1998. Gentle philosopher and dearest father of Anita, devoted brother of Thelma, wonderful grandfather of Dan and Zach, loving great-grandfather of Lucy and Ethan, caring uncle to a warm family, dear friend of Bob and Margaret. Services at 12 PM on Thursday at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Critic's Notebook; The Voice Is What Counts, Not the Color of the Skin
description: When the Chicago Lyric Opera was assembling a cast for its premiere production of the Anthony Davis opera ''Amistad,'' which ran through last month, the company faced a choice and a challenge.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAVERMAN, SYLVIA (COOKIE)
description: BRAVERMAN-Sylvia (Cookie) of New Rochelle, NY. on February 17. Beloved wife of Harry. Devoted mother of Nancy Berlin and George Braverman. Cherished grandmother of Louis and Rachel. She will always be in our hearts and will be remembered with deepest love. She was truly a wonderful human being. Service Thursday 1:30pm at Riverside, 21 W Broad ST, Mt Vernon, NY.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR RALLIES. The dollar rose against the Japanese yen for the fifth consecutive day as traders became more skeptical of the Japanese Government's ability to turn the economy around. In New York, the dollar finished at 126.65 yen, up from 125.20 Friday.

title: U S West to Ask F.C.C. Permission to Build Big Data Network
description: The U S West Communications Group plans to ask Federal regulators for permission to build a big new data network, executives close to the company said yesterday, joining a new attack on rules that keep the Bell local telephone companies out of the $80 billion long-distance market.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOCH, RABBI ABRAHAM
description: BLOCH-Rabbi Abraham. The New York Board of Rabbis mourns the passing of its longtime member. May Heaven console his family and congregants. Rabbi Marc Schneier, President Rabbi G.S. Rosenthal, Exec. VP

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHN, ARTHUR
description: COHN-Arthur. The Board of Directors, Officers and Staff of Carl Fischer, Inc., mourn he passing of our distinguished friend and colleague, Arthur Cohn. As Director of Serious Music for the firm since 1973, Arthur had an enormous impact on the growth and development of the Fischer Catalogue. As a performed and published composer, conductor, and the author of numerous books on music, his importance to the musical community cannot be overstated. We join with his many associates throughout the music world in saluting the life of this extraordinary man, and extend to his beloved wife, Lois, and the rest of his family, our deepest sympathy. Charles Abry, President Carl Fischer, Inc

title: In Las Vegas, Top Restaurants Are the Hot New Game
description: WELCOME to bad taste city. Tackytown. Vulgarville.

title: El Nino's Storms Wreak Havoc With Florida's Tourist Season
description: The long reach of El Nino has cast a shadow across the Sunshine State, causing concern that the impending heart of the tourist season in Florida will be as wet and windy as the last several weeks.

title: Norwich Terrier Is Rated Best in Westminster Judging
description: It was a hard day's night, in fact there were two of them, but after 48 hours of hard-core human judging, the 2,500 polished entrants were whittled to seven finalists last night at the Westminster Kennel Club dog show. And wouldn't you know it, the most productive show dog in the nation for 1997, the perky Norwich Terrier Ch. Fairewood Frolic, was judged best in show at Madison Square Garden.

title: What to Look for
description: ALPINE SKIING -- WOMEN'S SLALOM

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONAHUE, JOHN F.
description: DONAHUE-John F. of Point Lookout, N.Y. (formerly of Garden City) on February 16, 1998. Devoted husband of Mary (nee Ryan). Beloved father of Patrick, Mark, Jane and Ann. Proud grandfather of James and Genevieve. Dear brother of Mary Paffrath, James and Joseph Donahue. Reposing Charles J. O'Shea Funeral Home, 603 Wantagh Ave. (exit 28N SS Pkwy) Wantagh. Funeral mass Thursday, 10AM, Our Lady of the Miraculous Medal, R.C. Church, Point Lookout. Interment Calverton National Cemetery. Family will receive friends Wednesday 2-5 and 7-10 PM.

title: Plotting That's Not in the Script
description: ''I'm telling you, I'm telling you, I'm not worried in the least!'' exclaims one of the major players in ''Moon Over Broadway,'' the new documentary tribute to euphemism, spin, flop sweat and culture clash that opens today at the Film Forum. As captured delectably by the eminent team of D. A. Pennebaker and Chris Hegedus, the backstage machinations behind the Broadway show ''Moon Over Buffalo'' become material as rich as what the filmmakers found in ''The War Room.'' And they're not much less political, either.

title: THE XVIII WINTER GAMES: ROUNDUP; Koreans Surge In Short-Track
description: The South Korean fans at the White Hat arena in Nagano, Japan, had perfect timing last night. So did the five South Korean short-track speed skaters who won two gold medals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REINER, WILLIAM W.
description: REINER-William W. 94. Retired attorney, on February 10. Resided in Canton (Boston) MA; formerly of Prague and New York. Husband of the late Edith Bohrer, brother of the late Paul Reiner and the late Mitzi Pick, father of Tom and Marty, grandfather of Salem, Lisa and Jesse.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARDNER, DR. THOMAS JEFFERSON
description: GARDNER-Dr. Thomas Jefferson. Professor Emeritus at Baruch College of the City of New York. Died February 13, 1998, at New York Hospital. Memorial services Thursday, February 19, at 6PM, at the Community Church of New York, 40 East 35th St., NYC.

title: Jordan Is Angered by Israeli Findings on Assassination Fiasco
description: Jordanians reacted angrily today to an Israeli commission's report that absolved the Israeli Prime Minister of blame in an assassination attempt against a Jordanian citizen in Amman.

title: Treasury Prices Up Sharply in Rally Linked to Asian Events
description: Treasury securities rose sharply yesterday, pushing long-term yields to the lowest level in more than a month, in a rally powered by new turmoil in Indonesia and data suggesting that Asia's economic problems have slowed United States growth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREEN, EDNA REINHERZ
description: GREEN-Edna Reinherz. Age 99. On February 15, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Mortimer J. Green. Devoted mother of Robert and Donald. Dear mother-in-law of Estelle and Carol Green. Cherished grandmother of Michael, Peter, Margaret, Matthew, Sara and Mark. Loving great-grandmother of Quinn. Service Thursday 10AM at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Interment at Shaaray Pardes Cemetery, Easthampton, LI

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, ANTON
description: ROSENBERG-Anton, 71, of Woodstock, NY and NYC, died February 14, 1998. Beloved husband of Joan for over 40 years; loving father of Shaun, Jeremy and Matthew; and father-in-law of Anne, Claudia and Kerry. Anton was a close friend to some of his generation's most influential artists including: Zoot Sims, Gregory Corso and Mason Hoffenberg. Some will remember him as ''The Angel of The Subterraneans.'' He will be forever remembered for his gentle charm, artistic diversity, wacky inventions, ascerbic wit and selfless concern for others. His love will be missed by all. For information on the memorial service, please call (718) 432-3016.

title: Metro Business; Cablevision On-Line Unit
description: The Cablevision Systems Corporation of Woodbury, L.I., announced yesterday that it had selected a small SoHo new-media company, Studio Now, to create original content for its new online service, Optimum Online.

title: Health Experts Oppose Legal Protection for Tobacco Industry
description: Two of the nation's leading authorities on public health, C. Everett Koop, the former Surgeon General, and David A. Kessler, former Commissioner of Food and Drugs, said today that they opposed giving tobacco companies protection against lawsuits.

title: FRANCHISE FINANCE AGREES TO SELL 8% STAKE TO INVESTOR
description: The Franchise Finance Corporation of America said yesterday that it had agreed to sell an 8 percent stake to Colony Capital Inc. for $100 million, to increase its ability to provide real estate financing to fast-food restaurants and other businesses. Colony, an investment firm in Los Angeles, will also get warrants to buy an additional 3 percent stake in Franchise Finance, which is based in Scottsdale, Ariz. Franchise Finance provides real estate financing to more than 2,500 restaurants, convenience stores and automotive parts and services outlets in 47 states. Its clients include Arby's, Burger King, Taco Bell and Wendy's. Colony Capital has invested in more than $4.5 billion of real estate and related assets.

title: Man Charged With Sabotage Of Computers
description: A computer programmer who was dismissed from his job at a New Jersey engineering company has been charged with planting a computer ''bomb'' that deleted software critical to the company's operations and caused the loss of more than $10 million in sales and contracts, according to court papers unsealed yesterday.

title: Rangers' Campbell Will Be Dismissed
description: Less than a year ago, Colin Campbell was rewarded with a contract extension after coaching the Rangers to a surprising upset of the Devils in the Eastern Conference playoffs on their way to the Stanley Cup semifinals.

title: Restaurant Wasn't Toast of Town; Ed Sullivan's Seemed to Have Everything but Success
description: The old-world glamour was gone. There was no jazz ensemble playing in the balcony, no martinis flowing from the bar, no guests in the leather supper-club booths. All of that was over, and Earl Geer was presiding over a dream unraveled.

title: Cocaine and Heroin Seized in Sullivan County
description: Federal agents seized more than 600 pounds of cocaine and heroin from a house in Fallsburg yesterday morning in what agents said was the first seizure of this magnitude in Sullivan County. Although the drugs were stored in the Fallsburg house, their destination was New York City, agents said.

title: I.R.A. Ally Asks Irish Court to Block Ouster From Peace Talks
description: Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, said tonight that it would seek an order on Wednesday in an Irish Republic court to block any move to expel it from the Northern Ireland peace talks.

title: Tigers' Juggernaut Rolls On
description: PRINCETON 71, PENN 52

title: Just Because the Grades Are Up, Are Princeton Students Smarter?
description: To their great relief, one of the first lessons anxious freshmen learn here at Princeton University is that it is virtually impossible to flunk a class.

title: Open Admission Gives Working Class a Chance
description: To the Editor:

title: 2001 Is Mets' Goal for Stadium
description: Hurdles remain, but the Mets' co-owner, Fred Wilpon, said today that he is optimistic that before the 2001 season is over, the Mets will be playing in a new stadium with a very Brooklyn feel to it right next to Shea Stadium.

title: Open Admission Gives Working Class a Chance
description: To the Editor:

title: A Judge in Texas Rules in Favor of Microsoft
description: A Texas judge ruled today that the Microsoft Corporation did not hinder a state investigation into its business practices by requiring partners to notify the software maker before complying with the state's demand for information.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YAVERBAUM, ARNOLD, M.D.
description: YAVERBAUM - Arnold, M.D. Rachel, Peter, and Danny, bid adeiu to their dear grandfather. They join Justine, Harvey and Kathy in cherishing his laughter. They will forever collect boxtops, memorize line ups, and believe in house calls. Thank you for the magic, grandpa. We love you.

title: Hall Is Arrested in Florida on Marijuana Charges
description: They have canceled John Hall Day, which was scheduled for Saturday at Port Charlotte High School in Florida.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  METZ, ANNA. (NEE STEINHARDT)
description: METZ-Anna. (nee Steinhardt) on Tuesday, February 17, 1998. Of West Orange, NJ. Beloved wife of the late Robert J. Metz. Loving mother of Susan Good and Richard Metz. Cherished grandmother of Kenneth and David Good, adored great-grandmother of Lara Good, dear sister of the late Edith Rapp. Funeral services at the Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vaux Hall Road, Union, NJ on Wednesday, February 18, 1998 at 2:15 PM.

title: Coach Is Trying to Steer Kwan in Right Direction
description: He has coached figure skating for 38 years, becoming more familiar than he wanted with great expectation and heartbreaking letdown. Finally, at 59, Frank Carroll may win an Olympic gold medal with Michelle Kwan.

title: Asia Crisis Hurting A Builder of Factories
description: Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, a Japanese builder of factories, said yesterday that it had cut its full-year profit forecast by 25 percent because of up to 400 billion yen ($3.18 billion) in delayed payments from Southeast Asia. Sharp declines in the value of the region's currencies have left Southeast Asian governments and corporations struggling to pay Mitsubishi Heavy for constructing steel, chemical and textile factories, said Yoshihisa Tsuda, a vice president of Mitsubishi Heavy.

title: Foote, Cone Unites Marketing Offices
description: Foote, Cone & Belding Worldwide said yesterday that it had combined all its direct marketing offices under the FCB Direct Worldwide banner and named top executives to head the new division.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMMONS, SUSAN (GOLDMUNTZ)
description: SIMMONS-Susan (Goldmuntz). On Feb 17, 1998, beloved wife of the late Frank, loving mother of Gail and Sarah, cherished daughter of Ruth and the late Edgard Goldmuntz, dear sister of Michael and David Goldmuntz, and grand daughter of Gerda Loewengart. Services Thursday 9:30 A.M. at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: 2 Big Korea Investors in Debt to Morgan
description: Two of South Korea's biggest institutional investors said today that they owed J. P. Morgan & Company more than $12 million on Asian currency derivatives, the type of contract at the core of an intensifying dispute between the American investment bank and other Korean companies.

title: Hostile Offer For Computer Services Unit
description: Computer Associates International Inc. intensified its unwelcome pursuit of the Computer Sciences Corporation yesterday, filing a formal tender offer to buy its stock for $108 a share in cash.

title: Taiwan Pushes for Role in Southeast Asia Rescue
description: Shunned internationally, ignored by the International Monetary Fund and technically at war with China, Taiwan has been given a rare opportunity to flex its financial muscles by the economic calamities in Southeast Asia.

title: Limited Plans Big Overhaul Of Operations
description: The Limited Inc. said yesterday that it would shut down unprofitable stores in its women's apparel businesses, close all but one of its Henri Bendel specialty shops and spin off another subsidiary, Abercrombie & Fitch, to Limited shareholders. The plan is the biggest revamping since the Limited went public in 1969.

title: An Evening of Hurdles
description: The soprano Kathleen Battle reacted with grace on Sunday night when the Carnegie Hall stage lights went off momentarily as she performed an aria from Verdi's ''Attila'' with the Minnesota Orchestra. The musicians managed to continue in the dark. Ms. Battle seemed rattled but kept singing.

title: Shunned by Mayor, Budget Panel Dinner Is a Hot Ticket
description: The Citizens Budget Commission, the independent watchdog agency, has sold a record number of tickets to its annual fund-raising dinner tonight -- a financial success made possible, its members say, by heavyhanded criticism leveled at the group by the Giuliani administration.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHULSKY, MARIE
description: SHULSKY-Marie. Fifth Avenue Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of its esteemed member and extends heartfelt sympathy to the bereaved family. Dr. Sol Roth, Rabbi Hermann Merkin, Founding Pres. David Yagoda, Chairman Prof. William Schwartz, Pres.

title: Sudan to Loosen Islamic Rule a Bit
description: Nine years after it seized power in a military coup, the Islamic party that has molded the Sudan into a religious state is enacting a new constitution that officials here maintain will allow a return to party politics and greater political freedom.

title: By the Book; A Chef's Philadelphia Story
description: WRITING a cookbook is now as much a part of being a celebrity chef as making an appearance at the James Beard Foundation. But Georges Perrier's lavish new book, ''Georges Perrier: Le Bec-Fin Recipes'' (Running Press, $35), is not some pro forma exercise. It starts by recounting the career of the highly rated chef, who for three decades in Philadelphia has been an important influence on America's culinary evolution.

title: Ernst Junger, Contradictory German Author Who Wrote About War, Is Dead at 102
description: Ernst Junger, an aloof warrior-author regarded as one of Germany's most controversial and contradictory writers, died yesterday in Wilflingen, in southwestern Germany, where he had lived for nearly 50 years. He was 102.

title: Metro Business; Fragrance Company Plans New Jersey Site
description: Givaudan-Roure, the fragrance and flavor division of Roche Holding Ltd., the multinational health care conglomerate in Basel, Switzerland, will build a 180,000-square-foot manufacturing and distribution complex in the International Trade Center in Mount Olive Township, N.J.

title: Rebuilding of Subway Tunnel Will Mean Delays for Riders
description: Only eight years after it opened, the 63d Street subway tunnel will be partially shut Sunday for repairs that will last 15 months, causing extra transfers and long waits for approximately 12,000 riders daily in Manhattan, Roosevelt Island and Queens, New York City Transit announced yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BOXER, EMILY HAHN
description: BOXER-Emily Hahn. Dearest and adored mother and great lady, you are forever loved and missed. Your family and friends.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERS, PAULINE
description: PERS-Pauline. Beloved wife of the late Dr. B. Elliott. Devoted mother of Deena Pers and Jessica Pers. Dear sister of Adele Pasahow, Monroe Kriesberg, Gerald Kriesberg, Stanley Kriesberg and Sabina Brown. Loving grandmother of Andrew B. Stein and Daniel T. Stein. Services at ''GuttermanMusicant'', Hackensack, N.J. on Wednesday at 1:30pm

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: PARKWAY PROPERTIES INC., Jackson, Miss., agreed to buy 13 office buildings in the South from an Atlanta-based real estate investment company for $165.7 million in cash. The seller's name was not disclosed.

title: Open Admission Gives Working Class a Chance
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORELLI, MILLIE (NEE CIRIEGIO)
description: MORELLI-Millie (nee Ciriegio) On Feb. 16, 1998. Loving wife of the late Peter J. Cherished mother of Benedict P. Morelli. Loving mother-in-law of Arlene. Devoted grandmother of Justin and Alexander. Reposing at Andrew Torregrossa and Sons, 345 Avenue U, Brooklyn, NY. Funeral Mass Friday 9:30am Saints Simon and Jude RC Church. Interment Greenwood Cemetery. Viewing Wednesday and Thursday 2-5 and 7-10pm.

title: Restaurants; Transported to Tuscany, Occasionally
description: WHAT do you suppose a plate of spaghetti with olive oil, garlic and peppers costs a restaurant?

title: APPLIED GRAPHICS IN $461 MILLION DEAL FOR DEVON GROUP
description: Applied Graphics Technologies agreed yesterday to buy Devon Group Inc. of Stamford, Conn., for about $461 million in cash and stock, gaining more clients in the Midwest for its business of digitally formatting images for magazines and catalogues. Applied Graphics, based in New York, will pay $30 a share in cash and 0.6 share of Applied Graphics stock for each Devon share. Shares of Devon surged $14.125 yesterday, or 30 percent, to $60.625. Shares of Applied Graphics rose $2.375, to $52.50.

title: Courts Can't End Veto Debate; New York's Penalty
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMONS, MAXINE
description: SIMONS-Maxine. February 17, 1998. Wife of David Simons. Devoted and dedicated mother of Allison Sans and the late Robert Post. She will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Funeral private.

title: Far From The Fjords
description: The program for ''Gint,'' Romulus Linney's new play at the Theater for the New City, says that it has been adapted ''from Ibsen's 'Peer Gynt.' '' Hmm.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Ralston Purina shuns news, even when it's good.
description: PET owners love the Ralston Purina Company's canine and feline cuisine. So why do some investors consider its stock a dog?

title: Calendar
description: Real Estate 101

title: Wynn Cuts Mirage Stake
description: Stephen A. Wynn, the chairman of Mirage Resorts Inc. in Las Vegas, Nev., disclosed today that he had reduced his stake in the casino company to 14.2 percent by selling three million shares. He now has 27.2 million shares, which fell $1 today, to $23.5625.

title: China's Election Plan Is Hardly New Strategy; McCain-Feingold's Fate
description: To the Editor:

title: Courts Can't End Veto Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINN, ESTELLE
description: FINN-Estelle. 96, on February 16, 1998 in Palm Beach, FL. Widow of the late Louis Krones and the late Benjamin Finn; beloved mother of Budd, Robert and Edward Krones, mother-in-law of Marjorie Krones and Cynthia Saypol, sister of Raymond Ackerman, step-mother of Philip and Alvan Finn, also survived by numerous grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Services on February 19 at 11 am at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave, NYC 10021. Donations in her memory may be made to Hadassah or the charity of your choice.

title: Nets' New Practice Facility Befits a First-Class Team
description: John Calipari was guiding his team on a tour through the Nets' new practice facility today, and the players, seeing the state-of-the-art facility for the first time, were suitably impressed by the palatial locker room and the new court.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANCO, SALVATORE
description: FRANCO-Salvatore. The New York Chapter of the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation International records with deep sorrow the death of Sal Franco, loving husband of Carol. Sal was a special friend and supporter of diabetes research from the very beginning. He will be missed by everyone. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the bereaved family. Robert B. Obernier, President

title: CLINTON DESCRIBES GOALS FOR A STRIKE ON IRAQI ARSENALS
description: Accusing Saddam Hussein of lying and cheating to dodge international controls and cling to chemical and biological weapons, President Clinton warned today that he was prepared to order a campaign of air strikes to ''seriously diminish'' the threats posed by Iraq with its arsenal and regional ambitions.

title: Police Union, Seeking More Pay, Asks for New Contract Talks
description: Days after the Giuliani administration announced that firefighters who performed more work would receive higher pay than police officers, the city's largest police union said yesterday that it wanted to renegotiate the officers' contract and discuss incentives to increase productivity.

title: Knicks Get Late Boost By Dudley On Boards
description: It took a while for the Knicks to get comfortable with preying upon another team's misery. There had to be an epiphany of sorts, a moment when the Knicks realized that they were far superior to the troubled Nuggets tonight.

title: Former Midshipman Guilty In Killing of Teen-Age Rival
description: A jury here convicted a 20-year-old former Naval Academy midshipman of capital murder today, and a judge quickly sentenced her to life in prison.

title: Foundation Health Systems Will Sell an Insurance Subsidiary
description: Foundation Health Systems Inc. said today that it planned to sell its workers' compensation insurance unit and had hired Salomon Smith Barney, a unit of the Travelers Group, as financial adviser for the sale.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLAMM, DONALD
description: FLAMM-Donald, 98 of Palm Beach and New Jersey, passed away February 15, 1998. Beloved husband of Elayne. Dear brother of Milton Flamm. Loving stepfather of Jim Knee, wife Linda Knee, Bobby Knee, wife Nancy Knee. Cherished grandfather of Daniel Knee. Caring father-in-law of Harry Needelman. Loving uncle of nieces Carol (Nobuo) Akiyama, Jacqueline Flamm, husband Michael Aslett, Nola (Richard) Baris, nephew Gary (Mollie) Flamm. Brother-in-law and sister-in-law Al and Gloria Brokman, nieces Hope (Barry) Linderman, Tyler Meryl, Donna Klein and Debra Brokman; and many great nieces & nephews. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Melech Yisrael, Jewish Federation, Hebrew Free Loan, Anti-Defamation League, Orthodox Union or a charity of your choice. Funeral service to be held today 12:00 noon at ''The Riverside'' Amsterdam Ave. New York, NY. Interment to follow at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. We thank you and love you with all our hearts.

title: Arthur Cohn, 87, Versatile Composer, Conductor and Author
description: Arthur Cohn, a versatile and prolific composer, conductor and author whose books and articles celebrated the diversity of classical music and made it accessible to a large audience, died on Sunday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. He was 87 and lived in Manhattan.

title: It's 7 Pieces of Gold for Norway's Dahlie
description: Every Olympic event that Bjorn Dahlie enters is not simply a race against his opponents, but a race against his predecessors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BALKE, HENRY A.
description: BALKE-Henry A. On February 15, 1998 of Little Neck, NY. Husband of Francine Balke. Son of Margaret Frary. Father of Henry S. and Elizabeth A. Stepfather of Scott, Mara and Steven. Brother of Bob and Donald. Also survived by eight grandchildren. Services in Doyle B. Shaffer, Inc. Funeral Home, Little Neck Pkwy. and Northern Blvd., Little Neck. Thurs 8 PM. Visiting Thurs 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Interment private. In lieu of flowers donations to North Shore Univ. Hosp. would be appreciated.

title: Hot and Cold Varieties of Vichyssoise
description: A WELL-REMEMBERED treat in my childhood was being taken to the old Ritz-Carlton Hotel in Manhattan for lunch. Carefully dressed in a pale-green wool dress that almost matched the carpet, I was led down a short flight of stairs to a large table. It was a warm spring day and I was served a smooth, creamy, ivory-colored soup that was flecked with green and that almost filled a two-handled consomme cup.

title: Samuelsson Continues Rangers' Poor Luck
description: The Rangers have not played in more than a week, but their seasonlong slump continues here at the Winter Olympics. It was personified by the case of Rangers defenseman Ulf Samuelsson, who was banned from the hockey tournament after three games for his native Sweden because he also holds a United States passport. Under Sweden's laws, this makes him ineligible for its national team.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRESSMAN, JERRY S.
description: PRESSMAN-Jerry S. On February 17, 1998. Of West Orange, NJ. Formerly of NYC and Newark NJ. Devoted father of Alan Pressman and Stanton Pressman. Also survived by four grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. Funeral from the Bernheim-Apter-Goldsticker Suburban Funeral Chapel, 1600 Springfield Avenue, Maplewood, NJ on Wednesday, February 18 at 12 noon. Interment Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I think what I was proving was that only fools answer hypothetical questions. You know, sometimes being a spokesman means shutting up.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AUERBACH, GEORGE
description: AUERBACH-George. 89. Of Howard Beach, N.Y. Passed away in Tamarac Fl. on February 16, 1998. He is survived by his loving wife of 65 years, Sophie, devoted children, Sandra (Herbert) Weiss, Robert (Elizabeth) Auerbach, four cherished grandchildren, and six great grandchildren. A member of the Masons and Shriners. Mr. Auerbach was the Founder of Ashland Desk Co. which later became Furniture Rental Associates, Inc., UFO, Inc., a Director of Wheels Plus Roller Rinks and an owner of Casa del Ray Bingo. The stockholders and employees of Furniture Rental Associates, Inc. and its allied companies mourn the passing of our beloved Founder, George Auerbach. Chapel services will be held on Wednesday, February 18 at 2:30 P.M. at Riverside-Gordon Memorial Chapel, Tamarac Fl. 954-523-5801. Interment will take place in New York on Friday, February 20, 11:30 A.M. Beth Moses Cemetery, Farmingdale, N.Y.

title: Open Admission Gives Working Class a Chance
description: To the Editor:

title: An Orchestra at One With Its Conductor
description: If the stalwart principal trumpet of the Royal Concertgebouw Orchestra felt a moment of surprise, he did not show it when, on Monday night, he played the fanfare that launches Mahler's Fifth Symphony and found himself sounding out the chill of Avery Fisher Hall rather than being warmly embraced by his home venue, the baldly designated ''Concert Building'' in Amsterdam, from which this orchestra takes its name.

title: The Fed Reports Slowdown In Industrial Production
description: Industrial production unexpectedly stalled in January as utility output fell 4 percent, the Federal Reserve said today.

title: Possibility of Tampering With Yanks' Williams
description: George Steinbrenner has insisted that he will not allow Bernie Williams's contract status to become the dominant issue of spring training for the Yankees. On the eve of the team's arbitration hearing with the All-Star center fielder, however, Steinbrenner mused openly about the possibility that the Arizona Diamondbacks had tampered with his player.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAMAN, CHESTER A.
description: BRAMAN-Chester A. 71, on February 16, 1998 in Vero Beach, Fla. Born in New York City, April 9, 1926. Graduate of Pomfret School and Yale University, Class of 1946. U.S. Navy, 1945-1953; discharged as Lieutenant Commander. Retired Executive Vice President of Graniteville (textile) Company, NYC. Former resident of Darien and Old Lyme, Ct., and of Vero Beach since 1992. Member of the N.Y. Yacht Club. Survived by his wife of 45 years, Sally Lane Braman; three sons, William L. Braman of Boston, Ma., Edward H. Braman of Nashville, Tn., Timothy T. Braman of Los Angeles, Ca.; two sisters, Eleanor B. Grasso of Old Lyme, Ct. and Mary B. Murray of Isle of Wight, NY; a brother, Lawrence Braman of Boston, Ma., and six grandchildren. Funeral service at 2pm Thursday, Feb 19th at CoxGifford Funeral Home, Vero Beach. A Memorial Service will be held at a later date.

title: On the Morning Show, Short Shrift From CBS
description: By the time I flipped on my television at 7:40 yesterday morning, the second period of the women's Olympic gold-medal hockey game had five minutes to play.

title: Business Travel; Microsoft is moving into the business of supplying fast Internet access for hotel guests.
description: AT last, Seattle -- a city in Microsoft's backyard -- has a hotel with a bit of dazzling computer technology. It's the Vintage Park, which in a deal with the Redmond, Wash., software giant has outfitted 30 of its rooms and suites with computers, Microsoft Office Suite software and digital T-1 lines that can provide access to E-mail and the Internet at speeds up to 100 times faster than a dial-up modem.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBIN, IRA LLOYD
description: RUBIN-Ira Lloyd. The Officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Ira Lloyd Rubin, a generous supporter of UJA-Federation. A gifted cardiologist, he was a dedicated leader in our Physician's Division through his activities at Montefiore Medical Center. His bequest to UJA-Federation will benefit our affiliated agencies for generations to come. We extend our sincerest sympathies to his beloved wife, Beatrice; and his brother, Adrien. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair Louise B. Greilsheimer, President Stephen D. Solender, Exec. V.P.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEHRER, ARTHUR
description: LEHRER-Arthur. On February 15, 1998. Beloved husband of Phyllis, loving father of Halli and Rob, Karen and Steve, Susan and Michael, adoring grandfather of Sara, Melanie, Katie, Jamie, and Aaron. Services Thursday, February 19, at 11 A.M. Sunset Chapels, 1285 Northern Blvd. Manhasset, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MUIR, CLYDE
description: MUIR-Clyde. February 17, 1998. Beloved husband of Arlene, loving father of Susan and John. Devoted grandfather of John David. Devoted brother of Richard Muir of Florida. Past Master of Brandeis Masonic Lodge #

title: SmithKline Beecham's Net Increases 8.9% in Quarter
description: SmithKline Beecham P.L.C. reported an 8.9 percent gain in fourth-quarter earnings yesterday despite the strong British pound, which may have hurt new-product sales by the large London-based drug maker.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LANDAU, EVA J.
description: LANDAU-Eva J. February 18, 1982. Who found well deserved rest and peace 16 years ago today. Your loving son, Robert

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEBENS, HENRY
description: LEBENS-Henry. The Board of Governors and members of Montammy Golf Club express their deepest sorrow at the passing of their beloved member and extend their heartfelt sympathy to Roslyn, Leslie and Donna, and the entire family. Stanley Plonchak, President

title: Homemade Pickles: Quick to Make, Quick to Eat
description: WE'RE not snack-food snobs. A given day might find us munching on anything from potato chips to pretzels to cheese puffs. But when the big game is on or special guests are coming over, we're likely to bring out the homemade pickles. That's right, pickles. They may not be trendy, but as a snack food or even a side dish, they are intriguing, uniquely satisfying and virtually fat-free.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSSMAN, RABBI HERMAN
description: GROSSMAN-Rabbi Herman. We note with sadness the passing of our beloved colleague who served pulpits in Pennsylvania and New York before embarking on a 20 year career as a VA chaplain. After his retirement, he made aliyah to Israel with his family. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Roz and to his children and to all who were touched through his rabbinate. Rabbi David L. Lieber, President Rabbi Joel H. Meyers, Exec. VP The Rabbinical Assembly

title: Yeltsin Tells Parliament to Fix Economy, and Win I.M.F. Aid
description: With much-needed cash from the International Monetary Fund at stake, President Boris N. Yeltsin sharply chastised Parliament today over its spending plans and renewed a threat to form a new Government if his Cabinet did not quickly resolve Russia's economic problems.

title: China's Election Plan Is Hardly New Strategy
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POTTS, REV. JAN HALLSTROM
description: POTTS-Rev. Jan Hallstrom. On February 15 of a heart attack. Wife of Rev. David Potts and mother of Aaron and Annemarie. Also survived by parents C. Evert and Vivian Hallstrom and sister, Judy Walker. In lieu of flowers, donations to Pilgrim Covenant Church. Visiting Thursday 7-9pm and Friday from 2 followed by funeral service at 4pm. Herbst Funeral Home, 7501 Fifth Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: Cold Cash Succeeds Cold War as the Berlin Film Festival's Mission
description: During the cold war, the Berlin Film Festival had loads of money and a strong political mission. Today it is hard up and struggling to find a new identity. Not that it has many options. At the world's main film festivals, business has long since supplanted art or even politics as the main concern. Berlin, it seems, has had little choice but to go commercial.

title: INVESTMENT GROUP BUYS NEBRASKA TEXTBOOK COMPANY
description: Haas Wheat & Partners Inc. said yesterday that it had bought the Nebraska Book Company for $245 million, with plans to expand the company, a wholesale supplier of used college textbooks. Haas Wheat, a buyout firm based in Dallas, acquired the book distributor, which is based in Lincoln, Neb., from Olympus Partners, another investment group. Nebraska Book provides 2,000 college campuses with textbooks and operates its own chain of 54 college bookstores. It also recently purchased the Collegiate Stores Corporation, a buying service that serves more than 500 college bookstores.

title: $25 and Under; Ceviche and Filet Mignon, Courtesy of Cuba
description: CORNELIA STREET, just a block long, is the Restaurant Row of Greenwich Village, full of superb, modestly priced restaurants. Little Havana, a sweet new Cuban restaurant, is the latest member in good standing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LESTER, RUTH
description: LESTER-Ruth. On Feb. 16, 1998, deeply loved by Henry, Bunny, Jennifer, Lara, Ray, Joe, Eyal... and countless others. We will miss her very much.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL SLIDES. Crude oil prices fell to a four-year low yesterday on signs that there might be a compromise that would forestall a military strike against Iraq, oil traders said. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, crude oil for March delivery dropped 36 cents, to $15.66 a barrel.

title: Accounts
description: * N2K Inc., New York, to Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners, New York, as the first integrated communications agency of record for Music Boulevard, the company's on-line retail music service. Billings were estimated at $5 million to $10 million. Iballs, New York, will continue handling N2K's Internet ad placement.

title: Needless Senate Secrecy
description: Congress is a public institution, and members who use their power to prevent action on legislation or nominations should have to do so in the open. That basic principle of accountability seems to have been lost on the Senate, which allows individual lawmakers to impose a secret ''hold'' on items they object to, thereby blocking their consideration indefinitely.

title: Theater Records
description: CHRISTOPHER REISMAN, an artist and teacher from Blue Point, N.Y., has earned a place in the Off Broadway record books: He has seen the gay-themed musical revue ''When Pigs Fly'' a record 14 times. (The society decorator MARIO BUATTA has seen it 13 times, the producers say.)

title: Clinton Team Asks Judge to Dismiss Jones Suit
description: President Clinton's lawyers asked a Federal judge today to throw out Paula Corbin Jones's sexual misconduct lawsuit, arguing that even if Mr. Clinton did confront her with a crude sexual proposition nearly seven years ago, she had produced no evidence that he had violated any laws.

title: Panel Hearing Louima Case Is Said to Call 3 From P.B.A.
description: Three officials of the New York City police officers' union have been subpoenaed to testify before a Federal grand jury investigating charges that officers brutalized Abner Louima, lawyers familiar with the investigation said yesterday. They said the union and the officers were seeking to quash the subpoenas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITE, ELIZABETH
description: WHITE - Elizabeth Cleveland Spear (Mrs. William R. White), F.G.B.S. The New York Genealogical and Biographical Society regrets the passing of its 20th president (1983-1986) since its founding in 1869. Mrs. White's notable work was as member of the Society's publication committees since 1936, and as editor maintaining the Society's ''Record'' as a leading genealogical publication in America. A long-time trustee (1963-1993) and Fellow she was Honorary President at her death on February 4, 1998. Henry Middendorf, President Henry C.B. Lindh, Chairman Executive Commietee Edward F.L. Bruen, Secretary

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: The Perjury Loophole
description: ''Perjury in civil cases is virtually never prosecuted.'' Who said that? I did. And so did dozens of other purported experts when members of the news media asked us if Kenneth W. Starr, the independent counsel for Whitewater, would be looking into whether President Clinton and Monica S. Lewinsky lied under oath in the Paula Jones sexual harassment case. We were wrong.

title: Tony Show to Be Held at Radio City
description: The Tony Awards will be at Radio City Music Hall and on CBS again this June, the League of American Theaters and Producers and the American Theater Wing announced yesterday.

title: Graham Says the Jets Wanted Him Too
description: Kent Graham said he spurned what he called a serious overture from the Jets last week to sign a free-agent contract with the Giants.

title: School Officials Attend 'Megan's Law' Training
description: The Camden County Prosecutor's office held a training session on ''Megan's Law'' yesterday for 120 school principals and superintendents, and is scheduled to hold a similar session for day care operators today.

title: Another Record for Dow as Investors Dismiss the Negatives
description: The Dow Jones industrial average continued its trek into record territory yesterday, posting its fifth consecutive high as an economic report pointed to slower economic growth while a new round of merger news heartened investors.

title: Low Ceiling On U.S. Aims
description: President Clinton today outlined a military goal in dealing with Iraq so modest that he will have little trouble declaring it achieved, even if it fails to deal with the larger threat posed by Saddam Hussein.

title: The Crux of the Iraq Crisis
description: With the approach of a new moon over Iraq next week, and the darkness it will provide for air operations, the days for diplomacy would appear to be dwindling fast. That is why Kofi Annan, the United Nations Secretary General, is preparing for an urgent visit to Baghdad, and it is why President Clinton traveled to the Pentagon yesterday to issue his most explicit warning to Saddam Hussein that the United States will use military force if he refuses to allow unrestricted access to U.N. weapons inspectors.

title: Acquirer Found for Part Of Failed Japanese Bank
description: The Chuo Trust and Banking Company of Japan said yesterday that it would take over 63 branches of Hokkaido Takushoku Bank Ltd. and hire 1,100 employees of the lender, whose collapse in November shook Japan's financial industry.

title: DEATH IN THE ALPS: A special report.; How Wayward U.S. Pilot Killed 20 on Ski Lift
description: When a Marine Corps jet hit a ski lift in northern Italy two weeks ago, killing 20 people, the pilot was violating orders to fly 1,000 feet above the ground and had veered into an area that the Italian Government says was both off course and off limits for this flight.

title: Federated and States Settle on Collections
description: Federated Department Stores Inc. will pay $10.6 million to settle complaints by 20 states that it illegally collected payments from bankrupt credit card customers, New York officials said yesterday.

title: IWS COMMUNICATIONS PLANS TO ADD CAPROCK BUSINESSES
description: IWL Communications Inc. said yesterday that it would buy the Caprock Communications Corporation and Caprock Fiber Network Ltd. for about $124.5 million in stock to broaden the phone services it offers to remote sites, like oil rigs. IWL said it would pay 10.6 million shares to Caprock's owners. IWL had 3.75 million shares outstanding on Dec. 31, and its shares rose $1.875 yesterday, or 19 percent, to $11.75. The closely held Caprock companies, based in Dallas, provide long-distance service and had revenue of $48 million last year. Houston-based IWL, which primarily serves oil and gas companies, had sales of $12.1 million in the second half of 1997. It went public last June.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORRELICK, RABBI BENJAMIN H.
description: GORRELICK-Rabbi Benjamin H. We note with sadness the passing of our beloved colleague. Ordained in 1934, he served for 55 years at Congregation Beth Achim in Detroit, MI. After many years in the rabbinate he became emeritus of Beth Achim 29 years ago. We extend our deepest condolences to his daughter Elisheva, to his grandchildren and to all who were touched through his rabbinate. Rabbi David L. Lieber, President Rabbi Joel H. Meyers, Exec. VP The Rabbinical Assembly

title: The 49ers Didn't Know The Gold Was In the Photos
description: In the 1850's, when the gold rush was in full swing, a daguerreotype artist posted this notice to the babies of San Francisco:

title: Records Shattered By Dutch In Sweep
description: On the eve of the men's 10,000-meter Olympic speed-skating race this afternoon, the defending champion and world record-holder, the retired Boss Koss -- or, according to his driver's license, Johann Olav Koss -- made a prediction.

title: About New York; A New Nation May Not Mean A New Home
description: MIREILLE came to this country last June 16 with a forged passport and fresh memories of her father's assassination by political opponents in Zaire. She spent five months and a day in detention while immigration authorities reviewed her claim for political asylum. They ruled in her favor and released her.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, ALBERT
description: SHAPIRO-Albert, on February 16, 1998, of Sands Point, L.I. Beloved husband of Honey (Honora). Devoted father of Stephen Shapiro, Barbara Witkin, Kelly and Lou Gonda. Dearest brother and best friend to Harold. Adored brotherin-law to Barbara. Cherished grandfather of Eli, Eva, Nicolas, Jonathan and Michael. Loving son of the late Eva and Benjamin Shapiro of Blessed Memory. Also acknowledged by all his nieces, grandnieces and grandnephews. He was a man of amazing wisdom and kindness, a respected and admired friend to all. Services today, 12 noon, at Community Synagogue, 150 Middle Neck Road, Sands Point. Interment, New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, L.I.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEBER, ESTHER
description: GEBER-Esther of Miami Beach, died February 16, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Leon. Loving mother and mother-in-law of Robert and Rosetta Geber. Services in Florida on Thursday at Riverside-Gordon Mem.Chapels.

title: Teacher Who 'Freed Many Minds' Is Eulogized
description: Under normal, kinder circumstances, it might have seemed like graduation day as teachers and students from Hoboken High School lined up this morning outside St. Francis Roman Catholic Church. But since a popular social studies teacher was shot to death outside the school on Thursday, little has been normal and life here has seemed anything but kind.

title: Commercial Real Estate; With New Freedom, Choosing a Power Supplier
description: As the date for partial deregulation of electrical power nears, managers of major properties in New York City appear divided over how to approach the impending freedom to choose a power supplier.

title: Two Senators Propose Anti-Paparazzi Law
description: A bipartisan pair of high-powered Senators came to Hollywood today to promote legislation intended to curb the abuses of paparazzi who stalk celebrities. The bill would make it a Federal crime to chase someone in a way that risks bodily harm in an effort to photograph or record the person for commercial purposes.

title: Slain Girl's Neighbors Now See a Dangerous World
description: Until the abduction and killing of 15-year-old Katrina Suhan over the weekend, Dorothy Moran regularly walked South Amboy's streets for two miles each night to strengthen her back muscles after recent surgery.

title: Sharpton Finishes His Testimony Painting a Flattering Self-Portrait
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton concluded his testimony at the Tawana Brawley defamation trial today by telling jurors that his big hair and big voice were matched by an even bigger heart.

title: An Officer Fights to Take Back His Union
description: THEY are bidding on his locker over at the 19th Precinct station house, now that Officer John Loud has decided to take on something bigger than the street criminals he has chased over rooftops and through alleys for the last 29 years. Sergeants pull him aside and quietly urge him to watch his back. Retired officers send him letters in tiny scrawls calling him a hero.

title: Fraschilla Keeps Eyes On Prize
description: ST. JOHN'S

title: Old Glory Gets a Cheer As U.S. Team Plays in Iran
description: For the first time in nearly two decades, Iran displayed the American flag today in a gesture of friendship rather than hatred.

title: City in Perspective
description: Somewhere beneath New York City, a subway train on the express track catches up to a train on the local track. For a few moments the two rattle along side by side until the faster train pulls away. But while the trains run in tandem, a passenger on one peers through the tunnel darkness at the occupants of the other. Everyone looks so tired in the lighted room of that parallel car, so preoccupied. And for an instant, you are lifted out of the web of your life. You can almost see yourself being borne away in that other train to some distant, unfamiliar station where a different existence is already in progress. Then the trains separate because of diverging routes or a speed differential and that moment of awareness comes to an end.

title: Ex-Aide of Top Soldier Says His Assault Ended Her Career
description: Brenda L. Hoster, the retired sergeant major whose accusations of sexual misconduct sparked the court-martial here of the man who had been the Army's top enlisted soldier, lost her composure today only when talking of the hurt inflicted on that soldier's wife of 25 years.

title: The Neediest Cases; Paralyzing Experience of Sudden Homelessness
description: Not many people can eat Big Macs every day and still lose weight. But since he became homeless last month, Thony Angerville has managed to shed 25 pounds while subsisting on a fast-food diet.

title: The Chef
description: NEARLY every cuisine has a traditional dish involving cooked ground meat. There are French pate, American meatloaf, Chinese dumplings and, of course, Italian meatballs in red sauce. They are loved, even revered. Sweden's meatballs in gravy have become, it seems to me, the only example that is actually reviled -- the dreaded dish of wedding buffets around the world. I find this disrepute rankling, and I've tried, with my own approach to the sauce, to give this maligned meatball enough of a twist to restore its charms.

title: U.S. Women First at Gold In Ice Thriller
description: They talked the talk of winners, gold-medal winners, these articulate and fresh-faced young women of the United States Olympic hockey team. What would they do next? Where would they go? Whom would they meet? What more lay in store?

title: TV Notes; Olympic Surge For Letterman
description: As disappointing as the Olympics have been for CBS, there have been some important compensations for the network.

title: Riding Shotgun for Wall Street; Combative Lawyer for Aggressive Brokers Is in Demand
description: When prosecutors delve into the financial and securities markets, Stanley S. Arkin never seems to be far away.

title: Off the Menu
description: Little India on 58th St.

title: An Intimate Party For a Mere 250
description: The invitation called it ''a small and private'' gathering, but the guest list for a Saturday-evening party at the home of the songwriter DENISE RICH has grown to 250. ''That's not enormous, when you consider she has a huge duplex,'' said one friend who has seen the R.S.V.P.'s, ''and she can tent and heat her roof if she has to.''

title: Annan to Go to Iraq to Seek a Solution to Arms Impasse
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan announced tonight that he is traveling to Iraq to try to resolve the crisis that has developed over President Saddam Hussein's refusal to open his country to unconditional inspection for proscribed weapons of mass destruction.

title: At Bat for the Gold
description: Spring training has begun, but all is not right with our national pastime. Still troubled about the dismal Nielsen ratings for last year's World Series, the lords of baseball surely must be intrigued with the packaged, made-for-television melodramas being broadcast on the Winter Olympics. Maybe they'll push for some changes . . .

title: Mayor Defends Payment for a Police Base
description: Angrily brushing aside criticism that the city is placing its police services up for sale, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday defended the city's decision to accept $5 million from a business group to put a police substation near Wall Street, saying it was analogous to his plan to move a police base from one part of Queens to another.

title: Leave Tomb Alone
description: To the Editor:

title: Currency Boards Are No Elixir
description: Facing a plummeting economy and angry rioters, President Suharto of Indonesia has turned in desperation to a magical remedy known as a currency board. Such a board would tie the value of Indonesia's currency, the rupiah, to the value of the dollar and commit Indonesia to accumulating large dollar reserves with which it could, if needed, buy back all the rupiah its central bank has issued. In theory, a dollar-backed currency board assures foreign investors that their money is safe, leading them to return and thereby stimulating recovery.

title: Courts Can't End Veto Debate; Political Deviousness
description: To the Editor:

title: Eating Well; Value of a B-List Diet (as in Vitamin B)
description: CURRENT dietary advice often seems to be a moving target. All fat is bad; no, just some fats are bad. Carbohydrates are good; no, some carbohydrates are better than others and some are downright bad.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Battle Is Seen After Bid for Parts Maker
description: The SPX Corporation, a maker of automobile parts and tools, made a $3 billion hostile bid for Echlin Inc. today, setting off a possible bidding war for one of the biggest auto-parts companies.

title: Gain for Winfrey in Suit By Beef Producers in Texas
description: Throwing a major legal cloud over the ''veggie libel laws'' that have sprouted in more than a dozen states in recent years, a Federal judge ruled today that a group of Texas beef producers could not use the Texas food-defamation statute as a basis for their much-publicized lawsuit against Oprah Winfrey.

title: The War That Decided the Vote, Not Vice Versa
description: RE-ELECTING LINCOLN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIAMS, LILLIAN
description: WILLIAMS-Lillian. On February 15, 1998. Loving wife of the late Isidore, adored mother of Marilyn, Teddy, and the late Joan. Grandchildren Ilise, Ilene, Jimmy, Andrew and Mark, great grandchildren Jillien and Julia, also her beloved brothers Morty and Jesse. Funeral service Wednesday, February 18, 12:30 PM, Riverside Memorial Chapel.

title: Train Kills a Man Wandering on Tracks
description: A New Jersey Transit train struck and killed a man who was wandering on the tracks last night, halting traffic on the Morris and Essex Line for more than an hour, transit officials said.

title: Officials Confirm Russia-Iraq Deal on Plant
description: Nearly four years after the end of the Persian Gulf war, Iraq's military procurement officials struck a deal with Russian companies to build a huge plant that could have been used to produce large quantities of biological weapons, according to American and foreign officials.

title: Police Show Film of Attack on Georgian Leader
description: Georgian police investigators have released a videotape of the assassination attempt last week against the Georgian leader, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, that a senior Government official said had been filmed by the attackers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLD, HERBERT
description: GOLD-Herbert. Of Monroe Township, NJ formerly of Glen Cove, NY, died at home, Feburary 7. He succumbed to lymphoma after having fought it ferociously. BA and MA, Hofstra University; had been a fiscal consultant. Served overseas with Allied Forces HQ, WW II. Survived by his beloved wife of 30 years, Ann; dear sisters and brothers-in-law, Gloria and Ed Sedran, Harriet and Sandy Popper; his much-loved nieces and nephews Howard Sedran, Cheryl Laks, Jonathan Popper, Terri Sedran Weinschenk. Donations to VNA-Hospice, 141 Bodman Pl., Red Bank, NJ, 07701.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, LAURA
description: ROSENBERG - Laura. Devoted wife of the late Morton. Loving mother of Alan (and Anita), Judi (and David). Adored grandmother of Jill (and Michael), Jeffrey (and Carolyn), David, and Debbie (and Craig). Great grandmother of Emily, Justin, Samantha and Griffen. Funeral Services West Palm Beach, Wednesday, Feb. 18, 1998.

description: Everyday and Exotic: A Times Square Grocery
