description: To the Editor:

title: Social Security And Abracadabras
description: In his State of the Union Message, President Clinton called for using ''every dime'' of the budget surplus to help insure Social Security's future. ''Save Social Security first!'' was his simple prescription for how to use the money. His budget, however, contains a different message: ''Spend it!''

title: Phone Checks Approved For Juvenile Parolees
description: A pilot project to track the movement of paroled juvenile offenders using telephone voice recognition technology has succeeded in freeing parole officers for other activities and will be made permanent, officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORREST, BARBARA
description: FORREST-Barbara. Friend of childhood-so much sparkling sun on the lake. Love, Abby

title: Post-Game Racial Fight: Who Started It?
description: Five violent black-white encounters constitute this week's ''Trial Story'' on Court TV. The first of the programs, on Monday, brought back the Texas trial of a skinhead for conspiring to murder a black man, and the second, on Tuesday, covered the trial of two whites charged with setting a black tourist on fire in Florida. But tonight's defendant, charged with eight counts of attempted murder, is black; the alleged victims are white.

title: Deal on Metrocard Fares Is Proving Popular
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority's 11-fares-for-the-price-of-10 deal seems to have been an immediate hit among bus and subway riders, transit officials said yesterday.

title: Ex-Chief Quits Post At Mercury Finance
description: The Mercury Finance Company's former chief executive, John N. Brincat, has resigned from its board and agreed to repay part of his bonuses for 1994, 1995 and 1996.

title: Sears Agrees to Purchase Spray-Tech
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company said today that it had agreed to buy Spray-Tech Inc. for an undisclosed amount, giving it control of the fourth-largest United States remodeling contractor.

title: As Trade Talks Roar, Warriors Deal Smith
description: Joe Smith is going home. Anfernee Hardaway and Mitch Richmond are going nowhere. And in the next 48 hours, Christian Laettner could be headed almost anywhere.

title: In Pursuit of the Perfect Roast Chicken
description: IT wasn't until the fifth chicken had been stuffed, coated and roasted that I almost gave up, acknowledging that there was no way an ordinary gas oven could produce the moist and tender breast that comes out of the $30,000 oven in the Bouley Bakery kitchen.

title: White House Stone Wall Briefly Breached
description: For a few brief hours today, the White House stone wall of silence on Monica S. Lewinsky was breached.

title: Florida Bible Class Was Too Sectarian
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: People
description: * Peter McHugh was named to the new position of managing director and executive creative director at Hal Riney & Partners/Heartland, Chicago. He had been group creative director at Fallon McElligott, Minneapolis.

title: HADCO TO ACQUIRE CONTINENTAL CIRCUITS FOR $185 MILLION
description: The Hadco Corporation agreed yesterday to buy the Continental Circuits Corporation for $185 million in cash, bolstering its position as the largest publicly traded maker of interconnect circuit boards in North America. Hadco will pay $23.90 a share in cash. It will also assume $33 million of Continental's debt. Shares of Continental, which is based in Phoenix, jumped $6.6875, to $23.5625. The purchase will make Hadco much bigger than any other of the estimated 650 small circuit-board manufacturers in the United States and will help it compete with its larger rival, the CMK Corporation of Japan. Shares of Hadco, of Salem, N.H., slid $2.25 yesterday, to $47.50.

title: 2 Youths Held in Attempt At High-Tech Shooting
description: Two Westchester County teen-agers were charged with attempted murder yesterday after they shot at three people leaving a Bronx apartment building late Monday using a machine pistol equipped with a laser scope, the police said.

title: 16th Bomb Threat, This Time With Powder
description: The police evacuated 1,800 students from a high school in Pine Hill yesterday, after another in a series of bomb threats was phoned in and a box containing explosive powder was found on the roof.

title: $15 Million Gift Is Aimed at Keeping Newark Students in School
description: Challenging students to aim for academic greatness, officials from the Ford Foundation and Lucent Technologies told ninth graders at the Malcolm X Shabazz High School here today that they would provide $15 million for a program intended to help them graduate and then go on to college.

title: Wilpon Believes Mets' Glass Is Half-Full
description: Like almost everyone else in the organization, the Mets' co-owner, Fred Wilpon, expresses excitement about his team's prospects this season. And Wilpon was not even able to see much from his pitchers, catchers and the handful of position players because of today's heavy rains.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DERHAM, DONALD A.
description: DERHAM-Donald A. On February 14, 1998. Husband of the late Margaret. Beloved father of Timothy and Donald, Jr. Brother of George Derham. Grandfather of Janet, Elizabeth, Donald III, Theodore, Annika and Paul. Brother-in-law of Joan and Joseph Fries and Alana and Leon Granello. Friends may call Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday, 2-5 and 7-10 PM, at the Thomas F. Dalton Funeral Home, 29 Atlantic Ave. (at RR Plaza), Floral Park. Mass of Christian Burial Friday, 9:45 AM, at St. Gregory the Great R.C. Church. Interment Long Island National Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCARTHY, JOSEPH F.
description: McCARTHY-Joseph F. Fortified with the sacraments of Holy Mother Church, Sunday, February 15, 1998. Dear husband of Helen E. McCarthy (nee O'Leary). Dear father of Helen P. (John P. Sr.) Sheehan. Dear brother of Mary Walkawich and the late Jack, Mike, Billy, and Larry McCarthy. Dear grandfather of John P. Jr., M.D. (Sandy), Dennis M. (Liz) and Joseph B. (Anne) Sheehan. Dear grandfather of Alex Joseph, Brendan Kyle, Alison Marie, and Maegan Lynn Sheehan. Dear brotherin-law of Thomas O'Leary and Alex Walkawich. Dear uncle, great uncle, cousin. Funeral mass Wednesday, February 18, 10 A.M. at Saint Anselm at the Abbey, 500 S. Mason Rd, St Louis, Missouri. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Valhalla, N.Y. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to the American Heart Association. Albert R. Conner-Colonial, Directors

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CENSOR, BELLA (ROSEN)
description: CENSOR-Bella (Rosen). Park East Synagogue and Rabbi Arthur Schneier Park East Day School mourn the passing of Bella (Rosen) Censor, beloved mother of our dedicated Principal, Rabbi Jeremy Rosen. Sincere condolences to the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, President Jerry Forst, Vice President Jack Rosen, Vice President Audrey Feuerstein, Chairman, Board of Education

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTOCK, CHARLES, M.D.
description: WEINSTOCK-Charles, M.D., on February 15, 1998. Beloved father of Catherine and Margot. Survived by his wife Marion and his sister Dorothy Marks. Memorial service at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St, Sunday, 1PM.

title: Here and There
description: PATRICIA HIGHSMITH, who chronicled well-mannered murderers and their intrigues, left her $3 million estate to Yaddo, the artists' colony in Saratoga Springs, N.Y. Ms. Highsmith, who died in 1995, wrote her first published novel, ''Strangers on a Train,'' at Yaddo in 1948. . . . ''Every time we opened those communicators on the Enterprise, it was A.T. & T.,'' quipped WILLIAM SHATNER, the ''Star Trek'' star who is to announce a new line of prepaid long-distance cards today in Manhattan. ''We could have used a debit card if it had existed.'' . . . ''We have struck an iceberg,'' read one of the entries in a volume of distress signals from the Titanic that sold for $123,000 at Christie's East. The buyer was not identified.

title: Havana Journal; Divided Loyalties Tugging at Cuba's Children
description: More than eight years after the cold war melted in the rubble of the Berlin wall, the children of Cuba continue to dive under desks in schools all over the island.

title: Flipping and Twisting, Americans Jump to Gold
description: Nikki Stone jumped from the fourth floor better than any other woman this morning and won an Olympic gold medal. Eric Bergoust did similarly among the men, leaping perhaps from the fifth floor, and he too earned a gold for his troubles. It was a gold-medal sweep for the Americans in the freestyle skiing aerials.

title: Studies Confirm Relationship Of Alcohol to Breast Cancer
description: An analysis of six long-term studies conducted among a total of more than 300,000 women has confirmed that drinking alcohol can raise a woman's risk of developing breast cancer. But the increase in risk is very small for those who consume no more than one drink a day.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, WALTER
description: LEVY-Walter. With profound sorrow the Officers and Board of Trustees of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations mourn the death of our devoted friend and colleague. Wally served Reform Judaism for many years, giving of his time and talents with loving dedication. A man of the book, his life was an expression of the greatest values of our faith. We express heartfelt sympathy to his beloved wife, Bea, and all his loved ones. Jerome H. Somers, Chairman Rabbi Eric H. Yoffie, President Rabbi Alexander M. Schindler, President Emeritus

title: It's 'I' Before 'U,' Except in the Park
description: Is the Central Park Conservancy the gang that can't spell straight?

title: INSIDE
description: Fund-Raiser May Be Indicted

title: Correction
description: A music listing in the Arts and Leisure section last Sunday for the Mannes Orchestra's concert tomorrow night misstated the address. The performance is at Symphony Space, 95th Street and Broadway, not at the Mannes College of Music.

title: Temptation; Nothing Succeeds Like Excess: A Rich Taste of Italy
description: THE decadence on Madison Avenue doesn't stop with the clothing. Sant Ambroeus, a pasticceria and cafe that has been open near 78th Street for 15 years, also purveys the luxuries of Italy, in an understated, Giorgio Armani kind of way.

title: RISKING I.M.F. AID, SUHARTO DISMISSES CENTRAL BANKER
description: President Suharto of Indonesia defied President Clinton and the International Monetary Fund today by dismissing the head of his central bank, a step that increased the risk that the country would lose a rescue package worth roughly $40 billion.

title: The Minimalist; Taking a Different Tack On Fish and Chips
description: WHEN one of my daughters was young, there was a time when her main passion in life was potatoes, especially crispy ones. It didn't matter how they were cooked -- as home fries, french fries or roasted. As long as they had that external crunch and internal mealiness, she was happy.

title: Liberties; President Irresistible
description: We've all been wondering what explanation could be bold enough, brazen enough, majestic enough to get Bill Clinton off the hook.

title: In Colorado Classroom, Students Seek Their Own Olympic Goals
description: Thousands of miles from Nagano, Japan, fourth- and fifth-grade students in Greeley, Colo., have their own Olympics quest: designing snowboards using a new Web site created in a partnership of PBS, I.B.M. and CBS, which is broadcasting the Winter Games.

title: Lessons From a Choreographer's Pilgrimage to Broadway and Back
description: Dance on Broadway and the concert stage might seem worlds apart, one glamorous and the other a thing of leotards and dirty feet. George Balanchine was the first to bridge the gap, in the late 1930's. Today, there is an increasing modern-dance presence on Broadway as the musical has become more stylized and more coolly post-modernist, with choreographers like Mark Morris (''The Capeman''), Garth Fagan (''The Lion King'') and Doug Varone, who created the dances for the recent ''Triumph of Love.''

title: Ruling Due on Witness In Long Island Beating
description: Disputes forced a delay in the trial of Austin Offen on charges that he tried to murder a Long Island man while an off-duty New York City police officer allegedly held the victim's friends at bay with a gun.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHING, FLORENCE (NEE LUM)
description: CHING-Florence (nee Lum). Born October 30, 1914, died February 13, 1998. Beloved widow of Hin (aka Henry) Ching. Wake, February 24, at Wah Wing Sang Funeral Home, 26 Mulberry St, Manhattan.

title: Democratic Fund-Raiser's Indictment Is Imminent
description: The Justice Department has prepared an indictment accusing a Democratic fund-raiser, Maria Hsia, of lying about her role in organizing a 1996 event at a Buddhist Temple in California attended by Vice President Al Gore, law enforcement officials and Ms. Hsia's lawyer said today.

title: Pratt & Whitney to Introduce New Engine
description: Hoping to regain its once-leading share of the global market for jet engines, Pratt & Whitney announced yesterday that it would introduce a radical new engine design that it said would be quieter, cleaner, more efficient and more reliable than anything currently offered by its competitors.

title: Parks Aren't for Cars
description: To the Editor:

title: Fame One Lawyer Can Do Without
description: Not too long after the Monica S. Lewinsky story broke, Carl Cooper, a Pittsburgh lawyer, was chatting on the telephone with his friend, Francis D. Carter, a lawyer in Washington.

title: Kellogg to Make Health Claim for Cereal
description: The Kellogg Company received approval by the Food and Drug Administration today to make a health claim for cereal containing the fiber psyllium. A rule allowing companies to advertise that foods containing a certain amount of psyllium ''may reduce the risk of coronary heart disease'' will take effect Wednesday, an F.D.A. spokeswoman said. Kellogg's Bran Buds will qualify, she said.

title: The success of 'Titanic' has marketers scrambling to create product tie-ins.
description: THE surprising success of ''Titanic'' is already rewriting the rules of Hollywood film making. Now it may also be rewriting the rules of movie marketing.

title: Kenny Anderson Is Traded To Celtics in 7-Player Deal
description: Kenny Anderson is on his third team in a week.

title: Would Punishing Iraq Carry Too High a Price?; Balkan Precedent
description: To the Editor:

title: Campbell Today. Smith Tomorrow?
description: With a league-leading payroll of $44 million, Neil Smith has built one bad hockey team. For that much money, most general managers could build two or three bad teams.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, HENRY W.
description: ROSENBERG-Henry W. Of Basking Ridge, New Jersey on February 18, 1998. Beloved husband of Diana Lawrence. Father of Kevin of Easton, Massachusetts, Marc and Leigh of Basking Ridge. Grandfather of Shari and Aliya Rosenberg of Easton, Massachusetts. Son of Frieda Rosenberg of Somerset, NJ. Relatives and friends are invited to attend services Friday, 2:30 PM at The Gallaway and Crane Funeral Home, 101 South Finley Ave, Basking Ridge, NJ 908-766-0250. Those planning an expression of sympathy are asked to consider contributions in his name to Pathfinders Village Edmeston, New York 13335.

title: Our Towns; Sculpture Museum for Sale. See Angelo. Watch Step.
description: EVERYTHING changed when the willow tree in the front yard was toppled by a storm 15 years ago. Well, maybe not everything. But if the tree hadn't keeled over, this much is for sure: it wouldn't be where it is now, and neither would Angelo Nardone.

title: Among Blacks, Washington Ranks as the Top Surname
description: When Gregory Washington met Craig Washington, he saw something he had never observed in someone with his last name: white skin. "I thought he was going to be black," said Gregory, an African-American, of his first meeting with a new co-worker at a company in Torrance, California. "I told him he was the first white Washington I'd ever seen. I joked that we must be brothers."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, MILTON
description: BROWN-Milton. The Brooklyn College community mourns the passing of Milton Brown, Department of Art. His twenty-five years of teaching and service will be long remembered. Vernon E. Lattin, President Brooklyn College

title: Bull Says Profit Fell By 45% in Second Half
description: Compagnie des Machines Bull S.A. said yesterday that its second-half profit fell 45 percent as the French computer maker took charges for training costs and disclosed a reorganization plan aimed at increasing its market share. Profit fell to 539 million francs ($88 million), from 988 million francs in the second half of 1996, the company said, confirming preliminary figures released Feb. 3. The company took 129 million francs in charges for training costs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIBMAN, HANNAH (SILVERMAN)
description: LIBMAN - Hannah (Silverman). Aged 88, on Feb. 18, 1998. Devoted wife of the late Morris, loving mother of Jill, Kit Howard (Robert), Hillard (Elaine). Adored grandmother of Brett, Jodi (Steven), Jim, Jon (Kathleen). Greatgrandmother of Griffin and Gage. Co-founder in 1929 of Camp Hillard, Hartsdale, New York, she will be sadly missed by all who knew and loved her. Funeral services will be held at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street at 11 AM, Friday, February 20. Shiva will be observed at the home of Kit and Robert Howard, Sunday through Tuesday.

title: Currents; RESTAURANTS -- Welcome to Pisello
description: A 450-pound copper pea pod signals the arrival of a restaurant, Pisello. The name is Italian for ''pea pod.'' The sign was designed and made by Jack Abbate of Regency Service Carts in Brooklyn. To make it look like a relic, Mr. Abbate soaked it in sea water for a month. Pisello is scheduled to open Monday at 200 Eighth Avenue (20th Street); 212-206-0038. TIMOTHY JACK WARD

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REIMER, MARTIN C. III.
description: REIMER-Martin C. III. On February 15, 1998. Of San Antonio, Texas. Husband of Marilyn and the late Dorothy Reimer. Father of Martin Reimer IV and Robert Reimer. Brother of Richard Reimer. Visitation on Thursday 2-4 and 7-9 P.M., Friday 11:30-12:30 PM, Hawthorne Funeral Home, 21 Stevens Ave, Hawthorne, NY where funeral services will be held Friday 12:30PM. Interment Kensico Cemetery.

title: Volvo in Deal to Buy Korean Equipment Unit
description: Volvo A.B., the Swedish auto maker, said yesterday that its construction division had agreed to buy the Samsung Heavy Industries Company's construction equipment business for an undisclosed sum. The acquisition includes a Korean distribution organization and a plant in the southern city of Changwon. The unit, which makes excavators, earth-movers and cranes, had sales of $700 million last year. Samsung, Korea's second-largest conglomerate, said last month that it would get out of all its businesses except for three core activities.

title: Currents; BOOKS -- Go Curl Up With a Chair
description: Most prize winners get weighty medals. Recipients of Germany's Federal Award for Design Leadership get weighty books -- paeans to their careers, written by a designer the winner chooses. The 1997 winner, Rolf Fehlbaum, chief executive of Vitra, a Swiss furniture company, asked Tibor Kalman, a Manhattan graphic designer, to tell his life story -- and famed chair obsession. ''Chairman'' $35, will be in stores in March. Information: (800) 722-6657. ELAINE LOUIE

title: Treasuries Move Lower as Report Shows Strength in Economy
description: Treasury securities were lower yesterday, driven higher early by data showing an absence of inflation but hurt by selling after a report on housing indicated that there was still plenty of strength in the economy.

title: Would Punishing Iraq Carry Too High a Price?; Sign of Weakness
description: To the Editor:

title: Residential Resales
description: Brooklyn

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Is silver the glitter of yesterday? Or is it the new ingredient of the reasonably prudent portfolio?
description: A BATTLE for silver's honor is on. Will silver slip back into a commodity backwater? Or will it, with its newest champion, Warren E. Buffett, supplant gold, and become an investment that is talked about at cocktail parties and that money managers recommend as part of an investor's portfolio?

title: Metro Business; Atlantic City Posts Slight Rise in Visitors
description: The number of visitors to Atlantic City increased slightly last year even though the casino industry had cut back on costly promotions of bus tours that brought people to the casino for the day, the South Jersey Transportation Authority reported on Tuesday.

title: Chinatown Cool To Film Site Role
description: Some businessmen in Chinatown don't want the new OLIVER STONE film, ''The Corruptor,'' to be a disrupter. Never mind that the cast includes CHOW YUN-FAT, who has the box-office power in Asia of a Sylvester Stallone or an Arnold Schwarzenegger: store owners are worried that cameras and crew will choke the neighborhood when location shots are filmed on Mott and Doyers Streets in the spring.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRODSKY, BERNARD, M.D.
description: BRODSKY-Bernard, M.D. Psychoanalyst, 84. Died suddenly February 12, 1998 while swimming in the Caribbean. Beloved husband of Marilyn. Loving father of Nina, Laura and Mary and fatherin-law of Kenneth Roth and Stuart Zura. Adoring grandfather of Lisa and Emma Roth. His passion for life and art, his probing intellect, his dedication to his patients and his love for family and friends, will be warmly remembered and greatly missed. A Memorial Service, Sunday, March 1, 2:30 P.M., at Frank Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave, New York City.

title: Record Big Board Seat Sale
description: A seat on the New York Stock Exchange sold yesterday for a record $1.8 million, exceeding last week's price by $50,000. Stock exchange seats trade at auction much the same as member stocks. The highest current bid for an exchange seat is $1.35 million. The lowest price at which an exchange member is willing to sell a seat is $1.9 million. The exchange does not disclose the names of buyers and sellers.

title: McCann-Erickson Wins 17 Mobius Awards
description: Offices of McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising, part of the McCann-Erickson World Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, won the most awards at the 27th annual Mobius Advertising Awards ceremony, sponsored by the United States Festivals Association.

title: Dow Climbs by 52.56 to Reach Its 6th Consecutive High
description: The indefatigable Dow Jones industrial average rose to another record yesterday, as investors shrugged off the conflict with Iraq and Asian economic concerns and took heart from technology earnings.

title: Would Punishing Iraq Carry Too High a Price?; Other Alternatives
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REINHARD, HERMIA
description: REINHARD-Hermia. The Jewish Center mourns the passing of the beloved mother of its member, Andrew Reinhard. May her family be comforted among those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Jacob J. Schacter, Rabbi Samuel Goldman, President Elza Weinman, Sisterhood

title: Trenton Official Seeks Campaign Fund Change
description: In a letter to state election officials who began a series of hearings yesterday on campaign finance reform, the Senate President, Donald T. DiFrancesco, said that out-of-state contributions should not count toward the $210,000 minimum that candidates must raise to qualify for matching funds.

title: State Panel Rebukes Judge for Lewd Remarks
description: The State Commission on Judicial Conduct publicly censured a judge on the State Supreme Court in Queens yesterday for making sexual remarks to a female employee.

title: Arafat Gaffe Brings Ouster At a Museum
description: The United States Holocaust Memorial Museum forced its director to resign today, ending a troubled tenure that was highlighted by an embarrassing on-again-off-again invitation last month to Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Economic Scene; In Indonesia, Showdown On Risky Bet
description: The stage has been set for the most bitter confrontation in the 53-year history of the International Monetary Fund.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: BLESSINGS CONSIDERS A POSSIBLE SALE OR MERGER
description: The Blessings Corporation said yesterday that it had hired the investment bank Bowles Hollowell Conner & Company to aid in evaluating strategic alternatives to help the company, a plastic-film and packaging maker, continue its global expansion and improve operations. Alternatives include a sale of the company, a merger with another company or an investment by another company or party. Blessings is not currently in talks with any companies about any investments or acquisition, according to its controller, Wayne Durboraw. Shares of Blessings rose $1.50 a share, more than 9 percent, to a three-and-a-half-year high of $17, giving the company a market capitalization of about $172 million.

title: Suharto's Choice as No. 2: Whiz or Loose Cannon?
description: He has designed submarines and railway carriages. He believes that economic growth can be engineered by rapidly bouncing interest rates up and down. He likes to refer to his boss, President Suharto, as S.G.S., for Super Genius Suharto.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, DAVID
description: KATZ-David. February 18, 1998. Of Delray, formerly of Brooklyn and Fort Lee. Self employed advertising executive. Devoted husband of the late Bertie. Survived by two sisters and dear nieces and nephews. A W.W. II veteran. Was active in many charities. Contributions may be made to Deborah Hospital. Funeral services Friday 2 P.M., at Mount Golda Cemetery, Huntington, Long Island.

title: The Neediest Cases; Ex-Addict Helps People With AIDS Get On With Life
description: Almost all recovering addicts can recall the time they hit rock bottom, a moment of clarity that forced them to see beyond the depths of their addiction. For Russelle Miller, it was the day six years ago that she unexpectedly ran into her 14-year-old daughter after a weeklong binge of smoking crack.

title: O'Donnell Might Call The Signals Once More
description: Neil O'Donnell suddenly appears to be emerging again as a viable Jets quarterback. In fact, his agent, Leigh Steinberg, said yesterday that O'Donnell would not easily yield on the Jets' request that he restructure his 1998 salary, which is worth more than $4 million. A $2.75 million advance on that salary is due tomorrow.

title: Study Finds More Views Than Facts
description: More than 40 percent of the early news reports on the investigation of President Clinton's relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky consisted of analysis, opinion and speculation, not factual reporting, according to a watchdog group composed largely of practicing journalists.

title: Placebo Use Halted In Studies of AIDS
description: After finding that $80 of the drug AZT will cut in half the transmission of AIDS from mothers to their newborns, Government health officials are canceling heavily criticized overseas studies that left some pregnant women with the disease receiving only ineffective dummy pills.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption with a dance review on Monday about a performance by Urban Bush Women on Saturday night at Aaron Davis Hall in Manhattan misidentified the dancer in the foreground. She was Diedre Nyota Dawkins, not Kristin McDonald.

title: Johannesburg Journal; Of Leaders and Lovers: A South African Epidemic
description: Will Nelson marry Graca? Will F. W. divorce Marike? Will P. W. stay out of jail long enough to see his wedding day?

title: Crackdown on Errant West Side Cyclists
description: Somewhere on the Upper West Side last night, dozens of people sat waiting for dinners that either never arrived or were stone cold when they did.

title: Popular Detective Will Head Chicago Police
description: To lead a police department beset by corruption, charges of brutality and dissension within the ranks, Mayor Richard M. Daley today chose Terry Hillard, a detective popular among uniformed officers.

title: Page's MSG Deal Is Not Renewed
description: The MSG Network has chosen not to renew the contract of Bob Page, who sprinkled sports news with barbed commentary on ''MSG Sportsdesk.''

title: Design Notebook; Step Right Up: Let an Architect Thrill You
description: ON a gloomy morning in Times Square shrouded in mist, the architect David Rockwell stands inside a steel dome modeled on the Mount Palomar Observatory. A rusted gantry for a Death Saw is suspended ominously over his head.

title: TOP CLINTON AIDES FIND DOUBT ON IRAQ AT CAMPUS IN OHIO
description: The Administration rolled out its big guns here today at Ohio State University to make its case on Iraq, but the three top foreign policy officials were greeted with tough questions, catcalls and a lot of anxiety about American goals.

title: 'Dinosaur' Stirs Mexico's Old Guard
description: Manuel Bartlett Diaz, the Governor of Puebla State, had just outlined his plans to seek the governing party's nomination for the Mexican presidency in elections two years from now.

title: Two Men, One Vision: Films With a View; A Festival Celebrates the Dark Explorations Behind the Decor, Cuisine and Henry James
description: In the movies, where working partnerships generally have the shortest shelf life, the team of Ismail Merchant and James Ivory is a phenomenon. Over the last 35 years, they have made more than 40 films, all produced by Mr. Merchant, more than half directed by Mr. Ivory and many of them written by Ruth Jhabvala.

title: Phillips's Agent Talks to Mets
description: The agent for Tony Phillips is hoping to interest the Mets in his client. The agent, Tony Attanasio, phoned Mets General Manager Steve Phillips on Tuesday to try to sell the team on his 38-year-old client, who was not tendered an offer by the Anaheim Angels after a turbulent 1997 season.

title: Bad Vibes From the Heartland Launch Fleet of Finger-Pointers
description: After years of dabbling in the ''feel your pain'' techniques of Oprah Winfrey, the Clinton White House wound up feeling plenty of its own today.

description: Old Friends, Madcap Hoydens And Balloon Squashing

title: Would Punishing Iraq Carry Too High a Price?; Vietnam's Lesson
description: To the Editor:

title: En Route to Kuwait, G.I.'s Say They Can Meet Any Iraqi Challenge
description: If there is a time for self-reflection in the Army, it should be while soldiers, days away from deployment to the Persian Gulf, wait in line to make sure that their wills, life insurance and medical records are up to date.

title: JAN BELL IS IN $92.8 MILLION DEAL FOR MAYOR'S JEWELERS
description: Jan Bell Marketing Inc. plans to buy the closely held Mayor's Jewelers Inc. for as much as $92.8 million in cash, stock and assumed debt to expand into the retail luxury-jewelry market. Mayor's and shareholders with about a 75 percent stake in Mayor's signed a letter of intent, said Jan Bell, based in Sunrise, Fla., whose primary business is marketing retail products through Wal-Mart Inc.'s Sam's Club unit. The transaction value will be $92.8 million if all Mayor's shares are purchased. The acquisition will give Jan Bell, which had $243.1 million in sales last year, 23 retail stores in Florida and Georgia. Mayor's is based in Coral Gables, Fla.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FERGUSON, MOLLY JEAN (NEE SHUTTLEWORTH)
description: FERGUSON-Molly Jean (nee Shuttleworth). Age 57, of Morris TWP, Sunday, Feb. 15, 1998. Wife of John A., mother of Manie Jean Ferguson Walker, of Hong Kong, and Alexandra Ferguson Goggin, of Mendham, NJ, daughter of Herbert L. and Jean (nee Dutcher) Shuttleworth 2nd, of Amsterdam, New York. A memorial service will be held at 10 A.M. Tuesday, Feb. 24 at the First Presbyterian Church of New Vernon At The Crossroads, Lee's Hill Road, New Vernon, New Jersey. Memorial gifts may be made to The Molly Jean Shuttleworth Ferguson Fund for Cancer, C/O Community Foundation of New Jersey, PO Box 317, Morristown, N.J. 07963-0317. There will be no visitation. For information contact The Bailey Funeral Home Inc., Mendham, N.J.

title: CHANCELLOR MEDIA TO BUY 2 RADIO STATIONS FROM CAPITOL
description: The Chancellor Media Corporation agreed yesterday to buy two Washington radio stations from the Capitol Broadcasting Company for $72 million to become the city's No. 1 radio station group based on market share and revenue. Chancellor said it would acquire the mainstream rock station WWDC-FM and the adult-standard programmer WWDC-AM from the closely held Capitol Broadcasting. Chancellor, based in Irving, Tex., now owns five FM and three AM radio stations in Washington. After the acquisition, Chancellor said, it will rank first or second in revenue in eight of the country's top 10 radio markets in terms of revenue. Chancellor owns 99 radio stations in 21 markets. Its shares rose 56.25 cents, to $40.25.

title: Data Reaffirm Good News On Economy
description: Reinforcing evidence of a robust economy and nearly nonexistent inflation, the Government reported yesterday that prices paid by manufacturers posted the biggest decline in nearly four years last month while housing construction remained vibrant.

title: The McCurry Confessions
description: In past administrations, White House press secretaries have demanded direct access to the President and sometimes complained publicly or quit when they did not get it. But all that has gone by the board with the McCurry Doctrine. President Clinton's spokesman, Mike McCurry, not only boasts about not wanting to know what President Clinton knows about Monica Lewinsky, he abases himself publicly for speaking candidly about his own thoughts as to Mr. Clinton's relationship with the former intern. Mr. McCurry's euphemistic definition of his pre-Lewinsky approach -- ''telling the truth slowly'' -- is a distortion of the job's best traditions. It is also a disservice to the taxpayers who have to pay his salary.

title: The Public Private Past of a Filmmaker's Kin
description: A WRITER wishing to make off with the emotional family jewels need only sit back and reflect; for the documentary filmmaker, it is more difficult. Go home for a party with a sound man and a camera and even the most obtuse member of the family will realize something is cooking.

title: Ready, and at Ease
description: American soldiers heading for the Middle East from Fort Stewart, Ga., are expressing little concern about the dangers they may face. Page A8.

title: New York State Sues Mover, Saying Customers Were Cheated
description: The New York State Attorney General's Office obtained an order yesterday temporarily shutting down a Manhattan-based moving company that it said had bilked 58 New Yorkers out of more than $80,000.

title: AMERICAN ARCHITECTURAL PLANS TO BUY WEATHER-SEAL
description: The Louisiana-Pacific Corporation agreed yesterday to sell its Weather-Seal window and door unit to the American Architectural Products Corporation as part of its effort to shed $1 billion in assets not tied to its main building products lines. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed. Weather-Seal, a regional maker of windows and doors, has seven plants in Ohio and about 750 employees. The purchase is the latest in a series for American Architectural. Louisiana-Pacific said in October that it would sell nonstrategic assets and cut 3,500 jobs in two years to focus on expanding and improving its line of products that compete nationwide. American Architectural, based in Youngstown, Ohio, is also a maker of doors and windows.

description: HARM-Carl S. On Feb. 17, 1998. A leader in the development of Community Boards for Mental Health Centers and a champion of Tenants Rights through his work with Park West Village Tenants Association and related groups. He is survived by his wife of 35 years, Mary Gay Harm; a son, Ronald Carl of Ashland, Oregon; one sister, Margaret Wasem; two grandchildren, nieces and nephews. Memorial service Saturday, Feb. 21, 11AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St.

title: Personal Shopper; Counter Stools: The View From Up Higher
description: LET'S face it, without a tall stool, you would just be standing there. You often pull one up without even noticing, at a kitchen counter or a work table. And they have brought many people luck -- just think of how many romances have started on bar stools.

title: Imperfect Alice
description: The misspellings in Central Park have Parks Commissioner HENRY J. STERN running around like the Mad Hatter. Yesterday, just a day after he had signs that spelled the Mayor's name ''Guiliani'' fixed, someone alerted Mr. Stern to a mistake on the Alice in Wonderland statue. ''All mimsy were the borogroves,'' it says. Lewis Carroll's word was ''borogoves.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERAGHTY, MARY (NEE TUBRIDY)
description: GERAGHTY-Mary (nee Tubridy). Of Riverdale, NY on February 17, in her 88th year. Native of Clohanmore, Cree, Co. Clare, Ireland. Loving wife of the late Matthew. Dear mother of John, Joseph and Edward and mother-in-law of Margaret and Barbara. Cherished grandmother of Kate and Elizabeth. Dear sister of Peggy Hamann, Michael and Thomas Tubridy and Paddy Tubridy (Ireland) and Sean Tubridy (England) and sister-in-law of Cecily Geraghty. Dear aunt to many. Reposing Thursday 2-4 and 7-9PM, at Riverdale-On-Hudson Funeral Home, 6110 Riverdale Avenue. Mass of Christian Burial Friday 10am at St. Margaret of Cortona Church. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations to Fordham Prep School, East Fordham Road, Bronx, NY 10458 would be greatly appreciated.

description: Garth H. Drabinsky likes to visit the theater he just finished building in Manhattan and watch the crowds stream in to see the musical he just finished producing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MC KINNEY, KENT
description: MC KINNEY-Kent, 61, horseman, master film editor. On February 16, 1998 in Columbia, MO. Survived by Elizabeth, Wickety and Cappy Hotchkiss, Megan Whitfield, Molly Farmer, Doyne Mc Kenzie.

description: LEHRER-Arthur. On February 15, 1998. description: DRUKIER-Charles. Beloved husband of the late Toby. Devoted father of Ira. Father-in-law of Gale and adored grandfather of Jennifer. He was charismatic, gentle and strong. All those who were fortunate to know him will always remember and miss him. His good deeds were boundless, and there will always be a place for ''Chaskel'' in our hearts. Services Friday, 9AM, Schwartz Brothers Memorial Chapel, Queens Boulevard and 76th Road, Forest Hills.

The account has been handled by four agencies before Zurich combined Scudder, Stevens & Clark with Zurich Kemper Investments.

description: Of all the failures under Communist rule in East Germany, none received as much ridicule as the smoke-belching little box of a car known as the Trabant.

description: Taxpayers will have the opportunity to donate to the state's missing children's fund on their New York tax forms this year.

description: A new salary cap and a new general manager have not changed the Giants' basic operating principle when it comes to dealing with its young, most promising players.

title: HOMEUSA SHARES SOAR ON $162 MILLION FLEETWOOD DEAL
description: The stock of the mobile home retailer HomeUSA Inc. jumped 18 percent yesterday after the company said Tuesday that it had agreed to be purchased by Fleetwood Enterprises Inc. Fleetwood's offer was $10.25 a share in cash or Fleetwood stock -- a total of $162 million. Shares of HomeUSA rose $1.4375 to close at $9.8125. Shares of Fleetwood rose $1.875, to $46.625. Fleetwood, based in Riverside, Calif., a housing and recreational-vehicles maker, said it would not pay more than 49 percent of the price in cash and expects to close the deal in about four months.

We are so saddened by our loss. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to his family.

title: Sinn Fein Argues for Ban on Ouster From Talks
description: Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, argued in the Irish Republic's High Court here today for an order to forbid the Irish and British Governments to expel the party from the Northern Ireland peace talks, but the hearing was adjourned until Thursday with no decision.

He is survived by his wife Claudia Jones Cleaver of Amherst, Massachusetts, his five children, Kevin Cleaver of Bethesda, Maryland, Claudia Cleaver of Petaluma, California, Carole Cleaver of New York, N.Y., Cynthia Margiotta of Gillette, Wyoming, and Jacqueline Cleaver of Richmond, Virginia, and six grandchildren. Funeral services will be held at Leeds Church in Markham, Virginia on Thursday, February 19 at 2:00PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLAMM, DONALD
description: FLAMM-Donald. The officers and Board of Directors of the Hebrew Free Loan Society mourn the loss of Donald Flamm, Vice-President and Board member for over 50 years. May they be consoled among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. David Durst, Chairman Judah Gribetz, President Shana Novick, Executive Director

description: A small chartered plane carrying Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross went out of control today after leaving the ground during takeoff at Buffalo-Niagara International Airport, skidding into a grassy field, according to the authorities.

description: Paris, Milan, Seventh Avenue and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, please take note.

title: A Purgatory Of Auditions
description: Barry is the kind of gruff-voiced guy who says ''Listen, doll'' to total strangers. Sid is the kind who holds his cupped hands in front of his chest to indicate the size of a woman's breasts. Arnie seems harmless, but if he's casting a summer-theater show with the other two, he can't be very nice.

title: Jurors Seem Weary As Brawley Trial Plods
description: There are about 700 pages of testimony, transcripts and other court papers that have been used as evidence in the Tawana Brawley defamation case, and yesterday the weary jury heard more of them.

title: Auto Makers to Buy More From Minority-Owned Companies
description: The Clinton Administration has reached an agreement with the Big Three auto makers to increase their purchases from minority-owned companies by nearly $3 billion by the year 2001, officials from the Administration and the auto makers said today.

title: Calendar; Celebrating Alvar Aalto
description: Aalto Retrospective

title: A Combo Platter of Royal Self-Ruin
description: In his back-to-back productions of ''Richard II'' and ''Richard III,'' the director Ron Daniels presents opposing portraits of royal self-destruction. ''My large kingdom for a little grave,'' wails the self-pitying poet, Richard II, resigned to his demise. ''My kingdom for a horse!'' cries the bloody man of action, Richard III, sneering at oblivion to the last.

title: Western Slopes Wooing Discerning New Yorkers
description: The ski area at Jackson Hole, Wyo., was on its way last month to a record-breaking snow year. Less snow this month has moderated those expectations. But banner year or not, Jackson Hole wasn't worrying. Having wooed New Yorkers over the last decade, the mountain resort knew it could depend on its discerning New York crowd.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''This is a tremendous example of what democracy is all about. People expressing their opinions would not be able to do that in a number of countries, including Iraq.''

title: Would Punishing Iraq Carry Too High a Price?; A Complete Blockade
description: To the Editor:

title: Democratic Fund-Raiser Indicted in Campaign Finance Abuses
description: A Federal grand jury today indicted a Democratic fund-raiser, Maria Hsia, on charges that she laundered illegal contributions through a Buddhist temple in California to the re-election campaigns of President Clinton, Senator Edward M. Kennedy and other politicians between 1993 and 1996.

title: More Police on Wall Street
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's endorsement of a plan to place a new police substation in Manhattan's Wall Street area sends the troubling message that wealthier communities can buy more police attention. That area is already one of the safest in the city. Dozens of other neighborhoods have a greater need for police, yet they will not benefit from a new station because they cannot afford to pay.

title: DNA Databanks Giving Police A Powerful Weapon, and Critics
description: Of all the new thrills that DNA analysis offers forensic scientists, nothing seems to beat what they call a ''cold hit'': when a computer discovers the identity of a killer or rapist by matching DNA from blood, semen or saliva left at a crime scene with a DNA profile in a database. A criminal is fingered by his own genes.

title: Kenneth Frankel, 56, Director Won Obie for Broadway Show
description: Kenneth Frankel, a prolific stage director who won an Obie award for his production of Simon Gray's ''Quartermaine's Terms'' and staged the premiere of Mark Medoff's ''When You Comin' Back, Red Ryder?,'' died last Thursday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 56.

title: Columbia/HCA Is Target Of U.S. Search in El Paso
description: In the first seizure of evidence from the company since July, Federal law-enforcement officials on Tuesday served a new search warrant at the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation's corporate offices in El Paso, participants in the case said yesterday.

title: Suspension for Racism Is Upheld by Court
description: In separate decisions yesterday, the State Supreme Court ruled that a municipal employee can be punished for using a racial slur against a colleague, and that even a single instance of racial name calling by a supervisor can constitute job discrimination.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELLHORN, MARTHA
description: GELLHORN-Martha. We note with sorrow the passing of Martha Gellhorn, staunch supporter and devoted life-long friend of the International Brigades and the Spanish Republic. Veterans of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade

title: Sports of The Times; Message in Defeat: Big Boys Don't Cry
description: THEY certainly won't be remembered for their sum performance, or even one particular game. The 1998 United States men's Olympic hockey team may not have bored us to tears, but in defeat moved absolutely no one to cry, not even the American hockey women, who the previous night nearly melted the ice inside the Big Hat Arena.

title: A Raucous Meeting on Iraq
description: Madeleine Albright, William Cohen and Samuel Berger traveled to Ohio State University in Columbus yesterday to explain America's Iraq policy to the heartland, no doubt expecting a warm reception and a dignified setting. Instead the Secretary of State, the Secretary of Defense and the national security adviser found themselves parrying hostile questions and competing with a small but noisy band of protesters, all of it broadcast around the world by CNN.

title: Mayor Orders Review of Plan For Substation
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani took a step back last night from his whole-hearted endorsement of the Police Department's agreement to accept $5 million from a business group to put a substation near Wall Street, demanding that a key detail be dropped and ordering a review of the arrangement in the coming months.

title: Nets Fail Task at Hand Before Trade Deadline
description: Jayson Williams walked into the Nets' locker room before tonight's game and jokingly asked reporters: ''So what's the latest? Is Christian Laettner coming?''

title: Brazil's Brighter Future
description: Cynics used to joke that Brazil is the country of the future, and always will be. For decades its rich economic potential was squandered by political mismanagement. But with a set of sensible financial reforms, President Fernando Henrique Cardoso has improved the odds that Brazil's prosperous future may yet arrive, at least for its middle and upper classes. Mr. Cardoso, who seeks re-election this year, must now see that the poor majority also stands to benefit.

title: Legislative Divisions Threaten Toxic Cleanup Program
description: New York State's Superfund program, created in the wake of Love Canal and considered one of the most effective cleanup programs in the nation, is in danger of running out of money as lawmakers here are deeply divided about its future.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 12 about the growing number of lawyers connected to Kenneth W. Starr's investigation of President Clinton misspelled the surname of a judge and civil rights leader, now deceased, who was a friend to some of them. He was H. Carl Moultrie, not Moultri.

title: Essay; Support Your President
description: Bill Clinton has decided he will not be the President to bring down Saddam Hussein or even to eliminate Iraq's potential for terror warfare.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANLEY, WILLIAM J.
description: HANLEY-William J. Of Scarsdale, NY, of Feb. 16. Beloved husband of Marjorie. Loving father of Richard, Patrick, Claire, Philip and Larry. Bennet Funeral Home, Scarsdale Friday 7-9PM. Funeral Mass, I.H.M. Scarsdale, 10AM Saturday. Interment at 2 P.M., Monday, St. Mary's Cemetery, Salem, Mass.

title: Would Punishing Iraq Carry Too High a Price?; What Bush Did
description: To the Editor:

title: Former New York Official To Lead Philadelphia Police
description: Reacting to criticism that Philadelphia's police force is ineffective, sometimes corrupt and in dire need of new blood, Mayor Edward G. Rendell reached outside the city today and hired a new police commissioner, John F. Timoney, former first deputy commissioner in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOMAZOV, ELSIE
description: LOMAZOV-Elsie. On February 18, 1998. Of Masssapequa Park, L.I. Beloved wife of the late Aaron. Devoted mother of Bernice and Jerome Zwanger, M.D. Dear sister of Harry Rudish. Adored grandmother of Susan, Roberta, Melissa and Betsy. Cherished great grandmother of Eva, Alisa, David, Daniel, Julia, Emily and Elliot. Services on Friday at 1 P.M., at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island.

title: Arnold Aronson, 86, Leader In Struggle for Civil Rights
description: Arnold Aronson, who devoted six decades to the civil rights struggle and was a planner of the 1963 March on Washington and a founder of the Leadership Conference on Civil Rights, died on Tuesday at his home in Wheaton, Md. He was 86.

title: 2 Companies in Deal For Arthritis Drug
description: The Monsanto Company's G. D. Searle unit said today that it had entered an agreement with Pfizer Inc. to promote and develop new Searle arthritis drugs, which could be the first of a new class of painkillers that do not irritate the stomach.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, JEANNE GORDON
description: GOLDMAN-Jeanne Gordon, 80. On February 17, 1998, after a valiant fight with long-term chronic illnesses. Of McLean, VA, former NYC opera singer, poet, artist, wife, mother, and grandmother. Beloved wife (for 56 years) of George S. Goldman, M.D.; loving mother of Kathryn Louise and her fiance James Schuyler, S. Amber Gordon and her husband Mark J. Estren; devoted and cherished grandmother of Meredith and Nicholas Estren. Also loved by surviving sisters-in-law Berenice Finkelstone and Wallye Rosenbluth, and numerous nieces, nephews and cousins. She will forever be in the hearts of those whose lives she touched. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Fairfax Hospital Fund for Nursing Excellence, INOVA Health Foundation, 8001 Braddock Rd, Springfield, VA 22151. A memorial service will be held Sunday, February 22, 3 PM, at McLean Community Center, 1234 Ingleside Avenue, McLean, VA.

title: Arrest Is Made in the Killing Of a South Amboy Schoolgirl
description: A man described by the police as a transient was arrested last night in the bludgeoning death of a 15-year-old New Jersey schoolgirl.

title: Events; Art, Crafts and Flowers
description: An Artist's Work

title: Metro Business; Penncorp in Buyout Talks
description: The Penncorp Financial Group of Manhattan said yesterday that it is negotiating a management-led buyout of two of its insurance subsidiaries.

title: Nagano Sees the Artistry of Kwan
description: Tara Lipinski issued a challenge with the performance of her life tonight and Michelle Kwan answered it with a short program that was deliberate and safe, but precise and refined enough under great pressure to win first place on eight of the nine judges' cards. The judges have shown that they favor elegance in the Olympic Winter Games, and Kwan is one of the most artistic skaters in history.

title: Two Witnesses Called by Starr Could Shed Some Light on the 'Talking Points'
description: Three pages of ''talking points'' said to have been given by Monica S. Lewinsky to her friend, Linda R. Tripp, are one of the enduring mysteries of the investigation into the relationship between President Clinton and Ms. Lewinsky.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERRICK, SNOWDEN TERHUNE
description: HERRICK - Snowden Terhune. Born 4th of March, 1919. Son of H.T. and Elinore Morehouse Herrick. Deceased 18 February, 1998 of leukemia. Is survived by his wife Casey Isaacs Herrick. Daughter of Stanley M. Isaacs, former Borough President of Manhattan. And his son Michael Morehouse Herrick of the Netherlands. Was Deputy Director of the United Nations Center for Economic and Social Information (1969-1979). Chief of Public Information Branch of the International Labor Organization (ILO) 1954-1967 while stationed in Geneva, Switzerland. He was also known as a civil rights activist; during W.W. II U.S. Air Force Captain Public Information Officer. A graduate of Yale University class of '40. No service held. Visitors welcome after 5 P.M. at 345 East 73 St, New York City. No flowers please. Contributions can be made to The Stanley M. Isaacs Neighborhood Center.

title: 15-Year-Old to Stand Trial As an Adult in Strangling
description: The 15-year-old New Jersey youth accused of strangling a sixth grader who was selling school candy door to door last September was ordered today to stand trial for murder as an adult, exposing him, if convicted, to life in prison without parole.

title: Going After Shark, With a Tongue That's Sharp
description: IN THE SLICK OF THE CRICKET

title: Would Punishing Iraq Carry Too High a Price?; Creating a Hero
description: To the Editor:

title: Conference on Car-Truck Crashes Is Planned
description: The Federal highway safety agency announced today that it would convene an international conference here in early June to analyze what happens when cars collide with so-called light trucks -- sport utility vehicles, pickups and mini-vans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEBEL, PATRICIA STEWART
description: NEBEL-Patricia Stewart. On Feb. 11, 1998, at Norwalk Hospital in Norwalk, CT. She is survived by daughter, Victoria of San Francisco, CA., son, Christopher of Gilford, CT., son, Dino of Westport, Ct., and four grandchildren. Born in London in 1928, she was awarded a scholarship to the University of London, studied with Jean Piaget in Geneva, and received her Master's Degree through a fellowship at Bank Street College of Education in New York. In 1956 she married Emil Nebel, son of prominent Westport sculptor Berthold Nebel, and moved to Westport, Ct. In 1963 she became Director of the Westport - Weston Cooperative Nursery School and retired 30 years later in 1993. Passionate advocate for child-centered preschool education, beloved mother and grandmother, cherished confidante, Mentor and friend, she will be missed by many. A Memorial Service will be held 1pm, Saturday, Feb. 21 at the Unitarian Church, 10 Lyons Plains Road, Westport, CT. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to The Pat Nebel Grandchildren Education Fund c/o the Westport-Weston Cooperative Nursery School, 10 Lyons Plains Road, Westport, CT. 06880.

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: Fallen Angels

title: Looking for Answers, Rangers Dismiss Campbell
description: The ax that often seemed about to fall on Colin Campbell finally descended on him yesterday, with the Rangers firing their head coach with just 25 games to go in a hugely disappointing regular season.

title: Police Union Will Conduct an Internal Inquiry Into Its Finances
description: Faced with a group of dissident delegates questioning its finances, the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, the powerful union representing police officers, hired a retired judge yesterday to conduct an internal inquiry into any allegations of misconduct.

title: Bridge; Goading the Opponents Into a Slam That Will Fail
description: Books based on newspaper columns are seldom very readable, but ''The Times Book of Bridge'' by Robert Sheehan is an exception. It is available from The Bridge World for $16.95 including mailing. Information: (800) 599-0033.

title: Sports of The Times; Bronze Medal Was There for the Taking
description: HER eyes were watering before she left the ice. It wasn't that the judges had consigned her to third-quadrant hell, it was that Nicole Bobek had done it to herself.

title: Currents; YOUTH CENTERS -- Crime-Fighting Design
description: The latest project by Russell Shubin, a Los Angeles architect, isn't renovation so much as it is disarmament. His firm, Shubin & Donaldson, which completed one youth center in South-Central Los Angeles in 1995 (top), is within three months of completing another, near Watts, for the Los Angeles County Sheriff's Youth Foundation.

title: Graf Wins In Singles Comeback
description: Showing no signs of the knee injury that threatened to end her career, Steffi Graf made a successful singles comeback yesterday in Hanover, Germany.

title: Some CUNY Trustees Seek To End All Remedial Courses
description: Just weeks after Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani called on the community colleges of the City University of New York to drop their remedial programs and refuse to take students who are not ready for college-level work, some of the university's own trustees opened another flank by proposing that the senior colleges stop offering remedial classes.

title: Happy Dog Story
description: If only PRINCE, a long-haired Belgian tervuren that is insured for $100,000, had had a first-class seat.

title: Mexico Accuses Foreigners of Aiding Rebels
description: The Government is clamping down on foreigners in the troubled state of Chiapas who show support for the Zapatista guerrillas or monitor events in Indian regions where the rebel movement is active.

title: Seton Hall Gets an Assist From a Freshman Guard
description: SETON HALL 64, RUTGERS 54

title: Ziff-Davis Expects to Raise $460 Million
description: The computer magazine publisher Ziff-Davis Inc. expects to raise $460 million through an initial public offering of stock in the United States, Ziff's Japanese parent said today.

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column in Business Day yesterday, about marketing and the film ''Titanic,'' omitted a word in the title of a coming book about the sinking of Titanic. It is ''The Titanic Disaster Hearings: The Official Transcripts of the 1912 Senate Investigation.''

title: Turf; Walls That'll Always Have Venice
description: JUST a year ago, the faded murals in the grand ballroom of this larger-than-life apartment not only depicted ruins -- they were ruins; the fake cracks in the walls had turned to real ones, and the paint had started to fall off.

title: Harry Caray, 78, Colorful Baseball Announcer, Dies
description: Harry Caray, whose zesty, raucous style of baseball play-by-play electrified airwaves and roused fans for more than half a century, died yesterday at Eisenhower Medical Center in Rancho Mirage, Calif. He was 78.

title: Tommy John Joins Yankee Broadcasts
description: Tommy John was added to the Yankees' broadcast booth on Channel 11 yesterday, joining his former teammate Bobby Murcer on the station's 50-game schedule. John replaces Rick Cerone, who has moved on to the Baltimore Orioles.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: SOUTH KOREAN WON WEAKENS. The won fell more than 4 percent to its weakest level in three weeks despite a rally in South Korean stocks and a sovereign debt upgrade by Standard & Poor's. In New York it cost 1,688 won to buy a dollar, compared with 1,620.50 on Tuesday.

title: Fortunes for U.S. Are Mixed on Ice
description: YOUNG GUNS -- The best performance of 15-year-old Tara Lipinski's life was not quite enough, as 17-year-old Michelle Kwan skated a safe, precise short program and took the lead in women's figure skating going into the long program. Page C1.

title: 5,000 Lose Power After Fire in Switch
description: A fire in an electrical switch cut power to 5,000 Brooklyn residents for two hours last night, Con Edison said. Three firefighters were slightly hurt.

title: Would Punishing Iraq Carry Too High a Price?; Libya Evades Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: Accuser Tells of 1996 Encounter With Army's Top Sergeant
description: One afternoon in Florida in 1996, Sgt. 1st Class Rita Jeczala said, she offered some spiritual guidance to Sgt. Maj. Gene C. McKinney, who was then the Army's highest-ranking enlisted soldier. Sergeant Major McKinney had recently lost his only child in an automobile accident, and Sergeant Jeczala had seen grief in his eyes as he lectured the recruiters at her station at Rockledge, Fla., about the importance of family.

title: Sports of The Times; Another 54 Years To Wait?
description: IT'S only four years since the Rangers won the Stanley Cup, but already there's a fear that it will be another 50 before they win it again. If the Rangers' magic number of years between gulps of Champagne is again 54, there's no need for anyone still wearing Mark Messier's replica Ranger sweater to react angrily to all those taunting chants of ''1994'' that will be heard on Long Island and in New Jersey in the decades to come.

title: Police Cannot Find Burglar, but They Can Read His Film Proposal
description: He was the smoothest of the smooth, a burglar who took only the finest jewelry from the finest homes in Greenwich, Conn., and Westchester County.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREEN, EDNA REINHERZ
description: GREEN-Edna Reinherz. Age 99. On February 15, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Mortimer J. Green. Devoted mother of Robert and Donald. Dear mother-in-law of Estelle and Carol Green. Cherished grandmother of Michael, Peter, Margaret, Matthew, Sara and Mark. Loving great-grandmother of Quinn. Service Thursday 10AM at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Interment at Shaaray Pardes Cemetery, Easthampton, LI

title: A Web of Patterns Colored by Emotion
description: Doug Varone's dances rush headlong into movement that spills, even spools out onstage. There is a dazzle to these complex, swiftly formed patterns.

title: Streaking Into Utah, Knicks Get Blindsided
description: The game was being finished by the extras as the Knick starters sat on the bench the entire fourth quarter with their chins resting on their knees, almost in the fetal position.

title: Would Punishing Iraq Carry Too High a Price?
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 More Officers Disciplined in Louima Case
description: In the latest round of disciplinary actions to arise from the 70th Precinct police torture case, two anti-crime officers have been placed on modified duty for withholding information about the alleged attack from Federal investigators and police detectives, officials said yesterday.

title: Scouts Like Him
description: ''Put your minds at rest,'' MICHAEL GREENE, the president of the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences and MAYOR RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI's least favorite impresario, told the crowd at the Waldorf-Astoria. ''Despite recent

title: Would Punishing Iraq Carry Too High a Price?; Six-Point Test
description: To the Editor:

title: Currents; GLASSWORKS -- Murano Does the Renaissance
description: An exhibition of blown glass at the Boca Raton Museum of Fine Art in Florida celebrates 600 years of glassmaking by the Seguso family on the island of Murano, near Venice. One hundred reproductions, in limited editions of six, are available at the museum or at the Seguso Viro showroom in New York. Some of the objects are interpretations of vessels found in Renaissance paintings.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: DONALDSON, LUFKIN & JENRETTE INC., New York, the investment firm, said its board had declared a 2-for-1 stock split, payable on May 11 to shareholders of record as of April 27.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHN, ARTHUR
description: COHN-Arthur. The American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers mourns the loss of its esteemed member, Arthur Cohn, an inspired composer, author, publisher, violonist, conductor and courageous advocate for 20th Century music. At age 87, he continued to serve on ASCAP's Special Classification Committee, and earned consecutive ASCAP annual awards since 1960. He was also a Deems Taylor Awards recipient for his seminal writings. To his wife Lois, daughter Leslie, and son Alan, we extend heartfelt sympathy from his ASCAP colleagues and friends. Marilyn Bergman President & Chairman, ASCAP

title: Bob Merrill, 74, Composer and Lyricist, Dies
description: Bob Merrill, one of Tin Pan Alley's most prolific tunesmiths, who wrote music, lyrics or both for popular Broadway musicals including ''Funny Girl'' and had the nation tapping its toes to such novelty hits as ''How Much Is That Doggie in the Window?,'' was found dead in his car on Tuesday in Culver City, Calif. He was 74 and lived in Beverly Hills.

title: COOPER CAMERON TO BUY ORBIT VALVE FOR $100 MILLION
description: The Cooper Cameron Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the privately held Orbit Valve International Inc. for about $100 million in cash. Orbit, based in Little Rock, Ark., manufactures valves for the oil, gas and petrochemical industries. The company had 1997 revenues of about $85 million. Cooper Cameron, a Houston-based oil industry equipment supplier, had 1997 revenues of $1.81 billion. Shares of Cooper Cameron rose $1.75, to $51.25.

title: Placebo Use Is Suspended In Overseas AIDS Trials
description: Saying they have finally found a cheap way for developing nations to use the drug AZT to reduce mother-to-infant transmission of the AIDS virus, Government health officials announced yesterday that they were suspending the use of dummy pills in a series of controversial overseas experiments on pregnant women.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stocks Keep Climbing, Paced by Nike Shares

title: Maier, After All That, Takes His Second Gold
description: Hermann Maier came to these Olympics with a legitimate chance to win four gold medals. He ended up with two, but anyone who saw his once-in-a-lifetime crash in the downhill knows that Maier was fortunate, not unfortunate, in Japan.

title: Would Punishing Iraq Carry Too High a Price?; Small-Scale Production
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTOCK, CHARLES, MD.
description: WEINSTOCK-Charles, MD. The William Alanson White Psychoanalytic Institute and the William Alanson White Psychoanalytic Society note with profound sorrow the death of an Institute graduate, a Society member, a colleague and friend. Dr. Weinstock's earnest and assiduous endeavors towards the well-being of the Institute and the Society touched many hearts. His gentle presence will be missed. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wonderful family. Marylou Lionells, PhD, Director, White Institute Allison Stern Rosen, PhD, President, White Society

title: Huskey Has Impressed Mets With Professional Attitude
description: Butch Huskey didn't hear all the talk this off season about the Mets' interest in acquiring Gary Sheffield, who plays the same position as he does. Huskey had his own agenda anyway.

title: Lucent Is Planning a 2-for-1 Stock Split
description: Lucent Technologies Inc., whose shares have more than tripled since its spinoff from the AT&T Corporation, said today that it had scheduled a 2-for-1 stock split.

title: UNITED VIDEO IN $229.5 MILLION DEAL WITH LIBERTY MEDIA
description: United Video Satellite Group Inc. said yesterday that it would buy some satellite broadcasting interests from the Liberty Media Group unit of Tele-Communications Inc. for about $229.5 million in stock, raising Tele-Communications' stake in United Video. United Video will issue about 6.375 million shares to Liberty in exchange for Netlink International, a provider of distant-broadcast signals to cable-television operators, and Liberty's 40 percent stake in Superstar/Netlink Group, their joint venture that sells programming to satellite customers. Liberty is the programming arm of TCI, the nation's largest cable-television company. Shares of United Video rose $1.375, to $37.375; Liberty Media's class A shares fell 50 cents, to $25.625, and Tele-Communications rose 40.625 cents, to $29.53125.

title: Tribute Serves Gershwin Over Easy, on the Cool Side
description: For ''Sweet and Low-Down,'' one of several Carnegie Hall Jazz Band concerts this year that will celebrate the centennial of George Gershwin's birth, the guitarist Howard Alden led a sextet at Weill Recital Hall on Tuesday night. The group, a boiled-down version of the Carnegie Hall Jazz Band -- including Steve Turre on trombone, Renee Rosnes on piano and Dick Oatts on saxophone, alongside guitar, bass and drums -- played about a dozen tunes. The instrumentation and the dynamics of the room did more to define the evening than Mr. Alden's arrangements.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORELLI, MILDRED
description: MORELLI-Mildred. The partners and staff of Lipsky, Goodkin & Company, PC, deeply mourn the passing of Mildred Morelli, a lovely and gracious lady, mother of our esteemed client and friend of many years, Ben Morelli. Our heartfelt condolences to him and his family. Lipsky, Goodkin & Co.

title: Would Punishing Iraq Carry Too High a Price?; Simplistic Accounts
description: To the Editor:

title: Public Eye; 30 Years After '2001': A Furniture Odyssey
description: THE future has been aging lately, at least on screen. Production designers for new movies -- even for over-the-top productions like the 1997 film ''The Fifth Element'' -- reflexively turn to the same furniture that appeared long ago in movies about the future. Last year's science-fiction hit ''Men in Black'' was locked into an Eero-period look for its headquarters: Eero Aarnio's 1965 Ball chair, in which Will Smith wriggles uncomfortably, and Eero Saarinen's 1956 pedestal table, which Mr. Smith drags noisily across the floor.

title: Making Books; A Big Anomaly In Short Stories
description: It's like trying to sell Joyce. Few things make publishers and agents scurry away faster than short stories. Well, maybe poetry does, since occasionally a short story becomes a movie. So it was a thundery occurrence in book publishing when Viking Penguin recently beat out eight other bidders at an auction and paid a $275,000 advance for a collection of short stories by a woman who writes advertising copy.

title: Would Punishing Iraq Carry Too High a Price?; No More Alamos
description: To the Editor:

title: Wall Collapses at Warehouse in Brooklyn
description: The rear wall of an abandoned, two-story warehouse collapsed in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon.

title: Currents; OLYMPICS -- Can You Read the Icons?
description: The most visible symbols of the Olympic Winter Games on television this evening will be Michelle Kwan and Tara Lipinski in a preview of their free skate programs. Less dramatic, but ubiquitous behind the scenes are the 15 curvaceous pictograms representing athletes in motion. The icons were designed for the games by Landor Associates International. While not as saccharine as the Snowlets, the games' official mascots, inset, the pictograms appear everywhere. Six abstracted ones make up the attenuated petals of the snow flower, official symbol of the winter games. More than 100 Landor designers in seven countries, including Japan, labored over the snow flower. ''When you're designing for the Olympics, you're creating an entity that has two weeks to live,'' said Kay Stout, chief marketing and creative strategist for Landor, best known as a shaper of corporate identity. Some may see the pictograms as contemporary hieroglyphics. Milton Glaser, the graphic designer, said: ''The world has gone logo crazy. Nine times out of 10, a word would be most understandable.'' Yo, is that a bobsled, or Shamu? A nouveau Rorschach test: Can you guess which sports the snow flower represents? Or identify the pictograms at right? We couldn't. (See below.) PATRICIA LEIGH BROWN

title: Currents; ANTIQUES -- Titanic Splendor on the Block
description: If you missed bidding on Titanic memorabilia on Tuesday at Christie's (a batch of telegraphed distress signals went for $123,500), maybe you'd like to bid on a $160,000 dining room from Titanic's sister ship, Olympic. On May 19, Sotheby's Sussex plans to put the elaborately carved French walnut paneling and fixtures on the block. They were installed in a home in Southport, England, when Olympic was taken out of service in 1935. Production designers referred to photographs of this Edwardian interior in making the dining room for the film ''Titanic.'' Information: (212) 606-7285. TIMOTHY JACK WARD

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BALKE, HENRY
description: BALKE-Henry. We are saddened by the passing of a good friend and dedicated Auxiliary volunteer. Our deepest sympathy is extended to his family members. Hilary Chilton, President, Auxiliary North Shore University Hospital Manhasset

title: In America; Suffering for Saddam
description: It is very difficult to grasp the immensity of the suffering of the Iraqi people. They are led by a madman who lurches from one ruinous war to another, who builds palaces while his people die by the tens of thousands in hospitals that barely have electricity let alone adequate medicine and functioning equipment, who indulges his fetish for poison gases and other fiendish weapons even as depressed and hungry Iraqi children take to the streets to beg for a few pathetic mouthfuls of food.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMELS, IRVING WILLIAM
description: SIMELS-Irving William, 85. Son of Louis and Lee. Mount Vernon and Bronx, dentist for over 45 years, beloved husband of Lilyan, father of Toba Stutz, and Robert Simels, grandfather of Edward, Jennifer and Rebecca Stutz, and Alexandra Simels, and his brother Raymond. Brother-in-law to Ruth Kaslof, Uncle to Tina Harriet and Lisa. Former Lieutenant in U.S. Army during W.W. II and a Freemason Lodge Mt. Masada. Stuyvesant H.S. Arista Hon. society, NYU. Case Western Reserve. Shiva observed at 21 East Ridge Road in Waccabuc. Funeral to be held on Friday, February 20 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Broad Street, Mount Vernon.

title: Judge Not, Law Schools Demand Of a Magazine That Ranks Them
description: Emotional distress. Loss of income. Grave injury to bragging rights.

title: From Dazed, To Ousted, To Dejected
description: One day after the United States women's hockey team turned in an inspiring gold-medal performance, the more heralded men's team made a quiet and feeble exit from the Olympic tournament with a 4-1 loss to the Czech Republic today.

title: For U.N. Chief, Scarcely Room For Negotiating
description: Kofi Annan didn't want to be a messenger.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Prime Minister Aims to Make Italy Competitive : Prodi Rolls Out Reforms
description: ROME  With little fanfare, the government of Prime Minister Romano Prodi has begun to roll out a series of free-market reforms to deregulate the retail sector, the stock market and the bureaucracy.

title: Currents; TRADE SECRET -- Adding Translucent Texture
description: An architect's secret is out: Subtly patterned Masterglass, which adds texture and defines a space without closing it off, is now for sale to homeowners. Seen in stores like Emporio Armani, the panels can be used as shower or cabinet doors, dividers and shelving, or to hide an unsightly view. Designed and made in France, it comes in stripes, dots, dashes and squares at Bendheim Architectural Glass, 122 Hudson Street (North Moore Street), for $12.50 a square foot. For safety, as a divider, it should be tempered. Information: (212) 226-6370. ELAINE LOUIE

title: DART BUYS BACK FOUNDING-FAMILY MEMBER'S SHARES
description: The Dart Group Corporation, operator of the Crown Books Corporation and other businesses, said yesterday that it had bought back all shares held by Ronald Haft, a member of the company's founding family. The company also ended its two-class common stock structure and adopted a shareholder rights plan to thwart unwanted takeover offers. The company purchased 407,818 class A nonvoting shares and 222,294 class B voting shares from Mr. Haft by forgiving a $77.6 million loan to Mr. Haft and paying about $800,000 cash. Mr. Haft had borrowed the money to buy the shares. Dart, based in Landover, Md., also abolished the dual-class common stock structure. All of its common stock will now have one vote a share. Dart shares rose $4, to $121.50.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PALAMARA, SISTER LORETTA, M.S.C.
description: PALAMARA - Sister Loretta, M.S.C. First anniversary Memorial Mass, Thursday, February 26, 1998, at 12 Noon in the Chapel of the Cabrini Medical Center.

title: Usinor Profit Rose Sharply in '97 2d Half
description: Usinor S.A., Europe's No. 2 steelmaker, said yesterday that its profit had almost doubled in the second half of 1997 and would rise further this year as stronger demand from European manufacturers pushed prices higher. Usinor earned 1.254 billion francs ($205 million), up from 656 million francs in the second half of 1996. The steep rise, however, was less than analysts had expected.

title: An Appreciation / She Covered 7 Wars but Preferred Writing Fiction : Martha Gellhorn:A Life of Wit and Rage
description: PARIS  Martha Gellhorn died Sunday, the day before she had planned to fly to Luxor for some swimming and uncrowded sightseeing since she reckoned that there would be no tourists about after the recent massacre and, although nearly blind, even she would be able to see the outsized monuments of Karnak.

title: On My Mind; Who Was President?
description: For at least five months, all through the latest crisis created by Saddam Hussein, Bill Clinton failed to carry out one of the most important of any President's duties to the American public.

title: Seikaly Traded to Nets in a Last-Minute Deal
description: John Calipari was ready to call it a night, content to let the National Basketball Association trading deadline pass without making a move, when the phone rang at 5:15 this evening. On the other end was the Nets' general manager, John Nash, reporting an offer that caused Calipari, the team's coach, to take off the coat and settle down for a long night.

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: No Vacancies In a Busy Season

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a crackdown on aggressive bicycle riders on the Upper West Side of Manhattan misstated the cause of death for Arthur Kaye of Fort Lee, N.J., who was struck by a bicylist in November. He died of a head injury after the accident; he did not die of a heart attack.

title: Olympian Heights for Women, Not for Viewers; Nike's Living Billboards
description: To the Editor:
