title: A Rising Hindu Tide Frightens India's Muslims
description: Amid the hubbub of other Muslims lining up about him, the graybeard with a filigreed topi resting atop his head leaned forward and virtually shouted his preference into the stranger's ear. ''With this vote, Congress wins!'', he said, waving a white voter's registration slip. ''With this vote, Muslims remain free!''

title: Kwan's Well-Conceived Plan
description: When Michelle Kwan had her cast removed last November, her self-assurance also peeled away. The stress fracture in her left foot had not healed as quickly as she had hoped. She began skating timidly and in pain, and one day tears came to her eyes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRUKIER, CHARLES
description: DRUKIER-Charles. Beloved husband of the late Toby. Devoted father of Ira. Father-in-law of Gale and adored grandfather of Jennifer. He was charismatic, gentle and strong. All those who were fortunate to know him will always remember and miss him. His good deeds were boundless, and there will always be a place for ''Chaskel'' in our hearts. Services Friday, 9AM, Schwartz Brothers Memorial Chapel, Queens Boulevard and 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: N.H.L. Wants to Clear Air: Competing Is a Good Thing
description: With the United States men's hockey team no longer around to explain itself, the job of clarifying one of the more self-indicting parting comments was left today to Gary Bettman, the National Hockey League's commissioner.

title: Chic Swooning Among the Gondolas
description: Long, long ago, near the end of the 16th century, ''Dangerous Beauty'' would have us believe, Venice was the world's undisputed capital of dull soft-core sex. In the rich golden light reflected off the city's canals, pneumatic courtiers transported directly from a 1998 Guess? jeans advertisement by way of ''Masterpiece Theater'' would spend their afternoons making goo-goo eyes at one another from passing gondolas.

title: France Gives Strong Support To U.N. Chief
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan, who is traveling to Iraq, got firm backing today from President Jacques Chirac for his last-ditch effort to bring a peaceful resolution to the crisis over weapons inspections.

title: 5 Are Accused of Video Piracy After Detectives Raid Factory
description: Bronx detectives, following a trail that began when a street peddler was arrested last month, crossed the Harlem River yesterday and raided a Manhattan counterfeiting factory where video pirates were producing 8,000 tapes a week of such current movies as ''Titanic,'' ''Senseless'' and ''The Replacement Killers,'' the authorities said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEIN, JEFFREY GLENN
description: WEIN-Jeffrey Glenn. Beloved husband of Linda (nee Farfel). Devoted father of Jared. Cherished son of Lee and Rhoda. Brother of Barry and Linda. Services ''Gutterman-Musicant,'' Hackensack, NJ, Friday, 2 PM. (1-800-522-0588).

title: 'Leather Jacket Love Story'; Directed by David DeCoteau; Not rated; 85 minutes
description: Can Kyle (Sean Tataryn), a dewy and tow-headed 18-year-old poet from Sherman Oaks, find true love in the arms of Mike (Christopher Bradley), a well-traveled 30-year-old carpenter in a black leather jacket who scorns what he calls ''vanilla sex'' (any coupling not involving handcuffs and other heavy-duty hardware)? That's the question hanging breathlessly over ''Leather Jacket Love Story,'' the movie equivalent of a gay romance novel that opens today at the Quad Cinemas (13th Street, west of Fifth Avenue, in Greenwich Village).

title: Residential Real Estate; Developers Join in Project on East Side
description: It is just a hole in the ground now, but over the next 15 months, a luxury rental building with 156 apartments will take shape on the southwest corner of 82d Street and First Avenue, the third project on the Upper East Side by one of New York City's newer development teams.

title: Race, Love and the Black Proprieties
description: The influence of Oprah Winfrey is so vast it's scary. Single-handedly, she waves her magic wand over the products of American culture -- books, diets, personalities -- and turns them into gold. But it's hard to complain when her taste in the arts has been so consistently strong, starting with the Book Club feature on her show that made Toni Morrison a best seller. (The current lawsuit by Texas ranchers, claiming that a remark by her sent cattle prices plummeting, is only the most recent and bizarre tribute to her perceived power.)

title: Metro Business; New Hotel Planned In Greenwich Village
description: A Greenwich Village building that housed what was once the nation's largest lending library, and which before that was the scene of one of New York's weirdest riots, is going to be reborn as a hotel.

title: Computer Services Company Vows Fight on Hostile Offer
description: The Computer Sciences Corporation said yesterday that it would fight the $9.8 billion hostile takeover offer made on Tuesday by Computer Associates International Inc.

title: New Deal for Buckley May Include Starting
description: The Giants kept linebacker Marcus Buckley by signing him to a three-year free-agent contract yesterday, and he could also be on his way to succeeding the veteran Corey Miller in the starting lineup at strongside linebacker.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COGEN, CHARLES
description: COGEN-Charles. The Officers and members of the United Federation of Teachers mourn the loss of Charles Cogen, the founding president of the UFT. By winning the nation's first contract for teachers he set the stage for current education reforms and was a pioneer in the continuing struggle to win professional dignity and respect for teachers everywhere. We extend our deepest sympathy to the surviving family. Public school teachers and students throughout the nation owe him a great debt of thanks. The Officers and Members of The UFT Randi Weingarten, President

title: Mawae Becomes Highest-Paid Center
description: The Jets completed their first major move of the off season yesterday when they made Kevin Mawae, the former Seattle Seahawk, the highest-paid center in the National Football League.

title: Fair for Art Ferrets
description: An art fair has an atmosphere all its own: neither art gallery nor museum, it is really a kind of theater, each booth being a small stage set where the play is already in progress. This description is apt for the 1998 Art Show at the Seventh Regiment Armory this weekend. This is a fair for art ferrets, people willing to peek around corners or follow an artist's work from booth to booth, in treasure hunt fashion. One quarry could be Fernand Leger, whose works at the fair include a study in pencil, above, for his ''THREE MUSICIANS,'' at the Loria booth; another Leger drawing can be found at Rachel Adler, and paintings at Richard Gray and James Goodman. A similar tour through the fair could be conducted in pursuit of Picasso treasures and works by other artists.

title: Royal Goods
description: It was a night when royalty seemed to be everywhere. Sotheby's began its nine-day sale of the Duke and Duchess of Windsor's belongings. A few blocks away, PRINCESS ELIZABETH of Yugoslavia presided over a first. It was, she announced, the first time the Russians had allowed a non-diplomatic event to be held at the Russian mission, at 136 East 67th Street.

title: FILM IN REVIEW
description: 'Long Live the Republic'

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRILL, ETTA
description: BRILL-Etta. On February 19, 1998 after a brief struggle against old age. Life member of Hadassah and a multiple Ima. Beloved wife of the late Hyman, loving mother of Charles and the late Leon, Morris, Betty and Jack, dear sister of Hana, cherished grandmother of Hal, Marlene, Hillary, Peter, Ron, Sandy, Sheldon and Artie, greatgrandmother, great-great-grandmother, aunt and friend to all who loved her. Services on Sunday 12:15PM, at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: A Dutch Flash Makes Witty Settle for Silver
description: Marianne Timmer and Chris Witty are good pals. They even went on vacation to Mexico together last year with their boyfriends. Today, the speed skaters finished 1-2 in the 1,000-meter Olympic race, three days after Timmer had won the 1,500 and Witty had finished third.

title: Futile Efforts to End Israel's Religion Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: A World of Cultural Influences Meet in a Single Program
description: Cultural mixing was a theme of the New York New Music Ensemble's concert at Merkin Hall on Wednesday night, when the program included works by composers who are all in the habit of traveling, literally and metaphorically, among their four different time zones.

title: The I.R.A. Holds All the Cards
description: Two murders in Northern Ireland, which the police have linked to the Irish Republican Army, are forcing a plainly reluctant British Government to demand the suspension of Sinn Fein, the political wing of the I.R.A., from talks on the province's political future.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, HANNAH
description: KATZ-Hannah, 94 years. Died on February 19, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Isadore. Devoted mother of Sylvan and Lorraine Katz, Bunny and Stanley Shulman, Dr. Paul and Linda Katz and Wendy and Norman Kay. Cherished grandmother of Randy and Virginia Katz, Alicia Shulman, Joyce and Eric Cohen, Dana Katz, Leslie Kay and Robin Kay and Daniel Katz and great-grandmother of Jason and Warren Katz. Dear sister of Ruth Weisberg.

title: North Light In Winter: Sibelius
description: Here are some favorite Sibelius recordings of the classical-music critics of The New York Times. Compact disks range in price from $15.99 for a single disk to $25.98 for a two-disk set or $40 for a four-disk package. (An introduction appears on page 1 of Weekend.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, HON. LEWIS R.
description: FRIEDMAN-Hon. Lewis R. The board and staff of the Educational Alliance deeply mourn the sudden and untimely death of Judge Lewis R. Friedman, beloved husband of our devoted and committed Trustee and Senior Vice President, Bernice. Lew devoted his professional and personal life, as does his wife, to create a community more sensitive and responsive to the needs of the under served, immigrants and refugees. Whether sitting on the bench or on the board of one of his charitable institutions, Lew demonstrated that perfect blend of humor, intellect and humanity. We extend our heart felt condolences to the Friedman family. Arthur I. Sonnenblick, President

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Trade Deficit Widens

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FUHRMAN, SEYMOUR JEROME
description: FUHRMAN-Seymour Jerome. On February 17, 1998, of Bridgewater, NJ (formerly of Yonkers). Darling husband of Isabel. Adored father of Elen Weiss, Joel Fuhrman and Gale Pilla and grandfather of seven. Funeral services Sunday at 10 AM at Bernheim-Apter-Goldsticker Funeral Home, Maplewood, New Jersey, 973-763-3505.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Technology Stocks Rise, But Dow's Run Ends at 6

title: Fears on Margin Buying by Small Investors
description: After going on a borrowing binge in the first half of the 1990's, American consumers have been accumulating debt far more slowly over the last two years.

title: Mississippi Legislature Accepts Bill to Ease Voter Registration
description: After a debate that stirred memories of literacy tests and the poll tax, the Mississippi Legislature today became the last in the nation to accept a Federal mandate that requires states to let citizens register to vote at motor vehicle offices and social services centers.

title: Sleaze Journalism? It's an Old Story
description: The American press is once again at risk grave risk! -- of abandoning its proud tradition of sobriety, fairness and impartiality. Or so say most of the people who are paid to fill air time and column inches with that sort of pronouncement.

title: Swiss Reject Claim Over 2 Jews Deported in '42
description: Switzerland's Cabinet today rejected a Jewish man's claim for financial damages for the wrongful deportation of his parents, who were killed at Auschwitz.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TANDET, BARBARA
description: TANDET-Barbara. The members of Rockrimmon Country Club are saddened by the passing of their long-time good friend and extend sincere sympathy to her husband and family. Leonard Danon, President

title: Arab Writers Who Pushed for Change
description: THE DREAM PALACE OF THE ARABS

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the baseball announcer Harry Caray yesterday misstated the Chicago Cubs' stadium location. It is on the north side of the city, not the south.

title: Suharto Again Backs Down On Challenge To the I.M.F.
description: For the second time in a month, President Suharto gave in to international pressure over the country's economic crisis, backing away for the moment from a quick-fix plan to peg the Indonesian currency to the dollar.

title: Hooked Rugs Snag Buyers Of Folk Art
description: ''Collecting hooked rugs is like eating comfort food,'' said Nancy Druckman, director of the American folk art department at Sotheby's in New York. People may see hooked rugs many ways -- as paintings in yarn, family mementos, even floor coverings. But they can't resist them. Hooked rugs have recently surpassed American quilts in popularity in sales at galleries and fairs. Experts concur that good hooked rugs are increasing in value by 10 to 20 percent a year.

title: CLINTON SETS OUT TO REVIVE SUPPORT FOR STAND ON IRAQ
description: A day after American policy toward Iraq was passionately picked apart at a town hall meeting in Ohio, President Clinton tried to reassemble the pieces today, declaring that the country would ultimately support an American military assault.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARONSON, ARNOLD
description: ARONSON-Arnold. An example of how one person can make a difference, Arnie was truly society's mentor. May his family be comforted among the mourners of Zion. Association of Jewish Community Relations Workers, AJCRW Marlene Gorin, President

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Ernest Withers

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, DAVID
description: KATZ-David. February 18, 1998. Of Delray, formerly of Brooklyn and Fort Lee. Self employed advertising executive. Devoted husband of the late Bertie. Survived by two sisters and dear nieces and nephews. A W.W. II veteran. Was active in many charities. Contributions may be made to Deborah Hospital. Funeral services Friday 2 P.M., at Mount Golda Cemetery, Huntington, Long Island.

title: Sports of The Times; An Unknown Heroine Of Nagano
description: LARISA LAZUTINA was the object of this search Wednesday afternoon, and a search it was. An interview had been arranged with the cross-country ski champion through the Russian Olympic Committee in Nagano. The directions to the hotel where she was staying with the Russian ski team in this beautiful mountain town were generous, but sketchy. All roads and phone numbers seemed to lead nowhere. It was already nearly an hour past the scheduled meeting time.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: 'Empire Within'

title: 3 Governors Shifting Focus To Spending
description: A few years ago, the newly elected Republican Governors of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut were in the vanguard of the movement to cut state taxes and rein in spending.

title: Observer; Not the Wine, Stupid
description: Terrible, terrible news!

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLY, WILLIAM E. II
description: KELLY-William E. II, age 68, of Spring Lake, New Jersey, died on February 18, 1998 at his home in Spring Lake, New Jersey. He had been hospitalized at ColumbiaPresbyterian Hospital. Born in Brooklyn, NY, graduate of Brooklyn Preparatory, Columbia University and Columbia University Law School; former partner at Lane & Mittendorf LLP, NYC; predeceased in death by his parents, Edward L. and Edna Flannery Kelly; survived by his wife of 43 years, Grace Saunders Kelly, of Spring Lake, NJ; eight children, Edward (Alison) of Sea Girt, NJ; William E. III (Diane) of Rumson, NJ; Robert of Spring Lake, NJ; Richard (Marybeth) of Brielle, NJ; Ellen Gerard (William) of Glen Ridge, NJ; Elizabeth Lally (Joseph) of St. Paul, Minnesota; Elaine Giuliano (William) of McLean, Virginia and Michael (Patricia) of Chatham, NJ; and seventeen grandchildren. He is also survived by a sister, Maura Patricia Kelly of Alexandria, Virginia. For information contact O'Brien Funeral Home in Wall, NJ. Mass of Christian Burial will be at St. Catharine's Roman Catholic Church, Spring Lake, NJ on Saturday, February 21st, 1998, at 10:30 A.M. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be sent to the William E. Kelly Memorial Fund for Medical Research, C/O Fisher Fallon LLP, 301 Morris Avenue, Spring Lake, New Jersey 07762.

title: Only 4 Are Entered in Fountain of Youth
description: Only four horses, all of them strong candidates for the Kentucky Derby, were entered today in the Fountain of Youth Stakes after Sweetsouthernsaint was withdrawn with inflammation in his leg, leaving the race with its smallest field, but a strong one nonetheless.

title: Olympian Heights for Women, Not for Viewers; Nonheroic Coverage
description: To the Editor:

title: For CBS, Little U.S. Gold and Tarnished Ratings
description: Every four years, Americans gather around their television sets and get caught up in the drama, the emotion, the scenic tapestry of the Winter Olympics.

title: For U.S. Men's Hockey, No Olympic Highlights
description: A ROUGH EXIT -- When it departed Nagano after a disappointing showing in these Winter Games, the United States men's hockey team left behind wrecked suites in the Olympic village. ''I'm not proud of what happened,'' said Walter Bush Jr., the head of U.S.A. Hockey. Page C1.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIETER, KATHRYN (NEE BOLAND)
description: DIETER-Kathryn (nee Boland). The family of Kathryn Dieter mourns the passing of their beloved mother, formerly of Bayside, New York, recently residing at the Mary Manning Walsh Home. She was the wife of the late Conrad Dieter. She is survived by her five children, Kathleen Dieter of New York City, Carole Donnelly of Cincinnati, Ohio, Margaret Dieter Miller of Ithaca, N.Y., Richard Dieter of Wheaton, MD., and George Dieter of Somers, N.Y., nine grandchildren and six great grandchildren. Wake at the John Krtil Funeral Home, 1297 1st Avenue (70th Street), NYC, Friday evening, 6-9 PM. Funeral Mass will be at the Mary Manning Walsh Home, 9:30AM Saturday, preceded by viewing at 9 A.M.

title: Guard Robbed of Payroll Cash In Delivery to Mt. Sinai Hospital
description: A man disguised as a United Parcel Service worker robbed a security guard of $107,000 in payroll funds yesterday morning as he tried to deliver the cash to a Manhattan hospital, the police said.

title: 200 Vintage Photographs Acquired by the Modern
description: The Museum of Modern Art, which was the first major museum to show Garry Winogrand's work, has acquired the largest collection of his photographs in private hands. The collection's more than 200 black-and-white vintage prints had been assembled by Eugene M. Schwartz, who died in 1995, and his wife, Barbara, avid collectors of contemporary art.

title: North Light In Winter: Sibelius
description: Here are some favorite Sibelius recordings of the classical-music critics of The New York Times. Compact disks range in price from $15.99 for a single disk to $25.98 for a two-disk set or $40 for a four-disk package. (An introduction appears on page 1 of Weekend.)

title: Judge Orders Release Of Youths' Names
description: A judge is allowing the release of the names of two juveniles charged with murder. Saying the community has a right to know their identities, Judge Cornelius P. Sullivan of Superior Court in Burlington County allowed prosecutors on Wednesday to name Michael A. Johnson, 16, of Pemberton, and Bryan C. Dennis, 15, of Mount Holly, as defendants in the killing of John B. Minogue, 77, on Feb. 8. Prosecutors had urged the judge to release the names to alert the public to the violent nature of the crimes, said Martin C. Mooney, chief of the Family Court unit of the County Prosecutor's office.

title: Here and There
description: ''I've learned I need closet space -- next year I'll have more,'' said JUNE KELLY, the first black gallery owner to display works at the Art Dealers Association of America Show, where the price of a ticket to the opening depended on when you arrived. In the first hour, admission was $500; in the second hour, $250, and from then on, $135. The show, at the Seventh Regiment Armory, at Park Avenue and 67th Street, benefited the Henry Street Settlement. . . . The writer ROBERT NICHOLS borrowed a tuxedo for the second time in four years -- for the same reason: his wife, GRACE PALEY, was receiving an award, this time from the Literary Committee of the National Arts Club. (The other time, she was a finalist for the National Book Award.)

title: And Best Dress?
description: The race is on among designers hoping to dress the Academy Award nominees. The right gown on the right actress could mean a morning-after-the-Oscars sales boost. Consider COURTNEY LOVE'S snow-white Versace dress, which brought a lot of attention to the design house last year -- before Gianni Versace's murder.

title: Death Penalty To Be Sought For 5th Time In Brooklyn
description: Brooklyn District Attorney Charles J. Hynes said yesterday that he would pursue his office's fifth death penalty case, and opponents seized on the move as evidence that prosecutors have been arbitrarily seeking the death penalty since it was reimposed two years ago.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: AETNA INC., Hartford, purchased 49 percent of Seguros Mercantil, a Venezuela-based insurance company, for about $30 million in order to enter the country's recently formed pension fund industry.

title: Compagnoni Wins Gold In 3d Olympics in a Row
description: A dark-haired, charismatic Italian Alpine skier who trains alone and is more popular at home than any other athlete won another Olympic gold medal today.

title: Soft-Money Socializing With the President
description: ONE doesn't actually cook when President Clinton comes over to eat -- that's what caterers are for -- but there was still a great deal of preparation necessary for last night's Presidential dinner party in West Orange, N.J.

title: Two Golds, One Stunning Crash: Now Maier Is Fast and Familiar
description: Without the crash, Americans would have cared very little about Hermann Maier.

title: Those Lethal Oysters
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the selection of a Chicago superintendent of police misspelled his surname in some copies. He is Terry Hillard, not Hilliard.

title: Is He Mr. Wrong? Mr. Right? Whatever, She's Ms. Kvetch
description: There have been plenty of urban, neurosis-strewn romantic comedies inspired by the work of Woody Allen, but Julie Davis's spirited ''I Love You . . . Don't Touch Me!'' has something special: Ms. Davis. As the writer, director, editor and role model behind this enjoyable low-budget date movie, Ms. Davis shows off confidence to burn. Presenting a 25-year-old heroine who is finicky about men to the point of remaining a virgin, her film is bright, energetic and obviously eager to please.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CASSIN, WILLIAM
description: CASSIN-William. Just thinking of you. Love, Billy, Danny, Michelle, Brian and Laura

title: Court Upholds 'Megan's Law' For New York
description: New York's highest court today upheld the state's two-year-old ''Megan's Law'' that requires convicted sex offenders to register with their local police after their release from prison and allows officials to make public the names of some of them.

title: China Pins Economic Hopes On an Obsolete Asian Model
description: Inside an arched entrance way to the sprawling headquarters of North China Pharmaceutical Group, a display of oversized photographs points to the political connections that created and then nourished this drug-making giant for 40 years.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 9.

title: Want U.N. Support on Iraq? Then Pay the Bill; Dangerous Strategy
description: To the Editor:

title: DDB Needham Wins Bayer Account
description: The Bayer Corporation unit of Bayer Group said yesterday that it had awarded its corporate advertising account to DDB Needham New York, part of Omnicom Group. The account, with billings estimated at $9 million, had been handled for the last three years by the Chicago office of Foote, Cone & Belding, a unit of True North Communications.

title: Arafat Shuts Stations Over Iraq Support
description: The Palestinian Authority has shut down nine radio and television stations in the West Bank in recent days in an attempt to stifle public expressions of pro-Iraqi sentiment among Palestinians.

title: Ex-All-Star Seeks Spot In Bullpen With Mets
description: Four years ago, John Hudek became just the fifth player in big-league history to begin the season in the minors and go on to be selected for the major league All-Star Game. Now Hudek, a hard-throwing right-hander, is just trying to find a spot in the Mets' bullpen.

title: Art Returned To Museum; Dispute Persists
description: Fifteen works by the artist Robert Rauschenberg, abruptly removed by constables last week from a retrospective show here, were just as abruptly put back on the walls of a Houston museum today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHACHNER, MELISSA
description: SCHACHNER-Melissa. Temple Beth Sholom of Roslyn Heights, New York, mourns the passing of our beloved member, Melissa Schachner, and extends heartfelt condolences to her family. Alan B. Lucas, Rabbi Dr. Philip Adler, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRYDEN, HARRIET DAVIS
description: DRYDEN-Harriet Davis. Age 75. Passed away quietly after a long battle with Lou Gehrig's disease, Feb 19, 1998. Survived by husband Robert; daughter Emma and brother Martin S. Davis. Former researcher and writer for CBS and Bosley Crowther. We miss her.

title: A New Battle in Belgrade: The Big Buses That Can't
description: Milos Javanovic, a city bus driver, climbed into his worn vinyl seat, turned the key to unleash a blast of black diesel smoke and glanced at the dials on his dash board, none of which worked. He nursed the 17-year-old bus into traffic, ignoring a high-pitched squeal from the brakes, and began another day's work, for which he would be paid weeks late.

title: Knicks Add Cummings to Fill a Hole
description: The Knicks did not break up the circle they have spent years building around Patrick Ewing before the trading deadline. They just patched it with Terry Cummings.

title: Miller's Hot Hand Helps Pacers Put Away Sixers
description: PACERS 82, 76ERS 77

title: National News Briefs; Democratic Fund-Raiser Enters a Not Guilty Plea
description: A Democratic fund-raiser today pleaded not guilty to felony charges that she conspired to disguise illegal contributions from a Buddhist temple in California to a number of political campaigns, including President Clinton's re-election effort.

title: MATRIX CAPITAL TO BUY LEADER MORTGAGE FOR $32 MILLION
description: The Matrix Capital Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire the Leader Mortgage Company, a privately held mortgage company based in Ohio, for $32 million. Under the deal, Matrix Capital, a Denver-based savings and loan holding company, would pay $27.5 million in common stock and $4.5 million in cash. The stock exchange ratio would be based on the value of Matrix's common stock over a 10-day trading period before the deal is closed, which may be as late as the third quarter of 1998. Matrix's stock rose 75 cents yesterday, to $15.50. Matrix Capital also said it would change its name to Matrix Bancorp.

title: President's Legal Advisers Argue Executive Privilege Before Judge
description: President Clinton's closest adviser, Bruce R. Lindsey, accompanied by a retinue of 10 White House and private lawyers, returned to Federal court for a second day today, skirmishing with prosecutors over whether executive privilege shields top aides from some testimony in the Monica S. Lewinsky investigation.

title: Love Takes Many Forms (Just Ask the Gorilla)
description: It's big, busy, well acted and well directed, and while it is imaginative in its conception, ''Subtle Bodies'' turns out not to have a whole lot on its mind.

title: Accounts
description: -- Swedish Match North America, Richmond, to Buntin Group, Nashville, to handle its Red Man Brands, which had been handled by Keller Crescent, Evansville, Ind., which will continue to handle other Swedish Match brands. Though billings were not disclosed, total brand spending for Red Man is estimated at $5 million to $7 million.

title: F.B.I. Investigates Agents' Travel Expenses
description: The F.B.I. and Justice Department said today that they had opened an internal inquiry into whether several senior F.B.I. agents improperly billed the Government when they attended a dinner last fall honoring a retiring colleague.

title: A Mute Asian Civilization That Speaks Eloquently
description: ''Great Cities, Small Treasures: The Ancient World of the Indus Valley'' is the kind of exhibition that the Asia Society was born to do. The subject is unfamiliar enough to be overlooked by big-gun institutions. The visual material -- sculptures, seals, jewelry -- is seldom seen live, even by specialists. (Almost everything in the show is on loan from museums in Pakistan.) The objects themselves have a low-key presence exactly suited to the Asia Society's intimate setting.

title: Corrections
description: A dance review yesterday about a performance by Doug Varone and Dancers on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater misidentified a work on the program. It was ''Possession,'' not ''Obsession.''

title: CALGON CARBON CHIEF RESIGNS AND COMPANY MAY BE SOLD
description: The Calgon Carbon Corporation said yesterday that its chief executive had resigned and that the company might put itself up for sale amid a rapid consolidation of the water-treatment industry. Calgon Carbon, based in Pittsburgh, said Colin Bailey, the architect of several acquisitions, had resigned as president and chief executive because of differences with the board of directors over the direction and management of the company. Calgon hired the investment bank Morgan Stanley to advise it on a possible sale and other ways to raise its share price. Calgon's shares jumped $2.5625, or 23 percent, to $13.5625.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Kenny Scharf

title: Want U.N. Support on Iraq? Then Pay the Bill
description: To the Editor:

title: A.B.L. Set to Begin Playoff Tournament
description: To many people, when the Women's National Basketball Association made its debut last year, the almost-as-new American Basketball League seemed doomed. There had never been a successful women's pro basketball league, and now there were two leagues.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOHMER, ROBERT HUGO
description: SOHMER-Robert Hugo. On February 18, 1998 of Rye, New York. Beloved uncle of John, Harry III and Annina Sohmer-Knight. Also survived by devoted sister-in-law Anne Sohmer and grand nephew Harry Brown Sohmer. Graduate of St. Bernard's, member of St. Anthony's, St. George's and University of Pennsylvania. Retired Vice President of the Sohmer Piano Company. Services private. Contributions to Friends of the Osborne, Rye, New York 10580, would be appreciated.

title: Charles Cogen Dies at 94; Led Teachers in New York
description: Charles Cogen, the first president of the New York City teachers' union and the leader of a one-day strike in 1960 that won bargaining rights for the city's public-school teachers, died Wednesday. He was 94.

title: A City of Surprises, Not All Big
description: This may be the fourth-largest metropolis in the United States, but it is much less well known to most Americans than the big three, Los Angeles, New York and Chicago. It is a steaming, hyper-air-conditioned, boom-bust-boom town that oozes across 500 relentlessly flat, bayou-laced square miles, the most ethnically and racially diverse, most unionized city in all of Texas, with aching disparities between rich and poor matched in few other places in the country.

title: What to Look For
description: ALPINE SKIING -- MEN'S SLALOM

title: Finance Scandal In Japan Takes A Nasty Turn
description: An outspoken politician in Japan's dominant party stunned the nation today by hanging himself just as the police were about to arrest him in a widening investigation into financial corruption involving the Finance Ministry and the institutions it regulates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLF, DOROTHY
description: WOLF-Dorothy. Of Hollywood Fla. formerly of Riverdale, NY. On February 16. Widow of the late David Wolf. Beloved mother of Daniel and daughter-in-law Cheryl. Proud and loving grandmother of Eric, Jordan and David. Devoted and loving sister to Banjamin Loeb, sister-in-law Jean and niece Ellen. She will forever be remembered in our hearts and the hearts of so many whose lives she touched with her time and talent, loving dedication and sense of humor. She was a truly unique and wonderful human being and will be sorely missed. Donations in her memory may be made to the Hollywood Art and Culture Center/ Dorothy Wolf Memorial Fund, 1650 Harrison Street, Hollywood, Fla. 33020. A ceremony will be held in her honor at the center on Monday, March 9 at 11 A.M.

title: Cells of Fetus Could Link Some Mothers To a Disease
description: Long after a woman has given birth, cells from her fetus may still circulate in her blood stream, and a new study being reported today has linked those cells to development of a disease in the mother years after pregnancy.

title: A Finland Festival, With Sibelius Concerts and Other Events
description: The Sibelius events are part of a ''Finland in New York'' festival that will run through the spring. Here are the Sibelius events, along with a sampling of other music events that are part of the festival:

title: From Shetl to Fiesta, A Painter's Wanderings
description: It's often better to be a big frog in a small puddle, and so it was for the painter Lasar Segall (1891-1957). Born in the Jewish quarter of Vilnius, Lithuania, he left for Germany at 15, developed an Expressionist style and later migrated to Sao Paulo, Brazil, where he spent the rest of his life. He was a leading light in the development of modern Brazilian art, and he is commemorated by a Lasar Segall museum in Sao Paulo. But as a painter he was uneven and derivative.

title: Bozell Selected By Hilton Hotels
description: The Hilton Hotels Corporation has named Bozell Worldwide, part of True North Communications, as the new agency on its account, with billings estimated at $40 million.

title: Lord Granville, After 100 Crowded Years
description: Lord Granville of Eye, the oldest member of the British Parliament, died in a London nursing home on Saturday, two days after making a rare appearance in the House of Lords to celebrate his 100th birthday.

title: Elegance In Shadow And Shape
description: Long before Tanqueray gin had Mr. Jenkins in its advertisements, the Weber and Heilbroner Shops had the Fabric Group. In 1927, the photographer Anton Bruehl invented a trio of male cutout dolls joined at the pants cuffs and elbows. Every week in The New Yorker, the Fabric Group would go ''abroad'' in their fedoras to have dangerous adventures like deep-sea diving with fish or spelunking with dinosaurs. They weathered all perils with jaunty good humor, while wishing they were back home wearing their Fabric Group suits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKELSTEIN, MAURICE L.
description: FINKELSTEIN-Maurice L. Age 77, on February 18, 1998. Beloved husband of Lenore. Devoted father of Jeanne, Alice and Jay. Adored grandfather of Jared and Sarah. Former president of Benjamin Flax, Inc. and past-captain of the New Rochelle City Tennis Team. His laughter, wisdom and strength will be missed.

title: Going in (Magic) Circles With Mystical Questions
description: ''The Mandala'' is as watchable as a soap opera and just as messy.

title: Trade Deficit For 1997 Hit 9-Year High
description: The nation's 1997 trade deficit reached its highest level in nine years, the Government reported today, and a jump in December suggested the deficit would surge again this year because of Asia's financial crisis.

title: In Subways, Money Alone Is a Crime
description: CONSIDER the case of the Gun Hill Three, perhaps the most unlikely fare-beaters you ever will meet. They walked free out of Bronx Criminal Court yesterday.

title: INSIDE ART
description: Money for Monet And a Rotunda

title: Piece by Piece, Windsor Legacy Disperses
description: They came from Paris and San Francisco, Omaha and Australia to watch the final chapter of the 20th century's most celebrated love story -- that of the Duke and Duchess of Windsor -- begin to unfold last night in the first of nine days of sales at Sotheby's. Some came for purely sentimental reasons, others with commercial aspirations. And curiosity was a big draw, as it is at any celebrity auction.

title: Olympian Heights for Women, Not for Viewers; Marijuana Generation
description: To the Editor:

title: In Fighting Land Mines, Friendship Is Casualty
description: At the very beginning, six years ago, the notion of a global campaign to ban deadly land mines was an idea that fascinated two very dedicated friends.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENSPAN, NOAH
description: GREENSPAN - Noah. Devoted husband of the late Flora, beloved father of Harry David Greenspan. Dear brother of Bernard Greenspan of San Ramon, California. Retired civil engineer and builder. Attained the rank of major in World War II. Services Friday 11AM at Schwartz Brothers Jeffer Memorial Chapel, Queens Boulevard at 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a suspect in burglaries in Greenwich, Conn., referred incorrectly to police comments identifying the author of a book proposal about the life of the suspect. The proposal was written by William Knoedelseder, a California author. While the suspect, Alan Golder, did sell the rights to his story, he did not write the proposal or use a pseudonym.

title: Democratic Chiefs Urge Faithful to Go on Offense for Clinton
description: Trying to help President Clinton deflect accusations about his sexual conduct, leaders of the Democratic National Committee asked party stalwarts today to express their support for the President, ''from calling into talk radio to coffee break conversations at the office.''

title: Two Are Nominated for Board Of New York Times Company
description: The board of The New York Times Company has nominated two executives for election as directors at its annual shareholder meeting on April 16.

title: Insanity Defense for Youth Accused of Murder
description: One day after learning that their client would be tried as an adult, lawyers for Samuel Manzie, the New Jersey teen-ager accused of killing 11-year-old Edward P. Werner in September, said they would pursue an insanity defense in the case.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Anselm Kiefer

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIBEN, NED (EBN)
description: LIBEN-Ned (Ebn). His family is heartbroken to announce his sudden and tragic death of a heart attack at age 44. A musician, composer, arranger and producer, he worked with among others, The Ramones, Ravi Shankar and The Talking Heads at his recording studios, Sundragon and Sound Over Soho. He released three major label albums, one with his band EbnOzn. His sweetness, warmth, generosity and wit touched everyone who knew him. He will be deeply, deeply missed. He leaves his wife Sallie, his baby Max, his mother Diana, his sisters Laura and Lucy, his sister-in-law Marie, and many close relatives and friends. Services today 11:15AM, at the ''Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam.

title: Irish Career Terrorist Too Good at His Job
description: The wonderful Irish actor Stephen Rea has one of those crumpled wise-child faces in which you can read a lifetime of sorrow, confusion and betrayed innocence. Even while playing a toughened I.R.A. terrorist in ''The Break,'' a sense comes through of the little boy inside the weary warrior, peering quizzically through a face that has collapsed with age and trouble. This mixture of dazed vulnerability and hard-headed fatalism make Mr. Rea's character, Dowd, poignant, no matter how violent and wrongheaded his actions. Every move he makes has a sad Existential resonance.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Toland Grinnell

title: I.M.F. Relaxes Loan Terms For Russians
description: Against the backdrop of an economic crisis in Asia, the International Monetary Fund said today that it would continue lending Russia money and relax the tax collection targets that have been a condition for further funds.

title: Traditional Skills and Modern Ideas
description: Christopher d'Amboise's ''Circle of Fifths,'' performed by the New York City Ballet on Wednesday night at the New York State Theater, is easily one of the oddest dances in the company's repertory. The 1997 piece deposits one of the company's most exquisite classicists, Peter Boal, on the ground, motionless, for much of the ballet. Flexed limbs, so contrary to the long, curving body line of ballet, are a motif, too, particularly for the hands.

title: Annan Reaches Iraq Today as Many U.N. Employees Pull Out
description: Less than 24 hours before Secretary General Kofi Annan is to arrive in Iraq with a proposal to prevent an American attack, his aides said tonight that they had been given no assurances that President Saddam Hussein would meet him.

title: College on a Sense-Enhancing Drug
description: Marlon Wayans, the wild man of the Wayans family, reaches everywhere for laughs in ''Senseless,'' and the film itself displays the same antic desperation. The gags, like the plotting, have a giddy edge that can be sharp, but just as often they go nowhere. Mr. Wayans may be the most unabashed, elastic comic this side of Jim Carrey, but the many distractions in ''Senseless'' keep his performance uneven. As directed by Penelope Spheeris, who can have a high time with low fun (''Wayne's World,'' ''The Beverly Hillbillies''), this comedy only intermittently manages to be so dopey that it's smart.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARB, ALLAN E., M.D.
description: GARB-Allan E., M.D. Age 68. Of Cos Cob, CT. On February 18, 1998 of a stroke. Born and raised in New York City. Graduate of Elisabeth Irwin H.S., Oberlin College, OH., Class 1951, Downstate University of New York (M.D.), Columbia University, New York, Mayo Clinic, MN. Retired Corporate Medical Director and Vice President of Bristol-Myers Squibb. Member of B.M.I. and the Friars' Club. Husband, for forty-one years, of Phyllis (nee Ballantine). Father of Wendy Grayson, John, Matthew and Jennifer. Brother of Judy Kaleko. Grandfather of eight. Memorial service will be held Saturday, February 21st, 11AM, First Lutheran Church, Greenwich, CT. Burial will be private.

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Galleries, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan and are open Tuesdays through Saturdays from 10 or 11 A.M. to 5 or 6 P.M.; gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: A Seducer With a Whiff Of Genius (Or Pizza)
description: What a creep.

title: Clinton Trip To New Jersey Raises Funds For Democrats
description: As President Clinton dined tonight at a $25,000-per-couple fund-raiser in the private home of a major contributor to the Democratic Party, dozens of antiwar protesters demonstrated outside the well-guarded gates of the exclusive Llewellyn Park section of West Orange, chanting, ''We don't want a bloody war,'' and holding signs that urged, ''No Bombs, No War Against Iraq.''

title: Bills on Child Support Are Voted by Assembly
description: Two bills that would make it easier for officials to collect child support payments were passed yesterday by the Assembly.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Technology; Headlamps, Out of the Shadows
description: IN the early days of the automobile, nighttime drivers marked their presence with candles and lamps that burned kerosene or acetylene gas -- the sorts of devices that had been used on carriages and ships. Those early marker lamps were quickly replaced by focused electric headlamps that could light the road ahead, then by sealed-beam lamps in which the bulb, reflector and lens were housed in a single, reliable unit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILSON, REVEREND CLARENCE E. C.S.P.
description: WILSON-Reverend Clarence E. C.S.P. On Feb. 19, 1998 at age 84 was a native of Sudbury, Canada. Ordained a Paulist priest on 1/31/ 43, Father Wilson served in Paulist parishes, on campuses, and information centers in San Francisco, Clemson, SC, Boston, and Grand Rapids in addition to 27 years at St. Peter's Parish in Toronto, Canada. A wake wil be held Sunday evening, February 22, 1998 at 7:30PM, and the funeral mass will be on Monday, 2/23/98 at 11AM both at the Providence Center, 3276 St. Claire Avenue East, Scarborough, Ontario, Canada. Interment will be at Holy Cross Cemetery, Richmond Hill (North of Toronto).

title: GILLETTE PLANS TO SPLIT ITS STOCK AND INCREASE DIVIDEND
description: The Gillette Company said yesterday that it planned to split its stock 2 for 1 and increase its dividend by 19 percent. If approved by shareholders, the stock split would double the number of shares, to 1.1 billion, halving the value of a share. The company had 558.8 million shares on average as of Dec. 31. Gillette's shares rose $1.9375 yesterday, to $106.5625, on the New York Stock Exchange. The new shares would be issued at an unspecified date to shareholders of record as of May 15. A quarterly dividend of 25.5 cents, up from 21.5 cents, would be paid on June 5 to shareholders of record as of May 1.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: The menu at the two-month-old Pacific East sounds so delicious that from the moment I read it, I couldn't wait to eat there. I liked the reception, too: the man on the telephone bantered pleasantly as he took my reservation, and he was every bit as accommodating when I walked into the warm, modest, attractive room.

title: Blue Chips Take a Breather From Setting Record Highs
description: The stock market was generally lower yesterday, ending a blistering run that had repeatedly sent most major indexes to record highs.

title: Barnes & Noble Vows to Stock Art Books Despite Indictments
description: Barnes & Noble, the nation's largest bookstore chain, vowed yesterday to stock art books containing photographs of nude children despite grand jury indictments on obscenity charges in two southern states.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Olympian Heights for Women, Not for Viewers
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLAMM, DONALD
description: FLAMM-Donald. A wonderful, unforgettable friend who initially unselfishly arranged the program for evacuee British children to telephone their parents during World War II through his ownership of WMCA. Our sympathy to Elayne, Milton, his wife and all the family. Dolly and Bob Raisler

title: Truths of All Lives, Comfortable or Not
description: Moviegoers with a taste for the classics must suppose that Jane Austen, Henry James, E. M. Forster and now Virginia Woolf have much in common: fondness for formal gardens, luxurious vanilla costumes and grand parties that turn life into one long, privileged frolic. Yet even for viewers who accept this as the visual language of the literary adaptation, Woolf's majestic ''Mrs. Dalloway'' represents a formidable challenge.

title: FAMILY FARE
description: Show and Tell With Big Bird

title: Court Lets City Restrict Flights at 34th St. Heliport
description: In a victory for residents who have long been irritated by helicopter noise, a Federal appellate court has allowed New York City to restrict the operations of its East 34th Street Heliport in Manhattan.

title: The Art of Judging Sports
description: In Olympic events where artistry blends with athleticism, and performance cannot be measured in terms of points scored or time elapsed, there will always be an element of subjectivity in the decisions of the judges. Politics adds an extra measure of volatility, especially in ice skating.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHULSKY, MARIE
description: SHULSKY-Marie. ROFEH International mourns the passing of Marie Shulsky. May her family find strength in the good deeds done for Israel and mankind. The Bostoner Rebbe

title: Preparing Computers for Century's End
description: With less than 23 months left until the year 2000, New York City's government is facing the same daunting problem that looms for major computer users everywhere: it must spend vast sums of money to keep its myriad systems from crashing or running amok in the seconds after Dec. 31, 1999.

title: Israel Radio Often Finds Best Friends Are Iranian
description: The young woman calling from Iran spoke very quietly into the telephone.

title: 2 Men Accused of Possessing A Possible Toxin in Nevada
description: Federal agents charged two men here today with possession of a toxin believed to be anthrax after tracking them for hours on Wednesday as they prepared to test the substance at a suburban medical clinic, the authorities said.

title: Island Life Not Idyllic For Youths From U.S.
description: Drugs. Gangs. Guns. Like many other Dominican immigrants in the New York metropolitan area, the parents of Lizza Santos were distressed by what they saw going on around them. So just before their daughter started high school in September, they sent her to live with her grandparents here while they remained in the United States.

title: 4 Students Held in Calls Of School Bomb Threats
description: Four high-school students have been arrested in connection with 16 bomb threats that have disrupted classes at Overbrook Senior High School and Junior High School since the start of the school year, the police said yesterday.

title: Another Leader of the Navajo Nation Resigns Under a Cloud
description: Three years ago, Albert A. Hale took office as president of the Navajo Nation, promising to end corruption and rancorous internal politics at a reservation the size of West Virginia. Yesterday he resigned under fire for personal and political misdeeds, and apologized to the quarter-million people who live in the nation's largest Indian reservation.

title: Futile Efforts to End Israel's Religion Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: Where Troubles Melt Like Lemon Drops
description: Sincerity in a singer is such an evanescent quality that to become aware of it risks exploiting it to death. The cabaret singer Phillip Officer, who is appearing at the Firebird Cafe, 363 West 46th Street, Clinton, through Feb. 28, somehow manages to avoid the pitfalls of such self-consciousness, pouring out his heart without ever sounding manipulative or self-pitying. Mr. Officer effuses a corn-fed, gosh-oh-gee innocence that feels as genuine as it is irrepressible, and his enthusiasm is contagious.

title: A District Good Times Forgot; Once Invincible, Connecticut Congresswoman Faces Tough Fight
description: The withered heart of this once proud Yankee mill town tells the story of Representative Nancy L. Johnson's political troubles.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: President of Visa International to Retire
description: The president and chief executive of Visa International Inc., Edmund P. Jensen, will retire at the end of the year to focus on business ventures, investments and volunteer work.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORELLI, MILLIE
description: MORELLI-Millie. The staff of the law firm, Dinkes & Morelli, extend our heartfelt condolences to our respected and loved Senior Partner, Benedict P. Morelli on the loss of his beloved mother, Millie Morelli.

title: French Baroque Group Shows Flexibility
description: Christophe Rousset, the French harpsichordist, founded Les Talens Lyriques in the early 1990's. Although the period-instrument world can seem crowded and overlapping, this group has quickly found its niche in previously unexplored (or at least underexplored) Baroque repertory. Its recording of the soundtrack for ''Farinelli,'' the film about the famous 18th-century castrato, gave it international exposure, and its recordings, most notably an account of Handel's ''Riccardo Primo'' on L'Oiseau-Lyre label, have won it a considerable following.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WECHSLER, MAXWELL
description: WECHSLER-Maxwell. On February 19th. ''A Lover of Zion'' of Hamden, CT. Husband of Bernice Wechsler, also survived by three loving children, a sister and eight grandchildren. Services Friday at 11 A.M., at the New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: War and Peace: An Epic of Bugs

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERRILL, BOB
description: MERRILL-Bob. The Board of Directors and members of the National Academy of Popular Music regret the passing of Bob Merrill, an esteemed member of the Songwriters' Hall of Fame. Frank Sinatra, Chairman Bobby Weinstein, President

title: Report on Pedophilia Exposes Deep Rifts in Belgium
description: BRUSSELS  The official report on this country's pedophile scandal, debated by Parliament on Thursday, left Belgians with less cause than ever to have any faith in their national institutions.

title: Trouble in Spice World; McCormick Faces Changing Demographics, Changing Tastes
description: The spice maker McCormick & Company, like many corporations on the cutting edge, has its own Web site. And there, the company hopes, digital visitors will find recipes that will inspire them to cook using McCormick ingredients.

title: Sharpton's Lawyer Attacks Interviewer
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton's lawyer sought to discredit a writer in the Tawana Brawley defamation case who suggested 10 years ago that Mr. Sharpton had ''betrayed his race.''

title: Olympian Heights for Women, Not for Viewers; Active Maternity Leave
description: To the Editor:

title: North Light in Winter: The Elusive Sibelius
description: For no apparent reason related to the calendar of births and deaths, this musical season in New York has gravitated toward Sibelius. In December, Lincoln Center presented a festival, ''Northern Lights,'' centering on performances of Sibelius symphonies by Sir Colin Davis and the London Symphony Orchestra.

title: FILM IN REVIEW
description: 'Comrades, Almost a Love Story'

title: Navy Woman Tells of Being Propositioned by Army's Top Sergeant at 1996 Event
description: Sgt. Maj. Gene C. McKinney once propositioned a Navy petty officer at a health benefits conference in Denver in 1996 by telling her he would show her ''passion like I'd never seen before,'' she testified here today.

title: North Light In Winter: Sibelius
description: Here are some favorite Sibelius recordings of the classical-music critics of The New York Times. Compact disks range in price from $15.99 for a single disk to $25.98 for a two-disk set or $40 for a four-disk package. (An introduction appears on page 1 of Weekend.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAYMOND, ETHEL GROSS WILLIAMS
description: RAYMOND-Ethel Gross Williams, 84, died Feb 16, 1998. Loving mother of Helene Williams Spierman and Cynthia Lane. Beloved grandmother of Benjamin Spierman. Shiva February 19 in Dania, FL; Feb. 22, 12-6PM, in Rego Park, NY; February 23, 7-9 PM in Manhattan.

title: Lewis Friedman; Judge, 56, Heard Complex Cases
description: Justice Lewis R. Friedman of State Supreme Court in Manhattan, who was entrusted with the most complex commercial cases on the docket, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital after suffering a heart attack. He was 56 and lived on the Upper East Side.

title: Tennis Open Drops Caterer After Food Complaints
description: Few tennis fans lucky enough to have attended last year's United States Open finals are likely to remember the score of Patrick Rafter's remarkable victory. Yet fewer fans are probably able to shake the memory of the price of pizza in Flushing.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: William Zorach

title: Spain's Biggest Bank Trying to Get Bigger
description: Banco Santander S.A. offered yesterday to pay 630 billion pesetas ($4.1 billion) in stock to buy the 52 percent of Banco Espanol de Credito S.A. that it does not own, in an effort to cement its lead as Spain's biggest bank. Santander will offer Banesto shareholders one share for every 3.2 Banesto shares, or about 1,975 pesetas a share. Trading in the companies' shares was halted yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about the Labor Department's report on producer prices in January referred incorrectly to the report's most widely followed index. It measures the prices that manufacturers, farmers and other producers pay for finished goods, not the cost of raw materials and semifinished goods. The index fell seven-tenths of 1 percent last month.

title: New Video Releases
description: The Edge

title: U.S. Players Vandalize Living Suites At Village
description: Some members of the United States Olympic hockey team vandalized their living suites in the athletes' village after the team was eliminated by the Czech Republic on Wednesday, according to Olympic and hockey officials.

title: Metro Business; Stock Offering Increases
description: Doubleclick Inc., an Internet advertising company in New York, increased the size and anticipated price range of its initial public offering yesterday, a day before the shares are expected to begin trading.

title: Yes to Voluntary School Uniforms
description: Under current policy, parents and administrators at individual New York City schools can vote to require students to wear uniforms. It is entirely a matter of local initiative and choice. That would not be the case under a proposal by the Board of Education president, William Thompson. He would make uniforms mandatory for students up to sixth grade, unless planning teams at the schools vote to opt out of the plan. With Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew and others urging schools to generate independent proposals for reform, the Thompson plan sends a coercive message.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Peter Dreher

title: What Terrifies Airlines? Reservation in Name of Reijen
description: KUALA LUMPUR  Friends and business acquaintances of Hugo vanReijen agree: You do not want this man in front of you at the airport ticket counter.

title: Stretching the Privilege
description: It remains unclear whether the White House will formally invoke executive privilege to shield important Presidential associates like Bruce Lindsey from having to answer certain questions regarding President Clinton's relationship with the former White House intern Monica Lewinsky. But there are strong signals it may come to that. A formidable squad of 10 lawyers accompanied Mr. Lindsey to the Federal courthouse in Washington yesterday, where they conferred privately with prosecutors and the judge overseeing the grand jury before Mr. Lindsey began his second day of testimony. The White House has also retained outside counsel to represent the President should he choose to assert executive privilege.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FIRESTONE, HENRY
description: FIRESTONE-HENRY Jan. 13, 1917 Feb. 20, 1997. Always in our hearts. Jeffrey, Barney, Lynne, David and Stephen

title: Toxic Peril and the New York Connection
description: It began yesterday morning with a sketchy report that two white supremacists harboring plans to unleash biological toxins in New York City's subway system had been arrested. It ended at night with a considerably different, and somewhat less threatening, version of the original report.

title: Men's Group To Lay Off Entire Staff
description: Only four months after drawing hundreds of thousands of men to a prayer gathering on the Washington Mall, Promise Keepers, the evangelical men's movement, said yesterday that it would lay off its entire 345-person staff on March 31 because of financial problems and rely on volunteers at least temporarily.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, DAVID
description: MILLER-David. The officers and employees of Young & Rubicam Inc. note with sadness the passing of its retired general counsel and revered counselor. No one did more to establish and maintain the character and principles of the agency and its people. We send our deepest sympathy to his wife Sally and his two children.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLY, WILLIAM E.
description: KELLY-William E. The partners and employees of Lane & Mittendorf LLP mourn the passing of William E. Kelly, our colleague for more than forty years. His counsel and friendship will be greatly missed. Our thoughts and condolences are extended to his family.

title: What's in a name? Della Femina, who could write a book on nomenclature, is adding a Jeary.
description: ONE of Madison Avenue's best-known creative executives, Jerry Della Femina, is reinventing himself once again, this time with the help of a former top manager of Saatchi & Saatchi, Michael J. Jeary.

title: Iraq Neighbors Fear a Burden If U.S. Strikes
description: To the Pentagon, the term ''collateral damage'' has long been a euphemism for the loss of civilian life and property. But the phrase has taken on a broader meaning in the Arab world. Today it is used widely, from people in coffee shops to columnists in newspapers, to mean that Americans do not care about Arab lives, governments or economies.

title: Research Ties Radon to as Many as 21,800 Deaths Each Year
description: Mounting evidence points to radon in homes as an important public health problem, causing as many as 21,800 deaths annually from lung cancer, a National Research Council panel said today.

title: Working for the Clintons Can Mean Big Legal Bills
description: Margaret A. Williams, the former chief of staff to Hillary Rodham Clinton, says she tries not to read the news from Washington these days. Every time Ms. Williams, who is trying to live unnoticed in Paris, learns of another White House friend going before another grand jury, it reminds her of what binds her and dozens of other Clinton associates to this Administration: huge legal bills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAYLOR, PETER BURR
description: TAYLOR-Peter Burr. On February 14, 1998 in Boulder, CO. Devoted husband of Jeanne. Loving father of Susan T. Windward of Glendale, CA., and Anne Taylor of Anchorage, AK. Proud grandfather of Shane and Taylor Wallace. Brother of Walter Jennings Taylor of Busby, MT. and Aspen, CO., Jean Taylor Johnson of Essex, CT. and the late Henry Stillman Taylor. A graduate of Saint Paul's School, he attended Dartmouth College and served in P.T. boats in WWII. Memorials in his name may be sent to the University of Colorado, Athletic Dept., Boulder, CO 80302.

title: In a Shift, Giuliani Forms Commission to Study Power Allocation in Charter
description: Concerned about efforts in the City Council to weaken mayoral power by revising the City Charter, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani made a pre-emptive strike yesterday by forming his own panel to look into the issue.

title: Drinks
description: From elegant watering hole to scruffy local pub, these 12 bars are prime places for meeting, greeting and sometimes even eating. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are from Ruth Reichl's and Mr. Asimov's dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: ADAPTEC SAYS IT WILL BUY A HYUNDAI SUBSIDIARY
description: Adaptec Inc. agreed yesterday to buy Symbios Inc., a subsidiary of Hyundai Electronics America, for $775 million in cash as it seeks to diversify its business and reverse a recent slowdown in sales growth. Adaptec, which makes computer adapter cards that connect PC's to printers, storage drives and other accessories, will take a charge to buy Symbios, which makes external storage devices for Sun Microsystems and Hewlett-Packard. Last month, Adaptec, based in Milpitas, Calif., said its third-quarter profit fell 11 percent, to $37 million, because of weak sales in North America. Symbios, based in Fort Collins, Colo., had 1997 sales of $620 million. Adaptec rose 93.75 cents yesterday, to $25.625, before the deal was announced.

title: Those Lethal Oysters
description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It's terrible. They don't cover the events. They show Tara Lipinski practicing three weeks ago. Don't show me that.''

title: Life Support Is Removed After a Court Order
description: Despite objections by his family, a hospital removed a brain-dead 23-year-old from life support yesterday, after having taken the unusual step of seeking a court order to end his life.

title: Of Italian Hustlers And Rin Tin Tin
description: Not a good month for big new releases, February has come through in the smaller video niches. In the ''classics'' reissued category, for example, ''Elmer Gantry,'' ''Lolita,'' ''All the President's Men,'' ''Treasure of the Sierra Madre,'' ''Casablanca'' and ''Tom Jones'' lead several score prominent old titles available in new packaging. For lovers of old television series, there are a half-dozen more episodes of ''The Adventures of Rin Tin Tin,'' and for history buffs there is ''The Fifties,'' a six-cassette series based on the book by David Halberstam, to be released Tuesday by A&E.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBLATT, DAVID ALAN
description: ROSENBLATT-David Alan. On February 18, 1998, of Manhattan, NY, devoted father of Pamela and Matthew Rosenblatt, succumbed to complications of diabetes after putting up a heroic battle. Beloved first-born of Claire and William Rosenblatt of Boca Raton, FL. Loving big brother of Stuart, Mark and Laura, cherished uncle of Sarah, Kevin and Jacob, and dearest brother-in-law to Elizabeth, Luann, and Carl. David was a man of incredible kindness, generosity, and humor who befriended all those who crossed his path. His mastery of the printing and advertising field was universally admired by both colleagues and competitors. Services at 11:15 AM on Sunday, February 22, at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, West 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, New York. Interment to follow at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR SLIPS. The dollar fell against the mark and the yen ahead of this weekend's meeting of the Group of Seven. In New York the dollar ended at 1.8162 marks, down from 1.8216, and at 126.16 yen, down from 126.40.

title: Prosecution Finishes Testimony in Park Avenue Murder Case
description: The final witness against John J. Royster took the stand yesterday afternoon, telling the jury of the last glimpse he had of his wife just hours before she was beaten to death on a Park Avenue sidewalk.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, MARTHA
description: WEISS-Martha. Devoted wife of Lester. Beloved mother of David, Joyce, Jack and Joan. Cherished grandmother of Eric, Paula, Howard, Ricci, Dara, Adam and Samantha. Loving greatgrandmother of Tyler, Jesse and Seth. Devoted sister of Fae, Ruth, Beverly and the late Morton. Services 11:30AM, Friday at ''Boulevard Riverside Chapel'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, New York.

title: North Light In Winter: Sibelius
description: Here are some favorite Sibelius recordings of the classical-music critics of The New York Times. Compact disks range in price from $15.99 for a single disk to $25.98 for a two-disk set or $40 for a four-disk package. (An introduction appears on page 1 of Weekend.)

title: Black Helicopters
description: To the Editor:

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in New York City this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: TENNIS: ROUNDUP
description: FABER GRAND PRIX

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: 'Utz'

title: Invading Coward's Privacy, Or, Who Let the Sailor In?
description: In Craig Archibald's ''Private Life'' -- obviously about Noel Coward -- there is more of Mr. Archibald than of Coward, and to some admirers of this actor that is not at all a bad thing.

title: PLATINUM TECHNOLOGY AGREES TO ACQUIRE MASTERING
description: The business-software developer Platinum Technology Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire Mastering Inc., an information-technology training company, for $138.7 million in stock. Under the deal, which is scheduled to close in the second quarter, Platinum would swap 0.448 of a share of its stock for each Mastering share. News of the acquisition sent Mastering's stock up 21 percent, to $11.50, a gain of $2 a share. Shares of Platinum slipped 6.25 cents, to $27.0625. Mastering, based in Scottsdale, Ariz., had 1997 revenues of $40.9 million. Platinum, based in Oakbrook Terrace, Ill., had 1997 revenues of $623.5 million.

title: Justice Dept. to Join Suit Against TRW
description: The Justice Department said today that it would join in a whistle-blower lawsuit that accuses TRW Inc. of falsely billing the Government for expenses.

title: Clinton Promotes Clean Water and Democrats
description: President Clinton today promoted his initiative to clean up the country's polluted waters and then brought more than $1 million into Democratic Party coffers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHN, ARTHUR
description: COHN-Arthur. Mannes College of Music mourns the passing of friend and donor Arthur Cohn. We are immensely grateful for his generous support of Mannes's Harry Scherman Library, to benefit future generations of music students. We extend our deep condolences to his wife Lois and to his family. Joel Lester, Dean

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Rose Marasco

title: A Fair That's More Fun Than Any of Its Parts
description: An art fair has an atmosphere all its own, alternately oppressive and stimulating, and weird either way. Neither art gallery nor museum, it is really a kind of theater, each booth being a small stage set where the play is already in progress.

title: Somerfield to Acquire British Food Retailer
description: Somerfield P.L.C. agreed yesterday to pay about $:473 million ($776 million) in stock for Kwik Save P.L.C. Somerfield offered seven shares for every six Kwik Save shares, giving its shareholders 62.5 percent of the new company and Kwik Save shareholders 37.5 percent. Based on Wednesday's closing price, the offer values each Kwik Save share at 304 pence.

title: The Cars Were Big and Elvis Was Young
description: The year 1950 was a landmark on the march to the millennium. Although halfway marks have limited value for doomsayers, and no one had reason yet to predict that the failure of computer clocks would bring about the fall of civilization, half a century was used up, and experience suggested that the second half was likely to bring some changes. As, in fact, it did.

title: Torre Likes the Look Of Any of His Lineups
description: As the manager who will determine how the Yankees' hitters line up, Joe Torre likens himself to a happy little kid. He intends to shuffle the batting order in spring training, try different combinations, slide his various All-Stars up and down the lineup.

title: Olympian Heights for Women, Not for Viewers; A Safety Issue
description: To the Editor:

title: North Light In Winter: Sibelius
description: Here are some favorite Sibelius recordings of the classical-music critics of The New York Times. Compact disks range in price from $15.99 for a single disk to $25.98 for a two-disk set or $40 for a four-disk package. (An introduction appears on page 1 of Weekend.)

title: Budgets and Asterisks
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLYNN, MARJORIE MARY
description: FLYNN-Marjorie Mary. Formerly of Astoria, Bayside, and Little Neck. Long-time widow of Robert J. Flynn who had worked for Cities Service Oil Company for 43 years and died in 1966. One of the five daughters of Joe and Amelia Schneider of Bethpage (Central Park); devoted and beloved mother of Robert H. Flynn (Margaret) and Donald C. Flynn (Reina). Grandmother of Maura, Hilary, Christopher, Geoffrey, Amy, Kevin and Sarah. Great grandmother of nine. Survived by her children, grandchildren, great-grandchildren, her sister Florence, numerous cousins, nieces, nephews and Evelyn Ballment. She was a happy, beautiful, and truly kind woman, who loved her home and her family. Wake on Friday at Doyle B. Shaffer Funeral Home in Little Neck. Funeral Mass at 9:45 AM on Saturday, February 21 in St. Mary's Church in Manhasset.

title: TARRAGON AND NATIONAL INCOME REALTY PLAN TO COMBINE
description: Tarragon Realty Investors Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire National Income Realty Trust for $78 million in stock, combining two real estate investment trusts with holdings in California, Florida and Texas. Under the deal, Tarragon would exchange 1.97 of its shares for each share of National Income. National Income's stock jumped $2 a share, to $18.125, in Nasdaq trading, where Tarragon's stock was unchanged at $10.0625. National Realty is based in New York, and Tarragon is based in Dallas. The combined company, to be called Tarragon Investors, would control more than 12,000 multifamily apartments and 1.7 million square feet of retail and office space.

title: Olympian Heights for Women, Not for Viewers; In Search of Rationality
description: To the Editor:

title: Simon DeBartolo Wins Fight For a Prime Group of Malls
description: The Simon DeBartolo Group Inc. secured its position at the top of the shopping-mall industry yesterday, winning a bidding war for Corporate Property Investors in a $4.8 billion deal and gaining control of a premier group of shopping centers, as well as the General Motors Building, a landmark office tower in Manhattan.

title: The Neediest Cases; A Chef Who Lost It All Is Finally Off the Streets
description: On good days, when Michael Geda lived on the street, he slept in a cheap motel on the West Side Highway. On bad days, when his panhandling yielded less than the $44 it cost for a room, he rode the A train until dawn. But during his eight months of homelessness, he rarely slept more than a few hours on the train, one of the few lines that remain underground, and warm, along most of their routes. ''Either the police harass you or, on bad nights, thieves try to rob you,'' said Mr. Geda, 61, a thickly bearded man with leaden eyes and hands that never stop fretting. ''I don't like to remember this.''

title: Torch Songs and a Suspicious Wife
description: If Billy Joel had never made the career leap from Long Island piano bars to rock arenas, he might have ended up like Denis Leary's cynical, wisecracking protagonist in Juan J. Campanella's flaccid film noir, ''Love Walked In.'' A cocktail pianist and aspiring author of crime novels, Jack Hanaway is an affable charmer with a mean streak that pops out when he's performing. Before playing the pre-rock standards that are his stock-in-trade, Jack likes to deliver sarcastic monologues that thinly echo the rants of another Dennis (Miller), as he twits his well-heeled audiences for being shallow, smug yuppies.

title: Fund Concern Fined $125,000 Over Ads
description: The Fundamental Service Corporation, a fund company in New York, and two executives have agreed to pay $125,000 to settle charges that they falsely advertised a volatile, money-losing mutual fund as a conservative investment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARA, GERALD B., M.D.
description: KARA-Gerald B., M.D. With great sorrow, The New York Eye and Ear Infirmary Board of Directors, Medical Staff and Administration mourn the passing of an esteemed ophthalmologist, renowned intraocular surgeon and guiding force within the hospital. After completing residency here in 1949, Dr. Kara joined the Infirmary's medical staff, where he became a surgeon director in ophthalmology, chairman of the Medical Board and, since 1991, a trustee of the Infirmary. Dr. Kara served as director of the internationally known Post Graduate Institute of The New York Eye and Ear Infirmary for more than thirty years. Our sincerest condolences to his wife, Gisela. Peter Frelinghuysen, Chairman, Board of Directors Robert C. Della Rocca, M.D. Chairman, Medical Board Joseph P. Corcoran President and CEO

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COTTON AT FOUR-YEAR LOW. The price of the March contract dropped 1.26 cents yesterday, to 64.17 cents a pound, on the New York Cotton Exchange. Cotton is off almost 13 percent in the last six months.

title: Rio Journal; Slums, and Samba, Have Their Day
description: The ragtag band stopping traffic on Visconde de Piraja, the shopping strip in upper-crust Ipanema, was the kind that drivers here roll up their windows to avoid: dressed in worn clothes, grease smeared over their faces and predominantly black.

title: Prosecutors Building a Case for a Federal Louima Trial
description: When defense lawyers, prosecutors and the inevitable media pack gather in a state courthouse in Brooklyn for pretrial sessions in the case of four police officers charged with brutalizing Abner Louima, a hum of spinning wheels seems to sound in the minds of some participants.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Apostles of the Faith That Books Matter
description: When I was 8 years old, my mother took me by the hand and marched me four blocks up the street to a storefront branch of the public library. We opened the door and crossed over into a rectangular room lined from floor to ceiling with books. At a desk in the center of the room sat a large woman with gray hair piled up on her head and rimless glasses secured to the bridge of her nose. My mother approached the desk, pointed at my head and said, ''She likes to read.''

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Broken Rangers Are Now Muckler's Team to Fix
description: The rebuilding of the Rangers has begun.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CURIE, MARIE
description: CURIE-Marie. On February 7, 1998. Peacefully, at home, after a brief illness. This dynamic lady will be missed by her many devoted friends. A memorial service will be held Saturday, February 21st, 11AM at the Church of the Epiphany, 239 E. 21 St, NYC.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: 'Portraits'

title: Two Convicted of Laundering Drug Cash
