description: Two San Francisco interior designers who decorated lavish homes for a Colombian drug lord, then collected many of their cash payments in New York, were convicted yesterday in Federal District Court in Brooklyn on charges that they laundered drug money.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANLEY, WILLIAM J.
description: HANLEY-William J. Of Scarsdale, N.Y., on Feb. 16. Bennett Funeral Home, Friday 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass, I.H.M. 10AM Saturday.

title: HOLLYWOOD PARK TO BUY CASINO MAGIC FOR $81 MILLION
description: Hollywood Park Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the Casino Magic Corporation for $2.27 a share, or $81 million, in cash. It also agreed to assume debt of about $240 million from Casino Magic, which has casinos in Bay St. Louis and Biloxi, Miss.; Bossier City, La., and Neuquen City and San Martin de los Andes in Argentina. The company said it would look to acquire more casinos outside of Las Vegas and Atlantic City. On Jan. 20, Grand Casinos Inc. proposed buying Casino Magic, according to a Federal filing. It offered to buy 25 percent of the company's shares for $1.60 each and swap one Grand Casinos share for 7.95 Casino Magic shares. Casino Magic is based in Bay St. Louis. Its shares rose 37.5 cents, to $2.0625, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Treasury Prices Fall Slightly in Light Trading
description: Treasury prices declined modestly yesterday. Trading was light as many investors chose to await next week's appearance of Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, on Capitol Hill, as well as an auction of new Treasury notes.

title: Ulster Peace Talks: Waiting for a Court
description: The possible expulsion of Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, from the Northern Ireland peace talks has produced a political theater of the absurd.

title: Murder Suspect Is Held on $1 Million Bail
description: A rootless, unemployed 24-year-old man charged with murdering a 15-year-old high school freshman last Saturday was held on $1 million bail today as the authorities pressed a search for others possibly involved in the slaying.

title: A Deal Kofi Annan Can Make
description: Diplomatic handicappers are not giving the United Nations Secretary General, Kofi Annan, much chance of resolving the Iraq crisis during his mission to Baghdad this weekend. But the shape of a plausible agreement, though largely unnoticed, can be found in inspection arrangements once accepted by both Iraq and the United States. If reconstituted and reaffirmed, they could give U.N. weapons inspectors the unrestricted access they must have, while honoring Iraq's claims of sovereign dignity at national palaces and other locations now off limits to inspection.

title: She Smolders, He Fumes: Gee, It's Hot
description: The opening scenes of Volker Schlondorff's juicy film noir, ''Palmetto,'' evoke semitropical rot in southern Florida with such a deliriously sensual appreciation of evil that when the movie eventually runs amok, you can almost forgive it for becoming a shrill, comic self-parody.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOMAZOV, ELSIE
description: LOMAZOV-Elsie. The Officers, Directors, Administration and Staff of the the Gurwin Jewish Geriatric Center extend their heartfelt sympathy to Bernice Zwanger, member of the Board of Directors, on the passing of her mother, Elsie Lomazov. Elsie had been a loved resident of the Gurwin Center and will be missed. Joseph Gurwin, President Alfred W. Levy, Chairman of the Board Herbert H. Friedman, Executive Vice President

title: Olympian Heights for Women, Not for Viewers; Tuning Out the Talk
description: To the Editor:

title: Johnson Thrown for Loop Amid Trade Talk
description: Jettisoning All-Star pitchers rarely seems to result in anything good for major league clubs. Ask the Mets, who suffered in the post-Tom Seaver era, and the Angels and Astros teams that had to persevere without Nolan Ryan. The 1997 Red Sox struggled so badly, it was as if the baseball gods were punishing them for not re-signing Roger Clemens.

title: Buffett and Fans, Happy Again in Margaritaville
description: Take heed, guardians of public virtue. Tear yourselves away from Marilyn Manson and those nasty rappers, and face popular music's true subversive: Jimmy Buffett.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   RAFSKY, ROBERT ALAN
description: RAFSKY-Robert Alan July 22, 1945-February 21, 1993 Five years and time has lost its meaning No way to measure it since your leaving The days and nights and all the seasons Tumble by without rhyme or reasons But the memory of you and your life so brillant Glows in our hearts in our bereavement.

title: Dream and Reality on the Hudson
description: New York City residents have long hoped to reclaim their Hudson River shoreline, replacing its rotting piers with an inviting mix of open spaces, playing fields and modest commercial development. That dream, which has alternately bloomed and receded, now seems closer to reality, largely because both Gov. George Pataki and Mayor Rudolph Giuliani have publicly endorsed it. They have also pledged $100 million each to make it happen. There are still obstacles, but every one is negotiable if the Mayor and Governor are willing to compromise and shift their formidable egos into neutral.

title: In Deep Freeze, a Little Air and DNA for the Future
description: If all goes as planned, at the stroke of midnight on Jan. 1, 2001, a team of international scientists will bore 65 feet into the frozen continent of Antarctica to bury several skinny, torpedo-shaped steel or ceramic containers with a 1,000-year ''Do Not Disturb'' sign.

title: The Neediest Cases; Far From Home in Ukraine, Woman Rears Grandson
description: After arriving in this country from Ukraine nearly three years ago with her young grandson, Roman, Galina Yavlinskaya had to brace herself each time she entered a supermarket. The sheer abundance of everything from fresh fruits and vegetables to cookies and candy would leave her weeping in the aisles for what her own children never had.

title: Ex-Governor, in Plea, to Aid in Whitewater Case
description: Marking an important breakthrough for Whitewater prosecutors, former Gov. Jim Guy Tucker of Arkansas pleaded guilty to a conspiracy charge today and agreed to cooperate with investigators who have spent the last four years examining the business dealings of the President and Hillary Rodham Clinton before they arrived in Washington.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Louis Jones, 84, Country Music's 'Grandpa'
description: Louis Marshall Jones, a mainstay of the Grand Ole Opry and country music since he transformed himself at age 22 into the corn-pone, banjo-pickin' Grandpa Jones who later gained ''Hee Haw'' fame, died on Thursday at McKendree Village in Nashville. He was 84 and lived in Goodlettsville, Tenn.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about Hindu-Muslim relations in India misspelled the name of the mosque in Delhi where Muslim women prepared for prayer. It was the Jama Masjid (the name means Friday Mosque), not Jammu.

title: College Quarterback Signed by Rockies
description: The Colorado Rockies signed John Hessler, a former University of Colorado quarterback, to a minor league contract as a pitcher. Hessler, 23, was an honorable mention all-Big 12 selection last season after completing 181 of 338 passes for 2,478 yards and 14 touchdowns.

title: U.N. Team Calls Iraq Sites Smaller Than Thought
description: United Nations experts issued a report here today that portrayed sites Iraq declared off-limits to weapons inspectors as much smaller and vastly different than Washington and the United Nations Special Commission to disarm Iraq have asserted.

title: FORD SETS 2-WEEK LAYOFFS TO CUT BACKLOG OF SMALL CARS
description: The Ford Motor Company will lay off 3,500 hourly workers at its assembly plant in Wayne, Mich., for two weeks starting on Monday to reduce a backlog of its Ford Escort and Mercury Tracer cars. Ford has a 117-day supply of unsold Escorts and a 103-day supply of Tracers, more than its 72-day target, Jim Bright, a Ford spokesman, said. Sales of small cars have been buffeted as consumers increasingly turn to larger vehicles and trucks. The Detroit-based Ford will display a redesigned Escort next week at the Geneva auto show and will start selling the car in Europe in the fall and in the United States next year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOHMER, ROBERT HUGO
description: SOHMER-Robert Hugo. On February 18, 1998 of Rye, New York. Beloved uncle of John, Harry III and Annina Sohmer-Knight. Also survived by devoted sister-in-law Anne Sohmer and grand nephew Harry Brown Sohmer. Graduate of St. Bernard's, member of St. Anthony's, St. George's and University of Pennsylvania. Retired Vice President of the Sohmer Piano Company. Services private. Contributions to Friends of the Osborne, Rye, New York 10580, would be appreciated.

title: Even on Sex and on War, a Time to Be Irresolute
description: The dire moment came early during Wednesday's so-called town meeting at Ohio State University, devised by the Administration to whip up enthusiasm for the bombing of Iraq, when Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen displayed for the CNN camera a picture of an Iraqi mother and child who he said had been killed by nerve gas. He titled it, ''Madonna and Child, Saddam Hussein Style.''

title: U.N. Expands Quota for Iraq's Oil Sales
description: The Security Council today more than doubled the amount of oil that Baghdad will be allowed to sell to buy food, medicine and other goods desperately needed by the 22 million Iraqis living under United Nations sanctions.

title: 11 Arrested in Scheme Over Insurance Claims
description: Two civilian police employees were among 11 people arrested Thursday for selling thousands of car accident reports to doctors and lawyers who used them to enlist victims in schemes to bilk insurance companies, county prosecutors said yesterday.

title: Great Brington Journal; There'll Always Be a Shrine to Diana, but Must It Be Here?
description: At a recent meeting, the Parish Council in this tiny village presented its new footpath report. It disclosed its plans for Operation Spring Cleaning, in which volunteers help tidy the shrubbery and pick up debris. It reviewed the traffic situation on Main Street.

title: Help for Disabled, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Indonesia Will Repay Deposits at Closed Banks
description: Indonesia will repay all the deposits stored at the 16 banks that were closed in November, totaling 3.1 trillion rupiah, the Finance Minister, Marie Muhammad, said yesterday. He said deposits would be repaid by the central bank and reimbursed by the Government over 10 years.

title: Pentagon Report Plays Down Cost of Expanding NATO
description: With only weeks before the Senate votes on whether to expand NATO, Clinton Administration officials say that a new Pentagon report has found that the direct costs of absorbing Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic into the alliance will be $1.5 billion over 10 years -- much lower than earlier Administration estimates.

title: Chicago Journal; For Cubs Fans, One Idol Never Wore a Uniform
description: Wrapped in a rubber rain suit, several sweatshirts and a sleeping bag or two, Greggo Wolin marked his spot outside Wrigley Field on Thursday, the first in line for Cubs tickets, a mere 17 hours before they went on sale.

title: Trump and State Defend Attempt to Seize Property
description: A judge in Atlantic County Superior Court heard arguments yesterday in a long-standing legal scuffle between small property owners in Atlantic City and the casino developer Donald J. Trump. In 1994, at the urging of Mr. Trump, state casino officials sought a court order to condemn the house where an Atlantic City widow, Vera Coking, has lived for more than 35 years so that Mr. Trump could use the site to build a limousine waiting area for one of his casino hotels, said Dana Berliner, a lawyer for Ms. Coking. Ms. Coking argued yesterday that the condemnation proceedings violated a constitutional requirement that the Government only seize private property if its provides ''just compensation'' and uses the property for the good of the public, Ms. Berliner said.

title: Court Gives Father Chance to Take Custody
description: A state appeals court ruled yesterday that the natural father of a 4-year-old boy can take the child away from his foster parents provided that he proves the move is in the child's best interest.

title: Truth in Mottoes
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEYER, MURRAY
description: STEYER-Murray. Beloved husband of Beatrice Steyer for 51 years. Loving father of Robert, Richard and Betsy and loved father-in-law of Fred and Patricia. Treasured grandfather of Matthew, Laura and Harry. Devoted brother of Frances S. Martinson and the late Roy Steyer. He died as he lived-with dignity and grace and surrounded by his family who cherished him. The funeral will be held at 10 AM, on Monday, February 23rd, at the Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road in Scarsdale.

title: In Other Rinks
description: THE EUROPEAN GAME -- It was an extraordinary day for Olympic hockey: Dominik Hasek was again dominant in goal as the Czech Republic shocked Canada in a shootout, and Pavel Bure scored five goals in Russia's defeat of Finland. On Sunday, the Czechs and Russians will revive one of the sport's best rivalries in the gold medal game. SportsSaturday, page C1.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISSE, EDWARD J.
description: WEISSE-Edward J. Beloved husband of Marie (nee Keller); devoted father of Annmarie and Mary Weisse, Linda Heaney and Norine Hopewell; dear uncle of Stephanie; beloved brother of Marilyn Manzella; cherished grandfather of Sarah, Matthew, Christina, Kevin and Jessica; devoted uncle of many nieces and nephews; dear fatherin-law of Michael and Thomas. Family will receive friends at Williams Funeral Home, 5628 Broadway at West 232 St, Bronx, on Saturday and Sunday from 2-5 and 79pm. Mass of Christian Burial, St. John's Church, Monday 10:45am. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Calvery Hospital.

title: Japanese Auto Exports Increased in January
description: Japanese auto makers increased exports last month compared with the month a year earlier as strong sales in Europe and the United States offset declines in Asia. Sales in Japan plummeted and overseas vehicle production fell. Four Japanese auto makers -- Nissan Motor, Honda Motor, Mitsubishi Motors and Mazda Motor -- reported higher exports in January. The Toyota Motor Corporation, Japan's largest auto maker, said exports fell 1.9 percent.

title: Press Freedom at Issue in Use of 'Sealed' File by Paper and Reporter
description: Should a reporter be jailed or fined, or both, if she reads a sealed court document mistakenly given to her by a court clerk? And should her newspaper pay damages for printing some details from the document?

title: LAWYER SAYS ALLY INFORMED CLINTON OF AID FOR INTERN
description: Vernon E. Jordan Jr., one of President Clinton's closest friends, kept the President personally informed of his efforts to find a job and a lawyer for Monica S. Lewinsky in the days after Ms. Lewinsky, a former White House intern, became a potentially damaging witness in the sexual misconduct case against Mr. Clinton, according to a lawyer who knows Mr. Jordan's version of events.

title: Dynamo on the Ice: Tara Kristen Lipinski
description: After she became the youngest woman to win an Olympic figure skating title, 15-year-old Tara Lipinski called her father tonight on a cellular phone and said, ''Happy Birthday, Dad.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRUKIER, CHARLES
description: DRUKIER-Charles. Our sympathy to you, Ira, Gale and Jennifer. He will be missed by all of us. Elli and Izreal Krakowski Lilli and Axel Stawski Harry and Andrea Krakowski

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENIMOFF, DR
description: BENIMOFF-Dr. Murray. On February 19, 1998. Husband of Norma (nee Woldman) of Cherry Hill, New Jersey. Father of Dr. Alissa (Dr. James) Fox and Dr. Nicholas (Susan Fussell) Benimoff. Grandfather of Jonathan Fox and Alexandra Fox. Services and Interment will be Sunday in Cleveland, OH. The family respectfully requests contributions in his memory be made to Jewish Family and Children's Service, 1301 Springdale Rd, Cherry Hill, New Jersey 08003. A memorial service will be held in Cherry Hill at a later date.

title: Beliefs
description: It has been repeatedly called a moral drama, this storm of accusations of Presidential adultery, deception and perjury and the countercharges of overstepping by prosecutors and the news media. So why have the views of religious leaders been almost entirely missing from the public commentary flooding the nation since mid-January?

title: Kirk Memorial Service
description: A memorial service for Grayson L. Kirk, who was president of Columbia University from 1953 to 1968, is scheduled for Monday at 4 P.M. in St. Paul's Chapel on the Columbia campus.

title: Clinton Orders Rights Action In Health Care
description: President Clinton took action today to improve the quality of health care provided to more than 85 million Americans who participate in Medicare, Medicaid and various health insurance programs for Federal employees, retirees and veterans.

title: Beethoven, the Heavyweight After All
description: Medically speaking, taking over a major American orchestra in the present financial and political circumstances may not be what every doctor would order for a conductor with a heart condition. But there on Tuesday evening at Carnegie Hall was Mariss Jansons, recovered from two heart attacks in 1996, making his first New York appearance as music director of the Pittsurgh Symphony Orchestra and looking utterly fit at 55.

title: The Accidental Inventor of Today's Capitalism; Jean-Baptiste Say, No Longer a Villain, Stands Guard Over Free Markets
description: He came of age in the French Revolution. In the spirit of the times, he greatly admired Benjamin Franklin and Thomas Jefferson. And when the Bourbons managed to get their throne back in 1814, a discouraged Jean-Baptiste Say almost emigrated to America. He even wrote to Jefferson, asking how much he would have to pay to purchase a working cotton farm near Jefferson's own Virginia spread.

title: With Two Drummers, Count on Swinging
description: Greg Bandy's show on Tuesday night at Sweet Basil was a display of jazz as entertainment. Mr. Bandy sang a song called ''Good Booty and Barbecue,'' and his pianist, Donald Smith, sang a hippie-ish tune. The group played a house-rocking calypso, and everywhere rhythm reigned. Fun was on the agenda.

title: Merger Negotiations End For Telenor and Telia
description: Norway and Sweden said yesterday that they had ended talks to merge their state-owned telecommunications companies, Telenor A.S.A. and Telia A.B., because they could not agree on how much influence each country should have. While neither side would blame the other, Telenor said yesterday that it was worried that Sweden would have been the dominant partner.

title: Fernando Abril Martorell, 61, Key Spanish Aide
description: Fernando Abril Martorell, a former Deputy Prime Minister and a key figure in Spain's transition to democracy after the Franco dictatorship, died on Monday at Puerta de Hierro Hospital in Madrid. He was 61.

title: INSIDE
description: Expulsion From Irish Talks

title: David C. Masket, 67, Ex-Apparel Executive
description: David C. Masket, a former president of Maidenform Worldwide, died at New York University Hospital on Feb. 3. He was 67 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Markets Rally After Trading Lower for Most of the Day
description: The stock market staged a comeback yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average returning to positive territory after a decline Thursday snapped a six-day streak of consecutive records.

title: Treasury Prices Fall as Many Investors Stay on the Sidelines
description: Treasury prices fell for the second consecutive session in light trading yesterday.

title: Top Sergeant Coerced Sex, Accuser Says
description: Sgt. Christina Roy testified today at the court-martial of Sgt. Maj. Gene C. McKinney that when she was seven months pregnant, she had sexual intercourse with him in his home because she ''felt it was easier to hurry up and get it over with'' than to resist or refuse.

title: Mayor Still at Odds With Grammy Chief
description: Just hours before the record industry began celebrating next week's Grammy Awards with a reception yesterday at Lincoln Center, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said he was not ready to make peace with the man in charge of the presentation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHSCHILD, ELSYE ROSENFELD
description: ROTHSCHILD-Elsye Rosenfeld. May 17, 1899-February 19, 1998. Loving wife for 52 years of the late Jesse. Much loved mother of Charles, Edmund, Stephanie and Kathy. Proud grandmother of Joshua, Adam, Oliver, Emily, Jesse, Sarah and Anna. Devoted sister of Rita, Ruth, Nonie, Irene and Flo. Caring aunt and grandaunt and surrogate parent to many. Elsye unselfishly committed her life to her family, friends, neighbors and community. Yeoman First Class, USN, in WWI, Manager of Camp Copake, Democratic Party Captain, Secretary and Board Member of Mt. Neboh Cemetery. She fought tenaciously for what she believed in and spoke what was on her mind. She was a brilliant, strong and beautiful person and will be long remembered and greatly missed. Services Sunday, February 22, at 10:30 AM, at The Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to St. Joseph's Hospital Foundation, 703 Main St., Paterson, NJ 07503, or Manhattan New School PTA, 311 East 82 Street, NY, NY 10028.

title: Donald Flamm, 98, Radio Broadcaster
description: Donald Flamm, a former New York broadcaster and theatrical producer who helped shape the notion of a Voice of America, died on Sunday at Good Samaritan Medical Center in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 98 and had homes in Palm Beach and Alpine, N.J.

title: Uncovered Short Sales Rise on the Big Board and Amex
description: On the smaller American Stock Exchange, the increase was smaller, with open short positions rising 1.3 percent, to 169,870,449 from 167,686,416.

title: The Unknown Soldier May Be Known
description: The family of Air Force Lieut. Michael Blassie, whose plane was shot down over Vietnam in 1972, believes that his body is interred in the Tomb of the Unknowns in Arlington National Cemetery. Lieutenant Blassie's mother has asked that the remains be exhumed and subjected to DNA testing so that her son -- if it is her son -- can be buried under a headstone with his own name. The request may be hurtful to Americans for whom the tomb is a particularly sacred site, particularly the families of the more than 2,000 servicemen still classified as missing in the Vietnam War. Nonetheless, it must be honored.

title: CENTEX ACQUIRING WAYNE HOMES STAKE FOR $60 MILLION
description: The Centex Corporation's Centex Homes unit said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire 90 percent of the single-family-home operations of Wayne Homes Inc., a privately owned construction company, for $60 million. Under the agreement, expected to close in early April, Wayne Homes' senior managers will retain a 10 percent interest in the company. The acquisition will occur after a pending sale of Wayne Homes stock by its shareholders to the WHI Acquisition Corporation of Connecticut. Dallas-based Centex said it would operate the business under the Wayne Homes name and retain its 500 employees.

title: What to Look For
description: BOBSLED

title: Tokyo Stimulus Fails to Draw Rave Reviews
description: Japan's ruling party today announced its fourth package of economic stimulants in the last four months, but the initiatives ignored bolder steps to improve the economy that have been urged by the United States and other countries.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the investigation into charges that a Haitian immigrant, Abner Louima, was beaten and sexually assaulted by police officers in Brooklyn in August misstated the charges facing Officer Thomas Wiese. He is charged with assault, not sexual assault.

title: Grace Displaces Grunge; 10-Year-Olds in Westchester Take to Ballroom Dancing
description: Freds and Gingers they were not. But in an age of rap and grunge, the 10-year-olds dancing waltzes, fox trots and merengues the other night made their own gawky argument on behalf of quiet grace and chivalry.

title: Sports of The Times; Lipinski Took a Head Start on Her Way to Gold
description: DURING the opening parade she radiated, a tiny star in a swarm of athletes. Her smile was magnetic. She was having fun.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINGATE, JUDITH WAGNER
description: WINGATE-Judith Wagner. Age 63 suffered a brain aneurysm and passed away suddenly on February 21, 1998. Judy spent most of her life caring for others. She was a strong caring mother and loved her husband, children and family so much. She recently ceased full time employment on January 31 as a nurse clinician in the Osteoporosis Center at the Hospital for Special Surgery in New York. Before her latest career at the Hospital for Special Surgery, she spent many years as a dialysis nurse. In addition to her career and family she spent many hours volunteering with the Junior League of Brooklyn and Northern Westchester. Judy is survived by her husband John, her daughter Jennifer, her sons Jack and Jeff as well as two grandchildren, Julia and Jane. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, February 24th, 11 A.M., at The Congregational Church of Huntington, 30 Washington Dr, off of Rt 25A North, Centerport, NY. In lieu of flowers if donations would like to be made in her name, please send to VIBS (Victims Information Bureau of Suffolk), a domestic violence agency where Judy was a Board member, P.O. Box 5483, Hauppauge, NY 11788. Her family misses her very much. We love you Mom.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, DAVID
description: MILLER-David. The officers and employees of Young & Rubicam Inc. note with sadness the passing of its retired general counsel and revered counselor. No one did more to establish and maintain the character and principles of the agency and its people. We send our deepest sympathy to his wife Sally and his two children.

title: Paid Maternity Leave Can Punish Workers
description: To the Editor:

title: Under Pressure, Indonesia Halts Currency Plan
description: Pressed by foreign governments and by the power of the international marketplace, Indonesia retreated today from a highly criticized plan to strengthen its ravaged currency.

title: Little Fear Is Shown By Troops Near Border
description: Sipping cardamom coffee in his tent just two miles from the Iraqi border, Sgt. Saad Ashban of the Kuwaiti interior forces said he had no fear that an American-led attack on Iraq would put him or his men in danger.

title: CKE RAISES PRICE IT WILL PAY FOR 557 HARDEE'S OUTLETS
description: CKE Restaurants Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to pay 3 percent more to buy 557 Hardee's fast-food restaurants from the franchisee Advantica Restaurant Group Inc. CKE, which also operates the Carl's Jr. restaurant chain, raised the amount it will pay to $381 million in cash and the assumption of $46 million in debt from $369 million in cash and $46 million in debt it offered last month. CKE has said that direct ownership of the Hardee's restaurants will put it in a better position to expand the brand and improve operating margins. Advantica, formerly the Flagstar Companies, is CKE's largest franchisee of Hardee's restaurants.

title: Versions of Truth, by the Book; American Mythology
description: To the Editor:

title: After 43 Years, Navy Withdraws From Operations in Antarctica
description: In a ceremony held yesterday in Christchurch, New Zealand, the United States Navy formally ended the predominant role it has played during the last 43 years of American operations in Antarctica.

title: For Lipinski, Skating Dream Turns to Gold
description: When she finished her routine, Tara Lipinski sprinted across the ice, as if trying to catch the glorious moment and hold it forever. Then she saw her scores and her placement above Michelle Kwan and she knew that at 15, she had become the youngest woman ever to win an Olympic figure-skating title. And she let out a shriek as joyous and uninhibited as her skating.

title: Arrests Reveal Threat of Biological Weapons
description: As Federal agents continued to build a case yesterday against two men charged with possessing lethal bacteria, Army scientists proceeded with tests to identify particular strains of disease organisms that might be in confiscated gear.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTH, DEBORAH IRIS BUSSICHIO AND GILLIAN MACKENZIE
description: ROTH-Deborah Iris Bussichio and Gillian Mackenzie, on February 18, of South Salem, New York. Beloved wife and daughter of Arlen. Loving mother and sister of Alexis Leah. Cherished daughter and grandduaghter of Theresa and the late Salvatore Bussichio. Loving sister and niece of Dennis Bussichio. Loving daughter-in-law and granddaughter of Abraham and Sylvia Roth. Reposing at Clark Associates Funeral Home, Katonah, New York, Saturday, 4-7PM. Funeral services at Temple Shaaray Tefila of Westchester, Bedford Corners, NY, on Sunday morning. Interment, South Salem Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the local chapter of The Nature Conservancy.

title: Anguish in Biggest Arab-American Community
description: Overhearing a conversation about possible air strikes against Iraq, George P. Asker set down the six boxes of baklava he had just bought and expressed the anguish he felt as a naturalized immigrant from Iraq.

title: Of Striving Gingerly for A Big Sound
description: A good tune and a good story were all Mary Lou Lord needed when she sang in subways and on street corners. She was partial to girl-loses-boy songs, where resentment has turned to resignation but the longing hasn't disappeared: ''For him these feelings fade away, but for me they're still the same,'' she sings in ''His Lamest Flame.''

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about two men who were charged with possession of a toxin in Nevada referred incorrectly at one point to the source of bubonic plague, which one suspect had previously been accused of obtaining. The plague is caused by a bacterium, not a virus.

title: Foreign Affairs; The Old Ball Game
description: While waiting to see if the U.N. Secretary General's 11th-hour visit to Iraq can avert a war, I sought some diversion by catching up on the sports news. Talk about depressing. If you want to see how the other great superpower at work in the world today -- the unfettered markets -- is reshaping our lives and uprooting communities, turn to sports.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AVEDON, SAMSON
description: AVEDON-Samson. Age 89, formerly of New York City and now of Hollywood and Miami, FL. died February 16, 1998. He was the husband of the late Pauline Grossberg Avedon and cousin of Dru and Harvey Avedon of New York. Samson Avedon was the Comptroller of the Gillman Paper Co. of New York City until his retirement 30 years ago. Information, contact Panciera Memorial Home, 4200 Hollywood Boulvard, Hollywood, Florida 33021; 954-989-9900.

title: Versions of Truth, by the Book
description: To the Editor:

title: Tomba, Showing His Age and Feeling the Pain, Goes Out Like a Lamb
description: The table was set, and the Emperor and Empress of Japan were seated.

title: Williams Tries to Put Business Aside
description: Bernie Williams headed for the shower after his first workout of spring training today when he came face to face with the man responsible for paying his $8.25 million salary this season, the man with whom Williams must come to terms if he is going to remain with the Yankees in 1999 and beyond.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GENERAL MOTORS CORP., Detroit, said its Delphi Automotive Systems unit had agreed to sell two spring factories in Michigan to the Walton Johnson Group Inc., a minority-owned Texas company, for undisclosed terms.

title: To Add Students, Adelphi Courts 2-Year College's Graduates
description: To rebuild its enrollment by attracting transfer students, Adelphi University announced today that it would guarantee admission for most graduates of Nassau Community College, a nearby two-year school.

title: Jones Says in Suit She Felt Threatened by Clinton
description: Paula Corbin Jones contends in her sexual-misconduct suit against President Clinton that she felt threatened by him during a 1991 encounter in a hotel room when he made a crude sexual proposal.

title: Judge Orders U.S. to Pay $1.2 Billion to 2 Arms Contractors
description: A United States Federal claims court judge has ruled that the General Dynamics Corporation and the Boeing Company are entitled to $1.2 billion from the Government for the improper 1991 termination of the Navy A-12 stealth attack aircraft.

title: ICE HOCKEY; League Looks Into Damage At Village
description: The director of security for the National Hockey League, Dennis Cunningham, interviewed several American men's hockey players by telephone today in an investigation of damage to property at the Olympic village during the Winter Games.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLFF, JOHANNA R.
description: WOLFF-Johanna R., 93, of Fort Lauderdale, Florida, formerly of NYC, died on February 19, 1998. Devoted wife of the late Fred G. Wolff. Loving mother of Barbara Graham of Scottsdale, AZ, and cherished grandmother of Lynne Goldstein of Essexville, MI., and Ellen Congiundi of Houston, TX. She is survived by five wonderful, great grandchildren: Lauren, Joshua, Samuel, Allison and Lisa. All those who were fortunate to have known her will always remember and miss her.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRILL, ETTA
description: BRILL-Etta. Shalom-Fannie Zornberg Group of Hadassah mourns the passing of our esteemed lifemember and extends heartfelt sympathy to the family. Jaki Soreff, President

title: Despite City Vow, Children Are Still Housed in an Office
description: Seven months after child welfare officials vowed to use their ''best efforts'' to stop housing troubled children in offices overnight, dozens of adolescents are still sleeping in fold-up cots in New York City's emergency placement building every week, even after the creation of more than 200 new foster care beds.

title: Witness Can't Pick Out Man In L.I. Beating
description: A key witness to the near-fatal beating of a black man during a brawl outside a Long Island nightclub nearly two years ago failed today to identify the man accused of bludgeoning the victim with an iron rod.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SILVER TUMBLES. Silver futures fell yesterday for the third time this week. The March contract dropped 29.7 cents, or 4.4 percent, to $6.523 an ounce on the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange.

title: Gilkey Says He's Over His Subpar Season
description: As far as Bernard Gilkey is concerned, he has already stuck a fork in 1997. There is nothing he can do about it. It's done with. Good riddance.

title: Why Drug Makers Court Consumers; Ad's Side Effect
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEANIN, GRACE GORDON
description: DEANIN-Grace Gordon, 73. Of New York City, died on February 19, 1998 after a long illness. Dr. Deanin, Professor Emeritus at the University of New Mexico, School of Medicine, designated member of The Hall of Fame of Hunter College, author of many scientific papers, is survived by her husband Malcolm, her 2 daughters Nancy and Alice, and three grandchildren. Donations in Dr. Deanin name may be made to organizations of your choice. A Gathering celebrating her life and work will be announced soon.

title: Knicks See Why They Retained Houston
description: Damon Stoudamire is like a pint of Haagen-Dazs, small, rich and smooth. A treat and an indulgence. He was certainly tempting for the Knicks.

title: Purse Strings and Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: Insurance Deal in Houston
description: HCC Insurance Holdings Inc. said today that it had agreed to buy the Kachler Corporation, a privately held insurance agency, for $32.5 million in stock. HCC, based in Houston, is a specialty-insurance concern. Kachler, also based in Houston, specializes in life, accident and health insurance for large commercial customers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINGER, SYLVIA
description: SINGER-Sylvia. Beloved wife of the late Morris. Devoted mother of Myrna and Stephen, Larry and Barbara. Adored sister of Fay and Marilyn. Adored grandmother of Eleni, Tommy, David, Jonathan and Luke. Services Sunday, 12 noon, at Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, Queens Boulevard and 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: Sports of The Times; Just Win, or He'll Grab Your Shirt
description: ARTIE COX remembers the first time he met Ron Artest. The young man from Queensbridge was only 11 years old and was trying out for Cox's summer league basketball team in Long Island City. Even then, Artest possessed a passion to win, an unchanneled, unbridled intensity that frequently spilled over into confrontations with teammates, fans, opponents.

title: A Liberal On Top Court Is Resigning
description: Judge Vito J. Titone, one of the most liberal members of New York's highest court, said today that he would resign from the Court of Appeals. The decision gives Gov. George E. Pataki the opportunity to make his second appointment to the seven-member bench that he has sharply criticized as being overly lenient.

title: Ex-Treasurer Accused of Theft Of $750,000 From Drew U.
description: The former treasurer of Drew University in Madison, N.J., surrendered to the authorities yesterday to face charges of stealing more than $750,000 from university accounts over an eight-year period, officials said.

title: Building Mishap on Queensboro Bridge Delays Traffic for Hour
description: A rolling platform under the Queensboro Bridge took off on its own yesterday afternoon, leaving one ironworker clutching a catwalk and another clinging to an I-beam before firefighters arrived to rescue them.

title: Women's Health in Peru
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SHORR, DAVID
description: SHORR-David. We miss you. Wish you were here. Love. Your Family and Friends

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERRILL, BOB
description: MERRILL-Bob. I am deeply saddened by the loss of my colleague, collaborator and friendone of the last quality writers whose work was at home on both the Hit Parade and the musical stage as we once knew them. Successes or not, whether ''Carnival,'' ''Take Me Along,'' ''Sugar,'' or ''Breakfast at Tiffany's,'' the shows we created are experiences I cherish. I will always appreciate his contribution to ''Hello, Dolly!'' His talent, integrity and compassion defined his ability to write music and lyrics that made people want to believe that ''Love Makes the World Go Round.'' David Merrick

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Should we build 500 toilets? I don't know. But we do know that 152,500 tickets have been sold and there is no place for the people to park.''

title: In a Mysterious Germ Case, 2 Worlds Collide
description: One is a right-wing radical, a known associate of racist hate groups who made his living inspecting septic tanks, who was once convicted of illegally obtaining bubonic plague bacteria and later boasted about how easy it would be to kill hundreds of thousands of people by releasing it into the New York City subway, the authorities charge.

title: Now Will We Heed the Biological Threat?
description: The arrest Thursday in Las Vegas of two men suspected of being anthrax terrorists and the standoff with Iraq over its biological weapons program capture perfectly the twin dangers posed by bioweapons: that of a rogue state and that of a lone terrorist. The Government needs to be ready for both; at the moment, it is ready for neither.

title: CFM TECHNOLOGIES DISCLOSES MERGER TALKS WITH RIVALS
description: CFM Technologies Inc., which makes equipment used in semiconductor production, has held informal talks with the industry leaders, Applied Materials Inc. and the Lam Research Corporation, about a possible sale, CFM's chairman disclosed. ''We've had some discussions, but most of them are preliminary,'' the executive, Christopher F. McConnell, said. He said a merger or sale this year was unlikely, but added, ''We're open to just about everything.'' Shares of CFM, which operates in Europe, Asia and the United States, were unchanged yesterday at $17.50, down from more than $41 last February.

title: Editorial Notebook; A Massacre That Transformed Mexico
description: After three decades of official silence, Mexicans may soon learn crucial facts about a spasm of government violence that changed their history. The event was the army massacre of students on Oct. 2, 1968, barely a week before the opening of the Mexico City Olympic Games. The bloodshed that night brought a demand for democracy and accountability that grew over the years. Tens of thousands of protesting students were gathered in the Plaza Tlatelolco when troops opened fire. Most believe that many more died than the official toll of 32.

title: Keeping Copyright in Balance
description: Congress is considering a bill to extend by 20 years the term of copyright protection. Since 1976, when copyright was last extended, the term has stood at the lifetime of the author plus 50 years or, in the case of corporate authors, a total of 75 years. Supporters of this bill, mainly the film industry, music publishers and heirs who already enjoy copyright revenues, argue that extending copyright will improve the balance of trade, compensate for lengthening life spans and make American protections consonant with European practice. But no matter how the supporters of this bill frame their arguments, they have only one thing in mind: continuing to profit from copyright by changing the agreement under which it was obtained.

title: The Brawley Defamation Trial Turns to the Issue of Opinions
description: Much of today's testimony and bluster in the Tawana Brawley defamation trial swirled around the right to express personal, if unflattering, opinions.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stock Rally Resumes After One-Day Pullback

title: School Uniforms, the $80 Million Boondoggle
description: Last week, William C. Thompson Jr., the president of the New York City Board of Education, proposed ''a mandatory uniform policy'' for all public elementary schools in New York City. Later in the week, Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew and Mayor Rudolph Giuliani also jumped on the uniform bandwagon. But if enacted in New York, as proposed, by the fall of 1999, the program could be a financial disaster.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BERNSTEIN, WILLIAM
description: BERNSTEIN-William. In loving memory. Always in our hearts. Alan and Julia

title: U.S. Plan for Iraq Envisions 4 Days of 24-Hour Bombing
description: As Saddam Hussein defied United Nations inspectors late last month, President Clinton's top foreign policy advisers huddled in the basement White House Situation Room to wrestle with their military options.

title: FAIRFAX FINANCIAL PAYING $75 MILLION FOR SKANDIA UNITS
description: Fairfax Financial Holdings Ltd. of Canada said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Skandia International Insurance Corporation of Sweden and Skandia U.K. Insurance P.L.C. of Britain for $75 million. Fairfax Financial, based in Toronto, is a financial services holding company. It will add the Skandia companies to its Odyssey Re Group. The acquired businesses, which specialize in reinsurance, have combined total assets of $745 million. The sale will enable Swedish Skandia A.B., the Nordic region's largest insurer, to concentrate on its core nonlife insurance, savings and asset-management businesses.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the Manhattan murder trial of John J. Royster, who is accused of having killed one woman and assaulted three others in June 1996, referred incorrectly to a prosecution witness. While two witnesses were surviving victims, one was a relative of the third victim.

title: A Wall Street Whistle Blower Settles His Own Fraud Charge
description: A former Smith Barney official who has rocked Wall Street with allegations of widespread fraud in the municipal bond market agreed yesterday to settle civil charges that he had committed fraud himself when underwriting a municipal bond issue in 1994.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, MOLLIE
description: KATZ-Mollie, 84. On Feb. 19, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Louis Katz. Devoted mother of Joan and Harriet. Cherished grandmother of Alan, Lauren, Erica, Lisa and Roy. Loving great grandmother of Alexandra. Dear sister of Ada and Sidney. Services are on Sunday, February 22, 1 P.M., at Floral Park Cemetery, New Jersey.

title: Why Drug Makers Court Consumers; Vulnerable Stereotype
description: To the Editor:

title: Raymond Bushell, 87, Lawyer And Collector of Japanese Art
description: Raymond Bushell, a lawyer who was a collector of Japanese art and an authority on the miniature sculptures called netsuke, died on Jan. 17 at a nursing home in San Francisco. He was 87.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZABELL, IRVING
description: ZABELL-Irving. Of Concord, California, formerly of Great Neck, N.Y. He leaves a loving family of wife Naomi, daughters Geri, Patrice and Gina, and four grandchildren. This strong and gentle man will be deeply missed by his family and friends.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COGEN, CHARLES
description: COGEN-Charles. Died on February 18 in Washington, D.C. Husband of the late Tess Cogen, father of Joel and Edward, father-in-law of Beth Gilson, Sarah M. Cogen and Ruth Prager Cogen, grandfather of Jessica Cogen, Jeffrey Cogen, Deborah Cogen Swartz and Mark Cogen, and great-grandfather of ten. Services Sunday, February 22, at Riverside Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York City, at 12:30 PM. Contributions may be made to Cornell University (Development Office, Ithaca, NY 14850), Jewish Labor Committee, Educators' Chapter (25 E. 21st St., NYC 10010) or Parkinson's Disease Foundation (710 W. 168th St., NYC 10032).

title: Journal; Dying In Columbus
description: Like a matinee idol who's lost his looks, a Presidency that lives by show business can die by show business. That's what happened this week in Columbus, where an Administration that knows nothing if not how to put on a good TV show died big time, just when it could least afford to, before an international audience of millions.

title: Arabs See Double Standard In U.S. Backing for Israel
description: When President Clinton spoke this week of sharply reducing Iraq's ''capacity to threaten its neighbors,'' he referred to Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and the other Persian Gulf nations, but above all to the American commitment to the security of Israel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNBAUM, DOROTHY
description: BERNBAUM-Dorothy. Beloved wife of the late Ralph Bernbaum, a former associate and friend. Our sincerest sympathy goes out to her family. Kalmon Dolgin Affiliates, Inc.

title: Short Field Must Catch Lil's Lad
description: Only four horses will be on the track in the Fountain of Youth Stakes at Gulfstream Park on Saturday afternoon, and three of them are expected to be chasing Lil's Lad, the 6-5 favorite. But who can catch him and supply some early clues to the talent on the road to the Kentucky Derby?

title: Babbitt Attended Political Session Days Before the Initial Decision on a Casino
description: Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt attended a political meeting at the White House just two days before Interior Department staff members reached a preliminary decision to reject an Indian casino application in May 1995, according to a copy of Mr. Babbitt's schedule that was not previously disclosed.

title: Short-Term Credit Rating Lowered for Hong Kong
description: Hong Kong's short-term credit rating was cut yesterday for the first time in 14 years as Moody's Investors Service Inc. warned that the territory's financial markets faced more risk from Asia's economic turmoil. Moody's cut the rating to Prime-2, the first reduction since it assigned a Prime-1 rating to Hong Kong in 1984. The ratings company, based in New York, also cut its long-term Hong Kong outlook to ''negative'' from ''stable.''

title: Women's Health in Peru
description: To the Editor:

title: Versions of Truth, by the Book; Power and Bias
description: To the Editor:

title: Op-Art; Six Degrees of Monica
Corrections
description: A list of credits on Wednesday with a film review of ''Moon Over Broadway'' omitted the production company. The movie was released by Artistic License Film.

title: Why Drug Makers Court Consumers
description: To the Editor:

title: Morgan Merger Creates Windfall, at Least for Boss
description: The merger of Morgan Stanley and Dean Witter, Discover & Company , announced a little more than a year ago, has already worked out well for the combined company's top executive.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: HICKS, MUSE DROPS DEAL TO BUY UNITED ARTISTS
description: Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Inc., the Texas buyout firm, scuttled an agreement late yesterday to buy United Artists Theater Group for $850 million in cash and stock from an investment group led by Merrill Lynch & Company. Hicks, Muse said the decision would not affect its agreement with Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company to buy Regal Cinemas Inc., which it plans to combine with its other cinema properties, for $1.5 billion. The firm did not say why it had ended the transaction. Officials of Hicks, Muse, United Artists and Kohlberg Kravis did not return telephone calls seeking comment. But the CNBC cable television channel, citing unidentified people close to the situation, said problems with the price of the deal arose as a result of United Artists' financial performance in 1997 and projections for 1998.

title: Czechs and Russians Renew The Rivalry of Another Era
description: Several times during this extraordinary performance, Pavel Bure, the captain of the Russian hockey team, raced down the ice with the puck on his stick, leading a speeding stream of nine other skaters to the Finnish goal line. It looked like a game of ''crack the whip'' that children play on skating rinks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOHANSKY, FRANCES (SCOLNIK) NEE GLADSTONE
description: KOHANSKY-Frances (Scolnik) nee Gladstone. Aged ninety-eight, on February 19, 1998. Devoted wife of the late Jack Scolnik and George Kohansky. Loving mother of Marilyn Swerdlin (Jules) and Herb Scolnik (Hermine). Adored grandmother of June (Ira), Scott (Andrea), Meryl (Gary). Sister of Milton Gladstone. Great grandmother of four.

title: Tuned to Sound Out of Tune
description: Kyle Gann's reputation as a composer is beginning to equal his renown as a writer on new music. A couple of recent recordings have included pieces by him, and on Thursday he was at Merkin Concert Hall to perform, as keyboardist and vocalist, several of his compositions.

title: 2 Rabbis Who Play Divinely
description: If it were possible to arrange a match between representative groups of rabbis, priests and ministers it is likely the rabbis would prevail. Their team would certainly include Leonard Helman of Santa Fe, N.M., a Reform rabbi who regularly wins magazine bidding contests, and Richard Margolis of Melbourne, Fla., a Conservative rabbi. Both developed bridge skills in seminary. As partners, they reached the final of the 1997 Life Master Pair Championship in Albuquerque, N.M., a very strong event, and scored a complete top on the diagramed deal.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: CANADIAN DOLLAR CLIMBS. The Canadian dollar rallied this week, recovering from last month's record lows, bolstered by strong economic data. The currency ended at 70.44 United States cents, up 1.7 percent for the week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARA, GERALD B., M.D.
description: KARA-Gerald B., M.D. With great sorrow, The New York Eye and Ear Infirmary Board of Directors, Medical Staff and Administration mourn the passing of an esteemed ophthalmologist, renowned intraocular surgeon and guiding force within the hospital. After completing residency here in 1949, Dr. Kara joined the Infirmary's medical staff, where he became a surgeon director in ophthalmology, chairman of the Medical Board and, since 1971, a trustee of the Infirmary. Dr. Kara served as director of the internationally known Post Graduate Institute of The New York Eye and Ear Infirmary for more than thirty years. Our sincerest condolences to his wife, Gisela. Peter Frelinghuysen, Chairman, Board of Directors Robert C. Della Rocca, M.D. Chairman, Medical Board Joseph P. Corcoran President and CEO

title: Writer's Troubling Look at Face of Troubled Youth
description: The night she calls ''the children's riot,'' was a turning point for Cristina Rathbone. She was living in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, when she found herself in a liquor store among dusty, overpriced bottles, watching a retarded man flee a beating by a group of prepubescent boys. The man used the store as a sanctuary, and the door was locked against the boys throwing bricks and bottles.

title: H. Gardner Ackley, 82, Dies; Presidential Economic Adviser
description: H. Gardner Ackley, an economics adviser to Presidents John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson, and a United States Ambassador to Italy, died in Ann Arbor, Mich., on Feb. 12. Professor Ackley, who retired in 1984 after 43 years as a member of the economics department at the University of Michigan, was 82.

title: American Player Prefers To Keep Feet on Ground
description: As Ernie Stewart weighed the prospect of flying for 10 hours this week, his desire to play in Saturday's friendly match against the Netherlands -- and ultimately for the United States national soccer team in another World Cup tournament -- prevailed over his considerable fear of boarding an airplane.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, HON. LEWIS R.
description: FRIEDMAN-Hon. Lewis R. Devoted husband of Bernice, beloved father of Karen, cherished son of Dr. Sylvia N. and the late Harold, loving brother of Dr. Diane. Services 11AM Sunday, Park Avenue Synagogue, East 87th Street and Madison Ave. Contributions may be made to the Forman Friedman Fund, Foundation for the Jewish Community, 150 East 58th Street, 26th floor, N.Y.C. 10155.

title: Mangurian Named Cornell Coach
description: Pete Mangurian was named head football coach at Cornell University after spending the last 10 seasons as an assistant in the National Football League under Dan Reeves.

title: Revenue From New York's Park Concessions Jumps 20%
description: The grass isn't the only thing that's green in the city's 1,600 parks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINBERGER, ARON
description: WEINBERGER-Aron. Born on February 5, 1904 in Auschwitz, Poland, earned Doctor of Laws from University of Krakow, Poland. As a young lawyer he dedicated his life to political and Zionist causes. During W.W. II, he spent several years with his family in concentration camps where he was elected camp leader. Fluent in ten languages, he was appointed interpreter and liaison officer by allies after liberation. In New York, he joined Jewish National Fund where he worked 23 years as Foundation Director to support State of Israel. He spent most of his life giving to numerous philanthropic organizations. The Officers and Directors of the Jewish National Fund extend their heart felt condolences. Beloved husband to Bertha, loving father of Susan, cherished grandfather of David, Michele and Yael, who will miss his brilliance, warmth, wit and dignity. Ronald Lauder, President Russell Robinson, Exec VP

title: Another World Mark Set as German Defends 5,000 Title
description: The first day of Olympic speed skating ended with a world record. So did the last. In between, there were plenty of other shock waves in the M-Wave, and what made it all the better was that there was not a single delay, cancellation or weather report to fret over.

title: Women's Health in Peru
description: To the Editor:

title: Benjamin Aranda 3d, 58, Judge Who Opened Jobs to Minorities
description: Benjamin Aranda 3d, a judge of the Los Angeles Municipal Court and a founder of organizations that worked toward increasing employment opportunities for minorities in the judicial system, died on Jan. 28. He was 58 and lived in Torrance, Calif.

title: British Brewer Will Buy Big Hotel Chain
description: Bass P.L.C., the British brewer that has been seeking to expand its ownership of higher-priced hotels, took a giant step toward that goal late yesterday as it agreed to buy the 187 Inter-Continental hotels from the Saison Group of Tokyo for $1.4 billion.

title: THE XVIII WINTER GAMES; Four-Man Bobsled Is Cut Short
description: What started as a light drizzle at the four-man bobsled competition yesterday ended up making a little bit of Olympic history. Brian Shimer, one of the American drivers, was in position to make some, too.

title: Founding Fathers Have the Last Word
description: John Catanzariti riffled the manila folders, thousands of them, packed tight into a row of dull metal shelves in a basement room at Princeton University's Firestone Library.

title: Bank Janitor Sentenced In Cash Machine Theft
description: While cleaning up a Jersey City bank last August, a janitor cleaned out one of the bank's automated teller machines, Federal prosecutors have said.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-5

title: For Gutted Marlins, The Thrill Is Gone
description: The Florida Marlins the World Series champion Florida Marlins -- had what was billed as their first full-squad workout today. The Marlins used the term full squad loosely.

title: About New York; Plea for Mercy From a Parish For a Prisoner
description: GROWING up in El Barrio in the 1950's, Gloria Quinones used to get a kick out of watching television. Not everybody's family could afford one. And not everyone could boast of seeing a friend on one, as she did when she watched ''Star Time Kids,'' where her pal Dee danced.

title: Sports of The Times; A Great Olympic Image Left for the Imagination
description: BELEAGUERED by the demise and unruly departure of its obnoxious Americans, hockey nonetheless had a rare and wonderful opportunity to manufacture a great and lasting Olympic moment here yesterday afternoon but unfortunately left the great part sitting on the bench.

title: GULF CANADA RESOURCES PLANS ASSET SALES TO CUT DEBT
description: Gulf Canada Resources Ltd. plans to sell its oilfields in the North Sea and other assets and spin off part of its natural gas pipelines and processing businesses in western Canada to raise the equivalent of about $600 million to lower its debt. Gulf Canada will sell its interests in four British North Sea oilfields that it does not operate, a coal field and some exploration lands in Nevada and some nonproducing assets in Canada. It will sell 49 percent of its network of pipelines and gas-processing plants in central Alberta to a newly formed income trust that will be a publicly traded entity. While Gulf Canada is based in Calgary, Alberta, its executive offices are in Denver.

title: The Little Project That Couldn't; Others Learn From a Failed Test in Worker Democracy
description: These days, the Harman Automotive Inc. rear-view-mirror factory here may seem like just another industrial casualty as it limps toward a final shutdown at the end of the month.

title: British and Irish Governments Suspend Sinn Fein From Northern Ireland Talks
description: The Irish and British Governments today expelled Sinn Fein, the I.R.A.'s political wing, from the Northern Ireland peace talks at least until March 9.

title: White House Acts to Shield Testimony
description: The Clinton Administration drew into a protective posture today as Government lawyers deliberated on multiple fronts over how to shield witnesses from testifying fully before a grand jury investigating the President's relationship with a White House intern.

title: Why Drug Makers Court Consumers; Glossy View of H.I.V.
description: To the Editor:

title: Wait Grates on Tony Phillips
description: Tony Phillips is waiting to hear from the Mets. ''Not even patiently,'' he said today from his home in Scottsdale, Ariz. ''I'd like to know one way or another whether I'm going to play this year.''

title: Silence Tempered by Kindness and Control
description: The pianoless trio for saxophonists can become the great enveloping swamp from which musicians don't return. The open context makes them overplay, or loosen control, or run out of ideas. Along comes Sherman Irby, an alto-saxophonist who is known for mastering bands by playing quietly, and at the Jazz Standard (116 East 27th Street, Manhattan), he has taken on the challenge by leading a group made up of only saxophone, bass and drums.

title: Abandoning Tonality, Unfettered By Angst
description: This second season in the New York Philharmonic's three-year survey called ''American Classics'' is focusing on important mid-20th century works for voice and orchestra. Thursday night's concert featured Lukas Foss's ''Time Cycle'' with the soprano Dawn Upshaw as soloist, a deserving choice, since this 1960 work, considered a breakthrough at the time, is more known about than known.

title: Giuliani Crows as Theft Suspect Is Caught on Jaywalking Charge
description: Ever since he had barricades erected in midtown Manhattan in December and pledged to enforce jaywalking laws in the nation's most pedestrian-oriented city, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has endured a public relations black eye. New Yorkers cocked their heads skeptically over his claims that the measures would improve safety.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   HAMLIN, KATE
description: HAMLIN-Kate. For Kate, who will always be with us. Love, Gabe, Hara, Jere, and Dan

title: Seikaly Looks On as Nets Struggle
description: Rony Seikaly arrived from Florida tonight, limping into Continental Arena shortly before halftime of the Nets-Cavaliers game. Before introducing himself to his new teammates, Seikaly retreated under the stands to meet with reporters. And while he gushed over the prospects of his new team, the Nets were just a short distance away playing like anything but the contenders he was describing.

title: A Seminar on Group Homes Helped Lessen Resistance
description: To the Editor:

title: Shimer Two Hundredths Too Slow for His Coveted Medal
description: The day began with tremors from a late-morning earthquake, 5.0 on the Richter scale. For Brian Shimer, though, this was just another seismic disturbance at the Olympics. He has experienced just about everything in his bobsledding career, from a disqualification for improper equipment to a recent doping charge that was later discounted.

title: Glory of Brooklyn, in a Kings Point House
description: DR. EDWARD ELKOWITZ of Kings Point has recreated downtown Brooklyn in his basement. It's a big basement. ''I have the Navy Yard and thousands of little people,'' Dr. Elkowitz said. In addition to Brooklyn, his basement also holds Gettysburg and two other cities. ''I built all the houses and buildings,'' he said. ''I bought the people.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REINISCH, MARJORIE BRONNE
description: REINISCH-Marjorie Bronne. At the age of 82. On February 20, in her sleep at home. She was a devoted wife and wonderful mother who will be greatly missed by all her friends. She leaves a loving daughter, Carol Reinisch, and sonin-law, Robert Suitor. She was the light of many lives. Burial services will be private in Glens Falls, NY. In lieu of flowers donations may be sent to the Audobon Society or the Girl Scouts of America.

title: TELEVISION; Shaking an Old (and Unearned) Image
description: TOM SELLECK still remembers fielding a question several years ago about whether he believed he could graduate from television to film, having eight years and an Emmy behind him as the star of the 80's television drama ''Magnum, P.I.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COX, GRACE D.
description: COX-Grace D. On February 20, 1998. Wife of Arnold J. Calie. Sister of Monsignor Matthew J. Cox, deceased. Beloved aunt of Edward and Richard Cox. Past President of National Women's Lawyer's Association, State Department representative. Friend and benefactor to many. Graduate of St. Mary's College, Ohio, Hunter College and NYU Law School. Visitation Sunday evening, 7-9 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave, at 81st Street.

title: League's Top Rookies Count to Three, and Then Leave for Greener Pastures
description: It was an idea that seemed well-founded. Instead of paying enormous salaries to unproven players like Shawn Bradley and Glenn Robinson, install a rookie salary scale that would not reward the league's young players until they had three years under their belt.

title: A Search for Truth, or a Partisan Inquisition?; An Agent's Duty

title: National News Briefs; California Doctors Group Votes to Consider Union
description: The California Medical Association agreed this week to consider creating a union subsidiary that would bargain collectively for state government-employed doctors and residents in training, the first professional group in the nation to step into the gulf that has traditionally separated organized medicine from physicians' unions.

title: Brina Vitenson, T. S. Maldonado
description: Dr. Brina Annette Vitenson, a resident in obstetrics and gynecology at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, N.Y., was married last evening to Dr. Thomas Sabatini Maldonado, a surgical resident at New York University Medical Center in Manhattan. Justice Howard Miller of State Supreme Court in New City, N.Y., officiated at the Puck Building in Manhattan.

title: New Heathrow Service From Central London
description: Heathrow Express, a new 100-m.p.h. rail link between Paddington Station in London and Heathrow airport, is scheduled to start in June. With 398 seats, it is to reduce the travel time between central London and the airport -- which can take as long as an hour by car -- to 15 minutes. By 1999, a full luggage check will be available at Paddington. Tickets will be about $17.70.

title: The Re-education of Philip Reed
description: ONE day last month, determined to buy locally in his new neighborhood, Philip Reed, a fresh member of the City Council, walked across East 116th Street from his office and ordered a sandwich at the back of a narrow little deli. The man behind the counter said he could make no sandwiches because there had been no bread delivery that day.

title: A Sendup of Hollywood With a Moral, Yet
description: SERIOUS WORKS about Hollywood's place in the American landscape are not so commonplace that one can easily pass up Jon Robin Baitz's very entertaining, slightly off-center exploration of breathtaking sleaze, ''Mizlansky/Zilinsky or Schmucks,'' the new comedy now at the Manhattan Theater Club.

title: Iverson and 76ers Hand Nets Third Loss in Row
description: Not long ago, the Nets were soaring. Suddenly, they are slumping.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Andy Warhol, Poetry, and Gossip in the 1960s By Reva Wolf. University of Chicago, cloth, $70; paper, $27.95.

title: In the Region/Connecticut; Pfizer Reaches Across the Thames for More Space
description: PFIZER'S CENTRAL RESEARCH operation in Groton will soon straddle the Thames River with a new $150 million project that will give it 400,000 square feet of research and laboratory space on the waterfront in New London.

title: U.S. Is Advising Its Citizens to Leave Iraq as Soon as Possible
description: The United States advised American citizens today to leave Iraq as soon as possible, while President Clinton met with his top foreign policy aides to discuss their options, both diplomatic and military, once the United Nations Secretary General completes his trip to Baghdad.

description: Special Today: Fashions of The Times

title: Ellen Kreger, Robert Pfeifer
description: Ellen Marie Kreger and Robert Carl Pfeifer were married yesterday in Bronxville, N.Y. The Rev. Walter Tennyson performed the ceremony at the Reformed Church of Bronxville.

title: Mental Patient Returned to Center
description: Seven weeks after he disappeared from a supervised residence, Larry Hogue, a mental patient who harassed residents of the Upper West Side in the late 1980's and early 1990's and became a symbol of the state's inability to treat mentally ill drug addicts, was admitted to Creedmoor Psychiatric Center in Queens early yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN DER MEULEN, ALICE J.
description: VAN DER MEULEN-Alice J. Died January 22, 1998. Wife of Howard Van der Meulen, step-mother of Peter Van der Meulen and Pamela Van der Meulen. Memorial service Monday, March 2, 7 PM, at the All Souls Unitarian Church, 1157 Lexington Ave (80th St).

title: Rubble Trouble For Second Year In 10th Precinct
description: ''It's like 'Barney Miller,' huh?'' Bobby Vilches, a police officer, asks as he walks through Chelsea's 10th Precinct station house. In fact, it's more like ''Barney Miller'' under construction.

title: Commercial Property/Insurance Companies; A New Awakening in Real Estate Investment
description: INSURANCE companies used to be conservative players in the commercial real estate investment game. But many have become more aggressive and are changing their way of doing business.

title: Needing Direction? Try Catalogues.
description: MY fortune is made. If smokers can blame their health problems on cigarettes and sue tobacco companies for vast sums of money, I can certainly win my case against the catalogue companies. Catalogues are a multiple health hazard. As evidence, I offer a heap of chiropractic bills from carrying loads of the wretched things from the post office every day, and witnesses to testify to the mental anguish, lack of self-esteem and marital conflicts brought on by the contents of these wretched catalogues.

title: Two Major Races Converge at Oft-Tricky Cape
description: If it were not considered one of the most desolate pinnacles of land on the planet, Cape Horn might have been a good place to set up a lawn chair last week.

title: Museum Fees
description: To the Editor: The Practical Traveler article on museum admissions is, as usual, interesting and helpful. In the listing of free museums in London, however, the Wallace Collection should not have been omitted. Besides being free, it is open seven days a week. This museum is full of magnificent works of art.

description: WHEN Rubin Azar decided to get rid of his 1979 Toyota Celica Supra, he didn't want to go through listing it in a newspaper, waiting for people to come look at it and haggling over price. So, Mr. Azar, who lives in North Babylon, N.Y., donated it to the Big Brothers and Big Sisters of Long Island.

title: As Crisis Nears, Affordable Units Of Housing Lag
description: IN Westchester, one of the wealthiest counties in the United States, more than 12 percent of the households -- 38,400 -- live in deficient and overcrowded housing. Still, six years after the Board of Legislators called for 5,000 units of affordable housing by the turn of the century, little is being accomplished toward that goal, a study by an independent advisory group has found.

Swan of South Orange, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. John Thomas Barbagiovanni 2d, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Barbagiovanni of Medford, N.J. The Rev. Ronald W. Johnson performed the ceremony at the Wyoming Presbyterian Church in Millburn, N.J.

description: Tara Lipinski and Michelle Kwan's figure skating duel on Friday night fueled a 22.6 prime-time Nielsen rating for CBS, the network's best prime-time performance of the Winter Olympics. Still, the rating was 47 percent lower than the comparable day in the 1994 Winter Olympics, and 10 percent lower than in 1992.

title: Homeowners Should File Soon to Obtain a School-Tax Break
description: TENS of thousands of Westchester homeowners could lose hundreds of dollars or more in property tax breaks if they fail to file a form -- in some cases by May 1 -- asking for a school-tax break with their community's assessor's office.

title: Editorial Observer; The Lost Art of Constructing Personality Cults
description: As Communist regimes toppled in Eastern Europe, so did their icons. The statues of former leaders were knocked over, the streets dubbed for them renamed, the museums honoring the contribution to peace and brotherhood of various secret police chiefs shuttered. Now in a capitalist twist, Romania is not only dismantling its cult of personality. It is selling the offerings and graven images.

title: Smithtown Warned Of Contaminated Water

Zubin Mehta will conduct the orchestra and chorus of the Maggio Musicale Fiorentino in the production by the Teatro Comunale of Florence.

description: BRILL-Etta. On February 19, 1998 after a brief struggle against old age. Life member of Hadassah and a multiple Ima. Beloved wife of the late Hyman, loving mother of Charles and the late Leon, Morris, Betty and Jack, dear sister of Hana, cherished grandmother of Hal, Marlene, Hillary, Peter, Ron, Sandy, Sheldon and Artie, greatgrandmother, great-great-grandmother, aunt and friend to all who loved her. Services on Sunday 12:15PM, at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

(for Champion) Fairewood Frolic, the most successful Norwich Terrier in the history of this bred-in-a-barn-to-roust-barn-rats breed.
