title: Muckler Begins Job Of Saving The Season
description: John Muckler had not worn skates in two years. But he laced them on today and went bravely on the ice to conduct his first practice as the new Rangers coach.

title: A Search for Truth, or a Partisan Inquisition?; No Longer Relevant
description: To the Editor:

title: C.I.A. Bares Its Bungling in Report on Bay of Pigs Invasion
description: One of the most secret documents of the cold war is out: the Central Intelligence Agency's brutally honest inquest into the 1961 Bay of Pigs fiasco, which laid the blame for the disastrous invasion of Cuba squarely on the agency's own institutional arrogance, ignorance and incompetence.

title: Hong Kong,Feeling Flu-ish
description: In Hong Kong, Feeling Flu-ish'' (Feb. 1), Ian Buruma trots out the canard that recent elections prove Hong Kongers overwhelmingly favor democracy. In the 1991 election -- the first in which the franchise was opened to the rank and file -- only 1 in 5 people voted. Not surprisingly, pro-democracy candidates won; but the real numbers were to be found in those who stayed away. Given a chance to let the world know whether they wanted democracy or stable relations with China, the vast majority -- about 80 percent -- chose stability.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 14 about St. Petersburg as Dostoyevsky knew it misstated his age at death as well the surname of a friend whose death deeply affected him. A reader's E-mail message received Jan. 27 points out that Dostoyevsky was 59, not 58, and that the friend was Apollon Grigorev, not Gorogyev. The message also points out that a canal name was misstated. It is Griboyedov, not Griboyedova.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUTZKY, HARRY
description: LUTZKY-Harry. Of Atlanta, GA, died February 21. Survivors: wife Ruth Lutzky; daughters Paula and David Coplon, Barbara and Stuart Packer, and Linda and Edwin Lopez; son Ira and Paula Lutzky; sisters Shirley and Jeffrey Berger, and Helen and Jack Kruger; and 12 grandchildren. Donations to Hadassah. Gutterman's Funeral Directors, 516-764-9400.

title: An Rx for What Ails the Jazz Concert Hall
description: IF JAZZ at Lincoln Center does in fact receive a new space at the New York Coliseum at Columbus Circle, as was proposed two weeks ago, the architects and sound designers will have an easy set of prescriptions to follow: Make the space sound like the Village Vanguard. Make it feel like the Apollo Theater. And make it look like the Palacio de la Salsa in Havana, a dance hall with an area by the stage that can be cleared of seats. If all this comes to pass, the jazz-concert experience in New York will be radically different from what it has been.

title: Botswana's Teeming Riverfront
description: EVEN before we reached our lodge at the Chobe National Park in Botswana, we knew we had been wise to include the riverfront in our African wildlife excursion. As our driver turned down a dirt road along the Chobe River, which separates Botswana from Namibia in these parts, we were suddenly confronted with a flood plain alive with animals. On the Namibian side of the river, herds of elephants and buffalo moved toward the water to slake their thirst in the late afternoon sun. On our side, Botswanan territory, a herd of elephants, with babies in tow, cavorted in the water and mud, alongside puku antelopes and baboons, while hippos snorted in the shallows and crocodiles sunned themselves on the bank. It was an impressively rich tableau, even for travelers like us who had already spent three days in the bush pursuing wildlife. For those visiting a game park for the first time, it makes a postcard-perfect introduction to southern Africa's wildlife.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: Free Choices

title: The View From/Rye; Artists Take Their Cue From Nature
description: HIS feet are strapped to a wheelchair. His hands are strapped to the same wheelchair. He needs electronic assistance to breathe. This 44-year-old, Douglas Cassara, paralyzed from the neck down in a car accident 13 years ago, still takes great pleasure in art -- not only viewing it, but making it.

title: Sports of The Times; Japan Gives Athletes A Lesson in Respect
description: THEY were three United States athletes who will not be on a Wheaties box or Campbell's soup can. Mike Peplinski, a curler. Moira D'Andrea, a speed skater. Erin Warren, a luger. At Tohbu Junior High School, no one cared if they had won a medal or how they had rated on CBS. They were important Olympians, as much as Tara Lipinski and Picabo Street.

title: 4 Arrested After Delivery In the Bronx of Marijuana
description: Four men who accepted delivery of 700 pounds of marijuana from Mexico were arrested in the Bronx on Friday night, the police said.

title: The C.I.A. on the C.I.A.: Scathing View of Invasion
description: Following are excerpts from ''The Inspector General's Survey of the Cuban Operation,'' a highly critical internal inquiry into the Central Intelligence Agency's Bay of Pigs invasion in 1961. The 150-page report, written in numbered sections, was one of the most secret documents of the cold war. It was released under the Freedom of Information Act to the National Security Archive, a nonprofit group that collects and publishes declassified Government reports.

title: Attention Disorder: Providing Help
description: As a provider of services for attention deficit disordered children and teen-agers for more than 15 years, I was pleased to see an article focusing on the services available to parents of and children with ADD/ ADHD [''New Focus on Attention Deficit Disorder,'' Jan. 18]. I was, however, dismayed that the article did not provide a complete overview of the services offered on the Island.

title: Our Towns; A Lonely Life If You Love A Pit Bull
description: IT'S important for Maddie Delgado to reach the park with Pooch well before dawn.

title: Food; Bread Winners
description: In malaysia, you could be watching a gourmet cooking show on cable television one minute and running for your life the next. Monsoons, you understand, are still a force to be reckoned with, even as the country keeps pace with Western technology. This fact of life explains why Malaysian cooking has, at its heart, quick and elemental dishes that can be made at leisure or in the middle of disaster.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONNER, ALECIA M.
description: CONNER-Alecia M. The family of Alecia Conner mourn the passing of their beloved mother on February 18. She is survived by her children Story Vogel and his life companion Judith Kelly of Coronado, CA; Kent Vogel of NYC; and Martha Vogel of Virginia. Although she will be missed tremendously, her smile, enormous joy of life, and care for others shall live on. A memorial mass will be held Friday, February 27 at St. Thomas More, 65 E. 89th St., NYC at 11 AM.

title: Museum Fees
description: To the Editor: I read with interest Betsy Wade's Practical Traveler column (Dec. 28) ''Best Things Are Free? Rarely.'' I agree that it's unfortunate that it has become so costly to visit New York's great museums.

title: Celebrating a Century of Calder
description: More than 250 works by Alexander Calder will go on view at the National Gallery of Art in Washington on March 29 in a retrospective marking the 100th anniversary of his birth.

title: Crime
description: Some people are perpetually at war with themselves. A cop identified only as Hanson in Kent Anderson's jolting crime novel, NIGHT DOGS (Bantam, $22.95), is one of those people. Working his beat in the tough north precinct of Portland, Ore., during the spring of 1975, this Vietnam veteran treats the lowlifes with rough compassion. But he keeps flirting with the savagery he feels inside him, drinking until he's numb and replaying his old nightmares as a Green Beret.

title: Seacoasts Galore At Boston Aquarium
description: Being in Boston, the New England Aquarium is on the coast. But in the first exhibition in its new west wing, ''Coastal Rhythms: Creatures on the Edge,'' it allows visitors to experience coasts far from New England.

title: Campaign Finance Set to Fire Up the Senate Once Again
description: After a yearlong, $3.5 million investigation into the fund-raising abuses of the last Presidential race, the Senate on Monday will take up the debate once again, with advocates of overhauling the campaign finance system still struggling for votes.

title: Gadgets That Would Make Q Proud
description: THE end of the cold war did not take all the espionage out of politics -- just ask Linda Tripp and Monica Lewinsky. But the collapse of the Eastern bloc, along with the resulting declassification of files from the K.G.B. and the Stasi, East Germany's dread secret police, has certainly provided historians with enough material for a fresh look at what may go down as the golden age of spying. And the gadgetry of this era -- from miniature cameras to a method of capturing someone's scent that has nothing to do with Michael Jordan cologne -- is the subject of ''Spytek,'' a special on the Discovery Channel tomorrow from 8 to 11 P.M., with a repeat at midnight.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SHIELDS, FRANCES L.
description: SHIELDS-Frances L. We think of you daily with all our love. We miss you very much. Henry and Eileen

title: On Language; Washing Our Dishes
description: ''She was a straight shooter -- and she had great dish,'' the book agent Lucianne Goldberg told Time magazine about her friend Linda Tripp, who accepted Ms Goldberg's advice to tape-record conversations with Monica S. Lewinsky. To The New Yorker's Jane Mayer, the literary agent explained: ''I did it because it's . . .fascinating! I love dish! I live for dish!''

title: Two Pianists, Sharing Much, Yet So Different
description: ONE picture, as the saying goes, is worth a thousand words. But when it comes to music, neither pictures nor words drive the story because 1,000 of either cannot convey a single note. Photos, telling though they may be about skin color, image and attendant assumption of privilege, have no worth at all in defining the art of powerfully distinctive pianists.

title: A Big Red Menu
description: NO one really has room for dessert after dinner at the Big Red Tomato, which is unfortunate. Carmela Giambona, who owns the restaurant with her brother, Vincent, offers a different selection each night, and it is rarely less than terrific.

title: A Slight Hint of Progress, Maybe, on Needed Housing
description: For years, fear, mistrust and political battles have stood in the way of solutions to Williamsburg's housing crunch. Earlier this month, some progress was made, but the solution could still be some time away.

title: The Neediest Cases; With No Family to Help, Teen-Ager Sets His Sights on College
description: Bruce Levine may have only been 8, but he knew there was something odd about his mother's new boyfriend. The man, Gary Fernandez, did not seem to have a regular job, yet he handed over a briefcase of cash when he paid for the family's new house in Jacksonville, N.C. He kept a pistol tucked in his waist and frequently returned home with trunkloads of VCR's, televisions and fur coats.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.
description: Feeding the Life Force With Food That's Alive

title: The Purse Strings
description: This spring's evening pouch is right out of a Jane Austen novel.

title: In Scarsdale, Specialities From Canton
description: AFTER a promising debut almost four years ago, Jade Palace's kitchen was plagued with unevenness. But the kitchen again appears to be in competent hands and at this moment is one of the best places in the county for regional Chinese cuisine. Unlike the few other top-notch Chinese restaurants, Jade Palace specializes in the dishes of Canton, often thought to be the best in China. They are light and depend on the pure flavors of fresh ingredients, including a myriad of fresh vegetables and seafood. In fact, restaurants in Chinatown in Manhattan cannot come close to producing Jade Palace's best.

title: Gone, Perhaps, but No Less Chatty
description: IN his suite at the Parker-Meridien Hotel, James Van Praagh was savoring the last laugh. ''When we were pitching the book I told the people at Bantam it would be the No. 1 best seller,'' he recalled, ''and they said, 'Every author likes to believe that.' He grinned. ''Well, now they believe me.''

title: Madness in a Tropical Manner
description: THE POSTHUMOUS MEMOIRS OF BRAS CUBAS By Joaquim Maria Machado de Assis. Translated by Gregory Rabassa. 219 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $25.

title: Two Are Arrested For Threats at Fire
description: Three firemen were taunted and menaced by two onlookers after putting out a suspicious fire in the hallway of a Brooklyn housing project on Friday night, the police said yesterday.

title: SMELL THE CODE
description: Later this year, Bell Atlantic will unleash 646, the area code supplementing the beloved 212 in New York. Capitalizing on the perceived ''glamour'' of the old digits, the fashion designer Carolina Herrera and her daughter, known as Carolina Jr., have responded with 212 Carolina Herrera, a gardeniaesque scent that purports to capture Mom's Upper East Side ritz and Daughter's West Village hip. Since 212's initial rollout in the fall, sales have been strong nationally and in Latin America, and the perfume will soon hit Europe. So these numbers really have universal appeal? ''This area code is not only understood everywhere,'' says Fernando Aleu, whose company, Compar, sells 212, ''it is accepted with relish.''

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN
description: Mrs. Dalloway

title: Is There Fault in the Stars In Morningstar's Ratings?
description: A new study from the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania pans the ''star'' rating system used by Morningstar Inc., the fund research firm in Chicago. But Don Phillips, the president of Morningstar, uses terms like ''silly'' and ''nitpicking'' in describing its results.

title: Exercising Options
description: What do you call a designer exercise sandal? Gym dandy.

title: Art in Progress: The Quirky Appeal of Pollarding
description: YOU either like the look of a pollarded tree, or you don't. A tree with its top branches cut back near the trunk surely does not have a natural look. In winter, it is a clubbed head capping a clear trunk, or clubbed heads each capping a few short, thick side branches atop a clear trunk. In summer, a mass of vigorous shoots bursts wildly out of that clublike head or heads.

title: C.I.A.'s Self-Critique In Bay of Pigs Fiasco
description: One of the most secret documents of the cold war is out, 36 years after it was written. It is the Central Intelligence Agency's own inquiry into the Bay of Pigs fiasco, the invasion to overthrow Fidel Castro that caused the deaths of nearly 1,500 raiders. With brutal honesty, the report put the blame squarely on what it described as arrogance, ignorance and incompetence within the C.I.A. itself.

title: THE XVIII WINTER GAMES: NOTEBOOK; South Korea Rolls
description: As short-track speed skating ended yesterday, South Korea continued its dominance, Japan won its first gold in the sport and the United States was shut out entirely.

title: Minors Under Cover
description: In an effort to crack down on stores and bars serving alcohol illegally to minors, the police in the Yonkers Youth Division have begun a six-month program using volunteers younger than 21 as undercover agents. The sting is part of a Federal, state and county effort to reduce drunken driving among youths, Police Sgt. Joseph Apiscopa of Yonkers said. Bodegas, delicatessens, supermarkets, liquor stores and bars will be among the targets of the operation, he said.

title: What's in the Office Air? Workers Smell Trouble
description: CHRONIC headaches are among the many symptoms cited by workers with a vague condition known as ''multiple chemical sensitivity.'' What is clear, however, is that defining the workplace malady -- or even agreeing that it exists -- is becoming a big headache for the legal and medical professions.

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: Thomas Norton, 63, Art Expert and Author
description: Thomas E. Norton, an art consultant, writer and former senior vice president and director of Sotheby's, died on Feb. 7 at the Dartmouth Hitchcock Medical Center in Lebanon, N.H. He was 63 and lived in Kennebunkport, Me.

title: The View From/Mystic; Deep Sea, High Tech And a Beluga's Smile
description: THE beluga whales that call Mystic Marinelife Aquarium home looked happily oblivious to the construction going on around them as they frolicked in their outdoor tank on a near-freezing January morning. Their smiles, or seeming smiles, remained untouched as workers pounded away on a $52 million renovation that is scheduled to be completed in the spring of 1999.

title: Streetscapes/53 East 77th Street; A Medieval-Style House With a Murder in Its Past
description: THE curious medieval-style house at 53 East 77th Street was built in 1901 but completely altered in 1927 to include some of New York's most distinctive interiors, incorporating decorative elements ranging from ancient sculpture to 20th-century ironwork. The house's history includes a murder-suicide involving two brothers. Now Cello, a high-end music-system business, has gutted the building for a new headquarters, but the architect says that some of the original elements will be reinstalled.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: NIAGARA: A History of the Falls

title: The Preacher's Life
description: THE ULTIMATE INTIMACY

title: How Best to Oust Hussein?
description: Many people are calling for the United States to overthrow Saddam Hussein. But how would we actually do it?

title: Night and Day
description: Winter solstice was approaching, and holiday shoppers thronged the city streets. Sasha Nicholas and Ashleigh Fernandez, two roommates home on break from Princeton, were leapfrogging the season by thinking of spring. What makeup would make those perennial classics, the white shirt and the black dress, look new?

title: A Search for Truth, or a Partisan Inquisition?; McCurry Does His Job
description: To the Editor:

title: CALL KAREN
description: You can use 900 numbers to call everybody from preachers to prostitutes. Now you can also dial up Karen Finley, the notorious performance artist who once drew fire from Senator Jesse Helms for standing on a stage at Lincoln Center and smearing chocolate on her body. (One of her tamer demonstrations, actually.) For the next six months, in an art project sponsored by Creative Time, an arts group based in Manhattan, callers who want even more Finley can dial 1-900-ALL-KAREN to hear her taped musings on motherhood, art and her ongoing dramas with political opponents. Billed as the first over-the-phone public art installation, the call-ins aren't cheap -- $1.75 for the first minute, $1.25 each minute thereafter -- but Finley says she'll do her best to be provocative, intimate and spontaneous. Given her reputation, does she figure a lot of callers will expect talk-dirty-to-me stuff? ''It would be foolish of me to think I don't provoke controversy,'' she says, ''but I don't consider my work to be dirty.''

title: Trading on Insider Preoccupation
description: JOE ESZTERHAS, the screenwriter and force of nature, had seen Hollywood from both sides now. Having been to the economic mountaintop with ''Basic Instinct'' (worldwide gross: $350 million) he spiraled into an artistic abyss in September 1995 with his lascivious bomb ''Showgirls'' and failed to climb back out the following month with ''Jade,'' a dull, plodding thriller that starred David Caruso and Linda Fiorentino.

title: Lee Sherman, 84, Choreographer And Dancer at Roxy Theater
description: Lee Sherman, who danced with Doris Humphrey and Charles Weidman in the 1930's and 40's, died on Feb. 12 at the Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan after a brief illness. He was 84 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Sports of The Times; One Great Shortstop Lives Again at Age 127
description: IT'S as if he were discarded nearly a century ago into a time capsule that was forgotten until now.

title: Rescue 911
description: BRINGING OUT THE DEAD By Joe Connelly. 271 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $23.

title: A Charter School's Teachers Get Lessons in Elbow Grease
description: It was a school holiday, and that meant a clean-and-repair day for Jacqueline Quagliana, who teaches fourth grade at the Soaring Heights Charter School here.

title: A Search for Truth, or a Partisan Inquisition?; Secret Service Testimony
description: To the Editor:

title: Backtalk: Nagano's Legacy: Female Gladiators; Their Ice Hockey Gold Opens a Door, but to Where?
description: Late in the third period, when she saw Tara Mounsey slam the Canadian into the boards, Arlene Gorton nearly choked on her breakfast bagel. Her first thought was pure coach-think: ''Dumb penalty.'' But sitting at home in Providence, R.I., she already knew the final score, so her second thought was more academically sociological: ''This is the final public knell of the artificial construct of what is masculine and feminine in sports.''

title: Muzzle and Leash
description: Most dogs are welcome in Larchmont, but not pit bulls and other breeds that are considered vicious, according to a new law enacted by the local Board of Trustees. Now certain dogs are unwelcome unless they are muzzled and tightly leashed in public places, James Staudt, the Village Lawyer, said.

title: El Nino's Warmth Is Providing the Island With a Mild Winter
description: EL Nino, which has racked the West Coast with floods and mudslides and drenched the Southeast, is bringing Long Island one of its mildest winters on record.

title: Education Aid To Localities Gets 2d Look From Trenton
description: Widespread grumbling about New Jersey's allocation of school aid for the 1998-99 academic year has prompted the state to start an immediate and broad search for mistakes in its grants to local districts.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: DOWNTOWN BROOKLYN

title: From Columbus to 2000, Show Offers Disquieting View of U.S.
description: ARNOLD MESCHES is that rare contemporary artist who embarks on elaborate painting cycles. He takes the long view of history, in his case history that always involves America. In his exhibition at the Neuberger Museum of Art here, 20 paintings from Mr. Mesches's ''Anomie Series,'' painted between 1989 and 1996, provide a bumpy, provocative ride, beginning with the landing of Columbus and ending in 2000.

title: Speedy Lil's Lad Holds Up In a Step Toward the Derby
description: Lil's Lad raced into the leadership of this year's class of Triple Crown candidates today when he won the Fountain of Youth Stakes at Gulfstream Park by more than two lengths over Coronado's Quest.

title: Family History
description: ECCENTRIC NEIGHBORHOODS By Rosario Ferre. Illustrated. 340 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $24.

title: A New Side of Houston Emerges After Surgery
description: It is late at night, near bedtime. Just before Allan Houston flips off the lights, he will slip into something less comfortable.

title: A Trip Back in Time, to Welfare Island
description: TWO years ago, Danielle B. Hayes decided to take some out-of-town guests some place different -- Roosevelt Island. On the tram ride over, Ms. Hayes, a photographer who has exhibited on five continents, told them about pictures she took there as a student in 1968.

title: Lawmaker Hedging on Term Limit Vow
description: He said it plain. He said it simple. And he said it often.

title: For Jordan, Lewinsky Matter Tests a Friendship
description: Are Vernon Jordan and Bill Clinton still best friends?

title: Ginny Bond and Michael Donahue
description: FOR a fairy-tale romantic wedding, there is almost no better setting than the Hotel Bel-Air in Los Angeles, whose pink bungalows, set on lawns cov ered in flower petals, are hidden among overgrown magnolias and bushes as poufy as ballgowns. There is even a moat to cross, as if to remind guests they've left the real world behind. On Valentine's Day, 130 guests, mostly New Yorkers, took over the Bel-Air for the wedding of Ginny Lynn Bond and Michael John Donahue.

title: Jaffa History
description: To the Editor: Serge Schmemann misrepresents the history of Jaffa by calling it a ''beautifully restored ancient port'' (''What's Doing in Tel Aviv,'' Dec. 21). Jaffa, the largest Arab city in Palestine, had 50,000 to 70,000 residents when Menachem Begin's Irgun Zvai Leumi attacked on April 25, 1948, nearly three weeks before Israel became independent. The Irgun forces bombarded Jaffa town and port, using nine tons of explosives in a single day.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: SOUL KISS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHIN, ROCKWOOD Q.P.
description: CHIN-Rockwood Q.P., 86. Died on February 18th, 1998 in Massachusetts after an extended illness. Husband of the late Frances Wang Chin, mourned by three children, Gracia Barry of Chapel Hill, NC, Rockwell Chin of NYC, Barry Chin of Marshfield, MA, eight devoted grandchildren, sister Ettie C. Hong of Freeport, LI. Funeral service to be held March 1st, at 10 A.M., at MacDonald Funeral Home, Marshfield, MA.

title: Voice Mail Provided Free To Residents of Shelters
description: In Burlington County, domestic violence victims and people who were recently homeless now have voice mail available.

title: Philadelphia
description: Philadelphia has been flinging off old mood problems, and its new self should be brighter than ever in the spring, when parks and row houses are draped in blossoms. But every year, those who can't wait celebrate spring's precursor in the first week of March, the weeklong flower show known as the nation's biggest, best and surely most extravagant.

title: Ms. Ott, Mr. Crookenden
description: Michelle Lynn Ott and Charles Stephen Napier Crookenden were married yesterday at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York. The Rev. William McDonald Tully performed the ceremony.

title: Ask How Many, Don't Ask Why
description: Phil Arkow has 2,000 dog license tags. He has one dog. There is no entirely satisfactory explanation for this wide discrepancy, which keeps getting worse. Before he is done, it is Mr. Arkow's stated purpose to gather thousands more tags but remain with the single dog.

title: Flashback
description: A woman stands alone in a city street at night. Helmut Newton's camera has captured an intensely private moment, the figure's inner calm in marked contrast to the rakish cut of her suit. Three balls of light hover by her head, like thoughts drifting from her solitary reverie. In this all but timeless street, with its Roman arches and stone-laid trottoirs, we may hesitate for a moment to place the date. Is it the time between the World Wars, when Marlene Dietrich and Greta Garbo donned men's clothes and shocked the world? Is it the unisex 1970's or the power suit 80's? Characteristic of Helmut Newton's best work, it doesn't really look like a fashion photograph -- a portrait, that is to say, of a suit. It seems more like a society portrait, or a celebrity taking a break from a late-night party, snapped on the sly.

title: MARKET TIMING
description: TUESDAY

title: A Romantic Image He'd Gladly Shed
description: RUFUS SEWELL has been called ''Byronic'' so often that he has begun to have a recurring fantasy: he will shave off his rich, dark curls and begin his acting career again, typecast this time as an unpretty skinhead.

title: Here Come The Party Animals
description: WE don't usually allow animals of any kind,'' Susan Palmarini of Tavern on the Green said grimly as she watched what appeared to be three glossy black sausages, dressed in miniature samurai costumes, hurtling about one of the restaurant's private dining suites. ''But tonight we made an exception. They are pedigreed after all.''

title: Trying to Pierce the Veil of a Serial Killer
description: LONG before the serial murderer Ricardo Caputo was convicted in 1994 of the stabbing death of his 20-year-old female friend in her parents' Flower Hill home, Linda Wolfe knew his name.

title: Liberties; The Satan Files
description: Saddam is in his bunker.

title: A Search for Truth, or a Partisan Inquisition?; When Polls Lie
description: To the Editor:

title: Bottom of the Barrel
description: STAR-SPANGLED MEN

title: Charter Members
description: Late last month, Governor Whitman announced that she had approved proposals to open 23 more charter schools by 1999.

title: A Knowing Chef With Some Work to Do
description: THE location in Norwalk of the new Basil's has seen many tenants but perhaps none as brave as the current one. William Paul, the chef at Basil's, has geared his menu to Mediterranean and Continental cuisine, possibly as a direct challenge to the Spanish restaurant, Meson Galicia, across the street.

title: A Search for Truth, or a Partisan Inquisition?; Not Yet a Scandal
description: To the Editor:

title: The World: Present Tense; Oh, To Be Young, Charismatic and Centrist in Germany
description: IF there is one message that has been drummed home to Germans, as much by foreigners as by their own postwar leaders, it is that the past must never be suppressed. But are Germans -- or, at least, their politicians -- suppressing the present?

title: Proust at the Shore
description: WHAT worked for Marcel Proust has yet to work for Paul Tomlin, but he remains optimistic.

title: $415,000 for the Desk Where a King Quit
description: The George III mahogany library table at which King Edward VIII signed his abdication in 1936 was sold yesterday at Sotheby's for $415,000 to an unidentified telephone bidder.

title: Style; The French Twist
description: The French as usual are highly amused by the latest American sex scandal. Useless to explain that this case, at least officially, is not so much about sex as about lying: they say, ''There are naturally some occasions when a gentleman must lie.'' What has gripped the Parisian dinner tables is not the pretense that a deep crime has been committed, to do with suborning perjury, but the President's taste in women.

title: Diplomats Say Attack Would Rip Aid Chain
description: Military attacks to punish Baghdad for its refusal to grant United Nations inspectors full access to suspected weapons sites would jeopardize the intricate web of monitoring and relief operations the United Nations has built across Iraq with Washington's encouragement, some United Nations officials and diplomats say.

title: Lying Rampant in Civil Suits But Prison for Lying Is Rare
description: A Vermonter who had lived for a while in a back-to-nature community, Laura Kross was called to give a deposition when the Federal Government sued to take over the property on the ground that people were growing marijuana there. Ms. Kross lied; asked whether she had seen residents smoking marijuana on the property, she said, ''Uh-uh.''

title: Has Vanguard Windsor's Shine Begun to Fade?
description: TWO years after he took the helm of the mighty Vanguard Windsor fund, Charles Freeman has hit some choppy waters.

title: A Lot of Room to Grow
description: He drifts to sleep in a specially designed eight-foot bed, where his size 15 feet barely fit. To accommodate his 42-inch inseam, the material for his dress pants had to be purchased in France. Neal Fingleton is 7 feet 5 inches, weighs 270 pounds and is still growing. He is taller than all but two players in the National Basketball Association. He is only 17 years old.

title: Cultivating Audiences Of a New Generation
description: IS there real life after basketball, ice hockey, indoor soccer and Girl Scout cookie sales?

title: Julian Bond Elected to Lead A Reorganizing N.A.A.C.P.
description: Julian Bond, a long-time fighter for civil rights, was narrowly elected chairman of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People yesterday evening. In the second round of balloting, Mr. Bond defeated Joe Madison, a Maryland radio host, by a vote of 29 to 24, with one abstention.

title: It Might Take More Than a Village
description: WAITING FOR A MIRACLE

title: As Surveillance Cameras Peer, Some Wonder if They Also Pry
description: It had gotten so that Barbara Katende didn't even mind the cameras anymore. The ones at the courthouse she walks past every night made her feel safer. So did those at bank machines. She even accepted the ones placed in department stores to prevent shoplifting.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SALZBURG, JOSEPH
description: SALZBURG-Joseph. Papa Joe. One year today. We love and miss you. Barbara and Karen and your grandchildren

title: The World; A Firm Friend Starts to Waver
description: FROM the time Turkey sent soldiers to fight alongside Americans in the Korean War, leaving more than 700 of them buried in the cold Korean earth, this country has been one of the United States' closest allies.

title: Veda Lost?
description: It's been a decade now since Doug Henning, the big-haired magician, and Maharishi Mahesh Yogi, the big-bearded founder of Transcendental Meditation, announced plans to build Maharishi Veda Land, a $1.5 billion, 1,400-acre New Age theme park near Niagara Falls, Ontario. Veda Land was supposed to haul in six million visitors a year with unique attractions like a ''Magic Flying Chariot Ride,'' a ''Corridor of Time Ride'' and something called ''the world's only levitating building.''

title: The Fundamentals
description: To the Editor:

title: BEST SELLERS: February 22, 1998
description: Weeks

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN
description: Sphere

title: A Search for Truth, or a Partisan Inquisition?; Press Abets a Crime
description: To the Editor:

title: Across the Snow, Without Gravity or Muscles
description: IT was initially unclear whether our rented snowmobile was enemy or friend. It was a sparkly Caribbean-turquoise color, which was comforting. But its speedometer went to 160 miles an hour, which was not. Further adding to our discomfort was the knowledge that we were crossing over to the Dark Side. As longtime cross-country skiers, my companion, Louise, and I tended to view snarling snowmobiles as the enemy. In the still, Robert Frost world of New England's wintry woods, snowmobiles always seemed about as appropriate as a Sinead O'Connor concert at the Vatican.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRESCHLER, JULIA
description: GRESCHLER-Julia. On February 21, 1998. Beloved mother of Jerome (Gloria). Loving grandmother of Ira Greschler, Marlene Adams, and Jonathan Greschler, and great grandmother of six. Services Tuesday, February 24, 9:30 AM at ''Boulevard-Riverside Chapels'' 312 Coney Island Ave. at Prospect Park Circle, Brooklyn.

title: POSTINGS: 41 Apartments, 20 Floors, Average Price $1 Million; New Condo Rising on W. 86th
description: A new arrival has snuggled into a site on the south side of 86th Street a few doors east of Amsterdam Avenue, completing a line of high-rise apartment houses with a condominium in which the average apartment will sell for about $1 million.

title: At Concert, the Island Wonders, Can 'Piano Man' Say Goodbye?
description: HE is probably America's quintessential suburban singer/performer. He is certainly Long Island's.

title: A Search for Truth, or a Partisan Inquisition?; Now Investigate Starr
description: To the Editor:

title: Brash Civilian Lawyer Battles Army in Court-Martial
description: If he were a typical commuter, Charles W. Gittins might endure 90 minutes on the highway each morning inching his way from his farm near the West Virginia border to his law office here.

title: ODD URGES
description: * It has been suggested that President Clinton has a thing for ''big hair.'' If so, such a proclivity is mundane compared with the American subculture of sex fetishisms. * Two new magazines -- Fetish and Hustler's Taboo -- cover offbeat objects of obsession, including corsets and toes. * ''Crush fetishists'' -- according to Web sites like ''Exclusively Crushing'' -- like watching ''gorgeous women's feet stomping. . .everything from food to cigarettes and insects.'' * ''Microphiliacs'' like to imagine loved ones reduced to the size of miniatures. * ''Infantilists'' believe ''total incontinence'' is a bodily thrill -- and even diaper each other at parties. * Is this healthy? Charles Gatewood, owner of Flash Videos, a fetish-video company, thinks so. ''After AIDS,'' he says, ''fetishes are a safe way to express sexuality without any sex.''

title: Perot's Return to Business: The Vote's Not In
description: ONCE again, Ross is boss. Having given up, for the time being, on his vision for reforming the nation, Ross Perot has set himself on the mission of reforming his own business.

title: Italian Fare, With Touches of Yesteryear
description: THE newly opened L'Angolo restaurant in Great Neck is a time warp Italian. Diners in search of trendy, au courant dishes will not find them here. But those who love traditional Italian fare will feel at home. L'Angolo's prices are also reminiscent of yesteryear. With the exception of a few specials at $19 and one beef dish for $17.75, none of the entrees are priced higher than $15.95.

title: Tradition Counts
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: No Longer Hard to Find, Fennel Shines on Its Own or in Soup
description: FLORENTINE fennel looks like a bulbous head of celery, but it has the delicate taste of anise. It used to be relatively hard to find except in Italian markets, but over the last few years it has become increasingly popular.

title: The Persistence Of the Portraitist
description: Solomon writes that Close's portraits ''signal the ascendancy of what might be called Friendly Art.'' On the contrary, it is the spectator's sense of familiarity that his works most radically challenge.

title: Baldwin Girl Finds Camelot (on Broadway)
description: IT is not an impossible odyssey, from Baldwin to Camelot, with an occasional side trip to the Hamptons. All you have to do is act. Ask Margaret Colin, who stars in the title role of ''Jackie'' on Broadway.

title: Chef in Two Hats: Consultant and Caterer
description: CHILLS, fever, nausea, cramps. Food poisoning is not a pretty sight. As concern regarding food-borne illnesses grows, the United States Food and Drug Administration recently issued new regulations for seafood wholesalers and manufacturers. The plan, called Hazard Analysis Critical Control Point, requires seafood handlers to document the critical points where their products might be at risk.

title: The Persistence Of the Portraitist
description: Deborah Solomon sculptures an exquisite portrait of the artist Chuck Close (''The Persistence of the Portraitist,'' Feb. 1). In 1991, I interviewed Close for a TV series. He seemed to be skipping around his studio in his wheelchair, joyfully playing with color and line and space.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a United Nations team's report on ''presidential sites'' in Iraq misattributed two statements about the situation. It was another United Nations official, not Richard Butler, the chairman of the United Nations Special Commission to disarm Iraq, who said: ''Iraq has been trying to create sanctuaries. Whether the areas are 15, 55 or 150 square miles is irrelevant.'' In discussing a discrepancy between the team's figures and the commission's figures, it was also the official, not Mr. Butler, who said the fact that the team would get a different set of sites from the Iraqis ''misses the point.''

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASKETBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JEANSON, JUNE
description: JEANSON-June. On Dec. 20, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Robert. Loving sister of Ruth, Nancy and the late Richard. Devoted aunt and great-aunt. Employee of Bankers Trust Company for over 50 years. She is deeply missed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHSCHILD, ELSYE ROSENFELD
description: ROTHSCHILD-Elsye Rosenfeld. May 17, 1899-February 19, 1998. Loving wife for 52 years of the late Jesse. Much loved mother of Charles, Edmund, Stephanie and Kathy. Proud grandmother of Joshua, Adam, Oliver, Emily, Jesse, Sarah and Anna. Devoted sister of Rita, Ruth, Nonie, Irene and Flo. Caring aunt and grandaunt and surrogate parent to many. Elsye unselfishly committed her life to her family, friends, neighbors and community. Yeoman First Class, USN, in WWI, Manager of Camp Copake, Democratic Party Captain, Secretary and Board Member of Mt. Neboh Cemetery. She fought tenaciously for what she believed in and spoke what was on her mind. She was a brilliant, strong and beautiful person and will be long remembered and greatly missed. Services Sunday, February 22, at 10:30 AM, at The Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to St. Joseph's Hospital Foundation, 703 Main St., Paterson, NJ 07503, or Manhattan New School PTA, 311 East 82 Street, NY, NY 10028.

title: Africa's 'White Tribe' Fears Dark Past Is Prologue
description: As an 11th-generation Afrikaner, Christoff Heyns struggles these days over what to teach his three children about their heritage. He is uncomfortable with seemingly innocent elements of his own childhood like khaki shorts, which ultimately became a symbol of the Afrikaner right wing. He examines traditional songs for racist undertones. He picks through historical figures for those worth admiring.

title: Draped in Melon
description: Manuel Canovas, a Paris-based home-textiles designer, is known for his $300-a-yard silk fabrics for draperies and upholstery. So some might be surprised to see his name on the label of popular new swimwear.

title: Greenwich Fights Beach Lawsuit With Army of Experts
description: For this wealthy community on Long Island Sound, few issues are as important as keeping nonresidents off its beaches. For years, town officials have rejected Federal and state money for park improvements, fearing it might obligate them to admit outsiders.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, PHYLLIS SHARTSIS
description: ROSS-Phyllis Shartsis. Of Beverly Hills, CA. Died February 15, 1998, after a brief illness. Formerly of New York, she had been an executive with ABC Radio Network. Ms. Ross is survived by her sisters Elaine Max of Charleston, W.Va. Diane Wax of Washington, D.C. and her aunt and uncle, Florence and Herbert Duchan of Plantation, FL. She leaves many wonderful, caring friends in New York and California.

title: In Soft Focus
description: The sheer white dress - layered, smocked or crocheted - is this spring's antidote to winter's hard edge.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; In a Tight Market, Monmouth Beckons Office Users
description: FOR the last 25 years the 723,000-square-foot office building set on 40 acres along Tinton Avenue in the Monmouth County community of Tinton Falls was leased by the Army for its communications and electronics command center.

title: Republicans Take a Lead In Financing
description: Republican members of the New York State Legislature have raised somewhat more money in preparation for this year's elections than they did in the comparable period before the 1996 contests, while Democrats' fund-raising has remained essentially unchanged, a review of campaign records shows.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENSTEIN, STANLEY CHARLES
description: ROSENSTEIN-Stanley Charles. Aged 63. Of Mamaroneck, NY. Died on February 14, 1998. Retired Executive from Mobil Oil Corporation and Retired Lt. Commander of the U.S. Navy. Beloved husband of Barbara; father of Andrew and Denise; brother of Bette Klein.

title: Croton Resident Wins Silver Medal
description: EIGHT days ago, Gordy Sheer of Croton-on-Hudson made it to the podium. Next, he will make it to the head of the parade.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: LONG ISLAND VINES
description: A Blanc Slate

title: Horrendous Job
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Grandfather Martinez Is Set to Throw Some Strikes for Atlanta
description: The Atlanta Braves, winners of six consecutive division championships, are not unashamed. They will accept help from anywhere and from anyone. Now they are prepared to enlist the aid of a grandfather to bolster their vaunted starting rotation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUDES, STANLEY
description: RUDES-Stanley. On February 19, 1998. Born January 7, 1911 in Brooklyn, New York. Graduate NYU, Class of 1932. Husband of Mignon Rudes. Beloved brother of Kate R. Kolber. Cherished father of Terri R. Davis and Jerome H. Rudes. Devoted grandfather of Randy Davis, Jeff Davis and Lisa Sparks and great-grandfather of Alyssa Davis and Sydni Davis. Loving uncle to Fred Kolber, Mark Kolber and Philip Kolber and their families. Stanley will be remembered by family and friends in San Antonio, TX and Boca Raton, Fl. His wit, warmth, integrity, intellect and sporting passions will be dearly missed. Contributions in his name may be dedicated to Gold Coast Home Health Services, 911 East Atlantic Blvd, Suite 200, Pompano Beach, Florida 33060-7301.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLF, JASON
description: WOLF-Jason of Newton, MA and Palm Beach, FL married to Bea for 56 years. Father of the Honorable Mark Wolf and Eric Wolf of Boston, and Jeffrey Wolf of NYC.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REINHARD, HERMIA
description: REINHARD-Hermia. Congregation Ohav Sholom mourns the loss of Hermia Reinhard, beloved mother of its member and past president, Andrew Reinhard. May the family be comforted among those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Aaron D. Mehlman Joshua Schwartz, President Board of Trustees

title: Finland Upsets Canada for Bronze Medal
description: With bronze medals hanging on their chests, flowers in their hands and a few tears in their eyes, the blue-shirted hockey players of Finland stood in a line across the wide ice at Big Hat arena today and bowed, over and over again, to their happy fans and to their Japanese hosts. They had just defeated Canada by 3-2 to finish third and win the bronze medal in the Olympic hockey tournament. The winners earned the same rank achieved by the Finnish women's hockey team earlier in the week.

title: Sex and Power
description: To the Editor:

title: Going in Style: The Loved One Gets a New Age Send-off
description: A Taurus rocket launched earlier this month from Vandenberg Air Force Base in Lompoc, Calif., carried a standard payload of three communications satellites. But also along for the ride were the cremated remains of 30 individuals who had paid $4,800 each to become one with the universe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERERA, CHARLES A., M.D.
description: PERERA - Charles A., M.D., Ophthalmologist, died January 27, 1998 at 92. Graduate of Horace Mann, Princeton; received M.D. from Columbia Univ; practiced in NYC; served as editor of ''May's Diseases of the Eye''. Attending Ophthalmologist at Presbyterian Hospital and Cl. Prof. at Columbia, he was beloved by his patients, member of American Academy of Ophthalmology, New York Ophthalmological Soc., American Ophthalmological Society and NY Academy of Medicine. Devoted to the arts, he sponsored numerous musicians; was co-founder of the Toscanini Archives at New York Pub. Library. A Quaker, was founder of Scarsdale Friends Mtg., Bd. Member of Amer. Friends Service Committee, Trustee of NY Yearly Mtg. Dearly missed, he is survived by sister, Lydia P. Marcus, brother, George A. Perera, children Sylvia Perera, Donald Perera, Ellen Scott and Carol Weingeist, 11 grandchildren, 9 great grandchildren. He was predeceased by his wife, Ruth Brinton Perera and son John. Donations may be made to American Friends Service Committee or Fight for Sight. Memorial Service: March 7, 2:00 PM, at Kendal, Rt. 1, Kennett Sq., PA.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We can get on with our lives and not have to worry about being the ones running the evil empire anymore.''

title: A New Wrinkle In High Fashion
description: A $3,000 metallic Versace gown comes with several commitments: You will explain to friends why you spent the equivalent of a family's life savings on a garment. You will bare more skin than you ever have publicly outside the junior high school locker room. And you will dry-clean.

title: Correction
description: A listing last Sunday with an article about stocks and stock options held by the executives of large companies referred incorrectly to holdings in Coca-Cola. They were those of Roberto C. Goizueta, the chairman and chief executive who died in October, not of his successor, M. Douglas Ivester.

title: A Story More Articulate on Page Than Stage
description: NOTHING is more essential to the life of the theater than the cultivation of young audiences, and nothing is more nurturing to the life of the mind than the love of reading, developed early.

title: February 15-21; Fiasco, the Report
description: A commission investigating the bungled attack on a Hamas official in Jordan last fall cleared Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of any blame.

title: Mocking Portrait
description: To the Editor:

title: In Graphic Detail
description: Among these slim summer dresses, new patterns can be detected.

title: Are Grammy Write-Ins Possible?
description: NEXT WEDNESDAY, when the Grammy Awards are announced, Category 90 will not get the most publicity, but it may present the biggest challenge. This is where listeners get to consider what was the ''best classical contemporary composition'' released on record during 1997.

title: In America; War Games
description: ''War hath no fury like a noncombatant,'' said C. E. Montague, the writer and veteran of World War I.

title: A Search for Truth, or a Partisan Inquisition?
description: To the Editor:

title: Managers With a Mission to Avoid the Status Quo
description: TONY TACCONE, in the middle of his first season as artistic director of the Berkeley Repertory Theater here, referred to himself and the woman sitting in his office, Molly Smith, as ''comrades in arms.'' About the same age -- he is 46, she is 45 -- they are both experienced theater directors who earned their leadership stripes in similarly modest-sized nonprofit institutions.

title: Justin Macedonia, Tiffany Thomas
description: Tiffany Shannon Thomas, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Thomas of Yardley, Pa., was married yesterday to Justin Keith Macedonia, a son of Anne Macedonia of Riverdale, the Bronx, and Carmine Macedonia of Davenport, N.Y. The Rev. John A. Boehning performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in Manhattan.

title: Cloud Cover
description: On the horizon for spring: the short raincoat

title: Dormitory Plan: One Minus, Many Pluses
description: If Columbia University's proposal to build a 14-story dormitory on the northeastern corner of Broadway at 113th Street is carried out as planned, 373 undergraduates will get beds, the neighborhood will get a new public library, and an adjacent town house, which some have deemed historic, will get a restored facade even as it loses its rear half.

title: A Calculable Loss?
description: DAMAGES

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIBMAN, HANNAH (SILVERMAN)
description: LIBMAN - Hannah (Silverman). Aged 88, on February 18, 1998. Devoted wife of the late Morris, loving mother of Jill, Kit Howard (Robert), Hillard (Elaine). Adored grandmother of Brett, Jodi (Steven), Jim, Jon (Kathleen). Greatgrandmother of Griffin and Gage. Co-founder in 1929 of Camp Hillard, Hartsdale, New York, she will be sadly missed by all who knew and loved her. Shiva will be observed at the home of Kit and Robert Howard, Sunday through Tuesday.

title: Surreal, London To Los Angeles
description: AS its principal founder, Andre Breton, predicted, Surrealism has become indistinguishable from everyday life. So it is an occasion when viewers have a chance to encounter a large block of the real thing, as they do with the intensive survey ''The Surrealist Vision'' at the Bruce Museum in Greenwich.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: FLYING SOLO

title: Laughing With the Bourgeoisie; A New Television Show for a New China, Shot in Manhattan, Skips the Politics
description: New York City: A grimy city of danger and despair. America: A confusing land of ruthless capitalists and thwarted dreams.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINSLOW, ALFRED B.
description: WINSLOW-Alfred B. Of Sarasota, FL, and Westport, CT, passed away February 20, 1998, after a long and courageous battle with cancer. Devoted husband of Jytte Winslow and father of Merry, Richard and Frederick Winslow and Mark and Nina Hellman and eight grandchildren. Mr. Winslow was a graduate of Fordham Law School and was a naval aviator during World War II, and was active in real estate and law in New York City and CT. He was predeceased by his first wife, the former Barbara L. Judell. He was the son of Leopold and Rose Weinstein. He will be greatly missed. Memorial services will be held at Temple Beth Israel in Long Boat Key, Sarasota, Florida, on February 21, 1998. Any contributions may be directed to Hospice of Sarasota, Florida.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BERNSTEIN, ELLIOTT
description: BERNSTEIN-Elliott, February 22, 1954-April 2, 1994. Happy Birthday Darling, come with us to the Magic Show today. Love you, Mom.

title: Paint It Black: London Goes Goth, Again
description: IT'S Goth night at Gossips in Soho, and the 300-plus crowd of 20-somethings are dressed entirely in black. They jostle elbow to elbow to the thundering drum machine of ''Alice'' by the Sisters of Mercy or stretch out on velvet sofas watching Bela Lugosi films on the video monitors. Carefully powdered faces and heavy, precise black eyeliner represent hundreds of hours in front of the mirror. Gender is irrelevant: men as well as women sport tight patent-leather bodices, leather trousers and tresses of black or bleached white hair.

title: Summer Rentals: The Prices Are Holding Steady
description: LAST year when Sotheby's rented out a 1900's oceanfront estate in East Hampton, L.I., for $200,000 for the month of August, the company considered it a record for the area. Then, a couple of weeks ago, the estate's owner called Frank Newbold, head of Sotheby's East Hampton office, and said he had negotiated a deal himself for this summer.

title: A Search for Truth, or a Partisan Inquisition?; Other People's Gawking
description: To the Editor:

title: The Beauty Of Tea
description: The waters in the fountain of youth are now green, at least according to cosmetics companies. Green tea -- held in high esteem in Asia, where drinking it is considered a way to purify the body and lift the spirits -- has become a popular ingredient in everything from shampoo to deodorant. There are Coty's green-tea bath crystals and shower gel in its Healing Garden line; Avon's Stress Shield Serum, a skin revitalizer-moisturizer; Clinique's Weather Everything S.P.F. 15, a cream with sun block, and a Green Tea line from Aubrey Organics, including deodorant, sun block for children and shampoo.

title: Bus Fare Cuts Are Extended To 3 Boroughs
description: Beginning next week, thousands of commuters from Queens, Brooklyn and the Bronx could save up to $1 on the bus fares of private express lines subsidized by the city, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, HON. LEWIS R.
description: FRIEDMAN-Hon. Lewis R. Devoted husband of Bernice, beloved father of Karen, cherished son of Dr. Sylvia N. and the late Harold, loving brother of Dr. Diane. Services 11AM Sunday, Park Avenue Synagogue, East 87th Street and Madison Ave. Contributions may be made to the Forman Friedman Fund, Foundation for the Jewish Community, 150 East 58th Street, 26th floor, N.Y.C. 10155.

title: Bought by CBS
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Bridging Generations
description: GRANDPARENT-grandchild travel is shooting up like an adolescent.

title: Turkey Skimps on Its Great Monument
description: ISTANBUL'S crowning glory is the 1,460-year-old Haghia Sophia, once the central church of the Byzantine Empire, later a great mosque where Ottoman sultans were crowned and now a museum that is always full of tourists.

title: V.A. Financing
description: Saying that it ''literally adds insult to injury,'' County Legislators Vito J. Pinto and George Oros have criticized a plan by the Department of Veterans Affairs to shift up to $80 million from the V.A. hospital in Montrose to other budget categories.

title: Punishing the Paparazzi
description: In the grand scheme of things, the need of celebrities for protection against photographers is not one of the critical issues facing this republic. It is getting inordinate attention now because of the death of Princess Diana and the fact that Hollywood has a lot of money for politicians who propose laws to restrict news gathering by the tabloids. A bill unveiled last week by Senators Dianne Feinstein and Orrin Hatch is more responsible than some previous suggestions. But it still proposes restrictions that are at best unnecessary and at worst harmful to legitimate news gathering and the free-expression rights of citizens.

title: The Rest of the Schumann Story, or Some of It
description: THINK OF Schumann, and the somewhat warped, childlike realm of ''Kinderszenen'' and ''Carnaval'' probably springs to mind. Or perhaps the tortured, Romantic world of ''Dichterliebe'' and ''Frauenliebe und Leben.'' Either way, the piano and the voice are the favored vehicles of Schumann's trenchant, evocative powers.

title: February 15-21; The Tale of Two Teams
description: The United States sent two hockey teams to the Winter Olympic Games in Nagano, Japan. One is coming home with gold, the other with a tarnished reputation.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Power of the Word

title: POP/JAZZ; A Love Ballad's Tortured Trip To the Grammys
description: ONE SUNDAY last April, Diane Warren, the 42-year-old songwriter whose pop ballads have been theme songs for some of Hollywood's biggest movies in recent years, invited LeAnn Rimes to her home in Southern California to listen to a few works in progress. Just before midnight, Ms. Warren asked the 14-year-old Ms. Rimes, who had just won a Grammy for best new artist, to record a demonstration tape for a song she had been working on for the film ''Con Air,'' starring Nicolas Cage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLTZMAN, STUART A.
description: HOLTZMAN-Stuart A. On February 20, 1998. Beloved husband of Mady. Devoted father of Alexis and Nicki. Loving brother of Robert. Uncle to Jill, Jay, Larry, Paul, Alex and Benjamin. Funeral service Sunday, 12 noon, at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERRILL, BOB
description: MERRILL-Bob.The American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers mourns the sad loss of our esteemed member, Bob Merrill, writer of many memorable songs and Broadway scores. We extend our condolences to his family. Marilyn Bergman President & Chairman, ASCAP

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEYER, MURRAY
description: STEYER-Murray. Beloved husband of Beatrice Steyer for 51 years. Loving father of Robert, Richard and Betsy and loved father-in-law of Fred and Patricia. Treasured grandfather of Matthew, Laura and Harry. Devoted brother of Frances S. Martinson and the late Roy Steyer. He died as he lived-with dignity and grace and surrounded by his family who cherished him. The funeral will be held at 10 AM, on Monday, February 23rd, at the Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road in Scarsdale.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GETTINGER, PAUL P.
description: GETTINGER-Paul P. 42 years today. Our wonderful and dearest father. We miss you and love you today and every day. Martin and Gloria

title: Ripping Up Queens Plaza
description: For well into the next millennium, the staccato sounds of jackhammers, the blaring of car horns and the beeping of bulldozers backing up will be familiar to anyone who works near or passes through Queens Plaza.

title: In The Moment
description: If pretty is the message, then the medium is stretch jersey - twisted and draped.

title: An At-Home Delivery Service, Literally
description: MIRIAM SCHWARZCHILD likes to say she practices the second-oldest profession: midwife.

title: Drills, Bits and Their Many Uses
description: A DRILL, either electric or hand, and an assortment of drill bits are a necessary part of any tool kit. For general tasks, it's best to acquire a number of twist drills (sometimes called Morse drills). These bits are essentially steel rods with two helical grooves or flutes running about two-thirds of the length. The remaining one-third, called the shank, is the part that is chucked into the drill..

title: VIEWPOINT; A Fight for Restroom Rights
description: THE fact that bosses who are free to use the toilet whenever they want can bar workers from responding to the same need is a power inequity. Though the right to go to the bathroom has not figured conspicuously in debates about workplace democracy, it may soon be a labor-management issue.

title: A Merger Creates a New, Unamusing Ride, to the Bank
description: An old African proverb holds that when elephants fight, it is the grass that suffers. Some Coney Island residents might argue that the same can be true when elephants make love.

title: The Nation; The Law Ranks Its Privileges
description: THE investigation of President Clinton's link to Monica S. Lewinsky is barely a month old and it has already set a peculiar record: Most variations on the ancient legal concept of special privileges that excuse people from testifying in court and before grand juries.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Goop Is Cool

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMP, PAUL T.
description: CAMP-Paul T., 78. Of San Marcos, CA., formerly of Somers, NY, passed away Feb. 16, 1998. Born in Springfield, MA on May 2, 1921. Retired as International Quality Control Director for Pfizer Inc. Survived by his wife of fifty-three years, Phyllis Reynolds Camp of San Marcos, CA., one daughter Jacqueline Eldridge of Santa Barbara, CA, two sisters, Jane Camp Krause of Concord, NC and Joy Camp of Concord, N.C., one grandson Mark Eldridge of Santa Barbara, CA. Services private.

title: Eldery Gamblers And Health Risks
description: The recent article on compulsive elderly gamblers [''For the Gambling Elderly, Help in Fighting Addiction,'' Feb. 8] has prompted us to share the results of our research conducted on 398 casino-related deaths occurring in Atlantic City between 1982 and 1986. Our study showed that gambling among the elderly can be hazardous to their health. Eighty-three percent of the total number of fatalities were due to sudden cardiac death. Most of the victims were elderly, white, retired men who had previously diagnosed medical conditions. Many also suffered from medical problems known to be associated with compulsive gambling (e.g., psychosomatic illnesses, addictive disorders, depression and suicidal tendencies).

title: Huntington's Role Regarding Environment
description: Regarding the Jan. 18 article ''Environmental Bond Act Is Little Used.''

title: A Hospital's Effort to Decrease Caesareans
description: LISBETH STEEN-HACKETT'S first baby was born by Caesarean section, her second by vaginal delivery. ''It was like night and day,'' she said recently, three days after her second child was born. ''I'm already doing laundry and picking up around the house. Five years ago, on the third day I was in the hospital, walking around with an I.V. pole. You felt it. You went through major surgery.''

title: INVESTING WITH: Robert E. Torray; Torray Fund
description: THOUGH hardly given to spontaneous outbursts of merriment, Robert E. Torray, the portfolio manager of the Torray fund, could not help but crib a quote from Groucho Marx to close his latest shareholder letter: ''Are you going to believe what I tell you, or are you going to believe your own eyes?''

title: 150 Evacuated in Fire In a Building in Hoboken
description: At least 150 people were evacuated from a Hoboken apartment building yesterday evening after fire swept through a fourth-floor hallway, fire officials said.

title: Take Me Out to the Ballgame, or at Least Let Me Buy a Seat
description: OFFICIALLY, the first ball won't be thrown until April. But Trenton Thunder fans already have baseball fever.

title: FROM THE DESK OF; The Apple Is Shinier, But I Miss the Worms
description: NO one is more painfully aware of New York City's renaissance than her defectors, those of us who left in the wave of corporate relocations of the late 1980's and early 90's.

title: Buried Evidence
description: THE ICE HOUSE, a two-part drama having its premiere on Mystery!, is based on Minette Walters's chilling tale of adultery, betrayal and murder. When the husband of Phoebe Maybury (Penny Downie) disppeared and no body was found, the police abandoned their inquiries but not their suspicions of Phoebe's involvement. Ten years later, when a badly decomposed corpse is found in an abandoned ice house on the Maybury estate, the murder investigation resumes. Chief Inspector Walsh (Corin Redgrave, above right, with Daniel Craig), who was originally assigned to the case, is convinced he now has the murderer, but his young sergeant isn't so sure -- THURSDAY at 9 P.M. on CHANNEL 13. Yolanda A. Andrews

title: Agent Plays Clerk in Real-Life Office Comedy
description: It was on an evening about three years ago. Michael Hartman, a theater press agent, was working late at the office. He had a lot to do, and the constantly ringing phone was distracting him. Finally, to silence the noise, he picked it up, only to hear the caller ask for him.

title: Doing Homework For a Laugh
description: What did the teacher of the comedy workshop say to the students?

title: SHOPPING WITH: Marlo Thomas; That Girl, All Grown Up
description: THAT GIRL. For a generation of television viewers, those two words evoke a Pavlovian avalanche of memories. Knee-high white patent-leather boots. Micro-miniskirts that somehow manage to look demure. Donald, the patient-as-Job boyfriend. And, oh, that theme song!

title: Not Color Blind: Just Blind
description: Few African-American students are likely to enter the great public law schools of California and Texas in the fall. That is the direct, foreseeable consequence of a California referendum and a Texas Federal court decision. So concerned were civil rights groups about the popular and legal doctrine that led to this result that they joined together to deny the U.S. Supreme Court the opportunity to decide an apparently definitive affirmative action case involving teachers in Piscataway Township, N.J. Do such events -- especially Piscataway -- foretell the end of affirmative action, or have we simply lost sight of our long-term vision of a color-blind society?

title: Calling Infertility a Disease, Couples Battle With Insurers
description: Roberta Kraft is $38,700 in debt. She owes money on her Visa card. She owes money on her American Express card. She owes money to her parents and to her best friend from college. She and her husband have not bought new clothes in two years and live in a cramped one-bedroom apartment because they have spent all their discretionary income -- and a good chunk of their future earnings -- in a single pursuit: trying to have a baby.

title: Angrily Cute
description: Though they operate on a tiny scale, folks who publish homegrown zines and countercultural literary journals face the same problem as mondo-corporate publishing houses: it's hard to get noticed in a world that is saturated with media.

title: Trenton Is Turning From Its Longtime Support of Abortion Rights
description: For the first time in decades, legislators are vigorously supporting proposals to restrict access to abortion in New Jersey, where both Democrats and Republicans used to champion abortion rights.

title: Gaudy, Hokey, the Circus in All Its Hype
description: ALTHOUGH the eyes of a child may be more telling, all ages are susceptible to the charms of the circus. In ''The American Circus: Barnum, Bridgeport & Beyond,'' an exhibition at the Discovery Museum in Bridgeport through June 7, the dazzling world of the circus takes center stage. Galleries, transformed into a big top, strut flaming orange-red walls as repositories for posters, photographs, route books, clown costumes and other memorabilia from Barnum luminaries like Tom Thumb, Jenny Lind and P. T. himself.

title: Making Maestros for the World
description: IF YOU THINK that Finland's hottest exports are Nokia cell phones and Finlandia vodka, think again. Some of the most coveted podiums in the classical-music world are being snapped up by young Finns.

title: A Jeweler As Striking As the Jewels
description: RENE LALIQUE'S glorious Art Nouveau jewelry was an instant success in America when it was introduced at the St. Louis World's Fair in 1904. Alice Roosevelt, the oldest daughter of President Theodore Roosevelt, and Helen Gould, a New York socialite, were among those who praised the seductive beauty and inventiveness of Lalique's pieces. And Henry Walters, a Baltimore financier, railroad magnate and philanthropist, secretly bought nine of Lalique's gold and enamel extravaganzas, including pendants of naked women, an exotic necklace of stalking tigers, an exuberantly shaped pansy brooch and an erotic tiara crowned with an ivory orchid.

title: Grab It Quick and Duck Under the Floorboards
description: The Borrowers

title: How the Album Got Played Out
description: The 40th annual grammy awards will be held at radio City Music Hall Wednesday night, and among the nominees for Album of the Year is Radiohead's ''OK Computer,'' which you've probably never heard of, much less spent a lot of time listening to. Upon its release in July by Capitol Records, one of the country's biggest labels, it was hailed by popular-music critics -- whereupon it peaked at No. 21 on the Billboard 200 album chart and then sank like a stone. Its appearance on numerous year-end ''best of'' lists had it climbing again last month, to No. 70.

title: Sports of The Times; The Games Are Bigger, but Are They Better?
description: IT seems like a very long time ago during the Edo Dynasty, I believe it was -- that I wrote that the 1998 Winter Games were now official because the Great Gretzky and the Mighty Kwan had arrived.

title: Pondering the Cosmic Questions
description: WHY was I born? Is life but a dream? What is good? What is evil? Such eternal questions can reflect the palaver of pop lyrics or the depths of an existential search, a spiritual quest.

title: February 15-21; Test of Wills
description: President Suharto of Indonesia is not accustomed to sharing power. So when the International Monetary Fund suggested he could lose $43 billion in loans to bail out his economy unless he manages things the fund's way, it created a nasty standoff.

title: Another Posse Sets Its Sights on a Renegade Beach
description: OLD LYME, on the east side of the mouth of the Connecticut River, has seven beach colonies on Long Island Sound. Six of them -- White Sands, Hawk's Nest, Miami Beach, Old Colony, Old Lyme Shores and Point o' Woods -- are suitably proper summer havens for middle-class families from the central part of the state, some of whom have been visiting the beaches generation after generation for most of this century. They are cottage owners or renters but also guardians of behavior. By example, or by rules enacted by their separate beach associations, almost little fiefdoms of government, they keep things tidy. Respectability, that's the key word.

title: With Cigarette Tax Higher, January Sales Are Lower
description: Sales of cigarettes fell by about a third in January, based on reports last week by the state Treasury Department of revenues generated by the new sales tax of 80 cents a pack. Cigarette sales tax receipts actually rose -- to $26.8 million from $19.7 million in January 1997 -- but not at nearly the same rate as the 100 percent increase in the cigarette tax, which used to be 40 cents a pack, said Mary Lou Murphy, a spokeswoman for the department.

description: Weeks

title: In High Gear
description: The animated classics exuberant and wearable, ready for action.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; How She Got Bent Out of Shape
description: Even the little kids in Marysville know about promiscuous Georgia Sayers. ''Hey, it's Harry, Dick and Tom, havin' fun with Nancy's mom,'' they taunt her perpetually embarrassed daughter at the start of Norma Peterson's novel, RHONDA THE RUBBER WOMAN (Permanent Press, $24), which is set in small-town Pennsylvania in the 1940's. When Mom gets lonely, Eddie Jeffers (who's ''in the circus business'') takes up residence, and Nancy's desperately adaptive talent finally kicks in: she can bend all the way over and put her nose to the floor. With Eddie's encouragement, Nancy hits the stage of the Magic Midway carnival as Rhonda the Rubber Woman and discovers what it feels like to be her own -- distinctly acrobatic -- person. Norma Peterson died of leukemia in January 1997, and ''Rhonda the Rubber Woman'' is both her first and last novel. She seems to have had a vast array of incidents and emotions at her fingertips, as well as an eye for a woman's small comforts in wartime -- makeup, clothes, swing music, friendship. Apparently at ease with everyday incongruities, Peterson may have incorporated a few too many into her plot, but she also gave life to a resilient heroine who embellishes the contortions of fate with a few twists all her own. Sally Eckhoff

title: A Host of Choirs Take Turns in Recital
description: THIS afternoon the combined vocal resources of three New Haven Choirs are pooled in pursuit of ''Festive Vespers.'' The 4 o'clock program is described as ''magnificent works for multiple choirs in the superb architecture and acoustics of Christ Church.'' Joining the host ensemble are the choirs of Trinity and United Churches, the three directors -- Robert Lehman, R. Walden Moore and Mark Brombaugh -- taking turns on the podium for Walton's Coronation Te Deum, Mendelssohn's ''Hear My Prayer'' and John Tavener's ''Hymn to the Mother of God.'' An offering will be taken to benefit Christ Church's organ restoration fund.

title: Lillian Garcia, Bruce Mandell
description: Lillian Jeanette Garcia, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Felix J. Garcia of Key Biscayne, Fla., was married last evening to Bruce Alan Mandell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew J. Mandell of West Hartford, Conn. The Rev. Robert Caudill, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated with Rabbi Loring Frank at the Biltmore Hotel and Country Club in Coral Gables, Fla.

title: Ehhh, What's Up, Toons? More Adult, Just as Loony

Grade-school students toil away at calculus and astrophysics; the best and brightest graduate to designing virtual-reality pinball games. Is it any wonder, then, that animation is going prime time?

description: Catherine Cox Ballantyne, a daughter of Martha and Joseph Ballantyne of Ithaca, N.Y., was married yesterday to Andrew Huai Chiang, the son of Betty and George Djia Chee Chiang of Potomac, Md. An officiator of the Oakland California Temple Presidency performed the ceremony at the Oakland Temple of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints.

title: At the Top By Way of a Bottom Line
description: IF YOU TAKE away the art and keep the commerce, who's No. 1 in Hollywood right now? Shortly before the Oscar nominations were announced recently, the results of another annual popularity contest, one that has lasted almost as long as the Academy Awards, were revealed. Quigley Publishing Company, which has produced the International Motion Picture Almanac for 64 years, released the results of its annual Top 10 Moneymaking Stars poll. Among this poll's top 10 stars of 1997, only two, Jack Nicholson (for ''As Good as It Gets'') and Robin Williams (for ''Good Will Hunting''), also received Oscar nominations.

title: Democrats Find No Chinese Impact on Election
description: Efforts by the Chinese Government to influence American elections in 1996 did not have any impact on the Presidential campaign, said a draft report prepared by Democrats on the Senate committee investigating campaign finance abuses.

title: A Sisterhood of Mothers From Around the World
description: THE SETTING: The opening dinner of the four-day conference of Chabad-Lubavitch women at the cavernous Beth Rivkah girls' school on Lefferts Avenue in Crown Heights. The school, as yet unfinished, will hold 2,000 girls when it is complete. Wednesday night, it held 600 Lubavitch women from around the world who had come for the annual conference, which was to include workshops on topics ranging from ''Beautiful Fruit Platters'' to ''Planning Pesach: Relieving the Pressure, Avoiding the Stress'' to ''Effective Parenting for Large Families.'' The men had their own conference in November.

description: Ingrid Casares, the night-life queen and Madonna confidante, may finally be allowed to bring a version of her famously fabulous Miami Beach spot, Liquid, to the Flatiron District.

title: Sing Sing Anecdotes Find a Chronicler
description: THE Big House. Up the river. The last mile. Sing Sing has become so ingrained in the culture that phrases referring to the prison are part of the lexicon. For more than 150 years, Sing Sing has overlooked the Hudson River from the village of Ossining, and for that century and a half, people have been both intrigued and repelled by what goes on behind its walls.

title: New York's Starving Libraries
description: Beleaguered libraries throughout the state took heart last month when Gov. George Pataki included $88.5 million in this year's budget to aid libraries, which run mainly on inadequate local tax revenues. If the Legislature approves the plan, the state will finally deliver aid that it has been promising since the library funding law was passed in 1990. The money is badly needed to acquire new books and computer equipment to access the Internet and electronic library catalogues.
