description: To the Sports Editor:

title: The Burden of a Happy Childhood
description: My grandparents' house, in Brooklyn, was my sanctuary, too (Lives: ''The Burden of a Happy Childhood,'' by Mary Cantwell, Feb. 1). It housed their brothers and sisters, their children and grandchildren. The house was sold in 1961, after Nana's death. Last month, I got the courage to knock on the door. I was invited in by a gracious woman who insisted on giving me ''the tour.'' I remained composed until she lifted an embroidered cloth, revealing my grandmother's mahogany dinner table, which my grandfather had sold her. In its reflection, I saw so many faces, gathered in love on the Sabbath.

title: Sprain Road Agreement
description: With both sides declaring victory, Yonkers and Greenburgh recently settled their border dispute over use of an abandoned road. On Feb. 13 Greenburgh dropped its lawsuit against a $150 million commercial development in Yonkers, In exchange, Yonkers agreed not to use Sprain Road in adjacent Greenburgh for through traffic.

title: The Waters Run Even in Winter
description: MY first day in Saratoga Springs was characteristically grand: I was led up the stairs of a 55-room mansion and told to make myself at home in a tower studio, complete with a prayer closet and bust of the Madonna.

title: Quiet Brooklyn Tracks Stir Dreams of Planners
description: This is about an 11-mile walk in a more or less straight line, a stroll along a Brooklyn railroad track that once represented the industrial heart of the city and might do so again someday. Or might just become a skinny but very long park.

title: Love Songs in Concert
description: IT is never too late for love, so even though Valentine's Day has passed, Juliet will be united with Romeo today at 2:30 P.M. in a free recital at the White Plains Public Library. The husband and wife singers -- and Mount Vernon residents -- Richard Slade and Cynthia Reynolds, joined by the pianist Stephen Francis Vasta, have concocted a romantic scenario, interspersing songs by Schubert, Wolf and others with four duets from Gounod's opera ''Romeo and Juliet.''

Could the Frenchway Travel agency get the models Kate Moss and Naomi Campbell from Cape Town to Havana by that Monday? They absolutely had to be there for a photo shoot for Harper's Bazaar.

description: MEMBERS of the St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church in North Stonington are making some hard decisions. They are planing for a time when they may not have a full-time priest.

description: It smells like a beach ball and can survive a sudden rainstorm or a salty wave. And it has arrived in stores for spring or summer dreamers.

title: War in The Gulf? Peace in The Pits
description: War is . . . swell. That was the stock market's rather unseemly message when the United States bombed Iraq seven years ago. The Dow Jones industrial average shot up more than 100 points the day the bombardment began, and in the following month it soared 17 percent. Indeed, the current leg of the bull market began when Desert Storm did, in January 1991.

title: Valentine Sees Options for the Leadoff Spot
description: The Mets might not have an archetypal leadoff hitter on their roster this spring, but Manager Bobby Valentine said he was not concerned. The Florida Marlins did not have one last season, he noted, and they won the World Series.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; America's Magic Mirror
description: Imagine the fun the curators of the Library of Congress and the picture editor Vincent Virga had combing through the library's 100-year-old special collections for EYES OF THE NATION: A Visual History of the United States (Knopf, $75), a sumptuous visual chronicle of the life and times of America. The result showcases more than 500 illustrations, manuscripts, engravings, prints, movie stills and other artifacts stretching back to the 15th century. The accompanying text by the historian Alan Brinkley rolls through the high and low points of the nation's history, but it is the captions that sparkle the brightest, adding context while offering surprising information on such oddities as the 19th-century public fascination with phrenology (''the science of reading the human personality from the shape of the cranium''). The book contains classic documents like the first draft of the Declaration of Independence and the stark Depression-era photographs that emerged from the Farm Security Administration, but there are far less well-known entries that are equally fascinating, including Alexander Graham Bell's crude sketch of a telephone, a wanted poster for John Wilkes Booth and a spectacular array of illustrated maps showing the gradual broadening of the continent's terra cognita. The images with the most lasting impact focus on popular culture and everyday life: a couple of pages from an 18th-century primer used by New England settlers, for example, or a woodcut from an antislavery tract showing a slave owner's wife whipping a black girl, or a modest daguerreotype of a seamstress seated at an industrial sewing machine, whose set jaw and steely glance speak volumes about the pride and pain felt by female factory workers in the mid-1800's. Scott Veale

title: DIARY
description: TRADE DEFICIT

title: A Safari on Four Legs
description: THE Cessna flew at 1,500 feet above Kalahari Desert scrub that had recently been ravaged by bush fires. From the window I watched eagles and vultures glide beneath us on the thermals. It was a bleak and inhospitable vision, Africa at the end of a long dry winter. But then I saw something glinting, as if the sun were bouncing off a mirror. The Cessna began its descent and I saw a channel of water snaking into the distance. Beyond it were blue lagoons and vivid green flood plains. A lone elephant stood in the middle of an oxbow lake; a herd of antelope sat neat as china figurines on a small palm-fringed island. I'd arrived at the edge of Botswana's Okavango Delta. The game viewing had already begun, and I suspected it would only improve, for I'd flown in for five days of exploration, not on foot or by canoe, but on horseback.

description: GENE MARSHALL wears only couture. And when she gave a soiree in her suite at the Plaza 10 days ago to celebrate the latest additions to her already glorious wardrobe, she packed the place with revelers who ooh-ed and ah-ed at her every new ensemble.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DABNEY, SETH MASON, III
description: DABNEY-Seth Mason, III. Attorney. Died suddenly on February 17, while vacationing on Captiva Island, FL. Age 79. Born in Brooklyn, graduate of CCNY and Columbia University Law School. Served with US Army Signal Corps in WW II. Resident of Ridgewood, NJ, until joining Caterpillar Inc and relocated to Peoria, IL. He was Secretary and General Counsel of Caterpillar from 1974 until his retirement in 1983, when he became Of Counsel to the Peoria firm of Westervelt, Johnson, Nicoll & Keller. He is survived by his wife of 51 years, M. Jean Dabney (nee Tomai); two sons, Seth Mason, IV, of Oxford, MS, and James Wilson of Ridgewood, NJ; three grandchildren; and a sister Henrietta L. Dabney, of NYC. Interment at The Evergreens Cemetery in Brooklyn will be private. A memorial service will be held at 11 AM, on Saturday, March 14, at the Westminster Presbyterian Church in Peoria. Memorials may be made to Planned Parenthood of Greater Peoria, The Peoria Symphony Orchestra or Columbia University School of Law.

title: Uprising the Indie
description: The woman on Eighth Street is wearing a huge leather biker's jacket over a ballerina crinoline that juts out at the hem. She's got heavy tights on, and engineer's boots, and the part of her sweatshirt sticking out from beneath her jacket creates a whole other layer of texture and silhouette. With her dreadlocks and skinny Oakley sunglasses and with the chrome ring through her septum, she embodies a type of dressing you're not likely to encounter anytime soon in Vogue. A lot of people might see in her a card from a demented Old Maid deck. I, on the other hand, see a Holly Golightly for the new millennium.

title: Dr. Jack Myers, 84, a Pioneer In Computer-Aided Diagnoses
description: Jack D. Myers, a doctor who was widely regarded as one of the nation's best at diagnosis and who developed one of the first computer programs to help doctors diagnose complex cases, died on Jan. 31 at his home in Pittsburgh. He was 84.

title: Upstairs, Downstairs
description: THE low-slung couches in the upstairs lounge at Moomba were full of pretty young things, male and female, in knit caps and tank tops. It was 11:30 Tuesday night, and they were shouting over pulsing electronic music, and, with practiced nonchalance, ignoring Twiggy Ramirez and his entourage.

title: Missing the Irony
description: Molly Haskell's politically correct slings and arrows land wide of the mark with regard to ''Deconstructing Harry.''

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: HARLEM; A Global Vision for 116th St., Born in Istanbul
description: In the wake of revivals of 42d and 125th Streets, another struggling east-west artery -- 116th Street -- is the focus of an effort to create an international model of urban planning.

title: I.R.A. Is Eyed As Bombing In Ulster Casts Pall on Talks
description: The police chief of Northern Ireland said today that the bomb that ripped the center of a predominantly Protestant village west of here late on Friday night had been planted by ''Republican extremists.''

title: Schizophrenia's Most Zealous Foe
description: ''We won't be getting any brains in the mail today,'' the nation's best-known schizophrenia researcher says as he hurries to a meeting at his Washington laboratory. ''They don't mail them over the weekend. We'll probably get some fresh brains Fed Exed tomorrow.'' Dr. E. Fuller Torrey, a psychiatrist, has had many grand passions during his three-decade crusade to cure schizophrenia, but none greater than his new human brain bank. For years, a major obstacle for scientists researching the neurological roots of serious mental illnesses -- schizophrenia, manic depression, depression -- has been the lack of first-rate human brains to study. ''The only schizophrenic brains available have been very old and not in very good shape,'' Torrey says. They came from state hospitals and nursing homes, from patients so elderly that by the time they died the brain had atrophied. ''We wanted to be in position to get better brains, brains of people younger and not dead long.'' Brains that would be full of unaltered proteins and neurotransmitters, viruses and cytokines that might hold the answers to schizophrenia's cause.

title: Lost Years, but Found Serenity
description: Members of Alcoholics Anonymous come to know the Serenity Prayer: God, grant me the serenity to accept the things I cannot change; the courage to change the things I can; and the wisdom to know the difference.

title: Drug Abuse Problems Are on the Rise as the Labor Pool Shrinks
description: ILLEGAL drugs are a big problem for Garry M. Ritzky: too many of his job applicants use them. Mr. Ritzky, risk and human resources director for Turner Brothers Trucking Inc., a transportation and oil services company in Oklahoma City, is having a hard time finding candidates who are clean of cocaine, marijuana and heroin.

title: Retirement Foresight From the Younger Set
description: JUSTIN BIER is about to make the third annual contribution to his I.R.A. He has kept the money in Treasuries so far, but now that he has a tidy sum accumulated, he is scouting out equity investments.

description: As finance ministers from the world's leading industrialized countries gathered here today, the United States and its European allies identified a new villain in the Asian financial crisis: not currency market speculators, not the crony capitalists of Indonesia and Korea, but the paralyzed Japanese Government.

The Limu Coalition, composed of Kanaka Maoli (native Hawaiian) and other environmental groups, wishes to let readers know that there have indeed been illegal operators on our island for five years.

title: The Low Down
description: Down-to-earth shoes that keep pace with this spring's fashion.

title: Q&A/Michael Amoruso; Disabled Lawyer Chisels Away at Limits
description: UNTIL he was in the seventh grade, Michael Amoruso, hard of hearing and with a yet undiagnosed seeing problem, was kept in special classes at school -- ones that supposedly would help him but in fact, he said, did not. Finally, when he was mainstreamed in parochial school, he began to flourish academically. He went to college and then law school.

title: Prescribing a Fiscal Pill For a Long-Term Cure
description: New Jersey is awash in cash.

title: Allergic Reactions to Nuts Are Dangerous to Millions
description: With food-allergy awareness on the rise, nuts have become a major source of concern, with some schools banning peanut butter from the premises and restaurants and food processors scrambling to avoid inadvertently mixing nuts with other foods.

title: Fiercely Competitive, Skaters Pursue the Dream
description: AS the Olympic flame fades over Nagano, young skaters across the Island are dreaming of future Olympiads. Already the stage is set for Sara Hughes of Kings Point, the reigning National Junior Champion, who is a strong contender to represent the United States in Salt Lake City in 2002. But Sara Hughes is not alone. Hundreds of young skaters on Long Island wake up before sunrise every morning to pursue the perfection of body and spirit that the sport demands.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: PLENTY GOOD ROOM

title: Five Months and Burned Bridge In Yonkers Set for Comeback
description: EARLY in the morning of Oct. 9 last fall, a gasoline tanker and a small passenger car collided on Central Park Avenue in Yonkers directly beneath the northbound lanes of the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway. The driver of the passenger vehicle was killed, and 8,800 gallons of Texaco gasoline exploded and burned.

title: In the Region/Long Island; In a Strong Market, Many Deals Close Quickly
description: IN September 1955, the owners of a 250-year-old colonial in Oyster Bay Cove put their six-bedroom, five-and-a-half bath house up for sale for $975,000. They later reduced the price to $895,000, still with no success, and finally pulled it off the market 11 months after listing it.

title: Mining Generations of Living Experience
description: A DREARY winter day, with snow and sleet competing for attention, would tempt most people to remain indoors, but not the group gathered in the library of the Raymond E. Baldwin Center in Stratford on a recent morning.

title: The Nation: Tobacco Talks; Congress Mulls a Commercial Break
description: IT would be ''absolutely impermissible'' for the Government to block lawsuits against the tobacco companies, David A. Kessler, the former Commissioner of Food and Drugs, said last week. ''There should be no concessions to this industry.''

title: Lives; The Conversion Diet
description: You can laugh at the array of little tinted bottles of arcane nutritional supplements that today's health devotees amass on their kitchen counters like a huddle of voodoo dolls. These worrywarts must see in these pills the magic of Lourdes.

title: Cast Your Magazine Upon the Waters
description: Recently we took our literary magazine, Open City, to the streets. Setting up a table at the corner of Prince and Wooster Streets, next to the Korean sunglasses salesman, the illicit tarot card reader and the elderly black woman selling her handmade handbags in pastel shades, we flogged our journal -- judged ''ambitiously highbrow'' by The New York Times and one of ''the 10 best magazines of the year'' by Library Journal -- to anyone we could get to stop and pay attention to us. To the SoHo procession of tourist families, art gallery interns, fashion stylists, photographers and local laborers, we must have presented an anomalous and perhaps desperate sight. But that didn't prevent the vast majority from ignoring us.

title: Ideas & Trends; In the Game of Cloning, Women Hold All the Cards
description: THE shocking notion that, some day, it might be possible to clone human beings seems to propel ethicists, press pundits and the like into flights of science fantasy. All offer their most provocative scenarios. And so, inevitably, do a few brave scientists.

title: Not Quite Gone, Far From Forgotten: Newark, Capital of Jazz
description: In the early part of the century, Newark was known as a ''ticklers town.'' The great black jazz piano players had to come and play in the clubs in the section called the Coast on their way to greatness. None other than Duke Ellington said in his memoirs that in the 1920's, one of the best places to hear black music was Newark.

title: Small Talk
description: Hannah Clarke, a 32-year-old entertainment publicity agent, unclipped her Motorola Startac 8600 V.I.P. cellular telephone from the strap of her Prada handbag and flipped it open to check her messages. She had an earlier model of the phone but felt compelled to upgrade when she heard about the new series.

title: A Question of Intelligence
description: Churchill and

title: A Search for Truth, or a Partisan Inquisition?; Paula Jones Paradox
description: To the Editor:

title: A Fresh Crop of Restaurants in L.A.
description: THE Los Angeles restaurant scene hasn't looked so vibrant in years. Angelenos who care about fine dining have been especially excited about the debut of Wolfgang Puck's new Spago Beverly Hills. This Spago, which opened last April, has relegated the original to its current name of Spago Hollywood. Mr. Puck deserves credit for raising the bar on California cuisine with his breathtaking Beverly Hills restaurant, but a couple of other hot arrivals are clearing it with him. Los Angeles also boasts two top-notch new places supplying a fortifying shot of tradition with authentic Italian and French cooking.

title: The Complaint Department; An El Morocco Before El Morocco
description: To the Editor:

title: February 15-21; Suspected Toxin and 2 Arrests
description: Two men in Las Vegas were charged with possession of a toxin believed to be anthrax, but testing showed the substance to be a nonlethal form of anthrax that could be used in making a vaccine, Federal authorities said.

title: LONG ISLAND OPINION; When a Life Is Defined in Houses
description: My husband and I sold our house, which we owned for 12 years. Though we did not move far away, major roads and hills make getting from the new neighborhood to the old in anything but a car not worth the risk. This house was our first and I still do my shopping near it. Recently, I stopped by our old corner. I slowed my car and looked from a safe distance at what used to be my house. I felt like I was spying on a former friend and, seeing this friend doing fine without me, hurt.

title: Kauai's Call
description: To the Editor: I read Don Wallace's ''Kauai's Call Is Irresistible'' (Jan. 18) with interest and concern. He leaves the impression that hiking at night in Hawaii, and specifically on the Kalalau Trail, is fun.

title: Enterprising Russian Team Hasn't Forgotten World-Beater Roots
description: Look at that middle-aged man with the dark hair and the famous face, walking in and out of the Russian dressing room at the Olympic Games. Is that Vladislav Tretiak, one of the greatest goalies in world hockey history? Yes, it is. Now he is coaching the goalies for the Russian national team.

title: Corrections
description: A review on page 8 of The Times Book Review today about ''The Dream Palace of the Arabs,'' by Fouad Ajami, includes an erroneous reference to the death of an Arab poet, taken from the reviewer's advance proofs. The writer who died after the exile of Adonis (Ali Ahmad Said) to Paris was Saadallah Wannous; Adonis remains alive.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Park Slope, Brooklyn; Where the Past Is an Abiding Presence
description: FOR children raised in Park Slope, a premier Brooklyn neighborhood richly laden with advantages, impoverished beginnings can never be an excuse for later failures.

title: Footloose
description: Reaching new elevations for spring, the mule goes ultrafeminine.

title: Familiar Pages for the Dormant Plant Tender
description: THERE'S nothing like a good book to soothe the waiting time before outdoors becomes irresistible. Everyone has a few favorites in the home library. Here are just a few personal choices -- some quite worn from many years of reading or reference, a few alas now out of print, some classics and others brand new.

title: Gretchen Smith, A. R. McFarland
description: Gretchen Anne Smith and Andrew Roberts McFarland were married yesterday at St. Paul's United Methodist Church in Houston. The Rev. L. James Bankston, a United Methodist minister, officiated at the ceremony, in which the Rev. Peter Larsen, an Episcopal priest, took part.

title: Older, Wilder Paris
description: Oh joy and goody goody for MIDNIGHT (1939), Billy Wilder's deft romantic comedy, with Claudette Colbert as an American chorine stranded in France and entangled with worldlings. There's an outspoken cabbie (Don Ameche), a pretty aristocrat (Mary Astor), her roving young paramour (Francis Lederer) and her rich old husband (John Barrymore). Ms. Colbert finds herself at a swank chateau party and in a marital mess, as amusing as it is chaotic. The best part is the early Paris musicale introducing the sly drollery of Barrymore, who pockets his every scene. But the whole thing, with its sporting cast and Continental flavor, spins and winks with mischief -- Wednesday at 1:15 P.M. on AMC. Howard Thompson

title: Corrections
description: The New & Noteworthy column on page 32 of The Times Book Review today misstates the title of a paperback about Andy Warhol by Victor Bockris. It is ''Warhol.'' (''The Life and Death of Andy Warhol'' was the hardcover edition, in 1989.)

title: The Complaint Department; Roosevelt Avenue Has Caring Neighbors
description: To the Editor:

title: Q&A: Fred Chernow; Trouble With Memory? He Has Remedies.
description: FRED CHERNOW is unforgettable. He has ways of making sure you'll remember everything he says, even if you've been known to misplace your keys or forget your spouse's birthday. After 37 years as a New York City school teacher and principal, Mr. Chernow now spends his time as a memory consultant to offer hope for all those who have walked into a room and forgotten why they went there.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DRABKIN, STEVEN WAYNE
description: DRABKIN-Steven Wayne. 10/19/61-2/23/81. The heart hath its own memory, like the mind, and in it are enshrined his precious keepsakes. Loving Family

title: Until Ed McMahon Calls, They Need to Slice Debt
description: TWICE a month, Elizabeth Genel sits down at the dining table in her seaside condominium to face a small mountain of bills. Fortified with a Pop Tart and a Diet Coke, she makes short work of the stack, reducing it to nothing in 60 minutes flat. At the same time, unfortunately, she also levels the family checking account.

title: The Gore Guide to the Future
description: On the evening of january 14, president clinton summoned his closest advisers to the Yellow Oval Room in the White House family quarters to map out how best to promote the upcoming State of the Union Message.The deliberations turned to a more urgent political matter: how to rescue the Vice President.

title: Women at 50
description: To the Editor:

title: The Sort of Renown That Would Make Any Troupe Green
description: ONE MORNING back in 1975, Garry Hynes was sitting with her friend Marie Mullen in a coffee shop in the small town of Galway on the western coast of Ireland. They had just left the local university and, with the breezy optimism of youth, planned to start the first fully professional theater company anywhere in Ireland outside Dublin. But they had to choose a name for it or the bank would not open an account.

title: Corrections
description: A picture on page 26 of the Arts and Leisure section today, with an article about the actor Rufus Sewell, was published in error and is credited erroneously. It is his portrait, not a scene from the film ''Dark City.'' It is by Nathaniel Welch, for The New York Times.

title: Strategies For Selling A Co-op
description: WHILE the basic strategy for selling an apartment is the same as that for selling a single-family house -- accentuate the positive and, if possible, eliminate the negative -- community living often makes some additional strategies necessary.

title: Anton Rosenberg, a Hipster Ideal, Dies at 71
description: Anton Rosenberg, a storied sometime artist and occasional musician who embodied the Greenwich Village hipster ideal of 1950's cool to such a laid-back degree and with such determined detachment that he never amounted to much of anything, died on Feb. 14 at a hospital near his home in Woodstock, N.Y. He was 71 and best known as the model for the character Julian Alexander in Jack Kerouac's novel ''The Subterraneans.''

title: The Boys in the Burbs
description: TWO GUYS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, LIONEL EDWARD
description: GORDON-Lionel Edward. Of Pompano Beach, FL. Loving husband of Maxine and the late Ethel Levy; father of Judith, Stefanie and Amy, brother of Jeanne Schwinger and the late David

title: The Big City; Calling All Noisebusters
description: In the past, i've advocated vigilantism (read ''eggs'') as the best weapon against car alarms and other noise pollution, but clearly this strategy isn't working. While crime has dropped, noise complaints to the city have risen sharply. Noise is easily the most common quality-of-life lament. City officials have recently increased the fines for noise polluters, but the new penalties aren't likely to do much good, either. Anti-noise zealots require better weapons. We must unleash the three most powerful social forces on the planet today: capitalism, environmentalism and the determination of New York parents to get their children into the right schools.

title: No Substitute for the Real Thing
description: HALF A century ago Walter Benjamin famously predicted that mechanical reproduction would eradicate the aura of the original art object for the masses, who are ''bent toward overcoming the uniqueness of every reality by accepting its reproduction.'' Benjamin's prediction is now a mantra of Internet advocates, for example. When images of virtually all art are available on line at the touch of a mouse, they say, people will lose their craving for originals.

title: Donald Trump's Plans
description: With plans for two golf courses under way, Donald Trump, the Atlantic City real estate developer, is proposing to build a third one in Westchester. His latest plans call for an 18-hole golf course in Yorktown on 155 acres off the Taconic State Parkway known as French Hill.

title: February 15-21; Dismissed
description: The United States Holocaust Memorial Museum forced out its director a month after its embarrassing on-again, off-again invitation to the Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat. The museum invited him, then disinvited him, then re-invited him. In the end, Mr. Arafat declined.

title: Full Speed Ahead
description: Those of us who look to fashion to anchor us in the moment have been hard pressed for some time now to find clothes that haven't been lifted straight out of another decade. The retro impulse has been rampant not only in fashion but also in design, in pop music, in Broadway revivals and Hollywood remakes: our culture has become a hall of mirrors, refracting the styles of the past. Considering how much easier it is to copy a flea-market find than to invent something new, it is perhaps no wonder that in recent years we've felt as if we were living in an era without its own identity. Of the two recognizable trends that have so far distinguished the 90's in fashion, grunge was over before it began, and minimalism, prescribed as a hangover remedy for the morning after the 80's, is a movement that dates back some 30 years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHULSKY, MARIE
description: SHULSKY-Marie. Mirrer Yeshiva Central Institute, 1791-5 Ocean Parkway, Brooklyn, NY expresses its heartfelt sorrow and condolences upon the recent passing of Mrs. Marie Shulsky, wife of Mr. Rubin Shulsky, Chairman of Our Board of Directors. She is survived by her husband, Mr. Rubin Shulsky and daughter, Rena. May the AMighty shield the family from further sorrow.

title: On Marijuana
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Make the Rounds In Midtown
description: CHURRASCARIA PLATAFORMA** [Rating: Two Stars]

title: Pushing the Ceramic Into the Metaphorical Realm
description: Phyllis Kudder-Sullivan

title: A Search for Truth, or a Partisan Inquisition?; Different Breed of Leak
description: To the Editor:

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Dodge Ram Quad Cab; A Grand Slam in the Door Wars
description: TRUCKS are the big thing, and the biggest-selling trucks are large indeed. Americans bought nearly three million pickups last year, about two-thirds of them ''full sized'' -- an understatement given how hefty these haulers have become.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: HUDSON WATERFRONT; A New Voice for the Sailors
description: The latest in the long history of activist groups concerned with development along the Hudson is the Working Waterfront Association, a group whose members are engaged in small-time commerce in and around the river.

title: Adam Purple's Last Stand
description: IT'S a bright Sunday morning and the sole resident of 184 Forsyth Street, a small, spry man with a long gray beard, is in his backyard performing his most cherished ritual.

title: Word for Word / Consensual Relationship Agreements; For Water Cooler Paramours, The Ties That (Legally) Bind
description: YOU know what a prenuptial agreement is, but did you know there's a similar sort of agreement for when you want to get hot and heavy with that sexy someone over by the copying machine?

title: A Big Night for Rap, but Not All Stars Shone
description: THE SETTING: The blistering beat of the floors at Cheetah, the Chelsea club where, on Tuesday night, silver disco balls hung from bright red ceilings as button-down MTV executives mixed with leather-clad rap and hip-hop legends: a precursor party for an upcoming MTV special, ''Back in the Day'' on the history of hip hop.

title: Kauai's Call
description: To the Editor: Kauai is indeed irresistible. As a frequent visitor, I would add one suggestion, to explore the option of staying at a bed-and-breakfast inn.

title: The Complaint Department; On the Boundaries Of the Comfort Zone
description: To the Editor:

title: A Palette of Light
description: As a stained-glass artist, J. Kenneth Leap brings good stories to light. Using literary, historical and Biblical subjects, he creates windows with bold lines, realistically painted forms and eye-catching colors. Connecting the traditions of the past with the needs of the present, Mr. Leap hopes his viewers will always ''see something new, find something that holds their interest.''

title: Cold Water For the Hot-Fund Strategy
description: HOT funds, it seems, can burn investors.

title: An Encore for Lipinski Hasn't Been Chiseled in Ice
description: Kevin Costner watched her from the stands. The Governor of Michigan called to offer congratulations. Even Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright called, presumably wanting to talk about salchows instead of Scuds. And when Tara Lipinski went to bed on Friday night, she clutched her gold medal as if it were a teddy bear.

title: Cigars to Go
description: It was bound to happen in these fast-paced times. A steak-and-seafood restaurant outside Washington now has something for the on-the-go cigar lover: a drive-through humidor. The restaurant, Sam & Harry's, in Tysons Corner, Va., opened on Feb. 9 in a former bank. Instead of offering deposit slips at the drive-through window, it is serving up Macanudos and Davidoffs.

title: Get Smart? He'd Rather Not
description: I don't know about you, but as far as I'm concerned, my current New Jersey driver's license, with its jaunty red stripe and its grandiose 15-digit serial number, is about as smart as I want any driver's license to be. (Incidentally, why does Trenton need all those digits, when the Federal Social Security system scrapes by with a mere nine digits for every American, dead and alive, since the New Deal?)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARA, GERALD B., M.D.
description: KARA-Gerald B., M.D. Memorial services for Dr. Gerald Kara wiil be at St. Vartans Armenian Church, 630 Second Avenue, Thursday, February 26, at 3PM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The New York Eye and Ear Infirmary. S. Liebowitz, M.D.

title: Picking the Flowers Of the Revolution
description: Let me see if I have this straight. Last month, you ran a sympathetic article about the efforts of a Florida TV station to keep from going tabloid. Then you publish Andrei Codrescu's ''Picking the Flowers of the Revolution'' (Feb. 1), which tells us where to go to procure young, beautiful women at bargain-basement rates. While Codrescu takes just the right tone of reprimand for this outrageous situation (in the interest of journalistic verisimilitude, I'm sure), he ends by describing how one such waif felt in his arms: ''She is a flare,'' symbolizing socialist Cuba's demise. But still, pandering is pandering.

title: Americans Are Heeding The Call of the Loon
description: The Canadian ''loonie'' has been attracting Americans in record numbers. Canadian currency -- which has a loon pictured on the one-dollar coin -- is trading near its all-time low, having dropped nearly 10 percent in value over the last year.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DENERSTEIN, EZRA J.
description: DENERSTEIN-Ezra J. Six years today. Forever in my heart and thoughts. Rita

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOWNSEND, CHARLOTTE S.
description: TOWNSEND-Charlotte S. Suddenly, of an aneurism, on February 20, 1998 in Devon, PA. Vibrant and warm, she was our beloved materfamilias. Widow of Charles C. Townsend and of John K. Ewing, 3rd. Fond mother of the late John D. Ames, Jr. of Glenview, IL, William S. Ames of Boston, MA and Knowlton Ames Reynders of Bedford Hills, NY, and stepmother of Charles C. Townsend, Jr. of Hopewell, NJ, Barbara T. Crawford of Devon PA, and Caroline E. Michahelles of Florence, Italy. She prized her ten devoted grandchildren and her eight great grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at Washington Memorial Chapel, Valley Forge, PA on Saturday, March 7 at 1:00 PM.

title: Ideas & Trends: Team Work; All for One, One for All and Every Man for Himself
description: THESE days, it seems everyone is a team player, willingly or not.

title: Players' Lament: Good Money, Bad Timing
description: Around the National Football League, there are players who signed new contracts in 1997 who must be choking on their Cheerios as they hear about the latest contracts on the radio or see them in newspapers.

title: Reading With Your Ears
description: A hospital bed can be an isolated place, especially when you are groggy or otherwise uncomfortable, unable to focus on a printed page or that little television set. And in any case, ''Hard Copy'' might not be the window on the world you would prefer. But as of last month, television offers something else for patients at St. Barnabas Medical Center in Livingston. A service called TV Reader, broadcast from 7 A.M. to midnight through the set's sound device, features live readings from newspapers (including this one, The Star Ledger of Newark, The Wall Street Journal), magazines (American Heritage, The New Yorker) and books.

title: Factions of Von Trapp Family Are Fighting in Court Over Money
description: The von Trapps, a family known around the world, asked the Vermont Supreme Court this week to resolve a bitter financial dispute between two factions of the family.

title: L'ecole de Flathead
description: With the Food Network broadcasting around the clock, you might assume

title: Guardian of Procedure in Clinton Inquiry
description: Keith Watters, a prominent criminal defense lawyer, says he was amused last week after White House lawyers went into Federal District Court here to stop leaks in the grand jury investigation into the relationship of President Clinton and Monica S. Lewinsky.

title: Al Gore and the Temple of Cash
description: It took more than a year of prodding to get the Justice Department interested in how the White House and the Democratic National Committee financed the 1996 campaign, but the indictments are flowing now. Maria Hsia is charged with laundering over $55,000 from the Buddhist temple luncheon for Vice President Al Gore on April 29, 1996. A Senate committee's charge that Ms. Hsia was a Chinese intelligence agent during an eight-year period when she worked closely with Mr. Gore and the D.N.C. has yet to be proved, but the tale of those years is too important to be lost amid war talk and sex scandals.

title: Coyote Season Tally: 900 Hunters, 11 Kills
description: The 900 hunters who went after Eastern coyotes during the hunting season earlier this month nearly tripled the number of animals they shot last season -- 11 compared with 4 -- but they still did not make a dent in the coyote population.

title: Tests Indicate Seized Material Is Nonlethal Form of Anthrax
description: Laboratory tests of material seized as potentially deadly anthrax bacteria in Las Vegas, Nev., this week found that it was actually a harmless veterinary vaccine used to prevent anthrax and could not spread the disease to animals or humans, the authorities said today.

title: POSTINGS: Real Estate Board Conference; Learning About The Market
description: It will be a nuts and bolts session on issues of moment to Manhattan's residential brokers.

title: In 2002, Get Ready For Tomba The Tourist
description: He wanted to go out a winner, or at the very least, a medalist. Alberto Tomba did not do either in Japan.

title: Habitats/175 East 71st Street, 221 East 61st Street; The Ups and Downs Of Selling and Buying
description: A YEAR ago, a desire for more green space in the back of their minds, Michael C. and Alexandra Mulitz decided to test the market for their duplex in an East Side town house.

title: Organized Crime Has Reorganized, So F.B.I. Follows Suit
description: Decades of law-enforcement assaults have succeeded in draining much of the vitality of the Mafia, once America's most powerful organized crime group, and younger generations of the traditional crime families have moved increasingly into legitimate businesses. That has created room for new groups to move into heroin distribution, robbery, extortion and fraud.

title: CHIEF OF U.N. SEES GLIMMER OF HOPE IN BAGHDAD TALKS
description: Emerging from his first round of talks with Iraqi leaders in his last-ditch effort to find a solution to the standoff over United Nations weapons inspections, Secretary General Kofi Annan said today that he hoped to be able to return to New York next week with a written agreement.

title: A Search for Truth, or a Partisan Inquisition?; Civil Service Escapades
description: To the Editor:

title: School Uniforms
description: New York City is considering uniforms in its schools. Liz Morrisey's journalism students at Midland Park High School talk about uniforms.

title: If Voltaire Had Been a Czech . . .
description: SHEDDING LIFE

title: Martin Duffy Jr., Sheila Lahey
description: Sheila Campbell Lahey and Martin Joseph Duffy Jr. were married on Friday by the Rev. Andrew G. Varga at St. Luke's Roman Catholic Church in Westport, Conn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINGATE, JUDITH WAGNER
description: WINGATE-Judith Wagner. Age 63 suffered a brain aneurysm and passed away suddenly on February 21, 1998. Judy spent most of her life caring for others. She was a strong caring mother and loved her husband, children and family so much. She recently ceased full time employment on January 31 as a nurse clinician in the Osteoporosis Center at the Hospital for Special Surgery in New York. Before her latest career at the Hospital for Special Surgery, she spent many years as a dialysis nurse. In addition to her career and family she spent many hours volunteering with the Junior League of Brooklyn and Northern Westchester. Judy is survived by her husband John, her daughter Jennifer, her sons Jack and Jeff as well as two grandchildren, Julia and Jane. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, February 24th, 11 A.M., at The Congregational Church of Huntington, 30 Washington Dr, off of Rt 25A North, Centerport, NY. In lieu of flowers if donations would like to be made in her name, please send to VIBS (Victims Information Bureau of Suffolk), a domestic violence agency where Judy was a Board member, P.O. Box 5483, Hauppauge, NY 11788. Her family misses her very much. We love you Mom.

title: Beyond the Virtual Pet: Nano Fighters
description: Once, there was peace in the land of virtual pets. Tamagotchis, those electronic imports from Japan, were free to be born, live and die in the clutches of their mostly pre-teen owners.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-11

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CURREY, DAVID P.
description: CURREY-David P. of Erieville, NY, February 20, after a long illness. Cornell, '65, devoted to the dairy industry. Husband of Ruth, father of David and Matthew.

title: When a Smorgasbord Replaces a Diet Plate in a 401(k)
description: MARIANNE SANTISTEVAN is a 41-year-old supermarket clerk and mutual fund fanatic.

title: A TV Generation Is Seeing Beyond Color
description: IT'S NOT HARD to figure out why, come Mondays at 9 P.M., Anna-Lucille Calabrese can be found parked in front of ''Buffy the Vampire Slayer.'' Like Buffy, the heroine of the hip hourlong drama on WB about a girl who reluctantly takes on the task of ridding her high school of an infestation of the undead, Anna-Lucille, 13, is bright, popular and tinged with teen-age irony.

title: Somers Youth Meets His 'Jeopardy!' Match
description: IF you want to keep a secret, tell Sahir Islam, who won $5,000 in the ''Jeopardy!'' $100,000 Tournament of Champions and did not tell anyone for a month.

title: In Full Swing
description: Pleated or voluminous, spring's charmed circle is the skirt.

title: February 15-21; Top Cops
description: Despite the nation's declining crime rate, there are still problems in big city police departments, like corruption and brutality.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, DAVID
description: MILLER-David. The officers and employees of Young & Rubicam Inc. note with sadness the passing of its retired general counsel and revered counselor. No one did more to establish and maintain the character and principles of the agency and its people. We send our deepest sympathy to his wife Sally and his two children.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTH, DEBORAH IRIS BUSSICHIO AND GILLIAN MACKENZIE
description: ROTH-Deborah Iris Bussichio and Gillian Mackenzie, on February 18, of South Salem, New York. Beloved wife and daughter of Arlen. Loving mother and sister of Alexis Leah. Cherished daughter and grandduaghter of Theresa and the late Salvatore Bussichio. Loving sister and niece of Dennis Bussichio. Loving daughter-in-law and granddaughter of Abraham and Sylvia Roth. Reposing at Clark Associates Funeral Home, Katonah, New York, Saturday, 4-7PM. Funeral services at Temple Shaaray Tefila of Westchester, Bedford Corners, NY, on Sunday morning. Interment, South Salem Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the local chapter of The Nature Conservancy.

title: February 15-21; A Moot Beef
description: In the continuing slugfest between Oprah Winfrey and the Texas cattlemen accusing her of defaming their beef, the talk-show host scored a round, big time.

title: Top-Ranked Tar Heels Humbled by Wolfpack
description: For one memorable afternoon, the best team on the floor of the Dean Smith Center was not the No. 1-ranked team in the nation. For 40 shocking minutes, the team that best executed its plan was the one with three freshmen in its starting lineup and four among its top six players.

title: If It's Not Breakfast, Do Not Disturb
description: LET others rank museum visits, transcendent vistas, cathedral spires and historic sites as topmost reasons for European travel. It's a measure of my blunted esthetic that the morning arrival of a breakfast tray at my hotel-room door is a high point of my day.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: Journeying from page to screen, books enrich the films on television this week.

title: Rutgers Gets a Confidence Booster
description: Rutgers 62, Syracuse 58

title: The Complaint Department; Two Little Words, So Much Confusion
description: To the Editor:

title: Transit Worker Is Injured In a Subway Explosion
description: An explosion in a Manhattan subway last night left a transit worker seriously injured and disrupted train service along the N and R lines for nearly 45 minutes, transit officials said.

title: Double Bind
description: To the Editor:

title: Where Nijinsky and Pavlova Did Their First Plies
description: RUSSIAN BALLET has fascinated audiences in the West for nearly 100 years, and anyone who wants to know why can find out this week, when a group of young dancers from St. Petersburg arrives at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Starting Wednesday, 65 students of the renowned Vaganova Ballet Academy will appear in four performances with recent graduates who are now stars of the Kirov Ballet.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: THE CONSUL'S WIFE

title: This Is a Player
description: It is another n.b.a. saturday night, the arena filled with artificial noise and flashing lights as the 10 starters wander onto the court with the practiced casualness of men who take the rapt attention of thousands for granted.

title: Different Audiences
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHERTOFF, SKIP
description: CHERTOFF-Skip. On February 20, 1998. Beloved husband of Toni. Loving father of Deirdre Lee. Services Sunday, 12:15 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: CBS Erred In Its Choice Of Studio Host
description: In their post-mortems, CBS executives will say Jim Nantz performed well as the prime-time host of the Winter Olympics. They have to say that. They paid a bundle to keep him last year and anointed him a versatile television prince.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COGEN, CHARLES
description: COGEN-Charles. Died on February 18 in Washington, D.C. Husband of the late Tess Cogen, father of Joel and Edward, father-in-law of Beth Gilson, Sarah M. Cogen and Ruth Prager Cogen, grandfather of Jessica Cogen, Jeffrey Cogen, Deborah Cogen Swartz and Mark Cogen, and great-grandfather of ten. Services Sunday, February 22, at Riverside Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York City, at 12:30 PM. Contributions may be made to Cornell University (Development Office, Ithaca, NY 14850), Jewish Labor Committee, Educators' Chapter (25 E. 21st St., NYC 10010) or Parkinson's Disease Foundation (710 W. 168th St., NYC 10032).

title: Thumbs Up For Venice, Art, Dogs And More
description: While some revelers go to exhibitions, some others make exhibitions of themselves.

title: A Soup for All Seasons, Fresh From the Garden State
description: When the New Jersey Historical Society in Newark observed National Soup Month in January, it invited chefs to demonstrate favorite recipes. One of them was Tim Shafer of Tim Schafer's Cuisine in Morristown, would cheerfully steam up your kitchen windows on a cold winter day. It will taste at least as good this summer when fresh Jersey tomatoes and other vegetables are at their peak.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZEIDMAN, EUGENE M.
description: ZEIDMAN-Eugene M. Age 93, on February 17, 1998, peacefully at home in Birmingham, Alabama. Attorney and long time leader of Birmingham Jewish community. His wife of 57 years, Ida Fisher Zeidman, and grandson, John Fisher Zeidman predeceased him. Survived by daughter, Adele Z. Silver of Cleveland, Ohio, son Philip F. Zeidman of Washington, DC, five grandchildren, Jonathan (Melissa), Michael (Deborah), and Sarah Silver and Betsy and Jennifer Zeidman and two great-grandchildren. Memorial gifts may be made to Zeidman Family Center for Chinese Studies at Sidwell Friends School, Washington, DC or Daniel Jeremy Silver Fellowship, Center for Jewish Studies, Harvard University, Cambridge, MA.

title: Austria
description: To the Editor: About the article by Jane Perlez, ''Austrians Are Puzzled by Lagging Tourism'' (Dec. 14): My two visits to Austria have convinced me there are places much more desirable for spending my time and money.

title: February 15-21; A Charge of Wrongdoing
description: The indictment of Maria Hsia, the second Democratic fund-raiser to be charged with criminal wrongdoing in less than a month, suggested that the Justice Department's investigation into campaign finance was picking up steam after a year of Republican criticism that it was drifting under Attorney General Janet Reno. Ms. Hsia appeared in Washington to plead not guilty to a six-count indictment accusing her of disguising illegal contributions from a Buddhist temple in California to President Clinton's re-election campaign. ''I have done nothing wrong and I am prepared to fight,'' Ms. Hsia said. DAVID JOHNSTON

title: Lost Hopes of the Arabs
description: THE DREAM PALACE OF THE ARABS

title: February 15-21; Motor Voter, Delta Style
description: Mississippi has grown accustomed to being last over the years, and it remained true to form. After a vote in the State House of Representatives Thursday, it became the final state to pass legislation for voter registration at drivers' license bureaus and social services offices, as mandated under the 1993 Federal motor voter.

title: Once Upon a Hickory Ski, Still on Patrol
description: CLARENCE ROSENBECK knew he was on to something when, as a teen-ager, he received a gift of hickory skis with leather toe straps. He practiced in the yard of his Torrington home, then took to the woods using branches for poles. Soon he bought steel-edged downhill skis from Sears Roebuck and after learning that President Roosevelt's Civilian Conservation Corps had cleared a trail at Mohawk Mountain State Park in Cornwall, he and three friends tied their skis to the roof of a car and headed east on Route 4. No ski lifts existed in the 1930's, but Mr. Rosenbeck and his pals made do: They took turns driving the others to the top of the mountain.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: MAKING THE CORPS

title: English Leather
description: The Avengers

title: THE GUIDE
description: Scouting for Bald Eagles

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENZER, SYLVIA
description: ENZER-Sylvia. On February 16, 1998. Beloved wife of Michael. Devoted mother of Roberta Kahn and Sharon Enzer. Cherished grandmother of Scott and Audra. Loving sister of Jules Weinstein.

title: Breathless Dahlie Wins 8th Gold
description: Bjorn Dahlie crossed the finish line for the final time in what was almost certainly his final Olympics and pitched forward as if he had been shot from behind.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, a word is truncated in a headline today on page 96 of Women's Fashions of the Times, Part 2 of The Times Magazine. The headline should read, ''Spring Training: Team Seventh Avenue Takes the Field.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPRINGER, FRED
description: SPRINGER-Fred. The Board of Directors, administration, Medical Research Advisory Board, volunteers and members of the American Parkinson Disease Association, Inc, mourn the passing of longtime member of the Board of Directors, Fred Springer. He served as President Emeritus and Treasurer until his passing. Mr. Springer lead the organization as President from 1965 until 1988. He and his late wife, Faye, were guiding forces of the Rockaway chapter (now named the Faye Springer Memorial Chapter), as charter board members. Mr. Springer has been an exemplary member since the formation of the APDA 37 years ago. His service and devotion to help ''ease the burden and find the cure'' for Parkinson's Disease patients and their families, will be remembered with fond admiration. Sincere condolences to his son Jay Springer. John W. Pillarella, Sr., President, Board of Directors American Parkinson Disease Association, Inc. Joel Gerstel, Executive Director American Parkinson Disease Association Inc.

title: ON THE MAP; Where 150 Million M&M;'s Are Churned Out, a Taste of Secrecy
description: On Main Street in rural Hackettstown, in Warren County, the air carries the unmistakable scent of chocolate.

title: It's No Wonder Few Are Watching
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Kauai's Call
description: To the Editor: Don Wallace described the call of Kauai so well we can't wait to return to the Garden Isle.

title: Reconstructing Central Park's Black History
description: To Cynthia R. Copeland, Central Park is filled with ghosts -- and this month, those ghosts went on the Internet.

title: At the Casinos
description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week.

title: Q and A
description: Down on the Farm

title: Spring Training
description: Seventh Avenue Takes the Field

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAFT, NORMAN
description: KRAFT-Norman. My friend of more than 60 years, I miss him already. Humor, intellect, compassion and empathy were his hallmarks. Fiercely loyal to his family, his friends, and his people. Normie, thanks for the memories. Harold Zweighaft

title: Injury Ends Sales's Career Just Short of Record
description: With just one regular-season game left in her senior year, Nykesha Sales's basketball career at the University of Connecticut is over.

title: The Iraq Agreement
description: A definitive assessment of the deal United Nations Secretary General Kofi Annan struck with Saddam Hussein over the weekend must await disclosure of the details this week. But as sketched out by Mr. Annan's aides yesterday, the arrangement would appear to defuse the Iraq crisis, at least temporarily. By agreeing to permit unrestricted inspection of previously closed presidential sites, Mr. Hussein has ended Iraq's most flagrant defiance of the Security Council resolutions adopted in the wake of the Persian Gulf war. But the agreement, because it is limited to eight contested sites, leaves open the possibility of Iraqi belligerence about other locations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAGNER, MARK
description: WAGNER-Mark. On February 20, 1998. Beloved husband of Sheila. Loving father of Brian, Caren, Holly, Roger and Carolyn. Devoted son of Beatrice and Henry. Dear brother of Charlene and Corinne. Adoring grandfather of Ryan and Rachel. He will also be greatly missed by his partner and friend, Saul Kalender.

title: Despite Threat of Missiles, the Iraqi Capital's People Take a Crisis in Stride
description: In a city where crucial negotiations about the fate of Iraq's 22 million people might be headed toward an optimistic resolution, the people of Baghdad seemed cool and placid today -- almost nonchalant.

title: Race Discrimination Furthers Income Inequality; More Vocational Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Retooled Indians Resume Their Quest
description: No, Mike Hargrove said, he hasn't heard any spring-training talk among the players about his team's excruciating extra-inning loss in the seventh game of last year's World Series.

title: Mets Put a Stop to Sheffield Trade Talk
description: It seemed a logical fit. Gary Sheffield would have given the Mets the marquee slugger their lineup so desperately lacks. But trading with the Florida Marlins for Sheffield would also have forced the Mets to alter their outfield chemistry and assume a significant portion of his six-year, $61 million contract, which includes a no-trade clause and a $12 million option for a seventh year.

title: Leadership Plan Unravels at EMI
description: The future of EMI Group P.L.C.'s top music executive, James G. Fifield, was thrown into doubt late last week, according to people close to the executive and the company.

title: They Pledge Allegiance to the Bread; Disciples of a French Delicacy, 3 Malaysian Immigrants Bake With Conviction
description: When they arrived in New York City in the late 1980's, the three immigrants from the Malaysian capital of Kuala Lumpur did not expect to take up baking. Between them they could not tell a bagel from a hot dog bun.

title: Prostitutes on Wane In New York Streets But Take to Internet
description: The old prostitution haunts now crawl with nearly as many police officers as streetwalkers, part of New York City's continuing assault on ''quality of life'' crimes. Once-seedy areas where the sex business flourished, like Times Square, have given way to Disney-style family entertainment. And the combined forces of AIDS and drug addiction have further thinned the ranks of prostitutes on neighborhood streets.

title: Amid Blame, United Artists Sale Collapses
description: As soon as the sale of United Artists, the nation's third-largest theater chain, collapsed on Friday, the blame game began.

title: Abroad at Home; Sex and Leadership
description: Thirty-five years ago J. Edgar Hoover, obsessed by racist fears, began wiretapping and bugging Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. The eavesdropping caught Dr. King in apparent marital infidelity. The F.B.I. Director had a tape sent to him with an anonymous letter suggesting that Dr. King commit suicide or his ''filthy, abnormal self'' would be exposed.

title: Behind the Superman, an All-Too-Human Thinker
description: NIETZSCHE IN TURIN

title: Lincoln's Absolutism Could Be Relative; A Man of Compromise
description: To the Editor:

title: The Neediest Cases; Continuing to Give, Despite Obstacles Great and Small
description: A stolen car. Kidney stones. Unemployment. These misfortunes, which plowed into Joseph Leary's life just before Christmas, helped turn December and January into his ''winter of major discontent,'' as he put it.

title: Devils' Focus on Return Is Finishing Up Strong
description: Break is over. After five days on the beach in Barbados, Doug Gilmour was back at practice today, and so were more than a dozen of his Devils teammates who had been relaxing while the National Hockey League took a recess for the Olympics.

title: Monitor Bosnian Aid
description: To the Editor:

title: Movie studios may face more rigorous rules for how they keep their books.
description: THE DAYS when film accounting was more creative than many film scripts may soon be coming to an end.

title: French Bank to Buy Cowen for $540 Million
description: Societe Generale, the big French bank, said yesterday that it would pay $540 million in cash to acquire Cowen & Company, a New York investment bank that specializes in the health care, technology and communications industries.

title: Who's Lining Up At Box Office? Lots and Lots Of Girls; Studios Aim at Teen-Agers, A Vast, Growing Audience
description: Girl Power has seized the entertainment business.

title: INSIDE
description: Caterpillar Pact Rejected

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FREMER, FLORENCE
description: FREMER - Florence. Remem bered today and every day. Forever loved and missed. Sam, Judy, Sue, Mike, Bobby, Deb Jon, Dave, Jordan, Morgan, Grace

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The Secretary General expects that it will be acceptable to the Security Council -- all 15 members.''

title: Villains, Heroes And the N.H.L.'s Nagano Experience
description: Ron Wilson, the coach of the United States men's hockey team, sat in Big Hat arena late last week, watching national teams of rival coaches playing in the semifinals of the Olympic tournament.

title: Loses Job, Starts Company And Looks Like Tom Selleck
description: All those vague CBS promos for Tom Selleck's new sitcom turn out to be smarter than they seemed. They promised a Selleck comedy, without hinting what the show was about. Sure enough, the premise of ''The Closer'' is as mundane as they come, but this generic workplace comedy is redeemed by Mr. Selleck at his sly, charming best.

title: Editorial Notebook; Sorting the Trees in the Forest by Name
description: From a distance, the woods in winter look monochromatic, gray with undertones of dull red and olive, as if all the trees were a single species. But I awoke recently with a deep taxonomic yearning, a desire to sort the trees in the neighboring forest by name. This is the kind of inclination I always obey because there is no purer accession of knowledge than the one that transforms the character of your immediate environment. You could argue, I suppose, that naming the trees is just a surrender to the scientific demiurge. But it is actually a way of being drawn into the detail of the landscape.

title: Taking In the Sites; The Internet Gears Up For Conflict With Iraq
description: It has become fashionable recently to say the Internet has come of age as a news vehicle. As O. J. Simpson made his second run through the limelight, the Internet came of age. When robots landed on Mars, the Internet came of age.

title: Turmoil in India's Largest State Clouds Vote
description: India's system of staggered voting moved through the second of three crucial days today with 200 million voters going to the polls in a general election, but with an overall result still at least 10 days away the probable outcome became murkier than ever.

title: Fishing the Bridges In the Florida Keys
description: Henry Flagler, co-founder of Standard Oil, would probably not have wanted to be remembered as the Father of the Fishing Pier. But the fact remains that his doomed Key West Extension railroad, which toppled into Florida Bay during a hurricane in 1935, left behind what may be the greatest network of fishing platforms in the world.

title: Wearing a Crown and a Gardenia With an Ageless Grace
description: Unofficial crowns tend to weigh heavily on the heads that receive them. But Julie Wilson, the onetime 50's showgirl who has evolved into a grandly theatrical interpreter of popular standards, has earned the sobriquet ''queen of cabaret,'' taking over a title once held by Mabel Mercer. If history repeats itself, Ms. Wilson, who is playing an open-ended engagement at Michael's Pub at Bill's Gay 90's (57 East 54th Street, Manhattan), can establish herself as a regal longtime presence in its upstairs restaurant the way that Mercer did in several New York clubs during the 1950's and 60's.

title: Lincoln's Absolutism Could Be Relative
description: To the Editor:

title: Lil's Lad Takes Road to the Derby One Step at a Time
description: Ten weeks from the main event, the colt leading the parade of horses on the road to the Kentucky Derby is Lil's Lad, who scored a smashing victory Saturday in the Fountain of Youth Stakes at Gulfstream Park. But his trainer, Neil Howard, knows all about the hazards ahead.

title: Schweppes Is Said to Agree to a Bottling Deal
description: Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C., the maker of Dr Pepper and 7-Up, is expected to announce as early as today that it will acquire a pair of Midwestern bottling companies in a $730 million deal as the first step in creating a national distribution system of its own.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMS, JOSEPH
description: ABRAMS-Joseph. Age 89. On February 20, in Saratoga Springs, NY. Born March 7, 1908. Lifelong resident of Paterson and Totowa, NJ. Devoted husband of the late Ruth. Cherished father of Kenneth and daughter-in-law Madeline. Loving grandfather of Pamela, Ursula and Joshua. Great-grandfather of Mickey, Jamie and Miles. Services at Louis Funeral Chapel, Fairlawn, NJ, Monday, 1:30 PM. Visitors welcome at the home of Pam Abrams, Monday evening and anytime Tuesday. Contributions can be made out the Paterson Public Library System and sent care of Kenneth Abrams.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEN, SHIRLEY
description: ROSEN-Shirley. We mourn the untimely passing of a dear friend and ardent Hadassah supporter who fought her illness courageously and in high spirits to the very end. Our condolences to Leo and the entire family. Lenny and Sonia Lipton Ethyl Pelunis

title: Officers' Privilege
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRESCHLER, JULIA
description: GRESCHLER-Julia. On February 21, 1998. Beloved mother of Jerome (Gloria). Loving grandmother of Ira Greschler, Marlene Adams, and Jonathan Greschler, and great grandmother of six. Services Tuesday, February 24, 9:30 AM at ''Boulevard-Riverside Chapels'' 312 Coney Island Ave. at Prospect Park Circle, Brooklyn.

title: Agencies to Collaborate On Realtors Campaign
description: The National Association of Realtors in Chicago has selected two agencies, Townsend & O'Leary in Laguna Hills, Calif., and Richardson, Myers & Donofrio in Baltimore, to collaborate on the organization's first national campaign. Billings are estimated at $32.4 million over three years.

title: Woman Arrested in Beating Death of Foster Son
description: A Brooklyn woman was arrested yesterday on second-degree murder charges in the beating death of her 23-month-old foster son on Saturday morning, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GINSBERG, LOUIS
description: GINSBERG-Louis. Cherished son, deeply caring brother, and dear uncle. Devoted husband of the late Lillian Rosenblatt Ginsberg and the late Renee Haskin Ginsberg. Adored and adoring father of the late Bernice Ginsberg Segal. Beloved and loving grandfather of Elizabeth and Daniel, and granddaughter-in-law Laurie. Delighted great-grandfather of Hannah and Nathan. He was an inspiring mathematics teacher in Brooklyn public high schools for 40 years, and a generous and profoundly considerate human being. Contributions may be made to the Bernice G. Segal Summer Research Internships Fund at Barnard College or to the Carroll Center for the Blind in Newton, MA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNTON, HARLOW DONALD, M.D.
description: DUNTON-Harlow Donald, M.D. Of Cresskill, NJ, at home on February 21, 1998. Psychoanalyst and Professor of Child Psychiatry for the past 50 years at C.P.M.C. Beloved husband of Patricia (nee Hall). Devoted father of Craig D. of New Richland, MN, Timothy of Seattle, WA, and Lese of NYC. Father-in-law of Peggy of New Richland, MN, and six stepchildren. Dear brother of Russell of Wocott, NY, and Gary of Hamstead, NC. Loving grandfather of 18 grandchildren. Friends may call at the Barrett Funeral Home, 148 Dean Drive, Tenafly, NJ, on Tuesday, 6-9 PM. Interment private. A memorial service at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center will be announced at a later date.

title: Starks's Offense Meshes With a Stifling Defense
description: Life as a sixth man can be deadly on the ego. No one says your name during player introductions. Then you have to harness your nervous energy on the bench, wait your turn and hope against hope that you can kick-start the team before it is time to sit again.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALLAGHER, CATHERINE (NEE COX)
description: GALLAGHER - Catherine (nee Cox). On February 21, 1998. Mother of Sheila Hendricks, Nora Kennington, Catherine Gallagher and Maureen Markel. Viewing at Walter B. Cooke-Kennedy Funeral Home, Manhattan, Monday, February 23.

title: A Dramatic Puccini Love Story Returns to the Met
description: It is always wonderful to hear ''La Boheme'' sung by glorious voices. But even fledgling singers, if they are at least ardent and engaging, can bring this opera to life, which may be one reason it remains Puccini's most enduringly popular work.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBAUM, EVA MOLLIE
description: ROSENBAUM-Eva Mollie. Beloved wife of the late Max. Devoted mother of Daniel, Byron, Suzanne Rosen, and the late Dr. Jordan. Mother-in-law of Claire, Jeannette, Arthur Rosen, and Roslyn. Cherished grandmother of twelve. Great-grandmother of seven. Services 12 noon, Monday, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Times Appoints Editorial Writer
description: Eleanor Randolph, a national correspondent for The Los Angeles Times who is based in New York City, is joining the editorial board of The New York Times today. Her appointment as an editorial writer was announced by Howell Raines, editorial page editor.

title: Solving the Pumpkin Mystery
description: Soon to be answered at Cornell University: What exactly is impaled atop the bell tower? These are some theories offered by passers-by on campus yesterday.

title: Race Discrimination Furthers Income Inequality; Statistics Can Deceive
description: To the Editor:

title: Sweeping Changes Said to Be Near for Oxford
description: Oxford Health Plans, one of the New York region's largest health maintenance organizations, is close to announcing that it will make sweeping changes to its top management and that it has raised more than $600 million in badly needed capital, according to people involved in the negotiations.

title: A Hearty Stew of Influences Enriches Hungarian Works
description: Looking for the pure center of Hungarian music is like removing the layers of an onion only to find that the object of your search is the peelings you have thrown aside. Hungarian music is many things at many times, and the overlay of Romanian and Transylvanian strains, the heavy hand of first Jewish and then Gypsy musicians, and finally the Hungarian-ness that Germans and Austrians distilled and filtered into their own music, all discourage systematic history-making.

title: Spanish Publishers Look to Latin America
description: Spanish publishers have seen just about everything imaginable wreck their sales in Latin America, from hyperinflation and devaluations to dictators prone to censor books. They have lost money and at times retreated from the region which one industry veteran termed ''the tomb.''

title: Van Horn Blames Himself for Nets' Three-Game Slide
description: In the moments after the Nets' third consecutive loss on Saturday night, Coach John Calipari had the reason figured out, pinning the team's problems on a lack of defensive intensity.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: McCain-Feingold, at Last
description: The long-delayed debate on the campaign finance legislation sponsored by Senators John McCain of Arizona and Russell Feingold of Wisconsin starts today. The question now is whether its determined opponents, led by the Republican leader, Trent Lott, and the G.O.P.'s chief obstructionist, Mitch McConnell, can stall a bill designed to prevent a repeat of the scandalous 1996 campaign.

title: Not All Campaign Contributors Expect Access
description: To the Editor:

title: In Prague, 70,000 Fans Gather to Savor Moment
description: Soon after midnight, with a big Czech flag rolled up in her knapsack and a small one painted on her cheek, 16-year-old Eva Havrankova and three friends began a long walk to Prague.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLASSMAN, PHILIP
description: GLASSMAN-Philip. Beloved husband, loving father, devoted brother, cherished grandfather and uncle, past national vice president of N.O.I.T.U. Services will be held today, 12 noon, at Nieberg's Midwood Chapel, 1625 Coney Island Avenue, (corner Ave M), Brooklyn, 718-377-2700.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Allstate Suing Doctors And Lawyers Over Crashes

title: Equity and Related Offerings This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: The Misguided Max Tax
description: The latest fad in the seemingly endless stream of budget proposals involves limiting total tax payments. Bill Archer, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, wants to cap Federal revenue at 19 percent of gross domestic product. Some have gone even further, pushing for a constitutional amendment that would limit Federal taxes to 25 percent of income. The ''Max Tax,'' a variation on this theme, would let each taxpayer choose between filing under the current system and simply paying 25 percent of gross income.

title: TV Cable Box Software May Blur Digital Signals
description: For more than a year, the Microsoft Corporation has been cajoling the nation's television broadcasters into abandoning high-definition television and using only the computer industry's favored, lower-resolution transmission formats when digital broadcasts begin in the fall.

title: Lincoln's Absolutism Could Be Relative; Jefferson on Equality
description: To the Editor:

title: Advocate Clings to Hope For Campaign Overhaul
description: Whether from mercy, maturity or wintry ennui, the constituents of Senator Russell D. Feingold never once mentioned Monica S. Lewinsky this week as the Senator made his regular rounds to hear what is on their minds. The lawmaker seemed grateful for that small favor.

title: Vanishing Stethoscopes
description: To the Editor:

title: Accord Is Reported to Open Eight Iraqi Sites
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan will not reveal the details of his agreement with Saddam Hussein until he presents a report on his Iraq visit to the Security Council this week, United Nations officials said today. But the outlines of the accord -- and its limitations -- have emerged during three days of meetings here.

title: Uncertainty For Those Still Outdoors
description: Offering sex and aching for crack cocaine, Latoya Cook danced alone beneath a street light in industrial Brooklyn. She stumbled, began dancing again, then rushed to meet the client who was going to get her through the night.

title: Robert Jorgen, 72; Worked to Find Shelter for New York's Homeless
description: Robert Jorgen, who led New York City's efforts to offer emergency shelter for homeless families from the time their files began to trickle to his desk until his retirement from the Human Resources Administration in 1986, died on Jan. 22 at his home on the Upper East Side. He was 72.

title: New Attacks Will Not Halt Irish Talks
description: The British and Irish Governments have decided that terrorist attacks by sectarian splinter groups will not be allowed to derail the Northern Ireland peace talks, which are working toward a May 1 deadline for an agreement on the future of the British province, officials close to the negotiations say.

title: Allstate Acts to End Auto Accident Fraud
description: In a busy week, Alex Pillco might have been involved in 10 or 12 auto accidents.

title: Morris E. Kriensky, 80, Wartime Map Maker
description: Morris Edward Kriensky, an artist and writer who helped Gen. Claire Lee Chennault's Flying Tigers bomb their targets with precision in the 1937-45 Sino-Japanese war, died on Feb. 8 at Beth Israel North Hospital in Manhattan. He was 80 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Young Players Beat Veterans At an Unusual Tournament
description: The Betty Kaplan Teams is the only event in New York City, and perhaps in North America, that requires the players to rotate partnerships. In play on Saturday at the New York Helmsley Hotel in Manhattan, a young foursome snatched the title from a group of established stars. Jesus Arias, Shira Jacobson, Ann Mittman, all of Manhattan, and Albert Tom of Flushing, Queens, scored 80 victory points, 1 point ahead of Michael Rosenberg and Debbie Zuckerberg of Tuckahoe, N.Y., Mike Kamil of Holmdel, N.J., and Steve Weinstein of Glen Ridge, N.J.

title: U.S. Treasury to Hold Its Regular Auction of Bills During the Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills. It also includes two-year and five-year notes being auctioned tomorrow and Wednesday and a 52-week bill being auctioned on Thursday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOOLF, IRVING L.
description: WOOLF-Irving L. Beloved husband of Sandi Longhi and the late Shirley. Devoted father of Marcia Haise and Lewis Woolf. Dear brother of Marvin. Loving grandfather of Jeffrey, Wendy and Brian Haise, Jessica and Jonathan Woolf. Services 1 PM, Tuesday, February 24, at Temple Israel of New Rochelle, 1000 Pinebrook Boulevard, New Rochelle, NY.

title: A Stabat Mater's Grief Without Tears
description: ''Stabat Mater,'' the new and strangely moving ballet Peter Martins has choreographed to Pergolesi's most famous church music, opens on a startling image.

title: Lincoln's Absolutism Could Be Relative; Required: Belief in God
description: To the Editor:

title: Cabdriver, Shot 3 Times, Captures Armed Robber, Police Say
description: A 57-year-old livery cab driver who was held up by a gunman inside his taxi in Brooklyn yesterday morning fought back and was shot three times during a struggle in which he managed to disarm his assailant and, despite his wounds, hold the suspect at gunpoint until help arrived, the police said.

title: Barclays Discusses Merger With Standard
description: Barclays Bank P.L.C. of Britain has approached Standard Chartered Bank P.L.C. with a merger proposal that would create one of Britain's most powerful financial institutions, bank advisers said yesterday.

title: Powerless to Forget an Afternoon When Time Froze
description: As the leader of the band Pere Ubu, the singer David Thomas is a storyteller, and as full of theories as he is of music. This spring he'll get to put all sides of himself to the test. In March, the band will release a sly new album, ''Pennsylvania,'' and in April it will appear at a four-day ''Disastodrome'' festival at the South Bank arts center in London that Mr. Thomas organized. (''We call it Disasto so nothing can go wrong,'' Mr. Thomas writes.)

title: Stephen James, 73, Cold War Peace Advocate
description: Stephen D. James, a onetime advertising copywriter whose unlikely proposal for a vast Soviet-American hostage-exchange program propelled him onto the cold war stage and led to cultural exchange tours in the 1960's, died on Jan. 30 at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 73 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Czechs Have the Gold and the Goalie
description: The Czech Republic had the fewest National Hockey League players of the Big Six teams in the Olympic tournament, but it turned out that the Czechs had the one who mattered most: Dominik Hasek.

title: Trial to Start for Doctor Accused of Shaking His Baby to Death
description: The caller to 911 seemed at the edge of panic. ''Listen, my baby is in cardiac arrest,'' he said, explaining that he was a physician. ''I'm performing CPR,'' he added, imploring the dispatcher to rush paramedics to his home in Cambria Heights, Queens.

title: IRAQI AGREES TO INSPECTIONS IN A DEAL WITH U.N. LEADER; WASHINGTON AWAITS DETAILS
description: President Saddam Hussein agreed today to lift his ban on arms inspections at presidential properties, a United Nations spokesman said, apparently defusing a crisis that brought the United States to the brink of another attack on Iraq.

title: From Street to Field, and Shared Turf
description: Covered in mud and sweat, his body aching, his shirt torn, Reggie Johnson looked as though he had just survived a battle on Saturday as rain clouds began to roll over this small city just east of Los Angeles.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: It Turns Out That James Bond Isn't Working for MI-6 After All
description: We all know Bond, James Bond, but it seems what we may not know is just exactly who the gallant spy actually works for.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEYER, MURRAY
description: STEYER-Murray. Beloved husband of Beatrice Steyer for 51 years. Loving father of Robert, Richard and Betsy and loved father-in-law of Fred and Patricia.
