Treasured grandfather of Matthew, Laura and Harry. Devoted brother of Frances S. Martinson and the late Roy Steyer. He died as he lived-with dignity and grace and surrounded by his family who cherished him. The funeral will be held at 10 AM, on Monday, February 23rd, at the Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road in Scarsdale.

title: On Washington's 266th, Birthday Well-Wishers and Admirers Visit His Part of Town
description: They looked like members of some Presidential cult, standing before the statue of George Washington at Federal Hall and worshipfully waving one-dollar bills.

title: Cigarette Maker Manipulated Nicotine, Its Records Suggest
description: Tobacco industry documents, including some released in recent weeks, strongly suggest that one of the nation's largest cigarette producers, the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, altered nicotine delivery to smokers, apparently believing that doing so would increase the ''kick'' of its popular Winston brand and make it more competitive.

title: That Reagan Charm Hides an Elusive Man
description: ''I haven't figured him out,'' Ronald Reagan's son Ron Jr. says at the start of ''Reagan.'' ''I don't know anybody who has figured him out.'' That remains the assessment of the four-and-a-half-hour documentary that begins tonight on PBS.

title: Technology That Tracks Cell Phones Draws Fire
description: Cellular telephones, long associated with untethered freedom, are becoming silent leashes, as cellular telephone companies around the world have begun installing equipment that will allow them -- or the police, ambulance dispatchers, worried parents or jealous spouses -- to precisely track the location of callers.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: San Jose Sweeps New England
description: LASERS 83, BLIZZARD 71

title: Ferraro Assails D'Amato on Fund-Raising
description: On the eve of renewed Congressional debate over legislation to restrict campaign contributions, Geraldine A. Ferraro denounced Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato yesterday for repeatedly blocking such measures, and urged him to support a campaign finance reform bill coming to the Senate floor this week.

title: A Long Rise Over Perilous Hurdles
description: President-elect Kim Dae Jung was not born in a family of privilege, like many Asian politicians, but rather was raised on a poor island so remote it did not get electricity until 1988.

title: Officials Say Surplus Is for Patching Budgets, Not New York
description: For the second straight year, New York City is expecting a huge budget surplus. But at the same time, its public works often seem to be on the verge of collapse, with bricks raining down from schools, streets caving in, and students learning in bathrooms in crowded schools with coal furnaces.

title: The Tango Used as Tribute To a Homeland and Its Past
description: For Juan Jose Mosalini, the tango is about evanescence and memories. His music is constantly in transition: from timid to bold, from pensive to carefree, from enraptured to desolate. Themes begin tenderly and grow triumphal, then melt into swooning reveries; the music swells, eases back, ponders and surges again. Mr. Mosalini is based in Paris -- he left Argentina during its political upheavals in the 1970's -- and his music is an expatriate's tribute to a lost homeland and a bygone era.

title: Frankfurt Balkind Hires Indigo Founders
description: Frankfurt Balkind Partners in New York is hiring the founders and employees of Indigo Information Designers, a New York company that has specialized in Internet development.

title: Cornell Wants to Know: Is It a Pumpkin or Plastic?
description: When an enormous pumpkin was first sighted atop Cornell University's 173-foot bell tower last October, impaled on a seemingly inaccessible lightning rod, school officials said they would need to hire a crane or erect scaffolding to remove it.

title: Race Discrimination Furthers Income Inequality
description: To the Editor:

title: The Women and Men Who Reached the Top Three Steps
description: ALPINE SKIING

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEPIDUS, MARSHALL, M.D.
description: LEPIDUS-Marshall, M.D.; F.A.A.P. We mourn the loss of our dear friend, colleague, past President of Suffolk Pediatric Society, past Treasurer of Chapter 2, and advocate for passage of the Bicycle Helmet and Seatbelt laws in New York. We will miss you, Marshall. Executive Committee Chapter 2, District II American Academy of Pediatrics

title: Favorite Trick's Trainer Is Racing the Clock to Reach the Kentucky Derby
description: Bill Mott has 74 race horses stabled in his barn at the Payson Park campus in rural Indiantown, Fla., but only one of them is what you might call a mystery horse: Favorite Trick, the undefeated juvenile champion of last year, the newly elected Horse of the Year for 1997 and the early favorite for the Kentucky Derby.

title: Patents; A musician wins protection for a set of exercises used as therapy for repetitive stress injuries.
description: PATENTS that grant exclusive ownership of a method of practicing medicine, without relying on a new tool or device, have focused attention on changing perceptions about what constitutes intellectual property. There was a time when such patents were unheard-of. Then patents awarded to medical devices began to cover their methods of use. And now there are patents that simply cover a way of tying a stitch, say, or crafting an incision, or performing an operation.

title: White House Denies Using Investigators to Go After Starr
description: The White House today forcefully denied that it had engaged private investigators to examine political opponents of the President or members of the staff of Kenneth W. Starr, the independent counsel pursuing the Monica S. Lewinsky case.

title: Drought in Borneo Feeds Fear of New Forest Fires in Asia
description: The eastern coast of Borneo, dry after a year of drought, is bursting into flame again, raising fears that a wave of choking smoke could soon blanket Southeast Asia as it did last fall.

title: A New Kind of Leader for Korea, and Asia Too
description: His head shaven, his taut body dressed in a prison uniform, Kim Dae Jung lay huddled under a blanket in his freezing cell, shivering uncontrollably and despairing that he had wrecked the lives of his wife and three sons.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the Central Intelligence Agency's internal report on the 1961 Bay of Pigs invasion, and a front-page summary of the article in some copies, misstated the death toll among the invaders. Of about 1,500 commandos, 114 died, not nearly 1,500, and 1,189 were captured; the rest either never landed or made their way back to safety.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Echlin, the Target of a Takeover, Is Said to Receive Other Offers
description: Echlin Inc., an auto parts maker that is the target of a $3 billion hostile takeover bid, has been contacted by several concerns interested in buying the company, a person close to Echlin said. The Dana Corporation, Cooper Industries and Allied Signal are among those thought to have expressed interest.

title: In the Shadow of Silicon Valley, 'Digital Coast' Emerges
description: No true booster of Silicon Valley or its New York wannabe, Silicon Alley, would dispute the benefits of a catchy moniker for raising a region's high-technology profile and attracting coveted talent and venture capital.

title: Essay; Closing In on Clinton
description: Ten lawyers in the coordinated Clinton defense marched into a grand jury room threatening to throw a cloak of ''executive privilege'' over the suspected plotting of Bruce Lindsey to keep Monica Lewinsky quiet.

title: Vienna Journal; Homeless, but My Dance Card Is Full
description: This is the season when Vienna gets giddy with balls. Everybody has one: the coffee-house owners, the fire fighters, the atomic scientists, even the Government, which was the host last week for the century-old Opera Ball, which mixed lyrical waltzes with aging Hollywood celebrities.

title: A Young Baritone Spends An Evening With Schubert
description: Conventional wisdom about the recent death of the song recital took the evening off on Friday, as Nathan Gunn gave his New York debut recital, performing Schubert's ''Schone Mullerin'' to a full and enthusiastic house at Weill Recital Hall.

title: Merciless Blue Devils Add To Bruins' Growing Misery
description: ''Where's Jelani? Where's Jelani? Where's Jelani?''

title: History's Revenge
description: Once there was a President named Warren Harding.

title: TV, the Nemesis of Reading, Bolsters a Paper's Circulation
description: Cinnamon is an 8-year-old golden retriever that runs out each morning to fetch The Atlanta Constitution from the sidewalk in front of John Anderson's house here in suburban Atlanta.

title: Library of Congress Plans to Post Black History Exhibition on Line
description: The Library of Congress is formatting its ''African-American Odyssey'' exhibition for presentation on the Worldwide Web to coincide with Black History Month. The on-line display of much of the library's African-American collection is scheduled to include 240 manuscripts, books and photographs, and will be posted on line by May 2.

title: $8 Million Literary Trove Given to Morgan Library
description: The Carter Burden collection of American literature, more than 30,000 volumes plus rare manuscripts, letters and other papers, with an estimated value of $8 million to $10 million, has been given by the Burden family to the Pierpont Morgan Library in Manhattan. Mr. Burden, a businessman, politician and benefactor of the arts, died in 1996.

title: Ribicoff of Connecticut Dies; Governor and Senator Was 87
description: Abraham A. Ribicoff, the powerful and popular Governor of Connecticut, Congressman and United States Senator who served as Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare under John F. Kennedy, the President he helped elect, died yesterday at the Hebrew Home for the Aged at Riverdale in the Bronx. He was 87 and had homes in Manhattan and Cornwall Bridge, Conn.

title: Staying With the Pitch; Stalwarts of Face-to-Face Sales Reluctant to Peddle on Line
description: At a virtual Tupperware party, no coffee is served and there are no demonstrations of the product's notorious ''burp'' when properly sealed or how the cheese plane doubles as an eggplant peeler. But Regina Baker thinks her modern interpretation of the fabled American sales gathering is an effective substitute.

title: Metro Matters; Albany Scoffs At a Lesson On Schools
description: AT Los Angeles High School, a huge bunkerlike building on the edge of Koreatown, there is no such thing as summer vacation, and there hasn't been for years.

title: Some not-so-nostalgic memories of the old times with computers.
description: THE dark marks on the linoleum are the remnants of where, some 30 years ago, a noisy keypunch stood. I spent hours thumping at its keyboard, punching out lines of Fortran computer programs onto cards that once warned users not to ''fold, spindle, or mutilate.'' Each card coded a single line of the program (''IF N=3,'' one card might read, ''THEN GOTO 1260''). Thousands of cards accumulated, stored in long cartons.

title: Smiling Hosts and Splendid Performances
description: The 18th Winter Olympics came to a celebrative conclusion tonight after 16 days of disruptive weather and uninterrupted good will on the part of the Japanese.

title: Monitor Bosnian Aid
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWAYNE, WILLIAM H.
description: SWAYNE-William H. In Hollis, NH, February 16, age 85, eminent geologist and retired V.P. of Morgan Guaranty Trust; father of Terry Brooks, Hollis, N.H., Thompson Swayne, Basking Ridge, N.J., Eleanor Jones, Houston, TX and William Swayne, Stevensville, MD. Services are private. For information, contact Farwell Funeral Service, Nashua, NH.

title: Merrymaking Is Clashing With Tradition in Mardi Gras Tableaux
description: The parades, the lifeblood of the pre-Lent Carnival season for many people here, still course through St. Charles Avenue to cries of ''Throw me something, mister!''

title: A Dixie Book Burning
description: Religious conservatives led by Randall Terry, who was once head of the anti-abortion Operation Rescue movement, are waging a dangerous crusade against Barnes & Noble, the nation's largest bookstore chain, for selling art books containing nude photographs of children. The targets of the campaign are the works of two well-known photographers, Jock Sturges and David Hamilton. Mr. Sturges, whose photographs are in collections of the Museum of Modern Art and the Metropolitan Museum of Art, is known for scenes of nude children and families that are more sentimental than disturbing. He was the target of a well-publicized child pornography investigation in 1990 that ended when a Federal grand jury refused to indict him.

title: Race Discrimination Furthers Income Inequality; A Matter of Class
description: To the Editor:

title: Washington Is Installing Tougher Parking Meters
description: Crews are installing state-of-the-art parking meters in downtown Washington, replacing old and damaged meters in an effort to recover lost revenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINSLOW, ALFRED B.
description: WINSLOW-Alfred B. ''Old Two Dogs''-we miss you already and will never forget you at the helm in the Galapagos-8 foot seas and the rail down. Sail on, buddy. Linda and John Lori and Alan Barbara and Carlos Harriet and David Joyce and Bern

title: Historic Farmland Is to Be Preserved
description: Tranquillity Farms, 620 acres of farmland that was once owned by the descendants of Peter Stuyvesant, will be preserved as open space under an agreement announced Friday by the Nature Conservancy.

title: Yankees Keep Developing Prospects
description: Eric Milton's decision to have a Yankees logo tattooed on his back probably sealed his fate. Then late last month, when the 22-year-old pitcher's name became a part of the daily Chuck Knoblauch trade rumors, other Yankees minor leaguers working out with Milton could not resist teasing him.

title: Nissan Motor Expands Agency Relationship
description: The Nissan Motor Company has expanded its relationship with TBWA Chiat/Day by awarding it the account of Nissan Diesel America, a unit of Nissan Diesel Motor that distributes Nissan light- and medium-duty trucks in the United States under the brand name UD trucks. Billings were estimated at less than $5 million.

title: Higher Quota Urged for Immigrant Technology Workers
description: Under pressure from Congress and the computer industry, the White House is seriously considering proposals to increase the immigration quota for computer scientists and other information technology workers, so that foreigners can fill thousands of job openings in this country.

title: New From Spain, the Traditional and Much More
description: The National Ballet of Spain seeks to combine old and new ways of dancing. But its choreographic mixtures were not always satisfying when it began a 10-day engagement at the City Center on Friday night. Although the troupe had originally planned to open last Tuesday, the necessity of repairing damage to the special floor it uses for flamenco numbers forced a postponement.

title: Sports of The Times; A Verbal Gold Medal To a Perfect Host Nation
description: ALANA BLAHOSKI did not trash her room when her competition was over. Instead, she tucked her hockey gold medal into a pocket and went for a train ride to Matsumoto, the picturesque castle town an hour from here.

title: Thwarted Hearts Tempered by Bons Mots
description: Libby, the unlikely but successful prostitute in Nicky Silver's ''Maiden's Prayer,'' lets her thoughts drift when she's working. She is with her clients only in the flesh; her mind is with someone else entirely.

title: Sports of The Times; Has Garden Heard Last Boos for Barkley?
description: AS soon as Charles Barkley moved off the Rockets' bench toward the scorer's table midway through the first quarter, the Knicks' fans began to boo. Not that it disturbed him.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the Federal district judge in Washington overseeing the grand jury investigation of President Clinton referred incorrectly in some editions to Mr. Clinton's degree from Georgetown University. The President earned his bachelor's degree from Georgetown; he got his law degree from Yale University.

title: In the Data Storage Race, Disks Are Outpacing Chips
description: An I.B.M. laboratory already renowned for such Lilliputian feats as spelling out words with individual atoms has developed a disk drive the size of a poker chip that can hold the equivalent of more than 500 large novels. It offers striking evidence that one of the computer industry's oldest technologies is in the midst of a remarkable renaissance.

title: The agency behind the toga-clad pitchman for Little Caesars pizza is calling it quits.
description: CLIFF FREEMAN & PARTNERS has managed to turn a toga-clad gnome shouting ''Pizza! Pizza!'' and a cast of wacky characters including dancing dogs, feisty grandmothers and precocious infants into a powerful sales force for the Little Caesars pizza chain. But now Freeman has unexpectedly resigned the company's account after more than a decade.

title: M. Norvel Young, 82, Head of Pepperdine U.
description: M. Norvel Young, the chancellor emeritus who guided Pepperdine University through a period of robust growth as its third president, died last Tuesday at his campus residence in Malibu, Calif. He was 82.

title: Showalter, the Organization Man, Puts Stamp on Diamondbacks
description: The Arizona Diamondbacks, a new franchise, culled players, coaches and other personnel from 22 major league organizations. And the presence of such established stars as Matt Williams, Andy Benes, Jay Bell and Devon White reflects a different kind of beginning than the one suffered by the 1962 Mets.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MUFSON, JOANNA
description: MUFSON-Joanna. August 16, 1969-February 23, 1983. Now that I am without you, all is desolate. All that was once so beautiful is dead. Mom and Abby

title: This Week
description: EVENTS

title: John Fulton Is Dead at 65; Spain's First U.S. Matador
description: John Fulton, a Philadelphia-born artist who worked with cape and sword in the bullrings of Spain, then celebrated his momentary masterpieces of ritual death by painting pictures of the very bulls he had slain using their own blood, died on Friday in a hospital near his home in Seville. He was 65, and had been the first American to qualify as a matador in Spain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIRNBAUM, JACK
description: BIRNBAUM-Jack. Young Israel of Forest Hills mourns the passing of its former president, Jack Birnbaum. May the Almighty console the family together with all the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBISON, JAMES E.
description: ROBISON-James E. Of Armonk, NY, on February 21, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Jeanette Hoffman Robison; dear father of Molly Davies; devoted grandfather of Annabel Lee, James and April Davies; brother of Myrtle (Roby) Raymond. Interment will be private in the family plot at Trenton, Missouri. In lieu of flowers, the family requests memorial donations be made to your favorite charity.

title: Report Finds Bias in Lending Hinders Home Buying in Cities
description: While the number of Americans who own their homes has reached a record level, a new report by the United States Conference of Mayors contends that discriminatory lending practices in urban areas have kept many city dwellers from participating in the boom.

title: A Public Master Class
description: American Ballet Theater is to present a public master class tomorrow at 7 P.M. at the Kaye Playhouse, 68th Street between Lexington and Park Avenues. John Meehan, a former Ballet Theater principal who now directs the company's junior troupe, is to coach Ethan Brown and Sara Mau, dancers with Ballet Theater, in duets from Ronald Hynd's ''Merry Widow,'' exploring the interaction between the lead characters. Tickets are $10. For reservations: (212) 772-4448.

title: U.S. Will Proceed With Buildup In Mideast, Clinton Officials Say
description: Senior Clinton Administration officials, cautioning that deeds and not words are required to resolve the crisis with Iraq, said today that they would withhold judgment on the agreement announced in Baghdad by the United Nations Secretary General, Kofi Annan, until he returns to give them a detailed briefing.

title: Back From the Brink With Iraq
description: Refraining from military action sometimes requires greater courage by a President than using force, as Lyndon Johnson learned too late in Vietnam. President Clinton wisely decided yesterday to hold his fire against Iraq, tentatively endorsing the agreement reached over the weekend between Saddam Hussein and Kofi Annan, the Secretary General of the United Nations. If Mr. Hussein honors his newly minted commitments, the threat of military conflict should recede further in the days ahead.

title: Despite Intern, President Stays In Good Graces
description: Most Americans are inclined to think that President Clinton, despite his denials, had an affair with a former White House intern. But, in the statistical equivalent of a collective shrug, most call it understandable for the President to lie about his sexual conduct, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEN, SHIRLEY
description: ROSEN-Shirley. The Jewish Center of Atlantic Beach records with profound sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Mrs. Shirley Rosen, beloved wife of Leo and mother of Meryl and David. May the family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem and know no further sorrow. Dr. Basil Herring, Rabbi Arthur Udell, President Armand Lindenbaum, Chairman, Board of Trustees

title: A Heroes' Welcome From 130,000
description: The Czech Republic's gold medal-winning Olympic hockey team returned home from Japan tonight to a tumultuous flag-waving welcome from more than 130,000 countrymen clustered on balconies, perched on window ledges and crushed against a makeshift stage in the Old Town Square.

title: Accord With Iraq Pushes Oil Prices Down to 1994 Levels
description: The price of crude oil fell sharply yesterday after Iraq and the United Nations Secretary General signed an agreement allowing the inspection of weapons sites, staving off for the present the prospect of United States air attacks and the risk of an interruption of oil supplies.

title: They Also Serve Who Also Dance
description: Maybe ANDRE AGASSI was warming up for a rerun of his 1994 Grand Slam adventure, when he won the United States Open even though he was unseeded. There he was, waiting for a court at the Vertical Club on East 61st Street. His opponent was SARGIS SARGSIAN, whom he defeated at the Australian Men's Hardcourt Championships last month.

title: For Bargain Basement Buying, Time May Be Right
description: THE day of the $800 brand-name desktop computer has arrived, if you are willing to overlook the extra $200 for a cheap monitor. That sounds great, but $500 (sans monitor) machines are likely to appear by the end of the year. So what to do? Wait? Buy a cheapie, consider it disposable, and plan an upgrade to a faster bargain in a couple of years? Or plunk down hundreds of dollars more for a top-of-the-line machine with a potentially longer shelf life?

title: PLUS: CYCLING -- RUTA DEL SOL; Armstrong Is Optimistic
description: Just 16 months after announcing he had testicular cancer, Lance Armstrong raced again in Spain last week, finishing 12th among 121 cyclists in the five-day Ruta del Sol. Yesterday, he told reporters how excited and optimistic he was about his comeback.

title: Plea Change in Death Case Stirs Questions
description: Facing a possible death sentence for a triple murder, Darrel K. Harris took the deal that prosecutors offered him, agreeing to plead guilty to the killings in return for a sentence of life in prison without possibility of parole.

title: Canadian Power Deal
description: TransCanada Power Services Ltd. a unit of TransCanada Pipelines, said today that it would spend $83.7 million to buy a power plant in northern Ontario and expand two plants.

title: Q&A
description: Birth Order and Height

title: U.S. Seeks Solution for Byproduct of Uranium
description: The Federal Government has been storing a uranium byproduct for so long that some of the 28,000 cylinders stacked in an open yard here are labeled ''M.D.,'' for Manhattan District, leftovers from the project that built the first atom bomb.

title: NASA Must Reignite Research, Panel Says
description: TO fulfill dreams of exploring the solar system, finding planets around distant stars or possibly traveling to other worlds, the United States needs to invest more in key space-related technologies that no one else is developing, experts say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIBICOFF, SENATOR ABRAHAM A.
description: RIBICOFF-Senator Abraham A. The Board of Directors, residents and staff of The Hebrew Home for the Aged at Riverdale mourn with profound sorrow the death of Senator Abraham Ribicoff. Eminent statesman and distinguished national leader, Senator Ribicoff made a difference in the lives of millions of Americans in his years of dedicated public service, just as he touched all of us with his warmth and gentleness in his stay at the Hebrew Home at Riverdale. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his loving and devoted wife Casey and the entire Ribicoff family. Milton A. Gilbert, President Bernard Goldberg, Chairman Jacob Reingold, Vice Chairman Daniel A. Reingold, Exec. V.P.

title: Now! Read the True (More or Less) Story!; Publishers and Authors Debate the Boundaries Of Nonfiction
description: In the frenzied commerce of best-selling books, truth is stranger than fiction, no matter how dull or stubborn the facts.

title: Q&A / Juwono Sudarsono, Defense Official : Racism in Indonesia Undercuts Unity
description: The 7 million ethnic Chinese in Indonesia make up just 3 percent of the population, but they control a large share of economic wealth. On a visit to Singapore, Juwono Sudarsono, deputy governor of the National Resilience Institute, an arm of the Indonesian Defense Ministry that trains senior civilian and military officials, discussed the situation of the Chinese minority with Michael Richardson of the International Herald Tribune.

title: HARNISCHFEGER TO IMPOSE CUTBACKS AND TAKE A CHARGE
description: Harnischfeger Industries said yesterday that it would cut jobs and investment and take a charge of as much as $150 million to improve its pulp and paper machinery business, which has been weakened by Asia's economic crisis. Harnischfeger, which makes equipment for the paper, pulp and mining industries and is based in St. Francis, Wis., said it was aiming to save about $30 million to $40 million a year in costs. The company said it expected to offset the charge with a gain from the sale of 80 percent of its materials unit to Chartwell Investments Inc. of New York. It also said yesterday that its quarterly net income fell to $21.7 million, or 46 cents a diluted share, from $30.9 million, or 64 cents, a year earlier. Shares of Harnischfeger rose 75 cents, to $32.875.

title: A Testy Hussein Deputy and a Candid U.N. Chief Fence With the Press
description: The ink was barely dry today on Iraq's agreement with the United Nations when the two men who signed it were already back on the barricades of the next crisis.

title: Europeans Offer Praise For Accord With Iraq
description: European allies warmly hailed the accord brought back from Baghdad tonight by United Nations Secretary General Kofi Annan.

title: Starr Investigation Maintains a Balance; Jones Case Ruling
description: To the Editor:

title: Drug Giants Cancel Plans For a Merger
description: Less than a month after announcing that they were in talks aimed at forming the world's largest pharmaceuticals company, SmithKline Beecham P.L.C. and Glaxo Wellcome P.L.C. said late yesterday that the discussions had ended.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEW, BABETTE
description: NEW-Babette. On Feb. 22, 1998 at the age of 84, after a long illness. Beloved mother of Amy Kovner White and Victor A. Kovner, cherised grandmother of Anne Plumer and Elsie White. Her talent, beauty and artistic sensibility enhances the lives of those who love her. A private Memorial will soon be scheduled.

title: I.Q. Scores Are Up, and Psychologists Wonder Why
description: IT is a favorite pastime of older people to lament the defects of the young. Every generation seems to be convinced that in its day, standards were higher, schools were tougher and kids were smarter.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Sunday Styles this week about Marlo Thomas misidentified the university from which she received a George Foster Peabody television award. The awards are administered by the University of Georgia, not Columbia.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report on the Metro Business page on Friday about a hotel planned for the former site of the Astor Place Opera House in Greenwich Village misstated the circumstances of a riot at the opera house during a performance of ''Macbeth'' in 1849. The riot began after supporters of an American actor, Edwin Forrest, interrupted the performance of his English rival, William C. Macready. But only one of the actors, Mr. Macready, was in the play.

title: Huskies Defeat Pesky Friars
description: CONNECTICUT 77, PROVIDENCE 68

title: REIT to Buy 3 Hotels
description: Equity Inns Inc., a real estate investment trust, said today that it had agreed to acquire three hotels in two separate transactions totaling $43.1 million. In one transaction, it will pay $30.5 million for the 168-room Residence Inns in Portland, Ore., and the 104-room one in Boise, Idaho. Equity will also buy the 169-room Hampton Inn in San Antonio for $12.6 million. The deals are expected to close in early spring.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LLUVERES, CLARA
description: LLUVERES-Clara. On February 23, 1998 at Calvary Hospital, Bronx, N.Y. Survived by her niece Clara, nephew Andrew, grand nieces Elena, Cornelia and Antonia. Memorial Mass Thursday, February 26th, 10AM at Holy Name Church, 96 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, NYC. Presiding Monsignor Charles McDonaugh and Monsignor Charles Kavanaugh.

title: New Jersey Chief Justice Will Join in School Funding Decision
description: Saying she no longer has a conflict of interest, Chief Justice Deborah T. Poritz announced today that she would join her colleagues on the New Jersey Supreme Court in deciding whether the state should spend an extra $312 million a year on urban schools.

title: Chamber Society Moves From the Adventurous Back to the Usual
description: With its recently completed ''Musical Evolutions'' series, examining exploratory works composed between the years of creative ferment from 1887 to 1920, the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center presented some genuinely provocative programs. But on Sunday night the organization went back to the tried and true with a more typical, unchallenging program, which will be repeated tonight.

title: Ireland and Terrorism
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TURITS, JOAN
description: TURITS-Joan. Passed away after a long and courageous fight with illness on February 18 surrounded by family and friends. A 42 year Poughkeepsie, NY area resident, born February 16, 1933 in New York City and educated in City schools. She married Allan Turits November 22, 1952, who survives at home. Joan was the daughter of Michael G. Miller and the late Helen W. Miller. Mr. Miller and his wife Sophie, two sons, Andrew and Mark, Mark's wife Kathy Bryant and their two sons, Jack and Jesse also survive. She was a member of the Temple Beth-El, Poughkeepsie and its ORT, Hadassah and Sisterhood chapters. She was active also in local schools' PTA. Services were conducted by Rabbi Charles Feinberg at Temple BethEl on February 20th. Interment was at the temple cemetery. Those wishing to honor her memory may do so by donation to the Muscular Dystrophy Association. She is deeply missed and will be forever remembered and loved in our hearts. Blessed be her memory.

title: A $161 Million Deal In Doctors' Services
description: The Envoy Corporation said today that it would buy three closely held companies specializing in electronic services for doctors and other health care providers, in stock transactions valued at $161 million.

title: The Reagan Riddle
description: As President, Ronald Reagan projected optimism, conviction and nostalgia for a simpler time in America. Now retired and afflicted, he is poignantly beckoning Americans once again to recall a moment when Presidential leadership itself seemed more simple and open than it is today. The President who stood for irreducible verities like opposing Communism and unleashing ''the magic of the marketplace,'' as he un-self-consciously put it, has been vividly captured by the two-part documentary broadcast on PBS last night and tonight. No less impressive is the program's acknowledgment that the man in the middle remains an enigma.

title: Science Watch; Total Eclipse on the Web
description: One of nature's most majestic and benign spectacles, a total solar eclipse, will sweep across the Caribbean on Thursday morning, relieving a few thousand lucky tourists of the need for sunblock for a few minutes, anyway.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHSTEIN, JOSEPH
description: ROTHSTEIN-Joseph. On Feb. 21, following a long and courageous struggle with multiple sclerosis at home with his family. Devoted husband of Gale. Loving father of Caron Siegel and Jay Rothstein. Adoring and proud grandfather of Ian and Todd Siegel. Dear brother of Raphael. Son of the late Fanny and Pincus. Private services were held.

title: Most Global of Sports
description: To the Editor:

title: Mancur Olson, 66, a Professor And Author of Economics Books
description: Mancur Olson, 66, an economist at the University of Maryland widely admired for his research on how groups that represent specialized interests affect economic growth, died last Thursday. He lived in University Park, Md.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVIN, MARTELL ''MARTY'' (NEE TRINZ)
description: LEVIN-Martell ''Marty'' (nee Trinz), 94. Devoted wife of the late Jacob David Levin. Beloved mother of Henriette (Fredric) Preiss of White Plains, N.Y. and Judith (Louis) Genesen. Adoring grandmother of Henry (Ruth) and Jon (Ronda) Blinder, David (Patty) Kovacs, Deborah (Nicholas) Sullivan, Lisa Genesen (David Tabolt) and Dr. Mark (Leigh) Genesen. Great grandmother of Hanna Blinder, Jack and Kelly Kovacs, Sarah and Lucy Sullivan, Claire Tabolt and Emma and William Genesen. Loving sister of the late Sam and Edward Trinz, Lucy Roderick and Bea Mansfield. Fond aunt of many nieces and nephews. Services Wednesday, Feb. 25th at 11 A.M. at Chicago Sinai Congregation, 15 West Delaware. Interment private. Please omit flowers. Memorials to friends of Hospice Northwestern Memorial Hospital, 250 East Superior, Chicago, Illinois 60611, would be appreciated. For further information please call Furth Funeral Direction 773-784-4300.

title: Rescue Plan for Oxford Health Hits Snag
description: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, the New York-based leveraged buyout firm, is no longer involved in the effort to inject badly needed capital into Oxford Health Plans, the troubled health maintenance organization, people close to the talks said yesterday.

title: Special Elections Set in Nassau and Queens
description: Gov. George E. Pataki said today that a special election would be held on March 24 to fill a vacant State Senate seat in Nassau County and a State Assembly seat in Queens.

title: Most Global of Sports; Judging the Skaters
description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''World opinion will mean that this deal must be accepted. The Americans would find themselves in dangerous isolation if, pointing to some trifling detail or another, they insisted on a military strike.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALONEY, MURIEL F.
description: MALONEY-Muriel F. Of North Merrick on February 22, 1998. Wife of the late J. Fred Maloney. Devoted mother of Jeanne Malvetti and Brian T. Maloney. Loving grandmother of Daria, Nicole, Denise and Michelle. Visiting on Tuesday 7-9 PM and Wednesday 2-5 and 7-9 PM at the N. F. Walker Funeral Home, 2039 Merrick Avenue, Merrick. Funeral Mass Thursday 9:45 AM at Sacred Heart RC Church. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery Mausoleum.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Arts and Ideas section on Saturday about the economic theory of Jean-Baptiste Say misstated the number of years between the publication of Adam Smith's ''Wealth of Nations'' and Say's ''Treatise on Political Economy.'' Smith's book first appeared in 1776, 27 years before Say's treatise, not 7.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TANNER, FREDERICK C., JR.
description: TANNER-Frederick C., Jr. Of Greenwich, CT. On February 23. Survived by his wife Dorelle Moulton Tanner, daughters Alexandra Tanner and Fredericka Tanner, stepson Vincent Andreus, 3 grandsons and three step-grandchildren. Brother of Ogden Tanner and Jane Trimingham. Graduate of Hotchkiss and Yale '39. Attended Harvard Law School. Service at 4:30 PM on Thursday, February 26, at Round Hill Community Church, 395 Round Hill Rd., Greenwich, CT. Contributions may be made to the Yale Alumni Fund-Memorials, PO Box 1890, New Haven, CT. 06508.

title: Nine West Puts An Account in Review
description: Nine West Group said yesterday that it had placed in review the account of its Easy Spirit brand of women's footwear, with billings estimated at $15 million to $20 million. The creative portion has been handled by Lotas Minard Patton McIver in New York, while Media That Works in Cincinnati has handled media planning and buying.

title: Unoccupied Building Collapses in the Bronx
description: An unoccupied four-story building in the Bronx that had been under construction collapsed early today in rainy and windy weather, officials said.

title: Arrogance on NATO
description: To the Editor:

title: Professors Fear to Grade Harshly; Math Is Still Tough
description: To the Editor:

title: Union Planters To Buy Magna
description: The Union Planters Corporation, Tennessee's largest bank holding company, said today that it would acquire the Magna Group for $2.3 billion in stock to expand its reach in the St. Louis metropolitan area.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: FIRST WESTERN BANK N.A., New Castle, Pa., a commercial bank, agreed to acquire 16 branch offices in western Pennsylvania from PNC Bank Corp., Pittsburgh, for $58 million.

title: Showa Denko Pleads Guilty To Price Fixing
description: Showa Denko Carbon Inc. agreed to pay $29 million and plead guilty to taking part in a worldwide conspiracy to fix prices for integral parts in the steelmaking process, the United States Justice Department said today.

title: Lethal Virus Comes Out of Hiding
description: DEEP in a freezer in a closet-sized room at the Armed Forces Institute of Pathology here are tiny vials of a clear liquid containing irreplaceable molecules. They are submicroscopic shards of one of the most deadly viruses the world has ever known, the influenza virus that swept the world in 1918.

title: In the Words of Clinton: 'What Really Matters Is Iraq's Compliance'
description: Following is a transcript of President Clinton's news conference yesterday about the agreement with Iraq, as provided by the Federal News Service, a private transcription agency:

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: A Giant Eye and a New Era Are About to Open
description: FOR the last decade a consortium of European nations has been building what will be by far the world's largest optical telescope. Three months from now the first of the Very Large Telescope's four glass eyes will open on the universe, and a new era in astronomy will begin.

title: By Design; Showing Off the Arms
description: There is something insouciant about rolled-up or pushed-up sleeves. Now, the effect is being built in, as many of spring's shirts, sweaters and jackets come with three-quarter sleeves.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOLAND, FLORENCE L.
description: BOLAND-Florence L., on February 22, 1998 of Forest Hills, N.Y. Affiliated with Association of National Advertising for many years.

title: TV's Olympic Ads: Straight From Dullsville
description: Now it can be told. As if all the reasons viewers shunned CBS's coverage of the 18th Olympic Winter Games weren't enough to chill network executives, there was yet one more: dreadfully dull commercials.

title: Soccer, Bigotry And the Irish Soul
description: An exceptionally rewarding night of theater awaits anyone who hurries to the Irish Arts Center before the limited run of ''A Night in November'' ends on Sunday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, MAX W.
description: STEIN-Max W. Of Pembroke Pines, FL. Passed away Feb. 23, 1998. Beloved husband of Shirley. Father of Edward and Barbara. Grandfather of Michael, Penny, David, and Steven. Brother of Sam. Brother-in-law of Mary, brother-in-law of Emma Harrison, Jack and Adele Tompkins, stepfather of Emily, Robert, Nancy, step grandfather of David, Jennifer, Brian, Sandra, Alexandra and Andrew. Funeral services and burial will be held Thursday, February 26 at 10 A.M. Schwartz Brothers, 114-03 Queens Blvd., Forest Hills.

title: Control Suddenly Giving Way To Chaos
description: Something fresh popped up on the dance horizon with Company Toothpick, an experimental group from Helsinki that appeared on a program with Jonathan Hollander's Battery Dance Company at Florence Gould Hall.

title: Samson Takes On Philistines (Again)
description: This cannot be said of MAYOR RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI, but there are New Yorkers whose calendars could summarize their after-hours plans in five words: all Grammy Awards, all week. At the first Grammy party -- at the very noisy, very crowded apartment of the songwriter DENISE RICH -- HEATHER LOCKLEAR look-alikes with the labels of their very sheer dresses showing wandered through the very large duplex.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; The Fed's relatively high interest rate hasn't cut growth.
description: WHILE market interest rates have fallen sharply over the last 10 months, one rate has not budged.

title: Sports of The Times; N.H.L.'s Best Should Stay In Olympics
description: THE Winter Olympics had a closing ceremony, but they're not over for a while. At least not for any of the United States Olympic Trash Team, alias the male hockey players.

title: The Newest Temps in Law Firms: Lawyers
description: After practicing law in California for 10 years, Gideon E. Mark realized that he preferred problem solving to confrontation and wanted to be a management consultant instead of a litigator. He got a master's degree in business from Columbia University but could not pay for the additional schooling he needed to switch professions.

title: The Los Angeles Contemporary Look
description: Many fashion moments come in screaming. Lacy lingerie looks. Padded shoulders. The stiletto. Magazines pump up the volume, retail buyers enthuse in fashionese, and the industry's other town criers join in, only to declare the whole thing finished -- often before the average customer has succumbed.

title: Pataki Has an Audition on the National Stage
description: Gov. George E. Pataki of New York thinks President Clinton failed to lay out the case for an attack on Iraq, had that proved necessary. He believes the Republican Party must reclaim its title as the party of the tax cut. And he has some advice to Republicans who want to win the White House in 2000: pick a candidate from outside of Washington, say, the governor of a large state.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Kohlberg Kravis Is Seen Pulling Out of Oxford Deal

title: Rarely Performed Solos With an Urban Air
description: Shane O'Hara took on a crucial but difficult task with ''The Nagrin Project,'' an evening of six solos by Daniel Nagrin that Mr. O'Hara performed on Saturday night at the Merce Cunningham Studio Theater. Work by Mr. Nagrin, one of the great solo dancers and choreographers of American modern dance, has been preserved on video. But the pieces, closely associated with their creator, are seldom seen onstage today.

title: Douglas's Future Rests On Jet Plans for Defense
description: Lacking a second-round draft pick this year, and facing the loss of their first-round choice in 1999, the Jets have been listening to a series of attractive offers regarding one of their few impact players, the pass-rushing end Hugh Douglas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CITRON, JUDITH
description: CITRON-Judith, Born July 12th 1908. Died February 22, 1998. Beloved wife of Arthur (for 65 years). Dear mother of Joel, daughter-inlaw Linda, devoted grandmother of David and Steven. Adored great grandmother to Courtney and Mariah. Loving sister and aunt.

title: Biggest British Bank Posts 10% Profit Gain
description: HSBC Holdings P.L.C., Britain's largest bank, said yesterday that its net income rose 10 percent in the second half of 1997, in line with expectations, as an increase in bad debt provision for the Asian economic crisis offset strong growth in Britain. HSBC, a British bank that traditionally makes most of its money in Asia, posted net income of $:1.76 billion ($2.89 billion) in the six months that ended on Dec. 31, up from $:1.60 billion a year earlier.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COPLEMAN, BENJAMIN, M.D.
description: COPLEMAN-Benjamin, M.D. of Freehold, NJ, on Feb. 23, 1998, in his 90th year of complications from a stroke. Survived by his wife, Grace Levine Copleman, children Ralph and Martha, grandsons Paul and Andrew Copleman; he was also father-in-law of Joyce Copleman and Oliver Rosengart. Born 12/14/08 in New Brunswick, NJ, he practiced radiology in Perth Amboy, South Amboy and Holmdel, NJ for many years; he was also Director of Radiology at Roosevelt Hospital in Menlo Park, New Jersey. A Fellow of the American College of Radiology, he was a member of many professional associations and published over thirty papers. Funeral Wednesday, Feb. 25 at 11 A.M., in the chapel of Beth Israel Memorial Park, Woodbridge, NJ. Donations in lieu of flowers may be sent to the American Cancer Society.

title: NETWORK ASSOCIATES ACQUIRING TRUSTED INFORMATION
description: In a merger of two computer-security providers, Network Associates Inc. agreed yesterday to buy Trusted Information Systems Inc. for $300 million in stock. Shares of Trusted Information surged 53 percent, gaining $6.6875, to $19.3125. Network Associates, which fell 50 cents yesterday, to $62, will pay 0.323 share for each Trusted Information share. Trusted Information is based in Glenwood, Md. Network Associates, of Santa Clara, Calif., was created late last year by the merger of the Network General Corporation and McAfee Associates.

title: The Neediest Cases; Mother, Frustrated by the Welfare System, Finds Help
description: Marga Diaz will readily admit to a few unwise decisions in her younger days. ''I was always a good little girl, so when I became a teen-ager, I rebelled with a vengeance,'' said Ms. Diaz, 25, one of eight children who grew up in a crowded apartment in Flushing, Queens.

title: Vandalism Stigma Worries Rangers
description: They pleaded guilty to going medal-less in Nagano, Japan, but deemed themselves innocent of suite-bashing or pub-crawling while overseas. When Brian Leetch, Mike Richter and Pat LaFontaine, the trio of Rangers who went seeking Olympic gold with the much-hyped United States team, returned to their day jobs today, apology was in the air and John Muckler, their new coach, was in their faces.

title: A Fight to Acknowledge a Life; Mother's Efforts Help Alter Policy on Suicide Victims
description: Marcia Eskin may never know why her son, Jonah, hanged himself after finishing his freshman year at West Orange High School in 1994. He did not leave a note. Reading book after book, Mrs. Eskin has searched for solace, for answers, and has found little of either.

title: Parents Get Satisfaction From Ruling
description: Since her 7-year-old daughter, Megan, was murdered by a neighbor in the summer of 1994, Maureen Kanka says she has traveled about 50,000 miles, pressing for passage of laws intended to protect children from sex offenders.

title: Asia May Pinch Us Yet
description: Geopolitical shocks always seem to bring out the failings of forecasters. That was certainly the lesson of the OPEC disruptions of the 1970's and again in the Persian Gulf war of 1991 -- both times, economists failed to understand the lethal interplay between fear and reality.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL: WOMEN'S TOP 25 GAME
description: FLORIDA INTERNATIONAL 113 CENTRAL FLORIDA 59

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBBINS, BERNARD, M.D.
description: ROBBINS-Bernard, M.D. Beloved husband of the late Beatrice. Loving brother of Dr. Edward Robbins. Services 1 P.M., Wednesday at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Starr Investigation Maintains a Balance
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZEHNER, EARL E.
description: ZEHNER-Earl E. Died early Friday, February 20th, after a short illness. A resident of Manhattan for many years, he was a longtime member of the Art Students League and of the Church of the Healing Christ where a memorial service will be held Sunday, March 1st. He is survived by one niece and many loyal friends.

title: Lives and Homes Destroyed In a Night of Deafening Fury
description: Joel Heaton's luck finally abandoned him shortly after midnight today.

title: Senate Committee Studies School-Choice Program
description: When state lawmakers approved Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's school financing law in 1996, many of them failed to notice a clause that authorized the Commissioner of Education to set up a program allowing parents to choose the public schools their children attend.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Bowed, Not Battered; Taiwan Is Riding Out the Storm That Is Inundating Its Neighbors
description: Every 12 seconds, a matte black computer monitor tube slides off a robotized assembly line here and is packed by human hands in Styrofoam cases for shipment around the world. Last year, the company, Chunghwa Picture Tubes Ltd., shipped 20 million of them to computer makers from I.B.M. and Philips to Toshiba and Acer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOHEBAN, RACHEL
description: MOHEBAN-Rachel, DWI victim. Wife of Abraham. Mother of Rom, David, the late Ilan and Nira Gross. Services today at 8:45 A.M., Schwartz Brothers, Forest Hills.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/World Music CD's; Monks and Pygmies With a Beat
description: Cyro Baptista

title: A Buildup For Kuwait Followed By Letdown
description: Many people in Kuwait were convinced that the latest crisis with Iraq had presented the world with an opportunity to punish or even crush their neighbor and nemesis, Saddam Hussein. And so after they awoke today to news that a United Nations mission had improved the prospects for peace, many Kuwaitis confessed that their feelings were decidedly mixed.

title: 2 Sit in Indian State's Chair as Music Stops
description: With results in India's general election barely a week away, the country's largest state, Uttar Pradesh, slid into something approaching political farce today, with unpredictable consequences for the two main political groups fighting for power.

title: Sir Francis Harry Hinsley, 79, British Historian
description: Sir Francis Harry Hinsley, a British historian and authority on wartime intelligence and naval warfare, died on Feb. 16 in Cambridge, England. He was 79 and had been associated with St. John's College, Cambridge University, since his student days.

title: Theatreplex-Orix Venture
description: Theatreplex Entertainment Properties Inc. said today that it had formed a $250 million joint venture with the real estate unit of the Orix Corporation of Japan to buy, develop and provide financing for movie theaters in the United States. The companies plan to invest the money over the next two years and then take the company public as a real estate investment trust, or REIT. The venture comes amid a trend toward bigger and more luxurious theaters containing 15 to 20 screens and costing about $10 million to build.

title: AT LEAST 38 DIE AS TORNADOES RIP CENTRAL FLORIDA
description: A series of tornadoes ripped swaths about 50 miles wide across Central Florida early today, killing at least 38 people and leaving patches of destruction that state officials said were as bad as anything they saw in the wake of Hurricane Andrew. It was the deadliest swarm of tornadoes on record in the state.

title: Metro Business; New York Office for Sun
description: Sun International Hotels Limited, which recently won approval to take over the Resorts Casino Hotel in Atlantic City, will open its first office in New York in June, company officials have said.

title: Yanks Have 2 Plan B's Should Starters Falter
description: Everybody from George Steinbrenner to Joe Torre agrees that the Yankees' rotation represents the team's greatest potential weakness. But it's all a matter of relativity.

title: Supreme Court Won't Weigh 'Megan's Law'
description: The Supreme Court today turned down constitutional challenges to laws in both New York and New Jersey that provide for communities to be notified about the whereabouts of paroled sex offenders.

title: Bypassed in New York, No. 1 in Philadelphia
description: HAPPINESS crackles, you don't even need to understand the words to pick up on it. The lilt of the voice on the answering machine; the ready laugh when met; the sweep of the hand, taking in the universe, including City Hall, with an overflowing generosity of spirit. Even old, public enemies, in such circumstances, can be forgiven.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMPSON, ROBERT I.
description: THOMPSON-Robert I. Research Frontiers Incorporated notes with great sadness the death of our Executive Vice President, Director and good friend, Robert I. Thompson, on Saturday, February 21, 1998. Mr. Thompson was an inventor on many patents relating to devices for the control of light. He was a devoted husband, father and grandfather. His family, friends and colleagues will all greatly miss him.

title: Senate Resumes Debate on Campaign Financing
description: The Senate opened debate today on the overhaul of the nation's campaign finance laws. But despite the litany of fund-raising abuses in the 1996 campaign, lawmakers remained as divided as ever over how or even whether to change the financing system.

title: Atlantic City to Vote On Added School Taxes
description: Residents of Atlantic City will vote tomorrow on whether to tax themselves and the city's casinos an additional $6 million to cover a projected shortfall in this year's school budget.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POSNIAK, EVELYN
description: POSNIAK-Evelyn. Beloved wife of Sol. Sister of Irving. Mother of Fred. Grandmother of Marissa and Amanda. Mother-in-law of Karen. Her strength helped provide great love to all who knew her. She will be greatly missed from all. Funeral services today, 9:30 A.M., at Yablokoff Funeral Home, Brooklyn.

title: U.S. Says 2 Chinese Offered Organs From the Executed
description: In an undercover operation that officials say could confirm suspicions about human rights abuses in China's prisons, Federal authorities in New York City have arrested two men, including one who claimed to be a former Chinese prosecutor, on charges of conspiring to arrange transplants of kidneys and other organs taken from the bodies of executed Chinese inmates.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Four Executives Are Honored
description: Four executives have been named as the 1998 inductees of the Point-of-Purchase Advertising Industry's Hall of Fame, administered by the Point-of-Purchase Advertising Institute in Washington.

title: Foreign Affairs; Craziness Pays
description: Another deal with Saddam Hussein? Hmmmmm. Why does it leave me feeling uneasy -- as if I had just agreed that Ted Kaczynski could be my mailman, because he's promised, this time, for sure, no more letter bombs? You just know that sooner or later something is gonna go boom.

title: Brooklyn District Attorney Enters the Race for Governor
description: Making his official entry into a crowded gubernatorial race, Charles J. Hynes, the Brooklyn District Attorney, yesterday unleashed a torrent of criticism of Gov. George E. Pataki, saying that Mr. Pataki had stripped spending from higher education and mass transit.

title: Arrogance on NATO
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Citizen Holik Feels Czech Pride Over Gold
description: The more Bobby Holik read this morning about the Czech Republic's gold medal performance in men's hockey at the Winter Olympics, the more the Devils' center could feel something coming over him. He looked down at his arms.

title: New N.A.S.D. President to Lead Expansion
description: Richard G. Ketchum, the chief operating officer of the National Association of Securities Dealers, has been promoted to president and will assume more responsibility for the overseas expansion of the Nasdaq stock market.

title: J. P. Morgan Weighs Merger And Cuts Jobs
description: J. P. Morgan & Company, frustrated in its efforts to become a major investment banking concern, said yesterday that it would consider a merger, a once unthinkable option for a company that has historically prided itself on determining its own fate. The company also said that it would dismiss about 5 percent of its employees, or some 700 people.

title: For One Newcomer on Nets, Coach's Yells Are Welcome
description: Brian Evans was barely unpacked Saturday night, still trying to remember the plays and schemes he had just been force fed by the Nets, when he was called on to make his first appearance midway through the third quarter.

title: OMNICARE IN STOCK DEAL FOR COMPSCRIPT, A RIVAL
description: Omnicare Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire a rival pharmacy-management concern, Compscript Inc., for $63.3 million in stock. Under the agreement, Omnicare will value each Compscript share at $4.50. Shares of Compscript gained 53.125 cents yesterday, to $4. Shares of Omnicare rose $1.875, to $35.8125. Compscript, based in Boca Raton, Fla., provides pharmacy management, infusion therapy and consulting services to 137 long-term-care centers in five states. It has annual revenue of $52 million. Omnicare, of Cincinnati, provides pharmacy and related services to 5,500 long-term-care centers in 37 states. On closing, the deal will give Omnicare annual revenue of $1.2 billion.

title: Blankers-Koen Reflects on the New
description: Fifty years ago, Fanny Blankers-Koen of the Netherlands became the only woman to win four gold medals in track in one Olympics. She probably could have won more. She passed up the long jump and the high jump although she held the world records in both.

title: Monsanto Paying Delta Farmers to Settle Genetic Seed Complaints
description: The Monsanto Company has quietly begun paying settlements to Mississippi Delta farmers who contend that a cotton strain genetically engineered to survive being sprayed with a company weed killer failed to perform as promised, the company, a state official and the farmers' lawyers said yesterday.

title: Confusion Upsets Subway Riders at Start of 15-Month Repair in 63d Street Tunnel
description: Mariana Spinello, 13, was 45 minutes late to school yesterday. Chesley Charles fretted about his son Kadeem, 2, who waited past sundown for his father at a day-care center. And confusion reigned at subway stations in Manhattan and Queens and on Roosevelt Island as commuters on the B and Q trains turned to token sellers and one another to figure out where to go and how.

title: Philadelphia Neighborhood Reborn
description: The spires of downtown skyscrapers are clearly visible from the apartment on Gratz Street where Robin Witherspoon lives in the Cecil B. Moore neighborhood of lower North Philadelphia. For years, they were just about the only pleasant part of the view.

title: This Time, Experts Say, El Nino Probably Had a Role
description: It seems as though every flake of snow or drop of rain this winter is attributed to the warming of Pacific waters known as El Nino. While that troubles scientists who study the weather, they say that El Nino may well have set the stage for the deadly series of tornadoes that tore through Florida early today.

title: American Air And J.A.L. Are Expected To Join Forces
description: In the latest linkup between international airlines, American Airlines and Japan Airlines are expected to announce an alliance in Tokyo tomorrow, executives said.

title: Protesters Disrupt CUNY Board Meeting Over Remedial Education Proposal
description: The trustees of the City University of New York had just been informed of the largest cash gift they had ever received -- $10 million from George Weissman, the former chairman of the Philip Morris Companies and of Lincoln Center, and his wife, Mildred -- when a slender, young blond man leapt onto the board table yesterday afternoon, disrupting Mr. Weissman's remarks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENNEDY, ELIZABETH WRIGHT
description: KENNEDY-Elizabeth Wright. Of New York City and Chatham, MA. On February 20. Mrs. Kennedy was in her 30th year of teaching at St. Bernard's School. She is survived by her daughter Cornelia Kennedy Atkins, son-in-law Lawrence Atkins, and grandson Robert Andrew Atkins. Memorial service 10 AM, Saturday, March 7, at Holy Trinity Episcopal Church, 316 E. 88 St. Contributions may be made to the Sarah Wright Atkins Fund, St. Bernard's School, 4 E. 98 Street, NYC or St. Christopher's Episcopal Church, Chatham, MA.

title: Possible Tampering Reported
description: George Steinbrenner, principal owner of the Yankees, has called Bud Selig in the last 48 hours and alerted the acting commissioner to newspaper reports speculating about possible tampering by the Arizona Diamondbacks involving Bernie Williams, the Yankees center fielder.

title: Botha, Ex-Premier, Pleads Not Guilty to Contempt in Inquiry
description: Former President P. W. Botha pleaded not guilty to charges of contempt today, accusing South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission of having reneged on an agreement to allow him to testify in writing.

title: On Pointe in Black Boots From the Black Sea
description: Many troupes specializing in theatrical adaptations of folk dances are wildly energetic. There was certainly plenty of vigor in the performance that the Georgian State Dance Company presented on Saturday night at Lehman Center for the Performing Arts. But this admirable company also emphasizes elegance, and its dancers and musicians never fail to communicate a love of their homeland, the Republic of Georgia on the Black Sea.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEBEL, FREDERICK R. M.D.
description: MEBEL-Frederick R. M.D. On February 21, 1998. Devoted husband of the late Claire. Loving father of Elaine and Stuart. Beloved fatherin-law of Steven Schwartzreich. Adored grandfather of Ken, Jay, and Lauren. Lifelong resident and physician of Rockville Centre. Services Tuesday 12 noon at Gutterman's Inc, 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, Long Island.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPIRO, PERRY
description: SPIRO-Perry. On February 22, 1998. Devoted husband of Rita, loving father of Carolyn Spiro Cannata and Gregory Cannata, and Edward Spiro and Ellen Schwartz. Adoring grandfather of Alison, Sara, Matthew, and Robert. Caring brother of Benjamin. Former principal of JHS 135, Bronx. His was a life of public service, personal courage, and devotion to family. Services Wednesday, February 25, 10AM, the ''Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: No Immunity for Tobacco
description: It would be foolish and unjust to grant the tobacco industry any legal immunity for past or future conduct given newly released industry documents showing that cigarette manufacturers targeted young smokers and very likely manipulated nicotine in cigarettes to provide a greater physiological ''kick.'' Yet tobacco industry leaders insist that they will not curb advertising and merchandising that is attractive to youths without Congressional approval of a settlement that grants them substantial immunity from liability.

title: Most Global of Sports; What Home Team?
description: To the Editor:

title: Senate Bill Would Raise The Driving Age to 18
description: The minimum age for a full driver's license would rise to 18, and all new drivers would be subject to some restrictions for one year under bill approved by the Senate Law and Public Safety Committee yesterday.

title: Science Watch; Silent Company for Birds
description: PLASTIC pink flamingos, derided for decades as tacky lawn fauna, can now take their place beside the electron accelerator and the Mars Pathfinder as powerful tools of science, thanks to a team of researchers in Florida.

title: Metro Business; Staples to Take Over Most Rickel Leases
description: Staples agreed yesterday to buy the leases on 41 of 52 stores formerly occupied by Rickel Home Centers, the bankrupt building materials retailer based in South Plainfield, N.J.

title: Pop, Jazz, Whatever, With Ideas So Sweet
description: Cyrus Chestnut is perceived as a jazz player, but in the broadest sense of the term he is a pop musician. He easily transmits his ideas beyond the lip of the stage; his ideas are unremittingly sweet and playful. Most important, he swims between musical identities in transitions so smooth they're barely noticed.

title: Adoptive Parents Win Battle for Russian Girls
description: An Arizona couple found guilty of slapping and verbally abusing their newly adopted Russian children on a plane trip home from Moscow last May were granted full custody of the children yesterday.

title: Quote, End Quote
description: ''When was the last time you saw a teacher on a talk show? asked FRANK McCOURT, a former teacher and the author of ''Angela's Ashes,'' who will receive the Creative Leadership Award from New York University today. ''When the experts gather to discuss education and the schools, there's always somebody from a think tank or a university or a union head, but it's like discussing surgery without having a surgeon in the room.'' JAMES BARRON with MONIQUE P. YAZIGI

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERSTEIN, MILDRED
description: SILVERSTEIN - Mildred, 87, Bradenton, FL, died Sunday, Feb. 22. Graveside services Wednesday Feb. 25, 11 A.M. at Mount Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, New York.

title: A New Tangle for the Sale of the Islanders
description: The $195 million sale of the Islanders, which has been delayed several times, may become snarled again if an agreement between the team's prospective owners and the company that manages Nassau Coliseum is not reached today.

title: Personal Health; A Tad of Testosterone Adds Zest to Menopause
description: A FRIEND who remarried at 51 was feeling reborn, enjoying a renewed vitality and rejuvenated sex life with her new husband. But three years later, as she entered menopause and began hormone replacement therapy, her libido crashed. In great distress, she consulted her gynecologist, who suggested that she add a tiny dose of testosterone to her hormone regimen. Within weeks, she was back to feeling like her premenopausal self, once again enjoying sex.

title: Professors Fear to Grade Harshly; Maybe They Earned It
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNTON, HARLOW DONALD, M.D.
description: DUNTON-Harlow Donald, M.D. February 21, 1998. The staff and faculty of Child Psychiatry at Columbia extend their condolences to his wife Patricia and to his family. Dr. Dunton was a pioneer in the field, a former Director of the Division and a senior Professor in the Department. Many benefited from his kindness and support. His outstanding teaching and wisdom will be deeply missed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KNAPP, EVA WITTE
description: KNAPP-Eva Witte. Bronxville, NY February 23, 1998. Wife of George G.P. Knapp. Mother of Edward, Wesley, Helen and Elizabeth. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, NY between the hours of 6-8 PM, Thursday. Mass of Christian Burial St. Jospeh's Church, Bronxville on Friday, February 27 at 10 A.M.

title: MetroStars: Import, Export
description: About the only similarity between the MetroStars of last year and this season's team will be their preseason training in Italy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLEISIG, ESTHER
description: FLEISIG-Esther. Cherished wife of the late Harry. Loving mother, adored grandmother, great grandmother and sister. You will live on in our hearts. Services 10:15AM Wednesday, February 25, at ''Sinai Chapels'', 162-05 Horrace Harding Exprsswy, Fresh Meadows, N.Y.

title: Media Feeding Frenzy
description: To the Editor:

title: Want to Play In New York? Ask Politely
description: WITH the Grammy Awards being held tomorrow night at Radio City Music Hall, it's none too soon to wonder if the recording industry's big show will move to another city next year and become, as a headline writer put it, the Scrammys.

title: Buying a Deal as Hussein Buys Time
description: President Clinton had no real choice today.

title: Nasdaq at New Closing High as Technology Shares Soar
description: Technology stocks soared yesterday as investors brushed aside concerns about the impact of Asia's economic woes on American corporate profits, catapulting the Nasdaq composite index to a new closing high.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBISON, JAMES E.
description: ROBISON-James E. He flew (63 missions in W.W. II), he soared, skied, golfed, traveled, worked and gave. Generous to extreme, he sought no gratitude. He was one of a kind where sadly few will follow. A Friend

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FRIEDMAN, SAMUEL
description: FRIEDMAN-Samuel. 1920-1985. Sorely missed. What an empty void. We think of you every day. Love, Eleanor and Arthur

title: Despite Ratings, Games Boosted CBS
description: If ''The Closer'' isn't any good, blame the Winter Olympics hype.

title: Ice Storm Takes Its Toll on Vermont's Maple Syrup Industry
description: FOR most of the tens of thousands of Canadians and New Englanders left without power after last month's crippling ice storm, life has nearly returned to normal. But for sweet-tooths around the world addicted to the unique flavor of maple syrup and ''Indian sugar,'' the storm is expected to raise the cost of maintaining their expensive habit.

title: ATMEL AGREES TO BUY A TEMIC BUSINESS FROM VISHAY
description: The Atmel Corporation agreed to buy a unit of the chip maker Temic Telefunken Microelectronic G.m.b.H. from Vishay Intertechnology Inc. for about $140 million in cash. Atmel, a San Jose, Calif., maker of integrated circuits, will buy the part of Temic that makes chips for the telecommunications, automotive and consumer markets. Temic sold about $300 million of the chips in 1997. In December, Vishay said it would buy Temic from Daimler-Benz A.G. for $500 million. Vishay, of Malvern, Pa., will keep Temic's infrared data communications business and the units that make power and discrete chips.

title: Relics of a Once Feisty Future Rest in Peace in London
description: ''Regard art critics as useless and dangerous,'' proclaimed the 1909 manifesto that gave birth to Italian Futurism. And since it was a call to arms intended to shock, the manifesto penned by the poet Filippo Tommaso Marinetti offered other similarly inspired slogans, among them, ''No work without an aggressive character can be a masterpiece,'' and, ''We will destroy the museums, libraries, academies of every kind.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REFF, BENJAMIN F., M.D.
description: REFF-Benjamin F., M.D. Feb. 2, 1998 at the age of 90. Devoted and beloved father of Albert A. Reff and Hariette Wittenberg Saturn, grandfather of Joshua Wittenberg and Jacqueline Saturn. A maverick and compassionate physician who chartered his own course and whose lust for life was an example to his family, friends and patients. Donations in his memory to the United Jewish Appeal.

title: When the Elderly Fall, Shoes May Be to Blame
description: TO reduce the risk of a fall and subsequent injury, older people are often advised to wear sturdy shoes. But a new study has shown that the very shoes many older people select as protection can actually increase their risk of falling.

title: A Year Later, Victim Forms A New Group To Fight Guns
description: A year to the day after he was shot in a rampage atop the Empire State Building, Matthew Gross spoke publicly for the first time yesterday about the shooting that shattered his life, and announced the formation of a new anti-gun organization.

title: Rally on Defused Iraqi Crisis Is Short-Lived as Dollar Falls
description: An early bond market rally on the defused Iraqi crisis faded yesterday and left prices lower for the fourth day, hurt by weakness in the dollar and apprehension about the Congressional testimony today by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUDDY, LYN
description: DUDDY-Lyn. On February 23, 1998. TV producer, composer and songwriter for Jackie Gleason Show, Arthur Godfrey and Merv Griffin. Beloved son of the late John and Mae Duddy; loving nephew of Ann Gowen and Kathy McMullen. Also survived by many cousins and friends. Reposing Wednesday, 3-5 and 7-9 PM, at Chas. Peter Nagel Funeral Home, 352 East 87 Street, New York City, and Thursday 2-5 and 7-9PM, at the Denis S. O'Connor Funeral Home, 91-05 Beach Channel Drive, Rockaway Beach, New York. Mass of Christian Burial on Friday 10 AM, at St. Camillus Church, Beach 99 Street, Rockaway Park, NY. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: Patterns
description: The New Chloe at Bergdorf's

title: No Injuries As Car Bomb Damages Ulster Town
description: For the second time in three days a bomb believed to have been planted by Roman Catholic guerrillas ripped the center of a predominantly Protestant town today.

title: Jose Maria de Areilza, 88, Ex-Franco Aide
description: Jose Maria de Areilza y Martinez de Rodas, who was Franco's Ambassador to the United States in the 1950's but later soured on the Government and, after the dictator's death in 1975, served briefly as Foreign Minister, died on Sunday at his Madrid home. He was 88.

title: President's Adviser Ordered to Divulge Contact With Press
description: In a further escalation of the battle between the White House and the independent counsel Kenneth W. Starr, a senior White House adviser said today that he had been subpoenaed to testify before a Federal grand jury about any conversations he had had with journalists about Mr. Starr's office.

title: Reviving a Revival
description: Promise Keepers has fallen on hard times. Last November, after attendance at its rallies dropped, the group stopped charging admission fees. And last week, it announced plans to lay off its entire 345-member staff and rely on volunteers.

title: Waste Hauler Sentenced To 33 Months for Fraud
description: The owner of a Westchester County garbage-hauling company was sentenced yesterday to 33 months in prison for tax fraud conspiracy.

title: Metro Business; Utility Names New Chief
description: Nathaniel D. Woodson, an executive with the Westinghouse Electric Corporation for 30 years, will head the United Illuminating Company, a power company based in New Haven, the utility announced yesterday.

title: Chimfunshi Journal; Humans Answer Call to Be Their Cousins' Keepers
description: Mike was found in a box going round and round the luggage carousel at the Nairobi airport. Louise was found in a Moscow airport, dehydrated, hogtied, drugged with booze and crammed into the false bottom of a cage of rare parrots.

title: AVIS TO BUY FRANCHISES IN TEXAS FROM HAYES LEASING
description: Avis-Rent-A-Car Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Avis franchises and vehicles in Dallas, Fort Worth, San Antonio and Austin, Tex., from the Hayes Leasing Company for $200 million. The acquisition will add the Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport site to Avis's operations. Avis, based in Garden City, N.Y., is the world's No. 2 car-rental company, after the Hertz Corporation. It is 27.5 percent owned by the Cendant Corporation, a marketing concern. Avis owns 200,000 vehicles and has 15 million rental transactions a year. Hayes, with 1997 revenues of $77 million, owns 8,000 vehicles. Shares of Avis rose $1.25 yesterday, to $34.

title: INSIDE
description: Victory for 'Megan's Laws'

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORY, CHRISTOPHER B.
description: CORY-Christopher B. Of Boston died in the China Airlines crash Taipei, Taiwan, February 16, 1998. He is survived by his father Dr. Joseph P. Cory, his mother Janet A. Burbank Cory, two sisters Denise A. Hubbard, Diana M. Cory and one niece Olivia Seymour. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, March 7 at 2 PM at the Unitarian Church, Westport, CT. Visitation will be Thursday and Friday from 2-4 and 7-9 PM at the Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home, Greenwich, CT. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Bread & Roses, Georgetown, CT or PFLAG

title: A Team of Nomads Finds a Home at Hunter
description: George Brown proved he was a good basketball player when he started three games last season for the University of Alabama. Then he decided that he wanted to be a better dad. So he left school and returned to New York to help raise his 3-year-old daughter.

title: A Memoirist Who Disregards the Details
description: NOW AND THEN

title: Starr Investigation Maintains a Balance; Clintonites' Legal Bills
description: To the Editor:

title: Pianist Puts Off Recital
description: Because of a death in the family, the pianist Ursula Oppens has canceled her recital on Thursday at 8 P.M. at the Miller Theater at Columbia University. The concert has been rescheduled for March 29 at 3 P.M. at the Miller. Ms. Oppens's concert on March 12 is to take place as scheduled at 8 P.M. at the Miller, on Broadway at 116th Street.

title: On My Mind; Softening Saddam's Deal
description: Saddam Hussein would accept the ''diplomatic solution'' being offered to him by the United Nations, including the United States, because he could not ever dream up a softer deal for himself. I thought and wrote that, but amendment is now needed.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: MARK RISES SHARPLY. The dollar fell to a two-and-a-half-week low against the mark after a tentative agreement was reached to defuse the crisis with Iraq. In New York, the dollar cost 1.7933 marks, down from 1.8214.

title: California Hit by Strongest Storm of Season
description: The strongest storm of a waterlogged season hit an already drenched California today, worsening flooding, causing more mud slides and imperiling dozens of homes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SACKS, DR. WILLIAM
description: SACKS-Dr. William. On February 22, 1998. Beloved husband of Irene Sacks. Father of David Sacks of Ottawa, Judi Sacks of Morris Plains, NJ, Elaine Rust of Upper Montclair, NJ and Patricia Sacks of Lake Stockholm, NJ. Brother of Gertrude Sack and Harry Sack. Grandfather of Christine and Emily. Funeral Services will be held at the Shrine of St. Joseph, Stirling, NJ on Thursday, February 26 at 4PM. Visiting hours at Valley Memorial Funeral Home, 1012 Valley Road, Gillette, NJ on Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9 PM.
