Donations in his name can be made to the Long Hill First Aid Squad, PO Box 145, Gillette, New Jersey 07933.

title: Nassau Executive Assailed on Budget Deficit
description: In winning re-election as Nassau County Executive last fall, Thomas S. Gulotta flooded local television with campaign ads portraying him as a tax-cutting budget master. Now the accountants have totaled the ledgers for 1997, and they show that the $2.2 billion county budget ran a $35.6 million deficit.

title: Study Ties Sport Utility Vehicle Hazard to Weight and Frames
description: In the first Federal study intended to determine why sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks kill an unusually high number of drivers of other vehicles, regulators have blamed their weight and frames, which are stiffer and ride higher off the road than those of cars.

title: Toshiba to Add U.S. Tube Output
description: The Toshiba Corporation said today that its United States electronics division would begin making computer-monitor tubes in New York as part of an industry shift toward having parts suppliers situated near finished-products makers.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Feb. 17 about the marketing of mental health drugs directly to consumers understated the number of Americans believed to have schizophrenia. The National Institute of Mental Health estimates that the disease affects more than two million Americans, not 800,000.

title: Ross Wetzsteon, 65; Began Obies
description: Ross Wetzsteon, a longtime editor at The Village Voice who helped create the Obie Awards for Off Broadway and Off Off Broadway theater and was for 28 years the chairman and host of the annual event, died on Friday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan after heart surgery. He was 65 and lived in Greenwich Village.

title: Pitfalls in Cutting Korea's Lifetime Work Force
description: When this country's most militant labor union shelved a potentially crippling strike early this month, fears started to fade that the chances for South Korean economic recovery would be set back by debilitating labor unrest.

title: St. Peter? King Arthur? Been There, Done That
description: Want to meet a small-scale guru? He's yours tonight, courtesy of a ''Dateline NBC'' crew that tracked him down in Sedona, Ariz., and infiltrated his commune or company or congregation or con game with a hidden camera. He calls himself Gabriel of Sedona, wears a colorful headband or rag, tells of inhabiting many other personae over many centuries and runs tax-free businesses.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Injectable Heart Drug Grows Blood Vessels
description: DOCTORS in Germany have developed an experimental drug that creates new blood vessels and increases the blood supply to the human heart within days after injection, they reported yesterday in an American medical journal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, SARAH
description: SCHWARTZ-Sarah. On February 22, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Herman. Devoted mother of Robert and Martin. Beloved mother-in-law of Susan and Enid. Cherished grandmother of Amy Tanenbaum, Eric, Jonathan and Adam Schwartz. Much adored great grandmother of Mitchell and Jeffrey. Services were held February 23, 1998, at Plaza Memorial Chapel, New York City.

title: CHS ELECTRONICS TO ACQUIRE 80% OF HONG KONG CONCERN
description: CHS Electronics Inc. said yesterday that it would buy 80 percent of the Hong Kong-based microcomputer distributor SIS Distribution Ltd. for $70.4 million. SIS Holdings, the distributor's parent, will keep the remaining 20 percent of the company. CHS, of Miami, will pay $28.16 million cash initially and $42.24 million a year later in cash or shares. The company distributes networking products and software to retailers and wholesalers, mainly in Europe and South America. The recent financial turmoil in Asia was one of the reasons for the acquisition, CHS's chairman and chief executive, Claudio Osorio, said, citing ''some excellent opportunities where price is concerned.''

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the popularity of ballroom dance classes among fifth and sixth graders in Westchester County, N.Y., misspelled the surname of one girl in the class. She is Jocelyn Buly, not Boly.

title: Mets Assess Rewards And Risks Of Phillips
description: Tony Phillips's agent, Tony Attanasio, has told the Mets what his client is seeking to sign with them. He has even proposed a clause that would lead to the forfeiture of the player's salary if Phillips demonstrates a problem with cocaine, the drug involved when Phillips pleaded guilty to a possession charge last year while with the Anaheim Angels.

title: Argentines Press Ex-Soldiers on Swiss Cash
description: The recent discovery in Switzerland of at least four bank accounts registered to former members of the Argentine military has provided prosecutors, human rights advocates and politicians with new ammunition in the battle to punish those responsible for crimes during the country's last dictatorship.

title: State's Witness Assails Judge In Brawley Case
description: A writer who has become one of the most contentious witnesses in the Tawana Brawley defamation case took it upon himself today to castigate the judge while trying to undermine the Rev. Al Sharpton's defense.

title: Choosing Schools Betters Students In East Harlem
description: Twenty-four years after a school district in East Harlem began one of the nation's most extensive experiments in educational competition, a study released yesterday found that the district's program of allowing students to choose what schools to attend had lifted achievement in all schools and had not created a system of haves and have-nots.

title: Moving Forward at the N.A.A.C.P.
description: With Myrlie Evers-Williams stepping down, the National Association for The Advancement of Colored People has chosen the veteran legislator and civil rights worker Julian Bond to replace her as chairman. In Mr. Bond the nation's oldest civil rights organization has selected a solid, charismatic figure with proven credentials and a steady compass on race relations.

title: DSM Bids $1.3 Billion For Gist-Brocades
description: DSM N.V., a Dutch chemical and plastics maker, said yesterday that it had bid 66 guilders a share, a total of 2.7 billion guilders ($1.3 billion) in stock and cash, for Royal Gist-Brocades N.V. The stock of Gist-Brocades closed at 60 on Friday. DSM will offer one-sixth of a DSM share plus 32.50 guilders in cash for each of the Gist-Brocades shares.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'SULLIVAN, JOHN P.
description: O'SULLIVAN-John P. On February 22nd, 1998. Beloved husband of Patricia. Father of Kathleen Scansaroli, Patricia Tamburino, Anne Barton, Susan Singleton, Marguerite Conway, Julie Koziarz, Elizabeth McElroy, Amy O'Shea, John V. O'Sullivan and the late Moira O'Sullivan. Brother of Eileen Blake and Peter O'Sullivan. Also survived by twelve grandchildren. Reposing at Lloyd Maxcy Beauchamp Chapel, Shea Place, New Rochelle. Mass of Christian Burial, on Wednesday 11 A.M., Holy Family Church. Interment Beechwoods Cemetery. Visiting hours Tues. 2-4, 7-9 PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions to St. Joseph's Hospital, Dialysis Center, Yonkers, N.Y., or the Westchester Association for Retarded Citizens, White Plains, New York preferred.

title: Composers Of Norway, On Down Through Many Eras
description: It is tempting to make too much of the coincidences of programming, but it seems as though the Scandinavian countries have joined forces to wrest the spotlight away from central Europe. This season, Finland has been represented by generous helpings of Sibelius and more fleeting glimpses of contemporary composers. At Alice Tully Hall on Saturday evening, Norway, by way of the Edvard Grieg Society of New York, demanded attention as well.

title: Williams Is in Line To Sign a Third Time
description: You can bench him, you can put him on the injury list and you can even trade him. But you cannot get rid of Herb Williams. He is the Power Forward Who Will Not Go Away.

title: Sybase Eliminates 600 Jobs In a Move to Restore Profits
description: Sybase Inc., struggling to regain profitability, said today that it had dismissed nearly 600 employees, or about 10 percent of its worldwide work force.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARDNER, HENRIETTA HOLTZMAN
description: GARDNER-Henrietta Holtzman. A pianist and educator, she was the wife of the late Pulitzer Prize winning composer, violinist and teacher Samuel Gardner. She was a founding member and past president of The Music Teachers Association of The Public Schools of The City of New York, and a past president of The Lincoln Chapter of the B'nai B'rith Women. She succumbed to advanced age at The Jewish Home and Hospital in the Bronx, February 22. Mrs. Gardner was graduated from The Juilliard School and received graduate degrees from Teachers College, Columbia University. She was her husband's accompanist and taught for many years in the City's public schools. She is survived by her son, Herbert Straus Gardner and his wife Jane of New York and Juno Beach, Florida, two grandsons James A. and Jeffrey H. Gardner, a great-granddaughter, a step-daughter Sara G. Clement and her children and grandchildren. A person of warmth, enthusiasm, humor and dedication to public service, she will be mourned and missed by her family, friends, former students and colleagues. Services on Tuesday 10:45 AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Telling Vivid Stories Through Sound
description: The fitness of the Met Orchestra under James Levine could not have been better displayed than it was at Carnegie Hall on Sunday afternoon, in a program where qualities of sheer sound were paramount. Berlioz's ''Symphonie Fantastique'' ended the concert, and was by turns rousing and gentle, but always atmospheric and always strongly focused.

title: Scientist at Work: Mark Ptashne; Virtuoso in Plucking Violin or Secrets of Genetic Switches
description: DR. MARK PTASHNE rises early every day and retreats to his music studio before breakfast. For two hours or more, he plays the violin. Then he heads for the laboratory, where he is a molecular biologist.

title: Deutsche Bank Plans Layoffs
description: Deutsche Bank A.G. expects to lay off up to 100 people in the United States this week, according to an executive at the company, who declined to be identified by name.

title: CLINTON SAYS IRAQ IS PROMISING UNCONDITIONAL ACCESS TO SITES
description: President Clinton said today that Iraq had agreed to allow United Nations weapons inspectors immediate and unconditional access throughout the country, and he began to seek British, French and Russian support for a Security Council resolution that would warn Saddam Hussein of serious consequences if the deal is violated.

title: Professors Fear to Grade Harshly
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAFT, NORMAN
description: KRAFT-Norman. On Feb. 21, 1998. Beloved and devoted husband of Diane. Father of Zina and Mark, father-in-law of Matthew and Shawna, grandfather of Alex, Jesse and Nicole, devoted brotherin-law, uncle and great uncle. Here was a man with a heart filled with the gift of love, the precious ability to share that love, a man with the character to truly and fully commit to others. Here was a man who brought joy to all who knew him. Through laughter and tears, there was always this man, Norman Kraft (Noach Tanchum Ben Aaron Yankov). Services will be held Tuesday, Feb. 24 at 12 noon, Schwartz Brothers Chapel, 114-03 Queens Blvd., Forest Hills, N.Y.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Saturday about Donald Flamm, a former New York broadcaster and theatrical producer, misstated the given name of a survivor. His brother is Milton Flamm of Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., not Morris.

title: Billy Sullivan, 86, Founder Of Football Patriots, Dies
description: Billy Sullivan, a former newspaperman, printing salesman, college publicist and oil-company executive who founded the Boston (now New England) Patriots professional football team and ran it for almost 30 often-rocky years, died yesterday at his retirement home in Atlantis, Fla. He was 82 years old and, according to his son Chuck, had suffered from prostate cancer for eight years.

title: Professors Fear to Grade Harshly; New System Needed
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Child Agencies Approved Foster Mother Held in Death
description: A Brooklyn foster mother accused of killing a 23-month-old boy in her care had been approved by two foster care agencies and seemed to be handling the boy and his two brothers well, child welfare workers said yesterday.

title: Investcorp Tops Quebecor In Bid for Watmoughs
description: Investcorp S.A., an international investment holding company, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Watmoughs Holdings, a British printing company, for $:250 million ($408.8 million), topping a hostile bid from Quebecor Inc. of Canada.

title: The Softer Side of Summitt
description: It is clear from watching Pat Summitt these days that she has a certain comfort level and control of her surroundings. After all, Tennessee women's basketball is big business, and Summitt is the coach who made it happen.

title: Grammy Chief Stops Short Of Full Apology to Giuliani
description: As the Grammy Awards ceremony tomorrow drew closer, the man in charge of the event refused yesterday to meet Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's condition for ending their feud: agreeing that he insulted several mayoral aides last month.

title: How Accord Will Work: Special Group Is Set Up
description: Following is the text of the agreement signed by the Iraqi Deputy Prime Minister, Tariq Aziz, and the United Nations Secretary General, Kofi Annan, obtained by The Associated Press:

title: Chess; When Kasparov Is Absent, Anand and Kramnik Shine
description: The 60th Hoogoven International Tournament in Wijk-aan-Zee, the Netherlands, from Jan. 16 to Feb. 1, showed once again that when Garry Kasparov does not compete, the first prize goes to Viswanathan Anand and Vladimir Kramnik. These two grandmasters, one from India, the other from Russia, scored 8 1/2-4 1/2 to lead a distinguished 14-player field in this traditional competition.

title: Curtains Going Up Here and There
description: With two big movie premieres at opposite ends of Manhattan, it was a night when the publicity machines were going full blast.

title: Excerpts From Fed Chairman's Testimony Before House Panel
description: Following are excerpts from testimony yesterday by Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, before the House Banking Committee:

title: Dudley Is Injured In Dismal Knick Loss
description: The boos accompanying a deflating loss made the Knicks wince. Yet on a night when they played their worst basketball of the season at Madison Square Garden, the image of Chris Dudley on crutches was far worse.

title: Bozell Resigns From Merrill Account
description: Bozell Worldwide in New York said yesterday that it had decided against participating in a review called by a large client, Merrill Lynch & Company, thereby resigning from the worldwide account after 12 years. Billings were estimated at $70 million.

title: A Seduction, A Romance And a Farce, Via Chekhov
description: Ludicrous as the comparison may seem, Richard Wargo's ''Chekhov Trilogy'' makes a listener appreciate Wagner's ''Ring'' cycle all the more. The ''Ring,'' though conceived over three decades on the grandest scale, is nevertheless the most tightly unified of theatrical creations.

title: Arrests Put Focus on Human Organs From China
description: However it plays out in the criminal justice system, the arrest in New York of two Chinese citizens on charges of conspiring to sell human organs has drawn attention to practices inside China that have long drawn criticism from Western human rights advocates.

title: South Korea's New President Appeals to North to End Decades of Division
description: Kim Dae Jung, one of Asia's most vigorous voices for democracy and political tolerance, was inaugurated as South Korea's President this morning and immediately called for reconciliation and cooperation with North Korea.

title: Rio Journal; The Beauty of It! Face Lifts Pay for Poor's Surgery
description: As Marcia Rodrigues, a former actress, neared the daunting threshold of her 50th birthday, the question she faced was not whether to have plastic surgery, but where.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, STELLA (BROWNIE)
description: KAUFMAN-Stella (Brownie). A year has gone since your flame went out, but the memories of how brightly it burned will live on in our hearts. We love you. We miss you, my precious. You were truly special. Your loved ones.

title: Burger Signing Near
description: The Jets appear close to a deal with Todd Burger, a free-agent guard who played with the Chicago Bears for the last six seasons and became a starter two years ago. Burger, who went to Arthur L. Johnson Regional High School in Clark, N.J., and played at Penn State, would fill an immediate need at left guard. GERALD ESKENAZI

title: If You're Being Watched, the Law Is No Help; Traces Wherever We Go
description: To the Editor:

title: Executive Privilege Invoked In Clinton Aides' Testimony
description: President Clinton is invoking executive privilege to shield top aides from testifying about internal White House discussions on the Monica S. Lewinsky investigation, according to lawyers involved in the case.

title: Food Stuff; A Rich Stranger Rides In From the West; Lips Smack
description: Double Rainbow, an ice cream brand from San Francisco, has finally made it to New York. It is a super-premium confection that is a bit younger than its tie-dyed name suggests, since it has been on the market for about 20 years. This ice cream is utterly smooth and despite its high butterfat content, 17 percent, does not have a heavy, tongue-coating fatness.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPSHULTZ, EDWARD
description: LIPSHULTZ-Edward. February 22, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Yvette, loving father of Richard, dear brother of Edythe and Frederick Cooper. Devoted uncle of Susan Stein and Barbara Cooper. Graveside service Wednesday, 11 A.M., at Montefiore Cemetery, St. Albans, Queens.

title: Test Kitchen; Espresso (and Cappuccino) Artistry at Home
description: MAKING espresso at home has never been easier or -- in some cases -- better, thanks to a new technology that simplifies the process considerably. An increasing number of electric espresso makers for the home are now designed to accept round pods -- single servings of dark-roasted, finely ground coffee sealed in filter paper, like teabags. A few have just appeared on the market, but most will be available in coming months.

title: ENGELHARD TO BUY MALLINCKRODT'S CATALYST UNIT
description: The Engelhard Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Mallinckrodt Inc.'s chemical-catalyst unit for $210 million in cash to expand and diversify its line of chemical-making products. Mallinckrodt's catalyst business has about $100 million in sales a year and includes two manufacturing plants in Texas and Pennsylvania that employ 280 people. Mallinckrodt is based in St. Louis. Engelhard, based in Iselin, N.J., a maker of specialty chemicals and engineered materials, had sales of $3.63 billion in 1997.

title: Oxford Health May Be Facing Deep Changes
description: For the two million members of Oxford Health Plans, the era of affordable choices among high-quality doctors could change radically under a shake-up announced yesterday to stop the company's financial bleeding.

title: Continental Is Said to Reach Deal On Contract With Pilots' Union
description: Continental Airlines and its pilots' union reached a tentative agreement on a new five-year contract late yesterday, clearing a potential obstacle to a recently announced alliance with Northwest Airlines, according to a person close to the negotiations.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MICROAGE INC., Tempe, Ariz., a computer reseller and technology services company, laid off 300 employees, or 6 percent of its work force, and is considering splitting into two independent companies to cope with slow sales and lower profits.

title: COURT, 6-0, BACKS NEW YORK STATUTE LIMITING SEX SHOPS
description: New York State's highest court upheld today the constitutionality of a New York City zoning law that bans X-rated businesses from residential neighborhoods, paving the way for the city to start closing down sex shops that are in violation of the law.

title: More Sleaze Journalism
description: To the Editor:

title: Soviet Defector Warns of Biological Weapons
description: A defector from the former Soviet biological weapons program said in an interview today that Moscow's cold war plans for World War III included preparing ''hundreds of tons'' of anthrax bacteria and scores of tons of smallpox and plague viruses.

title: G.E. Wins Delay of Study on Cleaning Up Hudson
description: Under pressure from the General Electric Company and a powerful upstate Congressman, the United States Environmental Protection Agency has decided to slow down completion of an important study of PCB contamination in the Hudson River.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIRNBAUM, ANDOR JACK BIRNBAUM
description: BIRNBAUM-Andor Jack Birnbaum, passed away in Jerusalem this past Friday evening. Shiva is being observed in Raanana, Great Neck and Manhattan. David Birnbaum, his mother Rhoda, and sister Eve will all be at the Manhattan Shiva after 4PM Thursday, February 26. The Manhattan Shiva address is Birnbaum-Goldberg 35 W. 90th St. (off C.P.W.). Fax contact number is 212 398-9438.

title: School Uniforms Help
description: To the Editor:

title: Interest on State Bonds Is Lowest Since 1971
description: The state sold $410 million in bonds yesterday to pay for programs ranging from historic preservation to assistance for people with disabilities, and the interest rate, 4.77 percent, was the lowest since 1971, state officials said.

title: Blair Puts His Weight Behind Dome Of Millennium
description: The Millennium Dome, Britain's ambitious monument to the next century, has been derided as an extravagant irrelevancy, a political vanity project and a colossal waste of $1.24 billion.

title: A Glenn Gould Fan Plays an Answer to His Idol's Question
description: A young man who elects Glenn Gould as his idol -- to the extent of making Bach's ''Goldberg Variations'' the main work in his Naumburg Award recital, and even of composing a reply to Gould's piece ''So, You Want to Write a Fugue'' and calling it ''Yes, I Want to Write a Fugue!'' -- might seem to be putting himself in danger. But I think Anthony Molinaro, who played at Alice Tully Hall on Monday night, is going to be O.K.

title: The Neglected Cuisine of Tunisia
description: IN America's rush to adapt and adopt all manner of Mediterranean cooking, one country, Tunisia, has been overlooked. For example, even though Tunisia is the world's fourth-largest producer of olive oil, almost all its oil is shipped to Spain, Italy and France for rebottling as their own. Tunisia also deserves credit for its couscous, which is more varied than it is anywhere else, and chefs worldwide can thank the country for harissa, the increasingly popular peppery condiment.

title: Whispering Campaign Was Prod for Subpoenas
description: For several weeks, Kenneth W. Starr, the independent counsel, has become increasingly irate about rumors concerning the conduct of several of his top prosecutors. And aides said he was convinced that the information, some of it false, was coming from the White House and loyalists of President Clinton.

title: Both Ben and Jerry Turn Down an Offer
description: Ben & Jerry's Inc. said today that its co-founders, Ben Cohen and Jerry Greenfield, had recently rejected a buyout offer from Dreyer's Grand Ice Cream Inc.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIBICOFF, SENATOR ABRAHAM A.
description: RIBICOFF-Senator Abraham A. The Board of Directors, residents and staff of The Hebrew Home for the Aged at Riverdale mourn with profound sorrow the death of Senator Abraham Ribicoff. Eminent statesman and distinguished national leader, Senator Ribicoff made a difference in the lives of millions of Americans in his years of dedicated public service, just as he touched all of us with his warmth and gentleness in his stay at the Hebrew Home at Riverdale. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his loving and devoted wife Casey and the entire Ribicoff family. Milton A. Gilbert, President Bernard Goldberg, Chairman Jacob Reingold, Vice Chairman Daniel A. Reingold, Exec. V.P.

title: TV Notes; Competition Winners
description: In terms of ancillary benefits from the Olympics, CBS's positive results included the highest-rated week for its evening newscast in more then three years, and two weeks of victories for David Letterman in the late-night competition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, FLORRIE
description: GOLDMAN-Florrie. Died February 20. Devoted wife of the late Julius. Her children Alan and Don, their spouses Joanne and Cheryl, her grandchildren James, Cathy and Drew and great grandchild Peter celebrate her life. Donations to Brooklyn Hospice, 6323 7 Avenue, Brooklyn, N.Y. 11220.

title: George S. Leonard, 86, Lawyer
description: George S. Leonard, a former Washington trial lawyer and Justice Department official during the Eisenhower Administration, died on Feb. 16 at Alexandria Hospital in Alexandria, Va. He was 86 and lived in Alexandria.

title: 2d-Half Net Fell 73% at NatWest
description: National Westminster Bank P.L.C.'s implied second-half net income fell 73 percent, which was worse than expected, amid problems with private banking and Asian loans. NatWest did not break out second-half figures as it said full-year net rose 56 percent. But after subtracting announced first-half results, second-half net income was $:139 million ($228 million), compared with $:513 million a year ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARLTON, MARGARET GILLIES
description: CARLTON-Margaret Gillies, 94. February 21, 1998. Wife of the late Winslow Carlton, mother of Mary G. Swope, Ann W. Carlton, and Rhona Carlton-Foss and grandmother of Tim and Ian Swope and Margaret Carlton-Foss. Funeral Services 3:30 PM, Saturday, Feb. 28, Church of the Messiah, Church St., Woodshole, MA. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Henry Street Settlement.

title: Bank Pledges $5 Billion For Low-Income Areas
description: First Union Corporation agreed yesterday to set aside $5 billion for loans to individuals and small businesses in low- and moderate-income areas over five years if a merger with CoreStates Financial Corporation is approved.

title: Op-Art
If You're Being Watched, the Law Is No Help; Privacy Solution?
description: To the Editor:

title: Grand Central Gets Northern Exposure; The Terminal Is Looking Uptown With a New Maze of Passageways
description: While no one was looking, Grand Central Terminal grew four blocks longer.

title: Lawmakers Demand Prompt Test of Hussein's Promise to U.N.
description: Republican and Democratic lawmakers made demands today for a quick test of President Saddam Hussein's promise to allow United Nations weapons inspectors unfettered and unconditional access throughout Iraq.

title: Disney Shareholders Vote Down Independent Director Measure
description: Walt Disney Company shareholders today rejected a move by some large institutional investors to redefine what constitutes an independent director, although the measure garnered the support of 35 percent of the shares voted.

title: Astros See Tornado's Terror Up Close
description: About 200 yards from the Houston Astros' spring training complex, nine people died in one of a series of the deadliest tornadoes to hit Florida. A sizable portion of the team's players was eternally thankful today that the same tornado spared them.

title: Rave On: Carlesimo Doesn't Plan to Change
description: When P. J. Carlesimo talks about the Incident, he sounds as if he were a studio commentator rather than the coach who was assaulted by one of his players. He is either in denial, or he genuinely believes that he can see the forest through the trees in the matter of Latrell Sprewell vs. the System.

title: Clinton Budget Will Only Add to the Surplus
description: To the Editor:

title: Finding Harmony Amid the Diversity
description: ONE NATION, AFTER ALL

title: Critic's Notebook; A Bout of Bad Taste Can Make a Day Worthwhile
description: Bad taste is a great equalizer; it comes in many guises, but eventually it afflicts us all somewhere, at some time. It is easy enough to accept bad taste that has been sanctioned by critics or artists: camp, punk or the entire world of Andy Warhol. Harder to admit is that it is an integral part of our daily lives. But if we can talk so openly about things like depression or sexual dysfunction, surely we can admit to chronic bouts of bad taste.

title: About New York; Gun They Could Not Get Killed Son
description: TWO ''Cop of the Month'' plaques honoring Transit Officer Pedro Murphy hang near an official portrait of him in the living room of his Staten Island home. They face certificates and photographs marking the day in 1996 when his wife, Catherine, graduated from the Police Academy. Although Mr. Murphy has four years on her in seniority, she has something on him, too.

title: Ethnic Chinese in Malaysia Can Buy Big Equity Stakes
description: The Asian economic crisis has forced Malaysia to relax its policy of promoting indigenous Malays over Chinese, which had been considered sacrosanct over the last 25 years.

title: Trout as Wild as All Outdoors, Almost
description: THEY call this place the Magic Valley. Just past the town of Bliss, about an hour southeast of Boise, the reason for the name is evident. First comes the sound, a distant white noise, building to a roar as you approach. Then the sight: water shooting out of the canyon walls, hundreds of springs at the end of a journey from snow melt in the Rocky Mountains, through a vast underground aquifer, bursting out to join the Snake River.

title: Citing Improving Economy, Moody's Raises City's Bond Rating
description: A major Wall Street credit-rating agency raised New York's long-term creditworthiness yesterday, citing the city's improving economy and City Hall's prudent budget management.

title: A Lean Unit Explores Fat Subjects For HBO
description: The debate is lively, the topics as diverse as the 15 people sitting at the conference table at HBO-NYC brainstorming about development projects. There are nine women and six men. Four are black, one is Asian-American, two are gay. All but three are under 35. And they constitute almost the entire permanent staff of a television movie studio that last year won more Emmy Awards than any other.

title: Connecticut Lawmakers Try Again to Force Health Insurers to Pay for Birth Control
description: Legislative leaders from both parties said today that they were determined to pass a bill that would require all insurance companies to cover the cost of prescription birth control, an expense that many women now pay out of their own pockets.

title: Interpublic Group continues its shopping spree by buying Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos.
description: FORTY-EIGHT hours after Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos finished helping a big client, John Hancock, advertise during the Winter Olympics, the agency went for the gold, too, by agreeing to be acquired by the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: Foster Agencies Called Lax, and Faulted in a Girl's Death
description: A study by New York City's child welfare agency has found that foster care agencies often fail to report allegations of abuse and neglect suffered by children at the hands of their foster parents, a problem that the report says may have contributed to the death of a 4-year-old girl.

title: Creating Musical Thunder With Elegance and Self-Restraint
description: When Anton Mordasov made his New York debut as an orchestral soloist, five years ago, he was a recent winner of the Rachmaninoff Piano Competition in Moscow. Since then he has won another gold medal, at the 1996 World Piano Competition, in Cincinnati. He claimed his prize, a debut recital at Alice Tully Hall, on Saturday evening.

title: Market Place; SmithKline-Glaxo Failure Dampens Merger Talk and Drug Stocks
description: The collapse of merger discussions between SmithKline Beecham and Glaxo Wellcome has squelched merger fever in the American pharmaceutical market.

title: Both East and West Coasts Emerge Battered From the Ferocious Grasp of Nature; In California, at Least 9 Die In Latest El Nino Drenching
description: The worst El Nino storm of a stormy winter left much of California cleaning up today from torrential rains, rare tornadoes, treacherous mud slides and flash flooding that damaged homes, washed away cars and caused the deaths of at least nine people from the central coast to the Mexican border.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SILVER FALLS. CPM Group forecasts that new silver supply will rise 12.5 percent this year while demand will grow 3 percent, cutting a deficit between demand and supply by 25 percent. March silver fell 13.8 cents, to $6.335.

title: Senators Vote to Keep Alive Bill Overhauling Campaign Finances
description: Defying the Republican leadership, a majority of the Senate today voted to keep alive legislation that would overhaul the way that the nation's political campaigns are financed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILBRIDE, GERARD A.
description: GILBRIDE-Gerard A. Of North White Plains, NY on Feb. 22, 1998. Former Assistant Dean, Brooklyn Law School. Husband of Mary Gilbride. Father of Rod and Edward F.X. Gilbride, Jayne Bauer, Christine Gilbride, Grace Hottinger, Nancy Conforti, Mary Richards, Betsy DeSoye, Joan Shea, Carolyn Schaus and Sheila Passenant. Brother of John T. Gilbride and John J. Mullaney. Grandfather of 26. Funeral Mass Saturday 10AM at St. Bernard's Church, White Plains, NY. Interment Mt. Calvary Cemetery. Reposing at the Ballard Durand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Avenue, White Plains, New York, Thursday 7-9 PM, Friday 2-4 and 79 PM. Memorial contributions to Jesuit Seminary and Mission Bureau, 39 East 83rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10028, would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOYT, BARBARA
description: HOYT-Barbara. The Board and staff of Spence-Chapin Services to Families and Children mourn the loss of a valued friend who gave of her skills, wisdom and support for forty years as a member of the Board of Directors. She will be remembered with great fondness for her dignity, charm and dedication. The Directors and staff extend our deepest sympathy to her family and to her many friends.

title: FIRST UNION TO CUT 7,480 JOBS AFTER CORESTATES MERGER
description: The First Union Corporation said yesterday that it would eliminate 7,480 jobs and close 172 bank branches in the Philadelphia area after its acquisition of the Corestates Financial Corporation. The net loss of jobs will be about 4,400, however, because First Union expects to move or create 3,075 jobs in the area, said John Georgius, First Union's president. First Union, of Charlotte, N.C., had said in November that it would pay $16.5 billion for Philadelphia-based Corestates. At the time, Corestates said that it expected no more than 3,000 jobs to be lost. About 17 percent of Corestates' branch network in Pennsylvania, New Jersey and Delaware will be closed as a result of overlaps with First Union offices.

title: Nazi Monster or Not? A Twisting Search for the Truth
description: At first impression, Arthur Goldman, the antihero of Robert Shaw's gripping play, ''The Man in the Glass Booth,'' which is being given a searching revival at the Jean Cocteau Repertory, appears to be a brash New York real estate tycoon, a German-born Jew who survived the Nazi camps and now enjoys spending his fortune on silk suits, vicuna coats and Havana cigars. When he tires of looking at his Rembrandt, he has his gofers replace it with his Poussin.

title: TV Notes; Fate of ''Ellen''
description: ABC steadfastly denied yesterday that it has made any official decision about the future of its comedy ''Ellen,'' even in the face of comments the show's star, Ellen DeGeneres, made to a camera crew this week in which she flatly said the show was headed for cancellation.

title: Irabu Begins a Rebuilding Year With Two Good Innings
description: Hideki Irabu's advance billing last year was based on power, like a movie built around special effects. His fastball lights up a radar gun, Yankees scouts said, and his forkball explodes. If anything good came out of his disastrous 1997 season, it was that Irabu apparently learned he cannot survive on power alone.

title: Donald S. Russell Dies at 92; Politician and Federal Judge
description: Donald Stuart Russell, a former Governor of South Carolina, former United States Senator and a Federal judge for more than 30 years, died on Sunday, his 92d birthday, at his home in Spartanburg, S.C.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TURNER, JAYNE
description: TURNER-Jayne. It is with profound sadness that the friends and family of Jayne Turner announce her passing on February 13, 1998 due to complications from a stroke. She will forever be remembered in the hearts of those she touched with her time and talent as one of Broadway's most gifted dancers. Miss. Turner is survived by her mother Mrs. Gertrude Hornby.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARMANIE, RAYMOND
description: ARMANIE-Raymond. Artist, photographer, 1939-1998. Beloved son of Edith, brother of George, father of Kevin, Raymond, Rodney, Nicole, Amber, and Lauren. Dear friend to many who loved him. Memorial service Sat., Feb. 28, 1-4. Lasher's Funeral Home, 100 Tinker St. (Rte 212) Woodstock, NY.

title: Sports of The Times; Thomas Isn't Appreciated By Baseball
description: FRANK THOMAS of the Chicago White Sox is the best ballplayer no one pays much attention to -- to the detriment of baseball. What Thomas has achieved is a lot to ignore, but somehow the sporting public is managing quite nicely but wrongly to do so.

title: Study Faults Teams' Efforts on Hiring Minority Coaches
description: Despite a growing number of blacks, Hispanics, Asian-Americans and women in the league headquarters of professional basketball, football and baseball, minority groups are still greatly underrepresented among the teams' head coaches and managers, the Northeastern University Center for the Study of Sport in Society said reported yesterday.

title: Sharpton's Lawyer Ends Questioning of Writer
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton's lawyer yesterday ended an exhaustive cross-examination of a witness in the Tawana Brawley defamation case who he sought to paint as a racist writer who had been biased against Mr. Sharpton for years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, THEODORE R.
description: MILLER-Theodore R. The staff of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center notes with sorrow the passing of their dear colleague Dr. Theodore Miller, a pioneering surgical oncologist. Dr. Miller joined the staff of Memorial Hospital for Cancer and Allied Diseases in 1947. From 1964 to 1972 he was Chief of the Orthopaedic Service. At the time of his death, Dr. Miller was an Emeritus staff member. Dr. Miller's contributions to treatment and patient care will serve generations of physicians. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Dr. Miller's family. The Staff of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center

title: Annan Says He Has the Council's Backing
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan said today that he had the Security Council's general approval for his agreement with Saddam Hussein, which gives United Nations weapons inspectors unrestricted access in Iraq, and that he expected the Council's unanimous support once the details were worked out.

title: Kofi Annan's Flawed Agreement
description: Kofi Annan, the Secretary General of the United Nations, was far too optimistic yesterday when he said, ''I think I can do business'' with Saddam Hussein.

title: Edith Oliver, 84, Drama Critic At New Yorker for 31 Years
description: Edith Oliver, a diminutive, raspy-voiced and highly influential drama critic at The New Yorker for more than three decades who got her start writing questions for radio quiz shows, died on Monday at her home in Manhattan. She was 84.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOKOLOFF, NOEL NIKOLAI
description: SOKOLOFF-Noel Nikolai. Age 74. In San Francisco on February 21, 1998. He is survived by companion William Vitale, brother Martin, children Julia, Katie and Andrew Sokoloff, and four grandchildren. Noel was born in Cleveland, OH December 27, 1923, the son of famed orchestral conductor Nikolai Sokoloff. A gifted composer, Noel enjoyed a distinguished career with the Mannes College Music Department. In the early 1960's, Noel entered the Episcopal ministry and served parishes in Washington, D.C. and New Hampshire. In 1979, Noel moved to New York City, where he served as Rebuilding Coordinator for Saint Luke's in the Field. He later moved to San Francisco where he combined his love of music with an active ministry as part of the clergy at Saint Luke's Church.

title: Suspect Is Convicted Of 6 Murders in Queens
description: A man who fled to Mexico after he and two other men killed six people in a Queens apartment was convicted yesterday in the murders.

title: Sips; A Southern Ginger Ale With Sting in Its Tail
description: THE first swallow brings on a four-sneeze fit. The second one clears out the sinuses and leaves the tongue and throat throbbing with prickly heat. John T. Edge, a food scholar with the Center for the Study of Southern Culture at the University of Mississippi, has compared it to ''a slap in the face from a spurned lover.'' Blenheim Ginger Ale, the sweet-hot pride of South Carolina, pulls no punches, and its feisty approach has propelled it from modest regional fame to cult status.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OLIVER, EDITH (GOLDSMITH)
description: OLIVER-Edith (Goldsmith). Devoted sister of Robert Goldsmith and sister-in-law Joyce. Loving aunt of Diane, Joan and Vicki and great-aunt of Heather, Christopher and Robin. A memorial gathering will be held at a future date.

title: Prices Retreat After Fed Chief Dims Hopes for Rate Cut
description: Bond prices fell sharply yesterday after the chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, delivered a cautionary message on the economy that indicated that the central bank was unlikely to change its current monetary policy any time soon.

title: Pirates' 3-Point Barrage Quells the Hurricanes
description: SETON HALL 76, MIAMI 71

title: Point Guards Square Off
description: HEAT 104, JAZZ 102

title: Young Kirov Stars to Perform in Brooklyn
description: Young stars of the Kirov Ballet, most of them recent graduates of the Vaganova Ballet Academy, the company's school in St. Petersburg, Russia, will perform with the school's students in a four-day program opening tonight at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The Kirov dancers are Igor Zelensky, Ulyana Lopatkina, Zhanna Ayupova, Anastasiya Volochkova, Andrian Fadeyev and Vyacheslav Samodurov. Ms. Lopatkina will not dance on Friday and Saturday.

title: The Chef
description: MANY cooks these days, at least restaurant cooks, pay a lot of lip service to the notions of purity and simplicity of ingredients. But when they actually approach the stove, they feel a tremendous compulsion to push on into complexity, and in the process, that vaunted purity is lost. This arctic char recipe, I believe, is emblematic of my own maturation as a cook. I'm not going to tell you that I've abandoned all my training and experience -- or that there's no work to this recipe (there is). But it is the pristine fish I have in mind throughout the preparation of this dish, as I try to create a framework of nuance and elegance.

title: Wife of Former Top Soldier Tells of Ties to His First Accuser
description: The first Mother's Day after her only child died in 1996, Wilhemina McKinney spent the day with a dear friend, Sgt. Maj. Brenda C. Hoster, her husband's public affairs aide. The two women shopped and dined at a favorite Thai restaurant, where they chose the basil chicken.

title: Fears of Higher Premiums and Perhaps Less Choice
description: Doctors, hospitals and employers that deal with Oxford Health Plans gave it mixed reviews yesterday as Oxford named a new chief executive, Dr. Norman C. Payson, and announced its latest plans to overcome heavy losses.

title: INSIDE
description: Students Weak in Math

title: Greenspan Injects a Note of Caution on the Good Times
description: Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, warned investors and lenders today against assuming that economic good times would last forever and suggested they could be underestimating the risks confronting the economy's powerful seven-year-old expansion.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Science Watch column yesterday about a solar eclipse that will sweep across the Caribbean tomorrow misstated the times of two broadcasts on the Internet about the event. The first, at 10 p.m. today (not 4 p.m.), will offer background information. The second, at noon tomorrow (not 6 a.m.), will include live views of the eclipse. Times are Eastern standard.

title: Quote, End Quote
description: ''The School of American Ballet gave me, gave my wife and gave all four of our children an education, an environment, a home,'' said JACQUES D'AMBOISE, who received the school's Artistic Achievement Award at Lincoln Center. ''My wife said that, so I'm stealing from her.'' JAMES BARRON with MONIQUE P. YAZIGI

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBBINS, BARNARD H., M.D.
description: ROBBINS-Barnard H., M.D. The Officers, Board of Directors and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Barnard H. Robbins, M.D., devoted husband of the late Beatrice Goldstein Robbins. His compassion and concern for those less fortunate will live on in the generous gifts he created for their benefit through UJA-Federation, and Beth Israel Medical Center, a UJA-Federation beneficiary. We extend our sincerest condolences to the entire family. Services 1 P.M., Wednesday, February 25, at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue and 76th Street. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair Louise B. Greilsheimer, President Stephen D. Solender, Exec. V.P.

title: German Scientologists
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNTON, H. DONALD, M.D.
description: DUNTON-H. Donald, M.D. The Executive Committee, faculty, staff and candidates of the Columbia University Center for Psychoanalytic Training and Research, express our deepest sorrow over the death of our colleague, H. Donald Dunton. He was a distinguished training and supervising analyst at the Columbia Psychoanalytic Center and chair of child psychiatry at Columbia University. We will miss not only his warmth and vitality but his creativity and intellectual vigor. We extend our sympathy to his wife Patricia, his children, Craig, Timothy and Lese, and his eighteen grandchildren. Robert A. Glick, M.D., Director

title: OBERLIN FARMS DAIRY TO BE SOLD TO SUIZA FOODS
description: The Suiza Foods Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Oberlin Farms Dairy Inc., a processor of dairy products, for an undisclosed sum. Oberlin, based in Cleveland, had annual sales of $76 million last year. Suiza said it would continue to operate the business as Oberlin Farms Dairy and retain all its managers and employees. Suiza, based in Dallas, is a food and packaging concern with 1997 sales of $1.86 billion. The acquisition will enable Suiza to improve service to regional customers in the Midwestern states.

title: Rankings May Change Focus at Law Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: The Stage as King's County: Another 'Richard' Opens
description: Richards are dropping all over town these days. It started a couple of weeks ago with Richard III, wiped out in a Moonwork production at the Stella Adler Conservatory downtown. Both he and Richard II have been dispatched in Theater for New Audiences' presentations in midtown. Now Richard II buys it at the Pearl Theater Company's home on St. Mark's Place. All have drawn sizable audiences.

title: Crayola Box of 64 Turns 40
description: Once upon a time, the children of America found it very difficult to color within the lines. That was because their 48 Crayolas -- their Burnt Siennas, Carnation Pinks, Prussian Blues and Magentas -- were blunt, worn right down to their paper wrappers. And the parents of America were reluctant to lend their kitchen knives to sharpen them.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the increasing number of lawyers who take temporary assignments at law firms and corporate legal departments misstated the name of an agency for temporary lawyers in New York. It is Strategic Legal Resources, not Strategic Legal Services.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REED, DR. FRANCES C., PH.D.
description: REED-Dr. Frances C., Ph.D. in Psychology. She leaves behind her beloved husband, Lionel C. Reed, and her four sons, Drs. Harold, Lawrence, Irving and Barry Reed. A feminist before her time, she devoted her life to the education of the slow learner and was instrumental in the development of tests used to diagnose these problems. Her family and friends sadly mourn her passing. Susan, Alex and Lacey Tisch

title: Journal; Days of the Locust
description: After a month of being hit by 24-hour cable news, the Internet and ye olde print media with more bombshells than he'd planned to drop on Saddam Hussein, Bill Clinton can do no wrong. One more bounce in his numbers and he just may revive the First Lady's health-care plan.

title: Compromise Is Reached on Power Plant Emissions in Midwest
description: The Environmental Protection Agency and eight Northeastern states have reached a compromise schedule for requiring electric power plants in the Midwest to cut down on smog-causing emissions that drift eastward and pollutes the air over Pennsylvania, New York and New England, state officials said today.

title: EMI's Management Uncertainty Continues
description: EMI Music scrambled last week to reassure investors that it had stabilized its management structure after a succession plan collapsed. But the future of the record company's team appears more uncertain than ever.

title: For Counsel, A Thin Line Divides Can And Should
description: Because grand juries have such sweeping powers, Federal prosecutors and criminal law professors say, there is little question that Kenneth W. Starr had the legal authority to subpoena a White House aide to testify about his media contacts before the Federal grand jury investigating President Clinton.

title: Commercial Real Estate; New Diagnostics for Building Facades
description: As the recent partial collapse of the facade of a building at Madison Avenue and 55th Street and other incidents around the city have shown, problems with construction and weathering can cause brickwork to peel away from the main part of a structure.

title: Sales Is Given Free Shot, And Sinks It for Record
description: What a way to set a record.

title: 10,000 Cards Later, A Host Returns
description: ''Good morning, and welcome to 'Today' on this Tuesday morning. I'm MATT LAUER, and nothing makes me happier than to say, 'along with KATIE COURIC.' '' And so did Ms. Couric return to the ''Today'' show yesterday, a month after her husband died of colon cancer. Wearing his wedding ring on a chain around her neck, she thanked viewers for their support, adding ''my heart goes out'' to all who are struggling with life-threatening illnesses ''and are wondering how the world keeps going.''

title: Showdown for Campaign Reform
description: As the showdown over campaign finance tied up the Senate yesterday, two important things became clear. A solid majority of the Senate favors legislation to ban unlimited campaign contributions. Second, the majority leader, Trent Lott, will stop at nothing to thwart the majority's will. Now is the time for John McCain of Arizona and other supporters of the most important political reform in a generation to stand up to Mr. Lott.

title: That's Professor Muckler, Gentlemen
description: Their practice rink has been turned into a classroom, and their lines have been redefined. Their practices last two hours, with timeouts only for further instruction on the brave new world of up-tempo playmaking endorsed by the latest Ranger leader, 63-year-old John Muckler.

title: Tobacco Leaders Refuse to Budge on Pact
description: The top executives of the major tobacco companies told Congress today that they would never agree to modify their advertising and marketing practices unless the lawmakers gave the industry substantial protection against lawsuits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROCHA, FRANK
description: ROCHA-Frank. February 20, 1998, of Woodstock, NY. Husband of Marie, father of Phyllis and Irene, brother of Claude. Funeral 3 P.M., on Friday, Lasher Funeral Home, Woodstock, New York.

title: Canada Presents Balanced Budget, the First in Almost 30 Years
description: After several years of cutting deeply into some of Canada's most cherished social programs, the Government today introduced the first balanced budget in nearly 30 years, cautiously promising to restore some services and lower taxes without returning to the big spending that first put the budget in the red in 1970.

title: Greenspan's Comments and Scuttled Merger Dampen Market
description: Rising Treasury bond yields and the scuttling of what was expected to be the largest merger ever dampened enthusiasm for stocks yesterday.

title: Liberties; D.C. Confidential
description: I'm worried about my garbage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIDSON, BERNICE
description: DAVIDSON-Bernice. Retired Research Curator at the Frick Collection, died on February 24, 1998. She is survived by her sister and brother-in-law, Anne and David Ferry of Cambridge, Mass., a nephew, Stephen Ferry, a niece and her husband, Elizabeth Ferry and David Wood. There will ba a memorial service at a later date.

title: A French Morsel With Its Own Memories
description: WITHOUT Marcel Proust's memories to help them, canneles, delicious little cakes from Bordeaux, remained an obscure regional specialty until quite recently. They were first mentioned in Larousse Gastronomique last year. Now, they seem to be everywhere in Paris and have made their way to New York.

title: Firms Named To Handle Big Bond Sale In Lilco Deal
description: The Long Island Power Authority today named several major financial and legal firms to handle what is slated to be the biggest municipal bond sale in the nation's history.

title: Restaurants; Spicy Lamb Stew and Thali, From India
description: I HAVE rarely encountered a more frustrating restaurant than Pondicherry. One night I am eating Mauritius-style lamb with caramelized quince, exclaiming over the freshness of the spices, the beautifully pointed flavors, savoring every bite. One week later, eating the same dish, I find myself searching desperately for something, anything, to like about the dull, pallid stew. What is going on?

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Down-Home Cook Makes Good In the Big City
description: THE man at the bar drains his bottle of Bud, leans back and stretches. ''How about a hamburger or something?'' he says, just loud enough for Terrie Mangrum, seated at a nearby table, to hear. Her cheeks flush. ''I could smack this guy,'' she says, her voice low. ''That really makes me insane. This is not a burger joint.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLTZMAN, STUART A.
description: HOLTZMAN-Stuart A. A quintessential mensch taken from us much too soon. He touched our lives and taught us so much. He will be missed and never forgotten. Elizabeth and Joel Lieberman

title: Judge Says Union Cannot Pay Official's Legal Bills
description: A Federal judge yesterday barred a union local representing more than 50,000 New York City janitors and doormen from financing the defense of a lawsuit brought against the local's president, Gus Bevona.

title: Mossad Chief Quits but Defends His Role in Jordan Fiasco
description: The head of the Mossad, Israel's intelligence agency, resigned today, apparently under heavy pressure from within the agency to accept responsibility for the bungled attack on a top Palestinian militant in Jordan last fall.

title: State Recommends Tests Of Drinking Wells
description: The State Department of Environmental Protection yesterday recommended that tens of thousands of drinking wells be tested by their owners after 265 of 2,239 wells sampled were found to have elevated levels of mercury.

title: Herb Scharfman, 86, Sports Photographer
description: Herb Scharfman, a sports photographer for International News Photos and Sports Illustrated, died last Saturday in Scottsdale (Ariz.) Memorial Hospital. He was 86.

title: White House And Starr Clash On Subpoenas
description: The legal confrontation between President Clinton and the independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr, took a sharply personal turn today, as Mr. Starr summoned a senior adviser to the President to a Federal grand jury, seeking the source of what he called ''misinformation'' being spread about prosecutors. The White House responded by accusing Mr. Starr of a ''brazen'' abuse of power.

title: 'True Believer' Hopes To Salvage a Reputation
description: Norman C. Payson is certainly not in it for the money. When he sold his New Hampshire company, Healthsource Inc., last year, he pocketed some $90 million.

title: Sex Shop Owners Greet Zoning Ruling With Air of Resignation
description: At Club 44, a Times Square strip joint, there was an air of resignation. ''There are a million ways to get by in this business,'' said Sherry Golden, the club's manager, as a dozen patrons leaned languidly against her bar yesterday and a bare-breasted dancer worked the runway.

title: Three Are Treated After Witnessing Suicide
description: Three people were treated for trauma yesterday after a man jumped to his death from the 17th floor of a midtown Manhattan building as they were leaving a subway station, the police said.

title: Novell Reports Operating Profit For First Time in Four Quarters
description: Novell Inc., which was once the leading provider of computer networking software but has more recently fallen on hard times, reported its first operating profit in four quarters yesterday. The earnings exceeded Wall Street estimates, but sales were well below the level reported a year earlier as the company struggles to complete a turnaround.

title: PALEX TO BUY FOUR CONTAINER-MANAGEMENT BUSINESSES
description: Palex Inc. said yesterday that it would acquire four container-management businesses with combined annual revenues of $100 million, making it the nation's largest provider of steel drum services. Terms were not disclosed. The businesses are the Acme Barrel Company, the Container Services Company, the Consolidated Container Corporation and the Drum Service Company. Together, they have 12 facilities in nine states. Palex, based in Houston, said that the acquisitions would give it annual revenue of $300 million, 44 facilities in 18 states and 3,000 employees.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LLUVERES, CLARA
description: LLUVERES-Clara. On February 23, 1998 at Calvary Hospital, Bronx, N.Y. Survived by her niece Clara, nephew Andrew, grand nieces Elena, Cornelia and Antonia. Memorial Mass Thursday, February 26th, 10AM at Holy Name Church, 96 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, NYC. Presiding Monsignor Charles McDonaugh and Monsignor Charles Kavanaugh.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUSSEY, RAYMONDE
description: LUSSEY-Raymonde. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of Raymonde Lussey, beloved sister of our devoted benefactor Sylvie Nathanson. Sincere condolences to the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, President Jerry Forst, Vice President Jack Rosen, Vice President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLACK, GAYLE, PH.D (NEE GAYLE MARKS)
description: BLACK-Gayle, Ph.D (nee Gayle Marks). Cherished mother, devoted wife, beloved sister and dear beautiful friend to many. She died as she lived-with courage, dignity and grace surrounded by loving family and friends. Gayle will be missed by her husband Shelly Marks, daughter Margot Black and brother Joel Black as well as by many other loving family members and friends. She was the vibrant daughter of the late Sylvia and Nathan Black. Gayle Black, Ph.D was author of the ''Sun Sign Diet'' book as well as a private practice nutritionist and president of the Cancer Survival Center in New York City. She was an active participant in the SHARE breast cancer network and a member of Temple Shaaray Tefila. Services will be held Thursday, February 26th at 9:30AM at Temple Shaaray Tefila, 250 East 79th Street, in New York City.

title: By the Book; Television's 'Two Fat Ladies' Have Sung
description: FEELING playful, I badly wanted to produce an edible ''hedgehog,'' a whimsical five-pound meatloaf with olives for eyes and almonds for prickles, offered by the wildly popular British cooking team known as ''The Two Fat Ladies.''

title: LAZARD FRERES LOWERS OFFER FOR NURSING HOME COMPANY
description: Lazard Freres & Company said yesterday that its real estate fund had cut its purchase offer for the Kapson Senior Quarters Corporation of Woodbury, N.Y., a nursing home owner and operator, to about $230 million from the original offer of $250 million, without citing a reason. Lazard Freres's fund will begin a tender offer within five business to buy all of Kapson's 7.75 million shares outstanding at $14.50 each for a total of $112.4 million and all of Kapson's 2.4 million preferred shares for $27.93 each, or a total of $67 million. The fund will also assume about $50.6 million in debt. Kapson Senior Quarters stock fell 75 cents a share, to $14.25. Kapson owns 23 nursing homes with 2,510 units in Connecticut, New Jersey, New York and Pennsylvania.

title: Clinton Likely to Win Over Senate on Expanding NATO
description: The Clinton Administration's campaign to sell the Senate on the expansion of NATO appeared near a successful conclusion today, with the final approval of the chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, who said the expansion ''will make NATO stronger and make Europe more peaceful and united.''

title: Rankings May Change Focus at Law Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Workers Were Exposed To Carcinogen, U.S. Says
description: The Federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration yesterday announced fines totaling $209,750 against two affiliated companies in Union for improperly exposing workers to a carcinogen used in brazing gold to other metals.

title: HEWLETT-PACKARD TO SELL SOFTWARE LINE TO PLATINUM
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company agreed yesterday to sell its Intelligent Warehouse line of products to the software company Platinum Technology Inc. Financial terms of the deal were not disclosed. The products, which include Intelligent Warehouse and Datamart Manager, are software programs that allow users to get information from diverse data bases through any access tool. Under the agreement, Platinum will receive the modules and applications as well as the rights to the product names and their trademarks. Platinum, based in Oakbrook Terrace, Ill., had 1997 revenues of $623.5 million. Hewlett-Packard, the Palo Alto, Calif., electronics company, had 1997 revenues of $42.89 billion.

title: Gebrselassie Doesn't Mind Being Pushed by His People
description: No one in Ethiopia has ordered Haile Gebrselassie to win or else. No one has told him that if he does not win, he disappoints the entire nation. But the world's most successful distance runner feels he must win for his people.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORY, CHRISTOPHER B.
description: CORY-Christopher B. Of Boston died in the China Airlines crash Taipei, Taiwan, February 16, 1998. He is survived by his father Dr. Joseph P. Cory, his mother Janet A. Burbank Cory, two sisters Denise A. Hubbard, Diana M. Cory and one niece Olivia Seymour. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, March 7 at 2 PM at the Unitarian Church, Westport, CT. Visitation will be Thursday February 26 and Friday February 27 from 2-4 and 7-9 PM at the Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home, Greenwich, CT. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Bread & Roses, Georgetown, CT. or PFLAG.

title: The Pop Life; A Life Well Mixed
description: For several years, the name Armand Van Helden has evoked more than just a person or artist. It brings to mind a sound, a style, a guarantee to dance. In Britain, a whole genre of club music, speed garage, has developed as an offshoot of his remixing style, which has earned him a Grammy nomination for best remixer, a category added this year.

title: St. John's Wins in Snow at Syracuse
description: First the Red Storm had to fight Mother Nature, and then it had to battle the Orangemen. But on a night not fit for man or Big East beasts, St. John's surmounted the elements (as much as 8 inches of snow covered the roads on the way to the Carrier Dome) and then prevailed over Syracuse, 67-65, in an important conference game.

title: In Taiwan, Production And Export Data Plunge
description: Taiwan's factories slowed in January and export orders posted their steepest decline in more than a decade as declining growth across Asia throttled one of the region's healthiest economies. Industrial production fell 16.8 percent from December and was down 6.8 percent from a year ago, the Government said. Export orders fell 14 percent, to $8.46 billion, the biggest year-on-year decline since 1987.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KALOWSKY, MARGUERITE M. (NEE MCHALE)
description: KALOWSKY-Marguerite M. (nee McHale). On February 24, 1998, of Dunmore, PA. A graduate of Kings County Hospital School of Nursing, Class of 1932. Beloved wife of Alec. Loving mother of Carol and Margo Benoit. Dear sister of the late John. Very proud grandmother of Danielle, Bob, Megan and Alec. Visiting on Wednesday, 2-4 and 7-9PM, Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 4th Avenue, Bklyn. Mass of Christian Burial Thursday, 9 AM, Saint Anselm.

title: Mondale to Visit Jakarta to Press Suharto on I.M.F. Reform Plan
description: President Clinton has asked former Vice President Walter F. Mondale to travel to Indonesia this weekend, the White House said today, as Mr. Clinton's second special envoy to see President Suharto in the past month.

title: Calendar
description: A Career Day on Food

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: If You're Being Watched, the Law Is No Help
description: To the Editor:

title: College Endowments Top $150 Billion On the Wings of a Soaring Economy
description: Robust investment returns coupled with strong donations to higher education have created a financial boom for American colleges and universities, 25 of which now have endowments of $1 billion or more.

title: Both East and West Coasts Emerge Battered From the Ferocious Grasp of Nature; In Florida, Measuring The Losses
description: In the midst of a man-made picture of placidity lakes, streets lined with palm trees, housing subdivisions with names like Remington Pointe and Flamingo Lakes -- residents dealt today with the mess thrust upon them by nature.

title: Goalie Makes History
description: Mike Ginal, a sophomore from Depew, N.Y., was the Crimson goalie for the last 3 minutes 10 seconds in a 6-1 victory over Colgate on Friday. Ginal thus became the first athlete with a prosthetic limb to play in a Division I game.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''This study has burst another myth. Our best students in mathematics and science are simply not world class.''

title: Sinclair to Buy 13 TV Stations
description: Sinclair Broadcast Group Inc. said today that it had agreed to acquire the privately held Sullivan Broadcast Holdings Inc. for about $800 million in cash and stock.

title: Large Charge Causes Major Loss at Waste Management
description: Waste Management Inc., the nation's largest garbage collector, said today that it was taking a $1.5 billion charge against its earnings for the last quarter of 1997 to reflect accounting changes that are intended to quiet investor skepticism about the reliability of its financial reports.

title: Ken Starr's Misjudgments
description: It has long been apparent that Ken Starr has a tin ear for political appearances and public relations, but his decision to subpoena a White House aide, Sidney Blumenthal, undermines important legal and constitutional principles. On the tactical level, this move by the independent counsel is bone stupid. As a matter of principle, it is an attack on press freedom and the unrestricted flow of information that is unwarranted by the facts and beyond his mandate as a prosecutor.

title: Out to Lunch
description: Gov. George Pataki of New York had an on-the-record lunch with Washington political reporters on Monday in which he offered President Clinton loads of unsolicited advice about foreign affairs, but said it would be presumptuous to tell Senator Alfonse D'Amato how to vote on campaign finance reform. The Senator and the Governor obviously went to the same school when it comes to giving policy suggestions only to people who are guaranteed to ignore them. When Mr. D'Amato was making his much-publicized crusade against teacher tenure, he told reporters he would not think of urging his opinions about that state issue on the state's Governor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TIEDEMANN, KAETHE E. NEE KREUTZER (TANTE KAETHE)
description: TIEDEMANN-Kaethe E. nee Kreutzer (Tante Kaethe), on February 23rd, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Henry. Devoted mother of the late Linda Bremer. Dear grandmother of Hans Bremer, Jr. Fond aunt of Drew, Brian, Janice and Christopher Kasler, Heide Wanek, Doris Wolff and Ulrich Kreutzer. Dear grand-aunt of Drew, Jr., Jonathan, Matthew, and Christopher Kasler. Loving sister of Emma Ruf and the late Eugene, Maria and Fritz Kreutzer. Dear cousin of Johanna Gotimer and Joanna V. Kasler. Visitation Wednesday and Thursday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at the E.C. Waldeck Home for Funerals, 7614 4th Ave., Brooklyn. Service 10 AM, Friday, at Zion Lutheran Church, 125 Henry St., Brooklyn. Interment following at Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Brooklyn Hospice or the Brooklyn branch of the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation would be appreciated.

title: Price of Donor Eggs Soars, Setting Off A Debate on Ethics
description: Fertility clinics call them egg donors, with the emphasis on the word ''donor.'' They are young women who provide eggs for infertile women and who, in return, are paid for their time and inconvenience. Human eggs, fertility experts say, are not bought and sold.

title: Brodeur Will Get a Post-Olympic Breather
description: One of the Devils' two Olympians arrived today in time to practice, but the weary traveler, goalie Martin Brodeur, will not play here Wednesday night against the Florida Panthers.

title: Thais Increase Some Sales Taxes
description: The Government here raised taxes today on products including gasoline, cigarettes and beer, as it struggles to close a budget deficit while the economy creeps along at the slowest rate since the 1960's.

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about the defamation trial of the Rev. Al Sharpton misstated the role of a witness, Philip Nobile, in some copies. He was a plaintiff's witness, not a state's witness; the case is civil.

title: Simplifying Elections for School Boards
description: It took 35 days to hand-count the 172,000 paper ballots cast in the most recent New York City school board elections, held in the spring of 1996. But if a legislative task force has its way, that cumbersome, Byzantine process will never be repeated.

title: Others Coveting Giants Linemen
description: The restricted free agents Scott Gragg and Lance Scott, two starters on a Giants offensive line that evolved into a surprising strength on last season's surprising team, have been targeted in recent days by other teams looking for line help.

title: Wine Talk; New Spanish Passions, Beyond Rioja and Catalonia
description: FOR years, buying Spanish wine -- aside from sherry and sparkling wine -- meant choosing between Rioja and Catalonia. From the Rioja region, just over the Pyrenees, in the north central section, came such familiar names as Paternina, CVNE, Montecillo and the various Marqueses: Murrieta, Riscal and Caceres.

title: Rice Senior Remains Unbeaten
description: Sean Wright, a senior at Rice High School in Manhattan, remained undefeated in nine individual races this indoor season when he won the 200-meter dash last night in a meet record 21.90 seconds at the Eastern States Interscholastic Track and Field Championships.

title: WPP Group Acquires Consulting Company
description: WPP Group, which owns agencies including the J. Walter Thompson Company and Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, said yesterday that it had acquired Management Ventures Inc., a retail consulting company in Cambridge, Mass. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE ANGELIS, LORRAINE
description: De ANGELIS-Lorraine. February 24, 1998. Beloved daughter of Ethel and the late Guido De Angelis. Loving sister of Kenneth and Kayel. For funeral information call The Abbey at 212-288-1900.

title: Rules Could Change At Troubled H.M.O.
description: Members of Oxford Health Plans may eventually face fewer choices, higher costs or both under a shake-up aimed at reversing heavy losses at the big managed-care company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURKHARDT, GLORIA
description: BURKHARDT-Gloria. Dedicated teacher, librarian, photographer and lifelong student. Devoted daughter, loving sister, cherished aunt and cousin. Visiting Wed., at the Horn-Dannecker Funeral Home, 336 West 23 Street, NYC, hours: 3-5, 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Thursday from the Church of Our Savior, Park Avenue at 38th St. at 10:30 AM. Memorial contributions may be sent to Friends In Deed, 594 Broadway, New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMPBELL, PATRICK J.
description: CAMPBELL-Patrick J., 79. Former General President of The United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners of America. Died Feb. 21, 1998 in Palm City, Florida. He is survived by his wife Catherine, two sons, Patrick and Kevin, daughter Cynthia and six grandchildren. Viewing at Higgins Funeral Home, New City, New York, Wednesday and Thursday February 25 and 26 from 2-4:30 and 7-9 P.M. Burial mass at St. Anthony's Church in Nanuet, NY on Friday, February 27 at 10 A.M.

title: Corrections
description: A credit was omitted in Sunday Styles this week for a picture of the Gene Marshall, the doll with a glamorous wardrobe that is a hit on the collectible circuit. The photographer was Steven Mays.

title: Not 'Book Burning'
description: To the Editor:

title: China Breaks the Ice to Offer Political Talks With Taiwan
description: After two and a half years in deep freeze, China sought today to thaw its relations with Taiwan by offering to resume talks on the future of the island. Beijing still regards Taiwan as a rebel province and still threatens to retake it by military force.

title: A Mended Heart
description: Police Commissioner HOWARD SAFIR, who turned 56 yesterday, went back to the place where he had bypass surgery nearly a year ago. The occasion was the dedication of a new cardiac prevention and rehabilitation center at the New York University Medical Center, at 530 First Avenue.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN UNDER PRESSURE. The yen weakened as Japanese stocks slid on disappointment with Government plans to stimulate the economy. In New York, the dollar cost 127.88 yen, up from 127.82.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, the continuation of an article yesterday about an experiment in school choice in an East Harlem district was omitted from some copies. Readers wishing corrected copies of the article may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or telephone (212) 556-1992. E-mail: quality@nytimes.com. (Include a postal address.)

title: Off The Menu
description: Back to the Kitchen For 'Dining Around'

title: Islanders' Sale Has Hit a Snag
description: The $195 million bid by New York Sports Ventures to purchase the Islanders has survived several complications, but the latest one -- a refusal by S.M.G., the company that manages the Nassau Coliseum, to sign documents necessary for the completion of the transaction by yesterday's deadline -- might prove fatal.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Scuttling of Drug Merger Contributes to Stock Drop

title: Nets Get No Points For Effort In Victory
description: Keith Van Horn had shown little confidence all night, and he had little reason for it most of the night.

title: TV Notes; Olympic Ratings Far From Gold
description: Even though the final rating was a disappointment, CBS still got something for its Olympics investment: huge increases in the network's overall prime-time rating for the season.

title: Glaxo and SmithKline Deal Unraveled Quickly
description: Jan Leschly, chief executive of SmithKline Beecham P.L.C., must have been surprised when he received an unusual telephone call last week from Glaxo Wellcome P.L.C.'s chairman, Sir Richard Sykes, in London.

title: Oxford Investors Build In Some Insurance, in Case Things Don't Work Out
description: The rescuers of Oxford Health Plans evidently fear that the news from the company may get worse before it gets better.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOUT, FERRIS MEIGS
description: STOUT-Ferris Meigs, 75. Of Roosevelt, N.J. On February 22, 1998. Much loved husband of Virginia Edwards Stout. Loving father of Penrose Vass, Susan Andrews, Nathaniel Meigs Stout and Lucia Stout Huebner. Admired stepfather of Alison Edwards Petrilla and Alan Edwards. Proud grandfather of Ilana Cleo, Andrew Ferris Meigs, Margaret Price and Titus Benjamin Stout and Katherine Louise, Charles Augustus Huebner. Fond step-grandfather of Joshua Morton and Nicholas Ross Edwards and Molly Fay Petrilla. Mr. Stout was born and raised in Bronxville, New York.

title: The Mets Lose Interest In Signing Tony Phillips
description: The Mets announced tonight that even before a background check of Tony Phillips was completed, they were no longer interested in signing the free-agent infielder, outfielder and leadoff batter.

title: If You're Being Watched, the Law Is No Help; Missing Consent
description: To the Editor:

title: Eating Well; Selling Olestra Despite Experts' Doubts
description: THE color photograph on the cover of the public relations material shows a handsome weathered barn in a field planted with soybeans. The deep blue sky is streaked with billowy, white cumulus clouds. Inside the brochure, there is a close-up of this field, the farmer knee-deep in his crops. The scene is so real the insect holes in the leaves of the plants are visible.

title: Profits at Intuit Down by 7.7%
description: Intuit Inc. said today that its second-quarter operating profit declined 7.7 percent, meeting analysts' expectations, as the company fights off competition in the consumer market for financial software.

title: Rankings May Change Focus at Law Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: A Familiar Tale of Sacrifice, Traversing Today and '39
