description: Talk about a revival. With amazing grace, the director David Herskovits summons the animating spirit of an old melodrama and allows us to experience it as something fresh. The play is ''Mamba's Daughters,'' and in his sensitive and stimulating staging of it at the Here theater in SoHo, Mr. Herskovits pulls off the dandy trick of adding his own modernist commentary without drowning out the voices of the authors of this 1939 drama of black life in rural South Carolina.

title: M. T. Mehdi, 70, Arab-American Leader
description: Mohammad T. Mehdi, an outspoken critic of Israel who was often quoted in the press and also spoke on radio and television, died on Monday. He was 70 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Henny Youngman, King of the One-Liners, Is Dead at 91 After 6 Decades of Laughter
description: Henny Youngman, the King of the One-Liners, who implored his audiences for more than six decades to ''take my wife -- please,'' died yesterday at the Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 91 years old and lived on West 55th Street in Manhattan.

title: Words of Kim Dae Jung: Call for Reconciliation
description: Following are excerpts from President Kim Dae Jung's inaugural address today, as translated by the South Korean Government:

title: Debut by Ballet Troupe With Roots in the Joffrey
description: Pleasing crowds is no longer much in fashion. But the MorganScott Ballet Company, which made its New York debut on Friday night at the John Jay College theater, made a virtue of that lost art. The choreography was attractive and the dancers skillful and persuasive. But what stood out about the new venture was its sheer fun. If Edward Morgan and Daniel Scott could bottle the evening's warmth and bubbling spirits, they would have no trouble raising money to keep their company going.

title: Think New Ideas Gets Expanded Role
description: Network Associates Inc., the computer security provider based in Santa Clara, Calif., said yesterday that it had expanded its relationship with Think New Ideas by naming the agency to handle worldwide advertising and marketing.

title: Day of Hope in South Korea
description: Today's inauguration of President Kim Dae Jung marks an advance for South Korean democracy and a new chance for reconciliation on the Korean Peninsula. It also starts a widely watched test of whether economic openness and political accountability can cure East Asia's financial ills. Mr. Kim's record of overcoming obstacles is so impressive that supporters may expect more than he can accomplish. But his performance since last December's election invites optimism.

title: Lawyers for Jones Get More Response Time
description: Lawyers for Paula Corbin Jones today were given 10 more days to respond to a motion to dismiss her sexual misconduct lawsuit against President Clinton, even though Mr. Clinton's lawyers said the extra time would probably be used to search for more women to testify.

title: LEAR IS GETTING DELPHI'S AUTOMOBILE SEAT UNIT
description: The Lear Corporation agreed yesterday to buy the automobile seat unit of Delphi Automotive Systems, which is a subsidiary of the General Motors Corporation, for an undisclosed price, adding a business with $1.2 billion in annual revenue. The sale, which analysts pegged at as much as $500 million, is part of Delphi's plan to shed unprofitable businesses before a possible public offering. Delphi sold its coil-spring business last week and said it would have a buyer within three weeks for its lighting unit. Delphi sells its parts to G.M. and other auto makers. Lear's stock fell $1.25 a share, to $52.75, while G.M. rose $2.1875, to $68.50.

title: Sampras Escapes Ouster
description: The seventeen-year-old Xavier Malisse nearly turned his professional debut into a huge upsets, pushing Pete Sampras to three sets before the world's No.1-ranked player prevailed 4-6, 6-3, 7-5 last night in the Advanta Championships in Philadelphia.

title: From the Valley of Obscurity, Robeson's Baritone Rings Out; 22 Years After His Death, Actor-Activist Gets a Grammy
description: His name will crop up as a sidelight at tonight's Grammy Awards ceremony, one of four artists from the past honored at an event relentlessly focused on the musical currents of the moment.

title: The Neediest Cases; A Path Out of a Household in Terror
description: One morning in 1994, just a month after Nicole Simpson and Ronald Goldman were found stabbed to death in Los Angeles, Nicole K. received a chilling phone call from her abusive husband.

title: TV Notes; Biological Timeliness
description: Diane Sawyer spent last weekend in Siberia, thanks to the way two of last week's biggest news events converged to make her long-term reporting project on biological warfare suddenly very timely.

title: Wal-Mart Net Rises 17.3% in Quarter
description: Wal-Mart Stores Inc. said yesterday that its earnings in the fiscal fourth quarter rose 17.3 percent, bolstered by lower inventory costs amid strong holiday sales of jewelry, Christmas decorations and toys.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Smoother Road From Lab to Sales; DNA Technique Aims to Predict Whom a Drug Will Benefit
description: Four years ago, Daniel Cohen dazzled the scientific world when his Paris lab roughed out the first comprehensive map of all human chromosomes. This year, Dr. Cohen will complete a far more detailed map and attach it to a tantalizing business proposition: use the map to predict the responses of individual patients to new drugs.

title: Northeaster Drenches Coastal Areas Again
description: A storm from the Atlantic caused coastal flooding today, leaving some people with flooded basements and others with undrivable cars.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IRWIN, ROSE
description: IRWIN-Rose. Beloved wife of the late Jack. Devoted mother of Stephen and Faith Braunschweig. Loving grandmother of T.H. Waldman, Gregory Irwin and Jacqueline and Matthew Braunschweig. Dear sister of Irene Kalvin and Sam Levitan. Services Thursday 11AM ''Parkside'' Chapels, Queens Blvd and 66 Ave, Forest Hills.

title: Business Travel; No doubt about it now: During 1997 air fares took the biggest annual jump in four years.
description: AMERICAN EXPRESS has confirmed what business travelers have contended for months: During 1997 air fares underwent the largest annual increase in the last four years.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Ross Wetzsteon, an editor at The Village Voice, misstated his involvement with the Obie Awards for Off Broadway and Off Off Broadway theater. The awards were begun in 1956 by Jerry Tallmer, not by Mr. Wetzsteon. After joining The Voice in 1966, Mr. Wetzsteon worked to build the Obies into a major award.

title: U.S. Trails the World in Math and Science
description: The most comprehensive and rigorous international comparison of schooling ever undertaken reveals American high school seniors to be among the industrial world's least prepared in mathematics and science, prompting educators and political leaders, including President Clinton, to call for a re-examination of the nation's approach to teaching quantitative skills.

title: In Storm Over Pluralism, a Hopeful Rabbi
description: THE 350 Conservative rabbis who gathered in Israel last week for their annual convention were fully prepared to return to their American pulpits depressed. The compromise proposal that would have granted their movement the first flicker of recognition in Israel had just been angrily rejected by the country's ultra-Orthodox Chief Rabbinate Council, dashing months of delicate negotiations. To make matters worse, the decision was praised by Benjamin Netanyahu, the prime minister.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLATTERY, EDWARD J.
description: SLATTERY-Edward J. Of Bronxville, formerly of Irvington. Beloved husband of the late Evelyn, dear father of Robert Slattery, Anne Foley and Eileen Slattery. Fond grandfather of Marie and Alison Foley and Kim and Corey Slattery. Dear brother of Eleanor Slattery. Mass 10:30 AM Thursday Immaculate Conception Church, Irvington. Visiting Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9 Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford, (Saw Mill Exit 17), Dobbs Ferry. Memorials to Irvington Vol. Ambulance Corps.

title: Chief Judge Announces Plan to Streamline Family Court
description: Seeking to transform a court system that has been plagued with delays, Chief Judge Judith S. Kaye announced plans yesterday to streamline operations at the overburdened Family Court.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROGAN, PEGGY DUNN
description: BROGAN-Peggy Dunn, writer, teacher, educational consultant on February 15 in Ishpiming, MI after a long illness. Born Margaret Dunn in Chisholm, MN. on July 9, 1918. Graduate of Northwestern University. Teacher at Home School in New York City. Predeceased by husband Whit Brogan and brother John Dunn but leaves behind thousands of children who were touched by her work.

title: The Minimalist; New Condiment Without Work
description: IT isn't often that you come across a ''new'' condiment, especially one that can be made with a single dried ingredient. But if you simmer dried mushrooms until tender and toss them in a blender with their cooking liquid, you get a thick, potent and delicious puree.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Fingerprints on Iraqi Accord Belong to Albright
description: Early on Sunday morning, Feb. 15, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright boarded a small C-20 Air Force plane at Andrews Air Force base and flew to New York for a secret meeting with Secretary General Kofi Annan at his Sutton Place town house.

title: Not 'Book Burning'; Court Permits Ban
description: To the Editor:

title: $25 and Under; A Bistro Evocative of Provence? But of Course
description: TAKE a small space, add spare but evocative decor and a short menu of elegantly inexpensive food, and voila: another modern bistro.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STAUFFACHER, LILLIAN MOSS
description: STAUFFACHER-Lillian Moss, 81, of N. Palm Beach, FL., formerly of Greenwich, CT, on February 23, 1998. Wife of 54 years of Charles B. Stauffacher, prominent New York businessman (retired). Mother of Lillian Gillies, of Glen Head, NY and Charles D. Stauffacher, of Roxbury, CT. Grandmother of Heidi Stauffacher, James Gillies and Barrett Stauffacher. In lieu of flowers, contributions to an organization of one's choice are preferred by the family.

title: FAC REALTY TRUST TO SELL 59% STAKE TO LAZARD FRERES
description: FAC Realty Trust Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell a 59 percent stake to the investment bank Lazard Freres & Company for $200 million. The company, based in Cary, N.C., also said it had agreed to buy 11 Southeast shopping centers from affiliates of Konover & Associates for $100 million in stock, cash and assumed debt. Shares of FAC Realty rose 56.25 cents, to $9.4375. The properties FAC Realty is buying from Konover contain two million square feet of space. FAC Realty will use some of the proceeds from the Lazard investment to help pay for the Konover purchase. In that agreement, FAC Realty will sell $200 million of stock to Lazard's Prometheus Southeast Retail L.L.C. affiliate in the next two years at $9.50 a share.

title: Veracity of Soldier's Accuser Is Questioned
description: Defense witnesses testified today that Sgt. Maj. Gene C. McKinney's primary accuser was a liar, unlikely to tell the truth even under oath, and motivated by a yearning for attention.

title: Jurors in Brawley Case Criticize Court Behavior
description: The jury in the Tawana Brawley defamation case yesterday asked the judge to exercise control over the tone of the proceedings.

title: Generale des Eaux In Talks With Havas
description: Generale des Eaux S.A., France's biggest water utility, said yesterday that it was in talks to buy Havas S.A., which could cost it about 26 billion French francs ($4.3 billion) and turn the company into France's biggest media concern. The boards of Generale des Eaux and Havas will discuss the takeover plans on March 9.

title: French and German Teams Take Titles in The Hague
description: Of the many tournaments played each year in Europe, the most international is certainly the Forbo-Krommenie, played last weekend in The Hague. The Nations Cup, for four invited teams of the highest class, was won by France, with a foursome of reigning world champions: Paul Chemla, Michel Perron, Christian Mari and Alain Levy. The other teams represented the Netherlands, the United States and China, and they finished in that order.

title: Toys 'R' Us Says Earnings Will Fall Short of Estimates
description: Toys ''R'' Us, the nation's largest toy retailer, warned yesterday that it expected to fall significantly short of earnings estimates for the year, catching Wall Street off guard. It also appointed a new president and chairman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EAGAN, JOSEPH C.
description: EAGAN-Joseph C. In Westport, CT., February 19, 1998. Husband of the late Phyllis Renshaw Eagan; father of Richard Eagan of Brooklyn, N.Y.; grandfather of two. Former stockbroker with Frank C. Masterson & Co., and retired partner Eagan & Griffin. Cremation and interment were in Ferncliff Cemetery, Hartsdale, New York.

title: A 20th-Century Soprano With 18th-Century Coloration
description: Listeners who prefer conventional operatic tone production and projection speak dismissively of Emma Kirkby's light, clear, almost boyish soprano. But this English singer's sound has a purity that makes it ideal for the Renaissance, Baroque and early Classical works in which she has specialized, and she brings considerable interpretive insight to this music.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR JUMPS. The dollar's volatility against the German mark continued yesterday. It jumped .0212 percent, to finish at 1.8188. It dropped 1.3 percent Monday before inching higher Tuesday.

title: Tragedy Gives Rise To a Sacred Scroll
description: Twenty-six years ago, just before their wedding, Yisrael and Aviva Shifra Deren met with Rabbi Menachem Mendel Schneerson, the Lubavitcher Rebbe, for his counsel.

title: Art for a Duchess
description: So who was the artist identified as ''***Costantino'' in the three-volume catalogue of items from the Duke and Duchess of Windsor auction? He or she did two still lifes that were sold last night at Sotheby's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANE, ROSE
description: KANE-Rose. Beloved wife and mother, formerly of Wantagh, Long Island. Died at the age of 88. She was a devoted teacher in the Levittown schools for 25 years. She is survived by her son David and his wife Karen and sons Ben and Alex. She was the adored wife of the late Ellis Kane. She is also survived by her beloved, longtime companion Abraham Allen.

title: ASEAN Seeks Funds to Avert Another Costly Season of Haze
description: SINGAPORE  With forest fires in Indonesia threatening to cast another pall of smoke-borne pollution over Southeast Asia, officials in the region appealed Wednesday for international aid to help prevent a recurrence of the 1997 crisis that is estimated to have cost more than $1.3 billion in damage to health, disrupted industry and transport and lost tourism.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IMBLEAU, HELEN V.
description: IMBLEAU-Helen V., 95. Beloved wife of the late Dr. J.E.L. Imbleau of Union, N.J., died in Salisbury, CT., on February 17, 1998. She is survived by her daughters, Yvonne Imbleau MD, Jamesburg, NJ, Cherie Imbleau, Cranbury, NJ and Valerie Imbleau, Canaan, CT.

title: Demand Is Constant/An 'Excessive Fondness' : For Indians, Ignoring World, All That Glitters Is Gold
description: NEW DELHI  Never mind that gold is losing its glitter as an investment worldwide, Subhash Bhola's jewelry shop is doing brisk business. So are hundreds of other gold stores that cram the same middle-class neighborhood in New Delhi.

title: The Private Icons of a Civil Rights Legend
description: HANDS held high -- the right clenched in a fist, the left as if grasping for some long-sought goal.

title: The Iraq Deal: War Averted, or Just Delayed?; Now Pay U.N. Debt
description: To the Editor:

description: GARSON-Arthur. Devoted husband of Patricia, loving father of Susan Taylor, Thomas Garson, Kathleen Frank and Arthur Garson, Jr, proud grandfather of Whitney Taylor, Devin Taylor, Tag, Michael, Lauren and Kathleen Garson, Holly Youngwood, and fond great-grandfather of Patric Taylor Moores. Visiting Thursday 5-8PM, memorial service Friday 2:30PM both at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave, NYC. In lieu of flowers, contributions would be appreciated to R.S.V.P.I., 500 5th Avenue, 35 flr, NYC 10110 or to Dystonia Medical Research Foundation, Suite 3B, 162 East 80 Street, New York City 10021.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRISMAN, JONATHAN H.
description: GRISMAN-Jonathan H. Of Dallas, TX. Cherished son of Arnold and Rita and the late Marilyn. Dear brother of Suzanna Kaplan and brother-in-law of Martha Kaplan. Loving nephew of Rachelle Grisman and uncle of Joseph. Services ''Gutterman-Musicant'', Hackensack, New Jersey, Thursday 1 PM.

title: To: Readers
description: From: Circuits@nytimes.com

title: Computing; Parents' Dilemma: A Child's Own PC?
description: MY old friend Phiber Optik got his first computer when he was in elementary school, a fact that my third-grade daughter, Zoe, reminded me of the other night when she asked for her own desktop setup.

title: Dylans, Father and Son, Gather Grammys; Shawn Colvin Wins for 'Sunny'
description: Back in the 1960's, Bob Dylan sang, ''My name it is nothing.'' But at the 40th annual Grammy Awards ceremony, the Dylan name was a guaranteed winner. Mr. Dylan's album ''Time Out of Mind'' brought him three Grammys, including album of the year. The rock category was dominated by Jakob Dylan and his own band, the Wallflowers, who won awards for best rock performance by a duo or group and best rock song for their hit ''One Headlight.''

title: Without His Children, Everett Begins Anew
description: Carl Everett is delighted to be gone from ''the worst city in the world;'' he does not trust New York's foster care system, and he resents the Mets' treatment of him. Furthermore, he said today: ''They already know they lost one of their best players. If you ask me, they can't make up my talent with one player.''

title: Here's Your Winner, If Heft Alone Counts
description: ENCYCLOPEDIA BRITANNICA 98

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JASEN, ANNA
description: JASEN-Anna. Beloved wife of Michael. Devoted mother of Georgette and Max. Adored grandmother of Noah and Alexa. Services Friday 12 noon at Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial, Queens Blvd & 76 Rd, Forest Hills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOROWITZ, RUTH
description: HOROWITZ-Ruth. On February 22, 1998. Devoted mother of Lewis and Daniel. Loving sister of Mildred Pryzant and Phil Pepperman. Cherished grandmother of Alyse, Robert, Nissa, Andrew and William. Services Friday, 12 Noon at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

description: LESCAULT-Anne, February 24, 1998, of Somers, New York and Jupiter, Florida, and formerly of Pound Ridge, New York. Wife of the late Theodore Lescault and H. Kenneth Meyer. Also survived by one brother-in-law, one sister-inlaw, one aunt, several nieces and nephews, and great-nieces and great-nephews. Reposing at Clark Associates Funeral Home, Katonah, New York, Friday, 2-4 and 79PM with services at the funeral home Saturday, 11 AM. Interment, Middle Patent Cemetery, Banksville, New York.

title: Depositors Hope for Windfall When Independence Savings Goes Public
description: When Independence Savings Bank, a venerable savings institution based in Brooklyn, offers its stock to the public in the next week or so, about 50,000 depositors, many of them with small accounts, may have a chance to cash in as insiders on an initial public offering, just like Wall Street high rollers.

title: In the Pursuit of Thinness, Almost Anything Is Worth It
description: ''Dying to Be Thin'' is only too literal a title for tonight's ''48 Hours'' report on Americans' obsession with fat.

title: Union Pacific Faulted in '97 Accidents
description: The Union Pacific Corporation's faulty operating and safety practices contributed to a series of rail accidents that killed 11 people last year, the Federal Railroad Administration said today.

title: Chairman of City Campaign Finance Board Calls for Sharp Changes in Rules
description: The chairman of the New York City Campaign Finance Board called yesterday for drastic changes in the city's campaign finance rules, including stricter limits on contributions, a ban on donations from corporations and most organizations, and new rules to encourage small donors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IRWIN, ROSE
description: IRWIN-Rose. Beloved wife of the late Jack. Devoted mother of Stephen Irwin and Faith Braunschweig. Loving grandmother of T.H. Waldman, Gregory Irwin and Jacqueline and Matthew Braunschweig. Dear sister of Irene Kalvin and Sam Levitan. Devoted mother-in-law of Karen Irwin and Ralph Braunschweig. Services today 11AM ''Parkside'' Chapels, Queens Blvd and 66 Ave, Forest Hills.

title: Most of the Major Market Gauges Surge to Record Levels
description: If investors were concerned about the fate of the stock market this year, their fears seem to have dissipated.

title: Fruit to Walls to Floor, Ads Are on the March
description: At a grocery store here recently, Kenna Nevill found to her irritation that the apples she was about to buy had morphed into juicy red film advertisements.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHARF, FLORENCE C.
description: SCHARF-Florence C. Of Manhattan. Dear niece of Rose Scharf Lerner. Graveside services today 10:30 A.M. at New Mount Carmel Cemetery, Brooklyn, NY. For information call Weinstein-West End Chapel at: 1-800-452-9597.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BAUMAN, LIONEL R.
description: BAUMAN-Lionel R. Beloved partner, friend and colleague. Died Feb 27, 1987. Sorely missed by all. Eugene M. Grant & Company

title: EXTERIORS -- Checkerboards Mark The Spot: A Museum
description: In 2000, when the Long Island Children's Museum moves to its new home, a former airplane-maintenance hangar in Hempstead, it will not be a discreet place. It will have a yellow roof, black-and-white checkerboard patterns on some of the outside walls and eight times more space -- 44,000 square feet -- than it currently has in Garden City, where it opened in 1993 in space donated by Lilco.

title: PHILIP MORRIS TO CUT 1,900 JOBS IN TOBACCO UNIT
description: The Philip Morris Companies said yesterday that it planned to cut 1,900 jobs, or 11 percent of its United States tobacco unit's work force, through a voluntary early retirement offer as it moved to trim costs amid a decline in United States smoking. The plan will result in pretax charges of about $290 million in the first half of the year and generate annual pretax savings of about $160 million, beginning in 1999. Most of the job cuts will be at its plants in Richmond and in Louisville, Ky. Philip Morris, which has about half of the United States cigarette market, is bracing for a further drop in demand. American sales, which decline about 1 percent to 2 percent annually, may fall more if Congress passes a proposed $368.5 billion industry settlement of health-related lawsuits.

title: Skip Away Is the Favorite
description: With a bankroll of $6 million and his sights set on $10 million, Skip Away entered the $500,000 Gulfstream Park Handicap yesterday in Hallandale, Fla., as the 3-5 favorite to win his fourth straight Grade I stakes.

title: Some Teacher Training to Be Farmed Out
description: The New York City Board of Education approved a contract yesterday to turn over teacher training in one of the city's most troubled school districts to an agency that preaches that the attitudes of teachers are responsible for the failure of poor minority students.

title: The Iraq Deal: War Averted, or Just Delayed?; Mideast Tunnel Vision
description: To the Editor:

title: Aalto, a Modernist Ahead of His Time
description: The Museum of Modern Art's new Alvar Aalto show is a sleeping beauty. Impeccable scholarship, lucid presentation, an admirable refusal to impose on Aalto an alien point of view: these are the exhibition's considerable strengths. But they aren't enough to bring Aalto to life. The show makes loving him feel morbidly perverse.

title: CONTINENTAL AND PILOTS AGREE ON 5-YEAR PACT
description: Continental Airlines and its pilots' union announced a tentative agreement on a new five-year contract yesterday, clearing one obstacle to the carrier's planned alliance with Northwest Airlines. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed, but a person close to the negotiations said it would protect Continental's 5,100 pilots if the carrier was to merge with Northwest or any other airline. The tentative contract also gives the pilots an opportunity to share in profits that may result from the alliance, the person said. James Moody, a spokesman for the Independent Association of Continental Pilots, said it would be two months at the earliest before results of the ratification vote were announced.

title: Not a Crook? Voters in India Don't Always Care
description: Here in the badlands of Uttar Pradesh State, India's Wild West, Dharam Pal Yadav is regarded as one of the baddest of the bad: a 45-year-old gangster with at least 25 outstanding criminal charges, including at least 6 for murder.

title: Tightening the Annan Agreement
description: Now that the full text of Secretary General Kofi Annan's agreement with Saddam Hussein has been published, it is clear that some provisions require close watching to prevent a weakening of weapons inspections. Mr. Annan has assured Washington he will not let the plan be exploited by Iraq, and critics of the deal like Senator Trent Lott have exaggerated the potential problems. But President Clinton is right to demand clarification on several points.

title: Big Newsprint Maker Offers $1.4 Billion to Acquire Rival
description: Abitibi-Consolidated Inc. said today that it had offered $2 billion (Canadian), or $1.4 billion (United States), to acquire Avenor Inc., a rival newsprint producer that rejected the unsolicited proposal as inadequate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FILMUS, TULL
description: FILMUS-Tully, ninety-four. Renowned Artist, of Great Barrington, MA., died February 25, 1998. Burial services will be held at Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, New York, at 2:30 P.M.

description: While the schedule shows Sacramento next for the Nets on Thursday night, it is hard for them to ignore the home-and-home set that awaits them this weekend against the Miami Heat.

description: GOLDBERG-Sylvia. Beloved wife of the late Sidney. Devoted mother of Robert Goldberg and Sue Bunin. Loving grandmother of Amy Eller. Dear sister of Seymour Soroch. Services were held privately.

title: With a Twang and a Teardrop
description: Ralph Stanley and the Clinch Mountain boys stood five across, all in cowboy hats and ties and shirt sleeves, except Mr. Stanley, who wore a dark suit. When they sang, their voices floated out of them like balloons, mysteriously hovering free of their bodies. Mr. Stanley, who turned 71 yesterday, was the banjoist and harmony singer of the bluegrass band the Stanley Brothers; he's one of the most venerable of American musicians.

title: The Iraq Deal: War Averted, or Just Delayed?; Real-World Policies

title: Boom Towner Will Be Retired
description: Boom Towner, winner of the Toboggan Handicap at Aqueduct in 1992 and 1995, will be retired, ending a 10-year career on the New York circuit. The gelding, who placed fourth in his last outing on Feb. 4, posted a 29-16-13 career record in 82 starts with $961,290 in earnings.

title: Red Storm Wants a Little Respect
description: Having won 12 of their last 13 games and earning a first-round bye in next week's Big East tournament, Coach Fran Fraschilla and his St. John's players are looking for a little R and R -- ranking and respect.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CROSS, ROWENA B.
description: CROSS-Rowena B. On February 24 after an extended illness. Mourned by her loving sons, Robert, Grant, and Bradley Dewey, brother, Eric Bauer, and seven young grandchildren. Funeral services will be held on February 27 at 11 A.M., at Church of the Heavenly Rest, 5th Avenue at 90th Street. For those who wish, gifts may be made to Westover School, Inc., Whittemore Road, POB 847, Middlebury, Connecticut 06762. Her memory will live forever in the hearts of all who loved her.

title: Enlisting Mice in the Quest For Ergonomic Correctness
description: FIRST it was keyboards, then mice that were blamed for the hand and arm pain of repetitive stress injuries in computer users. Naturally, hardware designers saw not only a problem to be solved but also a new market niche. Ergo, the ergonomic keyboard, of which there are many, and now, ergonomic mice.

title: Finding Release For Strong Emotion In a Solo
description: One minute Doug Varone and his dancers were cavorting eccentrically through a floridly operatic piece called ''Bel Canto'' on Sunday afternoon at the Joyce Theater. The next moment, Mr. Varone was alone onstage, but just as eccentric, in a new solo called ''Knave.''

title: Testing Time for New Winter Gear
description: Ski gear and apparel for next season are surfacing now at various trade exhibits around the country. But the question for skiers and snowboarders is whether to take advantage of current sales or wait for September to be titillated by the new and possibly more expensive gear for 1999.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Gretzky Returns to a Bigger Ranger Role
description: Now that John Muckler, a friend and mentor from his Edmonton days, is the head coach, Wayne Gretzky expects his role with the Rangers to expand. Despite his age, the 37-year-old Gretzky can truly become the cornerstone of the vast renovation that is imminent for a team that is looked upon as overage and underachieving.

description: The feverish real estate market that has sent prices of Manhattan apartments soaring and tightened the grip on office space continues to be felt in the retail sector as well.

title: Lawyer for Jones Tells of Settlement Talks
description: The principal lawyer for Paula Corbin Jones said today that he held secret discussions in recent weeks with one of President Clinton's lawyers in which they offered his client a cash settlement and an apology to drop her case.

description: GILBRIDE-Gerard A. Of North White Plains, NY on Feb. 22, 1998. Former Assistant Dean, Brooklyn Law School. Husband of Mary (nee Maloney) Gilbride. Father of Rod and Edward F.X. Gilbride, Jayne Bauer, Christine Gilbride, Grace Hottinger, Nancy Conforti, Mary Richards, Betsy DeSoye, Joan Shea, Carolyn Schaus and Sheila Passenant. Brother of John T. Gilbride and John J. Reposing at the Ballard Durand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Avenue, White Plains, New York, on Thursday 7-9 PM, Friday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Memorial contributions to Jesuit Seminary and Mission Bureau, 39 East 83rd Street, New York, New York 10028, would be appreciated.

title: Madonna's Child Gets a Trim
description: MTV has agreed not to broadcast everything it has on MADONNA and child. At her request, the cable network has cut 53 seconds from a documentary that is scheduled to be broadcast on Sunday at 10 P.M. The footage shows the rock star playing with her infant daughter, Lourdes.

title: A Welter of Wireless Choices
description: CELL phones: they're quick and they're easy. So why are they so hard to buy?

title: LONG ISLAND BANCORP SHARES RISE ON BID FROM ASTORIA
description: The stock of Long Island Bancorp Inc. rose more than 12 percent yesterday after it was reported that another New York bank had approached it with an offer. The American Banker reported yesterday that the Astoria Financial Corporation made an informal offer of $55 a share last week, and Long Island Bancorp came back with a counterproposal of about $60 a share. Based on the savings and loan holding company's 24 million shares outstanding, the offer would be worth $1.3 billion to $1.4 billion. Shares of Long Island Bancorp rose $6.6875, to $60.5625, while Astoria Financial was unchanged at $54.50.

title: A Russian Baritone's Harrowing Song Cycle
description: In the first half of his recital on Tuesday evening at Carnegie Hall, a wide-ranging assortment of Baroque and Classical songs and arias, the Russian baritone Dmitri Hvorostovsky offered greater satisfaction than many another singer can muster in an entire evening. Then he proceeded to put it all in the shade, with a second half consisting of ''Petersburg,'' a stunningly powerful ''vocal poem'' by Georgi Sviridov.

title: Public Eye; Flying Off the Door And Into Your Heart
description: AFTER more than two decades of being relegated to the doors of restrooms around the world, Everyman and Everywoman are broadening their horizons. Once found only in public spaces, the not-so-dynamic duo have infiltrated the rest of the world via popular graphics.

title: In Mini-Storage, All the Comforts of Home

Edwin DeCastro, 41, a customer-service representative at Paine Webber, and his wife, Dr. Yolanda Aranguren-DeCastro, 37, a physician, have just discovered that they are out of disposable diapers and baby wipes. Does he dash down to Rite-Aid? No, he gets into his gold Grand Cherokee Laredo with a serious roof rack and makes an emergency run down the West Side Highway to Manhattan Mini Storage on 44th Street and 12th Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOMAROW, ROBERT S.
description: KOMAROW-Robert S., 72. Of Westport, died Tuesday, February 24th, 1998 at Bridgeport Hospital. Mr. Komarow earned a Bachelor's Degree in Engineering from the Cooper Union. He subsequently earned two Master's Degrees from Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute and New York University. A resident of Westport since 1969, Mr. Komarow worked for Norden Systems in Norwalk for thirty years. Mr. Komarow is survived by Sylvia, his wife of 47 years, his two brothers, Seymour and Paul, his five children: Ronni, Steven, Bruce E., Lawrence J., and Judy, and his 6 grandchildren. A funeral service will be held Thursday, Feb. 26, at The Abraham L. Green & Son Funeral Home in Fairfield, CT. Memorial gifts can be made to Westport Emergency Medical Services or charity of choice.

title: BB&T PLANS TO PAY $265.3 MILLION FOR MARYLAND FEDERAL
description: The BB&T Corporation agreed yesterday to buy Maryland Federal Bancorp Inc. for $265.3 million in stock as the bank expands its presence near the nation's capital. BB&T, which is based in Winston-Salem, N.C., agreed to exchange 0.5975 share of its stock for each BB&T share. The transaction values Maryland Federal, based in Hyattsville, Md., which has bank branches in 24 cities, at $37.12 a share. Shares of Maryland Federal jumped $4, to $35.75, while BB&T slipped 31.25 cents, to $61.6875. BB&T is expanding quickly in Washington and Virginia through acquisitions.

title: One Nation, Drunk or Sober
description: The danger posed by an intoxicated driver does not change when the driver crosses state lines. Neither should the legal test for sobriety. That is the practical thinking behind pending legislation in Congress to create one uniform Federal standard for drunken driving. Some critics say the measure would infringe on states' rights. But this is a problem that transcends state boundaries, requiring a tough, consistent national approach.

title: In His Own Words
description: MAYOR RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI

title: Museums Paint Prosperity By Numbers
description: Picasso, even as a youngster, had star power, and he proved it last year by becoming the art world's box-office champion.

title: Baptist Leader Is Charged With Theft; His Fund-Raising for Burned Black Churches Is Called Fraudulent
description: The Rev. Henry J. Lyons, president of the nation's largest predominantly black religious denomination, was charged in St. Petersburg, Fla., yesterday by the state authorities with racketeering and theft, stemming from accusations that he had misused his position for personal financial gain.

title: INSIDE
description: Dylans Dominate Grammys

title: Yo! Robot! I'll Have Some Sushi and a Beer
description: The hand rolls may still be hand-rolled, but most of the other fare is made digitally. And that is not the high-tech half of it here at Yo! Sushi, a new restaurant near Piccadilly that in terms of cuisine and gadgetry aims to be more Japanese than anything west of the Ginza.

title: Ju Tang Chu, 97, Chinese Banks' Ex-Head
description: Ju Tang Chu, a retired chairman of the Shanghai Commercial Bank, now based in Hong Kong, and the Shanghai Commercial and Savings Bank, now based in Taipei, Taiwan, died on Feb. 9 in a Hong Kong hospital. He was 97 and lived in Hong Kong.

title: Teacher Is Accused Of Seeking Sex With Girl
description: A teacher from New York State was charged with trying to arrange a sexual encounter with a child through the Internet, the Bergen County Prosecutor's office said yesterday. An adult who read electronic messages that the teacher had posted posed through the Internet as a fictional 13-year-old girl, then helped in his capture, the prosecutor's office said.

title: Metro Business; Bank Settles Benefits Case
description: In a case that Federal officials described as ground-breaking, the Israel Discount Bank of New York agreed last week to provide people suffering from mental disability the same long-term benefits that are available for physical conditions.

title: Be Polite or Else, Giuliani Warns In Announcing Civility Campaign
description: Building on his vision of New York as an urban Eden, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced a string of new initiatives yesterday that he predicted would further transform the traditionally gritty city into a friendly, tranquil place where drivers don't speed and residents treat one another politely.

title: H.M.O. Drops Medicaid In Connecticut
description: Oxford Health Plans has decided to pull out of the Medicaid program in Connecticut, and state officials said yesterday that they would divide the 33,000 poor people covered by the troubled health maintenance organization among the state's other insurers.

title: Clinton Visits Tornado Sites And Comforts The Survivors
description: President Clinton paused here today among the newly dispossessed, surveying a shattered trailer park and comforting those left battered, broken-hearted and homeless by the tornadoes that rampaged through Central Florida early Monday.

title: Internet Bureau Locates in New York
description: The Internet Advertising Bureau, an association for on-line advertising, has established a headquarters and named its first director.

title: Swinging Biography: Playing Boswell to Those Sisters
description: There's hardly a contemporary vocal group that isn't indebted to the Boswell Sisters (Connee, Martha and Vet), the New Orleans-born trio being saluted in an effervescent revue, ''Rhythm on the Rainbow,'' that runs at Rainbow and Stars through March 28. Earthier and more blues-oriented than the Andrews Sisters, who succeeded them as America's most popular female vocal group, the Boswells were classically trained musicians who went pop after being irresistibly drawn to the blues and jazz in their hometown.

title: The Iraq Deal: War Averted, or Just Delayed?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Iraq Deal: War Averted, or Just Delayed?; American Arrogance
description: To the Editor:

title: Trade Secrets; Lighting a Kitchen's Varied Terrain
description: YOU don't have to be a professional designer to know when the lighting in the kitchen isn't right. Meat looks gray. The upper reaches of the cabinets are swallowed in darkness. You end up chopping onions in your own shadow. And no one would willingly cozy up to eat a quiet dinner there.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AVENOSO, KAREN
description: AVENOSO-Karen. The family and friends of Karen Avenoso mourn her passing on February 25, at age 31. Wife of Jonathan Sherman, daughter of Ellen and Frank, sister of Kenneth, granddaughter of Lillian Stark, Karen was adored by her family and touched countless others with her words and spirit. Hers was a life far to short. A graduate of Smithtown High School in Smithtown, New York, she received a Bachelor's degree in English Literature, Phi Beta Kappa, from Dartmouth College and a Master's Degree in 19th Century English Literature from Oxford College, on a Rhodes Scholarship. She was an education reporter at the New York Daily News and, at her death, the Boston Globe. The family asks that donations be made to the Karen Avenoso '88 Scholarship Fund C/O Melanie Norten, Stewardship Office, Dartmouth College, 63 South Main Street, Hanover, N.H. 03755-2047. A memorial service will be held at Temple Emanu-El, 756 East Broad Street, Westfield, New Jersey, at 10:45 AM, on Friday, February 27.

title: Alfred Terlizzi, 58, Chairman Of Capezio and Friend to Dance
description: Alfred Terlizzi, board chairman of Capezio/Ballet Makers and an unassuming friend to performers and other dance professionals, died on Feb. 8 at his home in Naples, Fla. He was 58 and also lived in Wayne, N.J.

title: Karen Avenoso, 31, Boston Globe Reporter
description: Karen Avenoso, an education reporter for The Boston Globe who also wrote about her yearlong battle with Ewing's sarcoma, a rare form of cancer, died yesterday at her home in Westfield, N.J. She was 31.

title: . . . With Liberty and Laptops for All?
description: IN the first heady days of his Speakership, Newt Gingrich suggested a credit for low-income families to buy portable computers and then, among heckles, quickly renounced the proposal as ''a dumb idea.''

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: EVEREN CAPITAL CORP., Chicago, is laying off 250 workers, or about 30 percent of the 900 employees, at its Dallas-based Principal Financial Securities unit, which it bought in December for $75 million.

title: Treasuries Rise After Greenspan's Testimony Is Shrugged Off
description: The prices of Treasury securities gained for the first time in six days yesterday, as the chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, concluded two days of Congressional testimony by saying little else to alarm investors in bonds.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TIGHE, MADELINE
description: TIGHE-Madeline. Always loved, always remembered on this and every day. Miss you, Mom. Pamela and the Family

title: Liggett May Cooperate in Tobacco Inquiry
description: Representatives of the maker of L&M and other cigarette brands are exploring an agreement with Justice Department officials under which the cigarette producer would cooperate in the Government's criminal investigation of the tobacco industry, lawyers involved with the talks said yesterday.

title: NEW ON THURSDAYS
description: The Times today introduces Circuits, a weekly section covering the personal side of digital technology in everyday life. In this issue: An article on the lure of electronic organizers for the perpetually harried and frantic, along with columns on computers and games and an attempt to answer the question ''What Exactly Is a Megahertz?'' SECTION G.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Feb. 16 about Anthony Le Vier, a test pilot, misidentified the type of stealth plane that was manufactured at the Lockheed Skunk Works. It was a fighter, not a bomber.

title: Nike's Problems Don't Seem To Be Short Term to Investors
description: Nike remains the king of the hill in athletic footwear, but its kingdom is under assault.

title: Empire Blue Cross Rejects Takeover Plan
description: The board of directors of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, New York State's largest insurer, rejected yesterday a takeover proposal by a coalition of the region's hospitals and the union representing health care employees.

title: Making Books; Those Neanderthals Make for Best Sellers
description: The male as oaf and worse, long a rich and lucrative literary tradition, appears to be blooming this year as usual in a variety of fiction. Not surprisingly, all of the books are by women. The genre probably started with Restoration comedy, which was written by men. The plots were similar, however convoluted. There were the stupid women, ignorant of the world and innocent, who had to be protected and even elevated by men. And so forth. But, of course, the reverse was true.

title: 1,200 Welfare Families Lose Cash Assistance
description: Cash assistance was cut off this month to 1,200 families that failed to meet a deadline to find work or enroll in a job training program under the state's new welfare law, according to figures released on Tuesday.

title: Two Big British Insurers Agree to Merge in $11.5 Billion Deal
description: Commercial Union P.L.C. and General Accident P.L.C. said today that they had agreed to merge in an $11.5 billion transaction, better positioning themselves in Europe's increasingly competitive insurance industry.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb 15 about the coming church trial of the Rev. Jimmy Creech, a United Methodist minister in Omaha, for performing a ceremony uniting two women, misstated the surname of a critic of Mr. Creech. He is Bob Howell, not Howard.

title: Jets Add Burger and Byars To Free-Agent Acquisitions
description: The Jets continued to make key moves in the free-agent market yesterday. They added a starting guard from the Chicago Bears, Todd Burger, and, 12 years after thinking about drafting him in the first round, signed the versatile and respected fullback-tight end Keith Byars.

title: S.& P. Cuts Ratings On 15 Indonesian Banks
description: Fifteen Indonesian banks' ratings were cut by the Standard & Poor's Corporation, which expressed worry that the Government's guarantee of their deposits is not comprehensive. The ratings were already below investment grade.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNTON, HARLOW DONALD, M.D.
description: DUNTON-Harlow Donald, M.D. Esteemed colleague, Harlow Donald Dunton died on February 21, 1998. His clinical and pedagogic contributions to the Department of Pediatrics have been legion. He helped train two generations of pediatric residents and nurses in child psychology and psychoanalytic disorders. He will be remembered as a man of warmth and youthfulness by his colleagues in the Department of Pediatrics and at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. John M. Driscoll, Jr., M.D. Chairman Department of Pediatrics College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University and Director of Pediatric Service Babies & Children's Hospital of New York

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILBANK, POSY D.
description: MILBANK-Posy D. The Board of Trustees, staff and consumers of ICD-International Center for the Disabled note with deep sadness the passing of Posy (Rose), beloved wife of our Honorary President, Jeremiah Milbank, Jr. Gracious, warm-hearted and generous, Posy Milbank shared in Jeremiah Milbank's commitment to ICD and his support of its mission. She will be greatly missed by all who knew her, and we offer our deepest sympathy to Jeremiah Milbank, Jr. and to all members of the family. Harry G. Hohn Chairman of the Board of Trustees ICD-International Center for the Disabled

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REED, DR. FRANCES C., PH.D. IN PSYCHOLOGY
description: REED-Dr. Frances C., Ph.D. in Psychology. She leaves behind her beloved husband, Lionel C. Reed, and her four sons, Drs. Harold, Lawrence, Irving and Barry Reed. A feminist before her time, she devoted her life to the education of the slow learner and was instrumental in the development of tests used to diagnose these problems. Her family and friends sadly mourn her passing. Susan, Alex and Lacey Tisch

title: ODE TO A DESIGNER -- Defying Japanese Logic
description: Divine craftsmanship and breathtaking economies of form are qualities one expects from Japanese design. But whimsy? Shiro Kuramata, one of Japan's most influential and radical designers, mastered the first two in the postwar years, when he was among the first to break with the modernists' death grip on absolute geometries. But it was his subtle humor and bold experiments in new materials that have assured his prominent place in design history.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUGHES, MARIE C.
description: HUGHES-Marie C. On February 24, 1998. Survived by her loving family. Reposing at Gannon Funeral Home, 152 East 28 Street, NYC on Thursday, 2-5 and 7-9PM. Funeral Mass Friday, 10 A.M., Epiphany Church, 2nd Avenue at 22 Street. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery.

title: Memories of the Holocaust With a Call for Peace
description: The Kibbutz Contemporary Dance Company from Israel made its New York debut on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater with ''Aide Memoire,'' a 90-minute experimental dance piece ending with the words, ''a time for peace.''

title: Young Editors Speak Up and Out
description: NET surfers have been riding waves of dirt since the White House scandal broke, but are they ready for ''All the Principal's Men?'' Bolt Reporter is banking on it.

title: Subtleties of Governing a Virtual World
description: START a new life in the offworld colonies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUBBELL, DOROTHY TWYEFFORT
description: HUBBELL-Dorothy Twyeffort. A woman of elegant strength, died February 23, 1998 in Falmouth, Me. She was 89. Born in Paris, to American parents, Josephine and Louis Twyeffort, she lived there until she graduated from Vassar in 1930. A year later she married William Bradford Hubbell and moved to Bedford, N.Y. Captain W.B. Hubbell died in 1943, serving in the Army Air Corps in Alaska. She lived on Mianus River Road in Bedford for 63 years and retired to Me. in 1995. She is survived by their sons William B. Hubbell, Jr. of Cumberland Foreside, Me., John T. Hubbell of Asheville, NC., daughter Anne H. French of Bedford, NY and by 8 grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. Mrs. Hubbell was an Elder of the Bedford Presbyterian Church as well as a devoted supporter of the Mianus Gorge Preserve. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be sent to the Mianus Gorge Preserve, 167 Mianus River Road, Bedford, New York. 10506. A memorial service will be held in the spring in Bedford when the lilacs are in bloom.

title: COX RADIO TO BUY FM STATION IN ORLANDO FOR $145 MILLION
description: Cox Radio Inc. said yesterday that it would acquire a radio station in Orlando, Fla., from the Alton Rainbow Corporation for $145 million, increasing to five the number of FM stations it operates in the area. Cox Radio said Orlando was the 26th-largest radio market in terms of revenue. The purchase of WTLN-FM is part of its strategy to buy clusters of stations serving markets in the Sun Belt. Cox rose $2.9375, to $43.9375. In a related transaction, the Atlanta-based Cox said it would sell the assets of WZKD-AM in Orlando to Thomas Moffitt Jr. for $500,000, cutting its AM radio holdings in Orlando to two.

title: Moving Day Angst at the Citadel of Chic
description: PEOPLE at Conde Nast are so unwilling to talk on the record about their future office space that striking up a conversation with White House staff members about Monica S. Lewinsky would have to be easier.

title: So What, Exactly, Is a Megahertz?
description: IN the movie comedy ''Spinal Tap,'' a rock guitarist explains to an interviewer that his amplifier is much better than others because the top reading on his dials is 11. When he wants to push his rocking to the limit, he can turn the dials to 11, while other, lesser guitarists get stuck at 10.

title: Uncovered Short Sales Rise 2.8% on Nasdaq for Month
description: Stock market prices may be rising lately, but optimism that the rise will continue appears to be fading a bit.

title: Metro Matters; Charter Battle Is a Seriously Comic Matter
description: IT isn't easy to turn Charter revision into slapstick. But Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and the City Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, are certainly giving it a shot.

title: Halliburton Said to Acquire Oilfield Rival
description: The Halliburton Company, the Dallas-based energy services concern, is expected to announce today that it is acquiring a rival in the field, Dresser Industries, for $7.7 billion. The deal would be a tax-free stock swap, a person close to the talks said.

title: Economic Scene; Devalue the yuan? China doesn't seem about to do that.
description: CHINA faces slower growth, increased pressure from Asian competitors for its export markets and a desperate need to create real jobs for millions now ungainfully employed in bloated state enterprises. Devaluing its currency, the yuan, could ease some of these pressures. Last week Lee Hsien Loong, the Deputy Prime Minister of Singapore, told The Wall Street Journal that Chinese ''devaluation can't be entirely ruled out.''

title: PROFILE; For the Newly Disk-Lorn, Someone to Dry Their Tears
description: FRANCINE SCHWARTZ of Novato, Calif., was devastated when she lost Faith. She panicked. She cried. She became immobilized by fear and guilt.

title: THE DEAL ON IRAQ: SECRET ARSENAL: The Hunt for the Germs of War -- A special report.; Iraq's Deadliest Arms: Puzzles Breed Fears
description: On a January day in 1995, Dr. Rod Barton, a United Nations weapons inspector with a gambler's instinct, decided to try bluffing the Iraqis. Ever since their defeat in the Persian Gulf war, they had steadfastly denied ever making any kind of germ weapons, despite much evidence to the contrary.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''As much as people might argue that the record was tainted, we showed people that we cared more about helping this kid than winning a game.''

title: The Iraq Deal: War Averted, or Just Delayed?; The Ritter Test
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EIDELSBERG, ROBERT
description: EIDELSBERG-Robert. The Board of Governors and members of Bocaire Country Club record with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member Tuesday, February 24, 1998. He will be missed. Services will be held on Friday, February 27, at 11 A.M., at Temple Beth El, 333 S.W. 4th Ave., Boca Raton, Florida. Interment will be at Eternal Light. Barry Berger, President

title: Ex-G.O.P. Star Says He'll Quit Congress in '98
description: Representative Bill Paxon, the Republican Wunderkind who was stripped of his House leadership position last summer for conspiring to oust Speaker Newt Gingrich, unexpectedly announced today that he would retire from office after this term and give up a career in politics to spend more time with his family.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; 'A big event' for the Big Board, posing legal and competitive risks and even harm to its reputation.
description: FOR institutional investors, who must sometimes buy or sell huge blocks of stock, an illegal tactic known as front-running is a constant fear. And a stock market that allows it to happen risks losing business.

title: Under Close Scrutiny, Turkey's Pro-Islam Party Has a Makeover
description: Leaders of Turkey's banned pro-Islamic party are trying to reorganize themselves in another party, but federal prosecutors and their own former leader are watching them suspiciously.

title: New Attempts At Abduction Of Children In the Bronx
description: A gnawing fear has gripped parents and children in a Bronx neighborhood where, the police say, a man has tried to abduct or molest seven schoolgirls in the last two months. Many parents now walk even their older children to school. Sidewalks that normally teem with youths are empty. And plainclothes police officers are out in force, casting wary glances at suspicious-looking young men.

title: Big Board Floor Brokers Charged in Illegal Profits
description: A ring of rogue brokers operating from the floor of the New York Stock Exchange used their positions to make more than $11 million in illegal trading profits, Federal prosecutors charged yesterday.

title: Power Deregulated. Consumers Yawn.; California's Effort to Promote Plan For Electricity Is Off to a Slow Start
description: They've tried everything.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHARFMAN, HERB
description: SCHARFMAN-Herb. The Officers and Trustees of the New York Sports Museum & Hall of Fame regret the passing of a charter member of the New York Sports Hall of Fame on February 21 in Scottsdale, Arizona. Bill Shannon, President Jordan Sprechman, Secretary

title: Bruised Knicks Find Williams and Childs Soothing
description: He was away for only six days. But it seemed as if someone had ransacked Herb Williams's second home while he was gone.

title: Risking Dissent, U.S. Is Expected to Waive Drug Sanctions Against Colombia
description: The United States has decided to waive drug sanctions against Colombia on national-security grounds, senior Administration officials said today.

title: Sanofi Profit Fell 18.9% in 2d Half of '97
description: The profit of Sanofi S.A. fell 18.9 percent in the second half of last year as the company built up its sales network before the release of two new drugs expected to be the driving force of future earnings. Sanofi, France's second-biggest drug company, posted a profit of 860 million French francs ($142.8 million), when income was bolstered by the sale of several divisions. Sanofi's profit for the full year rose 10 percent, to 1.92 billion francs from 1.74 billion francs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINBERG, SEINDEL
description: STEINBERG - Seindel. Beloved mother of Susie Warshaw (David) and the late Albert Steinberg, beloved grandmother of Heidi R. Steinberg Solomon (James), Marla Steinberg Kucmanic (Albin), Beth Steinberg and Yonatan Warshaw. Shiva in Cleveland, Ohio through Sunday evening and in Edison, New Jersey through Wednesday morning. May the family be consoled among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem.

title: New Era Begins With Thud For Isles
description: Trevor Linden was not all that was new for the Islanders tonight.

title: Disappointments With Father, Work and Life
description: A WORKING GIRL CAN'T WIN

title: COLLEGES: WOMEN'S BASKETBALL
description: TEXAS TECH 87, NEBRASKA 62

title: Full Opening Today Of New Thruway Bridge
description: Four and a half months after a gasoline tanker explosion destroyed a bridge overpass on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway, a new seven-lane bridge is expected to open completely this morning.

title: Reports Suggest Another Misstep by Israeli Spy Agency
description: The Mossad intelligence agency, its reputation already tarnished by a botched assassination attempt in Jordan, suffered another ''very serious'' failure in Europe last week, Israeli radio and television reported this evening.

title: Rose Milbank, Philanthropist And Volunteer, Is Dead at 81
description: Rose Sheppard Milbank, a longtime volunteer with the Red Cross and the United Nations, and a philanthropist who supported projects in underdeveloped countries, died on Monday at Greenwich Hospital in Greenwich, Conn. She was 81 and had suffered a stroke, a family spokesman said.

title: A Campaign Inquiry Follows Cash to U.S. From Macao
description: House and Senate investigators, examining how overseas money was laundered into President Clinton's re-election campaign, have unearthed evidence that a Macao developer entered the United States at least six times carrying large sums of cash, Congressional officials said today.

title: Faldo Is Back at the Site Of His Only '97 Victory
description: In the 12 months since winning last year's Nissan Open, Nick Faldo has not played like Nick Faldo very often. He has struggled with his putting and his confidence, and he has been frustrated by his inability to recapture the form that made him one of the world's top golfers.

title: Court Denies Indian Authority in Alaska Case
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that a remote village in north-central Alaska inhabited by 350 Athabaskan Indians was not ''Indian country'' and so could not displace the state's taxing and regulatory authority over an area that is about the size of Delaware.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, SAMUEL J.
description: COHEN-Samuel J., 90, on Feb. 24, 1998, in Baltimore, Md. Husband of Marie; father of Elaine (Leonard) Wurzel; grandfather of Mark (Ellen), Larry (Martha), and greatgrandfather of Jill, Max and Greg; brother of Esther, Molly, Morris, Gussie, Zelda. He will be lovingly remembered forever. Contributions may be sent to Independence Hall Preservation Fund (Samuel J. Cohen Fund), 313 Walnut Street, Philadelphia, PA. 19106.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENNEDY, ELIZABETH W.
description: KENNEDY-Elizabeth W. Saint Bernard's School mourns the loss but cherishes the memory of Elizabeth W. Kennedy. For nearly thirty years she was a much loved, inspiring teacher and friend to her boys and their parents and to her colleagues.

title: Clinton Finds Support in a Town's Prosperity
description: With his 6-year-old brow creased in concentration, Jimmy Reardon raised his feet and began to pedal. His bicycle teetered in uncertainty before striking that magical moment of balance, and he glided across the high school parking lot here with the cheers of his proud father, James Reardon, ringing in his ears.

title: Queens Man Is Charged In 2d Rape of Daughters
description: It began as a shocking but all-too-common case of child abuse: a 35-year-old Queens man was arrested yesterday, the police said, after he raped and sodomized his 10-year-old and 7-year-old daughters.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: C.I.A. Drafts Covert Plan to Topple Hussein
description: The Central Intelligence Agency has been drafting plans for a major program of sabotage and subversion against President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, Government officials say.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COPPENRATH, LUCETTE
description: COPPENRATH-Lucette. Cherie, always you were my pride and joy. My love for you will never die. Bob

title: Amplifying Voices For Human Rights
description: SHORTLY after President Daniel arap Moi of Kenya was re-elected in December, the rolling grasslands of that east African nation were marred with lethal bloodshed. As ethnic violence has continued, the wheels of human rights organizations have been spinning, trying to turn world attention toward yet more human suffering.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KALINA, MARGIT (NEE RAAB)
description: KALINA-Margit (nee Raab). Age 75, survivor of Auschwitz and Bergen-Belsen. On February 25, 1998, beloved wife of the late Ladislav, loving mother of Yuri and Vera, dear mother-in-law of Gilbert Levine, K.C.S.G., and Melissa Shiflett, adoring grandmother of David, Gabriel, and Rachel. May she rest in peace.

title: Advocates of School Uniform Plan Enlist Children to Help Make Their Case
description: Supporters and critics of a proposal to require New York City elementary school pupils to wear uniforms squared off yesterday at a Board of Education meeting that featured a skit by Harlem schoolchildren portraying the dress code's power to raise self-esteem, but was also marked by the threat of a formal challenge to the plan.

title: Residential Resales
description: Manhattan

title: Storms Expected to Raise Price of Produce
description: The rainstorms that pummeled Florida and California this winter are starting to have an economic impact beyond the human misery and dislocations caused by deadly flooding, mudslides and tornadoes.

title: TOP G.O.P. SENATOR OPPOSES U.N. DEAL ON IRAQ INSPECTION
description: The Senate Republican leader urged President Clinton today to reject the United Nations accord with Iraq, while the Administration worked on bolting down precise details.

title: The Iraq Deal: War Averted, or Just Delayed?; End to U.S. Largess
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BONDY, HORTENSE
description: BONDY-Hortense. West End Temple Neponsit, New York mourns the death of a founding and deeply devoted member of the Congregation.

title: Severed Phone Cable Cuts Service Around New York
description: Thousands of businesses and consumers in the New York area went largely without telephone service yesterday afternoon after a sliced fiber-optic cable in Illinois led to scattered telephone shutdowns across the nation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISBARD, CELIA
description: WEISBARD-Celia. Beloved wife of the late Louis. Devoted mother of Gloria Warshofsky and Herbert Weisbard. Adored grandmother of Lawrence and Edward Brochin and Lee Amy Fenn and Robert Weisbard. Great grandmother of eight. Loving sister of Susan Rosen and Dorothy Shapiro. Services 9:30 A.M., Friday at ''Boulevard Riverside Chapel,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, New York.

title: A Grammy Party For the A List
description: The first time that CLIVE DAVIS, the head of Arista Records, gave an A-list party before the Grammy Awards, Olivia Newton-John was hot. That was 20 years ago. This time around, videos by SEAN (PUFFY) COMBS played in the new, 30-seat screening room in Mr. Davis's apartment on East 57th Street, something that could not have happened at the 19 previous parties.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about the failure of an experiment in workplace participation misstated the location of Wayne State University, where Irving Bluestone, a former top official of the United Automobile Workers union, is now a labor relations professor. It is in Detroit, not outside it.

title: Bertelsmann Plans Website For Book Sales Via Internet
description: Bertelsmann A.G., the German media conglomerate, announced plans yesterday for a global electronic bookstore that has the potential to become the world's largest merchant of books. The entry of Bertelsmann, with its vast resources, publishing experience and international distribution network, would challenge the Internet pioneers that now reign in electronic bookselling.

title: INTERIORS -- Simply Luxurious, Luxuriously Simple
description: In 1996 Bill Sofield left Aero Studio, his SoHo home-furnishings store and design partnership, to embark on a new project with Tom Ford, the Gucci designer. They had met when Mr. Ford was shopping at Aero, and a friendship and professional collaboration began.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCALLISTER, ADELAIDE NEILSON
description: MCALLISTER-Adelaide Neilson Vernon. New York and Salt Lake church, civic, and philanthropic worker and supporter of the arts, passed away February 23, 1998 of natural causes in Salt Lake City just six days short of her 96th birthday. While in New York (1930-1976) she served as vice president on the national board of American Mothers Inc. and vice president of the PTA of Browning School for Boys. She played important roles with the Utah Symphony's three Carnegie Hall concerts in NY in 1966, 1971 and 1974. She was co-chairman of the 1962 Grant Johannsen Benefit Concert for the NY State Center LDS Building Fund in Lincoln Center's thennew Philharmonic Hall. She was married to Weston Vernon, Jr. (1926-1949), one-time president of the N.Y. Bar Association and later to G. Stanley McAllister, former executive CBS and Lord & Taylor and president of the NY Stake LDS (Mormon) Church. She is mourned and beloved by her four children: Weston Vernon III, Silver Spring, MD, Robert Gerard Vernon, Salt Lake City, Maridon McAllister Morrison, Bountiful, UT and Kenneth Fielding McAllister, Amelia, OH, 19 grandchildren, 38 great-grandchildren, a sister Ellen N. Barnes, Salt Lake City and sister-in-law Marilyn H. Neilson, Salt Lake City. Funeral at 12 noon, on February 27, Salt Lake City, through Larkin Mortuary. Burial Logan, Utah (her home town).

title: Can You Spare a Dime? Click Yes.
description: RICH SCHMIDT did not see much point in posting a personal Web page that listed, say, the contents of his CD collection. ''No one would care,'' he said. But then he hit on an idea that might get attention and address a rather persistent lack of disposable income: ask strangers for money. The result, the Amazing ''Send Me a Dollar'' Website (tt.net/send-me-a-dollar/), is an example of a very old profession updated for the Web. The virtual beggar has arrived.

title: Ribicoff Is Eulogized for Many Facets of His Public Service
description: If there was one theme among the eulogies at Abraham A. Ribicoff's funeral yesterday at Temple Emanu-El in Manhattan, it was the many facets of his career in government, politics and public service.

title: Organ Suspect Was Set Up, Lawyer Asserts
description: The lawyer for a Chinese man accused of trafficking in human organs taken from executed Chinese prisoners said yesterday that he believed his client had been set up by a prominent human rights activist who held a grudge against the Chinese leadership.

title: Coach's 'Gift' to Injured Athlete Sets Off a Fast-Breaking Debate
description: It was a dramatic moment of sentimentality, stagecraft and gender politics. Nykesha Sales, a 21-year-old senior at the University of Connecticut, limping on a ruptured Achilles' tendon, was allowed to score an uncontested basket during a game at Villanova on Tuesday night so she could break her college's scoring record. Her 2-point goal required an elaborate scheme involving opposing coaches, players, officials from both universities, referees and even the commissioner of the Big East Conference.

title: Turnpike Agency Faults Federal Plan for Link
description: The New Jersey Turnpike Authority yesterday rejected a proposal by the Federal Environmental Protection Agency to change the proposed path of Route 92, asserting that its own plan is better for both commuters and the environment.

title: Sports of The Times; Making, And Missing, The Point
description: SETTING records and breaking records is a vital part of sports. Manipulating records to fit a script is an entirely different matter.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Toys 'R' Us in Shake-Up As It Issues Profit Warning

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SILVER DOWN AGAIN. Silver for March delivery fell 32.8 cents, or 5.2 percent, to $6.007 an ounce yesterday. The supply outlook has improved with a rush of sellers and producers attracted by the recent price rally.

title: THE NEW BOHEMIA -- Ordering: Comfortable Minimalism
description: If West Chelsea has a lot of artists, then Lot 61, a new restaurant at 550 West 21st Street, which opens on Saturday, intends to feed them. The restaurant is in a 5,000-square-foot former garage near the piers along the Hudson River. When Amy Sacco, the former manager of the Monkey Bar and Vong, decided to start her own place there, she wanted it to be sleek and starkly modern, yet inviting. If minimalism can be comfortable, Lot 61 is.

title: What Comes First, the Game or a Record?
description: As the last few minutes ticked away last April 14 in Philadelphia, Bernie Bickerstaff watched disgustedly from the sideline. The rookie Allen Iverson, on instruction from his coach, had just hoisted another 3-pointer in a game the 76ers would lose by 21 points.

title: Hackers' Hot-Rod Makeovers Create Turbocharged Palm Pilots
description: It's fast, it's cheap, and it's out of Palm Computing's control.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MERSON, BEATRICE (BILLIE)

Your life was an inspiration and guide for all of us to live by. We will love you and miss you all the days of our lives. Your devoted husband Carl, your adoring children Miriam and Larry, Ann and Ardie, your sister, brother and sister-in-law and all your nieces and nephews

title: Reference Disks Speak Volumes
description: LIKE typewriters and slide rules, the multivolume encyclopedia has been rendered nearly extinct by the microchip. But in the nine years since the first CD-ROM encyclopedia appeared (Academic American, by Grolier), it has become by far the dominant format and has made encyclopedias far more available. For the $1,500 price of the 32 hard-bound volumes of Encyclopedia Britannica, for example, a parent can now buy a budding scholar the same information on CD-ROM, plus a computer to run it on and the Encarta and World Book CD-ROM encyclopedias to boot.

title: Sticking to a Style That Children Know
description: WORLD BOOK 1998 MULTIMEDIA ENCYCLOPEDIA

title: PLACE SETTINGS -- Mix and Mismatch
description: There is an art to setting a table with mismatched china, in the British landed-gentry style, and Regina McMenamin knows it. She makes place settings in which the patterns -- with common themes like modern graphics, pink flowers, geisha girls or Blue Willow -- are different but resonant. She started her company, Let's Dish, in December in Manhattan. Ms. McMenamin, who is the advertising and promotions manager for the Four Seasons restaurant, says she haunts antiques shops and flea markets daily to add to her collection of 300 pieces. A five-piece setting starts at $90. Information: (212) 288-6958.

title: Credit Suisse's Japan Loan Deal
description: Credit Suisse First Boston may buy as much as one trillion yen ($7.9 billion) in bad loans from Japanese banks at a fraction of their face value, hoping to reap profits by selling the land held as collateral, an executive at a United States investment company acting as an adviser said.

title: Believing What We Read, and Vice Versa
description: In the opening of Mark Twain's ''The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn,'' we're assured by the narrator, Huck Finn, that ''The Adventures of Tom Sawyer,'' the novel that precedes it, ''is mostly a true book, with some stretchers.''

title: WebTV Offers Cheap Web Access, but Consumers Are Wary

Why not? Television sets are a little like elbows and navels, went some of the thinking: just about everyone has them, but only 4 out of 10 American households have computers.

title: The Lovestruck Midas Behind the Candidate
description: ONE of the more absorbing questions swirling around Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross, who plans to formally announce her campaign for governor next month, is this: How much money is her smitten and generous husband able, and willing, to spend on his wife's political ambition?

title: Help for the Needy
description: For 86 years readers of The Times have reached into their pockets to help the poor, the elderly and new immigrants by contributing to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. This winter's fund drive, which ends on Saturday, has raised more than $5.4 million, the largest amount ever collected by the annual appeal. Many readers were moved to give because they know that even in a strong economy the most vulnerable groups suffer from hunger, homelessness and abuse.

title: Essay; Mud Wrestling
description: How fortunate the Clintons are to have a thin-skinned prosecutor like Ken Starr pursuing them.

title: Bloomberg to Supply AOL With On-Line Business Data
description: Bloomberg L.P. will announce today that it has signed on as America Online's featured provider of business information, giving another vote of confidence to on-line consumer markets that have yet to show a profit.

title: Under Attack, Foster Agencies Link Lapses to Budget Cuts
description: Defending themselves against charges of failing to monitor foster homes, officials of private foster care agencies in New York City yesterday blamed reduced spending by the city and state for mounting caseloads and diminished oversight.

title: A Fetish For Order
description: BY any measure, Lisa Van Dusen's life is a hectic one. Her job as marketing director of a twice-weekly newspaper in Palo Alto, Calif., rivals the demands of being mother to two young sons, volunteering at their school and staying active in her community. For the past 15 years, Ms. Van Dusen, 43, has carried at her side through busy days a leather binder crammed with schedules, a calculator, paper clips and work rosters. Now she is grappling with a thoroughly modern dilemma: whether to replace this three-pound notebook with an electronic organizer that would be not much larger than an audio cassette but could hold 10 times as much information.

description: Senator Orrin G. Hatch, chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, has no intention of acting on the renomination of Bill Lann Lee as the nation's top civil rights officer, Mr. Hatch's spokeswoman said today. And in the sometimes strange logic of Washington, that means Mr. Lee can remain indefinitely as Acting Assistant Attorney General for Civil Rights.

title: The Mayor's Civility Speech
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani warned an audience of New York City officials and supporters yesterday that ''the cynics and pessimists'' would ridicule his new quality-of-life initiatives against reckless driving, noise and litter. He is missing the point. New Yorkers, even cynical ones, will obviously applaud efforts to crack down on speeders and bleating car alarms. But the Mayor seems to be making such issues the focal point of his second term. On that level, his targets are distressingly trivial.

description: The Supreme Court gave the banking industry an important if perhaps temporary victory today in an intensifying battle to stop the expansion of credit unions. It invalidated a Federal regulation that had allowed millions of people to join the alternatives to banks.

The Yankees are on the verge of signing Ricardo Aramboles, a 16-year-old top-flight pitching prospect from the Dominican Republic, and while David Cone threw two good innings in his first game action since his shoulder surgery last fall, the left-hander David Wells has been sidelined by a strained muscle in his rib cage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOUNGMAN, HENNY
description: YOUNGMAN-Henny. The Officers, Governors and Members of the New York Friars Club deeply mourn the loss of their beloved Friar and Friend, Henny Youngman. Henny brought the gift of laughter into the Friars Monastery daily through his quips, one-liners and unique take on the world around him. We are honored and proud to have played such a large part in the larger-than-life world of this endearing comic. He was an entertainer who made a nation laugh and today we take pause, in our sadness, to laugh at the memory of hearing those infamous words, ''Take my wife, please.'' Alan King, Abbot Freddie Roman, Dean Jack L. Green, Dean Emeritus Jean Pierre Trebot, Executive Director

title: Scenic Views, Even Indoors, On Wallpaper
description: Last Saturday, Carolle Thibaut-Pomerantz drove eight hours to look at some wallpaper in a house in northern New England. The owners of the 18th-century home had invited her there to determine whether the wallpaper could be removed, restored and sold. Ms. Thibaut-Pomerantz, who divides her time between Manhattan and Paris, is probably the only American dealer who specializes in antique French wallpapers.
