title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEALON, THOMAS FRANCIS, JR., M.D.
description: NEALON-Thomas Francis, Jr., M.D. A resident of Greenwich, CT., died Feb. 23, 1998, one day before his seventy-eighth birthday. Dr. Nealon was a retired Professor of Surgery with dual faculty appointments at New York University School of Medicine and at New York Medical College. He served as Chairman of the Department of Surgery at Saint Vincent's Hospital in New York City from 1968 until his retirement as Chairman in 1991. During that tenure Dr. Nealon certified the training in surgery of 250 house officers and eightysix chief residents, each of whom has pursued careers throughout the U.S. and abroad. Dr. Nealon served in the United States Navy during World War II and the Korean War achieving the rank of Lieutenant (jg) MC. Dr. Nealon's academic career commenced in 1949 when he served one of the first fellowships in Oncologic Surgery awarded by the American Cancer Society. This focus on cancer research remained through his early career when lung cancer and the correlation between cigarette smoking and cancer of the lung where first established. He later made major contributions to the management of breast cancer by using microscopic characteristics of breast cancer cells to predict subsequent behavior of the cancer. Dr. Nealon was born on February 24, 1920 in Jessup, PA, a small town in the mountainous coal-mining region of Northeast Pennsylvania. He received a Bachelor of Science degree from Jefferson Medical College in 1944. After an internship at the U.S. Naval Hospital in Brooklyn, New York, Dr. Nealon received his training in Surgery from John H. Gibbon, M.D., a recognized giant in American Medicine who is noted for having developed the ''Heart-Lung Machine'', the technology which first permitted open heart surgery. Dr. Nealon's partnership with Dr. Gibbon began with residency training at Jefferson Medical College in Philadelphia, but extended from those days in the early years of the 1950's to 1968 when Dr. Nealon left Jefferson having achieved the rank of Professor of Surgery. Dr. Nealon's entire career was influenced by this prolonged mentorship and partnership with Dr. Gibbon. Dr. Nealon was a member of the operative team which performed the first successful open heart operation every performed on a human. Dr. Nealon's participation was pivotal in the development of the textbook titled ''Surgery of the Chest'' with Dr. Gibbon serving as primary author. This text immediately was recognized and remains the primary source document for both cardiac and non-cardiac thoracic surgery. Dr. Nealon was elected to Alpha Sigma Nu Honorary Society at the University of Scranton and he was elected to Alpha Omega Honorary Society at Jefferson Medical College. He was the recipient of an Honorary Degree, Doctor of Humane Letters conveyed by the University of Scranton in 1979. Dr. Nealon was a member of essentially all the prestigious societies in surgery and thoracic surgery playing a particularly active role in the American Cancer Society, the American Surgical Association, the American Associaton for Thoracic Surgery, the American College of Surgeons, serving as a member of the Board of Governers from 1972-1978, the New York Surgical Society, serving as President in 1978 and the New York Cancer Society, serving as President in 1978 and 1979. Dr. Nealon served as an invited editor of many journals and was a member of the Advisory Editorial Board for the ''Journal of Thoracic and Cardiovascular Surgery'' for many years. He was the author of more than 200 journal articles and many book chapters. He wrote two texts, one serving as the first reference on the surgcal management of cancer. Dr. Nealon remained throughout his life committed to medical education, surgical research and patient care. Dr. Nealon was a member of the Knights of Malta and the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick. Dr. Nealon is survived by his wife of fifty-one years, the former Mary Catherine Hawe and by four children, son Thomas F. Nealon, III and his wife Marjie of Miami, FL, daughter Marty Nealon and her husband Richard of New York, NY, son William Hawe Nealon, M.D. and wife Cathie of Galveston, TX and daughter Kathleen Anne Nealon and husband Eric of New York, NY. He leaves three sisters, Louise Loftus of Denver, CO, Annaclaire Mangan of Mount Holly, NJ and Jean Smith of Lawrenceville, NJ. He also leaves twelve loving grandchildren and countless friends, former pupils, trainees and patients each of whom have been touched by his life. A Memorial Service will take place on Saturday, February 28, 1998, at 2:30PM at St. Michael The Archangel Roman Catholic Church, 469 North Street, Greenwich, Connecticut 06830. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the Thomas Francis Nealon, Jr., M.D. Memorial Fund, C/O University of Texas Medical Branch, Department of Surgery, Galveston, Texas 77555-0544. Attn: William H. Nealon, M.D.

title: Cast Album Sampler: Broadway Changes Its Tune
description: What a jumble of contradictions! On one hand, two of the biggest hit musicals to open on Broadway in the last two years, ''Titanic'' and ''Ragtime,'' are grand millennial pageants, resurrecting events and characters that date back nearly a hundred years. On the other, strong contemporary pop echoes run through these shows' period-flavored scores. As much as they look backward, both embrace an impersonal blockbuster mentality and pop-record esthetic that, like it or not, are revolutionizing the sound and substance of the Broadway musical.

description: Designing In the Streets

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNHEIMER, CHARLES. PH.D.
description: BERNHEIMER-Charles. Ph.D. February 21, 1998 at age 55 in Berkeley, CA. Professor of French and former Chair of the Comparative Literature Program at The University of Pennsylvania, devoted teacher, esteemed colleague and friend, beloved brother, son and husband. Authored or edited five scholarly books and numerous articles. Charlie loved to read and write, was passionately interested in the exchange of ideas and an enthusiastic traveler. Survived by his wife Olga Matich, sister, Celia Bernheimer, and mother Gladys Berhemimer. Son of the late Richard Bernheimer. Memorial to be held March 23 at The University of Pennsylvania. Contributions in his name can be made to the American Cancer Society for Research on Pancreatic Cancer.

title: Covering Infertility Won't Hurt the Uninsured; Truly a Disease
description: To the Editor:

title: Gestures, Nods and Eyebrows to Inspire Conductors
description: Conductors may not actively foster the notion that their art is partly magic and mystery, but few of them discourage that view. Violinists use their own hands to give life to their ideas about tempos, dynamics and phrasing. Pianists manipulate the keyboard to convey their decisions about balance and coloration. But conductors work at a remove: their technique is less about agility than about the ability to inspire others to give the conductors' musical imaginings sound and substance.

title: Mystery Guest
description: The fashion crowd is buzzing about the mystery man at JULIEN MACDONALD's show in London on Tuesday. His front-row seat put him next to the stylist ISABELLA BLOW and her lobster-shaped hat.

title: Devils Keep On Rolling, But Stevens Is Hurting
description: The Devils continued to cut a wide swath through the Atlantic Division tonight, beating the hapless Tampa Bay Lightning, 4-1, despite an injury to their captain and star defenseman Scott Stevens.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOSEPHSON, ABE
description: JOSEPHSON-Abe. Beloved husband of Anne. Loving father of Dr. Barry Josephson and Harriet Josephson Sachs. Cherished grandfather of Braden and Mark Josephson. Services at Boulevard Riverside, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I., 11:30 AM, Friday.

title: Mayfair Puts His Best Attitude Forward
description: When Billy Mayfair married Tammy in 1984, the couple exchanged vows on the 18th green of a golf course in Irving, Tex.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIEN, JOYCE ANNE
description: WIEN-Joyce Anne. On February 26, 1998. Beloved daughter of Elizabeth and Nathan. Dear sister of Eugene and Bess. Loving aunt of Michelle, Stephane, Craig, Jeffrey and Charles. Services Sunday March 1st, 1998, at 1 P.M., at ''Kirschenbaum's'', 1700 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: Covering Infertility Won't Hurt the Uninsured; Risks for Egg Donors
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CANIZARO, BARBARA
description: CANIZARO-Barbara. Called home to the Lord, Feb. 26, 1998. Beloved sister of Normandie Canizaro, Joy (Nick) DeCicco. Devoted aunt of Michael and Ann Marie DeCicco, April and Kevin LoMonte, Nicole and John Hetherington, Sita and Gavin Then, and great-aunt of John Hetherington, Jr. Memorial services will be held at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Avenue (at 20th Street), NYC, Monday, March 2, 1998, 11 A.M.

title: New Owners Take Over Club
description: Howard Milstein, the new co-owner of the Islanders, made a commitment yesterday in Uniondale, N.Y., to the team's long-suffering fans: ''Our goal is to give the fans what they deserve, a great hockey team with devoted owners. We pledge to fill that empty place in every fan's heart with a Stanley Cup.''

title: Court Is Told Of Suicide Try As Ex-Archer Aide Is Absent
description: Mark E. Whitacre, the former executive with the Archer Daniels Midland Company whose work as a Government informant helped crack a huge price-fixing cartel, tried to kill himself today, hours before he was scheduled to be sentenced here on charges of stealing millions of dollars from the grain giant, his lawyer said.

title: John A. Blum, 82, Ex-Executive at Macy's
description: John A. Blum, who spent a long career as an advertising and public relations executive with R. H. Macy & Company, died on Tuesday in Colebrook, Conn. He was 82 and lived in Colebrook.

title: New Ranking On Drug Sales In U.S. in '97
description: Bristol-Myers Squibb, the pharmaceutical industry's quiet giant, has replaced Glaxo Wellcome P.L.C. as the top drug seller in the United States, an annual survey of pharmaceutical sales showed yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the deregulation of the electricity industry in California misidentified the utility marketing company that sought Union Bank of California as a customer. It was Energy Pacific, a joint venture of the Enova Corporation and Pacific Enterprises; it was not Edison Source.

title: Campaign Finance Laws Over the Years
description: 1970's -- In 1971, Congress passes the Federal Election Campaign Act (F.E.C.A.), setting limits on and requiring disclosure of spending by candidates for Federal office and providing public financing for Presidential campaigns. After the Watergate scandal brings down President Richard M. Nixon, Congress in 1974 creates the Federal Election Commission to enforce the act's provisions.

title: Accounts
description: -- Southwest Airlines Inc., Dallas, to Dieste & Partners, Dallas, to handle advertising aimed at Spanish-speaking consumers, previously handled by Siboney USA, Dallas, a unit of True North Communications. Billings were estimated at $3 million.

title: Blinding Sport Trucks
description: To the Editor:

title: Lewinsky Is Facing Legal Limbo
description: In the last four weeks, Monica S. Lewinsky has turned from potential star witness to potential defendant in the independent counsel's investigation of President Clinton and his relationship with the former intern.

title: Panel on Police Relations Urges City Residency for New Officers
description: The task force that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani formed after the Abner Louima case to try to improve relations between the Police Department and residents voted yesterday to recommend that all new police officers be required to live in the city.

title: CAMPBELL DIRECTORS SET SHARE RATIO FOR VLASIC SPINOFF
description: The Campbell Soup Company said yesterday that its directors had set the share ratio for the spinoff of its Vlasic pickles, Swanson frozen dinners and Swift meat businesses as Vlasic Foods International, part of its plan to focus on selling more soup, biscuits and confectioneries. Campbell said its shareholders would receive on March 30 one share of Vlasic Foods International for every 10 Campbell shares they own as of March 9. Last week, the Internal Revenue Service granted the spinoff tax-free status. Vlasic Foods, which will be based in Cherry Hill, N.J., has sales of about $1.4 billion, or about 18 percent of Campbell's revenue in the 1997 fiscal year. Shares of Campbell Soup, based in Camden, N.J., rose 37.5 cents, to $58.1875.

title: A Strip Club Ban That Pays No Heed to Class
description: Nothing much was moving late Tuesday night in midtown Manhattan except garbage men in their rain slickers and, inside one gentlemen's strip club, a never-ending parade of bare-bodied women.

title: Celestial Instrument Brought to Earth
description: Not many harpists manage to have a career as a soloist. As an instrument in an orchestra or chamber ensemble, the harp can provide swashes of ethereal colors, swooshing arpeggio effects, and, in quieter moments, delicately etched melodies. But it cannot stand up to the din of an orchestra, and as a solo instrument it has clear limits.

title: The Shrinking Military Complex; After the Cold War, the Pentagon Is Just Another Customer
description: As the United States maintains an armed buildup in the Persian Gulf against Iraq, the nation's military contractors are completing a multiyear, multibillion-dollar reorganization that has left them less tied to the Pentagon's needs and more beholden to shareholder pressures and civilian market forces.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, HENRIETTA (QUEENIE)
description: KATZ-Henrietta (Queenie), age 95 of Lauderhill, FL, formerly of New York. Beloved wife of the late Hyman (Kitty). Loving mother of Henry (Margaret), Richard (Judy), and Lucy (Ed) Weidman. Adored by eleven grandchildren and fourteen great-grandchildren. Graveside services Sunday, March 1st, Beth Moses Cemetery, Farmingdale, Long Island 11 AM. Friends and family may call at the home of Lucy and Ed Weidman on Sunday, Monday, and Tuesday from 4:00 P.M. to 9:00 P.M.

title: Metro Business; Bank Group Gives To Small Businesses
description: Twelve small businesses in the New York City metropolitan region have received $7.2 million from the New York Community Investment Company.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BAUMAN, LIONEL R.
description: BAUMAN-Lionel R. Beloved partner, friend and colleague. Died Feb 27, 1987. Sorely missed by all. Eugene M. Grant & Company

title: World News Briefs; Ex-Official in Spain Gets Corruption Sentence
description: The man who was a chief of the Civil Guard in the Socialist Government of Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez was sentenced today to 28 years for embezzling millions of dollars in public funds, taking kickbacks and evading taxes.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  JANSON, RICHARD W. (RICK)
description: JANSON-Richard W. (Rick) Feb. 27, 1946-Dec. 2O, 1987 ''Here's looking at you, kid'' Love always, Frank Nash

title: The Man Likely to Be Mexico's No. 1 Trafficker (the Job's Open)
description: Ever since the authorities reported last year that Mexico's most influential drug trafficker, Amado Carrillo Fuentes, had died during surgery, American and Mexican anti-drug agencies have been monitoring the underworld for signs of a successor.

title: Sex and Perjury
description: To the Editor:

title: A Few Cents Between Farm And History
description: YESTERDAY was just another day for Bill Moody and his family, which means it was another day of back-breaking labor on their dairy farm in Hamden, N.Y. They were up at 5 A.M. to begin three hours of milking and feeding 140 cows. Then they had barns to clean, machinery to fix and sick calves to fuss over, by which point it was getting dark, time to start the milking and feeding all over again.

title: Giuliani Withdraws Money For a Bronx Asthma Program
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that the city was withdrawing its money from a multimillion-dollar asthma education and treatment initiative in the Bronx, saying the organization selected to run the program was refusing to agree to the city's plan for financial and program supervision.

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: Curtain Times: Not Just 8 P.M.

title: Insurer Sets Review Plan For Disputes
description: The five Blue Cross and Blue Shield health insurers in New York State announced yesterday that they would voluntarily submit disputes with patients who are denied medical coverage to an independent third party for review.

title: IRON MOUNTAIN IN $28 MILLION DEAL FOR INTERMATION
description: Iron Mountain Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire Intermation Inc., a closely held records-management business, for $28 million in stock, cash and assumed debt. Iron Mountain, based in Boston, provides retrieval and storage of records for government and businesses. It has more than 50,000 accounts and annual revenue of $208.8 million. Intermation, with offices in Seattle and Portland, Ore., provides records-retrieval and storage services for business and the medical profession. The move will bolster Iron Mountain's position in the Pacific Northwest, the company said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCHEL, LOUIS
description: HIRSCHEL-Louis. Died February 25, 1998 in Sharon, CT, at the age of 83 years young. His brother Arthur Hirschel of Florida survives him. Additionally, his daughters Yvette and her husband David Smith of River Vale, N.J., Myrnaand Nat Yagoda of Fort Lee, N.J., and his son Marc and his wife Paula Hirschel of Sharon, CT. Lou also leaves behind his grandchildren Craig, Todd, Danielle and Seth, and his very best friend Mona King Myerson of Woodlands, Florida. After immigrating from Poland in 1929, Lou helped established Batterman and Hirschel Caterers of Rego Park, Queens and Yonkers, N.Y. He touched many people's lives with both his personality and his tremendous sense of humor and will be greatly missed by all. Graveside services will be held Friday, February 27, 1998 at Mount Hebron Cemetery in Flushing, New York at 10:30 A.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JORGEN, BOB
description: JORGEN-Bob. We mourn the loss of our dear friend and advisor, Bob Jorgen, former Acting Director and Board Member. His help to us in difficult times was wise and invaluable. The Board and Staff of Family Dynamics

title: Marlins' Zaun Waits on a Trade to Mets
description: If the Florida Marlins traded Greg Zaun to the Mets, he would run the 72 miles to the Mets' spring camp faster than it obviously takes Gary Sheffield to drive the 155 miles from his home in St. Petersburg to the Marlins' camp here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PATTERSON, BARBARA FROST
description: PATTERSON-Barbara Frost, 70, died on February 22nd, 1998, in Saint Augustine, Florida. Born in Cleveland, Ohio on November 8, 1927, the daughter of Dr. Clyde D. Frost and Ruth Harrington Frost. Employed in the early 1960's by the Southern Regional Council, a prominent Atlanta-based civil rights organization. Worked primarily for the organization's Voter Education Project, under the direction of Vernon E. Jordan, Jr. Created beautiful quilts and hooked rugs. Survived by three sons, Adam Zach, Philip Zach and Andrew Patterson; one brother, Dr. James L. Frost; and one grandson. Predeceased by a daughter, Catherine Frost Patterson, in 1968. She will be dearly remembered by her children and family for her knowledge, wit, generosity and compassion. Her deep, unconditional love for her family and close friends will be irreplaceable and greatly missed. A memorial service will be held at the Cutler United Methodist Church in Cutler, Maine, on Saturday, March 7, 1998 at 1 P.M. Contributions in her memory can be made to the Cutler United Methodist Church, PO Box 233, Cutler, ME 04626.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: POMEROY COMPUTER RESOURCES INC., Erlanger, Ky., a network integration company, agreed to acquire Global Combined Technologies Inc., Oklahoma City, a closely held computer reseller and network integrator. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Voters Decline To Increase Taxes
description: Atlantic City voters rejected a measure late Wednesday night to tax themselves and the city's casino industry an extra $6 million to make up for a shortfall in this year's school budget.

title: Auriemma Wants End To the Record Hoopla
description: Geno Auriemma has no regrets. The coach of the Connecticut women's basketball team said yesterday that he had done the right thing and that he had been surprised by the controversy it had set off. And Auriemma added, ''I just wish it would go away.''

title: U.S. Takes Over the Louima Case; 5th Suspect, a Sergeant, Is Indicted
description: The Federal Government yesterday formally took over the prosecution of four police officers implicated in a brutal attack on Abner Louima and expanded the case by indicting a Brooklyn sergeant for reportedly helping the four officers cover it up.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Relishing A Coincidence

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARSHALL, JOAN L. (NEE SLATER)
description: MARSHALL-Joan L. (nee Slater). Of Glen Rock, on February 25, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Allan S. Marshall. Devoted mother of Robert M. Marshall and Sally A. Schwartz. Loving grandmother of Harris S. Marshall. Funeral service today at 12 Noon, February 27, 1998, Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, 150 Rte 4 E, Paramus, NJ.

title: Dispute on Bible Course Is Settled
description: A county high school course designed to teach the Bible as history will be renamed, and students will be required to take world history or comparative religion along with the Bible course, according to an out-of-court settlement reached between Lee County school officials, parents and civil liberties groups.

title: Ethics of Organ Sales; Black-Market Myth
description: To the Editor:

title: Observer; The Supporting Cast
description: Television's talking heads and everyone else who professes a lot of savvy about whatever is in the air keep telling us why the President's popularity stays high despite the cheesy sex scandal now running in Washington.

title: Clinton Continues to Stumble Over the 'E' Word (Encryption)
description: President Clinton described the economic impact of the Internet today in glowing terms to an audience of technology investors here, but he failed to touch on the issue that increasingly appears to matter most to Silicon Valley: the fiery debate over the Administration's policy on data scrambling.

title: Paribas Posts Gain Despite Asian Losses
description: The profit of Compagnie Financiere de Paribas rose almost sevenfold in the second half of 1997 even after charges for bad loans and trading losses in Asia wiped out 3 billion francs ($500 million). Paribas earned 2.4 billion francs, up from 350 million francs a year earlier. For the full year, Paribas posted a 51 percent rise in earnings to 6.6 billion francs, from 4.35 billion francs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURGE, MARIANNE
description: BURGE-Marianne. On February 26, 1998. Retired Partner of Price Waterhouse. Loving wife of William H. Burge. Also survived by many cousins in Paris and Sydney, Australia. Service on Friday 11:30AM, Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Entombment Trinity Mausoleum.

title: Exploding on the Scene Like a Shooting Star
description: When the young painter Robert Delaunay came back to Paris in the fall of 1908, after a year of military service, he returned to a new artistic universe. The early Cubist work of Picasso, Braque and Gris had been exhibited for the first time, setting off powerful shock waves.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Richard Tuttle

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Students View Operation Via Satellite Broadcast
description: To Desi Lincuna, an eighth grader from Jersey City, seeing a heart patient's chest cut open and stitched back up was by no means a gross-out.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Barbara Crowther, 60, Firm's Manager
description: Barbara Benson Crowther, a business manager of a law firm and a volunteer in mental health, died yesterday at her home in Palmyra, Va. She was 60 years old. She died of a heart attack, her husband, F. Bosley Crowther 3d, said.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: John Wesley

title: On My Mind; Annan's Bad Gamble
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan is gambling his reputation on the word, honor and actions of Saddam Hussein -- a decision that raises sad questions about the future and course of the United Nations itself.

title: Jo Floyd, 74; Led Growth and Change at Christie's
description: Jo Floyd, the former chairman of Christie's International, died on Feb. 20 in a hospital in London. He was 74 and had cancer, a colleague said.

title: Angotti, Thomas Wins Hardee's Account
description: Hardee's Food Systems Inc. in Rocky Mount, N.C., said yesterday that it had named Angotti, Thomas, Hedge in New York to handle the creative portion of its account. Billings, estimated at $80 million, are expected to rise to $100 million.

title: 4 Indicted in Immigrant Smuggling Scheme
description: A Federal grand jury today indicted a former Olympic bicyclist from Iraq and three others in a scheme to smuggle hundreds of people from the Mideast through Latin America and the Caribbean and then on to Mexico, where they crossed the Rio Grande to their ultimate destinations in cities including Los Angeles, Las Vegas, Detroit and New York.

title: Surgery Ends McDonald's Season
description: Cleveland Indians right-hander Ben McDonald underwent season-ending surgery on his pitching shoulder, the team said. The operation was performed Wednesday night by Dr. Lewis Yocum, who repaired McDonald's rotator cuff.

title: A Golden Visit
description: KARYN BYE, a forward on the United States women's gold-medal-winning hockey team at the Olympics, has been learning to be a celebrity in New York this week, doing the talk shows and signing autographs.

title: INSIDE
description: Crossroads on Indonesia

title: A Movie About a Really Horrendous Movie. Get It?
description: Having flouted Hollywood's power elite in all the familiar ways, Joe Eszterhas now tries something really risky: being unfunny. There's little to laugh at in the nonstop potshots taken by the satire now called ''An Alan Smithee Film: Burn Hollywood Burn,'' and the only target most of them hit is the screenwriter's own foot. Bad-mouthing boomerangs when it is this one-note, and when its supposed in-joke nature doesn't reveal anything you couldn't learn from a big stack of movie magazines on a rainy afternoon. Nobody watching Mr. Eszterhas's bilious, stereotype-filled attack on the film business is likely to suppose that the author is part of the solution rather than part of the problem.

title: Durable Orders Rose by 0.7% Last Month
description: Orders for durable goods rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in January, the Commerce Department said today, indicating that the Asian economic crisis had little impact on American manufacturers.

title: Controlling Sex Shops
description: New York City's drive to curb the proliferation of sex-related businesses in the five boroughs has cleared its last big legal hurdle. In a unanimous ruling on Tuesday, New York State's highest court rejected the contention that the city violated free-speech rights by using its zoning power to ameliorate the detrimental impact of pornography shops on city neighborhoods, thus preserving an important plan for making the city more livable.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARR, MIRIAM
description: CARR-Miriam. On February 26, 1998. Loving and devoted sister of Irving (Miriam), Mortimer (Lila), Rita (Leo) Lieberman and Leon (Bernice). Cherished aunt and great aunt. Renowned former supervisor of microbiology at the V.A. Hospital, NYC. Graveside services today 1:30 PM at Beth Moses Cemetery, Farmingdale, L.I.

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Galleries, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan and are open Tuesdays through Saturdays from 10 or 11 A.M. to 5 or 6 P.M.; gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELIAS, SYLVAN H.
description: ELIAS-Sylvan H. The members of Vladeck, Waldman, Elias & Engelhard, P.C., their associates and employees, mourn the passing of Sylvan H. Elias, a founding member of the firm. He was a superb lawyer, a good friend, and a kind and gentle man. Services will be held Sunday, March 1, at 12:15 PM, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York City.

title: Leonardo Nole, 91, Prometheus Statue's Model
description: Leonardo Nole, a longtime postal worker who achieved a measure of immortality simply by standing nude on one foot and pretending to fly, died on Sunday at a nursing home in Sacramento, Calif. He was 91 and the model for the famous titan-sized statue of Prometheus at the Rockefeller Center skating rink.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINDWEHR, ROSE PETERMAN
description: WINDWEHR-Rose Peterman, 94, died February 25, 1998. Devoted daughter of Aron and Shifra Peterman. Beloved sister of Anna, Dora, Pauline, Tillie, Albert and Joseph. Loving wife of Isadore Windwehr. Mother of Janice Adler and Marilyn Klinghoffer. Grandmother of Ilsa, Lisa, Jerry, Paul and Ian. Great-grandmother of Max and Michael Leon. The last of her generation, the end of an era. A truly unique woman of strength, courage, dignity and beauty. Her tenacious, indomitable spirit provided guidance to us all. She adored her precious and loving family and friends. Her daily loyal visitors, caregivers and family cherished her. She was our inspiration. We will miss her so much. Funeral Menorah Chapel in Union, N.J., Friday February 27, 11:30 A.M. Donations to Leon and Marilyn Klinghoffer Memorial Foundation of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai Brith in NYC. Ilsa, Paul, Max Lisa, Jerry and Michael Leon

title: Yeltsin Gives His Cabinet Public Rebuke On Economy
description: In a special Government meeting that was half encounter group and half stagey show trial, President Boris N. Yeltsin lashed out at his Government for failing to correct the country's ailing economy and threatened a Cabinet shake-up.

title: As Iraqi Tension Eases, Arabs Criticize U.S. Role
description: With the Iraq crisis in remission, one question thrown into sharp relief is whether the standing of the United States in the Middle East has suffered.

title: 5 Groups Seek Open Hearings on Privilege
description: Five news organizations today filed a motion in Federal District court here, seeking to make public arguments between the White House and the Office of the Independent Counsel over the use of executive privilege.

title: Writer Ends Testimony In Brawley Case
description: One of the most contentious witnesses in the Tawana Brawley defamation case finished his testimony yesterday and court was adjourned for the weekend after being in session only one hour.

title: A 75-Year-Old Strikes Out on His Own
description: No one could have predicted that Ving Rhames and Jack Lemmon would become a new nonfiction odd couple, but now their names are forever entwined. In what has already become Hollywood legend, Mr. Rhames (the star of ''Don King: Only in America'') beat out Mr. Lemmon (''Twelve Angry Men'') to win the Golden Globe Award as best actor in a television drama last month. The winner called the purported loser up on stage and handed him the award. ''I knew Don King was a character, but I didn't know you were crazy,'' Mr. Lemmon said, looking pleasantly flummoxed.

title: Kraft Foods Makes Agency Shifts
description: The Kraft Foods unit of the Philip Morris Companies said yesterday that it would realign the accounts of nine brands with billings estimated at $200 million. The reshuffling is the most recent in a series of account consolidations at Kraft.

title: Respect Wish of Unknown Soldier's Family
description: To the Editor:

title: Unplugged: It's Wells and the Love Sponge
description: Morning commuters wading through stoplights here these days can tune into Bubba the Love Sponge on WXTB, and chances are that sometime between 7:30 and 8 A.M. they will hear Yankees pitcher David Wells.

title: More Copies of Memo Turn Up in Mob Case
description: When prosecutors appeared in Federal District Court in Manhattan in December to tell a judge that the Government had accidentally made public a confidential document outlining its strategy in a case involving the Mafia's infiltration of Wall Street, the judge agreed to order defense lawyers who had obtained copies of the document to send them back immediately.

title: Fatal Bicycle Accidents Reach 10-Year High
description: Twenty-two bicyclists were killed in accidents with cars last year in New York City, the highest number in a decade, according to figures from the city's Department of Transportation that were released yesterday by a bicyclist advocacy group.

title: Respect Wish of Unknown Soldier's Family
description: To the Editor:

title: Turf Was Cattlemen's, But Jury Was Winfrey's
description: After a six-week trial in which she charmed a city in the very heart of America's cattle country, the talk-show host Oprah Winfrey won a smashing legal victory today when a Federal jury in Amarillo, Tex., ruled that she bore no liability for a television program of hers that explored whether ''mad cow disease'' threatened the country's beef supply.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Business Day yesterday with the continuation of a front-page article about the growing presence of advertisements referred incorrectly to one product, Hot Damn. It is a cordial, not a hot sauce.

title: Stumbling Upon the Desert's Secret
description: THE ROAD TO UBAR

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Loren MacIver

title: Health Secretary Urges Donor Priority for Sickest Patients
description: With more than 4,000 Americans dying each year while waiting to receive an organ transplant, the Clinton Administration said today that it planned to dismantle the 14-year-old regional system for distributing donor organs and replace it with one in which the sickest patients would go to the top of the waiting list, no matter where in the country they lived.

title: Campaign Reform Has Nine Lives
description: There was no shortage of gleeful burial crews on Capitol Hill yesterday proclaiming the death of campaign finance reform. In truth, it was disappointing that no more than 51 senators, well short of the 60 needed, voted to cut off a filibuster of the McCain-Feingold bill led by Trent Lott, the majority leader. But if reform supporters keep attaching the measure to other legislation in coming weeks, the most significant cleanup of the nation's polluted electoral system since the post-Watergate reforms of the 1970's can still be salvaged.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILBANK, ROSE
description: MILBANK-Rose. The Board of Governors, Trustees, staff and members of Boys & Girls Clubs of America wish to express their profound sorrow over the psssing of Mrs. Rose Milbank, the wife of Jeremiah Milbank, our dear friend and former President and Chairman. Along with her husband Jerry, ''Posy'' Milbank demonstrated a lifelong concern for America's children, working tirelessly on their behalf, both on the national and local level. We will miss her greatly. Boys & Girls Clubs of America Rick Goings, Chairman Roxanne Spillett, President

title: Officials Link Clinic Blasts And Bombing At '96 Games
description: Federal authorities have uncovered physical evidence that for the first time links the fatal bombing at the 1996 Olympic Games in Atlanta with bomb attacks at abortion clinics in Atlanta in January 1997 and in Birmingham, Ala., last month, law-enforcement officials said today.

title: Grammy Options
description: Who besides MAYOR RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI skipped the Grammy Awards? DAVID BOWIE and his wife, IMAN, went to ''Hedwig and the Angry Inch,'' at the Jane Street Theater in the West Village. ''I had no idea that he was there, thank God,'' said the show's headliner, JOHN CAMERON MITCHELL, adding that Hedwig owes a lot to Mr. Bowie. But the show's guitarist, CHRIS WIELDING, noticed him just before the script called for the Bowie classic ''Heroes.''

title: Police Arrest Teen-Age Suspect In Abduction Attempts in Bronx
description: The police arrested a 15-year-old last night who is believed to be responsible for the attempted abductions of at least 10 schoolgirls across the Bronx, the authorities said.

title: Bid to Save Fish Puts West on Notice
description: After nearly half a century of breakneck urban growth, the West Coast was given a bill, of sorts, by the Federal Government today. Federal officials announced that wild Pacific salmon are nearly extinct and put major urban areas on notice that millions of people are likely to face disruptions and higher living costs if the fish are to be restored as the law requires.

title: Metro Business; Big Bill for Computer Bug
description: Citicorp said yesterday that it expected to spend a total of $600 million to inoculate its computers against the year 2000 problem.

title: Serena Williams Declines Offer
description: Contending that she was more concerned with the grade she receives in her senior zoology class than with her tennis, 16-year-old Serena Williams confirmed yesterday that she would be unable to fit Fed Cup duty into her spring or summer schedule despite a plea from the team's returning captain, Billie Jean King.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VASAR, MIRIAM
description: VASAR-Miriam. On February 20, 1998. Active member of the Estonian community. Contributions may be made to the Estonian American Fund, 4 Noyes Court, Silver Spring, Maryland 20910.

title: After years of anticipation, Young & Rubicam is finally preparing for a public stock offering.
description: THE long anticipated foray of Young & Rubicam Inc. onto Wall Street is at last under way.

title: Taiwan's Top Banker Vows to Hold the Line
description: Perng Fai-nan, the new governor of Taiwan's central bank, said yesterday that he would hold the Taiwan dollar steady as the island rides out Asia's economic turmoil. Laying out his plans for the first time, Mr. Perng made controlling inflation his top priority and said few policies would change soon. He is known for his prowess in the currency market and slow approach to financial reform.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBAUM, RUTH
description: GREENBAUM-Ruth. On February 25th, 1998 in Venice, Florida. Born 1913 in Brooklyn, New York. Beloved wife of the late Solomon. Loving mother of Ellen Runestad and Karen Luks; grandmother of Robin, Marc, Rachel and David. Burial Eternal Light, Boynton Beach, Florida, Sunday, March 1.

title: Trying to End Furor, College Picks Jewish Studies Director
description: In an effort to end the anger aroused when a non-Jewish professor resigned as chairman of the Jewish studies program at Queens College after complaints from Jewish critics, the college president has announced the appointment of Prof. Benny Kraut, a widely published specialist in modern European and American Jewish history and Judaica, to lead the department.

title: U.S. LAUDS MEXICO ON DRUG EFFORTS, COUNTERING D.E.A.
description: Despite a confidential Government assessment that recent drug-enforcement measures by Mexico have not produced ''significant results,'' the White House announced today that the Mexican Government was ''fully cooperating'' in the fight against drug trafficking.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BILENKER, HINDA FISHER
description: BILENKER-Hinda Fisher. Of Elizabeth, NJ, Feb. 25, 1998 in Boca Raton, Florida. Loving wife of Mortimer to whom she was married for 49 years. Adored mother of Dr. Robert (Barbara) Bilenker, Judith (Maynard) Rabinowitz, Ellen (Dr. Martin) Lebosky and Dr. Arthur (Terry) Bilenker. Cherished grandmother of Ted, Alan, Joshua and Stephanie, Jennifer, Eric, Janine, Daniel and Carrie. Beloved sister of the late Rabbi Henry Fisher and the late Harry Fisher. Services today, Fri., Feb. 27, 1998, 11 A.M., at ''The Jewish Education Center'', 330 Elmont Avenue, Elizabeth. Info ''Gutterman-Warheit Memorial Chapel'' 1-800-992-9262.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LESCAULT, ANNE
description: LESCAULT-Anne, February 24, 1998, of Somers, New York and Jupiter, Florida, and formerly of Pound Ridge, New York. Wife of the late Theodore Lescault and H. Kenneth Meyer. Also survived by one brother-in-law, one sister-inlaw, one aunt, several nieces and nephews, and great-nieces and great-nephews. Reposing at Clark Associates Funeral Home, Katonah, New York, Friday, 2-4 and 79PM with services at the funeral home Saturday, 11 AM. Interment, Middle Patent Cemetery, Banksville, New York.

title: The Boardwalk in Winter? Absolutely
description: As a lover of beach resorts out of season, I cherish most the Boardwalk in winter. Anyone who asks which boardwalk clearly did not grow up in Brooklyn, Truman Capote's ''mythical dominion against whose shores the Coney Island sea laps a wintry lament.''

title: Taipei Journal; For Heaven's Sake, Don't Fly a U.F.O.
description: Ho Hsien-jung cradled a bloated aluminum saucer on his lap and looked worried.

title: A Gasp for Breath Inside an Airless Life
description: Sometimes you don't even know what you've been craving until the real thing comes along. Watching the Druid Theater Company's production of ''The Beauty Queen of Leenane,'' the stunning new play from the young Anglo-Irish dramatist Martin McDonagh, is like sitting down to a square meal after a long diet of salads and hors d'oeuvres. Before you know it, your appetite has come alive again, and you begin to feel nourished in ways you had forgotten were possible.

title: Philharmonic Retains Masur, But Will Seek A Successor
description: After a bitter row in which he complained of being pressured to retire, Kurt Masur and the New York Philharmonic agreed yester day to extend his contract as music director to 2002, but also to plan for a successor.

title: Only Her Admirer Knows for Sure (Maybe)
description: There are actors who'd like to do ''Death of a Salesman'' and there are actors who would be happy to appear in a Madonna video wearing a bathing suit and doing the looniest of double-takes when the star wiggles by. Joe, the disappointed idealist at the center of ''The Real Blonde,'' another bright, barbed New York satire from the director of ''Living in Oblivion,'' manages to be both during the course of this acerbically funny fable. Tom DiCillo, who wrote and directed this shrewd comedy with a sharp notion of exactly what he wants to skewer, presents Joe's career roller coaster as a cautionary tale for the vain and trendy. As in ''Living in Oblivion,'' it's clear that the filmmaker truly knows his terrain.

title: New York City's Budget Surplus Is Expected to Surpass Record
description: New York City will end its fiscal year with a budget surplus between $1.4 billion and $1.5 billion, almost certainly surpassing Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's prediction and last year's record surplus of $1.4 billion, city and state auditors said yesterday.

title: FAMILY FARE
description: Dance, African And American

title: Et Cetera
description: SENATOR EDWARD M. KENNEDY's daughter-in-law, KATHERINE KENNEDY, gave birth to a son at Yale-New Haven Hospital on Wednesday. She waited to announce the baby's name until the Senator arrived (by train): Edward M. Kennedy 3d. She is a psychiatrist at the Yale Medical School. Her husband, TED KENNEDY JR., is a lawyer . . . Two dozen magazine executives (including JOHN MACK CARTER, the president of Hearst Magazines Enterprises, who will be 70 tomorrow) leave today on an Outward Bound trip to Nepal. Is everybody ready? ''I've been going to spinning classes,'' said MIKE PERLIS, the president of TVSM, a cable-guide publisher. ''That's organized indoor bike riding classes.'' JAMES BARRON with PHOEBE HOBAN

title: It's One Game at a Time
description: Donell Mitchell remembers the silent flight home. Kashif Hameed remembers wishing he could start over.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Jean Fautrier

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Andy Warhol

title: Colombia's Chief Sees Victory in U.S. Backing for Anti-Drug Effort
description: Colombian officials today greeted Washington's conditional certification of their efforts to combat the flow of drugs into the United States as a victory for their beleaguered President, Ernesto Samper.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR FALLS. Talk about new steps to stimulate Japan's weak economy sent the dollar lower against the yen yesterday. In late trading, the dollar was quoted at 127.30 yen, down from 128.65 yen on Wednesday.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 8.

title: A Virtuoso Sculptor Of Idealized Royalty And Lively Bourgeois
description: Even viewers conversant with 18th-century art may draw a blank at the name of the French sculptor Augustin Pajou (1730-1809), who is the subject of a large, strange and interesting retrospective -- his first ever, it turns out -- at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Union Pacific Predicts Loss and Cuts Its Dividend
description: The Union Pacific Corporation, the nation's largest railroad company, forecast a first-quarter loss yesterday, announced plans to issue as much as $1 billion in securities and cut its dividend by more than half as it struggles to untangle an eight-month rail logjam.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''My reaction is that free speech not only lives. It rocks.''

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: 'Not for Sale'

title: The Neediest Cases; Foster Parents Find Fulfillment in Caring for Seriously Ill Children
description: Shante cannot walk, talk or see. At 12, she has the mental capacity of a newborn and spends nearly all her waking hours convulsed by laughter. She cannot feed herself or go to the bathroom on her own.

title: Treasury Prices Fall Again Despite Weak Economic Reports
description: The prices of Treasury securities were down for the sixth time in seven days yesterday as investors apparently ignored weak economic reports usually bullish for the bond market.

title: New Video Releases
description: Gravesend

title: Sex and Perjury; Honesty in Office
description: To the Editor:

title: Court Asked to Reject School Spending Request
description: Legislative leaders took the unusual step yesterday of urging the New Jersey Supreme Court to reject a judge's recommendation that the state spend an additional $312 million a year on urban schools.

title: DEADLOCK IN SENATE BLOCKS CAMPAIGN FINANCE  REFORM, ALL BUT KILLING IT FOR YEAR
description: The Senate today all but buried campaign finance overhaul effort for at least another year.

title: Time Can't Kill 'Mockingbird'
description: In the leanest week for new movie releases so far this year, video dealers are looking hungrily for the films that got the top Academy Award nominations earlier this month. Not much is ready. With Oscar candidates usually released in theaters late in the year, three of the five best-picture candidates -- ''Titanic,'' ''Good Will Hunting'' and ''As Good as It Gets'' -- are still in movie houses and nowhere near ready for their video turns. Only ''The Full Monty,'' to be released next week, will be available before the awards next month. The fifth nominee, ''L.A. Confidential,'' is scheduled for release April 14.

title: Boeing to Overhaul Executive Pay
description: The Boeing Company announced plans this week to overhaul management pay, tying it more closely to the company's stock performance to make top executives more accountable for Boeing's financial performance.

title: U.S. Says Evidence Connects 3 Bombings
description: Federal authorities investigating a fatal bombing in Birmingham, Ala., last month, a bomb attack at an Atlanta abortion clinic and the explosion at the 1996 Summer Olympics in Atlanta have evidence that they say links the three. The main link is that plates used in the two Atlanta bombs were cut from a batch of metal at a plant that employed a friend of Eric Robert Rudolph, who is wanted in the Birmingham bombing.

title: You Are Getting Sleepy: Who Are You, Anyway?
description: Alex Proyas's noisy psychedelic movie nightmare, ''Dark City,'' is so relentlessly trippy in a fun-house sort of way that it could very easily inspire a daredevil cult of moviegoers who go back again and again to experience its mind-bending twists and turns. Although its story doesn't add up when you analyze it afterward, the movie does take you on a visually arresting ride that offers many unsettling surprises right up to a sentimental sunburst of an ending that has a paranoid undertone.

title: Steakhouses
description: Many restaurants offer steaks, but few are as dedicated to any single dish as the New York steakhouse. Here are 12 to choose from. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are from Ruth Reichl's and Mr. Asimov's dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: Out of the Ashes
description: First the date was Feb. 1, then early March, now April 15.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOVICK, SONIA
description: NOVICK-Sonia. We mourn the passing of the mother of our esteemed member, Arnold Novick, and pray that the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Young Israel of Great Neck

title: Ethics of Organ Sales
description: To the Editor:

title: To Epiphany While Skipping Rebellion
description: Jazz musicians, like novelists, have to avoid post-modern cliche; an approach that was once predicated on exploding old forms can often seem cheap and dispensable now.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE SLUMPS. Prices fell 2.6 percent on signs of growing inventories. Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange supplies have risen to the highest level since December 1995. May coffee fell 4.5 cents, to $1.662 a pound.

title: Truck Hijacking Yields 1,500 Cases of Beer
description: So maybe it was the allure of a fine Dutch import. Maybe it was the prospect of a big payday. Or maybe it was just a matter of a lot of people feeling very thirsty on another balmy day in the dead of winter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIDMANN, DINA
description: WIDMANN-Dina. On February 26, after a long illness. Beloved wife of Dr. Marcus Widmann. Loving mother of Harriet and Martin Spitz, and Roger and Judith Widmann. Devoted sister of Eitel Sander and the late Kurt. Cherished grandmother of Daniel, Emily, Kenneth, Robert and Jenny and Lisa. Loving sister-in-law of Fina Eytan. Service are today, at 1:30 P.M., at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, New York.

title: Gossip on Web Gives News Novel Spin
description: Close followers of the Drudge Report and they know who they are -- know that the Internet gossip column can always be counted on for a novel spin on the news of the moment, particularly when it touches on the publisher Matt Drudge himself, as so much of it seems to these days.

title: N.F.L. and Players Extend Pact in Principle Into 2003
description: The National Football League and its players, after months of intense and sometimes nasty negotiations, have agreed in principle to an extension of the collective bargaining agreement that will insure labor peace through the year 2003. That's the good news.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in New York City this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Wife in Stifling Marriage Seeks a Shining Knight
description: Don't feel bad for Nora: at least she got to live in that nicely furnished Scandinavian doll's house. Save your pity instead for Mae Wilenski. All she has to show for a stultifying marriage is a shack on Staten Island.

title: COMFORT SYSTEMS SAYS IT ACQUIRED 16 MORE BUSINESSES
description: Comfort Systems USA Inc. said yesterday that it had acquired 16 businesses for $125 million in cash, stock and debt to expand its heating, ventilation and air-conditioning installation and maintenance business. Comfort Systems, based in Houston, was formed last year to acquire heating, ventilation and air-conditioning services businesses. With the acquisitions, mainly of closely held contractors, Comfort Systems will have annual revenue of more than $485 million and operations in 29 cities. The company said it would continue to make acquisitions as it tries to add about $100 million in revenue a quarter, 60 percent from service and 40 percent from installations.

title: Cummings Finds Touch To Energize The Knicks
description: Terry Cummings still has two suitcases sitting in the middle of his hotel room floor, spilling over like foam from a mug.

title: Covering Infertility Won't Hurt the Uninsured; Children in Need
description: To the Editor:

title: J. P. Morgan In Korea Battle On Derivatives
description: Editor's Note Appended

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STAUFFACHER, LILLIAN MOSS
description: STAUFFACHER-Lillian Moss, 81, of N. Palm Beach, FL., formerly of Greenwich, CT, on February 23, 1998. Wife of 54 years of Charles B. Stauffacher, prominent New York businessman (retired). Mother of Lillian Gillies, of Glen Head, NY and Charles D. Stauffacher, of Roxbury, CT. Grandmother of Heidi Stauffacher, James Gillies and Barrett Stauffacher. In lieu of flowers, contributions to an organization of one's choice are preferred by the family.

title: H.M.O.'s Plan To Seek Profits Draws Criticism
description: Doctors, patients and advocates for the poor and for retired people spoke out in opposition today to a plan by Vytra Healthcare, the largest health maintenance organization on Long Island, to convert to profit-making status and sell shares on the stock market.

title: Precinct Silence on Louima Is Still Under Investigation
description: The Federal indictment unsealed yesterday in the 70th Precinct police torture case paints a picture of a small-scale cover-up aimed at protecting the officers who prosecutors say assaulted Abner Louima, a Haitian immigrant, and beat another man the morning of Aug. 9.

title: When Coaches Conspire to Set a Record; A Sweet Moment of Teamwork
description: College basketball, at least as played by women, is still school sports -- athletics as part of the learning experience. One lesson it teaches is that the score is a stern arbiter that does not always give worthy players their just rewards. But another is that individual achievement is useless without cooperation. Nykesha Sales is a notably unselfish player. Had she hogged the ball more often, she could undoubtedly have broken the record before she was injured. In organizing a special opportunity for her to sink one final basket, her coach and teammates paid tribute to the importance of teamwork.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANE, ROSE
description: KANE-Rose. Abraham Allen and his son Philip and his wife Laura mourn the passing of Abe's beloved longtime companion Rose.

title: Labor Chief Visits to Rally Unions and Hear Workers' Hopes
description: John J. Sweeney, the A.F.L.-C.I.O's president, brought the labor movement's road show to the Big Apple yesterday to hear what was on the minds of New York City's workers -- and they gave him an earful.

title: Viacom Posts a Less-Than-Expected Loss
description: Viacom Inc. lost less money in the fourth quarter than analysts had expected, and the company's results are likely to improve further because of the record-setting success of the film ''Titanic.''

title: When Coaches Conspire to Set a Record; A Shot Against Women's Sports
description: Nykesha Sales is a terrific basketball player and, by all accounts, a terrific person. But that hardly justifies the elaborate rigging that allowed Ms. Sales, the University of Connecticut's injured star forward/guard, to limp down the court to score an uncontested basket during a game on Tuesday with Villanova, thereby breaking her school's scoring record. Some record. It will go down as a two-point shot that set back women's sports. The only record broken was for poor judgment.

title: A Cellist Whose Gifts Blossomed Very Early
description: Alexander Chaushian, barely out of his teens, is a fine cellist, and a worthy first recipient of the Young Concert Artists' Summis Auspiciis Prize, to be given to those ''with highest expectations.'' In his case, though, the expectations are already being met. He has played concertos not only with the Philharmonic of his native Armenia but also with leading orchestras in Europe, and has given recitals at important venues. He arrived at the 92d Street Y on Tuesday evening as a highly accomplished performer, proficient in everything except choosing an accompanist.

title: The Mannerly Mayor
description: It seemed somehow appropriate that Mayor Rudolph Giuliani should choose Ash Wednesday, the beginning of Lent and the days of contrition, to announce his war on bad behavior. As he delivered a keynote address to 150 top officials, his ash-marked forehead surely reinforced his image as the world's oldest altar boy.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Karl Struss

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: The Winter the Cold Forgot; Some Pray for Snow, but Others Feel Spring Fever
description: While El Nino, the weather-warping pool of warm Pacific Ocean waters, has wrought havoc from California to Florida, the capricious condition, coupled with a straying jet stream, has essentially erased winter in and around New York City.

title: Rare Look at Kirov Legacy, From the Classroom to the Stage
description: The United States debut of 65 pupils from the Vaganova Ballet Academy, accompanied by several stars of the Kirov Ballet in St. Petersburg, Russia, is a historic event.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Safety; 3 Issues Test Resolve Of Federal Regulators
description: THE Federal Government faces three significant car safety issues, but the Transportation Department has neatly sidestepped one, on air bags, stilling a public outcry about their occasional dangers without disabling many bags. On another, drunken driving, both houses of Congress may take up debate for the first time on a national standard. But action seems less likely on the third issue, seat belts, which is probably the most important of the three in terms of lives at risk.

title: U.S. Faces Hard Choice as Suharto Balks at Economic Reform
description: The Clinton Administration has concluded that President Suharto of Indonesia has once again sent the effort to rescue his country wildly off track, ignoring most of the commitments he signed six weeks ago with the International Monetary Fund.

title: COLONIAL BANCGROUP AGREES TO BUY A LAS VEGAS BANK
description: Colonial Bancgroup of Alabama agreed yesterday to acquire Commercial Bank of Nevada for about $29.5 million in stock and tap into the rapidly growing Las Vegas market. Colonial, based in Montgomery, Ala., will gain $120.1 million in assets and three branches in the Las Vegas area. Commercial, based in Las Vegas, is a closely held company active in commercial, construction and real estate lending. Colonial is Alabama's fifth-largest bank, with $7.5 billion in assets and 227 branches stretching across four states.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARSON, ARTHUR
description: GARSON-Arthur. Devoted husband of Patricia, loving father of Susan Taylor, Thomas Garson, Kathleen Frank and Arthur Garson, Jr, proud grandfather of Whitney Taylor, Devin Taylor, Tag, Michael, Lauren and Kathleen Garson, Holly Youngwood, and fond great-grandfather of Patric Taylor Moores. Visiting Thursday 5-8PM, memorial service Friday 2:30PM both at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave, NYC. In lieu of flowers, contributions would be appreciated to R.S.V.P.I., 500 5th Avenue, 35 flr, NYC 10110 or to Dystonia Medical Research Foundation, Suite 3B, 162 East 80 Street, New York City 10021.

title: Playful Portraits Conveying Enigmatic Messages
description: There aren't many living American painters whose retrospectives would generate the interest that Chuck Close's show at the Museum of Modern Art has already done. Partly it's because a taste for his work is so easily acquired; never mind that he sticks to the often unloved category of portraiture. After all, who can deny the cool, snappy, absurd allure of those first giant black-and-white paintings, like mug shots on the scale of highway billboards? They turn out to have lost almost none of their shock value after 30 years.

title: BALLARD MEDICAL AGREES TO ACQUIRE TRI-MED SPECIALTIES
description: Ballard Medical Products said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Tri-Med Specialties Inc., a closely held company that makes diagnostic tests for the bacterium that causes stomach ulcers, for $26 million in stock. Ballard Medical, based in Draper, Utah, makes medical products for neurological and vascular surgery. It had sales of $34.1 million for the quarter ended Dec. 31. Tri-Med, based in Lenexa, Kan., makes products that help diagnose the peptic ulcer bacterium, helicobacter pylori.

title: When Love Is Blind At First Sight
description: Watching David Schwimmer play the bad boy, fabulously, is a lot of fun. As Max Abbitt, a sportscaster who uses his minor celebrity to pick up women, Mr. Schwimmer is the kind of self-satisfied dumb guy who chews cocktail straws with a smile, who thinks Australia is in Europe, who defines marriage and children as the first two steps toward death. Max should be despicable, but Mr. Schwimmer's boyish lovability (his Ross-ness, as fans of ''Friends,'' the NBC sitcom he stars in, might say) shines through.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about Secretary General Kofi Annan's briefing to the United Nations Security Council on his agreement with Iraq misstated a word in a remark to reporters by Britain's chief representative, Sir John Weston. He said ''the professional integrity of the inspection process remains intact.'' He did not refer to ''political'' integrity.

title: Defense Rests In Royster Trial
description: The defense in the trial of John J. Royster rested its case yesterday after a psychiatrist testified that the defendant felt he was watching himself from a distance when he battered four women during a series of attacks in the summer of 1996.

title: Witness to the Atrocity Behind the Medicine
description: EVERY atrocity spits out a few, the ones who make it through and cannot forget, who are oppressed with the need to bear witness. Close your eyes and Harry Wu, the human rights advocate, might be Elie Wiesel. Just a few details of time and geography are different.

title: Financial Chief Is Leaving New York Times Co.
description: The New York Times Company said yesterday that Diane P. Baker, a senior vice president and chief financial officer since September 1995, had resigned, effective March 31. John M. O'Brien, senior vice president for operations, was appointed acting chief financial officer while the company searches for a permanent replacement.

title: Three Assists by Gretzky Boost Muckler's Debut
description: You can talk about theories until you're blue in the face, but the Rangers understand the most fundamental principle of hockey: when he is on, Wayne Gretzky is still the best system in the game.

title: Respect Wish of Unknown Soldier's Family
description: To the Editor:

title: Swiss Confirm New Fiasco By Agents For Israel
description: The Swiss authorities today confirmed reports that five agents of the Israeli Mossad were caught last week trying to bug a house in Bern, the Swiss capital, and that one of them was in detention.

title: James Bond vs. Saddam Hussein
description: There is a seductive quality to covert spy operations. Turn over millions of dollars to the Central Intelligence Agency, the theory goes, and let it use the black arts of sabotage and subversion to accomplish what diplomats and generals cannot. Washington is now enthralled by the idea that James Bond methods can remove Saddam Hussein from power. Unfortunately, the notion is a fantasy and a poor substitute for the hard work of dealing with the threats presented by Iraq.

title: Doubt Cast on Alibi Offered in Defense of Former Top Sergeant
description: In what could be a turning point in the court-martial of Sgt. Maj. Gene C. McKinney, the cross-examination of an employee of an auto repair shop left the impression today that the sergeant major had doctored evidence for an alibi that was not offered in pre-trial hearings last year.

title: 55 Suffolk County Officers Accused of Lying About Qualifications on Exams
description: Fifty-five Suffolk County police officers, many hired almost a decade ago, will face dismissal for lying about their qualifications on entrance examinations, the county's Police Commissioner said today.

title: In the stratosphere of Lucent Technologies stock, how high is too high? What is fair market value?
description: IN the telecommunications-equipment industry, as in many others, biggest is often best. But telecommunications investors looking for quick profit may not want to apply that maxim just now.

title: Catalogue Retailer Urges 'No' to Takeover Bid
description: Argos P.L.C., reporting a 7 percent fall in 1997 profit, reiterated yesterday that shareholders should reject as ''inadequate'' a $:1.6 billion ($2.6 billion) takeover bid by Great Universal Stores P.L.C. Argos, a catalogue retailer, said net income in the year that ended on Dec. 27 fell to $:86.9 million ($139 million), from $:93.96 million. (Bloomberg News)

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Korean Pitcher Shows Mets His Stuff
description: Jae Weong Seo was beginning to feel a little bit left out.

title: Metro Business; Queens Site for CompUSA
description: CompUSA, the computer products chain, said it would open one of its largest stores in October in a newly constructed addition to Lefrak Center in Rego Park, Queens. The company said the store, with 41,000 square feet of retail space, would be about 50 percent larger than the average in its chain, which operates 146 stores across the nation.

title: Nets Get The Breaks And Then The Victory
description: John Calipari was yelling himself hoarse, begging the Nets to somehow pull out a victory tonight, when Jayson Williams walked slowly toward his coach from midcourt. Calmly, like an emergency room doctor, Williams said to Calipari, ''We'll be all right.''

title: People
description: -- Amy L. Andrews was named sales development director at People magazine, New York, published by the Time Inc. unit of Time Warner Inc., succeeding Gina G. Giambalvo, who became marketing director at a sibling publication, Teen People. Ms. Andrews had been executive vice president at Zenith Media Services, New York, jointly owned by Cordiant Communications Group P.L.C. and Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C.

title: Getting Ready for 'Next Time' in Iraq
description: The apparent resolution of the standoff between Iraq and the United States is an occasion for neither celebration, as some in the Clinton Administration suggest, nor recrimination, as some of the Administration's critics would have us believe. It is, rather, a sobering reminder of the need to prepare now for the next -- and, in my opinion, inevitable -- confrontation with Saddam Hussein.

title: Bond Mutual Funds Attracting Increasing Number of Investors
description: The pace of new cash going into stock mutual funds is slowing from last year's record pace, and bond funds are attracting increasing numbers of new investors, fund companies reported yesterday.

title: Louima Voices a Measure of Defiance
description: His voice was barely audible and his hands shook as they clutched a statement, but as Abner Louima faced a throng of journalists in his lawyer's office yesterday in TriBeCa, his message was defiant.

title: A CLINTON ADVISER DETAILS TESTIMONY
description: After a long career as a scribbler in the shadows, Sidney Blumenthal got his moment in the sun today, as he emerged smiling from the Federal courthouse to tell about his two-hour questioning before the grand jury investigating the relationship between Monica S. Lewinsky and President Clinton.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARRELL, RUSSELL
description: CARRELL-Russell. Of Salisbury Ct. Russell brought life and vitality into the world of antiques. A Russell Carrell Show guaranteed both the collector and the antiques dealer that this was an event of high standards. His shows had a ''special'' look and feel. For over four decades, he was a friend of, and a mentor to, so many. Possessed with a delicious sense of humor, he made those years the best of all possible times. Thanks Russell, for the wonderful memories.

title: Quartey to Meet Whitaker for Title
description: It took 18 months of negotiation to pull it off, but Ike Quartey, the World Boxing Association welterweight champion, will finally meet Pernell Whitaker in a 12-round championship bout on April 25 at the Thomas and Mack Center in Las Vegas, Nev. The bout will be televised as part of HBO's Championship Boxing series.

title: CRESCENT REAL ESTATE BUYS WASHINGTON OFFICE BUILDING
description: Crescent Real Estate Equities Inc., headed by the billionaire financier Richard Rainwater, said Wednesday night that it had bought the Washington Harbour office building in Washington for $161 million. The purchase of the building, in Georgetown, is Crescent's first in Washington. The property was sold by a Japanese financial institution that Crescent did not name. Washington Harbour is 95 percent occupied by a number of prominent law firms, shops and restaurants. Crescent, based in Fort Worth, is one of the country's biggest and fastest-growing real estate investment trusts.

title: $1 Billion Price Tag For Preservation Effort
description: A state panel said yesterday that New Jersey needs to spend about $1 billion over the next 10 years to preserve 1 million acres of open space and farmland.

title: As Bill Died, Lawmakers Turned To Other Business: Raising Funds
description: By day, lawmakers spent most of this week debating legislation that would have significantly curbed campaign spending. By night, they chased ever more campaign money, not pausing to mourn the failure of another effort to overhaul the nation's campaign finance system.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOULD, ROBERT EMERY, M.D.
description: GOULD-Robert Emery, M.D. February 25, 1998. Psychiatrist and psychoanalyst, teacher and activist. Loving husband of Lois and father of Anthony and Roger. Memorial service on Sunday, March 1, 5 PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARL, ANN
description: PARL-Ann. On February 25, 1998. A resident of Bayside, N.Y. for many years. Beloved wife of Charles V. Loving mother of Charlie and Jack. You will live in our hearts forever. We will miss you greatly. Services Monday, March 2, 11AM, Charles P. Nagel Funeral, 352 East 87 Street, New York City.

title: Oil Service Companies Surge; Dow Hits 8th Recent High
description: The stocks of oil service companies surged yesterday in the wake of the Halliburton Company's agreement to acquire Dresser Industries for $7.7 billion in stock. Some industry analysts said they believed that the agreement could lead to a stampede among other companies to find partners.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: On a gray winter day, there's nothing like lunch at the Judson Grill to lift your spirits. The energy in that big, handsome room is so electric that you feel you are in the very heart of Manhattan.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Sending Up The Groves (Uh, Jungle) Of Academe
description: With anthropology as its springboard, ''Krippendorf's Tribe'' vaults into the groves of academe in search of comedy and romance and, improbably, manages to come up with a fair share of both.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Marina Rosenfeld

title: Milken Settles S.E.C. Complaint for $47 Million
description: Michael R. Milken, the financier who used a huge junk bond empire in the 1980's to make or break a swath of big American companies, agreed yesterday to pay $47 million to settle a Securities and Exchange Commission complaint that he had violated a 1991 order barring him from the securities industry for life.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOBEL, WILHELMINA Y.
description: SOBEL-Wilhelmina Y. Aged 72. Died February 24 in Westport, Connecticut. Wife of the late William Sobel. Travel Executive. Memorial Service Saugatuck Congregational Church, Westport, Connecticut, Saturday Feb 28, 12 Noon.

title: Covering Infertility Won't Hurt the Uninsured
description: To the Editor:

title: Getting a Rare Look At a Russian Legacy
description: Sixty-five pupils from the Vaganova Ballet Academy, accompanied by several stars of the Kirov Ballet in St. Petersburg, made their United States debut at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Wednesday night.

title: Penney and Gap Post Increases in Earnings
description: Two big retailers -- the J. C. Penney Company and Gap Inc. -- reported increases in earnings yesterday for the fiscal fourth quarter. Penney's results were above analysts' expectations, while Gap's were generally in line with estimates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABELSON, EVELYN F.
description: ABELSON-Evelyn F. On Feb. 25, 1998. Mother of Lauren Clements, Richard G. Abelson and Joanne Abelson. Grandmother of Becky Haglund, Larry Clements and Corey and Nicholas Abelson-Goelz. Donations to Adopt A Dog, Lake Avenue, Greenwich, CT.

title: A PATTERN OF MISCONDUCT: A special report.; The Violent Life of Tito Wooten
description: The proceeding in Hasbrouck Heights Municipal Court last Dec. 17 lasted mere minutes. Tito Wooten, a star defensive back for the New York Giants, was facing charges that he had choked, beaten and bloodied his girlfriend, Akina Wilson. Wilson, who had told the police that she was pregnant when the Dec. 7 incident occurred in a New Jersey hotel room, appeared in the courtroom alongside Wooten.

title: A Musical Tour of Architecture as an Ode to Fertility
description: If any film could be described as an architectural symphony, it is Hiroshi Teshigahara's 1984 movie, ''Antonio Gaudi.'' The film, which begins a one-week engagement today at the Walter Reade Theater, takes a sweeping look at the revolutionary Spanish Art Nouveau architect's work, which is centered in Barcelona. Using few spoken words and relying mostly on sketchy biographical subtitles to tell Gaudi's story, the film is a visual rhapsody enhanced with music and sound effects created by the renowned Japanese film composer Toru Takemitsu and two collaborators.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLECHER, MARION (NEE GOOLNICK)
description: BLECHER-Marion (nee Goolnick), of Forest Hills. Beloved wife of Benjamin; devoted mother of Ellen Lazer; dear mother-in-law of Robert; loving grandmother of Adam and Stephen. Graveside service on Friday, February 27, at 11 A.M., in Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. Contributions may be made to The Juvenile Arthritis Foundation, Atlanta, Georgia.

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Palestinian Census Dwarfs Old Tally; So Who's Right?
description: Results of the first Palestinian census were announced today, showing 2.9 million Palestinians in the West Bank, Gaza Strip and East Jerusalem.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: 'Roots and Reeds'

title: U.N. Leader Rebuts Critics Of His Pact With Baghdad
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan moved quickly today to rebut criticism from Congress and elsewhere that he knuckled under to Saddam Hussein by creating a special arrangement for inspecting the eight presidential complexes that the Iraqis hitherto put off limits.

title: G.O.P. Bill Proposes Check On Whether Voter Is a Citizen
description: Saying they are rankled by their inability to detect and stamp out voter fraud, Republican House leaders plan to push legislation next month that would toughen voter registration by requiring some sort of check on a person's citizenship.

title: Landeta Becomes The Packers' Punter
description: The Green Bay Packers have signed the veteran punter Sean Landeta, the ormer Giant who spent last season with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers. Landeta, 36, replaces Craig Hentrich, who signed last week with the Tennessee Oilers.

title: Yanks Consider Taking Cordero
description: The Yankees are exploring the possibility of signing Wil Cordero, the former Boston infielder and outfielder, who was released by the Red Sox after an incident involving domestic battery last summer.

title: Making Public Sculpture: How a Vision Finds Form
description: Much public sculpture is so dull that it poses the question why it was done, not how. But in the current show ''Stages of Creation: Public Sculpture by National Academicians,'' the National Academy Museum dispenses with such judgments. Presenting work by 33 Academy members, in the form of three-dimensional models and studies as well as photographs and drawings, the show is an uncritical report on the process of making public art, from initial commission to final installation.

title: PFIZER CONSIDERS SALE OR SPINOFF OF TECHNOLOGY GROUP
description: Pfizer Inc. said yesterday that it might sell or spin off its medical technology group as it focuses on its more profitable drug business. Pfizer, which is based in New York, sells the cholesterol drug Lipitor and the antibiotic Trovan. It said it was reviewing ''strategic options'' for the medical technology group after sales lagged behind those of the pharmaceuticals unit. Sales for the technology unit rose 1 percent, to $424 million, in the fourth quarter, while revenue in the drug unit increased 13 percent, to $2.58 billion. Pfizer rose $1.875, to $90.25.

title: Sonia Gandhi, the 'Foreigner,' Startles the Political Pundits
description: After she arrived in India as a bride from her native Italy 30 years ago, Sonia Gandhi extracted what proved to be a vain promise from her husband, Rajiv Gandhi: He vowed he would stick to his life as an airline pilot and never expose himself, his wife or his children to the clamorous, often dangerous world of Indian politics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERRIFIELD, ANNE W.
description: MERRIFIELD-Anne W. Age 96, formerly of Maplewood, N.J. died peacefully on February 13, 1998 in Peterborough, New Hampshire. Survivors include three sons, Peter S., Eric S., David C., their four children and six great grandchildren. Also surviving is her brother John Wortendyke and his family.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Milken Settles Charges, Apparently Ending Case
