title: Schreyer Fights On Amid the Tears
description: Cindy Schreyer played through tears yesterday just hours after learning of her grandfather's death yet matched her best round to take the midway lead at the Australian Ladies Masters in Gold Coast, Australia, at eight-under 136.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGEL, STEWART
description: SIEGEL-Stewart. Senior Technical Editor of Fleet Owner Magazine passed away February 11, 1998. He will be sorely missed by his wife, Leslie (nee Sokolow); his son, Russell and daughter-inlaw Elise; his granddaughter, Erin; his brother, George.

title: Wilson Has a Heart Murmur
description: While the Mets were taking their spring team photo this morning, Paul Wilson was returning from the doctor's office. A routine physical examination earlier in the week detected a heart murmur. Wilson, a 24-year-old right-hander, who was monitored all day, said he had had the murmur for many years. Both he and the Mets' front office said the monitoring was a precautionary measure and that there was nothing to worry about.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAYNER, CHESBROUGH
description: RAYNER-Chesbrough On February 26, 1998. Beloved daughter of Chesbrough Patcevitch. Devoted sister of Minot Amory and his wife Victoria. Service Tuesday, March 3, 11 AM, St. Thomas Church, Fifth Avenue at 53rd St, NYC. In lieu of flower,s contributions may be made in her name to Sloan Kettering, NYC.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARSON, ARTHUR
description: GARSON-Arthur. The Board of Trustees and members of the Oceanbeach Club note with great sadness the death of longtime member, past President and dear friend Arthur Garson. Our condolences go out his wife Patricia and their children Tim, Tom, Susan, and Kathy. Sandy Paskin, President Laurie Lowenstein, Secretary

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBINSON, ISABEL ALEXANDER MACGREGOR BROWNE
description: ROBINSON - Isabel Alexander MacGregor Browne. Sunday, February 22, 1998. She is survived by her husband, Hugh, her daughter, Isabel Browne Driscoll, Corinth, VT; and sons, Belmore Browne, Durham, NH; James Robinson, Kent, CT; and MacGregor Robinson, Norfolk, CT. Isabel had ten grandchildren. Donations in her memory may be sent to the Norfolk Library, Norfolk, CT 06058.

title: MEDITRUST TO SELL NEWLY ISSUED PAIRED SHARES
description: The Meditrust Corporation said yesterday that it would sell up to 8.5 million newly issued paired shares at $32.625 a share to Merrill Lynch & Company's Merrill Lynch International unit and use the proceeds -- as much as $277 million -- to pay down debt. Meditrust, based in Needham Heights, Mass., is a real estate investment trust with interests in more than 500 health care facilities in 37 states. Meditrust said the paired common shares, whose price is subject to adjustment in a year, would initially be nonvoting, but would convert to voting shares upon the completion of its merger agreement with La Quinta Inns Inc. A paired-share structure enables Meditrust to own and operate businesses while sheltering revenue from corporate taxes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIBERT, ORION J. COLONEL, USAF (RET)
description: LIBERT-Orion J. Colonel, USAF (Ret). On February 17 at St. Joseph's Retirement Community, Lauderdale Lakes, Florida. Born in Madison, WI., on April 8, 1901 Col. Libert was a 1928 graduate of Georgetown University's School of Foreign Service. Col. Libert served abroad with the 8th Air Force in London during World War II, and was an International Affairs Officer in the Office of the Secretary of Defense during the Korean War. He was also a Foreign Service Officer with the U.S. Department of State having served in various capacities in Washington, D.C., Santiago, London, Paris, Manila, Montevideo and Bogota. Prior to his retirement in 1962. Col. Libert served as First Secretary for Economic Affairs and Deputy Chief of Mission for the U.S. Embassy in Panama. He is survived by his wife Viola, three sons: Francis G. of Rockville, MD, John C. of Great Falls, VA, and Andre J. of Fairfield, CT; a daughter, Mary T. Simonette of Palmyra, VA; nine grandchildren and two great grandchildren.

title: Grade Inflation Is Often Cover for Bad Teaching; Perverse Obsession
description: To the Editor:

title: American With Cure-All Enlivens Jakarta Crisis
description: President Suharto was desperate. His country's economy was sinking fast, the currency and stock market had plummeted, and food shortages were causing riots. Nothing he tried was working.

title: Obituaries Used to Plan Burglaries, Officials Say
description: Three Bergen County teen-agers are suspected of using obituaries published in a local newspaper to plan the burglaries of at least 10 homes over the last two months, county prosecutors announced yesterday.

title: With Dues Long Paid, Musicians Reap Awards
description: Resplendent in white tie and tails, carrying a bone and a skull, Screamin' Jay Hawkins whooped and growled and hooted his hit from 1956, ''I Put a Spell on You,'' punctuated by a smoke bomb. Then he strolled over to a podium to accept what he said was the first award of his career: the Pioneer Award from the Rhythm-and-Blues Foundation, which held its ninth annual awards ceremony on Thursday night at the Imperial Ballroom of the Sheraton New York.

title: World Court Claims Jurisdiction In Pan Am Flight 103 Case
description: Rejecting arguments by the United States and Britain, the World Court in The Hague ruled today that it had the authority to decide whether Libya must surrender two of its citizens for trial on charges of blowing up a Pan American jumbo jet over Scotland in December 1988.

title: Reopening Recommended For Salem I Reactor
description: Three years after it was closed because of management and equipment problems, the Salem I nuclear reactor is ready to be reopened, a Federal nuclear inspection team said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, HENRIETTA (QUEENIE)
description: KATZ-Henrietta (Queenie), age 95 of Lauderhill, FL, formerly of New York. Beloved wife of the late Hyman (Kitty). Loving mother of Henry (Margaret), Richard (Judy), and Lucy (Ed) Weidman. Adored by eleven grandchildren and fourteen great-grandchildren. Graveside services Sunday, March 1st, Beth Moses Cemetery, Farmingdale, Long Island 11 AM. Friends and family may call at the home of Lucy and Ed Weidman on Sunday, Monday, and Tuesday from 4:00 P.M. to 9:00 P.M.

title: Franco Says Arm Has Years Left in It
description: For the second consecutive spring, John Franco arrived in camp in perhaps the best shape of his life.

title: Mexico Expels French Priest in Latest Move Against Outsiders in Rebel Area
description: The Government has deported a French priest who served for 32 years in an Indian parish in the southern state of Chiapas, turning a campaign against foreigners in the state into a new confrontation with the Catholic Church.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about a debate at a Board of Education meeting on requiring school uniforms, which included a skit by Harlem schoolchildren, misidentified the children's school. It was P.S. 125, not P.S. 129.

title: Is Investigating Lies a Waste of the Court's Time?; Duty to Criticize
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton Looks Elsewhere on Finance Reform
description: A day after efforts to overhaul political campaign financing were defeated in the Senate, President Clinton sought today to achieve changes by administrative means.

title: OCCIDENTAL PETROLEUM TO SELL SOME PROPERTIES
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said yesterday that it would sell some natural gas properties in Oklahoma and Kansas to Oneok Inc. for $135 million to help pay for its purchase of a Federal petroleum reserve. Oneok, based in Tulsa, Okla., said the properties included more than 400 wells. The purchase will nearly double Oneok's oil and gas reserve base. Occidental's oil properties in the two states and holdings in the Hugoton field, which is North America's largest gas field, are not included in the sale. The Los Angeles-based Occidental said earlier that it would sell some properties to help finance its $3.65 billion purchase of the United States Naval Petroleum Reserve at Elk Hills, Calif., and to repurchase up to 40 million shares of stock.

title: Peary's Black Alter Ego, Braving an All-White Vista
description: Comdr. Robert E. Peary's claim that on April 6, 1909, he was the first man to reach the North Pole has long been disputed. Frederick A. Cook said that he had beaten Peary to the pole, getting there on April 21, 1908. And historians in recent years have shown that it's likely both men missed the pole by a couple of hundred miles. One thing that's certain about Peary's pursuit of the North Pole, though, is that on each of the nine expeditions that took him closer to his life-consuming goal, he was accompanied by a black man named Matthew Henson.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WU, WILLIAM IU, LIANG
description: WU-William Iu-Liang, age 85, of Westport, CT., died Wednesday, February 25, 1998 in CT. Survivors include his loving wife, Jeannine; his son, Norman Wu, of Orlinda, CA; his daughter Suzanne WuBliss, of Seattle, WA; four grandchildren; Lori and William Wu, and Michael and Erica Bliss; and two nieces; Linda Wu, and Lorraine Wu-Chen. Funeral services were held privately by his family.

title: A Top Seeding Is at Stake In St. John's-UConn Part 2
description: St. John's will close out its surprising regular season tonight with a game at Connecticut that will determine the top-seeded team in next week's Big East tournament at Madison Square Garden. But in the eyes of Coach Fran Fraschilla of the Red Storm, this game is just the conclusion of what he called the first of three seasons for his team.

title: Stay, Nebraska Begs Brightest, We'll Pay You
description: Brian Knudtson is a convert. At least, people in Nebraska hope so.

title: Sports of The Times; Building Blocks For the Nets
description: THE Nets showed off their new $3 million training facility yesterday on the eve of a weekend home-and-home series with the red-hot Miami Heat. John Calipari was preparing for his showdown with his model, Pat Riley. The facility is the next major step in what the Nets' impetuous coach calls changing the team's culture. Sauna, bright practice courts, lap pool, weight room, pool tables.

title: Dow Closes Above 8,500 As Blue-Chip Issues Rally
description: The stock market continued to rally yesterday, setting yet another record in a year that many Wall Street experts had expected to be a troublesome one.

title: Oxford Tells New Jersey It Will Pull Out of Medicaid
description: Oxford Health Plans, the troubled managed care company, continued its retreat from the region's Medicaid programs yesterday, announcing that it would no longer insure some 44,000 poor people in New Jersey as of July 1.

title: 30-Year Yield Rises Over 6%, But Then Falls
description: Treasury prices rebounded smartly from early losses to end higher yesterday.

title: APPLE COMPUTER TO DISCONTINUE NEWTON LINE
description: Apple Computer Inc. said yesterday that it would stop making Newton software and products so it could focus on its Macintosh operating system. The Newton operating system is used in Apple's Messagepad 2100 and eMate 300 computers. The company plans to sell the remaining Newton-based hand-helds and will begin making Mac OS-based models next year. Apple's decision comes amid increasing competition in the palmtop-computing market from machines that use Microsoft's Windows CE software and computers like 3Com's Palm Pilot that use their own systems. Apple's shares rose 12.5 cents yesterday, to $23.625.

title: Museum Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: WHEAT GAINS. Wheat rose to its highest level in two weeks on expectations of tight supplies and reports that India needed grain. Wheat for March delivery rose 6 cents a bushel, to $3.275, on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIRNBAUM, ZALDIN ETHEL
description: BIRNBAUM-Zaldin Ethel. Devoted wife of the late Stanley. Beloved mother of Alfred and Meg, Marty and Nancy. Dear sister of Seymour and Harriet. Adored grandmother of Stephanie, Michelle, Shane, Samantha and Elizabeth. She will be sorely missed and loved by all. Services Sunday 12:00 noon at Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial, Queens Blvd. and 76th Rd., Forest Hills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAY, FAY SUCHERMAN
description: MAY-Fay Sucherman. Died in Eugene, Oregon, on February 21, 1998, at the age of 88. Formerly of Brooklyn, NY. Beloved wife of the late Irving May. Devoted mother of Sondra May Steinman, of Fairfax, CA, Maurice May, of Needham, MA, and Glenn May, of Eugene, OR. Grandmother of eight and great-grandmother of six. Mrs. May was an accomplished actress and supporter of Jewish causes. Contributions in her memory may be made to the May Scholarship Fund, Hebrew Rehabilitation Center for Aged, 1200 Centre St, Boston, MA 02131

title: Kirov Stars, So Glittery Yet Classical
description: Anastasia Volochkova and Igor Zelensky of the Kirov Ballet are tall and blond. Paired together in the ''Shades'' scene of ''La Bayadere,'' they exude a haughty glamour.

title: Deferring the Hudson River Cleanup
description: The Environmental Protection Agency's decision to delay its final report on PCB contamination of the Hudson River exasperated New Yorkers who have waited 20 years for a plan of action to clean the river of its most dangerous chemical. Environmentalists were especially distressed because the E.P.A., which had lately showed some gumption on the issue, appeared to have caved in to pressure from the General Electric Company, whose factories polluted the river, and from Representative Gerald Solomon of Glens Falls, who runs the House Ways and Means Committee.

title: Talk of British Bid Spurs Credit Lyonnais Stock
description: The shares of Credit Lyonnais soared to a three-year high yesterday amid speculation that the company, once on the verge of bankruptcy, will attract buyers when the French Government puts its majority stake up for sale. The shares of Credit Lyonnais, a French retail bank, closed at 445 francs ($74.16), up 47 francs. The share price has been soaring in recent weeks.

title: Yankees Seeking Answers About Cordero
description: With a background check on Wil Cordero already under way, Brian Cashman, the Yankees' general manager, said today that there were ''important questions'' to be answered about the possible acquisition of a player who received a suspended sentence last summer after being charged with beating and threatening his wife.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, ANNE E.
description: SCHWARTZ-Anne E. Of Sarasota, FL, died Tuesday in Sarasota. Graveside services will be held Sunday the 1st 10:30 AM, at Mt. Pleasant Cemetery, Valhalla, NY.

title: Johnson Hurt; Knicks Could Be Short for Lakers
description: It was him again. Andrew Lang of the Milwaukee Bucks left a mark on yet another Knick when he banged into Larry Johnson's thumb on Thursday and bent it back like a slingshot.

title: Dignifying Work That's Never Done
description: From 1936 to 1940, the Works Progress Administration dispatched staff writers to record Americans' life histories for a Folklore Project begun by the Federal Writers' Project. At its peak, the Writers' Project employed 6,500 men and women at a salary of $20 a week each. The Library of Congress has collected 2,900 of these documents, written by more than 300 writers from 24 states. The histories, which include narratives, dialogues and reports, are on the World Wide Web at http:// lcweb2.loc.gov/wpaintro/wpahome.html.

title: General Tells Rwanda Court Massacre Was Preventable
description: The former commander of United Nations peacekeeping troops in Rwanda said this week that the 1994 massacres that left at least 500,000 people dead could have been stopped if a small, well-armed force had been sent in early with that objective.

title: 3 Charged in Extortion From Airport Contractors
description: Three men with ties to the Gambino and Genovese organized crime families have been charged with extorting nearly $200,000 from contractors who helped build the commuter monorail at Newark International Airport, Federal prosecutors said yesterday.

title: Jaspers Move On By Ignoring Dry Spells
description: Brendan O'Brien, a senior forward for Manhattan College's basketball team, was 0 for 16 in his last two games, but his refusal to dwell on such a dry spell today helped keep the Jaspers alive in the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference tournament.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BAUMAN, LIONEL R.
description: BAUMAN-Lionel R. Beloved partner, friend and colleague. Died Feb 27, 1987. Sorely missed by all. Eugene M. Grant & Company

title: Even Legends Adjust To Time and Trend, Even the Vienna
description: By the time-honored standards and traditions of this orchestra, it almost qualifies as a revolution.

title: Videotape of Baby Abuse Is Admissible, Court Says
description: A clandestine videotape of a baby sitter beating a 5-month-old girl and stuffing a blanket in her mouth can be introduced as evidence in the sitter's assault and child endangerment trial, a state appeals panel ruled yesterday.

title: Is Investigating Lies a Waste of the Court's Time?; Certifying the Truth
description: To the Editor:

title: Palestinian Broadcasts
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Court Sets Veto Arguments

title: Clinton Finance Figure Speaks Out
description: James T. Riady sat nervously in his penthouse office, surrounded by photographs of his friend President Clinton, and started to deny that he had been a spy for China.

title: Union Officials Must Testify in Louima Case
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that three officials of the New York City police officers' union must testify before a Federal grand jury investigating charges that police officers from the 70th Precinct in Brooklyn brutalized two Haitian immigrants last August.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHARD, MARY E.
description: RICHARD-Mary E. The Board of Directors, staff and volunteers of the Theodore Roosevelt Sanctuary, Inc., deeply the mourn the untimely death of our Executive Director, Mary E. Richard. We extend our heartfelt condolences to all the members of her family and to her many friends. Mary's commitment and dedication to the sanctuary and its mission have been and will continue to be an inspiration to us all. Becky Stern, President

title: ARCO Says It Plans to Sell Its Coal Business in the U.S.
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company announced a preliminary agreement yesterday to sell its large coal business in the United States to a unit of Beacon Group, a New York investment firm that would become the second-biggest coal operator in the country with the purchase.

title: Hunter Wins Title and an N.C.A.A. Berth
description: Hunter avenged its only loss of the season, improved its record to 26-1, captured its seventh CUNY tournament title and cruised into the National College Athletic Association Division III tournament last night by routing York, 76-55, at the Cardinals' court in Jamaica, Queens.

title: The Hudson Still Waits for Help
description: What's more important to the Environmental Protection Agency -- pollution or politics? It has been 24 years since the E.P.A. issued a report that found that two General Electric factories had dumped enough PCB's into the Hudson River to set a ''new record for PCB contamination in freshwater fish.'' The agency failed to confront G.E. then, and remains too politically timid to do so today.

title: Allen B. Morgan, 89, Banker in Tennessee
description: Allen B. Morgan, a former chairman and chief executive of First Tennessee Bank, died on Monday at the Allen Morgan Health Center of the Trezevant Manor retirement community in Memphis. He was 89.

title: The Teach and Sell School of Retailing; Shopping as an Educational Experience
description: Upon entering the new Discovery Channel store here, customers will not immediately recognize what's for sale. And that just may be the key to its success.

title: Cambodian Truce Declared, Raising Hopes for New Vote
description: Cambodia's two main rival factions declared a cease-fire today, raising tentative hopes that a peace plan could take root and open the way for competitive elections later this year.

title: Hip Pointer Could Sideline Stevens
description: Devils Coach Jacques Lemaire had urged defenseman Scott Stevens to take the last two games off to rest after the Olympics, but Stevens did not listen. Now he may pay a price. Stevens could miss tonight's game against the visiting Carolina Panthers after sustaining a left hip pointer in a 4-1 victory Thursday night at Tampa Bay.

title: U.S., After 35 Years, Lifts Arms Embargo Against South Africa
description: The United States is lifting a 35-year-old arms embargo imposed against South Africa at the beginning of the apartheid era, Vice President Al Gore said today.

title: Stewart Moves Up on Mayfair
description: While Billy Mayfair maintained his lead through the second round of the Nissan Open today, Payne Stewart maintained the pressure on him.

title: The Theater's on a Roll, Gliding Down 42d Street; Fast-Moving Times Square Revitalization Leaves No Stone or Building Unturned
description: Tomorrow, a theater weighing 7.4 million pounds will be rolled down 42d Street. The engineers who arranged the trip say that it is no big deal.

title: Journal; Mixed Nuts
description: Ken Starr's critics have it all wrong. He is not a partisan zealot acting under orders from the right-wing moneybags Richard Mellon Scaife. He is not an inquisitional bully who takes a sadistic, ''Sophie's Choice'' pleasure in pitting Lewinsky mother against child. He is not the most fanatical foe of the First Amendment since Joe McCarthy.

title: Rising Star Finds a Squeeze To Make a Difficult Game
description: The New York metropolitan area has a talented group of players in their 20's who have the potential to reach the top levels of the game, but only one is a woman. She is Elizabeth Reich of Manhattan, who was a member of the winning Reisinger Knockout Championship Team in Manhattan last year.

title: Asia and the Dollar
description: To the Editor:

title: Is Investigating Lies a Waste of the Court's Time?; The Clergy's Silence
description: To the Editor:

title: Dance Program Put Off
description: A performance by the Arthur Aviles dance group scheduled for today at the Edge Theater in the Bronx has been postponed until March 7.

title: Practice a la Muckler: No Ranger Breathers the Next Day
description: Hours after they returned from Toronto following an inspired 5-2 victory, the Rangers discovered today that things have already changed under their new coach, John Muckler.

title: EUROPEANS CLEAR REMAINING HURDLE TO CURRENCY UNITY
description: Countries across Europe cleared a crucial hurdle today for introducing a single currency, providing concrete evidence that they have yoked themselves to a common economic policy of slashing budget deficits and suppressing inflation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADELMAN, MILTON H., M.D.
description: ADELMAN-Milton H., M.D. The faculty and staff of the Department of Anesthesiology of New York University Medical Center and the entire community of the New York University School of Medicine wish to express our profound sorrow on the passing of our esteemed colleague, Milton H. Adelman, on February 26, 1998. Dr. Adelman had been a faculty member and a Clinical Professor of Anesthesiology in the Department of Anesthesiology at NYU School of Medicine since 1991. Upon earning his B.S. from New York University in 1931 and his M.D. from the University of Maryland, Dr. Adelman began his professional career at the Hospital for Joint Diseases where he spent from 1941 to 1946 as an Associate Anesthesiologist. In 1942 he was appointed an Assistant Attendant Anesthesiologist at the Mount Sinai Hospital, where he remained for most of his career. Dr. Adelman was a member of several prestigious professional organizations, including The American Society of Anesthesiologists and the New York State Society of Anesthesiologists, and a Fellow of both the American College of Anesthesiologists and New York Academy of Medicine. Noel L. Cohen, M.D. Interim Dean Herman Turndorf, M.D., Chairman Department of Anesthesiology NYU School of Medicine

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRODY, NATHAN
description: BRODY-Nathan. Beloved husband of Estelle, devoted father of Dr. Gordon Brody, devoted fatherin-law of Celeste Brody, dear brother of Sonya Wichard, loving grandfather of Emily and Hanna. Services ''Wien & Wien'', Sunday, 10:30 AM. For info 1-800-322-0533.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOULD, ROBERT, MD
description: GOULD-Robert, MD. The faculty and staff of the department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Science at New York Medical College note with sadness the passing of Dr. Robert Gould, our friend and esteemed colleague. Dr Gould was an exemplary teacher in the medical school and a respected clinician at Metropolitan Hospital Center. Dr. Gould held dual appointments as Clinical Professor in Psychiatry and Obstetrics and Gynecology. His many students and colleagues will miss him.

title: Humphries Quits the N.F.L. After Series of Concussions
description: Stan Humphries was driving through his neighborhood two weeks ago when the headache hit. He grabbed his ear and pulled over in pain. He and his wife, Connie, sat in the car for 10 minutes until the throbbing ended.

title: UConn Women Not a Tourney Lock
description: For years, Big East women's basketball supremacy has been the private preserve of Connecticut. The Huskies have won the conference's last five regular-season titles and its last four championship tournaments. Over the last five seasons, their Big East regular-season records have been 17-1, 18-0, 17-1, 18-0 and 17-1.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Proposed Euro Currency Overcomes Crucial Hurdle

title: Colombian Peasants Seek Way Out of Drug Trade
description: At first, nothing could have been easier for these struggling rural hamlets than getting into the drug business. Up and down the Valle del Cauca these scattered villages climbed on the coca bandwagon early, enjoying a five-year joyride that is still referred to here to as La Bonanza.

title: Safir Is Said to Seek to Punish A Chief Over False Crime Data
description: Police Commissioner Howard Safir is pressuring the chief of the department's Transportation Bureau to retire or be demoted because of a series of embarrassing revelations that the Police Department purposely underreported subway crime, law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: National News Briefs; Gingrich Sees Surplus In the Budget This Year
description: Speaker Newt Gingrich said today that the Government would run a budget surplus this year for the first time since 1969 as tax receipts surged.

title: Aetna Is Said To Seek Deal In Health Care
description: Aetna Inc., one of the nation's largest health insurers, is in discussions to buy the health care subsidiary of the New York Life Insurance Company in a deal that would be valued at about $1 billion.

title: A Sense of Place; Milwaukee Feels at Home in the N.L., Even if Its Team Doesn't
description: Is it better to be a National League team in the American League, or a National League team in the National League?

title: Jordan Gets a Summons from Grand Jury
description: Vernon E. Jordan Jr., President Clinton's close friend and unofficial adviser, has been summoned to appear on Tuesday before the grand jury investigating the relationship between the President and a former White House intern, Monica S. Lewinsky, lawyers involved in the case said today.

title: Grade Inflation Is Often Cover for Bad Teaching; Faculty Is Powerless
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHIENBERG, BARNEY
description: SCHIENBERG - Barney. Loving and devoted husband of Charlotte; father of Mark and Paul; daughter-in-law, Candida, brother of Kate, Joe, Abe and Harry, mourn his passing on February 25, 1998 while vacationing in Sarasota, FL. Barney was a caring relative and steadfast friend and will be remembered by all. As a salesman and importer of women's accessories over many decades, he built a successful career expanding and running the New York subsidiary of a Swiss importing company and retired as its Executive Vice President in 1986. After retirement, he was a consultant to a Taiwanese manufacturer for 10 years. Barney was a veteran of the Army Air Force in World War II serving in Africa and Europe. He touched life and all who knew him and has left an everlasting impact on all our lives. Funeral Service, Sunday March 1, 11 A.M., at Gutterman's Funeral Home (Riverside Building), Amsterdam Avenue and 76th Street in Manhattan. Following Services he will be laid to rest in Beth El Cemetery in Paramus, NJ.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZELVIN, SADIE KAPLAN
description: ZELVIN-Sadie Kaplan. Beloved wife of the late Arnold, February 26, in Cherry Hill, NJ. She will be remembered lovingly by sister Fay Smolin, children Eleanor Scheiner, Joseph and Norman Zelvin. Grandchildren Leslie Jaffe, Roberta Hall, Lynn Zelvin, Michael Zelvin, Diana Harris, Alexander Zelvin; great grandchildren Andrew and Jennifer Jaffe, Arielle and Jeremy Hall. Services at The Riverside Mount Vernon, New York, Sunday, March 1, at noon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NASON, HENRY
description: NASON-Henry, 73. Of Wilmington, DE. Formerly of Rochester, N.Y., and NYC, died February 5 after a long illness. Survivors include sons, Neville of Redwood City, CA and Andrew of Wilmington, DE and daughter Fonda of Kew Gardens, NY. Memorial service Saturday, March 7 at 4:00 PM, Second Presbyterian Church, 6 West 96 St., NYC. Burial will be private. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Delaware Hospice, 100 Clayton Building, 3515 Silverside Road, Wilmington, DE. 19810.

title: Grade Inflation Is Often Cover for Bad Teaching
description: To the Editor:

title: About New York; Bronx Booster Can Now Use A Push, Too
description: DAVID MUCHNICK glided into his hospital room in his wheelchair and glanced at the window. ''Is it warm out there?'' he asked. ''I hear it's been crazy out there. I haven't been out since before Thanksgiving. I'm not happy I missed the most summery winter in years.''

title: Tunnel Work To Cut Service On 2 Subways
description: Commuting by subway can be a trying experience under normal circumstances. But beginning Monday, things will get even tougher for some of the estimated 200,000 commuters who take the Nos. 2 and 3 trains.

title: Foreign Affairs; Iraq Of Ages
description: Saddam Hussein is a recurring figure in Middle East history -- the local despot who upsets the regional order by being too rapacious at home and abroad. But while you can't understand what's happening in this Iraq crisis without reference to some of the region's oldest political patterns, you also can't understand it without reference to some more modern political trends -- namely U.S. hegemony after the cold war and globalization.

title: Palestinian Broadcasts
description: To the Editor:

title: New Start for Bond And the N.A.A.C.P.
description: Back in the 1960's the young Julian Bond was seen as the civil rights leader most likely to take up the mantle of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. He never did. Now Mr. Bond has chosen to re-enter the limelight as chairman of the N.A.A.C.P. The job offers a new chance for both Mr. Bond and a troubled organization.

title: Is Investigating Lies a Waste of the Court's Time?; Obstruction of Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: The 2-Point Turmoil
description: It was bound to come to this. The deepest fears surrounding the entry of women into what formerly were men's games lie in the question of whether women will change the game.

title: United News Sells Northern England Papers
description: United News and Media P.L.C. said yesterday that it had sold its United Provincial Newspapers, based in northern England, for $:360 million ($592.4 million) to a group led by the venture capital company Candover Investments. The London-based company also agreed to sell its Spanish advertising periodicals business, UPN Espana, for $:42.75 million ($70.3 million) to the Cendant Corporation, a Connecticut-based real estate and car-rental company.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Secretary General Kofi Annan's agreement with Iraq referred imprecisely to the relative ranks of Richard Butler, chairman of the Special Commission charged by the Security Council with carrying out weapons inspections in Iraq, and the Under Secretary General for Disarmament Affairs, Jayantha Dhanapala, who will oversee the work of a new group created within the Special Commission to inspect the eight presidential sites put off-limits by Iraq. Both hold the rank of Under Secretary; Mr. Dhanapala does not outrank Mr. Butler.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, SIDNEY M.
description: MILLER-Sidney M. The employee of L.V. Myles Inc. express their sincere sorrow at the passing of our beloved chairman. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Barbara, his sons, Paul, Bruce, Eric and Adam, his daughter-in-laws, Debby, Sharon, Cheryl, and June, and his grandchildren, Luke, Max, Hannah and A.J.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: DOMINION RESOURCES INC., Richmond, a utility company, acquired Unicom Corp.'s power plant in Kincaid, Ill., for $186 million in cash.

title: Suspect Killed in Brooklyn Drug Shootout
description: A police sergeant leading an undercover buy-and-bust operation was wounded and a drug suspect was killed in a burst of gunfire early yesterday as they wrestled in a notorious crack house in Brooklyn. The police said the sergeant, who was saved by his bulletproof vest, may have been shot by backup officers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, EDWARD
description: LEWIS-Edward. The passing of Ed Lewis is noted with sorrow. A longtime associate, good friend and able consultant in the real estate field. He will surely be missed. With deep sympathy, Sarah Korein

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMEIER, HARRIET
description: GOLDMEIER-Harriet. Beloved wife of Larry, adoring mother of Allen (Cheryl), Sharon (Ted), Steven (Debbie). Loving grandmother of David, Lindsey, Jason, Julie, Lori, Alex and caring sister Rita. Harriet in her short life touched so many people with her love, wisdom and innate beauty. She redefined the meaning of the word ''family'', which was her sole underlining purpose in life. She lived to the fullest. Donations may be made to the North Shore Hospital Pulmonary Research Fund or American Lung Association. Funeral services Sunday 12 noon at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York. Interment Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR RETREATS AGAIN. The dollar fell a second day on reports that Japan was planning $159 billion in tax cuts and public works spending to stimulate the economy. In New York, the dollar fell to 126.10 yen from 127.18.

title: Some Rain, Some Rust In Yanks' Spring Opener
description: George Steinbrenner departed Legends Field today appearing somewhat exasperated, and there could be no surer sign of the change in seasons. Steinbrenner detests losing, and the Yankees lost their first exhibition game to Detroit, 8-5. The summer game has officially entered its spring season again.

title: SmithKline Stock Rises on Talk of a Bid
description: The shares of SmithKline Beecham P.L.C. jumped briefly in London today after it was reported in British newspapers that Glaxo Wellcome P.L.C. might make a hostile bid for SmithKline after merger talks failed this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELIAS, SYLVAN
description: ELIAS-Sylvan, on Feb. 25, 1998. Adored husband of Sylvia (Fidler). Cherished father of Roberta Krinick and Felice Miller and fatherin-law of Howard Krinick and Jordan Miller. Devoted grandfather to Nancy, Michael, Pamela, Amy, Ari, Gina and great-grandfather to Eric. Loving brother of Ruth Goldstein. Services on Sunday, 12:15, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a Critic's Notebook article in Weekend yesterday about new Broadway cast albums included an incorrect reference to the composer Andrew Lloyd Webber. He was not involved in the musical ''Les Miserables.'' Its music was written by Claude-Michel Schonberg. The article also omitted one of the ''Jekyll and Hyde'' recordings that are available. The one-CD original Broadway cast album is on Atlantic Records.

title: Religion Journal; A Visit From a Cardinal (Maybe a Future Pope?)
description: At some point in a Pope's rule, talk may turn to the question of who might succeed him as head of the Roman Catholic Church. The longer a pontificate, the greater the chance for speculation, worth noting when one considers that Pope John Paul II -- still vigorous and traveling the world -- has reigned since 1978, longer than all but 12 of his 261 predecessors.

title: Fresh Vision for an Intellectual Journal: Diversity, Brevity, Even a Cover Picture
description: When Anne Fadiman was a teen-ager in the late 1960's, she and her family would gather around the television set every Sunday afternoon for ''General Electric College Bowl.'' Using the arm of a lounge chair as a make-believe buzzer, they would test their knowledge of history, literature, politics, science and sports against the nation's elite college students. The competition was usually no match; Fadiman U., as they called themselves, lost only twice in nearly six years.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about the swearing in of Valdas Adamkus, the President of Lithuania, referred imprecisely to the role of his predecessor, Algirdas Brazaukas, in breaking with Moscow. The President when independence was declared, on March 11, 1990, was Vytautas Landsbergis, though Mr. Brazaukas was active in the independence movement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PENDY, GARY M.
description: PENDY-Gary M. Senior VicePresident of Credit Lyonnaise Securities in New York City, of Morristown, NJ, on Thursday, February 26, 1998. Husband of Joan. Father of Michael and Gregory. Son of Evelyn. Brother of Bruce and Sherry Wrucke. Survived by three nieces and one nephew. Funeral Mass on Monday, March 2, 1998 at the Church of Christ the King, Blue Mill Road, New Vernon, NJ at 10:30AM. Interment, Holy Rood Cemetery. Visition at the Doyle Funeral Home, 106 Maple Ave, Morristown on Sunday 2-4 and 79PM. In lieu of flowers, donations in Gary's memory to St. John's University c/o the Hockey Program, PO Box 7222, Collegeville, MN 56321

title: Gresser May Be Replaced On the Board of Education
description: The Queens Borough President is moving to replace Carol A. Gresser, the longtime New York City Board of Education member who has clashed with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani over his choice for schools chancellor and over school security, according to advisers who have been consulted about possible replacements.

title: She Can Read Minds, Too
description: An American success story, built on a pile of corpses, a lot of fuzzy philosophy and plenty of luck attributable to bad aim, convoluted plotting and over-the-top motivation, reaches a satisfying but far-fetched conclusion in ''Caught Up.''

title: It's No Joke: The Nets Are Ready for a Big Series
description: Keith Van Horn strained to keep a straight face, putting on a most earnest expression when he was asked about the Miami Heat. ''I don't know anything about Miami,'' Van Horn said. ''We haven't talked about them at all.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROFMAN, HENRY
description: BROFMAN-Henry. February 26, 1998. Beloved husband of Pearl for 64 years. Devoted father of Dr. Jerelyn Brofman and Faith Block. Loving grandfather of Debra Sue Goldberg and Heidi Levine, and great-grandfather of Barry Leonard Goldberg. Donations in his memory can be made to the Diabetes Association. Services Sunday 12:30 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amerstam Avenue.

title: Russell Carrell, Winter Antiques Impresario, 81
description: Russell Carrell, a manager of charity antiques shows across the country for three decades, most notably the Winter Antiques Show at the Seventh Regiment Armory on Manhattan's East Side, died on Feb. 19 at the J.F.K. Medical Center in Lake Worth, Fla., after an emergency airlift from his Caribbean winter home on St. Kitts. He was 81 and also had a home in Salisbury, Conn.

title: Trial to Begin for Man Charged in L.I. Beating
description: With a jury selected, opening arguments were scheduled for Monday in the trial of Austin Offen, who is charged with the near-fatal beating of a Long Island man with a steel bar nearly two years ago while an off-duty New York City policeman allegedly held the victim's friends at bay with a gun.

title: Hoechst Had Profit In Last Quarter of '97
description: Hoechst A.G., Germany's largest maker of chemicals and pharmaceutical products, said yesterday that it swung to a fourth-quarter profit as it spent less money on revamping measures like plant shutdowns and job cuts. Hoechst said fourth-quarter profit was 154 million marks ($85 million), in contrast to a loss of 336 million marks a year earlier. Full-year net income fell 36 percent, to 1.343 billion marks ($741 million) from 2.114 billion marks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLIFFORD, KATHERINE CORBETT
description: CLIFFORD-Katherine Corbett, of New York and Montclair, N.J., on February 21. Wife of the late Paul Clifford. Loving mother of Denis, Joanne, Steven, Gregory, Douglas, Justin and Catherine. She also leaves seven grandchildren. Memorial service on Saturday, March 7th, at 11 o'clock A.M., at Saint Cassian's Roman Catholic Church, Montclair, New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEALON, THOMAS F., M.D.
description: NEALON-Thomas F., M.D. The Board of Trustees, Sisters of Charity, Auxiliary, Medical Staff & Administration of Saint Vincents Hospital and Medical Center note with sadness the passing of our esteemed friend and colleague. A member of the Saint Vincent's staff since 1968, Dr. Nealon formerly served as Chairman of the Department of Surgery at the Medical Center for more than twenty years. He held several academic appointments including Professor of Surgery at New York University School of Medicine and New York Medical College. Affiliated with many professional organizations, Dr. Nealon served on the Board of Governors of the American College of Surgeons, was a former President of the New York Cancer Society, former president of the New York Surgical Society, as well as an active member of the very prestigious American Surgical Society. Dr. Nealon took great pride in his close affiliation with the Sisters of Charity and Saint Vincents Hospital, as well as his tremendous dedication to surgical residency training. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Kay, and their children. Thomas A. Coleman Chairman of the Board Karl P. Adler, M.D. President and CEO Saint Vincents Hospital and Medical Center

title: Jones Fund Is Not for Lawyers, Group Underwriting Suit Says
description: The institute underwriting Paula Corbin Jones's sexual misconduct lawsuit against President Clinton said today that another legal defense fund controlled by Ms. Jones herself had not been earmarking its donations for her lawyers.

title: Hamed and McKinney Have a Deal, for Now
description: The on-again, off-again match between Prince Naseem Hamed, the World Boxing Organization featherweight champion, and Kennedy McKinney is on again. Negotiations for the bout, scheduled for April 18 in Manchester, England, have been running hot and cold for the last month, but McKinney has apparently decided that he does not mind fighting Hamed in Hamed's backyard for less money than he was seeking.

title: Charter Schools Gaining Support
description: As one of his key proposals for improving public education last year, Gov. George E. Pataki championed parent-run schools with freedom from many state rules and practices only to see the proposal blocked largely by his Democratic rivals in the Legislature amid opposition from school administrators and the powerful teachers' union.

title: Sanwa Bank Investing In Yamaichi Trust Unit
description: Sanwa Bank said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire 18.6 percent of the shares outstanding in the Yamaichi Investment Trust Management Company, bringing its total stake to 20.7 percent. Sanwa, which is based in Osaka, is one of the biggest commercial banks in Japan.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETERS, DAVID B., MD
description: PETERS-David B., MD, at 94. Longtime resident and physician of Brooklyn. Loving husband of Laura. Devoted father of Antony and Adrian, Michael and Barbara, Holly and Marc. Adored grandfather of Mark and Joan, Scott, Bradley and Kimberly, Amy and Robert, Elyssa, Rebecca, Jenna. Dear great grandfather of Emma Hope. Services will be on Sunday at 1 P.M., at the ''Dix Hills Chapel'' of I.J. Morris. Interment to follow at the Beth El Cemetery, Paramus, New Jersey.

title: Certifiably Wrong on Mexico
description: The Clinton Administration does no favor to Mexico or its own credibility by certifying that Mexico is ''fully cooperating'' in the fight against drug trafficking. Compounding the damage, the White House Drug Policy Director, Barry McCaffrey, fatuously claims that Mexican cooperation is ''absolutely superlative.''

title: Toward Justice in the Louima Case
description: Nearly seven months after the brutal torture of a Haitian immigrant named Abner Louima in a bathroom of New York City's 70th Precinct House, Federal prosecutors have moved closer to establishing accountability by indicting four police officers, as well as a Brooklyn sergeant alleged to have helped his four colleagues cover it up.

title: Suspect in Southern Bombings Is Enigma
description: Perhaps he is concealed in the folds of the pleated ridges that ring this Appalachian mountain town. Perhaps he has been harbored by associates. But just as beguiling as the mystery of where Eric Robert Rudolph may be hiding is the question of why a reclusive 31-year-old carpenter with no known propensity for violence may have planted a deadly bomb at an Alabama abortion clinic, and possibly others at a crowded park, a building housing an abortion clinic, and a gay nightclub, all in the Atlanta area.

title: Teen-Ager Charged in Her Baby's Death Seeks Separate Trial
description: One of the teen-age New Jersey sweethearts charged with murdering their newborn son at a Delaware motel in 1996 has asked a judge to hold separate trials because their defenses will conflict.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEMMER, ROCHELLE
description: STEMMER - Rochelle. Beloved mother of Steven, Brian and Mary. Dear daughter of Ida Haller. Adored sister of Barbara and Lou Lazar. Cherished grandmother of Julia and Benjamin. Services at ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 312 Coney Island Avenue, at Prospect Park, Brooklyn. Sunday at 11:00AM.

title: Is Investigating Lies a Waste of the Court's Time?; Inappropriate Subpoena
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Somali Army Officer Is Arrested in Virginia
description: A former Somali Army officer believed to have been responsible for the deaths of thousands of his countrymen in the early 1990's was arrested in suburban Virginia today, the Immigration and Naturalization Service said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POVZEA, MURRAY
description: POVZEA-Murray. Age 77. On February 26, 1998. Devoted husband of the late Florence Sclar. Beloved father of Eve Povzea and Shelley and son-in-law Richard Shields. Your wisdom and guidance will be sorely missed. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett. L.I. 2:15pm Sunday.

title: Chessy Rayner, 66, Decorator and Fashion Icon, Dies
description: Chessy Rayner, a decorator, fashion icon, editor and author of ''New York: Trends and Traditions,'' a recently published book about significant Manhattan interiors, died on Thursday night at Sloan-Kettering Medical Center in New York. She was 66.

title: Suspect, 15, In Attacks To Be Charged As an Adult
description: Akeen Browder, a 15-year-old with no criminal record, was described yesterday by friends and neighbors as someone who never swore, who protected younger children from bullies and who got along well with people in his Bronx neighborhood, where he often played football in the street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPSHITZ, MELVINA
description: LIPSHITZ-Melvina. Beloved wife of Leonard. Devoted mother of Joel Fraser and Howard and Ruth Fraser. Loving grandmother of Megan Fraser-Garrett and Benjamin Fraser. Beloved sister of Selma Shore, Dorothy Weidenfeld and Robert Epstein. A tireless worker for Israel and lover of Yiddish culture. Funeral service on Sunday, March 1st at noon, Hirsh & Sons, Jerome Avenue at 167th Street, Bronx, New York.

title: Judge Blocks Zoning Limit On Sex Shops
description: Just days after New York State's highest court upheld a zoning law that would ban X-rated businesses from residential neighborhoods in New York City, a Federal district judge temporarily blocked the Giuliani administration yesterday from enforcing the law.

title: Remembering Youngman, With Laughter
description: It was maybe 15 seconds past the official noon starting time yesterday when Jack L. Green, agent and former Dean of the Friars Club, turned in his seat, tapped his watch and noted that it was unusual for things to start late at Riverside Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue at 76th Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAND, SAMUEL
description: RAND-Samuel. The Congregation of Westchester Reform Temple mourns the death of its devoted longtime member and extends sympathy to his bereaved family. Marjorie Miller, President Richard J. Jacobs, Rabbi Judith Schindler, Assoc. Rabbi

title: Murdoch Halts a Book Critical of China
description: HarperCollins has dropped plans to publish a book by Chris Patten, the last British Governor of Hong Kong, because of complaints from the company's owner, Rupert Murdoch, that it took too negative a view of China.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Dr. Robert E. Gould, a psychoanalyst and expert in treating social outcasts, misidentified the chairman of the New York State commission that investigated the 1971 Attica prison uprising. The commission, on which Dr. Gould served, was headed by Robert B. McKay, the former New York University Law School dean; Arthur L. Liman was its chief counsel.

title: A Lack of Civility? Pupils Politely Point Out Other Problems
description: The second graders gamboling around him, their teacher, Aaron M. Burke, was saying, generally abide by the rules of the schoolyard: no swearing, no pushing, share the ball, take turns, no electronic toys.

title: HUTCHINSON TECHNOLOGY SHARES FALL AFTER LOSS IS CITED
description: Shares of Hutchinson Technology Inc. fell yesterday after the company said it lost money in the first eight weeks of its second quarter because of weak demand for disk-drive assemblies. Hutchinson said it has lost 56 cents a diluted share in the first eight weeks of its second quarter, which ends March 29. Its shares fell $1.125, to $23.125, in Nasdaq trading. Disk-drive makers have been struggling with slow demand, excess supply and falling prices. Analysts had expected Hutchinson to lose 56 cents a share for the entire quarter, according to I.B.E.S. International Inc. Hutchinson, the world's largest maker of disk-drive suspension systems for computers, said disk-drive makers had decided to use up inventories of suspension systems rather than buy more.

title: Justices to Hear President's Appeal on Line Item Veto Ruling
description: The Supreme Court announced today that it would try once again to decide the constitutionality of the Line Item Veto Act, setting April 27 to hear the Clinton Administration's appeal from a recent ruling that struck down the 1996 law.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIS, EVERETT I.
description: WILLIS-Everett I., of Rye Brook, New York, February 27th. Beloved husband of Margaret, loving father of Everett I. Willis, Jr. and Robert F. Willis, grandfather of Katherine E. Willis and Evan Charles Willis. Also survived by his sister, Lonna Chapman. Mr. Willis was a retired senior partner at the firm of Dewey Ballantine LLP where he became a member of the Firm in 1944. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate contributions to Rye Presbyterian Church, Rye, New York. There will be a memorial service on Wednesday, March 4, 11 A.M. at Rye Presbyterian Church, Rye, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURNS, ETHEL
description: BURNS-Ethel, died on February 27, 1998. For many years she was connected with educational broadcasting on WNYE-FM and WNYETV channel 25, with many of her program series winning Emmys for CBS-TV, where they were broadcast. Among the programs she produced for television and radio were American Musical Theater, Dial M For Music, Around The Corner, and It's Fun To Sing. She will be missed by her TV and radio friends. For information regarding funeral arrangements contact at Riverside 212-362-6600.

title: Appeal Ending With a Record Sum
description: The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, which raises money for seven of the city's oldest and most prominent charities, winds up its 86th annual appeal today with a record-setting tally. Since Thanksgiving, when the campaign began, donors have sent the fund $5,449,158, compared with the $5,083,551 received in 1991-92, previously the most successful drive.

title: Simply A Genre Of Its Own
description: Miles Davis's move toward rock and funk backbeats from 1967 to 1975 has been only half absorbed by his admirers. Endless jazz-fusion bands have borrowed the thrashing of his rhythm sections, as well as the athletic soloing over static vamps committed by some of his employees. But hardly anyone, either in performance esthetic or on record, has built on the structural challenges of Davis's music from that period: dramatic dropouts of sound, layering of metronomic and swing rhythms, randomly cued melodic fragments. Those, and Teo Macero's brilliant editing manipulations, are the glory of that music, on records like ''Live Evil'' and ''In a Silent Way.''

title: Dr. Spock, Old and Infirm, Needs Money, Wife Says
description: For more than a half century, Dr. Benjamin Spock has been the sage of sensible parenting, dispensing advice on matters from croup to hyperactivity in his enduring book, ''Baby and Child Care.'' But now it is the baby doctor who needs help, according to his wife, who this week issued a highly unusual appeal for donations to subsidize costly home health care for the ailing 94-year-old pediatrician and author.

title: Topsy-Turvy Test Results
description: If you had told American educators a week ago that their 12th graders would match those in Germany, Austria and the Czech Republic on international math and science tests, they would have broken out the champagne. This week the results showed exactly that, but no one cheered because all four countries were at the bottom of the rankings. The puzzling results did not deter politicians from repeating their calls for national curriculum standards, education vouchers or other solutions. But the scores are riddled with too much uncertainty to compel simple conclusions.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCARTHY, JOHN J.
description: McCARTHY-John J. On February 26, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Vivian. Loving father of John, Jr., Peter and the late Daniel. Dear brother of Patrick and the late Margaret Geber. Cherished grandfather of Danielle, Meaghan and Caitlin. Visiting Sunday and Monday, 2-5 and 7-9PM, McLaughlin & Sons, Third Ave at 97th St, Bklyn. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, 10:15 AM, Saint Patrick's Church.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Who among us would say on balance that our kings have been more impressive and have more impressive records than our queens?''

title: Johannesburg Journal; For Rising Crime Rate, High-Rise Jail to Match
description: Admittedly, the Ponte Building here is no Empire State Building. To be kind, it looks like a cement knockoff of the Capitol Records Tower in Los Angeles. To be cruel, it resembles a giant hair curler.

title: National News Briefs; Soldier's Lawyer Says Papers Weren't Altered
description: The civilian defense lawyer for Sgt. Maj. Gene C. McKinney today denied that his client had doctored evidence for his alibi and unsuccessfully sought to have the charges at the sergeant major's court-martial dismissed based on what he termed prosecutors' leaks of information.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORAN, GERTRUDE CORBETT
description: MORAN-Gertrude Corbett 92 years of age, on Tuesday, February 24, 1998 in Palm Beach, Florida. Wife of the late George Francis Moran. She is survived by her daughter Laura Moran (NYC) and numerous nieces and nephews. Funeral Mass Monday March 2, 1998, St. Vincent Ferrer RC Church, NYC. Interment St. John's Cemetery, Middle Village, NY. Wake services were held in Florida. For Information, Thomas M. Quinn & Sons Funeral Directors 35-20 Broadway, L.I. City, NY.

title: Equal Rights to English Throne: Firstborn Would be First in Line
description: In another move to put a fresher face on the British monarchy, Queen Elizabeth II has told Parliament that she approves of plans to end the ages-old tradition of having the eldest son ascend to the British throne.

title: Harry Caray Remembered As Baseball Ambassador
description: Harry Caray received one more standing ovation today when more than 1,000 mourners packed Holy Name Cathedral here for a funeral Mass honoring him.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Post Gives Julian Bond New Start
description: On the wall of Julian Bond's impeccably neat study hangs a black and white picture of Mr. Bond as a skinny, 2-year-old boy in short pants, holding hands with two famous black intellectuals, E. Franklin Frazier and W. E. B. Du Bois.

title: I.B.M. TO MAKE CHIPS FOR ADVANCED MICRO DEVICES
description: The International Business Machines Corporation will make microprocessors for Advanced Micro Devices Inc. as the computer-chip maker tries to catch up with the Intel Corporation's market-leading Pentium line. Advanced Micro has struggled to turn out enough of its K6 chips for personal computers amid production limitations and trouble with new technology. While the two-year agreement will help it alleviate some manufacturing restraints, it will not solve a bigger issue. Intel will enter the market for processors used in popular $1,000 computers before Advanced Micro ships its first product from I.B.M.'s plant. Advanced Micro's shares fell $1.625, to $23.50, and I.B.M. fell $1.625, to $104.3125.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINTHROP, AMORY (ELIZABETH)
description: WINTHROP-Amory (Elizabeth). Of Millbrook, N.Y. Died Feb. 26, 1998. Daughter of the late Robert Winthrop and the late Theodora Ayer Randolph. Survived by her sisters Theodora Hooton and Cornelia Bonnie, and a niece and nephews. Ms. Winthrop was an accomplished horse-woman and a horse show judge. She was a director of The Fund for Animals & Founder and President of the Winley Foundation. A memorial service will be held at a future date. Contributions in her memory may be made to Winley Foundation, attention Anne Barone, R.R.1, Box 40, Millbrook, N.Y. 12545 or The Institute for Ecosystems Studies.

title: A High-Profile Loss for a Diminished Delegation
description: In New York State's Congressional delegation, Representative Bill Paxon was something of an anomaly. He was a western New Yorker in a delegation dominated by New York City and its suburbs, a conservative surrounded by moderates and liberals, a seemingly plain-vanilla guy among some of the louder personalities on Capitol Hill.

title: Revised School Aid Figures Due Next Week, State Says
description: A week after acknowledging that they had made mistakes in allocating school aid to some local districts for the coming school year, Whitman administration officials vowed today to revise the aid figures by Tuesday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   GREEN, WILMA
description: GREEN-Wilma February 28, 1989 Remembering MY GREAT LADY

title: New Respectability For Manners; Scholars Tackle a Topic Long Thought Too Trivial for All but Fussbudgets
description: The subject of manners once seemed worthy of serious attention. The authors of the Talmud took up such topics as burping, yawning and bad breath. Erasmus wrote the 16th-century equivalent of a best seller on civility and Edmund Burke considered manners more important than laws.

title: More Americans Are Getting Away From It All This Winter
description: Thousands of skiers from Florida take their vacations at the Winter Park resort in Colorado this time of year. But last month Joan Christensen, an employee of Winter Park, headed for the Florida Keys with her husband, Dan, for a weeklong vacation.

title: Scientist Who Announced Cloning of Sheep Dolly Is Taking Steps to Win Over Critics
description: A year after the announcement that Dr. Ian Wilmut had cloned Dolly the sheep from the adult cell of another sheep, no other scientist has succeeded in repeating the experiment, despite several efforts. Now Dr. Wilmut is in a defensive posture, undertaking new tests to confirm that his claim was correct, and critics are asking why these tests were not required before publication by the scientific journal in which his report appeared.

title: Is Investigating Lies a Waste of the Court's Time?
description: To the Editor:

title: OSHKOSH TRUCK ADDS MCNEILUS FOR $250 MILLION
description: The Oshkosh Truck Corporation has purchased the McNeilus Companies of Dodge Center, Minn., a maker of garbage-truck bodies and concrete mixers, for $250 million, as it expands in the garbage- and construction-truck business. Oshkosh, based in Oshkosh, Wis., has annual sales of $683 million and makes fire trucks and other specialty trucks under the Oshkosh and Pierce brands. The closely held McNeilus, has annual sales of $327 million.
